headline: JPMorgan Hires Health Care Banker From Deutsche
text: JPMorgan Chase has hired Ravi Sachdev, a health care banker from Deutsche Bank, as a managing director, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

headline: Robiola-Stuffed Tomatoes
text: 4 large ripe tomatoes

headline: Tony Awards Eligibility Calendar Has Broadway Worried
text: 2:51 p.m. | Updated  Few calendar dates are more important to Broadway power brokers than the eligibility cut-off for the Tony Awards, the date by which all shows need to have opened to be considered for that season’s highest theater honors. Heading into 2010-11, however, the Tonys remain without a cut-off date — and maybe because it’s an otherwise slow theater week, that is causing consternation.

headline: A Spicy Corn Stir Fry
text: The other day I decided to make spicy corn stir fry, and as soon as I started cooking, I thought of a better way to make it, or at least one element of it.

headline: How Baby Fever Spreads Through Offices
text: Speaking of babies, a new study out of Sweden finds that women workers are more likely to have babies if their co-workers recently had babies.

headline: Mistakes
text: So, what big mistakes have I made over the years? Two, I think.

headline: Going Rogue
text: Rake, a new men’s line of suit separates made to mix and match, fancies as its customer ‘‘a gentleman of rogue habits.’’ The owner, Clive Darby, late of the Savile Row outfitter Kilgour, marries the precision of English tailoring with the louche sexiness of Serge Gainsbourg. ‘‘He didn’t follow some dictated idea of what a suit should be,’’ Darby says. ‘‘He wore it with jeans, with sneakers or with fabulous brogues.’’ The whole collection — reversible waistcoats, wrinkle-resistant jersey jackets that pair well with booze-stained undershirts — targets global gadabouts who travel light. Jackets from about $1,545. Go to rakestyle.com.

headline: Employment Boom?
text: While I was getting ready for dinner in Istanbul, where I am on vacation, I looked at my e-mail and discovered that the Institute for Supply Management’s manufacturing numbers for August had shocked some analysts. They expected a decline, and got an increase.

headline: Step Down to Step Up
text: THE designer Alejandro Ingelmo, known for his sexy stilettos (above, Spider, available for order, $725), has opened an 800-square-foot store in the bottom level of a brownstone in SoHo, at 51 Wooster Street (near Broome Street); (646) 649-5126, alejandroingelmo.com.

headline: One Store Scoops Up the Lot
text: VENA CAVA has translated its blend of unique prints, vintage aesthetic and subtle silhouettes into a limited-edition collection for Aqua, the Bloomingdale’s in-house label. The pieces range from $98 to $198, and include a military jacket, faux fur vest and studded shorts.

headline: No Longer Thinking Uniformly
text: THE National Football League’s design philosophy for women’s clothing used to be reduced to a simple formula: “Pink it and shrink it.” Now female tailgaters or remote-wielding couch potatoes can opt for the stylish N.F.L. Women’s Apparel line designed by different licensees. It includes a sheer and fitted Jaguars T-shirt (Touch by GIII, $39.99).

headline: Near Kandahar, the Prize Is an Empty Town
text: MEHLAJAT, Afghanistan  When the governor of Kandahar Province came to this town, freshly liberated on Sunday from the Taliban, his armed entourage appeared to outnumber what was left of the population.

headline: The Unfinished Tale of an Unlikely Hero
text: DESCRIBING a walk through the garden outside her home in Cleveland Heights, Ohio, after a rainstorm, Joyce Brabner said she was looking for a dry place to sit and talk about how things have been going since the death of her husband, Harvey Pekar, the comic-book writer.

headline: ‘Cool It,’ Film Rival to ‘An Inconvenient Truth,’ Gets a U.S. Distributor
text: The environmental message of former Vice President Al Gore‘s “An Inconvenient Truth” is about to get a little competition at American cinemas. On Wednesday, the distributor Roadside Attractions said it had acquired Ondi Timoner‘s documentary “Cool It,” about the Danish statistician and writer Bjorn Lomborg, for release in the United States, just before that film is to make its make its world premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival.

headline: The Cheat: A Hot Tomato
text: The last of the tomatoes are coming in now, wide and cracked, heavy with the captured humidity of passing summer, each one a Neruda poem shedding its own light, benign majesty. It is time to eat them, these sunsets of the season, then put away our flip-flops and face the fall.

headline: Smoke-Roasted Chicken Thighs With Paprika
text: 1 tablespoon sweet paprika

headline: Updates, on Soldiers and Sons
text: Allison Buckholtz’s husband, Scott, is home. She has written here on Motherlode, and on her Slate blog, Deployment Diaries, about holding the family fort in Washington, D.C., with 6-year-old Than and 4-year-old Esther, while he served two tours of duty in Iraq. Today — one day after the official end of U.S. combat operations in that country — she has an essay on Slate announcing Scott’s recent homecoming. His newest assignment will be a Navy staff job near home, where, she writes, he will be “driving to work every morning and pulling up to the house every evening. The domestic dullness I’ve long craved is imminent.”

headline: From Apple, a Step Into Social Media for Music
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple jumped into the social networking business on Wednesday, introducing Ping, a service built into iTunes that is intended to help users discover new music and, presumably, buy more songs from Apple.

headline: Maryland Hostages Safe as Police Kill Gunman
text: Police officers shot and killed a gunman with a history of protesting against the Discovery Channel, the authorities said, ending a nearly four-hour ordeal on Wednesday at the company’s headquarters in Silver Spring, Md. The gunman, apparently wearing explosives, had taken two employees and a security guard hostage, officials said.

headline: An Oasis Off London’s Beaten Path
text: WITH its picnic tables and chipped folding chairs, Towpath feels as if it should be in a shack on the beach, not on the ground floor of a converted factory in East London.

headline: At the Center of the Storm, but Still a Mystery
text: “A man without a shadow”; a “pleasant man with a pleasant family living in a pleasant North London house”; a bright, telegenic, yet elusive politician with a “smooth facade.” This is how a newspaper article in The Guardian famously described Tony Blair long before he became prime minister of Britain in 1997.

headline: Courtside: A Tennis Dream Comes True
text: Lauren Herring and her partner earned a wild card to the Open by capturing a doubles title in August. Lauren's father will be watching watching with pride on Thursday.

headline: Letter: Portland Is To ...
text: To the Editor: I was amused to read “36 Hours in Portland, Me.” (Aug. 22) and find that (wow!) our city offers shops that are “more Brooklyn Flea than L. L. Bean”; a neighborhood that’s “like Notting Hill,” and a bar “more Munich than Maine.” While your writer is correct that Portland is much more than the tourist stereotype of “lobster, lighthouses and L. L. Bean,” it is, blissfully, itself: a singularly interesting place that doesn’t need comparisons (foreign or domestic) to illuminate it.

headline: At the Open: First Class, Economy and All Business
text: Every few minutes the 7 train lurches into the Willets Point station, and more crowds, speaking in various languages, although clearly not from Queens, form scrums at the doors. They disgorge from the air-conditioned cars and head in the other direction from Citi Field, onto the boardwalk.

headline: Letter: Bogs and Bikes
text: To the Editor: I read with much excitement Clifford J. Levy’s, “In Estonia, Jiggling and Bog-Trekking” (Aug. 22). My husband and I recently returned from a trip to Estonia that included a full-day mountain bike excursion to Lahemaa National Park. We had limited time in the park, so our guide from City Bikes in Tallinn recommended a coastal route perfect for a leisurely ride.

headline: What We’re Reading: Help the Poor, Patronize a Sweatshop
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Darkness in the Village, Where Lives Were Lost and Saved
text: For almost four months, I had deliberately avoided the intersection of Seventh Avenue and West 12th Street — no easy task when coming and going from Greenwich Village. Since it was impossible to imagine that St. Vinny’s was dark, I couldn’t bear to confront the evidence with my own eyes.

headline: Why Labor Day Is the Best Time to Buy a Car
text: If you’re considering buying a new car, you may want to consider buying it this weekend.

headline: Azarenka Collapses With Mild Concussion
text: Up went her service toss at the United States Open on Wednesday, and Victoria Azarenka, already wobbly on her feet and down in the first set of her second-round match, 0-4, took a swing and missed completely, the ball bouncing off her back before landing on the steamy surface of the grandstand court.

headline: Super Slide Opens in Singapore Airport
text: Who cares about delayed flights when you can pass the time riding a 40-foot-tall, jumbo twister slide?

headline: Two Takes on ‘Blood Simple’
text: A. O. Scott dissects a scene from the Coen brothers’ “Blood Simple” and a scene from its remake, Zhang Yimou’s “A Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop.”

headline: Framing a Statement
text: TRANSLUCENT sunglass frames make a perfect chic-geek statement. A recent sweep of downtown Manhattan stores found, from top, Han sunglasses, $198, at Oak, including 28 Bond Street (Lafayette Street), (212) 677-1293, oaknyc.com; Super sunglasses, $135, at Gargyle, 16A Orchard Street (Canal Street), (917) 470-9367, gargyle.com; and Love Child sunglasses, $15, In God We Trust stores, including 265 Lafayette Street (Prince Street), (212) 966-9010, ingodwetrustnyc.com.

headline: Interviews on Water Use Are Thirsty Work
text: Fieldwork Begins

headline: Ford Replacing Classic Police Cruiser With an S.U.V.
text: The Ford Motor Company announced on Wednesday the availability of a new Police Interceptor utility vehicle. Based on the new Ford Explorer, the vehicle is meant to complement the front-wheel-drive police sedan based on the Taurus that was introduced this year.

headline: Hudson, N.Y.: Where Bands Feel at Home
text: The riverside town of Hudson now boasts a robust grassroots music scene.

headline: Burger King’s Post-I.P.O. Stock Price Isn’t Royal
text: As Burger King holds talks with prospective buyers, including Brazilian-backed 3G Capital, it’s worth looking at how the buyout-backed fast food giant has performed since going public again in 2006.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. A clear majority of Americans say Sarah Palin is not qualified to be president. A fact you can’t refudiate or frapricate.

headline: Cardinals Shopping Leinart
text: The Arizona Cardinals have begun calling teams with quarterback needs to gauge interest in Matt Leinart, the former first-round pick and Heisman Trophy winner at Southern California who has failed on numerous occasions to seize the Cardinals’ starting job. He now appears to have been supplanted by Derek Anderson, who was released by the Cleveland Browns in the off-season.

headline: Afghanistan Official Tries to Ease Depositors’ Worries About Troubled Bank
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan’s top bank official tried Wednesday to calm fears of a meltdown at one of the country’s largest financial institutions, while scores of Afghans lined up to empty their accounts and found the bank unwilling to comply.

headline: How to Get Loyalty Card Prices Without Loyalty Cards
text: All those loyalty cards you have dangling off your keychain or plumping your wallet? Gone. In their place, smartphone users will have free apps like Key Ring or Cardstar on their cellphones.

headline: Courtside: A Tennis Parent Is Ready for the Big Event
text: C. L. Herring remembers the first time his little girl beat him up in tennis.

headline: Fuld Says Lehman Could Have Been Saved
text: Richard S. Fuld Jr. told a federal commission that his firm, Lehman Brothers, failed only because the Federal Reserve refused to step in as it did with other firms.

headline: Romer’s Final Washington Dispatch: More Stimulus
text: 6:51 p.m. | Updated  The full text of Ms. Romer’s talk is now on the White House Web site.

headline: An Iraqi Woman’s Change of Address and New Life
text: Correspondents who covered the war in Iraq are reflecting on their time there and the official end of United States combat operations. Erica Goode was a correspondent in Baghdad in 2008.

headline: F.C.C. Seeks More Input on Wireless Internet Rules
text: WASHINGTON  On the Internet, data moves at the speed of light. The Federal Communications Commission, not so fast.

headline: Big Interest in Tiny Cars
text: Thousands of people gathered in Crystal Lake, Ill., for the first International Microcar/Minicar World Meet.

headline: We Made It Ourselves | Dry Creek Peach Jam
text: If you were one of those children who read Roald Dahl’s “James and the Giant Peach” and thought the idea of living inside the giant stone fruit sounded swell, you really ought to get yourself a jar or two, or 14, of Dry Creek Peach jam.

headline: Discontent in Baghdad
text: Stephen Farrell reports on growing frustrations among Iraqi citizens as the United States brings an end to its combat mission.

headline: Of Two Minds About Books
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Auriane and Sebastien de Halleux are at sharp odds over “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” but not about the plot. The problem is that she prefers the book version, while he reads it on his iPad. And in this literary dispute, the couple says, it’s ne’er the twain shall meet.

headline: Clinton Heading Back to Arkansas for Lincoln
text: Former President Bill Clinton, who strongly supported Senator Blanche Lincoln in her primary battle this year, is heading back to Arkansas next week to stump for her.

headline: Berdych Makes an Early Exit
text: Michael Llodra, a veteran French competitor ranked 35th in the world, upset the Wimbledon finalist, seventh-seeded Tomas Berdych of the Czech Republic, 7-6 (3), 6-4, 6-4, in the first major upset of the United States Open men’s singles championship.

headline: Immigrants’ Oral Histories Going Online
text: A collection of more than 1,700 recorded oral histories from immigrants who arrived in the United States through Ellis Island will be available free online starting Thursday at www.ancestry.com/immigration. The histories, recorded by the National Park Service starting in the 1970s, are housed at the Ellis Island Immigration Museum and until now have been available only to island visitors.

headline: Rangel Joins Muslims in Rally for Downtown Mosque
text: Facing one of the more contentious re-election campaigns of his 40-year career, United States Representative Charles B. Rangel waded into a polarizing debate on Wednesday as he spoke out in favor of an Islamic center and mosque planned near ground zero.

headline: O Urban Pioneers!
text: In 1967, my husband and I bought and fully renovated a four-story brownstone on Manhattan’s Upper West Side, creating a duplex for ourselves and two floors of rental apartments. Despite its Manhattan address, our friends envied neither our money nor our luck; at the time, it didn’t take much of either to buy in the neighborhood.

headline: Neighborhood Looks
text: San Francisco fashion includes distinctive elements of a local style that seems to be generated by some loopy organic collective impulse rather than an editorial cabal.

headline: Beijing Opera Academy of China
text: The Beijing opera’s popularity is waning among modern audiences but young students still flock to opera training academies.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lahore and Elsewhere
text: Three bombs ripped through a Shiite Muslim procession in the eastern Pakistani city of Lahore on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported, killing 25 people and wounding about 150 others. The explosions appeared to be the latest in a string of attacks by Sunni extremists against the minority Shiites they consider infidels.

headline: In Somalia, Battle Ends for Streets of Capital
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  The streets of Mogadishu, Somalia’s besieged capital, were finally quiet on Wednesday, after 10 days of heavy fighting that has claimed more than 100 lives.

headline: Hiking New England’s Highest Peaks
text: A look at the height and difficulty level of six New England peaks.

headline: E.U. Casts Legal Doubt on French Roma Expulsion
text: BRUSSELS — The legality of France’s crackdown on Roma migrants was thrown into doubt Wednesday when a report from the European Commission said that French law lacked minimum safeguards required by the European Union to protect deportees.

headline: Usage Rights for a TV Show Season Pass on iTunes
Airgas’s Novel Question
text: Airgas has raised a novel question of Delaware law. As I discussed on Monday, Airgas has claimed that Air Products’ proposed bylaw amendment to move Airgas’s 2011 annual meeting to January is invalid under Delaware law.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 1
text: A view of the day in sports, including cycling in Italy and the world basketball championships in Turkey.

headline: How to Choose and Work With a Mentor
text: AS a small-business owner, you may feel isolated. Without a large organization’s resources, you may long for a sounding board for your frustrations and fears or a discreet, impartial adviser with whom to discuss the tactical and strategic challenges of running a company.

headline: Harrison Breaks Through in Upset
text: In his first men’s singles appearance at the United States Open, the 18-year-old qualifier Ryan Harrison ousted 15th-seeded Ivan Ljubicic of Croatia, 6-3, 6-7 (4), 6-3, 6-4.

headline: Ping Fosters Music Discovery, Not Friend Discovery
text: On Thursday Wednesday morning, Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, showed off a new social network for music called Ping. It runs inside the newest version of Apple’s iTunes software. Ping also works on the latest software for iPhones and iPod Touches. (Apple hasn’t made it available for iPad this time around.)

headline: Graphic Content | Thurston Moore’s Indie Books
text: With publishers looking for ways to capitalize on e-books, starting an independent publishing house may be as foolhardy as investing in Betamax. But that’s not stopping Thurston Moore of Sonic Youth. He and the editor/publisher Eva Prinz founded Ecstatic Peace Library (ecstaticpeacelibrary.com, or facebook.com/pages/Ecstatic-Peace-Library/346362294368), which features art, design, photography and poetry books, including “Fly Me” by Yoko Ono, a limited-edition book and box of kites, each with a kite frame, strings, instructions on flying and a message from Ono.

headline: Bieber Fever
text: The teenage pop star performed before an enthusiastic, sold-out crowd at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night.

headline: Sampling Dublin’s Theater Scene
text: A handful of theaters cultivate a small but energized theatrical community.

headline: Theater Talkback: Just When You Think You Know Somebody . . .
text: There are some people you feel can never surprise you, you know them so well. You’ve spent hours in their company, you know all their little habits, you even hear what they’re going to say before they say it. And then, every so often (and it could be the 20th encounter), one of them does something that knocks you for a loop and you think, “I never really knew you at all.”

headline: How Do You Know When to Trust Your Gut?
text: We’ve just published a small-business guide that offers lots of helpful advice about how to find a mentor. But no matter how you find your mentor and no matter how good your mentor is, there will most likely come a time when you have to answer this question: Do I follow the advice I’m being given or do I trust my gut?

headline: The Tribes of San Francisco
text: San Francisco

headline: Your Own Hot Spot, and Cheap
text: Someday, they’ll build wireless Internet into every building, just the way they build in running water, heat and electricity today. Someday, we won’t have to drive around town looking for a coffee shop when we need to check our e-mail.

headline: Carrying the Spear (and Dagger) for a Fading Art Form
text: BEIJING  “Watch out for that sword,” the rehearsal director shouted. “I don’t want anybody’s head getting cut off because you don’t know what you’re doing.”

headline: A Weekend in Silicon Valley
text: The Valley’s dozen or so cities are continuing their shift from corporate strip malls to urban hubs.

headline: You Never Forget That Star-Struck Encounter With Your Idol
text: Two recent Off Broadway plays — A. R. Gurney’s “Grand Manner” and Jonathan Tolins’s “Secrets of the Trade” — explore what happens when showbiz-besotted fans meet their idols. Sometimes a backstage encounter with a star is life changing; visiting on an off night can be awkward and awe draining. (Mr. Gurney’s actual meeting with the actress Katharine Cornell was quite brief, though the play imagines a very different outcome to that encounter.)

headline: For the A-Cup Crowd, Minimal Assets Are a Plus
text: IT is commonly assumed that small-chested women feel that nature’s lottery has left them coming up short. The parade of heaving bosoms in Victoria’s Secret catalogs not only suggests that bigger is better but also that supersizing with a push-up bra is universally desired.

headline: Composers’ Influences, Side by Side
text: In his 10-part recital series at the Dicapo Opera Theater the pianist Ian Hobson is celebrating the Chopin and Schumann bicentennial year by putting both composers in context. Each recital includes works by one or both, and pieces by others who influenced or were influenced by them. In place of program notes Mr. Hobson has invited David Dubal, the author and pianist, to introduce each work. His comments are highly personalized (what he tells his students, what he likes or finds terrifying about particular pieces) and more than a little hagiographic.

headline: Hey, Mr. Restaurant Critic! Open House Edition
text: Given the hardship assignment of spending a few lazy, late summer days basking in the sunshine, watching incredible athletes compete at the highest level and generally soaking up tennis-related atmosphere around the city during the Open, I needed help, so enlisted a trouper to handle one of the more specialized and grueling chores.

headline: Donning Sinatra’s Mystique, From Movie Sailor to Saloon Dandy
text: “May you live to be 100, and may the last voice you hear be mine.” So went a cocky, wisecracking toast that Frank Sinatra was fond of delivering to audiences in his later concert performances. Those words were heard again during Tuesday’s opening-night performance of the well-traveled revue “Our Sinatra,” at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

headline: Conan Unveils ‘Conan’
text: Continuing to diminish expectations after his brief “Tonight Show” run lost the Emmy Award for best variety, music or comedy series to “The Daily Show” on Sunday night, Conan O’Brien revealed the modest title of his coming TBS program in a YouTube video on Wednesday. After a lengthy setup and an attempt at a drum roll that Mr. O’Brien, above, acknowledged sounded more like a purring cat, he revealed that the show would be called “Conan.” Yes, “Conan.” That’s right, just “Conan.” In a Twitter message on Tuesday, Mr. O’Brien joked that he was prepared to announce the show’s title earlier “but my lawyers tell me ‘The Return of Nanny McPhee’ is taken.” “Conan” is scheduled to make its premiere Nov. 8 on TBS.

headline: Men’s Cosmetics Becoming a Bull Market
text: WHEN cosmetics began disappearing from her bathroom drawer a few years ago, Gretchen Bain, who lives in Merchantville, N.J., knew the culprit.

headline: ‘Talent’ Tops TV Ratings After Obama Speech
text: NBC’s “America’s Got Talent” earned the top ratings on Tuesday after President Obama’s live address pre-empted the start of network schedules in some time zones. According to Nielsen’s estimates, an average of 11.3 million viewers tuned in to “America’s Got Talent” from 9 to 11 p.m., far more than any other program that night. CBS was second with reruns of “NCIS” (8.1 million), “NCIS: Los Angeles” (7.3 million) and “The Good Wife” (5.1 million); ABC was third with “Wipeout” (6.5 million), “Shaq Vs.” (4 million) and “Primetime: Crime” (3.1 million). Fox averaged 3.6 million for back-to-back repeats of “Glee.”

headline: Michael Douglas Discusses His Cancer on ‘Late Show’
text: Michael Douglas said in an interview with David Letterman on Tuesday evening that he had started treatment for Stage 4 throat cancer, and offered cautious optimism that he would recover from it. Appearing on Mr. Letterman’s “Late Show” on CBS to promote his coming film, “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps,” Mr. Douglas, above left with Mr. Letterman, said he was given the diagnosis earlier in the summer after seeing several doctors for a nagging sore throat. Asked by Mr. Letterman about the severity of his condition  a Stage 4 cancer is defined as one that has spread to other parts of the body  Mr. Douglas replied: “The big thing you’re always worried about is it spreading, so I am head and neck. I am above the neck, so nothing’s gone down, and the expectations are good.” Mr. Douglas, 65, said he had completed the first week of an eight-week chemotherapy regimen. When asked by Mr. Letterman if he smoked, Mr. Douglas said he smoked and drank, adding, “This particular type of cancer is caused by alcohol and drinking.” When asked about his chances for recovery, Mr. Douglas replied: “The percentages are very good. I would hate to say, but right now it looks like it should be 80 percent, and with certain hospitals and everything, it does improve.”

headline: Divisive Artist Returns To MoMA P.S. 1
text: Six months after the performance artist Ann Liv Young was at the center of a divisive performance at MoMA P.S. 1, the museum on Tuesday granted her request to return, Ms. Young and the museum said. Ms. Young announced her return a few weeks ago, but at the time the museum said no such event had been approved. Tuesday’s decision followed two meetings with various staff members at MoMA P.S. 1, in Long Island City, Queens, including one with its director, Klaus Biesenbach. Ms. Young is to stage a public performance-lecture there on Sunday, discussing her original February appearance. That February performance involved a confrontation between her and a fellow artist, Georgia Sagri, and was curtailed abruptly when Mr. Biesenbach ordered the electricity shut off. “I think it’s great,” Ms. Young said Tuesday afternoon after her second meeting at the museum. The performance-lecture will be at 2 p.m. in the temporary studio that the artist A. L. Steiner occupies in the museum basement as part of the “Greater New York” exhibition. (Though the event is open to the public, it is a small space.) Ms. Steiner will be present, and so will a security guard. But Mr. Biesenbach won’t: he’ll be traveling.

headline: Katy Perry Wafts Her Way To No. 1
text: It took cotton-candy-scented CDs (and a couple of hit songs and a skin-baring video), but Katy Perry’s “Teenage Dream” (Capitol) handily bumped Eminem’s “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope) from No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. “Teenage Dream” sold 192,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, taking Ms. Perry to the top of the chart for the first time. Fantasia, who won “American Idol” six years ago, opened at No. 2 with her third album, “Back to Me” (J), which sold 117,000, and “Recovery” fell two spots to No. 3 with 98,000, the first time in 10 weeks of release that its sales have dipped below 100,000. Usher’s mini-album “Versus” (Jive) opened at No. 4 with 46,000 copies sold, and his full-length “Raymond vs. Raymond” (Jive), which was released in March and reissued last week in a package that included “Versus,” jumped 12 spots to No. 19 with 20,000 sales. The country group Little Big Town bowed at No. 5 with 42,000 sales of its new album “The Reason Why” (Capitol Nashville).

headline: Ellis Island Oral Histories Online
text: A collection of more than 1,700 recorded oral histories from immigrants who arrived in the United States through Ellis Island will be available free online beginning Thursday at ancestry.com/immigration. The histories, recorded by the National Park Service starting in the 1970s, are housed at the Ellis Island Immigration Museum and have previously been available only to island visitors. They capture moments like Lawrence Meinwald’s first glimpse of the Statue of Liberty: “It was very early in the morning and we heard this rumbling,” he says. “My father and I dressed and went to the deck. There were people of all denominations, some on their knees making the sign of the cross, Jews in their prayer shawls as we were passing the Statue of Liberty.” The tapes are the latest addition to Ancestry.com’s United States Immigration Collection, which has 170 million records including lists of passengers who immigrated by ship to America between 1820 and 1960, more than seven million citizenship and naturalization records, border crossings and passport applications. Ancestry.com’s full collection of United States immigration records will be searchable free for a limited period, Thursday through Monday. The Ellis Island Oral History collection will remain free.

headline: Revisiting Max’s, Sanctuary for the Hip
text: IF a fiction writer were to sit down and conjure up a Manhattan nightspot where a John Chamberlain sculpture flanked the jukebox and Debbie Harry waited tables, where the earth artist Robert Smithson held court with Waylon Jennings, where struggling artists could cash their checks and pick up their mail, where the New York Dolls and Charlie Rich played (in the same year!) and where an unknown named Bob Marley once opened for a slightly less unknown named Bruce Springsteen, he would probably be scoffed at for fabulist excess.

headline: Miranda Lambert Leads Country Nominations
text: Step aside, Taylor Swift: the Country Music Association seems to have a new sweetheart of the rodeo. Miranda Lambert, right, who with Dierks Bentley announced the nominations for the C.M.A. Awards Wednesday on “Good Morning America,” landed nine nominations in total, more than any other artist this year. Ms. Lambert, the former “Nashville Star” finalist, was nominated for female vocalist of the year and album of the year (for “Revolutions”), and picked up two nominations in the single-of-the-year category, for “The House That Built Me” and “White Liar,” both of which were also nominated for music video of the year. Ms. Lambert is also a contender for the C.M.A.’s top prize, entertainer of the year, along with Lady Antebellum, Brad Paisley, Keith Urban and the Zac Brown Band. Lady Antebellum picked up five nominations in all, including vocal group of the year, single of the year (for “Need You Now”) and album of the year. The awards ceremony will be broadcast on Nov. 10 on ABC.

headline: ‘Phantom’ Sequel Unlikely For Broadway In Spring
text: It looks increasingly unlikely that “Love Never Dies,” Andrew Lloyd Webber’s sequel to “The Phantom of the Opera,” will come to Broadway in spring as planned. A spokesman for the production said on Tuesday that “Love Never Dies,” right, was still set for the Neil Simon Theater in spring, but the London production’s director, Jack O’Brien, and choreographer, Jerry Mitchell, who were expected to work on the Broadway show, have left to focus on their new musical, “Catch Me if You Can,” said two Broadway producers who are not involved with either show, but have spoken with Mr. O’Brien and Mr. Mitchell. The producers shared the details on condition of anonymity because Mr. O’Brien and Mr. Mitchell asked them not to say anything publicly. The producers said their understanding was that a Broadway version of “Love Never Dies” would not happen this season. Mr. O’Brien and Mr. Mitchell did not return messages seeking comment. “Love Never Dies” opened in March in London to mostly negative reviews. The spokesman for “Love Never Dies,” Adrian Bryan-Brown, said plans to bring the show to Broadway in the spring were still on, and “we’re just waiting for a date.”

headline: Send in the Heartthrob, Cue the Shrieks
text: Justin Bieber’s love isn’t of the puppy sort. Instead his songs crackle with the first blush of seduction and power — sweet enough to deceive his youngest fans, and probably their parents too, but absolutely delivered with a devious glint in his eye.

headline: Protest Shuts Down Oil Rig off Greenland
text: Greenpeace halted exploratory drilling by a Scottish oil firm off the coast of Greenland on Tuesday after four protesters scaled an oil rig and suspended tents from its underside.

headline: Medicating Children
text: Tens of thousands of preschoolers are prescribed powerful anti-psychotic drugs, but some psychiatrists say that pills are a simple solution to a complex problem.

headline: Soldiers of Convenience
text: Heavily armed pirate militias, financed with tens of millions of dollars in ransoms, are becoming a factor in Somalia’s civil war.

headline: Whose Side Are You On? It Might Be the Taliban’s
text: The Taliban try to kill American troops every day.

headline: Child’s Ordeal Shows Risks of Psychosis Drugs for Young
text: OPELOUSAS, La. — At 18 months, Kyle Warren started taking a daily antipsychotic drug on the orders of a pediatrician trying to quell the boy’s severe temper tantrums.

headline: 2 Charged in MedImmune Insider Trading Scheme
text: Another day, another set of insider trading charges — this time revolving around two buddies accused of illicitly trading in MedImmune.

headline: Iraqis’ Reactions to President Obama’s Speech
text: Mosul

headline: Shopping With Marc Murphy
text: The chef and restaurateur behind Landmarc and Ditch Plains in Manhattan shopped for picnic gear.

headline: In Missouri, Card Playing for a Good Cause
text: BackStoppers is a charity in the St. Louis area that gives financial aid to the families of police officers, firefighters and medical workers who were killed in the line of duty. Bridge did its part to help when Bridge Haven ran a pro-am game on Sunday that raised $3,500.

headline: Cardinal, Who Mediated in Belgian Abuse Case, Says He Was Misled
text: PARIS — With the recent release of tapes chronicling the private clash of a family over sexual abuse by a Belgian bishop, the retired cardinal who played a role as a mediator is now distancing himself from his longtime colleague and friend.

headline: Mazda’s New Concept Car: Not Going With the Flow
text: Mazda rolled out a surprise this week in Milan: a concept car that its design chief says outlines the company’s future design language.

headline: Brooklyn College Furor Is More Heated Online
text: Reading about it online, you would think that the controversy over this year’s assigned reading for students new to Brooklyn College would have led to fevered student and faculty protests by now, making the campus the latest to be roiled by the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: How Women Reshaped the Modern Kitchen
text: “Counter Space: Design and the Modern Kitchen,” an exhibition that opens Sept. 15 at the Museum of Modern Art, will explore the way the kitchen has evolved since the start of the 20th century. Juliet Kinchin (right), the curator of the show, talked about the role women played in designing rational kitchens — including some early ergonomic models — and the symbolism of utensils like Philippe Starck’s Juicy Salif Lemon Squeezer.

headline: Picnic Essentials
text: SUMMER is winding down, but picnic season isn’t over yet.

headline: Sales at Intérieurs, Nest Interiors and Desiron
text: Intérieurs is discounting some floor samples (Modenature’s Renversant sofa, originally $8,734, is $4,000; Modenature’s Teatime daybed in suede, regularly $10,362, is $4,900; the India Song chaise, above, originally $6,190, is $2,490); 228 East 58th Street (Second Avenue), (212) 343-0800, interieurs.com.

headline: Ceramics That Seek a Timeless Look
text: “I’m not trying to reinvent the wheel,” said Eric Bonnin, speaking of the ceramics collection he introduced at the New York International Gift Fair. “I want to make simple, classic things that will survive the test of time. When you buy something handmade, you want to keep it for a while.”

headline: A New Tableware Line at Metropolitan Museum Gift Shop
text: Le Chat Noir, a new line of decorative accessories at the Metropolitan Museum of Art gift shop, was inspired by the work of a painter and printmaker best known for the image of a slinky black cat he created for a cabaret poster in 19th-century Paris.

headline: Monocle Magazine Opens West Village Shop
text: A space that measures 188 square feet is not what most retailers would consider generous. But to Tyler Brûlé, the editor in chief of Monocle magazine, the storefront that size on Hudson Street that houses his latest Monocle Shop is more than adequate. Despite the small footprint — a trademark of all the Monocle shops, from London to Tokyo, Hong Kong and Los Angeles — the store, which opened last week, carries a fairly large, well-edited selection of merchandise.

headline: Tables Made With Birch Branches
text: John Begin, a 48-year-old furniture designer in Cambridge, N.Y., once made furniture from slabs of wood. Now he makes it out of branches.

headline: A Web Site for Midcentury Modern Buyers
text: Marla Dekker and Kevork Babian, graphic designers who live in Brooklyn, have been collecting midcentury modern furniture for decades and storing it in their five-story brownstone. Recently, though, their collection “finally reached critical mass,” Ms. Dekker said, and their Web site, Townhouse.bz, was born.

headline: Preparing the Garden for Cooler Weather
text: How to ease the transition from summer to fall, and prepare for next spring.

headline: As Summer Fades, Duties in the Garden Shift
text: STARTING a flower garden, I’ve discovered, is hard work. There’s the tilling and the composting and the planting and the mulching and the weeding and the pruning and the watering and the warding off of deer, woodchuck, moles, beetles and mildew.

headline: Home Is Where the Tax Exemption Is
text: STATE and local governments are cracking down on people for improperly claiming something called the homestead exemption. Take Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, who was accused of doing just that on a home he owns in Washington, D.C.

headline: A Home in the Alps With Forward-Thinking Design
text: The owner of an art gallery built a nontraditional concrete house in a Swiss village where her private collection can shine.

headline: In Switzerland, a Cast-Concrete Mountain Retreat
text: VNÀ, Switzerland

headline: Lincoln Center 'Blades'
text: An excerpt from a new sequential video display on 13 vertical 4-by-8-foot L.E.D. screens along the south side of West 65th Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues.

headline: U.S. Adds Legal Pressure on Pakistani Taliban
text: WASHINGTON  The United States government on Wednesday ratcheted up legal pressures against the Pakistani Taliban, the Qaeda-linked group accused of a role in the failed Times Square bombing in May and in the suicide bombing at a C.I.A. base in Afghanistan in December.

headline: Whose Menu Is It? Ours, BLT Answers, in Lawsuit Against Tourondel
text: As Bloomberg News reported on Tuesday, the BLT Restaurant Group, sued Laurent Tourondel in Federal District Court in Manhattan, claiming, among other things, that his LT Burger restaurant in Sag Harbor, N.Y., infringed on its trademark. So their split earlier this year has not been as amicable as it seemed.

headline: Sam Sifton at the United States Open
text: On the Straight Sets blog, Michael Kimmelman talks to Sam Sifton about the food at the United States Open tennis championship in Queens.

headline: Ferrari 458 Italia Supercar Is Recalled
text: The Ferrari 458 Italia, a midengine 560-horsepower sports car that sells for well over $200,000 and drew rave reviews after its 2009 introduction, has proved to be a lot hotter than its owners anticipated.

headline: Showcasing Graffiti Taggers’ Art, Legally
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: 'The March of Time'
text: An excerpt from "March of Time" newsreel footage.

headline: Analysis: How Llodra Upset Berdych
text: Michael Llodra rode his retro serve and volley game to a 7-6 (7-3), 6-4, 6-4 convincing victory over one of the game’s power players, Tomas Berdych, in straight sets on the Grandstand court. Time and again, Llodra slid in his wide lefty slice, forcing Berdych to reach on his two-handed backhand return.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Sept. 1
text: A few straight set victories, and a player collapses during her match after sustaining a concussion.

headline: Two Men’s Upsets, Two Different Causes
text: Two notes from the day’s earlier matches: Having heard many players yesterday dismiss the heat as an issue, Ivan Ljubicic, a 31-year-old Croat, blamed his loss on it.

headline: A Time for Reflection on Two Wars
text: To the Editor:

headline: Before the Talk of Peace, Terror in the West Bank
text: To the Editor:

headline: Medical-Tube Errors: A View From the Industry
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Search of a Case to Protect the iPad
text: The Apple iPad, so sleek and glassy, should be in a design museum, watched over by heavily armed guards with fierce dogs. But millions of iPads are bouncing around in backpacks or purses where they are gradually and inexorably scratched, dinged and pummeled by far less important objects.

headline: Officials Deny Misconduct in Sex-Trafficking Inquiry
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have sharply criticized a defense lawyer’s claim that the government engaged in misconduct by allowing a cooperating witness in a Mafia case to run a sex- trafficking ring that involved a 15-year-old girl.

headline: Remembering Photographer Corinne Day
text: Whenever I looked at a picture of Kate Moss I thought of Corinne Day, who died last Friday at her home in England. The two women, model and photographer, were linked long past Ms. Day’s first pictures in the early ’90s of the teenage Ms. Moss, and I suppose that is inevitable when a truth is revealed.

headline: What’s Worse Than Badly Fitting Shoes?
text: Whether they resemble Olive Oyl or Jessica Rabbit, women of all degrees of buxomness have found the right fit thanks to Linda Becker, a k a Linda the Bra Lady. Ms. Becker, 60 (“but I look like I’m 40”), started her first shop 23 years ago in Lafayette Hills, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia, and opened a store in New York in 2005. She sells 200 sizes of bras at Linda’s Bra Salon, on Lexington Avenue, with a second shop scheduled to open in Murray Hill this fall.

headline: Borders Reports a Larger Quarterly Loss
text: The Borders Group posted a loss for the fifth time in six quarters as revenue at established stores fell and profit margins declined.

headline: 2 Afghan Aid Workers Killed by Roadside Bomb
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least two employees of the aid organization Oxfam were killed when their vehicle struck a roadside bomb, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Fired Education Chief Says New Jersey Governor Defamed Him
text: Bret D. Schundler, the fired New Jersey education commissioner, charged on Wednesday that Gov. Chris Christie had defamed him and knowingly misstated Mr. Schundler’s role in an episode that cost the state a $400 million federal grant.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: New Twists on Old Games
text: Wouldn’t it be nice if a flick of a finger was all it took to get videos from your laptop to your TV or photos from your phone to a friend’s? On this week’s Tech Talk podcast from The New York Times, Ashlee Vance, a Times technology reporter, tells Bettina Edelstein about a new software platform from the chip maker Broadcom that’s devised to make it easier to share content and seamlessly move it from one device to another. Mr. Vance says, the challenge for Broadcom is getting a broad range of manufacturers to embed its software in their products.

headline: New Trophy for Colleges: Capital One Cup
text: College sports have a new trophy to hoist.

headline: Maker of Botox Settles Inquiry
text: Allergan, the maker of Botox, agreed on Wednesday to pay $600 million to settle charges that it illegally promoted and sold the drug through 2005 for unapproved uses like treating headaches.

headline: Overseas Growth Helps Lift Revenue at Heinz
text: The food company H. J. Heinz said first-quarter revenue rose 1.6 percent as sales in developing markets soared. It also said reductions in ketchup prices at Wal-Mart Stores helped demand.

headline: Leinart’s Available, But Buyers Are Scarce
text: The Arizona Cardinals have begun calling teams with quarterback needs to gauge interest in Matt Leinart, the former first-round pick and Heisman Trophy winner at Southern California who has repeatedly failed to seize the Cardinals’ starting job.

headline: Can Privacy Sell Ping?
text: Apple moved quickly to allay potential concerns about information privacy on Wednesday when it introduced Ping, its music-focused social-networking service for the 160 million users of its iTunes service.

headline: The Audacity of Taupe
text: THE Oval Office has been tweaked, in a makeover orchestrated by the California decorator Michael Smith. In response, television audiences and the blogosphere seemed to produce a collective yawn: too brown, too dowdy, too ho hum, they pronounced as one.

headline: Monetary Fund Warns G-7 on Debt Levels
text: WASHINGTON  The world’s most developed economies, which have been racking up spending since the mid-1960s, face record levels of debt as a result of the 2008-9 financial crisis and have little room for maneuver, the International Monetary Fund warned on Wednesday.

headline: An Office Fitted for a President
text: The subtly shifting décor of the Oval Office, from Franklin Delano Roosevelt’s presidency through the latest makeover for Barack Obama.

headline: Dell and Its Deadline
text: The deadline for Dell to respond to Hewlett-Packard‘s offer for data storage company 3Par is only hours away.

headline: Cleaning the Henhouse
text: The latest salmonella outbreak, underscoring the failures of industrial farming, reminds me of the small chicken flock that I tended while growing up on a family farm.

headline: Woods Looks to Make Another Leap in Standings
text: NORTON, Mass.  Looking loose, rested and ready, Tiger Woods arrived at the T.P.C. Boston shortly after 3 p.m. Wednesday. He went right to work in a practice session aimed at carrying over the positives from his final round at the Barclays last week into this week’s Deutsche Bank Championship.

headline: Study Sees Heart Risk in Meridia Diet Pill
text: A clinical trial of Meridia, a controversial diet pill, in nearly 10,000 overweight or obese older patients over many years found that the drug increased the risks of heart attacks and strokes while doing little to slim their waists.

headline: A Dream House After All
text: Boston

headline: Court Blocks New York Tax on Tribal Cigarette Sales
text: A state law to tax cigarettes sold by Indian tribes in New York had barely gotten off the ground on Wednesday when a state appellate court judge brought it to a halt, blocking an effort that Gov. David A. Paterson said could help stabilize the state’s finances.

headline: On Big Moving Day, Boston Battles a Pest
text: BOSTON  As if all the double-parked moving vans, anxious parents and mountains of discarded furniture and trash are not enough to fray nerves on the day when thousands of college students move into their apartments here, city officials on Wednesday were up against a tiny problem that poses a huge threat.

headline: Blasé About Hurricane Maps? Remember 1938
text: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, N.Y.

headline: Sarah’s Amazing Race
text: Sarah Palin is going to Iowa to be the headliner at a Republican fund-raiser. In the state that will be the first to hold a contest in the 2012 presidential campaign, even if it has to do it in 2011.

headline: Grief Across Latin America for Migrant Killings
text: AGUA CALIENTE, Guatemala  He was warned the journey north would be hard, so Gilmar Morales beefed up on eggs and sausage, bought some ham sandwiches from the bodega across the street, told his mother he loved her and set off with two other relatives on a path well-traveled by young people here in one of Latin America’s poorest countries.

headline: Eyes Fix on Radar Gun When Rookie Pitches
text: CINCINNATI  Aroldis Chapman is testing the limits of just how fast a human can throw a baseball. On Wednesday night at Great American Ball Park, in the second electrifying appearance of his major league career, Chapman fired a fastball that registered 103.9 miles an hour, the hardest pitch in the majors over the last three seasons.

headline: The Real Say on Pay
text: The Financial Times reported this week that lawyers for corporate America are warning of a “logistical nightmare” from a provision in the new financial reform law that requires companies to disclose the ratio between a chief executive’s pay package and that of a typical employee.

headline: As Pettitte Progresses, Yankees Move Vazquez Back Into the Rotation
text: For all the tumult that has engulfed the Yankees’ rotation during Andy Pettitte’s absence, it will probably not look much different when he returns.

headline: A Celebratory Road Trip for Education Secretary
text: PORTLAND, Me.  A chartered bus adorned with slogans about “Hope” and “Dreams” was rumbling through this part of the country this week, carrying a public servant who made regular stops to greet mayors and local television cameras.

headline: Seeking the Ordinary in the Eccentric
text: THE virtuoso Canadian pianist Glenn Gould is one of those performers, like James Dean or Maria Callas, whose life and legend nearly overshadow their artistic achievements. But since Gould also insisted on keeping his private life shielded, he would seem to be a particularly elusive and unlikely choice for a documentary film that presumes to call itself “Genius Within: The Inner Life of Glenn Gould.”

headline: Britain: Inquest Into Spy’s Death
text: The body of a British spy, found dead in his apartment in London last month, had been padlocked into a gym bag and put in the bathtub, officials said Wednesday at the inquest into the man’s death, but how he died is not yet certain. The Westminster coroner, Dr. Paul Knapman, said that the body of the missing intelligence officer, Gareth Williams, 30, above, was discovered in an “advanced state of decay” on Aug. 23. A pathologist found that Mr. Williams had not been stabbed or shot, and that there were no obvious signs of strangulation, said a spokeswoman for the Westminster Coroner’s Court. A post-mortem exam last week failed to establish a conclusive cause of death. The inquest has been adjourned until next Wednesday.

headline: A Long Battle for the Hudson River
text: Milestones in the decades-long duel between the Environmental Protection Agency and General Electric to purge the Hudson River of toxic chemicals.

headline: South Africa: Sympathy Strike Is Suspended as Talks Continue
text: A two-week-old strike by teachers, nurses and other public employees continued to paralyze public services on Wednesday, but the trade union federation, Cosatu, said it had suspended sympathy strikes by mining and manufacturing workers planned for Thursday. Negotiations were continuing on the government’s offer to give more than a million public employees pay raises of 7.5 percent, double the inflation rate.

headline: On Course for a Cleaner Hudson
text: The cleanup of the Hudson River by the General Electric Company — dredging industrial pollutants that have been poisoning the river for 60 years — finally started last year. That is the good news. The bad news is that the project turned out to be full of unexpected problems.

headline: A Phonebook for the 21st Century
text: A start-up called Inflection wants to build a 21st-century version of the phonebook.

headline: My Summer Home
text: During the bittersweet days of September light, when a low-angled sun is unwavering in its withdrawal, I always have trouble saying goodbye. How to shutter the season? How to close the summer home with a memory to last through the dark months?

headline: Rigor Required, Cream Puffs Need Not Apply
text: EVERY four years some of the most skilled artisans in France compete for the government’s highest distinction for trade workers, the right to be called Un des Meilleurs Ouvriers de France (One of the Best Craftsmen of France, otherwise known as MOF). “Kings of Pastry,” a documentary by Chris Hegedus and D. A. Pennebaker that opens in New York on Sept. 15, explores the never-before-filmed pastry division of the competition.

headline: Katrina, Five Years Later
text: New Orleans is rebounding well from the devastation wrought by Hurricane Katrina in 2005 and could conceivably end up on a stronger economic footing than before the storm  if the city redevelops in the right way. For that to happen, federal, state and local authorities must step up the effort to restore flood-damaged neighborhoods, some of which are heavily blighted and still have less than half their prestorm populations.

headline: Boy Scouts Settle Suit With Victims of Abuse
text: The Boy Scouts of America have reached a financial settlement with six men who say they were sexually abused when they were members of the same troop in Oregon in the 1980s.

headline: Tough Women and Flawed Men
text: IN 1935 Warner Brothers released a pair of romantic melodramas starring Kay Francis and George Brent, and directed by Frank Borzage: “Living on Velvet” in March, and “Stranded” just a few months later in June. Both have now been released on DVD through the Warner Archive Collection, the burn-on-demand service (warnerarchive.com) that offers (mostly) unrestored editions of lesser-known titles from the huge Warner Brothers library.

headline: State Pension Fund Faces Shortfall, Candidate Says
text: Every year, New York State issues a report that depicts its pension fund at the peak of health  not a penny short of what it needs to pay retirees their benefits. In some years, the report even shows a little surplus.

headline: 18-Year-Old Qualifier Upsets No. 15 Ljubicic
text: After requiring underhand serves just to qualify for the main draw of the United States Open, Ryan Harrison followed a more conventional path into the second round on Wednesday.

headline: When Warriors Hurt Themselves
text: “Dwell time” is military shorthand for the precious home-front visits back to family life that soldiers enjoy between the multiple deployments of modern warfare. The need for enough dwell time  and for a fairer, less stressful distribution of repeat deployments  is a keystone finding in a study of the alarming rise in suicides afflicting the military as it soldiers on in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: In Somali Civil War, Both Sides Embrace Pirates
text: HOBYO, Somalia  Ismail Haji Noor, a local government official, recently arrived in this notorious pirate den with a simple message: we need your help.

headline: For President and Predecessor, a Chill Returns
text: WASHINGTON  On his first visit back to the White House after leaving the presidency, George W. Bush sat in the Oval Office with his successor, President Obama, for a briefing on the earthquake in Haiti. It was January 2010  nearly a year to the day after Mr. Bush left office  and it seemed, at the time, like a door might be opening between the two men.

headline: What to Watch on Thursday at the Open
text: With the women’s game more and more dominated by big-hitting human ball machines, a second-round matchup between Maria Jose Martinez Sanchez and Patty Schnyder provides a welcome change of pace.

headline: Bloggingheads: Mideast Hope vs. Cynicism
text: Hussein Ibish, left, of the American Task Force on Palestine and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: Scantily Clad Dancers Are Nowhere to Be Found When Turkey Plays
text: ANKARA, Turkey  A team that takes the court during timeouts is the one that is stirring up the most controversy at the basketball world championships.

headline: Leaders Gather for Mideast Talks
text: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority appeared together Wednesday with President Obama, who urged the leaders to produce “lasting change” during their peace talks in Washington.

headline: Feud With Palin in Background of Alaska Upset
text: ANCHORAGE  The message might have seemed gracious, on its face.

headline: Scholastic Books Revamps Its Marketing
text: WHEN Karen Rice was a little girl, Santa Claus visited multiple times a year. At least it felt that way when Ms. Rice, now a 22-year-old elementary-school teacher in Elizabethtown, Ky., got the books she ordered from the Scholastic Book Club.

headline: New Rules for Biotech Sugar Beets Promised This Year
text: The Agriculture Department said Wednesday that it planned to have interim rules governing genetically modified sugar beets in place by the end of the year after a judge revoked the government’s approval of the plants last month.

headline: Stimulus Averted Depression, Romer Says
text: WASHINGTON  Christina D. Romer, chairwoman of President Obama’s Council of Economic Advisers, said in a farewell speech on Wednesday that the administration’s stimulus policies averted “a second Great Depression.”

headline: Burger King Has Suitors From Brazil
text: Burgers and beer  an American meal if there ever was one  could soon have a distinctly Brazilian flavor.

headline: Lottery Numbers
In Community Service, Celebrity Justice Means the Same Dirty Work
text: Caroline Giuliani is most likely headed the way of Boy George and Naomi Campbell: donning gloves, a pale face mask, neon vest and work boots before commencing several hours of scrubbing, sweeping and tidying the messy corners of a Sanitation Department garage in Manhattan.

headline: Adam Langer Solves the Thursday Crossword
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — If you came here looking for answers — go away. Come back when you’ve tried one more time. You’ll figure it out.

headline: After a Cameo on Cable, Jets Hit the Stage
text: The police stopped rush-hour traffic at Eighth Avenue and West 47th Street on Wednesday so the buses could pass through and their passengers, burly men in jackets and ties, could make the curtain. These were the Jets, en route to the off-Broadway Actors Temple Theater. It was just before 9 a.m., earlier even for actors than for professional athletes.

headline: The High Cost of Eggs
text: My Thursday column is about the cost of industrial farming practices. I’m thinking not so much the price we pay in the store but the price we pay in pollution, in antibiotic-resistant diseases and in food poisonings such as the salmonella outbreak now in the headlines. It’s not so much eggs that sicken people with salmonella — it’s industrial farming models.

headline: A Serve Short of Another Run
text: Alona Bondarenko must have flashed back to last year’s United States Open when Melanie Oudin held serve to go up by 5-4 in the second set Wednesday. Cracking her racket in frustration after a forehand error, Bondarenko heard the overheated crowd come alive as Oudin yelled, “Come on!” Having been thoroughly outplayed by Bondarenko in the first set, Oudin was on the verge of turning the second-round match her way and forcing a third set.

headline: Takahashi, as Free Agent, Could Leave the Mets
text: One of the few positives for the Mets this season has been the surprising performance of Hisanori Takahashi, the Japanese left-hander who signed a minor league contract in February and developed into one of the team’s most versatile players.

headline: Still Not in Fine Form, Burnett at Least Gives Yankees a Chance to Win
text: Regardless of how poorly A. J. Burnett pitched in August, or in June, or throughout his intensely frustrating season, he entered his start Wednesday night with a rotation spot secured. His manager said there was never a doubt.

headline: Lineup and Card Game Feel Lonely for Wright
text: ATLANTA  One by one, David Wright’s card-game partners have disappeared from the table. Their almost daily routine, starting in spring training, has been broken up by the business of baseball, which includes injuries and the turmoil of a lost season.

headline: A Painting Vanishes, and Questions Mount
text: The lawsuit seemed destined to become a late-night television punch line: man gets drunk, claims he loses million-dollar painting, gets taken to court.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: Son Missing, Arum Skips Promotion
text: It was, Manny Pacquiao said, an unusually subdued news conference Wednesday at Chelsea Piers for his Nov. 13 super welterweight title bout against Antonio Margarito at Cowboys Stadium.

headline: Pondexter Leads Liberty Into Finals in the East
text: For more than a year, the Liberty has been remodeling itself. There were subtractions in 2009 and additions in the off-season, a sluggish start to 2010 and a surge in the second half of the season.

headline: Five and Five: No. 7, Virginia tech
text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 7, is Virginia Tech. You can find a larger Virginia Tech preview here.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,246 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Inconsistencies in Lehman Case
text: Dick Fuld, the former head of Lehman Brothers, seems to still be feeling the effects of his own home-brewed Kool-Aid. Mr. Fuld hasn’t stopped attributing his investment bank’s demise to “uncontrollable” market forces, false rumors and the lack of a government rescue. That point of view neglects his own hubris and failure to buttress the firm. But he makes at least one fair point: regulators were damagingly inconsistent.

headline: Reds’ Chapman Blazes Into the Majors
text: CINCINNATI – So far, so perfect for Aroldis Chapman. In his first two career appearances, on Tuesday and Wednesday here against Milwaukee, Chapman has faced six batters and retired them all.

headline: New Life for Chimpanzees
text: A group of primates, which were formerly used for medical research, have found a reprieve from the testing. But that might not last.

headline: Will Aging Chimps Get to Retire, or Face Medical Research?
text: ALAMOGORDO, N.M. — Flo the chimpanzee bounds about her enclosure, hurls a rubber ball then stares quizzically at the New Mexico green chili pepper that will be her morning snack.

headline: Man Accused of Stealing a Bus Is Arraigned
text: When Darius McCollum was arrested on Tuesday, the circumstances were all too familiar. Once again, he stood accused of taking a bus or a subway car for a ride.

headline: California Senate Debate Turns on Economy
text: SAN FRANCISCO – Senator Barbara Boxer of California and her Republican opponent, the businesswoman Carly Fiorina, sparred in their first – and perhaps only – debate on Wednesday night, with jobs taking a front seat in a state rife with economic problems.

headline: Word of the Day | transgression
text: transgression •\tranz-ˈgre-shən\• noun

headline: A Dream House After All
text: From Karl E. Case on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times:

headline: Settlements in West Bank Are Clouding Peace Talks
text: WASHINGTON  Israeli and Palestinian negotiators cleared the first hurdle on Thursday in their elusive quest for Middle East peace: they agreed to keep talking, two weeks from now in Egypt.

headline: Hurricane Earl Starts Bearing Down on Carolina Coast
text: Hurricane Earl pounded North Carolina late Thursday night with powerful but diminishing strength, pelting the eastern part of the state with bands of rain and severe blasts of wind as communities and seaside towns across the eastern seaboard braced for the storm’s devastating force.

headline: Seattle’s Jackson to Get Third M.V.P. Award
text: For years, Lisa Leslie was the dominant presence in the lane in the W.N.B.A. Now her on-court nemesis, Lauren Jackson, is leaving her mark on the league.

headline: News Quiz | September 2, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: A Calmer Roddick Accepts Call, if Not Explanation
text: Considering his sustained level of anger on the court after a disputed foot-fault call during his four-set loss to Janko Tipsarevic of Serbia at the United States Open, Andy Roddick was slightly regretful, if not apologetic afterward.

headline: Wiesenthal Worked for Israeli Spy Agency, Book Alleges
text: JERUSALEM  Simon Wiesenthal, a Holocaust survivor who gained worldwide fame for decades as a one-man Nazi-hunting operation, was in fact frequently on the payroll of the Mossad, Israel’s spy agency, a new biography asserts.

headline: Crisis Panel Lends Ear to Lehman’s Ex-Chief
text: In the nearly two years since Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, its former chief executive, Richard S. Fuld Jr., has often seemed a tragic and solitary figure, telling anyone who would listen that the investment bank could have survived if only it had had more time — and received a bailout like the government gave other Wall Street banks.

headline: Kamsky Wins Strong Tournament in Azerbaijan
text: The reigning United States champion has been on a roll lately.

headline: Burger King Has Suitors From Brazil
text: Burgers and beer — an American meal if there ever was one — could soon have a distinctly Brazilian flavor, Peter Lattman and Andrew Ross Sorkin report in The New York Times.

headline: Monetary Fund Warns G-7 on Debt Levels
text: The world’s most developed economies, which have been racking up spending since the mid-1960s, face record levels of debt as a result of the 2008-9 financial crisis and have little room for maneuver, the International Monetary Fund warned on Wednesday.

headline: In Lahore, Mourning for Victims of Attacks
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  With the police on high alert, hundreds of people attended funeral prayers here on Thursday for the victims of suicide bombers who attacked Shiite Muslim worshipers on Wednesday, killing dozens.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Dogdom
text: Today’s word, in association with the inspirational Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Primus Mulls Appeal of Taiwan Decision on Nan Shan
text: The buyers of American International Group‘s Taiwan unit will be constructive as they seek to pursue the $2.2 billion bid even after Taiwan’s regulators rejected it, a top executive told Reuters on Thursday.

headline: S.E.C. Said to Look at Effects of Quote Stuffing
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into a Wall Street trading practice in which unusually large numbers of orders to buy or sell stocks are placed in a fraction of a second, only to be canceled almost immediately, The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday.

headline: China Digs for Ways to Stymie BHP’s Potash Bid
text: China is stepping up attempts to hamper BHP Billiton‘s $39 billion hostile offer for Potash Corp., amid worries about future supplies of fertilizer it needs to rapidly boost food production.

headline: A.&P. Said to Mull Sale of Food Emporium
text: Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, which operates the struggling A.&P. supermarket chain, is mulling the sale of its Food Emporium stores to boost liquidity,  The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Independent Lawmaker Supports Australian Leader
text: SYDNEY, Australia Prime Minister Julia Gillard cleared another hurdle on Thursday in her bid to break Australia’s first parliamentary deadlock in 70 years, winning the tentative support of an independent legislator from Tasmania.

headline: Citigroup to Cut Banking Account Fees
text: Citigroup will cut in half the minimum balance on checking accounts with the highest level of service, in a push to get more customers to use the bank for their primary accounts, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Bernanke Testifying to Crisis Inquiry Panel
text: Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke is set to appear before a panel investigating the financial crisis to give his take on the meltdown and his views on potential systemwide risks posed by large financial institutions, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Its Name is Earl
text: WHO was fleeing the coastline in North Carolina, and WHO was heading toward it, in anticipation of Hurricane Earl? WHY?

headline: Berkshire Makes Formal Bid for Wesco Subsidiary
text: Berkshire Hathaway has made a formal offer to buy the roughly 1.4 million shares it doesn’t already own of its subsidiary Wesco Financial, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Why Develop Apps for Android?
text: Pinger, a developer of mobile applications, can get twice as much in sales from programs for Apple devices than for phones powered by Android software. That’s not stopping it from creating its first Android app, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Watching a Teenage Girl Die by Mortar
text: Adam Ferguson believes that facing difficult moments honestly — without emotionally separating himself from the situation at hand — yields more engaging photographs.

headline: Mathematicians, Musicians and Chess Masters
text: Sunday’s chess column was about Noam Elkies, a Harvard mathematics professor who is also a music composer and chess player. Though Mr. Elkies is unusual at being talented in all three areas, he is not entirely unique. Through the years, there have been a number of strong chess players who were excellent mathematicians or musicians.

headline: F.D.I.C. Claim on Bankrupt Colonial Dismissed
text: A claim from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation that it is owed more than $900 million by Colonial BancGroup, the ex-parent company of Colonial Bank now under the control of the authorities, has been dismissed by a federal judge, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Pakistan’s Future Problem: ‘Too Little Water’
text: Today’s idea: Flood-ravaged Pakistan’s long-term problem is not too much water, a columnist says; it is too little water — and one day it could cause a war with India.

headline: Indian Steelmaker Draws up Short List for Issue
text: The state-run Steel Authority of India Limited has shortlisted JPMorgan, Deutsche Bank and four others to manage a follow-on share offering that could raise up to $1.7 billion, Reuters reported Thursday, citing four sources with direct knowledge of the situation.

headline: Do Your Test Scores Reflect How Good Your Teachers Are?
text: Among educators, there is a lot of talk about “value-added modeling,” a system that uses specific data, including students’ standardized test scores, to determine teacher effectiveness and even, according to one Times article, be used to “[rank] teachers from best to worst.” Do you think your test scores, class rank and other statistics related to your achievement accurately reflect how much you truly learn and how good your teachers are?

headline: Lanvin to Make Clothes for H & M
text: Lanvin, one of the oldest Paris fashion houses, announced today that it will do a collection this fall for H & M.

headline: Man Group Gives GLG’s Roman Top Post
text: Man Group, the British hedge fund company, named GLG head Emmanuel Roman as its chief operating officer on Wednesday, to help Man Group integrate its recent acquisition of the GLG business, Reuters reported.

headline: G.M. to Start Roadshow After Midterms
text: General Motors plans to begin courting investors for its initial public offering immediately after the Nov. 2 midterm Congressional elections, Reuters said Wednesday, citing two sources familiar with the plans.

headline: Dubai P.E. Firm Buys First Sukuk in Britain
text: Millennium Private Equity, a Dubai government-linked investment company with about $5 billion in capital, plans to use Islamic financing for venture capital in Europe after buying the first corporate sukuk in Britain, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: In Ireland, Dangers Still Loom
text: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a principal in Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Theme at London Festival Is Simply ‘Funny’
text: From Sept. 6 to 12, London’s normally regal Old Royal Navy College will be a frenzy of standup comedy, burlesque dancing, go-go girls and stilt-walkers during the second annual Greenwich Comedy Festival.

headline: Petrobras Strikes $42.5 Billion Deal for Brazil Fields
text: In a step toward one of the largest share offerings this year, Petroleo Brasileiro, the Brazilian national oil company, said Wednesday that it had agreed to issue $42.5 billion in new stock to the Brazilian government to win the right to 5 billion barrels of oil in offshore fields.

headline: Two Lehman Estate Units Need a Rescue
text: Two struggling units of Lehman Brothers Holdings, the bankrupt investment bank, need hundreds of millions of dollars in capital to stave off failure that could cost Lehman billions, Reuters reported, citing court documents.

text: Q.

headline: Social Media Are Easier Than You Think
text: With so many new technologies and tools, we business owners often feel as if we’re playing catch-up — as if we don’t even know what we don’t know. In just the last few years, there’s been a land grab by newly minted social media experts staking claim to social media prowess. Last month, the team over at Thought Lead hosted an online meet-up of 60 social media and online marketing experts titled The Influencer Project. The one-hour seminar gave all of the experts 60 seconds to offer their best advice on how companies could increase their influence online. For anyone with attention-deficit impulses (ahem) this was nirvana.

headline: The Football Laws, From Football Outsiders
text: Aaron Schatz has posted a summation of seven years of research at his Web site, Football Outsiders. Here are the headlines, with a few comments of explanation from Schatz. You’re encouraged to read the post for the full explanations:

headline: G.M. Is Trying to Corner the Market on ‘Range Anxiety’
text: With apologies to Mel Brooks, “high anxiety” is a woefully outmoded concept. More explicit diagnoses are required to classify our post-millennial tensions and neuroses. General Motors, seems to acknowledge this, Jalopnik reported, having recently filed paperwork to trademark the phrase “range anxiety.”

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –Chris Whalen, in a broadside against Fannie, Freddie and too-big-to-fail banks, writes on his Reuters blog: “Fed Chairman Bernanke and the other members of the FOMC are killing the real economy to save the banks — but none of the benefit flowing to the banks is reaching U.S. households. In fact, the Obama Administration has been providing political cover for the Fed to conduct a massive, reverse Robin Hood scheme, moving trillions of dollars in resources from savers and consumers to the big banks and their share and bond holders.”

headline: Open House, Day 4: Does America Crave American Tennis Champions?
text: Michael Kimmelman, the Times’s chief art critic, and Gerry Marzorati, editor of the Sunday Magazine, are covering the Open from uncommon perspectives. Each morning, they discuss what’s happening. Join the conversation — or ask a fan-oriented question — by sending in a comment. Gerry Marzorati: Morning, Michael. You wrote perceptively yesterday about a certain kind of Open goer, the guy or gal who revels in the midway — the proximity to a spectacle, the feeling of being close enough to sports stars and television broadcasts and a decent bar to sense fun, or even importance. I sat close to a different sort of Open goer — those men and women longing for a next American men’s single’s sensation.

headline: The GoPro Camera Goes Anywhere
text: At first glance the GoPro HD Hero camera looks like a toy you would find inside a carton of cereal; it’s a tiny little box, just a couple of inches square in every direction. But as soon as you turn it on and begin recording images or video, you realize it packs more power than most professional cameras on the market today.

headline: Avis Raises Bid for Dollar Thrifty
text: The Avis Budget Group said on Thursday that it had raised its cash-and-stock bid for Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group to more than $1.3 billion and maintained that its offer remained superior to a proposal by Hertz Global Holdings.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Cutting 3,500 Back-Office Jobs
text: Royal Bank of Scotland said Thursday that it would cut 3,500 jobs and close sites in England over the coming year.

headline: Bill Gates on R&D, a Carbon Tax and China’s Climate Role
text: Bill Gates, the software innovator and development philanthropist who has recently championed a big research push to advance non-polluting energy choices, has weighed in with some new thoughts after reading a critique of his thesis by Richard Rosen of the Tellus Institute. Rosen asserted that putting too much focus on research aimed at energy breakthroughs was “dangerous” because it might encourage people “to put off investment in the many good renewable technologies that we have today, in the hope that something dramatically better will come along in the future.”

headline: I Don’t Wanna Grow Up: Late Night With ‘Yo Gabba Gabba!’
text: I keep reading that “Yo Gabba Gabba!”, a colorful, music-themed show that is broadcast on Nickelodeon’s Nick Jr. channel, is intended for a preschool audience. How can this be? My wife and I, who as far as we know have nary a child between us, went to a “Yo Gabba Gabba!” concert at the Beacon Theater in November. We dancey-danced to songs like “Party in My Tummy” and “Get the Sillies Out.” We cheered when they brought out the special musical guests Dinosaur Jr. and Darryl (DMC) McDaniels of Run-DMC, and we squealed when balloons rained down from the theater’s ceiling (one of us did, anyway). We even sat next to Gilbert Gottfried! You’re telling me we weren’t the target audience for this show?
