headline: The Inflation Cure
text: Ken Rogoff is proposing — not for the first time — that the United States use a burst of inflation to get out of its slump. My reaction is a mix of agreement and exasperation. I agree that higher inflation would help; my exasperation comes from Rogoff’s offhandedness about the whole thing. How, exactly, are we supposed to get this burst of inflation?

headline: Catalysta
text: An unlikely portmanteau created to improve the image of cats and cat-owners – and to dispel the “crazy cat lady” cliché.

headline: Do Fluorescent Lights Trigger Migraines?
text: This week’s Well column in Science Times focused on pediatric migraine and why back-to-school time, with lost sleep, skipped meals and other bad habits, can trigger migraine pain.

headline: Updated Hurricane Warnings for U.S.
text: Updated | 1:06 p.m. In its latest advisory on the dangers posed by the approach of Hurricane Earl, at 11 a.m. on Thursday, the National Hurricane Center in Miami said that the “dangerous” storm is “heading for the Outer Banks,” of North Carolina, where it is expected to pass tonight. The center also added a hurricane warning for portions of Massachusetts.

headline: Frame Job
text: Gerry Beckley has some peculiar enthusiasms. A founding member of the ’70s Cali-rock band America, he spends most of his days on the road reviving ‘‘Sister Golden Hair.’’ And each morning, like clockwork, he photographs the view from his hotel-room window — a ritual he’s kept up for about 15 years.

headline: Yankees Start String of Five Consecutive Day Games
text: For the next five days, Yankee Stadium transforms into Wrigley Field of the East. No, not because of the rowdy, beer-soaked fans in the bleachers (on second thought …). Rather, each of the next five games will begin at 1:05 p.m., as the Yankees get into the spirit of the holiday weekend.

headline: Burger King to Sell Itself to 3G for $4 Billion
text: Burger King agreed on Thursday to sell itself to the investment firm 3G Capital for about $4 billion, including the assumption of debt, marking the second time in eight years that the fast-food giant has taken itself private.

headline: The Peanut Solution
text: Like most tales of great invention, the story of Plumpy’nut begins with a eureka moment, in this case involving a French doctor and a jar of Nutella, and proceeds through the stages of rejection, acceptance, evangelization and mass production. The product may not look like much — a little foil packet filled with a soft, sticky substance — but its advocates are prone to use the language of magic and wonders. What is Plumpy’nut? Sound it out, and you get the idea: it’s an edible paste made of peanuts, packed with calories and vitamins, that is specially formulated to renourish starving children. Since its widespread introduction five years ago, it has been credited with significantly lowering mortality rates during famines in Africa. Children on a Plumpy’nut regimen add pounds rapidly, often going from a near-death state to relative health in a month. In the world of humanitarian aid, where progress is usually measured in subtle increments of misery, the new product offers a rare satisfaction: swift, visible, fantastic efficacy.

headline: Toyota Feels Exchange-Rate Pinch as Rivals Gain
text: TOKYO — For all the turmoil over Toyota’s wave of recalls, the company, the world’s largest automaker, may face a bigger problem: the surging yen.

headline: Gates, in Afghanistan, Speaks on Local Issues
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived here on an unannounced visit on Thursday, and found himself grappling with some of Afghanistan’s most troubling domestic issues as well as the military ones.

headline: Joan Nathan on Rosh Hashana Cooking
text: Joan Nathan replies to readers’ questions about Rosh Hashana cooking.

headline: Poetry Pairing | September 2, 2010
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by former U.S. Poet Laureate Ted Kooser.

headline: Lazio Leads Paladino by 12 Points, Survey Finds
text: Updated, 10:44 a.m. | Former Representative Rick A. Lazio is holding on to his lead in the race to win the Republican nomination for governor, according to a survey released on Thursday. But Mr. Lazio, who has been seen by members of his own party as a weak candidate and who has struggled to raise money, has failed to ignite the passion of a significant number of voters, the Quinnipiac University poll found.

headline: Thursday Reading: More on Textbook Prices
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Discounts Help Lift Back-to-School Sales
text: Back-to-school season started off on sale, with retailers receiving new merchandise in August, and then marking it down to get it out the door.

headline: Store Review: California Carnivores in Sebastopol, Calif.
text: Even before Audrey II, the singing carnivorous plant, begged Seymour to feed her in the 1960 film version of “The Little Shop of Horrors,” flesh-eating plants have ensnared our collective imagination as unlikely predators.

headline: From Mickey to Murakami: Kaikai and Kiki to Join Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade
text: If familiar figures like Kermit the Frog and SpongeBob SquarePants are simply too jejune for you as their larger-than-life, helium-filled representations wind their way toward Herald Square on Thanksgiving morning, the organizers of the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade have added two new entrants to the 2010 lineup that they hope will appeal to more erudite tastes. Kaikai and Kiki, two weirdly cute (or is that cutely weird?) characters created by Takashi Murakami, the Japanese pop artist, are being turned into balloons that will mix it up with the traditional cartoon stars and corporate trademarks that will populate the parade’s 84th annual run on Nov. 25, the parade’s producers said on Thursday.

headline: H.P. Wins 3Par as Bidding War Ends
text: Dell on Thursday pulled out of the bidding for 3Par, giving the company and its promising cloud technology up for Dell’s rival Hewlett-Packard.

headline: Accounts Differ on Fatal NATO Strike on Afghans
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Airstrikes by NATO forces that killed 12 people on Thursday in northern Afghanistan have produced sharply conflicting accounts as to whether the attacks hit a team of election campaign workers, including the parliamentary candidate himself, or a group connected with an Uzbek terrorist network.

headline: Survey: Employers Pass on More Health Costs to Workers
text: Score one for the nation’s employers. On average, the total cost of a family health insurance policy rose just 3 percent last year, to $13,770 in annual premiums, according to a survey of employer health benefits released onThursday by the Kaiser Family Foundation, a nonprofit research group. (See updated article.)

headline: Upper Cuts
text: Whenever it feels like the sky is falling on men’s fashion, it’s warming to remember that one of Beau Brummell’s London tailors, Meyer & Mortimer, is still dressing the hyper-fastidious. This fun fact is one of hundreds in ‘‘Bespoke: The Men’s Style of Savile Row’’ (Rizzoli), a new tome as handsome as its subject. Up front, the author James Sherwood clears up any uncertainty fogging the much-abused term: To earn the label bespoke a garment must be measured, cut and sewn by hand; the pattern must also be hand-cut. When the pioneers of custom British tailoring took their first orders in the early 1800s, they were for clothes inspired by the ‘‘honest’’ wardrobe of the English country gentleman. In 1929 Hawkes & Co. did the unthinkable by introducing ‘‘immediate wear’’ to Savile Row, and by 1948, sales of the firm’s off-the-peg suits surpassed those of bespoke. It’s a trend that has never been reversed, though not for want of trying. In the ’90s, Richard Anderson, Ozwald Boateng and Richard James opened shops, forming what Sherwood tags ‘‘The New Establishment.’’ And Edward Sexton, Spencer Hart and Timothy Everest are currently powering a ‘‘Row Renaissance.’’ ‘‘Bespoke’’ is especially good on the crazy language peculiar to the Row. Who knew that a ‘‘tab’’ is a fussy customer, or a ‘‘crushed beetle’’ a badly made buttonhole?

headline: Off Off Off Broadway? Try Dublin
text: THE half-dozen cocktail tables on the sidewalk by Grogans Pub were mobbed with after-work, pint-packing patrons, but my companion that evening, the American actor Harris Yulin, promised that the seats were worth the wait. “I love the gloaming in Ireland,” Mr. Yulin said, and indeed, once we snagged a spot, the long summer twilight of Dublin was orangey warm and slumbering, worthy of a Tony Award for lighting.

headline: Time to Put Choreography Back on Its Feet
text: WHEN two performers barely move while staring into each other’s eyes for nearly 90 minutes, as Maria Hassabi and Robert Steijn did last spring in their collaborative duet “Robert and Maria,” conventional notions of dance dissipate like phantoms.

headline: Renaissance Portrait Inspires Gift Shop Goods
text: A STUNNING Italian blonde — a real Renaissance beauty — has been turning heads in Madrid this summer, seemingly unperturbed by the heat despite the long sleeves and heavy layers of her richly brocaded dress.

headline: 36 Hours in Silicon Valley
text: LIKE the high-tech companies that give this lush region its name, Silicon Valley thrives on reinvention. Situated just south of San Francisco Bay, the valley was once an agricultural cradle, home to orchards and vineyards. These days, of course, it bears fruit of a different sort, as the home of tech giants like Apple, Google and Intel. Buoyed by the resilience of tech companies, the valley’s dozen or so cities, which include Mountain View and Palo Alto, have managed to sidestep the recession, continuing their shift from corporate strip malls to urban hubs. The valley now buzzes with cultural spaces, lively restaurants and a hyper-educated workforce that has no problem keeping up.

headline: Clayton, Dubilier Buys Stake in Univar
text: Private-equity shop Clayton, Dubilier & Rice announced Thursday morning that it had acquired a large minority interest in Univar, a large chemical distribution business, from the buyout firm CVC Capital Partners.

headline: A More Odorous Invader Joins the Party
text: Never mind the raccoons. Here come the skunks.

headline: Life Imitates Franzen
text: Dave Weigel has the definitive take on the deeper political implications of James Lee, the lunatic anti-population growth obsessive who took hostages at the Discovery Channel yesterday, and then was shot and killed by the police. (Hint: there aren’t any.) But what about the literary implications? By which I mean, isn’t this incident further evidence that Jonathan Franzen has made some Faustian bargain to guarantee that his attempts at the Great American Novel always feel peculiarly timely? (Mild spoilers follow below.)

headline: In Medical School Shift, Meeting Patients on Day 1
text: For generations, medical students have spent two years in classrooms and laboratories, memorizing body parts and dissecting specimens, eagerly anticipating the triumphant third year when they would be immersed in working with actual people who have actual diseases.

headline: Popcast: Ben Ratliff on Miles Davis and Marty Stuart
text: Miles Davis’s “Bitches Brew,” released in 1970, was his record that won over the Woodstock generation, a double album with a rumbling rhythm section, rock-influenced solos and a Dali-meets-psychedelia cover painting. It went platinum and has been reissued numerous times, including in two new versions from Sony Legacy filled with bonus material.

headline: 6 Days, 6 States, 6 Peaks
text: THE world’s Seven Summits — the highest mountain on each continent — were in the news this year when the Alaskan climber Vern Tejas set a record by ascending them all in just 134 days. Inspired by him, I set out to climb a few peaks of my own. My challenge would be to hike what I call the Six Summits — the highest point in each New England state. I required no pack animals, porters or supplemental oxygen. Armed instead with a map, compass, hiking boots and a blue Honda, my journey lasted six days and brought me to six unique places. Below is a guide to my quest, presented in order from the point with the highest elevation to that with the lowest.

headline: Vineyard Hopping, in Maryland?
text: ON a recent warm summer evening, well over a thousand people packed the lawns at Boordy Vineyards in Hydes, Md. Families tucked into picnics, toddlers ran freely, and couples and singles danced on the makeshift floor to a swing band pumping out oldies. But the main reason for the crowds was the wine.

headline: Depositors Panic Over Bank Crisis in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  One of the principal owners of the Afghan bank at the center of an accelerating financial crisis here said depositors had withdrawn $180 million in the past two days. He predicted a “revolution” in the country’s financial system unless the Afghan government and the United States moved quickly to help stabilize the bank.

headline: Isner Struggles to Put Marathon Match in Past
text: On Wednesday, the last match at Louis Armstrong Stadium featured tennis’s tallest curiosity. There stood John Isner, yes, that John Isner, the really long man who at Wimbledon played that really long match.

text: The appearance of a mountain lion Tuesday near downtown Berkeley, Calif., caused a stir in this animal-loving, environmentally conscious community, where residents may obsess about locally grown organic food but don’t expect to be on the menu.

text: BERLIN — When a German banker and former government official spoke publicly about a unique “Jewish gene,” when he attacked Islam as a source of violence and stunted development and when he espoused genetic theories that evoked the fright of the Nazi past, the political leadership here quickly condemned him as racist and called for him to be fired.

headline: The Sound of Silence

text: ON a sweltering August night in New York the young members of the JACK Quartet found themselves playing a gig at the Stone on the Lower East Side, a no-frills performance space: just a small room with black concrete walls, no stage, no bar, and folding chairs for roughly 50 people. A rattling air-conditioner did not provide much relief, and during the 60-minute set, which included Webern’s Six Bagatelles and Philip Glass’s String Quartet No. 5, the noisy thing had to be turned off.

headline: On the Disc, Not the Stage
text: FOR opera buffs “Great Strauss Scenes,” the new recording from the American soprano Christine Brewer (Telarc TEL-31755-02), may be both a rewarding treat and an exasperating tease.

headline: The End of the Summer Reading Challenge and Our Final Favorite
text: This is it! We ran our New York Times Summer Reading Challenge for 14 weeks, and last week was, well, the last week.

headline: Q. and A. With Larry Stefanki
text: Before Andy Roddick lost at the United States Open Wednesday night, before a foot fault whipped him into a fury, I sat down with Larry Stefanki, Roddick’s coach. We talked about mono and marriage and Roddick’s place in tennis history. Here are some excerpts from the 20-minute interview.

headline: Why Mothers and Fathers Play Differently
text: Oxytocin has been called “the love hormone” because levels of it rise in women during childbirth and breast-feeding, and it is thought to facilitate bonding. It is present in men, too, and everything from eye contact to orgasm can increase its amount.

headline: Storm Front Coming
text: Hurricane Earl appears to have the entire Atlantic Coast in a state of heightened anxiety: Will the storm wash out the long weekend, taking with it entire weddings, vacations and summer-end barbecues?

headline: An Oil Platform Burns, Blanketing the Gulf With Angst
text: NEW ORLEANS — An oil platform in the Gulf of Mexico caught fire on Thursday morning, forcing its 13 crew members overboard and sending waves of anxiety along a coast that has just begun to recover from the Deepwater Horizon disaster.

headline: Poparazzi | Celebrity Spawn
text: You might not think that preschoolers would be a rich vein for those who mine celebrity gossip. But growing public interest in Hollywood offspring has meant that children of famous people who were once off limits to paparazzi now find themselves roasting in the spotlight.

headline: Call It the Stanford Award
text: Stanford’s football team does not make it to many premier bowl games, but the Cardinal rules college sports by another influential measure: it has won the Directors’ Cup 16 years in a row.

headline: As Colleges Compete, Major Money Flows to Minor Sports
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  He has a budget of almost $95 million, growing fast, and command of three private planes. He oversees a newly renovated and certified green building as well as nearly a dozen other tricked-out facilities that are among the most prized on campus.

headline: Mets Haven’t Surrendered Yet
text: The Mets have not been mathematically eliminated from playoff contention, but after losing three straight games this week to the first-place Atlanta Braves, they have about as much chance of making the postseason as Oliver Perez has of winning back his starting spot in the rotation.

headline: Tending to Patients During a Hurricane
text: Just over five years ago, Dr. Ruth Berggren, an infectious-disease specialist then on the faculty of Tulane Medical School, was assigned to cover 9 West, the H.I.V. ward at Charity Hospital, a public hospital in New Orleans. Almost all of the patients at the time were battling H.I.V. or tuberculosis, and most had been admitted to the ward in nearly critical condition, the result of some devastating constellation of poverty, crippling mental health issues, substance abuse and difficulties accessing routine health care. While these patient cases were among the most challenging in the city, the doctors and nurses of 9 West took pride in their ability to be effective and compassionate patient advocates. This, they believed, was the patient-clinician relationship at its very best.

headline: Testing the Bonds of Doctor and Patient
text: In this week’s Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen begins an occasional series that profiles physicians who are doing something extraordinary with the doctor-patient relationship. This week’s column features Dr. Ruth Berggren, an infectious disease specialist who five years ago stayed behind at Charity Hospital in New Orleans taking care of the H.I.V. patients left stranded by Hurricane Katrina.

headline: U.S. Asks Educators to Reinvent Student Tests, and How They Are Given
text: Standardized exams  the multiple-choice, bubble tests in math and reading that have played a growing role in American public education in recent years  are being overhauled.

headline: TimesCast | September 2, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, the results of a new poll on opposition to the proposed Islamic center near ground zero, the youth vote in Colorado and an interview with retired football coach Bobby Bowden.

headline: Chinese Company Aims Big With Android Smartphone
text: SHANGHAI — Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications equipment giant, made its first big move into the global smartphone market on Thursday by announcing the release of Ideos, which the company calls an affordably priced device preinstalled with Google’s Android 2.2 operating system.

headline: Analysis: How Tipsarevic Ousted Roddick
text: Janko Tipsarevic played four sets at an extraordinary high level to upset Andy Roddick in a match filled with winners and forced errors. Each player was admirably stingy in the unforced error department, with Tipsarevic committing only 30, while Roddick made a scant 23, both low numbers in a long, grueling match played mainly from the baseline.

headline: Q&A: Anniversary Dinner in Vienna
text: My wife and I have occasionally celebrated our wedding anniversary, Dec. 31, in Europe, once in London at Rules and once in Paris at a small cafe near the Eiffel Tower. This year we are contemplating Vienna, and would like some suggestions for dining in a very Viennese style, but not at a luxurious price.

headline: Little Big Zooms for Olympus Pen Cameras
text: Olympus has (finally) officially released details on two new zoom lenses that will add a lot of versatility to its Pen Micro Four Thirds (M.F.T.) cameras. The company also is adding a handsome all-black E-P2 kit to its Pen camera lineup.

headline: China Sustains Blunt ‘You First’ Message on CO2
text: Yu Qingtai, China’s lead negotiator in climate talks from 2007 through the tumultuous conference in Copenhagen last December, recently gave a blunt speech at the Bejing University School of International Studies on climate, diplomacy and the balance of national and global interests in limiting global warming.

headline: Laptops Look Like Racecars — and Not in a Good Way
text: At a meeting with Advanced Micro Devices the other day, representatives talked to me about chip sets and clock speeds, of discrete graphics and die sizes. But in passing, they mentioned an additional company initiative that really perked me up: laptop stickers.

headline: The Worst Way to See San Antonio
text: San Antonio must be a really great city to visit. I say that because I made the most ill-timed, boneheaded, rookie-error-filled, first-time visit in tourism history. And even then, I had a good time.

headline: N.E.A. Gives Grants to Five Theaters for New Plays
text: The National Endowment for the Arts on Thursday announced grants of $20,000 to five theaters for work on promising new plays that have the potential to receive full productions.

headline: Bernanke Says He Failed to See Financial Flaws
text: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, who told Congress in 2007 that the subprime mortgage crisis was “likely to be contained,” said Thursday that he had failed to recognize flaws in the financial system that amplified the housing downturn and led to an economic disaster.

headline: To Honor Louis Chevrolet, Head to Switzerland
text: LA CHAUX-DE-FONDS, Switzerland — Louis Chevrolet, the namesake of the famed automobile, was not French. Yes, he did spend a number of his formative years living in France. But he was, in fact, Swiss, and born in this town in the Jura Mountains of northern Switzerland on Dec. 25, 1878.

headline: Seeing Things | Mapping the Fossil
text: A novel collaboration between design and geoscience has led to the groundbreaking discovery of what may be the earliest known form of animal life. Bradley Samuels, one of the five principals of Situ Studio in Brooklyn, a firm that specializes in design and fabrication, and Adam Maloof, a Princeton University geosciences professor, met in high school, where they were ski buddies. Despite their different career paths, both men are visual thinkers and realized that the tools and methods of their respective “trades” could be used to expand each other’s worlds. Their joint effort began a few years ago, when Maloof was working on a project involving a meteor crater and recognized that the digital technology that Situ’s designers use to visualize data could be used to map the crater.

headline: What We’re Reading: Double-Dip Odds
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: ‘You Can’t Take it With You’ Revival Off for Fall
text: Cross the revival of “You Can’t Take It With You” off the list of Broadway shows for this fall. The producer Elizabeth I. McCann, who had announced she would mount the show in November, said on Thursday that she is now aiming for a spring opening of the 1936 comedy by George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart about the loopy Sycamore family, which won the Pulitzer Prize for drama.

text: They are getting younger and younger, these Formula One drivers. I mentioned in the previous post how Fernando Alonso, Lewis Hamilton and Sebastian Vettel had all be acting as trailblazers in recent years, setting records for being the youngest this or the youngest that in Formula One.

text: I’ve learned to shrug off some fairly ignominious baggage associated with being a resident of New Jersey: the Burr-Hamilton duel, the Hindenburg disaster, “Jersey Shore,” the Nets’ 2009-10 season. But the news that my state was once part of the Third Reich  that was an unsettling surprise.

text: The Wimbledon finalist Vera Zvonareva withstood a slew of her own errors and a spirited second-set challenge from the German Sabine Lisicki to win in the second round of the United States Open, 6-1, 7-6 (5).

headline: Elsewhere: Save the Words
text: In a bid to save little-used words from extinction, the Oxford University Press has launched a Web site – Save the Words – where members of the public are invited to adopt a lexeme.

headline: U.S. to Add Fee for Travelers From Visa-Waiver Countries
text: Visitors traveling to the United States from the 36 countries that participate in the Customs and Border Protection’s visa-waiver program currently have to fill out an online form called the Electronic System for Travel Authorization, or ESTA, prior to entry. Starting on Sept. 8, that registration process will require a $14 fee, paid by credit or debit card.

headline: Problem Child
text: The Austrian-born artist Gottfried Helnwein is perhaps better known for his Johnny Cash-like sartorial style (black everything, including the ever-present bandanna) and his neo-Gothic Irish castle (site of the star-crossed union of Marilyn Manson and Dita Von Teese) than he is for his own startling body of work: macabre paintings with photographic resonance played out on a grand scale and often in public settings. Throughout his career, Helnwein has glided easily between watercolor, oil and installation work, but his big subject has always been childhood, and not the happy sort.

headline: Camping in a Brooklyn Wilderness
text: Sandra Stevenson, a photo editor at the Times, took her family camping in Brooklyn recently. Here is her report.

headline: Inspired by Oudin, and Emulating Her
text: A year ago, Beatrice Capra was playing the junior tournament at the National Tennis Center when she was captivated by Melanie Oudin’s run to the quarterfinals of the United States Open, thrilled to see a fellow 17-year-old crashing the big stage. But even a few weeks ago, Capra could hardly imagine she might be the one following in Oudin’s footsteps.

headline: Courtside: Butorac Finds Success in Doubles
text: When he was playing Division III tennis for Gustavus Adolphus College in St. Peter, Minn., no one thought Eric Butorac would make a living playing the sport, least of all Butorac himself.

headline: John Cage, 79, a Minimalist Enchanted With Sound, Dies
text: John Cage, the prolific and influential composer whose Minimalist works have long been a driving force in the world of music, dance and art, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

headline:
9 Israelis on Olympic Team Killed with 4
Arab Captors as Police Fight Band That
Disrupted Munich Games
text: Munich, West Germany, Wednesday, Sept. 6--Eleven members of Israel's Olympic team and four Arab terrorists were killed yesterday in a 23-hour drama that began with an invasion of the Olympic Village by the Arabs. It ended in a shootout at a military airport some 15 miles away as the Arabs were preparing to fly to Cairo with their Israeli hostages.

headline: Jane Addams A Foe of War and Need
text: At Hull House, in the squalid slums of Chicago's West Side, Jane Addams, a priestess of understanding among neighbors and of peace among nations, kept open hours for prince and pauper alike. It was her shrine and it will remain her monument.

headline: President Shot at Buffalo Fair
text: Buffalo, Sept. 6.--President McKinley, while holding a reception in the Temple of Music at the Pan-American Exposition at 4 o'clock this afternoon, was shot and twice wounded by Leon Czolgosz, an Anarchist, who lives in Cleveland.

headline: Grandma Moses Is Dead at 101; Primitive Artist 'Just Wore Out'
text: HOOSICK FALLS, N. Y., Dec. 13--Grandma Moses, the spry, indomitable "genuine American primitive" who became one of the country's most famous painters in her late seventies, died here today at the age of 101.

headline:
German Planes Raid London All Day; British Bomb Berlin, Starting Fires; Carol Is In
Flight, Riots In Rumania
text: London, Saturday, Sept. 7--German bombers resumed their night patrol over London early this morning. Returning after a day in which they had raided airports near the metropolitan area and hit a factory in the Thames Valley, they dropped high-explosive and incendiary bombs causing casualties and starting fires.

headline: Open House Via Twitter, Day 4

headline: Inflation, Deflation, Debt
text: Some readers ask what’s actually a very good question: even granted that inflation reduces the real liabilities of debtors, it also reduces the real assets of creditors. So why is there any benefit to the economy?

headline: Ford Gives Pardon To Nixon, Who Regrets 'My Mistakes'
text: Washington, Sept. 8--President Ford granted former President Richard M. Nixon an unconditional pardon today for all Federal crimes that he "committed or may have committed or taken part in" while in office, an act Mr. Ford said was intended to spare Mr. Nixon and the nation further punishment in the Watergate scandals.

headline: Claude Pepper, Fiery Fighter For Elderly Rights, Dies at 88
text: Claude Pepper, the unabashed liberal Representative and former United States Senator from Florida who became a champion of the elderly in a political career that spanned 60 years, died yesterday afternoon at Walter Reed Army Hospital. The oldest member of Congress, he was 88 years old and lived in Miami.

headline: The Kitchen Sink in Your Drink
text: If you aren’t up on all the mischief that transpires behind the bar these days, the scene I’m about to describe  and the experiment to which it belonged  will sound pointless at best and repulsive at worst, and it will peg me as someone with too much time on his hands. Too much candy as well.

headline:
Mao Tse-Tung Dies In Peking At 82; Leader Of Red China Revolution; Choice Of Successor
Is Uncertain
text: Peking, Sept. 9--Mao Tse-tung, the pre-eminent figure of the Chinese Communist revolution and the leader of his country since 1949, died today at the age of 82.

headline: Alf Landon, G.O.P. Stand-Bearer, Dies at 100
text: Alfred M. Landon, the former Governor of Kansas who gained lasting fame for his landslide defeat by Franklin D. Roosevelt in the 1936 Presidential election, died at his home in Topeka yesterday, 34 days after his 100th birthday.

headline: Measure Your Neighborhood’s Transportation Costs

The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 4, is Oklahoma. You can find a larger Oklahoma preview here.

headline: Roger Maris is Dead at 51, Set Record Home Runs
text: Roger Maris, who held the major league record for the most home runs in a single season, died yesterday at M. D. Anderson Hospital and Tumor Institute in Houston after a two-year bout with cancer, hospital officials said. He was 51 years old.

headline:
Troops Use Machine Gun on Boston Mob; 5,000 Guarding City as Riots Continue; City
Acclaims Parade of Fighting First
text: New York lived yesterday probably the last chapter in its history of great military spectacles growing out of the war.

headline: Hijacked Jets Destroy Twin Towers and Hit Pentagon
text: Hijackers rammed jetliners into each of New York's World Trade Center towers yesterday, toppling both in a hellish storm of ash, glass, smoke and leaping victims, while a third jetliner crashed into the Pentagon in Virginia. There was no official count, but President Bush said thousands had perished, and in the immediate aftermath the calamity was already being ranked the worst and most audacious terror attack in American history.

headline: Ferdinand Marcos, Ousted Leader Of Philippines, Dies at 72 in Exile
text: Ferdinand E. Marcos, who ruled the Philippines for 20 years until he was ousted in 1986, died in exile here today at St. Francis Medical Center after a long battle with heart, lung and kidney ailments. He was 72 years old.

headline: Death Penalty Advocate Is a Challenge for the Defense
text: NEW HAVEN  In the three years since his wife and two daughters were killed at his home in Cheshire, Conn., Dr. William A. Petit Jr. has become perhaps the most passionate and visible advocate for the death penalty in Connecticut. More than once he has indicated that the ultimate punishment ought to be imposed on the two longtime criminals who are charged with killing his family.

headline: Earl Downgraded, but Suffolk Remains on Alert
text: Updated, 4:10 p.m. | The National Weather Service has downgraded Hurricane Earl to a Category 3 hurricane as of 2 p.m. Thursday, but a tropical storm warning remains in effect for Suffolk County, where sustained winds of more than 40 miles an hour are expected to blow in Friday afternoon, with gusts of up to 60 miles an hour. All up and down the East Coast residents were preparing.

headline: Remade in China: Coen Brothers’ Tale of Infidelity and Revenge
text: Twenty-five years ago Joel and Ethan Coen, rising stars of American independent cinema, made their debut with “Blood Simple,” a twisty tale of adultery and revenge with an obvious debt to “The Postman Always Rings Twice.” Six years later Zhang Yimou, a star of China’s rising fifth generation of filmmakers, contributed his own variation on the “Postman” theme with “Ju Dou,” his second feature as sole director. And now, for no good reason but with reasonably happy (which is to say grisly) results, Mr. Zhang has honored the unlikely affinity between himself and the Coens with a faithful remake of their first movie, a replica of “Blood Simple” called (in America) “A Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop.”

headline: New York Poll Finds Wariness for Muslim Site
text: Two-thirds of New York City residents want a planned Muslim community center and mosque to be relocated to a less controversial site farther away from ground zero in Lower Manhattan, including many who describe themselves as supporters of the project, according to a New York Times poll.

headline: Paul Rowland | Model Citizen
text: Contrary to what you may have heard about modeling agents, Paul Rowland, the skullcap-wearing, tattoo-bearing grizzly man behind Ford Model‘s women’s department, says he’s never stopped a pretty girl on the street to give her his card. “I’m way too shy to do that,” says the 50-year-old, an ex-model himself. The Arkansas native came to New York in the 1980s to pursue painting but gave it up after the bohemian thing got boring. “I was just tired of being poor,” he says. Rowland went on to create two agencies — Women, in 1988, and Supreme, in 2000. Both were both known for dispensing with glam in favor of a more eclectic look. “At Supreme, the girls looked like Smith students — a little intellectual, a little odd looking,” he says.

headline: Redemption as a Team Sport
text: “The Winning Season,” a mousy little film about an alcoholic loser who becomes the coach of a high school girls’ basketball team in Indiana, is so afraid of its own shadow that it cowers in a corner trying to decide what it wants to be.

headline: Comedy and Conspiracy Theories
text: Allan Sherman

headline: A Family Caught in the Wheels of China’s Industrial Locomotive
text: According to an introductory note that appears on screen at the beginning of Lixin Fan’s documentary “Last Train Home,” every year, during the lunar New Year, 130 million workers return from China’s industrial cities to their homes in the countryside. This temporary shift in population, which the film calls the largest human migration in the world, is one of those numbers that seem impossible to comprehend. One hundred and thirty million people, moving between work and family, stoking the engines that drive the machinery of worldwide consumer capitalism. What does that look like? What does it mean?

headline: Kia Recalls 35,000 Souls and Sorentos for Fire Hazard
text: About 35,000 Kia Souls and Sorentos are being recalled because of a fire hazard involving lights intended to flash with the sound of music from the stereo system.

headline: The Strangeness of 3M’s Cogent Deal

headline: Line Umpires’ Job Is to See, but Not Be Seen
text: Before dispersing for another workday of long hours and concentrated effort, the most unknown, underpaid and unappreciated people on court at the United States Open received expert advice for those uncomfortable moments when a player, amid the self-torturous process that is a professional tennis match, takes an unwitting partner in the continuing drama.

headline: Roethlisberger and Goodell to Discuss Suspension
text: Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger will meet with Roger Goodell, the commissioner of the N.F.L., on Thursday to ask that his suspension be reduced from six games. Goodell imposed the penalty in April, after allegations that Roethlisberger had sexually assaulted a Georgia college student at a nightclub.

headline: Liberty to Move to Newark During 3-Year Garden Renovation

headline: Martyrs in the Valley of Peace
text: NAJAF, Iraq — In the Cemetery of the Martyrs of the Army of the Imam Mahdi, death is not mourned. There is no grief or lamentation, save the reading of the Koran that plays from scratchy speakers. The men here have died as martyrs, and sacrifice is exalted.

headline: 4-Year-Old Girl, Just 15 Pounds, Found Dead in Brooklyn
text: Updated, 5:24 p.m. | The police are investigating the death of a 4-year-old girl in Brooklyn whose body was found after officers were called to her family’s apartment. The girl, Marchella Pierce, weighed 15 pounds and had suffered severe health problems since birth, the authorities said.

The inherent snag for Braden is that he must share the territory with the other starter, and on Thursday afternoon he happened to pitch opposite the one man who can lay claim to the mound at Yankee Stadium.

headline: A Shadow of Sex Abuse at Day Care

headline: Blue Hill’s Tomato Sliders
text: After the favas have gone, we can stuff our sorrow with heirloom tomatoes. Two weeks ago, I learned of a surprising take on the tomato from an even more surprising source: my father, a man who always puts a beefsteak before a beefsteak.

headline: Growl, and Let the Severed Heads Fall Where They May
text: Conveniently timed to sprinkle gasoline on the fires of the immigration debate, Robert Rodriguez’s splatter comedy “Machete” has already riled up hardliners in advance of its release. Although laughter is the appropriate response to this pulpy, lighthearted gorefest, its pro-Mexican, anti-American stance is so gleefully inflammatory that some incensed nativists may refuse to get the joke.

headline: Putin Extends Ban on Russian Grain Exports
text: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin announced Thursday that Russia’s ban on grain exports, which was adopted last month after a severe drought and heat wave depressed the harvest, would be extended well into next year because of continued uncertainty over production.

headline: Furniture as Sculpture: A Craftsman’s Legacy
text: The Pennsylvania carver and sculptor Wharton Esherick, known for his mid-20th-century undulating furniture, did not start out in woodworking. Instead he spent decades painting Cubist and Impressionist landscapes and portraits and designing prints, posters and theater sets. Not until his 40s, around 1930, did he adapt his faceted drawing style and skewed perspectives to chairs, desks, tables and bookcases.

headline: Once Around the Park, Then Farewell
text: I AM torn. As you read this, I’m packing for a flight to Paris, where I’ll be living and working for the next few years. It’s wildly exciting for me, and also somewhat terrifying. I have traveled abroad, but I have never lived anywhere but here, up and down the East Coast. I’m thrilled to have a new city to explore, and such a beautiful one. But as summer has wound down and my departure has grown closer, it’s become clear just how much I will miss New York, my home for nearly 30 years. My daughters were born here. Beloved friends and colleagues are here. New York has been my canvas, my stage, my movie set. Wherever I go, memories greet me.

headline: After Marathon, Cilic Withers
text: At the end of a five-set endurance test that lasted just one minute shy of five hours, Kei Nishikori of Japan outlasted 11th-seeded Marin Cilic of Croatia, 5-7, 7-6, 3-6, 7-6, 6-1. Cilic was cramping on the court during the later stages of the match.

headline: Antics Aside, a Dalí of Constant Ambition
text: ATLANTA  Salvador Dalí’s late work started unusually early. He was born in 1904 and soon displayed a precocious skill for ultra-refined hyperrealism. By the late 1920s he had painted some of the smallest, most peculiar masterpieces of Surrealism. Within a decade he was widely seen as having entered  again precociously  a decline that became ever more precipitous, exacerbated by relentless self-promotion, shameless hucksterism and a fervent return to Roman Catholicism.

headline: Simon Wiesenthal, the Man Who Refused to Forget
text: Simon Wiesenthal, the legendary Nazi hunter, was in many ways a smaller-than-life character. Balding, mustached, the wearer of frumpy suits and neckties, possessed of an old-world Yiddish accent and a distracted air, he often seemed to be stooped, one observer said, “as if permanently looking for a mislaid piece of paper.”

headline: A Language Explorer Who Heard Echoes of Africa
text: WASHINGTON  Like many small-budget, education-intensive institutions, the Smithsonian’s Anacostia Community Museum here depends on the kindness of friends and strangers for certain kinds of support.

headline: Leader of Climate Panel Review Discusses Findings

In the exchange, Shapiro rejects interpretations of the report that asserted the committee was, in a sidelong way, calling for the resignation of the panel chairman, Rajendra K. Pachauri. Here’s one excerpt focused on flaws the committee found in its review:

headline: Like, Yeah, Totally
text: My brother’s longtime girlfriend is in her late 20s, but you’d likely peg her much younger. The culprit? She makes the end of every statement sound like a question. (She also draws out the last word of every sentence like thisssss.) She’s been unsuccessful in her career and is unemployed. I bet prospective employers find her speech childish and immature. Should I encourage my brother to point it out?

headline: Rodent Road Trip and Human Bonds
Face Time | Flexible Hours
text: Timex took a trip back to the future to honor its 156-year history of timekeeping by introducing a small collection of watches with inspiration coming straight from its own archives. By recreating period design details like color, typeface and finish, Timex is paying homage to classic watch faces of the 20th century. The 1970s style features that serpentine, expandable, flexible metal watchband that was all the rage. The revolutionary band of interlocking links allows it to be stretched and slid over the hand, providing for one-size-fits-all functionality. Timex is taking a trip back in time to prove its credo that it does indeed take a licking and keep on ticking.

headline: ‘Yank!’ Won’t Reach Broadway This Season
text: A Broadway production of the World War II gay love story “Yank!” has been postponed until the fall of 2011, the producers confirmed via a spokesman on Thursday.

headline: T. I. Is Arrested
text: Months after his release from a federal prison the rapper T. I., below, was arrested Wednesday night with his wife in Los Angeles on drug charges, The Associated Press reported. T. I., whose given name is Clifford Harris, was pulled over at a traffic stop in West Hollywood and arrested on charges of possession of a controlled substance. A representative for the Los Angeles sheriff’s department told The A.P., “Deputies smelled a strong odor of marijuana emitting from the vehicle,” adding that “a narcotics investigation ensued” resulting in the arrest of T. I. and his wife, Tameka Cottle. They were arrested on suspicion of possessing methamphetamines, a sheriff’s deputy told The A.P., and released from jail at about 4 a.m. Thursday after each posting $10,000 bail. T. I., who is in the action movie “Takers,” remains on probation after pleading guilty to federal weapons charges stemming from a 2007 sting operation in which he was caught receiving three machine guns and two silencers that had been bought for him. After his guilty plea T. I. appeared on an MTV reality series, “T. I.’s Road to Redemption,” in which he warned teenagers about the dangers of guns and violence. He was released from an Arkansas prison in December and from a halfway house in March. Under the terms of his release, he was ordered not to commit another federal, state or local crime and not to illegally possess a controlled substance.

headline: From Mickey To Murakami In Macy’s Parade
text: If familiar figures like Kermit the Frog and SpongeBob SquarePants are simply too jejune for you, the organizers of Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade have added two new entrants to their 2010 lineup. Kaikai and Kiki, above, two weirdly cute (or is that cutely weird?) characters created by Takashi Murakami, right, the Japanese Pop artist, are being turned into larger-than-life balloons that will mix it up with the traditional cartoon stars and corporate trademarks for the parade’s 84th annual run on Nov. 25, its producers said on Thursday. The balloon likenesses of Mr. Murakami’s characters will be about 40 feet long when uninflated, and about three stories tall when filled with helium. Mr. Murakami is to be the fourth contemporary artist in recent years to have his work translated to the parade-balloon medium, after Tom Otterness (whose upside-down Humpty Dumpty made its Macy’s debut in 2005), Jeff Koons (whose inflatable bunny came next, in 2006) and Keith Haring (whose estate contributed to a figure-with-heart balloon in 2008). Asked in a telephone interview if Mr. Murakami’s characters might be a bit unsettling for younger viewers, Robin Hall, the parade’s executive producer said: “Fangs are very hot right now, if you’ve missed this trend. This is an excellent year for Murakami. And these balloons are adorable. They have a charm to them.”

headline: ‘Talent’ On Top
text: The remaining members of the Top 10 on “America’s Got Talent” were announced on Wednesday as the show topped another night in the ratings. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 10.3 million viewers watched the 9 p.m. elimination episode on NBC, easily making it the most watched show of the night. In the 8 p.m. hour, NBC’s “Minute to Win It” (6.1 million) lagged well behind CBS’s “Big Brother,” which led the time slot with 7.7 million viewers and helped propel CBS into second place over all. ABC was third with its three-hour broadcast of the “CMA Music Festival: Country’s Night to Rock” (6 million) while Fox finished in fourth place with “MasterChef” from 8 to 10 (4.7 million).

headline: N.E.A. Grants To Theaters
text: The National Endowment for the Arts on Thursday announced grants of $20,000 each to five theaters for work on promising new plays with potential to receive full productions. The five grants, provided by the endowment’s New Play Development Program, will go to About Face Theater in Chicago for Tanya Saracho’s “Albert Cashier Project”; Children’s Theater Company in Minneapolis for Larissa FastHorse’s “Fancy Dancer”; Cornerstone Theater Company in Los Angeles for Tom Jacobson’s “West Hollywood Musical”; the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, N.J., for Emily Mann’s “Hoodwinked”; and Woolly Mammoth Theater Company in Washington for Danai Gurira’s “Zimbabwe Project.” The grants are intended to support American nonprofit theaters working with playwrights on scripts that are in draft stage and show artistic promise. The money is usually used to support readings and workshops for the new plays, research, and expenses incurred in assisting the playwright.

headline: Release For Rival To ‘Inconvenient Truth’
text: The environmental message of former Vice President Al Gore’s “Inconvenient Truth” is about to get a little competition at American movie theaters. On Wednesday the distributor Roadside Attractions said that it had acquired Ondi Timoner’s documentary “Cool It,” about the Danish statistician and writer Bjorn Lomborg, above, for release in the United States, just as the film is about to make its world premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival. Mr. Lomborg, author of the best-selling book “The Skeptical Environmentalist: Measuring the Real State of the World,” published in Denmark in 1998, and the follow-up, “Cool It: The Skeptical Environmentalist’s Guide to Global Warming” (2007), has argued against what he believes are extreme and alarmist scenarios presented by other environmentalists, and has urged scientists and governments to pursue practical solutions for global warming using the limited resources at their disposal. Roadside Attractions said the film would be released in the fall.

headline: Pakistani Diplomat Endorses Cricket Conspiracy Theory
text: Updated | Friday 1:22 p.m. Despite the deadly bombings in Lahore on Wednesday, the continued misery and rage of millions of Pakistanis affected by the worst flooding in decades, the murder of a female teacher by militants and the unsealing of a report to Pakistan’s Supreme Court on the lynching of two teenage boys wrongly suspected of theft by an angry mob, Pakistan’s leading newspaper, Dawn, still managed to find room on its home page on Thursday for a report on a meeting between the country’s top diplomat in Britain and three scandal-plagued cricket stars.

headline: Landscapes Framed by a Chevy
text: If you were a serious photographer in the 1960s, a Robert Frank or a Garry Winogrand crisscrossing the country on a Guggenheim grant, you needed a car as much as your Leica. But what if Mr. Frank, or Winogrand, had never left the wheel? That perverse thought seems to have inspired a recent series by another photography great, Lee Friedlander. Mr. Friedlander’s “America by Car” has just been published in book form and, starting on Saturday, will be on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

headline: Town Houses of West End Avenue
text: West End Avenue and vicinity was once a stronghold of town houses. Three of the now-rare breed bear distinctive traces of the attentions of recent owners.

headline: Assaying the Norwegian Resistance
text: In the search for the least-mined “Jeopardy” category, Norwegian War Heroes would probably give Gardeners of the Serengeti a run for its money. Rallying to rectify this oversight — or to atone for the embarrassment of their last major cinematic effort, “Bandidas” — the Norwegian filmmakers Espen Sandberg and Joachim Roenning have brought us “Max Manus,” a solidly acted biopic of World War II derring-do.

headline: Three Apples of Somebody’s Eye
text: IN its original incarnation, West End Avenue was a boulevard de la haute bourgeoisie, the West Side’s counterpart to Madison Avenue. The avenue and its flanking streets were lined with architecturally varied row houses and near-mansions. Of the few that remain, three in particular are of interest, bearing distinctive traces of the attentions of recent owners.

headline: A Film Within a Film
text: The Portuguese director Miguel Gomes and a producer sit at a table discussing the characters Mr. Gomes has written, but not cast, for “Our Beloved Month of August,” the film they are making and in which, at the moment, they are playing themselves.

headline: Recapping ‘Hard Knocks,’ Episode 4: Where’s Revis?
text: When last we left “Hard Knocks,” the Jets were headed back to New York. With a week to prepare for the third preseason game, where the starters will see the most playing time, the Jets had a great deal of work to do. Outside of LaDainian Tomlinson, the offense has not looked as advertised, with Mark Sanchez looking shaky at best. The first-team defense has been excellent, but the second team has been subpar, to be kind. The Jets hope to see the offense pull its weight while having to make some tough cuts after the game.

headline: White Wedding
text: The bungled wedding story and the road movie collide happily in “White Wedding,” an enjoyable film set in South Africa that makes full use of the country’s lingering apartheid tensions and generational divides without ever losing its smile.

headline: A Post-9/11 Pop Musical
text: “Clear Blue Tuesday,” a pop musical about living in New York post-9/11, is earnest and well meaning and, while dangerously sentimental at times, never quite crosses the line into maudlin. It also has an attractive cast of actors and singers culled from New York stages and clubs. The good vibes are palpable, despite the sadness of much of the material, and you may find yourself moved by a rooftop serenade or a subway platform reunion.

headline: A Street Hustler Becomes a Reluctant Father
text: Footloose young men being humanized by unexpected fatherhood is an occasional movie fantasy that (like the Dardenne brothers’ gritty gem “L’Enfant”) requires great skill to avoid mushy sentimentality. That’s why Sean Baker’s “Prince of Broadway” is such a delight: like its subject, Lucky (Prince Adu), a silver-tongued street hustler, the movie is sharp, charismatic and so light on its feet we never know which way it will turn.

headline: Lessons From an Inevitable Victory

There are limits to our strength and to our talents that willpower and desire just can’t overcome. Sports also confirm these truths.

headline: Has-Been Writer Hopes to Break Out of a Slump

It is, alas, a lost cause, because  playwrights, please pay attention; we’ve been over this repeatedly  nobody likes a whiner, especially a whiny writer, which is what Mr. Scolari plays. But it’s kind of fun watching this skilled veteran of stage and television give it his all.

headline: Freedom Trains
text: In the winter of 1916, as Americans read the news of unimaginable slaughter in a distant yet rapidly spreading European war, it was easy to overlook stories like the one in The Chicago Defender reporting that several black families in Selma, Ala., had left the South. A popular ­African-American weekly, The Defender would publish dozens of such stories in the coming years, heralding the good jobs and friendly neighbors that awaited these migrants in Chicago, even printing train schedules to point the way north. Smuggled into Southern railroad depots by Pullman porters, dropped off by barnstorming black athletes and entertainers, The Defender emerged as both cheerleader and chronicler of an exodus that would lead about six million African-Americans to abandon the states of the Old Confederacy between 1915 and 1970. “If all of their dream does not come true,” it confidently predicted, “enough will come to pass to justify their actions.”

headline: Davydenko Is Latest Upset Victim

headline: As Mayor, Brown Remade Oakland’s Downtown and Himself

headline: U.N. Delays Release of Report on Possible Congo Genocide

headline: Local Theater Anchors the Fringe Festival
text: September is always a big month for small theater in San Francisco. After the inevitable summer burnout on outdoor Shakespeare productions, breezy musicals and tourist-friendly revues, audiences plunder the city’s various black-box spaces with a renewed fervor for the fresh and unusual.

headline: Turkey: U.N. Panel Gets Report on Flotilla Raid
text: Turkey submitted its investigative report on Israel’s raid on a Gaza-bound aid flotilla to a four-member United Nations panel on Thursday. Eight Turks and a Turkish-American citizen were killed in the raid on May 31, for which Turkey seeks an official apology and compensation for the relatives of the dead. The United Nations panel is to examine documents from Turkey and Israel and deliver its first progress report in mid-September, Turkey’s Foreign Ministry said.

National Tennis Center — was under a tropical storm watch and the highest chance of showers was not forecast until later Friday afternoon.

headline: France: Minister Admits Lending Support on Award
text: Labor Minister Éric Woerth, left, conceded Thursday that he wrote a letter in 2007 to Nicolas Sarkozy pressing for a state award for his wife’s future employer. The employer, Patrice de Maistre, is the wealth manager for Liliane Bettencourt, France’s wealthiest woman. Mr. Woerth had denied intervening on behalf of Mr. de Maistre to get the Légion d’Honneur. On Thursday, Mr. Woerth admitted writing the letter, which was leaked to the news media, but said that at the time he was just a member of Parliament, Mr. Sarkozy was not yet president and Mr. de Maistre was not yet his wife’s employer. But the admission is embarrassing for Mr. Sarkozy and Mr. Woerth.
