headline: How to End the Great Recession
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Despite Scrutiny of For-Profits, Crucial Questions Are Unanswered
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Clergy Seeks Less Tension Among Faiths
text: Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan and several other religious leaders in New York City are planning to meet regularly to try to reduce the kind of tensions that have surrounded plans for an Islamic center near ground zero.

headline: Ramirez vs. Konerko? That’s a No-Brainer
text: Frank Thomas said goodbye and Manny Ramirez said hello in the same week. These White Sox just don’t seem comfortable sailing in tranquil seas.

headline: Despite Hurricane Warnings on East Coast, Some Head Into Danger
text: It reflected the uncertainty that greets an approaching hurricane that on Thursday, some guests at Gurney’s Inn at the eastern tip of Long Island were anxiously trying to cancel their reservations, while others, with a gambler’s pluck, were looking forward to a breathtaking spectacle.

headline: In Latest Battle for Control of Stuyvesant Town, the Tenants Are Wooed
text: The last time the mammoth Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village complexes were sold, their tenants were largely ignored. Now, two lending groups battling in court for control of the sister complexes on the East Side of Manhattan are both trying to curry favor with the 25,000 residents.

headline: The Real Story
text: Next week, President Obama is scheduled to propose new measures to boost the economy. I hope they’re bold and substantive, since the Republicans will oppose him regardless  if he came out for motherhood, the G.O.P. would declare motherhood un-American. So he should put them on the spot for standing in the way of real action.

headline: Public Hospitals Look to Overhaul Affiliations With Medical Schools
text: New York City’s public hospital system is embarking on a long-term attempt to gain more control over running its 11 hospitals by renegotiating longstanding affiliation contracts with some of the city’s most powerful medical schools.

headline: BP Says Limits on Drilling Imperil Spill Payouts
text: BP is warning Congress that if lawmakers pass legislation that bars the company from getting new offshore drilling permits, it may not have the money to pay for all the damages caused by its oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Republican Raises More Than Feingold
text: Senator Russ Feingold, the Wisconsin Democrat locked in a tough re-election contest, raised less money during July and most of August than his main Republican challenger, Ron Johnson.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Liberty to Call Newark Homeduring Renovations at Garden
text: The Liberty will play its home games at the Prudential Center in Newark the next three seasons while Madison Square Garden is being renovated. The extra tenant is a bonus for the Prudential Center, which opened in 2007 and whose main tenants have been the Devils and the Seton Hall basketball team. The Nets will play in Newark for the next two seasons before moving to an arena being built in Brooklyn.

headline: The Alternate History
text: The Democrats could be heading toward a defeat of historic proportions in November, but it is possible to imagine a scenario in which things might have turned out differently:

headline: Mistrust and the Mosque
text: The furor over the proposed Islamic cultural center and mosque near ground zero keeps giving us new reasons for dismay. As politicians and commentators work themselves and viewers into a rage, others who should be standing up for freedom and tolerance tiptoe away.

headline: Housing on the Brink
text: There was a glimmer of hope in housing data this week. Pending sales  signed contracts between buyers and sellers  rose in July, by 5.2 percent, beating expectations of a modest decline. Sales are still down by 19 percent compared with a year ago. But any sign of activity was a welcome relief because most potential buyers have been sidelined by an array of economic ills: unemployment, job insecurity, fear of further price declines or the inability to get a loan.

headline: Shifting the Health Cost Burden
text: The latest annual survey of employer health benefits contains good news for the employers but bad news for their workers. The good news is that the average total premium for employer-sponsored health insurance (typically paid partly by employers and partly by their workers) rose only a modest 3 percent this year for family plans, reaching $13,770 in 2010.

headline: Really Looking
text: One day I can hear the faint rustle of autumn coming. The next day I can’t. One evening summer leaks away into the cool night sky, and the next morning it’s back again. But there is headway. Birdsong has gone, replaced by the whining bagpiping of the insect creation. I look out across the pasture as dusk begins and see a shining galaxy of airborne bugs. How would it be, I wonder, to have an awareness of the actual number of insects on this farm?

headline: Friday: Beautiful Boy
text: Before you cross the streetTake my handLife is what happens to youWhile you’re busy making other plansBeautiful, beautiful, beautifulBeautiful boy.

headline: Fewer Young Voters See Themselves as Democrats
text: FORT COLLINS, Colo.  The college vote is up for grabs this year  to an extent that would have seemed unlikely two years ago, when a generation of young people seemed to swoon over Barack Obama.

headline: Angry Players Are Seeing Holes in the Electronic Judging System
text: When electronic line judging was introduced at the United States Open in 2006, the golden age of the tennis tirade appeared to be doomed.

headline: Mets’ Catcher of the Future Has Memories of Wrigley
text: CHICAGO  As hard-core St. Louis Cardinals fans living in Breese, Ill., the Tholes cherished few things more than trips to Wrigley Field to watch their team play the rival Cubs.

headline: Candidates for California Senate Seat Come to Debate Ready for Battle
text: SAN FRANCISCO  During her 18 years in the Senate, Barbara Boxer has earned a reputation for being unafraid to confront colleagues, conservatives or even the United States Army Corps of Engineers, as she did last year when she chided a brigadier general for calling her “ma’am” during testimony instead of “Senator.”

headline: Justice Dept. Sues Sheriff Over Bias Investigation
text: PHOENIX  The Justice Department filed a lawsuit on Thursday against Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County for not cooperating with an investigation into whether his department was systematically violating the rights of Hispanics.

headline: Panic Kept at Bay in Smooth Rescue Mission
text: In his 20 years as a boat captain, Dan Shaw had never tried to rescue an entire crew out of the water. But on Thursday, he received a radio alert that 13 workers from an oil platform that caught fire in the Gulf of Mexico were bobbing in choppy, fast-flowing waters not far from the flames.

headline: Add Jets’ Offensive Coordinator to Sanchez’s List of Duties
text: PHILADELPHIA  The Jets’ preseason finale Thursday against the Philadelphia Eagles, a 21-17 victory, included time well spent for quarterback Mark Sanchez. On the first play of the second quarter, he pulled on a headset, checked a play sheet and became an offensive coordinator.

headline: U.S. Fails to Notify Victims About Prison Furloughs
text: WASHINGTON  The federal Bureau of Prisons has long recognized a potential problem with its handling of furloughs of inmates for medical treatment: nobody has the job of notifying crime victims and witnesses that an inmate is being temporarily released.

headline: Giants Put Focus on Backup to Manning
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  From the moment quarterback Eli Manning’s forehead was gashed in the first preseason game to the start of the fourth exhibition, the Giants were unsettled at quarterback.

headline: Ohio’s Governor Spares Life of a Death Row Inmate
text: CINCINNATI  A death row inmate convicted of murdering a child and two adults was spared the death penalty Thursday by Gov. Ted Strickland of Ohio, who said there were possible problems with the evidence.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,248 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans Thursday:

headline: Video Game Maker Take-Two Reports an Unexpected Profit
text: Take-Two Interactive Software, publisher of the Grand Theft Auto video games, reported an unexpected third-quarter profit and raised its earnings outlook on sales of its newest release, Red Dead Redemption.

headline: Time to Consider the Unloved Dell
text: Are Dell’s shareholders on Xanax? The computer maker has finally bowed out of its mad bidding war for 3Par, the data storage company. Yet its investors displayed neither much concern about overpaying nor relief about the deal’s being dropped. After a decade of scandals, missed opportunities and dismal performance, they may have stopped caring.

headline: Bloggingheads: Blame Bush?
text: Noam Scheiber, left, of The New Republic and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic debate whether President Obama should campaign against his predecessor.

headline: Mets Win, But Santana Is Injured
text: ATLANTA — The Mets did not need any more bad news this season, so when Johan Santana came off the mound after the fifth inning Thursday with some tightness in the upper left chest, his night was finished.

headline: Blake Plays Role of Mr. Met at Tennis Center
text: Of all the frustrated Mets fans, James Blake is among the more well known.

headline: Girl’s Death in Brooklyn Prompts Police Inquiry
text: The police are investigating the death of a sickly 4-year-old girl in Brooklyn whose body was found after her mother called 911 on Thursday morning and reported the child was unresponsive. The girl, Marchella Pierce, weighed only 15 pounds and had suffered severe health problems since birth, the authorities said.

headline: Transparency and the I.R.S.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Looking for Reasons to Be Optimistic, Manuel Turns to Duda
text: ATLANTA — The Mets have been left behind in another pennant race and Manager Jerry Manuel is out in the open sharing his views freely and willing to participate in a little high jinks.

headline: Dispute Over Witness in Embassy Bombing Case
text: With the trial of a terrorism suspect held for nearly five years in the C.I.A.’s “black sites” and later in the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, only weeks away, a dispute has arisen over the role of a key government witness.

headline: Pakistan: Lahore Mourns Victims of Bombings
text: With the police on high alert, hundreds of people attended funeral prayers in the eastern city of Lahore on Thursday for the victims of suicide bombers a day earlier. The authorities raised the death toll in the attacks to 31 from around 25 and said more than 280 had been wounded. Zulfiqar Hameed, chief of the Lahore police investigation unit, said no arrests had been made. The explosions on Wednesday singled out Shiite Muslims and set off violent clashes between local police officers and protesters infuriated by the attacks.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times poll was based on telephone interviews conducted Aug. 27 to 31 in New York City with 892 adults. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.

headline: Holiday on Monday Labor Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: N.F.L. Febreze Commercial
text: In an N.F.L.-themed spot for Febreze, a woman sprays her living room to eliminate odors from a game-day party.

headline: Gail Koff, Principal in Jacoby & Meyers, Dies at 65
text: Gail J. Koff, who could be considered the silent partner in the national law firm Jacoby & Meyers, a sort of legal Wal-Mart for the middle class, died Tuesday in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 65.

headline: H.P. Outbids Dell for Data Storage Company
text: Hewlett-Packard offered to buy 3Par, a maker of storage systems, for about $2.3 billion, ending an 18-day bidding war with Dell.

headline: Four Members of Jewish Patrol Are Shot in Brooklyn
text: Four members of an Orthodox Jewish volunteer patrol in Brooklyn were shot Thursday night after they followed and confronted a man in a vehicle who had been acting suspiciously, the police and witnesses said.

headline: Analysis: Iraq’s Military Needs After 2011
text: BAGHDAD — The poster behind the Iraqi general’s desk was of an M1 Abrams battle tank. When his cellphone rang, it played the theme song from the Clint Eastwood movie “The Good, the Bad and the Ugly.”

headline: What to Watch at the Open on Friday
text: Ryan Harrison takes the court Friday against Sergiy Stakhovsky coming off one of the biggest upsets of this (or any) United States Open on Wednesday, when he ousted 15th-seeded Ivan Ljubicic.

headline: Fight Interrupts Djokovic Match
text: Novak Djokovic’s second-round match against Philipp Petzschner of Germany was delayed briefly in the middle of the first set after a fight broke out in the upper deck at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Vance Bourjaily, Novelist Exploring Postwar America, Dies at 87
text: Vance Bourjaily, a novelist whose literary career, like those of Norman Mailer and James Jones, emerged out of World War II and whose ambitious novels explored American themes for decades afterward, died on Tuesday in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Cammie King, Scarlett and Rhett’s Girl, Dies at 76
text: Cammie King, who as a cherubic little girl played the daughter of Scarlett O’Hara and Rhett Butler in “Gone With the Wind,” then enjoyed something of a fan following at film festivals, died on Wednesday at her home in Fort Bragg, Calif. She was 76.

headline: With Eye Offshore, Storm Diminishes
text: Despite the air of nobility that clings to the name, Earl arrived on the East Coast on Friday as little more than a routine storm with heavy downpours and blowhard winds  nothing like the full-throated hurricane that was feared.

headline: Word of the Day | bountiful
text: bountiful •\ˈbau̇n-ti-fəl\• adjective

headline: News Quiz | September 3, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Bernanke Says He Failed to See Financial Flaws
text: Ben S. Bernanke, who told Congress in 2007 that the subprime mortgage crisis was “likely to be contained,” said Thursday that he had failed to recognize flaws in the financial system that amplified the housing downturn and led to an economic disaster, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: BP Wary of  Limits on Drilling Imperil Oil Spill Payouts
text: BP is warning Congress that if lawmakers pass legislation that bars the company from getting new offshore drilling permits, it may not have the money to pay for all the damages caused by its oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, Clifford Krauss and John M. Broder report in The New York Times.

headline: Harrisburg Expects to Miss a Bond Payment
text: The capital of Pennsylvania has taken a step closer to a possible bankruptcy declaration, warning this week that it was not going to make a scheduled payment of $3.3 million on its general obligation bonds because it did not have the money, Mary Williams Walsh writes in The New York Times.

headline: Heavy in Dollars, China Warns of Depreciation
text: China on Friday offered a rare glimpse into its foreign exchange reserves, confirming that they are overwhelmingly allocated in dollars, while a central banker said the mountain of cash could face depreciation risks, Reuters reports.

headline: European Central Bank Optimistic About Economy
text: The European Central Bank offered a slightly more optimistic view of the euro area’s economy Thursday, but also extended its lifeline to troubled banks in the zone amid signs that the gap in growth between Northern and Southern Europe was growing.

headline: Depositors Panic Over Bank Crisis in Afghanistan
text: One of the principal owners of the Afghan bank at the center of an accelerating financial crisis here said depositors had withdrawn $180 million in the last two days. He predicted a “revolution” in the country’s financial system unless the Afghan government and the United States moved quickly to help stabilize the bank, Dexter Filkins reports in The New York Times.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Planchering
text: Today’s word, in association with the renowned Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Burkle to Appeal Barnes & Noble Poison Pill Ruling
text: Ron Burkle, the billionaire investor, plans to appeal a Delaware court ruling that upheld an anti-takeover “poison pill” put in place by bookseller Barnes & Noble, Reuters reports.

headline: The Many Iterations of William Shatner
text: He’s late. He calls to explain. “A mix-up,” he says, and then, “I read all your stories.” Pause. “You. Are. A. Grrreat. Writer.” Another pause. “What’s your name?” I tell him. He says, “Of course it is.” I ask what his name is. “MY NAME? I. Am. William. Shatner!”

headline: $2.9 Million Raised by BankSimple
text: BankSimple, the not-quite-a-bank provider of front-end services for a number of treasury-focused banks, raised $2.9 million in its first round of funding. First Round Capital, IA Ventures and Village Ventures led the round, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Peace Talks
text: WHO are the people in the photograph above?

headline: Tycoon Unwraps Packaging Ambitions With U.S. Deal
text: The reclusive New Zealand billionaire buying the United States maker of Hefty brand trash bags to create the world’s second-biggest packaging business started out as a tow truck driver and bounced back from the brink of bankruptcy more than a decade ago to become his country’s richest person, The Associated Press writes.

headline: Would a Public Kosmos be Worth $5 Billion?
text: The private equity backers of the oil firm Kosmos Energy are considering taking it public in either Britain or United States, which could value the company at around $5 billion, The Financial Times reported.

headline: A.I.G. Applies to List AIA in Hong Kong
text: American International Group filed an application with the Hong Kong Stock Exchange to list its Asian life insurance unit, AIA, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters on Thursday.

headline: How Would You Decorate the Oval Office?
text: The Oval Office was just redecorated with new furniture, wallpaper and accessories, including a rug woven with quotations. What do you think of the room’s new look? How would you have chosen to decorate it? What quotes do you think should be woven into the rug?

headline: Financial Tech Emerging From Crisis Doldrums
text: A $15 billion private equity bid for payments processor Fidelity National Information may have fallen short in May, but it did enough to whet the appetite for other potential deals in a financial technology industry slowly emerging from its worst crisis ever, Reuters reported.

headline: Israeli Pesticide Firm Calls Off Talks to Buy Albaugh
text: Makhteshim Agan Industries of Israel ended talks to acquire a United States firm, Albaugh, for about $1 billion, blaming findings during due diligence, sending its shares lower, Reuters reported.

headline: British Austerity Policies Aid Corporate Debt
text: British companies are beating the world in the bond market as investors bet Prime Minister David Cameron’s efforts to tame the budget deficit will preserve the Britain’s top credit rating, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Genzyme’s Termeer Could Sell Company
text: Henri Termeer, a biotech industry pioneer and chief executive officer at Genzyme, is on the verge of losing control of the company he transformed from a start-up in 1983 into a cutting-edge drug maker with $4.5 billion in annual sales, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Abbott Halts Sale of Flu Vaccine Business
text: Abbott Laboratories has called a halt to the sale of its European flu-vaccine unit because of a dissapointing run of initial bids, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: In Istanbul, 8,000 Years of History
text: From the moment you enter the “Legendary Istanbul” exhibition at the Sakip Sabanci Museum, you are plunged into a dark and moody prehistoric forest, and, sitting on a tree stump, you watch as the Sea of Marmara forms.

headline: Silly Season Over for Giants
text: The Giants closed their preseason with a win over the New England Patriots on Thursday night, but until their season starts next Sunday against Carolina, they are “just another team” surrounded by intriguing questions.

headline: On Health Care, the Devil’s in the Details
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Why U.F.O.’s Slowed Down
text: Today’s idea: U.F.O.’s slowed down in the popular imagination because those reporting them became less fascinated with speed as it became less alien to them, an article says.

headline: Och-Ziff Says Assets Up by $200 Million
text: Och-Ziff Capital Management Group, the New York hedge-fund firm run by Daniel Och, said assets under management rose by $200 million last month as investors deposited money in its funds, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Ex-Lehman Trader’s Fund Set to Double Assets
text: The OGI Global Macro Fund, run by a former Lehman Brothers Holdings proprietary trader, Allan Bedwick, is set to double its assets to about $100 million this month after outperforming hedge-fund peers globally, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Cleaner Chatroulette Rival Raises Seed Round
text: VChatter, a video chat startup led by online dating pioneer Will Bunker, has raised $250,000 in seed funding, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Banker’s Book Triggers Race Debate in Germany
text: 7:06 p.m. | Updated The Bundesbank has requested that Thilo Sarrazin be fired.

headline: China Said to Approach Alberta Fund to Block BHP
text: Chinese investors approached Alberta Investment Management to consider a joint counterbid for Potash of Saskatchewan, the Canadian pension fund’s chief executive officer said, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Attack in Tajikistan Highlights Fears of Militancy
text: MOSCOW  A car rigged with explosives rammed into a police building in northern Tajikistan on Friday, killing at least one person and wounding 25 others in an apparent suicide attack, Tajik police officials said.

headline: Tip of the Week: Where Is That Attachment?
text: If you are mystified over where a spreadsheet or document is — was it an attachment to Gmail or a Google Doc? —Gmail Labs has a time-saving solution called Apps Search. To turn it on, log in to your Gmail account on the Web, click the green Labs icon (or click Settings and then the Labs link). Scroll down to Apps Search and click the button next to Enable the features. Then click on the Save Changes button. The search box in the Gmail window now says Search Mail and Docs — and lets you look in both places at once for that elusive file.

headline: Petrobras Could Raise $75 Billion in Offering
text: Petroleo Brasileiro, Brazil’s state-controlled oil company, may raise as much as 129 billion reais ($75 billion) in a sale of new voting and preferred shares as part of a stock-for-oil swap with the government, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: In Sudden Bidding War, Andean Goes With Goldcorp
text: Goldcorp, the Canadian gold mining company, said Friday that it would buy its Australian rival, Andean Resources, for 3.6 billion Canadian dollars ($3.4 billion) in cash and stock, beating out an all-share offer from Eldorado Gold.

headline: Why I.B.M. Took a Different Path in Storage
text: 10:38 a.m. | Updated to correct the name of the company that EMC purchased last year.

headline: BMW’s Mini May Offer an Off-Road Coupe
text: Even as BMW’s Mini brand plans to start selling its new, beefed-up Countryman model in Europe in a couple of weeks — along with a refreshed line of existing models — there are reports that the brand is considering a Countryman off-road coupe.

headline: Jets’ Ryan Says He Has No Reason to Trust McKnight
text: A few speed reads on players who have disappointed:

headline: Wall Street Finishes Higher for the Week
text: Indexes on Wall Street ended the week higher on Friday, propelled by a better-than-expected report on the nation’s job market.

headline: Ex-G.M. Chief to Lead Sunoco Spinoff
text: Nine months after his ouster from General Motors, Fritz Henderson has resurfaced in another leadership position.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: — Time looks beyond the jobs reports at how the stimulus is changing America. “For starters, the Recovery Act is the most ambitious energy legislation in history, converting the Energy Department into the world’s largest venture-capital fund.”

headline: Small Gains for Small Business in Federal Contracting
text: For the first time since 2005, the Small Business Administration reports that the share of federal contracts going to small business increased over the previous year. But the federal government still fell short of its small-business contracting goals, and longstanding criticisms about how the government keeps score continue to cast doubt on the agency’s report card.

headline: Big Winners in 3Par Bidding War: 3 V.C. Firms
text: The weeks-long bidding battle between Hewlett-Packard and Dell over data storage company 3Par may have left both battered and bruised. But it also left some of 3Par’s biggest and earliest backers feeling flush.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Justin Bond
text: In an intimate rooftop performance overlooking the Lower East Side, the notorious Justin Bond delivered a string of songs — both originals and covers — accompanied on guitar by the beautiful Nathan Carrera, who wore a dress, false eyelashes and no shoes. The evening came courtesy of the artist Matthu Placek, who in the off hours hosts a monthly salon. The tiny roof lounge brought the audience close enough to feel Bond’s breath as he delivered powerful messages about acceptance and the absurdity of discrimination.

headline: Another Lengthy Gridlock in China
text: Yet another gargantuan traffic jam has gripped the freeway that links Inner Mongolia’s coal fields to metropolitan Beijing, possibly exceeding a blockage on the same road that drew global attention last month, Chinese news sources report. More than 100 regional police officers manned the road, called the Jingzang Highway, in an effort to break the 75-mile, 10,000-vehicle gridlock, the state broadcaster CCTV reported Thursday.

headline: Growth in Jobs Beats Estimates, Easing Concerns
text: American businesses added more jobs in the last three months than originally estimated, calming fears of a double-dip recession. Yet the pace of growth signaled that the wheels of the economic recovery were still spinning in place.

headline: Mandelsonian
text: An unlikely eponym, modestly defined by its subject Peter Mandelson, as “subtle, strategic, hard-working and ultimately very loyal.”

headline: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: Throwing the Book at Them
text: The second volume of “Chi’s Sweet Home,” written and illustrated by Kanata Konami, lands at No. 6 on the manga list this week. It tells the story of a kitten named Chi who finds herself separated from her family of feral cats. Chi is taken in by the family of a young boy named Yohei, but not without risk: Their lease does not allow pets and Chi’s feral tendencies are no pleasure to be around either.

headline: Paradoxes Of Deleveraging And Releveraging
text: Whenever the issue of fiscal stimulus comes up, you can count on someone chiming in to say, “Only a moron could believe that the answer to a problem created by too much debt is to create even more debt.” It sounds plausible — but it misses the key point: there’s a fallacy of composition here. When everyone tries to pay off debt at the same time, the result is contraction and deflation, which ends up making the debt problem worse even if nominal debt falls. On the other hand, a strong fiscal stimulus, by expanding the economy and creating moderate inflation, can actually help resolve debt problems.

headline: Fantasy Targets for Your Weekend Draft
text: Chet Gresham blogs about fantasy football at Razzball. You can follow him on Twitter @Chetrazzball.

headline: Comparing This Recession to Previous Ones: Job Changes
text: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that month’s nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Research’s official business cycle dates.

headline: Open House, Day 5: The Players We Like, and Hawk-Eye v. Foot Faults
text: Michael Kimmelman, the Times’s chief art critic, and Gerry Marzorati, editor of the Sunday Magazine, are covering the Open from uncommon perspectives. Each morning, they discuss what’s happening. Join the conversation — or ask a fan-oriented question — by sending in a comment. Gerry Marzorati: Morning, Michael. Reading your blog post last night after dinner, I sense a certain affection there for Taylor Dent — one I have to say I don’t quite share. He strikes me as some stray Belushi brother who got his hands on a Wilson T2000 back then and never gave up. But I am intrigued by the notion of which players we find likable, and which we don’t.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 53 at Shiite Protest
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A blast detonated by a suicide bomber ripped through a Shiite protest, the second such attack in three days, in the southwestern Pakistani city of Quetta on Friday, killing at least 53 people, police and rescue officials said. At least 100 people were wounded.

headline: Chic in Review | Going Gaga for Halloween
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Thanks to Earl, Surf’s Up. Way Up.
text: Surfers and fishermen flocked to the curling waves near Montauk at sunrise on Friday as a hurricane, diminished but still powerful, drew nearer.

headline: Video: College Students on the Fence
text: The Times’s Kirk Johnson traveled to Fort Collins, Colo., to speak with college students about the 2010 election and found that while many students are liberals on social issues, the weak job market has taken a toll on their loyalties.

headline: Complaint Box | The Expanding Workday
text: A few weeks ago, while working as a freelancer at a Manhattan advertising and marketing firm — in a job that was somewhat similar to my old job on the staff at a marketing firm in Fort Lee, N.J. — I got to wondering why so many people were still there after 8 p.m., and why there was a settled air of monotony suggesting that this was the way it was and always would be.

headline: The Slog
text: It’s easy to get confused by month-month fluctuations in the jobs report. But the bigger picture of the economy’s performance over the three years is starting to look very consistent. Today’s jobs report confirms that. We don’t seem to be in a double-dip recession. We do seem to be in a long slog.

headline: Updated Hurricane Warning for U.S.
text: As a weakened Hurricane Earl moves north, the National Hurricane Center said in its latest advisory, released at 8 a.m. Friday, that weather conditions should improve in the Outer Banks region of North Carolina later this morning.

headline: Inside the List
text: GRAND TOUR: This week’s hardcover fiction list offers plenty of armchair travel to exotic locales, from Tudor England (“The Red Queen”) and Renaissance Siena (“Juliet”) to the postapocalyptic Four Lands (“Bearers of the Black Staff”) and post-James Patterson Stockholm (“The Postcard Killers”). But for sheer geopolitical adventure and scenery — not to mention attack dogs and intestinal parasites — nothing can match the real-life 10th parallel, chronicled by Eliza Griswold in her nuanced account of conflict between Christians and Muslims in a swath of the globe that runs from West Africa to the Philippines. (It enters at No. 14 on the nonfiction list.)

headline: Forty Years of the 4077th: Elliott Gould on the Anniversary of ‘MASH’
text: Attention, attention: Saturday night’s movies at the Walter Reade Theater will include a special showing of “MASH,” the 1970 Robert Altman comedy that used the Korean War as a vehicle to satirize the Vietnam War. This screening, celebrating the 75th anniversary of the Twentieth Century Fox studio and the 40th anniversary of “MASH,” and presented by Twentieth Century Fox Home Entertainment and the Film Society of Lincoln Center, will feature a question-and-answer session with the film’s stars Elliott Gould (who played Trapper John McIntyre), Sally Kellerman (Margaret Houlihan, a k a Hot Lips) and Tom Skerritt (Duke Forrest), as well as Mr. Altman’s widow, Kathryn Reed Altman.

headline: The End of Tenure?
text: In tough economic times, it’s easy to gin up anger against elites. The bashing of bankers is already so robust that the economist William Easterly has compared it, with perhaps a touch of hyperbole, to genocidal racism. But in recent months, a more unlikely privileged group has found itself in the cross hairs: tenured ­professors.

headline: My Flesh Is Your Canvas
text: V. I. Warshawski, the hard-headed sleuth in Sara Paretsky’s series of crime novels, isn’t afraid of a little violence, so you can count on her to get into a few good brawls in BODY WORK (Putnam, $26.95). Just don’t expect this pugnacious Chicago private eye, who proudly refers to herself as “a street fighter,” to walk away from any display of violence, including her own, without examining its root causes.

headline: Why Are Wages Rising?
text: Average hourly pay for all workers had another nice increase in August. It rose 6 cents, to $22.56, after having risen 5 cents in July. Job growth may have tailed off in recent months, but wage growth for people with jobs has picked up:

headline: The Meaning of ‘Man Up’
text: The New York Mets lost their closer Francisco Rodriguez, a k a K-Rod, to season-ending surgery on a torn thumb ligament last month. But really the Mets lost him to two simple words: “man up.” According to The New York Daily News, that’s what Carlos Peña, the father of Rodriguez’s girlfriend, told him outside the Mets clubhouse, inciting an altercation that led to K-Rod busting his thumb and getting arrested on third-degree-assault charges for good measure.

headline: Imagining the Prophet
text: As a leader of alternative medicine who was born in India and raised as a Hindu before opening a wellness center in California, what led you to write your new book, “Muhammad,” a fictionalized biography of the Muslim prophet?  I had previously written “Jesus,” and I grew up in an environment where the kids in my school were either Muslim or Jewish or Zoroastrian. New Delhi has a very eclectic mix. There wasn’t any animosity. Having said that, my grandparents were prejudiced and Islamophobic. If a Muslim’s shadow crossedmy grandmother’s body — she lived with us — she would go and take a shower.

headline: The Back Story
text: Ask anybody about the most meaningful object he owns, and you’re sure to get a story — this old trunk belonged to Grandpa, we bought that tacky coffee mug on our honeymoon, and so on. The relationship between the possessions we value and the narratives behind them is unmistakable. Current technologies of connection, and enterprises that take advantage of them, surface this idea in new ways — but they also suggest the many different kinds of stories, information and data that objects can, or will, tell us.

headline: App Smart Extra: Create Grocery Lists
text: Thursday’s App Smart column gives props to two useful shopping apps, Key Ring and Cardstar, which will store your grocery coupons on the phone and spare you from carrying around loyalty cards for your favorite retailers.

headline: Good Fortune, Misfortune
text: I took my teenage daughter and one of her friends, whose father died last year, to my employer’s annual outing, a Mets game and raffle. The grand prize was a 47-inch TV. Coincidentally, the friend mentioned that her family needed a new TV. As fate had it, she held the winning ticket. She was thrilled. After the game, we took her and the TV to her house. Her mother was delighted but soon phoned to say that since I paid for the tickets, the TV is mine. Is it? STUART ILKOWITZ, LIVINGSTON, N.J.

headline: An Adopted Boy Considers His Origins
text: Jonah, our youngest, spent the day in the water again. At 5 he’s already an exquisite swimmer, diving for coins our Provincetown neighbors throw into the tide for him to fetch. Now we’re lying in his bed together waiting for him to fall asleep, and he’s thumping my stomach like it’s a beach ball.

headline: A Labor Day Arrangement
text: If you’re heading to a Labor Day party this weekend, don’t show up empty-handed. Better yet, bring something handmade. Here’s an easy, impressive D.I.Y. floral arrangement.

headline: Letter: What Is It About 20-Somethings?
text: As I read Robin Marantz Henig’s discussion of 20-somethings, I was struck by the sense that the new life stage she was ascribing to this generation could actually be something that adults of all ages experience today: feeling unstable, struggling with ferocious competition for jobs, wondering if our relationships and finances can go the distance. I consider it progress that every young person doesn’t feel the need to complete school, leave home, marry and have a child by a certain deadline. There is no “one size fits all” adulthood. Let’s not forget it was the boomers who created the 50 percent divorce rate, who initiated the corporate-casual workplace, who made 60 the new 40. Today’s 20-somethings just want what we all want: the opportunity to live life on our own terms and in our own time frames.

headline: Screen Test | William Shatner
text: The actor on laughter, Star Trek and getting older.

headline: Friday Reading: The Expanding Workday
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Coordinating Help for a Neighbor in Need
text: We’ve all had this experience, haven’t we? A neighbor or friend is struggling through an illness or a family emergency, so we offer our sympathy and help.

headline: Another Item for Climate Panel’s To-Do List
text: A committee convened by the InterAcademy Council, the association of the world’s leading national science academies, delivered a long to-do list to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change on Monday, including steps ranging from limiting the term and policy recommendations of its leadership to fostering more transparency in its machinations and being more careful to describe the science determining the strength, or weakness, of particular conclusions.

headline: Science Fiction Chronicle
text: REDEMPTION IN INDIGO  By Karen Lord.  Small Beer Press, paper, $16.

headline: Brendan Fraser to Make Broadway Debut in ‘Elling’
text: If Daniel Craig could leave the James Bond franchise behind to make his Broadway debut last fall in “A Steady Rain,” Brendan Fraser certainly can hold off on another installment of “The Mummy” to make his. Mr. Fraser will appear on Broadway in November in the new comedy “Elling,” based on the Norwegian novels by Ingvar Ambjørnsen.

headline: Up Front: Ander Monson
text: No one medium can contain Ander Monson. Luckily, we live in an age when no one medium needs to.

headline: Living in Your Head
text: The conceit of Charles Yu’s new meta-science-fictional novel, “How to Live Safely in a Science Fictional Universe,” is a touch wacky. Yu’s protagonist, a time machine repairman also named Charles Yu, has lived the past decade of his life boxed up in a tiny TM-31 Recreational Time Travel Device. His two companions are TAMMY, the love interest (of sorts), a neurotic, depressed, sexy piece of software, and Ed, a non­existent yet “ontologically valid” dog. You might be forgiven for thinking that this setup smells strongly of vintage Douglas Adams. It does. Like Adams, Yu is very funny, usually proportional to the wildness of his inventions, but Yu’s sound and fury conceal (and construct) this novel’s dense, tragic, all-too-human heart.

headline: With a Nod to His Past, Plant Moves On Again
text: LATE last year, in a Nashville recording studio, Robert Plant, the former Led Zeppelin frontman, had a revelation. He was working on a new solo record, a project he began after scrapping plans for a sequel to “Raising Sand,” his 2007 album of duets with the country singer Alison Krauss that sold 2.5 million copies worldwide.

headline: Never Say Never: Swans Return
text: I SAW just a little bit of a Swans show in 1983, in their early days, during their period of slow-but-alert, theater-of-cruelty music. If I remember right, I had come to CBGB to hear Heart Attack, the fastest punk band I knew, and after that the tempos plunged. Sonic Youth played next: lots of strange tunings, innocently curious. Then came Swans, with violent songs that sounded as if they were barely moving.

headline: Hey, Dad, Get With the (3-D) Program
text: THIS is going to be sweet. Soon, very soon, those unappreciative little rotters who 15 years ago were expressing contempt for the television shows that were so important to their parents will be getting the same dissing from their own kids. That’s right, you 20-somethings; you’re about to be inducted into the Dinosaur Club.

headline: Good Day for Paul Hogan: ‘Crocodile Dundee’ Star Can Return to U.S.
text: Break out the Vegemite, crank up the Men at Work, and prepare to celebrate the Australian cultural influences of the 1980s: Paul Hogan is a free man. Mr. Hogan, the Australian-born star of the “Crocodile Dundee” movies, has been granted permission to return to his home in the United States after reaching a deal with Australian tax officials, The Associated Press reported.

headline: A Complete Look at a Complex Character
text: THINKING back to the impression Detective Chief Inspector Jane Tennison made when the British crime drama “Prime Suspect” first reached America in 1992, it’s easy to focus on strength: the hard set of her jaw as she took on the sexism and cronyism of a London police force that, in real life, had only four female detectives out of a total of about 500 at the time.

headline: The Magnificent Seven
text: 1. Who’s afraid of Katie Eary? The buzzy London designer, inspired by Irvine Welsh’s dark, hallucinatory 1995 novel, ‘‘Marabou Stork Nightmares,’’ has created enormous reptile-print coats, hats with studs resembling teeth and other frightful creations that might haunt your sleep. Go to katieeary.co.uk.

headline: Analysis: How Capra Beat Rezai
text: Colette Lewis, over at ZooTennis covering the juniors, has followed the rise of Wednesday’s surprise winner, Beatrice Capra, and had some insight into the match:

headline: The Early Word: 9.6 Percent
text: The unemployment rate rose slightly in August to 9.6 percent, though the private sector did add more jobs than had been forecast.

headline: A Steel Symphony, Pounded Out in Brooklyn
text: As the sun sets over a string of tire repair and auto body shops in Brooklyn, the first jaunty notes of a jangly symphony ring out. The roar of Atlantic Avenue subsides as the music floods these ragged blocks, filling the grease-soaked garages with a breath of island air.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: FREEDOM,  by Jonathan Franzen (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.) Like Franzen’s previous novel, “The Corrections,” this is a masterly portrait of a nuclear family in turmoil, with a majestic sweep that gathers every sociocultural morsel of our shared millennial life.

headline: Obama to Unveil Plans to Shore Up Economy
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama, calling the latest jobs report “positive news,” said Friday that he planned to unveil a “package of ideas” next week to shore up the flagging economy, and does not regret his administration’s decision to declare this season the “recovery summer.”

headline: To Put Blacks in Pipeline, Possess the Pipeline
text: Richard Williams strolled across the grounds of the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center on Wednesday afternoon. Ever the recognizable figure, he was greeted by men and women, young and old. Some just wanted to say hello, others asked to have their picture taken with him, and others simply wanted to offer his daughters good luck.

headline: Paperback Row
text: OPEN: An Autobiography,  by Andre Agassi (Vintage, $15.95.) “I hate tennis, hate it with all my heart, and still I keep playing . . . because I have no choice.” Pushed by his ferocious father, 7-year-old Andre is forcing himself through another practice. “Open,” written with J. R. Moehringer, author of “The Tender Bar,” is “one of the most passionately anti-sports books ever written by a super­star athlete — bracingly devoid of triumphalist homily and star-spangled gratitude,” Sam Tanenhaus said in the Book Review. The book, he added, is “not just a first-rate sports memoir but a genuine bildungsroman, darkly funny yet also anguished and soulful.” Agassi and his wife, Steffi Graf, chose not to build a tennis court behind their home.

headline: Food Safety Tips for the Budget-Conscious
text: EGGS, lettuce, peanuts, spinach. It seems as if every time we turn around there is another outbreak of a scary foodborne illness.

headline: Simian Says
text: Early in Sara Gruen’s new novel, “Ape House,” one of the characters gives a mini-lesson on American Sign Language, which, she instructs, “is not simply signed English — it’s a unique language, with a unique syntax.” Instead of saying, “Yesterday I ate cherries,” for example, this character explains that in A.S.L. you might sign, “Day-past eat cherries me.”

headline: Readers’ Questions on Deep-Ocean Biology
text: After a smooth cruise into San Diego, where Atlantis would be embarking on her next expedition, the science teams went their separate ways, cars brimming with cooler-packed samples. We’ve had a couple of weeks to sort things out (a process which involved many brushes with frostbite, as samples were carefully arranged in freezers set at minus 80 degrees Celsius), and we are continuing to design and conduct experiments to tease out the secrets of the Hydrate Ridge ecosystem.

headline: For G.M., Four Cylinders May Soon Be Enough
text: With the engine-downsizing revolution sweeping the world, automakers are ruthlessly lopping cylinders from their once-royal V-8s and V-6s. As The Times reported on Aug. 13, small, sophisticated 4-cylinder engines are showing up in the oddest places; in luxury sedans and in once-profligate S.U.V.’s, like the redesigned 2011 Ford Explorer

headline: Care During Crisis
text: After the floodwaters of Katrina receded, an investigation took place to determine whether health care workers had hastened the deaths of some patients.

headline: Roethlisberger’s Suspension Reduced to 4 Games
text: Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger will serve a four-game suspension for behavior that led to sexual assault allegations after a March encounter with a college student at a Georgia nightclub last spring.

headline: Bringing It All Back Home
text: Whoever it was in 1969 who named the very first Bob Dylan bootleg album “Great White Wonder” may have had a mischievous streak. There are any number of ways you can interpret the title — most boringly, the cover was blank, like the Beatles’ “White Album” — but I like to see a sly allusion to “Moby-Dick.” In the seven years since the release of his first commercial record, Dylan had become the white whale of 20th-century popular song, a wild, unconquerable and often baffling force of musical nature who drove fans and critics Ahab-mad in their efforts to spear him, lash him to the hull and render him merely comprehensible.

headline: The Grand Slam Age Game
text: There was a time when Venus Williams could practice all day, stopping only after she hit the 550 balls that her father threw her from a shopping cart. “Last one!” she would tell him, excited to have reached her goal.

headline: 11 Ways to Use Our Blog This School Year
text: Teachers and administrators often ask us if we have a handout they can give to their colleagues to tell them about The Learning Network.

headline: Stormy Weather
text: The narrator of Giles Foden’s new novel is a retired meteorologist and Cambridge don looking back on the planning for the invasion of Normandy, when he and a team of scientists struggled to produce the reliable forecast required to choose a favorable D-Day. Henry Meadows is composing “this blotted memoir of my wartime days” in 1980 aboard a vast, surreal vessel he has helped construct: a sort of navigable iceberg complete with fitness center, library and cinema, not to mention a mosque for the Baluchi workers and the Saudi Arabian sheik who has commissioned the ship as a way of delivering fresh water to the desert. The bizarre comedy of this prologue is nicely set off by the melancholy Meadows’s dry, professorial delivery.

headline: Vietnam Raids Restaurants Selling Exotic Meats
text: Vietnamese forestry officials seized hundreds of pounds of illegal wildlife from restaurants in a popular tourist province this week, in what was one of the country’s largest such enforcement actions.

headline: Creating a Safer Kitchen
text: Food scares, like the latest salmonella outbreak and egg recall, often trigger a rethinking in cooking and shopping habits. In today’s Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad explores the costs and options consumers face on their quest for germ-free kitchens.

headline: Worlds in Collision
text: India, we are reminded ad infinitum, is a land of contradictions. Immense wealth rubs shoulders with unimaginable poverty; soaring modernity with crude tradition; the world’s largest democracy with its most stifling caste system.

headline: Niger Responds to Acute Malnutrition
text: Shawn Baker is the regional director for Africa of Helen Keller International. He has spent 25 years living and working in Africa, including nine years in Niger.

headline: We Three Things | In My Cups
text: After years of working exclusively in two dimensions, I found myself drawn to the mysterious, nowhere-to-hide realm of the third. My collection of McCoy vases, Poole pottery catalogs and Omega Workshop books was growing out of control, so I thought I’d drag the lake of my compulsions and get some mud under my fingernails. I’ve taken up pottery. It has only resulted in my becoming even more obsessed, and I see perfect pulling everywhere I look.

headline: Marilyn Monroe And The Slump
text: Aha: I forgot that after reading this: Amid Downturn, Divorce and Infidelity Decrease

headline: Mariner and the MAC Question
text: Mariner Energy cannot seem to get a break.

headline: Airlines Waive Fees for Flights Affected by Hurricane Earl
text: Several major airlines are waiving change fees — and in some cases, price differences — for flights that are affected by Hurricane Earl, through Sept. 4. This morning, the Lede blog posted a graphic and a complete list, of the storm warnings and watches in effect on Friday morning. Here are the changes we’ve found. If you know of others, please let us know in the comments section below. As the weather progresses, check specific airline Web sites for changes.

headline: No. 1 Sleuth
text: Lord Peter Wimsey, Hercule Poirot, Philo Vance, many another — they are like a drooping bouquet of exotically named flowers, withering away in one of subliterature’s deserted mansions. Once, during the 20th century’s interwar years, the first great age of detective fiction, they were the genre’s stars, often equipped with comical verbal tics or curious sideline interests, but always abiding by the ironbound conventions of classic crime fiction. Their work demanded more ratiocination than roughhouse and, in the end, a gathering of all the murder mystery’s many suspects in the country house library, where the gentlemanly investigator reveals the killer’s always surprising identity.

headline: Jennifer Shalant and Luke Groskin
text: THE rock hyrax, a relative of the elephant that resembles an obese gerbil, is not likely to inspire romance. But for Luke Groskin and Jennifer Shalant, who work at the Bronx Zoo, the small creature played a part in starting their relationship.

headline: How to Pep Up a Cheap PC
text: About a year ago I bought a cheap Dell: a $600 desktop packaged with a 20-inch LCD screen. Budget computers like this typically don’t have a discrete graphics card, which is necessary for advanced graphics like 3-D gaming. My Dell came with AMD HD 4200 integrated graphics — and an open PCI Express (PCIe) slot for a future upgrade to a discrete graphics card.

headline: Weekend Competition: The Dog Ate My Excuse
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to submit excuses they have heard, or given, that seem too outlandish to be true (perhaps because they are).

headline: Hannibal Rising
text: Other battles are perhaps just as famous — Thermopylae, Waterloo, Gettysburg — but the aura of Cannae, where Hannibal obliterated the largest army the Roman Republic had ever put into the field, is unmatched. The battle is unparalleled for its carnage, with more men from a single army killed on that one day, Aug. 2, 216 B.C., than on any other day on any other European battlefield: something like 50,000 Romans died, two and a half times the number of British soldiers who fell on the first day of the Somme.

headline: A Child Psychiatrist Responds
text: Dr. Mary Margaret Gleason, a child psychiatrist at Tulane University, took questions from readers on our Prescriptions blog on Thursday, as part of a discussion concerning an article published in The New York Times about a young boy’s misdiagnosis and medications.Dr. Gleason had treated the young boy, Kyle Warren, and works at an early treatment center for children with mental health issues and their families. (Watch a related video on Kyle, his family and Dr. Gleason’s take on the issue.)

headline: Sunday Shopping Linked With Less Happiness
text: How do you spend your Sunday? For many, this traditional day of rest and churchgoing has become a day to shop, but it may be taking a toll on happiness.

headline: Kaufman & Hart Delayed
text: Cross the revival of “You Can’t Take It With You” off the list of Broadway shows for this fall. The producer Elizabeth I. McCann, who had announced she would mount the show in November, said on Thursday she was now aiming for a spring opening for this 1936 comedy by George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart about the loopy Sycamore family. The production was supposed to have a pre-Broadway run at the Huntington Theater Company in Boston this month, but that was canceled in the spring, a Huntington spokeswoman said, because Ms. McCann and her producing partners were not able to complete the deal with enough lead time for the theater. With the Huntington run off, Ms. McCann said in an interview, her director on the production, Anna D. Shapiro, a Tony Award winner for “August: Osage County,” took on other projects that would keep her busy through the fall.

headline: Lost Tribe
text: I must have terrible luck. I’m an Ameri­can Jew who, from time to time, has — like the characters in Joan Leegant’s “Wherever You Go” — found my way to Israel. But unlike her characters, I’ve never managed to stumble upon small sculpture galleries nestled behind lemon trees. The muezzins haven’t sounded for me at perfect poetic moments. And, though I’ve been approached by good-looking Israeli men with motorcycles, none seemed motivated by a burning desire to talk politics.

headline: TimesCast | September 3, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, a better than expected jobs report, dancing with the dead in Madagascar and a new telecommunications robot.

headline: Open Mike: Ladies and Gentlemen, Start Your Engines
text: After being the second Serbian man in a row to win the last match of the day in Arthur Ashe Stadium, Novak Djokovic, who beat the German Philipp Petzschner, 7-5, 6-3, 7-6, told reporters after his second win of the tournament that he was starting to get into a rhythm.

headline: Words Cannot Express
text: Is language first and foremost an artifact of culture? Or is it largely determined by human biology? This issue has been argued back and forth for a couple of centuries with no clear resolution in sight. Guy Deutscher’s 2005 book “The Unfolding of Language” placed him firmly in the pro-culture camp. Now, in his new book, “Through the Language Glass,” he examines some idiosyncratic aspects of particular languages that, in his opinion, cast further doubt on biologically based theories of language.

headline: Turkey May Let U.S. Equipment Pass
text: ISTANBUL  Turkey, which in 2003 damaged relations with the United States by refusing to allow Americans troops to invade Iraq via its southeast border, has agreed in principle to allow the United States to move technical and logistical military equipment through the country as part of the withdrawal from Iraq.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: On Saturday, a swath of 46th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues becomes the epicenter of the Brazilian Cultural Parade and Festival from 1 to 6 p.m. Besides a festive parade, bands, samba dancers and the annual pageant, there will be food, particularly typical dishes of northern Brazil, like moquecas (a seafood stew) and vatapa (peeled black-eyed peas formed into a ball and deep-fried).

headline: In the Forest of Instruments, Signs of Evolution
text: At this summer’s classical music concerts, you could of course find a healthy array of violins, trumpets and cellos. But amid the familiar strings and brass have sprouted some odd instruments and strange adaptations of standard ones.

headline: Ghost, Come Back Again
text: A  boarding school in the British Isles. Reverent children huddle in a gloomy chamber, watching as one of their fellow students assays a devilishly difficult trick. The boy’s hand trembles. And then — success! A jet of fire, a “cold and beautiful purple-blue enchantment,” fills the ancient tower with an indescribable illumination.

headline: From Hiding, Indonesian Defends Free Expression
text: JAKARTA — Hiding out with a two-year jail sentence hanging over his head and vigilantes vowing to track him down, the editor of Indonesia’s defunct version of Playboy magazine, Erwin Arnada, insists he was never in the pornography business.

headline: Rodriguez to Face Pettitte in Rehab Session
text: Saturday’s meeting between the Yankees and the Toronto Blue Jays will be a single game at Yankee Stadium, but it may seem like a doubleheader in terms of the Yankees’ roster.

headline: Punk’d, Iraqi-Style, at a Checkpoint
text: BAGHDAD — An Iraqi reality television program broadcast during Ramadan has been planting fake bombs in celebrities’ cars, having an Iraqi army checkpoint find them and terrifying the celebrities into thinking that they are headed for maximum security prison.

headline: Endless War
text: In 1947, Hanson W. Baldwin, the hawkish military correspondent of this newspaper, warned that the demands of preparing America for a possible war would “wrench and distort and twist the body politic and the body economic . . . prior to war.” He wondered whether America could confront the Soviet Union “without becoming a ‘garrison state’ and destroying the very qualities and virtues and principles we originally set about to save.”

headline: Unhappy Days
text: Art historians tell us that photography revolutionized painting. Suddenly there was a better way of recording the physical appearance of things, and artists had to discover new purposes for brush and pigment. But for those living through the revolution, the process must have seemed more gradual. Long after the Impressionists and Cubists and Futurists, there must have been serious portraitists who continued to earn a living depicting brides on their wedding day or businessmen made good.

headline: Vegetarian Recipes for Barbecue Season
text: If your Labor Day plans include a picnic or barbecue, be sure to check out Martha Rose Shulman’s latest installment of Recipes for Health, which offers flavorful options for vegetarian eaters. She writes:

headline: Immortal Beloved
text: Paul Valéry said that a poet is like a man who carries huge weights up to a roof and drops them all at once on the head of a passer-by. With her first novel, “This Must Be the Place,” Kate Racculia has climbed to the highest roof and dropped the heaviest weights she could carry. Witness her ambitious premise: a 32-year-old photographer, on the brink of a nervous breakdown after the accidental death of his wife, flees his home in California for a boardinghouse in Ruby Falls, N.Y. — all because of a mysterious postcard, written 16 years earlier, found among his wife’s belongings and addressed to her childhood best friend but never sent.

headline: August Job Numbers
text: Catherine Rampell and Motoko Rich talk about the August job numbers and what they mean.

headline: Playing a Bandleader and Keeping It Real
text: VINCE GIORDANO didn’t just record, with his band, the Nighthawks, much of the music on “Boardwalk Empire.” He also served as an invaluable historical resource.

headline: Gas Cars Could Get 74 M.P.G. by 2035, Researcher Says
text: A new report from a University of Michigan researcher estimates that, even without going electric, U.S. cars and trucks could achieve an average efficiency of 74 miles per gallon by 2035. Compared to a federal 2005 Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) baseline, that’s a tripling of fuel economy.

headline: Santana Has Strained Chest Muscle
text: CHICAGO — Less than 24 hours after Johan Santana was removed from a game against the Atlanta Braves, the Mets confirmed Friday that he had a strained chest muscle. Whether he will make his next start on Tuesday in Washington is still unclear.

headline: Building a ‘Boardwalk Empire’
text: The lavish HBO production recreates Prohibition-era Atlantic City.

headline: Excerpt: 'Boardwalk Empire'
text: The HBO series is set in Prohibition-era Atlantic City.

headline: What We’re Reading: Imagining a Bigger Stimulus
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Sept. 3
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: At First She Didn’t Succeed, but She Tried and Tried Again (960 Times)
text: SINCHON, South Korea

headline: On Long Island, Tracking Earl’s Muted Wrath
text: Updated, 4:12 p.m. | While Earl continues to lose steam as it chugs northward — at 11 a.m., the National Weather Service downgraded it to a Category 1 hurricane — eastern Long Island may yet be in for a bit of a lashing.

headline: The Art of Thinking Clearly Under Great Pressure
text: In his book “Clutch: Why Some People Excel Under Pressure and Others Don’t” (Portfolio, 2010), Paul Sullivan looks at the criteria that account for performance  including financial performance  in times of challenge or adversity. Here is an excerpt.

headline: Scientists Criticize System of Certifying Fisheries
text: As I noted back in June, the Marine Stewardship Council has come under increasing fire for giving its stamp of approval to industrial fisheries that some scientists say are anything but environmentally sustainable.

headline: Call to the Jonathan
text: Jonathan Albaladejo, who set an International League saves record with 43 this season, came on to complete the Yankees’ one-hitter versus the Athletics on Thursday. Albaladejo is the seventh Jonathan in the majors this season and the third who is primarily a closer.

headline: A Move by Sony, to Compete With the Wii
text: 5:14 p.m. | Updated  to correct how a player’s hand location is detected by the console.

headline: Tropical Storm Earl
text: The projected path of Tropical Storm Earl from the National Weather Service.

headline: A Crash. A Call for Help. Then, a Bill.
text: ABOUT a year ago Cary Feldman was surprised to find himself sprawled on the pavement in an intersection in Chicago Heights, Ill., having been knocked off his motor scooter by the car behind him. Five months later he got another surprise: a bill from the fire department for responding to the scene of the accident.

headline: A Boardwalk Grows in Brooklyn
text: A time lapse video shows the construction of the $5 million set for HBO's "Boardwalk Empire" in a lot in Greenpoint.

headline: Pessimism Permeates Mideast Media on Talks
text: JERUSALEM  Palestinian and Israeli commentators were mostly pessimistic on Friday in assessing this week’s meeting of their leaders in Washington. Many described it as political theater  dark suits, cordial handshakes and lofty speeches  offering little chance to end the conflict.

headline: A Tour Through Maryland’s Wine Region
text: A tour of where to sip, where to stay and where to indulge in Maryland.

headline: A Niche of the Unreal in a World of Credulity
text: Since 2008, ChristWire.org has emerged as the leading Internet site for ultraconservative Christian news, commentary and weather reportage.

headline: ‘Ape House’
text: Chapter One

headline: Video of Quetta Attack From Pakistani Television
text: As my colleague Salman Masood reports, a bomb attack on a Shiite protest against Israel on Friday in the Pakistani city of Quetta killed at least 40 people. A Pakistani Taliban commander told The Associated Press that his group was responsible for the attack.

headline: On the Boardwalk, HBO Hangs Out With a New Mob
text: ON a blistering afternoon last June, outside a Polish social club in Greenpoint, men in heavy wool tuxedos, with slicked-back hair and pencil-thin mustaches, were blotting their brows. They looked like overheated figures from a Peter Arno drawing. Nearby were some very slender young women in spangly, ankle-length dresses. A couple were wearing feathered headdresses; others had their hair in paper curlers. But because this was Brooklyn, where people wear weird getups all the time, nobody paid them any attention.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Isabel Wilkerson

headline: Copy That: A Response
text: In my essay for The Stone, “The Third Replicator,” I argued that new replicators can piggy-back on older ones. This happens when the product of one replicator becomes copying machinery for the next replicator, and so on. Memes appeared, I wrote,  when humans (a product of genes) became capable of imitating, varying and selecting a new kind of information in the form of words, actions, technologies and ideas. The same thing is happening now, I argued, with a new replicator. Computers (a product of memes) are just beginning to be capable not only of copying but of copying, varying and selecting digital information. This means the birth of a new  replicator ─  temes, or technological memes.

headline: A Day to Dance or Weep?
text: ON the morning of her 40th birthday, Dana Foote woke up to blue skies and indulgent plans: a massage, a facial and a party with friends at a favorite Italian restaurant in her Greenwich Village neighborhood. She dropped off her young son and daughter at school and was chatting on the sidewalk with a few other mothers when a plane flew overhead, noticeably loud and low. A few minutes later, a school official came out to report that a plane had crashed into the World Trade Center. And Ms. Foote arrived home just in time to see the second plane crash, from the terrace of her apartment.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Havana and Elsewhere
text: Fidel Castro, the former president of Cuba, wearing his green military cap and clothing like the commandant of old, spoke before the Cuban public on Friday, warning of the threat of nuclear war. Reuters reported that Mr. Castro, 84, made his speech from the same steps of the University of Havana where 60 years ago he stirred fellow students to political action in the beginnings of the revolution that eventually put him in power in 1959. About 10,000 people, mostly students, filled the steps and nearby streets to listen to the man who led Cuba for 49 years before an intestinal illness prompted his resignation as president in 2006.

text: Thursday in The New York Times, I reviewed the MiFi from Virgin Mobile. It’s a pocketable, portable Wi-Fi hot spot, which ensures that you and up to four other people can get online almost anywhere you go. Anywhere in Sprint’s 3G network, that is.

headline: A Song of Ancient Love, Spun in Modern Isolation
text: At home in Europe, the Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas has emerged in the last 15 years or so as one of contemporary music’s most original thinkers. Trained in modernist enclaves like Darmstadt, Germany, and Ircam, the electronic music center in Paris, Mr. Haas saw past dogma and schematics to forge a fresh, uncompromising style rooted in primordial force and visionary intensity. A growing tally of notable performances and prestigious commissions attests to the visceral grip of his sound.

headline: 40 Years After ‘MASH,’ Gould Reflects on an Era
text: Attention, attention: Saturday night’s movies at the Walter Reade Theater in Lincoln Center will include a special showing of “MASH,” the 1970 Robert Altman comedy that used the Korean War as a vehicle to satirize the Vietnam War. This screening, celebrating the 75th anniversary of the 20th Century Fox studio and the 40th anniversary of “MASH,” and presented by 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment and the Film Society of Lincoln Center, will feature a question-and-answer session with the film’s stars Elliott Gould (who played Trapper John McIntyre), Sally Kellerman (Margaret Houlihan, a k a Hot Lips) and Tom Skerritt (Duke Forrest), as well as Mr. Altman’s widow, Kathryn Reed Altman.

headline: G.O.P. Poised to Control 30 Governor Seats

text: Facebook’s Places feature, which went live two weeks ago, lets Facebook users tag themselves and others as present at specific locations on Earth, such as a frozen yogurt shop or a Lady Gaga concert. The feature has incited a panic among some users who misunderstand how it works.

headline: Brendan Fraser to Make His Broadway Debut
text: If Daniel Craig could leave the James Bond franchise behind to make his Broadway debut last fall in “A Steady Rain,” Brendan Fraser, above left, certainly can hold off on another installment of “The Mummy” to make his. Mr. Fraser will appear on Broadway in November in the new comedy “Elling,” based on the Norwegian novels by Ingvar Ambjornsen. Mr. Fraser and, above right, Denis O’Hare (“Take Me Out,” television’s “True Blood”) are set to play a mismatched pair of roommates navigating the shoals of friendship, work and women. Also cast are Jennifer Coolidge (the film “Best in Show”) as the love interest of Mr. Fraser’s character and Richard Easton (“The Coast of Utopia,” “The Invention of Love”) as the poetry mentor to Mr. O’Hare’s character. Doug Hughes (“The Royal Family,” “Doubt”) will direct the play, which had a popular run in London. The production is scheduled to begin preview performances at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Nov. 2 and open on Nov. 21.

headline: ‘Brother’ Is Biggest on a Late-Summer Night
text: CBS topped the ratings on Thursday night as an elimination episode of “Big Brother” and two crime-show repeats earned the largest audiences in prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates, which were subject to more revision than usual because of pre-emptions of network schedules in several cities by live football broadcasts, “Big Brother” delivered a strong 10.6 million viewers at 8 p.m. while CBS’s “CSI” and “The Mentalist” drew 9.8 million and 8.5 million viewers at 9 and 10. ABC earned a second-place finish, garnering its best ratings at 9 for a new episode of “Rookie Blue” (7 million) and another 6.8 million at 8 for a rerun of the game show “Wipeout.” At 10, ABC’s “NightlinePrime” drew 5.2 million viewers, finishing behind not only CBS’s rerun but also NBC’s repeat of “Law & Order: SVU” (5.7 million). NBC was third, and Fox ranked fourth.

headline: California Lawmakers Approve Stolen-Art Bill
text: California lawmakers have given final approval to a bill that would extend the time in which people can sue museums to recover what they believe are stolen works of art. A spokesman for Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said he had not decided whether to sign the bill, which would give people six years to file a claim instead of the current three. The legislation, approved this week, grew out of cases in which time became a factor in litigation involving art looted by the Nazis. California once had a law that set no time limit on such claims, but it was struck down as unconstitutional by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals this year. Without that law, courts have generally held that the statute of limitations governing stolen art begins when the claimant discovers the work’s whereabouts, or when they should have discovered it with reasonable diligence (because the work, for example, was posted on a museum’s Web site or featured in an exhibition). Under the new legislation, which governs claims against museums, galleries and auction houses, plaintiffs are freed from any reasonable-diligence provision and the clock does not start until plaintiffs have gathered enough information to evaluate whether they have valid claims. The California Association of Museums has described the bill as “unnecessary, unfair, unconstitutional and disruptive” of property rights.

headline: Good Day for Paul Hogan: He Can Return to U.S.
text: Break out the Vegemite, crank up the Men at Work and prepare to celebrate the Australian cultural influences of the 1980s: Paul Hogan, above right, is a free man. Mr. Hogan, the Australian-born star of the “Crocodile Dundee” movies, has been granted permission to return to his home in the United States after reaching a deal with Australian tax officials, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Hogan was served with a departure prohibition order by the Australian Tax Office last month when he traveled to Sydney for his mother’s funeral. He has been investigated by Australian officials who say he put film royalties in offshore tax havens, a charge he denies, and Mr. Hogan has said he cannot afford to pay even 10 percent of his tax bill, though he did not say what amount he owes. A lawyer for Mr. Hogan said in a statement Friday that after a “cordial and cooperative” meeting with tax officials, an agreement had been reached. “While the commissioner and Mr. Hogan remain in dispute on more general taxation issues, Mr. Hogan continues to protest his innocence and denies any wrongdoing,” the statement said, according to The A.P. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

headline: Woo Gets Lifetime Prize at Venice Film Festival
text: After facilitating the dispersal of countless bullet casings via the slow-motion shootouts he pioneered in his films, John Woo, below, was rewarded Friday with an estimable piece of metal that he gets to keep: the Venice Film Festival gave its Golden Lion award for lifetime achievement to Mr. Woo, the director of Hong Kong action movies like “Hard-Boiled” and “The Killer” and Hollywood blockbusters like “Mission: Impossible II,” The Associated Press reported. In its citation, the festival praised him “as an innovator of the contemporary language of cinema,” but Mr. Woo said, “I wouldn’t say that I have much contributed to film society, even though I made several good films.” He said he hoped his future work would provide “a bridge between the good things of the West and the East, so we can further our mutual knowledge and build a strong friendship.” Following the historical “Red Cliff,” set in China’s feudal period, Mr. Woo’s latest film is “Reign of Assassins,” a martial-arts movie showing out of competition in Venice.

headline: ‘Yank!’ Won’t Reach Broadway This Season
text: A Broadway production of the musical “Yank!,” a gay love story set during World War II, has been postponed until the fall of 2011, a spokesman for the producers said. The spokesman, Rick Miramontez, said that the musical’s creators wanted more time to overhaul the show’s book and that the director on board, David Cromer (“Our Town”), had several competing projects to schedule. Mr. Miramontez said fund-raising for the production, which is expected to cost about $5 million, had not been a problem. With music by Joseph Zellnik and book and lyrics by David Zellnik, who are brothers, “Yank!” revolves around two young soldiers whose friendship turns into romance during the war. The musical drew mostly good reviews during an Off Broadway run at York Theater Company in the winter, when it was one of several musicals and plays in New York that featured gay love stories. Mr. Miramontez said that Mr. Cromer and Bobby Steggert (above, a Tony nominee for “Ragtime”), who starred in the Off Broadway production, remain committed to a Broadway production of “Yank!” and that Mr. Cromer was working on the show virtually every day.

Actually, it is not so much a festival as an installment of the barge’s Here and Now contemporary-music series, to be repeated four times through Sunday. But even as Bargemusic’s increasingly eclectic programming goes, this was an extravagant show. It began with new music for traditional Japanese instruments, touched on a handful of modern and avant-garde styles, and ended with a jazz set.

headline: A Physician Examines His Novels
text: BUSSUM, the Netherlands — When Hans Keilson’s first daughter was born, in 1941, he was in hiding in the Netherlands. A Jewish doctor from Germany who had published a novel in 1933 and seen it banned months later, he fled the Nazis in 1936, when he was forbidden to practice medicine. The Nazis soon occupied the Netherlands too, and the woman who became his first wife, a German Roman Catholic, pretended the child’s real father was a German soldier.

They’re ugly, she says, in a voice that walks a straight and uninflected line, as if the slightest animation might throw her off balance. Her words reduce American playhouses to an unforgiving, haiku-esque collection of phrases: “Four walls. I cannot take them. We’re prisoners here. The hell of the life.”
