headline: Venerable Craft, Modern Practitioner
text: Robert Ambrosi sweeps into the restaurant kitchen, past sizzling chicken and buttery mashed potatoes, and goes straight for the knives  carving knives and chef’s knives, paring knives and fillet knives, all made dull by clashes with flesh and bone. He picks them up and replaces them with identical twins.

headline: Reading, Watching and Sleeping Sports
text: The sportscaster Warner Wolf, 72, wakes up most mornings at 4 a.m. to prepare for his air time; Sunday is an exception. He has been in the business for some 50 years, and settled in 2004 at WABC Radio, where he is now the sportscaster for “Imus in the Morning”; he also has his own show on Saturdays on ESPN Radio in New York. During football season, which starts this week, he spends Sundays glued to the television at his home on the Upper West Side. The rest of the year, he might go to a matinee with his wife, Sue. ALEX VADUKUL

headline: Motown Wheel Thieves Working Overtime
text: It seems that Mayor Dave Bing wasn’t the only prominent figure to lose his wheels in Detroit this week.

headline: Going Québécois Before Going West
text: Marooned on a lonesome block, at the corner of 21st Street and 49th Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, the M. Wells diner serves a Québécois take on short-order cooking: from crab and egg hash to pickled pork tongue. Opened this summer and offering, for the moment, breakfast and lunch but no dinner, it is housed in a restored chrome structure, and its menu, greasy spoon-wise, is printed on a place mat. “We’re sort of in the middle of everywhere and nowhere,” said Sarah Obraitis, who owns the place with her husband, Hugue Dufour, meaning that customers include surprised construction workers (“Buckwheat what?”), iPod users and, one day last week, a couple of shaggy dudes from Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

headline: New York World
text: In the past few weeks, a Korean daily newspaper explored the implications of young Korean-Americans forswearing their Korean citizenship; an Irish newspaper interviewed the oldest living Irishwoman (in upstate New York); and, above, the editor of a group of Indian newspapers had an amusing take on the debate over the Islamic community center planned two blocks away from the World Trade Center. KIRK SEMPLE

headline: Questions About New York
text: Q. Who designed the plantings in the British Garden in Hanover Square, which Queen Elizabeth II formally dedicated on July 6? Was it Prince Charles?

headline: Tea Party Express Stands by O’Donnell
text: Amid mounting questions about Christine O’Donnell’s personal finances and integrity, the Tea Party Express is sticking by its conservative upstart.

headline: The Cinematic View From Telluride
text: TELLURIDE, Colo.— In the movie world, Labor Day marks both the last gasp of summer—as the blockbusters eke out their last dollars, and a few latecomers straggle into theaters—and the beginning of the long march through the autumn toward the Oscars. The Venice Film festival is already underway, the Toronto International Film Festival is looming and, in the meantime, there is Telluride, which opens Friday night and lasts through the long weekend.

headline: H.I.V. Prevention Gel Hits Snag: Money
text: JOHANNESBURG  When scientists celebrated the announcement in July that a vaginal microbicide had finally been found that significantly reduced H.I.V. infections in women, there was still a prosaic  though essential  piece of the puzzle missing: money.

headline: A Museum Quest Spins On and On
text: IN the lobby of a budget hotel in Midtown Manhattan, Craig Wilson began his staff meeting, oblivious to guests strolling past. The location, he conceded, was far from ideal; the same could be said for the prospects of his venture.

headline: Looking for Luck in South Texas
text: In this installment of the Continental Picture Show series, Alec Soth tests his fortune among bingo players and lottery hopefuls.

headline: Italian Cities Plan to Shut Roma Camps
text: MILAN  Some 20 years ago, Marco Deragna, a Roma whose family has been in Italy for generations, moved to a field on the outskirts of metropolitan Milan and made his home there.

headline: Mariner Rig Accident Undercuts Efforts to End Drilling Moratorium
text: An oil rig caught fire in the Gulf of Mexico on Thursday, forcing workers to dive overboard to escape the flames, and sending chills through a region just beginning to recover from one of the worst oil spills in history.

headline: It Turns Out That Good Putting Really Is Child’s Play
text: Eric Alpenfels, the director of instruction at the Pinehurst Golf Academy in North Carolina, has spent hundreds of hours researching how average golfers putt.

headline: China: Another Traffic Jam on the Jingzang Highway
text: Yet another gargantuan traffic jam has gripped the freeway that links Inner Mongolia’s coal fields to metropolitan Beijing, possibly exceeding a blockage that drew global attention last month, Chinese media reported. More than 100 Inner Mongolian police officers staffed the road, the Jingzang Highway, in an effort to break the jam, which stretched for 75 miles and involved 10,000 vehicles, the state broadcaster CCTV said Thursday.

headline: Help for Those Just Starting Out in the Jazz World
text: JAZZ musicians have long lamented the loss of the apprenticeship system, which vanished along with the nightspots that lined former music hubs like Dixwell Avenue in New Haven and West 52nd Street in Manhattan, where players of different generations shared bandstands, beer and trade secrets after the marquees went dark.

headline: Afghanistan: Close Monitoring of Troubled Bank to Resume
text: The Afghan bank under severe threat of collapse was closed, as usual, on Friday, the national day of rest. The country’s banking system will reopen on Saturday, and observers will closely monitor the number of creditors who try to withdraw their assets from Kabul Bank in anticipation of an increasing financial crisis that Khalilullah Frozi, one of the bank’s two largest shareholders, has said could lead to its collapse.

headline: Iran: Opposition Beginssatellite Television Channel
text: Iranian opposition activists have started a new satellite TV channel, RASA TV, from Belgium as an alternative to Iran’s increasingly state-controlled media. The channel is also available online. One of the channel’s organizers, Ebrahim Nabavi, said in an interview with Radio Free Europe that the goal was to break the government’s “monopoly” on information and fight censorship in Iran. The opposition leader and cleric Mehdi Karroubi appeared on the channel and praised it on Thursday, just hours before pro-government crowds surrounded and attacked his house, clashing with his bodyguards and preventing him from attending the annual Jerusalem Day rally on Friday.

headline: On Television, Hoping to Stand Out in a Crowded Field
text: If you watch the United States Open, the 11 o’clock news, “Law & Order” repeats or just about anything else in the coming days, you will likely find yourself watching something else: campaign advertisements from the five Democrats running for attorney general.

headline: A Coaching Philosophy Informed by Life’s Trials and Brushes With Mortality
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  The mementos in Mike London’s office provide a rough sketch of his career: photographs, souvenir footballs, the 2008 N.C.A.A. championship ring he won as the coach at Richmond, the image of the rotunda on the University of Virginia campus.

headline: On an Avenue Far From Sesame Street
text: I smiled all the way through the Gateway Playhouse’s sweet, naughty, hilarious, absolutely first-rate production of “Avenue Q.” Except when poor Kate Monster was stood up at midnight on the Empire State Building’s observation deck. But then the penny that she threw down to the street hit Lucy the Slut in the head, knocking her out, and I was laughing again. (Lucy the Slut totally deserved it.)

headline: 30 False Fronts Won Contracts for Blackwater
text: WASHINGTON  Blackwater Worldwide created a web of more than 30 shell companies or subsidiaries in part to obtain millions of dollars in American government contracts after the security company came under intense criticism for reckless conduct in Iraq, according to Congressional investigators and former Blackwater officials.

headline: A Harmonic View of Nature, in a Cultural Tangle
text: Wouldn’t it be nice if we could all live peacefully on this continent, engaging with nature in our myriad ways? History has not unfolded that way, of course. But you wouldn’t know it by visiting “Engaging With Nature: American and Native American Artists (A.D. 1200-2004)” at the Montclair Art Museum.

headline: Playing Anne Frank to Remind the World
text: MILLIE PERKINS read Anne Frank’s diary for the first time as she flew cross-country more than 50 years ago to audition for the role of Anne.

headline: F.D.A. Backtracks and Returns Drug to Market
text: Two weeks ago, the Food and Drug Administration announced that it would remove the drug midodrine from the market because the drug’s maker never confirmed that the medicine  approved in 1996 under an abbreviated process  actually worked against dizziness and fainting.

headline: Tangible Progress at the World Trade Center
text: Photographs from the Times’s Fred R. Conrad provide an intimate view of construction at the site of the World Trade Center.

headline: Caught on Video: Fans Supplement Action on Court
text: Hooliganism is rare in tennis, on the courts or in the stands. So when a heated argument turned into a brief melee Thursday night in the upper reaches of Arthur Ashe Stadium  and two men tumbled down a few rows of $45 seats  it was captured by fans with camera phones, not ESPN.

headline: In Pennsylvania, a ‘Race Card’ Accusation
text: 9:14 p.m. | Updated 9:07 p.m. | Updated

headline: Modified Salmon Is Safe, F.D.A. Says
text: A salmon genetically engineered to grow quickly is safe to eat and poses little risk to the environment, the Food and Drug Administration said Friday.

headline: Defense Secretary Offers Cautious Views on Wars
text: SENJARAY, Afghanistan  No one has ever accused Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates of happy talk, but during a trip this week to assess the state of America’s two wars his words were more restrained than usual.

headline: Former Chief of G.M. Joins Sunoco
text: Nine months after his ouster from General Motors, Fritz Henderson has taken on another leadership position.

headline: The Struggle for What We Already Have
text: For something that seems so simple and straightforward, “net neutrality” has sure created one big mess.

headline: On the Street | Rad Men
text: Bill Cunningham photographs the sleeves-rolled, suspender-wearing male contingent at a jazz-age lawn party at Governors Island.

headline: Renovated Michigan Stadium Is Set to Open
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  The original 1920s financing plan for the University of Michigan’s now-iconic football stadium relied on a bond issue that allowed each bondholder to purchase two season tickets. A university history noted that it was assumed “a new stadium would quickly pay for itself.”

headline: DioGuardi Leaves ‘American Idol’
text: After only two seasons, Kara DioGuardi is exiting “American Idol,” setting the stage for an announcement later this month about a new panel of judges for the show.

headline: Where Dams Once Stood, Prospectors Spur Anger
text: GOLD HILL, Ore.  When four dams on the Rogue River here were scheduled for removal, environmentalists predicted many benefits: more salmon and steelhead swimming upriver to spawn; more gravel carried downriver to replenish the riverbed; more rafters bobbing along 57 miles of newly opened water.

headline: Texas Probes Google on Ranking of Search Results
text: The Texas attorney general has opened an antitrust investigation into how Google ranks search results, the first United States case to strike at the heart of the company’s main search business.

headline: St. Louis Has Big-Name Talent, but Also a Big Division Deficit
text: ST. LOUIS  The future was not supposed to arrive so quickly for the St. Louis Cardinals. They should be driving confidently to the postseason, where the makeup of their roster could set them up nicely. Instead they are striving to put off the hard questions they face.

headline: Campbell Profit Rises, but Outlook Disappoints Investors
text: The Campbell Soup Company, the world’s largest soup maker, reported higher quarterly profit and income on Friday, but gave an earnings forecast that trailed analysts’ estimates.

headline: U.N. Raises Concerns as Global Food Prices Jump
text: UNITED NATIONS — With memories still fresh of food riots set off by spiking prices just two years ago, agricultural experts on Friday cast a wary eye on the steep rise in the cost of wheat prompted by a Russian export ban and the questions looming over harvests in other parts of the world because of drought or flooding.

headline: War and the City: March Song
text: This is the first of a five-part series, “War and the City,” by the Iraq war veteran Roy Scranton, chronicling his path from unemployed youth to soldier to civilian writer in New York City.

headline: On Economy, Democrats Face a Lack of Unity
text: WASHINGTON  Democrats are entering the fall sprint to the midterm elections lacking a unifying message to address the lackluster economy, scrambling to come up with further job-creating remedies and out of time to show substantial results before voters go to the polls.

headline: World Trade Center Complex Is Rising Rapidly
U.S. Open Replay: Sept. 3
text: Photos from Day 5 of the United States Open.

headline: Low Scores, Then a Storm Pelt Deutsche Bank’s Course
text: NORTON, Mass.  In the calm before the storm Friday, the players in the first round of the Deutsche Bank Championship  at least most of them  staged a pre-hurricane party at the T.P.C. Boston. As outer bands of rain from a weakening Hurricane Earl crept softly across a course set up conservatively for the storm’s arrival, tour players put up an array of flamboyant numbers.

headline: Indictment Accuses Firm of Exploiting Thai Workers
text: A federal grand jury in Honolulu has indicted six labor contractors from a Los Angeles manpower company on charges that they imposed forced labor on some 400 Thai farm workers, in what justice officials called the biggest human-trafficking case ever brought by federal authorities.

headline: Spotlight Shifts to Shallow-Water Wells
text: For decades, thousands of oil and gas platforms have operated quietly in the shallower waters of the Gulf of Mexico, largely forgotten by the public and government regulators.

headline: On the Last Train to Montauk, in a Race to Beat a Storm’s Arrival
text: On Thursday afternoon, as Hurricane Earl swirled several hundred miles to the south and the only raindrops in Manhattan fell from sweating air-conditioners, the Long Island Rail Road declared that on Friday all trains headed to the North and South Forks would be suspended or have their routes shortened as a precaution.

headline: Ivanovic Rolls to Rematch With Clijsters
text: Ana Ivanovic is looking more and more like her old self these days, and that was never more apparent than at the United States Open on Friday.

headline: Pulse
text: Mademoiselle Agnès, host of “Girl on the Run,” on the Sundance Channel; Céline lines sandals in rabbit fur; and other items.

headline: Alaska Winner, Lover of Privacy, Loses His Own
text: FAIRBANKS, Alaska — The man with the best chance of becoming the next senator from Alaska lives at the end of a long gravel road here at the edge of the continent. Tribulation Trail is the name of his street. Signs warn against trespassing. A dog’s baritone bark rattles the aspens when car wheels, unexpected, churn the driveway.

headline: Celldex Loses a Partner in Brain Tumor Treatment
text: Pfizer is pulling out of an agreement with Celldex Therapeutics to finance the development of an experimental brain tumor vaccine, Celldex said Friday. The vaccine, called rindopepimut, is “no longer a strategic priority of Pfizer,” which will return the rights to the therapy to Celldex on Nov. 1, Celldex said. The treatment is in the second of three stages of testing generally required to win regulatory approval. Pfizer licensed rights to the product in 2008 from Celldex for as much as $440 million, plus royalties. If approved, the brain cancer vaccine could have $450 million in peak annual sales and come on the market in 2013, Joseph Pantginis, an analyst at Roth Capital, said in May. Celldex’s chief executive, Anthony Marucci, said the company would need to raise more money to pay for late-stage testing but would not need another partner. Shares of Celldex, based in Needham Mass., fell $1.25, or 26 percent, to $3.53.

headline: H&R Block Dismisses Concerns About Mortgages
text: H&R Block told investors to ignore speculation that it faced a surge in costs tied to its defunct mortgage business. Concern about potential losses tied to buybacks of home loans “is not based on fact,” and reserves to protect the company against claims are adequate, the chief executive, Alan M. Bennett, said Thursday during a conference call about fiscal first-quarter earnings. The call included repeated queries about claims, which have totaled more than $680 million. H&R Block originated mortgages through January 2008, and some were sold to become part of mortgage-backed securities. The company’s mortgage buyback liability “remains within our reserved expectations, and we continue to view related reserves as adequate,” the chief financial officer, Jeffrey T. Brown, said. H&R Block reported a loss from continuing operations of $127.6 million, or 40 cents a share, for the three months ending July 10, compared with $130.6 million, or 39 cents, in the same period last year. Its net loss narrowed to $130.7 million from $133.6 million. Shares of H&R Block, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., rose 73 cents, or 6 percent, to $13.30.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Divide Over the Islamic Center
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Fitness Plan That’s Not Just for the Military
text: To the Editor:

headline: Is Government Effective? New Jersey’s Costly Error
text: To the Editor:

headline: For This Coach, the Orders Come From His Wife
text: SAN ANTONIO  The Silver Stars of the W.N.B.A. have a husband-and-wife act that flouts convention. Imagine Katie Holmes getting top billing over Tom Cruise, or Gavin Rossdale singing backup for Gwen Stefani.

headline: U.S. Withholds Millions in Mexico Antidrug Aid
text: MEXICO CITY  The United States will withhold about $26 million promised for Mexico’s drug war because of concerns that the country has not done enough to protect its people from police and military abuse.

headline: A Gay Republican Comes Out
text: To the Editor:

headline: First Lady Plans a Careful Return to the Campaign Trail
text: WASHINGTON  After 18 months of careful image-making and bipartisanship, Michelle Obama is shifting course as first lady, stepping up her policy agenda and dipping into election-year politics to campaign and raise money for Democrats.

headline: Of Janitors and Kings
text: Martha Escobar is staring into the cold, dark, unforgiving eyes of destitution.

headline: Accepted Notion of Mars as Lifeless Is Challenged
text: For all the triumph of NASA’s 1976 Viking mission, which put two unmanned spacecraft on Mars, there was one major disappointment: The landers failed to find carbon-based molecules that could serve as the building blocks of life.

headline: The Ungreat Debate
text: We do not generally look to gubernatorial debates for excitement. But this week there was a fascinating one in Arizona, where Gov. Jan Brewer gave a bad performance of epic proportions. Really, Richard Nixon in 1960 was Demosthenes in Athens compared with this one.

headline: A Mosque Invisible to Many Is a Target
text: WATERPORT, N.Y.  The small congregation established a mosque here three decades ago in a 19th-century farmhouse surrounded by apple orchards and cornfields. In the farmhouse’s simple prayer room, they prayed for many things, including peace and quiet that has never fully come.

headline: Mets Negate Scoring Burst With Pitching Letdown
text: CHICAGO  In a year of disappointment and frustration for the Mets, even things that have gone right are often coupled with a corresponding misstep.

headline: Saturday: Aid to King Hrothgar
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s crossword is by Mark Diehl. As you can see from his photo on XWord Info, he’s a dentist. I’ve seen Little Shop of Horrors, so I know dentists enjoy inflicting pain. True to form, 32 of Dr. Diehl’s 42 New York Times puzzles have run on a Friday or a Saturday. This one starts out like a root canal, but eventually, answers start to emerge. Let’s take a look at how to dig out a few of them.

headline: The Magic of the U.S. Open at Night
text: Night tennis is a different world from that of day tennis. The lights, the feel of the court, the atmosphere: everything moves in a way that it doesn’t quite match the way it does under the sun, like a whole other sport in and of itself.

headline: Coughlin Meets With Jacobs, Who Is Upset About His Role
text: Last season, the Giants’ ground attack stalled as Brandon Jacobs and Ahmad Bradshaw battled injuries. Now that they are healthy, the team is contending with another matter: keeping them happy.

headline: With Backup Quarterback a Question Mark, Giants Trade for Rosenfels
text: The Giants solved their backup quarterback problem Friday night, when they acquired Sage Rosenfels, along with running back Darius Reynaud, from the Vikings for a fifth-round draft pick in 2011 and a conditional pick in 2012. Rosenfels has appeared in 32 games in his career, with 10 of his 12 starts coming in 2007 and 2008 for the Houston Texans. He was 6-4 as a starter with Houston. Last season, with Minnesota, Rosenfels did not attempt a pass behind Brett Favre.

headline: Goldcorp Offers $3.4 Billion for Australian Rival
text: Goldcorp, the Canadian gold miner, said Friday that it would buy its Australian rival, Andean Resources, for $3.4 billion in cash and stock, topping an all-share offer from Eldorado Gold.

headline: In Protecting Hasidic Neighborhoods, Squads Patrol Without Guns or Badges
text: On Thursday night in Brooklyn, a suspect was chased and quickly surrounded by a group of patrolmen in blue uniform jackets who ordered him to halt.

headline: Europe Takes a Big Step to Avert Economic Crises
text: BRUSSELS

headline: Strong Net Play to Match His Sense of Humor
text: Michael Llodra’s originality is not restricted to his style of play.

headline: Purple Oreo, and Other Teas
text: With the focus of a bartender, Zachary Schaffer, 24, stood behind the Boba Boys counter in the Harbor Square minimall in Port Jefferson on a recent afternoon. He vigorously shook a stainless steel tumbler, then poured a frothy green liquid over tapioca pearls in a clear cup, adding a thick, colorful straw.

headline: At the Inn, Eye-Openers in a Revamped Setting
text: THE Jedediah Hawkins Inn in Jamesport caused a stir when it first opened on the North Fork in the summer of 2006. This stylish, refurbished 1863 sea captain’s house was a beauty, and the kitchen of its restaurant, called Jedediah’s, was run by Tom Schaudel, one of the island’s best known and most respected chefs.

headline: Ready-to-Eat for Rosh Hashana
text: Fridays are busy at Sarah’s Tent in Deal, a kosher gourmet grocery that is a popular stop for ready-to-serve Shabbat dinners. Entrees include Syrian- and Mediterranean-inspired dishes like roasted chicken with apricots ($7.99 a pound).

headline: U.S. Military Bands: Lighter and Faster
text: Modern wars need a modern military, light and fast on its feet, and the United States Army has changed accordingly. So has its music.

headline: Chinese Cooking, as the Chinese Do
text: YOU’D never guess it from the outside, but a daring and beautiful experiment is under way in a shopping center on Route 10 in Whippany. A prize-winning chef, just off the plane from Shanghai, teamed up late last year with three New Jersey women he had never met, and who had no prior restaurant experience, to seek a following for real Chinese cooking among a suburban audience.

headline: Landis Said to File Suit Against Cycling Team
text: Floyd Landis, who was stripped of the 2006 Tour de France title for doping, has filed a federal whistle-blower lawsuit against his former team  the United States Postal Service squad that included the seven-time Tour winner Lance Armstrong  claiming that the team defrauded the government, two people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

headline: The Pacific Campaign, Dam Division
text: ON Sept. 1, 1945 — 65 years ago this week — I arrived in Leyte Gulf, the Philippines, aboard a Navy transport ship. Along with other newly commissioned ensigns in the Navy Civil Engineer Corps, I was prepared to join one of the Seabee battalions being mustered for an invasion of the Japanese mainland. However, as we had learned during our voyage across the Pacific, the A-bombs had been dropped and Japan had capitulated. As the fates would have it, the day after our arrival — Sept. 2, 1945 — Japan formally surrendered to the Allies.

headline: Religious Outlier
text: With all of the consternation about religion in this country, it’s sometimes easy to lose sight of just how anomalous our religiosity is in the world.

headline: Fan Lowlights
text: Live sporting events were once a safe venue for family entertainment. Now, they sometimes seem to be more in line with the U.F.C.’s Octagon. Following the most recent incident of fan violence, which saw a young fan tussle with someone at least 30 years his senior, we decided to look back on some of the lowlights in fan behavior.

headline: A Moo Moo Here, a Blue Ribbon There
text: ON a recent August morning, Tara Bergstrom, 14, gingerly stepped around the walk-in chicken coop at her home in Katonah, introducing a visitor to her flock of Comets and Rhode Island Reds. “This is Daisy, this is Star, this is Buttercup,” she said, picking up Buttercup and stroking her rust-colored feathers. “This is Fern, and this is Fawn — they’re like best friends.”

headline: William Ferguson, Kim Smith
text: William Hume Ferguson and Kim David Smith are to be married Sunday by Elizabeth Bonsal, a Connecticut justice of the peace, who is to officiate at her home in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: Anna Lenhardt, William Lee III
text: Anna Rachael Lenhardt and William Russell Lee III were married Saturday in New York. Msgr. Robert Romano performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Thomas More.

headline: Amy Melville, Patrick Suehnholz
text: Amy Lynn Melville, a daughter of Monica Sciamanna Melville and John P. Melville of Goshen, N.Y., was married Saturday to Patrick Joralemon Suehnholz, a son of Catherine McCormack Suehnholz and Keith G. Suehnholz, also of Goshen. The Rev. George S. Salzmann, the Catholic chaplain to the Harvard graduate schools, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew’s Roman Catholic Church on Block Island, R.I.

headline: Neely Shah and Ronnie Chatterji
text: Neely Manoj Shah and Aaron Kumar Chatterji are to be married Sunday at the Westin Atlanta Perimeter North hotel in Atlanta. Dr. Bhagirath Majmudar, a Hindu priest, is to officiate.

text: Devon Marie Wilson and George Matthew Dentler were married Friday at St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral in Manhattan. The Rev. George E. Agger, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Kathleen Liu, Weili Shaw
text: Kathleen Liu and Weili Shaw were married Saturday at the B. R. Cohn Winery and Olive Oil Company in Glen Ellen, Calif. Catherine L. Chou, a friend of the couple who was granted permission by Sonoma County to be a deputy marriage commissioner for the day, officiated.

headline: Aaron Lustbader, DJ Martin
text: Aaron Jonathan Lustbader and Dwight Jonathan Martin were married Saturday by Rabbi Douglas E. Krantz at the Interlaken Inn in Lakeville, Conn.

headline: Maren Messing, Adam Bernstein
text: Maren Jessica Messing and Adam Jacob Bernstein are to be married Sunday at the Wainwright House, an event space in Rye, N.Y. Cantor Jeffrey S. Shiovitz is to officiate.

headline: Jessica Dang, Timothy Holme
text: Jessica Ying Dang and Timothy Peter Holme are to be married Sunday at Relais du Soleil, a guest ranch and event space in Glen Ellen, Calif. Jason M. Miller, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, is to officiate.

headline: Jennifer Fisher, Adeniyi Taiwo
text: Jennifer Lynn Fisher and Hafeez Adeniyi Taiwo were married Friday in Windsor, Conn. The Rev. David C. Parachini performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church, where he is pastor.

text: Diana May-Yen Eng and Jimmy Akashi Wang were married Saturday evening. The Rev. Matthew D. Na, a United Methodist minister, officiated at Oheka Castle, a hotel and estate in Huntington, N.Y.

text: Cortney Lynn Harding and Jeffrey Edward Stokvis were married Monday by Josephine Tagliarini, a staff member of the city clerk’s office, at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. On Saturday, Stanley K. Lam, a friend of the couple, led a ceremony for family and friends at the Foundry, an event space in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Ana Cano, Kevin Nennig
text: Ana Cristina Cano and Kevin Thomas Nennig were married Saturday at St. Paul the Apostle Church in New York. The Rev. Gilbert Martinez, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Meaghan Woodbury and Jonah Stuart
text: Meaghan Mary Woodbury, a daughter of Susan and Vincent Woodbury of Massapequa, N.Y., was married Saturday to Jonah Hall Stuart, the son of Susan B. Harman of Santa Rosa, Calif., and Dr. Bradley H. Stuart of Forestville, Calif. The Rev. Charles N. Mangano performed the ceremony at Curé of Ars Roman Catholic Church in Merrick, N.Y., where he is the pastor.

headline: Adrienne Stortz, Christian Ryther
text: Adrienne Delia Stortz and Christian Curreen Ryther are to be married Sunday morning on a lawn by the Pool in Central Park. Kevin M. Mauro, a Universal Life Minister and a friend of the couple, is to officiate.

headline: Ashley Kramer, David Kinzler
text: Ashley Anne Kramer, the daughter of Marianne Kramer and Francis H. Kramer of Gibsonia, Pa., was married Saturday to First Lt. David James Kinzler, the son of Carol Kinzler and Thomas Kinzler of Darien, Conn. The Rev. David A. Moczulski performed the ceremony at St. Boniface Roman Catholic Church in Pittsburgh.

headline: Jana Galan and Ronaldo Garces
text: Jana Galan and Ronaldo Flaminiano Garces were married Saturday at the Church of the Guardian Angel in Manhattan. Msgr. Michael F. Hull performed the ceremony.

headline: Barbara Osborn, Robert Laybourn
text: Dr. Barbara Hope Osborn and Robert William Laybourn were married Wednesday evening in Washington. The Rev. Jeffrey L. Maszal, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated on the patio of the Swedish Embassy in Washington. The couple repeated their vows Saturday evening during a formal wedding ceremony aboard the USS Sequoia, a former presidential yacht now moored on the Potomac River.

headline: Molly Worthen, Michael Morgan
text: Molly Catherine Worthen and Michael Cotey Morgan are to be married Sunday in New Haven. The Rev. David C. Cobb, an Episcopal priest, is to perform the ceremony at Christ Church New Haven, where he is the rector.

headline: Jenny Thompson, Daniel Cumpelik
text: Dr. Jenny Beth Thompson, the former Olympic swimmer and gold-medalist, and Daniel Richard Cumpelik, an owner of a home products business, are to be married on Sunday at Hammond Castle in Gloucester, Mass. The ceremony is to be led by Aaron M. Thompson, a brother of the bride, who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate at the event.

headline: Claire McCusker, Michael Murray
text: Claire Virginia McCusker, a daughter of Susan B. McCusker and Leo X. McCusker of Guttenberg, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Michael Francis Murray, a son of Linda A. Murray and Francis Murray of Annapolis, Md. The Rev. Albert P. Marcello III is to perform the ceremony at St. Teresa of Avila Roman Catholic Church in Summit, N.J.

headline: Jidan Koon, Bryant Terry
text: Jidan Koon and Bryant Thomas Terry are to be married Sunday at their home in Oakland, Calif. The Rev. Andriette Earl, a United Church of Religious Science minister, is to officiate.

headline: Faith Ferguson, Ronald Boire
text: Faith Ann Ferguson and Ronald Dale Boire were married on Friday at their home in Warwick, N.Y. Michael K. Brown, a former town justice of Hamptonburgh, N.Y., officiated.

headline: Anna Black, Eric Morin

Morin. Rabbi Seymour Rosenbloom is to perform the ceremony at Pine Forest Camp, which was founded in 1931 by Hughie Black, a great-grandfather of the bride.

Miller is to officiate at the Charles Krug Winery in St. Helena, Calif., with the assistance of Cantor Jessica Roskin.

headline: Elyse Buxbaum and Scott Stringer
text: Elyse Buxbaum, a museum administrator, and Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, were married Thursday at City Hall in New Haven. Mayor John DeStefano Jr. of New Haven officiated. On Sunday, the couple is to have a religious ceremony led by Rabbi Robert N. Levine at 632 Hudson Street, an event space in Manhattan.

headline: Vivian Kaufman, Benjamin Click
text: Vivian Vlasta Kaufman, a daughter of Jitka M. Raidl of Belmont, Mass., and Dr. Kevin J. Kaufman of Brookline, Mass., was married Saturday to Navy Lt. j.g. Benjamin Edwards Click, the son of Heather Tully Click and Alan R. Click of Peachtree City, Ga. Rabbi Harold L. Kudan officiated at the Harvard Faculty Club in Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Bringing the Bounty of the Field to the Feast
text: CONNECTICUT’S first Farm-to-Chef Harvest Celebration Week, starting Sept. 26, came about in response to a simple statement that Kevin Cottle, a longtime practitioner of cooking with locally produced foods, made at a routine Farm-to-Chefplanning session. He said, “We need to do more,” recalled Linda Piotrowicz, who runs the Farm-to-Chef program, an effort to connect producers with restaurants, at the Connecticut Department of Agriculture.

headline: Another Start for Peace Talks
text: The resumption of direct peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians this week was auspicious, despite a long history of failed attempts that fosters justifiable pessimism about the ultimate chance of success.

headline: Endorsements for New York
text: Like voters around the country, New Yorkers are angry at people in office, and they tend to be most peeved at anybody who works in Albany.

headline: Zoning Law Aside, Mosque Projects Face Battles
text: In disputes over the construction and expansion of mosques in California, New York, Tennessee and elsewhere, supporters of the projects tend to invoke constitutional principles of religious freedom.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: Kicking Off the Season
text: Can you feel the excitement? No, not about the start of the season. I’m talking about the return of the weekly pick ’em. We’re down to four prognosticators (though Thayer Evans is only a click away). And we’re not starting slow. There are plenty of unknowns heading into the first week. How will Notre Dame perform for Brian Kelly? Does Rich Rodriguex finally have his system working at Michigan? Will the preseason hype be a help or a burden for Boise State and Texas Christian? How many players will North Carolina actually suit up? There are all sorts of questions to be answered, not least of which is, which teams will win? We have our thoughts, but as always, if you agree, disagree or just want to talk about college football, feel free to comment below. Let the games begin.

headline: Bloggingheads: What Mr. Boehner Wants
text: Matthew Yglesias, left, of the Center for American Progress and Matt Welch of Reason discuss the policy agenda of a G.O.P. Congress.

headline: Louisiana: Blowout Preventer Is Removed
text: BP on Friday removed the damaged blowout preventer from atop the company’s stricken oil well in the Gulf of Mexico in preparation for the final plugging of the well, the government said. Thad W. Allen, the retired Coast Guard admiral who leads the federal response to the spill, said in a statement that the preventer  the roughly 500-ton safety device that failed in the Deepwater Horizon blowout in April  would be brought to the surface on Saturday. It will be replaced by a blowout preventer better able to handle any pressure increases that might result when a relief will is used to pump mud and cement into the well after Labor Day. The damaged blowout preventer will eventually be taken to shore and will be in the custody of investigators looking into the cause of the accident.

headline: Mother of Dead 4-Year-Old Will Face Charges of Drug Possession and Assault
text: The mother of a 4-year-old girl who weighed 15 pounds when she was found dead in her family’s apartment this week has been arrested on charges that include assault, endangering the welfare of a child and drug possession, the authorities said Friday.

headline: Holiday on Monday Labor Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: Nadal Falters but Advances in a Tough Victory
text: When Denis Istomin looks back at his second-round match against top-seeded Rafael Nadal, he will remember an exquisite skid mark. So will the new legion of fans he gained at the United States Open on Friday night.

headline: What to Watch on Saturday at the Open
text: If low-risk, high-percentage tennis is your thing, by all means skip the match between Gael Monfils and Janko Tipsarevic. These two are river boat gamblers in tennis shorts who know one — and only one — way to play the game: all in.

headline: George Hitchcock, Kayak Magazine Founder, Dies at 96
text: George Hitchcock, whose poetry magazine, Kayak, born in the cultural ferment of the 1960s, was one of the most distinctive, eagerly read literary journals of its time, died on Aug. 27 at his home in Eugene, Ore. He was 96.

headline: South Korea’s Foreign Minister Offers Resignation
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Foreign Minister Yu Myung-hwan of South Korea offered to resign on Saturday amid allegations that his ministry bent its regulations to hire his daughter during a period of high unemployment.

headline: With Eye Offshore, Storm Diminishes
text: CHATHAM, Mass. — A diminished Tropical Storm Earl slapped at Nantucket and the outer reaches of Cape Cod early Saturday but left barely a hint of damage, allowing coastal homeowners and vacationers to exhale as the Labor Day weekend got underway.

headline: Rosenfels Cleared for Landing With Giants
text: The Giants, not comfortable with Rhett Bomar as the primary backup to Eli Manning, acquired Sage Rosenfels from the Vikings on Friday.

headline: Classic Ad: At Home on the Road
text: With the Labor Day holiday weekend upon us, the Automobiles section turns, appropriately enough, to recreational vehicles. Larry Edsall’s profile of Ken Faber, a collector of vintage R.V.’s, notes that this year is the 100th anniversary of the first auto-related camping vehicles, which were first built commercially in 1910.

headline: 2 Bombings Kill 10 People in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Ten Afghans, including four policemen, were killed Saturday in two separate bombings, in the cities of Kunduz and Kandahar, NATO and local government officials said.

headline: Urban Forager | Shrubbery You Can Drink
text: Back in July, on a meditation weekend at the Omega Institute in Rhinebeck, N.Y., I spied flaming-red bunches of sumac fruit standing out from the branches of a tree like tiki torches.

headline: Open House, Day 6: Plot Twists, Oudin II and Other Red Herrings of Week One
text: Michael Kimmelman, the Times’s chief art critic, and Gerry Marzorati, editor of the Sunday Magazine, are covering the Open from uncommon perspectives. Each morning, they discuss what’s happening. Join the conversation — or ask a fan-oriented question — by sending in a comment.

headline: Rahmism
text: Jon Cohn’s post about what the administration may be considering, and what it isn’t considering, makes we want to cry.

headline: Historical Statistics
text: Some readers have asked where I get the numbers that go into posts like this. The answer is the Millennial Edition of Historical Statistics of the United States. It’s a spectacular source. The bad news is that it’s paywalled. But if you’re at a university, or have access some other way — I guess there’s a print edition too, which libraries might have — it’s great.

headline: Want to Cut Your Baggage Fees? Try a Hotel
text: Now that checked bag fees seem here to stay, two hotel companies have decided to build promotions around them to provide travelers some relief.

text: Ever wonder if new golf balls bought on sale in September will still be as good as new the following spring or summer? Ever wonder if new balls bought two or three years ago have lost any of their distance or performance capabilities?

text: Ashley Fisher began the year hoping to win his first Grand Slam doubles title. But injury, and surgery on both knees, forced him to consider other options. Sidelined at 34, he’s now trying to coach his way to a United States Open championship.

text: The prospect of a lockout in 2011 is looming over the N.F.L., as ominous as some supersize dirigible hovering over an outdoor stadium, casting a dark shadow and making unpleasant whirring noises.

headline: Prospering in a Recession, the Open Bucks a Trend
text: Nearly every sports team and tournament has been hit by the slowdown in corporate and consumer spending during the past two years. Then there is the United States Open, which continues to reel in record crowds, high-end sponsors, and hefty merchandise and food sales.

headline: Coaches Take More Risks, but Perhaps Not Enough
text: When Dan Fouts played for the San Diego Chargers in the early 1980s, the N.F.L. was so conservative that Don Coryell’s offense  Air Coryell  started a revolution merely by throwing on early downs because defenses were so predictably anticipating a run.

headline: The Perils Of Government By Poll, 30s Edition
text: In light of the way we actually got out of the Great Depression, it’s instructive — and depressing — to look at polling from that era. Two results from Gallup, in March 1938:

headline: In the N.F.L. on Fourth Down, Romer Says Go for It
text: David H. Romer is a respected economist whose ideas influence central bankers and governments hoping to pull out of a recession. He was an early adviser to the Obama campaign along with his wife and frequent collaborator, Christina, who spent the last two years as President Obama’s chief economist.

headline: Prospect for Knicks Is a Surprise for Russia
text: ANKARA, Turkey  An international scout for the last 15 years, Kevin Wilson said that no matter how politically incorrect it is, he engages in profiling when analyzing European players.

headline: Diagramless Ready to be Served
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Whenever I mention that solving a diagramless crossword gives a special kind of thrill you don’t get from the normal kind, people look at me funny. Trust me. Or just be brave. You need to exercise a different set of mental muscles, but the satisfaction level when it starts to come together is high. Check the notepad for symmetry and starting square hints unless you’re already a pro.

headline: New Program for Buyers, With No Money Down
text: MILWAUKEE  When the housing bubble burst, one of the culprits, economists agreed, was exotic mortgages, including those that required little or no money down.

headline: For Ellis, a Long, Strange Trip to a No-Hitter
text: When Rich Harden of the Texas Rangers came off the disabled list last month to pitch six and two-thirds innings without allowing a hit, interrupted by his manager rather than the Minnesota Twins, it was a further devaluation of one of baseball’s most hallowed currencies: the no-hitter.

headline: More Seek Seasoning Before Move to the Pros
text: Providence pushed Beatrice Capra deep into the first week of the United States Open and a position as untenable as the space between the service line and baseline on the tennis court.

headline: Afghanistan Tries to Help Nation’s Biggest Bank
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a bid to fend off the threat of a nationwide financial crisis, the Afghan government scrambled to shore up Afghanistan’s largest bank on Saturday after lines of frantic depositors mobbed the bank for a third day.

headline: Florida’s High-Speed Answer to a Foreclosure Mess
text: TEN days from now, a four-bedroom house on a cul-de-sac in Middleburg, Fla., is scheduled to be auctioned off at the Clay County courthouse, 25 miles south of Jacksonville.

headline: Giants’ Tuck Is Starting to Spread the Word
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  At the Giants’ practice facility is an enormous photograph, not quite in sepia but evoking the feeling that it was taken long ago. It captured Justin Tuck and Osi Umenyiora crunching Patriots quarterback Tom Brady, a reminder of a 2007 season when the Giants’ defense was magical, not maligned; when Tuck was one of the pass rushers engineering a Super Bowl upset, not the one who stood up at halftime of a humiliating season-ending loss to Minnesota to implore his teammates to summon some pride.

headline: Santana Throws and Says He Feels Fine
text: CHICAGO — The left-handed pitcher Johan Santana played catch in the outfield for about 10 minutes at Wrigley Field on Saturday morning and said he felt good enough to throw off the mound in the bullpen Sunday. If all goes well with that, he said, he expects to make his next scheduled start for the Mets on Tuesday against the Nationals in Washington.

headline: Earthquake Rocks New Zealand
text: The initial quake, which lasted up to 40 seconds, sent two people to hospital with serious injuries from debris.  New Zealand's second biggest city, Christchurch, is now under a state of emergency.

headline: Ryder List in Pocket, and Close to Vest
text: NORTON, Mass.  Corey Pavin’s list was in his back pocket, folded with edges as sharp as the crease in his tailored pants. On it were the names of the 20 or so golfers he had been talking to at the Deutsche Bank Championship. Eight of them have qualified for the United States Ryder Cup team by points; the rest would like to make it as one of the four captain’s selections.

headline: Tempered Storm Scrapes Coast of New England
text: CHATHAM, Mass. — A diminished Tropical Storm Earl left barely a hint of damage after slapping at Nantucket and the outer reaches of Cape Cod early Saturday, allowing coastal vacationers and business owners to exhale as a blue-sky Labor Day weekend got under way.

headline: As Veterans Leave, Astros Establish a Younger Core
text: As the general manager of the Houston Astros, Ed Wade traded the ace pitcher Roy Oswalt to the Phillies in late July. Oswalt has pitched brilliantly for Philadelphia, which is nothing new for former Astros. Another, closer Brad Lidge, propelled the Phillies to the 2008 World Series title.

headline: In Middle East Peace Talks, Clinton Faces a Crucial Test
text: WASHINGTON  For much of her tenure as secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton has been less an architect than an advocate for the Obama administration’s Middle East policy. With the resumption of direct talks last week, she now has no choice but to plunge into the rough and tumble of peacemaking.

headline: Mining Story Lines in the New N.F.L. Season
text: You know about Favre and McNabb, both Mannings and Revis, Haynesworth, Tebow and Ochocinco. If you did not look carefully, you might think the N.F.L. was an eight-man league, with the most successful, marketable or comical stars receiving all the attention.

headline: Educational Gaps Limit Brazil’s Reach
text: CAETÉS, Brazil  When Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva was sworn in as Brazil’s president in early 2003, he emotionally declared that he had finally earned his “first diploma” by becoming president of the country.

headline: Ballads Born of Conflict Still Thrive in Colombia
text: EL RETORNO, Colombia  He arrived at this town on the edge of guerrilla territory with his entourage. They included a producer, a sound man, two scantily clad dancers and a harried servant, who carried his cowboy hat, his snakeskin boots, his tequila and, of course, his bling: a bulky gold necklace emblazoned with the name of Uriel Henao.

headline: Stadium Renovation Part of Martin’s Legacy at Michigan
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — When the local businessman Bill Martin agreed to become Michigan’s interim director of athletics in March of 2000, he inherited a budget deficit and facilities that some coaches privately described as crumbling and antique.

headline: The House That Fischer Bought
text: Though a D.N.A. test has shown that a Filipino girl was not the child of the late chess champion Bobby Fischer, the girl’s mother and her lawyer in the Philippines have continued to argue that the girl, Jinky, is entitled to part of Mr. Fischer’s estate.

headline: Colombia's Prohibited Ballads
text: Uriel Henao is the king of the corridos prohibidos. His music documents the dark side of Colombian society.

headline: Jobs and Politics
text: The August employment report, released Friday, was not as bad as economists had forecast. Unfortunately, exceeding low expectations and making progress are not the same thing. Yet, speaking from the Rose Garden after the report was released, President Obama said the economy was moving in a “positive direction.”

headline: Border News
text: A nonpartisan study on illegal immigrants in the United States came out Wednesday. Here is the gist: Unauthorized immigration peaked three years ago, and is sharply receding. It is declining all over, but especially in housing-bust states like Florida, Nevada and Virginia.

headline: In Search of a Bedbug Solution
text: As bedbugs proliferate once again in New York City and other major urban areas, it is tempting to pray for a technological miracle to zap the pests into extinction. Alas, there is none. Frustrated New Yorkers and other victims will have to rely on an array of techniques that can often be costly, cumbersome, time-consuming  and only partially effective.

headline: After Bargains of Recession, Air Fares Soar
text: Air fares have marched steadily upward in recent months and are now close to pre-recession levels  and that’s not even counting all the fees that airlines have introduced lately.

headline: No Risk, Says Leader of Spill Response
text: Crews hoisted the blowout preventer that once sat atop BP’s stricken well to the surface of the Gulf of Mexico on Saturday night, and the federal leader of the spill response said that there was no longer any risk that the well might leak again.

headline: Resurgent Sharapova Brings Capra Back to Earth
text: Maria Sharapova’s familiar guttural shriek cut through the rippling wind, reminding her doe-eyed opponent, Beatrice Capra, that the tennis court is no place for mercy, and certainly not sympathy.

text: Ilya Kovalchuk’s two-month contract drama finally ended at 3 a.m. Saturday. The Devils got Kovalchuk, an elite 27-year-old forward, on their second try. Kovalchuk got a lot of money. Gary Bettman, the N.H.L. commissioner, got some peace of mind.

headline: Old Coaches Reside at Intersection of Life and Football
text: The questions had been carefully prepared long before I was escorted into the office of Paul W. Bryant, head football coach of the University of Alabama Crimson Tide, just after the start of the 1979 season. That was a good thing, because when I was invited to take a seat on the couch opposite his desk, a very soft cushion and the laws of gravity combined to create the first of several problems.

headline: The Poodle Speaks
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Pettitte and Rodriguez Make Progress as Yankees Keep Winning
text: As the grounds crew raked the pitcher’s mound and watered the infield, and as Reggie Jackson cleared every last particle of dirt off home plate, a cleaning staff wiped down seats that would not be filled for another three hours. On this day, the most important event at Yankee Stadium was closed to the public. Had the Yankees opened the gates at 10 a.m., fans would have streamed in.

headline: Woods Has an Up Day but Is Still Far Behind
text: NORTON, Mass.  In the on-again-off-again golf world of Tiger Woods, the question that follows him daily is whether he has resurrected his game and is ready to reclaim his kingdom, or he is still aimlessly astray and wandering alone in the dark.

headline: Freedom’s Just Another Word
text: AMONG the few scraps of news to emerge from Barack Obama’s vacation was the anecdote of a Martha’s Vineyard bookseller handing him an advance copy of Jonathan Franzen’s new novel, “Freedom.” The book has since rocketed up the Amazon best-seller list, powered by reviews even more ecstatic than those for Franzen’s last novel, “The Corrections.” But I doubt that the president, a fine writer who draws sustenance from great American writers, has read “Freedom” yet. If he had, he never would have delivered that bloodless speech on Tuesday night.

headline: His Corporate Strategy: The Scientific Method
text: SAN DIEGO

headline: Superbroke, Superfrugal, Superpower?
text: In recent years, I have often said to European friends: So, you didn’t like a world of too much American power? See how you like a world of too little American power  because it is coming to a geopolitical theater near you. Yes, America has gone from being the supreme victor of World War II, with guns and butter for all, to one of two superpowers during the cold war, to the indispensable nation after winning the cold war, to “The Frugal Superpower” of today. Get used to it. That’s our new nickname. American pacifists need not worry any more about “wars of choice.” We’re not doing that again. We can’t afford to invade Grenada today.

headline: BB? AAA? Disclosure Tells Us More
text: FOR investors who believe the credit rating agencies have escaped responsibility for sins committed during the mortgage mayhem, the wrist slap last week of Moody’s Investors Service by the Securities and Exchange Commission was just the last in a long line of missed opportunities.

headline: Dusty Baker’s House of Cool
text: ST. LOUIS –- Dusty Baker was talking about Joey Votto, which is something he does a lot these days. Votto, the Cincinnati Reds’ first baseman, is hitting .324 with 32 homers and 98 runs batted in, ranking no lower than fourth in all those Triple Crown categories.

headline: Deliveryman Is Shot Dead, Apparently From a Roof
text: A 39-year-old man driving on his bread delivery route through Brooklyn on Friday night was killed after bullets apparently fired by someone on a building’s rooftop pierced the ceiling of his work van and struck him in the head, the police said.

headline: Craigslist Blocks Access to ‘Adult Services’ Pages
text: Craigslist, the popular Web site for classified ads, has blocked access to its “adult services” section and replaced the link with a black label showing the word “censored.”

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 5
text: It’s midterm election talk as usual on the Sunday shows, as the network hosts and their guests shape their discussions around the economy, the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, and Mideast diplomacy.

headline: Learn to Lead From the Back of the Boat
text: This interview with Anne Berkowitch, co-founder and chief executive of SelectMinds, a social networking company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Online Giving Meets Social Networking
text: LATE last month, tens of thousands of runners who are registered for this year’s New York City Marathon got an e-mail from Mary Wittenberg, the president and chief executive of New York Road Runners.

headline: Simon Will Meet New Son — as Soon as He Loses
text: Resurgent after a year of injuries and doubt, Gilles Simon has put himself back into the third round of the United States Open, where he will face No. 1-seeded Rafael Nadal on Sunday.

headline: Number One!
text: Really. Via Barry Ritholtz, Wikio — using a Pagerank-type methodology — ranks this as the top business blog.

headline: America’s History of Fear
text: A radio interviewer asked me the other day if I thought bigotry was the only reason why someone might oppose the Islamic center in Lower Manhattan. No, I don’t. Most of the opponents aren’t bigots but well-meaning worriers  and during earlier waves of intolerance in American history, it was just the same.

headline: N.F.L. Preview: N.F.C. South
text: The N.F.L. has planned a parade in New Orleans on Thursday, the day of the season opener, which is a good way to remind the Saints that the party is over. As loaded as they remain, the Saints will have to guard against complacency and the fact that every opponent that will be trying to take down the champions. The Saints’ task will be made easier by the virtually intact offense of Drew Brees and his nearly unstoppable passing game. Brees was transcendent in the Super Bowl, and the Saints led the league in points last season. They also topped the league in scoring differential, despite a defense that finished 20th in points allowed. We will know plenty about the way the Saints handle the hangover when they open against Minnesota in an N.F.C. championship game rematch. After that, the schedule is manageable enough to at least ensure a return playoff trip, if not the division title.

headline: In an Age of Voices, Moving Beyond the Facts
text: WHAT some call opinion, others call interpretive journalism  a label as opaque as the practice. Call it what you will, nothing has generated more reader indignation in the past few weeks than when it has appeared on a news page.

headline: A Strong Password Isn’t the Strongest Security
text: MAKE your password strong, with a unique jumble of letters, numbers and punctuation marks. But memorize it  never write it down. And, oh yes, change it every few months.

headline: Resentment Simmers in Western Chinese Region
text: URUMQI, China  The five-star hotels are full, bulldozers are making quick work of dreary slums and billboards for “French-style villas” call out to the nouveau riche. In the year since rioting between the Han and Uighur ethnic groups killed nearly 200 people in this city in far western China, life appears to be returning to normal.

headline: A Course Load for the Game of Life
text: AS a Harvard professor who teaches introductory economics, I have the delightful assignment of greeting about 700 first-year students every fall. And this year, I am sending the first of my own children off to college. Which raises these questions: What should they be learning? And what kind of foundation is needed to understand and be prepared for the modern economy?

headline: Are Investors Unfair to U.S. Stock Funds?
text: INVESTORS have been fleeing stock funds in droves, moving their money into bond portfolios, the headlines tell us. But while there is some truth in these reports, they don’t provide a complete picture.

headline: Boise State Dreams of Title and Hopes the System Works
text: On Monday night, No. 3 Boise State will begin to chase its championship dream when it faces No. 10 Virginia Tech at FedEx Field in Landover, Md.

headline: People and Places That Innovate
text: INNOVATION is one of the most seductive words in the business world. It conjures up visions of bold new products and processes, entrepreneurial heroism, market leadership and big financial rewards. Small wonder, then, that the study of innovation has attracted all manner of executives, scholars, government officials and other curious observers.

headline: Dr. King’s Newest Marcher
text: Baltimore

headline: Mejia Shows Inexperience And Promise In a Defeat
text: CHICAGO  For the first four innings, the combination of a 20-year-old making his first major league start and a 27-year-old catcher making his big-league debut was working fine.

headline: The Restless Soul in the Bathroom Mirror
text: EVERY so often it happens. You’re standing in front of the bathroom mirror and a momentous life question hits you.

headline: Anything Is Possible
text: I WAS born in Haiphong, North Vietnam. When I was 7, my family moved to South Vietnam. I had 10 brothers and sisters, so it was a struggle to attend school because of the fees. I managed to graduate from college with a degree in literature and foreign languages.

headline: Monfils Ousts Roddick’s Conqueror
text: It’s a good guess Janko Tipsarevic is hoping he won’t run into Andy Roddick anytime soon. After the Serbian upset Roddick in Ashe Stadium Wednesday night, the two met to shake hands at the net, where the former champion told Tipsarevic — who had also upset Roddick in Wimbledon’s second round in 2008 — that anything less than a deep run in the 2010 U.S. Open would be unacceptable.

headline: Discordant Parts Find Harmony at the Open
text: In the online feature Open House, Michael Kimmelman, the chief art critic and Abroad columnist for The Times, is covering the United States Open in a series of video and blog posts on the Straight Sets blog. Here are excerpts from Kimmelman’s first week at Flushing Meadows.

headline: Robert Schimmel, Comic, Dies at 60
text: Robert Schimmel, a comedian who specialized in taboo-breaking humor of the sexual and scatological variety, died on Friday at a Phoenix hospital, where he was being treated for injuries suffered in an Aug. 26 car accident. He was 60.

headline: Raimon Panikkar, Catholic Theologian, Is Dead at 91
text: Raimon Panikkar, a Roman Catholic theologian whose embrace of Hindu scriptures and Buddhism made him an influential voice for promoting dialogue among the world’s religions, died on Aug. 26 at his home in Tavertet, Spain. He was 91.

headline: Mick Lally, Irish Actor and Founder of the Druid Theater, Dies at 64
text: Mick Lally, a popular Irish actor who helped found the Druid Theater, a troupe in Galway that gained international exposure with productions of native plays, especially by J. M. Synge and Martin McDonagh, died on Tuesday in Dublin. He was 64.

headline: Larry Ashmead, Editor With an Eye for Talent, Dies at 78
text: A 9-year-old boy once visited his local library in Rochester to hear a mystery writer read from her book. But what particularly thrilled him was to learn that the author had a day job as an editor sitting in a Manhattan skyscraper reading manuscripts.

headline: Frank C. Garland, 60, Who Connected Vitamin D Deficiency and Cancer, Dies
text: Frank C. Garland, an epidemiologist whose work helped establish a link between vitamin D deficiency and some cancers, including colon and breast cancer, died on Aug. 17 in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 60 and lived in San Diego.

headline: Computers as Invisible as the Air
text: THE personal computer is vanishing.

headline: Is Islamophobia the New Hysteria?
text: My Sunday column is about the long history of fear-mongering about newcomers and non-traditional religious faiths. As I write in the column, we have a glorious tradition of amity and religious freedom and tolerance — and also an inglorious history of intolerance and persecution. In the past it was directed most famously at Catholics, Mormons, Jews, Chinese, Japanese, Germans, Irish, Italians, Swedes, Poles and just about every other group.

A culinary tour of 14 combat dining packages served to soldiers in Afghanistan.

headline: A Taste of Home in Foil Packets and Powder

headline: Japanese Language Program Falls Victim to Economy
text: The only open-enrollment Japanese language program in the city’s high schools will no longer exist. The courses, at Percy L. Julian High School on the far South Side, are a casualty of budget cuts and teacher layoffs in Chicago Public Schools.

headline: Pyramid Redwood Park
text: Tucked next to San Francisco’s tallest building in the Financial District is an oasis of evergreens, ferns, flowers and fountains. As one of the most popular privately owned public open spaces  known as Popos  in the city, Pyramid Redwood Park provides a lunchtime sanctuary for white-collar workers.

headline: Rap and Hip-Hop, Now Accented With Jazz
text: When fans attend a performance by the Chicago rap stars Common or Kanye West (or, for that matter, the hip-hop princess Beyoncé or the neo-soul crooner Maxwell), they expect certain things: powerful choreography, glitzy peripherals like lights and props and the headliner on video screens in gigantic detail.

headline: In Troubled Area, Students Have a Safety Net
text: At 7:20 a.m. Wednesday, Elizabeth Cazares and her 10-year-old daughter, Lesly, stood in front of a liquor store in the Tenderloin district, waiting for one of Lesly’s fifth-grade classmates to join them and walk to school.

headline: Despite Talk, Potential Rivals for Daley Stand Back
text: Many Chicago political axioms have come under assault from reformers and federal prosecutors in recent years, including “Where’s mine?” and “We don’t want nobody nobody sent.” But “You can’t beat somebody with nobody” remains as true as ever with the 2011 mayoral election less than six months away.

headline: Many High-Paid Public Workers Live Elsewhere
text: Morris Tabak, assistant chief of the San Francisco Police Department, is one of the highest-paid employees San Francisco has ever had.

text: The slimmed-down Mardy Fish continued his hot summer on Saturday with an exhausting 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, 1-6, 6-3 third-round victory over Arnaud Clement of France at the United States Open.

headline: Paul Conrad, Cartoonist, Dies at 86
text: In the Watergate scandal, he drew Richard M. Nixon nailing himself to a cross. He stood Dick Cheney at a vast graveyard of veterans, saying, “For seven years, we did everything to keep you safe.” And on the frieze over the Supreme Court, he etched the hallowed words: “Of the insurance co’s. By the insurance co’s. And for the insurance co’s.”

headline: Obama to Pitch Permanent Research Tax Credit
text: WASHINGTON  As part of his pre-election push to spur the slumping economy and his party, President Obama this week will ask Congress to increase and permanently extend a popular but costly tax credit for businesses’ research expenses, and to pay for it by closing other corporate tax breaks, according to administration officials.

headline: After a Life in Labor, a Union Leader Retires, Frustrated by the Movement’s Troubles
text: WASHINGTON  After 38 years as a gung ho trade unionist, Anna Burger is retiring  with unmistakable frustration  from her post as the highest-ranking woman in American labor movement history.

headline: Vazquez Upset With Early Exit
text: A rather eventful day in Yankee-land Saturday began with Alex Rodriguez and Andy Pettitte facing each other in a simulated game; continued with Javier Vazquez laboring through four and two-thirds innings in his return to the rotation; and, at least on the field, came to an end after everything went the Yankees’ way in a crazy seventh inning.

headline: God and Politics, Together Again
text: IT took only a day for a massive exercise in unity to become the latest salvo in the culture wars.

headline: Winning Over New Fans by Speeding Up the Game
text: Many people who would like to see chess attract more fans agree that traditional games  which usually last several hours  are too slow for all but the die-hard.

headline: N.F.L. Preview: N.F.C. West
text: Did 49ers Coach Mike Singletary annoy someone in the scheduling office? The Niners open with three of their first four games on the road, with the home game against the Saints. Still, this is a team on the rise after finishing 8-8 last season, coupling a premier N.F.L. defense (fourth best in points allowed in 2009) with the hope that quarterback Alex Smith will make a big leap by playing the same offense for two consecutive years. Smith is surrounded by plenty of talent, including tight end Vernon Davis and the emerging receiver Michael Crabtree. Do not look for Smith to finally get to use the spread offense he prefers, though. Singletary wants to be an old-school, smash-mouth team — he defined that style as a player — and the Niners upgraded their offensive line in the draft to that end. Their schedule will not make it easy — they also play a “home” game in London and play the Cardinals twice late in the season — but the Niners should get above .500 for the first time since 2002, and that may be enough to win the division.

headline: Confronting the Power of the Natural World at Telluride
text: TELLURIDE, Colo.— One of the open-air panels at the Telluride film festival this year is called “Human/Nature,” about how filmmakers address the natural world, and it’s an apt subject, both because of the festival’s setting and because of one of the themes that links a number of selections in the program. Nestled in a high mountain valley surrounded by jagged, soaring peaks, Telluride, a former mining town, frequently upstages the movies on its screens, at least as far as sheer visual sublimity is concerned.

headline: Back Then: 1960
text: Hurricane Earl menaced the eastern seaboard in the last few days from Okracoke, N.C., to Nantucket, Mass. Almost exactly 50 years ago, Hurricane Donna devastated the Atlantic Coast, killing 116 people, mostly in Puerto Rico, pictured above. An article in The Times from Sept. 11, 1960, reported on the fate of Humacao, Puerto Rico:

headline: At Michigan, a Day of Record Numbers
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  No matter how he approached his analysis of Saturday’s 30-10 loss to Michigan, Connecticut Coach Randy Edsall kept coming back to Denard Robinson. After watching Robinson, a sophomore, break the Michigan record for rushing yards in a game by a quarterback with 197 in his first start, Edsall declared Robinson not just the difference in the game, but the difference on his team.

headline: Prime Number
text: 77.8: The average temperature in New York City for June through August, making it officially the hottest summer on record, according to the National Weather Service. The period passed quietly, without a cataclysmic event, like a mass blackout.

headline: Taming the Wild Tuna
text: IN the wide expanse of the wild ocean, there is perhaps nothing more wild than the world’s largest tuna  the giant Atlantic bluefin. Equipped with a kind of natural GPS system that biologists have yet to decode, the bluefin can cross and recross the Atlantic’s breadth multiple times in the course of its life. Its furious metabolism enables the fish to sprint at more than 40 miles an hour, heat its muscles 20 degrees above ambient, and hunt relentlessly at frigid depths in excess of 1,500 feet.

text: ST. LOUIS

headline: Leinart, With Career Full of Disappointment, Is Now Without Team
text: Four years ago, Matt Leinart stared into space, his megawatt smile dimmed by a 90-minute tumble through the draft, leaving him contemplating the twist in a klieg-lighted career that had included two college national championships and a Heisman Trophy. Leinart would almost certainly have been the first overall pick if he had left Southern California a year earlier, but on that day at Radio City Music Hall in New York, he could only drop his head into his hand when the Arizona Cardinals finally plucked him from his anxiety with the 10th overall pick.

headline: Prosecutors Detail Abuse in Brooklyn Girl’s Last Days
text: Two days after the bruised, emaciated body of a 4-year-old girl was discovered in a Brooklyn apartment, new information from officials emerged about her life and death as her mother on Saturday made her first appearance in court to face criminal charges.

headline: Day and Snedeker Lead After Second Round at Deutsche Bank
text: NORTON, Mass.  Brandt Snedeker, who missed the cut last week at the Barclays, shot his way to a tie at the top of the Deutsche Bank Championship on Saturday with a 64 that was the best score in a windswept second round at the T.P.C. Boston. It was the latest example of how “where there’s life, there’s hope” could be the working theme for the PGA Tour’s FedEx Cup playoffs.

headline: Yelling ‘Bedbug’ in a Crowded Festival
text: Last week, the Toronto International Film Festival dodged a bullet — or a Tweet, to be exact —fired by a film critic claiming that one of its major theatrical venues had a bedbug problem, according to The Globe and Mail newspaper. The news ricocheted around the film community, appearing on news and gossip sites like The Hollywood Reporter and Perez.Hilton.com. Not exactly the kind of publicity festival organizers had in mind — not when the event pulls in more than $162 million in revenue for the city. Bringing in the bedbug experts, organizers announced in Tweets that the theater had received a clean bill of health from city officials. With the rumor mill running at the speed of Twitter, it took days to set the record straight and avert potential disaster.

headline: Few Visitors in Boise, to Broncos’ Chagrin
text: The first month of a college football season is filled with teams from lesser-known conferences traveling to play teams from powerful ones. They are known as guarantee games, in which the road teams receive a guaranteed paycheck and often a guaranteed loss.

headline: L.S.U.’s Dual Threat Puts on a Show
text: ATLANTA — It seems like a risky move for a team to use its star cornerback, an All-American candidate no less, as a kick returner. But Louisiana State is doing just that with Patrick Peterson, exposing him in the open field to gunners on coverage teams and opening up the possibility that his knees could be wrecked.

headline: N.F.L. Preview: N.F.C. North
text: Watching Favre-a-thon 2010 unfold, the Packers might have stifled a giggle. They should not even pay attention. Green Bay is a Super Bowl-caliber team no matter what Favre does because General Manager Ted Thompson made the right bet at the right time on Aaron Rodgers, who is one of the top five quarterbacks in the league and looked particularly sharp in the preseason. If his line does not get Rodgers killed, the way it nearly did early last season, the offense will again be one of the most productive in the N.F.L. (The Packers were third in points scored last season.) The defense was seventh in points allowed, and although Al Harris and Charles Woodson are among the best cornerback tandems in the league, they are each at least 33 and injuries are taking a toll. Harris (knee) is on the physically unable to perform list and unavailable for at least six games. The best news for the Packers is that the schedule offers a relatively easy first six games before they play the Vikings, the Jets and the Cowboys in a row. After a bye, they face the Vikings, the Falcons and the 49ers.

headline: Forcier Unhappy After Not Playing for Michigan
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Michigan may have found this year’s starting quarterback and lost last year’s in a matter of hours Saturday.

headline: The Fans Cheer Loudly, but Blake Goes Quietly
text: A gusting wind that could have been mistaken for an ill wind was sending stray wrappers and napkins zipping through the air like Frisbees. But this was no picnic ground with a storm coming in. This was Arthur Ashe Stadium, the place where James Blake has played some of his most meaningful and convincing tennis, the place where he was honored for his perseverance and fortitude on the opening night of this United States Open.

headline: Dropping Jaws and Stopping Conversations in a Test-Drive
text: For the past three weeks I have been baby-sitting a robot. It is not your traditional looking robot  if there is such a thing yet  but looks like an extra-large lollipop on wheels.

headline: The Boss Is Robotic, and Rolling Up Behind You
text: SACRAMENTO  Dr. Alan Shatzel’s pager beeped at 9 on a Saturday morning. A man had suffered a stroke, and someone had to decide, quickly, whether to give him an anticlotting drug that could mean the difference between life and death.

headline: Democrats Plan Political Triage to Retain House
text: WASHINGTON  As Democrats brace for a November wave that threatens their control of the House, party leaders are preparing a brutal triage of their own members in hopes of saving enough seats to keep a slim grip on the majority.

text: Images from the first Saturday of the college football season.

headline: Short-Handed Tar Heels Rally but Fall Short
text: ATLANTA  North Carolina Coach Butch Davis has been under scrutiny for days for a scandal involving academics and agents that has rocked his program. Some words used to describe affairs in Chapel Hill were humiliation and embarrassment. There have been calls for Davis to step down and for the program to regain a balance between academics and athletics.

headline: Rock Bottom? France May Not Be Done Digging
text: It turns out all of us were wrong. Things could get worse for France.

text: Ukraine versus Spain usually means two guys anchored to the baseline blasting ground strokes at one another for hours on end — but not Sergiy Stakhovsky and Feliciano Lopez.
