text: The tournament is a qualifying event to select for the Grand Slam Final in Spain next month.

headline: Vows: William & Kim
text: Born half a world apart, it was the opera that brought William Ferguson and Kim Smith, both singers, together in Melbourne, Australia.

headline: Sounds of Africa Take Over London’s Stages
text: Fortunate in having one of Europe’s most vibrant African communities, London has long been a great place to hear music played by African musicians from all over the world. And for the last seven years, Londoners have been able to count on the London African Music Festival to organize an exciting and varied program of concerts and workshops, some of them free, all over the city.

headline: A Voice From the Next Offshore Oil Frontier
text: On Thursday, Interior Secretary Ken Salazar had a meeting with the only people  outside the gulf region whose waters had been opened to offshore oil exploration. He was in Barrow, Alaska, the capital of the North Slope Borough, where people have the same conflicted feelings about the oil industry as residents of the gulf states do. The energy industry centered in Prudhoe Bay is the economic engine of the North Slope, helping preserve the Inupiat culture, but it also presents a potential threat to that culture. Mayor Edward Itta of the North Slope Borough e-mailed answers to our questions about these conflicts. (The transcript of the exchange has been edited and condensed.)

headline: What’s Your Threshold for Wrong Charges?
text: I check my checking and credit card account statements nearly every day to make sure there are no fraudulent charges. For me, no amount is too small to fight — whether it’s the $300 in fraudulent debit card charges I noticed last month or more recently, a $10.95 “travel center” charge I realized I mistakenly made.

headline: What to Watch at the Open on Sunday, Junior Edition
text: If you want a humbling experience, head out to the field courts Sunday as the U.S. Open junior championship begins and try to pick out the next Ryan Harrison, Melanie Oudin or Beatrice Capra. Two years ago, you would have found America’s current sweethearts all playing in obscurity, in front of hundreds, not thousands, of people in the juniors tournament.

headline: Attack Shows Lasting Threat to U.S. in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  Insurgents mounted a coordinated attack on one of the main military commands in Baghdad on Sunday, briefly drawing fire from American soldiers, an event that underscored the ambiguity of the American military’s role in Iraq.

headline: N.F.L. Preview: A.F.C. East
text: It has been a long time since their rival in New England did not enter the season as the A.F.C. East favorite, but the Jets may engineer a hostile takeover. If the new cornerback Antonio Cromartie can return to his 2007 form and Darrelle Revis ends his holdout, the Jets will have the best secondary, and the best defense, in football. The first-team offense struggled in the preseason; Mark Sanchez still makes too many mistakes, and the offensive line looked spotty. But the surprise was how much life appeared in LaDainian Tomlinson’s legs. The real issue is that with so many big mouths and big egos, the Jets have raised expectations wildly and made themselves a target. In a closely bunched division, how well all those big names work together may determine whether the Jets are a well-publicized boom or bust.

headline: Open House, Day 7: Why Don’t Doubles-Loving Fans Watch Live Doubles?
text: Michael Kimmelman, the Times’s chief art critic, and Gerry Marzorati, editor of the Sunday Magazine, are covering the Open from uncommon perspectives. Each morning, they discuss what’s happening. Join the conversation — or ask a fan-oriented question — by sending in a comment.

headline: Follow the Open via Twitter, Sunday Edition
text: Gerry Marzorati, one-half of the Open House duo, is covering the United States Open via Twitter. Now that Sunday’s sessions are over, go directly to gerrynyt.

headline: Governor Forecasts: Understanding the Model
text: Our gubernatorial projections took a little longer than I expected. The original idea was that we could just take our Senate model, tweak a few of the parameters, and be ready to go. Indeed, our gubernatorial forecasting model shares a lot of the Senate model’s DNA. The basic blueprint of taking a robust average of polls, supplementing them with some demographic information and then using them to project the final standing of the candidates remains the same.

headline: Sunday Word: It’s All Political
text: With just over two months before the midterm elections, party leaders are solidifying their strategies and rallying their troops.

headline: N.F.L. Preview: A.F.C. North
text: The Ravens spent the off-season shoring up their offense, handing quarterback Joe Flacco the best receiving corps he has had by adding Anquan Boldin and Donte’ Stallworth, who recently broke his foot but is expected to return in October. Combine them with running back Ray Rice’s explosiveness, and the Ravens have real scoring potential — a good thing after they managed only 3 points against the Colts in the playoffs last season. That would usually be enough to make the Ravens a Super Bowl favorite without reservation.

headline: Analysis: How Nadal Can Win in New York
text: The United States Open title has eluded Rafael Nadal, who, like Bjorn Borg before him, dominated the European clay-court season and was able to adapt to grass and win Wimbledon a few short weeks later. I would argue that Borg’s feat was the tougher one to accomplish because the grass back then played faster, the bounces were unreliable and there were also many serve-and-volleyers who reveled on the slick, low-bouncing grass, John McEnroe chief among them.

headline: Mideast Leaders Hopeful After Opening of Talks
text: JERUSALEM  Palestinian and Israeli leaders expressed satisfaction and hope on Sunday in their first public utterances after the opening round of Middle East peace talks in Washington last week.

headline: The Brooklyn Griffin Finds a Perch
text: Perched high above an industrial stretch of East Williamsburg, a menacing robot nine feet high and seven feet wide surveys the street below, watching cars steal past graffitied factory buildings as if they were prey. Its fierce head sways and dips when a wooden rudder protruding from the back of its neck catches the breeze.

headline: Rodriguez Returns to Yankees’ Lineup
text: Alex Rodriguez returned to the Yankees’ lineup Sunday for the first time since Aug. 20, but Nick Swisher missed his third consecutive game.

headline: True to Erratic Form, Murray Tumbles Out Early
text: The dire forecasts  weather and otherwise  that were supposed to rattle the United States Open field seemed to pass Sunday with little of the expected doom and gloom. The wind, which had turned Saturday into a mess, calmed by Sunday afternoon, and all seemed well until Andy Murray, the tournament’s version of Eeyore, took the court.

headline: Delusions Of Recovery
text: I’ve had a couple of conversations lately with people who follow politics and public affairs, but aren’t that close to the economic discussion — and I’ve discovered that there are two comforting delusions still out there.

headline: She’s Making History, Working For Victory
text: I was going to post this later, but I thought maybe we all needed some cheering up.

headline: N.F.L. Preview: A.F.C. West
text: When will the rest of the A.F.C. West give the Chargers a run for the division title? Not this year. For all the off-season turmoil — whither Vincent Jackson and his holdout? — San Diego has the most talent by far. The passing game, even without Jackson, is deep and explosive and figures only to get better now that teams have to pay attention to Ryan Mathews instead of LaDainian Tomlinson, who led the 31st-ranked rushing offense last season. Still, you get the feeling the window is about to close on this team. Several big names, like linebacker Shawne Merriman and returner Darren Sproles, are in their contract years, and the Chargers simply can’t keep racing through the regular season (they won their final 11 games in 2009 and have one of the easiest schedules this season) only to collapse in the playoffs. Last season’s lackluster playoff loss to the Jets might be pinned on Norv Turner’s insistence on giving the ball to Tomlinson, but the excuses, and the Chargers’ dominance, are running out. San Diego should win the division again with ease, but every other team is aggressively trying to improve in the meantime.

headline: Double Eagle Lifts Singh Into Contention
text: NORTON, Mass. — For the second time in two years, a player has scored a double-eagle on the second hole at T.P.C. Boston during the Deutsche Bank Championship. Using a 5-iron, Vijay Singh holed his shot from 230 yards on the 567-yard par 5, which is a dogleg right. Singh’s shot was nearly all over water as the second green is fronted by a large pond.

headline: Afghan Government Moves Toward Seizing Assets of Troubled Bank’s Shareholders
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government took steps on Sunday toward seizing the properties of major shareholders of the troubled Kabul Bank, as perturbed crowds and national security forces surrounded the central branch of the bank, the country’s largest.

headline: In the Heat of Camp, the Hunger of Faith
text: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  For Minnesota Vikings defensive back Husain Abdullah, the most important clock inside the Metrodome was not the one keeping time for his team’s recent preseason game with the Seattle Seahawks. Another, showing the time of day, held greater significance for him and for the Vikings’ training staff.

headline: Lessons of the Summer Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES  Christopher Nolan proved there is always room at the multiplex, even in swimsuit season, for a smart, original story. Will Ferrell bounced back. Michael Cera fell flat. Animation was the No. 1 genre. Sorry, “Sex and the City” ladies: It’s over.

headline: First Lady Eyes Return to Campaign Trail
text: Facing the prospect of massive losses in November, Congressional Democrats are issuing distress calls to the White House: Don't send President Obama, send Michelle Obama.  NBC reports.

headline: For Nevada Quarterback, an Arm That’s Almost Too Good
text: The Nevada senior quarterback Colin Kaepernick had a devastating fastball when he pitched for Pitman High School in Turlock, Calif. He threw a pair of no-hitters, and in 2009 he was drafted by the Chicago Cubs even though he had not played organized baseball for three years.

headline: Seiji Ozawa’s Return to the Stage
text: MATSUMOTO, Japan — It was not exactly the return he had hoped for, but the conductor Seiji Ozawa scored a triumph of a limited sort here at the Saito Kinen Festival on Sunday afternoon as he returned to the public stage for the first time since surgery for esophageal cancer in January.

headline: N.F.L. Preview: A.F.C. South
text: Eight of the last 11 Super Bowl losers failed to qualify for the playoffs the next season. Get serious. As long as Peyton Manning is upright, the Colts are a Super Bowl contender. Bill Polian, the Colts’ president, has surrounded Manning with superb talent, so much so that Indianapolis’s 2007 first-round draft pick, Anthony Gonzalez, could be the odd man out in a fabulous group of receivers. The offensive line has gotten much bigger with the hopes of establishing a ground game, but how much does that really matter? Manning threw 571 passes last year and was a coach’s decision from leading Indianapolis to a likely undefeated regular season. The defense, which allowed fewer than 20 points a game, should be better in Year 2 under Larry Coyer because Bob Sanders, a supremely gifted safety, is healthy again. The only problem the Colts face is that the expectations are so high, if they don’t win it all, the season will be a huge disappointment. They will reach at least the A.F.C. championship game.

headline: Former H.P. Chief May Move to Oracle
text: Mark V. Hurd, who was forced to resign as Hewlett-Packard’s top executive last month after an investigation into a sexual harassment charge found that he had manipulated his expenses, is in talks with Oracle about a top executive position there, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Rodriguez Back in Lineup, but Other Concerns Persist
text: The Yankees’ winning streak ended at a season-best eight games Sunday with Alex Rodriguez taking a called third strike.

headline: A Bronx Film School Tale
text: It was just after the long Fourth of July weekend when the Ghetto Film School assembled its 2010 fellows at its headquarters in the South Bronx, a few floors above offices of the state parole division. Introductions were made, and then the 21 teenage students eagerly took possession of high-definition video cameras and began learning how to make movies.

headline: Going to Extremes to Seek Dramatic Accuracy
text: The critics, the financial backers, the friends and the family of cast and crew came to see Paul Weitz’s comedy “Trust,” but one more interested observer needed to weigh in, and she wasn’t there to judge which lines got the biggest laughs.

headline: Mystery and Evidence
text: There is a story about Bertrand Russell giving a public lecture somewhere or other, defending his atheism. A furious woman stood up at the end of the lecture and asked: “And Lord Russell, what will you say when you stand in front of the throne of God on judgment day?” Russell replied: “I will say: ‘I’m terribly sorry, but you didn’t give us enough evidence.’ ”

headline: New CDs
text: SARA BAREILLES

headline: War Intrudes on a Man’s Bucolic Idyll
text: Tom McCarthy’s much ballyhooed first novel, “Remainder,” was an oddly ingenious book that read like the work of an extremely precocious philosophy student who had read a lot of Robbe-Grillet, Sartre, Camus, Philip K. Dick and Georges Perec.

headline: Mom-Stepmom Two Step
text: Instead of Bollywood’s usual “steal this movie” ethos, “We Are Family,” a go-for-broke weepie produced by Karan Johar, gives screen credit where screen credit is due: to the writers of the Hollywood film that it’s based upon, “Stepmom” (1998), with Susan Sarandon and Julia Roberts.

headline: The Best of the Netherlands
text: Do you fancy yourself as an analyst? If so, you are East, in four spades. South leads a low heart. How can you make the contract?

headline: It’s the Same Old Mob, Now Sampled for Gamers
text: At what point, in the name of entertainment, is it acceptable to just give up on trying to develop an original, nuanced perspective on history and instead merely embrace the clichés inherited from earlier media?

headline: Housing Woes Bring a New Cry: Let the Market Fall
text: The unexpectedly deep plunge in home sales this summer is likely to force the Obama administration to choose between future homeowners and current ones, a predicament officials had been eager to avoid.

headline: Monday: An Official Puzzle
text: PUZZLE NOTES — Who would have thought there were enough phrases starting with SATURDAY NIGHT to weave a theme around them?

headline: Body Language, Translated and Remixed
text: MONTICELLO, N.Y.  The first time Iggy and the Stooges played a concert was July 1972. They had a new guitarist, James Williamson, and had changed their name from the plain Stooges.

headline: After Offense Puts on a Show, the Mets Talk of Bowing Out
text: CHICAGO  Perhaps it was just a cruel taunt from the fates, but on their most productive day in five years, the Mets finally conceded that their hopes of reaching the playoffs are over.

headline: This Time the Trouble Isn’t Wicked Stepsisters
text: The performer-writer Ann Liv Young belongs to the movement in the arts that was labeled Sensation in the 1990s. She performed “Snow White” naked, apart from a Disney mask on her face, while heavily pregnant. Dildos and masturbation have been part of her theatrical fare. At MoMA P.S. 1 in February she insulted a fellow artist’s work (accompanied by urination and masturbation) until management turned the lights off on her. And on Friday and Saturday she performed a one-woman “Cinderella” at the Issue Project Room in Gowanus, Brooklyn. In this, as an outspoken and trashy Southerner called Sherry, she converses with members of the audience (sometimes in a quarrelsome way) and also urinates and defecates onstage.

headline: Arena Full of Fans Caught Brazilian Fever and Had to Sing Along
text: Brazil’s top pop singer, Ivete Sangalo, boldly courted a wider audience with a concert on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. According to the promoters, Caco de Telha Entertainment, she was the first Brazilian musician to headline the Garden; the show was videotaped for her next live DVD. (She recorded a previous live DVD and CD, “Multishow ao Vivo: Ivete no Maracanã,” at a Rio de Janeiro soccer stadium, so the Garden was comparatively intimate, even on the weekend of New York’s Brazilian Day festival.)

headline: All Tomorrow's Parties
text: Photos from the music festival in Monticello, N.Y.

headline: Hearing ‘Spring’ as Summer Fades
text: NEW LEBANON, N.Y.  There were both chamber music staples and rarities on Saturday night at the Tannery Pond concert hall here, a barnlike structure built by Shakers in 1834 and now an acoustically fine and charmingly rustic performance space.

headline: Bedbugs? Other Strange Invaders Threaten Much Wider Damage
text: ACRA, N.Y.

headline: Seiji Ozawa Greeted Warmly on Return to Podium
text: It was not exactly the return he had hoped for, but the conductor Seiji Ozawa scored a triumph of a limited sort at the Saito Kinen Festival in Matsumoto, Japan, on Sunday afternoon as he returned to the public stage for the first time since surgery for esophageal cancer in January. He opened a program of the festival orchestra (he was supposed to have led all of it), conducting the first movement of Tchaikovsky’s Serenade for Strings. Then, because he was experiencing sciatic problems that recurred as a byproduct of the surgery, he stepped aside to let a younger conductor, Tatsuya Shimono, take over. When Mr. Ozawa, right, took the stage, he was greeted as warmly as the politest of audiences could manage: no standing, no cheering, but loud, sustained applause. Half standing, half sitting, he delivered brief remarks from the stage, explaining his difficulties, apologizing for being unable to do more and promising to be back next year. Then he conducted the movement, mostly standing and with typically vigorous gestures. The orchestra, obviously charged up for the occasion, delivered a searingly intense performance. Rhythmic clapping broke out after the concert, directed at Mr. Ozawa in the audience, and he half ran to greet Mr. Shimono and the players onstage.

headline: Writing Spice Girls’ Story
text: The Spice Girls have a saucy writer for their musical story. Jennifer Saunders, the creator, producer and star of the tart British comedy “Absolutely Fabulous,” has been hired to write the book for the musical, “Viva Forever,” Playbill reported. It will be a “modern fable of camaraderie, love and loyalty based on the songs of the Spice Girls,” according to a statement from one of the show’s producers, Judy Craymer. Ms. Craymer, who brought the musical “Mamma Mia!” to Broadway in 2001, has been developing the production with a former manager of the band, Simon Fuller. “I’m thrilled and terrified at the same time,” Ms. Saunders said in the statement. “My daughters grew up with the Spice Girls; I had to write the book for them as well as myself.”

headline: Footnote
text: The actress and playwright Lisa Kron (“Well”) is set to host the 2010 IT Awards, which recognize the achievements of Off Off Broadway theater. Among those to be presented with awards in Cooper Union’s Great Hall on Sept. 20 are the playwright Lanford Wilson (“Talley’s Folly”), who is being honored in the artistic achievement category, and the New York Neo-Futurists, an ensemble theater group that presents the series of original short plays Too Much Light Makes the Baby Go Blind. The group will receive the Caffe Cino Fellowship Award.

headline: Dioguardi Leaves ‘Idol’
text: The songwriter Kara DioGuardi is leaving “American Idol,” the Fox singing competition, after only two seasons, setting the stage for an announcement this month about a new judging panel. One judge, Randy Jackson, is apparently still tied to the show. An overhaul of “Idol” is under way ahead of its 10th season, and the leading contenders to replace the departed Ellen DeGeneres and Simon Cowell are Jennifer Lopez and Steven Tyler. “I felt like I won the lottery when I joined ‘American Idol’ two years ago,” Ms. DioGuardi, above, said in a statement late Friday. “But I feel like now is the best time to leave ‘Idol.’ ” Her departure had been rumored since late July, when Ms. DeGeneres left. But in mid-August her father, Joseph J. DioGuardi, a Republican who is running for Senate in New York, said there had been silence from the producers. “She read it the way you did and I did,” he said in a television interview. “In fact, her disappointment is that that’s the way she’s being treated, and she feels that’s not proper.”

headline: ‘Jersey Shore’ and Disney Enjoy Ratings Success
text: Heading into the Labor Day weekend, the summer cable telecasts “Jersey Shore” and “Camp Rock 2” were the two television standouts, surpassing offerings on the broadcast networks. The sixth episode of the second “Jersey Shore” season, on MTV, had a series-high rating on Thursday, with 6.5 million total viewers. The series has been steadily gaining audience this season, and it is firmly the summer’s most popular show among viewers 12 to 34. On Friday night it was the Disney Channel’s chance to crow. Its original movie “Camp Rock 2: The Final Jam,” starring Demi Lovato and the Jonas Brothers, drew eight million viewers, enough to qualify as the No. 1 cable movie of the year. The original “Camp Rock” in 2008 averaged 8.9 million viewers.

headline: Blair’s Book Is Greeted With Anger in Dublin
text: The former British Prime Minister Tony Blair was greeted by a barrage of plastic bottles, flip-flops and eggs at the first public reading of his new book on Saturday in Dublin. Witnesses told Agence France-Presse that more than 200 demonstrators were on hand to protest Mr. Blair, left, and his involvement leading up to the 2003 Iraq war, chanting antiwar slogans and holding signs that read “Blair lied, millions died” and “Lock him up for genocide.” In the book, which recounts his time as prime minister, from 1997 to 2007, Mr. Blair defended his decision to go to war but wrote that he did not anticipate the “nightmare” that followed. Mr. Blair was separated from the crowd by a security barrier and was not harmed. Four people were arrested and charged with public offenses, the police told Agence France-Presse. Several hundred others lined up at a back door of the bookshop to await their turn to meet Mr. Blair and have their copies signed. Antiwar activists have threatened to protest Mr. Blair’s next book signing, scheduled for Wednesday in London.

headline: Kanye West Tries Twitter to Explain His Actions
text: The rapper and producer Kanye West posted a series of messages on his Twitter account on Saturday morning in yet another attempt to explain his behavior at last year’s MTV Video Music Awards, where he grabbed the microphone from Taylor Swift and suggested that the prize for best female video should have gone instead to Beyoncé Knowles. In numerous posts published across just a few hours, Mr. West recounted some of the abuse he had taken from the public. “People tweeted that they wish I was dead,” he wrote. “No listen. They wanted me to die people. I carry that. I smile and take pictures through that.” Mr. West also defended his actions: “Who’s seen the play Wicked? I’ve seen it 4 times! Other than loving the music acting and costumes ... it’s my story!!! The Wicked witch of the west basically is so convicted to tell her truth when she does it she is outcasted by society and turned WICKED.” And he criticized members of the news media for “demonizing” him. But in the end, Mr. West wrote, “I take the responsibility for my actions,” and he offered Ms. Swift this message: “I wrote a song for Taylor Swift that’s so beautiful and I want her to have it. If she won’t take it then I’ll perform it for her.” After taking a break from the public for much of the past year, Mr. West has begun returning to the spotlight, announcing plans for a new album this fall and accepting MTV’s invitation to perform at this year’s awards show on Sept. 12.

headline: In Blue Ridge Mountains, a Steady Climb to the Top
text: The Virginia Tech football team’s success has become a rite of autumn in Blacksburg, with victories accumulating as consistently as the foliage that falls over the Blue Ridge Mountains. The Hokies have reached a bowl game each year since 1993, and only Ohio State and Florida have more wins since 1995.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: From Viral Video to Billboard 100
text: Viral videos tend to have a short lifespan online. The best ones might attract a few million views on YouTube and get a mention on a late-night talk show before fading into oblivion.

headline: Terms of Endearment, or Disrespect?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Glut of Shows Unwatched
text: The great thing about modern technology is that you never have to miss anything on television. That’s also the terrible thing about it.

headline: Aronian and Shirov Tied for Lead in Shanghai
text: Alexei Shirov won his third round game on Sunday and is tied for first in the Shanghai Masters tournament.

headline: Retiring Fed Official Considers More Bank Action
text: WASHINGTON  The former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, who retired last week after 40 years at the central bank, says that the economy is in “a slow slog out of a very deep hole,” and that the Fed should consider additional stimulus unless the recovery shows signs of “decent progress.”

headline: Adopt a Firehouse
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Ramadan Drumbeat Is Sounded in Queens
text: It was just past 4 the other morning when Mohammad Boota pulled his Lincoln Town Car into a service station on an industrial stretch in Long Island City, Queens, and bounded out  a typhoon of embroidered fabric, good cheer and unusual urgency.

headline: Provocative Artist Returns to MoMA P.S. 1
text: No one could have turned out the lights at the “performative discussion” between the provocative performance artist Ann Liv Young and the artist A.L Steiner at the sunlit MoMA P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens, on Sunday afternoon. But, as it turned out, the mood of the discussion couldn’t have been less like its subject: Ms. Young’s fraught and much-discussed appearance at P.S. 1 in February that ended with the museum’s director, Klaus Biesenbach, ordering the power shut off in the middle of the performance.

headline: For G.O.P., Tea Party Wields a Double-Edged Sword
text: Christine O’Donnell, running in Delaware to be the Republican nominee for the Senate seat once held by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., is a perennial candidate with a history of financial problems, including unpaid taxes and a home in foreclosure. Representative Michael N. Castle, her opponent in the primary, is a veteran congressman and former governor who has won statewide elections more than 10 times.

headline: Trouble in the Air
text: To the Editor:

headline: Responsibility for Torture
text: To the Editor:

headline: Stumbling Through Race, Padres Search For Swagger
text: SAN DIEGO  Adrian Gonzalez sauntered through the Padres’ expansive clubhouse Sunday morning in shorts and flip-flops, clutching a steaming cup of coffee. Not far away, Ryan Ludwick sat in a chair while Scott Hairston shaved his head with electric shears. Several players sat at their lockers, engrossed in their laptops or iPads. Heath Bell sat at his, fast asleep.

headline: From the Other Side of Ground Zero, Anti-Muslim Venom
text: The Internet evangelist Bill Keller moved toward the dais in tiny, quick steps on Sunday, exhibiting the anticipation of a man ready to address a crowd. Roughly 60 people stood before him in a hotel meeting room in Lower Manhattan, temporary quarters of his Christian center, his response to the mosque planned for an empty building nearby.

headline: Some See a Ploy as Craigslist Blocks Sex Ads
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Craigslist, by shutting off its “adult services” section and slapping a “censored” label in its place, may be engaging in a high-stakes stunt to influence public opinion, some analysts say.

headline: Even Hit Like ‘Kick-Ass’ Can Seem Like Miss at Debut
text: LOS ANGELES  In early April, as Lionsgate prepared to release “Kick-Ass,” the movie capital buzzed that the film looked to be a smash hit. Lionsgate had acquired it for just $15 million, and surveys that track audience interest projected a $30 million opening weekend.

headline: Suicide Attack Kills 3 Soldiers in South Russia
text: MOSCOW  A suicide bomber drove a car packed with explosives into a military installation in a Muslim region of southern Russia early Sunday, killing three soldiers and injuring more than 30 others, officials said.

headline: School Aid to New York State
text: To the Editor:

headline: Broadway Is Busy, With Pedestrians, if Not Car Traffic
text: It is Manhattan’s most famous thoroughfare, known around the world for its theater marquees and giant Macy’s. It has come to symbolize the outsize aspirations and swagger of New York.

headline: Before Dawn, Sounds of a Ramadan Ritual
text: Mohammad Boota, who is New York City’s foremost — and perhaps only — Ramadan drummer, is exploring new territory where he can awaken the faithful.

headline: The Long Road to Becoming a Lifer
text: As a young professional tennis player, Dick Norman used to watch the older men who played doubles, who hung on deep into their 30s, who clung to the vagabond style of tennis lifers.

headline: Uncommon Path Led Russia’s Coach All Over the World
text: ISTANBUL  At a cafe in St. Petersburg, Russia, in 2004, David Blatt realized he had found a new home. He had just accepted a job as the head coach of Dynamo St. Petersburg and was putting together a practice plan with an assistant.

headline: Floods in Pakistan Carry the Seeds of Upheaval
text: THATA SIAL, Pakistan  When the governor of Punjab Province arrived recently in this small town with truckloads of relief goods for flood victims, his visit was as much a political mission as a humanitarian one. His message to the hundred or so displaced people gathered under an awning was that the government was there for them.

headline: After Big Shots All Around, Day’s Lead Holds at One
text: NORTON, Mass.  The way the roars reverberated through the trees and across the golf course at T.P.C. Boston on Sunday, it almost sounded as if Tom Brady and the Patriots were pouring on the points up the road in Foxborough. But all this exuberance was generated by a day of chip-ins, hole-outs, back-nine 30s, eagles and double eagles at the Deutsche Bank Championship  where Jason Day, Brandt Snedeker, Luke Donald, Steve Stricker, Phil Mickelson and a host of others put on an extraordinary show in the PGA Tour’s FedEx Cup playoffs.

headline: Our Infrastructure Woes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corporate Boards
text: To the Editor:

headline: Apple Faces Many Rivals for Streaming to TVs
text: SAN FRANCISCO  When Steven P. Jobs introduced Apple’s first iPod in 2001, it held more music and was easier to use than the handful of rival products already in the market. But it had a big shortcoming: it worked only with Macintosh computers, then less than 3 percent of the PC market.

headline: In Britain, Labour Politicians Call for New Look at Scandal
text: LONDON  Senior opposition politicians are calling on the government to respond to renewed accusations that Downing Street’s chief communications officer, Andy Coulson, encouraged reporters to illegally intercept messages from the cellphones of public figures when he was editor of The News of the World.

headline: Anger Is Not the Answer
text: To the Editor:

headline: Thin Line for Group of Muslims in Egypt
text: CAIRO  One by one, the guests at the Muslim Brotherhood’s annual Ramadan iftar banquet strode to the rostrum. A who’s who of Egypt’s opposition began hectoring the Islamist group. The Brotherhood, they said, by far the most muscular and influential of Egypt’s dissident organizations, should withdraw from the coming parliamentary election that would most certainly be rigged by the authoritarian government.

headline: How to Tell if Apple Falters
text: When should investors sell Apple shares? The group’s push overseas and into the business market still holds promise, as does the steady stream of gadgets, like the updated Apple TV introduced by Steven P. Jobs last week. Apple’s trajectory should continue for some time, so its stock, which has gained more than 40 percent each year for the last five, looks attractive at 15 times estimated 2011 earnings. But no company can grow sales at that pace forever. While it may sound premature or even churlish to do so, we offer some strategic cues that could act as warning signs for investors that Apple’s growth is slowing.

headline: The Next Afghan Election
text: In less than two weeks, Afghanistan will elect a new parliament  a chance to show that the country is making progress. Unfortunately, the odds of success may not be much better than they were last year, when a presidential election, marred by violence and widespread fraud, left Afghans and the international community questioning the legitimacy of Hamid Karzai’s victory.

headline: Labor Day, Now and Then
text: Labor Day has been around for a surprisingly long time, longer than Mother’s Day, longer than Father’s Day, and almost as long as the official celebration of Washington’s Birthday.

headline: Nadal Has No Problem Riding Federer-Endorsed Vans
text: What drives Rafael Nadal, the men’s top seed in the United States Open? In his trips to and from Flushing Meadows, it has been a shuttle van with a likeness of his main rival, Roger Federer, the five-time Open champion who endorses the company that is supplying the tournament with cars.

headline: Iranian Woman Said to Be Lashed Over Photo
text: LONDON — A mix-up over a photograph led to a sentence of 99 lashes for the Iranian woman whose earlier death sentence by stoning from Iranian authorities caused an international outcry, a lawyer for the woman said Sunday.

headline: Follow the Money to the Floor
text: Three House members got word the other day that investigators have recommended that the ethics committee delve into their fund-raising from Wall Street donors  lucrative labors that happened to coincide precisely with some big votes on reforming Wall Street. Five other members were cleared in the same inquiry, raising the question of exactly what it might take to violate the Capitol’s notoriously porous rules about political fund-raising.

headline: 23 Accused of Coup Plot in Bahrain
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Bahraini officials announced on Saturday that they were charging 23 people, most of them activists from the Shiite majority, with coordinating a violent campaign to overthrow the minority Sunni government.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Unsolved Coal Ash Problem
text: In December 2008, a gigantic storage pond belonging to the Tennessee Valley Authority near Kingston, Tenn., effectively burst at the seams, spilling a billion gallons of mainly toxic coal ash from a T.V.A. power plant into surrounding lands and rivers.

headline: Two-Time Champion and ‘Part Jersey Girl’
text: Kim Clijsters made short work of Ana Ivanovic on Sunday for her 18th straight victory spanning five years at the United States Open, the tournament at which she happens to have won her only two Grand Slam titles. There has not been such home-court advantage at the National Tennis Center since John McEnroe.

headline: Changing Guard, Now Missing a Known Name
text: John Isner and Sam Querrey share several things in common. They are tall; they are young; and with Andy Roddick and James Blake already eliminated from the United States Open, they have been given the brightest of stages to present themselves as the leading men in the next generation of American tennis.

headline: Life Without a TV Set? Not Impossible
text: Most people do not think they need a television.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Sept. 5
text: Images from Sunday’s matches at the United States Open in Flushing Meadows.

headline: A Pitched Battle Over Bedbugs in Online Search Advertising
text: As people across the nation try to eradicate bedbugs from the crevices of their homes, a battle is being waged online among pest control companies over whose ad will be the first one most people see as they race to the Internet to learn about these insidious pests.

headline: Some Newspapers, Tracking Readers Online, Shift Coverage
text: In most businesses, not knowing how well a particular product is performing would be almost unthinkable. But newspapers have always been a peculiar business, one that has stubbornly, proudly clung to a sense that focusing too much on the bottom line can lead nowhere good.

headline: Dancing With the Dead
text: In a ritual in Madagascar, relatives remove corpses from graves every seven years, dance with them and then put them back in their crypts.

headline: Favorites and Friends Get Set to Slug It Out
text: Until Stanislas Wawrinka knocked out Andy Murray on Sunday night, it had been a remarkably straightforward first week at the United States Open.

headline: Espada’s Challengers to Join Forces Against Him
text: Gustavo Rivera, the main challenger to State Senator Pedro Espada Jr., received a major boost Sunday when a third candidate in the upcoming Democratic primary decided to drop out and back Mr. Rivera.

headline: Dead Join the Living in a Family Celebration
text: AMBOHIMIRARY, Madagascar — With fanfare befitting a parade, the shrouded remains of 17 bodies were removed from the family crypt, some sprayed with expensive perfume, others splashed with sparkling wine. Five brass bands took turns belting out cheerful melodies, and each emerging corpse was lifted onto the shoulders of its own set of revelers. The celebrators then joyously trotted about, dancing with the bones of the dead.

headline: 1938 in 2010
text: Here’s the situation: The U.S. economy has been crippled by a financial crisis. The president’s policies have limited the damage, but they were too cautious, and unemployment remains disastrously high. More action is clearly needed. Yet the public has soured on government activism, and seems poised to deal Democrats a severe defeat in the midterm elections.

headline: Memories Translate Well for Lendl
text: “You see, ya can’t please everyone, so ya got to please yourself.”

headline: Beyond the Upper East Side
text: Listening to Kyle Pope, the editor of The New York Observer, discuss how he wants to re-energize his newspaper sounds a lot like someone describing a Broadway show or a television series that has run a little past its prime.

headline: American Muslims Ask, Will We Ever Belong?
text: For nine years after the attacks of Sept. 11, many American Muslims made concerted efforts to build relationships with non-Muslims, to make it clear they abhor terrorism, to educate people about Islam and to participate in interfaith service projects. They took satisfaction in the observations by many scholars that Muslims in America were more successful and assimilated than Muslims in Europe.

headline: Slow Start for Pondexter and Liberty
text: The Liberty will have two days to ponder the two minutes that have left it teetering on the edge of elimination from the W.N.B.A. playoffs.

headline: Brain Waves and Newsstands
text: In early August, the British magazine New Scientist published a cover that had scored well on a test conducted by neuromarketers, who study the brain’s response to products. But the question remained: would that good review translate to sales on the newsstand?

headline: Weary Ogilvy Figuring Rest Will Improve His Numbers
text: NORTON, Mass.  Geoff Ogilvy was talking about what he called the mysteries of golf. Minutes earlier, he had almost chipped in for eagle on the 18th hole. When he knocked in a 1-inch birdie putt to go to 12 under par after three rounds of the Deutsche Bank Championship, he was in contention for a PGA Tour victory for the first time in nearly eight months.

headline: Paranoid About Paranoia
text: Last Wednesday, a man named James Lee entered the headquarters of the Discovery Channel with explosives strapped to his body, took three hostages at gunpoint, and waited for his demands to be met.

headline: Corporate Donors to Lawmakers’ Charities
text: At least 20 senators and representatives are associated with charities that routinely accept donations from corporations.

headline: Albany District Attorney Criticized in Steroid Case
text: As the district attorney for Albany County, P. David Soares has made a name for himself around the state by investigating top New York public officials, most recently weighing whether to prosecute Gov. David A. Paterson on perjury charges.

headline: Congressional Charities Pulling In Corporate Cash
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Joe Baca has achieved near celebrity status in his suburban Los Angeles district, as much for his record of giveaways  Thanksgiving turkeys, college scholarships, spare boots for firefighters  as for anything he has done in Congress.

headline: Victims’ Families Fight Film About Madrid Plane Crash
text: MADRID  A Spanish association representing victims of a plane crash and their families is fighting this week’s broadcast of the second half of a film about the crash.

headline: Boxers, Briefs and Books
text: Charlottesville, Va.

headline: In Europe’s Debt Crisis, Lending Was Still Strong
text: Even as Europe’s sovereign debt crisis intensified early this year, banks continued to load up on debt from Greece and other countries with the most acute fiscal problems, according to a report released on Sunday.

headline: At Soccer Game, Remembrance for a Fallen Player
text: As teams from St. Lucia and Jamaica took to an athletic field in East New York, Brooklyn, for the final match of an international soccer tournament on Sunday, players and fans alike found that their thoughts were on a player who was not there.

headline: Controversy on the Range
text: Animal rights activists campaign fiercely against roundups conducted by the Bureau of Land Management to control wild horse populations on public lands.

headline: That ’70s Feeling
text: Ithaca, N.Y

headline: When Picking Up a Ball May Mean a Penalty
text: Steve, Tom, Vic and Walt approach the green of the final hole of the club championship. Steve, whose ball lies 3 feet short of the green, notices that the pitch mark from Walt’s shot, who played after Steve, is a foot in front of the ball.

headline: Holiday Today: Labor Day
text: Holiday on Monday

headline: Golfers Welcome President Obama’s Participation
text: President Obama’s interest in golf has obviously gone to intense from casual. Five rounds in 10 family vacation days? That could pass as a clinical diagnosis for the bite of the golf bug. Every serious golfer recognizes the signs.

headline: Horse Advocates Pull for Underdog in Roundups
text: OUTSIDE RAVENDALE, Calif.  It is horse versus helicopter here in the high desert.

headline: Altered Movie Poster Puts the Spotlight on a San Francisco Agency’s Gun Ban
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A recent Supreme Court decision could alter what public transit riders here see in advertisements on city buses and trains and in transit shelters.

headline: G.O.P. Senate Candidate in Alaska Is Charged in Accident
text: Joe Miller, the Republican candidate for Senate from Alaska, has been found at fault in a three-car accident that happened shortly after he took a narrow lead in the Republican primary.

headline: Sports Replay: Sept. 5
text: Images from the day in sports, from dirt tracks to the racetracks.

headline: Kayakers Win Battle to Open Falls for a Plunge
text: OHIOPYLE, Pa.  For decades, kayakers and other whitewater boaters were prohibited by park safety rules from paddling over the crest of an 18-foot waterfall in this scenic corner of southwestern Pennsylvania.

headline: Democrats Go to Work on a Formidable Task
text: In a year of unremitting labor, Democrats now turn toward the final phase of their most arduous task of all.

headline: In Surprise Move, Jets Cut Richardson
text: Anyone who watches “Hard Knocks” knows how highly the Jets regard fullback Tony Richardson. On a recent episode when discussing possible cuts and the position battle between Richardson and the rookie John Conner, Coach Rex Ryan and General Manager Mike Tannenbaum praised Richardson’s leadership and what it brings to a young offense. Ryan had also said repeatedly that the team would keep two fullbacks.

headline: L.I.R.R. Service Is Disrupted After Track Fire
text: For the second time in as many weeks, a fire disrupted Long Island Rail Road service on Sunday, temporarily shutting down train service in and out of Pennsylvania Station.

headline: Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data this week will include the Federal Reserve beige book and consumer credit for July (Wednesday); the trade deficit for July (Thursday); and wholesale trade inventories for July (Friday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes a regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: News Quiz | September 6, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Jets Fans Can Exhale: Revis Reaches a Deal
text: Cornerback Darrelle Revis has confirmed that he has reached an agreement with the Jets on a new contract, ending his lengthy holdout.

headline: Cheers Greet Revis After Bitter Holdout
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On Labor Day, Darrelle Revis reported to work, ending his summer-long holdout and some 36 days of rancorous negotiations. When Revis stepped onto the Jets’ practice field around 1 p.m., he received a hero’s welcome.

headline: Suicide Bomber Hits Pakistani Police Station
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A suicide bomber rammed a vehicle packed with explosives into a police station in northwest Pakistan on Monday, killing 19 people and injuring at least 46, according to officials and local news outlets. Among the dead were nine police officers, eight civilians and two children, local and provincial authorities said.

headline: In North Korea, Signs Point to Key Political Conference
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Workers’ Party delegates from across North Korea were converging in Pyongyang, the country’s state media reported on Monday, as children and soldiers there rehearsed a celebration for their country’s biggest political gathering in 30 years.

headline: Spain Dismisses Basque Truce Announcement
text: MADRID  Spain’s interior minister said Monday that he did not trust a cease-fire announcement from ETA, the Basque separatist group, dismissing speculation about whether the country’s long fight against terrorism had come to an end.

headline: Taking the ‘Un’ Out of Unemployment
text: 1:51 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Paris Show That’s as Good as (Incan) Gold
text: The Incas called gold “the sun’s sweat,” but it’s the sweat behind that civilization’s handiwork with the cherished metal that’s on display in Paris, from Sept. 10 to Feb. 6, at the Pinacothèque de Paris museum.

headline: Q.&A.: Beefing Up Your Password Strength
text: Q.

headline: A More Poised Wozniacki Ousts Sharapova
text: The gap in off-court earnings between Maria Sharapova and Caroline Wozniacki remains a gulf. Sharapova, even without a pressure-proof second serve, remains the world’s highest-paid female athlete, while Wozniacki’s portfolio remains a work in progress.

headline: What to Watch on Monday at the Open
text: While the stars play at Arthur Ashe Stadium, tomorrow’s day session leads off with one of the more interesting matchups of the tournament when Richard Gasquet and Gael Monfils enter Louis Armstrong.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian | Basil, Spinach and Arugula Pesto
text: Many people make pesto from fresh basil, pine nuts, garlic, olive oil, cheeses and butter. The basil is raw, as is the garlic.

headline: Guide to N.F.L. Defenses, Part 1
text: Jene Bramel writes for Footballguys.com. You can also follow him on Twitter and reach him at bramel@footballguys.com.

headline: Japanese No! Japanese Yes!
text: Some musical entertainment:

headline: Stosur Wins Third-Set Tiebreaker in Wee Hours
text: Fifth-seeded Samantha Stosur of Australia and 12th-seeded Elena Dementieva of Russia battled for 2 hours 38 minutes before Stosur emerged at 1:35 a.m with a 6-3, 2-6, 7-6 (2) victory in the fourth round. In the third set, which took 1 hour, 16 minutes, Dementieva sprinted out to a 3-0 lead, but Stosur would not go down, eventually saving four match points. In the Monday-morning tiebreaker, Stosur took the first three points, thanks to three unforced errors by Dementieva. Read Thomas Kaplan’s report on the match.

headline: Turkey Joins Europe, Electrically Speaking
text: Turkey may be frustrated in its bid to become part of the European Union, but by the end of September, it will join Europe’s electric grid.

headline: Vain Glorious | The Spa at Trump Soho
text: Who: The Spa at Trump SoHo

headline: Slow Learners and Good Teachers
text: One of the objections that’s often raised to using test scores in teacher evaluations is that students are not randomly assigned to teachers. A teacher may be assigned a large number of troubled students because she is especially good at helping such students. Comparing her students’ test scores to those of an honors class obviously wouldn’t be fair.

headline: Open House, Labor Day Edition: Why Are the Spanish Men Dominating?
text: Michael Kimmelman, the Times’s chief art critic, and Gerry Marzorati, editor of the Sunday Magazine, are covering the Open from uncommon perspectives. Each morning, they discuss what’s happening. Join the conversation — or ask a fan-oriented question — by sending in a comment.

headline: Beamer’s Most Important Victory at Virginia Tech
text: Virginia Tech has reached a bowl game in 17 consecutive seasons, the third-longest active streak in the nation. Over that time, the Hokies have played in three Orange Bowls and three Sugar Bowls, one of which was the 1999 national championship game.

headline: Obama Offers a Transit Plan to Create Jobs
text: MILWAUKEE  President Obama, looking to stimulate a sluggish economy and create jobs, called Monday for Congress to approve major upgrades to the nation’s roads, rail lines and runways  part of a six-year plan that would cost tens of billions of dollars and create a government-run bank to finance innovative transportation projects.

headline: When It Comes to Car Batteries, Moore’s Law Does Not Compute
text: Silicon Valley may be an epicenter of the nascent electric car industry, but don’t expect the battery revolution to mimic the computer revolution, one of I.B.M.’s top energy storage scientists advises.

headline: Labor (Less) Day?
text: 8:08 p.m. | Updated It’s worth reading Robert B. Reich’s recent column in The Times exploring the roots of the enduring Great Recession and his solution and following it up with a dose of Juliet Schor, an economist and sociologist at Boston College who proposes Americans ramp back on work as a way toward fuller employment and more fulfilled lives. Here’s her recent video statement on Big Think:

headline: Blade Runners
text: Maybe it’s because I spent so much of my childhood rampaging through the woods pretending to be one of Robin Hood’s outlaws or the last Mohican, but I think of old-fashioned knives (the sort you’d use to survive in the wild rather than slaughter rival drug dealers) as being noble rather than scary.

headline: For E. B. White’s Willow Tree, Chapter Ends
text: In the 1940s, when E. B. White, the author and columnist for The New Yorker, looked out of his back windows onto the private Turtle Bay Gardens along East 48th Street in Manhattan, an old but picturesque willow tree commanded his view.

headline: Monday Reading: Insurance Tips for Renting Cars Abroad
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Afghanistan Pledges Support for Troubled Bank
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The chairman of the Central Bank of Afghanistan promised Monday to lend the embattled Kabul Bank “as much as it wants” to stave off a collapse, even as he continued to insist that the bank was solvent.

headline: Murray’s Loss is Nadal’s Gain
text: Andy Murray’s four-set loss to Stanislas Wawrinka on Sunday came as terrible news for fans of the Scottish player’s all-court counterpunching style. But fans of Rafael Nadal, another speedy counterpuncher, can now breathe a little easier.

headline: NumberPlay: A Second Reflection
text: A projectile is reflected back to its source. What are the two possible angles of the reflector?

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap: Facing the Inevitable
text: Season 4, Episode 7

headline: Potential for Double-Dip Recession Seems Small
text: Over the last few months there has been an increase in the concern and discussion over a possible double-dip recession, particularly after unemployment reports over the summer showed that the nation was shedding tens of thousands of jobs. However, a key element lacking in the talk of double-dip recessions is what actually caused past recessions – that is, what are the primary reasons an economy slows to the point where its growth contracts for at least two quarters – followed by an analysis of whether those conditions exist in the current economic environment. And judging from a variety of indicators, the potential for a double-dip recession seem small.

headline: Follow the Open via Twitter, Monday Edition
text: 7:05 p.m. | Updated Gerry Marzorati, one-half of the Open House duo, is covering the United States Open via Twitter. Now that Monday’s day session is all but over, go directly to gerrynyt to read his 140-character descriptions of the sights, sounds and matches of the Open.

headline: Dispatch | Wales Watching
text: Long the neglected sibling of England and Scotland, Wales is finally starting to come into its own. With some of Britain’s lushest scenery, a growing foodie movement and more castles than Starbucks and McDonald’s branches combined, the wee country — it’s just 160 miles long by 60 miles wide — resembles some sort of real-life Brigadoon. Prince William, living in North Wales while he trains to become an R.A.F. helicopter pilot, has already been spotted with Kate in Snowdonia National Park, and come October, the global media will descend on Newport, just northeast of the capital of Cardiff when golf’s prestigious Ryder Cup is played here for the first time.

headline: The Early Word: Labor Day
text: In a Labor Day speech today in Milwaukee, President Obama will call for a $50 billion investment in transportation projects to boost the economy and public confidence, White House officials said.

headline: Lacking Money and Leadership, Push for Taliban Defectors Stalls
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A $250 million program to lure low-level Taliban fighters away from the insurgency has stalled, with Afghans bickering over who should run it, and international donors slow to put up the money they had promised.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Melvin and Howard'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at "Melvin and Howard," the strange and possibly true story of Howard Hughes and his will.

headline: Timeless | Days of Thunder
text: ‘‘The ’57 Thunderbird is elegant, sporty — it’s a gentleman’s sports car,’’ says Evan Yurman, the design director of men’s jewelry and watches for David Yurman, not to mention a vintage car buff. Evan, who is the son of David Yurman, might very well be describing the company’s brand-new Classic 1957 Limited Edition watch, a sporty, elegant and, yes, gentlemanly timepiece that was inspired by cars from the ’50s and the Thunderbird’s instrument panel in particular. ‘‘I drive these kinds of cars a lot, and I’m always staring at the speedometer to see where I’m at,’’ he says. For Yurman, the ’50s were the golden era of American design, and not just in the automobile industry. ‘‘I tip my hat to it and hope I can only add to this legacy.’’ When it comes to cars, however, it’s ultimately what’s under the hood that gets him revved up: he loves the ’57 T-Bird for its beauty more than its brawn. ‘‘It is a cruiser, a cream puff,’’ says Yurman, who instead owns a ’66 Bel Air and a ’69 Ford Mustang. ‘‘I go for the one where some guy in the factory said, ‘Let’s make this car as fast as we can.’ ’’

headline: Analysis: How Youzhny Knocked Off Isner
text: Mikhail Youzhny used superb anticipation to read John Isner’s powerful serve in his impressive four-set win. As Isner tossed, Youzhny would shade to his right or his left, picking up the direction of the serve seemingly before Isner made contact. He wasn’t guessing, but the veteran Russian was picking up subtle cues that allowed him to get his return back in play.

headline: ‘Black Swan’ Gives Telluride Another Surprise
text: TELLURIDE, Colo.— The second “Sneak” of the Telluride Film Festival — the surprise appearance of a big-deal movie, usually making its North American debut, in a previous blank slot in the schedule grid — was Darren Aronofsky’s “Black Swan,” a backstage melodrama that often plays like a horror movie. It popped up Sunday, along with Mr. Aronofsky himself, making his first visit to this festival en route from Venice, where “Black Swan” opened last week and where his previous film, “The Wrestler,” won the top prize two years ago.

headline: 9 Years After 9/11, Public Safety Radio Not Ready
text: WASHINGTON  The inability of most firefighters and police officers to talk to each other on their radios on Sept. 11, 2001, at the World Trade Center  one of the most vexing problems on that day nine years ago  still has not been completely resolved.

headline: End-of-Summer Stir-Fries
text: We finally got our heat wave last week in Los Angeles, albeit for only a few days. I decided that rather than light the oven I would cook everything as quickly as I could on top of the stove. With the bounteous end of summer produce at my local farmers’ markets, it was a perfect week for stir-frying.

headline: Ask the Cook About Healthful Stir-Frying
text: The new cookbook by the food writer Grace Young, “Stir-Frying to the Sky’s Edge,” was the inspiration for this week’s Recipes for Health from Martha Rose Shulman. “When it comes to stir-frying, I have a guru, the cookbook author Grace Young,” Ms. Shulman writes. “Her new cookbook is the ultimate guide, whether you’re a beginner or a chef.”

headline: Stir-fried Succotash With Edamame
text: While we’ve still got corn and peppers aplenty, make this Asian version of the American classic succotash. I love the combination of sweet and seared flavors in this dish.

headline: The Fifth Set: A Thinking Man’s Endurance Test
text: There were the gusts that turned the ball toss on serves into an act of faith and then there were the sudden shifts of momentum. Sam Querrey, the last American man standing in the United States Open, did his best to weather both, but in the end was swept away. He lost in the fourth round to Stanislas Wawrinka of Switzerland in a five-set match at Arthur Ashe Stadium that alternately captivated and crushed the partisan crowd.

headline: Patrick McEnroe Resigns as Davis Cup Captain
text: Patrick McEnroe announced his resignation as the American Davis Cup captain on Monday, effective after the United States team’s next match, against Colombia in Bogota Sept. 17-19. McEnroe said he wanted to concentrate on his work with the young player development program he leads for the United States Tennis Association, as well as his television commentary and spending more time with his family.

headline: The Best of Two Bands at All Tomorrow’s Parties
text: MONTICELLO, N.Y. — Altar is the project-name of the American duo Sunn O))) and the Japanese trio Boris, convened in front of five enormous stacks of amplifiers. By the end of its show Sunday night at All Tomorrow’s Parties, it had grown to 10 members; a singer, Jesse Sykes, drifted in and drifted out. There were no rhythms, just drum beats that ended before they really started, like arrested lead-ins to a great song. There was a duet between bowed cymbal and bowed double-bass, and frequent use of a large gong.

headline: The Claim: The Day’s Events are Incorporated Into That Night’s Dreams.
text: THE FACTS In the world of sleep research, dreams are something of a black box. But one tidbit that scientists have discerned is the peculiar but predictable pattern in which dreams tend to occur.

headline: Topical Gel Catches Up With Pills for Relief
text: When I strained a back muscle playing tennis not long ago, my doubles partner, who happened to be a doctor, pulled a tube of cream from her gym bag and told me to rub it on.

headline: Desert Roads Lead to Discovery in Egypt
text: Over the last two decades, John Coleman Darnell and his wife, Deborah, hiked and drove caravan tracks west of the Nile from the monuments of Thebes, at present-day Luxor. These and other desolate roads, beaten hard by millennial human and donkey traffic, only seemed to lead to nowhere.

headline: Risks: Asleep, and Helping to Keep the Weight Off
text: Children under 5 who do not get at least 10 hours of sleep at night are almost twice as likely to be overweight or obese later in childhood, a new study reports. And naps during the day don’t count.

headline: Iran Remains Defiant, Nuclear Agency Says
text: WASHINGTON  Three months after the United Nations Security Council enacted its harshest sanctions yet against Iran, global nuclear inspectors reported Monday that the country has dug in its heels, refusing to provide inspectors with the information and access they need to determine whether the real purpose of Tehran’s program is to produce weapons.

headline: Prevention: Surgery Sharply Reduces Risk of 2 Cancers
text: About 1 in 400 women carry genetic mutations that put them at high risk for breast and ovarian cancer. For these women, doctors may recommend prophylactic mastectomy and oophorectomy, or removal of the ovaries  even before there is any sign of cancer.

headline: Monfils Advances to U.S. Open Quarterfinals
text: Gaël Monfils was already popular at the United States Open before this tournament, as a talented but enigmatic player who has embraced the New York atmosphere and tries to engage the fans during his matches. It has not hurt his image that he showed up this year with an outfit that made him look as if he had wandered onto the court fresh off a stroll in the surrounding Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, nor that he has powered his way into the quarterfinals.

headline: On Birds of Many Colors, Lice Dress the Part
text: Camouflage in nature is nothing new. A wide variety of animals, like rabbits, birds and deer, are cryptically colored to blend in with their background and guard themselves from predators.

headline: Forget What You Know About Good Study Habits
text: Every September, millions of parents try a kind of psychological witchcraft, to transform their summer-glazed campers into fall students, their video-bugs into bookworms. Advice is cheap and all too familiar: Clear a quiet work space. Stick to a homework schedule. Set goals. Set boundaries. Do not bribe (except in emergencies).

headline: Weight Problems May Begin in the Womb
text: You may think you know why Americans continue to get fatter and develop obesity-related diseases. But the explanation may start long before people have an opportunity to eat too much of the wrong foods and exercise too little.

headline: The Hair of My Chin
text: Q. If I tweeze out the single hair that grows from a facial mole, will it cause cancer, as my friend insists?

headline: South Africa Unions’ Strike Suspended
text: PRETORIA, South Africa  South Africa’s trade unions Monday suspended an almost  three-week-old strike by hundreds of thousands of government workers that had closed schools and hamstrung ambitious new efforts to expand urgently needed medical services in the region’s richest but most inequitable economy.

headline: Surviving by Disguising: Nature’s Game of Charades
text: One bright October morning, Fabiano Calleia, a researcher with the Federal University of Amazonas, was out in the lowland rainforest of Manaus, Brazil, tracking his usual group of eight pied tamarins as the small, dark monkeys with their dapper white shrugs grazed on the fruits of a fig tree. Suddenly the breakfast calm was shattered by the distinctive sound of a baby tamarin’s cry  a series of short, sharp whistles, like a boiling teapot doing Morse code.

headline: Nostrums: A Bit of Marijuana Is Found to Ease Pain
text: People with chronic pain who took just a puff of marijuana three times a day got some mild pain relief and, with rare exceptions, did so without getting high, a Canadian study reports. (Yes, they inhaled.)

headline: Tuberculosis: Automated Test for Drug-Resistant TB Gives Results in Hours, Not Weeks
text: A new automated test for drug-resistant tuberculosis gives accurate results in two hours instead of four to eight weeks, scientists said last week, and public health officials greeted the news enthusiastically, saying it could greatly speed up diagnosis.

headline: Mangold Expects a New Car From Revis
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. – Nick Mangold is waiting for his new ride.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Clues to Human Thought Found in Worm’s Brain
text: In humans, the cerebral cortex, the tissuelike outermost layer of the brain, is thought to play a critical role in creative and analytical thinking.

headline: Edible Nanostructures
text: 1 teaspoon gamma-cyclodextrin

headline: Researchers Create Nanostructures, and Whip Up a Recipe, Too
text: In the latest step in science’s never-ending quest for tinyness, researchers at Northwestern University have made edible nanostructures.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Norm Show'
text: The short-lived sitcom starring Norm Macdonald is receiving a DVD release by Shout! Factory.

headline: With Texans, Leinart Will Once Again Take a Back Seat
text: Matt Leinart’s career is inextricably linked to Texas, considering that it was the University of Texas  and Vince Young  who ended Leinart’s reign as the Southern California quarterback with a stunning victory against the Trojans in the 2006 national championship game at the Rose Bowl.

headline: Aggressive From the Start, the U.S. Leaves No Doubt
text: ISTANBUL  When the United States plays Angola in basketball, it is impossible not to recall Charles Barkley. During the Dream Team’s march of domination in the 1992 Summer Olympics, Barkley had a memorable moment in a pregame news conference.

headline: In Feast of Data on BPA Plastic, No Final Answer
text: The research has been going on for more than 10 years. Studies number in the hundreds. Millions of dollars have been spent. But government health officials still cannot decide whether the chemical bisphenol-A, or BPA, a component of some plastics, is safe. The substance lines most food and drink cans, and is used to make hard, clear plastic bottles, containers and countless other products. Nearly everyone is exposed to it.

headline: Shirov Takes the Lead of the Shanghai Masters
text: With a second consecutive win, Alexei Shirov is in first place by himself.

headline: In a Fight for a Tree, Ants Thwart Elephants
text: Campers know the pesky feeling of ants crawling up and down their arms and legs.

headline: Courtside: Understanding the Fifth Set
text: The Times's Karen Crouse talks about how players react to playing a match that lasts five sets.

headline: Learning to Talk the Talk in a Hospital
text: In hospitals, there is a special kind of communication among doctors and nurses, an essential skill not easily learned. I’ve come to call it the Rattle.

headline: For Young and Old, the Best Ways to Study
text: As students around the country go back to school and hit the books, scientists are offering new insights into the best ways to study and learn, reports Benedict Carey in the Science Times Mind column. He writes:

headline: Putin, Citing Roosevelt, Hints at a 3rd-Term Bid
text: MOSCOW  For months, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin has done nothing to dampen speculation that he is seriously considering a bid to return to the presidency in the 2012 election. On Monday night, he offered another hint at his plans by referring to the political career of a former president of a different country: Franklin D. Roosevelt.

headline: Tate Modern Expansion Is the Cost of Success
text: LONDON  When the Tate Modern opened here 10 years ago it was the first new national museum built in Britain in 100 years and the first museum in London devoted solely to modern art. A hulking brick building that was a former power station on the south side of the Thames River at Bankside, a slowly gentrifying area just opposite St. Paul’s Cathedral, the $208 million museum captivated the art world and made a city better known for its stuffier, historic collections into an international mecca for new art.

headline: In Japan, a Frail Ozawa Conducts Only One Tchaikovsky Movement
text: MATSUMOTO, Japan — As classical music lovers in New York and New England fret over the fitness of James Levine to start a demanding season at the Metropolitan Opera and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, grave concern over the health of another peripatetic maestro has spread to three continents. Like Mr. Levine, Seiji Ozawa has had a series of ailments in recent years, including pneumonia, shingles, sciatica and, this year, cancer of the esophagus.

headline: Courtside: Understanding the Fifth Set
text: Karen Crouse, who wrote Monday about the psychology behind the fifth set, discusses this concept further for The Times’s U.S. Open video series Courtside.

headline: A Musical Question: Does a Quartet Sound Different in the Dark?
text: Michel Galante, the director of the Argento Chamber Ensemble, has had a longtime fascination with the music of Georg Friedrich Haas and has included his works in his group’s programs for the last several years. And as the musical force behind the Moving Sounds Festival, which opened on Thursday, he unleashed a torrent of Mr. Haas’s work in New York last weekend.

headline: Beach Reads Finished, It’s Time for the Big Books
text: If summer is the sleepy season in book publishing, the fall always seems to make up for it.

headline: How Colombia Meets America, but Not Quite
text: The stories in Patricia Engel’s striking debut collection are like snapshots from someone’s photo album: glimpses of relatives, friends, lovers and acquaintances, sometimes posing, sometimes caught by the camera unawares. There are portraits of Latinos in suburban “Gringolandia,” and portraits of young drifters in Miami, 16 of them sharing a single apartment, mattresses crammed together on the floor “like it was war times.” There’s a skinny 16-year-old boy who always wears faded jeans and “a white button-down shirt that looked like it only got washed in the sink,” a high school mean girl who develops a fatal case of anorexia, a womanizing pot dealer who becomes the narrator’s best friend and a Colombian beauty queen who comes to America and is forced into prostitution.

headline: Air Products Raises Airgas Offer to $65.50 a Share
text: 6:00 p.m. | Updated Air Products and Chemicals on Monday raised its takeover offer for Airgas to $5.48 billion in cash, as it pressed forward with a proxy fight over the Airgas board of directors.

headline: Postracial Vigilantes in a World in Peril
text: “We are separatists, not supremacists,” the sedately spoken businessman says. “We are God-fearing patriots. And in a time when black radicals are in power in this country, we are desperately trying to remind our citizens of their founding beliefs.”

headline: Frustration Simmers but Doesn’t Boil Over in Loss
text: A. J. Burnett has a temper. Earlier this season, Burnett had to leave a Yankees game because he pounded his hands bloody on a clubhouse door after a frustrating inning.

headline: A Game That’s So Out of Hand That Perez Gets to Pitch
text: WASHINGTON  Half Street, which leads to the center-field gates of Nationals Park, turns into a carnival before most Washington Nationals games. Vendors line the sidewalks, and there is a patio with live music and free-flowing beer.

headline: Parades and Politics Across the Nation
text: Midterm races are gaining momentum in Delaware, Illinois and Arizona.

headline: Tasty Vegan Food? Cupcakes Show It Can Be Done
text: Many people equate a vegan diet with deprivation, thinking that recipes prepared without eggs, butter, meat or other animal products are certain to be tasteless and boring.

headline: A Rallying Cry Amid Attack Ads in Delaware
text: DOVER, Del.  Steve Bentz, a compact man sporting a blond flattop and a blue “beer party” T-shirt, was thrilled to meet Christine O’Donnell, a conservative running for the Senate, over the Labor Day weekend.

headline: In Arizona, Corn With Politics on the Side
text: CHINO VALLEY, Ariz.  The hugely popular Corn Dinner here is in its 64th year, and Carrie Zambrano, as the organizer, sends out invitations to political candidates far and wide offering them the opportunity to serve. Party label means not a thing to her with 6,000 cobs to sling in one night.

headline: Fed Up With Politics, and Politicians, in Illinois
text: NAPERVILLE, Ill.  From a tiny booth at a festival here, a radio station host gave Representative Mark Steven Kirk, the Republican candidate for Senate, a moment to make his pitch between plugs for free massages and the corn dogs being sold a few booths away.

headline: Always in Its Element, No Matter the Weather
text: With summer on the wane and autumn on the way, Nature’s where you want to be. And there’s no more bracing or reposeful place to find it than Storm King Art Center, one of the country’s premier outdoor sculpture parks, set on 500 acres of wide-open meadow and woodland in Mountainville, N.Y., about an hour’s drive north of Manhattan.

headline: ‘Storm King Wavefield’
text: Maya Lin’s outdoor installation in Mountainville, N.Y., is rows of rolling hills that change with the light and the season.

headline: After Tough Year, New York’s Haitians Gather
text: The sun rose over the tireless Haitian rara musicians and the throng of ecstatic fans who followed them. A shimmying mother pushed a stroller. A man on roller skates danced into his seventh hour. Two police officers sipped coffee. The fans chanted, “The day is coming.”

headline: Provocateur Returns to P.S. 1, but Not to Provoke
text: No one could turn out the lights at the “performative discussion” between the provocative performance artist Ann Liv Young and the artist A. L. Steiner at the sunlit MoMA P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens, on Sunday afternoon. But as it turned out, the mood couldn’t have been less like its subject: Ms. Young’s fraught and much-discussed appearance at P.S. 1 in February that ended when the museum’s director, Klaus Biesenbach, ordered the power shut off.

headline: War and the City: The Gyre
text: This is the second of a five-part series, “War and the City,” by the Iraq war veteran Roy Scranton, chronicling his path from youth to soldier to civilian writer in New York City. To read from the beginning, go to the first installment, “March Song.”

headline: Variations on a Theme of International Terrorism
text: Book to stage to screen is a familiar path, but the journalist Lawrence Wright has found a new variation: from a thick nonfiction book to a one-man Off Broadway show to an HBO documentary. Along the way the material, which began with the Pulitzer Prize-winning “Looming Tower: Al-Qaeda and the Road to 9/11” in 2006, has been reviewed and otherwise written about often enough that you may feel you know it, even if you haven’t read the book or seen the show.

headline: Movies, Mountains and High Hopes
text: TELLURIDE, Colo.  “If what we hear from down on the plains is true, and film culture is dying,” said the Australian director Peter Weir, up in the mountains here to present his latest movie, “The Way Back,” “then perhaps this place can become a kind of Machu Picchu of cinema.” Not a ruin, of course, but a fortress and a shrine, a sacred spot where embattled traditions can survive in troubled times.
