headline: After Antiwar Protest, Blair Cancels Appearance
text: The former British prime minister Tony Blair has canceled the next book signing of his new memoir, “A Journey,” which was scheduled for Wednesday at Waterstone’s bookstore in London, The Associated Press reported. After antiwar demonstrators threw plastic bottles, eggs and flip-flops at Mr. Blair on Saturday as he entered a Dublin bookstore, he said he did not want to further inconvenience the public with “the inevitable hassle caused by protesters.” Dominic Myers, the managing director of Waterstone’s, said the cancellation was “a matter of regret.”

headline: Art Critics Pan Museum and Dylan Exhibition
text: Bob Dylan’s latest exhibition of paintings was panned by Danish art critics after its opening on Saturday at the National Gallery in Copenhagen, Agence France-Presse reported. “When we talk about music, Bob Dylan is one of the great Picassos of the 20th century, but this is not the case for his painting,” the reviewer for the daily newspaper Berlingske Tidende wrote of Mr. Dylan’s “Brazil Series,” a collection of 40 acrylic paintings  including “The Argument,” below left  inspired by his travels in the cities, slums and countryside of Brazil, as well as eight drawings done specifically for the museum. Several other publications also criticized Mr. Dylan’s talent, and the museum, known in Denmark as the Statens Museum for Kunst, for picking the show because of the artist’s commercial appeal instead of the artistic value. Karsten Ohrt, the museum’s director, defended both, saying that Mr. Dylan was a “quality painter” and that his work interested Danish painters and art collectors. The exhibition runs through Jan. 30.

headline: Footnote
text: The writer, director and producer Tyler Perry has announced a release date of Nov. 5 for his film version of Ntozake Shange’s play “For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide When the Rainbow Is Enuf,” Variety reported. Lionsgate is producing this adaptation of the play of poems about love, sex, abortion and rape, with a screenplay by Mr. Perry and a cast including Whoopi Goldberg, Phylicia Rashad, Anika Noni Rose, Loretta Devine, Kerry Washington, Janet Jackson, Kimberly Elise and Macy Gray. The original stage production eventually made its way to Broadway and was nominated for a Tony award for best play in 1977.

headline: High Hopes For Poussin Sale at Christie’s
text: Christie’s in London is expecting a big sale of a painting by the French master Nicolas Poussin at a December auction. Christie’s said it was expecting the painting, “Ordination,” above, one of a set of seven 17th-century works by Poussin depicting the sacraments, to sell for between $23 million and $31 million at the old masters and 19th-century Art auction on Dec. 7, Reuters reported. That high estimate was based on last year’s old masters sale, when a drawing by Raphael sold for $47.9 million and a painting by Rembrandt went for $33.2 million. The seven paintings in the Poussin series were sold to the Belvoir estate of the Dukes of Rutland in the late 18th century. Of those works “Penance” was destroyed by a fire, and “Baptism” was acquired by the National Gallery of Art in Washington in 1946. The five remaining  “Ordination,” “Confirmation,” “Eucharist,” “Extreme Unction” and “Marriage”  have been on loan to the National Gallery in London since 2003. In a statement the estate said the sale proceeds would go to the restoration and long-term preservation of Belvoir Castle and Estate.

headline: James Cameron Plans Protest Film In 3-D
text: The director James Cameron has announced plans to make another 3-D film about an indigenous tribe trying to preserve its land. Unlike his Oscar-winning “Avatar,” however, this film will be a documentary about the Xikrin-Kayapó tribe in Brazil and its attempts to stop the construction of the Belo Monte hydroelectric dam, which is to be built near tribal lands on the Xingu River, a tributary of the Amazon, Agence France-Presse reported. Construction of the dam, which is to be the world’s third largest, will require the flooding of 200 square miles of the Xingu River basin. Opposition groups say the flooding will displace about 12,000 people and destroy the fishing industry, but the Brazilian government maintains that the lands will not be harmed and that it is taking environmental issues into consideration. In an interview Sunday in the newspaper Folha de São Paulo, Mr. Cameron said that when the Xikrin-Kayapó leaders asked for his help, he “could not turn away.” “I want to take a 3-D camera to film how they live, their culture,” he added. Mr. Cameron has made previous trips to Brazil to show his support and has already made a short film about the issue, which will be included on the forthcoming “Avatar” special-edition DVD. Work on the dam is scheduled to begin late this year or in early 2011.

For 12 hours a day on Saturday and Sunday, disc jockeys (not all using discs) pumped out 4/4 beats from four stages, and dancers in party costumes  with cat ears, fake-fur leggings, fluorescent wigs and all kinds of glitter  raised their hands in the air to channel them.

headline: Marketing Fanciful Items in the Lands of Make Believe

When certain books are unavailable as e-books in any format. When certain bands refuse to sell their albums on anything but plastic discs.

text: The latest New York Times poll was based on telephone interviews conducted Aug. 27 to 31 in New York City with 892 adults, of whom 754 said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.

All over her middle-class neighborhood, the stores were filled with an ample selection of goods, reflecting just how much Moscow has changed over the last two decades. With one exception.

headline: Rising to the Occasion
text: On Labor Day afternoon in Milwaukee, President Obama finally began to vigorously push the kind of high-profile, rebuild-America infrastructure campaign that is absolutely essential if there is to be any real hope of putting Americans back to work and getting the economy back into reasonable shape over the next few years.

headline: Germany: Deal Reached to Extend Nuclear Power Use
text: Reversing a popular decision to shut down 17 aging nuclear power plants by 2025, Germany’s coalition government agreed on Sunday to extend their use by up to 14 years, news services here reported on Monday. The decision, if approved by Parliament, would upend a plan adopted in 2002 that was opposed by energy producers, but supported by a public wary about an accident. The proposal would allow plants built before 1980 to remain open 8 additional years, while newer plants would be able to continue for 14 more years. Chancellor Angela Merkel hailed the plan, saying it would allow Germany the time to develop renewable resources. The deal also calls for reactor operators to pay billions of dollars in new taxes and fees to help finance a fund for renewable energy, news agencies reported.

headline: Britain: Strike Disrupts Subway Service in London
text: The 3.5 million riders on the London Tube faced disruptions on Monday when, at 5 p.m., as many as 10,000 subway drivers, station workers and engineers staged the first of a series of 24-hour strikes over employment cuts. Mayor Boris Johnson called in 100 extra buses and a 500-berth boat that will carry 10,000 people along the Thames River to help commuters.

headline: Who Should Provide Anesthesia Care?
text: Can a highly trained nurse deliver anesthetics as well as a physician who has specialized in anesthesiology, or does the nurse require close medical supervision? That issue emerges from two recent studies and from California’s decision last year to join 14 other states in freeing the nurses from a federal requirement that they be supervised by a physician. Colorado seems poised to join the group.

headline: In a New Role, Teachers Move to Run Schools
text: NEWARK  Shortly after landing at Malcolm X Shabazz High School as a Teach for America recruit, Dominique D. Lee grew disgusted with a system that produced ninth graders who could not name the seven continents or the governor of their state. He started wondering: What if I were in charge?

headline: China Begins Aviation Inquiry After Finding Fake Pilot Résumés
text: HONG KONG  The Chinese government is conducting a broad investigation into the qualifications of the country’s pilots, aircraft mechanics, flight trainers and other aviation personnel after finding that as many as 200 commercial pilots may have falsified their résumés in 2008 and 2009, according to reports in the Chinese news media on Monday and Tuesday.

headline: Japan’s Leadership Merry-Go-Round
text: Japan’s frequent leadership changes are dizzying and increasingly counterproductive. The country has had 14 prime ministers in the last two decades and could soon have another. That would make three in the last 12 months alone  hardly time enough to introduce new policies, much less effectively implement them.

headline: Hope for a Bronx Tower of Hip-Hop Lore
text: Housing advocates, tenants and elected officials have declared a victory in the Bronx with the announcement of the sale of the mortgage on an apartment building that has been called the birthplace of hip-hop. The sale, which was financed with significant help from city agencies, was the first step toward bringing in new owners after what tenants called an era of neglect.

headline: An Attorney General Bid Sets a Rare Focus Upstate
text: The math is easy: As much as 70 percent of Democratic primary voters in New York State live south and east of Bear Mountain. Accordingly, the candidates in this year’s primary for attorney general have spent much of their time seeking votes in New York City and its suburbs.

headline: A Necessary Moratorium
text: Last Thursday’s fire on a shallow-water oil production platform in the Gulf of Mexico claimed no lives and has caused no environmental damage. It was, however, a nerve-racking reminder that extracting fossil fuels is an inherently dangerous business. As such, it was a very good argument for maintaining the present moratorium on deep-water drilling in the gulf and removing it only when industry has met the standards the administration set forth in the spring.

headline: Polarization of Supreme Court Clerks
text: The conservative half of the Supreme Court overwhelmingly hires clerks who served judges appointed by Republican presidents.

headline: A Well-Traveled Path From Ivy League to Supreme Court
text: Justice Clarence Thomas recalled the reaction from “self-proclaimed smart bloggers” when he looked beyond the Ivy League to hire law clerks from Creighton, George Mason, George Washington and Rutgers for the Supreme Court term that started in 2008.

headline: A Sign of the Court’s Polarization: Choice of Clerks
text: WASHINGTON  Each year, 36 young lawyers obtain the most coveted credential in American law: a Supreme Court clerkship. Clerking for a justice is a glittering capstone on a résumé that almost always includes outstanding grades at a top law school, service on a law review and a prestigious clerkship with a federal appeals court judge.

headline: For E. B. White’s Tree, Chapter Ends

headline: Takeover Offer for Airgas Is Sweetened
text: Air Products and Chemicals on Monday raised its takeover offer for Airgas to $5.48 billion in cash, as it presses forward with a proxy fight over Airgas’s board. Under the terms of its new offer, Air Products would pay $65.50 a share, up from $63.50. The price remains below where Airgas shares have traded for much of last month; they closed on Friday at $66.67. Air Products also said that its takeover proposal hinged on winning three board seats and on the approval of several changes to Airgas’s bylaws at its shareholder meeting on Sept. 15. If neither happens, Air Products said, it will walk away. In a statement, Air Products’ chief, John E. McGlade, argued that the new offer represented a significant premium to Airgas’s share price in February, before the plan was unveiled.

headline: German Banks May Need New Capital
text: The 10 biggest lenders in Germany, including Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank, may need about 105 billion euros ($135 billion) in capital because of new regulation, the Association of German Banks said. The lenders would need to raise that sum to reach an estimated 10 percent Tier 1 capital ratio, a crucial measure of financial strength, according to Dirk Jaeger, who is responsible for regulatory topics at the group. The association said higher capital requirements, set to be proposed on Tuesday by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, might endanger the economic recovery by limiting the ability to lend.

headline: Gartmore Fund Is Said to Back Away From Firm
text: Gartmore Growth Opportunities may be breaking away from its namesake hedge fund management firm, The Financial Times reported. The fund notified Gartmore it might not be managing its assets any longer, a move that comes just days after one of Gartmore’s top executives, Gervais Williams, resigned.

headline: Petronas, Valued at $2 Billion, Files for I.P.O.
text: Petronas of Malaysia has filed a draft prospectus for an initial public offering of its entire petrochemicals business, moving a step closer toward creating country’s second largest I.P.O. after Maxis.

headline: Dubai Unit to Delay Repayment
text: Dubai Holding‘s main unit will delay repayment on a $555 million loan until Nov. 30, the company said on Tuesday, the second time it has failed to meet a repayment deadline, Reuters reported.

headline: Morgenson: BB? AAA? Disclosure Tells Us More
text: From Gretchen Morgenson’s latest Fair Game column for The New York Times:

headline: Menlo Ventures Looks to Raise Up to $800 Million
text: The primary investor of 3Par, Menlo Ventures, is looking to raise $600 million to $800 million for a new fund that would surpass Battery Ventures‘ and Institutional Venture Partners‘ $750 million funds raised this year, according to a report by Bloomberg News.

headline: European ‘Stress Tests’ Blurred Risky Debt
text: The European “stress tests” that looked at the viability of the continent’s major banks under a number of hypothetical scenarios, underestimated the amount of potentially risky government debt held by some of the institutions tested, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: European Regulators to Consider Anglo Irish Bank’s Future
text: Ireland’s finance minister, Brian Lenihan, met Monday with European Union regulators to discuss the crisis over Anglo Irish Bank — a day before talks that could lead to the creation of a system to shield taxpayers from paying for similar costly collapses in the future, The New York Times’s James Kanter reported.

headline: British Airways and Iberia Look to Asia for Deals
text: British Airways and Iberia have identified possible acquisition targets to pursue once their own merger completes, with Asia seen as a key region for expansion, Reuters reported.

headline: Justice Department Probes Google ITA Deal
text: The United States Justice Department is looking into Google‘s takeover of airline ticketing software firm ITA Software, to determine whether the deal would exert too much influence on the online travel industry, Reuters said, citing a report in The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Do You Identify Yourself as a Democrat or a Republican?
text: “Fewer Young Voters See Themselves as Democrats” was the headline of a recent Times article that described how “though many students are liberals on social issues, the economic reality of a weak job market has taken a toll on their loyalties.” Does that describe you, or young people you know? Do you identify yourself as a member of a particular political party? Why or why not?

headline: A New Way for Less to Mean More
text: One of the latest trends in the lead-into-gold financial alchemy of hedge funds is making money from bankruptcy, The Wall Street Journal writes.

headline: Test Yourself | English, September 7, 2010
text: Test your literacy skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times article “Solutions to Dorm Crowding.”

headline: Basel Committee Seeks 9% Tier 1 Capital
text: Global banks will be required to hold Tier 1 capital of 9 percent, including a 3 percent “conservation buffer,” Reuters said, citing a report in German weekly Die Zeit that quoted a draft proposal from the Basel Committee, the body drawing up global banking rules.

headline: Macquarie Profit Warning Signals Wider Malaise
text: Macquarie Group, the Australian investment bank, warned that profit in a number of its deal-making and trading divisions would be down by a quarter compared to the year before.

headline: Infrastructure

headline: Barclays Names Diamond as Its New Chief
text: Barclays of Britain said Tuesday that Robert E. Diamond Jr. would be its new chief executive, Julia Werdigier and Michael J. de la Merced report in The New York Times.

headline: Helpful Resources for Fantasy Football
text: Sara Holladay is the Fantasy Football Librarian.

headline: London Series Turns Sermons Inside-Out
text: This month The School of Life, an inquisitive, London-based organization founded in 2008, kicks off its monthly series of Sunday sermons, offering “hellfire preaching, an alternative parish newsletter, hymns, sticky buns, conversations with fellow ‘parishioners’ and the possible appearance of the Devil himself.” In other words, not your typical church talk.

headline: Not-So-Grand Design
text: Today’s idea: “We don’t have to look for the mind of God in nature and try to express it through our equations,” a scholar says. “Imperfect nature has plenty to offer, if we are willing to embrace its message.”

headline: See the Sound of Your Drawing
text: What if you could see a sound? What would the sound of wind chimes look like? Would it look different from the sound of your voice or a flute?

headline: A Word About Roethlisberger’s Rights
text: The former Steelers quarterback Terry Bradshaw had said “I pray they don’t cut” Ben Roethlisberger’s suspension. Mike Lupica of The Daily News said the ban “shouldn’t have been softened one bit.” Nigel Scott, a Fifth Down reader, says it was the right call.

headline: How Exactly Am I Going to Handle This?
text: When you’re pregnant, people ask a lot of questions: When are you due? Boy or girl? Do you have a name picked out? And when you are a pregnant business owner, people want to know how exactly you’re going to handle everything.Truthfully? I have no idea.

text: Q.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: — From the BBC, a radio show on “The Entrepreneur’s Wound.” Sometimes what doesn’t kill you only makes you richer.

headline: Citi’s $50 Billion Tax Headache
text: Citigroup‘s $50 billion tax question isn’t going away.

headline: Renewed European Worry Hurts Shares
text: United States investors took their cues from overseas on Tuesday and sent shares lower amid worrying news about the European banks.

text: Jene Bramel writes for Footballguys.com. You can also follow him on Twitter and reach him at bramel@footballguys.com.

headline: HSBC Says Green Stepping Down for Ministry
text: Stephen Green, chairman of HSBC, is stepping down to become the British trade minister, the bank announced Tuesday.

headline: Fresh Capital in the Uranium Fuel Race
text: For decades, the business of enriching uranium for  use in nuclear reactors was simple: companies bought the uranium and sent it to one of the plants built by the federal government as part of its nuclear weapons program. The government increased the proportion of uranium 235, the kind that splits easily in reactors.

headline: Another Kind of Medical Error
text: While there is a lot of discussion these days about how to improve the quality of medical care, Dr. Robert M. Wachter, a professor of medicine at the University of California, San Francisco, has identified what he believes is an important but neglected issue: diagnostic errors.

headline: Barclays: The Investment Bank Strikes Back
text: Is the ascension of Robert E. Diamond Jr. as chief executive of Barclays an affirmation of investment banking?

headline: Democrats Aren’t Running From Health Care. But What Are They Running On?
text: It’s clear that Republican candidates for Congress expect to gain traction from the health care bill that Democrats passed this year, and that most polls show at least a plurality of the country remains opposed to. Although most Democratic candidates are willing to address the health care issue, they are having to do so more carefully.

headline: Mercury is in Retrograde
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared the excuses they have used, overheard or been offered.

headline: What to Watch at the Open on Tuesday
text: With Mardy Fish and John Isner out, the focus for United States fans shifts to the other big American, 6-foot-6 Sam Querrey, who will face the giant killer Stanislas Wawrinka on Arthur Ashe Stadium on Tuesday.

headline: Thinking Outside the Two-State Box
text: On Sunday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said it was time to “embrace original thinking, to think outside the box” to find “new solutions to old problems” in the Middle East, as my colleague Ethan Bronner reported.

headline: May the Force of Nostalgia Be With You
text: Bobbie Wygant Interviews Harrison Ford for Star Wars 1977 from Atombomb.tv on Vimeo.

headline: Norm Macdonald Doesn’t Want to Go Back to Work Any More Than You Do
text: If you’re finding yourself in a post-Labor Day funk and feeling as if you have an uneasy relationship with your job, try putting yourself in the position of Norm Macdonald. On the one hand, Mr. Macdonald, the veteran “Saturday Night Live” performer and deadpan “Weekend Update” anchor, has a thriving stand-up comedy career and is a late-night television guest to look forward to when he makes his occasional appearances. On the other, Mr. Macdonald says he’s still trying to shake the reputation he was tagged with in 1998, when he was fired from “S.N.L.” by an NBC executive who didn’t find him funny.

headline: Did ‘TLC’ Mean a Paintbrush or a Sledgehammer?
text: The phrase TLC, or “tender loving care,” can mean many things to different people. A plant that needs a little TLC may want for water and sunlight. Someone who is coming down with a cold and needs a little TLC may want chicken soup and some extra blankets at night. Then there are homes that need TLC and the brokers who promote them.

headline: The Early Word: Back to School
text: President Obama, after seeing his daughters off for their first day of school, will spend the day in meetings with Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and the NATO secretary general, Anders Fogh Rasmussen.

headline: Food Crisis Worsens in West Africa
text: Torrential rains and flash floods that swept through cities and villages in West Africa in late August have intensified a food crisis in the region, leaving upwards of 10 million people suffering from severe food shortages, the United Nations and relief organizations warned last week.

headline: Godard Won’t Pick Up Honorary Oscar in Person
text: Lest the distinction of an honorary Academy Award contradict his reputation as a film-making provocateur and a feisty founding member of the French New Wave movement, Jean-Luc Godard has found a way to have his cake and eat it too: he will not appear in person to accept the award at a ceremony in November, but will likely send a colleague to receive it in his place, The Australian reported.

headline: Tony Stewart Wins in Atlanta
text: Tony Stewart, in a Chevrolet, raced away from the Ford of Carl Edwards on a late restart after a caution period and held on to win the Nascar race at Atlanta on Sunday night by 1.3 seconds. Jimmie Johnson, the defending series champion, was third in another Chevrolet. Stewart and Edwards were among 10 drivers whose finishes to date have gained them a position in the final 10-race drive for the season championship, which begins Sept. 19 at Loudon, N.H. Two of the 12 spots available in the chase remain open and will be decided next weekend at Richmond, Va., ostensibly among Greg Biffle, Clint Bowyer, Ryan Newman and Jamie McMurray. McMurray was the winner Saturday night of the Nationwide series event, edging Kyle Busch.

headline: Open House: Are Fans Loyal, Opportunistic or Just Suckers for a Pretty Face?
text: Michael Kimmelman, the Times’s chief art critic, and Gerry Marzorati, editor of the Sunday Magazine, are covering the Open from uncommon perspectives. Each morning, they discuss what’s happening. Join the conversation — or ask a fan-oriented question — by sending in a comment.

headline: Tuesday Reading: A Plan to Increase Jobs
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Man Booker Prize Shortlist Announced
text: Six authors, including Tom McCarthy for his novel “C” and Emma Donoghue for “Room,” were named on Tuesday to the shortlist for the 2010 Man Booker Prize for Fiction, the most prestigious literary award in Britain.

headline: Do Daughters Cause Divorce?
text: Parents of girls are 5 percent more likely to divorce than parents of boys. Economists first analyzed the data that way in 2003, when Gordon Dahl at the University of Rochester and Enrico Moretti at U.C.L.A., identified that gap, and noted that it widened as you added boys or girls to a family. Parents of three girls, for instance, are 10 percent more likely to split than are parents of three boys. And, they found, an unmarried couple is more likely to marry if they learn their unborn child will be a boy than a girl.

headline: Author Spotlight: Charles Yu
text: Charles Yu’s first novel, “How to Live Safely in a Science Fictional Universe,” was reviewed for us this past weekend by Ander Monson, who called it “a complex, brainy, genre-hopping joyride of a story, far more than the sum of its component parts.” He also compared the book (narrated by a time-machine repairman who lives with a virtual dog and a neurotic piece of software) to the work of Douglas Adams. “Like Adams,” Monson wrote, Yu is “very funny, usually proportional to the wildness of his inventions.”

headline: Author Spotlight: Charles Yu
text: Charles Yu’s first novel, “How to Live Safely in a Science Fictional Universe,” was reviewed for us this past weekend by Ander Monson, who called it “a complex, brainy, genre-hopping joyride of a story, far more than the sum of its component parts.” He also compared the book (narrated by a time-machine repairman who lives with a virtual dog and a neurotic piece of software) to the work of Douglas Adams. “Like Adams,” Monson wrote, Yu is “very funny, usually proportional to the wildness of his inventions.”

headline: A Car Fit for ‘The King’ Is Going to Auction
text: Elvis Presley may not have been known for car songs the way that, say, the Beach Boys were (despite the ridiculous “(There’s) No Room to Rhumba in a Sports Car” from “Fun in Acapulco”), but he certainly was known for cars: buying them, driving them, giving them away. Now one of his more impressive cars, a 1970 Mercedes-Benz 600, is being auctioned off in Surrey, England, at a Bonhams year-end event colorfully known as the Important Motor Cars and Fine Automobilia sale.

headline: About That Generator, Captain
text: This post is a sequel to “Where’s My Generator, Spy?”, in which an Afghan officer demanded “his” generator back from American forces.

headline: In Earthquakes, Poverty, Population and Motion Matter
text: There are plenty of reasons damage and deaths from the 7.1-magnitude earthquake that struck near Christchurch, New Zealand, on Saturday utterly paled compared to the absolute devastation wrought by the 7.0-magnitude quake near Port-au-Prince, Haiti. I sent a query about the different outcomes in Christchuch, Haiti (and Chile) to a half dozen engineers and geologists working on earthquake preparedness and design and you can read some of their observations below.

headline: Back to School: New York Times Resources for Social Studies and History
text: Whether your school year started in August or is just getting underway, here are some basic ways to use The New York Times use this year with your social studies and history students.

headline: Another, Safer Route for Engineers: National Security
text: I had an article today about the less-than-stellar job prospects for American software engineers.

headline: Jets’ Smallest Player Sees a Tiny Opening
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  A smaller drama played out Monday in the corner of the Jets’ locker room opposite Darrelle Revis’s locker. Larry Taylor, the 5-foot-6 free-agent wide receiver, kept his cubicle, three down from the spot where David Clowney used to dress.

headline: Kennedy Center Names Annual Honorees
text: Oprah Winfrey said her initial reaction to being told she was a 2010 Kennedy Center honoree could be summed up in two words: “Wowie gazowie.” Merle Haggard? He likened being named an honoree to a “nice kick in the stomach.”

headline: Plea Deal Discussed for Flight Attendant
text: Updated, 12:25 p.m. | For this moment in the spotlight, Steven Slater traded his flight attendant’s uniform for a dark blue suit. And this time, instead of going on the public address system and talking back to a passenger he said had blessed him out, he said nothing.

headline: The Week Ahead in Health Industry News
text: How much does malpractice cost the medical system? About $55.6 billion a year, or 2.4 percent of annual health care spending, according to a study on medical liability published today in Health Affairs.

headline: Analysis: How Wozniacki Beat Sharapova
text: In a hard-fought, straight-sets victory, Caroline Wozniacki defeated Maria Sharapova 6-3, 6-4, to advance to the quarterfinals. The match presented a contrast in styles, with Sharapova dictating with aggressive play while Wozniacki worked to outmaneuver Sharapova and force errors. In the end, Sharapova hit 32 clean winners, but her 36 unforced errors gave Wozniacki enough of a margin to pull ahead in each set.

headline: Clubhouse Confidential
text: Gay Talese left the prime real estate to his colleagues. Let other reporters write stories that would land their bylines on the front page. That meant covering the news. For Talese, the news was never the story.

headline: Sons of Captain to Carry On ‘Deadliest Catch’
text: The two sons of Capt. Phil Harris, a fisherman whose death was documented on “Deadliest Catch” last season, will remain on the series in future seasons.

headline: Men’s Group Gets Men Talking
text: “What’s on your minds today, gentlemen?” Paul Heron, a social worker, asked the circle of men. That’s the way he convenes most Wednesday afternoon gatherings of the Riverdale Senior Services center’s men’s group.

headline: At the Asian Feastival in Queens
text: As with so much in life, you get what you pay for in food festivals. Or feastivals.

headline: Many Kinds of Universes, and None Require God
text: Stephen Hawking, the most revered scientist since Einstein, is a formidable mathematician and a formidable salesman. “I want my books sold on airport bookstalls,” he has impishly declared, and he’s learned how to put them there.

headline: Bonds: Higher Returns Equal Greater Risk
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Prasada Capital.

headline: Critic of Russia Security Gets Reprieve
text: MOSCOW  For more than two years, the mayor of a Siberian village was held in a pretrial detention center after she filed complaints against the successor agency to the Soviet-era K.G.B. Finally freed on bail this summer after her case began attracting attention, she was unexpectedly given a further reprieve on Tuesday.

headline: A New Theory on the Origin of the Lewis Chessmen
text: The Lewis Chessmen are the most famous and important chess pieces in history. They have a long historical and scholarly record, part of which is that they were made in Norway roughly 800 years ago. But now two Icelandic men are challenging that belief and trying to prove that the pieces came from their country.

headline: The Goldman Contender for the HSBC Job
text: John L. Thornton, the former co-president of Goldman Sachs, is considered to be among the possible leading candidates to replace Stephen Green as chairman of HSBC

text: Links from around the Web.

headline: $600 Billion
text: Oy, it seems that another out-of-context quote of mine is being used to claim that I thought the Obama stimulus plan was just dandy. So: back in 2008, I wrote this piece in which I called for stimulus of 4 percent of GDP, or $600 billion. Didn’t we get that, and more?

headline: State Gains Would Give Redistricting Edge to G.O.P.
text: The midterm elections are being closely watched to determine whether Republicans will have a majority in Congress for the next two years. But it is the outcome of a lower-profile battle over state legislatures that could strengthen the Republican Party for a decade.

headline: Leader of the Pack
text: ‘They treated me like an invisible man,” Bruce Davidson told me. “I was a shadow.”

headline: N.F.L. Continues to Adjust Position of Umpire
text: The N.F.L. sent a memo to teams Tuesday outlining what it hopes will be the final tweaks to the umpire move to the offensive backfield. The move has provoked criticism, particularly from the Indianapolis Colts, because of concerns that the move slows down hurry-up offenses.

text: Today, the politics over President Obama's latest attempt to stimulate the economy, hundreds of looted Iraqi artifacts are returned to Baghdad, and controversy over the health risks of BPA.

headline: The College Essay as an Early Memoir
text: Last weekend, I participated in a weekend writing workshop. In a sun-filled room overlooking the Berkshires, I sat amid 30 or so other writers for two days, as we talked, listened, read and practiced the art of memoir writing.

headline: Seeking Your Back-to-School Admissions Questions
text: The end of Labor Day weekend is the unofficial beginning of the college admissions season — as high school seniors contemplate pushing the button on early and rolling applications, and juniors start to compile lists of colleges and draft essays.

headline: Kazan Documentary, With Scorsese Pedigree, Will Come to TV, DVD and Theaters
text: Wider audiences will soon have an opportunity to weigh in on a Martin Scorsese documentary about the filmmaker Elia Kazan, which has already drawn attention at the Venice and Telluride film festivals.

headline: Ads Urge Wineries to Stick a Cork in It
text: The Portuguese cork industry, backed by the Portuguese government, is undertaking an American-style campaign with a green twist.

headline: Listening To The Bond Market — Or Not
text: Stan Collender has been getting sort of, well, shrill over the way in which austerity enthusiasts told us that we had to utterly obey what the bond market was saying when interest rates were rising, but are telling us to ignore the market now that rates are very low.

text: Arnold Worldwide, Boston, part of Havas, promoted two executives to managing partners. They are Tom Guerin, executive vice president and executive director, and Neela Pal, executive vice president and global director for brand and business strategy.

text: My boyfriend and I want to take a vacation to an international urban destination over Christmas break (late December/early January). We were thinking of Turkey, but a quick scan of airfares showed high prices (more than $850). And I read that winters in Turkey are cold. Would you suggest some places that we should consider?

text: Portmanteau term denoting agreement tempered by a contrary view.

text: With the New York Stock Exchange as a backdrop, the United States Ryder Cup captain, Corey Pavin, rounded out his 12-man team Tuesday with three blue-chip choices and one initial public offering with some real potential.

text: Enterprise Products Partners, one of the nation’s biggest pipeline operators, said on Tuesday that it would buy Enterprise GP Holdings in a deal valued at more than $8 billion, simplifying the corporate structure of the group founded by the late billionaire Dan Duncan.

text: That’s the lesson of this TED talk from Sugata Mitra. Mr. Mitra conducts experiments in which he plants computers in poor villages in the developing world, without instruction or supervision, and watches what happens.

headline: The Start-Up’s Chicken-and-Egg Dilemma, Part 2
text: Thanks to all who shared their knowledge with in-depth assessments of the issues presented in She Owns It’s case study, “Getting Started: The Chicken-and-Egg Question.” Commenters explored numerous angles in their advice for Fran Gunsaulis, the owner of Oh Baby Foods. Some popular suggestions: find an investor, stay independent, ramp up e-commerce, raise prices and drop the delivery service — or at least forget about franchising for now.

headline: TimesCast: Obama’s Economy Jump-Start
text: On today’s TimesCast, Associate National Editor Marcus Mabry discusses President Obama’s latest effort to stimulate the economy with Sheryl Gay Stolberg, White House correspondent.

headline: Paladino, Insider, Runs Against Establishment
text: As he wages an insurgent campaign for governor of New York, Carl P. Paladino has styled himself as the anti-establishment candidate bent on reforming a state government that he says needs someone who can “take out the trash.”

headline: Inside Out | Necessary Luxuries
text: In an interview last week for a blog called A Lovely Being, I was asked what advice I had for someone who was doing up her first apartment. The question made me think about decorating my own first apartment, the things that I did then, which pieces have faded from memory and which ones I still love.

headline: The Boston Post Road: A Path Through History
text: Shoppers looking for a bargain along Connecticut’s heavily developed Route 1 corridor may not realize it, but their wheels are turning on historical ground. According to Eric Jaffe’s absorbing new book, “The King’s Best Highway,” the road that is now cluttered with gas stations, outlet shops and fast-food restaurants was in the 17th century a narrow wilderness trail, and the traveler making the round trip between New York and Boston would probably want to budget a month for the journey.

headline: Is BPA Safe? Europe Also Seeks Answers
text: European health officials seem to be in the same boat as those in America who are having trouble deciding whether the chemical BPA, or bisphenol-A, is safe.

headline: Follow the Open Via Twitter, Day 8
text: 11:08 p.m. | Updated  Gerry Marzorati, one-half of the Open House duo, is covering the United States Open via Twitter. Now that all the matches (except Nadal-Lopez) have concluded, go directly to gerrynyt to read his observations.

headline: Spitzer, Once Dubious, Now Supports Cuomo
text: Eliot Spitzer, who last spring expressed strong reservations about Andrew M. Cuomo’s qualifications to be his elected successor as governor, now says he will vote for him.

headline: The 2 Deal Makers Who Share Oracle’s Presidency
text: The hiring of Mark V. Hurd (pictured) as Oracle‘s newest co-president arises in part from the former Hewlett-Packard chief’s close friendship with the tech titan Lawrence J. Ellison.

headline: Looted Iraqi Artifacts Returned
text: Stephen Farrell reports from Baghdad on the return of Iraqi artifacts that were looted.

headline: He’s O.K.: ‘Rocky Horror’ Creator Given Residency in New Zealand
text: Talk about your celluloid jams: at the start of the summer, Richard O’Brien, the author and composer of the cross-dressing cult classic “The Rocky Horror Show” (and its midnight movie incarnation, “The Rocky Horror Picture Show”) applied for residency in New Zealand, where he planned to retire to the coastal town of Katikati. But like a statuesque man-monster climbing a small replica of the RKO Pictures tower, the British-born Mr. O’Brien, 68, was shot down: New Zealand immigration officials said he did not meet the criteria, which include being age 55 or under and having a job offer.

headline: Hussein Kalashnikov Returned to Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — This chrome-plated Kalashnikov AK-47 assault rifle, with a pearl hand grip and receiver, was manufactured by an Iraqi weapons factory which produced personalized assault rifles for Saddam Hussein’s family and friends. Bearing a tiny image of the dictator near the sighting mechanism, it was looted after the 2003 invasion and has been returned to Iraq along with hundreds of other items, as Steven Lee Myers reports.

headline: Looking at Hamas and Seeing the I.R.A.
text: As international attention focused on efforts to turn swords into plowshares in the Middle East, Gerry Adams, who convinced the I.R.A. to lay down its weapons and embrace politics, revealed on Monday that he had been engaged in the secret talks that led ETA, the Basque separatist group, to declare a cease-fire this week. The announcement came via a videotaped message.

headline: Quote Unquote | Trash and Vaudeville
text: –Ke$ha tells MTV how she acquired her ridiculous wardrobe. I understand she raids dumpsters for her clothes, but are they dumpsters behind a Halloween store?

headline: Edge Lost, Querrey Cannot Catch Up
text: Early in his fourth-round United States Open match against Stanislas Wawrinka, Sam Querrey’s serve looked like an unstoppable weapon. Querrey strolled around his side of the court as if he were ready to extend his run as the last American man in the American Grand Slam.

headline: Iraqi Treasures Return, but Questions Remain
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq announced on Tuesday the return of hundreds of looted antiquities that had ended up in the United States, even as a senior official disclosed that 632 pieces repatriated last year and turned over to the office of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki were now unaccounted for.

headline: G.I. Deaths Are First for U.S. After Combat Mission’s End
text: BAGHDAD  Two American soldiers were killed and nine were wounded on Tuesday when a firefight erupted inside an Iraqi Army base north of Baghdad, American and Iraqi officials said. They were the first American casualties since President Obama declared an official end to the United States combat mission in Iraq a week ago.

headline: Debate in House Race Stirs Big Passions for a Small Audience
text: It sounded a lot like amateur hour as a long-awaited radio debate began on Tuesday between Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, the nine-term incumbent from Manhattan and Queens, and her challenger in the Democratic primary, Reshma Saujani, a 34-year-old who was a lawyer for a hedge fund.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Cast Adds Four and Loses One More
text: “Saturday Night Live” has finalized its cast for the coming 36th season of the NBC late-night sketch series, hiring four new featured players while dropping a performer who was added to its ensemble last year. The information was provided by a person with firsthand knowledge of planning at “Saturday Night Live” but who was not given permission by NBC to speak on the matter.

headline: H.P. Sues Hurd Over His New Job at Oracle
text: Hewlett-Packard on Tuesday sued Mark V. Hurd, its former chairman and chief executive, one day after he joined rival Oracle as co-president.

headline: Trying to Unravel an Unsolved Murder, Surrounded by Living Reminders
text: His name is Carlos, and he lives in Woodhaven, Queens, with his parents, and he has a child. That’s about all Martha Mora knows about the man.

headline: H.P. Sues Its Ex-Chief in New Job
text: Hewlett-Packard’s tumultuous breakup with its former chief executive Mark V. Hurd may soon warrant its own reality TV show.

headline: Courtside: 'Open House'
text: Gerry Marzorati and Michael Kimmelman are covering the nooks and crannies of the Open. A report from the second week of the tournament.

headline: School of Rap | Big Easy Edition
text: The fifth anniversary of Hurricane Katrina did not go by quietly last month, but a candidate for this year’s most unlikely benefit record may have been overlooked — a forgivable failure of marketing on the part of Michael Patrick Welch, the New Orleans teacher who recorded and produced the album.

headline: Blast Strikes Pakistani Police Area
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A powerful blast ripped through a residential compound for police officials and their families in Pakistan’s restive northwest on Tuesday evening, killing at least 18 people, including women and children, officials said.

headline: Chicago’s Mayor Daley: ‘I’ve Done My All’
text: 5:35 p.m. | Updated  Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago said Tuesday that he would not run for re-election when his term expires next year, an announcement that could have implications from the Windy City to the White House.

headline: Shirov Wins Shanghai Masters
text: With a third consecutive win, Shirov has qualified for the Bilbao Masters Final next month in Spain. One other place remains up for grabs.

headline: Flea Theater Invests in a Permanent Home
text: With small theater companies across New York struggling to make rent or renegotiate leases in a difficult economic climate, executives of Off Off Broadway’s Flea Theater said on Tuesday that they have purchased a building downtown to create a new home, concluding that buying instead of renting was necessary for its survival.

headline: Street Cred vs. Green Cred
text: When it comes to environmental degradation, those who live and work in the open air are more exposed than most. Someone strumming a guitar for tips on the sidewalk or reading tarot cards at the curb or operating a pedicab cannot help but breathe in the pollution in the air.

headline: Letter: Another Taste of the Fair
text: To the Editor: Nothing wrong with reminding readers of the book, musical and movie “State Fair” in “Life Spins On, But the Midway Still Beckons” (Aug. 29), but for a more contemporary account, the author might have referred us to the David Foster Wallace essay “Ticket to the Fair,” reprinted as “Getting Away From Already Being Pretty Much Away From It All” in the collection “A Supposedly Fun Thing I’ll Never Do Again.”

headline: Letter: The Way It Was
text: To the Editor: Regarding the article “Nothing Boutique About It” (Aug. 15): There are few places in the world that have the Greenbrier’s old-time elegant ambience. In management’s attempt to please the regulars while also attracting the masses, the Greenbrier may be losing much of its uniqueness and charm. What’s wrong with timeless traditional?

headline: Potash’s Chief Speaks Out on BHP Bid
text: William Doyle, the chief executive of the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, hasn’t been shy about dismissing BHP Billiton‘s nearly $40 billion takeover offer for his company.

headline: Migrant Berry Pickers Complain of Conditions in Sweden
text: The image of migrant workers freezing, living in squalor or demanding better pay and conditions is not typical in Sweden.

headline: European Official Calls for Backing Building Projects
text: In his first State of the Union speech, José Manuel Barroso, the European Commission president, called Tuesday for the creation of bonds to initiate infrastructure projects and tackle unemployment.

headline: More Evidence for Store Brands
text: Earlier this year, I wrote a Bucks post about how consumers are increasingly opting for cheaper store-brand groceries and I shared my own anecdotal evidence that some store-brand products are just as good as their name-brand counterparts.

headline: "Zombieville"
text: The first "Zombieville" commercial from the Truth campaign that appeared during "The Real World: New Orleans."

headline: Youzhny Moves Into Quarterfinals
text: Despite hitting 40 unforced errors, five more than his opponent, Mikhail Youzhny of Russia worked his way into the United States Open men’s quarterfinals with a steady, four-set victory over Tommy Robredo of Spain, 7-5, 6-2, 4-6, 6-4.

headline: Elite or Expansionist? Soho Clubs Want to Be Both
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  Nick Jones, the founder of Soho House, a chain of members-only clubs that includes an outpost here, knows about exclusivity. Last winter, after he found the New York Soho House too crowded, he cut several hundred members from the rolls, sacrificing revenue to maintain the cachet his company depends on.

headline: Following the Open’s Eighth Day
text: Gerry Marzorati, one-half of the Open House duo, is covering the United States Open via his smart phone, mostly through Twitter but also through live-blogging. To read his updates from Tuesday, click on “Read More.” You can also go to gerrynyt.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Melvin and Howard’
text: This week, A. O. Scott explores the American Dream and its paradoxes with Jonathan Demme’s “Melvin and Howard.” The film tells the story of Melvin Dummar (Paul LeMat), a working man, who finds Howard (Jason Robards) in the desert after a motorcycle accident and gives him a ride into town. Howard turns out to be the reclusive billionaire Howard Hughes, who leaves Melvin a significant inheritance in his will. The movie asks questions about the complexities of our relationship to money and Mr. Scott calls it an “affectionate, authentic portrait of a typically contradictory American character.” Have you seen “Melvin and Howard?” Please share your thoughts.

headline: Who Hates Making School Lunch?
text: Jennifer Rosenstrach loves dinner. Loves it so much that Rosenstrach, a freelance writer and editor, has created a Web site, DinneraLoveStory.com, devoted to “helping parents figure out how to get family dinner on the table.” Loves it so much that she has kept a journal of what she has eaten for dinner every night for 12 years. (You can read Susan Dominus’s column about that dinner journal here.)

headline: Streaming Your Entire Computer to a Television
text: If you want to watch Web-enabled video on your television, you could buy a number of gadgets that will hook up directly to your TV set. But most of these contraptions offer only a narrow hallway of content and don’t allow full access to the Internet or a Web browser.

headline: A Night in the Kitchen at Eleven Madison Park
text: Behind the scenes at the chef Daniel Humm’s four-star restaurant.

headline: Filmmaker Ordered to Give Testimony in Chevron Case
text: 10:52 a.m. | Updated

headline: Jesse Owens Dies of Cancer at 66; Hero of the 1936 Berlin Olympics
text: Jesse Owens, whose four gold medals at the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin made him perhaps the greatest and most famous athlete in track and field history, died of lung cancer yesterday in Tucson, Ariz. He was 66 years old.

headline:
Young Black Leader Dies in Detention in
South Africa, Raising Fears of New Unrest
text: East London, South Africa, Sept. 13--Steven Biko, probably the most influential young black leader in South Africa, died while in police detention last night, allegedly after a hunger striker, and there were fears that his death could increase racial tension.

headline: Sin, the Hot New Government Revenue Strategy
text: A few months ago, I wrote about increasing popularity of sin taxes, which many states were levying or at the very least increasing in order to scrape together more money.

headline: Fashion Week Preview | Siki Im
text: There’s no lack of cultural references in the architect turned men’s wear designer Siki Im’s life — he was born in Cologne, Germany, to Korean parents; had a classical German education; studied at Oxford; and now lives in New York. So when the Ecco Domani Fashion Foundation award winner sets out to create a symbolic mash-up, he’s got the chops to do it. His collections make tongue-in-cheek literary references, blur the lines between masculine and feminine attire, and even manage to slyly subvert Savile Row tailoring. Not bad for someone who says he got into fashion by accident. The Moment stopped by Im’s studio recently for a preview of his spring 2011 collection, which he’ll unveil in a presentation tomorrow night.

headline: Leadership, Personal Courage, Devotion to Troops Won for Pershing Affection of Nation
text: John Joseph Pershing, Commander in Chief of the American Expeditionary Force in the first World War, entered the military service--in which he was to rise to the summit of distinction--almost by accident, for he was planning to be a lawyer when he saw the announcement of an examination for admittance to West Point which changed his career.

headline: Rabin and Arafat Seal Their Accord as Clinton Applauds 'Brave Gamble'
text: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- In a triumph of hope over history, Yitzhak Rabin, the Prime Minister of Israel, and Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the P.L.O., shook hands today on the White House lawn, sealing the first agreement between Jews and Palestinians to end their conflict and share the holy land along the River Jordan that they both call home.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 7
text: A view of the day in sports, with the world wresting championships in Moscow and the world basketball championships in Istanbul.

headline: Margaret Sanger Is Dead at 82; Led Campaign for Birth Control
text: TUCSON, Ariz., Sept. 6--Margaret Sanger, the birth control pioneer, died this afternoon of arteriosclerosis in the Valley House Convalescent Center. She would have been 83 years old on Sept. 14.
Moscow, Monday, Sept. 14--The Soviet Union hit the moon with a space rocket early this morning.

headline: Packaging Is All the Rage, and Not in a Good Way
text: SEATTLE  Doug Herrington’s office at Amazon.com suggests that he is particularly bad at getting items out of their packages. Along his wall, there is a Philips Norelco shaver still in its plastic clamshell casing, coffee pods in their retail display containers and a bottle of Tide inside a box.

headline: Minority Businesses Struggle to Secure City Contracts
text: Businesses owned by women and members of minorities still struggle to secure city contracts, despite nearly five years of legal mandates and targeted goals set by the city, says a new City Council report [pdf – see also below].

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Yes, Pakistan leads the report again on Tuesday, with photographs by Carl De Souza, Damir Sagolj and Asif Hassan, because the news is unrelenting — and almost unrelentingly bad. After scathing criticism that they were unprepared for the disaster and inept in their initial response, Carlotta Gall reported, government officials, ministers and even President Asif Ali Zardari are crisscrossing flood-affected areas of the country in a frantic effort to ease public anger and despair. Pakistani officials, diplomats and aid workers warn that while civil unrest has so far been averted, the aftermath of the worst-ever flooding in Pakistan could destabilize the country in the months to come and aggravate the already deep regional, sectarian and class fissures.

headline: Okie to Beatle: Kennedy Center Honorees
text: WASHINGTON  Oprah Winfrey said her initial reaction to being told she was a 2010 Kennedy Center honoree could be summed up in two words: “Wowie gazowie.” Merle Haggard? He compared being named an honoree to a “nice kick in the stomach.”

headline: The Battle for Stuyvesant Town
text: The fate of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village rests on the interpretation of one clause in a legal agreement.

headline: How “Blame Bush” Plays in Midterm Polls
text: Invoking George W. Bush’s name and linking him to Republican candidates in the 2006 and 2008 elections was certainly good strategy for Democrats – he was actually in office during those years and was a deeply unpopular president.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Sept. 7
text: Images from Tuesday’s matches at the United States Open in Flushing Meadows.

headline: New Ads in Florida Senate Race
text: How do you spell “independent” in Florida?

headline: Inquiry Into Paper for Bank Notes
text: De La Rue, which helps make paper currency for 150 countries, said Tuesday that the British authorities had been called in to investigate “deliberately falsified” tests on paper used to make bank notes.

headline: Bank Panel Nears Deal On Tighter Regulations
text: Regulators from the world’s largest economies appear close to agreement on tightening rules intended to prevent future financial crises, prompting renewed warnings from the banking industry that economic growth could suffer if institutions were required to raise more capital to insulate against market shocks.

headline: Britain Backs New E.U. Oversight Plan
text: BRUSSELS  Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, on Tuesday endorsed a variety of new watchdog agencies to supervise financial activities across the European Union.

headline: Send Us Your Back-to-School Photos
text: As the 2010-11 school year begins in New York City on Wednesday morning, we invite you to submit your photographs from the first day. Parents, show us your kids, their teachers and your fellow parents as pencils are sharpened, new backpacks donned and tales of summer camp recounted. Teachers, share the scene around your classroom and in your school’s hallways.

headline: Homes for $875,000
text: A seven-bedroom English tudor in Kansas City, Mo., a two bedroom bungalow in Sarasota, Fla, and a three-bedroom town house in Washington.

headline: Maersk to Use Cleaner Fuel in Its Hong Kong Shipping
text: HONG KONG  Aiming to reduce noxious fumes in one of the most densely populated parts of Asia, the Danish shipping giant Maersk Line said Tuesday that its ships would switch to low-sulfur fuel when at berth in Hong Kong  a move it hopes will help quicken regulation in Asia.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Black Cracker
text: At a party hosted by Original Plumbing, a quarterly magazine devoted to transsexual male culture, at the Bell House in Gowanus, Brooklyn, Black Cracker (né Ellison Glenn) took the stage by storm, unleashing a barrage of rapid-fire lyrics to thick bounce tracks. Included was a lament on his lack of cash flow in which he talked about his “Metrocard or quarters” since he can’t afford “an unlimited.”

headline: Top-Seeded Women’s Doubles Team Ousted
text: The top-seeded women’s doubles team of Gisela Dulko of Argentina and Flavia Pennetta of Italy fell in surprisingly easy fashion to Vania King of the United States and Yaroslava Shvedova of Kazakhstan.

headline: What You Get for ... $875,000
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Reviewing Fornino Park Slope
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: Who Needs the Gastrotourists?
text: TWENTY years ago, when Fifth Avenue in Park Slope could still be called marginal in the pages of The New York Times, Michael Ayoub opened Cucina there, on the corner of Carroll Street. The restaurant was an elegantly casual Italian trattoria that managed to charm both a burgeoning population of young brownstoners with jobs in Manhattan and the neighborhood’s old guard of professional-class Brooklynites.

headline: Assemblyman Voices Concerns About New Voting System
text: Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky said on Tuesday afternoon that he had asked the Justice Department to assign observers to New York City for next week’s primary election because he was concerned that the use of a new voting method might result in “voter confusion and disenfranchisement.”

headline: HSBC Chairman Joins British Government
text: LONDON  Stephen K. Green is stepping down as chairman of HSBC to join the British government as minister for trade and investment, the bank said Tuesday.

headline: Kazan Documentary to TV, DVD and Theaters
text: Wider audiences will soon have an opportunity to weigh in on a documentary by Martin Scorsese, above, about the filmmaker Elia Kazan, which has already drawn attention at the Venice and Telluride film festivals. On Tuesday representatives for Mr. Scorsese said that “A Letter to Elia,” a documentary directed by Mr. Scorsese and Kent Jones about Kazan’s life and career, would be shown on PBS’s “American Masters” series on Oct. 4, and included in the Elia Kazan Film Collection boxed set that 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment will release on Nov. 9. The documentary will be screened at the New York Film Festival this month with Kazan’s feature “America, America.” The boxed set will contain 15 Kazan films, including 5  “A Tree Grows in Brooklyn,” “Viva Zapata!” “Man on a Tightrope,” “Wild River” and “America, America”  that have not been released on DVD. The films will also be shown theatrically; dates and sites will be posted at lettertoelia.com.

headline: Godard Won’t Pick Up His Honorary Oscar
text: Lest the distinction of an honorary Academy Award contradict his reputation as a film-making provocateur and feisty founding member of the French New Wave movement, Jean-Luc Godard has found a way to have his cake and eat it too: He will not appear in person to accept the award at a ceremony in November, but will probably send a colleague to receive it, The Australian reported. In a brief interview, Mr. Godard, 79, above, told The Australian that he had received a letter from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences notifying him of his honorary Oscar. Though Mr. Godard did not answer additional questions, Anne-Marie Mieville, his wife and collaborator, said he was put off by the fact that the award would be given out at an event held several months before the Oscars ceremony. “He just told me, ‘It’s not the Oscars,’ ” Ms. Mieville said, adding that Mr. Godard would not travel to the United States for the occasion. “He’s getting old for that kind of thing,” she said. “Would you go all that way just for a bit of metal?”

headline: Booker Prize Shortlist Is Announced
text: Six authors, including Tom McCarthy for his novel “C” and Emma Donoghue for “Room,” were named on Tuesday to the shortlist for the 2010 Man Booker Prize for Fiction, the most prestigious literary award in Britain. The other finalists are Peter Carey for “Parrot and Olivier in America” (Faber & Faber), Damon Galgut for “In a Strange Room” (Atlantic Books; Grove/Atlantic), Howard Jacobson for “The Finkler Question” (Bloomsbury) and Andrea Levy for “The Long Song” (Headline Review; Headline Publishing Group). Mr. Carey, who is Australian, has won the prize twice, in 1988 and 2001. The winner is to be announced on Oct. 12. Each shortlisted author will be awarded £2,500 (about $3,800), and the winner will receive £50,000, about $76,600.

headline: Sons to Carry on ‘Deadliest Catch’
text: The two sons of Capt. Phil Harris, a fisherman whose death was documented on “Deadliest Catch” last season, will remain on the series in future seasons. The Discovery Channel said on Tuesday that it had signed a new contract with Josh and Jake Harris, who had worked as deckhands on their father’s boat, the Cornelia Marie, one of several boats featured on that popular reality series. The final episodes of the series last season showed the sons reacting to their father’s stroke and eventual death. Discovery said the Harrises would “expand their participation” on the show and ultimately “increase their experience on the sea with the hopes of becoming captains.” It did not specify the terms of the contract.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Adds Four and Loses One
text: “Saturday Night Live” has finished casting its 36th season, hiring four new featured players while dropping a performer who was added to its ensemble last year. The information was provided by a person with firsthand knowledge of planning at “Saturday Night Live” but who was not given permission by NBC to speak on the matter. Jenny Slate, above left, who finished her freshman year at “Saturday Night Live” in the spring, will not have her contract picked up for a second season, the person said. Will Forte, who performed on and wrote for “Saturday Night Live” for eight seasons, recently announced that he was departing. The new featured performers this coming season, the person said, will be Taran Killam, above right, an actor and comedian who has appeared on the sketch shows “Mad TV” and “Nick Cannon Presents: Wild ‘N Out” and the comedies “Scrubs” and “How I Met Your Mother”; Paul Brittain, a performer from the iO Improv Theater in Chicago; Vanessa Bayer, also of iO in Chicago; and Jay Pharoah, a comedian and impressionist. “Saturday Night Live” will have its season premiere on Sept. 25. Amy Poehler, the “S.N.L.” alumna and “Parks and Recreation” star, will be the host, and Katy Perry will be the musical guest.

headline: Few Words and a Whole Lotta Pictures
text: In the mythology of rock, Jimmy Page is the great guitar wizard, hurling Led Zeppelin’s thunder and fire down from the mountaintop. It’s an image that the band cultivated, of course, but it wouldn’t have stuck if it weren’t for Mr. Page’s skill, finesse and imagination, which made him one of the most influential guitarists in history.

headline: The Strange Web Genius of Sean Parker
text: His career as an Internet guru began with being interrogated by federal agents while in high school. Now the Web entrepreneur Sean Parker is about to be portrayed on the big screen by Justin Timberlake.

headline: Are Scanners Worth the Risk?
text: THE next time you go through security at the airport, you might be told to empty your pockets, put your hands over your head and stand still while an X-ray machine looks for anything hidden under your clothing.

headline: An Outkast Out There by Himself
text: Outkast is gone but not forgotten. Or maybe it’s forgotten but not gone. That’s more like it, actually. The group  perhaps the most important in Southern rap history, and certainly the most popular  doesn’t cast the shadow it did 10 years ago, or even 5. Its home city, Atlanta, has evolved styles at the rate of one or more a year, and increasingly it’s possible to see Outkast  consisting of Big Boi and Andre 3000  only in a rearview mirror.

headline: Collarini’s Play Restarts Discussion of His National Affiliation
text: While Andrea Collarini moves through the boys singles draw at the United States Open, discussion is jump-starting again about his move earlier in the year from the Argentine tennis association to the United States Tennis Association.

headline: Orlando’s Newest Attraction Is Medical
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Just off State Road 417, a five-minute drive east from Orlando International Airport, a 650-acre parcel of land is fast becoming a $2 billion medical campus, including a medical school, research laboratories and hospitals.

headline: Lethal Woman With Weapons Is Out for Covert Vengeance
text: Ancient mythology is full of beautiful female warriors who kill men without remorse and in high style. So is modern mythology. Not long ago Russian soldiers in Chechnya and South Ossetia were scared silly with improbable tales of Baltic mercenaries, blue-eyed, ice-blooded snipers sometimes known as White Stockings.

headline: Southwest Potatoes
text: Mark Bittman makes a side dish inspired by airplane food, with potatoes, black beans and corn.

headline: Ireland Takes Control of Dolphins From Parcells
text: Bill Parcells, the former Giants and Jets coach who has rebuilt five franchises as either a coach or a general manager, will no longer run the Miami Dolphins. On Tuesday, the team abruptly announced in a two-sentence statement that Parcells, who in one season turned a one-win team into the American Football Conference East champion, would remain with the club as a daily consultant but that Jeff Ireland, his protégé, would assume full control over all aspects and decisions relating to the team and its support staff.

headline: Will Boise State Reach the B.C.S. Final?
text: LANDOVER, Md. — With a little more than two minutes left in Monday night’s game, Boise State seemed headed to a loss against Virginia Tech that would inevitably energize the skeptics. The 10th-ranked Hokies had the ball and a four-point lead. The third-ranked Broncos had two timeouts and a prayer. But after a defensive stop, a punt and one more memorable drive, Boise State emerged with a 33-30 victory.

headline: Art Team Represents U.S. at 2011 Venice Biennale
text: The artistic team of Jennifer Allora and Guillermo Calzadilla will represent the United States at the 2011 Venice Biennale. The duo, who have been working together since 1995 and live in San Juan, P.R., were chosen by the Federal Advisory Committee on International Exhibitions, a group of arts professionals organized by the National Endowment for the Arts to advise the State Department. Their work explores relationships among art, politics and international identity through performances pieces, sculpture, photography and sound-and-video. This will be the first time a collaborative, rather than a single artist, will represent the United States and the first time that a combination of performance and installation will occupy the pavilion. The Indianapolis Museum of Art was selected as the commissioning institution for the 2011 United States pavilion and Lisa Freiman, chairman of the Indianapolis Museum of Art’s contemporary art department, will be the commissioner. She will organize the exhibition, which will include six new works by the collaborative team developed specifically for the United States pavilion, a 1930s Palladian-style structure designed by the architects Delano & Aldrich.

headline: Art Team Represents U.S. at 2011 Venice Biennale
text: The artistic team of Jennifer Allora and Guillermo Calzadilla will represent the United States at the 2011 Venice Biennale. She will organize the exhibition, which will include six new works by the collaborative team developed specifically for the United States pavilion, a 1930s Palladian-style structure designed by the architects Delano & Aldrich.

headline: British Police May Question Downing Street Adviser on Phone-Hacking
text: Updated | 7:09 p.m. During testimony to a British Parliamentary committee on Tuesday, a senior police official said that Scotland Yard is likely to ask Andy Coulson, Prime Minister David Cameron’s top media adviser, to respond to allegations by a former employee that he knew about the illegal interception of voice-mail messages by reporters who worked for him when he was a newspaper editor.

headline: In a Golden Land, but Grateful for Brass Rings
text: “Terriers,” a cop show beginning on Wednesday on FX, is the joint effort of Shawn Ryan, creator of “The Shield,” the bleak treatise on police corruption, and Ted Griffin, the writer of “Ocean’s Eleven,” the jaunty examination of high-end fraternal thievery. And the series feels precisely like the love child of these two seemingly inconsistent sensibilities. “Terriers” has a genetic disposition at once vaguely melancholy and eccentrically sprightly, but the good mood always seems to prevail. This is a welcome love child, one we are eager to embrace rather than put up for adoption.

headline: Special Grand Jury May Get Fatal Police-Shooting Case
text: Manhattan prosecutors are considering convening a special grand jury to investigate a fatal shooting in Harlem last month in which police officers fired a total of 46 rounds, according to a lawyer for a wounded man arrested after the shooting.

headline: Southwest Potatoes, With Cheddar, Corn and Patience
text: I PLAYED with these potatoes years ago, tinkering with a distinctively Southwest combination of jalapeños, corn, black beans, chili powder and so on. I wanted a super breakfast dish that you could serve even at lunch or dinner. Somehow, though, I never got them quite to the point I wanted.

headline: Renovating a French Farmhouse
text: A 1750s three-bedroom French farmhouse was bought for $685,000 and renovated for about $100,000.

headline: Nothing Left to Lose, or Too Dark to Contemplate
text: PHILADELPHIA  Freedom  such a lovely word. Currently adorning the best-seller lists, thanks to the latest literary blockbuster from Jonathan Franzen. And sure to be gravely or raucously intoned in political speeches from coast to coast as the election season heats up.

headline: Trend in Temp Hiring Doesn’t Bode Well for Overall Jobs Picture
text: Starting last winter and into this spring, the hiring of temporary workers surged, giving hope that companies were poised to convert those hires to permanent ones.

headline: Fashion Week Preview | Miss Wu
text: Keep your eyes peeled this fashion week for a wide-eyed newcomer making her debut for Jason Wu. Meet Miss Wu, the designer’s new house logo, who is appearing on ready-to-wear pieces, knitwear, eyewear and accessories, including this leather belt.

headline: O’Donnell Backers Meet Tea Party Leaders
text: Close to 40 Christine O’Donnell supporters packed a windowless conference room in the basement of a Wilmington motel on Tuesday to meet the leaders of the group that propelled their candidate onto the national political stage.

headline: In France, a Farmhouse of the Right Vintage
text: BOURG, France — “I’ve gotten quite good at cursing and screaming at workmen in French,” said Jill Lawrence, an English textile designer, in describing the skills she has honed in renovating two second homes in France.

headline: Politics on Film, but This Time Leaning Right
text: LOS ANGELES — After Michael Moore screened his anti-Bush documentary “Fahrenheit 9/11” for Hollywood’s assembled royalty at the headquarters of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences six years ago, the crowd broke out in a noisy ovation that it did not want to stop.

headline: Stage Partnerships Raise the Chance of Perfection
text: IT’S obvious even to those who’ve never set a foot backstage that collaboration is essential to theater. The most rigorously minimalist writing still requires an actor, a director, someone to help apply the greasepaint and move the follow spot.

headline: Teaching Science With Football
text: It’s almost like telling kids their favorite food was entirely made of really healthy vegetables.

headline: Previewing Lincoln’s Menu
text: A group of restaurant executives sat down to evaluate the chef Jonathan Benno’s menu for Lincoln, the new restaurant at Lincoln Center.

headline: Lincoln’s New Menu Is Put to the Test
text: IN the end, after years of planning and construction, after months of perspiration, angst and agita, it was all about the food.

headline: Second Chance for a Beast of Broadway
text: LONDON

headline: Bristol-Myers Squibb to Buy ZymoGenetics
text: Bristol-Myers Squibb said on Tuesday that it would buy ZymoGenetics, a biotechnology company in Seattle, for $885 million or $9.75 per share in cash. That is about $735 million net of cash acquired, Bristol-Myers said in a press release Tuesday afternoon.

headline: A Match With Nerves but Few Tics
text: Nerves. They were a big part of the big story so far on Tuesday, in what was one of the most thrilling matches of the Open, the amazing tussle between Stan Wawrinka and Sam Querrey on Ashe.

headline: Vice Chairman at Kia Resigns Following Recalls
text: The vice chairman of the Kia Motors Corporation, Chung Sung-eun, stepped down on Sept. 3 after recalls involving scores of vehicles worldwide for electrical problems.

headline: MasterChef Gets Another Season
text: Fox has picked up a second season of “MasterChef,” the standout reality show of the summer.

headline: Fashion Week Preview | Stefania Pia at Eva New York
text: “You know what happened last week?” asks the Italian-born Stefania Pia. “Allora, I went to Chinatown and got lost!” She says this with disbelief, eyes flashing from behind her signature circular glasses. Pia doesn’t often lose her way on the downtown scene. “I have angels that have taken my hand and walked me around New York,” says the 34-year-old, newly-minted jewelry designer, citing the Lower Manhattan fixtures Paul Sevigny (she spent last Christmas with his family) and Aaron Bondaroff, whom she met soon after she decamped from Milan in 2007.

headline: Away This Week
text: I’ll be traveling for the next week. Regular (or at least irregular) posting should resume around the 14th of September.

headline: A Villa in Corfu
text: A four-bedroom villa is on the market for 1.25 million euros ($1.6 million). It’s located just outside the 17th-century village of Pelekas, on the island’s west coast

headline: Rodriguez Is Back, but Girardi Is Cautious
text: Had Alex Rodriguez not taken full batting practice, jogged smoothly across the field and chatted amiably with teammates, opponents and members of the news media, his absence from the starting lineup Tuesday night might have been a red flag before the Yankees hosted the Baltimore Orioles.

headline: House Hunting in ... Greece
