headline: G.I. Deaths Are First for U.S. After Combat Mission’s End
text: Steven Lee Myers writes in The New York Times that two American soldiers were killed  Tuesday when a firefight erupted inside an Iraqi Army base. They were the first American casualties since President Obama declared an official end to the combat mission in Iraq.

headline: A Stockholm Apartment
text: An 860-square-foot unit on the top floor of a 19th century apartment building with two bedrooms is on the market for 4.5 million kronor ($620,000).

headline: The Geely Brand Will Fade Away, Company Says
text: Geely Automobile Holdings said Tuesday that the Geely brand would be gone by 2012. However, the Chinese auto company will soldier on with its Gleagle, Emgrand and Shanghai Englon brands. In other words, Geely will no longer market a car that bears the parent company’s name.

headline: Turkish Team Says It Paid a Top Kentucky Recruit
text: ISTANBUL  The best recruit in Kentucky’s top-ranked recruiting class, the Turkish center Enes Kanter, received more than $100,000 in cash and benefits over three years from the professional team he played for here, according to the team’s general manager.

headline: House Hunting in ... Stockholm
text: A TWO -BEDROOM APARTMENT IN STOCKHOLM’S OSTERMALM NEIGHBORHOOD

headline: Do People Want ‘Amateur Hour’ on Their TVs?
text: Last week Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, unveiled a new version of the Apple TV, which is smaller and, at $99, less expensive than the previous model.

headline: Back to School: Grading the Teacher
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Democrats’ Strategy
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Foot Out the Door: Parcells Steps Aside as the Dolphins’ Boss
text: Bill Parcells, the former Giants and Jets coach who has rebuilt five franchises as a coach or a general manager, will no longer run the Miami Dolphins.

headline: Vodafone to Sell Its Stake in China Mobile for $6.6 Billion
text: The Vodafone Group is selling its 3.2 percent stake in China Mobile Ltd. for about $6.6 billion.

headline: Analyst Sees Securities Firms Slashing Jobs and Pay
text: Securities firms worldwide will cut as many as 80,000 jobs in the next 18 months as revenue growth begins to slow, said Meredith Whitney, a former analyst at Oppenheimer & Company who now runs her own firm.

headline: Uses for the O.E.D.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Goodbye, and Hello
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chinese Officials Call for Less Friction With U.S.
text: HONG KONG  Top Chinese officials called Tuesday for quiet discussions instead of open friction with the United States, after a summer marked by bilateral disagreements over the value of China’s currency, American military exercises off the Korean Peninsula and American efforts to resolve territorial disputes in the South China Sea.

headline: Finding a Steadier Path in Gaza
text: KHAN YUNIS, Gaza  Tough-looking ambulance drivers in this central Gazan city are drawing images of their fears with crayons. In the northwestern village of El Atatra, in an overheated hall without electricity, 10-year-olds are closing their eyes and imagining a reassuring place. In Gaza City, women who have lost children to political violence are dancing away their tensions, their black abayas shaking and flowing.

headline: Our Oil Addiction
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Preference for Print
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama Is Against a Compromise on Bush Tax Cuts
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Wednesday will make clear that he opposes any compromise that would extend the Bush-era tax cuts for the wealthy beyond this year, officials said, adding a populist twist to an election-season economic package that is otherwise designed to entice support from big businesses and their Republican allies.

headline: New Call for Election Boycott in Egypt
text: CAIRO  One of Egypt’s most prominent opposition leaders, the Nobel laureate Mohamed ElBaradei, has issued the strongest call so far for a blanket opposition boycott of parliamentary elections this fall.

headline: China: Redevelopment Plan Scrapped for Historic Beijing Neighborhood
text: Beijing officials have shelved a much-attacked plan to redevelop the Gulou Drum Tower neighborhood, a warren of alleys and small homes dating from the Qing and Ming dynasties, into a tourist spot with high-end stores, The Beijing Times reported. The alleys, called hutongs, are among the few historic residential areas that have not been demolished in the city’s rush to accommodate a fast-growing population and capitalize on ballooning land prices. The redevelopment plan called for the hutongs and the old Drum Tower, a Beijing landmark, to accommodate a new museum of timekeeping, a high-end underground shopping center and parking. Most residents had been awaiting an order to move out. The newspaper quoted an unidentified city official as saying the so-called Time Cultural City is “a thing of the past,” but said the neighborhood’s future remained unclear.

headline: Mozambique: Government Reverses Major Increase in Price of Bread
text: The government has decided to reverse a major increase in the price of bread that helped set off deadly riots last week in a nation where poverty is widespread, Planning Minister Aiuba Cuerenei said Tuesday. He said that a subsidy would allow the price to be set at the previous level. Higher global prices for wheat had contributed to the government’s previous decision to raise the price of bread.

headline: Bedbugs Bad for Business? Depends on the Business
text: Recent reports that bedbugs have infiltrated office buildings, movie theaters and stores in New York did not come as a surprise to Wes Tyler, general manager of the Chancellor Hotel on Union Square in San Francisco.

headline: Building on Faith
text: AS my flight approached America last weekend, my mind circled back to the furor that has broken out over plans to build Cordoba House, a community center in Lower Manhattan.I have been away from home for two months, speaking abroad about cooperation among people from different religions. Every day, including the past two weeks spent representing my country on a State Department tour in the Middle East, I have been struck by how the controversy has riveted the attention of Americans, as well as nearly everyone I met in my travels.

headline: The Bears and the State of Housing
text: Of all the uncertainties in our halting economic recovery, the housing market may be the most confusing of all.

headline: South Africa: Fraud Charges Against Journalist Withdrawn
text: After reviewing the evidence gathered by state investigators, the National Prosecuting Authority said Tuesday that charges would be withdrawn against a journalist for the Sunday Times, Mzilikazi wa Afrika, who was arrested last month on fraud charges just days after he was a co-author of an article that laid out what it described as a questionable property deal between South Africa’s police chief and a politically connected businessman. Prosecutors left the door open to refiling the charges if new evidence comes to light. The newspaper had described the arrest as an attempt at intimidation, and its editor said Tuesday that the police chief owed Mr. wa Afrika an apology.

headline: Marshaling Fashion’s Troops
text: YOU might not be seated next to Daphne Guinness in the front row at the Narciso Rodriguez show, or overhear Madonna and Lady Gaga chatting backstage at Badgley Mischka. But at this year’s New York Fashion Week, which starts on Sept. 9 at Lincoln Center, lucky members of the public will be able to glimpse new looks by designers like Marchesa and Jason Wu, just like a certain Chanel-clad fashion editor.

headline: Russia: Chess Federation Chief Steps Down as Regional Leader
text: The controversial leader of a mostly Buddhist region in southern Russia, who has gained international attention for his prominence in world chess, said in a statement on Tuesday that he was stepping down after 17 years in power. The leader, Kirsan N. Ilyumzhinov, said he would not seek re-election as the leader of Kalmykia when his term ends in October, citing President Dmitri A. Medvedev, who has called for long-serving regional leaders to be replaced. Mr. Ilyumzhinov, who has also been president of World Chess Federation since 1995, said he would devote more time to promoting chess. He has been locked in a bitter fight for reelection to the chess federation with Anatoly Karpov, a former world champion, who has accused him of mismanagement and corruption.

headline: Britain: One-Day Strike Cripples London Subway
text: London’s subway system was crippled by a strike on Tuesday by maintenance workers, signalers, station workers and some drivers who were protesting plans to cut 800 workers in stations around London. The workers say the plan will compromise public safety, but Mayor Boris Johnson called it “moderate and sensible.” Service on most lines was sporadic, with huge crowds at bus stops as commuters tried to get to work. The unions say they will hold more strikes in October and November.

headline: FIFA Begins Tour of Sites in U.S. Bid
text: The United States entered the make-or-break stage of its bid to host the 2018 or 2022 World Cup on Tuesday as a six-person team from FIFA, soccer’s world governing body, began a tour to assess the American proposal.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,258 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: The Frugal Traveler: Touring the South
text: For the last leg of his 13 week trip, the New York Times Frugal Traveler Seth Kugel hopped on a train and made his way through Alabama, Georgia and Washington, D.C.

headline: Jewish Holy Days Collide With Fashion’s Big Event
text: As Jewish families gather to celebrate the New Year on Wednesday night, there are sure to be some fashion designers whispering prayers of their own.

headline: Glamour Promotes Its Brand and Its Readers
text: FOR decades, fans of soap operas have been watching the exploits of the young and the restless. Now, will the readers and advertisers of a well-known woman’s magazine want to be, or reach, the young and the posh?

headline: Bristol-Myers Agrees to Acquire ZymoGenetics for $885 Million
text: Bristol-Myers Squibb said Tuesday it had agreed to acquire ZymoGenetics, the maker of a hepatitis C drug the companies were jointly developing, for $885 million.

headline: Rangel Hits the Streets, Finding Love and Aversion
text: A 20-something office worker whipped out his iPhone and asked to be photographed with him. “Charlie Rangel!” he said, star-struck.

headline: At ABC News After Westin, Risk and Opportunity
text: David Westin’s resignation as president of ABC News represents, in the words of one long-time television news executive, “an inflection point” for an industry still trying to figure out how to survive.

headline: Mortgage Rates and Home Prices
text: But what about interest rates?

headline: New Jersey Transit Tries Out Quiet Cars
text: Quiet, even on New Jersey Transit’s new quiet cars, can be a relative term.

headline: U.N. Officials Say 500 Were Victims of Congo Rapes
text: UNITED NATIONS  Approximately 500 women were raped in eastern Congo in July and August, demonstrating that both rebel militias and government troops used sexual violence as a weapon, two senior United Nations officials said Tuesday.

headline: Williams and Clijsters Struggle but Advance
text: On a blustery night at the United States Open when the stars were often better served by receiving, Venus Williams and Kim Clijsters managed to muddle through.

headline: Christie, in Perpetual Motion, Aims to Put Lapse Behind Him
text: You might have thought New Jersey’s politicians were living in two different countries on Tuesday.

headline: Alms for the Rich and Powerful
text: The Elijah Cummings Youth Program in Israel sounds like a lovely idea: a charitable foundation that sends inner-city high school students from Baltimore to Israel to learn about the country and develop leadership skills. The program has undoubtedly been of benefit to many teenagers, but deeper pockets have benefited as well. Comcast, the cable company, has given generously to the foundation, prompting Representative Elijah Cummings, a Democrat from Baltimore, to urge the Federal Communications Commission to approve Comcast’s proposed merger with NBC. His charity even wrote its own letter to the F.C.C., saying it supports the merger in part because Comcast gives it money.

headline: Forced Labor
text: A conspiracy indictment was brought last week against a Los Angeles company, alleging forced labor on a chilling scale. Six contractors are accused of a scheme to hold 400 workers from Thailand in virtual slavery on farms in Hawaii and Washington State. The Justice Department says it is the largest human-trafficking case ever brought by the federal government. Just as disturbing is how familiar the accusations are.

headline: The Tiki Bar Has Returned
text: THE tiki revival — a gust of nostalgia for a time when Trader meant Vic’s, not Joe’s — planted its paper umbrellas at a couple of New York bars this year. But soon it will go for the big time when the 250-seat Hurricane Club opens on Park Avenue South.

headline: Marcus Samuelsson Opens in Harlem
text: “FOOD can be cooked from the soul,” said Marcus Samuelsson as he moved through the raw space of Red Rooster Harlem, his upcoming restaurant on Lenox Avenue near West 125th Street. “But that doesn’t make it soul food.”

headline: At Eleven Madison Park, Fixing What Isn’t Broke
text: THE past year has been good to Eleven Madison Park.

headline: Shea Gallante Comes Back to the Kitchen
text: SHEA GALLANTE was only 19 years old when he opened his first restaurant.

headline: What’s Opening This Season
text: BELOW 14TH STREET

headline: Reforming Meat
text: Early in the last century, the federal government tried to create competition in the meatpacking industry by breaking up the five corporations that controlled it. The result is that four big corporations control it now: JBS, Tyson Foods, Cargill and National Beef Packing. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack wants to try again, and we fully support him. In fact, we’d like to see him go much further.

headline: Keeping Track of the Kids
text: This is an era in which many devices are watching us. We carry about wireless phones that tell our service providers exactly where we are. Surveillance cameras blink down from corners and storefronts. Advertisers follow us effortlessly around the Internet. Still, plans in Contra Costa County, Calif., to tag preschoolers with radio frequency identification chips to keep track of their whereabouts at school seem to go too far.

headline: Surveillance Team Spooked Bomb Plot Suspects, Informer Says
text: Federal agents trailing four suspects in a terrorism plot last year almost exposed their own sting operation when the suspects apparently spotted their surveillance team, according to court testimony on Tuesday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Barclays, Naming Diamond as Chief, Focuses on Rapid Growth
text: LONDON  Robert E. Diamond Jr., the charismatic American behind the international expansion of the British bank Barclays, was named chief executive on Tuesday.

headline: A Duck With Leaner, Richer Meat
text: Lola ducks are a cross between the standard white Pekin variety and the wild mallard. The result is a smaller bird than the usual, with a somewhat richer, gamier flavor; meat with a finer, almost silky texture; and less fat under the skin. Last spring, Hudson Valley Duck Farm in Ferndale, N.Y., had a limited supply in some Greenmarkets and for chefs like Paul Liebrandt at Corton; now they’ve increased production.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Learn to Bake

headline: Ayada
text: I KNEW Ayada was a serious Thai restaurant when I started weeping at my table.

headline: Who Put the Whiskey in My Milkshake?
text: THERE is bourbon in the Bourbon Street milkshake, served at Brooklyn Bowl, the loud, slick palace of fun that opened last year in Williamsburg. There’s also a sizable gobbet of Nutella, its nutty richness meant to evoke pralines  and by extension New Orleans, and by further extension the wild time you might have in New Orleans but are now presumably having in Brooklyn. And, of course, there is ice cream  the good stuff, with egg yolks and real vanilla, certainly better than anything you’ve ever eaten in a bowling alley.

headline: As Stadiums Vanish, Their Debt Lives On
text: It’s the gift that keeps on taking. The old Giants Stadium, demolished to make way for New Meadowlands Stadium, still carries about $110 million in debt, or nearly $13 for every New Jersey resident, even though it is now a parking lot.

headline: Immigration Crackdown Steps Into the Kitchen
text: SAN DIEGO

headline: Political Ties Shielded Bank in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  In early 2009, as President Hamid Karzai scanned the landscape for potential partners to run in his re-election bid, he was approached from an unusual corner: a bank.

headline: Concern Is Voiced Over Religious Intolerance
text: WASHINGTON — Prominent Christian, Jewish and Muslim leaders held an extraordinary “emergency summit” meeting in the capital on Tuesday to denounce what they called “the derision, misinformation and outright bigotry” aimed at American Muslims during the controversy over the proposed Islamic community center near ground zero.

headline: In Florida, Many Lay Plans to Counter a Pastor’s Message
text: MIAMI  Even before national religious leaders and Gen. David H. Petraeus condemned Terry Jones’s plan to burn the Koran on Sept. 11 at his Gainesville church, grass-roots opposition had begun to swell.

headline: Experiments in Philosophy
text: Aristotle once wrote that philosophy begins in wonder, but one might equally well say that philosophy begins with inner conflict. The cases in which we are most drawn to philosophy are precisely the cases in which we feel as though there is something pulling us toward one side of a question but also something pulling us, perhaps equally powerfully, toward the other.

headline: Chicago’s ‘Mayor for Life’ Decides Not to Run
text: CHICAGO — Mayor Richard M. Daley dropped the bomb at a routine news conference at City Hall on Tuesday. With no prelude or fanfare, Mr. Daley announced that he would not seek re-election when his term expires next year.

headline: Team Revis Held Firm in Stressful Holdout
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  All Tuesday morning, Darrelle Revis’s neighbors dropped cakes and pies and welcome-back cards on his doorstep.

headline: Judge Calls for Punishment of Police Official
text: A high-ranking New York police official broke department policy by using human growth hormone and should be suspended for 30 days and placed on probation for one year, an administrative trial judge has determined.

headline: Weird Weather in a Warming World
text: GIVEN the weather of late, extremes seem to have become the norm.

headline: Republicans Have One-in-Four Chance to Claim Senate Majority, Model Shows
text: Republicans now have approximately a one-in-four chance of winning enough Senate seats in the Nov. 2 elections to claim an outright majority of the chamber, FiveThirtyEight’s latest forecasting model shows.

headline: Extreme Weather in a Warming World
text: I’ve written an essay for Wednesday’s Op-Ed page  offering a short look at extreme weather in a warming world and the two prongs of the climate challenge — the need to limit human vulnerability to the worst the climate system can throw at us and to curb emissions that are steadily raising the odds of unwelcome outcomes, particularly extreme heat and either too much, or too little, water.

headline: Wednesday: Imelda, the Shoe Lover
text: PUZZLE NOTES — We have another Times debut, today by Tracy Gray, a horticulturist from Maryland.

headline: Mets Call-Up Pitches Like Ace in Debut
text: WASHINGTON  At Nationals Park, where the fans know a thing or two about highly regarded young pitchers, the right-hander Dillon Gee drew hardly an acknowledgment from the crowd when he was introduced as the Mets’ starter Tuesday night.

headline: Documents Fill In Gaps in Narrative on Oil Rig Blast
text: LAFAYETTE, La.  In a quiet suburb of this oil town, there is a spacious brick house with all of the shades drawn. Inside is a graying and pale man who knows as much as anyone about what happened on the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig the day it exploded in the Gulf of Mexico. He is not talking.

headline: ‘House of Steinbrenner’ Fails to Convey a Compelling Story
text: In “The House of Steinbrenner,” the Academy Award-winning documentarian Barbara Kopple created an enormous storytelling challenge for herself: describe the generational shift in the Yankees family, from George to Hal Steinbrenner, and from the old Yankee Stadium to the new one.

headline: At Fashion Week, It’s Where You Sit That Counts
text: Bright and early Monday morning (Labor Day, though you wouldn’t know it), every seat in the offices of the fashion publicist Paul Wilmot was filled with a young account executive whose holiday weekend was being disrupted by the mechanics of New York Fashion Week, which begins on Thursday. At one table, the designer Naeem Khan was personally overseeing, with a team of three publicists, where each of the 872 guests will sit at his runway show on Sept. 16 at Lincoln Center.

headline: Consumer Reports Is Rating Surgical Groups
text: Medical groups that perform heart bypass surgery are now being rated alongside cars and toaster ovens in Consumer Reports.

headline: It’s Back to School. Then Back to Vacation.
text: A quirk in the calendar is giving the first week of school the feeling of an on-again-off-again relationship, with many students in the New York area having more days of vacation than instruction.

headline: Links to Wall St. Become Liability in Primary Races
text: When she set out to topple a popular nine-term Congressional incumbent, Reshma Saujani reveled in her background in the world of high finance, emerging as a national voice for an industry that felt besieged, blamed and battered after the banking collapse.

headline: In Attorney General Debate, Humor and Surprise
text: State Senator Eric T. Schneiderman endured withering criticism from the rest of the Democratic field for New York attorney general on Tuesday night, as the five candidates met a week before the primary election for their highest-profile debate yet.

headline: A New Lieutenant for Ellison’s War
text: Lawrence Ellison, chief executive of Oracle, has begun another phase of his battle with Silicon Valley. Mr. Ellison, an admirer of Sun Tzu, the ancient Chinese general credited with writing “The Art of War,” mocked the board of his rival Hewlett-Packard when it forced out Mark Hurd as chief executive last month. By now hiring Mr. Hurd, Mr. Ellison has backed up his words. He not only gains a well-regarded operations guru, he follows Sun’s dictum: “Know your enemy.”

headline: A Frenzied First Day for Applying to Private Kindergartens
text: They arrived every few minutes, all day  by car, by bicycle, on foot, with child in tow  at the arched doorway of the Trinity School on the Upper West Side, with one thing in common: All clutched envelopes whose immediate delivery, they believed, could dictate their child’s academic future.

headline: Orioles Foil Sabathia in His Bid for No. 20
text: C. C. Sabathia should get at least four more chances this season to reach the 20-victory plateau for the first time in his career. In the meantime, he can fret about losing one Tuesday night to a team he usually dominates.

headline: On White House Stage, Space Is Constrained; Imagination Is Not
text: WASHINGTON  “Dance is the soul of this nation!” Judith Jamison, artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, exclaimed on Tuesday afternoon in the East Room of the White House, at the end of a performance in her honor. Addressing her host, Michelle Obama, Ms. Jamison continued, “Your vision helps us sustain the heartbeat of what this country is about.”

headline: Science of N.F.L. Football
text: The National Football League, National Science Foundation and NBC have teamed up to show how pro football is full of cool science principles.

headline: For-Profit Colleges Step Up Lobbying Against New Rules
text: For-profit colleges have increased their lobbying against proposed Education Department rules to cut off federal financial aid to programs whose students take on too much debt for training that provides little likelihood of leading to a well-paying job.

headline: Saudi Time
text: It’s been a week and the newly minted Israeli-Palestinian peace talks have not broken down yet! Surely that is a good sign. It is a measure of how low expectations are for these talks that they have to be celebrated by the week. Now that they have begun, though, both sides will try to avoid being the one that scuttles them — and not only to avoid the wrath of the United States. It is because one senses that after all these years of stop-and-start peace talks — where someone declares “this is the year of decision, and if these talks fail the peace process is dead and buried” — this time it might actually be true. If these talks fail, with 300,000 Israeli settlers already living in the West Bank, and with Hamas becoming ensconced with its own government in Gaza, talk of a “two-state solution” will enter the realm of fantasy.

headline: What If Restaurants Stopped Hiring Illegal Immigrants?
text: In the 2004 film “A Day Without a Mexican,” all of California’s Mexicans suddenly disappear. The state wakes up to a world with no gardeners, nannies, strawberry pickers, maids, cooks, dishwashers. Through extreme exaggeration, the mockumentary makes point that without the Mexicans, the economy would essentially grind to a halt, and it satirizes those who want to send immigrants back across the border — or stop them from coming in. Presumably, if these abandoned low wage jobs were filled by legal workers making legal wages, everything would cost a whole lot more.

headline: Lincoln’s Forgotten Fort
text: WASHINGTON

headline: A Taste of History in the South, and a Hint of Home in New York
text: For my 13th and final week on the road, the agenda was packed with three great destinations: Birmingham, Ala., for its rich civil rights history and darn good barbecue; Savannah, Ga., for its enchanting squares and gracious 19th-century homes, and Washington, for its 6-year-old Leo and 3-year-old Grady, otherwise known as my nephews.

headline: Seymour Pine Dies at 91; Led Raid on Stonewall Inn
text: Seymour Pine, the deputy police inspector who led the raid on the Stonewall Inn, a gay bar in Greenwich Village, on a hot summer night in 1969 — a moment that helped start the gay liberation movement — died Thursday at an assisted-living center in Whippany, N.J. He was 91.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Virginia B. Smith, Former Vassar President, Is Dead at 87
text: Virginia B. Smith, a lawyer and economist who helped shape the contours of higher education as president of Vassar College, as a high public official in Washington and as a member of influential private research groups, died on Aug. 27 in Alamo, Calif. She was 87.

headline: The N.F.L. Plays, the Public Pays
text: On average, more than half the reported building costs of all active N.F.L. stadiums has been paid for with public money.

headline: Arizona: Green Party Wants Republican’s Recruits Off Ballot
text: The state’s Green Party said Tuesday that it had filed suit asking state election officials to disallow various homeless people and other candidates on the party’s November ballot who had been recruited by Republicans. The suit against Arizona’s chief elections official, Ken Bennett, and a host of public officials alleges that the candidates had been put on the ballot “to confuse the electorate and siphon votes” from Democrats. The party also wants to change the state’s election law, which makes it possible for someone to get on the ballot representing a minor party by receiving a single nominating signature. Steve May, who is on the ballot as a Republican, acknowledges that he recruited some friends, drifters in Tempe, to run as Green Party candidates.

headline: Bush Should Give the Heisman Back
text: Amid speculation that the Heisman Trustwould take back Reggie Bush’s trophy, the Downtown Athletic Club president, Jim Corcoran, said those reports were premature.

headline: Illinois: Tribe Seeks to Join Suit
text: Calling a potential invasion of Asian carp in the Great Lakes a threat to their culture and livelihood, a Michigan tribe asked a federal judge in Chicago on Tuesday for permission to join five states demanding emergency action to thwart the invasive species. The Grand Traverse Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians says the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago have allowed the fish to enter the lakes via shipping locks and gates.

headline: Pennsylvania: Court Rules on Cellphone Tracking
text: Judges can require that the government meet the standard of proof required to obtain wiretaps when requesting cellphone data to track suspects, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday. The Justice Department was fighting a Pennsylvania magistrate judge’s demand that investigators in a narcotics case seek a search warrant to obtain cellphone location data. It argued before the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit that a lesser court order was sufficient. Writing for the majority, Judge Dolores K. Sloviter said the judge could demand a warrant “sparingly,” and sent the case back to a magistrate court. Judge A. Wallace Tashima wrote in a concurring opinion that the majority failed to provide “any standards” to magistrates or prosecutors.

headline: Phillies Take Back First Place in N.L. East
text: PHILADELPHIA – Charlie Manuel laughed as he talked about his lineup in the Phillies’ dugout before Tuesday night’s game. He took several questions on it, then told the writers: “You say what you want to say. I’ll do what I want to do.”

headline: Phys Ed: How to Fix a Bad Tennis Shoulder
text: For a study published a few years ago in the British Journal of Sports Medicine, researchers at the High Performance National Training Center in Argentina X-rayed the shoulders of 18 elite older tennis players, both men and women. Each of the 18, between the ages of 51 and 75, had at one time played professionally, and all were still active in tennis, as either  competitors or teachers. None had experienced any unusual shoulder pain or problems. But when radiologists reviewed the players’ X-rays, they found signs of osteoarthritis, or loss of joint cartilage, in a third of the players’ dominant shoulders (generally the right). Shoulder X-rays from an age-matched group of Argentines who didn’t play tennis turned up arthritic changes in only 11 percent of the group. With understandable circumspection, the authors, operating under the auspices of the Argentine Tennis Association, concluded that years of “intensive tennis practice may be a predisposing factor for the development of mild degenerative articular changes in the dominant shoulder.” Playing tennis, in other words, might be gnawing away at the joint.

headline: Word of the Day | buffoonery
text: buffoonery •\bə-ˈfü-nə-re, bə-ˈfün-re\• noun

headline: Soderling Learns to Enjoy Tennis’s Top Echelon
text: Robin Soderling smiled at the suggestion that he has a dour approach to tennis. It is a commonly held belief, reinforced by his on-court demeanor, which suggests a man digging himself out of a Scandinavian winter.

headline: British Manager Starts Asian Fund of Funds
text: The British fund management firm City Financial said on Monday it had introduced an Asian fund of hedge funds in a move designed to tap into the rapid development of the hedge fund industry in the region, Reuters reported.

headline: Inquiry Into Paper for Bank Notes
text: De La Rue, which helps make paper currency for 150 countries, said on Tuesday that the British authorities had been called in to investigate “deliberately falsified” tests on paper used to make bank notes, David Jolly reports in The New York Times.

headline: A Diversion at the White House
text: The White House opened the East Room on Tuesday to the first of a planned series of events celebrating dance in America. Observers were invited to a performance featuring several troupes and, before that, to watch the first 30 minutes of a 90-minute class with schoolchildren led by an educator from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

headline: Bank of Japan Vows to Step Up, if Necessary
text: The Bank of Japan stood pat on monetary policy on Tuesday but vowed timely action when needed, setting the stage for possible easing in October when it has clarity on political leadership and the strong yen’s damage to the slowing economy, Reuters reported.

headline: Renewed European Worry Hurts Shares
text: United States investors took their cues from overseas on Tuesday and sent shares lower amid worrying news about the European banks, Christine Hauser writes in The New York Times.

headline: What to Watch on Wednesday at the Open
text: The play of Gael Monfils can be summed up in a word not often associated with his high-risk game: disciplined.

headline: Richard M. Daley: Milestones
text: A collection of notable moments in the history of Richard M. Daley, longtime mayor of Chicago.

headline: A New Center to Educate Traders in Singapore
text: Nanyang Technological University and the Singapore Exchange on Tuesday opened the Center for Financial Education, promoting it as Asia’s first live trading lab within a university.

headline: News Quiz | September 8, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Nadal Tops Lopez to Stay Hot at U.S. Open
text: On a day of high winds and epic five-set matches, top-seeded Rafael Nadal wasted little time in dispatching his fellow Spaniard Feliciano Lopez in the final match of a long day at the United States Open.

headline: Leonhardt: The Bears and the State of Housing
text: From David Leonhardt’s latest column:

headline: Britain Backs New E.U. Oversight Plan
text: Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, on Tuesday endorsed a variety of new watchdog agencies to supervise financial activities across the European Union, James Kanter writes in The New York Times.

headline: Another Cautionary Tale About Polls
text: A Gallup poll shook the political world last week with a headline saying “G.O.P.  Takes Unprecedented 10-Point Lead on Generic Ballot.” It reported that Republicans had their widest advantage to date on the question of which party voters would choose in the race for the Congressional seat in their districts.

headline: The Ad Campaign |  New Commercials in Florida
text: Gov. Charlie Crist and his Democratic opponent in the Florida Senate race, Representative Kendrick B. Meek, released their first television advertisements of the general election on Tuesday, and each tried to distinguish himself in the three-way race. Marco Rubio, the Republican candidate, ran his first commercial in late August.

headline: S.E.C. to Study Rapid-Fire Stock Orders
text: Federal regulators are examining certain practices involving “quote stuffing,” where large numbers of rapid-fire stock orders are placed and canceled almost immediately, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mary L. Schapiro, said on Tuesday.

headline: Senator Lisa Murkowski | Seeking a Way Out of Defeat
text: Senator Lisa Murkowski, who was defeated in the Republican primary in Alaska last month, said Tuesday that she was exploring ways to run in the general election, including as a write-in candidate or as a Libertarian.

headline: Vodafone to Sell China Mobile Stake for $6.6 Billion
text: The Vodafone Group is selling its 3.2 percent stake in China Mobile for about $6.6 billion. Some 70 percent of the proceeds will be returned to shareholders through a stock repurchase, and the rest will be used to pay down debt, Vodafone said on Tuesday by e-mail.

headline: Bristol-Myers Agrees to Acquire ZymoGenetics
text: Bristol-Myers Squibb said on Tuesday it had agreed to acquire ZymoGenetics, the maker of a hepatitis C drug the companies were jointly developing, for $885 million, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: China Moves to Ease Strain With U.S.
text: HONG KONG  Top Chinese officials are calling for quiet discussions instead of open friction with the United States, after a summer marked by bilateral disagreements over the value of China’s currency, American military exercises off the Korean Peninsula and American efforts to resolve territorial disputes in the South China Sea.

headline: Whitney Sees Securities Firms Slashing Jobs and Pay
text: Securities firms worldwide will cut as many as 80,000 jobs in the next 18 months as revenue growth begins to slow, said Meredith Whitney, a former analyst at Oppenheimer & Company who now runs her own firm.

headline: Cloud Storage Provider Raises $4.5 Million
text: Cloud storage provider Backupify, which specializes in backing up data from social media services like Twitter and Facebook, announced Tuesday that it raised $4.5 million in its first round of fund-raising, led by Avalon Ventures and General Catalyst Partners, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Karzai Family Ties Shielded Afghan Bank
text: In early 2009, as President Hamid Karzai scanned the landscape for potential partners to run in his re-election bid, he was approached from an unusual corner: a bank.

headline: Gates and Buffett to Sell Giving to China’s Richest
text: Microsoft‘s co-founder, Bill Gates, and the billionaire investor Warren Buffett plan to sell the art of giving to China’s super-rich in a visit later this month that’s already started some soul-searching among the world’s second-largest number of billionaires, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Your Daily Cheering Up
text: Now, this is not the end; it is not even the beginning of the end. But it is, perhaps, Begin the Beguine.

headline: Is Everything You’ve Been Taught About Study Habits Wrong?
text: According to an article in this week’s Science Times, “some of the most hallowed advice on study habits is flat wrong,” yet schools and parents continue to teach students methods have been proven to be ineffective. How do you study best? Do your study habits run counter to advice your teachers, parents or schools have given you?

headline: Chimp Retirement, or Research?
text: WHERE is the Alamogordo Primate Facility?

headline: Companies Join to Form $762 Million P.E. Venture
text: Assicurazioni Generali, Veneto Banca and Palladio Finanziaria are forming a private equity and infrastructure fund that will manage as much as 600 million euros ($762 million), Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Eldorado Surrenders Andean to Goldcorp
text: Eldorado Gold said Tuesday it would abandon its proposal to acquire Argentina-focused Andean Resources in light of Goldcorp‘s higher offer worth 3.6 billion Canadian dollars ($3.43 billion), Reuters reports.

headline: Standard Chartered Climbs Rankings in India
text: Standard Chartered, ranked 14th among merger advisers in India last year, has climbed to No. 2 by financing takeovers in the world’s second-fastest growing major market for acquisitions, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: UBS Hires Credit Suisse Executive for Asia
text: UBS, the largest Swiss bank, hired Stephen Pak from Credit Suisse to head a team that introduces Asian hedge funds to potential investors, after losing staff to rivals and new entrants, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: S.E.C. Said to See Surge in Fraud Tip-Offs
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has seen a surge in tip-offs concerning alleged corporate fraud as the Financial Reforms Act offers millions of dollars in bounty payments to whistle-blowers, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Final Basel Reform Goes to Oversight Body
text: Central bank and regulatory officials agreed on tougher new global bank capital rules on Tuesday but will keep bankers on tenterhooks about the details until Sunday when formal endorsement is expected, Reuters reported.

headline: Sinochem Approaches Temasek on Potash Bid
text: China’s state-owned Sinochem has invited Temasek, the Singapore sovereign wealth fund, to join a consortium that may bid for Canada’s Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, the world’s largest fertilizer supplier, Reuters reported, citing sources with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, September 8, 2010
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the Times article “Scheme Rattles Benin, an Anchor of Stability.”

headline: South Korea Aims Sanctions at Iran
text: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea listed 126 Iranian companies and individuals for economic sanctions on Wednesday, including a major banking operation, despite Iran’s warnings that the penalties would endanger growing trade and energy ties.

headline: Mourning at the Scene of a Stabbing
text: Ángel Franco came across 7-year-old Infinadi Harper one morning in July on East 116th Street in Manhattan, where a young woman had been stabbed to death the night before. Infinadi didn’t know the victim. But as she examined the makeshift memorial, balloons bobbing around her, Mr. Franco marveled at how quietly reflective she was.

headline: Police Station Opens in a Disputed Afghan District
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The first police station has been opened in Marja, seven months after United States Marines started operations to take control of that Taliban stronghold in southern Helmand Province, military officials said Wednesday.

headline: Sanofi C.E.O. Talks to Genzyme Investors
text: The chief executive of the drug maker Sanofi-Aventis,  Christopher A. Viehbacher, took his case for a takeover of Genzyme directly to the company’s investors in meetings in New York on Tuesday, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people who attended.

headline: $3 Billion Pulled From Funds in July
text: The global hedge fund industry shriveled a little more in July when investors pulled out nearly $3 billion after the loosely regulated portfolios posted losses in May and June, Reuters said, citing researchers.

headline: Dana Fights K.N.O.C. Bid and Buys Suncor Assets
text: Dana Petroleum, the British oil and gas producer, on Wednesday presented its arguments against the £1.87 billion ($2.88 billion) hostile cash bid of Korean National Oil Corporation, saying the offer was “inadequate and fails to recognize Dana’s existing value and strategic importance.”

headline: G.I.C. Said to Near Deal for Brazilian Bank Stake
text: Government of Singapore Investment Corp.‘s talks with Banco BTG Pactual to buy a 15 percent stake in the Brazilian investment bank worth about $2.4 billion are at an advanced stage, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Foster’s Rebuffs $2.1 Billion Wine Bid
text: Foster’s Group said Wednesday that it had rejected an unsolicited bid from an unidentified private equity firm offering from 2.3 billion  to 2.7 billion Australian dollars for its wine business, which it said it planned to spin off from its beer operations.

headline: N.F.L. 2010, According to The Onion
text: The Onion wished the new N.F.L. season good luck and broken legs with itsspoofing of traditional preview capsules.

headline: Prague Music Festival Transcends Genre
text: There are not many festivals that fuse virtuoso performances of the kamancheh (Persian spiked fiddle) with an experimental string quartet famed for its electro-acoustic interpretation of John Cage. But just such a combination — Kayhan Kalhor, an Iranian musician, will perform with the New York-based string quartet Brooklyn Rider — is what makes the Strings of Autumn festival one of Prague’s most innovative musical undertakings.

headline: Stimulus and Private-Sector Hiring
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Foster's Says It Rejected $2.5 Billion Bid for Wine Unit
text: Foster’s Group said Wednesday that it had rejected an unsolicited bid from an unidentified private equity firm offering from 2.3 billion Australian dollars to 2.7 billion dollars for its wine business, which it has said it plans to spin off from its beer operations

headline: Sri Lanka Ends Presidential Term Limits
text: NEW DELHI  Sri Lanka’s Parliament passed a proposal on Wednesday to remove presidential term limits from the Constitution, paving the way for the popular president to run for a third term and cement his grip on power.

headline: Greek Bank Announces Plan to Raise $3.5 Billion
text: National Bank of Greece, the debt-troubled nation’s largest lender, said that it planned to raise about 2.8 billion euros ($3.5 billion) in capital through selling rights and a stake in its Turkish subsidiary.

headline: Buyout Shops Said to Plan to Build Irish Bank on EBS
text: J.C. Flowers & Company and three other bidders for Ireland’s EBS Building Society may buy and merge several lenders to create a new competitor to the country’s biggest banks, two people familiar with the situation told Bloomberg News.

headline: Marketing Makeovers for 9 Small Businesses
text: The idea for Project Rev was hatched after research conducted by the Deluxe Corporation revealed what many of us already knew: many small-business owners lack marketing training and they experience more misses than hits in their initial marketing efforts.

headline: Willis Group Hires Ex-A.I.G. Chief Sullivan
text: Willis Group, the insurance company, said Wednesday that it had named the ex-American International Group chief executive Martin J. Sullivan to the position of deputy chairman. Mr. Sullivan will head a new business in the company, Willis Global Solutions, which will sell insurance and risk management advice globally.

headline: Jumping the Shark Didn’t ‘Jump the Shark’
text: Today’s idea: Contrary to popular belief, when the Fonz jumped the shark on “Happy Days,” it hardly marked the demise of the show, the episode’s writer says.

headline: BP Spill Report Hints at Legal Defense
text: WASHINGTON  BP spent months this summer trying to contain the gusher of oil on the floor of the Gulf of Mexico. Now the company is trying to contain the legal and financial fallout from the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon, and on Wednesday it released the results of an internal investigation that mostly pointed fingers at other companies.

headline: A Little More and a Little Less for the Bentley Continental GT
text: Bentley Motors introduced on Tuesday an updated version of its outrageously excessive Continental GT.

headline: Ex-Lehman Property Exec Said to Join Apollo
text: The former co-head of Lehman Brothers‘ real estate investment arm, Raymond Mikulich, will join Apollo Global Management to run the buyout firm’s North American property business, Bloomberg News reported Wednesday, citing an unnamed source.

headline: Links to Wall St. Become Liability in Primary Races
text: When she set out to topple a popular nine-term Congressional incumbent, Reshma Saujani (pictured) reveled in her background in the world of high finance, emerging as a national voice for an industry that felt besieged, blamed and battered after the banking collapse.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: 2:40 p.m. | Updated — Greece’s amazing shrinking economy. Nouriel Roubini has said he thinks the country should restructure. But before they do that, let’s figure out how they hid all that debt in the first place.

headline: Two ‘Trees’ Return to the World Trade Center
text: Far more colossal — and meaningful — than the 16 oak trees that were planted Aug. 28 at the World Trade Center, two of the steel “trees” that held up the original north tower have been returned to the site; this time, not as structural muscle but as memorial artifacts on a giant scale.

headline: Guide to N.F.L. Defenses, Part 3: The 4-3 Front Continued
text: Jene Bramel writes for Footballguys.com. You can also follow him on Twitter and reach him at bramel@footballguys.com.

headline: Pay Full Price for a Meal? That’s So Yesterday
text: Restaurants are using several new Web services to offer discounts to diners. One of them, VillageVines, the private sale site for restaurants in New York, is about to appear in more cities.

headline: On the Migratory Trail, Leaders and Followers
text: Using the tools afforded by the study of applied mathematics and evolutionary biology, two Princeton researchers have shown that migratory animals that travel en masse tend to fall into two categories: “leaders” and follow… Er, make that “social individuals.”

headline: Hawke, Lyonne and Rubin-Vega to Star in New Group Opener
text: Ethan Hawke (“The Coast of Utopia”), Natasha Lyonne (“Slums of Beverly Hills”) and Daphne Rubin-Vega (“Rent”) have been cast in the Off Broadway play “Blood From a Stone,” the New Group’s first production of its 2010-11 season, the theater company announced on Wednesday.

headline: Nonprofit Groups Detail Health Industry Funds
text: Drug, medical device and insurance companies give more than $100 million a year to nonprofit health-related groups that advise consumers and medical professionals, according to a report posted  by The Chronicle of Philanthropy.

headline: Three Ways to Socialize With Firefox
text: The Firefox browser is second only to Microsoft‘s Internet Explorer in use around the world. It’s the one most people install when they want to venture beyond IE because they can easily alter it.

headline: Group to Promote Competition and Innovation
text: Is the United States losing its international competitiveness in developing new drugs, medical devices and health care services?

headline: Meredith Monk and Others Join Lincoln Center White Light Festival
text: Lincoln Center has announced some last-minute additions to its White Light Festival. There will be a free concert on opening day, Oct. 28, by Meredith Monk and her vocal ensemble at the David Rubenstein Atrium; an Alice Tully Hall concert by Antony and the Johnsons on Oct. 30; and performances by members of Sigur Ros, the Icelandic band, on Nov. 15 at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle.

headline: A Wicked Weapon Foils the Net Rusher
text: You’ve just worked your way into the net, perhaps behind an approach shot that you really smacked into the corner. Or maybe you chipped and charged, knifing your opponent’s second serve down the line. You appear to be in command of the point now.

text: An up-to-the minute list of where to eat, drink and kick up your kitten heels near Fashion Week’s new home.

headline: Supreme Connection: First Street to Wall Street
text: Adam Liptak of The New York Times recently reported on how Supreme Court justices are increasingly hiring clerks that align with their politics.

headline: A Host Is Not at Home: Ellen Does Broadway for a Night
text: Now that she doesn’t have a new season of “American Idol” to prepare for, Ellen DeGeneres found a few creative ways to promote the coming season of her daytime talk show during a trip to New York on Tuesday. First she stopped by David Letterman‘s “Late Show” to deliver the evening’s Top 10 List, “Things That Have Been on Ellen DeGeneres’s Mind Lately.” (No. 8: “For the last time, I’m not Jane Lynch, I’m the other one.”) Then she hoofed it across the street from the Ed Sullivan Theater to the Broadway Theater, where she joined Kristin Chenoweth and Sean Hayes for a surprise appearance in the musical “Promises, Promises.” (We know she can dance, but we’re saying a little prayer in hopes that Ms. DeGeneres left the singing to the professionals.)

headline: Schools Open With New Challenges and Tight Budgets
text: Updated, 11:49 a.m. | On a day of firsts, more than one million New York City public-school children returned to class Wednesday morning to schools facing serious new challenges but tighter budgets with which to meet them.

text: Let the computer do the teaching. Some studies, expert opinion and cost pressures all point toward a continuing shift of education online.

text: Post amended on 9/8/2010, to clarify the definition of “downloaded.”

headline: New York State Still Has Highest Unionization Rate
text: New York remains the No. 1 state in terms of unionization rate, largely because the rate for government employees in the state is so high – 71.2 percent.

headline: Tibiwangzi
text: Term for forgetting how to write traditional Chinese characters – literally, “take pen, forget character.”

headline: Conductor Ozawa Makes His Way Back
text: MATSUMOTO, Japan  The conductor Seiji Ozawa has characteristically exuded life, energy and a positive spirit, both on the stage and in personal contact. He did so again in an interview on Tuesday afternoon in a conference room at the Matsumoto Bunka Kaikan, the main performance hall of the Saito Kinen Festival, which he directs. Mr. Ozawa, who just turned 75, looked a bit the worse for wear and sounded gravelly, having undergone surgery for esophageal cancer in January and having had problems with sciatica before and since.

headline: A Regenerative Feat for Solar Cells
text: Leaves aren’t nearly as efficient as photovoltaic panels in harnessing the power of the sun. The typical plant captures just 3 to 6 percent of the sunlight available to it, compared with about 15 percent for the average solar panel. But when it comes to cost-efficiency, Mother Nature has mankind beat by a mile.

headline: Advertisement or Vogue Feature? You Decide
text: Condé Nast calls it “contextual relevance,” a way to blend advertising and editorial content in a way that is meant to be seamless for readers.

headline: Former William Morris Chairman Takes On New Role at AOL
text: Jim Wiatt, the former chairman of William Morris, has stepped down from AOL’s board after less than a year to become a full-time “strategic adviser” to the Internet company as it seeks to build a broader portfolio of original programming.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Optimism and Job Searches
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: A Pastor of Public Relations
text: Updated |1:11 p.m. If nothing else, Terry Jones, the pastor of a tiny Florida church with just three or four dozen members, whose every stray thought on the subject of Koran burning is now reported each day by thousands of news organizations worldwide, has proved himself to be a master of public relations.

headline: Godard Watch, Day 2: Maybe He’ll Pick Up His Oscar After All
text: As plot twists go it may not be quite as dramatic as Jean-Paul Belmondo painting his face blue and tying dynamite to his head in “Pierrot le fou,” but Jean-Luc Godard has told the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences he may indeed appear in person to receive an honorary Oscar in the fall.

headline: Group Says Booster Seats Are Improving
text: Booster seats are better this year than they were last year at making lap and shoulder belts correctly fit children 4 to 8 years old, better restraining these children in a crash, evaluations by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety have found.

headline: Investor Fears Force Split-Up of Irish Bank
text: The European bank panic that rattled markets around the world last spring may have subsided, but the experience has left investors and analysts jumpy about the prospects of more Greek-style bank bailouts.

headline: Goldman Banker Named Glaxo C.F.O.
text: GlaxoSmithKline, the British pharmaceutical giant, said on Wednesday that Simon Dingemans, head of the European M.&A. business at Goldman Sachs, would become its new chief financial officer.

headline: Seeking Designated Buyer
text: DEREK JETER has spent his entire Major League Baseball career as a New York Yankee. But with his contract up at the end of this season, his life might be in for some adjustments. For now he is making at least one big change, selling his New York apartment.

headline: 3-D Glasses Outside the Theater
text: Moviegoers have been trained to treat 3-D glasses as disposable products. When the movie’s over you’re supposed to chuck the glasses into the bins sitting outside the theaters.

headline: The Vogue Show
text: Credit is due to Anna Wintour and her staff for organizing a large-scale runway show in the plaza of Lincoln Center on Tuesday night that, for 1,500 ticket-buying guests who paid $25 to $400 for a seat, quite accurately portrayed what the actual experience of attending Fashion Week is like on the inside: You had to wait around in the 81-degree heat for an hour and a half before the start of the show, which lasted exactly 15 minutes.

headline: Open House: Where Are the Inspiring Matches in the Women’s Draw?
text: Gerry Marzorati: Morning, Michael. I’m a little groggy this morning, having stayed to the end last night, which was early this morning. I was with a friend from work, and she’d come to see Rafa — like all the women seated around us, actually. There was a moment when he took off his shirt and toweled himself and — O.K., it wasn’t exactly Las Vegas Bachelorette Party…

headline: Rex Ryan: Bringing It Big
text: Late spring in Florham Park, N.J., under a cloudless sky on a bright green lawn lined for football. It’s too hot, there’s only one lonely shade tree, and Rex Ryan’s latest diet isn’t working out. The New York Jets’ head coach is up over 345 again. Across the way from Ryan is his most valued employee, the magnificent cornerback Darrelle Revis, who is so “frustrated” about his salary that he sometimes seems undone. Living in Ryan’s attic back at the house is Ryan’s best friend since his Oklahoma youth, Jeff Weeks, the Jets’ outside linebackers coach, who is going through a divorce. Down on the farm in Kentucky, Ryan’s father, the pioneering defensive coach Buddy Ryan, has been ill with diverticulitis, while out in Cleveland, Ryan’s twin brother, Rob, is coordinating the defense for Browns Coach Eric Mangini, who had Ryan’s job until he was fired for what holdover Jets delicately call “negativity.” That, at least, will never be Ryan’s problem. “How great is this!” he cries, looking around. “My life is perfect.”

headline: CNN Makes It Official: Piers Morgan Will Replace Larry King
text: CNN said Wednesday that Piers Morgan would take over for Larry King next January, putting an end to speculation about one of the most prized time slots in television.

headline: Clan Planned Philippine Massacre Over Dinner, Witness Says
text: MANILA  The clan accused of orchestrating the Philippines’ worst political massacre  also considered the single worst killing of journalists on record  plotted the attack over a family dinner, a longtime housekeeper testified Wednesday at the start of a long-delayed trial here.

headline: What We’re Reading: Lying Pants
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Early Word: Midwest Pitch
text: President Obama swoops down in Cleveland today to sell his policy prescriptions for strengthening the economic recovery. Jackie Calmes writes that Mr. Obama will take a partisan (yet personal) tone as he pitches a centrist batch of tax cuts and new spending. Though the proposals are unlikely to be approved by Congress before November’s midterm elections or in the lame-duck session that follows, they provide Democrats an agenda as they head into the home stretch of this election season.

headline: Britain’s Mercury Prize Goes to the XX
text: The XX, a British trio that dresses all in black and plays stark, hushed songs about stifled desire, has won the Barclaycard Mercury Prize for its album “XX.” The Mercury, a £20,000 prize (about $31,000) for the best album by a British or Irish act, is voted on by a small group of journalists and music industry professionals, and is regarded as one of Britain’s most prestigious music awards. In the past it has gone to PJ Harvey, Talvin Singh, Pulp and Portishead, but was criticized last year when it was won by Speech Debelle, a little-known London rapper who was soon dropped by her record company.

headline: Halal Foods Expand Reach in France
text: NANTERRE, France  For years, Anissa Benchamacha bought her meat in a parking lot, from vendors hawking near-expired products to Muslims eager to find food that met their religious requirements.

headline: Hellman & Friedman to Buy Associated Materials
text: Hellman & Friedman,  the private equity firm, agreed on Wednesday to buy Associated Materials, a maker of homebuilding products, from its current private equity owners for about $1.3 billion in cash.

headline: Back to School: New York Times Resources for STEM
text: As your school year gets underway and you start planning ahead for the semester, here are some ways to use The New York Times use this year with your science, health, mathematics and technology students. Please see also our ideas for all subjects and for social studies and history. And check back tomorrow for more ideas for language arts and fine arts.

headline: Barbour to G.O.P.: Keep Your Foot on the Gas
text: Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi admonished his fellow Republicans on Wednesday not to measure those curtains just yet.

headline: Maj. Gen. Israel Tal, Israeli Military Strategist, Is Dead at 85
text: JERUSALEM  Israel Tal, who as one of Israel’s most influential military strategists designed and developed its main tank, the Merkava, refashioned battleground doctrine and served as an adviser to prime ministers, died Wednesday. He was 85.

headline: Frito-Lay Adds Electric Trucks to Its Fleet
text: Frito-Lay North America announced on Wednesday that it would field a fleet of 176 battery-powered delivery trucks made by Smith Electric Vehicles. In the first wave, five each will be operated in New York City, Fort Worth and Columbus, Ohio. Six will be in Canada.

headline: The Architecture Biennale | A Last Look
text: If you happen to be in Venice this week for the Film Festival, a quick hop over to the Giardini is also highly recommended. The public park at the tip of the lagoon, overlooking the Lido, is host to most of the national pavilions of this year’s Architecture Biennale, which runs through Nov. 21. Perhaps the best way to tour the pavilions is to plunge straight in, literally, at the Polish Pavilion, which won the Golden Lion for National Pavilion in 2008.

headline: To Go Where Compact Fluorescents Cannot
text: Mention “new lighting technology” and what leaps to mind is probably a compact fluorescent curlicue. Shaped like a soft ice cream cone, it is viewed as a replacement for the ubiquitous 60-watt incandescent light bulb, which looks almost like it did 90 years ago.

headline: Orientation Week Is Over for Penn State Freshman
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Last Saturday, Rob Bolden became the first freshman quarterback to start a season opener for Penn State in 100 years. That was the easy part. Now, the hard part.

headline: Park51, ‘Parker Spitzer’ and Parking Those Sex Ads
