headline: Iran Lifts Sentence of Stoning for Woman
text: TEHRAN  An Iranian official has confirmed that the government halted the sentence of death by stoning of a woman convicted of adultery, but he reiterated that she was still facing accusations of murder.

headline: The Insider | Michael Nevin
text: Michael Nevin is founder and editor in chief of The Journal, a curated art and culture quarterly that began in 1999 as a photocopied snowboarding ‘zine. He is also the director of the Journal Gallery, situated in a converted garage on North First Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, next to the magazine’s office. Entry 29 of the journal is about to hit newsstands with a few surprises, including a supplement created by Nate Lowman titled “Life’s a Beach and Then You Die.” The accompanying exhibition, “Wish You Were Here,” goes up at the gallery on Sept. 16.

headline: An Argument Against Taking (and Retaking) the SAT and ACT
text: I recently received an e-mail from a father who said that his daughter had taken the SAT and ACT, and was contemplating retaking both exams. Should she? With the hope that this might prove a teachable moment for readers of The Choice (and me), I farmed the question out to Gwyeth Smith Jr. He is a longtime college counselor, now in private practice, who is the main character in David Marcus’s book “Acceptance: A Legendary Guidance Counselor Helps Seven Kids Find the Right Colleges – and Find Themselves” (recently published in paperback by Penguin.) Mr. Smith’s answer follows the question. — Jacques Steinberg

headline: What It Takes to Be a Good Mayor
text: David Brooks: Gail, in this sour season, let us pause to praise famous men. I was hoping to get you to talk about some politician who is doing an outstanding job. As for me, I’m going to gush about Richard M. Daley, who has decided not to run again as mayor of Chicago.

headline: Casey’s Mystery Bidder Raises New Questions
text: The market has been abuzz over the last 24 hours with speculation over the new mystery bidder for Casey’s General Stores – and whether this offer is real.

headline: Google Speeds Queries With ‘Instant’ Results
text: Those who find Google’s search engine to be impossibly slow will welcome Google Instant, an upgrade to the company’s search results that it unveiled Wednesday.

headline: U.S. Says Killings Won’t Affect Iraq Mission
text: BAGHDAD  The killing of two American soldiers by an Iraqi soldier at a military base north of Baghdad was a “deliberate act” but would not undermine the new American mission to advise Iraq’s security forces, the American military said in a statement on Wednesday.

headline: Massachusetts Gubernatorial Rivals Battle in Debate
text: In a four-way race that appears to be tightening, Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts, a Democrat, and Charles D. Baker, the Republican nominee, leapt into attack mode Tuesday in the race’s first televised debate, which also included two other challengers.

headline: Reader Photos From the First Day of School
text: So far today we’ve collected dozens of your photos from the first day of school in New York City (and several places outside of New York, too). Please keep sending them, using this simple upload form. We have published an initial gallery of your submissions and will be updating it throughout the day.

headline: Crisis Past, Obama May Have Missed a Chance
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Bryant’s Life and Death Cast a Shadow Over Paterno
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  Joe Paterno unofficially started his 45th season as the Penn State football coach with a request at the team’s media day in August that caused an eruption of laughter and made him smile.

headline: Survivor
text: What if the future were a giant reality television show in which children were pitted against each other in an elaborate fight to the death, in which politics, war and entertainment had finally become indistinguishable? This is the question raised by Suzanne Collins’s brutal and absorbing “Hunger Games” trilogy, and answered in the much anticipated final installment, “Mockingjay.”­

headline: Soldiers Halt Workers at Kabul Bank
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  On Wednesday, the last business day before a national holiday, state security forces punched and pushed back hundreds of governments workers trying to storm the central branch of the embattled Kabul Bank to claim their monthly wages.

headline: Capturing the First Day of School
text: Readers’ photographs of children in New York City and elsewhere as they head back to the classroom.

headline: Sorrow Wears and Uses Us
text: In an essay about his friendship with Norman Mailer, written in early 1961 at the peak of his eloquence, James Baldwin recalled his reaction to the news that Mailer was running for mayor of New York. Baldwin initially dismissed the rumor as a joke, until “it became hideously clear that it was not a joke at all. I was furious. I thought . . . you’re copping out . . . It’s not your job.”

headline: Officer Resigns, Then Pleads Guilty to Manslaughter
text: An off-duty police officer who struck and killed a woman in Brooklyn in 2009 pleaded guilty in Brooklyn Supreme Court on Wednesday to second-degree vehicular manslaughter. According to the terms of the plea agreement, the officer, Andrew Kelly, will serve 90 days in jail and receive five years probation.

headline: Your Pet’s Back-to-School Blues
text: Back-to-school season is a time of transition for the whole family, as parents and children begin to adjust to a new routine. But as the ASPCA reports, it’s also a difficult time for pets, who have grown accustomed to some extra attention during summer vacations and excursions to parks and beaches.

headline: Rooms With a View
text: The novel of braided, alternating stories, perfected by David Mitchell, is a narrative daisy chain designed to tease readers by a process akin to ­coitus interruptus. One story stops, another begins, then a third, then more, then it’s back to the first and so on. Novels like this suggest hidden connections between disparate sets of characters, although the spectacle of sheer juxtaposition — of incongruous stories slyly interpolated — is also part of their appeal. Sometimes major characters in one story become secondary characters in others. Or unexpected events ripple through the separate sections, providing an accidental link. To give their narrative centrifuge a provisional stability, novelists sometimes employ a framing device. Why not, for example, set one’s alternating stories in — of course! — a hotel? In this manner, a technique as old-fashioned as the 1932 film “Grand Hotel” merges with the postmodernism of Mitchell’s “Cloud Atlas.”

headline: Jay Alford’s Moment as a Giant
text: It’s not easy to pull off one of the biggest upsets in Super Bowl history. A catch like David Tyree’s helps.

headline: Perfect Children
text: Among the many astute touches in “The Widower’s Tale” is the fact that the action takes place within the orbit of two educational institutions looming large in the minds of today’s affluent, consumerist parents: an exclusive “progressive” preschool and Harvard. If we can somehow shepherd our children through the first and then into the other, the communal fantasy goes, they’ll land safely in some dreamy sphere of the elite, where there’s no suffering, no strife, no failure, where the workers are invisible and all the real estate is light-filled. This energized, good-humored novel, Julia Glass’s fourth, smashes through that illusion, beginning as satire, becoming stealthily suspenseful and ending up with a satisfyingly cleareyed and compassionate view of American entitlement and its fallout.

headline: Fashion’s New Home
text: A multimedia tour of Fashion Week’s new setting.

headline: Media Stacking
text: Using two (or more) forms of media simultaneously – for example, surfing the net while watching television.Revealing that more than half of Britons use another type of media while watching television, Andrew Laughlin wrote for Digital Spy:

headline: Ireland Moves to Split Up Troubled Anglo Irish Bank
text: The Irish government, bowing to market fears that its escalating banking losses might cause it to default, said Wednesday that it would split the Anglo Irish Bank into two entities, one of which would eventually cease operations, The New York Times’s Landon Thomas Jr. reported.

headline: Keeping a Different Kind of Score in the N.F.L.
text: Each N.F.L. season promises so much: 256 games, most of them meaningful, many of them close; breathtaking highlights, last-second touchdowns, 50-yard field goals in the snow, fourth-down gambles, goal-line stands, end-zone celebrations, post-celebration penalties, and television close-ups of the quarterback’s intense stare as he prepares to hand off in the fourth quarter of a 52-3 game.

headline: Ask Matt Bai: Obama’s Missed Opportunity
text: As he presents a new element of his plan to revive the economy, President Obama is already faced with the reality that voters have, fairly or not, decided that his first big effort, the $800 billion package enacted right after he took office, was a qualified failure, and that anything tagged as further “stimulus” will be cast by Republicans as throwing good money after bad.

headline: Children’s Books You (Might) Hate
text: Last week, while writing a guest post about something completely different, Josh Tyson mentioned in passing that he liked to read the book “The Giving Tree” with his two-and-a-half-year-old son. That led many of you to use the comments to make it clear that you really, really do not like that particular book.

headline: One Kind of Folks
text: It seems only fitting, 50 years after the publication of “To Kill a Mockingbird,” that a ­Vietnamese-born author who came of age in the United States has written a Southern novel with an Asian-American protagonist who likes to cite Harper Lee. “I was the town’s pariah, but no one was allowed to tell me so,” says Linh-Dao Nguyen Hammerick, called Linda, the piercingly eloquent narrator of Monique Truong’s second novel. “In Boiling Springs,” Linda remarks of her hometown in rural North Carolina, “I was never Scout. I was Boo Radley, not hidden away but in plain sight.”

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 8
text: A view of the day in sports, including a victory by Serbia at the world basketball championships.

headline: Game Excerpt: Medal of Honor
text: Some of the most popular cultural depictions of America's current wars happens to be in video games.

headline: Unsentimental Education
text: Graham Greene once said that writers should keep a chip of ice in their hearts. It’s sound advice, with exceptions. Despite her generous portrayal of her troubled family life, Liz Murray succeeds as an author. Few parents would seem to have been more deserving of contempt than the ones who raised her.

headline: Seoul-Searching With Tory Burch
text: When Tory Burch was last in Europe, she came armed with a voice recorder, which she used to capture her observations. The designer then traveled to Seoul, South Korea, to open her new boutique in Cheongdam-dong. (It’s like the South Korean Rodeo Drive.) Once there, she handed off the voice recorder to the filmmaker Van Neistat (of viral video fame), who gave himself the unusual task of pairing Burch’s commentary on her European jaunt — about cypress trees in Tuscany, a sunset over the Seine — with scenes from Seoul. The seemingly awkward conceit comes off cleverly, but it did leave us wondering what Burch thought of Seoul itself. “The city is very international and progressive,” she says. “I loved everything from the chic women to the interesting architecture. Walking into the Leeum museum was so exciting — there were three spider sculptures by one of my favorite artists, Louise Bourgeois. The stores are also fantastic, like Boon, Mue and 10 Corso Como. I definitely want to go back. There is so much more I’d love to see.”

headline: A Life in Nepal
text: Samrat Upadhyay’s fiction has tended to be small in scale, charting the infinitesimal tremors of middle-class angst. That his characters happen to live in Katmandu instead of, say, Bloomington, Ind. — where Upadhyay, who was born and raised in Nepal, now makes his home — is at times almost incidental. “Those Led Zeppelin days are over, friend,” a Nepali wife chides her husband in “Buddha’s Orphans,” Upadhyay’s new novel. “You need to get a job so we can start thinking about a child.” The fretting, the obsessive nostalgia, the muffled ache: it’s all distressingly familiar. We have scaled the roof of the world and met ourselves.

headline: A New Web Service Offers Restaurant Discounts
text: Over on the Bits blog, Claire Cain Miller writes about a new site that is offering discounts to restaurants in several major American cities.

headline: Otherwise Occupied
text: Military novels that stint on the shells a-bursting and the guns a-rat-a-­tatting tend to be positively prickly with black humor, filled with the kind of jocular cutting-contest rituals that occur between salvos in the field. Either the bodies mount, or the sarcastic asides do.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. John Boehner vying for speaker of the House. He’ll be a lot less tan if he gets a more demanding job.

headline: The View From the Driver’s Seat
text: One day in 1917, Henri Matisse persuaded his son to drive him into the country in the family car. He set up his easels and painted a view of the road and trees, seen through the windshield and out the car windows. He established a tradition of viewing the world from the car, whose latest flowering is visible in a show of photographs.

headline: Clinton Speech Offers Policy Overview
text: WASHINGTON — It was not quite as lofty as Madeleine K. Albright’s description of the United States as the world’s “indispensable nation,” but Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton came close to channeling her predecessor on Wednesday in declaring a “new American moment.”

headline: Fed Report Finds Signs That Growth Is Slowing
text: The United States economy showed “widespread signs” of slowing, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday, though modest growth continued from mid-July through the end of August.

headline: Atonement
text: Early in Darin Strauss’s first novel, “Chang and Eng,” a historical tale about conjoined twins born in Siam in 1811, Eng awakes to find that Chang has died in the night. “Then I too am done,” Eng thinks. The two men’s lives have been entwined almost beyond imagining, and one cannot survive without the other. Eng clings to his dead twin, then dies himself. It is impossible not to think of this moment, which appears once at the beginning and again near the end of the novel, when reading Strauss’s new memoir, “Half a Life.”

headline: Carlyle Hires Head of U.S. Equity Opportunity Group
text: The Carlyle Group “>said Wednesday that it had hired Rodney Cohen as the head of its new United States equity opportunity group, which will focus on investments in small to mid-sized companies.

headline: Molly Shannon Joins ‘Promises, Promises’
text: You always knew that Mary Katherine Gallagher was going to make it to Broadway one way or another. That overeager Catholic schoolgirl and aspiring entertainer may remain in semiretirement, but Molly Shannon, the “Saturday Night Live” alumna who portrayed her (along with characters like Sally O’Malley and a parody version of Ann Miller) on that program, is slated to make her Broadway debut in “Promises, Promises,” the musical’s publicists said on Wednesday. Ms. Shannon will take over the role of the barfly Marge MacDougall from Katie Finneran on Oct. 12; Ms. Finneran, who won a Tony Award for her portrayal of that character this year (and who is pregnant with her first child), will leave the production after Oct. 10. The leads of “Promises, Promises,” Kristin Chenoweth and Sean Hayes, will remain in the show through Dec. 26, when Ms. Shannon will also depart; no permanent role has yet been found for Ellen DeGeneres.

headline: Networking
text: When I first heard that the Department of Homeland Security had brought in a group of science fiction writers to brainstorm new ways that terrorists might attack America, something changed for me forever. I realized this was one of the first news stories I had ever totally believed — in part because it was like something from fiction. Even if it hadn’t happened yet, it could happen, and therefore probably would. In a late-capitalist marketplace where you can buy or sell almost anything, including artificial islands in Dubai (Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt apparently bought one in the shape of Ethiopia), nothing feels impossible. And in a world where fiction is becoming indistinguishable from reality, as the philosopher Baudrillard suggested, the flow of “truth” goes both ways. It’s just as likely that fiction will come true as it is that the truth will turn out to have been fiction all along.

headline: Carlsen vs. the World
text: Magnus Carlsen, the 19-year-old Norwegian who is the top-ranked chess player, will play a game against the world on Friday via the Internet. Carlsen will be making his moves from the Cooper Square Hotel in Manhattan.

headline: As the Smoke Cleared
text: The morning of Sept. 11, 2001, found me on my stoop in Boston’s South End, waiting for a ride to work. One minute I was enjoying the sunshine, worrying about the logistics of moving house. Then the first plane struck the north tower of the World Trade Center and my entire frame of reference lurched. What I don’t quite remember is how that painful, personal moment connected to America’s national experience in the aftermath of the attacks — and to what many saw as the erosion of civil liberties, unnecessary wars and the willingness to scorn allies and international institutions.

headline: The 38th Parallel
text: Bruce Cumings is a historian at the University of Chicago; the author of several books, including a doorstop two-volume history entitled “The Origins of the Korean War”; and a gifted controversialist. He distills his work in his new primer, “The Korean War,” which is dedicated to the memory of the South Korean president Kim Dae-jung, who promoted a “sunshine policy” with the North.

headline: Prison Raid in Nigeria Releases Hundreds
text: DAKAR, Senegal  More than 700 inmates in the northern Nigerian city of Bauchi were freed Tuesday night in a daring raid by well-armed attackers on a prison where members of an Islamist sect were being held, authorities and witnesses said Wednesday.

headline: Paradise Lost
text: A  green and fecund island, ­barely 20 miles off the east coast of Africa, Zanzibar for centuries represented gratified desire. For voyagers across the Indian Ocean its safe harbor was a refuge after a long journey. The vast Chinese trading fleet led by the eunuch Zheng He moored at Zanzibar in the early 15th century to exchange its silver for African gold. For Vasco da Gama, who landed there in 1499, beginning 200 years of Portuguese domination, it was an island of repose for men slaughtering their way across the Eastern seas.

headline: Buffalo Hunting
text: In the innocent, pre-Rugby days of the early ’60s, there was nothing ironic or fashiony about a free-hanging dartless suit or the kind of heathery saddle-shoulder Shetland crew neck beloved of John Cheever. Buffalo, N.Y., alone had maybe 15 family-owned men’s-wear shops selling what a certain three-hankie film would universally popularize as the preppy look. By the time Ralph Lifshitz paid a sales call on O’Connell’s, the only pre-“Love Story” haberdasher still operating in the Queen City, he was already the tie designer Ralph Lauren, and you have to assume he was paying attention.

headline: Conspiracy Theorem
text: Not so long ago, before Swedes and vampires ruled the best-seller list, readers snapped up thrillers with plots so gaudy their authors risked confinement hearings. “The Da Vinci Code,” “The Rule of Four” and their imitators sold millions of copies. Why? Maybe for the simple reason that we’re all conspiracists at heart, seeking hidden explanations for the puzzle of the world around us.

headline: Blue Book May Be on the Block
text: “What’s the Blue Book value?”

headline: A Fashion Week Debut, Seven Weeks in the Making
text: THREE years ago, a fashion event for Monique Péan meant stowing her best jewelry samples into an antique white box and hauling it to the Times Square offices of Vogue in the off chance that editors there might like her earthy, eco-friendly bracelets and necklaces.

headline: Latin Grammy Nominations Announced
text: Juan Luis Guerra, Alejandro Sanz, Jorge Drexler and Mario Domm lead the nominations for the 11th annual Latin Grammy Awards, announced on Wednesday morning in Los Angeles. Those veteran musicians received four nods apiece (Mr. Domm, a producer and songwriter from Mexico, shares three of his nods with his band, Camila), and will face one another — along with some newer faces — in most of the major categories.

headline: Trouble in the Monkey House
text: When Harvard announced last month that it had found the psychologist Marc Hauser “solely responsible” for eight instances of scientific misconduct, the news generated front-page headlines and streams of schadenfreude-laced commentary in the blogosphere. Hauser, an expert on human and animal cognition, is a star of the Harvard faculty and the author of scores of scientific papers, as well as the book “Moral Minds” (2006), a popular study of the evolutionary underpinnings of human morality. The irony of that last part — and of the title of Hauser’s book-in-progress, “Evilicious: Why We Evolved a Taste for Being Bad” — wasn’t lost on some observers.

headline: At New Site, No Runway Jostling
text: NEW YORK FASHION WEEK begins its run at Lincoln Center on Thursday after 17 years in Bryant Park — so expect to see disoriented fashion editors in treacherous shoes teetering about the Upper West Side.

headline: Final Sealing of Gulf Well Is Delayed Again
text: The final sealing of BP’s stricken well in the Gulf of Mexico has been delayed again, the government said Wednesday, as engineers worked to better understand the well’s condition.

headline: In the Trenches: ‘War Horse’
text: For centuries, the most glorified fighting — often reserved for officers and noblemen — was mounted combat.

headline: In the Trenches: ‘The War to End All Wars’
text: If World War I were a movie, it would be panned. The lead characters’ motivations are unclear. Nothing happens for long stretches of time, and when it does, the carnage puts Mortal Kombat to shame. A year or two could be cut. And that resolution at Versailles feels like a heavy-handed setup for a sequel.

headline: Eurofile | Going Wild in the Baltics
text: Though any reference to Estonian cooking generally draws a blank stare from even well-traveled gourmets, Alexander, one of the best and most interesting new restaurants in Europe right now, is found on the tiny and stunningly beautiful Estonian island of Muhu, a two-hour drive south from Tallinn, the country’s capital. It’s still rather confidential, but a gastronomic awakening is occurring in the countries that surround Europe’s other great sea, the Baltic, which has long been dismissed as a region of marginal culinary interest by a world besotted with everything Mediterranean.

headline: Where the Future Stars May Be
text: THE fashion calendar is glutted with scores of young hopefuls jostling to make their mark during New York Fashion Week. Some will attain the brief but glorious life span of a butterfly, spreading their wings for a season or two, while others will demonstrate formidable staying power. Among the more than 100 designers showing their spring-summer 2011 collections at Lincoln Center and elsewhere around town are a handful of strikingly inventive talents who have caught the eye of influential insiders.

headline: Strange New World
text: An exuberant imagination can be one of a child’s best companions. Sometimes it can be too much of a good thing, though, brimming not only with fantasies and inventions but also with worries and worst-case scenarios. Few things make a child’s imaginings go into overdrive like the first day of school, as Antoinette Portis delightfully captures in “Kindergarten Diary.”

headline: Deepak Chopra’s ‘Muhammad’ to Be Released Early as E-Book
text: “Muhammad,” Deepak Chopra’s fictionalized biography about the life of the Prophet Muhammad, will go on sale early in e-book form, weeks ahead of the print book’s publication date of Sept. 21.

headline: ArtsBeat: Deepak Chopra’s ‘Muhammad’ to Be Released Early as E-Book
text: “Muhammad,” Deepak Chopra’s fictionalized biography about the life of the Prophet Muhammad, will go on sale early in e-book form, weeks ahead of the print book’s publication date of Sept. 21. HarperCollins, the book’s publisher, said it had authorized Amazon and other e-book retailers to sell the book beginning Wednesday, trying to meet demand for the book since the national conversation has turned to Islam and the planned community center and mosque near ground zero. Read more at ArtsBeat…

headline: Obama, in Rally Mode, Steps Up Jabs at G.O.P.
text: CLEVELAND  Seeking to rally his struggling party for the final weeks of the midterm election, President Obama delivered his most partisan speech of the campaign so far on Wednesday, casting Democrats as fighters for the middle class and Republicans as protectors of “millionaires and billionaires” and special interests.

headline: Children’s Bookshelf
text: SCHOOL!  Adventures at the Harvey N. Trouble Elementary School.  Written by Kate McMullan.Inspired and illustrated by George Booth.  Feiwel & Friends. $12.99. (Ages 6 to 9)

headline: Hey, Mr. Critic!
text: The mailbot brought restaurant questions from Alberta this week, from eastern Connecticut and the wilds of parenthood. As ever, I did my best to give good advice. Send me your questions and follow along on Twitter.

headline: Study Shows Drop in Credit Card Use
text: Consumers are using credit cards less than in the past, at least according to data just released from Javelin Strategy and Research.

headline: On Clean Energy, China Skirts Rules
text: CHANGSHA, China  Until very recently, Hunan Province was known mainly for lip-searing spicy food, smoggy cities and destitute pig farmers. Mao was born in a village on the outskirts of Changsha, the provincial capital here in south-central China.

headline: Your Very Own $400,000 Robot
text: Regular readers of Bits will know about my love of robots. In short, I’ve always wanted to own one, but so far each experience with them has fallen a little short of my robotic expectations.

headline: Seoul-Searching With Tory Burch
text: A new short by the filmmaker Van Neistat tied to the opening of the Tory Burch flagship store in Seoul.

headline: Up Front: Dani Shapiro
text: The novelist and memoirist Dani Shapiro reviews “Half a Life,” Darin Strauss’s account of being behind the wheel in a fatal car crash as a high school student.

headline: Clean Energy Entrepreneurs Face More Obstacles in U.S.
text: With erect posture and clear gray eyes, Chuck Provini still looks like the Marine who graduated from the Naval Academy in 1969 and was repeatedly decorated for bravery in Vietnam.

headline: Code World
text: There are many stories Tom McCarthy chooses not to tell in “C,” his tour de force new novel encompassing the short life of one Serge Carrefax, born at the turn of the 20th century on a rural English estate. Serge’s father, a manic tinkerer with early wireless technology, runs a school for the deaf but seems oblivious to his own deaf wife, Serge’s mother, who’s so blinkered on opium (supplied by a mute gardener who grows the poppies himself) that she nearly lets Serge drown in a creek at age 2. Serge’s beloved older sister, Sophie, becomes sexually involved with a friend of their father’s and winds up committing suicide at 17 — possibly after having an abortion. Serge’s relationship to Sophie is preternaturally close, with incestuous overtones, and her death severs his only real human connection. But these dramas are merely suggested, their shadowy outlines ignored, sublimated or flat-out denied by those involved; Sophie’s self-poisoning is deemed an accident.

headline: Trip to Army Hospital Turns Into Mets Controversy
text: WASHINGTON  Carlos Beltran hit a sacrifice fly on Wednesday to provide the Mets with a third of their offense in a sleepy 3-2 matinee victory against the Washington Nationals. But what he did the day before may provide a better window on his relationship with the team.

headline: Are Films Bad, or Is TV Just Better?
text: FOR as long as anyone in the movie world can remember (which may be only 20 years or so, but never mind), the fall season has been marked by a sober kind of excitement. The commercial entertainments of summer give way to more ambitious fare, and the grown-up segment of the audience goes back to the theaters looking for stirring performances, complex storytelling, important themes and big emotions. That’s the theory, anyway.

headline: The Saints Have Taken Steps to Avoid a Letdown
text: The N.F.L. will throw one more parade for the New Orleans Saints on Thursday night, a brightly colored pageant meant to usher in a new season. The Saints will host a rematch with the Minnesota Vikings, whom they vanquished in overtime in the N.F.C. championship game, and provide a final joyride into the sunset for the feel-good story of last season.

headline: Zvonareva Overcomes Kanepi to Reach Semis
text: It was the shriek versus the shout. The Wimbledon finalist Vera Zvonareva of Russia powered her way into the women’s semifinals with a hard-fought victory over Kaia Kanepi of Estonia, 6-3, 7-5.

headline: Zvonareva and Wozniacki Adjust and Advance
text: While her classmates in Moscow ease into the new school year, Vera Zvonareva is grinding through her tennis exams at the United States Open. The tournament’s pass-fail format used to be a trial for Zvonareva, who had a hard time accepting any score short of perfection.

headline: Kramnik Wins Second Spot in Bilbao Final Masters
text: Vladimir Kramnik beat Levon Aronian in a playoff at the Shanghai Masters to qualify for the final.

headline: The Beads Show Her the Way
text: “I ALWAYS say everything finds its own place,” said Lori Goldstein, the stylist who for decades has helped create the look of Versace campaigns and the photo shoots of Annie Leibovitz and Steven Meisel. In her approach to fashion, she has kept an open mind when facing a rack of clothes, letting the look of each outfit come together naturally.

headline: Central Bankers Spurred to Complete New Regulations
text: FRANKFURT — The drama in Ireland has added urgency to efforts by central bankers and bank regulators to agree on global rules designed to prevent future crises.

headline: The Insider | Helping Immigrants Navigate City Government
text: Name: Fatima A. ShamaTitle: Commissioner of the Mayor’s Office of Immigrant Affairs.Age:  37Hometown: Born and raised in the Bronx.

headline: New Parents at Risk for Depression
text: Both mothers and fathers face an increased risk of depression after the birth of a child, and remain at some increased risk well into a child’s adolescence, a new British study shows.

headline: Hey, There’s a Lady Present
text: THE fashion stylist Annabel Tollman can rattle off a litany of reasons not to like this season’s 1950s-style box-frame handbags. “There’s something decidedly starchy about them,” she began.

headline: Delicious Ways to Love Downtown Los Angeles
text: DOWNTOWN Los Angeles has been “reviving” for the better part of 20 years.

headline: A Revived Restaurant Scene in Los Angeles
text: New eateries are keeping diners downtown.

headline: The Thoughtful Roar of the Housing Bears
text: I was a housing bear for a long time. And I’m not exactly bullish now. But I am a bit less bearish than some other real estate watchers. They’re making some thoughtful arguments today about why we should expect home prices to soon fall more.

headline: Swisher’s Homer and Posada’s Test Results Brighten Yanks’ Afternoon
text: Even though he was trying to protect a one-run lead, Baltimore Orioles closer Koji Uehara was bold enough to throw a first-pitch fastball to the Yankees’ Alex Rodriguez in the bottom of the ninth inning Wednesday afternoon. Rodriguez lashed a single. Nick Swisher made a mental note.

headline: Shopping With Luke Ives Pontifell
text: The founder of Thornwillow Press searched for bookends that are both functional and aesthetically pleasing.

headline: For This Musical Couple, It’s Simply a Matter of Chemistry
text: “Heaven.”

headline: Florida Pastor Says Koran Burning Still On
text: Updated | 6:31 p.m. Terry Jones, the pastor of a tiny Florida church that has garnered worldwide attention for its plan to burn more than 200 copies of the Koran, told reporters on Wednesday that, “as of this time, we have no intention of canceling.” He added, “we are not convinced that backing down is the right thing, so on Sept. 11 we will continue with our planned event.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: On a Chinese Oil Rig and Elsewhere
text: Two oil workers were missing and more than 30 others were rescued from a rig off China’s northeast coast that was damaged in a storm on Wednesday, the BBC reported. Helicopters and rescue boats searched for two people who fell from the platform, which was listing at a 45-degree angle in the Shengli oil field, operated by Sinopec, which is the second-largest in China. Sinopec said no oil has been spilled and that powerful waves generated by Typhoon Malou were the likely cause.

headline: In Season 9, iPods Still Get High Ratings
text: CUPERTINO, Calif.  At a special press event today, Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, unveiled a new lineup of iPod models, just in time for the holiday season. The diminutive iPod Shuffle still has no screen and is still made of brushed aluminum, but it now has _____ and comes in _____ colors. Apple tinkered with the proportions of the iPod Nano, too, adding _____ and redesigning the _____. The popular iPod Touch also received a makeover; it’s thinner now, and gains new features like a _____ and a _____. All models now offer better battery life and greater storage capacity.

headline: Panel Urges Tougher Offshore Regulation
text: Regulators who are supposed to police offshore oil and gas drilling are spread too thinly, poorly trained and hampered by outdated technology, according to a study by an Interior Department review board appointed after the BP oil disaster in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Views of Health Care Economics From a C.E.O. Named Bush
text: In the world of health care innovation, the founder and chief executive of Athenahealth has an outsize name. In part, that’s because his name is Jonathan Bush, and he is the nephew of one former president and the cousin of another. But it’s also because his company has mastered the intricacies of the doctor-insurer relationship and become a player in the emerging medical records industry.

headline: The View From Madison Square Park
text: Dan Hoffmann might normally eat his take-out lunches behind his desk at Grey Global Group, an advertising agency, but on a sunny Wednesday afternoon the week after Labor Day, he got an added bonus to go with his food: a side of tennis.

headline: Night of a Thousand Labels
text: Expect a frenzy of big-name designers, cocktails and limited-edition stuff from cool designers at the second coming of Fashion’s Night Out on Friday. Check out a full guide to where you can drink, spend and gawk.

headline: ZumoCast Offers a Personalized Cloud
text: So you want to take a video that is sitting on your computer and watch it on your iPad or iPhone. It shouldn’t be too difficult, right? Yet the options available from Apple, the company that makes the software and hardware for those devices, can either be very expensive or very slow.

headline: Is the Health Care Plan a Good Thing?
text: In a conversation published today, Jonathan Bush, founder and chief executive of Athenahealth, wades into the argument over whether the health care overhaul enacted into law this year is good for small business.

headline: A Conversation: Fashion's New Generation
text: Six emerging fashion designers talk with Eric Wilson about developing their businesses in New York City.

headline: Think You’ve Seen It All? You Have
text: THE time has come for Broadway to erect its own Statue of Liberty. I envision it overlooking Duffy Square and maybe having the face of Angela Lansbury. But those details can be worked out later. The important thing is that this monument offer the same kind of hope to the disenfranchised of show business that the original did to immigrants coming to Ellis Island. “Give me your flops, your has-beens,” the plaque on it might read. “Your dimming stars yearning to shine once more. Send these, the tarnished, tempest-tossed to me.”

headline: Elizabeth Jenkins, Woman of Letters, Dies at 104
text: Elizabeth Jenkins, a novelist whose biographies of Jane Austen, Lady Caroline Lamb, Henry Fielding and Elizabeth I established her as one of Britain’s foremost women of letters, died on Sunday in Hampstead, London, where she had been in a nursing home for several years. She was 104.

headline: Way Back Machine | The L.I.R.R. Reaches Manhattan
text: “Day Long Throng Inspects New Tube,” trumpeted the headline in The New York Times.

headline: Web Slinger Is Poised to Cast Net
text: NEW YORK’S newest Spider-Man lives by himself in an imposing glass tower high above Times Square. It’s a long way from Peter Parker’s Queens. But then again, so is “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” the high-octane Broadway musical directed by Julie Taymor, with music by Bono and the Edge and aerial technology designed by a member of Cirque du Soleil. For now Reeve Carney, the newly installed Spidey, can still walk unnoticed from his sparsely furnished apartment to his six-day-a-week rehearsals. But by the time the much-delayed, much-ballyhooed show — said to be the most expensive in Broadway history — opens at the Foxwoods Theater on Dec. 21 (previews begin Nov. 14), that may not be possible.

headline: When the Familiar Becomes Special
text: In his Theater Talkback on the ArtsBeat blog, Ben Brantley, chief theater critic of The Times, asked readers to recall “revelatory” performances that changed the way they thought about familiar characters. Here are some edited responses:

headline: A Writer’s Long Journey to Trace the Great Migration
text: ATLANTA  To finish “The Warmth of Other Suns,” her magisterial new history of the black migration in America, which carried millions of Southerners northward or westward, Isabel Wilkerson had to complete a sort of reverse migration. She began writing the book in Chicago, where she was the bureau chief for The New York Times, and finished it more than a decade later in a house in the Virginia Highland neighborhood of Atlanta. Ms. Wilkerson moved here in 2001, for reasons unconnected to the book, and immediately discovered, she said this week, that she “needed to be here, only I didn’t know it.”

headline: Following the Action at the Open
text: Gerry Marzorati, one-half of the Open House duo, is covering the United States Open via his smart phone and Twitter. You can follow his observations about Novak Djokovic’s victory over Gael Monfils, 7-6 (2), 6-1, 6-2, earlier Wednesday by clicking “Read more” or go directly to gerrynyt.

headline: Peek Returns to Banking With New Job at Barclays
text: Jeffrey M. Peek, the chief executive who built up the CIT Group, only to see it nearly capsize during the financial crisis, has returned to his investment banking roots with his latest job.

headline: Disturbed, at No. 1 Again, Earns Rare Distinction
text: Metallica and the Dave Matthews Band you expect to be giants of the Billboard charts. But Disturbed?

headline: Court Dismisses a Case Asserting Torture by C.I.A.
text: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Wednesday ruled that former prisoners of the C.I.A. could not sue over their alleged torture in overseas prisons because such a lawsuit might expose secret government information.

headline: Fashion’s Night Out in Pictures
text: “Fashion’s Night Out is like a mix between New Year’s Eve and Halloween,” says Ina Bernstein, the proprietor of the popular INA designer consignment shops. Now you can add opening night at the International Center of Photography to the mix. At a number of stores around town, A-list photographers will be hanging impromptu shows with work that connects to the freshly unpacked fall collections hanging on the racks.

headline: Courtside: The Wind Factor
text: Christopher Clarey on how the wind has and will continue to play a role at Arthur Ashe Stadium during the U.S. Open, and a look ahead to the semifinals match between Venus Williams and Kim Clijsters.

headline: At This School, Misfits Make Up the Student Body
text: Paul Murray’s “Skippy Dies” is a luxuriantly eccentric novel set in Seabrook College, a Dublin school that is a magnet for teenage misfits. One Seabrook boy keeps a collection of naturally occurring hexagons. Another grills his religion teacher on whether Jesus’ having been resurrected from death qualifies him as a zombie. A third spends much of his time mesmerized by a video game, imagining himself as “you, Djed, an ordinary elf from the forest” as he tries to save his elfish world from the grip of demons. It’s easy to see why he prefers this version of reality to the gloomier one that Seabrook offers.

headline: For Douglas Holtz-Eakin
text: Holtz-Eakin: GOP Too Focused On ‘Cocaine’ Of Sarah Palin To Rule

headline: When the Shah of Iran Took the Pictures
text: Newsha Tavakolian, 29, has been covering Iran for Polaris Images since 2001 and has freelanced for The Times since 2004. She discussed coverage of last year’s political upheaval in “Covering Tehran” (June 17, 2009) and shared her photographs of women singers in “A Quiet Song, With Feeling” (June 11, 2010). Her conversation with Amanda Rivkin has been edited and condensed.

headline: Courtside: The Wind Factor
text: Christopher Clarey, who wrote about how the wind has and will continue to play a role at Arthur Ashe Stadium during the U.S. Open, breaks down the topic further and looks ahead to the semifinals match between Venus Williams and Kim Clijsters.

headline: The Next Wave
text: THEY are not exactly a New York Six.

headline: Your First Day of School
text: Thanks to everyone who sent in photographs from the first day of school in New York (and New Jersey and Paris and Greece and Florida…). Click or drag above to explore the complete gallery. We’ll add photos through Thursday morning, so you may continue to submit your images Wednesday evening using this form.

headline: Three Tips on Using Google Instant
text: On Wednesday, Google introduced a major change to the way its search engine delivers results. Results now appear while you are still typing your search query. If you keep typing, Google’s results change to match.

headline: Kim France Out at Lucky; Brandon Holley of Yahoo Takes Over
text: Kim France, the editor who invented Lucky magazine in 2000 along with James Truman, who was the Condé Nast editorial directer at the time, has left the magazine. She was replaced by Brandon Holley, who worked at Condé Nast in 2007 until Jane, the magazine she was editing, was closed. Since then, Ms. Holley has been working as editor in chief of Shine, Yahoo‘s site for women.

headline: Federal Agency Sues LED Bulb Maker
text: Even as lighting companies report advances in LED technology, consumers are being warned that some LED lighting products do not live up to the hype.

headline: Soap Suds by Day, Political Drama by Night
text: Téa Delgado’s inoperable brain tumor may have been a teary story line this summer for fans of the character on “One Life to Live,” the ABC soap opera, but the protracted how-many-days-have-I-got death scenes could not have come at a better time for Florencia Lozano, who portrays her.

headline: Ah, Hamlet, I Thought I Knew You Well
text: There are some people you feel can never surprise you, you know them so well. You’ve spent hours in their company, you know all their little habits, you even hear what they’re going to say before they say it. And then, every so often (and it could be the 20th encounter), one of them does something that knocks you for a loop, and you think, “I never really knew you at all.”

headline: Obama’s Economy Speech in Ohio
text: The following is a transcript of President Obama’s speech about the economy in Parma, Ohio, as provided by the White House:

headline: ‘Talent’ Takes Lead
text: The Top 10 “America’s Got Talent” acts and the guest performer, Enrique Iglesias, helped lift NBC to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday as 12.3 million viewers tuned in to that reality show from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. No other prime-time program came close, though CBS’s “NCIS” rerun did lead the 8 p.m. slot with 9.9 million viewers. CBS placed second overall, broadcasting repeats of “NCIS: Los Angeles” at 9 (8 million) and “The Good Wife” at 10 (5.6 million). ABC was third with back-to-back episodes of “Wipeout,” a new one at 8 (8 million) and a rerun at 9 (5.6 million), followed by a low-rated installment of ABC’s “Nightline Prime” at 10 (3.3 million). Fox placed fourth.

headline: Mercury Prize Adds to Trio’s ‘Incredible Year’
text: The XX, a British trio that dresses all in black and plays stark, hushed songs about stifled desire, has won the Barclaycard Mercury Prize for its album “XX.” The Mercury, a £20,000 prize (about $31,000) for the best album by a British or Irish act, is voted on by a small group of journalists and music industry professionals, and is regarded as one of Britain’s most prestigious music awards. In the past it has gone to PJ Harvey, Talvin Singh, Pulp and Portishead, but was criticized last year when it was won by Speech Debelle, a little-known London rapper who was soon dropped by her record company. The nominees this year  who also included Paul Weller, Corinne Bailey Rae, Villagers, Mumford & Sons and Laura Marling  were seen as more populist, and the XX expressed surprise that it won. “We’ve had the most incredible year, and it has just felt like every day we’ve just woken up to something incredible we just weren’t expecting,”  Oliver Sim, the XX’s bassist, said when receiving the award on Tuesday. “It has felt just like a haze.”

headline: Mixed Results as NATO Drive on Kandahar Begins
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — The white flags of the Taliban no longer fly from neighborhoods in Kandahar City, as they did in some areas only two weeks ago, replaced instead by the red, black and green Afghan colors.

headline: Giving an Error the Boot
text: Q. My Windows XP computer won’t start up and gives me an “unmountable boot volume” message. Can this be fixed or is the hard drive shot?

headline: Wait, Godard Just Might Pick Up Oscar After All
text: As plot twists go it may not be quite as dramatic as Jean-Paul Belmondo painting his face blue and tying dynamite to his head in “Pierrot le Fou,” but that film’s director, Jean-Luc Godard, has told the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences that he may indeed appear in person to receive an honorary Oscar this fall. Mr. Godard’s wife, Anne-Marie Mieville, had previously told The Australian newspaper that her husband would not travel to the United States to receive the award, which is to be presented at a November event that is separate from the Academy Awards ceremony on Feb. 27. “He just told me, ‘It’s not the Oscars,’ ” Ms. Mieville said. But The Hollywood Reporter said the academy had received “a cordial, handwritten note” from Mr. Godard, the pioneering French New Wave director, indicating that he might make the trip. The academy told The Hollywood Reporter that Mr. Godard “graciously thanked the organization for the honor,” and described himself as “the fourth musketeer” alongside Francis Ford Coppola, Eli Wallach and Kevin Brownlow, who are also receiving honorary awards. The note, the academy said, “indicated that, schedule permitting, he would come to Los Angeles.”

headline: Genentech Scientist to Lead Rockefeller University
text: The No. 2 research official at Genentech will become the next president of Rockefeller University, in the first departure from the company’s top scientific ranks since its acquisition by Roche in March 2009.

headline: Chopra’s ‘Muhammad’ Released Early as E-Book
text: HarperCollins approved the early release of the e-book version of “Muhammad,” Deepak Chopra’s fictionalized biography about the Prophet Muhammad’s life that is to be published in printed form on Sept. 21. The book’s publisher authorized Amazon and other e-book retailers to begin selling the book on Wednesday, trying to meet demand for it because of the debate over a planned Muslim community center and mosque near the World Trade Center site in Manhattan. It was the first time that HarperCollins had placed an e-book for sale before the print edition  in this case weeks ahead of the print book’s publication. Dr. Chopra, above, an Indian-born guru and advocate of alternative medicine, has written other so-called teaching novels about the founders of world religions, including his best-selling books “Buddha” and “Jesus.” “Books spark conversations,” Michael Morrison, the president and publisher of HarperCollins’s general books division for the United States and Canada, said in a statement. “And in this case a national conversation has erupted.”

headline: Familiar Faces Lead Latin Grammy Nominees
text: Juan Luis Guerra, Alejandro Sanz, Jorge Drexler and Mario Domm, far left, lead the nominations for the 11th annual Latin Grammy Awards, announced on Wednesday morning in Los Angeles. Those veteran musicians received four nominations apiece (Mr. Domm, a producer and songwriter from Mexico, shares three of his with his band, Camila), and will face one another  along with some newer faces  in most major categories. Up for album of the year are Camila’s “Dejarte de Amar”; “A Son de Guerra” by Mr. Guerra, from the Dominican Republic; “Paraíso Express” by Mr. Sanz, a Spanish singer-songwriter who has 14 Latin Grammys under his belt; “Cardio” by Miguel Bosé, also from Spain; and “Y.” by Bebe, above right, a young Spanish singer who is up for two prizes. (Other nominees for two awards: the reggaetón star Daddy Yankee.) For record of the year, which recognizes a song’s performers, Mr. Sanz (“Desde Cuando”) is up against Camila (“Mientes”), the Brazilian singer Maria Bethânia (“Tua”), the Spanish singer Buika (“Se Me Hizo Fácil”) and Mr. Drexler, an Uruguayan singer-songwriter, for his “Una Canción Me Trajo Hasta Aquí.” The Latin Grammys ceremony will be on Nov. 11 at the Mandalay Bay in Las Vegas, and broadcast live by Univision.

headline: Casey’s Mystery Bidder: 7-Eleven
text: 7:12 p.m. | Updated The New York Times has more.

headline: Disturbed, at No. 1 Again, Earns Rare Distinction
text: Metallica and the Dave Matthews Band you expect to be giants of the Billboard charts. But Disturbed? A metal band from Chicago that is led by David Draiman, above, and has sold 11 million albums worldwide, Disturbed can now, with the success of “Asylum” (Reprise), its new CD, claim a rare chart distinction: along with Metallica and the Dave Matthews Band it is the only other rock band to have four consecutive releases go to No. 1. “Asylum” sold 179,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, beating out hits by Eminem and Katy Perry. Vol. 35 of the “Now That’s What I Call Music!” compilation series, with songs by the Black Eyed Peas, Lady Gaga, Justin Bieber and 17 others, opened at No. 2 with 105,000 sales, and Eminem’s “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope) holds at No. 3 in its 11th week out with 93,000. Ms. Perry’s “Teenage Dream” (Capitol), last week’s chart-topper, fell to No. 4 with 88,000, a 54 percent drop from its first-week sales. The “American Idol” alumna Fantasia fell three spots to No. 5 with her third album, “Back to Me” (J).

headline: Naomi Campbell: Model, Citizen
text: “I HAVE a past,” Naomi Campbell said on Tuesday. “I’m not proud of my past, some of the circumstances I was in. I’ve said that a hundred times. But I admit to my past. I own it. I don’t deny it. Denial is a very bad thing.”

headline: How a Captive Reporter Used Twitter
text: A Japanese journalist who was released this week after being held captive in Afghanistan for five months explained on Tuesday how he had managed to post two updates on Twitter from the phone of one of his captors.

headline: Nearly 5 Jobless Workers Per Opening in July
text: There were slightly fewer than five unemployed workers for each job opening in July, according to a new Labor Department report. Once again, that’s a better ratio than what the economy showed earlier this year, but it still indicates persistent softness in the American labor market.

headline: G.M. Makes a Play for Buyers and Investors
text: LORDSTOWN, Ohio  With its coming public stock offering as a backdrop, General Motors on Wednesday rolled out the Chevrolet Cruze, its most earnest attempt at building a compact car that Americans might buy because they like it  not simply because it is cheap.

headline: The Guardians of America’s Front Lawn
text: WASHINGTON  Representatives of the National Museum of African American History and Culture filed into a meeting room here last Thursday to discuss alternative designs for their proposed new building on the National Mall.

headline: Piers Morgan to Step Into Larry King’s Shoes
text: Piers Morgan will take over for Larry King in January, CNN announced on Wednesday, putting an end to the summer-long speculation about one of the most prized time slots in television.

headline: Trouble in the Heartland
text: As Bruce Springsteen, who is currently the subject of a special exhibit at Cleveland’s Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, sang in “Badlands,” there’s “trouble in the heartland.” And a lot of political action as well, which could bode well for the Buckeye State’s bid to land the 2012 Democratic National Convention.

headline: The Father of Modern Architectural Minimalism
text: How is a multimillion-dollar NoHo penthouse like a monastery, or a Calvin Klein store like a state-of-the-art racing yacht? They have been wiped clean of “thingness” (as the writer Bruce Chatwin might have said) by John Pawson, the father of modern architectural minimalism. Now 61, the British architect — who slept on a white hammock at boarding school and once spent 24 hours in a Japanese monastery, thinking he might like to be a monk — has a new monograph, “John Pawson: Plain Space.” Written with Alison Morris and out next month from Phaidon, it presents 30 startlingly minimal and gleaming white projects: boats, abbeys, houses and even a cricket pavilion. A show of the same title opens Sept. 22 at the London Design Museum, which Mr. Pawson has been hired to redesign.

headline: Bookends
text: LUKE IVES PONTIFELL, 42, founded Thornwillow Press 25 years ago, when he was a teenager — and with his wire-rimmed glasses, suspenders and striped tie tucked into high-waisted khakis, he looks the part of someone who has devoted his life to books.

headline: Fending Off the Weeds With Newsprint
text: THE garden suffered through another heat wave last week: day after day in the high 90s and no rain. (Didn’t I say that a few weeks ago?) Hurricane Earl roared up the East Coast, without a drop falling on our garden in Maryland.

headline: On a Mission to Save Cruise Ship Décor
text: MOORPARK, Calif.

headline: Armoires Made From Fallen Birch Trees
text: Old farmhouses and urban lofts have one thing in common: a lack of closet space. With that in mind, the Sawkille Company, a new store in Rhinebeck, N.Y., is offering a sustainable storage solution, appropriate for country or city: a white birch-bark armoire.

headline: Panasonic’s Streamlined Massage Chair
text: “Panasonic has been making massage chairs since 1969, but people using those chairs put them in the basement or in the office,” said Walter Taffarello, the group marketing manager for the wellness group at the Panasonic Corporation of North America. “Not in the living room.”

headline: A Mirror Framed in Copper
text: Genesis, a new mirror from the textile designer Maya Romanoff, is framed in thin oxidized copper squares inlaid in basswood.

headline: Design Firm Turns Dinnerware Into Works of Art
text: To many people — especially those under 40 — “porcelain dinnerware” has a staid sound to it. That’s why Caroline Pople, a product designer, and her husband, David Harding, an M.B.A. student, created Ink Dish, a design firm dedicated to injecting excitement into dinnerware.

headline: Sales at Moss, Crate & Barrel and McGuire
text: At the Moss annual warehouse sale on Sept. 11 and 12, seating, lighting, tables, storage and decorative objects will be marked down as much as 75 percent (the Antibodi lounge chair by Patricia Urquiola for Moroso, originally $6,000, will be $3,700; the Wrongwoods nightstand by Richard Woods and Sebastian Wrong for Established & Sons, regularly $2,170, will be $1,450); 133 Greene Street (Houston Street), (212) 204-7100 or mossonline.com.

headline: A Gristmill Turned Live-In Studio
text: For the painter Jan Green, the early 19th-century gristmill in upstate New York where she lives and works has been both a muse and a refuge.

headline: An Artist Turns a Gristmill Into a Refuge
text: HARPERSFIELD, N.Y.

headline: Stumbling Over Roadblocks to Love and Hope
text: When a film is billed as “the first Albanian-Serbian co-production,” as “Honeymoons” is, you expect it to earn the adjective brave, and “Honeymoons” does. But the brave thing is not so much the subject matter, which is something of a given: what would the movie be about but ethnic biases and tensions? The brave thing is how Goran Paskaljevic, the director and (with Genc Permeti) writer, chooses to end the film: short of either a happy ending or a tragic one, in the same sort of limbo that this part of the world seems to inhabit perpetually.

headline: Fashion Week Preview | Hermès’s Black Box
text: What are we hankering for at T as Hermès prepares to unveil the refurbished leather floor in its Madison Avenue flagship next Tuesday? The Hermès So-Black collection, of course. For the first time, a select number of blacked-out and gloss-finished Birkin bags and Kelly clutches — available in leather or crocodile and wrapped in a commemorative black box that is as impeccably chic as the bag — will be delivered to Hermès boutiques worldwide. Not surprisingly, the battle to procure these black beauties has resembled handbags at dawn. “The reaction has been quite exciting,” says Hermès’s C.E.O., Robert Chavez. “Our very eager clients are ready to get their hands on them.” It’s a comment that’s as understated as the bag.

headline: A Bonfire in Danger of Spreading
text: The United States ambassador in Iraq and the commanding general of United States forces in Iraq joined Gen. David H. Petraeus, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. and the Vatican in condemning a Florida pastor’s plans to mark the ninth anniversary of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks with a bonfire of Korans.

headline: John W. Kluge, Founder of Metromedia, Dies at 95
text: John W. Kluge, who parlayed a small fortune from a Fritos franchise into a multibillion-dollar communications empire that made him one of the richest men in America, died on Tuesday night at a family home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 95.

headline: In Newport, but Not of It
text: NEWPORT, R.I.

headline: Hope for the Future, and It’s in Her Size
text: A NUMBER of art galleries in New York closed their doors after the economy tanked. These tended to be scrappy, up-and-coming enterprises surviving with little more than a rented white box and a discerning eye. They established reputations by sifting through packs of nameless young artists and — with a little spit shine, P.R. and insider collusion — gave them a booster shot of recognition, lifting them from total obscurity to a low rung of somewhere.

headline: The Republicans’ 50-State, 428-District Strategy
text: Under the leadership of Howard Dean, the former governor of Vermont who was chairman of the Democratic National Committee from 2005 to 2009, the Democrats executed a move that came to be known as the 50-state strategy.

headline: A Road to Fame, Paved With Hair
text: ON a blazingly hot sunny day in Los Angeles, eight people are inside One Take Studios on a desolate street, prepping for a photo shoot. In a brightly lighted room, hair stylist, Sienree Du (Ri to her friends) tries to build a fake mohawk out of a model’s long, brown waist-length mane. The petite stylist joked with her muse, “Your agent didn’t tell you I was going to shave your hair?”

headline: A Ghost in Kandahar
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — The Afghan policeman shouldered his rocket-propelled grenade launcher one day in the first week of September and pointed it toward the police truck, a blue Ford Ranger pickup, and fired.

headline: Political Points Podcast: Economic Winds and the Windy City
text: Click to Listen

headline: Reopening History of Storied Norse Chessmen
text: The Lewis Chessmen are the most famous and important chess pieces in history. They have a long historical and scholarly record, part of which is that they were made in Norway roughly 800 years ago. But now two Icelandic men are challenging that belief and trying to prove that the pieces came from their country.

headline: Long Suits and a Rare Result
text: The diagramed deal occurred during the European Team Championships this summer. It caused excitement at most tables and a rarity in the senior match between Denmark and Ireland.

headline: A French Country House Copied for Newport
text: The founder of the TED conference and his wife, a novelist, share a grand home in Rhode Island with grounds that cross a French formal garden with a Slim Aarons photo.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Empathetic Fabric
text: Fabrics that can see and hear and emit sound may seem like products of science fiction, but they’re being developed at M.I.T. On this week’s Tech Talk podcast of The New York Times, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Yoel Fink, associate professor of materials science and engineering, about the work he’s doing with his students at the university to create fibers that communicate with their environments. Future applications may include textiles that can monitor health, capture images and store energy.

headline: Creditors Want Award Against Goldman Upheld
text: The legal sparring between Goldman Sachs and the unsecured creditors of the Bayou Group escalated late Wednesday, when the creditors asked a federal court to uphold a big award against the firm and remove the seal that has been placed on the case.

headline: Federer Keeps Alive His Half of Dream Final
text: With each vanquished opponent and each defiant shot into the swirling winds of Arthur Ashe Stadium, the matchup long coveted by tennis fans everywhere is steadily taking shape.

headline: After Fine, Botox Awaits Approval for Migraine
text: In public relations, it’s known as “seeding the market” — stirring up excitement for a forthcoming product or application.

headline: Panade
text: 6 tablespoons butter

headline: Field Report: Will Work for Food
text: Some of the most sought-after internships this summer weren’t on Capitol Hill or in the Vogue fashion closet. They were on farms. If you hadn’t applied by the end of the spring, you could forget about it. Ag-department graduates, career-changers and cooks looking to deepen their knowledge of ingredients are among those who have been turning to farmers to show them how to plow their trade. For months they live in group housing — even tents — working long hours for little or no pay beyond all-you-can-eat produce. It’s a cross between Michael Pollan summer school and Barbara Kingsolver boot camp.

headline: Ads to Target Democrats Who Supported Health Care Law
text: Revere America, a conservative advocacy group dedicated to repealing the health care law enacted earlier this year, announced on Wednesday that it is undertaking a multi-million-dollar television advertising campaign aimed at ousting Democrats in Congress who supported the law.

headline: Making Subway Bad News Look Better
text: Subwaygoers, get ready for a brighter, cleaner way to find out that your trip is ruined.

headline: Technology Gives Everyone a Great Seat at Shows
text: THE hub of New York Fashion Week may have moved from Bryant Park to Lincoln Center, but a swirl of exclusivity still surrounds the event, with its security guards and glamazon gatekeepers. How can an unaccredited clotheshorse crash the party? Go online.

headline: In This Galaxy, One Star Shines Brightest
text: ON Tuesday, a balmy night at the end of a golden late-summer day, Manhattan’s literary Elysium — novelists, editors, writers, publishers and agents — proceeded up a marble staircase to the glass-windowed salons and brick terrace of the Bowery Hotel. They’d come to witness the apotheosis of Jonathan Franzen, author of “Freedom” (his fourth book), the most feted novel of the season.

headline: The Buzz
text: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable nightspots in the week ahead.

headline: Excerpt: 'Undercovers'

headline: Finding a Smartphone to Fit Your Needs, Under $100

headline: Lawyers for Clemens Seek to Quash Defamation Suit
text: Less than a week after Roger Clemens appeared in a Washington courthouse to plead not guilty to charges of lying to Congress, his lawyers showed up in another courtroom  this time in Brooklyn  to defend him in a defamation lawsuit.

text: Tightened spending at the Pentagon is unsettling the defense industry, with Lockheed Martin announcing Wednesday that one-quarter of its executives had applied for buyouts as the company cut costs.

text: Representative Joe Sestak is bringing in another big gun to help raise cash for his Senate bid.

headline: Missing Mexico Investigators Believed to Be Dead
text: MEXICO CITY  The authorities said Wednesday that they thought they had found the bodies of two law enforcement officials who were involved in the investigation of the massacre of 72 migrants last month. The officials have been missing for more than two weeks, and the discovery underscored the grip that criminal organizations have on the region.

headline: U.S. Student Became Mexican Drug Kingpin
text: LAREDO, Tex.  The other children in his middle-class suburb teased him by calling him Barbie because of his looks, which reminded them of a Ken doll. The name stuck, and three decades later it would become associated with sadistic gangland slayings.

headline: Audit Assailed Group Hired to Aid Family in Abuse Case
text: The nonprofit organization hired by the city to provide preventive services to the family of a bruised and severely malnourished 4-year-old girl who was found dead in her apartment in Brooklyn last week had been the subject of a scathing city audit in 2008.

headline: When Youth Is a Job Qualification
text: Steven M. Volpe, 21, who graduated in June from the College of Staten Island, parlayed an unpaid spring internship at the New York City chapter of the Alzheimer’s Association into a paid summer internship. In August he was offered a job as a social media associate. He lives with his parents in Dongan Hills on Staten Island and moonlights Saturday nights selling business machines at a local Staples.

headline: Filmmakers Tread Gently on Author’s Dystopia
text: MARK ROMANEK’S “Never Let Me Go,” which opens Wednesday, is the latest in the seemingly unstoppable, self-replicating tradition of films about cloning. It goes without saying that most of them look alike. But if you’re unfamiliar with the book on which it’s based, Kazuo Ishiguro’s luminous novel of the same name, or if you want to be surprised this time by some unusual genetic modification, you might want to stop reading right here. That’s because this movie deviates from the standard Hollywood premise that clones are by definition evil, debased versions of their originals. It also deviates from the lesser convention that clones, like the monstrous replacement 8-year-old in “Godsend” or the Arnold Schwarzenegger duplicate in “The Sixth Day,” must be named Adam.

headline: U.S. Intervention Sought for Newark Police Abuses
text: Excessive force, false arrests and other abuses by the Newark police are so rampant that the federal government should investigate and appoint a monitor to oversee the department, a civil liberties group charges in a petition it plans to file on Thursday.

headline: New Schools in South Africa Serve the Underserved
text: CAPE TOWN  Gcobani Mndini, a shy, lanky 17-year-old, said he was already a gangster by the time he started ninth grade. His small gang, which called itself the Tomatoes, was robbing people, fighting over girls and getting high on Jack Daniel’s and marijuana.

headline: New Jersey Governor Unveils Ethics Reforms
text: The New Jersey laws that sharply restrict political contributions from state contractors would apply to local government contracting, too, under a set of ethics proposals that Gov. Chris Christie announced Wednesday.

headline: Falling Rates Aid Debtors, but Hamper Savers
text: Households and corporations alike are refinancing their loans in droves to take advantage of interest rates that seem impossibly cheap. But those same low rates come with a flip side, driving down the income of retirees and others who live off their savings.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Sept. 8
text: Images from Wednesday’s matches at the United States Open.

headline: Naughty Advances at a Writers’ Retreat
text: LONDON

headline: The Editor of Lucky Magazine Is Replaced
text: Kim France, the editor who invented Lucky magazine in 2000 along with James Truman, the Condé Nast editorial director at the time, has been replaced at the magazine. She will be succeeded by Brandon Holley, who previously worked at Condé Nast editing Jane magazine until it closed in 2007. Since then, Ms. Holley has been working as editor in chief of Shine, Yahoo’s site for women.

headline: Data on Seattle Nonprofits Is Now Public
text: The Seattle Foundation started a new program on Wednesday to provide access to its data, research and evaluations of almost 700 local nonprofit groups in and around the city and King County.

headline: Alzheimer’s Research
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mexico: Reporters Fall Victim to Crackdown on Drug Trafficking
text: More than 30 journalists have been killed or have disappeared in the nearly four years since Mexico began a bloody crackdown on drug trafficking organizations, an advocacy group reported Wednesday. Most of the crimes remain unsolved, the report by the New York City-based Committee to Protect Journalists said, and are often marked by shoddy investigations. Several news organizations, it said, have resorted to not reporting on drug-related crime and corruption for fear of running afoul of drug kingpins, who have planted operatives in newsrooms and corrupted some journalists. The report recommended strengthening laws against attacks on free expression.

headline: Debating the Economy
text: Americans are deeply worried about the economy and their jobs  and about whether their elected representatives in Washington have a real plan for digging out of this mess. They are right to be worried. But this week, at least, voters were given a clear choice about the direction the country can take in November and beyond.

headline: Britain: Premier’s Father Dies
text: Prime Minister David Cameron’s father died Wednesday shortly after the British leader joined other family members at his hospital bedside in Toulon, France. His father, Ian Cameron, 77, had suffered a stroke while on vacation. Mr. Cameron flew to France after learning of his father’s condition Wednesday morning. The trip caused him to cancel an appearance in Parliament, where he was expected to face questioning over the role of his communications director, Andy Coulson, in a cellphone hacking scandal. In a television interview this spring, Mr. Cameron said he had been inspired by his father, who, though born with a severe deformity in both legs that led eventually to their amputation, played competitive tennis as a youth and had a successful career as a stockbroker. “My father is a huge hero figure for me, because he’s an amazingly brave man,” Mr. Cameron said. “To have a disability in the 1930s and 1940s, a different age, was really tough, but he never let it affect him in any way.”

headline: Chilling Enough to Deserve a Remake
text: “THE first thing I said was, I don’t know if we should remake this movie.”

headline: Growing Appreciation for P.R. on Madison Avenue
text: THE recently acquisitive MDC Partners is at it again, with a deal that is indicative of the growing recognition along Madison Avenue of how much more interested marketers are becoming in using public relations to reach consumers.

headline: Lottery Numbers
In Bronx Bomb Plot, Tapes Shed Light on Informer
text: Hours before four men left fake bombs outside synagogues in the Bronx last year in what the authorities described as a plot by homegrown terrorists bent on jihad, a government informer had to remind the plot’s purported chief to lead his men in prayer.

headline: Google Unveils Tool to Speed Up Searches
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Google, which can already feel like an appendage to our brains, is now predicting what people are thinking before they even type.

headline: Torture Is a Crime, Not a Secret
text: Five men who say the Bush administration sent them to other countries to be tortured had a chance to be the first ones to have torture claims heard in court. But because the Obama administration decided to adopt the Bush administration’s claim that hearing the case would divulge state secrets, the men’s lawsuit was tossed out on Wednesday by the full United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The decision diminishes any hope that this odious practice will finally receive the legal label it deserves: a violation of international law.

headline: Officer in Fatal Accident Admits He Was Drunk
text: An off-duty police officer who struck and killed a woman in Brooklyn in 2009 pleaded guilty on Wednesday to second-degree vehicular manslaughter, and is expected to serve 90 days in jail  far less than the seven-year maximum sentence he had faced.

headline: After Mayor Daley
text: So he is not Mayor for Life after all. Richard M. Daley of Chicago said on Tuesday that he would leave office next year at the end of his sixth term. A city that has seen more than half a century of father-son mayoral rule, give or take a few mayors, was dumbstruck.

headline: N.C.A.A. Penalizes Princeton for a Major Rule Violation
text: Princeton University committed a major rule violation when a booster paid $33,000 toward the educational expenses of a tennis player, the N.C.A.A. announced Wednesday. It was the first time in 36 years that the N.C.A.A. found an Ivy League institution guilty of committing a major infraction.

headline: 7-Eleven Is Said to Be Among the Bidders for Casey’s Stores
text: The American convenience store chain 7-Eleven is the unnamed third party that has bid $2 billion for Casey’s General Stores, topping an offer from Alimentation Couche-Tard, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: For Emanuel, Temptation in the Form of a Dream Job
text: WASHINGTON  When Rahm Emanuel was running for Congress on the North Side of Chicago, he would often make calls while he was out shaking hands near the city’s elevated trains, with their distinctive rumbling sending an unmistakable signal that he was standing in his district.

headline: Considering Daley’s Exit, With Hope and With Fear
text: CHICAGO  Moments after Mayor Richard M. Daley announced that he would not seek re-election, a text message popped up on Mary Williams-Taylor’s mobile phone.

headline: Vodafone Is Liable for Tax on India Deal, Court Finds
text: MUMBAI, India  A court on Wednesday ruled against Vodafone, the cellphone company, in a tax case that could deal a significant blow to foreign investors who own or want to buy shares and companies in India.

text: SEPTEMBER

headline: For High Holy Days, Rabbis Weigh Their Words on Proposed Islamic Center
text: With their call to introspection and atonement, the Jewish High Holy Days have always challenged rabbis to find avenues into the consciences of their congregations  on personal matters, and worldwide issues like war and peace.

headline: War and the City: Be a Man
text: This is the third of a five-part series, “War and the City,” by the Iraq war veteran Roy Scranton, chronicling his path from youth to soldier to civilian writer in New York City. To read from the beginning, go to the first installment, “March Song.”

headline: November Release Schedule
text: Nov. 3

headline: Plumbing an Obstacle to 2nd Ave. Subway
text: The elusive Second Avenue subway line has been held up for decades by political turf wars and ill-timed recessions. Now frustrated New Yorkers can add another culprit to the list: plumbing.
