text: DECEMBER

headline: Blair Memoir a Hit, Despite a Few Hard Knocks
text: LONDON  “You are my 10th prime minister,” Queen Elizabeth observes to Tony Blair when she meets him at Buckingham Palace on his first day in office in 1997, according to “A Journey: My Political Life,” Mr. Blair’s new memoir. “The first was Winston. That was before you were born.”

headline: At Main Court, Wind Is Common Opponent
text: It was August 1997, shortly before the official opening of Arthur Ashe Stadium, the new center court at the United States Open, and the leading American players Pete Sampras and Jim Courier had just finished a practice session.

headline: Season Could Be Over for Marlins’ Johnson
text: PHILADELPHIA – It is looking less and less likely that Josh Johnson, the Florida Marlins’ All-Star right-hander, will pitch again this season. Johnson left the team to be evaluated by team doctors in Miami, who found shoulder inflammation and a mid-back strain.

headline: Thursday: Drawers at School
text: PUZZLE NOTES — Here’s a third new name to add to the rogues’ gallery of Times constructors this week: Kevin Wald. His theme features six typographic elements that are symmetrically positioned as entries — and visually displayed by the black squares. Sizable chunks of fill ensue.

headline: Winning a Tough Image, Prosecutor Gains Critics
text: For months, federal prosecutors had been circling Roger Corbin, a Nassau County legislator suspected of taking payments from a real estate developer. By September of 2008, preparing to indict Mr. Corbin on charges of tax evasion, they made plans to go to his home to interview him.

headline: Back in Class, Theme Is: We’ll Succeed With Less
text: The blackboard at Public School 212 in the Bronx made the sole objective for the first day of school plainly clear: defining rules and routines.

headline: Anger Flares in L.A. After Fatal Police Shooting
text: LOS ANGELES  City officials and Guatemalan leaders have moved to calm feelings and quell anger after the fatal shooting of a Guatemalan construction worker by a Los Angeles police officer set off two nights of violent protests in a neighborhood populated largely by Central American immigrants.

headline: Even in 20th Season, Journeyman Doesn’t Like Shortcuts
text: LEMONT, Ill.  Although the prospect of winning the PGA Tour Playoffs for the FedEx Cup and its $10 million bonus is real for some of the 70 players in the BMW Championship, there are others, like Tom Gillis, whose entire year will be made just by making the 30-man field for the Tour Championship in two weeks.

headline: Murkows– ? Merco– ? She’ll Settle for Winner.
text: Senator Lisa Murkowski has one of the most recognized last names in Alaska politics. That does not mean everyone can spell it.

headline: War Games
text: Unless you regard something like “Iron Man” as a film about Afghanistan, the movies inspired by America’s contemporary wars have consistently been box-office flops. Even “The Hurt Locker” grossed only $16 million in theaters. Video games that evoke our current conflicts, on the other hand, are blockbusters — during the past three years, they have become the most popular fictional depictions of America’s current wars. Last year’s best-selling game was Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2, which opens in Afghanistan; it was a sequel to a multimillion-selling 2007 game that features an American invasion of a nameless Middle Eastern country. Modern Warfare 2 has made “Avatar”-like profits for its studio, Activision. On the day the game was published in November, it sold nearly five million copies in North America and Britain, racking up $310 million in sales in 24 hours. By January of this year, the game’s worldwide sales added up to $1 billion.

headline: Are Video Games About War Better Than Movies About War?
text: In The Times Magazine, Chris Suellentrop takes a look at the success that the makers of the Modern Warfare video game series have had using Afghan War-inspired landscapes and story lines. Mr. Suellentrop notes that the Modern Warfare series, unlike films on the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan that have failed to draw a sizeable audiences in theaters, has demonstrated that players have an appetite for games that purport to connect them to the wars their college roommates, or their sons, might be fighting in.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,260 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Issue of Backup Status Stirs Jacobs’s Displeasure
text: With Ahmad Bradshaw emerging as the Giants’ starting running back, Brandon Jacobs’s apparent unhappiness has become a lingering issue.

headline: First Lady Asks Congress to Join Childhood Obesity Fight
text: SLIDELL, La.  Declaring the beginning of the “next phase” of a program to combat childhood obesity, the first lady, Michelle Obama, called on Congress on Wednesday to pass legislation that would make many of the program’s initiatives possible.

headline: Colorado Wildfire Guts 136 Homes
text: DENVER  At least 136 homes have been destroyed by a wildfire that swept through the mountains around Boulder this week and four people are still unaccounted for, Colorado authorities said Wednesday.

headline: Storm Hits Texas and Oklahoma
text: HOUSTON  At least two people died in flash floods as the remnants of Tropical Storm Hermine swirled through central Texas and into Oklahoma on Wednesday, the authorities said.

headline: Speeding in Illinois Is Getting More Costly
text: Facing a $13 billion budget deficit, Illinois will soon find its coffers further supplemented by a reliable source: disobedient drivers.

headline: The 5 Percent Doctrine
text: A minister in Gainesville, Fla., has created an international uproar by vowing to burn the Koran on Sept. 11. This is under the theory that the best way to honor Americans who died at the hands of religious extremists is to do something that is both religious and extreme.

headline: Alabama: Execution Set for Man Whose Competency Is Questioned
text: A man whose lawyers contend he received inadequate legal counsel during sentencing and should have been classified as mentally retarded is scheduled to be executed Thursday. In January, the United States Supreme Court upheld the death penalty for the man, Holly Wood, 50, who confessed to shooting his ex-girlfriend while she slept. Defense lawyers argued that a court-appointed lawyer with less than a year of trial experience failed to tell jurors during sentencing that Mr. Wood is not mentally competent to be executed. His I.Q. has been found to be well below 70, the score that experts often consider the border for mental retardation. But Alabama, like many states, considers other factors, including performance tests and employment history in evaluating competence.

headline: Japanese Demography
text: I’m not the first person by a long shot to make this point, but it’s fairly amazing how much of Japan’s relative slide since the early 90s can be explained not by economics per se but by demography.

headline: Study Questions Impact of Fourteenth Amendment
text: A repeal of the Fourteenth Amendment, which guarantees citizenship to anyone born in the United States, would cause big increases in the population of illegal immigrants in the country, said a report published Wednesday by the Migration Policy Institute, a nonpartisan research group. Using statistical projections, the report showed that the number of illegal immigrants could grow by 2020 to 14 million  about 3 million over the current estimate of 11.1 million  if citizenship were denied to children born in the United States who have at least one parent who is an illegal immigrant. By 2050, the population could reach 24 million, according to the projection, by Jennifer Van Hook, a professor of demography at Pennsylvania State University. Proponents of the repeal have argued that it would reduce the number of illegal immigrants by discouraging them from coming to this country to give birth.

headline: ‘Hard Knocks’ Ends, but Not Makeover by the Jets
text: The Jets’ long search for an extreme makeover has accelerated with their starring role in the HBO series “Hard Knocks,” which ended Wednesday night with Darrelle Revis’s return.

headline: Another Voice Raised Against Koran Bonfire
text: The evangelist Franklin Graham on Wednesday joined other religious leaders who are trying to persuade a Florida pastor, Terry Jones, to drop plans to burn copies of the Koran on the ninth anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks. Mr. Jones, however, declared he had no intention to cancel the bonfire and did not take Mr. Graham’s calls. “It’s never right to deface or destroy sacred texts or writings of other religions even if you don’t agree with them,” Mr. Graham said in a statement.

headline: The Healers of 9/11
text: This weekend, a Jewish woman who lost her husband in the 9/11 attacks is planning to speak at a mosque in Boston. She will be trying to recruit members of the mosque to join her battle against poverty and illiteracy in Afghanistan.

headline: Parking Rules
text: On Thursday, because

headline: Clip: 'Score: a Hockey Musical'
text: An exclusive scene from "Score: A Hockey Musical," the opening-night film of the Toronto International Film Festival.

headline: Returning to School in the City
text: Scenes from across the city as the school year began on Wednesday for more than 1 million students.

headline: Bloggingheads: Bad Policy, or Bad PR?
text: David Corn, left, of Mother Jones and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate the source of President Obama's political problems.

headline: New York State’s Chess Champion? He’s 14
text: Over the Labor Day weekend, Aleksandr Ostrovskiy became the youngest champion in 132 years.

headline: Imam Says Moving Center Could Spur Radicals
text: The imam Feisal Abdul Rauf said on Wednesday night that if he had known how much strife would arise over his plan for a Muslim community center and mosque two blocks from the World Trade Center site, he would not have proposed it.

headline: The Music You Won’t Hear on Rosh Hashana
text: TODAY is the first day of Rosh Hashana, the holiday that marks the beginning of the Jewish new year. For the next 10 days, through Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, Jews around the world will gather to chant the prayers of the High Holy Days to melodies that have been used for generations.

headline: Scarborough and Kinsley Will Write for Politico
text: Politico has built a successful enterprise on the idea that there is no such thing as too much information when it comes to political news. Now it is going to apply that concept to political opinion.

headline: Vote on Bid From Hertz for Rival Is Cleared
text: A Delaware judge has denied an injunction sought by a group of Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group investors hoping to block a Sept. 16 shareholder vote on the company’s pending $1.3 billion merger with Hertz.

headline: H.P. Should Take a Page From Apple
text: Oracle’s boss, Lawrence Ellison, may have unwittingly given Hewlett-Packard some brilliant advice. Before snatching Mark V. Hurd to help run his software company this week, Mr. Ellison called the board’s parting ways with the H.P. chief executive “the worst personnel decision since the idiots on the Apple board fired Steve Jobs.”

text: INTERNATIONAL

text: communal •\kə-ˈmyü-nəl, ˈkäm-yə-nəl\• adjective

headline: Google Unveils Tool to Speed Up Searches
text: Google, which can already feel like an appendage to our brains, is now predicting what people are thinking before they even type, Claire Cain Miller writes in The New York Times.

headline: Falling Rates Aid Debtors, but Hamper Savers
text: Households and corporations alike are refinancing their loans in droves to take advantage of interest rates that seem impossibly cheap. But those same low rates come with a flip side, driving down the income of retirees and others who live off their savings, Graham Bowley writes in The New York Times.

headline: Five Hours Back (and Forth) to School
text: After Neidaly Cruz’s school, the New York Harbor School, moved from Brooklyn to Governors Island this summer, her commute grew to two and a half hours from 45 minutes.

headline: BP Spill Report Hints at Legal Defense
text: BP spent months this summer trying to contain the gusher of oil on the floor of the Gulf of Mexico. Now the company is trying to contain the legal and financial fallout from the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon, and on Wednesday it released the results of an internal investigation that mostly pointed fingers at other companies, Ian Urbina writes in The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | September 9, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Indian-Pakistani Team Reaches Doubles Final
text: With the hope of promoting peace between their nations, the doubles team of Rohan Bopanna, from India, and Aisam-Ul-Haq Qureshi, from Pakistan, achieved two remarkable firsts Wednesday at the United States Open.

headline: David Dortort, ‘Bonanza’ Creator, Dies at 93
text: David Dortort, a television writer and producer whose idea to create a western drama based not on shoot-’em-ups but instead on the travails of a loving family resulted in “Bonanza,” one of the most popular shows in history, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 93.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra Gets Some Financial Aid
text: The financially troubled Philadelphia Orchestra says it has received $4 million from the William Penn Foundation to help pay for its operations, and another half-million toward an “intensive strategic planning process.” The orchestra, which recently emerged from a leadership vacuum, is struggling to finance its activities. To deal with major shortfalls it established what it calls a “recovery fund,” which — with the William Penn gift — now amounts to $12 million in donations and pledges. The foundation describes itself as “dedicated to improving the quality of life in the Greater Philadelphia region.”

headline: Clive Donner, 1960s-Era Film Director, Dies at 84
text: Clive Donner, who helped define the British New Wave with films like “The Caretaker” and “Nothing but the Best” and directed the emblematic swinging ’60s film “What’s New Pussycat?,” died on Tuesday in London. He was 84.

headline: G.M. Makes a Play for Buyers and Investors
text: With its coming public stock offering as a backdrop, General Motors on Wednesday rolled out the Chevrolet Cruze, its most earnest attempt at building a compact car that Americans might buy because they like it — not simply because it is cheap, Nick Bunkley reports in The New York Times.

headline: Saints and Vikings Together Again for N.F.L. Opener
text: “The Favre Indecision” may sound like a Robert Ludlum novel, but it is really the story of the Vikings’ off-season. Brett Favre is back in the Vikings’ huddle after Faux Retirement IV, but the Vikings have major questions that go beyond Favre’s gimpy ankle. Their receiving corps is thin in the wake of Sidney Rice’s injury, their big-name offensive line looked like a colander during the preseason, and the superstar running back Adrian Peterson is coming off a three-fumble performance in the Vikings’ 31-28 loss to the Saints in the N.F.C. title game. Despite his age and eroded approval rating, Favre retains the power to relegate the defending champion to the second paragraph.

headline: Shares Rebound as Concern on Portugal Debt Subsides
text: Indexes on Wall Street resumed their rally Wednesday after a successful auction of Portuguese government debt eased concerns about Europe’s financial system.

headline: Fed Report Finds Signs That Growth Is Slowing
text: The United States economy showed “widespread signs” of slowing, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday, though modest growth continued from mid-July through the end of August, Christine Hauser reports in The New York Times.

headline: Fashion Week Frenzy
text: WHY is figuring out the front-row seating at shows during New York Fashion Week a “trauma” for designers and publicists?

headline: Daily Lexeme: Xenagogue
text: Today’s word, in association with the acclaimed Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: F.S.A. Fines Goldman Over Abacus Investigation
text: The British securities regulator said Thursday that it had fined Goldman Sachs £17.5 million, or nearly $27 million, for failing to disclose the Securities and Exchange Commission’s investigation into the synthetic collateralized debt obligation known as Abacus.

headline: Health Plan Won’t Fuel Big Spending, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — A new government study says President Obama’s health care law will have negligible effects on total national health spending in the next 10 years, neither slowing nor fueling the explosive growth of medical costs.

headline: Smartpen Maker Livescribe Raises $39 Million
text: Smartpens are looking like a smart move at Livescribe. The company announced it has raised $39 million in a third round of funding to further build the market for its Echo and Pulse smartpens, which have tiny computers inside them, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Bair Warns of Government Mortgage ‘Exposure’
text: An influential United States banking regulator raised concern on Wednesday about the risk of “exposure” the government is taking on in the mortgage market and urged more stringent standards for underwriting mortgages, Reuters said.

headline: Can Kno Bring Tablets to the Classroom?
text: Kno, the maker of an coming digital textbook tablet, announced Wednesday it has secured $46 million as part of an equity and debt round, VentureBeat reported. Andreesen-Horowitz was the lead in the round, with Silicon Valley Bank and TriplePoint Capital participating.

headline: Test Yourself | English, September 9, 2010
text: Test your literacy skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues with sentences from two Opinion pieces and a blog post: “Attacking Social Security,” “Rage and Floods in Pakistan” and “Numberplay: Hanging Over the Edge.”

headline: Lloyds Agrees to Sell Crest Nicholson Stake to Varde
text: Lloyds has agreed to sell its stake in the home builder Crest Nicholson to the American investment company Varde, continuing to shed noncore assets and refocus on its core lending activities, Reuters reported.

headline: UBS Hires Two Bankers for Singapore
text: UBS has hired two bankers to join its team serving ultrahigh-net-worth individuals Singapore, the bank said in an internal memo, Reuters reported.

headline: Medieval Flagellation in an Italian Town
text: For centuries, residents of Guardia Sanframondi have marked the Feast of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary with a procession behind her statue through its medieval byways.

headline: What Are You Looking Forward to (or Dreading) This School Year?
text: Here in New York City, over a million kids went back to school yesterday, and The Times published both stories about budget woes and joyous first-day photos from readers. What’s notable about school year 2010-2011 for you? What are you looking forward to? What are you dreading? Why?

headline: Sticking by Greece, Norway Scoffs at Default
text: Norway, which has amassed the world’s second-biggest sovereign wealth fund, says Greece won’t default on its debts, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: S.E.C. Calls Proposed Citi Settlement is Fair
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has defended its proposed $75 million settlement with Citigroup, saying the penalty reasonably accounted for the seriousness of the bank’s alleged misconduct, Reuters said, citing a document filed in court on Wednesday.

headline: Philippines Leader Faults Police Over August Siege
text: MANILA — The Philippine government acknowledged for the first time on Thursday that some of the Hong Kong tourists killed aboard a hijacked bus last month here may have been hit by  police fire.

headline: Car Bomb Explodes in Market in Restive Region of Russia
text: MOSCOW  A car loaded with explosives detonated in a central market in Russia’s restive North Caucasus region on Thursday, killing at least 16 people and wounding as many as 100 in what the authorities said was most likely a suicide attack.

headline: Approval of Share Offering Weighs on Bank of China
text: Bank of China‘s Shanghai-listed shares languished on Thursday, reflecting lingering concerns over the health of the sector after the bank obtained regulatory approval for an $8.8 billion share placement in Hong Kong and Shanghai, Reuters reported.

headline: Thursday’s Matchup: Vikings at Saints
text: “The Favre Indecision” may sound like a Robert Ludlum novel, but it’s really the story of the Vikings’ off-season. Brett Favre is back in the Vikings huddle, but the Vikings have major questions that go beyond Favre’s gimpy ankle. Their receiving corps is thin in the wake of Sidney Rice’s injury, their big-name offensive line looked like a colander during the preseason, and the star running back Adrian Peterson is coming off a three-fumble performance in the Vikings’ 31-28 loss to the Saints in the N.F.C. title game. Despite his age and eroded approval rating, Favre retains the power to relegate the defending champions to the second paragraph.The Saints are as unassuming as Super Bowl winners get. Minor scandals nip at their heels (Reggie Bush’s Heisman trophy is being melted by the N.C.A.A. and recast as a Yoke of Shame), but the most succulent story to stick to the team has been Sean Payton’s affinity for fruit-flavored gum. “Get me Juicy Fruit – not (bleeping) Spearmint,” Payton yelled at the assistant Adam Bailey at the Super Bowl; you can picture Payton later channeling Joan Crawford in “Mommie Dearest” and bludgeoning Bailey with a carton of Dentine.

headline: Singapore’s G.I.C. Starts $3 Billion I.P.O.
text: The Singapore sovereign fund Government of Singapore Investment Corp. began the initial public offering of its logistics unit on Thursday, aiming to raise up to $3 billion in what could be the city-state’s biggest offering, Reuters reported.

headline: Will 2010 Be the Last Real Football Season?
text: Ian Nicol, a reader from Fort Collins, Colo., was a frequent (and incisive) commenter during the early-summer doldrums. He accepted our offer to write a short post looking toward the new season.

headline: At Paris Biennale, Look if You Can’t Buy
text: Few events could so completely satisfy an escapist fantasy of a life lived in luxury than the Biennale des Antiquaires. Now in its 25th decadent year, the festival brings together exceptional antique art, jewelry and furniture at the glorious Grand Palais from Sept. 15 to 22. Art dealers, collectors, jewelers and anyone curious about great art can wander exhibitions as refined as the objects on display. And expect crowds: the last Biennale drew about 80,000 people.

headline: The President Tinkers at the Margins
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is an author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Australia Regulator Blocks Bank’s Bid for AXA Unit
text: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission blocked National Australia Bank‘s $12 billion bid for AXA Asia Pacific for a second time, dashing the bank’s efforts to cement its dominance in the world’s fourth-largest wealth management market, Reuters reported.

headline: Goldman: Better H.R. Than P.R.?
text: Vilified by the public and the media though they may be, Goldman Sachs‘s employees still like the bank.

headline: Paulson’s Largest Fund Said to Drop 11%
text: John A. Paulson, who became a billionaire by betting against the American mortgage market, has lost 11 percent this year in his firm’s biggest hedge fund, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person briefed on the returns.

headline: Nets to Make Stop in Russia to Help Boost N.B.A. Ties
text: Mikhail D. Prokhorov and the Nets are wasting little time in doing their part to solidify a relationship between the N.B.A. and Russia.

headline: Switzerland’s Hedge Fund Reinvention
text: Swiss hedge funds have “reinvented themselves” this year as the country attracts new managers by offering lower tax rates than rival financial centers, Bloomberg News said, citing a Zurich University study.

headline: Vain Economist, Humble Historian
text: Today’s idea: Economists would do well to learn the modesty of historians, a columnist says. They better understand human complexity and the limits of social science.

headline: Analysts Tell HSBC Chief to Reject Chairman Post
text: The HSBC chief executive, Michael Geoghegan, should stay in his post and spurn any offer to become chairman, according to banking analysts, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Q.&A.: A Mac That Does Windows
text: Q.

headline: August Was the Cruelest Month
text: Writing checks is about the most loathsome activity in which I engage. I need a glass of white wine, tranquilizing music, a cleared dining room table and a half-dozen delays before sitting down to the nasty tasks of writing in cursive, subtracting with decimals, addressing envelopes with a pen and remembering how much a stamp costs.

headline: Stricter Rules on Lawsuits Are Good for Management
text: Two Supreme Court decisions making it tougher to pursue lawsuits may have begun to bear fruit for corporations fighting investor claims or employee litigation, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Washington State Man Drives 1,400 Miles Without Refueling
text: Craig Henderson of Bellingham, Wash., which is about 90 miles north of Seattle, planned to drive his home-built car from the Canadian border to Mexico without stopping for fuel. Before leaving on Aug. 29, he’d carefully calculated that his streamlined car could travel the more than 1,400 miles on 14 gallons of diesel.

headline: Cerberus Is Said to Be Mystery Firm in Foster’s Bid
text: Cerberus Capital Management is believed to be the firm that made an offer worth up to $2.5 billion for the wine business of Foster’s Group, The Australian newspaper reported.

headline: Hedge Funds Turn In a Bad August
text: Most hedge funds lost money in August as hundreds of managers, including some of the industry’s best-known names, stumbled when stock markets swooned anew, Reuters reported.

headline: EADS Chief Says a Billion Euro Deal Is Possible
text: The EADS chief executive, Louis Gallois, said his company was in talks with a few other firms in defense, services and security areas for potential deals and could comfortably make an acquisition of around 1 billion euros ($1.27 billion), Reuters reported.

headline: Union Accuses China of Illegal Clean Energy Subsidies
text: HONG KONG — A broad trade case filed on Thursday by an American labor union, accusing China of unfairly subsidizing its clean energy industry, pressed a hot-button jobs issue in the United States during a Congressional election season.

headline: Proxy Advisers Split on Airgas Board Candidates
text: Airgas on Wednesday got a split decision from two important proxy advisory firms in its battle against Air Products and Chemicals, including a recommendation by Institutional Shareholder Services favoring the three Air Products director nominees over the incumbent board members.

headline: On Our Radar: An Asian Carp Czar
text: The Obama administration appoints an “Asian carp czar” to oversee the federal response to keeping the invasive species out of the Great Lakes. “When it comes to the Asian carp threat, we are not in denial. We are not in a go-slow mode. We are in a full attack, full-speed-ahead mode,” says Senator Richard J. Durbin of Illinois. “We want to stop this carp from advancing.” [Chicago Tribune]

headline: Minister Wavers on Plans to Burn Koran
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  First, Terry Jones, the Florida pastor who set the world on edge with plans to burn copies of the Koran on Sept. 11, said Thursday that he had canceled his demonstration because he had won a promise to move the proposed Islamic center near ground zero to a new location.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: — Peter Orszag has re-emerged in the columns of the Opinionator blog, writing about a secret of success. It’s called “chunking.”

headline: As North Korea Marks Its 62nd Year, the World Is Left Guessing
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Koreans marked the 62nd anniversary of their nation’s founding on Thursday with ceremonies honoring its first leader, Kim Il-sung, as speculation abroad deepened over political developments in the reclusive nation.

headline: U.S. Trade Deficit Narrowed in July
text: The United States trade deficit narrowed by 14 percent in July as exports by American companies rose by about $2.8 billion, suggesting that trade would be less of a drag on growth in the months ahead.

headline: Video of Obama’s Comments on Koran Burning
text: Note: This post has been updated several times to reflect new developments during the course of the day.

headline: Guide to N.F.L. Defenses,  Part 4:  The 3-4 Front
text: Jene Bramel writes for Footballguys.com. You can also follow him on Twitter and reach him at bramel@footballguys.com.

headline: Fashion Week Video | Prabal Gurung
text: In this exclusive video, T catches up with the affable Prabal Gurung on the eve of his Spring/Summer 2011 show. In other Prabal news, check out the T Magazine/Prabal Gurung First Look Challenge on Polyvore.com.

headline: 3M Continues Deal Spree, Buying Arizant
text: 11:39 a.m. | Updated 3M said Thursday that it had agreed to buy Arizant, which provides ways to warm patients to prevent hypothermia, for $810 million in cash.

headline: ‘Mrs. Robinson, You’re Trying to Print a Document': Google as Muse
text: Some new Google features designed to predict what you’re typing before you’ve finished it are inspiring creative flashes across the Web – and not just among the people who make a living promoting these high-tech innovations.

headline: Poetry Pairing | September 9, 2010
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by former U.S. Poet Laureate Ted Kooser.

headline: Shifting Ground in Debate Over Muslim Center
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Politico Hires Scarborough and Kinsley as Columnists
text: Politico has built a successful enterprise on the idea that there is no such thing as too much information when it comes to political news. Now it is going to apply that concept to political opinion.

headline: What to Watch on Thursday at the Open
text: In the Spanish section of the men’s draw, Rafael Nadal will face his countryman Fernando Verdasco, who is coming off a five-set marathon against David Ferrer. Nadal, by contrast, is fresh off a relatively routine straight sets win over Feliciano Lopez.

headline: The Early Word: President Versus Pastor
text: President Obama is stepping up the rhetoric as the midterm elections draw near, delivering his most partisan speech of the campaign on Wednesday and adding his voice this morning to the chorus condemning the Florida pastor who plans to burn copies of the Koran on the anniversary of 9/11.

headline: Ex-Sun Chief Gets Healthy With New Venture
text: Jonathan Schwartz, the former chief executive of Sun Microsystems, has put down his servers, chips and software and decided to tackle something new – health.

headline: A Challenge to China’s Energy Subsidies
text: The United Steelworkers say they plan to file a legal case accusing China of violating World Trade Organization rules by subsidizing exports of solar panels and other clean energy equipment.

headline: Longtime Fans
text: Once the signature accessory for Karl Lagerfeld, who reportedly used them to ward off cigarette smoke, the fan — or éventail, as it is known in French — arguably reached its fashion zenith around the heyday of Oscar Wilde’s Lady Windermere. But fears of appearing démodée never stopped Raphaëlle de Panafieu from toting one around. “I always carried fans my father brought back from his trips to Asia,” recalls de Panafieu, who, along with Eloïse Gilles, recently bought the long-dormant French fan maker Duvelleroy. “They were bamboo throwaways, very simple. But they never left my purse.”

headline: End of an Era of White-Collar Prosecutions?
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Apple Lifts Restrictions for App Approvals
text: 7:39 p.m. | Updated  See our article about Apple’s changes.

headline: The Irrigation Juggernaut
text: Anyone who has flown over the American West on a clear day has probably noticed the enormous effect that irrigated farming has had on the landscape of the country. Fields of corn, potatoes and other crops can be seen dotting land that would otherwise be semi-desert, and the spray from some types of irrigation systems creates perfect circles of green in these parched landscapes.

headline: A Chinese Advocate Is Freed, but Stays Under Surveillance
text: BEIJING  A blind, self-taught lawyer imprisoned by the Chinese authorities in 2006 after years of exposing government abuses was freed Thursday and confined to his home in Shandong Province, surrounded by guards and watched through closed-circuit surveillance cameras.

headline: The President Supports His Party
text: President Obama is making another financial investment in the battle to hold the Democratic majority, sending $4.5 million to help the party’s candidates for House, Senate and governor.

headline: Week 1 in Fantasy Football Matchups
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 1. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below, and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

headline: For Snooki, a Day at the Beach Becomes 2 Days of Community Service (and a Fine)
text: President Obama may say from time to time that he has no idea who Snooki is, but Judge Damian G. Murray of Seaside Heights Municipal Court in New Jersey certainly seemed to recognize her. On Wednesday he handed Nicole Polizzi, the diminutive “Jersey Shore” star better known as Snooki, a $500 fine and a sentence of two days community service after she pleaded guilty to disturbing people at a New Jersey beach on July 30, The Associated Press reported. From the bench Judge Murray called Ms. Polizzi “a Lindsay Lohan wannabe” and invoked a few lines from “Animal House,” telling her, “Rude, profane, obnoxious and self-indulgent is not the way to live your life.” A lawyer for Ms. Polizzi told the judge she “was under the influence of some alcohol” when the incident occurred, during taping for a coming third season of “Jersey Shore.”

headline: Open House: Should a Roof Be Built Over Ashe?
text: Gerry Marzorati:  Good morning, Michael. I thought talking about weather conditions incessantly was something you only did if you were an airline pilot or a wedding planner but, No! You do it when you toss a small, fuzzy ball in the air and try to strike it cleanly as it descends. At one point yesterday, I watched poor Gaël Monfils watch one of his tosses end up completely out of his reach — nearly halfway to the service line. Maybe that’s what led him to try the most ridiculous — and thoroughly entertaining — shot I’ve ever seen: A splay-legged jump tweener facing the net from the baseline. He’s too young to have watched A.B.A. games, right?

headline: Thursday Reading: The Ideal Income
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: ‘This Is Officer Krupke. Send Me the Shredder!’
text: Last week, William Dobbs sent us a curious photo of an anomalous-looking vehicle with the telltale markings of the New York Police Department.

headline: Chile Inc.
text: Nickname bestowed on the Chilean government because of the prevalence of business executives.

text: 11:40 a.m. | Updated

headline: Dead Man Catwalking
text: It used to be that a great-looking guy hoped to hear the words, ‘‘He looks cool.’’ But the latest compliment goes back a couple of centuries: ‘‘Death becomes him.’’

headline: Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra Heading to Cuba
text: Jazz at Lincoln Center announced on Thursday that it would send its in-house band, the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, to Cuba next month.

headline: Ex-Railway Executive to Lead Burger King
text: 3G Capital, the new owner of Burger King, plans to name a former Brazilian railway chief executive as the fast-food chain’s new chief executive.

headline: ‘Bob Dylan in America’
text: For thirty years I have tried to write about American history, especially the history of American politics. It is extremely hard work, but gratifying over the long haul. Writing historical pieces about American music and about Bob Dylan wouldn’t have been in the cards but for a ﬂuke, the result of strange good fortune dating back to my childhood.

headline: Sean Wilentz’s History ‘Bob Dylan in America’
text: There’s a reason the title of Sean Wilentz’s “Bob Dylan in America” makes it sound like a semester’s worth of American Studies. There’s also a reason that a flipped version of the title, “America in Bob Dylan,” could be a college course with the identical curriculum. And Mr. Wilentz’s book actually contains the following marvel of rhetorical pedantry: “What does America tell us about Bob Dylan  and what does Dylan’s work tell us about America?”

headline: Somali Airport Is Attacked With U.N. Team on Premises
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Gunmen and suicide bombers attacked Mogadishu’s main airport on Thursday afternoon, shortly after a high-level United Nations delegation met with Somali officials there in an attempt to resolve an escalating internal political dispute.

headline: Sept. 11 in Ads, and Reasons to Raise City Kids
text: In the run-up to the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks this Saturday, controversies over book burning and Muslim building projects appear directly pitched to exploit the city’s and the nation’s still-raw emotions.

text: From Ashlee Vance at Bits:

headline: P.E. in 5th Set With Tennis Channel
text: 11:57 a.m. | Updated The Tennis Channel is televising just its second United States Open. But the cable network has been around for some time, with backing from a prominent group of investors. Here’s the story:

headline: Photos of the Moment | Siki Im
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

headline: Citation Needed: Houellebecq Responds to Charge of Plagiarizing Wikipedia
text: The French writer Michel Houellebecq may or may not agree with the description of him that appears on Wikipedia, which characterizes him as “a writer in the tradition of literary provocation that reaches back to the Marquis de Sade and Baudelaire” (to admirers) and “a peddler of sleaze and shock” (to detractors). But Mr. Houellebecq defended his right to copy material from the French edition of that online encyclopedia for his latest novel, calling it an artistic appropriation that he hopes “contributes to the beauty of my books,” The Independent of London reported.

headline: Courtside: The Scouting Life
text: At 33 and retired from professional tennis, Tripp Phillips is back at the Open scouting talented juniors as an assistant coach for the North Carolina men's tennis team.

headline: Courtside: The Scouting Life
text: After graduating from the University of North Carolina in 2000, Tripp Phillips went on to compete at the highest levels of professional doubles, reaching the semifinals of the United States Open in 2006.

headline: Favre’s Streak: The Most Amazing  Record?
text: (Editor’s note: Even if you’re suffering from Brett Favre fatigue, the YouTube video supplied by Larry Canale above is quite a treat.)

headline: Kandahar More Than a Century Ago – Fictional Injuries, Real War, Realpolitik
text: In his seminal work “Afghanistan,” first published more than 35 years ago, Louis Dupree describes the real-life 19th-century Afghan campaigns near Kandahar, immortalized in Sherlock Holmes’s first meeting with Dr. Watson. Mr. Dupree then goes into how, amid the real death and injuries of the Second Anglo-Afghan War of 1878-1880, one fictional wound came to bewilder Afghan tribal elders.

headline: Back to School: New York Times Resources for English and the Arts
text: This is the fourth and final post in a series on how to use The New York Times across the curriculum. Last Friday we provided ways to use The Times in any class, followed by Tuesday’s post on social studies and history and yesterday’s on science, health, math and technology.

headline: Google Advertises Its Display Advertising
text: Google is rolling out a new advertising campaign on Thursday for its display advertising platform. The campaign, called Watch This Space, will run in advertising trade magazines and in other print and online media. The “space” to watch makes reference to the blocks of display advertising users see on the Web pages they browse.

headline: Joe Mantello Will Act Again – For One Night
text: Joe Mantello, the Tony Award-winning director who had an acclaimed run as an actor in the 1993-94 Broadway production of “Angels in America,” will perform on stage for the first time since “Angels” in an Oct. 18 benefit reading of Larry Kramer’s play “The Normal Heart,” in which Mr. Mantello will play the central role of Ned Weeks.

headline: Living Together, Aging Together
text: My friend Marty and I used to fantasize about a gracious old apartment building in the center of our New Jersey town. It would be great to grow old with a cluster of friends, we told each other, in a place only a few steps from movies and shops, the YMCA and the bus into Manhattan. One day we’d buy it and create the Montclair Old Newspersons’ Home, taking seats on the co-op board so we could approve as residents only people we actually wanted to live with. All it would take was $30 or $40 million that nobody had.

headline: Obama Says Emanuel Would Be ‘Excellent’ Mayor
text: Is President Obama trying to send a signal about the mayor’s race in Chicago?

headline: Why to Be Wary of Add-On Insurance
text: Updated | Sept. 9, 2010

headline: German Military Braces for Scarcity After ‘Peak Oil’
text: A study by a German military think tank leaked to the Internet warns of the potential for a dire global economic crisis in as little as 15 years as a result of a peak and an irreversible decline in world oil supplies.

headline: David Rockwell Joins Board of Cooper-Hewitt Museum
text: The architect and designer David Rockwell has joined the board of the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in Manhattan, part of the Smithsonian Institution. Mr. Rockwell, who has been on the museum’s exhibitions committee since 2006, is the founder and chief executive of Rockwell Group. Among the firm’s projects are W hotels in Union Square and Paris, the Elinor Bunin-Munroe Film Center at Lincoln Center and the new restaurant at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Mr. Rockwell recently designed the Imagination Playground at the South Street Seaport, which is meant to encourage children to design their own play space.

headline: Paterson Sees Opening in Mosque Debate
text: Gov. David A. Paterson suggested on Thursday that the imam hoping to build an Muslim community center in Lower Manhattan had raised the possibility of moving the planned center, which will house a mosque, an auditorium and a pool.

headline: A New Meaning for ‘Dinner on the Go’
text: Isn’t that Perry Watkin’s head sticking out just beneath the roast chicken as he pilots his dining-room table at 130 miles per hour?

headline: Team Orders Are the Talk of Monza
text: MONZA, Italy – It was a sunny day in Monza, but the clouds of the previous day hung over the Formula One paddock as journalists grilled drivers during various press meetings on what they thought about the Ferrari team-orders affair.

headline: Team Orders Are the Talk of Monza
text: MONZA, Italy – It was a sunny day in Monza, but the clouds of the previous day hung over the Formula One paddock as journalists grilled drivers during various press meetings on what they thought about the Ferrari team-orders affair.

headline: Craigslist Pulls ‘Censored’ Label From Sex Ads Area
text: Is Craigslist’s adult services section gone for good?

headline: Fidel Castro’s Doubts About Cuban Communism and Iranian Anti-Semitism
text: Updated | Friday | 3:43 p.m. In what seems like a case of life imitating “The Simpsons,” Fidel Castro said, during a recent interview with Jeffrey Goldberg of The Atlantic, that Cuba’s communist economic model has proved to be a failure.

headline: Honda Announces Pricing for 2011 Odyssey
text: Honda has just released prices on its new 2011 Odyssey minivan, ranging from $28,580 for the base LX up to $44,030 for the top-of-the-line Touring Elite. The Elite trim level is new to Honda.

headline: Agents Bet on Future at the Juniors Tournament
text: Seth McKinley cruises the outer courts at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center, a bag on his back with one of his companies’ rackets poking out, just so. He is a marketing manager for the French racket maker Babolat, and as he watches teenage boys and girls rip forehands, McKinley bumps into his counterparts at Fila and Wilson.

headline: Now Mapping | NYFW Staff Picks
text: We’ve said it before, but we’ll say it again: There is more to New York Fashion Week than the Marc Jacobs show. The editors of T reveal what events they’ve underlined in their agenda books. Follow us on Twitter for dispatches from these and other #NYFW events.

headline: Lobbyists Rush to Hire G.O.P. Staff Ahead of Vote
text: WASHINGTON  With Democrats in danger of losing control of Congress, some prominent lobbying shops, trade groups and contractors are already moving to bring more Republicans on board to bolster their political fortunes.

headline: Maybe Parents Do Understand? Will Smith’s Daughter Gets a Record Deal
text: It’s always nice to see the music industry make room for a talented newcomer. On Wednesday, the Roc Nation entertainment company announced that it had signed a recording deal with the 9-year-old pop singer Willow Smith, whose debut single, “Whip My Hair,” has become a viral sensation after hitting the Web earlier this week. In a news release, Roc Nation said that Willow Smith, who is the sister of the “Karate Kid” actor Jaden Smith and – oh, yes – the daughter of the superstars Will Smith and Jada Pinkett Smith, will shoot her debut video in Los Angeles later this month. Jay-Z, the Roc Nation founder and president, said in a statement, “It’s rare to find an artist with such innate talent and creativity at such a young age. Willow is about to embark on an incredible journey and we look forward to joining her as she grows in all aspects of her career.”

headline: Photos of the Moment | Chadwick Bell
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.

headline: Visiting Ground Zero, Asking Allah for Comfort
text: Nearly every Sept. 11 since Sept. 11, Hadidjatou Karamoko Traoré has made sure that her three children were dressed in their best clothes, and taken them from their tidy brick home in the Bronx to the pit where the World Trade Center stood, and where her husband, their father, worked and died.

headline: TimesCast | September 9, 2010
text: Today, Brian Stelter and David Carr on a Florida pastor's planned Koran burning, a report from a bare knuckle Ohio house race and the Obama administration's efforts to spur U.S. manufacturing.

headline: Look Over There! Yes, It’s … a Celebrity!
text: Last week, Jan Benzel, a culture editor at The Times, wrote about seeing celebrities in New York as part of her New York Send-Off series of posts related to her departure for Paris. She hit a nerve. Dozens of City Room readers sent in reports of their own sightings. Here are some of our favorites:

headline: Q&A: A Family Christmas in Puerto Rico
text: Q.

headline: It Takes More Than Passion
text: Thanks for the great comments to my last post. Several of the comments made me stop and think about my own situation and experiences. While some very important lessons were passed along, I feel the need to offer a little context on some important subjects.

headline: Theater Talkback: Children’s Theater the Right Way
text: This summer ArtsBeat has been inviting members of the theater world to contribute to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. So far our guests have tackled the topics of comedy, ethics, “don’t ask, don’t tell”, immigration and how to define a hit show.

headline: Richard Chai Gets the Week Off to a Slick Start
text: This post marks the debut a new series, Fast Fashion, in which Eric Wilson will be sharing his first impressions of some of the latest runway shows.

headline: SAP Looks to Benefit From the Oracle Tempest
text: To most in the technology industry, Larry Ellison’s latest adventure — the rapid-fire hiring of Mark V. Hurd, ousted Hewlett-Packard chief executive, and the resulting Silicon Valley fireworks — is entertainment.

headline: Analysis: How Federer Conquered the Wind and Soderling
text: At 3-3 in the first set of their quarterfinal match last night, Roger Federer broke Robin Soderling with three smart shots into the wind, the last a breathtaking inside out forehand drop shot on break point that died in the wind for a winner. Before that, Soderling had been in control, holding serve easily and nearly breaking Federer twice.

headline: The Surgeon’s Pact With the Patient
text: The patient, in her late 50s with failing kidneys, had come to the hospital for what she and her doctors thought would be a simple procedure preparing her for dialysis. But instead of returning home the next day, the woman ended up in the hospital for nearly half of my internship. Her procedure went awry, she landed in the intensive care unit, and over the course of the next six months she returned at least a dozen more times to the operating room, all failed attempts to right what had gone so terribly wrong.

headline: Charlie Rose Joins the Legion of Honor
text: PARIS — Charlie Rose was made a knight in the Legion of Honor on Thursday in a ceremony at the French Finance Ministry. Christine Lagarde, the finance minister, lauded Mr. Rose as a great journalist, interviewer and friend of France. Mr. Rose, 68, declared himself a longtime devotee of Paris and singled out for special thanks Martine Frank, the widow of the photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson; and the heart surgeon Alain Carpentier, who performed what Mr. Rose said was life-saving open heart surgery in 2006. Both were among a cluster of friends gathered to fete Mr. Rose; others included the French philosopher Bernard-Henri Lévy, the political analyst Dominique Moisi and the director Danièle Thompson.

headline: Consenting to Surgery and More?
text: When a patient signs a surgical consent form, is he or she agreeing to more than just surgery?

headline: More Doors Open in Rome
text: GAINING entry to Rome’s archaeological sites is never a sure thing. Long affected by collapses, paltry budgets and red tape, historic sites must often limit access, even to places that have been recently restored at great expense. But this fall, many sites are revealing themselves anew, extending their hours and opening up areas that had been shuttered to the public.

headline: Planned Koran Burning Drew International Scorn
text: Before a Florida pastor canceled his plans to burn copies of the Koran on Sept. 11, the international outcry intensified Thursday, drawing vocal condemnations from world leaders and touching off angry protests in corners of the Muslim world.

headline: Wireless Goes Strapless | iPad Clutches
text: No doubt, the iPad has caused quite a stir. (If you don’t have one, you want one.) While some of us may be waiting for the next gen before diving in, a handful of fashion designers are already outfitting their iPads in the chicest of cases — no Swarovski bedazzling necessary. “The iPad suits our needs: it’s practical, versatile and mobile,” says Oscar de la Renta, who is smitten with his device and has already designed a pearlized taupe clutch for his well-wired fans. All casing aside, what are de la Renta’s latest apps? “I recently downloaded Netflix and Pandora,” he says. “I hope I am the first person to create a Bizet station.” You may not have created your own “Carmen” channel, but surely you can be an early adopter of the first iPad clutches and get a head start accessorizing the holiday season’s must-have gift.

headline: 36 Hours in Charleston, S.C.
text: CHARLESTON still has its cannons aimed at Fort Sumter, where the Civil War began, and has elected the same mayor, Joseph Riley, since 1975. It even has some of the country’s most aggressive historic preservation. But that doesn’t mean this charming Southern city has nothing new to offer. There are new galleries on Broad Street, and a festoonery of restaurants, bars and boutique bakeries have transformed the once-struggling design district on upper King Street. Charlestonians, governed by laws of hospitality as incontrovertible as those of gravity, cannot help themselves from sharing their new finds, even if you are “from off,” as those who grew up on this once swampy peninsula refer to outsiders.

headline: A Weekend in Charleston, S.C.
text: Though still historic, this charming Southern city has plenty of new offerings.

headline: Barnes & Noble Urges Holders to Reject Burkle
text: Barnes & Noble, the object of a proxy battle by the billionaire investor Ronald W. Burkle, sent shareholders a letter urging them to vote for its board nominees and to reject Mr. Burkle’s candidates, Reuters reports.

headline: Hotel Review: Babuino 181 in Rome
text: BASICS

headline: Vain Glorious | Flowerbomb Turns Five
text: Last night, Viktor & Rolf hosted an intimate gathering of beauty editors and a smattering of models — Erin Wasson, Shalom Harlow, Elisa Sednaoui — to commemorate five years since launching its first fragrance, Flowerbomb (an occasion famously celebrated with a Grace Jones performance in March across the pond). The soiree was held in a Grove Street town house that looked quite like the tuxedo-jacket-clad designers’ Amsterdam headquarters and featured a huge Flowerbomb bottle replica in pink flowers.

headline: Solar Dreams and Reality at the White House
text: A bio-fueled road trip from Unity, Maine, to the nation’s capital is aiming to press President Obama to put solar panels back on the White House. President Jimmy Carter had installed the first set of panels in 1979, but they were removed during the Reagan administration. Students from Unity College and allied climate campaigners, most notably Bill McKibben, are toting a treasured artifact owned by the school — one of the Carter-era solar hot water panels — to make the point.

headline: U.S. Forces Take Ship From Somali Pirates
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  In a predawn raid with helicopters hovering nearby, 24 American Marines scaled aboard a hijacked ship in the Gulf of Aden on Thursday, arrested the nine pirates on board and freed the ship  all without firing a shot, the American military said.

headline: A Cook Talks About Woks and Stir-Fries
text: The cookbook writer Grace Young recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers’ questions about stir-fries and wok cooking. Ms. Young’s new book, “Stir-Frying to the Sky’s Edge,” was recently published by Simon & Schuster.

headline: Fast-Food Deal on a Fast Track
text: 3G Capital wants the Whopper now.

headline: Deutsche Bank Said to Weigh Stock Sale
text: Deutsche Bank has begun approaching other banks about a potential stock sale that could raise as much as 9 billion euros, or $11.4 billion, Bloomberg News and The Financial Times reported on Thursday, citing unnamed sources.

headline: Algae Blooms Were Not Red Tide, Officials Say
text: Yes, that stuff floating in the water last week was reddish, but no, it was not red tide. Nor was it toxic, environmental officials from New York and New Jersey said on Wednesday.

headline: A.P. Wouldn’t Have Shared Images of Koran Burning
text: Though a fringe pastor in Gainesville, Fla., has suspended plans to burn Korans, The Associated Press wire service said Thursday that it would not have shared any images of a Koran being burned.

headline: A Challenge to Florida Beach-Driving Tradition
text: NEW SMYRNA BEACH, Fla.  Sandy Fletcher, a bartender with a dark tan at the Breakers beachfront restaurant here, remembers seeing the commotion in July. Lifeguards had stopped the usual flow of Sunday traffic on the hard sand. Sirens blared. “We knew it was something bad,” she said. Cellphones started ringing. “Then they said it was a 4-year-old.”

headline: Broadway Bound and Also Unbound
text: Dates are subject to change.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: Excerpt: 'Raising Hope'
text: Martha Plimpton stars in the new Fox sitcom.

headline: Embracing Malaise as a Plot Point
text: DECLINE and the erosion of the American dream infuse public discourse, so it’s inevitable that a streak of pessimism courses through the best new fall shows.

headline: Inside the List
text: GOD CONFUSION: Tony Blair’s memoir, “A Journey,” may have zoomed to No. 3 on the hardcover nonfiction list, but another Englishman has been hogging most of the headlines, or the flattering ones anyway. (Here’s NPR: “Tony Blair Cancels London Book Signing, Reluctant to Dodge More Shoes, Eggs.”) After advance excerpts of Stephen Hawking’s new book, “The Grand Design”(written with Leonard Mlodinow), appeared on both sides of the Atlantic, the Internet went wild with the news that Hawking had declared God dead after all, or at least unnecessary for setting off the Big Bang. (For good measure, he also declares that “philosophy is dead.”)

headline: IndyCar Series Drops Watkins Glen From 2011 Schedule
text: Although the Izod IndyCar Series has gained traction recently, picking up television viewers, sponsors and participants, Randy Bernard, its first-year chief executive, said that he would announce several major changes to the 2011 schedule Friday in Milwaukee.

headline: 4 Iraqi Prisoners Escape U.S. Custody
text: BAGHDAD  Four of the most dangerous prisoners in Iraq escaped overnight on Wednesday from American custody in a heavily fortified prison on the edge of Baghdad, an embarrassing security breach that led to an intensive manhunt, American and Iraqi officials said Thursday.

headline: Above the City at Night, the Call of the Wild Is Heard
text: No matter how urbanized New Yorkers like to think we are, the reminders of our natural world are constant. Canada geese, raccoons even skunks have brushed up against humans recently in a somewhat rude manner. Or at least it was rude to us.

headline: Sports Replay: Sept. 9
text: A view of the day in sports, including world championship action in basketball, judo and wrestling.

headline: Popcast: The Golden Palominos and Sara Bareilles
text: When is a band reunion not really a reunion? When the members changed with every record in the first place.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: The Rome skyline with St. Peter’s Basilica in the center.

headline: The Latest on How Much Card Rewards Cost the Poor
text: In July, the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston released a paper quantifying how much credit rewards cost the poor.

headline: The New Season in Theater
text: Images from some of the new productions of the season.

headline: G.M. Ventures Invests $3.2 Million in Battery Company
text: A Michigan lithium-ion battery developer, which is working on new technology the company says can give electric cars greater range, plans to announce on Friday that it has received $3.2 million from General Motors Ventures. G.M. said the new batteries could eventually end up in the company’s cars.

headline: In West Virginia Race, Double Negatives
text: Gov. Joe Manchin III of West Virginia aired his first television commercial in his bid for the state’s open Senate seat on Wednesday night and it wasn’t one of those fluffy biography ads.

headline: Fashion’s Night In
text: Ever wonder how clothing designers dress their homes? The Council of Fashion Designers of America and Assouline are publishing “American Fashion Designers At Home.” Written by Rima Suqi, a contributor to T and The New York Times, the coffee-table book ($65, which benefits the CFDA Foundation) looks at the homes of 115 CFDA members, from heavyweights like Diane von Furstenberg and Kate Spade to relative newcomers like Band of Outsiders’ Scott Sternberg. The interiors, which range from luxurious — like Eva Chow’s gold-leafed Los Angeles living room or Tory Burch’s opulent, surprisingly conservative Manhattan apartment — to industrial-funky, like Rachel Comey’s Long Island weekend house, may seem glamorous to those of us on the outside looking in. But as Suqi points out, even fashion designers “are not immune to the pitfalls of decorating or renovating. They have nightmare contractors, too.”

headline: Ron Bloom Is Obama’s Manufacturing Emissary
text: Not since Ronald Reagan has an American president spoken so emphatically about the importance of manufacturing. “We’ve got to go back to making things,” Barack Obama says, embedding that view in his oratory. Yet manufacturing’s presence in the American economy continues to shrink, defying the administration’s attempts to reverse that trend.

headline: A Ray of Sunshine in Every Bite
text: In my neighborhood it is known simply as “the muffin shop,” and it is the muffin shop, though that is kind of a shame because the real name, Blue Sky Bakery, is just so right.

headline: Obama’s Missed Opportunity: Answers From Matt Bai, Part I
text: 6:44 p.m. | Updated In his Political Times column on Wednesday, Matt Bai asserted that President Obama had missed an opportunity to rally the public behind his long-term initiative to restructure the economy. He is answering readers’ questions about the president’s approach and other top political issues this week.

headline: After Fire, Phillips Collection Seeks Donations Via Texting
text: Small donations via text message raised millions of dollars for Haitian earthquake victims. Are museums next? The Phillips Collection in Washington on Thursday announced a campaign to solicit $5 and $10 donations via text message to raise money for repairs to its building after a fire on Sept. 2. No artwork was damaged, but the museum’s offices were harmed.

headline: The New Season
text: The fall television season brings a full serving of new crime fighters and comedies.

headline: More Children Being Raised by Grandparents
text: The number of American children being raised by their grandparents rose after the recession began, according to a report from Pew Social Research.

headline: A Year in MP3s
text: Last September, my best friend, Susan, told me that I didn’t make enough music anymore. She was right; between 1996 and 2003, I put out a new record every year, played a few shows a month and did quite a bit of composing, mostly for solo musicians or small ensembles I’d met over the years.

headline: Toronto Film Festival Heads Downtown
text: TORONTO—The change is palpable, as the giant annual film festival here shifted its weight downtown, toward its new Bell Lightbox center in the entertainment district and away from the high-toned hotels and eateries of Yorkville. Good-bye Four Seasons, hello, Hooters, the Fox and Fiddle, and the Canadiana Backpackers Inn. All are a stone’s throw from the Scotiabank Theater, now a primary screening place for festival films. This reporter stopped into a restaurant just across the street from the Lightbox on Wednesday night, thinking to have dinner. The hostess pointed toward a nicely situated four-top near the window, and even cleaned up half of it. “Oh, O.K.,” she said, on being asked if the dirty glass and tableware might disappear from the other half as well.

headline: ‘Fiddler’ Up His Sleeve: Lin-Manuel Miranda’s Wedding Surprise
text: We weren’t able to make it Sunday to the wedding of Lin-Manuel Miranda and Vanessa Nadal (our invitations must have gotten lost in the mail or something), but the good folks at Broadway.com have posted this video of what was surely a highlight of the post-nuptial celebration: a wedding toast delivered by Mr. Miranda, the creator and composer of “In the Heights”, and his new father-in-law. It gradually turns into a family performance of Bock and Harnick’s “To Life,” with lyrics modified for the occasion. Make sure you stick around for the choreography – you’ll be totally kvelling.

headline: ‘Fiddler’ Up His Sleeve: Lin-Manuel Miranda’s Wedding Surprise
text: We weren’t able to make it Sunday to the wedding of Lin-Manuel Miranda and Vanessa Nadal (our invitations must have gotten lost in the mail or something), but the good folks at Broadway.com have posted this video of what was surely a highlight of the post-nuptial celebration: a wedding toast delivered by Mr. Miranda, the creator and composer of “In the Heights”, and his new father-in-law. It gradually turns into a family performance of Bock and Harnick’s “To Life,” with lyrics modified for the occasion. Make sure you stick around for the choreography – you’ll be totally kvelling.

headline: A Clip From ‘Score: A Hockey Musical’
text: What goes together better than musical numbers and Canada’s national sport? The Toronto International Film Festival will be celebrating both when it opens Thursday night with “Score: a Hockey Musical.” The film, directed by the Toronto-based filmmaker Michael McGowan, tells the story of a teenage hockey player (Noah Reid) and features Olivia Newton-John, along with a variety of Canadian personalities. The above clip gives a taste of the movie’s approach to the sport.

headline: Turkey Channeled ‘White Shadow’ as Basketball Caught On
text: ISTANBUL  The heyday of the television series “The White Shadow” was three decades ago, but Ken Howard, who played its main character, is still recognized on the street. American men who were in their teens in the late 1970s and early ’80s will lock eyes with him, smile and utter the same greeting: “Hey, Coach.”

headline: Fashion Week Preview | Prabal Gurung
text: In a T Magazine exclusive, Prabal Gurung gives us a sneak peek at his spring/summer 2011 collection before it is shown on the runway at New York Fashion Week this Saturday. If you’re wondering what the springboard for the collection is, Gurung mentioned on the day of his recent T video shoot that he has been more than a little obsessed with the protagonist in the coming Maggie Betts documentary and with Tilda Swinton’s bougie turn in “I Am Love.” “It’s a study in the power of femininity,” Gurung said, “but not in a clichéd way. I like the nuanced — and, you know, a really powerful woman can say so much with a nod or simply a word or two. All the women I love have that quiet strength.”

headline: Keeping a Summer Tradition, Despite Risks
text: Despite pleas from parents whose children have been killed by cars on the beach to ban the practice, driving on the sand remains a favorite activity on some Florida beaches.

headline: Theater Listings: Sept. 10 — 16
text: Theater

headline: An Uneasy Voter Mood
text: After voting for George W. Bush in 2004, Tuscarawas County in Ohio went for President Obama four years later. Republicans are counting on regaining support in areas like this.

headline: José Manuel Carreño to Retire
text: José Manuel Carreño, the veteran American Ballet Theater dancer, has announced he is retiring in August 2011. A special farewell evening for Mr. Carreño, who joined the company as a principal in 1995, will take place on June 30 at the Metropolitan Opera House and will feature a special performance of “Swan Lake” with Mr. Carreño in the role of Prince Siegfried, dancing opposite Julie Kent as Odette and Gillian Murphy as Odile. Mr. Carreño, who was born in Cuba, joined the English National Ballet in 1990 and the Royal Ballet in 1993. With American Ballet Theater, he has danced many roles, including the title character in “Apollo,” Albrecht in “Giselle,” Des Grieux in “Manon” and Solor in “La Bayadère.” In a 2000 review of “La Bayadère” Anna Kisselgoff wrote: “Mr. Carreño as Solor, the warrior who leaves Nikiya to marry Gamzatti, the rajah’s daughter, plumbs his role with depth and brilliance. He was a sensitive hero, troubled but commanding.” Following his retirement from American Ballet Theater, he plans to continue performing as a guest artist.

headline: New York Stoneware Is at Home in Albany
What We’re Reading: Health Spending for the Obese
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Men in Blue Without Shades of Gray
text: BRIAN BURNS still remembers the afternoon in the late 1990s when he was leaving the West Fourth Street subway station in Greenwich Village, by the basketball courts, and he was startled by a young man who pulled out a gun  “right in front me”  and fired off one shot in another direction. A police officer tackled the man almost immediately.

headline: Courtside: Signs Point to Federer-Nadal
text: Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal look unstoppable, meaning a meeting between the two at the U.S. Open in the final is a strong possibility.

headline: Democrats: 1994 This Is Not
text: Need another sign that Democrats are facing rocky political terrain this year? Prominent party members are taking it upon themselves to compare and contrast this year with 1994.

headline: Dressing Gordon Gekko, Then and Now
text: With just a few weeks to go until “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps” hits theaters, there’s a lot to talk about: the portrayal of the financial crisis, accurate or not; the acting; the symbolism. (And the cameos!)

headline: The Tale of Two Umudugudus (Villages)
text: It is difficult to account for the many effects on a community of having access to a clean and consistent supply of drinking water. Through a comparison of two umudugudus (villages), one with an improved source of water and the other without, I will try to document some of the themes that have occurred to me thus far. But before I begin this analysis I want to give a brief comparison of the two umudugudus.

headline: Christian Siriano on the Spice Route
text: One of the joys of Fashion Week is when designers leave little notes along the front row seats explaining their inspirations for the season. Christian Siriano, at his 2 p.m. show (view complete runway show), included a photo that showed the feet of one of his models. There was also a description of the shoes he had designed for Payless, inspired by “African, Indian and Chinese influences mixed with measures of elegant opulence.”

headline: Spare Times
text: Around Town

headline: Jazz At Lincoln Center Heading To Cuba
text: Jazz at Lincoln Center announced on Thursday that it would send its in-house band, the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, to Cuba next month. The trip is a first for the organization, which has increasingly stressed the Cuban aspect of jazz, and was facilitated by the Cuban pianist Chucho Valdés as part of a cultural exchange under the auspices of the Cuban Institute of Music, an agency of the Cuban Ministry of Culture. Mr. Valdés, with his own band, already has New York concerts scheduled at Jazz at Lincoln Center’s Allen Room on Oct. 22 and 23. “We have been fantasizing about this for a long time,” said Adrian Ellis, the organization’s executive director, who noted that the Mellon, Ford, Rockefeller and two other smaller foundations came up with the money to pay for the trip once the band had secured approval from the United States government. The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, led by the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis, above, will perform concerts of different kinds in Cuba Oct. 5-9, with large and small ensembles, as well as a Jazz for Young People performance.

headline: Art Collection To Be Sold
text: Max Palevsky, a founder of the computer-chip giant Intel, who died in May, collected art, lots of it. Christie’s will be selling his collection  more than 250 works ranging from antiquities to Impressionist, modern and contemporary art  in a series of auctions beginning in New York next month. The entire group is expected to bring $53 million to $78 million. Some works will be auctioned at Christie’s important Impressionist and modern art auction in New York on Nov. 3. Among them is Fernand Léger’s “Cup of Tea,” above, a 1921 painting depicting a voluptuous woman posed against a geometric background, which is estimated to fetch $8 million to $12 million. The sale will also include works by Egon Schiele and Giorgio Morandi. More works will be auctioned the following week, on Nov. 10, at the New York postwar and contemporary sale, including a classic Pop image by Roy Lichtenstein, “Girl in Mirror,” from 1964, which is estimated to bring $3 million to $4 million.

headline: House Tour: Margaretville, N.Y.
text: HOW MUCH $1.5 million. Taxes, $7,028.

headline: U.S. Pressures I.M.F. to Expand Role of Growing Economies
text: WASHINGTON  In a move that has met with resistance in Europe, the United States is pushing to reduce the Continent’s influence over the International Monetary Fund and grant more of a say to economies outside of Europe that are growing and leading the global recovery.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra Gets Some Financial Aid
text: The financially troubled Philadelphia Orchestra says it has received $4 million from the William Penn Foundation to help pay for its operations and another half-million dollars toward an “intensive strategic planning process.” The orchestra, which recently emerged from a leadership vacuum, is struggling to finance its activities. To deal with major shortfalls it established what it calls a recovery fund, which  with the William Penn gift  now amounts to $12 million in donations and pledges. The foundation describes itself as “dedicated to improving the quality of life in the Greater Philadelphia region.”

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: BROOKLYN BOOK FESTIVAL

headline: Harvard Endowment Reports 11% Return for Year
text: A year after a disastrous 27 percent decline that prompted layoffs, salary freezes and a halt to some campus expansion, the Harvard endowment on Thursday reported a solid 11 percent increase in its $27.4 billion portfolio for the fiscal year ended June 30.

headline: U.S. Basketball Team Advances to Semifinals
text: ISTANBUL  Chris Collins’s legs bounced with nervous energy as he listened to “The Star-Spangled Banner” before the United States played Russia on Thursday in the quarterfinals of the world basketball championships.

headline: Mantello Will Act For One Night
text: Joe Mantello, the Tony Award-winning director, will perform onstage for the first time since his run as an actor in the 1993-94 Broadway production of “Angels in America,” in an Oct. 18 benefit reading of Larry Kramer’s play “The Normal Heart,” in which Mr. Mantello will play the central role of Ned Weeks. Mr. Mantello, who won his directing Tonys for “Take Me Out” and “Assassins,” signed up for the reading of the landmark play about gay men and AIDS after having a conversation this winter with its director, Joel Grey, whom Mr. Mantello directed in the musical “Wicked.” Also in the ensemble cast for the reading at Broadway’s Walter Kerr Theater are Victor Garber, Jason Butler Harner, John Benjamin Hickey, Michael Stuhlbarg  and Patrick Wilson. The producer Daryl Roth is mounting the reading to raise money for two caregiver groups, Actors Fund and Friends in Deed.

headline: Field Of ‘talent’ Narrows While ‘Top Model’ Weakens
text: As “America’s Got Talent” pared its top 10 contestants down to four, the results episode of that NBC reality show ranked No. 1 on Wednesday night, attracting a solid 11.9 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. That was enough to propel the network to first place for the night. On CW, the debut of the new cheerleading comedy-drama “Hellcat” gave the network something to shout about, drawing three million viewers and improving slightly on the premiere of “America’s Next Top Model” (2.9 million), whose ratings were down slightly from the series’s premiere last fall. CBS finished in second place for the night, and Fox was third with a two-hour installment of “MasterChef” (5.7 million). ABC ranked fourth with comedy reruns.

headline: Harvard Endowment Posts 11% Return for Year
text: A year after a disastrous 27 percent decline that prompted layoffs, salary freezes and a halt to some campus expansion, the Harvard endowment on Thursday reported a solid 11 percent increase in its $27.4 billion endowment portfolio for its fiscal year ended June 30.

headline: Case Study | Beach-Plum Loco
text: I’m back up in Cape Cod, feeding what has for several years been a smoldering mania for beach plums (prunus maritima), with an eye to making not jelly but rather a homemade liqueur I stumbled onto quite coincidentally. I happened to be here while researching an article on sloe gin a number of years back. I learned that sloe berries are a type of wild plum, the fruit of a shrub called a blackthorn tree that grows in hedgerows in England. The English have never been able to cultivate them, and the fruit — being mostly pit surrounded by a thin pulp that is equal parts bitter, sour and astringent — is used, when it is used at all, for making sloe gin. It’s macerated in the strongest gin available, and sugar is added to the final result to create a homespun liqueur.

headline: U.N. Flood Relief Official Says She Will Seek More Money
text: NOWSHERA, Pakistan  The top United Nations emergency relief official visited a camp for monsoon flood victims in this northwestern district on Thursday and said she would soon be seeking more aid money beyond the $460 million sought in the initial global appeal for help.

headline: Navigating Tangier’s Labyrinth
text: Outside of the ancient medina, the Moroccan city shows signs of modernity.

headline: Lost in Tangier
text: AT midday in July, the Tangier medina was a ghost town. With shadows reduced to slivers, even in the narrowest of the ochre alleyways, residents retreated to lunch behind thick wooden doors or to relax inside their antique silver shops. It was hot and still, despite the occasional breeze from the Mediterranean, and only fools dared venture out — fools, that is, like me.

headline: New York’s Historical Homes for Autos
text: Among the very ambitious garages built in New York after 1900, some are still hard at work. But preservationists, by and large, take them as much for granted as everybody else.

headline: Iran to Release Detained U.S. Hiker
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Iran plans to release Sarah E. Shourd, one of the three American hikers detained last year and accused of spying, Iranian officials said Thursday.

headline: At Hangar 17, Pieces of Ground Zero
text: Panoramic photographs from an 80,000-square-foot hangar at Kennedy Airport where artifacts from Sept. 11, 2001, are being held.

headline: For the Car, and Far From Pedestrian
