text: CONSIDER the lowly garage, usually placed somewhere between the tenement and the outhouse as a fit subject for architectural appreciation and historic preservation. But public garages, which appeared in the early 1900s, often rose to respectable, even exciting, heights.

headline: A Raucous Reflection on Identity: Jewish and Feminine
text: Don’t be put off by the yawn-inducing title of the Jewish Museum’s “Shifting the Gaze: Painting and Feminism.” The show is a puckish, punchy look at the women’s art movement, one that takes as much inspiration from Marcia Tucker’s “Bad Girls” survey of 1994 as it does from more comprehensive, conventional shows of feminist art.

headline: Glamour Revives Port of Batumi
text: AN illuminated tower soars above the clear Black Sea and the mist-covered Caucasus mountains surrounding the port town of Batumi, Georgia. Its night lights flood the skyline, revealing a new building that contrasts with the 19th-century facades of the old town and casting a warm glow over a palm tree-lined promenade of strolling lovers and giggling families. The majestic structure — the tallest on the sea’s coast — calls to mind a mosque, a library or a museum.

headline: Sheraton Expands Footprint in China
text: Sheraton Hotels & Resorts is embarking on a wave of expansion in China, opening 8 hotels there by year’s end, which brings its 2010 total to 11. It plans to add 26 more in the next four years, far beyond its average of 4 per year.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: Art

headline: An Israeli Oasis as a Passage to Ancient Times
text: THERE are many reasons not to travel overseas with small children, and, as far as I can tell, only one reason to do so. Unfortunately for my children, who’d probably be just as happy to stay home, that reason is what keeps me slogging through the less glamorous parts of motherhood. When you travel you get the chance to prove to your children that life is at least as interesting as their bedtime stories. And if you can get them to believe that, then you can believe it too, at least for the duration of the trip.

headline: If the Condo Fits, Then Buy It
text: WELCOME to fashion week, à la real estate! Our first fashion maven to trot down the runway will be Rita Magli, the creative director at Bruno Magli in the 1990s, back when her husband, Morris Magli, was at the company’s helm. But rather than bags and stilettos, we will be showcasing Ms. Magli’s new apartment. Happily for those with a poetic sensibility, the condominium is in a building that was once one of the largest shoe stores in the world.

headline: The Creative Set Heads East in Beirut
text: The Mar Mikhael district is benefiting from a spillover from the hot Gemmayzeh neighborhood.

headline: Dante Enters New Realm, Sotheby’s 10th Floor
text: The line between auction houses and art galleries keeps blurring. It is no longer unusual for Sotheby’s and Christie’s to take over entire galleries. Sotheby’s did it in 1996, when it bought the André Emmerich Gallery. Christie’s followed, taking over Hall & Knight in 2004 and then Haunch of Venison three years ago. Like dealers, both companies also do much business selling works of art for clients privately. Now Sotheby’s is encroaching on dealer territory yet again but in a slightly different way. This month it is opening “Divine Comedy,” an exhibition of some 75 works organized around the theme of Dante’s epic poem.

headline: Maybe He Sold in Search of Better Acoustics
text: WHAT do you expect the home of a metal band rock star to look like? If you’re thinking black walls, skull-shaped door knobs, or at least something really, really loud, then you’re out of luck  at least in the case of James Shaffer, the guitarist for the band Korn.

headline: In the Present and Still Dance-Ready
text: “Forget where you’ve been,” Kele sang as he started his set at Webster Hall on Wednesday night with “Walk Tall,” the song that also starts his solo album, “The Boxer” (Glassnote). “Cut your ties to the past and wave it goodbye.” But he was smart not to take his own advice.

headline: Betaworks and The Times Plan a Social News Service
text: Something is stirring deep within the technology incubator Betaworks: A personalized news service called News.me that is being developed in collaboration with The New York Times.

headline: The Most Generous Countries on Earth
text: The United States is the fifth most-generous country on earth, tied with Switzerland, according to a new ranking from Gallup’s World Giving Index.

headline: Deep Under Brooklyn, the Tours Will Resume
text: Bob Diamond’s staying in Brooklyn, where he’ll continue his subterranean tours of a 19th-century railroad tunnel beneath Atlantic Avenue, and redouble his latest efforts to create a trolley line from Red Hook to Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Backstage at Fashion Week | Christian Siriano
text: The divinely scandalous designer Christian Siriano, who caused a flap this week with his comments about Brooke Shields and Haylie Duff, discusses the collection backstage.

headline: Recapping ‘Hard Knocks,’ Episode 5: King Revis
text: My apologies if I seem distracted, but I was woken up by the news of three-time Super Bowl champion Tom Brady’s car accident.

headline: Aggression on Wheels, With Bruises as Badges
text: AS a child of the 1970s, I spent a number of birthday parties in striped tube socks and bright white roller skates, whizzing around a place called Skate Country in New Orleans. I loved the freedom of doing figure eights to Olivia Newton John or couples skating to the Bee Gees. But when I entered the Hunter College gym this spring for the Gotham Girls Roller Derby home season opener, I instantly knew it was going to be so much better than Skate Country. On one side was a roaring crowd and on the other a line of the toughest-looking women in short shorts I had ever seen.

headline: A Plug-In Electric for Hyundai’s Home Market
text: Hyundai introduced its BlueOn electric car on Thursday at a news conference in Seoul, South Korea. The automaker, which has experienced phenomenal growth in recent years, reportedly hopes to catch up with rival Japanese manufacturers who have a big head start in hybrid and plug-in electric vehicles.

headline: Video and Latest Updates on Koran Burning Cancellation
text: Note: This post has been updated several times to reflect developments.

headline: At Lower East Side Tenement Museum, Lectures and Opera
text: If you’re reading this, there’s a good chance you’re overworked and underpaid. But don’t let it get you down. Instead get some perspective from the trials and tribulations of the 19th-century factory workers of the Lower East Side. In what was once a tenement built in 1863, the Lower East Side Tenement Museum offers a series of free lectures, readings and panel discussions about the lives of its former residents and their contemporaries. On Wednesday Philip Dray talks about his book “There Is Power in a Union: The Epic Story of Labor in America,” accompanied by scenes from the Downtown Art theater troupe’s “Waistmakers’ Opera,” a musical depicting one of the first strikes by female workers in America. (108 Orchard Street, at Delancey Street; 212-982-8420, tenement.org; the series is free unless otherwise noted, but reservations are requested: events@tenement.org.)

headline: ‘Nobody’s Fool’
text: Images from a new exhibition of works by Yoshitomo Nara, at Asia Society Museum.

headline: Where the Sidewalks End, and the City (Really) Begins
text: THE city as poem, art piece, happening, living theater: New Yorkers have all experienced their own versions, and the leaders of the conceptual walks that make up Elastic City want to create new ones.

headline: Stem Cell Financing Ban Ends, for Now
text: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court here ruled Thursday that federal financing of embryonic stem cell research could continue while the court considers a judge’s order last month that banned the government from underwriting the work.

headline: A Chance to Be Tim Gunn
text: It’s a slightly surreal experience seeing the “Project Runway” finale at New York Fashion Week live, as hundreds of people did this morning at Lincoln Center. You have the immediacy of the event – the lights, the cameras, the booming techno music straight out of a gay disco in the 1980s, the celebrities (Jordin Sparks sitting two rows away, a rumored Britney Spears somewhere in the house). But what you miss is the show’s most important element: the judges’ commentary.

headline: For Pelosi and Markey, an Oil Sands Mission
text: Representatives Nancy Pelosi of California and Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts are in Canada this week to learn and listen about oil sands development there. The two Democrats are getting an earful from Canadian officials as well as from Canadian environmental groups on the pluses and minuses of importing oil from Alberta.

headline: The Mystery of a Face, Up Close
text: It’s startling how very little happens in “Selective Memory,” and how slowly. And then how many meanings unfold. This mixed-media work, which opened on Wednesday at the Chocolate Factory, is radical in that word’s primary sense: “pertaining to or going to roots.” It’s a close-up study in perception: of a woman and, in particular, her face. It starts clinical, grows poetic and ends romantic.

headline: A Ray of Sunshine in Every Bite
text: In my neighborhood it is known simply as “the muffin shop,” and it is the muffin shop, though that is kind of a shame because the real name, Blue Sky Bakery, is just so right.

headline: Running Away From the Circus
text: Has Joaquin Phoenix lost it? That question began raging through the chattersphere in late 2008 and early 2009, especially after the actor showed up on the “Late Show With David Letterman” and didn’t jovially sell the goods. Beefed up and scruffy-faced, wearing sunglasses and undertaker’s basic black, he didn’t play to the crowd, flatter the host or flack for his latest film, “Two Lovers.”

headline: Now Accessorizing | Fright Collar
text: No, these aren’t the faces of harried magazine editors during fashion week. The jeweler Eddie Borgo, who is up for this year’s CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund award, based his Horror Collar on the Mayor of Halloween Town in Tim Burton’s 1993 film, “The Nightmare Before Christmas.” “His wild mood swings made his cone head spin around from a happy face to a scary one,” Mr. Borgo explains. “It’s a figurative representation of a two-faced politician.” The silver-plated brass and crystal necklace is $500 at Bergdorf Goodman.

headline: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
text: Muhammed Muheisen of The Associated Press depicts Ramadan by showing the shadow of a Palestinian youth in the West Bank reading verses of the Koran following an early morning prayer service. At almost the same time, Rosh Hashana was being celebrated in Ukraine (Slide 2).

headline: Cuddling With Little Girls, Dogs and Music
text: Feeling a tad museum-phobic? Cowed by expanses of immaculate white walls? Whipsawed by hermetic, aloof artworks? If so, Asia Society has the cure. It is “Yoshitomo Nara: Nobody’s Fool,” a homey, user-friendly exhibition that can feel like a little piece from somewhere over the rainbow.

headline: Takeover Bid Shines Spotlight on Crucial Player in Potash
text: OTTAWA  It is hardly a household word like, say, the oil cartel OPEC. That is why Canpotex, an organization with a corner on Canada’s potash production, used to go about its business in nearly complete obscurity.

headline: Fashion Moments
text: In and around Lincoln Center during the first day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Fischer’s Paternity Test Released
text: Marilyn Young, the Filipino woman who said that her daughter, Jinky, was the child of Bobby Fischer is pressing ahead with a claim to his estate, though DNA tests have shown that Mr. Fischer was not Jinky’s father.

headline: New Lives, New Deaths, New Challenges
text: RETAIL sales of video games have dipped slightly in 2010, but the overall quality delivered by the interactive entertainment industry has never been higher. Major titles like Red Dead Redemption, God of War III, StarCraft II, Mass Effect 2 and Heavy Rain have already established this year as a watershed for consumers who plunk down the $60 that most top games cost these days.

headline: A Wild Trip From Bathroom to Gallery
text: THE story of how of Dan Colen landed his first major show at the Gagosian Gallery sounds a bit like an art-world version of one of the Disney tales that sometimes show up in his painting.

headline: Lost In Translation
text: Ah — I see that my last post was too elliptical, mainly thanks to jet lag; people aren’t quite getting my point.

headline: Bank of England Leaves Rate at 0.5% on Signs of Slowing
text: The British central bank held steady Thursday on its benchmark interest rate amid new warnings that the recovery among major economies appeared to be losing steam faster than anticipated.

headline: A Smooth-Talking Texas Two-Timer
text: AMY LIPPMAN can pinpoint the moment in the pilot script for “Lone Star,”Fox’s new drama about a young, charming Texas con man named Bob Allen (James Wolk), when she knew this was a television series worth joining. In a hotel bar, a flirtatious beauty invites Bob up to her room, but he politely informs her that he has a couple of reasons for turning her down. What the audience knows and the woman doesn’t is that Bob’s living a double life, married to the daughter of an oil baron in Houston and living in small-town Midland with a second sweetheart whom he will soon  spoiler alert  also wed, and that he’s deeply in love with both of them.

headline: Where Even Robert Redford Has to Work to Sell His New Film
text: TORONTO

headline: Aggression on Wheels
text: You may get some bruises with rough-and-tumble roller derby, but you’ll also find camaraderie and a place to work out your hostilities.

headline: Building an Art of Virtuoso Ambiguity
text: The superb five-decade survey of drawings by Gerhard Richter opening at the Drawing Center in SoHo on Saturday is, without even trying to be, an event. It’s the first career overview of Mr. Richter in the United States since the much-praised “40 Years of Painting” at the Museum of Modern Art in 2002. It presents seldom-exhibited work, most of it abstract, in a medium that would seem a natural adjunct to his painting.

headline: The Dark Side of Cushnie et Ochs
text: It was hard to keep your eyes off the shoes on the runway of Cushnie et Ochs, the young label of the designers Carly Cushnie and Michelle Ochs. Were they stigmata shoes? Spikes have been big in footwear for a while, thanks to the glamazon stilettos that Christian Louboutin made for Rodarte, but these, by Alejandro Ingelmo, looked downright terrifying. They had a long, roughly three inches long, spike pointing up from the toe and another coming out of the back of the heel.

headline: Video: Uneasy Voters in Ohio
text: Tuscarawas County voted for George W. Bush in 2004 but became one of just five counties in Ohio that Barack Obama flipped four years later. Interviews with residents now suggests the president might not have as much luck if he were on the ballot this year. Administration initiatives simply have yet to be felt on the ground.

headline: Giants Get a Visit From Odierno
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Standing amid the Giants in their blue practice jerseys and red-trimmed helmets Thursday was a visitor in a uniform of a different sort. He wore camouflage fatigues.

headline: Rock ’n’ Roll’s Killer Meets Broadway’s
text: FRESH off a matinee performance of “Million Dollar Quartet,” Levi Kreis ran a nervous hand through his pompadour as he stood in the living room of a hotel suite high above Times Square on Wednesday. Mr. Kreis, the actor and musician who plays Jerry Lee Lewis in that Broadway musical, seemed unsure of how to comport himself when the suite’s primary occupant arrived. First he propped himself between two chairs, like a sprinter waiting for a starting pistol. Then, half-reverently and half-jokingly, he got down on one knee, which was the position he was found in when the real-life Mr. Lewis entered the room.

headline: Now Showing | The Graceful Dead
text: “People dealt with death differently in the 19th century,” says Eva Ulz, the curator of “Memento Mori: The Birth and Resurrection of Postmortem Photography” at the Merchant’s House Museum. “People looked forward to a reunion in heaven. Creating portraits was considered a precursor to that heavenly reunion. They shouldn’t be thought of as creepy.”

headline: Random Transformations
text: An interactive look at the work of Dan Colen, who explores the role of chance in the making of art.

headline: Betaworks and The Times Plan Social News Site
text: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

headline: Should Bush’s Heisman Be Taken Away?
text: Earlier this week, Yahoo Sports reported that Reggie Bush was expected to have his Heisman Trophy taken away by the end of the month. This stems, of course, from the N.C.A.A.’s determination that Bush committed multiple violations during his Heisman-winning 2005 season at U.S.C., including accepting cash, gifts and other benefits. Bush would become the first winner to be stripped of his Heisman.

headline: Excerpt: 'No Ordinary Family'
text: The new ABC series follows a family that is suddenly endowed with superpowers.

headline: Casey’s Confirms Talks With 7-Eleven
text: Casey’s General Stores on Thursday confirmed that 7-Eleven was the mystery bidder with whom it has been  having discussions on a deal as Casey’s tries to sidestep an unwanted offer from Alimentation Couche-Tard.

headline: Bid Puts Spotlight on Crucial Player in Potash
text: It is hardly a household word like, say, the oil cartel OPEC. That is why Canpotex, an organization with a corner on Canada’s potash production, used to go about its business in nearly complete obscurity.

headline: Prabal Gurung | First Look Challenge
text: Play high-fashion stylist and put together looks with the images from Prabal Gurung’s spring/summer 2011 collection, below. (Be sure to use at least three looks from the new collection.) Two lucky winners will be chosen by the designer and announced on Sept. 14. Each winner will receive a ticket to Prabal’s next New York show in February 2011 and a tour of his garment-district studio. The winning sets will also be showcased on The Moment, Polyvore and on our Facebook page. Full contest details can be found at http://www.polyvore.com/cgi/contest.rules?id=204817.

headline: Aboriginal Teenager’s Australian Road Trip
text: “There’s nothing I would rather be/Than to be an Aborigine/And watch you take my precious land away,” go the words to the politically barbed singalong that rings out in “Bran Nue Dae,” a deceptively slap-happy Australian pop fable set in the late 1960s.

headline: Excerpt: 'Outsourced'
text: The new NBC comedy is about a call center in India.

headline: Movements Expanded and Redefined
text: ONE thing about art objects: they never shut up.

headline: Excerpt: 'My Generation'
text: The new ABC mock-documentary series revisits a group of high school graduates 10 years later.

headline: Globetrotting While Staying Close to Home
text: Last year, for whatever reason  the economy, accidents of scheduling  our encyclopedic museums fell short on global mojo. Across the country ambitious shows of non-Western art were scarce. When this happens, history gets stalled; we get small. In the most culturally interconnected time ever, familiarity with the art of the rest of the world, which means exposure to other ideas and values, just makes practical sense: it keeps us in the cosmopolitan loop, makes us full citizens. When the art isn’t there and in clarifying contexts, we drop back on the learning curve when we should be moving ahead.

headline: Final: Saints 14, Vikings 9
text: The Fifth Down will be providing live analysis and perhaps some sarcastic asides during tonight’s N.F.L. season opener between the Minnesota Vikings and the New Orleans Saints.

headline: Apple Gives App Developers Its Review Guidelines
text: Apple, which keeps a tight lid on its products and inner workings, is loosening up a little.

headline: Optimism Breeds Opportunity
text: FOR those who care about Architecture with a capital A there will be plenty of new buildings to consider in the coming year, many of them showing off an unexpected optimism amid a trying global economy.

headline: ARM Mounts Next Offensive Against Intel
text: With its latest product release, the chip designer ARM may find it tough to maintain its tradition of understated British talking points. It would seem that some pomp and circumstance has been put on order.

headline: Enshrining an Extraordinary Poet of the Keyboard, Quirks and All
text: The Canadian pianist Glenn Gould, who died at 50 in 1982, has been a figure of fascination since he burst onto the classical music scene, with startling virtuosity and an unusual brand of flamboyance, in the 1950s. His interpretations of the piano repertory — the work of Bach in particular — were fresh and provocative, and his self-presentation was both matinee-idol charismatic and winningly odd. As Gould’s celebrity grew, some of his peculiarities became as famous as his playing. He insisted on sitting in a special low-slung chair, so that his long arms seemed to angle upward to the keyboard. He wore scarves, gloves and overcoats in all kinds of weather. He rambled charmingly in interviews and hummed loudly onstage.

headline: German Banker Resigns Amid Outcry
text: STUTTGART, Germany  Heading off a potentially embarrassing public fight, Germany’s central bank announced Thursday that it had agreed to part ways on amicable terms with Thilo Sarrazin, the author of a recently released book on immigration that caused a storm here by accusing Muslims of refusing to integrate and of “dumbing down” German society.

headline: Dalí, Richter and Houdini in Chains!
text: Dates and touring sites are subject to change.

headline: Big Plans, Big Spaces in Los Angeles
text: THE two newest buildings on the Los Angeles County Museum of Art’s 20-acre campus were designed by Renzo Piano, the Italian architect who has in recent years become one of the go-to guys for museum expansions. The first building, the Broad Contemporary Art Museum, drew a lot of advance coverage in the news media before its unveiling in 2008, in part because of the unrealized hope that its patron, Eli Broad, would give part of his blue-chip collection to the museum to coincide with its opening. But while that building  a major exhibition space for contemporary work  has done a lot to raise the museum’s profile, the response to its design has been mixed.

headline: Copley Rubs Elbows With the Ancient Olmecs
text: THIS fall the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, will open its long-awaited $345 million wing for Art of the Americas. Designed by the English firm Foster & Partners and appended to the museum’s east end, the four-story structure extends the original 1907 Beaux Arts building’s low profile but dispenses with the neo-Classical columns, capitals, entablatures and whatnot in favor of severe, rectilinear blocks: a central glass atrium  12,184 square feet under a 63-foot ceiling  flanked by granite and glass pavilions containing 53 galleries.

headline: Chinese Food, the Wines of Germany, and a Debate
text: BERLIN  As this country continues its uneasy dialogue about integration, spurred on by an anti-immigrant book written by an executive of the central bank, the restaurant owner Jianhua Wu is busy selling wine, promoting wine, eagerly and enthusiastically sampling and sipping wine. Not just any wine, but German wine.

headline: Portraits Shed Light Through Gay Prism
text: ALTHOUGH museums are generally thought of as progressive, gay-theme shows are almost unheard of at the country’s biggest art institutions. This fall a particularly unlikely one will break with that tradition: the august National Portrait Gallery, part of the Smithsonian Institution.

headline: Germany: 2 Charged With Spying
text: Two Libyan men, identified only as 42-year-old Adel Ab. and 46-year-old Adel Al., have been charged with spying on members of Libya’s opposition in Germany, the federal prosecutor’s office in Karlsruhe said. They have been in custody since their arrest in May. Adel Ab. is suspected of having worked as an officer for the Libyan secret service, overseeing a network of informal collaborators who systematically spied on Libyan opposition members living in Germany and Western Europe. The other man is suspected of spying on exiled opposition members on behalf of Adel Ab., who paid him for the information.

headline: Nadal Wins to Reach a Familiar Open Rung
text: The United States Open semifinals have been a New York stop sign for Rafael Nadal until now, a signal he has been too weary or too harried to ignore.

headline: Betting on $2 Billion Sale: Will the Market Blanch?
text: The 15-story building that covers an entire block north of the meatpacking district looks more like a brick fortress than a sleek Park Avenue office tower.

headline: Tigers Continue to Play Spoiler vs. White Sox
text: Colby Rasmus hit two home runs, Albert Pujols and Skip Schumaker also homered, and Adam Wainwright bounced back from a three-run first inning to lead the St. Louis Cardinals past the Braves, 11-4, in Atlanta on Thursday. Atlanta dropped a game behind idle Philadelphia in the National League East with its sixth loss in eight games.

headline: The Month That Squeezes Democracy
text: Thursday was the first day of Rosh Hashana, the Jewish New Year. Saturday is the anniversary of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Neither event is a boon to democracy as it is practiced in New York.

headline: Professional Seducer Finally Meets His Match
text: It is up to the wiry, pint-size French heartthrob Romain Duris to carry Pascal Chaumeil’s “Heartbreaker,” an overlong mélange of romance and slapstick that looks and sounds more American than French. (That is not a compliment.)

headline: A Sneak Peek at the New Season of ‘Glee’
text: The making of TV’s best seriocomic musical dancefest spectacular.

headline: Pentagon Plan: Buying Books to Keep Secrets
text: WASHINGTON  Defense Department officials are negotiating to buy and destroy all 10,000 copies of the first printing of an Afghan war memoir they say contains intelligence secrets, according to two people familiar with the dispute.

headline: Turn On, Tune In, Drop By
text: For devotees of Rudolph Schindler’s architecture, the 1934 Buck House in Los Angeles is a pure expression of his mature Modernist style. Essentially a whitewashed house of cards built around a central garden, the Buck House features custom-designed components, including shelving, lighting and door hinges. A complex series of clerestory windows punctuates its cantilevered roof, balancing light and mass, exposure and privacy. The Buck House is an urban oasis, where life is meant to be lived in uncluttered serenity. To leave it untidy would be inappropriate. To make a mess would be almost criminal. But this is exactly what the current residents, the artists Justin Lowe and Jonah Freeman, have done.

headline: Revealing Little, and Hoping It Will Make Viewers Want More
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: The Story Behind a Wikipedia Entry
text: James Bridle founded a Web site called Booktwo in September 2006 to “investigate, analyze, catalog and debate the future of literature and the publishing industry.” Over the years the site has been home to some interesting debates over literature and its transition from paper to screens.

headline: Padres Win and Lose With the Best
text: Not too long ago, the National League West race seemed all but over. On Aug. 25, the Padres won their 76th game, giving them a comfortable six-and-a-half-game lead over the San Francisco Giants. For many fans, it was time to start thinking about postseason pitching rotations. But on Sunday, 11 days later, San Diego was still stuck at 76 wins, having lost 10 consecutive times, and its division lead over the Giants had shrunk to a single game.

headline: A West Bank Enclave Is on Edge
text: ARIEL, West Bank  When a group of Israeli artists recently refused to perform in the new theater at this large Jewish settlement, local residents reacted with a mixture of hurt and defiance.

headline: ‘All’s I Know . . .’
text: Jan Conaway writes: “The first time I heard someone say ‘All’s I know is . . .’ was in the 1980s. As I'm sure you have noticed, this annoying expression has since become more and more prevalent, and I realize there is no hope that it will disappear. Do you know where all’s actually originated?”

headline: Dissidents Claim Iran Is Building a New Enrichment Site
text: WASHINGTON  A dissident group that had previously revealed the existence of several hidden nuclear sites in Iran claimed Thursday that it had evidence that the country was building another secret uranium enrichment plant.

headline: France: Calls to End Expulsions
text: The European Parliament urged France and other European states on Thursday “immediately to suspend all expulsions of Roma.” The resolution was nonbinding but stung French officials. Immigration Minister Eric Besson, left, in Bucharest for talks with Romanian authorities, said it was “out of the question” for France to suspend the deportations of foreigners who had stayed beyond their visas. “The European Parliament has exceeded its prerogatives, and we are certainly not going to comply with a political diktat,” Mr. Besson said. France has been asking Romania and Bulgaria to do more to integrate their Roma populations using European aid money. Also in Bucharest, European Minister Pierre Lellouche said that “France will call for commitments on police and judiciary cooperation, the fight against human trafficking and integration of Roma in Romania, as part of a national emergency plan spanning 2010-2013.”

headline: Britain: Phone Hacking Inquiry Approved
text: The House of Commons on Thursday approved a new parliamentary inquiry into the journalistic use of phone hacking, the practice of illegally intercepting cellphone messages, moving the matter to the Standards and Privileges Committee, which is to meet on Tuesday. Lawmakers in Parliament attacked the practices of tabloids in general and, in particular, those of News of the World, the News International-owned tabloid whose use of phone hacking several years ago has touched off a current furor. Tom Watson, a Labour member of Parliament, said lawmakers should stop being “scared” of the news media. “The barons of the media with their red-topped assassins are the biggest beasts of the modern jungle,” he said. “They have no predators, they are untouchable, they laugh at the law, they sneer at Parliament, they have the power to hurt us and they do so with gusto and precision.”

headline: This New House
text: With the world quickly using up its fossil fuels and driving itself further toward irreversible climate change, it’s easy to fall into despair about the future of domestic life. Cheap energy, land, water and building materials have made the last century of American homebuilding a story of ever-expanding luxury. Arguably, all of these will become scarce and expensive over the next 50 years. Will our children’s homes be anything as comfortable and expansive as our own?

headline: South Africa: Murder Rate Falls to Lowest Level Since Apartheid
text: Long plagued by violent crime, South Africa saw its murder rate decline by 8.6 percent over the past year to its lowest level since the end of apartheid. The number of murders has fallen to 16,834 in the past year, from 26,877 in 1995-96. Crime statistics released Thursday also showed a 10.4 percent drop in street robberies, and a 6.8 percent decline in carjackings, while home robberies rose 1.9 percent. The murder decline was singled out by police officials. “Of all the crimes, this is the one category you cannot easily cheat,” Police Minister Nathi Mthethwa said. “In other words, the fact that such a crime is counted based on the actual bodies makes it more reliable." He said greater police visibility on the streets and support from communities had helped lower crime rates.

headline: Palin Taps an Atlantic Grizzly
text: The “Mama Grizzly” club has a new member.

headline: It’s Late Summer, and the Phillies Are on the Move
text: PHILADELPHIA  It is nice to have options, in your wardrobe and your pitching staff. Just ask Ruben Amaro, the general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: Alaska Senator Could Announce Revived Candidacy
text: Just a few weeks ago, Joe Miller was casting Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska as part of a broken Republican establishment, an emblem of everything he wanted to fix about Washington. At one point, he even accused the Republican Party organization that backed her, the National Republican Senatorial Committee, of trying to “skew” the results of the Alaska primary on her behalf.

headline: Pettitte Rescues His Reputation With Stability
text: Trenton

headline: Tackling the Economy, and the Politics
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Chicago, the Legacies of the Two Mayors Daley
text: To the Editor:

headline: Talking Is Struggle for Kuchar; Playing Isn’t
text: LEMONT, Ill. — As befits his newfound stature as the golfer to spend the most time in or around the lead, Matt Kuchar has had plenty to say all year about the consistent run of good form that has lifted him to the top of the PGA Tour money list and the FedEx Cup points list.

headline: Paperbacks Are Better
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pregnant, but Not What She Expected
text: “Hideaway,” a French drama with lulling quiets and an undertow of emotional violence, gets off to an unpromising start with two addicts doing what they do best, nodding out and shooting up. The woman in bed, Mousse (Isabelle Carré), is sleeping or passed out, her hair spilling around her head. Her lover, Louis (Melvil Poupaud), is playing the guitar, his dirty fingers finding the notes as a cigarette burns between his lips. But he’s barely more animate and he soon fades, this time for good. Done in by a bad fix, he dies less than 11 minutes into “Hideaway,” upending Mousse’s life and perhaps our expectations for this story.

headline: Somewhere Man
text: Back in 1994, in the afterglow of his first big role  playing the doomed fifth Beatle, Stuart Sutcliffe, in “Backbeat”  Stephen Dorff did what any self-respecting young actor might do when the checks start coming in. He moved into the Chateau Marmont. “I had some money and I didn’t have a place to live,” Dorff, now 37, explained during a recent stopover in Manhattan. “So I said, ‘You know what? I’m checking into the Chateau.’ ” He toasted his 21st birthday with a “wild party” in one of the four bungalows. The premiere bash for “Backbeat” was held in its famous garden, where 700 guests, including Pia Zadora, Tori Spelling and Keith Richards, jockeyed for chicken skewers and face time with the newly minted star. Life at the Chateau was grand  for a while. “It got to the point where my business manager called and said, ‘Stephen, you need to take a movie or get a job, ’cause you’re out of money.’ And I said, ‘O.K., I guess I’m moving out.’ ”

headline: In Adding Book Section, the Journal Bucks Trend
text: In the last few years, newspapers including The Washington Post, The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune and The Boston Globe have ended their freestanding book review sections.

headline: Highway Stars
text: It’s Saturday, 7:15 a.m., and a thick June fog blankets San Francisco Bay. Mister Mort is wearing a blue bandanna fastened with a beaded Native American bolo clasp, a T-shirt with a solid pattern of tiny American flags and a pair of vintage camouflage pants. “This whole outfit is flea market,” he assures me, clearing his black hair from his brow as he settles into the back seat of a black 2004 Toyota Tacoma pickup. His buddy Jay has one hand on the steering wheel, the other cupping an iPhone. Beneath a vintage L. L. Bean chamois button-down, he wears a threadbare Black Flag T-shirt. The look is complemented by a ship’s lanyard bracelet and an anchor tattoo on his ring finger as well as his newest body ink  the words old salt printed beneath his right bicep. “I have an unhealthy fascination with maritime themes,” he says as he guns the engine for the start of another in a series of weekend style-hunting rambles they refer to as Jay and Mister Mort’s Truck Bed.

headline: Lazio’s Ties to Banking Industry Haunt His Bid for Governor
text: In 2008, JPMorgan Chase had a problem. A bill that threatened the profits of its lucrative credit card business had the potential to gain momentum in Congress. But the bank had a stable of lobbyists on its payroll ready to plead its case, including a well-connected rainmaker, former Representative Rick A. Lazio.

headline: Combat Game Goes Too Far for Military
text: LEAVENWORTH, Kan.  Sgt. First Class Brian Hampton knows it is just a video game. But the details are unnervingly familiar: the uniforms, the weapons, even the military bases and desert towns where the action is set. Each time Sergeant Hampton, a veteran of the war in Afghanistan, plays, his heart rate spikes, his breathing quickens and his muscles tense.

headline: Arrests in Bahrain: The Government’s View
text: To the Editor:

headline: Read the Report
text: Iran has spent the last four years ignoring the United Nations’ order to stop enriching uranium. And far too many of the world’s major players have spent the last four years ignoring Iran’s defiance.

headline: Man Tied to Missing Art Is Charged With Fraud
text: The case of a portrait by a 19th-century French painter that supposedly disappeared after a night of drinking by the man who had it took another twist on Thursday.

headline: A Sooner State Story of Better Family Unity Through Wrestling
text: The schmaltzy sports movie “Legendary” is a kind of contemporary answer to the old Charles Atlas ad in which a 97-pound weakling develops muscles and triumphantly punches out the bully at the beach. Here, he is Cal Chetley (Devon Graye), a bookish 135-pound Oklahoma high school student taunted by his classmates, who lives with his salty widowed mother, Sharon (Patricia Clarkson).

headline: The Effort Is the Prize
text: An earlier post highlighted the evidence that in many arenas, purposeful practice is the key to high performance. In other words, top performers in complex fields like medicine, math and chess become that way through repeated and focused practice that builds their skills until their performance seems almost super-human — rather than being born with highly exceptional skill.

headline: U.S. Urges Iraqis to Try New Plan to Share Power
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is encouraging a major new power-sharing arrangement in Iraq that could retain Nuri Kamal al-Maliki as prime minister but in a coalition that would significantly curb his authority.

headline: Transcript: Vice President Biden on Progress and Lingering Threats in Iraq
text: Following is a transcript by The New York Times of an interview with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. after his meetings in Baghdad and the change of mission ceremony at Camp Victory on Sept. 1. The questions by Michael R. Gordon are paraphrased. [Read the accompanying story by Michael R. Gordon and Anthony Shadid on the Obama administration’s push for a power-sharing arrangement to end the political stalemate in Iraq.]

headline: Unrequited Passion on the Cusp of 30
text: Another wedding movie, another 90-plus minutes of half-baked suspense wondering whether the bride- and groom-to-be will go through with the ceremony or back out at the last second. There you have the outline of “The Romantics,” a formulaic rom-com with an Ivy League pedigree and a higher-than-average SAT verbal score.

headline: A Rock Impresario Gambles on ‘Spider-Man’
text: Nearly a hundred feet above the stage of Broadway’s Foxwoods Theater, Michael Cohl wrapped his right hand around one of the cables that will soon fly actors over the audience at the musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.” For a moment Mr. Cohl, the accidental producer of the most expensive show in Broadway history, was on top of the theater world, and appropriately so: he is the money man who after years of delays has sent “Spider-Man” airborne. Thanks to him, theatergoers will get to see for themselves if it soars, or falls to earth.

headline: Fair Courts at Risk
text: The nature of state judicial elections has changed dramatically in recent years, and not for the better.

headline: Elite Field Taking Shape for Fifth Avenue Mile
text: The two-time Olympic medalist Bernard Lagat will be joined by his fellow Olympians Leonel Manzano and Nick Willis; the defending champion, Andy Baddeley of England; and the American mile record-holder Alan Webb in the Fifth Avenue Mile on Sept. 26, the New York Road Runners announced. The women’s field will include last year’s champion, Shannon Rowbury; the past champions Sara Hall and Carmen Douma-Hussar; as well as Molly Huddle, the American record-holder at 5,000 meters, and Kalkidan Gezahegn of Ethiopia, the world indoor champion in the 1,500.

headline: Secret Tape Has Police Pressing Ticket Quotas
text: For nearly every New Yorker who has received a summons in the city — caught at a checkpoint monitoring seat-belt use, or approached by a small army of police officers descending on illegally parked cars — quotas are a maddening fact of life.

headline: On a Brooklyn Street, a Simmering Feud and a Violent Death
text: With a songbird’s voice, a tart tongue and, occasionally, an iron fist, Patricia Wilson stood sentry over her patch of Brooklyn for nearly two decades, a town crier who saw everything and never shrank from a fight.

headline: Making Prisons Safer
text: Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. has spent nearly 15 months weighing new mandatory rape prevention policies for federal prisons and state correctional institutions that receive federal money. The policies, which are due this fall, need to be as tough as possible.

headline: Lennon’s Fave; Do You Know Him?
text: In 1968, when asked to name his favorite American rock group, John Lennon replied “Nilsson,” which was of course not a group at all but a Brooklyn-born, Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter named Harry Nilsson. To casual browsers in the pop-culture past, Nilsson, who died in 1994 at 52, is perhaps best known for a song he sang but did not write — Fred Neil’s “Everybody’s Talkin,’ ” from the film “Midnight Cowboy.” Those with longer, more detailed memories will also recall a wonderful animated children’s movie called “The Point!” and a lot of great songs, including one (“You’re Breakin’ My Heart”) that married a bouncy tune to a profane kiss-off more than a quarter-century before Cee-Lo came up with more or less the same idea.

headline: Court Rejects a City’s Efforts to Restrict Immigrants
text: A federal appeals court on Thursday upheld a lower-court ruling striking down ordinances adopted by the City of Hazleton, Pa., that banned illegal immigrants from renting housing or being employed there.

headline: E.P.A. to Study Chemicals Used to Tap Natural Gas
text: The Environmental Protection Agency sent letters to nine drilling companies on Thursday requesting detailed information about the chemicals contained in fluids used to crack open underground rock formations in the hunt for oil and natural gas.

headline: The Frozen War in Korea
text: “Chosin,” a documentary about the two weeks of fighting around the Chosin Reservoir that became the emblem of the brutality and privations of the Korean War, is an inside job. The director, Brian Iglesias, and his co-writer, Anton Sattler, are former Marines, and the film was supported by a web of veterans’ and Korean War legacy groups. It consists almost entirely of American survivors of the battle — the “Chosin few” — talking about the surreal horrors they experienced.

headline: An Invisible Chief Justice
text: The Pew Research Center asked people this summer to identify the current chief justice of the United States from among four possibilities: John Roberts, Thurgood Marshall, John Paul Stevens and Harry Reid. Only 28 percent correctly picked Chief Justice Roberts. The late Thurgood Marshall came in second, with 8 percent. Fifty-three percent could not make a selection, answering “don’t know.”

headline: Gentle Annie Folds Her Hand
text: Of all the ways to socialize in the city, for Annie Ettinger, nothing beats flashing four of a kind at a table of obsessive poker players. She raked in $150 with that hand at one of her countless all-night poker games in roaming illegal dens across the last 70 years.

headline: Budget Woes Hit Defense Lawyers for the Indigent
text: OZARK, Mo.  Some public defenders in Missouri say the stressed state budget is interfering with their ability to provide poor defendants with their constitutional right to a lawyer.

headline: After 3 Skip Hospital Visit, 3 Others Work as Volunteers
text: When three Mets helped volunteers fill care packages near ground zero for the crew of the U.S.S. New York on Thursday, there were no questions about which teammates were not there.

headline: Scott, Star in New York With Jets, Can’t Put Ties to Baltimore Aside
text: Jets linebacker Bart Scott will never forget the seven seasons he spent in Baltimore. The Ravens were the first team that believed in him, the only team that offered him a chance at a workout.

headline: Ipod Redux
text: David Pogue looks at iPods over the years and reviews this year's iPod Shuffle and iPod Nano.

headline: A Violent Homage to Genre Films
text: With its deliberate clumsiness, its seemingly random juxtapositions and a handmade look achieved through slavish attention to film stock, lighting, fashions and furnishings, Frankie Latina’s “Modus Operandi” bears a greater surface resemblance to the 1960s and ’70s genre films to which it pays homage than Quentin Tarantino and Robert Rodriguez’s “Grindhouse” did.

headline: A Late-Life Relationship
text: Is there an age limit for meeting cute? Apparently not, because Nik Fackler has his lead characters do it in “Lovely, Still,” and they are played by Ellen Burstyn, now 77, and Martin Landau, 82.

headline: Friday: Fist Bump
text: PUZZLE NOTES — In honor of this 1995 platinum rap hit and this 2009 Grammy winner, I’ve resurrected an earlier “Squares” cartoon, now in living color.

headline: Coverage of Koran Case Stirs Questions on Media Role
text: A renegade pastor and his tiny flock set fire to a Koran on a street corner, and made sure to capture it on film. And they were ignored.

headline: Retrieving Hostages in Brazil
text: A fly-on-the-wall documentary that plays like “Cops,” only with fewer drunks, “Sequestro (Kidnapping)” follows the day-to-day operations of the anti-kidnapping division of the São Paulo Police Department in Brazil.

headline: Germany Moves to Lift Ban on Long Distance Bus Trips
text: FRANKFURT — Sometime next year, budget-conscious Germans will climb aboard a bus in Frankfurt and make a trip that has been unheard-of for decades.

headline: For Giants, the Run Is an Early Priority
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  After last season, the Giants’ running backs had scar tissue, both visible and unseen. The team’s normally strong rushing attack slowed because of sore knees and ankles. That, in turn, wounded the Giants’ pride.

headline: Trading Away the Stimulus
text: Washington

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,409 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,261 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans Thursday:

headline: Goldman Fined in Britain for Not Disclosing a U.S. Inquiry
text: The British securities regulator said Thursday that it had fined Goldman Sachs £17.5 million, or nearly $27 million, for not disclosing the Securities and Exchange Commission’s inquiry into the synthetic collateralized debt obligation known as Abacus.

headline: Things Could Be Worse
text: TOKYO

headline: Alienation in Farm Country
text: At the heart of “The Afterlight,” a minimalist mood poem to loss and alienation, a tiny songbird flutters in a wooden cage. Its presence, like the looming solar eclipse, warns us of heavy-handed metaphors but not of the intoxicating beauty with which they will be expressed.

headline: U.S. Steps Up Its Effort Against a European System of Fees on Airline Emissions
text: The United States has stepped up pressure to prevent Europe from charging foreign airlines for greenhouse gas emissions when they take off and land there.

headline: The Genteel Nation
text: Most people who lived in the year 1800 were scarcely richer than people who lived in the year 100,000 B.C. Their diets were no better. They were no taller, and they did not live longer.

headline: Washington’s Onetime Political Star Now the Underdog
text: WASHINGTON  By any measure, Mayor Adrian M. Fenty has suffered an astonishing reversal of political fortune.

headline: Two Ex-Champions With a Lot to Gain
text: This is the matchup tennis fans have been waiting for.

headline: For G.O.P., 3-Way Primary May Dash Hopes in a House Race on Long Island
text: It was supposed to be one of the best hunting grounds for Republicans hoping to pick off vulnerable Democrats in Congress: the First District of New York, in Suffolk County, where Timothy H. Bishop, a four-term representative in a part of Long Island with deeply conservative pockets, had become perilously identified with his party’s liberal wing.

headline: The Overscheduled Child
text: In “Race to Nowhere,” the first-time filmmaker Vicki Abeles tries to condense a Hydra-headed problem — America’s overstressed, overscheduled, overcompetitive school kids — into a single, clear narrative. The bad news is that she doesn’t entirely succeed; the good news is that she and her co-director, Jessica Congdon, admirably convey the complexity of the issue with considerably more compassion than prescription.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Top Adviser to Lead Panel on Economy
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday will promote a longtime economic adviser, Austan D. Goolsbee, to chairman of his Council of Economic Advisers, signaling continuity even as a high unemployment rate has left much of the public dissatisfied with administration policies.

headline: Film Series and Movies Listings
text: Movies

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: What She Saw: A Life’s Dispatches
text: The career of Ruth Gruber — reporter, photographer, civil servant, memoirist, humanitarian — is remarkable, and not only for a woman of her generation. Not that the indefatigable but mild-mannered Ms. Gruber, now 98, would trumpet its singularity; to her it probably simply makes sense, given the aspirations of her youth. But “Ahead of Time,” a graceful documentary portrait directed by Bob Richman, illustrates just how extraordinary her life has been.

headline: Niche Bookstores Provide More Than Books
text: Tucked in a corner of San Francisco’s quiet Noe Valley, Omnivore Books is an unlikely prospect for a small-business success story.

headline: Judge Rules That Military Policy Violates Rights of Gays
text: The “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy toward gay members of the military is unconstitutional, a federal judge in California ruled Thursday.

headline: Transit Board Candidates Press Ahead, Off the Radar
text: AC Transit, the bus agency that serves Oakland, Berkeley and much of the East Bay, is facing a financial crisis.

headline: Race for Richmond Mayor Focuses on Jobs, Casino and Class
text: Nathaniel Bates, a 78-year-old retired parole officer, has run unsuccessfully for mayor of Richmond three times. He kicked off his fourth campaign one recent afternoon by attacking the policies of the incumbent, the Green Party’s Gayle McLaughlin.

headline: An Ascendant Nimby Crowd Threatens the Fun
text: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Insurance Prerequisite in U.S. Plan Has a Catch
text: At first glance, the new Pre-existing Condition Insurance Plan, commonly known as I.P.X.P., sounds like welcome relief for jobless Illinoisans who have serious medical issues and are struggling with the loss of employer-financed health care.

headline: Next Mayor Will Face Tough Decisions to Solve Financial Mess
text: Everybody who is anybody in Chicago politics has been mentioned as a possible replacement for Mayor Richard M. Daley after his shocking retirement announcement this week. But rather than pondering their chances, potential candidates might take a good look at City Hall’s balance sheet and ask themselves another question: Who would want to deal with this mess?

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Sept. 9
text: Images from Thursday’s matches at the 2010 United States Open.

headline: For Kelly, First Win Is Just a First Step
text: Dan McGrath is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Before Emanuel Looks at Mayor’s Job, He Should Look in Mirror
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: What to Watch on Friday at the Open
text: This is the matchup tennis fans have been waiting for.

headline: Foster’s Wine Said to Attract More Buyout Interest
text: Two of the world’s biggest private equity firms, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and TPG, are potentially interested in Foster’s wine business, but they are not working on rival bids, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Word of the Day | comatose
text: comatose •\ˈko-mə-ˌtos, ˈkä-\• adjective

headline: As Wall Street Sheriff, Coffey Would Be Discreet
text: The New York state attorney general candidate Sean Coffey on Thursday said he was the only contender qualified to police Wall Street and called Democratic rivals career politicians fixated on becoming governor, Reuters reports.

headline: Inquiry Sifting Cause of Blast in the Bay Area
text: SAN BRUNO, Calif.  For weeks, residents in this community of trim suburban homes in the hills near San Francisco International Airport had reported catching the occasional whiff of natural gas in the bay breezes. Utility repair crews were regularly seen driving around the neighborhood.

headline: Saints Score, Then Sputter, in an Opening Victory
text: NEW ORLEANS  The evening started with a giant inflatable Lombardi Trophy being wheeled across the field on a Mardi Gras float. Before the Super Bowl banner had even stopped fluttering in the draft, it looked as if the New Orleans Saints, after waiting more than 40 years for their first championship, would make another title their plaything. The Superdome was shaking, Drew Brees was passing and it was as if the repeat button had been pushed on the Saints’ magical season.

headline: Public Schools Face Lawsuit Over Fees
text: Public schools across the nation, many facing budget shortfalls, have been charging students fees to use textbooks or to take required tests or courses.

headline: Thomas Guinzburg, Paris Review Co-Founder, Dies at 84
text: Thomas Guinzburg, an editor and publisher who helped create The Paris Review, the enduring lion of American literary magazines, and who later became president of Viking Press, the publishing house founded by his father, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Karl Lagerfeld Retains His Allure
text: At some point in the last few years Karl Lagerfeld became a rock star and he’s not sure how that happened or what it is, exactly, that people are responding to. “That’s a good question,” he said on Thursday night in SoHo, his ponytail bobbing. “But I must say it’s very flattering. Many of the people in the crowd are young.”

headline: A Dual Strategy at Deutsche Bank
text: A Dual Strategy

headline: China Trade Surplus Narrows as Imports Jump
text: HONG KONG  A surprisingly large increase in imports caused China’s trade surplus to narrow in August, data released Friday showed.

headline: Wall Street Extends Its Rally
text: Stocks extended their September rally on Thursday after more encouraging news on the job market, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Breaking Out of the Mold
text: Édgar Ramírez, 'Carlos'

headline: News Quiz | September 10, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Faces to Watch
text: Clips from five breakthrough performances of the season.

headline: U.S. Urges I.M.F. to Expand Role of Growing Economies
text: In a move that has met with resistance in Europe, the United States is pushing to reduce the Continent’s influence over the International Monetary Fund and grant more of a say to economies outside of Europe that are growing and leading the global recovery.

headline: Top Adviser to Lead Panel on Economy
text: President Obama on Friday will promote a longtime economic adviser, Austan D. Goolsbee, to chairman of his Council of Economic Advisers, signaling continuity even as a high unemployment rate has left much of the public dissatisfied with administration policies.

headline: Betting on $2 Billion Sale: Will the Market Blanch?
text: The 15-story building that covers an entire block north of the meatpacking district looks more like a brick fortress than a sleek Park Avenue office tower.

headline: S.E.C. Said to Investigate Funds of Funds
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating investment advisory firms that channel investors’ money into hedge funds, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Snaste
text: Today’s word, in association with the formidable Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Rogers ‘Bullish’ on Japan’s Economy
text: Ed Rogers, chief executive officer at Rogers Investment Advisors K.K., a Tokyo-based fund-of-hedge-funds adviser, struck an optimistic tone over the outlook for the Japanese economy and investing in the nation’s stocks through hedge funds, in an interview with Bloomberg Television.

headline: Test Yourself | History, September 10, 2010
text: Test your knowledge of history with today’s question about the events of September 11, 2001, from On This Day in History.

headline: The Public’s Change of Heart
text: Since his election, Barack Obama’s approval ratings have slid steadily — as they often do for presidents during their first term — presenting a sharp contrast to the last election season. Just two years ago, most Democrats did all they could to associate themselves with Mr. Obama. During the midterms, however, Republicans are using his name as ammunition against their opponents. Below, Mr. Obama’s approval ratings in two states with close Senate races, and how candidates there are using his name in their campaigns.

headline: PPL to Sell Plant Interests to LS Power
text: PPL Corporation, the electricity supplier, is set to sell interests in some of its power stations to the LS Power subsidiary LS Power Equity Advisors for about $381 million, the company announced Thursday.

headline: Fashion Week Quiz
text: Complete Coverage: Spring 2011 Fashion Week

headline: What Do You Remember About Sept. 11, 2001?
text: Where were you nine years ago Saturday? What do you remember about that day or the days immediately after? If you’re in junior high, high school or even the first years of college now, you may have been too little then to have been aware of what was happening on the day itself. If so, what have you heard from adults or older friends or relatives about what those days and weeks were like?

headline: Anniversary of a Tragedy
text: Note: For this special 9/11 edition of 6 Q’s About the News, we are posing questions for which answers can be found on the Times Topics page about September 11, 2001. Use the short overview written by N.R. Kleinfield, as well as the articles and multimedia you can find on the page itself.

headline: QR National Set for $2.8 Billion in Loans Before Listing
text: QR National, Australia’s largest transport and logistics business, will likely agree to about 3 billion Australian dollars ($2.8 billion) of loans from as many as 10 lenders next week ahead of a planned share listing, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people familiar with the matter.

headline: New Rule Could Cut Into Earnings From I.P.O.’s
text: The largest brokerages in the United States say a provision in the regulatory reform legislation passed in July could hurt their lucrative sales of shares in initial public offerings, Reuters reported.

headline: Sanofi Stands by Previous Genzyme Offer
text: Sanofi-Aventis, the French drug maker, poured cold water on reports it had raised its offer for Genzyme, saying it was sticking to its bid of $18.5 billion, or $69 per share, Reuters reported.

headline: Shanghai Pharma Plans $1.2 Billion Hong Kong I.P.O.
text: Shanghai Pharmaceuticals, the Chinese partner of Roche Holding, said Wednesday it planned to raise at least 8 billion yuan ($1.2 billion) through a public share offering in Hong Kong to fund acquisitions, Reuters reported.

headline: Nomura Expanding Into North America
text: In its bid to become a top global brand, the Japanese investment bank Nomura is steadily expanding into North America, setting up offices in Houston and Toronto this month and employing a team of natural-resource bankers, The Wall Street Journal reports.

headline: Trichet Says E.U.’s Profligate Members Should Lose Vote
text: Jean-Claude Trichet, president of the European Central Bank, has suggested a punishment for members of the euro zone that contravene the financial laws of the region, a temporary ban from political decision-making in the region,  The Financial Times reported.

headline: AIA Said to Sign Distribution Deal With I.C.B.C.
text: AIA, an Asian arm of American International Group, has signed a distribution deal with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, affirming its position as China’s top foreign life assurer as it prepares for its November scheduled initial public offering, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Dubai World Finalizes Restructuring
text: Dubai World, the emirate’s state-run investment arm, said Friday that 99 percent of its creditors had agreed to the terms for restructuring $24.9 billion worth of debt, less than a year after the troubled conglomerate spooked global markets when it stopped paying interest on loans accumulated before the financial crisis.

headline: Judge Reinstates eBay’s 28.4% Craigslist Stake
text: A judge on Thursday reinstated eBay‘s 28.4 percent stake in Craigslist, but allowed the classifieds site to keep eBay off its board, Reuters reported.

headline: Fashionably Bad Teeth
text: Today’s idea: Fashion has fallen for the gap — as in teeth, an article says. In an age of digitally and cosmetically assisted perfection, flawed chompers, not to mention scars and tattoos, denote authenticity.

headline: Korean Pension Fund Eyes Woori Finance Stake
text: National Pension Service, South Korea’s biggest investor, said it was open to teaming up with Hana Financial Group or joining others to buy a stake in Woori Finance Holdings, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Afghan Protests Against Koran Burning Turn Violent
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A fringe Florida preacher may have suspended his Koran-burning, but word reached Afghanistan too late for 24-year-old Muhammed Daoud. He was shot to death during a protest outside a NATO base in western Afghanistan, according to Afghan officials.

headline: Lehman Investigation Said to Be Closing In
text: In the Securities and Exchange Commission‘s investigation into the fall of Lehman Brothers, scrutiny has turned to an accounting maneuver that artificially lowered the bank’s debt levels, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Craft Brews in the Land of Vino
text: Italy’s flourishing craft brew scene has so seized the capital that it’s tempting to predict that beer may soon eclipse wine as the Roman drink of choice. In the past 15 years, a smattering of small producers based primarily in the north has grown into a strong crop of more than 250 small microbreweries representing every national region. Names like Birra del Borgo, Birrificio Italiano and Le Baladin have gained international acclaim, and there are plenty of other noteworthy producers to look out for and no shortage of places in Rome where you can find their beers.

headline: Week 1 N.F.L. Matchups
text: Cowboys at RedskinsSunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Cowboys by 3 1/2

headline: For Whom Does the Health Insurance Broker Work?
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Deutsche Poised for $11.4 Billion Share Issue
text: Deutsche Bank, the largest German lender, is set to announce a share issue of up to 9 billion euros as it prepares for more stringent banking regulations and seeks to acquire a larger stake in Postbank, a person with direct knowledge of the matter told DealBook.

headline: Tip of the Week: Time Travel in Windows 7
text: The clock in the Windows 7 task bar gives you the time of day when you click on it, but you’re not stuck with just one time zone. To add more clocks, go to the Start menu, choose Control Panel and click on Clock, Language and Region. Next, click on Date and Time. (You can also click in the time in the Taskbar to open up the clock and calendar display and then click on “Change date and time settings.”)

headline: A Businesswoman Struggles to Get Credit
text: Just as banks are beginning to loosen up the reins a bit, the credit-card companies have been ratcheting up their restrictions — something that can have a major impact on small-business owners, many of whom use credit cards to finance short-term purchases.

headline: Reviving Ground Zero
text: The Times’s David W. Dunlap describes how the new World Trade Center complex is taking shape.

headline: Fashion’s Night Out Gets a Lift From VW
text: Awash in klieg lights and air kisses, New York’s Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week attendees are also willing participants in many lifestyle brands’ marketing experiments. Notwithstanding the corporate sponsor, however, many companies choose to aim at consumers who have no intention of braving Lincoln Center.

headline: Nokia Turns to Microsoft for New Chief Executive
text: Nokia, the cellphone maker, replaced its chief executive, Olli-Pekka Kallasvuo, on Friday with the head of Microsoft’s business unit in a bid to turn around the handset maker’s struggling smartphone lineup and stop a decline in market share in the United States, The New York Times’s Kevin J. O’Brien writes.

headline: Oops At The OECD
text: Regular readers may recall that back in May I fulminated about the OECD Economic Outlook. The Paris-based OECD is Conventional Wisdom Central; and in May, it dutifully relayed the conventional wisdom that advanced nations should start cutting spending and, even more remarkably, raising interest rates right away. As I pointed out, this made no sense even in terms of the OECD’s own forecasts, which said that unemployment would remain very high and inflation very low for years to come.

headline: Does It Matter if Ray Lewis Is Mad?
text: It wouldn’t seem to be a good idea to get Ray Lewis mad.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –What happens when your old buddy and your toughest boss are the same person? Mark Hurd’s about to find out.

headline: Fractal Inequality
text: William Easterly has a post comparing fractals and inequality, which is fine. But hey, I made that comparison many years ago!

headline: British Decline
text: Reading David Brooks today, I couldn’t help thinking of Bob Solow’s old line that efforts to explain Britain’s relative decline always end up in a “blaze of amateur sociology.” That’s not an attack on David; everyone does it — although I might point out that the reason so many smart kids go into finance, not manufacturing, is that the pay is much better.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Undead and Loving It
text: The manga list is teeming with new titles this week, including series that offer ghosts (“Bleach,” at No. 1), a different look at Alice, of Wonderland fame (“Alice in the Country of Hearts,” at No. 2), college relationships (“Junjo Romantica,” at No. 4) and vampires (“Chibi Vampire Airmail,” at No. 6).

headline: Bankers Hired for Jimmy Choo
text: Best-known for their glam role in “Sex and the City,” Jimmy Choo shoes may be getting a new owner.

headline: Now Online | T Men’s Fashion Fall 2010
text: Whether you fancy yourself a rugged individual, or simply want to dress like one, this is your season, and our fall men’s issue is here to guide the way. It starts with our cover star, Stephen Dorff, who in the course of his career has played a Beatle, a vampire, a transvestite, and in Sofia Coppola’s upcoming film, “Somewhere,” an actor whose career is on cruise control but whose life is about to veer into a ditch. Elsewhere in the issue, Jim Lewis visits the legendary photographer Bruce Davidson, whose Brooklyn Gang series from the 50’s still clicks today; Holly Brubach revisits the work of Gay Talese, the man who practically reinvented sports writing; and David Knowles hops in a truck with Mister Mort and Jay Carroll in search of great American style. And speaking of trips, Steve Pulimood drops in on the artists Justin Lowe and Jonah Freeman as they transform an icon of modernist design into a swinging LSD safe house.

headline: JPMorgan and UBS Said to Test BlackBerry Rivals
text: JPMorgan Chase may soon let employees use iPhones for corporate e-mail, making it an alternative to Research in Motion‘s BlackBerry  for the first time, two people familiar with the situation told Bloomberg News.

headline: No Ticket Quotas? A Tape Suggests Otherwise
text: Officially and forever, the position of the New York Police Department has been that there is no such thing as quotas and that any driver who complains of receiving a summons only because officers are forced to write a certain number of tickets per day or week or month is simply trying to shift blame.

headline: Coffice
text: Portmanteau term used in South Korea to describe how coffee houses are used for work, study and socialising.(Coff[ee] + [Off]ice.)

headline: E.P.A. Meeting Stalled by Security and Cost
text: The Environmental Protection Agency has been on something of a listening tour lately, holding public meetings around the country where stakeholders concerned about hydraulic fracturing can share their thoughts with the agency.

headline: Indus River Outsider
text: Some weeks ago I flew from New York to Islamabad, Pakistan, to experience summer in the country where my parents were born and where I lived as a child. I love summer in Pakistan: the mangoes, the monsoon and, this year, Ramadan, the mystical month of the Islamic calendar, all came in August. A week after I landed, the monsoon clouds arrived, but this time the Indus River swelled and burst its banks: my vacation coincided with the largest natural disaster in Pakistan’s history.

headline: East Side of Manhattan, 8:02 A.M.
text: A five-alarm fire swept through the neighboring one-story buildings housing the Frontier diner and Byblos restaurant on East 39th Street at Third Avenue overnight; 12 firefighters and 2 emergency medical workers sustained minor injuries.

headline: Living to Be a Parent
text: Remember Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs? You learned about it in your intro psych course: a neat and tidy pyramid, with fulfillment of “physiological needs” at its base, then things like “safety,” “love,” “belonging” and “esteem” stacked on top, all capped by “self-actualization.”

headline: Is Greed Still Good?
text: On the one hand, you make lefty documentaries, like your recent admiring portrait of the Venezuelan president Hugo Chávez, and on the other you make Hollywood blockbusters like your new “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps.” Do you see “Wall Street” as a vehicle for making money?  It’s a vehicle for people who are mathematically inclined and love to make money.

headline: For Those Who Fall in Love Too Easily
text: “Therefore marriage is not to be entered into unadvisedly or lightly, but reverently, deliberately…” — Marriage Ceremony from “The Episcopal Book of Common Prayer”

headline: Hearing Things
text: I have seen the future of rock and roll, and it’s merch. Of course, band-branded merchandise has been a major part of the music business, big and small, for years. The Ramones sold more T-shirts than albums (and you can buy a T-shirt that says so). And box sets for superfans have become increasingly elaborate and pricey artlike objects. But merchandise is gaining momentum, and it’s not hard to imagine a time when a fan buys a sculpture, home décor item or other tangible good and gets the music as a kind of free soundtrack accompaniment.

headline: Debt Be Proud
text: Big bond offerings from Hewlett-Packard and Home Depot swelled U.S.investment-grade debt issuance to its highest weekly total since May 2008, Thomson Reuters data shows.

headline: New Malick Film, ‘The Tree of Life,’ Will Finally Live on Screen
text: It’s the cinematic equivalent of seeing Halley’s Comet twice in a lifetime: it looks as if moviegoers will actually be getting a new film from Terrence Malick in a mere six years since his previous release. Fox Searchlight announced that it had acquired “The Tree of Life,” the latest film by Mr. Malick, an auteur unencumbered by conventional measurements of time and who took a 20-year hiatus between his features “Days of Heaven” (in 1978) and “The Thin Red Line” (in 1998).

headline: Engineering Terror
text: They say they believe in freedom and share our values. They say a few bad apples shouldn’t bring down judgment on their entire kind. Don’t be fooled. Though they walk among us with impunity, they are, in the words of Henry Farrell, a political scientist at George Washington University, “a group that is notoriously associated with terrorist violence and fundamentalist political beliefs.”

headline: Sharing Medication
text: I work for a nonprofit organization that sometimes provides limited funds for our clients’ prescriptions. An impoverished client hoped we could fill his prescription for antiseizure medication. We could not because of a lack of money. I take the same drug, same strength, for a different and more minor condition and usually have extra at month’s end. I am tempted to anonymously share my drugs — illegal and possibly dangerous, but considering his suffering, is it really wrong? R.I., PONTIAC, MICH.

headline: Resources | World Religions
text: Updated: Oct. 2013

headline: The Public’s First Peek at Lincoln
text: At last, humans, sampling hors d’oeuvres and sipping prosecco, finally walked in that alien-looking, wedgelike building under the curvy lawn roof at Lincoln Center.

headline: The Heat of the Night
text: “I’m still having those fevers,” the voice over the telephone reported casually. “It’s been a month. Should I be worried?” Dr. John Henning Schumann, an internist and a close friend of the caller, was worried. His college friend often asked him medical questions and had mentioned a viral illness a few weeks earlier. If it never went away — that was concerning. Schumann told him to see his doctor immediately.

headline: In The Long Run, Some Of Us Are Very, Very Confused
text: Brad DeLong has some fun with Megan McArdle acting as if using present values to compare costs at different dates were some weird leftist idea. But it actually gets funnier: she asserts that

headline: Open House: Windblown Ashe and Rooting for Kim or Venus
text: Gerry Marzorati: Morning, Michael. Well, Rafael Nadal made quick work of Fernando Verdasco, who did not play badly. Note to parents: Want your son to grow up to be someone who can play tennis in a wind tunnel? LOTS of soccer. It’s the FOOTWORK, stupid. Rafa, for instance, stormed the net last night with little, little steps — and not only got there but made tiny, last-second, microclimatic adjustments. And unlike, say, Stanislaw Wawrinka or Mikhail Youzhny, he did not dump his resulting volleys into the net.

headline: Letters: Women Who Hit Very Hard
text: Dewey Nicks’s photo essay is both beautiful and a very concise demonstration of why Serena Williams is the best women’s tennis player in the world. Stosur and Jankovic look balletic, Clijsters looks serious, Dementieva and Zvonareva look glamorous. But Williams looks as if she has exactly one thing in mind: to use that tennis racket to sweep everyone out of her way.

headline: An Interview with Darin Strauss
text: Darin Strauss discusses his new memoir "Half a Life."

headline: Letters: You Are What You Speak
text: Guy Deutscher continues a tradition of blaming Benjamin Whorf for the “strong” linguistic determinism hypothesis (“language constrains thought”). But Whorf never made that claim. He argued for the “weak” version — that language influences thought. After several paragraphs attacking a straw-man Whorf, Deutscher also writes about the weak version, which is plenty interesting in itself.

headline: Complaint Box | Summer Deep-Freeze
text: My wife and I just spent 10 days on holiday in New York City. It was our first visit to New York — actually, our first visit to the United States. We had a wonderful time. There is only one issue I would like to comment on: air-conditioning.

headline: Letters: Can Preschoolers Be Depressed?
text: Despite her admirable developmental perspective, Pamela Paul fails to consider the effect of a sociocultural context that utterly ignores the developmental needs of 3- to 5-year-olds. When small children are expected to sit still, follow a schedule, even learn the alphabet — when curiosity, movement and nonconformity earn a “frowny face” — why are we surprised that so many feel sad, guilty and unworthy? No other culture treats children this age as we do. No wonder so many American kids are unhappy.

headline: Letter: Taking Stock
text: Roger Lowenstein does a terrible disservice to investors by comparing the paltry 2.58 percent real yield on bonds with the 8.5 percent earnings yield on stocks. This is like comparing apples to oranges and implies that stocks are cheap and can achieve far better returns than bonds.

headline: App Smart Extra: Great Art for the iPad
text: Apps can greatly enrich the museum experience, as this week’s App Smart column points out. But what if you’re in the mood to browse some art from the friendly confines of your living room?

headline: Letter: The Right Stuff
text: As a fact-checker from the mid-70s, I loved reading Heffernan’s Aug. 22 column. The phone was my best friend for checking everything from a manager’s name and title to a quotation from Jimmy Carter’s mom. And it was amazing how much writers would depend on the fact-checking process to clean up their lazy reporting. Now whatever I read on the Internet, I question. One ofmy best sources along with the very good fact-checking sites is Snopes.com. It’s a godsend for those pesky viral opinion e-mails that everyone takes for fact.

headline: Friday Reading: Evidence of Ticket Quotas
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Editors’ Choice
