text: THE WARMTH OF OTHER SUNS: The Epic Story of America’s Great Migration,  by Isabel Wilkerson (Random House, $30.) This masterly account of the exodus of blacks from the South between 1915 and 1970 explores parallels with earlier European immigration.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE GROUND TRUTH: The Untold Story of America Under Attack on 9/11,  by John Farmer (Riverhead, $16.) “Whether through unprecedented administrative incompetence or orchestrated mendacity, the American people were misled about the nation’s response to the 9/11 attacks,” writes Farmer, who was senior counsel to the 9/11 commission. His study of newly available transcripts from federal agencies refutes later claims by Dick Cheney and Paul Wolfowitz that the military was ready to shoot down United Airlines Flight 93 before it could hit Washington; in fact, the plane had already crashed by the time the Northeast Air Defense Sector learned of its hijacking. “No one told us anything,” one military pilot recalled.

headline: Netflix’s Missed Connection
text: Last Friday, Netflix shut down the social network features on its site. Surprising? Not really. Be honest: when was the last time you or anyone you knew ever referred to the “community” features on Netflix?

headline: Bell Canada to Retake Control of Canadian TV Network
text: QUEBEC  Despite an unhappy experience in the media business, Bell Canada, the telecommunications company, said Friday that it would retake control of CTV, the country’s largest private television broadcaster.

headline: Peter Som: Over the Rainbow
text: Peter Som’s prints have the intensity of Murano glass, which is pretty intense for a 9 a.m. fashion show. Purple, orange, silver — and that’s just in one jacket, ladies.

headline: The Early Word: White House News Conference
text: President Obama is scheduled to hold a news conference this morning at the White House where he is expected to announce that Austan D. Goolsbee will succeed Christina D. Romer as head of the White House Council of Economic Advisers.

headline: Obama’s Missed Opportunity: Answers From Matt Bai, Part II
text: 4:33 p.m. | Updated In his Political Times column on Wednesday, Matt Bai asserted that President Obama had missed an opportunity to rally the public behind his long-term initiative to restructure the economy. He is answering readers’ questions about the president’s approach and other top political issues this week. The first set of replies came yesterday.

headline: Archbishop Bans Pop Music at Funerals
text: On Thursday in Australia, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Melbourne announced a ban on the playing of pop music at funerals, which, he said, are not to be described as “a celebration of the life of” the deceased.

headline: Live-Blogging Obama’s News Conference
text: President Obama held his first full-scale White House news conference in three months and the first of the fall campaign season. He announced his promotion of the White House economist, Austan D. Goolsbee, to succeed Christina Romer as chairman of the president’s Council of Economic Advisers, and also addressed other issues of the day, including the Middle East peace talks and the debate over extending the Bush tax cuts.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Favre Shows Rust; Is It Permanent?
text: NEW ORLEANS – Brett Favre eased off the dais Thursday night, looking more bewildered than beaten by the Vikings’ 14-9 loss to the Saints in the National Football League’s season opener.

headline: A Belated Debate on Modified Beets
text: While genetically modified crops have been the focus of pitched battles in Europe for nearly a decade, they have slipped into America’s fields and onto its tables with hardly a peep. Although the technology was only developed in the 1980s, more than three-quarters of the nation’s corn, soy and sugar beets are now genetically altered. The figure is close to zero in many European countries.

headline: Morning T Video | Iman
text: Iman, the legendary model turned multihyphenate, kicks off the “Morning T” series of video interviews with T’s online director, Horacio Silva.

headline: Nikon Adds Three Coolpix Shooters
text: Nikon has announced three new Coolpix point-and-shoot cameras: the P7000 for demanding photographers, a midrange S8100 with a 10X zoom, and a slick touch-screen S80.

headline: What Does Nokia’s New Chief Mean for M.&A.?
text: Nokia‘s announcement Friday that it had chosen a senior Microsoft manager to become its next chief executive has provided fodder for debate in deal land, with analysts speculating on where Stephen Elop could take the cellphone maker that would rival Google and Apple in the smartphone sector, and whether a tie-up between Microsoft and Nokia would be possible.

headline: British Artists Protest a Possible Cut in Government Funds
text: The Tate Modern museum, the planned site earlier this week for a launch party for Tony Blair‘s memoir that was canceled in fear of protests, became the site of a different demonstration on Friday when artists gathered in front of the museum to rally against possible government cuts to arts spending, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Chanel Party
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.

headline: The Week Ahead: Sept. 12 — Sept. 18
text: Television

headline: 3-D Television: A Black-And-White Issue
text: To the Editor:

headline: Max’s Kansas City: ‘i Might Take a TRAIN...’.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bell Canada Retakes Control of TV Network
text: In an unanticipated reversal, Bell Canada, the telecommunications company, said Friday that it would retake control of CTV, the country’s largest private television broadcaster, The New York Times’s Ian Austen reported.

headline: Parenting, and the Meaning of Life
text: So begins my latest essay in The New York Times Magazine this weekend. It’s a look at the most interesting of questions — what is our purpose here? And also at the more practical ramifications of the varied answers to that question. Is it our biological goal to become the best version of ourselves that we can be? Or is it to raise children to be the best that they can be? Or perhaps these are one and the same?

headline: White House Spurns Solar Panel
text: Bill McKibben, an environmental campaigner from Vermont with a flair for showmanship, was rebuffed Friday morning in his effort to get the White House to reinstall one of the solar panels that President Jimmy Carter had placed on the White House roof.

headline: Week in Pictures, Sept. 10
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

headline: White House Puts Off Solar Enthusiasts
text: The “Put Solar On It” team of activists and Unity College students reached the White House today (actually the Old Executive Office Building) and was politely rebuffed after stating their case for putting solar panels back on the White House roof.

headline: Ravens Stress Getting Ball Into End Zone, Not Just Keeping It Out
text: Westminster, Md.

headline: Guilty Plea in Fraud by Adviser to Stars
text: Kenneth I. Starr, the New York investment adviser who once counted Hollywood celebrities like Al Pacino, Martin Scorsese and Sylvester Stallone as clients, pleaded guilty on Friday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to charges that he diverted tens of millions of dollars of his clients’ money to pay for his lavish lifestyle.

headline: Lincoln Restaurant’s First Course
text: Thursday night, to celebrate the debut of New York Fashion Week and the 50th anniversary of the nation’s largest arts center, actual food was served — and actually consumed — for the first time at Lincoln, the $20 million, 150-seat new high-end restaurant housed in an alien-looking, wedgelike building at Lincoln Center. Our colleague Glenn Collins was there and has the story in Diner’s Journal.

headline: The Smile of an Arkansas Quarterback Makes His Transfer Look Easy
text: College football is littered with quarterbacks who transfer and find their new destination just as unfulfilling. Changing universities could have been a cheerless path, too, for Arkansas quarterback Ryan Mallett, but he had something to go along with his immense skill: his smile.

headline: Week 2 College Football Matchups
text: In any other sport it’s ridiculous to claim that anything that happens in the second week of the season can win or lose a championship. But college football is not like any other sport, and the second week of the season features some of the biggest games of the year. Ohio State puts its national championship hopes (and Terrelle Pryor’s Heisman hopes) on the line as a tough and hungry Miami team comes to the Horseshoe in a rematch of the 2003 national championship. Last year’s national champion Crimson Tide hosts Penn State in a matchup that may be a little more lopsided, but features two of the nation’s most recognizable programs. Speaking of recognizable programs, how about Florida State traveling to Norman to take on Oklahoma? Oh, and there’s also Notre Dame hosting Michigan. Then like a cherry on top, we get an intriguing SEC East tilt between Georgia and South Carolina.

headline: Weekend Competition: Define Education
text: This weekend, to mark the new academic year, Schott’s Vocab is soliciting definitions of education:

headline: Getting a Guide for the Jungle of Individual Health Policies
text: THE new health law will be a boon to self-employed individuals, who typically pay more for insurance than those covered by group plans. But they will have to wait: the much-anticipated health insurance exchanges, which will provide an easy way for consumers to compare plans and offer federal subsidies to those who qualify, aren’t scheduled to go live until 2014.

headline: BP Hirings at Barclays: Building Up an Energy Team
text: Barclays Capital has hired seven sales executives from BP, in a move meant to bolster its energy trading business in North America, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

headline: Reaction to Judge’s Ruling on ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: A federal judge in California ruled Thursday that the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy toward gay members of the military is unconstitutional. As John Schwartz reports, Judge Virginia A. Phillips of Federal District Court struck down the rule in an opinion issued late in the day. The policy was signed into law in 1993 as a compromise that would allow gay and lesbian soldiers to serve in the military.

headline: Zvonareva Knocks Off Wozniacki to Reach Final
text: Russia’s 26-year-old veteran, Vera Zvonareva, shook off four broken strings to surge to a victory over top-seeded Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark, 6-4, 6-3, on Friday to enter the women’s singles finals at the United States Open, her second successive final in the world’s four most important championships.

headline: Using a Broker to Buy Health Insurance
text: Consumers who are shopping for their own health insurance have the option of hiring a broker — someone who will, free of charge, help you price and compare various plans, as explained in today’s Patient Money column.

headline: Starr Pleads Guilty to Fraud Charges
text: 1:43 p.m. | Updated The New York Times has more on Mr. Starr’s guilty plea.

headline: Wary Coronation
text: A SWEATY June night in Tennessee was one more milestone for Kings of Leon: headlining a major American rock festival in their home state. On June 10 they topped the bill at the Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival in Manchester, about 54 miles from where the band members grew up, in Franklin. Kings of Leon’s band members are the three sons of a preacher named Leon Followill  Caleb, Nathan and Jared Followill  and their cousin Matthew Followill; they are now based in Nashville.

headline: TimesCast | September 10, 2010
text: Scott Shane on a new report that warns of homegrown terrorist threats, reaction from Kabul to a Florida pastor's wavering plans to burn the Koran and an Arts and Leisure fall preview.

headline: Casting a Spell of Rattle and Ether
text: THE jury is still way out on Salem. A young threesome from Michigan  Jack Donoghue, John Holland and Heather Marlatt  the band makes an alluring sound: the synthetic rhythm-rattle of Southern hip-hop crossed with the amniotic floatiness of 1980s electronic pop.

headline: Roger Ebert Gives Thumbs Up to New ‘At the Movies’ Series
text: The balcony is reopened: less than a month after the final episode of “At the Movies,” the long-running cinema criticism show, was broadcast, Roger Ebert said he would bring back a version of the series that will be shown on public television next year.

headline: Dispatches From the Edge of the Sonic Frontier
text: THE history of Western classical music is rife with forgotten side roads, populated by composers and styles overlooked, marginalized or otherwise neglected. The Propensity of Sound, a five-concert series that the Issue Project Room in Gowanus, Brooklyn, will mount in late September, follows one such unfamiliar path. Presented in collaboration with the British experimental-music magazine The Wire, the series will focus on three groundbreaking composers: Pauline Oliveros, Eliane Radigue and Laurie Spiegel.

headline: A Lawsuit’s Miscues, and Public Defenders’ Misgivings
text: One of the more interesting revelations stemming from the arrest Thursday of Thomas A. Doyle on charges of fraud related to a 19th-century portrait was the existence of numerous inaccuracies in a lawsuit filed a week earlier related to the same painting.

headline: Video of Fire in San Francisco Suburb
text: As my colleagues Anahad O’Connor and Liz Robbins report, a fire killed four people and destroyed dozens of homes after an explosion fueled by a ruptured gas line tore through a San Francisco suburb Thursday night.

headline: Ristretto | Coffee Cart
text: On Tuesday, Eleven Madison Park reopened after a week of minor renovations and a substantial overhaul of its approach to fine dining. The restaurant also rethought coffee. It now has a dedicated barista working a La Marzocco in the back, as well as tableside coffee service: if you so desire, your meal will end with the spectacle of coffee prepared on a siphon or Chemex set up on a cart wheeled across the restaurant’s terrazzo floor.

headline: Two Tributes For Mahler
text: IT is somehow fitting that Mahler, with his proclivity for excess, should have two commemorative years in a row: the 150th anniversary of his birth in 2010 and the 100th of his death in 2011. Not that he needs them.

headline: Visions of India, Plum Fairies And a War
text: NO matter how much dance you see, and no matter how much you travel to see dance, there is always great dancing of which you’ve seen all too little. At two performances by the Indian dancer Madhavi Mudgal, an exemplar of the Odissi idiom, she struck me as an artist of a classical purity to be ranked with the most refined and luminous Western dancers, Mikhail Baryshnikov and Kyra Nichols. Ms. Mudgal’s lyricism was reminiscent of Margot Fonteyn’s; the connection of eyes, head and arms conjured up vast and eloquent arcs, in subtly eloquent interplay with the rhythm of her lower body.

headline: On Roofs and Walls, They’re Honoring Trisha Brown’s Work
text: TRISHA BROWN can’t be boxed in. Since the 1960s and ’70s her daredevil, articulate vision of dance has come to life on walls, rooftops, rafts, tree trunks and ceilings. She has accumulated movement  the art of building one action on another to create a sensual chain of motion  conquered opera and choreographed works so magnificent that even she has admitted to having love affairs with them. (“Glacial Decoy” and “Set and Reset” lead the pack.) She is one of the most important American artists, not just of her time but also beyond.

headline: How to Get Your Children to School
text: School is back in session. And depending where you live, you’ve had days or weeks to get back in the routine. Which means you are probably still foundering around every morning trying to get out the door, right?

headline: Isn’t It Early For City Ballet? Not This Year
text: IN New York the cultural new year begins in September with a sudden feast of dance (and every other art form) after the summer famine. But since the New York City Ballet took up residence at Lincoln Center in 1964, its fans  and who isn’t one?  have had to tough it out until late November, the beginning of the company’s winter season. And even then there was an avalanche of “Nutcrackers” to get through before the gloriously dense repertory programs, with Balanchine and Robbins favorites and eagerly awaited new works and debuts, began in early January.

headline: Well-Traveled Baton On Met’s Guest List
text: WHEN Fabio Luisi conducted Strauss’s “Elektra” at the Metropolitan Opera in December, he illuminated startling subtleties in his exciting interpretation of the score. Performances of Berg’s “Lulu” and Humperdinck’s “Hansel and Gretel” during the Met season also revealed his talent for taut, nuanced music making in varied repertory.

headline: Arabesques and Pirouettes on Parade
text: Dates are subject to change.

headline: Goldman Names Asset Management Chairman
text: Jim O’Neill, the Goldman Sachs economist best known for coining the BRIC acronym, has been named chairman of the firm’s asset management business.

headline: A Walking Tour of Rome at Night
text: Take an audio-guided tour, via an interactive map, of the Colosseum, the Forum and the Jewish Ghetto.

headline: A Wee Taste of Europe: Will Americans Bite?
text: THERE are two types of small cars in America. First, there are the bare-bones, price-is-the-entire-object ennui-boxes. These are the cars you end up driving when you stubbornly resist the $2-a-day upgrade at the rental counter.

headline: A Conductor’s Herculean Schedule
text: TWO of the most anticipated events of the new season are coming right up, and they both involve James Levine.

headline: ‘Tribute in Light’ Will Keep Shining, This Year and the Next
text: Most New Yorkers may not know exactly where they come from or who turns them on and off. But almost everyone in the New York region who has gazed into the night sky on Sept. 11 in recent years has come to expect to find twin beams of bluish-white light reaching from Lower Manhattan heavenward.

headline: The 3,000-Mile Oil Change Is Pretty Much History
text: I STILL remember learning from my father how to carefully remove a dipstick to check the oil level in our cars. It was drilled into me — along with turning off the lights when you left a room and clearing the plates off the table after dinner — that oil needs to be changed every 3,000 miles or so.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Richard Chai Love
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

headline: Extra Applause
text: MARTHA PLIMPTON 'Raising Hope'

headline: 2011 Ford Fiesta
text: The Fiesta is the exemplar of the domestic hatchback’s newfound respectability.

headline: Simple Summer Stir Fry
text: Farmers’ markets are overflowing with vegetables, making it the perfect time to heat up the wok and stir fry, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: Recommended Weekend Reading
text: We canvassed the latest in medical literature and consumer magazines so you don’t have to.

headline: Hip-Hop’s New Medium for Choice Words
text: It was early last Saturday morning, or perhaps very, very late the previous night, when the stream of emotional posts began appearing on Kanye West’s Twitter feed: “The media tried to demonize me,” “I felt the recession from the ownership side,” “I’m ready to get out of my own way,” “I’m sorry Taylor.”

headline: Pentagon Loosens Restrictions for Press in Guantánamo
text: The Pentagon has agreed to revise some of the rules that have restricted what journalists are free to report on from Guantánamo Bay, resolving a conflict that peaked in May when four reporters were expelled from the naval base there.

headline: The Baker’s Apprentice: Peach or Apple Pie
text: Emily Weinstein is learning to bake with the food writer and cookbook author Dorie Greenspan. This week, Sarabeth Levine, of Sarabeth’s Kitchen, steps in as a special guest instructor, per Dorie’s suggestion. She is an expert in all things pie. Dorie will return next week.

headline: Answering the Siren’s Call in a ’71 Plymouth
text: GLENN SOKOLOFSKY, perhaps the closest thing New York City has to a curator of police car history, recently recounted an interesting story about the New York Police Department’s early patrol cars.

headline: Chinese Bond Purchases
text: Regular readers may remember that I’ve spent more than a year trying to knock down the idea that the United States dare not get tough with China, because we need them to keep buying our bonds; as I wrote way back in May 2009, given the fact that we’re in a liquidity trap, a decision by China to buy fewer of our bonds would actually be doing us a favor — it would weaken the dollar, and help our exports.

headline: Celebrity Finance Adviser Pleads Guilty
text: Kenneth I. Starr, the onetime investment adviser to the likes of Al Pacino and Sylvester Stallone, has pleaded guilty in federal court in Manhattan to charges that he diverted tens of millions of dollars of his clients’ money to pay for his own lavish lifestyle. Read more in the Business section.

headline: Concerns About Dengue Fever Rise in India
text: NEW DELHI  Indian health officials have struggled to allay domestic concerns about dengue fever even as the country scrambles to finish construction projects in time for the Commonwealth Games, which will take place here in less than a month.

headline: Morning T | Iman
text: Iman, the legendary model turned multihyphenate, kicks off the "Morning T" series of video interviews with T's online director, Horacio Silva.

headline: The Anatomy of a Breakup
text: BEFORE we met, my partner had changed names from a female-sounding one to a male one, and by the time we were together, everyone we knew either called him by this new name or spoke of him with male pronouns. He identified himself as a transgender man, woman to man. It wasn’t until two years after we began dating that he decided to have his breasts removed.

headline: Beckham Returns, Without the Pomp
text: CARSON, Calif.  As Landon Donovan was leaving a small group of reporters at the edge of the practice field Thursday, exiting stage left, he caught a glimpse of David Beckham, who had emerged after working out in the gym, ready to take his place.

headline: Russia Defers Razing of Seed Repository
text: A quick update on the battle to save a Russian seed bank, the Pavlovsk Research Station outside St. Petersburg:

headline: Vettel Fastest in Practice
text: MONZA, Italy – It was back to track action today in Monza as the team-orders talk from yesterday died out. While it is always impossible to tell much from Friday practice, the top three teams were nevertheless the fastest of the day.

headline: Vettel Fastest in Practice
text: MONZA, Italy – It was back to track action today in Monza as the team-orders talk from yesterday died out. While it is always impossible to tell much from Friday practice, the top three teams were nevertheless the fastest of the day.

headline: Where a Bank Watcher Banks
text: It’s not surprising that Jim Bruene, editor and  founder of the Online Banking Report and the Netbanker.com blog, has his personal savings account at an online bank.

headline: Your $26 After-Dinner Coffee at Eleven Madison Park
text: On the Moment, Oliver Strand, on his Ristretto blog, describes the new tableside coffee service at the reinvented Eleven Madison Park.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Thar She Blows
text: Apparently the Samurai Shopper is the last woman alive to indulge in something called a blowout. I’d heard of blowouts before, in their antiquarian sense: huge sales at the end of a retail season, a wholesale slashing of prices where shoppers teetered on the edge of sanity, lunging headfirst at trendy leftovers withering on the fashion vine.

headline: Dear Neighbor, Read This Note!
text: This week, a couple of neighborly notes — one complaining about skateboarding on the roof (warning: explicit language), another threatening to check residents’ identification before letting them into their own apartment building — made the rounds of the blogs.

headline: Japan’s Elderly Count Was Off by 234,000

headline: A Downside of Short Sales
text: STRUGGLING homeowners have found some refuge in short sales, in which lenders allow borrowers to escape foreclosure by selling a home for less than what is owed on the mortgage. Government programs offering incentives to both parties will push the number of short sales to 400,000 this year from 100,000 in 2008, according to CoreLogic, a financial consulting firm.

headline: Far From Shakespeare, but She’s Her Own Cast of Characters
text: LAST month Kanye West released “Monster,” a bizarre, electric new song that featured Jay-Z, Rick Ross, Nicki Minaj and the ghostly folkie Bon Iver. That Ms. Minaj’s verse was better than Jay-Z’s and Mr. West’s was an accomplishment. (“Can we just talk about Nicki’s verse???????!!!!!!!!!” Mr. West posted to Twitter. “I toooooooooooooooold yaaaaaaaaaaaaaaallll!!!!!!!!!!!!”) That her contribution to the song was weirder than Bon Iver’s is just par for the course.

headline: California Turns Festive, With Jazz Along the Coast
text: SUMMER has long been the high season for jazz festivals in New York  there were three, running almost simultaneously, in June  but the fall just might belong to California. Consider that the venerable Monterey Jazz Festival takes place next weekend, from Sept. 17 to 19. Or that the San Francisco Jazz Festival, up the coast, begins the following week, with concerts running through November. Then toss in a promising newcomer this year: the Angel City Jazz Fest, in Los Angeles the first week of October.

headline: Courtside: The Hawk-Eye Effect
text: Once criticized as a technological wet blanket that would slow down the game, the Hawk-Eye system, with its 10 cameras and ability to virtually replay any challenged shot, is now a new source of ente

headline: Courtside: The Hawk-Eye Effect at the Open
text: The whistles and catcalls that in the past accompanied questionable line calls at major tennis events have now been largely replaced by a new sound: an almost involuntary and collective “Waaaaoooooh.” Call it the Hawk-Eye sound effect. Once criticized as a technological wet blanket that would slow down the game, the Hawk-Eye system, with its 10 cameras and ability to virtually replay any challenged shot, is now a new source of entertainment. As the animated ball retraces the shot trajectory, all eyes transfix on the screen to see if it was in or out, and by how much. The closer the ball is to the line, the louder the audience expresses its amazement. “It’s important to show the fans and the players quite how close it is,” said Luke Aggas, tennis operations manager for Hawk-Eye Innovations.

headline: White House Spurns Solar Panel

headline: When Style Was Perfected at Max’s Kansas City
text: IT took panache to gain entry to Max’s Kansas City, Mickey Ruskin’s steak and beer house. In the 1960s and early ’70s, it was a refuge for artists and outliers of every stripe, a kind of gated community where men in suits and chunky Rolex watches were about as welcome as termites. A defiant originality could get you in the door, past the bar and into the fabled back room, where Dan Flavin’s neon sculpture cast visitors in a hellish but curiously flattering glow.

headline: A Suicide Leaves a Literary Journal and Its Editor in Limbo
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  Ted Genoways was just 31 when he took over as editor of The Virginia Quarterly Review in 2003, determined to propel the storied but old-fashioned literary magazine at the University of Virginia into the 21st century. Three years later he made good on his promise. The tiny journal won two National Magazine Awards and six nominations  up against perennial glamour titles like The New Yorker, Harper’s Magazine and Vanity Fair  and Mr. Genoways was hailed in national literary circles for his spunk and vision.

headline: Clijsters Will Face Zvonareva in Final
text: Near the end of a gripping semifinal at the United States Open on Friday that featured power versus power and experience versus experience, Kim Clijsters pulled the perfect shot out of her repertory. On a break point in a crucial game in the third set, Clijsters arced a lob high over Venus Williams’s head that Williams desperately stretched for, but could not reach. When the ball dropped in for a winner, Clijsters had achieved the final blow in a 4-6, 7-6 (2), 6-4 victory that gave her a chance to win her second straight Open.

headline: Home at First Sight
text: WALKING through the section of Bellerose, Queens, where Richard Steier lives with his wife, Gilda Hoyte-Steier, and her two sons, is like wandering through a patch of small-town America. The streets are lined with friendly-looking Capes dating to the 1920s, each topped with a small brick chimney. American flags flutter from every other porch. On a warm summer evening, the only sounds are the faint whoosh of sprinklers, the steady drone of cicadas and the thump of a basketball against a backboard.

headline: Romain Duris Lightens Up
text: Romain Duris possesses every one of the irresistible  — and maybe a little stereotypical — qualities of a French sauvage: the swagger, the scruff, the inimitable unruly head of hair that would take hours of practice and pomade for a normal human being to pull off. Duris, 36, has been building on his considerable natural acting talent ever since he was picked off the street in 1994 by the director Cédric Klapisch for “Le Peril Jeune.” He’s played a gangster-turned-pianist in “The Beat That My Heart Skipped” (2005), France’s best-known playwright in the 2007 period piece “Molière” and a hopeless romantic in the durable study-abroad idyll “L’Auberge Espagnole” (2002). (He was also a T cover star in 2006, as the pride of our portfolio on French leading men.)

headline: Artifacts | The Ghosts of Park Avenue

She didn’t respond — but how could she? She’s a ghost. A “White Ghost,” to be exact, one of two glossy fiberglass statues by Yoshitomo Nara that the Art Production Fund installed on the Park Avenue median this week. (The other is at 67th Street.)

headline: IPad vs. Newspaper, Fly-Swatting Edition
