headline: New Malick Film Set For Next Year
text: It’s the cinematic equivalent of seeing Halley’s Comet twice in a lifetime: it looks as if moviegoers will actually be getting a new film from Terrence Malick, below, in a mere six years since his previous release. Fox Searchlight announced that it had acquired “The Tree of Life,” the latest film by Mr. Malick, an auteur unencumbered by conventional measurements of time and who took a 20-year hiatus between his features “Days of Heaven” (in 1978) and “The Thin Red Line” (in 1998). Fox Searchlight described “The Tree of Life” as a chronicle of a Midwestern family in the 1950s and a son (who is played as an adult by Sean Penn) who is trying to resolve his relationship with his father (Brad Pitt). Though the movie has been rumored as a possible entrant in several 2010 film festivals and even a late-breaking qualifier this year for the Academy Awards, Fox Searchlight said it would release “The Tree of Life” in 2011. It will be Mr. Malick’s first feature since his (relatively recent) film about Capt. John Smith and Pocahontas, “The New World,” in 2005.

headline: Carreño To Retire
text: José Manuel Carreño, above, the veteran American Ballet Theater dancer, has announced that he is retiring in August 2011. A special farewell evening for Mr. Carreño, who joined the company as a principal in 1995, will take place on June 30 at the Metropolitan Opera House and will feature a performance of “Swan Lake” with Mr. Carreño in the role of Prince Siegfried, dancing opposite Julie Kent as Odette and Gillian Murphy as Odile. Mr. Carreño, who was born in Cuba, joined the English National Ballet in 1990 and the Royal Ballet in 1993. With American Ballet Theater, he has danced many roles, including the title character in “Apollo,” Albrecht in “Giselle,” Des Grieux in “Manon” and Solor in “La Bayadère.” After his retirement from American Ballet Theater he plans to continue performing as a guest artist.

headline: Ebert Gives Thumbs Up To New ‘at the Movies’
text: The balcony has reopened. Less than a month after the final episode of “At the Movies,” the long-running film criticism show, was broadcast, Roger Ebert, right, said he would bring back a version of the series that will be shown on public television next year. In an announcement on his blog at the Web site of The Chicago Sun-Times, Mr. Ebert said the new series, called “Roger Ebert Presents At the Movies,” would start in January and will have as its hosts Christy Lemire, film critic of The Associated Press, and Elvis Mitchell of NPR and a former film critic for The New York Times. In a statement, Mr. Ebert said the revival of the series was “the rebirth of a dream.” Mr. Ebert, who lost his lower jaw to throat cancer, said he would appear in segments on the new “At the Movies,” using a computerized voice but would not debate his co-hosts.

headline: Look Out for the Diaoyu Islands
text: Tensions have erupted over some barren rocks in the Pacific that you may never have heard of, but stay tuned – this is a boundary dispute that could get ugly and some day have far-reaching consequences for China, Japan, Taiwan and the United States.

headline: British Artists Protest Possible Cut In Funds
text: Artists gathered in front of the Tate Modern museum in London on Friday, to rally against possible government cuts to arts spending, The Associated Press reported. Britain’s coalition government has proposed a budget that could cut arts spending by as much as 25 percent, as it seeks to reduce a substantial budget deficit. A petition circulated by a British organization called Save the Arts and which has been signed by prominent British artists like Damien Hirst, Anish Kapoor and David Hockney, counters that “radical cuts to current levels of arts funding will decimate what has been one of the U.K.’s chief success stories over the past 20 years, and will bring an end to the U.K.’s reign as a global capital for culture.” A final decision on the cuts is expected next month.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
text: The observance of Id al-Fitr in the Middle East, Africa and Asia opens Friday’s report. Reuters documented the “Subdued Id in Pakistan” in a video and in photography by Morteza Nikoubazi (Slide 4). And look what Muhammed Muheisen of The Associated Press does with light — again (Slide 2).

headline: Phillips Collection Seeks Donations via Texting
text: Small donations via text message raised millions of dollars for Haitian earthquake victims. Are museums next? The Phillips Collection in Washington on Thursday announced a campaign to solicit $5 and $10 donations via text message to raise money for repairs to its building, above, after a fire on Sept. 2. No artwork was damaged, but the museum’s offices were harmed. Ann Greer, the director of communications and marketing, said the museum was already planning a “give-by-cell” campaign and had developed the mechanism for it before the fire broke out. At that point, she said, “we had people who were asking how they could help, and this seemed to us to be an easy way that they could do it, also at giving levels that people could afford.” A $5 or $10 donation can be made by texting “phillips5” or “phillips10” to 20222 and then following the prompts.

headline: Flea Theater Invests In a Permanent Home
text: Executives of Off Off Broadway’s Flea Theater said they had purchased a building downtown to create a new home, concluding that buying instead of renting was necessary for its survival. The Flea, a well-regarded TriBeCa theater known for the 9/11 play “The Guys” and productions of A. R. Gurney works, bought a two-story office building at 20 Thomas Street last December for $5.3 million, according to the artistic director, Jim Simpson. Crain’s New York Business first reported the sale. Mr. Simpson and the Flea’s producing director, Carol Ostrow, said in an interview that they were now in the quiet phase of a capital campaign to raise money to create at least two theaters within the 5,600-square-foot building. They said they planned to announce the fund-raising goals of the campaign next year  they declined to disclose the numbers  and added that they did not herald the purchase of the new building because they had wanted to announce the new home in tandem with the capital campaign. . They said for the foreseeable future the Flea would continue to produce shows in its current White Street space.

headline: N.F.L.’S. Opening Game Scores For NBC
text: The official kickoff of the National Football League season on Thursday night scored an impressive start in the ratings for NBC. Although final figures were not immediately available on Friday, preliminary estimates for the game between the New Orleans Saints and Minnesota Vikings were the highest in 13 years for any regular-season professional football game in prime time, and overnight ratings were up by nearly 30 percent from last year’s season opener, which drew 20.9 million viewers. CBS was second on the night with a new installment of “Big Brother” (7.7 million). ABC was third and Fox was fourth.

headline: Soothing and Easy, Turning Intricate
text: From a distance the music of Rosetta Trio can seem demure and untroubled. Its palette consists of acoustic bass and two guitars, one acoustic and one electric: a companionable setup, made even more so by the temperament of the players. There isn’t much call for showboating in the group’s material, though there’s usually room for improvisation. Listen casually, a bit distractedly, and you might mistake it all for soothing pleasantry.

headline: An Intimate Setting for Appealing Sounds
text: As occasional chamber-music series in Manhattan go, the Movado Hour at the Baryshnikov Arts Center is a hard one to beat. True, its offerings are limited to a handful scattered throughout the season. But for five years now, Pedja Muzijevic, the music director for the center and a versatile pianist of broad, eclectic tastes, has presented some of the world’s finest singers, instrumentalists and ensembles in this series of casual, free concerts.

headline: Progress in Twilight
text: A twilight view of the World Trade Center site taken Thursday evening shows 1 World Trade Center (with two cranes at top), now one-third of the way up to its 1,368-foot height, and the diaphanous 7 World Trade Center, to the immediate right, which was finished in 2006. In the right foreground is an area between the No. 1 subway line and Church Street, where two more skyscrapers and the PATH station will go.

headline: Creamed Corn That’s Much Too Good to Share
text: THERE are a thousand and one ways to prepare summer corn, but all I did this year was cream it.

headline: Court Denies Class-Action Status in Lilly Drug Case
text: Eli Lilly & Company won reversal of a ruling that had granted class-action status to a suit by pension funds, unions and insurers that claimed improper marketing of Zyprexa, its schizophrenia treatment, raised their costs.

headline: Wilpon Leaves Hospital Flap to the Players
text: Days after three Mets skipped a team trip to visit wounded war veterans at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, Jeff Wilpon, the team’s chief operating officer, declined to rebuke the players, saying that any discontent that stemmed from their absence should be worked out in the clubhouse.

headline: Couche-Tard May Raise Offer for Casey’s
text: Alimentation Couche-Tard, the Canadian convenience store operator, said late Friday that it would consider raising its unsolicited offer for Casey’s General Stores once again and it asked Casey’s to postpone its annual meeting on Sept. 23 for two to three weeks in order to “complete a full and fair sales process.”

headline: A Bear Hug? Nissan Ad Raises Eyebrows
text: From our colleagues at Green:

headline: Secrets of Perception in a Brooklyn Aerie
text: Every dance needs a room of its own, and the choreographer Anna Sperber has a great advantage in this regard: “Naomi,” her newest piece, sits in the Brooklyn sky like an urban treehouse.

headline: Pervasive Abuse Found in Belgian Church
text: BRUSSELS  Sexual abuse of children reached all parts of Belgium’s Roman Catholic Church, and it drove at least 13 victims to kill themselves, a report released Friday said.

headline: ‘Biker Fox’
text: Jeremy Lamberton’s sometimes amusing documentary “Biker Fox” is many things: a portrait of an idealist preaching a gospel of bicycling, loving nature and helping one’s fellow man; a study of anger management, or the lack thereof; an examination of someone unaware of his own acute loneliness.

headline: The Global Sports Forum With Christopher Clarey: U.S. Open Edition
text: Christopher Clarey, International Herald Tribune/The New York TimesWith Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal still in the mix, this should be a remarkable final weekend at the US Open. To mark the occasion, I’ve brought together some of the world’s leading tennis writers for a special edition of the forum. We have Philippe Bouin, who has covered more than 100 Grand Slam events for L’Equipe in France. We have Neil Harman, a leading voice of the sport in Britain for The Times of London. We have Juan Jose Mateo, who has chronicled Nadal’s rise and reign for El Pais in Spain. We’ll focus on Rafa and Roger and the business end of the men’s tournament, beginning with Saturday’s semifinals between Nadal and Mikhail Youzhny and between Federer and Novak Djokovic. Let’s start with the man whose country actually has a player left in the men’s tournament.

headline: On With the Bickering in a Fairy Tale
text: It’s easy to take pleasure in the dancing and music that occur in “Art/Family/Our Lives,” subtitled “I Ka Nye (You Look Well).” Nora Chipaumire and Souleymane Badolo are both remarkable dancers, with stylistic differences that make for more than one lively dance dialogue onstage. Their musical colleague Obo Addy

headline: Former President Clinton’s Busy Dance Card
text: Trying to capture some momentum in Ohio’s Senate race, Lt. Gov. Lee Fisher, the Democratic candidate, has called in reinforcements this weekend – former President Clinton, who has proven to be a popular presence for Democrats on the campaign trail this year.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: Second-Week Bonanza
text: While the opening week of college football brought with it all the requisite excitement of another season beginning, this weekend unquestionably features a better group of games. Most of the action comes out of the conference, notwithstanding an intriguing SEC matchup. Penn State and Alabama renew a rivalry, one that has conjured up memories of Joe Paterno coaching against Bear Bryant. Two first-year coaches (Florida State’s Jimbo Fisher and Notre Dame’s Brian Kelly) face big challenges, with the Seminoles traveling to Oklahoma and the Irish hosting a Michigan team that looked extremely dangerous in beating Connecticut in the season opener. But the marquee game on Saturday looks to be Miami at Ohio State. The Buckeyes’ Terrelle Pryor and the Hurricanes’ Jacory Harris are two of the most exciting quarterbacks in the country. Expect the winner of this game to vault right to the top of the Heisman discussion. But, enough talk. Let’s get on with the picks.

headline: ‘Resident Evil: Afterlife 3D’
text: Eight years, three movies and now a third dimension have added little to the video-game-derived saga of Alice (Milla Jovovich), scourge of zombies and lust object of teenage boys. In “Resident Evil: Afterlife 3D,” our well-armed heroine is now on her fourth attempt to best the dastardly Umbrella Corporation and rescue remnants of spandex-clad humanity from the slobbering victims of the deadly T-Virus.

headline: Sept. 10, 2001
text: Lucas Roman was not photographing for the ages. He was simply making a keepsake of his arrival in New York, where he was beginning a new life in film production. There was only one better spot from which to capture the city’s sweep than the observatory of the Empire State Building, where he stood on the night of Monday, Sept. 10, 2001. And that was from Windows on the World, atop the World Trade Center, where he was headed the next morning.

headline: Not-So-Great Moments in Diplomacy, Drunken Toast Edition
text: When Sha Zukang, the most senior Chinese official at the United Nations, rose to make a toast to Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon last week, his colleagues were no doubt aware of the fact that he has a history of making undiplomatic remarks.

headline: ContemporAsian
text: Four divergent perspectives, encompassing the literary and almost mystical, are on view in the Museum of Modern Art’s ContemporAsian series, presenting shorts from Thailand, Malaysia, South Korea and China through Thursday. While its spotlighted auteurs may be largely undiscovered stateside, that status is likely to change.

headline: Continuing Coverage of a Question Mark
text: Sept. 11 anniversary specials have been such a television staple since 2002 that by now they constitute their own small genre. This weekend, however, TV is largely sticking with coverage of the ground zero memorial ceremony (and any associated protests of the planned Muslim community center nearby) on Saturday morning, perhaps mindful of the excess we can expect for the 10th anniversary next year.

headline: In Vastness of Toronto, Small Films Take Root
text: TORONTO — A recurring wonder of this city’s vast, industrial-strength annual movie festival is that the frailest of flowers, personal film, still sprouts here.

headline: Republican Congressman Talks Government Shutdown
text: Washington saw a bit of a mid-90s flashback on Friday.

headline: A Guide to New Meadowlands Stadium
text: This week the Giants and the Jets will open the regular season at their new $1.6 billion stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Russia: Medvedev Defends Level of Political Freedom
text: President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Friday defended the level of political freedom in Russia, trying to refute criticism that the Kremlin had suppressed opposition. Mr. Medvedev, who pledged when he took office in 2008 to promote more liberal policies, suggested at an international forum that Russia had made strides given that the Soviet Union fell only two decades ago. “I categorically do not agree with those who maintain that there is no democracy in Russia, that it is ruled by authoritarian tradition,” he said. He added, “Russia, without a doubt, is a democracy. Yes, it is young, immature, imperfect, inexperienced  but it is democracy. We are at the very beginning of the path.”

headline: India: Dengue Fever Concerns
text: Health officials are struggling to allay domestic concerns about dengue fever as India scrambles to finish construction projects in time for the Commonwealth Games, scheduled to being Oct. 3 in New Delhi. India is expecting 8,000 athletes, and delays and accusations of corruption have marred preparations. The outbreak is a concern partly because the athletes’ quarters will be near a breeding ground for the mosquitoes that spread the disease. Some countries have issued travel warnings, while The Mirror reported in Britain that the head of England’s delegation had told team managers that athletes could withdraw over health concerns. Dr. Chusak Prasttisur, of the World Health Organization, said the worst could be yet to come. Dengue in India will peak in coming months, he said. But K. Sujatha Rao, the health secretary, said that the number of cases in New Delhi this year was no higher than usual.

headline: Britain: Minister Paid Detectives
text: A junior justice minister in Prime Minister David Cameron’s government has admitted that he paid private detectives to investigate Conservative party colleagues he suspected of being sources for newspaper articles claiming he had made excessive parliamentary expense claims. The minister, Jonathan Djanogly, 45, said he acted following “malicious allegations” last year, when dozens of members of Parliament were embroiled in an expenses scandal. He said he hired the detectives to “try to find out the sources” that said that he had improperly claimed more than $20,000 in cleaning costs for his home 75 miles north of London, and a similar sum for gardening costs. Mr. Djanogly repaid claims ruled improper, amounting to $38,750. But before the reimbursement, private detectives posing as reporters interviewed prominent Conservatives in his Huntingdon parliamentary constituency and reported their findings to Mr. Djanogly. Calls for the minister’s resignation were rejected by a spokesman for Mr. Cameron, who said the prime minister continued to have “full confidence” in him. “With hindsight, I can see that I may have overreacted,” Mr. Djanogly said.

headline: Still on Duty at Ground Zero, the Indomitable Nurse Reggi
text: ALL attempts to keep Mary Regina Shane from working exactly where she wants to have failed, thank you very little.

headline: 9/11/10: Reflection and Contention
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tax Cuts May Prove Better for Politicians Than for Economy
text: With Congressional midterm elections looming, the financial debate in Washington this fall will probably be consumed by one incendiary and expensive issue: whether, and how, to extend the multitrillion-dollar Bush tax cuts.

headline: Froggy’s Last Story
text: F. GWYNPLAINE MacINTYRE lived in two dimensions.

headline: When It Comes to Health, an Ounce of Prevention ...
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Your Palm, Memories of Horror and Valor
text: New York is not meant for memorials. In a city where everything lurches relentlessly into the future, who has time to mourn the past?

headline: Outside the Met, Fashion’s Overture
text: The purpose of Fashion Week isn’t to sell clothes; Macy’s can do that. Rather, the purpose of the shows is to dramatize fashion, to conjure the steel and vanity lurking in every housewife, and what better place to do that than at Lincoln Center, where very soon the Metropolitan Opera will open with three Rhine maidens taunting a lusty dwarf in “Das Rheingold.”

headline: For a Real Mideast Peace
text: To the Editor:

headline: Questions About New York
text: Q. What is the large concrete structure on the East River waterfront next to the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, at 60th and 61st Streets, with what looks like ornamental steel on top?

headline: Jewish Music, Preserved
text: To the Editor:

headline: Net Neutrality
text: To the Editor:

headline: Business Class Rises in Ashes of Caste System
text: CHENNAI, India — Chezi K. Ganesan looks every inch the high-tech entrepreneur, dressed in the Silicon Valley uniform of denim shirt and khaki trousers, slick smartphone close at hand. He splits his time between San Jose and this booming coastal metropolis, running his $6 million a year computer chip-making company.

headline: A Tagging Party for One of the Biggest Tags of All
text: The quilted Chanel cellphone holder was a choice “vintage” item from the ’90s. The black Chanel tweed skirt was from several years ago. Ditto the Chanel blouse with the keyhole neckline and the gold Chanel watch and the gold Chanel necklace and the gold-studded Chanel bracelet. The choicest piece was probably the Chanel Hula belt with its “skirt” of dangling chains. That item cost $3,000 back in 1982.

headline: Making A Pilgrimage To The Land Of My Fathers
text: I’m referring, of course, to Brooklyn. Robin and I will be talking with Jeff Madrick at the Brooklyn Book Festival, 11 AM Sunday.

headline: H.P.’s Blundering Board
text: There they go again.

headline: For the Love of Orange Juice
text: Ed Koch — the former mayor of New York and a one-man octogenarian media empire — is a busy guy. Between his radio show (“The Voice of Reason,” Friday nights on Bloomberg Radio), his punditry (HuffPo and New York Press) and his movie reviews (The Villager, Yonkers Tribune), there’s not a lot of time left over for leisurely Sunday mornings. In fact, Mr. Koch, 85, who lives in Greenwich Village, gets up at 6:30 a.m. every Sunday — “or a little earlier, about two minutes before the alarm goes off, it never fails” — and, more or less, gets right down to work. ALAN FEUER

headline: The New Plan for Army? Going Old School
text: WEST POINT, N.Y.  In his second year as Army football coach, Rich Ellerson has an office that looks comfy and lived in. He ought to feel at home. There are Ellersons all around. His father’s 1935 West Point cadet portrait rests on one wall of the office. On a facing wall is a picture of the 1962 Army football team that his brother John captained. Another brother is also a West Point graduate.

headline: As Colleagues Keep Their Distance, Rangel Finds a Re-election Ally in Bloomberg
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel finds himself shunned by some of his colleagues as he battles for re-election amid accusations that he committed numerous violations of House ethics rules. But Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is not only supporting Mr. Rangel, he is urging New Yorkers to do so, too.

headline: Pentagon Eases Some Rules on Guantánamo Coverage
text: The Pentagon has agreed to revise some of the rules that have restricted what journalists are free to report on from Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, resolving a conflict that peaked in May when four reporters were expelled from the naval base there.

headline: Study Cites Drone Crew in Attack on Afghans
text: A Predator drone pilot played down two warnings about the presence of children before military commanders ordered a helicopter attack that killed 23 Afghan civilians traveling down a road in February, an Air Force investigation has found.

headline: Paying the Price
text: Like homeowners in the path of an approaching wildfire, Democrats are scrambling to salvage what they can from an anticipated disaster in the coming elections.

headline: Patriots’ Brady Signs League’s Richest Deal, at the Moment
text: After Tom Brady signed his new contract Friday afternoon in the owner Robert Kraft’s office, the two talked about how fortunate Brady was to walk away from a car accident Thursday shaken but unharmed.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: THE P.S. 185 PLAYGROUND, the city’s newest schoolyard, is decidedly old-school, with spaces for skelly, boxball, red light-green light, ace-king-queen and running bases. This revival of old New York City street games is an initiative of the school’s principal, Kenneth Llinas, 61, who played them as a child in Flatbush.

headline: The Scene: Day Two
text: Photos from in and around Lincoln Center during the second day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Uncle Lends Steady Hand in Nadal’s Unsettled Life
text: It was nearing midnight at the United States Open on Thursday and Rafael Nadal was late for his postmatch news conference because he was in the men’s locker room shaving.

headline: Ex- Chief of Quellos Admits Swindling the I.R.S. Out of $240 Million
text: The former top executive of a once-prominent investment firm in Seattle pleaded guilty on Friday to charges involving questionable tax shelters that the firm sold to wealthy investors.

headline: Iran Halts Release of American Held for a Year
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Iran on Friday postponed the release of an American woman who has been detained along with two friends for more than a year, in an abrupt shift that suggested divisions within the Iranian government.

headline: Kuchar Fights Off Illness for Share of Lead
text: LEMONT, Ill.. — With his strength and tournament lead both slipping away, Matt Kuchar turned things around on the inward nine Friday, birdieing four of the last eight holes to retain a share of the lead with a one-over-par 72 in the second round of the BMW Championship.

headline: A Lesson From 9/11
text: Nine years ago today, we saw the world stand still. We saw the innocence of a nation crumble to the ground. We saw the face of evil form in plumes of smoke and ash. It was Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Dear Fellow Improbable…
text: It didn’t sound like my cup of tea. In fact, it sounded like some kind of boring “think tank” thing and I declined their nice invite.

headline: The Rebel
text: Meghan McCain’s new book is a frank, dishy and often scathing chronicle of her experiences during the 2008 presidential campaign.

headline: 2 Spots in Chase Are in Play, but It Will Be Tough Squeezing Into Them
text: Clint Bowyer already has some experience at beating deadlines. The 26th race of the season at Richmond, Va., has been the cutoff point for the 10-race Nascar Chase for the Sprint Cup, and Bowyer needed solid performances at Richmond in 2007 and 2008 to qualify.

headline: Daughter of John McCain Is a Rebel
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

headline: Sept. 11, 2010: The Continuing Human Damage
text: The 9/11 atrocity continues to scar tens of thousands of citizens who pitched in as cleanup volunteers and emergency responders in the toxin-laden clouds at ground zero, the Pentagon and rural Pennsylvania. Ordinary citizens, neighborhood residents and responders heedless of overtime worked side by side for weeks in New York City, many eventually developing grave illnesses that are disrupting lives and careers.

headline: On the Street | Foot Notes
text: Clothes are the main event at fashion week, but on the first two days, all eyes were focused on the shoes on the guests as well as those of the models.

headline: German Identity, Long Dormant, Reasserts Itself
text: BERLIN  As a youth in the 1950s, the film director Volker Schlöndorff tried to hide his German origins by learning to speak unaccented French. This summer, his daughter painted German flags on her cheeks and joined crowds of thousands on the Kurfürstendamm, a historic avenue, waving their black, red and gold banners to celebrate the country’s World Cup victories.

headline: Our Open
text: This is our Open, outdoors, exposed to the elements, as it should be. Let’s freeze the action. It could be an instant in one of the early matches, played in torrid conditions that now seem as distant as last year’s games. But it will probably be one of the wind-driven matches late in the second week.

headline: Using a Robot to Throw a Wrench Into the Stereotyping of Girls
text: Yuan Zhou, 14, softly crooned a pop chorus, but drew a blank look from her audience: a 14-foot robot named Girlzilla.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Police Deny Tape Describes Ticket Quotas
text: A secret recording of police commanders at a meeting in April does not capture a discussion of quotas but rather minimum productivity goals, the New York Police Department’s chief spokesman said Friday.

headline: Carrie Elston and James Tunick
text: Carrie Sperry Elston, a daughter of Frances Beinecke and Paul J. Elston of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married Saturday evening to James Alden Tunick, the son of Elizabeth S. Tunick and David P. Tunick, both of Manhattan. Katharine M. Preston, a Universal Life minister, officiated at Wave Hill, the public garden in Riverdale.

headline: Joann Ruvolo, Peter Hilton
text: Joann Ruvolo and Peter Robert Hilton are to be married Sunday morning at the Japanese Friendship Garden in San Jose, Calif. The Rev. Shosan Victoria Austin, a Zen Buddhist priest, is to officiate.

headline: Devora Whitman, Marc Allon
text: Devora Whitman and Marc Moshe Allon were married Monday in Montreal. The bride’s father, Rabbi Michael S. Whitman, performed the ceremony at the Congregation Shaar Hashomayim.

headline: Melissa Mangano and Brian Davidson
text: Melissa Catherine Mangano and Brian Christopher Davidson were married Saturday evening at the Hotel Monaco in Alexandria, Va. Maureen Burke, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

headline: Education Rift Fuels Spending in State Races
text: Mark H. Pollard was a little-known candidate for New York State Senate in Brooklyn facing the herculean feat of ousting a 26-year incumbent. But then he got an unexpected telephone call saying that a group of wealthy investors who supported charter schools wanted to meet with him.

headline: Jolene Rall and Christopher Birrer
text: Jolene Ann Rall, a daughter of Mary A. Rall and John Rall of Seaford, N.Y., was married Saturday to Christopher Daniel Birrer, a son of Christina D. Birrer and Dr. Richard B. Birrer of Locust Valley, N.Y., and Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. The Rev. Robert L. Hayden, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in Seaford at St. William the Abbot Church, where he is pastor.

headline: How to Cheat a Retirement Fund
text: A FEW weeks ago, at the insistence of the Securities and Exchange Commission, New Jersey agreed never again to fraudulently hide its underfunding of the state’s public pension system. Meanwhile, in Albany, Harry Wilson, the Republican candidate for state comptroller, has asserted that  if you do the math the way any ordinary financial analyst or economist would   New York’s pension system is underfunded by tens of billions of dollars and that, as a result, the state is essentially insolvent.

headline: U.S. Team Is High on Expectations but Low on Big-Game Experience
text: ISTANBUL  Until the United States entered the knockout round of the basketball world championships here, the last time Eric Gordon played in an elimination game he shot 3 for 15 for Indiana in an upset loss in the 2008 N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: A Cultural Divide Bridged in the Produce Aisle
text: Kim Zimmer is the marquee attraction in the world premiere of “Lost Boy Found in Whole Foods.” Soap opera fans know her as the many-times-married, twice-presumed-dead, chronically criminal Reva Shayne on “Guiding Light.” Film noir fans might or might not recognize her as Kathleen Turner’s look-alike school-days friend Mary Ann in “Body Heat.”

headline: Adrienne Chew and Heather Warncke
text: Adrienne Powell Chew and Heather Elizabeth Warncke were married Saturday at the Microsoft New England Research and Development Center in Cambridge, Mass. Judge Robert E. Beach Jr. of the Connecticut Appellate Court, an uncle of Ms. Chew, officiated.

headline: Horror in the Hedges
text: In a continuing effort to bring you cheerful news even when the world seems determined to be abysmal, I want to point out that next week is the end of the primary election season. Which began, as we all know, sometime during the reign of Ethelred the Unready.

headline: Kiersten Van Horne, David Gilbreth
text: Kiersten Van Horne and David Gilbreth were married Saturday at Gooseberry Neck Beach in Westport, Mass. The ceremony was led by Justin Hall, a friend of the couple who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate at this event.

headline: Tiffany Andrade, Frank DiCarlo
text: Tiffany A. Andrade and Frank S. DiCarlo were married Saturday at St. Christopher’s Roman Catholic Church in Midland Beach, Staten Island. The Rev. Joseph M. McLafferty, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Kaibin Hu, Jackie Chan
text: Kaibin Sun Hu and Jackie Chan are to be married Sunday by the Rev. Michael G. Ireland, an American Baptist minister, at Beaulieu Garden, an event space in Napa County, Calif.

headline: Rebecca Hoffberg, Jason Phillips
text: Rebecca Ariel Hoffberg and Jason Laurence Phillips were married Monday at Antrim 1844, an event space in Taneytown, Md. Rabbi Joanne Yocheved Heiligman officiated.

headline: Christina Lyndon, Trevor Winstead
text: Christina Marjorie Lyndon, a daughter of Kathryn D. Lyndon and Dennis C. Lyndon of Stamford, Conn., was married Saturday to Trevor Vietor Winstead, the son of Louise V. Winstead and David L. Winstead of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Francis T. Hoffmann, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Augustine in Larchmont, N.Y.

headline: Genna Griffith, Marc Giammatteo
text: Genna Leigh Griffith and Marc Andrew Giammatteo are to be married Sunday at the United States Military Academy at West Point. Rabbi Hirschel Jaffe is to officiate, with the Rev. Richard Hasselbach, a priest affiliated with CITI Ministries, taking part.

headline: Kristin Brown, Marco Anastasio
text: Kristin Lee Brown and Marco Angelo Anastasio were married Friday in Bayville, N.Y. The Rev. Stephen J. Brigandi performed the ceremony at St. Gertrude’s Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Naomi Schalit, John Christie
text: Naomi Brodie Schalit and John Thomas Christie are to be married Sunday at their home in Hallowell, Me. Richard Lawrence, a Maine notary public, is to officiate.

headline: Amelia Hanley, Christian Cavallo
text: Amelia Bruno Hanley, a daughter of Antonia F. Hanley and John F. Hanley of Westfield, N.J., was married Saturday to Christian Andrew Cavallo, the son of Kathleen and Anthony Cavallo of Sea Girt, N.J. The Rev. Thomas E. Conway performed the ceremony at St. Thomas of Villanova Roman Catholic Church in Surf City, N.J.

headline: Catherine Chandler, Jonah Deutsch
text: Catherine O’Connor Chandler and Jonah Schatzow Deutsch were married Wednesday at Chicago City Hall. Walter Williams, a judge in the circuit court of Cook County, officiated. On Saturday, Richard Rosengarten, a professor and the former dean at the Divinity School at the University of Chicago, led a ceremony incorporating Jewish and Catholic cultural wedding traditions at the home of Diana Young and William Brown, friends of the bride, in Buchanan, Mich.

headline: Sindy Subance and Alexander von Ziegesar
text: Sindy Subance and Alexander von Ziegesar were married Friday in Oxford, Md. The Rev. Kevin Cross, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Trinity, where he is the rector.

headline: Sarah Stroh, Philip Thornton
text: Sarah Bingham Stroh, the daughter of Kathleen Bingham Stroh and Leslie Stroh of New York, was married Saturday to Philip Scott Thornton, a son of Ann B. Thornton and R. James Thornton of Lawrence, N.Y.

headline: Nicole Moen, Michael Skoglund
text: Nicole Mireille Moen and Michael Lee Skoglund were married Saturday at the Weisman Art Museum in Minneapolis. Judge John R. Tunheim of the Federal District Court in Minneapolis officiated.

headline: Trevor Price, Bret Azzarelli
text: Trevor George Price and Bret Richard Azzarelli were married Tuesday at the XV Beacon Hotel in Boston. Janet Benzan Duval, a justice of the peace in Boston, officiated.

headline: Yuko Sakuma and Daniil Sosonkin
text: Yuko Sakuma and Daniil Sosonkin were married Tuesday evening at the Four Seasons Resort at Manele Bay in Lanai City, Hawaii. The Rev. Mike Lopez, who is affiliated with the World Ministry Fellowship, officiated.

headline: Dorothy Robinson, Nat Scott
text: Dorothy Newsom Robinson and Brewster Nelson Scott were married Saturday evening at St. George’s Chapel in Harbeson, Del. The Rev. Christopher C. Moore, an Episcopal priest and the priest associate at the chapel, led the ceremony.

headline: Exploring the Globe for the World of Ants
text: Greenport, N.Y.

headline: Foreign Service Officer R. Smith Simpson Dies at 103
text: If would-be diplomats cannot name an American artist or specify where a major American river is located, R. Smith Simpson wondered (and worried), how can they properly represent the United States in other countries?

headline: Sept. 11, 2010: The Right Way to Remember
text: Nine years after terrorists destroyed the World Trade Center, a memorial and a transportation hub are taking recognizable shape and skyscrapers are finally starting to rise from the ashes of ground zero.

headline: Free Them All
text: After imprisoning three Americans for more than one year, Iran raised and then dashed hopes that it would release one of them, Sarah Shourd, on Saturday. All three should be freed. Shane Bauer, Joshua Fattal and Ms. Shourd have lived lives of fear and depravation in Tehran’s infamous Evin prison for far too long.

headline: Stage Director Plans Busy Final Year
text: THE first thing Michael Wilson wants you to know is that he is not going anywhere. Not yet. Not until well into 2011.

headline: The Only Child: Not a Loner?
text: The Gist: Growing up without siblings doesn’t harm social skills.

headline: City Disavows Pastor’s Talk of Burning Koran
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  Stephanie George used to see members of the Dove World Outreach Center at her neighborhood grocery store, wearing T-shirts that said “Islam is of the devil.” But on Friday, she and her friend Lynda Dillon showed up early at Dragonfly Graphics to order a dozen shirts with a different message: “Love, not Dove.”

headline: Cilantro, the Flavor of Memory
text: OLIVER PLATT was having a Marcel Proust moment. His madeleine stand-in? Cilantro.

headline: Chamber Music With Muscle
text: WHEN the animated young conductor Eric Jacobsen takes the stage at the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah on Sept. 26, he will stand before some 45 musicians — an orchestra notably smaller than the ones that the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, the evening’s soloist, typically plays with when he performs the works that have been scheduled for his Caramoor appearance.

headline: Vacancies Strain White House’s Goals for Economy
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama signaled on Friday that he was close to choosing a director for a new consumer bureau, but an array of top jobs that will be crucial to shaping economic policy and financial regulation for the rest of his term remain unfilled.

headline: Long Past the Last Match Point, Debating What’s Next at Forest Hills
text: Three miles south of the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Queens, where players slice, smash and skid across the blue acrylic surface of Arthur Ashe Stadium as they compete for United States Open titles, the tournament’s birthplace lies on life support.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Global Rules for Banks Draw Near
text: FRANKFURT  If all goes well, the world will be a slightly safer place after top central bankers and bank regulators emerge Sunday from meetings in Basel, Switzerland.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Westchester and Putnam Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Cultural Calendar, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Saturday: Victorian Conveyance
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — There’s a mini-theme of eruption today with “Like the Great Geysir” and a “High point of 1980 news,” seen here before 1980 and during 1980.

headline: Gimme Hair Flying Straight and Free
text: WHEN I was 6 years old, I begged my mother to let me get a Dorothy Hamill. I envisioned my hair would be like the figure skater’s  a wedge cut flying freely from my head in slow motion as I did balletic jumps in our New Jersey living room.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: A Quick Look at a Busy Saturday
text: Kim Clijsters has an opportunity Saturday night to do what no woman has done since 2001: successfully defend her United States Open title.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Candidate’s Scented Mailing Says Albany ‘Stinks’
text: There could be a surprise waiting in your mailbox this weekend, courtesy of Carl P. Paladino, a Republican candidate for governor. Not the front of the brochure, which states that “Something really stinks in Albany.” Nor the back, which features images of tarnished Democrats like Gov. David A. Paterson, former Gov. Eliot Spitzer and former State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Bloggingheads: Stimulus, Part II
text: Annie Lowrey, left, of The Washington Independent and Peter Suderman of Reason debate President Obama's new spending plan.

headline: Reactions From Afghanistan
text: Afghan responses a Florida pastor's wavering plans to burn Korans on the ninth anniversary of the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001.

headline: A Judge Lauded as No-Nonsense and Scholarly
text: As a judge in the busy federal courthouse in Riverside, Calif., Virginia A. Phillips has presided over a rich and varied parade of cases through the years.

headline: Surviving on Italian Tradition
text: A couple of decades ago, the New York region was awash in Italian bakeries — the kinds of places that serve delicious minipastries; moist, springy cakes; and sometimes even a great cup of coffee. Today there are far fewer such establishments, but one of the best, the 51-year-old Caffé Trento, is still going strong.

headline: Chock Full o’Nuts Returns to Manhattan. But Is That Salmon on the Menu?
text: Back in the 1950s and ’60s, New York City was studded with Chock Full o’Nuts coffee shops, homegrown institutions where the budget-minded could sidle up to the lunch counter for a freshly prepared meal. But the restaurants  once nearly as ubiquitous as the Checker cabs that inspired their yellow-and-black decor  were all but gone by the early ’80s, leaving faded memories and eventually some smaller cafes and kiosks bearing the company name.

headline: A Mission to Stay Close to the Farm
text: IT has been almost four years since the Flying Pig on Lexington moved from the Mount Kisco train station into the space last occupied by the sophisticated Café Antico. With the new restaurant came the rustic spirit of the farm, with a somewhat predictable décor involving a large number of pig images and figurines. But the heart of a restaurant is in the kitchen. This one employs freshly harvested and organically cultivated vegetables, as well as products from livestock raised humanely at Cabbage Hill Farm, which is the restaurant’s owner and its major supplier. A few other similarly committed farms also supply the restaurant.

headline: A Blend Bright and Smooth
text: Producers who blend wines believe the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. That principle governs the Long Island Merlot Alliance’s 2007 Merliance, a composite.

headline: Yankees Take Cautious Approach With Posada
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Jorge Posada said his previous concussion came in September 2007, when Eric Hinske barreled into him during a bone-jarring collision at the plate. That night, he was taken to the hospital for a CT scan, which came back negative. But Posada played the next day, and the day after that, and the day after that, too.

headline: Santana’s Season Will End in Surgery
text: Season-ending shoulder surgery is ominous enough for any athlete and potentially devastating for an ace like Johan Santana, the veteran Mets left-hander.

headline: Accent on the Nautical, From a Lover of Sailing
text: A LOVE of sailing led Bernie DelBello to buy the restaurant Fiddleheads last year with a partner, Michael Ventre, in boat-loving Oyster Bay.

headline: Followed by a Loyal Following
text: There could have been any number of reasons Lovin’ Oven, a 46-seat cafe in Frenchtown, was mobbed during a recent Sunday brunch.

headline: A Real Diner, Seasonal and Local
text: WHEN the readers of Edible Jersey magazine gave the owners of a South Jersey diner a Local Hero Award, I added the restaurant to my list of places to try. But when friends came back from a visit there, excited about the everyday use of local products, I called for reservations.

headline: A Robot Called Girlzilla
text: Members of a girls' club build a 14-foot robot.

headline: Nokia Chooses a Microsoft Officer as Its New Chief Executive
text: BERLIN  Nokia, the leading maker of mobile phones, replaced its chief executive, Olli-Pekka Kallasvuo, on Friday with the head of Microsoft’s business unit in a bid to turn around the company’s struggling smartphone lineup and stop a decline in American market share.

headline: Supporting the Farmers, and the Hungry
text: IT was one of the twice-a-week half-price wine nights at the River Tavern in Chester. The bar was standing room only, and very little of that. While dipping fresh tortilla chips into the excellent made-to-order guacamole, we asked the waiter whether he thought the half-price gambit on Mondays and Tuesdays was responsible for the evening’s crush. Yes, he said, but Wednesdays, when cocktails are on sale, were even busier.

headline: Japan Plans Intervention to Stem Rise in the Yen
text: TOKYO  The Japanese government is gearing up to intervene in global currency markets to curb a strengthening yen, Prime Minister Naoto Kan said Friday, signaling an effort to limit further damage to Japan’s export-led economy.

headline: Among 9/11 Families, a Last Holdout Remains
text: In the nine years since Sept. 11, 2001, the legal claims for people who were injured or killed in the attacks have almost entirely been resolved. Thousands of victims and families entered a special compensation fund created by Congress and were paid more than $7 billion; a much smaller group chose to file lawsuits, which have been settled over time for about $500 million.

headline: Savory, Wood-Fired and Local
text: Stanziato’s Wood Fired Pizza is not your standard pizza joint. For one thing, there is the wood-stoked oven, its hearth visible right as you enter. Add to that the crispy-thin, pleasingly chewy crust, made in part from imported Italian flour, and you’re well on the way to a memorable pizza experience.

headline: Two French Automakers Start to Repay Government
text: PARIS  Renault and Peugeot Citroën, the French automakers, said Friday that they had begun to repay, ahead of schedule, the billions of euros in government aid they received to help them through the financial crisis and recession.

headline: Parking Rules for Id al-Fitr
text: Because of Id al-Fitr, the festival marking the end of Ramadan, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Saturday and Sunday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Houston Scrambles After Blaze That Destroyed Voting Machines
text: HOUSTON  Arson investigators have been called in to scrutinize a fire that destroyed the warehouse where all of Harris County’s voting machines were stored. The blaze left county officials scrambling to find enough equipment to hold an election in the nation’s third-most-populous county.

headline: U.S. Open Photo Replay: Sept. 10
text: Images from Friday’s matches at the United States Open.

headline: Found History in Velvet and Satin
text: Some of the rich history behind the stash of skullcaps at the Bialystoker Synagogue on Manhattan’s Lower East Side.

headline: Chamber of Commerce Accused of Tax Fraud
text: WASHINGTON  With a war chest rivaling that of the Republican Party itself, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce has emerged in the last year as perhaps the Obama administration’s most-well-financed rival on signature policy debates like health care and financial regulation.

headline: Typical Day for Mets: More Trouble and Another Loss
text: An excruciatingly long day for the Mets produced a string of new items for the club’s growing list of mishaps and misadventures.

headline: Sports Replay: Sept. 10
text: A view of the day in sports, with action on the mats, on the track and in the water.

headline: Eli Lilly Wins Court Ruling in Zyprexa Case
text: Eli Lilly & Company won reversal of a ruling that had granted class-action status to a suit by pension funds, unions and insurers that claimed improper marketing of Zyprexa, its schizophrenia treatment, raised their costs. A federal appeals court in New York threw out a September 2008 ruling by Judge Jack B. Weinstein of United States District Court in Brooklyn. He had said the plaintiffs, which included unions, pension funds and insurance companies, could pursue as a group claims that Lilly’s Zyprexa marketing caused them to pay more for the drug than it was worth. The plaintiffs were seeking $6.8 billion in damages. The appeals court reversed that decision, finding that the link between marketing Zyprexa to doctors and the injury claimed by the payers was “attenuated.”

headline: Profit Falls at Smith & Wesson as Gun Sales Slow
text: The Smith & Wesson Holding Corporation, the gun maker, said its quarterly earnings fell by about half as sales of firearms declined. The company issued a quarterly forecast that fell short of Wall Street expectations. Smith & Wesson said it earned $6.2 million, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter, down from $12.4 million or 21 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales in the period, which ended on July 31 and was the first quarter of Smith & Wesson’s fiscal year, fell 6.7 percent, to $94.9 million from $101.7 million. For the second quarter, it expects to break even with sales in a range of $97 million to $102 million. The forecast fell short of a profit of 11 cents a share and sales of $111 million expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters. The company, based in Springfield, Mass., reported results after the close of trading Thursday, and on Friday its stock fell 31 cents, or 8 percent, to $3.65 a share.

headline: On Fashion’s Night Out, Normal Hits the Streets
text: Fashion’s Night Out, now in its second year, may be responsible for several things: marking the unofficial start of fall fashion, bringing New York Fashion Week to the masses and demonstrating once again the power of Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue and the person most responsible for getting hundreds of retailers throughout the city to turn their stores into party spaces for a night.

headline: After Ruling on Gay Policy, New Questions for Obama
text: WASHINGTON  In many ways, the ruling on Thursday by a federal judge that found the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy toward gay and bisexual members of the military unconstitutional is good news for the Obama administration.

headline: Juan Mari Bras, Voice for Separate Puerto Rico, Dies at 82
text: Juan Mari Bras, a leading advocate for Puerto Rican independence who took his fight to Congress and the United Nations, died Friday at his home in Rio Piedras, a suburb of San Juan. He was 82.

headline: Irwin Silber, Champion of the Folk Music Revival, Dies at 84
text: Irwin Silber, a founder and the longtime editor of the folk-music magazine Sing Out!, who was one of the prime movers behind the folk-music revival of the 1950s and 1960s and, on a famous occasion, treated Bob Dylan to a public scolding for abandoning his political songs, died on Wednesday in Oakland, Calif. He was 84.

headline: Bent Larsen, Chess Grandmaster, Dies at 75
text: Bent Larsen, a Danish-born chess grandmaster who was a perennial challenger for the world championship during the 1960s and ’70s, died on Sept. 9 in Buenos Aires, where he had lived for many years. He was 75.

headline: What to Watch on Saturday at the Open
text: Kim Clijsters has an opportunity tonight to do what no woman has done since 2001: successfully defend her United States Open title. She’ll face Vera Zvonareva, who dispatched the No. 1 seed Caroline Wozniacki in straight sets on Friday.

headline: G.O.P. Takes Aim in Indiana
text: It was a safe bet that Representative Joe Donnelly, Democrat of Indiana, was nervous about his re-election when he starting broadcasting television ads last month trying to distance himself from his party leaders. He was among the first Democrats to run an ad criticizing Speaker Nancy Pelosi and President Obama.

headline: Big Spending, Not-So-Big Results
text: Despite breaking California’s campaign spending record and running thousands of ads since the June 8 primary, recent polls show that Meg Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor, is still neck and neck with her Democratic opponent, Jerry Brown, who just this week broadcast his first television and radio ads. Ms. Whitman, the former C.E.O. of eBay, has spent $100 million, mostly her personal fortune, while Mr. Brown has spent less than $1 million through the beginning of August. Ms. Whitman’s best chance of winning in November rides on whether she can capture the vote of independents, who make up a fifth of all registered voters in California. In 2006, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, a Republican, won after taking more than half of the independent vote.

headline: Homers by Cruz Cost Yankees a Lead, Then Game
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Yankees’ bus was supposed to depart Rangers Ballpark at 12:50 a.m. Saturday morning, but it was already 12:55 and one very important passenger had yet to board. “It’s waiting for you,” Derek Jeter was told, as he walked out of a clubhouse that had emptied quickly, and with little spoken, after 5 hours 12 minutes of ragged baseball ended with a 6-5 loss to the Texas Rangers in 13 innings.

headline: Guide to N.F.L. Defenses, Part 6: The 46 Defense
text: Jene Bramel writes for Footballguys.com. You can also follow him on Twitter and reach him at bramel@footballguys.com.

headline: Barn Finds Crash the Antique Car Party
text: The cars on display at the seventh-annual Fairfield County Concours d’Elegance in Westport, Conn., this weekend will mostly be pristine, but one sorry grouping will resemble the far back row in a used car lot. These cars are “barn finds,” and the upscale event (held on the grounds of a hunt club) made a special effort to find and display them among the million-dollar showpieces.

headline: Ravens Stress Getting Ball Into End Zone, Not Just Keeping It Out
text: Westminster, Md.

headline: Brian Jones Previews Michigan-Notre Dame
text: Brian Jones is a studio analyst for CBS College Sports Network. He can also be seen every Tuesday night during the season as part of “The Tony Barnhart Show” at 9 p.m. and “Inside College Football” at 10.

headline: American Teenager Gets a Taste of the Wheelchair Competition
text: Mackenzie Soldan has some schoolwork to get to this weekend, but she might be a little preoccupied by her first experience at the United States Open.

headline: A Champ Has Rivals, but No Equals
text: Esther Vergeer of the Netherlands will take to the court Sunday afternoon in a United States Open final and, if her previous 395 matches are any indication, she will win.

headline: Arroyo’s Leg Kick Reaches Back to ’86
text: As the Mets play out the schedule of another forgettable season, their younger fans might not realize just how dynamic, and influential, their team was in the mid-1980s. For proof, they can look at three stars of today.

headline: Time in a Basket
text: LIKE most synagogues, the Bialystoker Synagogue, on the Lower East Side, keeps a stash of skullcaps in the foyer, for anyone who forgot to bring one. In a tattered wicker basket, under a collection of limp nylon kippot and forgettable leather circles, lies a layer of shimmering velvet and satin yarmulkes in gaudy pinks, lemons, baby blues and golds.

headline: At a Memorial Ceremony, Loss and Tension
text: Updated, 12:19 p.m. | Thousands of relatives of the 9/11 dead gathered in a park near ground zero on Saturday morning for the ninth annual reading of their names as a nation debated whether a mosque and Islamic community center should be built near ground zero and a president pleaded for religious tolerance.

headline: Learning the Ropes
text: Orly Genger discusses her jewelry designs and what led to her success.

headline: Open House: Great Expectations (and Theater) for a Nadal-Federer Final
text: Gerry Marzorati: Morning, Michael. We all know what today is about. Today is about Rafael Nadal beating Mikhail Youzhny, then Roger Federer beating Novak Djokovic. This way we New York tennis fans get to have OUR Fed-Rafa final, just like all those other people have had in THEIR Slams. Today, in effect, is about the promise of great tennis TOMORROW.

headline: Sneak Peek | Tauba Auerbach for Ohne Titel
text: Science, art and fashion come together in the latest collaboration between Ohne Titel’s Flora Gill and Alexa Adams and their friend, the first-time jeweler and longtime artist Tauba Auerbach. The accessories, which will make their debut this weekend on the Ohne Titel runway, were the result of much experimentation — with shapes, geometry, problem solving and visual equations, even a science lab. “Our creative processes are similar and both very technical,” Gill says. “It made sense since our work shares a sleekness combined with underlying hand-wrought elements.” Contorting acrylic tubing around colorful enamel chords, Auerbach created a spiraling sculpture-like necklace and chose polished lucite and elastic bracelets. “I wanted to use a lot of clear material so that I could make big pieces that wouldn’t be too dominating,” she says. “I thought it would be interesting to see the clothes through the jewelry, and to make certain parts of the pieces like the elastic on the bracelets appear suspended in the air around the models’ wrists. I chose Lucite because it was durable and I could form it myself.” Our hypothesis? We’ll see bold graphics, wisps of bright orange and red alongside a looser silhouette with a play on sheer fabrics.

headline: City Disavows Pastor’s Talk of Burning Koran
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  Stephanie George used to see members of the Dove World Outreach Center at her neighborhood grocery store, wearing T-shirts that said “Islam is of the devil.” But on Friday, she and her friend Lynda Dillon showed up early at Dragonfly Graphics to order a dozen shirts with a different message: “Love, not Dove.”

headline: Two Killers, No Filler: Jerry Lee Lewis Performs With ‘Million Dollar Quartet’
text: After Levi Kreis, the Tony Award-winning star of Broadway’s “Million Dollar Quartet,” made the pilgrimage to the hotel suite of Jerry Lee Lewis, it was only fair that Mr. Lewis return the favor. On Friday night, Mr. Lewis, the last surviving principal member of a legendary 1956 jam session that also included Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash and Carl Perkins, came to the Nederlander Theater to play three encores with his “Million Dollar Quartet” counterparts. Video of Mr. Lewis’s performance (which we hear also drew former President Bill Clinton, his daughter, Chelsea, and her husband, Marc Mezvinsky, to the theater) appears above. Is this the first time that two Jerry Lee Lewises have shared the same piano?

headline: Day Of Infamy
text: Not much to say — except that it’s really sickening to see how an atrocity perpetrated against all people of good will has been appropriated as a partisan rallying point. When I wrote my first post-9/11 column, I got a lot of angry mail for reporting that partisan exploitation had already started; “How can I tell that to my young son?” demanded one irate father.

headline: Fashion Ties | Orly Genger’s Artful Accessories
text: Orly Genger is an artist with strong ties to fashion. Literally. Using only her fingers as tools, Genger crochets chunky yarn and heavy industrial elastic into monumental geometric forms that evoke the seemingly contradictory traditions of minimalist sculpture and women’s handicraft. In her collaborations with the jewelry designer Jaclyn Mayer, she transforms her signature forms into stunning statement necklaces that interweave metal with radiantly colored rope. This season, the Genger-Mayer team is creating runway accessories for Victoria Bartlett and Lela Rose. Here, Genger discusses her fashion designs and what led to her success.

headline: Pastor Cancels Burning of Koran
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  Terry Jones, the controversial pastor, said on Saturday that neither he nor his church would follow through on plans to burn copies of the Koran. In an appearance on NBC’s “Today” show, Mr. Jones said repeatedly and emphatically that the event, originally scheduled to coincide with the anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, was canceled and would not take place at any time.

headline: NYRB
text: Ah — forgot to link to our article in the New York Review. It came in long, so it has been broken into two parts; Part II coming soon.

headline: One Model To Rule Them All
text: Not really — but as we approach the second anniversary of Lehman’s fall, a few thoughts on how to think about macroeconomic policy.

headline: Saturday Word: Nine Years Later
text: The White House and Republicans – keenly aware of the political capital at stake with the midterm elections less than two months away – used their Saturday addresses to honor the lives lost during the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks nine years ago and promote the ongoing fight against terrorism. At the same time, President Obama and Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona, who gave the Republican weekly remarks, dealt subtle jabs to their opponents in Washington.

headline: Seeking ‘Passion’ in Toronto
text: TORONTO—It’s not too frequent that one would find Bill Murray, Mickey Rourke and Megan Fox in a room together, let alone a film, but there they all were, at the Toronto premiere of Mitch Glazer’s “Passion Play.” Somewhat of a passion project for Mr. Glazer, the film has made a 20-year journey from script to screen. “My hair was jet black when I started this thing,” Mr. Glazer said at the premiere. And Ms. Fox, who plays a woman with wings in the fantasy-drama, was three when the script first began to make its way around Hollywood.

headline: A Post 9/11 Parenting Moment
text: On this day, dark with memories, Larissa Kosmos reflects on what has changed — and what has not.

headline: Succession Gives Army a Stiff Test in Egypt
text: CAIRO  When a boiler at Military Factory 99 exploded in early August, killing one civilian worker and injuring six, a group of employees called a strike to demand safer working conditions, as they are entitled to do under Egyptian law.

headline: Attendance Dips at the Open
text: More than 640,000 tennis fans attended the United States Open in the first 12 days of the tournament, according to the United States Tennis Association. At least 60,000 more are expected over the final weekend.

headline: N. Korea Suggests Family Reunions
text: SEOUL, South Korea — In a surprise gesture of reconciliation that could ease tensions on the divided Korean Peninsula, North Korea proposed to South Korea on Saturday that they arrange reunions of families separated by a war six decades ago.

headline: Acrostic: Back at the Ranch …
text: ACROSTIC NOTES — There’s a nice smattering of clues and answers relating to the subject of today’s acrostic. F, K, Q and X have a definite tie-in, but what do you think about B, O and T?

headline: Nadal Dismantles Youzhny to Reach Final
text: Rafael Nadal jumped into the sunshine and jabbed both fists into the crisp September air, allowing a joyous grin to escape for a brief moment. He crushed the 12th-seeded Russian Mikhail Youzhny, 6-2, 6-3, 6-4 in the first men’s United States Open semifinal, and celebrated one hurdle now behind him.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Balenciaga’s Fashion Night Out Party
text: Scenes from Balenciaga’s Fashion Night Out party, which featured a performance by Karen Elson, as taken by Elle Muliarchyk.

headline: China and Tibet
text: Lodi Gyari, the Dalai Lama’s representative in Washington, has a good op-ed in the South China Morning Post (by subscription only). In particular, he makes two points that I think Beijing just doesn’t “get.” First:

headline: Runway Beauty | Rag & Bone
text: Gucci Westman and Guido Palau imagined the spring makeup and hair (respectively) of the Rag & Bone downtowner as a bit of an afterthought following a rainforest adventure. The inspiration, Westman explained backstage, “was a combination of a real girl who’s gone on a trip and Peter Lindbergh girls of the ’80s.” To wit, she used a taupe shadow (from Revlon’s Multi Use Palette in Suede Rhapsody, available next month), cream blush (Revlon Berry Flirtatious) and Revlon Colorburst Lipstick in Fashion’s Night Pout, which will only be available via the brand’s Internet giveaways. Most fascinating was Westman’s treatment of the brows: she brushed them through with Elizabeth Arden Eight Hour Cream and set them with Brilliant Diamant, a hairspray that she picked up in Paris. (“We only have one bottle to share between us!” she said.)

headline: On Sept. 11 Anniversary, Rifts Amid Mourning
text: The ninth anniversary of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, was marked on Saturday by the memorials and prayer services of the past, but also by events hard to envision just a year ago  heated demonstrations blocks from ground zero, political and religious tensions and an unmistakable sense that a once-unifying day was now replete with division.

headline: A G.O.P. Leader Tightly Bound to Lobbyists
text: WASHINGTON  House Democrats were preparing late last year for the first floor vote on the financial regulatory overhaul when Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio and other Republican leaders summoned more than 100 industry lobbyists and conservative political activists to Capitol Hill for a private strategy session.

headline: Alonso Carries Ferrari to Pole, at the Italian Team’s Home Race
text: MONZA, Italy — The qualifying session was interesting in more than just a few ways. For the first time since 2008 there is a Ferrari on the pole position, and the fact that it happened here in Monza for the Italian Grand Prix is not just special, it is magical. That it was Fernando Alonso who got it, while Felipe Massa took the third-fastest time was also certainly a nice feeling for the Spaniard who has been under fire so much since the team orders fiasco, where he has been accused of taking points for free from Massa.

headline: Nadal’s Uncle Is Heard From the Box
text: Rafael Nadal’s uncle, Toni Nadal, is also his coach. As I wrote in this profile, he keeps a low profile. The exception is during matches, when he has been known to coach his nephew from the players’ box, in violation of the rules.

headline: American Doctors Held in Zimbabwe

headline: Tough Season for Female Pitcher
text: CHICO, Calif.  Eri Yoshida, an 18-year-old sidearm knuckleball pitcher from Japan, arrived here in May amid widespread fanfare  a near-capacity crowd of 4,000 attended her first start. But she did little this season to disprove critics who saw her presence as a publicity stunt.

headline: Another Branch in a Baseball Family
text: CHICO, Calif.  At times the cloistered world of baseball feels small enough that it can be covered with cowhide, held together with red stitching and fit neatly in the palm of the hand.

headline: After Durant’s Big Day, U.S. Will Play for Gold Against an Unfriendly Host
text: ISTANBUL  Kevin Durant’s day of dominance began with a fadeaway jumper from the corner. It continued, fast and furiously, with a flurry of step-back 3-pointers, fast-break dunks and pull-up jumpers off crossover dribbles.

headline: Scorecard | Jason Wu Wins!
text: Give us Liberty! Day two of fashion week, and Scorecard finds critics wading through shades of greige. Minimalism is officially on, but the uptown girl’s downtown designer Jason Wu provided a welcome object lesson in crisp tailoring — with an explosion of riotous floral prints.

headline: Djokovic Outlasts Federer to Reach Final
text: Novak Djokovic of Serbia fought off match points and a history of losing the close ones to upset Roger Federer with a 5-7, 6-1, 5-7, 6-2, 7-5 victory to reach the men’s finals of the 2010 United States Open.

headline: Ohne Titel: Tight and White
text: At 12:30 p.m., half an hour after the doors opened at the Ohne Titel show and moments after a curtain was dropped at the entrance, the curtain reopened to admit Olivier Zahm, the editor of Purple magazine, who was still trying to stuff change from a cab ride back into his too-tight jeans as the show began. Make no mistake, Fashion Week is not just about the shows at Lincoln Center, as editors have had to hustle their way uptown, downtown and crosstown. And this was only Day 3, at a far-off place convenient only to the entrance of the Lincoln Tunnel.

headline: Prabal Gurung Makes a Case for Class
text: Believe it or not, Prabal Gurung had young Miley Cyrus and her miniskirts in mind when he began working on his spring collection. He was not inspired by her, mind you. He was reacting against her.

headline: With Escape, Djokovic Rewrites the Ending
text: Heart. Guts. They are essential elements for a tennis star. But somehow, despite emerging from war-ravaged Serbia and leaving his family at age 12 to become a champion, Novak Djokovic has faced questions about them as he has settled into a supporting role behind two of the greatest players in history.

headline: Prime Number
text: 0.92: The average return on interest-bearing deposit accounts in August, according to Market Rates Insight, which tracks bank rates. This was the lowest the measure has dipped since 1952, when the data begins. The ultralow rates penalize people with no debt who are trying to save, and those relying on returns from their nest eggs. The winners are borrowers. The 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage is at its lowest point in more than half a century.

text: The Obama administration has proposed tough and much-needed regulations for lucrative for-profit colleges. Industry is predictably pushing back hard, with legions of high-priced lobbyists and organized letter-writing campaigns. The administration must hold its ground.

headline: Readers’ Views: Equality Among the Dead

To give a public airing to a few more of the issues raised, I will periodically  starting today  publish comments from readers, along with brief responses from the Times staff and, when appropriate, myself.

headline: Time for This Big Dog to Bite Back
text: NO, he can’t. President Obama can’t reverse the unemployment numbers by Election Day. He can’t get even a modest new stimulus bill past the Party of No, and even if he could, there would be few jobs to show for it until (maybe) 2011. Nor can he rewrite the history of his administration. Its signal accomplishments to date are an initial stimulus package that was overrun by the calamity at hand and a marathon health care battle as yet better known for its unseemly orgy of backroom wrangling than its concrete results. While that brawl raged, the White House seemed indifferent to the mounting number of Americans being tossed onto the Great Recession scrapheap.

headline: Obama's Speech at the Pentagon
text: Marking the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks at the Pentagon, President Obama said, "We gather to remember, at this sacred hour, on hollowed ground." (Video: MSNBC)

headline: Disappointment for a Favorite
text: The field of the Grand Prix Cycliste de Quebec was filled with several top riders. But perhaps unsurprisingly, the clear favorite of the crowd was Ryder Hesjedal, a Canadian who finished seventh in this year’s Tour de France. Hesjedal, who rides for the American-backed Garmin-Transitions, offered a dramatic break from the field in the final laps of the 176.4-kilometer race, which featured two tough climbs and many tricky descents. But ultimately his fans were disappointed. Thomas Voeckler, a French rider usually known for long and unsuccessful solo moves, staged a short solo break on the uphill finish for the victory. The race marked the arrival of the International Cycling Union’s ProTour in North America, a race series that that is restricted to the world’s top teams. A second ProTour race will be held in Montreal on Sunday. ¶The United States Anti-Doping Agency has issued a lifetime ban to the cyclist Duane Dickey for a second violation for his use and possession of the banned endurance-boosting hormone EPO and his refusal to give a sample for testing. ban (AP)

headline: When Labor Peace Meant Prosperity for All
text: It is not too early for fans to hope that N.F.L. owners and players experience an Ebenezer Scrooge moment of enlightenment and see the error of their greedy ways. Otherwise, this season is going to be the last one for some time.

headline: We’re No. 1(1)!
text: I want to share a couple of articles I recently came across that, I believe, speak to the core of what ails America today but is too little discussed. The first was in Newsweek under the ironic headline “We’re No. 11!” The piece, by Michael Hirsh, went on to say: “Has the United States lost its oomph as a superpower? Even President Obama isn’t immune from the gloom. ‘Americans won’t settle for No. 2!’ Obama shouted at one political rally in early August. How about No. 11? That’s where the U.S.A. ranks in Newsweek’s list of the 100 best countries in the world, not even in the top 10.”

headline: China Explores a Frontier 2 Miles Deep
text: When three Chinese scientists plunged to the bottom of the South China Sea in a tiny submarine early this summer, they did more than simply plant their nation’s flag on the dark seabed.

text: While tennis fans hoped for a men’s final between Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer on Sunday  which is not going to happen  hardly anybody would have called for a women’s final between Kim Clijsters of Belgium and Vera Zvonareva of Russia.

headline: Is This America?
text: For a glimpse of how venomous and debased the discourse about Islam has become, consider a blog post in The New Republic this month. Written by Martin Peretz, the magazine’s editor in chief, it asserted: “Frankly, Muslim life is cheap, most notably to Muslims.”

headline: Pro Football Still Owes Debt to A.F.L., Fifty Years After Its Birth
text: Pro football’s structure is so perfectly configured: 32 teams split into two conferences, each with four division winners and two wild cards in the playoffs leading to the nation’s annual sports holiday, Super Bowl Sunday.

headline: Readers on the Anti-Muslim Frenzy
text: My Sunday column is back to the anti-Muslim frenzy, along with the nuttiness that has beset the Republican Party (52 percent of Republicans think Obama wants to impose sharia law….). I was particularly aghast at New Republic’s blog post by Martin Peretz wondering whether Muslims should be denied First Amendment rights, because I’ve admired the New Republic on so many issues over the years. Yet the New Republic will now be quoted decades from now when historians write about the bigotry of this season.

headline: Some Ask if Ozawa Is the Force That Japan Needs

text: PUZZLE NOTES — Today’s puzzle is going to cost you an ARM and a LEG, five times over. Those three-letter combos appear rebuslike, with five ARMs in the left half of the grid and five LEGs on the right.

headline: Iceland Considers Charges in Nation’s Banking Collapse
text: Iceland’s Parliament will consider whether to charge the country’s leaders in 2008 with negligence in connection with the nation’s banking collapse, after a committee recommended on Saturday that they be indicted.

headline: My Nine Years as a Middle-Eastern American
text: IN the late ’90s and early ’00s, I used to frequent a boutique in the East Village called Michael and Hushi. Hushi Mortezaie, an impish club kid born in Iran and raised in the Bay Area, made outlandish, psychedelic, robot-chic clothing and was getting the coolest of the East Village cool kids to wear his strategically slashed and torn Farsi-graffitied shirts, though none of them had any idea that in some cases they were bearing post-Iranian Revolution political slogans.

headline: Housing Doesn’t Need a Crash. It Needs Bold Ideas.
text: WE all know that most of us don’t tackle problems until they’ve morphed into full-blown crises. Think of all those intersections that get stop signs only after a bunch of accidents have occurred.

headline: Runway Grooming | Duckie Brown
text: At Duckie Brown’s runway show yesterday, American Crew, the men’s grooming brand, unveiled Curl and Boost, a new collection of specialized styling aids developed specifically for thinning and curly hair. Paul Wilson, the company’s artistic director, created two distinct looks to demonstrate the line’s versatility. While manipulating a model’s thick, curly locks, Wilson said that the first style, which was sleekly molded and sculpted close to the head, showed off “shorter, groomed, tamed and really shiny hair.” To sharply contrast that look, he created a second style that sported “full, lived in, dry-textured hair.” A tandem exercise in style extremes, the models’ hair complemented Duckie Brown’s spring fashions, which ranged from tailored trousers in muted tones to eye-popping bug print shirts. The Curl and Boost system, which is comprised of Curl Control (tames rough, unruly hair), Curl Construct (defines and shapes curls), Boost Powder (mattifies and builds texture), and Boost Cream (lifts thin hair to new heights), sell for $17.95 each and will be available at authorized American Crew salons beginning in January 2011.

headline: Resale Fees That Only Developers Could Love
text: REBECCA AND TRENT DUPAIX of Eagle Mountain, Utah, spent a year searching for their dream home. The couple, who have five children, considered 15 to 20 houses before finding “the one.”
