headline: Football’s Media Scrimmage
text: THE N.F.L.’s regular season started on Thursday, a welcome relief for football fans who spent the last month suffering through dull preseason matchups, which serve largely as ways for coaches to evaluate which players will be cut and which will get to sit at the end of the bench.

headline: Books, at a Price
text: FREDERICK FERMOR-HESKETH, THE SECOND BARON HESKETH, belonged to a family that had collected books since the 19th century. He was obsessed with having the very best, The Guardian reports, and willing to pay for it. Now, 55 years after his death, some of his collection will be sold. There is a Shakespeare’s First Folio, a volume of 36 plays published in 1623; a cache of letters from Elizabeth I to the jailer of Mary, Queen of Scots; and a John James Audubon’s “Birds of America,” valued at $6.2 million to $9.2 million. The oversize book, with 435 hand-colored prints, was first bought by an early paleobotanist, Henry Witham. Of that transaction, Audubon, who died in 1851, wrote: “I determined in an instant that this gentleman was a gentleman indeed. ... We all talked much, for I believe the good wine of Mr. Witham had a most direct effect.”

headline: In South America, a Mine of Riches and an Economic Sinkhole
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil

headline: As Time Passes, the Goals in Afghanistan Shrink
text: WASHINGTON

headline: The Presidency, Chained to the World
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA tried to seize the moment last week, at the traditional start of the midterm election season, by laying out a series of new economic proposals. And yet, at least politically, there was something almost tangential about Mr. Obama’s latest initiatives, which included $50 billion for infrastructure projects and an extension of the Bush tax cuts for all but the wealthiest Americans. The country’s economic trajectory heading into November is probably unchangeable at this point, which means that nothing the president does now is likely to alter the grim data confronting the electorate.

headline: Testing, the Chinese Way
text: When my children were 6 and 8, taking tests was as much a part of the rhythm of their school day as tag at recess or listening to stories at circle time. There were the “mad minute” math quizzes twice each week, with the results elaborately graphed. There were regular spelling quizzes. Even today I have my daughter’s minutely graded third-grade science exams, with grades like 23/25 or A minus.

headline: Mayor Daley’s Mark
text: A look at a few of very visible changes made to Chicago by Richard M. Daley, who has transformed the city in his six terms as mayor.

headline: Chicago Is Mayor Daley’s Kind of Town
text: ALL cities change over time, but Chicago may be in a class by itself. It took a measure of sheer willpower to transform the “hog butcher for the world,” as Chicago was known around the middle of the last century, into one of the most forward-looking of cities, with an abundance of public art and green space alongside an ever-expanding skyline.

headline: To Create Jobs, Nurture Start-Ups
text: MODERN tools of data analysis  fast computers, smart software and vast troves of digital information  often open the door to new insights. Consider the subject of jobs in America.

headline: Reading E-Books in All the Colors of the Rainbow
text: BLACK-AND-WHITE movies have their film noir appeal, yet it’s glowing color that rules on most consumer displays these days, with one exception: the pages of e-book readers. There, color is still supplied the old-fashioned way — not by filtered pixels, but by readers’ imaginations.

headline: Building the Bridges to a Sustainable Recovery
text: LAST year’s economic stimulus program helped stem a crisis that was poised to rival the Great Depression. That’s the conclusion of the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, which recently assessed the program’s impact.

headline: A Wealth of Choices for a Value Investor

text: I GREW up in Philadelphia. When I was 11, I bet Alan Horwitz, a family friend who owned a real estate firm, that I could beat him in basketball. He said he was going to teach me a lesson about betting.

headline: Buildings Are Set Ablaze During Protests in Kashmir
text: NEW DELHI  Thousands of demonstrators staged a violent protest in Kashmir on Saturday, setting fire to a police office and other government buildings in the latest angry outburst after three months of almost daily Muslim protests against Indian rule in the Himalayan region.

headline: Inflation in China Is Rising at a Fast Pace
text: HONG KONG  For K. K. Lam, a 37-year-old accountant in Guangzhou, inflation means higher prices for pork and for vegetables like bok choy.

headline: A Cincinnati Ice Cream Maker Aims Big
text: CINCINNATI  Bud Currie wields a metal paddle to furiously transfer thick ice cream crammed with Oreo cookie bits from a two-gallon cylinder into pints that will ship to grocery stores. For eight hours a day, his handiwork is the closest thing to mass production found in a new plant here that makes Graeter’s ice cream, a fourth-generation family brand that is a regional icon with national  if risky  ambitions.

headline: With Dapper Looks and Accurate Shots, Moore Strolls to the Third-Round Lead
text: LEMONT, Ill.  Looking like a matinee idol from a bygone era, Ryan Moore sauntered into the third-round lead at the BMW Championship on Saturday, shooting a breezy 66 for an eight-under-par total of 205, one stroke better than three players: Dustin Johnson (68), Charlie Wi (70) and Matt Kuchar (70).

headline: Greece Pledges More Economic Reforms
text: THESSALONIKI, Greece  Prime Minister George Papandreou declared Saturday night that his government had won a “relentless and grueling” battle to keep the country from going bankrupt, announced reforms to get the economy moving and sought to bolster the hopes of citizens whose salaries and pensions have been cut in an unprecedented austerity drive.

headline: An Uneasy Reversal of Roles for Theater and Its Caretaker
text: ATLANTA  For the last two weeks, Atlanta residents have been wrestling with the kind of difficult, emotional question normally posed only within families: when is a loved one too old to live alone?

headline: In Ingram’s Absence, Richardson Excels for Alabama
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Alabama’s Trent Richardson looks so dominant as a running back, Mark Ingram, the reigning Heisman Trophy winner, might have trouble getting his job back. Richardson had 92 yards rushing in the first quarter for No. 1 Alabama against No. 18 Penn State on Saturday.

headline: From Daley, No Endorsements or Regrets
text: CHICAGO  In this, a city now crawling with would-be candidates for mayor and what appear to be early signs of old divisions  racial, ethnic, geographic  that roiled City Hall in the past, at least one person seems unconcerned about the threat of a new era of political divisiveness.

headline: Boise State Loses Without Playing
text: With its high ranking in the preseason polls, a season-opening victory over Virginia Tech and a remaining schedule filled with winnable games, No. 3 Boise State was well positioned to make a run to the BowlChampionship Series championship game. Then the unexpected happened.

headline: Mets Prevail as Beltran Misses Game With Knee Pain
text: Compared with the medical news of the previous day about Johan Santana’s shoulder, the tendinitis in the left knee that kept Carlos Beltran out of the Mets’ lineup Saturday afternoon was no big deal.

text: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  Eight days ago, Michigan Coach Rich Rodriguez and quarterback Denard Robinson were two of the biggest question marks in college football.

text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: 30 Seconds with Lisa Leslie
text: Lisa Leslie, who joined the W.N.B.A.’s Los Angeles Sparks for the league’s inaugural season in 1997, was a three-time most valuable player and an eight-time All-Star before retiring last year. A former star at Southern California, she was in Manhattan recently to help promote the Capital One Cup, a new award in Division I college sports. It rewards athletic programs for their cumulative performance across multiple men’s and women’s sports.

headline: Watching the Catwalk, and Clicking ‘Add to Cart’
text: It used to be that designers showed clothes at Fashion Week to court the influential few, mainly the buyers and fashion editors who determined what styles would be hot in retail stores a season away.

headline: Boise State Loses Without Playing
text: When James Madison upset No. 13 Virginia Tech, 21-16, in Blacksburg, Va., on Saturday, it dimmed No. 3 Boise State’s chances of becoming the first team from a conference without an automatic Bowl Championship Series bid to reach the title game since the current system began in 1998.

headline: A Night Off for Jeter, in the Midst of an Off Year
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Yankees’ bus was supposed to depart Rangers Ballpark at 12:50 a.m. Saturday, but it was already 12:55 and one very important passenger had yet to board.

headline: Lucius Walker, Baptist Pastor for Peace, Dies at 80
text: The Rev. Lucius Walker, a Baptist minister who gained national attention with calls for reparations for the descendants of slaves and with repeated violations of the United States embargo of Cuba through caravans of humanitarian aid, died on Tuesday at his home in Demarest, N.J. He was 80.

headline: India’s Middle Class Waits for a Tee Time
text: NEW DELHI  When Arjun Atwal became the first Indian citizen to win a PGA Tour event, at the Wyndham Championship in North Carolina last month, newspapers here trumpeted his victory. India’s amateur golfers are still basking in the reflected glory.

headline: William H. Goetzmann, Pulitzer-Winning Historian, Dies at 80
text: William H. Goetzmann, who in a Pulitzer Prize-winning book overturned the idea of Western exploration in the 19th century as a series of random thrusts into the hinterland, finding instead that it was a far more systematic effort, died on Tuesday at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 80.

headline: Bill Gates Stirs Up the Education Debate in Toronto
text: TORONTO—Mild-mannered, soft-spoken, and beaming broadly, the Microsoft chairman Bill Gates looked every bit the benevolent businessman as he took the stage at the Toronto International Film Festival on Saturday evening, to help plug the education-reform documentary “Waiting for ‘Superman.’” Mr. Gates appears in the film, and, with his wife Melinda, heads a foundation that has invested heavily in improvements to education. But his aw-shucks manner couldn’t hide the fact that some of the proposals he tossed off on stage at the Winter Garden theater here were volatile stuff. “We’re investing in building these evaluation systems,” Mr. Gates said. He was referring to systems that would evaluate the performance of public school teachers, with an eye toward ending the current tenure system under which many teachers now work, and providing a way to weed out the worst teachers, while, perhaps, rewarding the best. He also mentioned, at least twice, changes to teacher pension systems.

Her comment was directed to Candy Pratts Price, the fashion director of Vogue.com, who was making a late arrival at the show, held on a pier off the West Side Highway, and had to walk past all the editors already in their seats.

headline: Russia Uses Microsoft to Suppress Dissent

headline: The End Is Near for the Mayor, but Citizens’ Woes Will Go On
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: The Daley Legacy, Inescapable
text: Trying to sum up the legacy of Mayor Richard M. Daley’s more than two decades in office in one neat snapshot is impossible. Mr. Daley is as complicated as the city he oversees. He is quick to anger, surprising, emotional; exceedingly loyal to some and ruthlessly business-like to others; parochial, yet overly sensitive when criticized for it. While he was in office, great strides were made. Mr. Daley oversaw a city that transformed its economy, making Chicago the vibrant hub of the Midwest. He remade the city’s front yard with Millennium Park, and showcased the city with a victory celebration after helping a Chicagoan win the highest office in the land. And he was ready to show it off on a global stage with an ambitious bid for the 2016 Summer Olympics. But there were also stunning setbacks. Moves like the middle-of-the-night takeover of Meigs Field solidified a reputation as a bully and autocrat. There was the humiliating Olympics loss  elimination in the first round of the International Olympic Committee’s voting process  and the privatization missteps. Recent high-profile crime in otherwise-stable neighborhoods undermined the good news of relatively lower crime rates. And now he leaves a financial mess for his successor. Most assuredly, Mr. Daley’s success as mayor will be debated for years. What follows is a look at his legacy in five areas  politics, education, crime, race and business  that will most likely frame Chicagoans’ discussions about the eventful mayoralty of Richard M. Daley. JIM KIRK

headline: Runway Beauty | Alexander Wang
text: It seems like Alexander Wang took in a showing of the Tamra Davis documentary, “Jean-Michel Basquiat: The Radiant Child,” which premiered this summer—backstage at his spring 2011 collection, the late artist was the most cited reference by makeup artist Diane Kendal, hairstylist Guido Palau, and Nonie Creme, co-founder of nail polish brand Butter London. Wang’s downtown gallerina was clad in sheer fabrics, optic white denim and wide-cut pants, paired with a no-look look that had beauty editors scratching their heads. “There isn’t really much makeup today,” said Kendal with a wry grin. She bleached brows by applying Wella Wellite Powder Lightener with a makeup brush “to keep the girls looking cool”—with the exception of Agyness Deyn, who apparently wasn’t up for a color change. And on the rest of the face? “Just concealer where needed and moisturizer. We wanted the skin to look shiny.” Over at the hair station, Palau said he “didn’t want hair color to stand out” and get in the way of the identity of Wang’s “new-age traveler woman.” To make the look uniform, he mixed Fuller’s Earth Clay–a cosmetic clay often used in DIY skincare recipes and that is also the main ingredient in popular 1940’s hair powder Minipoo—with white pigment and slicked the concoction through the hair. The resulting look was futuristic on models (including runway vets Karen Elson, Omahrya Mota and Karolina Kurkova), but in reality would look like someone in the middle of undergoing a double process (perhaps to emerge as the grey-haired woman seen earlier today at Cynthia Rowley). The nails, filed to a rounded shape, also appeared peculiarly half-done: manicurists applied one coat of Butter London Nail Foundation Flawless Basecoat followed by two coats of the brand’s Matte Finish Topcoat. The overall effect was certainly a look, and indeed, one best pulled off by a young art star, down to the late-breaking addition of faux rose gold septum rings.

In the slanty-sun and dark shade of Ashe late yesterday afternoon — the light evoked World Series games, which seems appropriate enough — the world of men’s tennis reached an inflection point, as we now like to say. What was before gave way. You know something is happening, and you do know what it is.

headline: Sleep Tight, and by Yourself

We want to be good friends, but even after explaining the risks of bringing bugs back to our place, he doesn’t seem to get it. We know we can catch bedbugs anywhere, and don’t want to make him feel like a leper, but we don’t want to risk infestation, either. What should we do? Anonymous

headline: Runway Beauty | Altuzarra
text: The spring beauty references to world travel, tribes and art keep coming, and seem to offer endless interpretations. Backstage at Altuzarra, the hairstylist Paul Hanlon deviated from his first plan. “Originally, we did a lot of dreadlocks, but it looked too dirty,” he said. “I wanted something very severe, but quite chic as well.” The solution: Hanlon slicked back the hair at the crown using Tigi Catwalk Your Highness Thickening Gel Creme, then back-combed sections “the way punks would” and flat-ironed them, creating pointy tips “so they look almost like knives.” For a final touch, each model got one of seven shades of Kryolan glow-in-the-dark gel painted on a thick stripe of hair above one ear. “We wanted the hair color to be a fluorescent accessory like a belt or a wristband,” Hanlon explained.

headline: When a Thief Comes to Call, Threat and a Bit of Chitchat
text: “The Smell of Popcorn” may remind you of an old news report. In 2005 a 26-year-old Georgia woman was taken hostage at gunpoint in the middle of the night in her own home. The man with the gun was the suspect in the courthouse killing of a judge and three others. headline: A Captive’s View of Life, and He’s 5
text: The narrator of Emma Donoghue’s “Room” is a 5-year-old boy who leads a busy life. “We have thousands of things to do every morning,” Jack tells the reader, and he seems to mean it. Jack is a smart, eager kid with a great imagination and unlimited energy. But he and his mother have been trapped in the 11-by-11-foot room of the title since the day he was born.

headline: Japanese Musicians Still Turn to the West
text: MATSUMOTO, Japan  The big news from Asia about Western classical music has been coming for a decade from China, where the surge in education and performance has been explosive. The brash and hugely gifted pianist Lang Lang has been an apt symbol of that explosion, though new star Chinese performers and composers seem to emerge by the month. The Chinese classical scene was amply represented in New York last season, alongside indigenous traditions, in a Carnegie Hall festival, Ancient Paths, Modern Voices, that prominently featured Lang Lang.

headline: ‘Boating’ With Philip Seymour Hoffman
text: TORONTO — The actor Philip Seymour Hoffman performed double-duty for his latest film, “Jack Goes Boating,” which screened earlier in the year at Sundance, is now playing here in Toronto and will open on September 17. The film, about a slightly reclusive limousine driver who finds love on a blind date, is adapted from Bob Glaudini’s 2007 play. Mr. Hoffman played the title role off Broadway and reprises it for the film, while also directing. He spoke with us abou the character of Jack and how he sought to portray him.

headline: Poet With a Kodak and a Restless Eye
text: WASHINGTON  The poet Allen Ginsberg, who died in 1997, adored life, feared death and craved fame. These obsessions seemed to have kept him, despite his practice of Buddhist meditation, from sitting still for long. He was constantly writing, teaching, traveling, networking, chasing lovers, sampling drugs, pushing political causes and promoting the work of writer friends.

headline: Scorecard | Alexander Wang Wins!
text: Need further proof that the Philoesque minimalist revival has come to America? Scorecard knows on day three of fashion week, New York’s prince of tough girl chic, Alexander Wang, saw the light. Meanwhile, Zac “my clothes are respected in Europe” Posen may be taking his signature show on the road to Paris, but he still found time to pile it all on to the max here in a Z Spoke kind of way.

headline: Monday: Brown Week
text: BROWN CROSSWORD WEEK — Every crossword this week, from Monday to Saturday, has been created by a member of the Puzzling Association of Brown University. Founded in 2008, the club for students has about 30 members, who meet weekly during the school year to solve and discuss puzzles. Each spring, it organizes a campuswide crossword tournament. Other universities with crossword clubs include Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Texas Christian. Brown’s club, though, has the most members with published puzzles.

headline: Immigrants Who Import Their Trauma
text: Lurking somewhere in the noisy mess of “underneathmybed,” a new play by Florencia Lozano that opened Sunday night at the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, is a potentially moving drama about the long reach of political violence.

headline: At Concert Tributes, a Mournful Undercurrent
text: For anyone who was a regular at Bargemusic before the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, that floating concert hall’s tribute to the victims and their survivors on Saturday evening was particularly poignant. You used to be able to see the World Trade Center from the seats on the barge in Brooklyn, through the huge picture window that overlooks the East River and Manhattan. On the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, Olga Bloom, the hall’s founder, watched the attacks from Bargemusic’s stage, where she had been doing her morning routine of playing through Bach sonatas.

headline: The Noises of Modern Life, Ending in a Bombardment
text: Approaching the work of Ryoji Ikeda, you risk becoming so mired in the what and the how that you can lose sight of something more pressing: the why. Since the mid-1990s Mr. Ikeda, a Japanese composer and multimedia artist now based in Paris, has fashioned music that explores and exploits aural perception by manipulating sounds at the outermost edges of what many listeners would term agreeable: extreme high and low frequencies; split-second variations in intensity, direction and duration; barely perceptible sounds; assaultive bursts of digital noise.

headline: A Total Loss in Texas Before the Yankees Head to a Showdown Series
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The visiting clubhouse at Rangers Ballpark has an eclectic décor: a few neon beer signs, a flag of Texas, a set of longhorns, some motivational sayings. One saying hangs above the primary bank of lockers.

headline: Evoking Collective Memories of a Dark Day
text: The first few years after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, an image became fairly common in dances created in New York: the act of looking up. On Saturday night at Le Skyroom, a fetching garret space at the French Institute Alliance Française with floor-to-ceiling windows and blue walls, the German choreographer and performer Raimund Hoghe offered his own meditation on the events of that day.

headline: Ochocinco and Owens Go Deep (Into the Tunnel)
text: There are various opinions on the best way to align your receivers for a Hail Mary play. Send three down one side. Run two together, then slide a third underneath.

headline: Holocaust Victim Is Remembered With His Music
text: A day before its memorial concert on Saturday for victims and survivors of the Sept. 11 attacks, Bargemusic paid tribute to the victims of another atrocity  Jewish composers killed during the Holocaust.

headline: A Master Class in Going the Distance, With No Compromises
text: Any concert by Sonny Rollins, the great unflagging sovereign of the tenor saxophone, bears the promise of a momentous occasion. His sold-out show at the Beacon Theater on Friday night delivered rapturously on that promise, with something else besides. Conceived as an 80th birthday celebration for Mr. Rollins, the concert found him in high spirits, in strong form and, for a generous stretch, in rare distinguished company. It was an evening worthy of an American master, and primarily because he made it so.

headline: More Post-Combat U.S. Gunfire in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  American military units fired on insurgents while supporting Iraqi troops northeast of the capital on Sunday, Iraqi officials said. It was the second such episode since the United States declared an end to its combat operations in Iraq less than two weeks ago.

headline: A Particularly Poor Weekend at the Box Office
text: The first weekend after Labor Day is typically the movie industry’s slowest of the year, as young audiences return to school, but the last three days were particularly weak. Despite sharply higher ticket prices, a lack of new releases left the North American box office down 11 percent for the weekend compared with the same period last year. The only fresh studio title in the market, “Resident Evil: Afterlife 3D,” was by far the most popular movie, selling about $27.7 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. This sci-fi movie, the fourth in a franchise, also opened strongly overseas with $45.5 million in sales. Constantin Film spent about $60 million to make “Resident Evil: Afterlife 3D”; Sony Pictures Entertainment bought the distribution rights. Sony’s crime thriller “Takers” was second with about $6.1 million for a new domestic total of $48.1 million. “The American,” a Focus Features release starring George Clooney, tumbled to third place with $5.9 million ($28.3 million total). “Machete” (20th Century Fox) was fourth with $4.2 million ($20.8 million total). Drew Barrymore’s “Going the Distance” (Warner Brothers) was fifth with $3.8 million ($14 million total).

headline: Sofia Coppola Takes Golden Lion in Venice
text: The director Sofia Coppola, above, was awarded the 67th Venice Film Festival’s Golden Lion prize for best film on Saturday, The Associated Press reported. “Somewhere,” Ms. Coppola’s drama about a Hollywood star who realizes how empty his life is after reconnecting with his 11-year-old daughter, stars Stephen Dorff (“Public Enemies”) and Elle Fanning, younger sister to Dakota. The festival jury was unanimous in its decision to award the prize to Ms. Coppola, said the director Quentin Tarantino, who served as this year’s jury chairman. “This film enchanted us from its first screening,” he said. The movie covers familiar territory for Ms. Coppola. Her widely praised 2003 film, “Lost In Translation,” shared similar themes, and Ms. Coppola spent much of her childhood moving around with her father, the director Francis Ford Coppola. Among the other prizes given out on Saturday were the Silver Lion, for best director, and the Osella, for best screenplay, both of which went to Álex de la Iglesia of Spain for his movie “Balada Triste de Trompeta” (“A Sad Trumpet Ballad”). A special jury prize was given to Jerzy Skolimowski for his film “Essential Killing,” which also earned Vincent Gallo (“The Brown Bunny”) an award for best actor.

headline: Tony Awards Stay at Home on CBS
text: CBS has extended its agreement with the Broadway League and the American Theater Wing to televise the annual Tony Awards ceremony, which honors theater professionals for distinguished achievement on Broadway. CBS has announced that a three-year agreement, through 2013, will keep the Tonys with the network, which has been broadcasting the ceremony since 1978. The Tony Awards telecast earned CBS two Emmy Awards this year, one in the special-class category and another for outstanding writing for a variety, music or comedy special. Next year’s show is to be televised in June. The awards were first held at the Waldorf Astoria on April 6, 1947, after being founded by the American Theater Wing as a tribute to Antoinette Perry, an actress, producer, director, and secretary and board chairwoman of the American Theater Wing throughout World War II.

headline: 2 Hollywood Newcomers Welcomed With Movies
text: The actress Noomi Rapace, above left, who portrayed Lisbeth Salander in the Swedish film adaptations of Stieg Larsson’s “Millennium” book trilogy, has been signed to play the lead female character in the coming movie “Sherlock Holmes 2,” according to The Hollywood Reporter. The Warner Brothers picture will bring back Robert Downey Jr. in the title role, along with Jude Law as Dr. Watson, with Guy Ritchie directing. Filming is expected to begin later this year. ... Christina Hendricks, above right, the more than capable office manager of Sterling, Draper, Cooper, Price on the television show “Mad Men,” has collected a bundle of new roles in movies. She has been cast in the romantic comedy “Life as We Know It,” with Katherine Heigl and Josh Duhamel; Hisako Matsui’s biographical film “Leonie”; and alongside Adrien Brody and James Caan in “Detachment.” Now Ms. Hendricks has landed a role in “Drive,” a new independent film adapted by Hossein Amini (“Killshot”) from the James Sallis novel, Variety has reported. She will join a cast including Ryan Gosling, Carey Mulligan, Albert Brooks, Bryan Cranston and Oscar Isaac. Nicolas Winding Refn will direct this thriller about a Hollywood stunt man involved in a heist gone wrong. Filming is expected to begin in Los Angeles in September, with Bold Films, OddLot Entertainment and Marc Platt Productions producing.

headline: Billie Joe Armstrong Talks at ‘Idiot University’
text: Billie Joe Armstrong, below, of the band Green Day may be doing more talking than singing during the next week. Beginning Tuesday, audiences at “American Idiot,” the Broadway show with music by Green Day, will be invited to remain after the performance for a discussion with Mr. Armstrong and the show’s director, Michael Mayer. According to Playbill.com, the two will be joined at “Idiot University,” as it is being called, by cast members from the show and members of the creative team. David Cote, theater editor at Time Out New York, will moderate the discussions, which will take place this Tuesday through Friday evenings and following the Sunday matinee. Mr. Armstrong will join Jordan Roth, president of the Jujamcyn Theaters, for a separate discussion at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday evening.

headline: ‘A Free Man of Color’ Adds to Its Cast of 33
text: Lincoln Center Theater has announced further casting for its coming production of John Guare’s play “A Free Man of Color.” Justina Machado (“Six Feet Under,” “In the Heights”) and John McMartin (“Into the Woods”), both above, have joined Jeffrey Wright (“Topdog/Underdog”), who will star as Jacques Cornet, a wealthy Don Juan whose life of leisure in early-19th-century New Orleans is altered when American rule is established in the Louisiana Purchase. The 33-member cast will also include Veanne Cox, Paul Dano and mos (formerly known as Mos Def), under the direction of George C. Wolfe (“Caroline, or Change”), a former artistic director of the Public Theater, which canceled its plans to produce the show in 2008 after an important financial backer withdrew her support. Previews at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center begin on Oct. 21, with an opening night set for Nov. 18.

headline: Runway Grooming | Simon Spurr
text: Kérastase Paris, the luxury hair-care line, debuted its first men’s hair maintenance system, Homme Capital Force, at Simon Spurr’s runway show today. Created to combat one of men’s more pressing grooming concerns- hair loss- Homme Capital Force features dual-action technology, Systéme Taurine, that deep-cleanses and fortifies the hair fiber from root to tip.

headline: Tea Partiers Bring Cause to Washington
text: WASHINGTON  Thousands of Tea Party supporters marched to the foot of Capitol Hill on Sunday, declaring their determination to topple the Democratic majority in Congress on Election Day.

headline: ‘Beat Memories’
text: Photos from the exhibition at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

headline: Hertz and Dollar Thrifty Agree to New $1.43 Billion Deal
text: 6:55 p.m. | Updated Hertz Global Holdings agreed on Sunday to raise its takeover offer for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group to about $1.43 billion in stock and cash, trumping a rival offer from the Avis Budget Group.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Walk the Line
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Skye Parrott.

headline: Israel Bends Slightly on Settlement Building
text: JERUSALEM  The prime minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, signaled for the first time on Sunday that he was willing to limit, though not completely halt, construction in the West Bank settlements after a partial building moratorium expires later this month.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Alexander Wang After-Party
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

headline: A Fashion Season Clad in White
text: At 6 p.m., the fashion flock reconvened to see Thakoon Panichgul’s spring collection in yet another gallery space in the far-flung reaches of Chelsea. After a long afternoon of rain, the editors were looking damp, clammy and restless for the show to begin. Many of them were anxious to get to Tom Ford’s cocktail party way up on Madison Avenue.

headline: Bad Economy Drives Down American Arms Sales
text: WASHINGTON  The global economic recession significantly pushed down purchases of weapons last year to the lowest level since 2005, a new government study has found.

headline: Clijsters’s Focus Is Family, With Eye on Majors
text: Kim Clijsters wants more major titles and more children, goals that would appear as incompatible as John McEnroe and silence.

headline: Afghan Commander Issues Rules on Contractors
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The NATO military command in Afghanistan has quietly issued new guidelines on contracting aimed at pushing commanders to take a tougher approach to how they spend billions of dollars. It is part of an effort to reduce corruption and decrease the funds that indirectly flow to the insurgency.

headline: F.C.C. Likely to Open New Airwaves to Wireless
text: WASHINGTON  When the Federal Communications Commission first approved the use of unlicensed bands of the airwaves decades ago, it began a revolution in consumer electronics  first in television remote controls and garage door openers, then in baby monitors and cordless phones, and most recently in wireless computer networks.

headline: New Beginning in New Stadium Leaves Giants Feeling Relieved
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The color of the gloomy sky Sunday matched the shade of the seats at New Meadowlands Stadium. But the Giants had lobbied for the right to play the first regular-season game in the new place, and a fortuitous coin flip and some sense-of-humor scheduling allowed them the chance to leave the bad memories of their 2009 departure from Giants Stadium  a 32-point loss to the Carolina Panthers  somewhere in the parking lot where the old building used to stand.

headline: Mexican Bicentennial Falls Short on Fervor
text: MEXICO CITY — There are the bicentennial buses. Bicentennial roads. A bicentennial marathon. A bicentennial song. The bicentennial digital library. A bicentennial video game. Even a bicentennial bird, the mountain trogon, and plant, the owl agave. And of course the bicentennial fireworks extravaganza, planned to be the largest the country has ever seen.

headline: Republicans Face Long Odds Against Gillibrand
text: They are the three dark horsemen in the race for the United States Senate from New York, kicking up cloudlets of dust as they canter toward the Republican primary election on Tuesday and a dubious distinction that Rudolph W. Giuliani, George E. Pataki, Theodore Roosevelt IV, Mortimer B. Zuckerman and Dan Senor considered pursuing but rejected: the strong likelihood of losing big in November to the Democratic incumbent, Kirsten E. Gillibrand.

headline: At New Meadowlands Stadium, Meat Cooked to Order
text: The New Meadowlands Stadium and its $1.6 billion price tag have been giving Jets and Giants fans sticker shock. To buy season tickets, most fans had to first spend thousands of dollars on personal seat licenses. The tickets are more expensive, too, as is the parking and food.

headline: A Street Vendor Takes the Big Step, From 59th Street to the Indoors
text: In his most trying moments, when the winter winds and the summer storms bore down with unforgiving intensity, the Senegalese street vendor would gaze across the street at Bloomingdale’s and allow himself a fantasy: his own concession inside its gilded doors.

headline: Crawford, With Talent Cultivated by Rays, May Be Too Good to Stay
text: BOSTON  Creative and forward-thinking as the Tampa Bay Rays are, they have not considered this suggestion from Mike Cameron. He proposes that the Rays use a two-man outfield, stationing Carl Crawford in the left-center-field gap.

headline: A Fiery Unknown Ruffles New York’s Republicans
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  Inside an Elks’ lodge here in the heart of middle-class Long Island, a crowd of 150 Tea Party members erupted into thunderous applause over the weekend when Carl P. Paladino, the resurgent Republican candidate for governor, outlined his plan to tame New York’s entrenched political class.

headline: Artists’ Collective and Burial Society Goes on the Move
text: For decades, the East Village has been home to countless avant-garde organizations and collectives, drawn to the area by its cultural vitality and low cost of living.

headline: Document Cites French Bid to Oust Roma
text: PARIS  French officials insist that they are not singling out the Roma as an ethnic group in their summer-long move to dismantle illegal camps of travelers, but an Interior Ministry document suggests otherwise.

headline: New Jersey Halts Work On Tunnels To Midtown
text: New Jersey officials have abruptly halted new work on an ambitious $8.7 billion plan to build two new commuter rail tunnels beneath the Hudson River, raising concerns about the fate of a project that had been hailed as a potential savior for the region’s overcrowded mass transit system.

text: In this installment of the Continental Picture Show series, Alec Soth tests his fortune among bingo players and lottery hopefuls.

headline: 2 Afghans Die in Protest Over Koran Burning
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two Afghans died in a remote area of eastern Afghanistan on Sunday when the police fired into a crowd protesting the planned burning of the Koran in Florida, a day after the burning had been called off.

headline: N.B.A. Has Sponsorship Deal With Global Bank
text: The N.B.A. has agreed to a four-year sponsorship deal worth more than $100 million with BBVA, the Spanish financial giant. BBVA will become the official bank of the league, the W.N.B.A. and the N.B.A. Development League, according to sources familiar with the deal who spoke on the condition of anonymity because it had not been announced.

headline: Fresh Off Victory, a More Confident Manning Prepares to Face His Older Brother
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Eli Manning lifted a stumbling Giants offense onto his back Sunday, throwing three touchdown passes to prevent an embarrassing defeat. He rallied the Giants three times and stayed cool even when some of his best passes became interceptions because his receivers deflected them into the air instead of catching them.

headline: Protecting Sanchez Outside the Pocket
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  At 23 years old, in his second N.F.L. season, quarterback Mark Sanchez remains the Jets’ single most important asset. Much thought goes into his every action, from macro plans (which events, what endorsements) to micro ones (dry cleaning, lost cellphones).

headline: In Primaries, Casting Votes Without Pulling a Lever
text: When New York City voters go to the polls on Tuesday to vote in primary elections for governor, attorney general, Congress and other offices, they may think they have showed up at the wrong location.

headline: Durant Lifts Americans Back to Top at Worlds
text: ISTANBUL  All the migraine-inducing whistles, artificial noisemakers and haunting chants from the overwhelmingly pro-Turkish crowd here could not rattle Kevin Durant in the world championships final Sunday.

headline: Kevin McCarthy, Actor, Dies at 96
text: Kevin McCarthy, the suave, square-jawed actor who earned accolades in stage and screen productions of “Death of a Salesman” but will always be best known as the star of the 1956 science fiction movie “Invasion of the Body Snatchers,” died Saturday at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass. He was 96 and lived in Sherman Oaks, Calif.

headline: At Goldman, Partners Are Made, and Unmade
text: On Wall Street, becoming a partner at Goldman Sachs is considered the equivalent of winning the lottery.

headline: U.S. Steps Up Efforts on Sudan Vote
text: WASHINGTON  With Sudan barely 100 days away from a referendum that is likely to split the country and that could even reignite a war, the Obama administration has begun a multifront diplomatic offensive built around incentives to keep Sudan from obstructing the vote.

headline: Hilfiger Collection Sticks to the Prep
text: The Strokes are performing at Tommy Hilfiger’s after party, which is just getting under way at Lincoln Center, so I will be brief. Mr. Hilfiger celebrated his 25th anniversary this evening with a collection he called “twisted country club.” He packed the front row with Neil Patrick Harris, Christina Hendricks, Bradley Cooper, Jennifer Lopez and Lenny Kravitz, so it was a little hard to concentrate on the clothes.

headline: New Tailgating Menu: Beer, Sausages and Travel
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The scent of sausages, peppers and steaks hovered over the Del Medico and Zito tailgating party, the latest incarnation of a tradition that goes back 40 years and continued Sunday at New Meadowlands Stadium.

headline: Senegal Court Forbids Forcing Children to Beg
text: DAKAR, Senegal  The judge spoke quietly, and decades of custom were quickly rolled back: the Muslim holy men were to be punished for forcing children to beg.

headline: Giants Replay: Sept. 12
text: As a crowd of 77,245 watched, the Giants defeated the Panthers, 31-18.

headline: The Congressional Ad Race: Who’s Buying and What’s Been Said?
text: In 56 of the most competitive House and Senate races, Republicans have spent nearly $20 million on general election television advertisements in the last six weeks. Democrats have spent nearly $13 million.

headline: In Ad Wars, Democrats Shy From Ties to Own Party
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Mark Schauer of Michigan does not dwell on the legislation he has voted for during his first term in Congress, which includes the Democratic stimulus plan and health insurance overhaul. But he reminds his constituents what he has fought against, declaring, “I must ask myself 10 times a day, what is Washington thinking?”

headline: Retooling in Response to Politico
text: Everyone knows that Washington is a pretty good place to look for news. Less well known? You can make money doing it.

headline: Risk and Reward
text: Two years after Lehman Brothers collapsed under the weight of mortgage-backed bets that went horribly wrong, banks’ pay practices have improved but fall short of what is needed to discourage bankers from once again taking unjustifiable risks.

headline: Revisiting the Eagles’ Call at Quarterback
text: Remember how Eagles fans booed the selection of Donovan McNabb in the 1999 N.F.L. draft, certain that Texas running back Ricky Williams was clearly the superior pro prospect?

headline: As Primaries Draw Near, Ads Take on Sharp Tone
text: Week after week, the five candidates in the Democratic primary for New York attorney general have managed to maintain a civil tone, refraining from personal attacks and focusing on their records  not their opponents  in their television commercials.

headline: Not a Food Crisis
text: Russia’s misguided decision to ban exports of wheat for the next 12 months has sent a destabilizing shock through agricultural markets, pushing prices of grains to their highest levels since 2007 and 2008, when food shortages sparked rioting around the world. The situation in poor grain-importing countries in Africa is tense. In Mozambique, the government backtracked on its decision to raise bread prices by 30 percent after riots in which more than a dozen people died. Still, the world need not experience another food crisis.

headline: The Bullet That Keeps on Killing
text: At the end of August, the Environmental Protection Agency turned down a petition to ban lead from the manufacture of hunting ammunition. According to the agency, it lacked the legal authority to regulate lead in that form.

headline: In From the Cold
text: To weaken the Afghan Taliban, American military commanders are hoping to lure fighters away from the insurgency with the promise of jobs, security and a better life. The idea is a good one. Like so much else in Afghanistan, this important initiative has badly faltered.

headline: I Know You Are, but What Am I, and Who Is He?
text: Just what do you think I is, anyway? Please don’t bother to correct my English. I’m using the grammar of existentialism, which Edward Albee deploys with the glee of a word-crazy freshman philosophy student in “Me, Myself & I.” This larky little comedy of ideas, about the conundrums of selfhood faced by a pair of identical twins and their addled mother, had its New York premiere on Sunday night at Playwrights Horizons. And if you furrow your nose, you can still whiff the infectious high spirits that must have gone into its writing.

headline: Viable Economic Structure Eludes Worldwide Tour
text: MONTREAL  Quebec’s largest city is something of a cycling mecca, with a highly developed rent-a-bike system and an annual recreational tour that attracts about 20,000 riders.

headline: China, Japan, America
text: Last week Japan’s minister of finance declared that he and his colleagues wanted a discussion with China about the latter’s purchases of Japanese bonds, to “examine its intention”  diplomat-speak for “Stop it right now.” The news made me want to bang my head against the wall in frustration.

headline: A City Transformed
text: The Chinese who have come to Prato, Italy, since the late 1980s have changed the city and its centuries-old textile industry.

headline: Dollar Thrifty Accepts Sweetened Bid From Hertz
text: Hertz Global Holdings agreed on Sunday to raise its takeover offer for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group to about $1.43 billion in stock and cash, trumping a rival offer from the Avis Budget Group.

headline: Chinese Remake the ‘Made in Italy’ Fashion Label
text: PRATO, Italy  Over the years, Italy learned the difficult lesson that it could no longer compete with China on price. And so, its business class dreamed, Italy would sell quality, not quantity. For centuries, this walled medieval city just outside of Florence has produced some of the world’s finest fabrics, becoming a powerhouse for “Made in Italy” chic.

headline: Chasing Federer, or Pulling Away?
text: With a pair of 2010 Grand Slam titles already in the bag and a potential third delayed one day because of rain, Rafael Nadal has clearly distanced himself from Roger Federer.

headline: Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include retail sales for August and business inventories for July (Tuesday); import prices for August and industrial production and capacity utilization for August (Wednesday); the Producer Price Index for August, the current account deficit for the second quarter, weekly jobless claims, and the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for September (Thursday); and the Consumer Price Index for August and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer confidence index for September (Friday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: An Energy Player to Reckon With
text: Eike Batista may soon be adding billions to his bank balance. Shares of the energy group OGX, the flagship vehicle of Mr. Batista, Brazil’s richest man, value its seven billion-odd barrels of shallow water oil reserves at about $5 apiece. That looks like a bargain against the $8.51 a barrel the government is extracting from Petrobras for deepwater crude. It’s no wonder China’s Sinopec Group and CNOOC are considering buying into OGX assets.

headline: N.F.L. Looks Into Possible Harassment by Jets
text: The N.F.L. is investigating the Jets’ behavior with a woman who was working as a reporter at Jets practice on Saturday. The reporter, Inés Sainz of TV Azteca, a Mexican television network, was reportedly harassed by players and coaches during practice and in the locker room.

headline: With a New Stadium, a Way to Avoid Driving
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For more than 100 years, fans of major league baseball in New York have taken the subway or the train to the game. But no such option has existed for football fans for the past quarter-century because the Giants and then the Jets played in the swampland of New Jersey.

headline: Boehner’s Smoking Habit Gets Scrutiny
text: WASHINGTON – When it comes to fighting what he views as the Democrats’ big-government agenda, the House Republican leader, John A. Boehner of Ohio, just won’t quit. It turns out, the same goes for his own heavy smoking habit.

headline: Retiring Later Is Hard Road for Laborers
text: At the Cooper Tire plant in Findlay, Ohio, Jack Hartley, who is 58, works a 12-hour shift assembling tires: pulling piles of rubber and lining over a drum, cutting the material with a hot knife, lifting the half-finished tire, which weighs 10 to 20 pounds, and throwing it onto a rack.

headline: A Mystery Man Unmasked
text: Usually the BBC and the News Corporation clash over matters like broadcasting regulations; now they are battling over a racecar driver who took a turn as a writer. Read more…

headline: For All, a Rain Delay; for Djokovic, a Reprieve
text: It was shortly after 6 p.m. Sunday. The United States Open men’s final between Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic had just been postponed, and Djokovic was leaning against a wall near the locker room in Arthur Ashe Stadium and grinning.

headline: Sports Replay: Sept. 12
text: A look at the day in sports, including the N.F.L.’s opening weekend.

headline: Celebrating Id al-Fitr Under Watchful Eyes of China
text: KASHGAR, China  Barbershop floors were littered with the remains of men’s haircuts and beard-trims. Women in head scarves walked the dusty streets carrying plastic bags stuffed with food from the bazaars: melons, grapes, fried sweets, Frisbee-shaped bread, chunks of freshly butchered sheep. Children with generous parents strutted around in new clothes: suits for the boys, white dresses for the girls.

headline: H.P. Nears $1.5 Billion Deal for ArcSight
text: Hewlett-Packard is close to a deal to buy ArcSight, a maker of security software, for about $1.5 billion, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Sunday, as the computing giant continues its recent buying spree.

headline: This Time, Johnson Seizes Chance and Championship
text: LEMONT, Ill.  On a bright Sunday at the BMW Championship, it all fell into place for Dustin Johnson. This time, as he played in the final pairing for the fifth time this year, there would be no impatience, no doubts and no rules infractions.

headline: Seeing a Tilt in Sunday Talk
text: It is a perennial complaint about American television news: that the guests on the Sunday morning public affairs programs are not representative of the country’s diversity.

headline: The Wish for a Conservative Dream Duo
text: ANCHORAGE  The T-shirts began showing up last year at Tea Party rallies, conservative confabs and book signings by the best-selling authors themselves, Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska, and Glenn Beck, the conservative talk show host.

headline: Old New Hampshire Hand Looks for G.O.P. Rebound
text: HAMPTON FALLS, N.H.  John H. Sununu, once the governor of this state and a powerful insider in the first President George Bush’s White House, was discouraged after the 2008 election. Not only had the Democrats firmly taken control in Washington and Concord, New Hampshire’s capital, but his son John E. Sununu had just lost his Senate seat in a bitter grudge match.

headline: The Oil Spill’s Money Squeeze
text: In May, Harriet M. Perry, the director of the fisheries program at the Gulf Coast Research Laboratory, was asked to examine some mysterious droplets found on blue crab larvae by scientists at Tulane University. An early test indicated that the droplets were oil, and she has continued to find similar droplets on fresh larvae samples taken all along the northern Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Fastest Net Service in U.S. Coming to Chattanooga
text: In the global race to see who can offer the fastest Internet service, an unlikely challenger has emerged: Chattanooga, Tenn.

headline: H.P. Is Said to Be Near Deal for Security Software Maker
text: Hewlett-Packard is close to a deal to buy ArcSight, a maker of security software, for about $1.5 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday, as the computing giant continues its recent buying spree.

headline: Days After ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Ruling, Another Challenge Heads to Court
text: For 17 years, Maj. Margaret Witt rose steadily through the Air Force and Air Force Reserves, winning plaudits from colleagues, strong performance reviews from superiors and service medals from the department. A flight nurse, she treated wounded troops during Desert Storm and was featured in Air Force promotional materials for years.

headline: Search Takes a Social Turn
text: Now, even on the Internet, it is not what you know but who you know.

headline: Tom Ford’s Very Small, Glamorous Show
text: When you’re Tom Ford, and you’ve been away from women’s fashion for six years, more than likely you’ve thought a great deal about your return, perhaps even plotted it down to the last buttonhole. That was the feeling imparted by Mr. Ford’s extraordinary show tonight, held in his men’s store on Madison Avenue before an audience of perhaps 100 editors. He had thought out every detail of the clothes and accessories, not least the kind of women whose glamour and personalities would express his ideas about dressing.

headline: Ron Kramer, Tight End With Packers and Lions, Dies at 75
text: Ron Kramer, a two-time all-American at the University of Michigan who became one of the first outstanding tight ends in the National Football League, playing for Coach Vince Lombardi’s Green Bay Packers championship teams of the early 1960s, died Saturday at his home in Fenton, Mich. He was 75.

headline: A Smoker, No Apologies About It
text: WASHINGTON  When it comes to fighting what he views as the Democrats’ big-government agenda, the House Republican leader, John A. Boehner of Ohio, just won’t quit. It turns out, the same goes for his own heavy smoking habit.

headline: Hollywood Reporter to Become a Weekly Magazine
text: LOS ANGELES  The Hollywood Reporter has been dying a slow death for a decade, bleeding from layoffs, vanishing advertisers and diminished relevance in a news cycle now dominated by cutthroat entertainment blogs.

headline: Man Convicted in ’91 Unrest Is Stabbed
text: A man who was convicted in the stabbing of a Hasidic scholar in racial unrest that engulfed Crown Heights, Brooklyn, in 1991 was stabbed early Sunday in Upper Manhattan, the police said.

headline: A Tech World That Centers on the User
text: This article was adapted from the book “I Live in the Future & Here’s How It Works” by Nick Bilton, the lead writer for The New York Times technology blog Bits. The book, to be published on Tuesday by Crown Business, examines the impact of technology on our lives.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell, Don’t Be All You Can Be
text: WASHINGTON, D.C. — Since the 1993 law known as “don’t ask, don’t tell” (D.A.D.T.) was enacted by Congress, more than 14,000 gay service members have been discharged, at a cost to taxpayers of $363 million  over the last decade. I am one of them. I was discharged just one month ago.

headline: N.B.A. Makes Sponsorship Deal With Spanish Bank
text: The N.B.A. has agreed to a four-year sponsorship worth more than $100 million with BBVA, the Spanish financial giant. BBVA will become the official bank of the league, the W.N.B.A. and the N.B.A. Development League.

headline: After Blast, Uneasiness for Residents Going Home
text: SAN BRUNO, Calif.  Hundreds of residents returned home on Sunday to the neighborhood that was evacuated after a natural gas pipeline exploded late last week.

headline: F.D.I.C. Takes Over Florida Bank
text: Regulators on Friday shut down a small Florida bank, bringing to 119 the number of bank failures this year, The Associated Press reports.

headline: American Beats American for U.S. Open’s Junior Title
text: Jack Sock, an American player with a big serve and a bigger forehand, beat his countryman Denis Kudla for the United States Open junior boys singles title Sunday. With every flick of his wrist, Sock, who won, 3-6, 6-2, 6-2, made 10 years vanish.

headline: Charles Leads U.S. Women Past Spain
text: Tina Charles had 17 points and 10 rebounds to help the United States’ women’s national team beat Spain, 85-69, in an exhibition game in Hartford. The United States led, 17-16, after one quarter, but Charles, the W.N.B.A. rookie of the year, scored 12 points in the second quarter. The United States is preparing for the world championships in the Czech Republic. ¶The N.B.A. has agreed to a four-year sponsorship deal worth more than $100 million with BBVA, the Spanish financial giant. BBVA will become the official bank of the league, the W.N.B.A. and the N.B.A. Development League. KEN BELSON

headline: Tired of Reality TV, but Still Tuning In

headline: Two French Automakers Start to Repay Government
text: Renault and Peugeot Citroën, the French automakers, said Friday that they had begun to repay, ahead of schedule, the billions of euros in government aid they received to help them through the financial crisis and recession, David Jolly reports in The New York Times.

headline: Social Networks Exhibit Senior Appeal
text: In the last year, social networking services have nearly doubled in popularity among online Americans over 50, while they made virtually no inroads among those ages 18 to 29, according to a report published by the Pew Internet and American Life Project. That spike in popularity includes those over 65 years old, who were twice as likely this year as last to say that they used such services.

headline: Building the Bridges to a Sustainable Recovery
text: Last year’s economic stimulus program helped stem a crisis that was poised to rival the Great Depression. That’s the conclusion of the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, which recently assessed the program’s impact, Robert H. Frank writes in The New York Times.

headline: Democrats Hoping to Take Advantage of G.O.P. Strength
text: With few signs of growth in their own political strength, Democrats set out this week on a two-month quest to leverage Republicans’ might against them.

headline: The Week Ahead

headline: Pursuit of the New, or Just the Sellable
text: Fashion doesn’t have much of a past now that everything is instant, and don’t expect clothes to look coherent or a designer to have a consistent style.

headline: Scramble for Tickets After Rescheduling of Men’s Open Final
text: Web sites like Craigslist and TicketMaster were overflowing with U.S. Open fans looking to buy and sell tickets for the men’s final, which was moved to Monday afternoon after persistent rain Sunday.

headline: Pennsylvania Speeds Aid to Its Struggling Capital
text: Pennsylvania is speeding payments of $3.6 million to its debt-laden capital, Harrisburg, to prevent the city from defaulting on a general obligation bond, Gov. Edward G. Rendell said on Sunday, Natasha Singer writes in The New York Times.

headline: Wrapping Men in New Colors for Spring
text: On Sept. 7, two days before the first day of Fashion Week, Pantone, a company that specializes in the trivialities of colors that designers use, announced its summary of what we would be seeing on the women’s runways for spring. There was a honeysuckle pink, a coral rose, a beeswax yellow and a variation on turquoise called Blue Curaçao.

headline: The War Between an Analyst and a Bank
text: For the last two years, Richard X. Bove, an outspoken analyst, has been engaged in a lonely legal battle to retain his ability to say whatever he likes, an ordeal that he says has been anything but fun, Andrew Martin and Louise Story of The New York Times report.

headline: Leader Tries to Rally Greece for Economic Battle
text: Prime Minister George Papandreou said Sunday that the spending cuts and economic reforms that his government has pushed through since May were “a small revolution,” but added that much more work was needed to revive the sluggish economy, Niki Kitsantonis writes in The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | September 13, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: The N.F.L.’s Worst Rule: ‘Going to the Ground’
text: N.F.L. Rule 8, Section 1, Article 3, Item 1: Going to the ground. If a player goes to the ground in the act of catching a pass (with or without contact by an opponent), he must maintain control of the ball after he touches the ground, whether in the field of play or the end zone. If he loses control of the ball, and the ball touches the ground before he regains control, the pass is incomplete. If he regains control prior to the ball touching the ground, the pass is complete.

headline: In Attorney General Race, Democrats Make Final Pitch
text: For months, they have shaken hands, nibbled corn dogs, dialed for dollars and clashed in debates. This weekend, in the homestretch of a long primary campaign, the five Democratic candidates for attorney general made their last dash to political battlegrounds — and their closing arguments to an electorate still up for grabs. Here, finally, is where the Democratic primary draws to a close: in a church in the Bronx and at a picnic in Hempstead; in a town square in Oyster Bay and on a street corner in Crown Heights — even amid the happy-hour throngs in Chelsea.

headline: Documentaries Zero In on Wall St., Mercilessly

text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea said Monday that it would send 5,000 tons of rice and other relief goods to victims of recent floods in North Korea, two days after the North proposed reunions of families separated by the Korean War.

headline: Aurelius Said to Be Sole Opponent to Dubai Deal

headline: Murakami’s Creations Invade Versailles
text: The Château de Versailles has been home to some oversize characters over the years (Louis XIV, say, or Marie-Antoinette), but starting tomorrow, it will host characters of a different sort: smiling flowers, alien sculptures and giant buddhas among them. They are the work of the Japanese artist Takashi Murakami, who follows Jeff Koons and Xavier Veilhan, as the latest pop artist to make Versailles his own — “My Versailles, manga style,” he calls it.

headline: Dodd-Frank Transparency Trips on Banks’ Black Boxes
text: It took a Congressional inquiry this year to force Goldman Sachs Group to disclose how much it made in the mortgage market — and that was only for 2007, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: From North to South, European Banks’ Capital Falls
text: After applying new banking regulations, Nordic banks will have the most surplus capital and be the most likely to distribute it to shareholders, while Italian banks will have the least available capital, according to a Matrix Corporate Capital analyst, Andrew Lim, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Sanofi Said to Line Up $10 Billion in Loans for Genzyme
text: Sanofi-Aventis, France’s largest drug maker, arranged about $10 billion of underwritten loans to back its bid for the United States biotechnology company Genzyme, two people familiar with the situation told Bloomberg News.

headline: Permira in Deal for Citigroup Satellite Broadcaster
text: Permira announced Monday that it had reached an agreement to purchase Asia Broadcast Satellite from a Citigroup venture fund. The Britain-based buyout fund, which is partnering with Asia Broadcast’s management on the deal, is paying about $200 million for the company in an all-equity transaction.

headline: Eisner on ABC 15 Years Later: Still Worth It
text: In hindsight, former Walt Disney chief executive Michael Eisner calls his decision in 1995 to buy CapCities/ABC, and with it, its crown jewel ESPN, ”one of the best acquisitions maybe of that whole century,” The Associated Press writes.

headline: Chinese Investors Said to Ponder Bid for Prudential

headline: Huang Maneuvers for Gome Control From Jail
text: The billionaire Huang Guangyu, fighting from jail for control of Gome Electrical Appliances, may seek to sell 400 privately owned stores to the company to increase his stake, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Oil Bets Up for First Time in Five Weeks
text: Hedge funds and other large speculators raised bets on gains in oil prices for the first time in five weeks on renewed signs the United States economy is recovering from the worst recession since the 1930s, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian | Vegan Vietnamese Noodle Salad
text: On the last warm days of the year, Michael Bao Huynh, the executive chef and owner of DOB 111 in Manhattan, will make a crunchy yet slippery Vietnamese vegetarian noodle salad. It has both hot (as in cooked) and cold (as in raw) vegetables, a scattering of fresh herbs and a piquant dressing made with fresh lime juice, garlic, Thai bird chilies, sugar and soy sauce.

headline: Three Groups Said to Mull ResCap Bids
text: Three groups — BlackRock, Fortress and Centerbridge Partners — are considering buying the mortgage finance business of GMAC, The Financial Times reports.

text: The red-hot coffee market may be cooling down soon as hedge funds pull back on bets that bean prices will go higher, Bloomberg News reported on Monday.

headline: H.P. to Buy ArcSight for $1.5 Billion

headline: Jockeying Delays Spill Research Money
text: In May BP pledged $500 million over 10 years for independent scientific research on the gulf oil spill – a substantial sum and a lonely one. There has only been one other major source of grants for study of the spill, from the National Science Foundation, which won high marks for timeliness but has substantially smaller pockets.

headline: Genzyme Sells Genetics Unit for $925 Million
text: Genzyme, which has been busy trying to fend off Sanofi-Aventis, announced on Monday that it was selling its genetics unit.

headline: Leukemia Drug Trial Fails
text: An experimental drug for acute myeloid leukemia being developed by Seattle Genetics failed to significantly improve survival in a mid-stage clinical trial, dealing another blow to efforts to treat the deadly blood cancer.

headline: Victims Angry as Belgium Responds to Church Abuse
text: BRUSSELS  The leader of the Roman Catholic Church in Belgium on Monday acknowledged the scale of the scandal that had engulfed the country over sexual abuse by priests and promised to do more for the victims, but he offered few short-term solutions and said little of substance about further pursuing the abusers.

headline: The MTV Video Music Awards: A Twitter Timeline
text: In a review of the MTV Video Music Awards in Monday’s New York Times, Jon Caramanica writes, “For the second year running,” the rapper Kanye West “got the last word.” Maybe he did on television, but in cyberspace, a steady flow of Twitter commenters were watching the awards program and passing judgment on Chelsea Handler‘s jokes, Lady Gaga‘s costume changes and all of the night’s musical performances – even Mr. West’s. Here’s an overview of how the night looked from the perspective of viewers who prefer their news and commentary in 140-character bursts:

headline: Open House: Just Another Manic Monday for Rain-Delayed Men’s Final

headline: We Three Things | Deep Woods
text: Inspired by the crisper air, my old sweaters and shinrin-yoku, I’m spending as much time as I can outside. While I’m not about to sally north, “Into the Wild”-style, my respect of, and attraction to, the woods is ever-present. One of my earliest memories is this 1979 National Film Board of Canada short, “The Log Driver’s Waltz,” from a song written by Wade Hemsworth, arranged and sung by Kate and Anna McGarrigle, with the Mountain City Four. Nature makes us better, and a log driver’s waltz pleases girls completely.

headline: Impeachment Trial Begins for Lousiana Judge
text: A special Senate committee this morning begins deliberating corruption charges against Judge G. Thomas Porteous Jr. It could set a precedent on whether a judge can be removed for conduct that occurred before he joined the bench.

headline: Sisters Acts
text: First came the expansionist decades, in which Hilton and Holiday Inn behaved like the Coke and Pepsi of the hotel business. Then came the boutique-hotel era, which moved lodgings from mass production to couture. But even the creators of one-off properties want to be able to offer their guests a change of scenery. Which explains the rise of the latest hotel hybrids: small-scale chainlets melding boutique DNA with expansionist ambition.

headline: Gingrich: President Exhibits ‘Kenyan, Anticolonial Behavior’
text: Newt Gingrich said this weekend that President Obama exhibited “Kenyan, anticolonial behavior,” an observation that drew angry if puzzled responses from Democrats and questions about Mr. Gingrich’s meaning and motivation.

text: Today’s idea: Our love of pets — indeed, our very civilization — derives from our primitive forebears’ need to understand animals so as to hunt, kill and eat them, an anthropologist says.

headline: National Oilwell in $500 Million Deal
text: National Oilwell Varco agreed on Monday to buy a subsidiary of BW Offshore of Norway for $500 million in cash.

text: Federal advisory panels this week will vote on whether to remove the weight-loss drug Meridia from the market and whether to move nonprescription cough medicines behind drugstore counters. headline: Webber’s 6th Place at Monza Helps in Formula One Chase
text: Mark Webber pulled out to a five-point lead over Lewis Hamilton in the chase for the Formula One championship, based on the outcome of Round 14 of 19 of the 2010 series at Monza, Italy, on Sunday. Webber finished sixth, while Hamilton crashed out of the event early.

headline: Multimedia Package | An Art Book You Can Wear, Too

headline: 2 Insurgents Could Hurt G.O.P. Chances for Senate Takeover
text: Tomorrow’s primaries in New York and six other states — the last of the 2010 cycle, save for Saturday’s primary in Hawaii and a runoff in Louisiana on Oct. 2 — originally looked as though they’d have little impact on the electoral landscape. Although some of the primaries were nominally competitive – like the Republican Senate race in Maryland, where a suite of 11 candidates will be on the ballot — they were typically not so in places where the nominee stood a strong chance of winning the general election.

headline: Cooking With a Mexican Favorite, the Tomatillo
text: If you’ve eaten salsa verde in a Mexican restaurant, you’ve eaten tomatillos. Though the name suggests that tomatillos are small green tomatoes, they are not. They’re in the same family as tomatoes but more closely related to the cape gooseberry and surrounded by a similar papery husk. Always look for tomatillos that have filled their husks, as they are not fully mature until they do. Remove the husks, then rinse the tomatillos, which will be sticky, and they’re ready to cook.

headline: Democrats Invoking Palin to Stir Base
text: INDIANOLA, Iowa  Gone are the days when President Obama was the biggest source of motivation for Democrats.

headline: Clinton Calls Settlement Deal Possible
text: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Monday that she believed the Israelis and Palestinians could work out a deal on Jewish settlements, leaving open the possibility that their fledgling peace talks could go forward even without a full extension of Israel’s moratorium on settlement construction.

headline: Patricia Zettler, Matthew Jordan
text: Patricia Jolene Zettler and Matthew Wade Jordan were married Saturday in Columbus, Ohio. The Rev. Forrest B. Williams, a minister of Calvary Ministries, officiated at the Venue at Smith Brothers, a catering hall.

headline: Roman Holiday: New ‘I, Claudius,’ With Derek Jacobi, Coming to British Radio
text: For American viewers of a certain impressionable age (and some old enough to know better), the original television mini-series “I, Claudius” was an eye-opening introduction to public broadcasting: a BBC-produced toga party teeming with ancient Roman soap opera, aristocratic orgies, nakedness, snakes and even naked snakes. (It also had the unforgettable performances of Derek Jacobi as the title character and stammering emperor-to-be, and John Hurt as the utterly insane Caligula, just to prove we weren’t watching only for the naughty bits.)

headline: Jamie Wainstock, Keith Kalnick
text: Jamie Michelle Wainstock and Keith David Kalnick were married Saturday evening at Blue Hill at Stone Barns, the restaurant on the Rockefeller family’s Pocantico Hills estate in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Michael A. White officiated.

headline: Ex-I.B.M. Executive Is Sentenced to 6 Months Jail Time
text: Robert W. Moffat Jr., the former high-level I.B.M. executive who pleaded guilty to leaking inside information to a hedge fund consultant linked to the Galleon Group, was sentenced on Monday to six months in jail, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Merle Sprinzen, Alain Tessier
text: Merle Sprinzen and Alain Joseph Tessier are to be married Sunday in East Providence, R.I. David C. Bender, a Spiritual Humanist minister, is to officiate at the Squantum Association, an events hall and social club.

headline: Julia Butler, Vigneshwar Rajendran
text: Julia Marie Butler and Vigneshwar Natesan Rajendran were married Saturday at the Mashomack Preserve Club, a fish and game preserve and social club in Pine Plains, N.Y. Justice Elizabeth K. Shequine of the Town of Washington Justice Court in Millbrook, N.Y., officiated. Immediately afterward, Robert Cutler, a friend of the bride’s family, presided over a ceremony that combined Hindu and Christian traditions.

headline: The Engine of Right-Wing Rage, Fueled by More Than Just Anger
text: In his new book, “The Backlash: Right-Wing Radicals, High-Def Hucksters, and Paranoid Politics in the Age of Obama,” the progressive journalist Will Bunch serves up his own anatomy of the Tea Party movement, that loose agglomeration of right-wing insurgents, libertarians, conservatives, evangelicals, survivalists, gun-rights crusaders, antitax protesters, deficit hawks, antigovernment zealots, militia members, Ayn Randers, Limbaugh “ditto heads,” Glenn Beck fanatics, birthers, Birchers, and supporters of Sarah Palin and Ron Paul.

headline: Tony Goldwyn Shows Some ‘Conviction’ in Toronto
text: TORONTO — The formidable phalanx of actresses lined up at a Monday morning news conference for “Conviction,” Fox Searchlight’s film about the real-life Betty Anne Waters and her fight to exonerate a brother wrongly convicted of murder, looked almost like a female version of “The Expendables.” Melissa Leo, Juliette Lewis, Minnie Driver, Hilary Swank, all in one battle-ready line. Ms. Swank, in the center, was their Sylvester Stallone. Ms. Lewis, cradling her trademark pout in 10 painted nails, was the estrogen version of Jason Statham.

headline: ‘Elf’ Completes Broadway Casting Well Ahead of Christmas
text: The holiday season just starts earlier and earlier every year, doesn’t it? On Monday the team behind the Broadway musical “Elf” unwrapped the names of the two remaining principal cast members for that yuletide-themed production: Sebastian Arcelus, who plays Bob Gaudio in Broadway’s “Jersey Boys” and has also appeared in “Wicked” and “Rent,” will step into the formidable tights of Buddy, the oversize North Pole denizen originally played by Will Ferrell in the 2003 film “Elf.” Amy Spanger, of Broadway’s “Rock of Ages” and “The Wedding Singer,” will play Jovie, a department store worker in need of some Christmas cheer, a role played in the movie by Zooey Deschanel. The previously announced Broadway cast will also include George Wendt (“Cheers”) as Santa. The “Elf” musical will be directed and choreographed by Casey Nicholaw (“The Drowsy Chaperone”) with songs by Matthew Sklar and Chad Beguelin (“The Wedding Singer”) and a book by Thomas Meehan (“Hairspray,” “The Producers”) and Bob Martin (“The Drowsy Chaperone”). It is to begin previews at the Al Hirschfeld Theater on Nov. 2 and open on Nov. 14.

headline: New York Fashion Week | The Céline Factor
text: As the New York spring collections began, just five days ago, the main question on the minds of fashion editors was how much Céline would there be on the catwalks. We knew it would be in the audience — that stripe-y tunic dress with zip shoulder (so Agnès B and yet so not) is ubiquitous at Lincoln Center, as are the wide-leg pants, the khaki shirt with gold zipper pulls, the soft square tote. But how much of the Céline designer Phoebe Philo’s tailored conceptualism, her hand with stripped-back superhot sportswear, would find its way into American clothes remained to be seen. We — fashion editors — all remember the Marni-fication of the industry a decade ago. We know very well what one cool brand can do to women’s closets. And, let’s face it: sportswear is the hallmark of American fashion. Bringing Céline back is like lugging coal to Newcastle.

headline: Teaching a Toddler to Curse
text: I was well into my 30s before I heard my mother utter a four-letter word. My children will not be waiting that long. I have never been one to curse constantly, and when I became a parent, I cleaned up my language even more, at least for a while. As my sons entered their tweens and then their teens, though, and it became clear that they knew far more “bad words” than I did, I loosened my tongue a bit. It began to feel Pollyanna-like to tell them, “Those are not nice words,” or even, “We don’t curse,” and my message instead became, “We don’t curse in certain situations.” Like in front of your teachers. Or your grandmother (even though I now know she knows those words). Or at a job interview. And, as one who uses words for a living, I tried to stress that curses are lazy. They are a unimaginative default in a language that has so many more interesting possibilities.

headline: British Museum Receives $38.5 Million Donation
text: 3:36 p.m. | Updated Two foundations run by the Sainsbury family, the founders of one of Britain’s largest supermarket chain, has donated $38.5 million toward an expansion of the British Museum, the museum announced on Sunday. The gift is one of the largest private donations to the arts ever made in Britain and comes at a time when cultural institutions there are bracing for an expected 25 percent cut in state funding when the government announces the results of a spending review on October 20. The British Museum is building a $360 million wing, designed by Richard Rogers, to house temporary exhibitions and a conservation center. The government has pledged roughly $35 million toward the new building.

headline: Three New Tricks for Gmail’s Priority Inbox
text: Two weeks ago, Google introduced a  Gmail feature that sorts incoming mail — not the spam, but the stuff you actually want — into important and unimportant messages. The Priority Inbox is a super-inbox that, based on your own past behavior with e-mail, places what it calls “important and unread” messages at the top of the list. For example, it could flag a shipping notice that contains a FedEx tracking number from an online retailer as important, while pushing the same merchant’s weekly newsletter down into the less-important section.
