headline: Vatican Library to Reopen Next Week
text: VATICAN CITY – The Vatican Library, which houses one of the world’s most important collections of manuscripts, will reopen next Monday after a three-year $12 million renovation, much to the relief of academics around the world. Msgr. Cesare Pasini, the prefect of the library, said at a news conference on Monday that he was “happy to alleviate the anxiety” of the many scholars who had written to him since the library closed in July 2007, cutting off access to its 1.6 million volumes, including 75,000 manuscripts.

headline: Sugar and Vice
text: Thin lips, button noses and beady eyes are all it took for Yoshitomo Nara to create the passive-aggressive brats and eagerly menacing pups that catapulted him to international art stardom in the 1990s. In serious need of love, they simultaneously attract and repel, typifying the culture of twisted cuteness endemic to Japanese manga comics. But the real revelation in “Nobody’s Fool,” the Asia Society’s arresting retrospective of the artist’s two-decade career, is how much he was influenced by punk bands like the Ramones – and the cover graphics of 1960s rock albums. His own collection of vintage King Crimson, Geoff Muldaur, Norman Greenbaum and Carole King albums anchor the museum-wide show, where his pyromaniac girls and orphaned dogs appear in lonely wooden shacks. One of them replicates his drawing studio at home — and is as endearingly angst-ridden as his art.“Nobody’s Fool” is on view through Jan. 2, 2011, at Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue.

headline: Tug of War Pits Genes of Parents in the Fetus
text: Under Mendel’s laws of inheritance, you could thank mom and dad equally for all the outstanding qualities you inherited.

headline: For Bad News Bulls, Adversity Is Opportunity
text: For the better part of a year now, a small band of investors and economists has been arguing that the torrent of grim news on jobs and the stagnating American economy is shrouding an immutable fact: the recovery is at hand, you just cannot see it yet.

headline: Ex-Im Bonkers
text: Via Jon Chait, a stark demonstration of the madness that has overtaken the American right. It seems that Newt Gingrich is approvingly citing an article in Forbes by Dinesh D’Souza, alleging that Obama is a radical pursuing a “Kenyan, anti-colonial” agenda.

headline: Changing Perceptions on Economics and Politics
text: I am back from vacation, a period when I had no access to e-mail for a couple of weeks. But I could read the papers on my Kindle, so in that sense I was not out of touch.

headline: Changing Perceptions on Economics and Politics
text: I am back from vacation, a period when I had no access to e-mail for a couple of weeks. But I could read the papers on my Kindle, so in that sense I was not out of touch.

headline: Quote Unquote | Radical Chic
text: –Elle’s Style Director Kate Lanphear follows her own fashion rules. What craziness can she suggest next, bags and shoes that don’t match?

headline: Nokia Executive to Leave; Hints of Chairman’s Exit
text: A shake-up at the top of Nokia continued on Monday after the company said the head of its smartphone business would be leaving.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kashmir and Elsewhere
text: Altaf Qadri is one of the more prolific and perceptive photographers on the Associated Press roster. He grew up in Kashmir, which gives his coverage of the unending strife there (Slides 1 and 2) a personal immediacy.

headline: The Advantages Of Taking A Stand
text: When Peter Oszag published his op-ed calling for an extension of all the Bush tax cuts, not just those for the middle class, I was one of the people who was really puzzled; why was Orszag proposing preemptive surrender on an issue where Democrats would seem, on the face of it, to have a huge political advantage?

headline: On Election Eve, the Final Rounds
text: Carl P. Paladino, who is running in the Republican primary for governor on Tuesday, greeted supporters on the Sister City Bridge in downtown Syracuse on Monday. He is facing Rick A. Lazio. Other races on Tuesday include the Democratic battle for attorney general, and efforts by Representatives Charles B. Rangel and Carolyn B. Maloney to fend off stiff challenges. Polls open at 6 a.m. in New York City, and at other times around the state. They close at 9 p.m. in New York City.

headline: The Boxee Box, Openness and Homemade Content
text: As the sofa wars heat up and big companies like Amazon, Google and Apple push their way into the living room, there are smaller outfits in this market that are offering some interesting and enticing options too.

headline: Upbeat Works to Honor a Solemn Day
text: Since 2002, the September Concert Foundation has organized free musical events during the week of Sept. 11, which now number around 200 concerts worldwide. On Saturday evening the organization offered a memorial concert featuring an eclectic selection of upbeat and patriotic choral works at St. Patrick’s Cathedral.

headline: Record Number Take SAT, but the Scores of Blacks and Puerto Ricans Lag
text: The number of graduating high school students who took the SAT climbed to 1.55 million last spring, a record figure that represents an increase of 1.2 percent, or nearly 18,000, over 2009, the College Board said Monday.

headline: Now Booking | Algodon Mansion
text: Considering how things go in Argentina — military coups, economic insolvency and, most recently, a coin shortage — the fantastically posh Buenos Aires neighborhood of Recoleta is still going strong. Its bosky streets are lined with embassies, museums and belle époque mansions that occupy entire blocks. It’s one big architectural pageant. And so, as legacy would have it, Recoleta remains a magnet for upscale boutiques and hotels like the new Algodon Mansion, which opened last month.

headline: Video Music Awards Earn High Ratings for MTV
text: Adding to MTV’s high-flying ratings year, the Video Music Awards drew an average of 11.4 million viewers on Sunday, representing the channel’s biggest single audience since 2002.

headline: European Commission Raises Growth Forecast
text: The European Commission significantly raised its growth forecast for the region on Monday because of strong output data during the second quarter, and said that the recovery was starting to broaden across sectors.

headline: Apple Changes Free iPhone 4 Case Program
text: On Friday, Apple announced that it would change the terms of the company’s free-case giveaway for the iPhone 4. The following was added to one of the iPhone pages on Apple’s Web site:

headline: Zestra Commercial
text: A two-minute ad for Zestra Essential Arousal Oils was created by ShadowBox Entertainment Pictures.

headline: Theyskens’s New Line for Theory
text: “In fashion, we don’t often know the prices,” said Olivier Theyskens, the designer who has taken a fashion sabbatical since leaving Nina Ricci in Paris last March. “We don’t have time to go into the stores.”

headline: For the Bad News Bulls, Adversity Is Opportunity
text: LONDON  For the better part of a year, a small band of investors and economists has been arguing that the torrent of grim news on jobs and the stagnating United States economy is shrouding an immutable fact: the recovery is at hand  you just can’t see it yet.

headline: The Public’s Quiet Savior From Harmful Medicines
text: CHEVY CHASE, Md. — She is unlikely to be mentioned at any 50th-birthday parties this year, but she is the reason many of those celebrations will take place.

headline: Senate to Take Up Big Pentagon Bill
text: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, told colleagues on Monday that he was planning to take up the annual Pentagon authorization bill next week. The bill includes a provision that would allow the Defense Department to end the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy in relation to gay and lesbian soldiers.

headline: Hybrids May Thrive Where Parents Fear to Tread
text: On May 15, 1985, trainers at Hawaii Sea Life Park were stunned when a 400- pound gray female bottlenose dolphin named Punahele gave birth to a dark-skinned calf that partly resembled the 2,000-pound male false killer whale with whom she shared a pool. The calf was a wholphin, a hybrid that was intermediate to its parents in some characteristics, like having 66 teeth compared with the bottlenose’s 88 and the 44 of the false killer whale, a much larger member of the dolphin family.

headline: A King’s Toils and Troubles From a Mixed-Media Angle
text: For an audience being held hostage by “TheBcam/MacBeth,” even the intermission is an ordeal.

headline: Charlie Crist’s Lines in the Sand
text: MIAMI–Charlie Crist has released two new television ads that place the Florida governor right where he feels comfortable: at the beach, in the mushy ground between liberals and conservatives.

headline: Dell Dumps Windows XP
text: Dell has become the first, but it will not be the last, to bid adieu to Microsoft’s workhorse operating system, XP.

headline: Video: Tea Party Takes Aim
text: Marcus Mabry, associate national editor, and Kate Zernike, The Times’s correspondent covering the Tea Party movement around the country, discuss the Tea Party’s ambitions in Republican primaries in Delaware and other states, and what it might mean for Democrats in the general elections.

headline: Kevin Spacey on Abramoff and Facebook in Toronto
text: TORONTO — Kevin Spacey had plenty to discuss in a brief interview on Monday afternoon at the Windsor Arms. (That Yorkville hotel remains a command post for stars at the Toronto International Film Festival, even though most festival proceedings have drifted downtown, toward the new Bell Lightbox.)

headline: Photos of the Moment | Diesel Black Gold
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Skye Parrott.

headline: Laurels at Cannes and Battles at Home
text: KHON KAEN, Thailand  The red carpet of the Cannes Film Festival is a world apart from the villages of rural Thailand, but Apichatpong Weerasethakul glides effortlessly between the two.

headline: Welcome to the Neighborhood
text: City Room salutes the East Village Local blog, produced by the students and faculty of the Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute at New York University, in collaboration with The New York Times. The new blog started today, just in time for Fashion Week and the primary elections. Its coverage area — which extends from Broadway to the East River, 14th Street to Houston Street — is home to roughly 70,000 people, but the number of New Yorkers and people who are interested in the East Village around the blogosphere is almost infinite. Check it out.

headline: Molière’s House Makes Room for Stanley
text: PARIS  The gilded and red velvet Salle Richelieu is the most hallowed stage of the Comédie Française, the three-centuries-old acting troupe. It has survived war, fire, political turmoil and financial difficulties, but only now is it encountering its very first American play.

headline: Capturing the Atom Bomb on Film
text: From 1945 to 1962, the United States military detonated hundreds of nuclear bombs in the atmosphere. George Yoshitake, 82, speaks about his experiences documenting the explosions and their destructive effects.

headline: Quote Unquote | Front Row Fodder
text: –Penn Bagdley tells New York Magazine his purpose at Fashion Week. Yup, that’s about right.

headline: Runway Beauty | Victoria Beckham
text: You wouldn’t expect to see Victoria Beckham wearing bright purple eyeshadow, so it was a bit of a surprise to see models wearing it in her presentation yesterday. (Another departure for the sexy star turned real-deal designer: the number of floral prints in the collection.) Using Lancôme products, Charlotte Tilbury created a dewy face, sans blush — a nice break from the contoured looks seen at Altuzarra and Thakoon — and added a thick layer of L’Absolu Rouge lipstick in pinky-beige Rich Cashmere followed by gobs of clear gloss. This was punctuated by the aforementioned indigo shadow, a blend of Lancôme Color Design shadows in Trendy and Drama — perfect shade names for a former Spice Girl. As if that wasn’t enough color, nails were painted with a bubblegum pink from Butter London. Didier Malige slicked models’ hair behind their ears (a style also seen at Cynthia Steffe, where Avon’s Tippi Shorter was going for “Virgin Suicides”-meets-Marcia Brady) and added a few crimps around the nape of the neck, held in place with Frederic Fekkai Sheer Hold Hairspray.

headline: Robot Invasion Welcomed in Japan
text: TOKYO — Could it be that the Japanese view of robots as friendly helpers — and not as the rebellious, violent machines that populate much of Western science fiction — is rooted in the Shinto religion, which blurs the boundaries between animate and inanimate? To the Japanese psyche, this theory goes, a humanoid and sentient robot may simply not feel as creepy or threatening as it does in other cultures.

headline: In Basketball, Danger of Head Trauma
text: During basketball practice last year, 12-year-old Nicole Dehart was shooting the ball when a defender tried aggressively to block her shot. The two players made contact, and Nicole hit the floor headfirst.

headline: Health Dividend Seen in Deeper Emission Cuts
text: Health advocates said Monday that adopting more ambitious targets for cutting greenhouse gases could save health programs up to 30.5 billion euros ($38.7 billion) in expenditures each year in the European Union.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Donnie Darko’
text: This week, A. O. Scott takes a look at Richard Kelly‘s cult film “Donnie Darko” (2001), about a tormented young hero, played by Jake Gyllenhaal, who may or may not be a schizophrenic time traveler with a giant, evil-faced rabbit friend named Frank.

headline: The Bomb Chroniclers
text: They risked their lives to capture on film hundreds of blinding flashes, rising fireballs and mushroom clouds.

headline: Shia LaBeouf’s Trip Down ‘Wall Street’
text: TORONTO — Known better for managing Transformers than commodities, Shia LaBeouf takes on a very different screen challenge in the Oliver Stone update to “Wall Street,” “Money Never Sleeps.” He plays a proprietary trader in a relationship with the daughter (Carey Mulligan) of Gordon Gekko (Michael Douglas). Here, Mr. LeBeouf discusses the intense preparation that went into building his character, including meeting with members of the financial world and doing some trading of his own.

headline: Christmas Is Coming; ‘Elf’ Cast List Is Ready
text: The holiday season just starts earlier and earlier every year, doesn’t it? On Monday the team behind the Broadway musical “Elf” unwrapped the names of the two remaining principal cast members for that yuletide-theme production: Sebastian Arcelus, above, who plays Bob Gaudio in Broadway’s “Jersey Boys” and has also appeared in “Wicked” and “Rent,” will step into the formidable tights of Buddy, the oversize North Pole denizen originally played by Will Ferrell in the 2003 film “Elf.” Amy Spanger, above, of Broadway’s “Rock of Ages” and “The Wedding Singer,” will play Jovie, a department store worker in need of some Christmas cheer, a role played in the movie by Zooey Deschanel. The cast will also include George Wendt (“Cheers”) as Santa. “Elf” will be directed and choreographed by Casey Nicholaw (“The Drowsy Chaperone”), with songs by Matthew Sklar and Chad Beguelin (“The Wedding Singer”) and a book by Thomas Meehan (“Hairspray,” “The Producers”) and Bob Martin (“The Drowsy Chaperone”). It is to begin previews at the Al Hirschfeld Theater on Nov. 2 and open on Nov. 14.

headline: Football Ratings Up
text: The first “Sunday Night Football” game of the season catapulted NBC into first place in the ratings for the night, earning what appeared to be the highest ratings ever for a “Sunday Night Football” broadcast. Although final audience figures were not available Monday, preliminary overnight estimates for the game were nearly as high as they were for Thursday’s season opener, which attracted 27.5 million viewers, the largest audience for a regular-season game broadcast in prime time in 14 years. Fox ranked second on the night, largely due to an overrun of its afternoon football coverage, which meant that more than 17 million viewers were tuned in to the network during the 7 o’clock hour. Following it, Fox broadcast reruns of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10 (4.9 million). CBS was third, earning 8.2 million at 7 for “60 Minutes” and 6.7 million at 8 for “Big Brother” but lower ratings at 9 and 10 for repeats of “Undercover Boss” (4.8 million) and “CSI: Miami” (5.3 million). ABC finished in fourth place with reruns followed by “The Gates,” at 10 (2.1 million).

headline: From Spain, Big Reds That Are Well Balanced
text: RIBERA DEL DUERO is a paradoxical region, ancient yet thoroughly modern. Its wines embrace the mainstream characteristics that seem so popular around the world. They are plush, opulent, flamboyantly fruity and powerfully oaky. Yet while some unavoidably stray into the homogenized international style, the best remain identifiably Spanish.

headline: British Museum Receives $38.5. Million Donation
text: John Sainsbury, the former head of a British supermarket chain, and his brother Simon, have donated $38.5 million toward an expansion of the British Museum, according to The Guardian newspaper and Reuters. The gift is one of the largest private cultural donations ever made in Britain and comes at a time when arts institutions there are bracing for an expected 25 percent cut in state financing when the government announces the results of a spending review on Oct. 20. The British Museum is building a $360 million wing, designed by Richard Rogers, to house temporary exhibitions and a conservation center. The government has pledged roughly $35 million toward it.

headline: ‘I, Claudius’ Radio Serial: Bring Your Own Togas
text: For American viewers of a certain impressionable age (and some old enough to know better), the original television mini-series “I, Claudius” was an eye-opening introduction to public broadcasting: a BBC-produced toga party, first shown in the United States in 1977, teeming with ancient Roman soap opera, orgies, nakedness, snakes and even naked snakes. (It also had the unforgettable performances of Derek Jacobi, right, as the title character and stammering emperor-to-be, and John Hurt as the utterly insane Caligula, just to prove we weren’t watching only for the naughty bits.) Now “I, Claudius” is heading back to the British airwaves in a new version that will feature Mr. Jacobi, but for which you’ll have to supply your own steamy pictures. BBC’s Radio 4 will produce a new serial adapted from Robert Graves’s historical novels to be broadcast starting in November, The Guardian reported. This time Mr. Jacobi will play the role of the emperor Augustus (portrayed in the original television adaptation by Brian Blessed), and Claudius will be played by Tom Goodman-Hill. An American air date for the series has not been announced.

headline: Invisible Dog, Off Leash and Reimagined
text: Serendipity can strike at any time. In the 1970s a World War II veteran named George Zorbas took a trip to Europe and returned with a novelty concept that became a runaway hit: the invisible-dog leash. As a visual prank, it fit perfectly in the era of the pet rock. He brought the loopy idea back to his factory in Brooklyn’s Boerum Hill neighborhood, where he already produced belts and jewelry, eventually employing as many as 150 people to churn out thousands of the stiff leashes and empty collars, 24 hours a day.

headline: Invisible Dog Art Space
text: A French theater director has transformed an abandoned belt factory into a neighborhood arts hub in Brooklyn.

headline: Vatican Library Restored; 1.6. Million Volumes Await
text: The Vatican Library, which houses one of the world’s most important collections of manuscripts (above, a reading room), will reopen on Monday after a three-year, $12 million renovation, much to the relief of academics around the world. Msgr. Cesare Pasini, the prefect of the library, said at a news conference on Monday that he was “happy to alleviate the anxiety” of the many scholars who had written to him since the library closed in July 2007, cutting off access to its 1.6 million volumes, including 75,000 manuscripts. The renovations were both structural  involving the reinforcement of foundations and floors  and technological.

headline: Crucial Work Remains in Rewriting Bank Regulations, Officials Say
text: BASEL, Switzerland  Stock markets cheered new regulations announced this weekend that were intended to prevent a recurrence of the financial crisis, but central bankers cautioned Monday that officials still must forge agreements to limit short-term bank risk and deal with institutions considered too big too fail.

headline: A123 Opens Michigan Battery Plant, With Federal and State Aid
text: A123 Systems, an electric car battery supplier to Fisker Automotive and BMW, among other companies, opened its new 291,000-square-foot lithium-ion battery plant in Livonia, Mich., on Monday, financed in part by a $249 million federal stimulus grant from the Energy Department.

headline: Good Sign In Toronto For Smaller Films
text: Yes, there are deals at the Toronto International Film Festival. Anne Thompson, a blogger who works with IndieWire, notes that the Weinstein Company sent a thrill through the Creative Artists Agency party on Sunday night with its purchase of “Dirty Girl” for a reported $3 million. That comes with the announced purchase of “Super,” a super-crime-fighter spoof, by IFC Entertainment. “Dirty Girl” is from the writer-director Abe Sylvia, “Super” from the writer-director James Gunn. The sales are a good sign for smaller films that depend heavily on the festival for their shot at becoming, well, large.

headline: Joaquin Phoenix Returning To Letterman’s Show
text: The physical form of Joaquin Phoenix, left, is headed back to David Letterman’s “Late Show”  will he bring his mind this time? On Monday press representatives for the show said that Mr. Phoenix, the living art experiment and occasional star of films like “We Own the Night” and “Walk the Line,” would be a guest on Mr. Letterman’s program on Sept. 22. It’s the first time that Mr. Phoenix has been booked on that show since his notorious appearance on Feb. 11, 2009, when he gave Mr. Letterman a largely nonresponsive interview that became a viral sensation and left viewers wondering whether Mr. Phoenix was playing an elaborate prank on the host and his audience. CBS said it would repeat Mr. Phoenix’s earlier “Late Show” interview on Thursday in anticipation of his Sept. 22 appearance, in which he’ll be promoting his documentary, “I’m Still Here,” which chronicles a year in which Mr. Phoenix said he was retiring from acting to pursue a career as a rapper.

headline: A 1988 Commission, Revisited on an Anniversary
text: The American String Quartet is celebrating its 35th anniversary this season, and the Manhattan School of Music, where it has been in residence for 26 of those years, is giving a party in the form of a three-concert retrospective, with two performances at the school and one at Merkin Concert Hall.

headline: Scorecard | Tom Ford Wins!
text: Minimalism isn’t the only revenant from the ’90s this New York fashion week. As Scorecard looks on over the shoulders of the G100 of top editors who attended Tom Ford’s cocktail-party-cum-Oscars-of-catwalk extravaganza for his new women’s line Sunday, we surmise that Fashion with a capital F is back, too. (No photos were allowed into cyberspace — how very like the premillennial Gucci era!)

headline: From Organ Loft, Sounds of Buxtehude and Bach
text: The organist and choral conductor Kent Tritle may be the only musician with more job titles and a busier schedule than Valery Gergiev. As the director of Music Ministries at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on Park Avenue, he oversees more than 400 services with music each year. As the music director of Musica Sacra and the Oratorio Society of New York, he routinely conducts insightful performances of repertory from Renaissance Masses to works by living composers. He is on the faculties at the Juilliard School and the Manhattan School of Music; he is the organist of the New York Philharmonic.

headline: Ravens Defeat Jets, 10-9
text: All off-season, the Jets were bold and brash, broadcasting to whoever would listen that they were destined to become champions. But they did not resemble the championship football team that the players and the coaches had made themselves out to be.

headline: Sure, Those Beards Remain, But Their Music Has Legs, Too
text: ZZ Top’s show at the Beacon Theater on Sunday was all base line. Not bass lines  there were those, too, and very steady  but an unbroken rumble of authority, an adherence to rules and a celebration of them. If you are the kind of person who likes to use a suspect and imprecise and maybe impossible term about music, then go ahead, because this was, more or less, a perfect concert.

headline: Lionsgate and Televisa Unite on Films
text: LOS ANGELES — Lionsgate’s African-American-focused film business, anchored by Tyler Perry titles, has become a gold mine for the studio. Movies with predominantly black casts that tell stories rooted in black culture — surprise! — bring out a sizable black audience.

headline: Toyota Plans 6 New Hybrids for 2012
text: DETROIT  Toyota plans to introduce two electric vehicles in the United States and six hybrid cars worldwide by the end of 2012, a company executive said Monday.

headline: Times Appoints Ad Vice President
text: The New York Times announced Friday that Kerrie Gillis had been named a vice president for advertising.

headline: 3 Is a Crowd, but 6 Is a Reality Show
text: Attention, New Yorkers: if you should see the Carpio sextuplets — in the park, on the street, in the subway, whatever — do not make eye contact or in any way pay them notice.

headline: Hedge Fund Group Defends High-Frequency Trades
text: The Managed Funds Association, the hedge fund industry’s main lobbying group, is urging federal regulators not to crack down on high-frequency trading, Bloomberg News reports. The group contends that proposed new rules, in response to the stock market flash crash on May 6, would increase costs for all investors and make markets less liquid.

headline: Gone Digital: Music Man Stays in Game
text: In 1997, when Richard Gottehrer started his digital music company, the Orchard, he already had a long and distinguished résumé on the creative, sexy side of the music business. As a Brill Building songwriter, he had helped write “My Boyfriend’s Back” and “I Want Candy”; later, as a producer of Blondie and the Go-Go’s, he brought the girl-group sensibility into the punk age.

headline: Grassley Not Looking for Twitter Cure
text: Don’t worry, Iowa. Senator Charles E. Grassley will probably survive his run-in with Twitter just fine.

headline: ‘The Backlash’
text: Chapter One: The Cassandra of Lower Delaware

headline: After Negotiations, Israel Emerges on Twitter
text: MADRID  Israel has acquired the user name @israel on Twitter, the microblogging Internet service, from the Spanish owner of a pornographic Web site, in an unusual transaction intended to help Israel exercise more influence over its image.

headline: Atomic Cinematographers
text: James Gorman and William Broad discuss declassified films made of atomic bomb tests between 1945 and 1962.

headline: Michael Bastian: In the Navy
text: Michael Bastian is a designer who seems to delight in casting his shows each season with a different archetype from the man-on-man adult film archives of Falcon Studios. Let’s see, there was that lumberjack show last season, and the lacrosse players show for Gant, another on camo warriors last year and then, on Monday, a fairly soft-core collection that included models who were hired because they fit the Navy Seal aesthetic. (Read: Ripped, and not just a little hairy.)

headline: Boehner Plays Central Role in Democratic Ad
text: WASHINGTON  Democrats are again stepping up their effort to elevate Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio into a symbol of the Republican Party virtually equivalent to the elephant. And in doing so, they are executing a strategy intended to do more than just provide President Obama and his party with a convenient punching bag.

headline: A ‘Shoo-In’ Struggles in Massachusetts Race
text: BOSTON  For more than a decade, Republicans in Massachusetts have been rooting for Charlie Baker to run for governor. The timing seemed perfect when Mr. Baker, a turnaround expert who was a whiz-kid aide to two governors in the 1990s, decided to challenge Gov. Deval Patrick this year.

headline: A Cultural Shift in the Jobs We Seek?
text: To the Editor:

headline: As Giants and Jets Open Their Stadium, Empty Seats Stand Out
text: The opening of any new sports stadium is usually accompanied by an A list of celebrities, Air Force jets flying overhead and a “sold out” sign at the ticket office.

headline: Racial Disparity in School Suspensions
text: In many of the nation’s middle schools, black boys were nearly three times as likely to be suspended as white boys, according to a new study, which also found that black girls were suspended at four times the rate of white girls.

headline: Glamorously, Tom Ford Is Back
text: The morning after Tom Ford’s first women’s show in six years, on Sunday night, editors who had been among the 100 invited guests looked at one another and, with a little shake of the head, smiled and said, “That was amazing, wasn’t it?”

headline: After 9/11/10: Voices in Favor of Building Bridges
text: To the Editor:

headline: My Police Ticketing Story
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cup Race Is Taking Different Direction
text: After an acrimonious America’s Cup duel earlier this year between the billionaires Larry Ellison and Ernesto Bertarelli in which the Americans prevailed using a trimaran and space-age wing sail, it was announced Monday that the next Cup races would be contested under an independent governing body and in the most modern of sailing craft, 72-foot-long wing-sailed catamarans capable of reaching 30 knots.

headline: Confessing to Crime, but Innocent
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Eddie Lowery lost 10 years of his life for a crime he did not commit. There was no physical evidence at his trial for rape, but one overwhelming factor put him away: he confessed.

headline: When Medical Students Meet Real Patients
text: To the Editor:

headline: Floods Stunt Pakistani Fight Against Insurgents
text: KALAM, Pakistan  The destruction caused by the recent floods and the huge relief effort undertaken since by the Pakistani Army have forced it to alter plans to combat Taliban and Qaeda militants, Pakistani military officials here said.

headline: A Walk Along Stone’s Wall Street
text: “You know, half the people in this place could be prosecuted.”

headline: Trial Starts in a Robbery That Ended With 3 Dead
text: NEW HAVEN  The morning she would die, Jennifer Hawke-Petit was calm as she stood at the teller’s window at a bank in Cheshire, Conn. She said that she needed to withdraw $15,000 because men were holding her family hostage at their home and that no one should call the police.

headline: Consumer Candidate May Avoid a Vote
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is considering appointing the legal scholar Elizabeth Warren to run a new consumer bureau on a temporary basis to avoid a potentially bruising confirmation battle in the Senate, according to people who have been briefed on the search.

headline: The Return of a Stumbling Eagle Raises Concerns
text: After all of the N.F.L.’s promises that players’ concussions have been and will be handled more carefully than ever before, it took only one Sunday for a clearly concussed player to return to a game.

headline: For Many, ‘Washroom’ Seems to Be Just a Name
text: BOSTON  The next time a man hands you a hot dog after making a run to the restroom and the concession stand at an Atlanta Braves baseball game, be careful: there is a good chance he did not wash his hands, according to a report released Monday by a group that sends spies into public restrooms in the name of science.

headline: Oprah Offers Audience Trip to Australia
text: Perhaps Oprah Winfrey has finally found a way to top her Pontiac car giveaway.

headline: Earthbound at the Country Club
text: Only afterward did I realize that the invitation for Tommy Hilfiger’s show was a plastic swatch of privet contained in a clean white box. Perfect, I thought.

headline: For Female-Aphrodisiac Makers, Effort at Parity
text: A WOMAN in her early 40s pops up on the TV screen. “Women are starting to talk about something they have been feeling for a long time,” she says, “wanting more sexual satisfaction.”

headline: A Beninois Priest Seeks New Respect, and New Practitioners, for Voodoo
text: COTONOU, Benin  This is not about secretive mutterings in the dead of night or freakish eccentrics, explained Dah Aligbonon Akpochihala, an eminent voodoo priest who has taken to the airwaves to preach the old messages of faith, fidelity and obedience integral to his religion. It is about bringing a younger generation on board.

headline: Oprah Winfrey Blesses a New Show, on Home Design
text: Oprah Winfrey, who is closing down her talk show after 25 years to build her own cable network, kicked off her final “farewell” season on Monday with an extravaganza of old faces and new prizes. Among other wonders, she told members of her studio audience that she would take all 300 of them with her to Australia, along with her pal John Travolta, who is to fly the Qantas Airways jet (he’s a pilot and a Qantas goodwill ambassador). Cue screaming.

headline: The Scene: Day Five
text: Photos from the fifth day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: New Ads to Try to Build Public Support for Gay Marriage
text: Advocates for same-sex marriage in New York, in a major departure from their strategy of lobbying political insiders, will begin making a direct appeal to ordinary voters in a series of commercials featuring Hollywood actors, fashion designers and civic leaders.

headline: Civil Rights Photographer Unmasked as Informer
text: ATLANTA  That photo of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. riding one of the first desegregated buses in Montgomery, Ala.? He took it. The well-known image of black sanitation workers carrying “I Am a Man” signs in Memphis? His. He was the only photojournalist to document the entire trial in the murder of Emmett Till, and he was there in Room 306 of the Lorraine Hotel, Dr. King’s room, on the night he was assassinated.

headline: From School Files of an Earlier Era, Faces Looking to the Future
text: Even before school started last week, proof of its imminent reality began to arrive in the mail: teacher assignments, supply lists, free-lunch forms, releases.

headline: Ayatollah Speaks of Plot to Abuse Koran
text: DAMASCUS, Syria  Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, delivered a fiery address on Monday accusing the United States government of orchestrating desecrations of the Koran by right-wing American Christian groups last weekend, Iranian state news agencies reported.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,263 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: Fans for Generations Choose Couch Over the 50-Yard Line
text: For Judy Staubo, football and family were the perfect Sunday mix, and the Giants were the beloved unifying thread. Six tickets on the 50-yard line were a treasured legacy to her, her children and grandchildren.

headline: Biotech Company to Patent Fuel-Secreting Bacterium
text: A biotech company plans to announce Tuesday that it has won a patent on a genetically altered bacterium that converts sunlight and carbon dioxide into ingredients of diesel fuel, a step that could provide a new pathway for making ethanol or a diesel replacement that skips several cumbersome and expensive steps in existing methods.

headline: From Giants Blue to Jets Green in 746 Easy Steps
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The blue pieces of turf from the Giants’ end zones were being swapped for the green of the Jets’. Workers cleaned the empty seats and aisles. Four computers hummed in the Oz-like control room, displaying all manner of information about New Meadowlands Stadium, including the temperatures inside the suites and surveillance video of the loading dock.

headline: Drug for Irritable Bowel Achieves Goals in Trial
text: An experimental drug can reduce abdominal pain and increase bowel movements in people with irritable bowel syndrome, a condition that affects millions of Americans, the drug’s developer said Monday.

headline: Everyone’s Really Mad; Almost Mad Enough to Vote
text: You might think that the mood this political season is being set by the likes of Glenn Beck or Sarah Palin or even that nobody pastor in Florida who outlasted his prescribed 15 minutes. You would be wrong. The guiding spirit this fall is the Bronx-born Paddy Chayefsky.

headline: In Iraq, Clearer Image of U.S. Support
text: WASHINGTON  American forces provided extensive support to the Iraqi military in a recent operation north of Baghdad, illustrating the risks that United States troops still endure in their new advisory role there.

headline: George C. Williams, 83, Theorist on Evolution, Dies
text: George C. Williams, an evolutionary biologist who helped shape modern theories of natural selection, died Wednesday at his home in South Setauket on Long Island, near Stony Brook University, where he taught for 30 years. He was 83.

headline: Zimbabwe: Health Workers Released on Bail
text: Six health workers with a California-based Christian AIDS charity, who are accused of failing to register and practicing without the supervision of a pharmacist, were each released on $200 bail Monday. The four Americans, one New Zealander and one Zimbabwean had been jailed since Thursday in Harare. (Their lawyer had earlier erroneously identified the New Zealander as an American). They are scheduled to return to court on Sept. 27.

headline: Primary Tuesday
text: Tuesday is Primary Day in New York State. Polls in New York City are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. Voters statewide will decide the Republican candidates for governor and United States senator, and the Democratic candidate for state attorney general. There are also races for numerous Congressional and state legislative offices. Voter information is available from the State Board of Elections at www.vote-ny.com or by calling 1-800-FOR-VOTE (1-800-367-8683); and from the City Board of Elections at www.vote.nyc.ny.us or by calling 1-866-VOTE-NYC (1-866-868-3692). Voters who have problems can visit Election Protection at www.866ourvote.org, or call 1-866-OUR-VOTE (1-866-687-8683).

headline: G.O.P. Braces for More Discontent in Primaries
text: As the long and turbulent primary season of the midterm election campaign drew to a close on Monday, the Republican establishment was placing its confidence on hold and bracing for the prospect that voters in yet another state would send a message of defiance to party leaders in Washington.

headline: Stars Make the Final Grasp for Candidate Recognition
text: Holy rat race!

headline: Barbara Holland, Defender of Small Vices, Dies at 77
text: Barbara Holland, a writer whose humorous essays sang the simple pleasures of drinking martinis, cursing and eating fatty foods, and who wrote an evocative best-selling memoir of her childhood and adolescence in the Washington suburbs, died on Sept. 7 at her home in Bluemont, Va. She was 77.

headline: 3-D Printing Spurs a Manufacturing Revolution
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Businesses in the South Park district of San Francisco generally sell either Web technology or sandwiches and burritos. Bespoke Innovations plans to sell designer body parts.

headline: Desktop Manufacturing
text: 3D printers let designers make three dimensional objects by just hitting "print" on their computers.  New businesses, like custom prostheses, are taking advantage.

headline: If These Walls Could Talk
text: The living room has long been the basic set of the American sitcom, from “I Love Lucy” to “Everybody Loves Raymond.” Most of them are unmemorable, transitional spaces; every front door seems to open directly onto a generic sofa. Many of them are all but repeated from show to show (quick: what’s the difference between the living rooms on “Raymond” and “King of Queens”?). They’re invariably decorated in a neutral palette, acting as a quiet, passive backdrop to the action.

headline: Harold Gould, Character Actor, Dies at 86
text: Harold Gould, a widely recognizable character actor in film and television who specialized, especially late in his career, in playing suave, well-dressed gentlemen in popular sitcoms, died Saturday in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 86.

headline: Riders Try to Fight Higher Fares but With Less of Their Old Fire
text: For two years running, thousands of indignant New Yorkers have gathered at public hearings to loudly protest higher fares for the city’s buses and subways, and for two years running, the higher fares have gone through.

headline: Determination and Hard Work Distinguish Defender for Rapids
text: You will not find the name Kosuke Kimura on any list of statistical leaders in Major League Soccer. But if you check his biographical information, you will discover that Kimura, a right-side defender for the Colorado Rapids, owns a singular distinction: he is the only player in M.L.S. history born in Japan.

headline: Foreign Stimulus
text: THE debate over Arizona’s controversial immigration law and Congress’s passage last month of another border security bill gives the impression that the only problem with our immigration policy is its inability to keep people from entering the country illegally. Not so. The country has an antiquated, jerry-built immigration system that fails on almost every count. The good news is that there is a way to replace it that will promote economic growth while reducing the flow of illegal workers.

headline: N.Y. Voters Are More Hopeless Than Angry
text: Uprising. Revolt. Judgment day. These are the words on the lips of aspiring insurgent candidates across New York, Republicans and Democrats alike, who have campaigned for months on hopes that a wave of voter anger will carry them to victory and upend the entrenched political establishment in Albany.

headline: USA Track Dismisses Executive in Charge
text: The midpoint between Summer Olympics is usually considered the least dramatic year in track and field. With no outdoor world championships on the schedule (they are held in odd years), athletes nurse injuries or reduce their competitive schedules to rest weary bodies.

headline: It’s a Busy Day for Voters as They Narrow the Fields
text: A battle for the soul of New York’s Republican Party. A wide-open field of Democratic attorney general prospects. A rare opportunity to kick out, or at least send a message, to an embattled congressman. A chance to upend the State Legislature.

headline: Buyout Firms’ Sales May Top Purchases
text: Are buyout barons becoming sellout barons?

headline: Yale Plans to Create a College in Singapore
text: Yale University announced on Monday that it was planning to create a liberal arts college in Singapore that would be financed entirely by the government there and could, in time, establish a new model for higher education in Asia.

headline: Correction
text: Re this post, it was General Jack D. Ripper, not Colonel Bat Guano, who had the thing about bodily fluids. Hey, when I’m wrong, I admit it.

headline: Pondering Their Losses During Wait for Winner
text: The postponement of the United States Open men’s final until Monday was already costing many people money.

headline: Imam Talks Compromise on Islamic Center
text: The imam working on the planned Muslim community center near ground zero said Monday he was open to all options to resolve the fierce dispute surrounding it, while possibly provoking the project’s opponents by declaring that the site, two blocks from the former World Trade Center, was not “hallowed ground.”

headline: Rockies Seem to Save Best for Last
text: DENVER

headline: Drug List Appeal Is Again Rejected
text: An appeals court ruled Monday that federal prosecutors illegally seized drug testing information for more than 100 baseball players who tested positive for steroids in 2003. The United States Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled, 9-2, that the authorities could not keep the tests.

headline: Cuba’s Public-Sector Layoffs Signal Major Shift
text: MEXICO CITY  In perhaps the clearest sign yet that economic change is gathering pace in Cuba, the government plans to lay off more than half a million people from the public sector in the expectation that they will move into private businesses, Cuba’s labor federation said Monday.

headline: Biden, the Go-To Democrat
text: As a former senator, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is intimately familiar with the Senate expression that there are show horses and workhorses. When it comes to the 2010 campaign season, Mr. Biden is definitely a workhorse.

headline: The Swat Valley, After the Flood
text: Pakistani troops are being diverted from combating Islamist militants in the Swat Valley to help the nation recover from the worst floods in its history.

headline: Tuesday: What Makes a Pin Spin?
text: BROWN CROSSWORD WEEK — Every crossword this week, from Monday to Saturday, has been created by a student at Brown University.

headline: Marijuana Ballot Measure in California Wins Support of Union, Officials Say
text: LOS ANGELES  A ballot measure to make California the first state to legalize the sale and use of marijuana has won the support of one of the state’s most powerful union, officials said Monday, offering the proposition a shot of mainstream legitimacy as well as a potential financial and organizational lift.

headline: France: Replacement Directive Omits Word ‘Roma’
text: Following revelations that French officials had been ordered to specifically single out ethnic Roma in an continuing security campaign, Interior Minister Brice Hortefeux on Monday signed a replacement directive in which the word “Roma” does not appear. The ministry gave no explanation for the change, but humanitarian groups and opposition politicians had denounced prior Interior Ministry documents, made public last weekend, as racist and potentially illegal. Amid international outcry, Immigration Minister Éric Besson, above, had made repeated assurances that no French measures had been aimed specifically at the Roma. On Monday, Mr. Besson said he had not been aware of the Interior Ministry order to the contrary. In August, the French government began publicizing the destruction of illegal Roma camps and the ensuing deportations.

headline: Powerful Union Supports Bid to Legalize Marijuana
text: Adam Nagourney reports that one of California’s most powerful unions, the Service Employees International Union, has come out in support of a ballot measure to make California the first state to legalize the sale and use of marijuana. The decision offers the proposition a shot of mainstream legitimacy as well as a potential financial and organizational lift.

headline: Swisher Seeks an Answer for His Injury
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  With first place in the American League East at stake, the Yankees opened their three-game series against Tampa Bay on Monday night without two of their starting outfielders and with minimal clarity as to when they would be healthy enough to rejoin the lineup. On the same day Brett Gardner received a dose of good news  a magnetic resonance imaging test revealed only inflammation in his right wrist and nothing structurally wrong  the Yankees made plans to send Nick Swisher into an M.R.I. tube on Tuesday to learn why the bone bruise on his left knee has not gotten better.

headline: Britain: Smuggling Accusations Prompt Investigation
text: Accusations that British soldiers in Afghanistan have used military aircraft flying back to Britain to smuggle heroin have led to an investigation and tighter security measures, Defense Ministry officials said. The accusations are said by the BBC to have originated with Afghans working for the British military. The extra procedures include the increased use of drug-sniffing dogs at the principal airfields used by aircraft that carry troops, equipment and casualties to Britain from Afghanistan, the officials said. “We are aware of these allegations,” a Defense Ministry spokeswoman said. “Although they are unsubstantiated, we take any such reports very seriously.”

headline: Venezuela: 36 People Survive Plane Crash
text: Thirty-six of the 51 people on board a plane operated by Conviasa, Venezuela’s state-owned airline, survived a crash Monday in the eastern city of Ciudad Guayana, Venezuelan officials said. Transportation Minister Francisco Garcés said 15 people on the French-built ATR aircraft died. The plane, a twin-engine turboprop, was flying between Margarita Island in the Caribbean and Ciudad Guayana.

headline: Brash or Crass, Jets’ Image Will Persist
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Iran: Hiker’s Family Asks That Bail Be Reduced
text: The family of one of three American hikers arrested more than a year ago by Iranian authorities cannot afford to pay her $500,000 bail set by Iran and is asking to have it reduced, an Iranian lawyer representing the hikers told The Associated Press on Monday. The lawyer, Masoud Shafie, was quoted as saying that Swiss officials, who represent American interests in Iran, were making the plea for officials to reduce the bail for the hiker, Sarah E. Shourd. Ms. Shourd and two companions, Shane M. Bauer and Joshua F. Fattal, were arrested near the Iranian border in July 2009.

headline: Community-Garden Rules Receive a Mixed Reaction
text: To protect the city’s sparse greenery over the years, New Yorkers have climbed trees, wagged freshly picked beets and carrots in the faces of politicians and barricaded themselves inside gardens.

headline: More High School Students Than Ever Took the SAT Last Spring
text: The number of graduating high school students who took the SAT climbed to 1.55 million last spring, a record figure that represents an increase of 1.2 percent, or nearly 18,000, over 2009, the College Board said Monday. The board, the nonprofit organization that oversees the college entrance exam, emphasized the impact of a rigorous high school curriculum on student performance. It said students who took four years of English and three or more years of math and science scored, on average, 151 points above those who did not. (A perfect score on the three-part exam is 2400.) But the National Center for Fair & Open Testing, a critic of the SAT, noted a decline in overall scores since 2006, when the federal No Child Left Behind testing mandates went into effect. When those figures are aggregated by race or ethnicity, the average scores of Asian-Americans climbed 36 points over that period, according to the Fair Test analysis, while those of black and Puerto Rican students fell 14 points, and those of white students decreased by 2 points.

headline: Seats to Spare, but Little Worth Watching
text: The list of alternatives was extensive. There was the United States Open men’s final across the street, the Jets’ opening game at their new stadium in New Jersey, and a Jay-Z and Eminem concert at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Arizona: Republican Who Recruited Green Party Candidates Quits Race
text: A former legislator who recruited several drifters to run for office as Green Party candidates has canceled his own run for the State House. Steve May, a Republican, said he pulled out because “the necessary personal alignment does not exist to continue the campaign.” His name will remain on the Nov. 2 ballot as will those of the people he recruited along Mill Avenue in Tempe. Besides facing an uproar over his recruitment efforts, he was criticized in the news media for having been arrested on charges of driving under the influence.

headline: A Champion’s March to Greatness
text: Day by day, climate after climate, Rafael Nadal keeps raising his game.

headline: The Silver Lining in Those Ash Clouds
text: THE volcanic ash clouds over Europe that caused major flight cancellations for six days last April actually had a long-term silver lining, some corporate travel managers say. For many companies, the ash clouds showed that existing travel crisis plans needed to deal with more than the usual list of emergencies like earthquakes, floods, civil unrest, terrorist attacks, crime and epidemics.

headline: Guilty Plea Is Expected in Beating of Classmate
text: A Serbian-born former college basketball player who fled the United States in 2008 is expected to plead guilty in Belgrade, Serbia, on Tuesday as part of a deal that would send him to prison for attacking a classmate in Binghamton, N.Y., officials who have been briefed on the case said Monday.

headline: Louisiana: Work on Well Resumes
text: BP said Monday that it resumed drilling of a relief well that is intended to put the final plug in its stricken well in the Gulf of Mexico. The company said that the crew of the Development Driller III rig began drilling again after technicians installed a device called a lockdown sleeve at the top of the stricken well on the seabed. The sleeve will keep a seal in place, preventing further leakage of oil and gas, if pressure inside the well increases during the final plugging operation. No appreciable amount of oil or gas has leaked for nearly two months. Company officials have said it will take about four days for the relief well to intercept the stricken well. After that, the final plugging operation, which will involve pumping mud and cement into the stricken well, should take about a week.

headline: Marc Jacobs: Mauve and Iris
text: In one of his periodic 1970s flashbacks, Marc Jacobs tonight seemed to point to Jodie Foster, the teenage prostitute Iris in “Taxi Driver,” and to images of women in mauve and flowers, perhaps especially those of the illustrator Antonio Lopez. Iris was an obvious allusion, because of the turn-back-brim hats, the curly hair, and the number of high-waist shorts and small knit tops in Mr. Jacobs’ spring 2011 collection. It was Ruth Morley who designed the costumes for “Taxi Driver.”

headline: Ending Strike, Mott’s Plant Union Accepts Deal
text: Dr Pepper Snapple and the union representing 300 workers at the Mott’s apple juice plant in Williamson, N.Y., announced a settlement late Monday that ends a 16-week strike and includes a wage freeze, but not the pay cuts the company had demanded.

headline: The Day After Tomorrow
text: Every political movement has a story. The surging Republican Party has a story, too. It is a story of virtue betrayed and innocence threatened.

headline: Where Buses Once Ran, Van Services Start Filling Gaps
text: Trudging along in an empty 15-seat van around noon Monday, the driver, Naresh Guness, harrumphed audibly as he made his way along a route once traversed by the Q74 bus.

headline: In Ugly Debut, Reality Sets in for Jets
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  On Monday night, the Jets went from the cozy confines of their reality television show to the cold reality of the N.F.L., where even teams who aspire to championships must avoid debilitating mistakes. What the Jets presented to a national television audience was disorganized chaos, the opposite of their stated theme.

headline: A Recovery’s Long Odds
text: We can keep wishing and hoping for a powerful economic recovery to pull the U.S. out of its doldrums, but I wouldn’t count on it. Ordinary American families no longer have the purchasing power to build a strong recovery and keep it going.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Republicans and the Middle Class
text: It was hard to know how serious a gesture of compromise Representative John Boehner, the House minority leader, was making on Sunday when he suggested that he would vote for a tax cut for the middle class even if it was not extended to the rich  and the subsequent reaction of some of his fellow Republicans made us even more uncertain.

headline: Morning T | Marc Newson
text: Horacio Silva takes tea with Marc Newson, the Australian-born, London-based industrial designer whose new show at the Gagosian Gallery includes his (very expensive) riff on the Aquariva speedboat.

headline: The New Bank Rules
text: Sunday’s agreement by international banking regulators to require banks to increase their capital cushions should reduce the risk of another financial meltdown. Bankers’ appetite for risky investments has not been quenched, and regulators will have to be vigilant.

headline: Fairness for Older Workers
text: Fifteen months ago, the Supreme Court’s conservative majority mowed past statutory language, Congressional intent and decades of precedent to make it much harder for older workers to prove age discrimination.

headline: Corrections
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: New York Primary Election Choices
text: The primary election in New York on Tuesday will be the first time all voters in the state use machines with a backup paper ballot. This is progress, especially for New York City, where the lever machines in use for a half-century should have been scrapped long ago.

headline: Nadal Caps Career Grand Slam
text: Rafael Nadal does, of course, share an era with Roger Federer, which has done the era plenty of good, but this season and this year’s United States Open now belong exclusively to Nadal.

headline: Pitching and a Big Hit Help the Rays Take First
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Every half-inning at Tropicana Field on Monday night grew to become a game within the game, a bout of one-upmanship that turned players into spectators. As zero after zero filled the center-field scoreboard, the Yankees and the Rays lined up along the dugout railings, at once curious, eager and anxious to see who would buckle first, with first place in the American League East at stake.

headline: Revis Doesn’t Seem to Miss Beat, And Family Doesn’t Miss Moment
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The family of Jets cornerback Darrelle Revis spent halftime inside their suite at New Meadowlands Stadium on Monday night. They ate cookies and picked at finger foods and refilled their drinks. All the while, Revis’s lengthy contract holdout seemed like a distant memory, even if it ended about a week ago.

headline: V.A. Agreed to Withholding of Benefits, Documents Say
text: The Department of Veterans Affairs agreed in September 2009, without telling six million soldiers and their families, to allow Prudential Financial to withhold lump sum payments of life insurance benefits owed to survivors of service members, according to documents made public through a request under the Freedom of Information Act.

headline: America’s Dominance of Global Wealth Is Slipping
text: For once, the poor are getting richer faster than the rich are getting richer.

headline: So You Want to Start a Business?
text: I recently met with two young men who are thinking about starting a business. They wanted some feedback on their idea for a Web site that sells a specialty product. Both are employed in a large business, and they thought they could start the new business on the side. They had done some research and came armed with some costs, some sales projections, and some market analysis.

headline: The Clean Air Act Turns 40
text: The federal Clean Air Act, one of the most consequential pieces of environmental and health legislation in American history, celebrated its 40th birthday on Tuesday. The law, which has been attacked by business interests since its birth as overly costly and prescriptive, is under siege again as the Environmental Protection Agency begins to invoke the law to rein in the gases that contribute to global warming.

headline: How Do People Use Their Smartphones?
text: Advertisers take note: People who have phones with Android operating systems are more likely to open an advertisement inside an app than are iPhone users. That, at least, is what the Nielsen  Company says in a new report that it released on Monday about how people use mobile apps.

headline: Letter: Can Preschoolers Be Depressed?
text: As a nutritionally minded health care provider, I believe Pamela Paul’s story (Aug. 29) on preschool depression was incomplete. I am amazed at how little attention nutrition receives in the clinical setting and at what a tremendous disconnect there is between what we know and what is practiced. There are now dozens of studies in the medical literature showing how deficits in specific nutrients such as essential fatty acids (omega-3 fats) contribute to depression, attention-deficit disorders, bipolar disorder and impaired cognitive development. Many mental-health experts do not properly understand or acknowledge the key role nutrition plays in brain functioning, especially regarding the developing brains of children. Until we realize that it is impossible for a brain to function properly when it is starved of essential nutrients largely absent from our Western, packaged diets, our mental-health treatments will remain incomplete.

headline: Word of the Day | diminution
text: diminution •\ˌdi-mə-ˈnü-shən also -ˈnyü-\• noun

headline: Bankers Launch $1.56 Billion Jurong Financing
text: The joint coordinating banks ING and Royal Bank of Scotland launched on Tuesday the much delayed $1.56 billion debt package for Jurong Aromatics Corp.‘s Singapore plant, the company and its bankers said.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Sept. 13
text: Images from the last day of the United States Open tennis championships.

headline: Jets Replay: Week 1
text: Images from the Jets’ 10-9 loss to the Baltimore Ravens at New Meadowlands Stadium.

headline: Bloggingheads: Denouncing Terrorism
text: Imam Abdullah Antepli of Duke University and Hussein Rashid of Religion Dispatches discuss the Muslim response to terrorism.

headline: Werner Herzog Follows His Passion in New Film
text: TORONTO — On Monday night here, 3-D may have found its future in the distant past. Certainly, Werner Herzog broke some ground by screening a new documentary, “Cave of Forgotten Dreams,” in 3-D.

headline: Biotech Company to Patent Fuel-Secreting Bacterium
text: A biotech company plans to announce Tuesday that it has won a patent on a genetically altered bacterium that converts sunlight and carbon dioxide into ingredients of diesel fuel, a step that could provide a new pathway for making ethanol or a diesel replacement that skips several cumbersome and expensive steps in existing methods, Matthew L. Wald writes in The New York Times.

headline: Few Passes Toward Revis, and Few Positives for the Secondary
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jets did not equivocate. When speaking about their secondary, they used nothing less than superlatives. But the talk did not match the walk Monday in their debut.

headline: The Padres Keep Their N.L. West Lead
text: DENVER – All the elements were in place for a San Diego Padres funeral at Coors Field on Monday.

headline: News Quiz | September 14, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Wall Street Extends September Rally
text: Investors looking for reassurances about the health of the global economy received just that Monday, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Work Remains in Rewriting Bank Rules
text: Stock markets cheered new regulations announced this weekend that were intended to prevent a recurrence of the financial crisis, but central bankers cautioned Monday that officials still must forge agreements to limit short-term bank risk and deal with institutions considered too big too fail, Jack Ewing writes in The New York Times.

headline: Warren May Avoid a Vote
text: The Obama administration is considering appointing the legal scholar Elizabeth Warren to run a new consumer bureau on a temporary basis to avoid a potentially bruising confirmation battle in the Senate, according to people who have been briefed on the search, Sewell Chan writes in The New York Times.

headline: Buyout Firms’ Sales May Top Purchases
text: From Reuters Breakingviews:

headline: A Walk Along Oliver Stone’s Wall Street
text: If one man epitomizes the populist view of Wall Street and corporate America, it is Oliver Stone, whose new film, “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps” opens next week. It is the sequel to his hit movie “Wall Street” in 1987. The original tapped into the zeitgeist of the moment by capturing the lust for money and power that led to the market’s crash, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: A.I.G. Said to Plan Exit From U.S. Ownership
text: American International Group is in talks with United States officials to formulate a plan that would speed up the insurer’s exit from government ownership, The Wall Street Journal said, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: How Will You Decide Where to Apply to College?
text: The Room for Debate blog asks “Why Are Colleges So ‘Selective’?” since, despite the recession, the competition to get into college is more intense than ever. Four experts answer the question by looking at demographic trends and discussing how innovations like the electronic use of the Common Application change the game. How will you decide where to apply to college? Do you already have a list? To how many colleges do you think you’ll apply? How stressful, in general, has the process been so far?

headline: Japan’s Premier Survives Challenge
text: TOKYO  Prime Minister Naoto Kan won a hard-fought vote within Japan’s governing party on Tuesday to stay on as prime minister, surviving a challenge by the party’s power broker, Ichiro Ozawa.

headline: Israel and Palestinian Leaders Extend Egypt Talks
text: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt  The leaders of Israel and the Palestinian Authority held more than two hours of face-to-face peace talks in this Red Sea resort on Tuesday, delving into several of the core issues that divide the two sides but not breaking an impasse over Jewish settlements.

headline: Morning T | Marc Newson
text: Horacio Silva takes tea with Marc Newson, the Australian-born, London-based industrial designer whose new show at the Gagosian Gallery includes his (very expensive) riff on the Aquariva speedboat.

headline: Regulations Good for Alternative Asset Deals
text: Alternative asset management deals may outpace traditional fund manager transactions this year for the first time ever, as regulatory pressures prompt banks to shed hedge fund and private equity assets, Reuters said, citing the results of a new study.

headline: Big-Name Speakers Head to DEMO 2010
text: DEMO Fall 2010, the technology conference coproduced by VentureBeat and IDG, is kicking off Tueday with a lineup of big-name speakers from the tech world, including Twitter cofounder and Square chief executive Jack Dorsey, SAP C.E.O. Bill McDermott, LinkedIn’s chief, Jeff Weiner, Hewlett-Packard’s chief technology officer, Phil McKinney, and Google’s  Enterprise president, Dave Girouard.

headline: Google Buys Quiksee, an Israeli Start-Up
text: Google has acquired Quiksee, an Israeli company that develops interactive video mapping technologies based on user-filmed videos, the companies said Tuesday.

headline: Citi Defends Proposed S.E.C. $75 Million Accord
text: Citigroup urged a federal judge to approve a proposed $75 million settlement with regulators over its failure to disclose mounting losses on subprime mortgages, Reuters reported.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Legerdeheel
text: Today’s word, in association with the doughty Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Grand Slam
text: WHO won the men’s final at the U.S. Open? WHOM did he beat? WHO won the women’s final?

headline: Reuters to Launch Next-Generation Desktop
text: Thomson Reuters will roll out on Tuesday its next-generation desktop product for financial professionals, incorporating Twitter-like social media features that it hopes will help it win customers from Bloomberg and others, Reuters reported.

headline: Air Products’ Advances on Airgas Repelled

headline: Stijl Standing
text: In 1927, Mies van der Rohe designed the innovative concrete-and-steel Weissenhof apartments in Stuttgart, Germany, which would become a landmark of International-style architecture; that same year, Gerrit Rietveld built the so-called chauffeur’s house (above), a little-known but remarkably similar building in his hometown of Utrecht, the Netherlands, which leaked and had to be redone shortly thereafter. Trained as a cabinetmaker, Rietveld — an early member of the de Stijl movement known for his Red-Blue Chair and Schröder House — suffered many such disappointments in a career of more than 45 years. But a new retrospective at Utrecht’s Centraal Museum illustrates how his groundbreaking ideas had a much broader impact than is generally acknowledged. ‘‘In Holland you have this feeling that maybe he was a genius but he wasn’t a good architect,’’ says Ida van Zijl, the curator of ‘‘Rietveld’s Universe,’’ which opens Oct. 20 as part of the Netherlands’ Rietveld Year. ‘‘People don’t realize how many works he made and how experimental they were.’’ The exhibition puts his furniture and architecture on an international scale, comparing it with Marcel Breuer, Le Corbusier and van der Rohe as well as showing its influence on contemporary designers. In a room dedicated to the Red-Blue Chair, the real thing will sit alongside a video of Maarten Baas’s charred homage.

headline: Counter Culture
text: This week, the hottest thing cooking at the Museum of Modern Art will be “Counter Space: Design and the Modern Kitchen.” The show, which opens Wednesday and runs through March 14, 2011, explores the 20th-century evolution of this pivotal room and its ongoing redesign as a barometer of a changing society. Drawn entirely from MoMA’s own collections, “Counter Space” comprises more than 300 works, including design objects, architectural plans, posters, photographs, archival films (including one that shows the motion-study pioneers Frank B. and Lillian M. Gilbreth, of “Cheaper by the Dozen” fame, and nine of their children), prints, painting and media works. Included are an image of a 1931 kitchen, designed by Lilly Reich, that looks as if it had been completed yesterday, and a tape of the famous 1959 kitchen debate between Richard Nixon and Nikita Krushchev. The exhibition also explores the role of the kitchen in feminist critiques and art movements like Surrealism, Pop Art and Fluxus.

headline: Japanese Awards Honor Loren and Pollini
text: The actress Sophia Loren, the pianist Maurizio Pollini and the sculptor Rebecca Horn are among the five winners of the 2010 Praemium Imperiale arts awards, the Japan Art Association announced on Tuesday. The awards, which recognize lifetime achievement in areas of the arts not covered by the Nobel prizes, come with a cash prize of roughly $169,000. The other winners this year are the Italian painter Enrico Castellani and the Japanese architect Toyo Ito. The association also named the Asian Youth Orchestra as the winner of its annual Grant for Young Artists award, which comes with approximately $56,000. The Praemium Imperiale awards were created in 1988 to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Japan Art Association and to honor its longtime honorary patron, Prince Takamatsu, who died in 1987. The awards will be bestowed in a ceremony in Tokyo on Oct. 13.

headline: The Real Balabustas of Tel Aviv
text: It’s not only men who are fanning the flames of Tel Aviv’s hot dining scene. Recently female chefs have started taking over the city’s normally testosterone-fueled kitchens and bakeries. (There are at least three new cupcake shops owned by the ladies.) Tamar Cohen-Tzedek opened Cucina Tamar (HaTsfira 10; 011-972-3-639-0407; entrees about $17 to $26) two years ago, and it’s now one of the top Italian spots in town. ‘‘When I decided to open a restaurant, I didn’t think, Oh, I’m doing this in a man’s world,’’ she says. ‘‘I just did it.’’ So did Einav Berman, who turns out plates like tomato tarte Tatin at her new restaurant, Asif (Lilienblum 18; 011-972-3-516-5198; entrees $16 to $31). At her home kitchen in the Florentin quarter, the American transplant Rima Olvera (above) cooks up a dinner feast for 14 guests every month ($125). And at Joz ve Loz (Yehuda HaLevi 51; 011-972-3-560-6385; entrees $10 to $22), Niva Eshed heads a team of four women chefs (plus one guy) who serve Mediterranean fare like chicken liver ravioli with horseradish sour cream. Unlike in male-dominated kitchens, she says, ‘‘there is no ego. More than for the food, we cook for the experience.’’

headline: Runway Beauty | Marc Jacobs
text: The Studio 54 style of Anjelica Huston, Pat Cleveland and Jerry Hall inspired Marc Jacobs this season. The designer’s beauty dream team — François Nars, Redken’s Guido Palau and Elisa Ferri for Creative Nail Design — didn’t disappoint. (Not that they could have: Arnold mentioned there was a six-hour beauty test the night before.) “We kept a few of the iconic things from the ’70s, like no eyebrows — we’re bleaching all the brows,” Nars said backstage. “Then a dark, reddish-brownish matte lipstick, a little bit of shiny, peachy color on the cheeks to give them a healthy look and deep forest green on the eyes with Vaseline on top.” A spring shade from Creative Nail called Perfectly Bare blended with mattifying top coat was applied to nails to “blank them out,” according to Arnold, mimicking the treatment of the brows. Toes, however, were painted a dark red. “Marc wanted deep, dark, shiny berry toes,” Arnold said. “When he saw Bloodline, he was like, ‘That’s it!’” Models were given one of four side-parted, texturized hairstyles ranging from Marcel waves to major Biba-esque frizz, depending on their natural hair type. “Marc hates hair extensions,” Palau said. “We wanted to capture that period, the decadent loucheness of the ’70s supermodels. You know, that kind of woman who reeks of perfume.” Ah, but would it be Daisy, Lola or even Bang?

headline: Studying Pierogi in Poland
text: My wife, Jackie, recently spent a week visiting a friend in Warsaw, which included an edifying lesson in how to make pierogi leniwe, or so-called lazy pierogi. The idea is that they are dough and (cheese) filling in one mass, not the usual two: a wrapper and a stuffing, one of which has to be painstakingly folded and sealed around the other. In fact, they are cheese dumplings or gnocchi, but it’s a nice conceit of nomenclature that you can get the pierogi experience in streamlined form.
