headline: Still Walking in My Cancer Shoes
text: I suppose I should get a new pair of shoes. The soles have come unmoored, the sides are scuffed and water-warped, dirt and dust cling to their seams (some of them ruptured), and the rawhide laces look as if they’ve been gnawed at by sly rodents.

headline: A Room of Mom’s Own
text: Over the past few weeks, a knot of writers I admire — Jodi Picoult, Jennifer Weiner, Laura Lippman, to name a few — have been leading an online conversation about why books by women are not given the same attention as those by men (particularly in this newspaper).

headline: LettingTax Cuts For The Rich Expire
text: So, let’s see: letting the high-end tax cuts expire on schedule is good economics; picking a fight with Republicans over the issue appears, from all the polls, to be very good politics — and that’s despite what has so far been an incredibly lame effort to explain the issues.

headline: States’ Rites
text: Two new photography books cast an eye on the American cultural landscape. Over the last 15 years, the legendary photographer Lee Friedlander has shot in almost all 50 states, employing the windows and mirrors of his rental cars to frame parts of the country that are often sped past — the churches, motels, bars and bridges. Those black-and-white pictures, collected in ‘‘America by Car’’ (D.A.P./Fraenkel; $50), are timeless in their shabby grandeur. And to coincide with this month’s survey exhibition at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, ‘‘From Here to There: Alec Soth’s America’’ (above; Walker Art Center; $60) is an anthology of past and new work that takes us through the country’s sad and dreamy subcultures, including ‘‘Broken Manual,’’ portraits of men who live off the grid. ‘‘I’ve had the opportunity to photograph all over the world,’’ Soth says, ‘‘but I keep coming back to America. I find it endlessly rich.’’

headline: Cable Contract Has Fines for Late Service Calls
text: Besides perhaps a root canal or a tax audit, few things can be more frustrating than making an appointment to have a cable technician visit your home. You’re given a four-hour window and find yourself waiting and waiting, with no idea when the technician will arrive. Inevitably, it seems, he does not show up until just before the window expires. Or, despite the four-hour time frame, he arrives late.

headline: Q&A: Best Route to Machu Picchu
text: Q.

headline: Cooking With Dexter: Prep School
text: I call home as I leave the office each weeknight, and that is Dexter’s cue to begin laying out the ramekins. When I kiss him goodbye in the morning, I hand him the recipes I’ll be cooking for dinner. Although he is only 6, by the time I get home he has minced the requisite number of shallots, blanched and peeled the tomatoes, seeded and julienned the peppers, soaked and blotted the salted capers and plucked all the tiny brown rocks out of the tiny brown lentils. Then he carefully transfers each ingredient to its own small white dish.

headline: Morning T | Iman
text: Iman, the legendary model turned multihyphenate, kicks off the "Morning T" series of video interviews with T's online director, Horacio Silva.

headline: Trial in Synagogue Bomb Plot Is Delayed Over Questions About Defendant’s Mental Health
text: The trial of four men accused of planting bombs outside synagogues in the Bronx was delayed for a second day on Tuesday, as a judge mulled what to do with a defendant who had become completely unresponsive and had to be brought into court in a wheelchair.

headline: Dressed to Kill at Vera Wang
text: Vera Wang cited an unusual inspiration for her spring collection this morning: Quentin Tarantino’s “Kill Bill.” There was a sort of Eastern vibe in a few details like obi belts, and maybe something armorlike in the quilted mini-vests, but beyond that it felt like Ms. Wang was pulling our legs.

headline: Drinking, Driving and Gold
text: One of the benefits of living in a city well served — at least for now — by a robust mass transit system is that drinking and driving is often less of nightly concern for revelers than it would be in, say, South Dakota.

headline: Oil Industry Targets Schwarzenegger
text: LOS ANGELES – The oil industry is going after Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, the California Republican.

headline: Harley-Davidsons to Remain Wisconsin-Made
text: Harley-Davidson motorcycles will continue to be made in Milwaukee, the company announced on Tuesday after a vote by its Wisconsin-based labor unions to accept wage and benefits concessions.

headline: Back to Nature at Rodarte
text: The Rodarte spring collection was undoubtedly a hit of New York Fashion Week. The designers Kate and Laura Mulleavy could not even take their bow before they were overwhelmed by a rush of editors and retailers praising them to the heavens. Even Elijah Wood was climbing up a stairwell to congratulate the sisters.

headline: New Afghan Corruption Inquiries Frozen
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  New corruption prosecutions have ground to a halt here as the result of a protracted dispute within the government over the limits of American-backed investigators who have pursued high-ranking Afghans, according to American and Afghan officials.

headline: Food-Processor Mayonnaise
text: As I discuss at length in the Dining section this week, the food processor excels at many things, but none more than mayonnaise. Equipped with a smallish work bowl, an egg, a cup of oil, a dash of vinegar or lemon juice and pretty much anything else you can imagine, you can make unbelievable, mind-blowing mayonnaise while you’re washing the dishes.

headline: Of Mussels, Repo Men and the Law
text: As Lake Mead’s water levels drop, the alkaline-laced minerals bleaching the 100-foot “bathtub rings” there are bleaching something else: nets of interlaced quagga mussels just above the water line. The mussels, an invasive species that has cost local governments nationwide tens of millions of dollars, showed up in force there three years ago, spreading all over the bottom and up the cliffs on the Arizona and Nevada sides of the reservoir.

headline: Strong Yen Fuels Rise in Japanese Takeovers
text: TOKYO  The purchases pale in prestige compared with deals like Sony’s takeover of Columbia Pictures, or Mitsubishi’s purchase of the Rockefeller Center, both at the peak of Japan’s economic bubble in 1989.

headline: A Metaphoric Turn to Cannibalism
text: 5:18 p.m. | Updated The Republican Party is eating its own, like a political version of the American pioneers who succumbed to cannibalism, and is giving their rivals a much needed opening, according to Tim Kaine, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

headline: Excerpt: 'Outlaw'
text: The new NBC legal drama stars Jimmy Smits as a Supreme Court justice who quits to become a defense lawyer.

headline: Knee Injury Sidelines Jenkins, Again
text: Throughout training camp, Jets defensive tackle Kris Jenkins seemed energized and revitalized. He looked slim, or as slim as a 360-pound man can look, a result of an unorthodox Cookie Diet and old-fashioned discipline. His latest comeback appeared nearly complete.

headline: Breaking In the New Voting Machines
text: Voters in New York stepped into the brave new world of electronic voting machines during primary elections.

headline: Senate Small Business Bill Advances
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate advanced legislation to aid small businesses on Tuesday after months of Republican resistance.

headline: Marc Newson | On the Go at Gagosian
text: Defying economic reality — and reality, period — the Gagosian Gallery is returning some glamour to travel with “Transport,” an exhibition opening today (through Oct. 16) and spotlighting the work of designer Marc Newson. Comprising full-scale models and working examples, this spare-no-expense undertaking covers the breadth of the London-based Australian’s innovative, hyper-styled vehicle designs, from his Ford 021C urban concept car (1999) and carbon fiber Biomega bicycle (2008) to the 2007 EADS Astrium Space Plane prototype and the freshly unveiled Body Jet jetpack. Easier on the tongue, however, is the highlight: the Aquariva by Marc Newson, the designer’s new take on the leisure speedboats of the legendary Italian company Riva.

headline: Zillow Replaces C.E.O. and Hints at a Public Offering
text: Is Zillow, the real estate Web site, getting ready to go public?

headline: More Trouble Ahead for Kabul Bank
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The run on deposits at the troubled Kabul Bank slowed Tuesday after a long religious holiday, but Afghan financial officials and businessmen said they foresaw further problems in stabilizing the bank, the nation’s largest.

headline: Lone Survivor of Home Invasion Gives Chilling Testimony
text: NEW HAVEN  Dr. William A. Petit Jr. was bleeding and fading in and out of consciousness, tied to a pole in his own basement, his hands and feet bound. He knew he had to get free. His heart, he said, “felt like it was going about 200 beats a minute.”

headline: Charter Controversies and Elephant Dung
text: Should New York City charter schools be required to have parent associations like regular public schools? From that basic question comes the first charter school controversy of the new school year.

headline: What’s Holding Back Small Businesses?
text: The biggest single problem facing America’s small businesses isn’t taxes or overregulation. It’s low demand, according to a new report released by the National Federation of Independent Business.

headline: Panasonic Adds an Interchangeable-Lens Camcorder
text: Panasonic has fused a professional camcorder with consumer Micro Four Thirds (MFT) lens technology, creating the first Micro Four Thirds interchangeable lens camcorder. The AG-AF100, which has a  pro-level price tag of an estimated $6,000 (body only), is designed to easily deliver the look and feel of 35mm film, according to Panasonic.

headline: Credit Suisse to Take Stake in York Capital
text: 8:36 p.m. | Updated

headline: Obama Writes Children’s Book
text: President Obama, already an internationally best-selling author, is about to add a children’s book to his collection.

headline: From Ribera del Duero, a Big, Rich Red Wine
text: “So round, so firm, so fully packed …” The words of the old Lucky Strike cigarette slogan, which became the title of a hit song in 1947 for Merle Travis, kept running through my mind as the wine panel was tasting Ribera del Dueros, the subject of my column.

headline: Pentagon Changes Rules to Cut Cost of Weapons
text: The secretary of defense, Robert M. Gates, announced more than 20 changes in purchasing procedures on Tuesday intended to rein in the ballooning cost of weapons systems and make military ships and planes more affordable.

headline: Primary Voter Turnout Stays Low, but More So for Democrats
text: For the first time since the 1930s, participation in Republican primaries exceeds participation in Democratic primaries, according to a report by the Center for the Study of the American Electorate at American University.

headline: The Auto Show Along 11th Avenue Is Expanding
text: On 11th Avenue in Manhattan is a stretch of auto dealerships similar to other car malls across the country, with glass-fronted showrooms displaying the latest and greatest models from Detroit, Germany and Japan.

headline: Single-Industry Buildings Withstand Tough Market
text: When Kenny Horowitz, a longtime worker in the fashion industry, decided to start his own business, he took a 10-year lease on a 10,000-square-foot showroom in 10 West 33rd Street, the Fashion Accessories Center.

headline: Signs of New Energy at the World Bank
text: I encourage you to read interviews conducted by The Times‘ Green blog and David Roberts at Grist with Daniel Kammen, a professor of energy at the University of California, Berkeley, who has been named chief technical specialist for renewable energy and energy efficiency at the World Bank.

text: Links from around the Web.

headline: City’s SAT Scores Bounce Back After Losses in 2009
text: New York City’s white and Asian students are scoring better on the SATs than at any time since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took control of the city schools, according to 2010 SAT scores released by the city Tuesday.

headline: Should the Doctor Hold a Patient’s Hand?
text: Jordan M. Gutovich, a Philadelphia medical student, was standing at a patient’s bedside when the man began to cry, an experience he writes about in a recent essay in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

headline: Sea Lake Yachts
text: Vince Morvillo, a blind yachtsman and national sailing champion, took some creative steps to keep his business afloat after Hurricane Ike hit Houston.

headline: Joseph Gordon-Levitt’s Live Show to Feature Movies, Music and ‘Little News Cupcakes’
text: After “Inception,” we’ve come to expect a certain degree of inscrutability from all of Joseph Gordon-Levitt‘s projects. But his latest venture may take the totemic cake: on Oct. 28, Mr. Gordon-Levitt, the “(500) Days of Summer” star who’s been lately turning up at downtown Manhattan clubs to sing Lady Gaga covers, will bring the festivities to the Town Hall in Midtown, where he and other artists will perform at a gala event called “Joseph Gordon-Levitt and the hitRECord.org Fall Formal.”

headline: Back-and-Forth Ads in Pennsylvania Rematch
text: It’s déjà vu Bucks County style.

headline: Military Contractor With $100,000 Belt Buckle Is Found Guilty
text: A former military contractor who made bullet-resistant vests and other body armor used in Iraq and Afghanistan was convicted on Tuesday of fraudulently enriching himself from company funds through the kind of extravagant spending exemplified by his purchase of a $100,000 belt buckle.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Rodarte
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Daria Strokous from Women Model Management before (right) and after (left) makeup by James Kaliardos and hair by Odile Gilbert. (Drag the orange bar right to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Letter: Endless Discoveries
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Going off the Grid in Mexico” (Sept. 29): In over 20 years in the international travel business, I am not sure I read a more informative and enlightening article. Just when so many of us think that the world has already been discovered, Seth Kugel shows us an example of the near endless tourist opportunities still available in our own “backyard!”

headline: Letter: More Dublin Theater
text: To the Editor: As an avid theater fan and one lucky enough to often enjoy Dublin theater, I was delighted with your “Off Off Off Broadway? Try Dublin” (Sept. 5) article by Patrick Healy. Mr. Healy imparted so much of what is great about theater in Dublin, its pubs and night life, but did miss a few marks. I’d like to note that the renowned Abbey Theater has a second small theater, the Peacock, housed under its main foyer area and seating only 147.

headline: Hot Springs in Taiwan
text: The mountainous northern region forms the island's volcanic belly.

headline: A Justice Takes Up the Defense
text: Supreme Court justices do resign.

headline: Strategies to Stretch Your Dollar in South America
text: THE first time I traveled to South America, in 1992, my mother told me, “We had to move the credenza at the office to see where you were on the bottom of the map!” I was in Ushuaia, at the southern tip of Argentina — a country that wasn’t exactly on most travelers’ must-see list.

headline: Military Contractor Convicted of Securities Fraud
text: A former military contractor who produced bullet-resistant vests and other body armor used in Iraq and Afghanistan was convicted on Tuesday of fraudulently enriching himself from company funds through the kind of extravagant spending embodied in his purchase of a $100,000 belt buckle, The New York Times’s A.G. Sulzberger reports.

headline: Nuela
text: NUELA is a large and garish new pan-Latin restaurant on West 24th Street that seems at first blush about as welcoming as a Miami nightclub.

headline: Board of Regents Ending Injunction Against Museums’ Art Sales
text: In a surprise development in the battle over whether museums should be allowed to sell art to cover operating costs, the New York State Board of Regents on Tuesday approved the expiration of emergency regulations regarding such “deaccessioning” on Oct. 8.

headline: Rodriguez Is Warned but Avoids Jail Time
text: Francisco Rodriguez, the Mets’ highly paid closer, violated an order of protection by sending his girlfriend 56 text messages in the last four weeks, prosecutors said on Tuesday in Queens Criminal Court.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Developments in Afghanistan on Tuesday took place away from some of the fiercest battlegrounds. The run on deposits slowed on the troubled Kabul Bank following a long religious holiday, Alissa J. Rubin and Adam B. Ellick reported, but Afghan financial officials and businessmen said they foresaw further problems in stabilizing the bank, the nation’s largest. New corruption prosecutions have ground to a halt in Kabul as the result of a protracted dispute within the government over the limits of American-backed investigators who have pursued high-ranking Afghans, Rod Nordland and Ms. Rubin reported.

headline: Scorecard | Theyskens’ Theory Wins!
text: Did Marc miss the mark?! As Scorecard can tell you, on the fifth day of shows critics weren’t totally buying Mr. Jacobs’s if-my-disco-heaven-looks-like-YSL-Rive Gauche-through-a-Missoni-blender, it’s-all-just-a-grand-Pomo-game thing. The former Nina Ricci and Rochas designer Olivier Theyskens, meanwhile, brought romance down from the lofty heights of couture — that’s a Theory they could fully support.

headline: Salmonella at Egg Farm Traced to 2008
text: WASHINGTON  A major egg producer linked to an outbreak of salmonella that has sickened more than 1,500 people conducted tests as far back as 2008 that indicated the possible presence of the dangerous bacteria in its henhouses, according to records released on Tuesday by Congressional investigators.

headline: Arctic Sea Ice Continues Its Summer Slide
text: The sea ice around the North Pole is poised to end this summer’s retreat shy of a record, but on track toward more open Arctic waters in decades to come.

headline: A Modest Plan to Save the Tigers
text: Most of the estimated 3,500 tigers that still roam the wild live in 42 relatively contained enclaves in India, Sumatra and Far Eastern Russia, with a smattering in Malaysia, Thailand and Laos. But those so-called source sites are losing ground to development, forestry and poaching and must be protected to save the tigers from extinction, according to a new paper from a group of conservationists, academics and government officials.

headline: Deciding Not to Screen for Down Syndrome
text: Amy Julia Becker is expecting her third child in January. She is 32 years old, and her age, plus the fact that her first child was born with Down syndrome, magnifies her odds of a chromosomal abnormality in this pregnancy, leading her doctors to suggest prenatal testing. In spite of the odds — or perhaps because of them — and her husband have declined the tests. In a guest post today, she explains why.

headline: Catching Up
text: Here’s a by-no-means exhaustive list of debates that I might have waded into in the last week, if I hadn’t been touring Ireland instead:

headline: The Lady and the Majority Leader
text: Check out the latest hot pop culture couple: Lady Gaga and Senator Harry Reid, the Nevada Democrat and majority leader.

headline: Small-Business Jobs Bill Clears Senate Hurdle
text: The Senate’s long-delayed small-business jobs bill — it was first introduced in late June — is finally on the brink of passage, now that the chamber has overcome a procedural hurdle to end debate. The measure cleared the cloture vote, 61 to 37, as two retiring Republican senators, George Voinovich of Ohio and George LeMieux of Florida, voted with the Democratic majority. A final vote on the bill is likely by week’s end.

headline: Self-Indulgent Actor, Served on a Skewer
text: To satirize overacting is easy. The drawn-out pauses, the sudden shifts in emphasis, the operatic syllable  you have seen these tactics before. Finding the pitch-perfect tone to skewer the pretentiousness of doing very little is more of a challenge.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Marc Jacobs
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.

headline: Former Chilean President to Lead New U.N. Agency
text: UNITED NATIONS — Michelle Bachelet, famous for breaking gender barriers by becoming the first woman elected president of Chile, will head the new global United Nations agency created to advance women’s rights, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon announced Tuesday.

headline: The Scene: Day Six
text: Photos from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Behind All the Sweets There’s Lots of Stress
text: Early on, not all the signs are promising for “Kings of Pastry,” a documentary by the veteran team of Chris Hegedus and D. A. Pennebaker (“Moon Over Broadway,” “The War Room”). The jaunty version of “The Marseillaise” that keeps popping up on the soundtrack contributes to an overall feeling of fustiness and inconsequence as we’re introduced to several contenders for membership in the Meilleurs Ouvriers de France, an exclusive fraternity of pastry chefs.

headline: Jamaica, Queens, 11:58 A.M.
text: Primary day continued on Tuesday afternoon amid reports of problems with new voting machines. Still, voters will have a chance to give them a try until 9 p.m. in New York City. You can see a slide show of primary day photographs here. Check back at nytimes.com/nyregion throughout the evening for minute-by-minute updates.

headline: Paul LePage’s Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day
text: Paul LePage, the Republican candidate for governor in Maine, appears to be tiring of media attention.

headline: Need to Define ‘DIP Loan’? There’s an App for That
text: If you’re a corporate lawyer and find yourself puzzled by financial jargon like “second lien” while doing document review, the law firm Latham & Watkins has a solution for you.

headline: Some Unlucky Animals, Giving Their Lives for Art
text: Can a play be interesting and forgettable at the same time? Apparently it can, because “Roadkill Confidential,” a new work by Sheila Callaghan, is intriguing to watch, yet it leaves no impression.

headline: Dickey Is at Home, In Any House
text: R. A. Dickey tucked into the legendary fare of a firehouse and gauged the camaraderie of a different kind of clubhouse.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Never Let Me Go’
text: Mark Romanek, the director of “Never Let Me Go,” discusses a scene from the film.

headline: For Old-Fashioned Flavor, Bake the Baking Soda
text: ACIDS are invaluable mainstay cooking ingredients. Lemon and lime juices, myriad vinegars and sour salt, or citric acid, can brighten and balance the flavor of almost any food. But what about their chemical opposites, the un-acids? These are the alkalis, and they’re a different story.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: The Flavors of Fall

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: A Smorgasbord at a Delancey Street Shop
text: This homey little storefront’s name, Fisk, means fish in Swedish. That’s almost all you need to know. Annika Sundvik, above, who owns it with her husband, John Lavelle, sells all sorts of fish and seafood, fresh and cured, and almost all in Scandinavian style. Tiny smoked Norwegian shrimp, homemade gravlax, peppered mackerel, smoked herring, pickled baby octopus and several roes, including lumpfish, wasabi and seaweed, are listed on a blackboard, along with fresh seafood like cod and lobster. Some cheeses, including Vasterbotten; produce like potatoes, beets, cabbage and onions; and pantry products, like lingonberry cordials and packaged flatbreads, are also sold. The couple, who own White Slab Palace, a restaurant and bar next door, are gradually adding prepared foods, like smorrebrod (open-faced sandwiches).

headline: Ketchup With a Pedigree
text: Those little artisanal condiment makers keep trying to unseat Heinz, to no avail. Still, they often come up with really excellent products. Sir Kensington’s, with a label that looks as if it belongs in Harrods, is the latest. It comes in a squat jar from which the ketchup can be easily spooned, and though it delivers spice and sweetness in moderation, like Heinz, it is much thicker and has a lustier tomato taste. The spicy version is ruddier and hotter. Brown sugar, agave nectar and honey are the sweeteners.

headline: Candies That Are Hotter Than Red Hots
text: Ghost pepper, a name for the bhut jolokia grown mainly in northeast India, is so powerful that the Indian military announced earlier this year that it was going to “weaponize” the peppers for hand grenades.

headline: Bill Clinton Endorses Jerry Brown
text: President Bill Clinton endorsed his long-ago rival Jerry Brown for governor of California, brushing aside Mr. Brown’s recent snippy joke about the Monica Lewinsky scandal.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Diane von Furstenberg
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.

headline: Unfinished David Foster Wallace Novel Gets Cover and Release Date
text: Little, Brown & Co. on Tuesday revealed the jacket art for “The Pale King,” an unfinished novel by David Foster Wallace that it will publish next year. In a news release, the publisher said the novel, whose cover design was created by Mr. Wallace’s widow, Karen Green, is set in “an IRS tax-return-processing center in Illinois in the mid-1980s,” and tells the story of “a crew of entry-level processors and their attempts to do their job in the face of soul-crushing tedium.”

headline: If Photojournalism Is Dead, What’s Luceo?
text: I was about to write two very different posts on the future of photojournalism when I realized that I should write only one.

headline: Rabbis for Human Rights
text: The Op-Ed Columnist Nicholas D. Kristof sees how Rabbis for Human Rights are a voice of conscience in the West Bank, protecting Palestinian farmers from some hostile Jewish settlers.

headline: From Federal Economic Policy to Football
text: David H. Romer is a respected economics professor whose ideas influence central bankers and governments hoping to pull out of a recession.

headline: Oil Industry Takes On Schwarzenegger
text: Our colleagues at The Caucus report that the oil industry is going after Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, who opposes a ballot proposition that would suspend the state’s landmark greenhouse gas bill.

headline: A Feast From Two Cultures
text: Mario Carbone, one of the chef-owners of the restaurant Torrisi Italian Specialties, demonstrates how to fry mozzarella sticks in a wok for the Feast of San Genarro in New York's Little Italy.

headline: Little Italy Meets Chinatown
text: ARCHES of red, white and green tinsel, hanging between the light posts of Mulberry Street, shimmered in the August heat.

headline: Woody Allen on Faith, Fortune Tellers and New York
text: Asked on Tuesday morning if it was appropriate to wish him a happy Jewish New Year, Woody Allen made it clear that such formalities were not necessary. “No, no, no,” he said with a chuckle, seated in an office suite at the Loews Regency hotel. “That’s for your people,” he told this reporter. “I don’t follow it. I wish I could get with it. It would be a big help on those dark nights.”

headline: Growing Up in a Hush, With the Ultimate Identity Crisis
text: The limits of beauty or, more rightly, the uses of visual beauty are revealed in the adaptation of Kazuo Ishiguro’s highly regarded dystopian novel “Never Let Me Go.” Directed by Mark Romanek, this coming-of-age story involves three British friends who are raised with others of their kind in a group home that proves more Orwellian than Dickensian. In time, they timidly make their way into the world, which turns out to be crueler than most of us would, I suspect, like to believe. Though here cruelty is done so prettily and with such caution that the sting remains light, giving the entire enterprise the aspect of a tasteful shocker.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Marc Jacobs
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Ginta Lapina from Women Model Management before (right) and after (left) makeup by François Nars and hair by Guido Palau. (Drag the orange bar right to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Mark Hartley and His ‘Machete Maidens Unleashed’
text: TORONTO — Skin and gore are front and center in Mark Hartley’s documentary “Machete Maidens Unleashed,” a wild look back at the exploitation cinema produced by Roger Corman, Joe Dante and a host of others in the Philippines in the ’70s and ’80s. While the women in the films were scantily clad (if clad at all), Mr. Hartley discusses how some of those actresses saw it as one of the most liberating times for women in film.

headline: Playlist: Big Boi
text: Melena Ryzik rolls with Big Boi, the Atlanta rapper and one-half of the hip-hop duo Outkast, as he performs in Brooklyn and takes a spin around Manhattan in a vintage Mustang.

headline: Crowd-Sourced Cachet for Private Sales
text: The ever-growing list of private flash-sale Web sites has just gotten longer with SniqueAway, a new site that is offering its first sales on Sept. 20. But this one has one selling point that Jetsetter.com and RueLaLa.com don’t: an affiliation with TripAdvisor.

headline: Met Opera Plans a Baroque Pastiche
text: They called it a pasticcio  pastry  a mishmash of arias by different composers, sometimes given new texts and often chosen by the singers. The practice of throwing together an opera from snippets, also called a pastiche opera, was standard operating procedure from the late-17th to late-18th centuries: a practice unthinkable in our age of textual authenticity.

headline: Church Explains Lack of Clear Apology
text: BRUSSELS  The day after the Roman Catholic Church in Belgium responded to its crisis over sexual abuse, a senior bishop said the church had not made a clear apology because it feared opening the door to a flood of claims for financial compensation.

headline: Putting Collars on Cats
text: Cat owners are often reluctant to put collars on their pets, a factor that can make it difficult for lost cats to be returned home. As today’s Observatory column reports: “Less than 2 percent of cats in animal shelters make it back to their owners, whereas about 15 to 19 percent of dogs are returned, and one reason is that more dogs wear collars.”

headline: For Blacks, Progress in Happiness
text: Set aside some prominent success stories, like the current occupant of the White House, and the last few decades have not been great ones for African-American progress.

headline: A Pay Model for Essays Taken From Itunes
text: If a song on iTunes sells for 99 cents, how about a literary essay? On Tuesday, Scribner began publishing 69 essays by Chuck Klosterman, the pop culture and sports writer, available individually from retailers like Amazon, Apple and BN.com for 99 cents each. Nearly all the essays, which include “Fargo Rock City, for Real” and “All I Know Is What I Read in the Papers,” have appeared in print books before. But Scribner is hoping that people who have become accustomed to buying songs individually might do the same for stand-alone literary works. It will also publish digital collections of Mr. Klosterman’s essays  “Chuck Klosterman on Rock” and “Chuck Klosterman on Sports,” for instance  for $7.99 each.

headline: Ay Kitchen
text: 115 Lexington Avenue (28th Street), Murray Hill, (212) 213-0200, aykitchen.com.

headline: David Foster Wallace Archive Is Opened
text: Fans and researchers now have the chance to page through the papers of the novelist David Foster Wallace, below. The Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas, Austin, which acquired manuscripts of his books, stories and essays in March, officially opened the archive on Tuesday. It includes material from Wallace’s own library, including marked-up copies of novels by Don DeLillo and others. Wallace, whose 1996 book, “Infinite Jest,” won widespread acclaim, committed suicide in 2008 at 46. A posthumous novel called “The Pale King” is expected out next year.

headline: Money Is Tight, and Other Toronto Traumas
text: TORONTO  “White people problems.”

headline: Cirque Du Soleil Plans To Play Radio City
text: To the extent that whimsical Canadian clowns can be described as sober people, a chastened Cirque du Soleil disclosed the details on Tuesday of a new show it plans to bring to Radio City Music Hall next summer. The announcement follows the commercial failure of another Cirque show (“Banana Shpeel”) this year at the Beacon Theater, which was supposed to be the Montreal-based company’s beachhead in a wider expansion into New York. The Radio City show, which does not yet have a title, will be a $50 million production that returns to the time-tested Cirque brand of acrobatic spectacle, like “Wintuk,” above. It will employ a cast of more than 70 and be directed by the filmmaker François Girard (“Thirty Two Short Films About Glenn Gould”; “Silk”). The creators hope the show will run for at least four months, starting in June, and return annually for four years. “There is only one way to succeed in New York, by becoming a citizen of New York City,” Daniel Lamarre, the chief executive of Cirque du Soleil, said in a telephone interview. “We have to earn our citizenship.” Cirque described the show as taking place in an abandoned theater where a magician “has lost his love and with her, his magic has disappeared.” Seeking her return, the magician “is plunged into a world inhabited by surreal creatures.”

headline: Exhibition of Haitian Art
text: An exhibition of Haitian painting, sculpture and works on paper  including Salnave Philippe-Auguste’s “Birds and Flowers,” a detail of which is shown above  will be on view at Affirmation Arts at 523 West 37th Street in Manhattan from Oct. 1 to Nov. 24, the gallery said on Tuesday. The exhibition, “Saving Grace: A Celebration of Haitian Art,” is being organized by a historian of Haitian art, Gérald Alexis, and will feature works from the Nader Gallery in Port-au-Prince, as well as others being lent by artists and private collectors in Haiti, Canada and the United States. Many of the best-known artists of the Haitian Renaissance, including Hector Hyppolite, Célestin Faustin, Wilson Bigaud and Préfète Duffaut, will be represented. The Nader Gallery survived the earthquake that devastated Haiti in January, but a private museum owned by the same family, and which housed some 12,000 works of art, was destroyed. Two paintings included in the exhibition, Hyppolite’s “Pot de Fleurs” and Faustin’s “Beau Rêve,” were pulled from the wreckage and restored by art conservators working in a lab set up in Port-au-Prince by the Smithsonian Institution.

headline: What the Latest Senate Small-Business Jobs Bill Offers
text: 1:56 p.m. | Updated The Small Business Jobs Act of 2010 — as detailed below — passed the Senate on Thursday by a vote of 61 to 38. Two Republicans, Sen. George Voinovich of Ohio and Sen. George LeMieux of Florida voted with the Democratic majority.

headline: Japanese Honors for Sophia Loren
text: Sophia Loren, below, the pianist Maurizio Pollini and the sculptor Rebecca Horn are among the five winners of the 2010 Praemium Imperiale arts awards, the Japan Art Association said on Tuesday. The awards, which recognize lifetime achievement in areas of the arts not covered by the Nobel Prizes, come with a cash prize of roughly $169,000 each. The other winners this year are the Italian painter Enrico Castellani and the Japanese architect Toyo Ito. The association also named the Asian Youth Orchestra as the winner of its annual Grant for Young Artists award, which comes with approximately $56,000. The awards will be bestowed in a ceremony in Tokyo on Oct. 13.

headline: CBS Takes Monday
text: Reruns on CBS topped network television ratings on Monday night, outperforming ABC’s finale of “Bachelor Pad.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, CBS’s comedies “Two and a Half Men” and “The Big Bang Theory” were once again the highest-rated shows in prime time, earning an average of more than eight million viewers in the 9 p.m. hour. ABC and NBC finished in a virtual tie for second place on the night. Although ABC’s two-hour conclusion of “Bachelor Pad” (5.8 million) edged ahead of NBC’s rerun of “America’s Got Talent” from 8 to 10 (5.4 million), ABC’s “Dating the Dark” (3.5 million) trailed NBC’s “Dateline” (4.4 million) at 10. Fox was fourth. On Sunday the MTV Video Music Awards drew an average of 11.4 million viewers, more than any other cable broadcast this year.

headline: Newspaper Group Offers a Guarantee to Marketers
text: NEWSPAPERS are joining media like television and magazines in guaranteeing some results for advertisers.

headline: Regents to End Injunction on Museum Art Sales
text: In a surprise development in the battle over whether museums should be allowed to sell art to cover operating costs, the New York State Board of Regents on Tuesday approved the expiration of emergency regulations regarding such “deaccessioning” on Oct. 8. Those rules, which enjoined such sales, have been in effect since 2008. After hearing views from museums statewide, “there was no consensus on the efficacy of those emergency regulations,” David Steiner, the state’s education commissioner, said in a statement. Thus, “those regulations will be allowed to expire, allowing the prior regulations regarding museum collections to once again take effect.” Last month the board indicated it planned to make the emergency regulations permanent, in part because a bill addressing the issue had stalled in the Legislature. “This removes a substantial obstacle to the monetization of art held in the public trust and to the transfer of art from public hands to private hands,” said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, who led the drafting of the bill.

headline: David Foster Wallace Archive Is Opened
text: Fans and researchers now have the chance to page through the papers of the novelist David Foster Wallace. The Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas, Austin, which acquired manuscripts of his books, stories and essays in March, officially opened the archive on Tuesday. It includes material from Wallace’s own library, including marked-up copies of novels by Don DeLillo and others. Wallace, whose 1996 book, “Infinite Jest,” won widespread acclaim, committed suicide in 2008 at 46. A posthumous novel called “The Pale King” is expected out next year.

headline: Debussy’s Gallic Urbanity and an Alluring Saint-Saëns Oddity
text: Now in its second season, the New York Chamber Music Festival at Symphony Space has expanded impressively. In a seven-day run that began last Friday, the festival is offering 13 concerts, up from 6 last year. Among the performers are musicians from the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, as well as several soloists and ensembles. The repertory includes a bit of everything: standard fare, rarities (piano quartets by Korngold and Joseph Marx), contemporary works and jazz transcriptions.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Never Let Me Go’
text: TORONTO — Love and loss are explored in the film “Never Let Me Go,” adapted from the Kazuo Ishiguro novel. The film, a quiet relationship drama with sci-fi undertones, stars Keira Knightley, Carey Mulligan and Andrew Garfield. The director Mark Romanek spoke about a confrontational scene in the film and the choices he made in putting it together.

headline: Putting Memories to New Use
text: WHEN the photographer Sara VanDerBeek was growing up in Baltimore in the 1980s, she yearned for the vanished art world of 1960s New York, in which her father, the experimental filmmaker Stan VanDerBeek, had played an important role. Mr. VanDerBeek, who died when Sara was 7, had collaborated with artists like Claes Oldenburg and Merce Cunningham, and worked with Bell Labs to create some of the first computer animations. Before and after his death, Ms. VanDerBeek said, friends from the old days often visited and talked about the excitement and experimentation of that time.

headline: Superheroes in Court at Yale Show
text: The case of “The People vs. Superman” is not found in the hornbooks that are scoured by the nation’s law students. But if they had been youngsters in 1967, when Action Comics No. 359 first came out, they might have been amazed to see the Man of Steel in an unusual situation. Instead of zooming through the sky or confronting talkative archvillains, he is in a courtroom, sitting in the witness chair. A little girl is standing in front of the Man of Steel, pointing at him.

headline: Nadal Savors His Latest Role: All-Courts Player
text: On the planet’s tennis courts  be they clay or grass or the blue, cushioned acrylic of the United States Open  Rafael Nadal has answered all the big questions. But with the matches finally done in New York and Nadal’s career Grand Slam complete, the questions kept coming Tuesday.

headline: Unlikely Group Charges Bias at University
text: For more than 35 years, the City University of New York, one of the nation’s most diverse higher education systems, has quietly struggled with a minority group that says it has been passed over for jobs. In June, members of the group issued a blistering report the size of a phone book. In July, one employee filed a federal discrimination lawsuit, and some state lawmakers are pushing for hearings this fall into what they see as blatant ethnic bias.

headline: Amid Blight and Scavenging, ‘Old G.M.’ Plants Linger
text: FLINT, Mich.  By day, hundreds of General Motors workers make pistons and other engine parts at a factory on this city’s east side. By night, gangs of thieves have repeatedly looted empty G.M. plants on the same property, and have twice fired shots at security guards.

Boehner on extending Bush-era tax cuts only for the middle class, but they said the debate would not threaten his quest to become speaker if the party won control of the House.

headline: Clicking Candidate.com, Landing at Opponent.com
text: PHOENIX — One might think that BobMenendez.com would be the Web site of Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. But no. headline: Suit on Health Care Bill Appears Likely to Advance
text: PENSACOLA, Fla.  A federal judge indicated on Tuesday that he would give a green light to a lawsuit filed by elected officials from 20 states who are challenging the constitutionality of the new health care law and its requirement that most individuals obtain medical insurance.

headline: India’s Protests Are Cherished and Maligned
text: CALCUTTA  This kaleidoscopic city of 15 million people stopped dead last Tuesday. Flights were canceled at the airport. The streets, ordinarily throbbing with traffic and humanity, were almost empty. And thousands of shopkeepers like Wazeed Khan shuttered their stores in observance of a familiar Indian ritual  the shutdown strike.

headline: In Gonzalez, Rockies Have a Budding Star
text: DENVER  Jose Contreras does not remember who told him, just that he first learned of Carlos Gonzalez on a spring training field in Arizona and never forgot the name. Gonzalez was only a prospect, but Contreras was told he would be the game’s next great superstar, like Miguel Cabrera with speed.

text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has set a goal of doubling American exports over five years, and has called on Congress to eventually ratify free-trade agreements that were negotiated by the Bush administration with South Korea, Colombia and Panama.

headline: Blagojevich Asks Judge to Throw Out Conviction
text: CHICAGO  Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, wants a federal judge to throw out his conviction for lying to federal agents, the single count the jury found him guilty of in August.

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Debates Karzai’s Place in Fighting Corruption
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is debating whether to make Afghanistan’s president, Hamid Karzai, a more central player in efforts to root out corruption in his own government, including giving him more oversight of graft investigators and notifying him before any arrests, according to senior American officials.

headline: Microsoft and Russia
text: Microsoft made the right decision to stop helping Russian authorities use claims of software piracy to harass and silence dissenters. On Monday, it announced that it is barring its lawyers from taking part in such cases and will provide a blanket software license to advocacy groups and news media outlets in Russia, undercutting the Kremlin’s tactic.

headline: Ratify the New Start Treaty
text: After 21 Senate hearings and briefings, the Foreign Relations Committee is scheduled to vote on Thursday on the New Start treaty. The first nuclear arms control agreement with the Russians in nearly a decade, it calls for both sides to reduce their deployed warheads modestly to 1,550 from 2,200. The treaty also will ensure that each country has continued insight into the other’s arsenal, with inspections and exchanges of information.

headline: Fishing at the Base of the Pyramid
text: Perhaps the most abundant remaining source of wild protein on the planet is krill, a tiny crustacean that lives in Antarctic waters. It is fed upon by nearly every Antarctic species, including whales, penguins, seals and many kinds of fish. The species with the greatest appetite for protein is humans. That harvest has now increased enough to start worrying ecologists.

headline: With That Guy as ...
text: By scanning earth’s television broadcasts long after we are gone, other civilizations will be able to make certain judgments about human society. How among untold billions of lives, a few were deemed worthy of repeated and copious observation. Milton Berle, Mary Tyler Moore, Ted Danson, Oprah Winfrey, Simon Cowell: Truly these were giants of the species.

headline: Kashmir Is Locked Down, but Bloodshed Continues
text: SRINAGAR, Kashmir  Since Sunday, when the government announced a round-the-clock curfew, everyone  men, women, teenagers, toddlers  has been locked in. There is no telling when the curfew will be lifted, and there is no leaving.

headline: Remembering Ron Kramer, Packers’ Rock at Tight End
text: Andy Barall, who writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down, with a few words about Ron Kramer, the former Packer tight end who died Saturday:

headline: Mexican Official Quits
text: MEXICO CITY  Mexico’s immigration minister resigned Tuesday, three weeks after 72 Central and South American migrants were killed in an attack that threw a spotlight on the often harsh treatment people endure while traveling through Mexico toward the United States.

headline: Russia: Fire Destroys Church Near Ravine Where Remains of a Czar Were Found
text: The main church at a monastery near the site where the remains of Czar Nicholas II and his family were dumped was destroyed in a fire on Tuesday. Officials said they had not determined the cause of the fire at the wood church at Ganina Yama, on the outskirts of Yekaterinburg, a city in the foothills of the Ural Mountains, where the family’s remains were found in a ravine in 1979. The monastery, which consists of seven churches, draws people from around the world who come to pay homage to the czar and his family.

headline: Vermont: Missionaries’ Aide Extradited in Smuggling Case
text: A former adviser to the American missionaries who were detained for attempting to remove children from Haiti after the earthquake there was extradited from the Dominican Republic to the United States this week, officials said. Jorge Puello, 32, faces charges in Vermont of smuggling migrants from Canada to the United States. He has also been accused in El Salvador of running a prostitution ring. Mr. Puello portrayed himself as a lawyer but was later discovered to be an international fugitive.

headline: Britain: Scotland Yard Renews Phone Inquiry
text: A lawyer for Sean Hoare, a former News of the World reporter who has said he was involved in a phone hacking scandal, said that Mr. Hoare had been questioned by detectives about whether Andy Coulson, the newspaper’s editor at the time, had asked him to hack phones. Mr. Coulson, now the communications director for Prime Minister David Cameron, has denied knowing anything about the hacking. After several former employees said in an article in The New York Times Magazine that phone hacking had been widespread under Mr. Coulson, Scotland Yard said it might reopen an investigation. Mr. Hoare appeared to be the first person to have been questioned in the new inquiry.

headline: Unthinkable Has Occurred: Jets and Giants Don’t Sell Out
text: When the Jets and the Giants decided to build New Meadowlands Stadium, they stocked it with 10,000 expensive club seats, dwarfing the 400 to 500 that each team sold for a relative pittance at Giants Stadium.

headline: Gonzalez, the Rockies’ Rising Star, Is at Home in Denver
text: DENVER — Watching the Colorado Rockies a few nights ago, on a broadcast from Colorado, I had to chuckle at a local commercial in which Carlos Gonzalez delivers tacos to hungry fans. It underscored just how anonymous Gonzalez still is, chasing a playoff berth and a Most Valuable Player award – and even, perhaps, a Triple Crown – while cheerfully hawking tacos on Rocky Mountain cable.

headline: France: Senate Passes Bill on Facial Veils
text: The French Senate on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved a bill barring women from wearing the full facial veil anywhere in public. If the law is approved by France’s constitutional council, it will go into effect next spring and set a range of fines for women, including tourists, who wear the full veil. It also provides criminal penalties for those who force women to wear it. The vote was 246 to 1, with many abstentions from left-wing legislators; the bill passed the lower house in July.

headline: A Confident Narciso Rodriguez
text: The first looks of the spring Narciso Rodriguez collection included a gray linen canvas dress, slightly nipped at the waist, with a baby pink lingerie strap across the open back, and a similar gray jacket worn open (the closures were hidden) over a light pink slip of a top. They had something in common with a look that is familiar to millions of women, the gray corporate suit worn over a pink blouse, but these seemed to be distant descendants. They looked like more modern and liberated cousins.

headline: Wednesday: Ammo for Idiots
text: BROWN CROSSWORD WEEK continues.

headline: Holding Tight to Grief While Struggling to Move On
text: Much care has been taken to provide an appealing frame for Lucy Thurber’s play “Bottom of the World,” which opened on Tuesday night at the Atlantic Theater Company’s Stage 2. Walt Spangler’s elaborate set is dominated by an impressive wooden structure suggesting the expansive reach of an old tree. On the platform provided by one of the sturdier branches, two excellent musicians supply bluegrass music, evocatively used to add emotional coloring to various scenes. Live music is a rare and appealing luxury at a modest Off Broadway production like this.

headline: Real Exchange Rates In Emerging Markets (Wonkish)
text: I’m doing some homework on various issues, and one of the things I’ve been doing is trying to work through what we should be seeing in the emerging economies now that the advanced economies seem set — thanks to bad policy and bad ideas — to experience a prolonged period, maybe a lost decade, of weak growth, high unemployment, and low interest rates.

headline: Japan Acts to Weaken Its Currency
text: TOKYO  Japan moved on Wednesday to prop up the dollar and weaken the yen in a bid to protect its export-led economy, intervening in international currency markets for the first time since 2004.

headline: Three Big Plays Put Yankees Back in First Place
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Signature moments have eluded the Yankees this year. No flurry of game-ending home runs in the Bronx, a paucity of extra-inning magic. Their victories have been clinical and resounding, and their losses — well, until the past week — have lacked panache.

headline: Ronald Walters, Rights Leader and Scholar, Dies at 72
text: Ronald W. Walters, who organized one of the nation’s first lunch-counter sit-ins to protest segregation as a young man and went on to become a leading scholar of the politics of race, died Friday in Bethesda, Md. He was 72 and lived in Silver Spring, Md.

headline: Rangel Easily Defeats Five Primary Rivals
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel, the battle-scarred Democratic incumbent facing numerous ethics charges, captured his party’s nomination on Tuesday after a nasty six-way primary battle in which his opponents sharply questioned his fitness to serve.

headline: Michael Burn, Writer and Adventurer, Dies at 97
text: Michael Burn, a British journalist and author whose eventful life included an early flirtation with Nazism; a daring commando raid on the fortified port of St.-Nazaire, France; imprisonment in Colditz Castle; a love affair with the British spy Guy Burgess; and a timely intervention in the aftermath of World War II that saved Audrey Hepburn’s life, died Sept. 3 at his home in North Wales. He was 97.

headline: Birmingham Bomb Kills 4 Negro Girls In Church; Riots Flare; 2 Boys Slain
text: Birmingham, Ala., Sept. 15--A bomb severely damaged a Negro church today during Sunday school services, killing four Negro girls and setting off racial rioting and other violence in which two Negro boys were shot to death.

headline: Taft Gained Peaks In Unusual Career
text: Twenty-seventh President of the United States and its tenth Chief Justice, William Howard Taft was the only man in the history of the country to become the head of both the Executive and Judicial Departments of the Federal Government.

headline: Phys Ed: Can Exercise Make Kids Smarter?
text: In an experiment published last month, researchers recruited schoolchildren, ages 9 and 10, who lived near the Champaign-Urbana campus of the University of Illinois and asked them to run on a treadmill. The researchers were hoping to learn more about how fitness affects the immature human brain. Animal studies had already established that, when given access to running wheels, baby rodents bulked up their brains, enlarging certain areas and subsequently outperforming sedentary pups on rodent intelligence tests. But studies of the effect of exercise on the actual shape and function of children’s brains had not yet been tried.

headline: Rival Candy Projects Both Parse Cocoa’s DNA
text: Scientists say they have determined the complete DNA sequence of the tree that produces cocoa beans, an accomplishment that is expected to vastly accelerate efforts to assure a stable supply of chocolate and to make it better-tasting and healthier.

headline: Newcomer Ousts Espada; Monserrate Loses Political Return
text: Pedro Espada Jr., the pugnacious and powerful State Senate majority leader, was roundly defeated in Tuesday’s Democratic primary election by Gustavo Rivera, a first-time candidate who won over Bronx voters fed up with the financial and political scandals swirling around Mr. Espada.

headline: Word of the Day | consensus

headline: In House Race, Maloney Defeats Primary Rival
text: Beating back an aggressive challenger, United States Representative Carolyn B. Maloney easily won the Democratic Party’s nomination on Tuesday, according to early returns in one of the most expensive Congressional primaries this year.

headline: A Test of Fortitude for Financial Regulators
text: The blind self-belief of financiers can’t be abolished. Neither can the industry’s cycles. But two years after the disastrous failure of Lehman Brothers, regulatory shifts have the potential to reduce the impact of a repeat. The challenge for politicians and watchdogs is not to go soft.

headline: G.M. Inquiry Focuses on Delphi Pension Motive
text: The special inspector for taxpayer bailout funds is looking into whether the Obama administration pressed General Motors in bankruptcy to backstop the pensions of the union retirees of a former division, Delphi, Mary Williams Walsh writes in The New York Times.

headline: Study Finds Wider View of ‘Family’
text: A majority of Americans now say their definition of family includes same-sex couples with children, as well as married gay and lesbian couples.

headline: In Berlin, Space for a Collection
text: Julius Eulberg collects porcelain birds and other figurines, which fill his bright two-bedroom apartment.

headline: In Germany, Part Temple, Part Bird Sanctuary
text: BERLIN — Julius Eulberg shares his 1,500-square-foot apartment here in Prenzlauer Berg, a recently gentrified district in the northeast of the city, with more than 350 porcelain birds, from albino peacocks to purple feathered macaws. They perch on shelves, and nestle together on and under antique tables.

headline: Juror Is Dismissed After He Complains
text: NEW HAVEN  A juror in the Cheshire murder trial was dismissed on Tuesday after writing the judge a note harshly criticizing prosecutors in the case.

headline: Homes for $1.5 Million
text: A 19th-century house in California, a condo in Chicago and a house in Connecticut.

headline: Schneiderman Wins Democratic Attorney General Race
text: Eric T. Schneiderman won a narrow victory in the Democratic primary for state attorney general in a race that was closely contested by the five candidates but drew relatively little notice or interest from voters.

headline: Open Air in Bali

headline: Anatomy of a Game-Clinching Play
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — I’ve watched the Throw from Greg Golson about 10 times now on replay, and every time I anticipate a different result. Did he really just throw out at third base Carl Crawford, voted the fastest player in baseball by recent a Sports Illustrated poll, from the right-field line — after catching the ball on his back foot — to clinch the Yankees’ 8-7 win? headline: Italy Seizes $1.9 Billion in Mafia-Linked Assets
text: The Italian police seized $1.9 billion in assets belonging to a Sicilian businessman linked to the Mafia in the country’s biggest blow against organized crime, Italy’s interior minister said Tuesday, Gaia Pianigiani writes in The New York Times.

headline: Results Are Mixed for Tea Party in New York
text: Christopher Cox, the wealthy son of the state Republican chairman and a grandson of President Richard M. Nixon, was crushed Tuesday night in his bid for the Republican nomination to represent Suffolk County in Congress.

headline: Washington Mayor’s Loss May Imperil School Reform
text: WASHINGTON  Adrian M. Fenty, the mayor of Washington, helped make his schools chief, Michelle A. Rhee, a star.

headline: Morgan Stanley Sued by Taiwan Bank
text: Taiwan’s China Development Industrial Bank (CDIB) has sued Morgan Stanley in a U.S. court to recover millions of dollars in losses it suffered from its investment in a residential mortgage product, Reuters reports.

headline: Strong Yen Fuels Rise in Japanese Takeovers
text: The purchases pale in prestige compared with deals like Sony’s takeover of Columbia Pictures, or Mitsubishi’s purchase of the Rockefeller Center, both at the peak of Japan’s economic bubble in 1989, Hiroko Tabuchi writes in The New York Times.

headline: In Tight Republican Race, DioGuardi Is Chosen to Face Gillibrand
text: Joseph J. DioGuardi, a former congressman from Westchester County, emerged from a field of little-known candidates on Tuesday as the Republican choice to take on Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in the November election.

headline: A.I.G.’s Asian Unit Appoints Chief Financial Officer
text: In a key move before its planned stock market listing in Hong Kong, the Asian life insurance unit of the American International Group named a chief financial officer on Wednesday, filling a position that had been vacant for several months, Bettina Wassener writes in The New York Times.

headline: Last Big Night of Primaries
text: Christine O’Donnell upset Representative Michael N. Castle in the race for the Republican Senate nomination in Delaware, Ovide Lamontagne and former Kelly Ayotte were locked in a tight race in New Hampshire, and Adrian Fenty lost to Vincent C. Gray in the mayoral primary in Washington D.C.

headline: Twitter Site Revamped and Simplified
text: Twitter unveiled a new Web site on Tuesday that it hopes will be user friendly, Claire Cain Miller and Miguel Helft report in The New York Times.

headline: Sharpe Faces Sex Allegation
text: Shannon Sharpe, an analyst for “The NFL Today” on CBS, is taking a temporary leave from the program to deal with a temporary restraining order filed against him by a woman who says he forced her to have sex with him and made threats against her. “We accept Shannon’s decision,” said LeslieAnne Wade, a spokeswoman for CBS Sports. “Beyond that, we decline to comment on a pending legal matter.” The case was reported by the blogger SportsByBrooks.com. A hearing is scheduled for Monday in Fulton County Superior Court in Georgia.

headline: Lionsgate and Televisa Unite on Films
text: Lionsgate’s African-American-focused film business, anchored by Tyler Perry titles, has become a gold mine for the studio. Movies with predominantly black casts that tell stories rooted in black culture — surprise! — bring out a sizable black audience.

headline: Flagstar Said to Eye $600 Million Share Sale
text: Flagstar Bancorp, the regional bank backed by a private equity fund, is trying to raise $600 million through a share sale and has approached private equity firms that may be interested in buying an equity stake, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Eisner Downplays Reports He May Run Tribune
text: Michael Eisner, the former Walt Disney chief who now runs his own investment firm, on Tuesday downplayed reports that he is being considered to head up the Tribune Company when the media firm exits bankruptcy protection.

headline: Buyout Shops Said to Mull Move for Edwards
text: The private equity owners of Edwards, the British engineering firm whose vacuum technology is used by the world’s biggest chipmakers, have hired a trio of investment banks to explore a $2 billion-plus sale or flotation, Reuters reported.

headline: Citigroup Faces Trial Over EMI Auction
text: Terra Firma Capital Partners can proceed to trial against Citigroup in their dispute over the private equity firm’s 2007 acquisition of EMI, the music group, a federal judge ruled on Tuesday.

headline: China ‘Paying Close Attention’ to BHP-Potash Deal
text: China is closely watching BHP Billiton‘s $38.5 billion bid to acquire one of the world’s biggest producers of potash and fertilizer, the government said Wednesday in its first official comment on the proposed takeover.

headline: Energy Trader Vitol to Pay $6 Million in Settlement
text: An energy trading firm has agreed to pay a $6 million fine to settle federal regulators’ charges of misleading an exchange by failing to disclose facts concerning its relationship with a subsidiary, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Is America a Great Country?
text: A column by Thomas L. Friedman has been on the Most E-Mailed List for several days. In it, Friedman suggests several reasons why the United States ranked No. 11 in Newsweek’s list of the 100 best countries in the world. One reason, he suggests, is the lack of a strong education system. Do you think the United States is a great nation? Where would you rank it on a list of great nations? Why?

headline: Buffett Continues to Unload Moody’s
text: Warren E. Buffett has unloaded another 1.35 million shares in Moody’s Corp., but Berkshire Hathaway still controls 12.6 percent of the credit rating firm’s stock.

headline: Woody Allen: The Director’s Cut
text: Boy, if life were﻿ only like this: on Tuesday morning, this reporter (who always regrets he never had the “Star Wars”-themed bar mitzvah party depicted in “Deconstructing Harry”) found himself ushered into a New York hotel office suite to speak with Woody Allen about his new film, “You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger.” And while Mr. Allen, 74, characteristically complained about the air conditioning in the chilly suite, he did not accuse his interlocutor of knowing nothing about his work, and spoke at length about the themes in his latest movie, his filmmaking process and his thoughts on getting older – not to mention his next feature, “Midnight in Paris,” whose ensemble cast happens to include the first lady of France.

headline: Voters Deliver a Reminder to Republicans (and Pundits)
text: One of the weaknesses of our Senate forecasting model is that, for all the precision we apply to the general election forecasts, we only eyeball the primaries, making estimates about the likelihood of each potential matchup on the basis of the polling and other factors. Nevertheless, we try to be pretty careful. For instance, we had assigned a 25 percent likelihood that Joe Miller would defeat the Republican incumbent, Lisa Murkowski, in Alaska, as happened. We had also assigned small likelihoods to a number of other outcomes that did not come to fruition, like J.D. Hayworth ousting John McCain in Arizona (Mr. McCain won by 24 points) or Chet D. Traylor unseating David Vitter in Louisiana (Mr. Vitter won by 81).

headline: Beyond Animal Rights, the Antibiotics Battle
text: I’ve reported in Iraq and Afghanistan and walked through a SARS ward in China at the height of that deadly epidemic. But my scariest moment as a reporter came this summer, when I visited an egg farm in Ohio to write about the debate over factory farming and animal confinement. I’m dangerously allergic to feathers, and I had to will myself (aided by a Benadryl) to walk into a barn filled with 168,000 hens.

headline: I’ll Take Broken Game-Show Records for $77,000, Alex
text: Roger Craig may have a little difficulty spelling the title of “The Bridge on the River Kwai,” at least in high-pressure situations when television cameras and the eyes of thousands of viewers are trained on him. But we’ll cut him some slack: by correctly identifying the title of that Pierre Boulle novel turned David Lean film, Mr. Craig, a 33-year-old graduate student at the University of Delaware, set a new one-day earnings record on “Jeopardy!”, winning $77,000 at the end of Tuesday’s broadcast, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Iraqi-U.S. Raid Near Falluja Leaves 7 Dead
text: BAGHDAD  Seven Iraqis were killed in a village near the city of Falluja on Wednesday during an early morning raid by American and Iraqi security forces on the house of a suspected insurgent leader, officials said.

headline: Kensal Rising
text: London’s bohemian vanguard has found a new home base in the twin neighborhoods of Kensal Rise and Kensal Green. The traditionally Portuguese district of Victorian row houses north of Notting Hill is home to buzzy gastropubs and incognito celebrities — Sophie Dahl and Jade Jagger live here — and the rents are still cheap enough that pioneering shop owners are hanging out shingles on Chamberlayne Road. Victoria Brotherson, the florist behind Scarlet and Violet (76 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-969-9446), sells vintage cut-crystal vases and chipped enamel pitchers alongside English blooms like cornflower and nigella. ‘‘I thought I was just going to have a little workshop,’’ she says. ‘‘I was taken by surprise that we were that busy.’’ In her wake, two vintage furniture stores, Howie & Belle (52 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-964-4553) and Circus Antiques (60 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-968-8244), have opened among the bookies’ offices down the street. And a 10-minute walk away in Kensal Green, Retrouvius (2A Ravensworth Road; 011-44-208-960-6060)is the brainchild of the designers Adam Hills and Maria Speake, a space stocked with repurposed architectural salvage. There’s quirky drinking and dining, too: besides the Chamberlayne Pub and Steakhouse (83 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-960-4311) and the wine bar Miro’s (75 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-203-235-0003), the gastropub Paradise by Way of Kensal Green (19 Kilburn Lane; 011-44-208-969-0098) serves seasonal and organic dishes and a beloved sticky toffee pudding. It doubles as a lounge and performance space that may hide in its warren of rooms a burlesque show, a wedding or even the singer Lily Allen.

headline: Using Varnish So News Doesn’t Break Your Server
text: A month ago, the City Room blog ran a call for photos, asking readers to submit their photos of New York City’s waterfront. Thanks to the Stuffy photo submission system, The Times can run these requests for user photos on a regular basis, and I generally remain unaware of them. In this case, though, my colleague and I were testing out a general traffic monitoring screen we’re calling “the big board.” At that moment, a web producer placed a Flash promo in the center well of the NYTimes.com home page. The promo pulled a data file directly from our application servers instead of using a static version saved to the Content Delivery Network.

headline: Touring Act
text: Sometimes forces beyond our control — rock bands, bloggers, fashion people — anoint a new epicenter of cool. Marfa, Tex., and Reykjavik, Iceland, had their moment, and now it’s Lisbon’s turn. The Walkmen named their latest album after the city. (J. Crew chimed in too, shooting a catalog there.) Hamilton Leithauser, the frontman, said the band traveled to Portugal while they wrote ‘‘Lisbon’’: ‘‘Everything just worked there. The rest of Europe doesn’t work as well for us — our horn players quit in Germany.’’ The results are 11 songs that range from explosive anthems (‘‘Angela Surf City’’) to lonely dirges (‘‘Stranded’’). ‘‘Lisbon’’ also marks the Walkmen’s debut on Fat Possum Records, based in Oxford, Miss., another drowsy town ripe for aesthetic reclamation any minute now.

text: Note: We are no longer accepting questions for this feature. Read answers to reader questions: Part I and Part II.

headline: Are You Hip to Hipmunk?
text: In 2003, I was at a book signing when a skinny 14-year-old boy came up to meet me. He was engaging and social, and said he was an amateur programmer and offered up his services as an assistant to writing my computer how-to books. I thought, “Aww, what chutzpah for a ninth grader!” — and forgot all about it.

headline: Wednesday Reading: When the Cable Guy Is Late
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: New Lawsuit Filed in Fracking Country
text: More than a dozen families in Susquehanna County, Pa., filed a lawsuit late Tuesday against the Southwestern Energy Production Company, asserting that a succession of “releases, spills and discharges of combustible gases, hazardous chemicals and industrial wastes” from the company’s nearby drilling sites had contaminated their drinking water and made them sick.

headline: Band Name Costs New Pornographers a Gig in Michigan
text: When the members of the New Pornographers chose their band name, they probably took it for granted that most listeners would understand they produced bouncy guitar- and synthesizer-driven indie rock for a living, and nothing more salacious than that. But the joke did not play well at Calvin College in Grand Rapids, Mich., which has canceled a planned concert by the New Pornographers on the basis of the group’s name, The Grand Rapids Press reported.

headline: G.O.P. Leaders Say Delaware Upset Hurts Senate Hopes
text: The Tea Party movement scored another victory on Tuesday, helping to propel a dissident Republican, Christine O’Donnell, to an upset win over Representative Michael N. Castle in the race for the United States Senate nomination in Delaware.

headline: Dozens Injured in Anti-American Protests in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A clash between anti-American protesters and the Afghan police injured 35 police officers and 12 civilians here on Wednesday, as each side accused the other of indiscriminately firing shots.

headline: New Designer Tries a Hand at Reviving Blass
text: The house of Bill Blass, after sitting out Fashion Week for a few seasons while its new owners retooled the business, introduced a small spring collection Wednesday morning by the designer Jeffrey Monteiro. On a stage in a black tent at Lincoln Center, Mr. Monteiro’s models wore a range of cocktail suits, graphically embroidered vests and a selection of red dresses, one of which was made of a loose knit.

headline: Necklace Worn by Diana Goes on the Block
text: Lot 65 at an auction scheduled for Sept. 24 in New York — on the block just after a police motorcycle that trailed John F. Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963, and just before Clark Gable’s medical bracelet — is a necklace that was worn once by the original owner. And also a pair of earrings that glimmer with diamonds and South Sea pearls.

headline: Last Night in Delaware
text: For a decentralized, essentially leaderless movement (the best efforts of Dick Armey and Jim DeMint notwithstanding), the Tea Party has cut its swath through the Republican primary season with a great deal of strategic savvy. Beginning with Pat Toomey and continuing through Marco Rubio and Rand Paul, Sharron Angle and Joe Miller, the candidates propelled to victory by Tea Partier enthusiasm have often given the national Republican Party heartburn, but none of them have been clearly un-electable — and if this fall is as good to the G.O.P. as it’s shaping up to be right now, most of them will probably end up winning. Whereas in those races where the “rightwardmost candidate” (to borrow William F. Buckley’s phrase) couldn’t possibly win a general election, the Tea Party hasn’t gone all in: Thus Carly Fiorina rather than Chuck DeVore is the Republican nominee for the California Senate, John McCain rather than J.D. Hayworth is the nominee in Arizona, Mark Kirk is the nominee in Illinois, etc.

headline: Games Theory
