headline: Learning by Playing: Video Games in the Classroom
text: One morning last winter I watched a middle-school teacher named Al Doyle give a lesson, though not your typical lesson. This was New York City, a noncharter public school in an old building on a nondescript street near Gramercy Park, inside an ordinary room that looked a lot like all the other rooms around it, with fluorescent lights and linoleum floors and steam-driven radiators that hissed and clanked endlessly.

headline: 3 Women Claim Bias at Goldman
text: Three former female employees at Goldman Sachs sued the investment bank on Wednesday, contending that the firm discriminates systematically against women.

headline: Amid Shelling, Mideast Peace Talks Drag
text: JERUSALEM  Peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians shifted to home turf here on Wednesday, amid a rain of mortar shells on southern Israel and with no sign that the two sides had broken an impasse over Israel’s moratorium on the construction of Jewish settlements.

headline: Asked & Answered | D.A. Pennebaker and Chris Hegedus
text: Best known for “The War Room,” the 1994 documentary that went inside Bill Clinton’s campaign hub in Little Rock, Ark., D.A. Pennebaker and Chris Hegedus have been co-directing since the mid-’70s. Next year, their work will be the subject of a retrospective at the Museum of the Moving Image. Their latest production, “The Kings of Pastry,” makes its theatrical debut at Film Forum. Bon appétit. The movie takes viewers to Lyon, France, to follow the  Alsatian pastry chef Jacquy Pfeiffer, the co-founder of Chicago’s French Pastry School, as he vies for France’s most prestigious trade award, the M.O.F. (Meilleurs Ouvriers de France, or Best Craftsmen of France). Held every four years, the grueling competition is the artisanal equivalent of the Olympics — or rather, it makes “Top Chef” look like a slumber party. “In a way,” Hegedus says, “television cooking shows have spoiled us for the possibilities of true drama in the kitchen.”

headline: James Bond’s 1964 Aston Martin DB5 to Be Auctioned
text: How could anyone resist pressing an “ejector seat” button, especially when the bright red temptation was in a car once owned by the world’s most famous British secret agent?

headline: Membership Rewards Will End Relationship with Continental
text: Updated 12:25 p.m. to add comment from Chase and additional information from Amex.

headline: Backstage Beauty | Narciso Rodriguez
text: “Narciso is a real-deal designer. He’s kind of to New York what Alaïa is to Paris,” the hairstylist Eugene Souleiman said during a break outside the Narciso Rodriguez show last night. “What he’s done this season is like a retrospective of himself — there are trousers, long dresses, bodices — so I wanted to do the opposite and have every girl look identical.”

headline: Tory Burch: Baja Fresh
text: Kanye West’s obsessive compulsion to attend fashion shows has taken him from the obscurest of avant garde collections in Paris to the commercial runways of Milan to the, uh, er, the 9 a.m. presentation by Tory Burch at New York Fashion Week on Wednesday.

headline: Part 3, Answers to Your Back-to-School Questions
text: Mr. Dingledine, an independent college counselor in Greenville, S.C., is responding to selected questions from readers of The Choice. His answers will continue throughout the week. To post a question, use the comment box below, or on the original post. Some questions, and answers, have been edited for space and style. –Jacques Steinberg

headline: Salvos Fly as Ethanol Ruling Nears
text: The Environmental Protection Agency has said it will rule by the end of this month on whether to allow gasoline retailers to sell a mixture that is 15 percent ethanol and 85 percent unleaded regular, a change from the current maximum of 10 percent ethanol. Coalitions have lined up — on one side, the corn farmers and ethanol producers, and on the other, the oil refiners, auto companies, manufacturers of gasoline-powered equipment and companies that use corn to raise livestock.

headline: Writing a Will, With a Lawyer Looking Over Your Shoulder
text: Writing a will using an online program will certainly save you some money, as long as you don’t make any mistakes that could potentially cost your heirs later.

headline: The Face of Fear in Hebron
text: Maja Hitij, 26, has worked as a freelancer in Israel, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip since 2008. She is a native of Slovenia. Her photos have been published in The New York Times, The International Herald Tribune, The Guardian, The Washington Post and Süddeutsche Zeitung. In 2009, she was an intern for The Associated Press in Berlin and Jerusalem. Her conversation with Amanda Rivkin has been edited and condensed.

headline: Musharraf Claims Support for a Comeback
text: Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan’s former leader, who seized power in 1999 and left the country amid unrest and legal troubles in 2008, said on Wednesday in Hong Kong that he intended to return home to lead a new political party and bring “change” to Pakistan.

headline: A Thai City of Sleaze Tries to Clean Up
text: PATTAYA, THAILAND — Somewhere in the world there may be a city with a more seedy reputation, a place more devoted to the sex industry and more notorious as a haven for criminals on the lam. But probably not.

headline: A Talk With Catherine Deneuve
text: TORONTO — The French actress Catherine Deneuve knows her way around a movie set. With 47 years onscreen, working with some of the most acclaimed directors in cinema, Ms. Deneuve has had one of the richest acting careers in film. And she shows no signs of stopping.

headline: Edwin Newman, Journalist, Dies at 91
text: Edwin Newman, the genteelly rumpled, genially grumpy NBC newsman who was equally famous as a stalwart defender of the honor of English, has died in Oxford, England. He was 91.

headline: Patient Voices: Schizophrenia
text: Paranoia, anxiety and delusions — schizophrenia can be a paralyzing mental illness. Seven people speak about its impact.

headline: The Voices of Schizophrenia
text: Few mental illnesses are as complex and confusing as schizophrenia, a mental disorder in which people may experience hallucinations or delusions, hear voices or have confused thinking and behavior.

headline: France Moves to Raise Minimum Age of Retirement
text: PARIS  Lawmakers in France’s lower house on Wednesday passed President Nicolas Sarkozy’s pension overhaul, which includes an increase of the minimum retirement age to 62 from 60, after several days of political cross-fire that ended with a raucous overnight debate.

headline: Quote Unquote | Payback Time
text: –Agyness Deyn’s friend explains why she walked in Alexander Wang’s show. Imagine if he killed a rat- she would have to star in his campaign!

headline: Reggie Bush’s Spin Move
text: You have to hand it to Reggie Bush. You really do. As elusive as he might be on a football field, he is at least equally talented at eluding responsibility away from one. Is it really possible to be the first person to give back a Heisman Trophy  just ahead of it being pried from your hands by the Heisman Trust after having obliterated N.C.A.A. rules  and paint yourself as a noble, selfless teammate and role model? Of course it is! If you’re Reggie Bush.

headline: The Nutsiness of Politics
text: Gail Collins: David, I am in Alaska, where people seem to be cheering Tuesday night’s Tea Party triumphs in Delaware and New York. We’ll get to those in a moment. I wanted to mention first the subjects that are really on people’s minds here — the filming of a Drew Barrymore movie in Anchorage and the mass migration of the walruses to the shores of the northwest. The movie was drawn here by tax credits and has been accompanied by an explosion of beautiful young women in the downtown area. The walruses seem to be fleeing global warming. Everyone is enthusiastic about the migration of beautiful young women, but the attitude toward a mile-long stack of walruses along the coast is more mixed.

headline: Man Charged as Money Source in Times Sq. Bomb Plot
text: Updated 12:34 p.m. | A Long Island man has been charged with providing thousands of dollars in cash that was used to support the failed plot to bomb Times Square in May, according to an indictment unsealed on Wednesday.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Zero Maria Cornejo
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

headline: Kelly McGillis, Melanie Leis
text: Kelly McGillis, the actress, and Melanie Leis, a sales executive, were joined in a civil union on Wednesday morning in Collingswood, N.J. Judge Robert T. Zane III, the municipal presiding judge for Camden County, N.J., officiated at the Collingswood Municipal Court.

headline: TimesCast | September 15, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, analyzing the Tea Party primary wins, an update on the Mideast peace talks and teaching middle school students to make their own video games.

headline: What’s Inside a Taliban Gun Locker?
text: Since last year, The New York Times and At War have taken several different looks at insurgent arms and munitions in Afghanistan, which can yield information about how insurgents equip themselves and fight, and how the Taliban has been able to maintain itself as a viable force for more than 15 years.

headline: The Numbers Behind Our Census Preview
text: This post will be on the far end of the technical spectrum for Economix. We expect many readers will be happy skipping this one and reading that one instead.

headline: China Shifts Away From Low-Cost Factories
text: DONGGUAN, China  Companies here in China’s industrial heartland are toiling to reinvent their businesses, fearing that the low-cost manufacturing that helped propel the nation’s economic ascent is fast becoming obsolete.

headline: Don’t Tell Facebook Friends That You’re Going Away
text: Over at the Bits blog, Nick Bilton points to reports out of New Hampshire that a gang of burglars has been selecting homes according to the Facebook status updates of their owners.

headline: Notes From the Underground | The Rapture
text: Maybe it was the endless flow of free vodka, but seeing the Rapture perform on a backyard porch at a house in East Hampton, N.Y., definitely felt like something out of a dream. For most of that summer day, the small audience of lucky revelers was scattered around a swimming pool, playing Ping-Pong and floating on inner tubes, but the band’s full length set — experienced at such proximity — inspired much dancing.

headline: How Much More ‘Americanized’ Should VWs Get?
text: Jonathan Browning, the newly named head of Volkswagen of America, stirred up a bit of controversy this week by suggesting the coming replacement for the New Beetle needed to be designed more for the tastes of the American market.

headline: At Kors, Walking on Sunshine
text: “Here Comes the Sun” was the music for the Michael Kors spring runway show, and if it wasn’t obvious by his sun-bleached boardwalk and privet hedge backdrop, Mr. Kors was in a “sunshine state of mind.” So said his press notes.

headline: A Common Problem in an Oversharing City
text: Before mentioning a new ranking of the nation’s cities in order of the “most social,” let us pause to acknowledge the bogus nature of such lists.

headline: Redford’s Film Is Picked Up in Toronto
text: TORONTO — “The Conspirator,” Robert Redford’s independently produced picture about the hanging of Mary Surratt in the wake of Abraham Lincoln’s assassination, has a home. Lionsgate and Roadside Attractions said they acquired rights to distribute the film in the United States and plan to release it next spring. Mr. Redford was one among dozens of filmmakers who showed their indie films at the Toronto International Film Festival, which is still under way.

headline: The Economics Of High-End Tax Cuts
text: I’ve thought of one way to explain why extending tax cuts for the top end is such a bad idea; it involves a bit of cheating, but in a way that doesn’t undermine the essential point.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Sophie Theallet
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: U.S. Economy Is ‘Blah,’ Soros Says
text: George Soros, the billionaire investor and philanthropist, on Wednesday had one word to describe the current state of the United States economy: “blah.”

headline: Vintage Retailer to the Stars
text: LONG ago, this black taffeta cocktail dress from the Eisenhower era probably knew a happier life — one of icy martinis and tail fins, backyard barbecues and Perry Como ballads. But after years of neglect at the bottom of a garbage bag full of old clothes, its hemline was shredded by rot. It now looked like a burial shroud for Morticia Addams.

headline: Craigslist Says It Has Shut Its Section for Sex Ads
text: Craigslist said on Wednesday that it had permanently closed the section of its sites in the United States that carried sex-related advertising, but it defended its right to carry such advertisements as well as its efforts to fight sex trafficking.

headline: Art for Guys Who Hate Museums
text: ON Monday morning, the street artist known as Blek le Rat, considered the godfather of stencil graffiti art, set out to create his latest work on a wall opposite the Standard Hotel on West 13th Street.

headline: The G-Star World Chess Challenge, in Video
text: Magnus Carlsen’s victory over the world last Friday in the G-Star Raw World Chess Challenge was well covered by the media. There are now many videos available of the event. It may be the first time that MTV has ever had reports on chess.

headline: A Voter Critiques the New Machines
text: Lynn Brenner, a friend of City Room, sent around an e-mail describing her voting experience in New York City on Tuesday and contrasting it with her experiences of past years. This follows a primary day that prompted many complaints. We thought it smartly summed up the experiences of many, and we happily present it here:

headline: G.O.P. Uses Obama ‘Otherness’ as Campaign Tactic
text: WASHINGTON  With every new swipe at President Obama’s exotic background or cultural influences, a contingent of Republican leaders are signaling that they believe the coming elections are more than just a referendum on the administration’s economic policies. Rather, to a degree that is striking, conservatives are also trying to make the fall campaign about the president himself and the kind of societal change he actually represents.

headline: Soros to Get a Day in Court Over Insider Trading Case
text: PARIS — Europe’s highest human rights court said Wednesday that it would accept a complaint by the international financier George Soros that his rights were impinged on by French courts in convicting him in an insider trading case dating back more than two decades.

headline: A Step in the Smart Direction
text: WOOOOOOSSHHH was the sound coming up from the floor of Leffot, jets of air shooting up either side of my foot as my right heel settled into a snug Alden chukka boot made of Chromexcel, with a sole cut from thick Goodyear rubber.

headline: Coming Children’s Show Draws Complaints
text: An advocacy organization is stepping up its criticism of a series for children that is scheduled to begin appearing next month on the Nicktoons cable channel. But those involved with the show are defending it.

headline: A Season’s Roundup of Beauty Choices
text: IN the breathless, never-satiated world of beauty, every season brings new enthusiasms. Here are some must-haves for autumn that fall squarely into the category of More Than Just a Passing Fancy. Without intending to limit myself to one continent, I ended up choosing nothing but European imports that struck me as distinctive, most of which have only recently become available here.

headline: And Now, On to 2012
text: With all eyes on November, the outcome of Tuesday’s primaries on the 2012 presidential campaign is already being debated.

headline: Poll Finds Mixed Views, or None at All, on Tea Party
text: Christine O’Donnell’s win in last night’s Republican primary for the United States Senate in Delaware shines another bright spotlight on the Tea Party movement, prompting the question: What impact will it have in a general election?

headline: Quiz: You Think You Know Broadway?
text: In the newly published “Broadway Musical Quiz Book” (Limelight Editions), the author Laura Frankos has written more than 80 quizzes about all things musical theater. The questions, over 1,200 in all, are divided up by category, including famous composers and lyricists (Stephen Sondheim, Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein), star performers (Patti LuPone, Carol Channing) and unusual themes (the seasons, U.S. history).

headline: Reader Rejoinders
text: An occasional assemblage of overheard or underappreciated words – generously emailed by co-vocabularists.

headline: Quote Unquote | Tom Ford, Lady’s Man?
text: –Tom Ford discusses one of the gorgeous models, Joan Smalls, who walked in the debut of his women’s collection. If only he were serious, sigh.

headline: Paladino Promises a Relentless Attack Against Cuomo
text: BUFFALO — Fresh from having romped to a lopsided victory in the Republican primary for governor, Carl P. Paladino vowed Wednesday to attack Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo “like General Patton,” saying he would exploit Mr. Cuomo’s “immaturity” and his “ego.”

headline: Ayotte Declared Winner in New Hampshire
text: 5:09 p.m. | Updated

headline: W.T.O. Said to Find Improper Subsidies for Boeing
text: The long-running trans-Atlantic spat over government support of the world’s two biggest aircraft makers gained fresh momentum on Wednesday as a trade panel found that Boeing had received subsidies that violated global trade rules, people briefed on the decision said.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Narciso Rodriguez
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Beer Garden Radar
text: It seems as if beer gardens are opening around every corner of New York. Now there’s a iPhone app to make sure you don’t miss that turn.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Her Dockers Slim Fits Are On Fire: Tea Party scores upset in Delaware primary with Christine O’Donnell, who told opponent, “This is not a bake-off, get your man pants on.”

headline: Four Are Severely Hurt in Bronx Fire
text: Update, 4:10 p.m. | Firefighters in the Bronx rescued a woman and child from a suspicious fire that engulfed their basement apartment early on Wednesday morning.

headline: Tracking Favre or the Mannings, Tricked-Out Phone in Hand
text: If you consider yourself an avid N.F.L. fan and life’s events somehow impaired your ability to closely track last Sunday’s opening day marathon, you may well suffer from L.C.S., or lame cellphone syndrome.

headline: Eagles’ Handling of Head Injury Draws Spotlight
text: On Sunday afternoon, more than 28 million people were watching Fox’s national broadcast when the Philadelphia Eagles’ Stewart Bradley rose woozily, stumbled and then collapsed onto the turf. The Fox announcers Joe Buck and Troy Aikman expressed concern and even horror. Players waved frantically for medical assistance.

headline: When Autistic Children Become Adults
text: Today, one in 110 children is estimated to have some form of autism spectrum disorder. But back in 1943 there were a total of 12. That was when the first article about a condition “unlike anything reported so far” appeared in a medical journal. A boy named Donald T. was called “Case 1” — the first child given a diagnosis of autism.

headline: A Baby Photo Becomes an Internet Meme
text: SOMETIME back in 2000, Allen S. Rout, a systems programmer from Gainesville, Fla., posted a few photos of his 5-month-old son, Stephen, on his personal Web site. They were the kind of photos that every parent takes, but one in particular stood out: Stephen wearing a pair of red overalls, smiling in a crib. “We’re really blessed,” Mr. Rout wrote as the caption. “Stephen is an amazingly happy baby.”

headline: Can You Run a Company From Jail?
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Brazen or Subtle, Mining the Past
text: NEW YORK has always been a knockoff kind of town, but to state that outright is to risk fashion heresy. Marc Jacobs, after all, has declared repeatedly that it’s fine  indeed modern  to “sample” the work of his predecessors, thereby giving implicit permission to rafts of his peers to “pay homage” to the past.

headline: Russia and Norway Agree on Boundary
text: MOSCOW — Russia and Norway resolved a long-running boundary dispute in the Arctic Ocean on Wednesday that may help open a portion of the frozen sea to offshore oil and gas development.

headline: Steve Martin Creates Steve Martin Bluegrass Prize
text: Hey, kids: Steve Martin wants to give you $50,000! There’s just one catch: you’re going to have to get really good at bluegrass music first.

headline: Man Is Accused of Sex Crimes Against 5 Women
text: Updated, 3:23 p.m. | A man claiming to be a French journalist whom prosecutors accused of preying on sophisticated women was charged Wednesday with various sexual crimes, including rape and forcing a woman to give him oral sex.

headline: Lehman Sues Canadian Bank and Others for $3 Billion
text: Lehman Brothers, which filed for bankruptcy exactly two years ago, has sued Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and dozens of other defendants to recover more than $3 billion of which it said it was deprived because of the bankruptcy filing.

headline: The Rise and Fall at New York Fashion Week
text: One thing we have learned so far from the New York spring runways is that waistlines are rising and hemlines falling, and heaven help those with stubby legs. To address the latter first: in nearly every collection (and certainly every strong collection) the preferred length is midcalf, with a welcome whiff of the ’70s (Marc Jacobs), the ’90s (Narciso Rodriguez) or whatever we call this decade (Rodarte). It’s an elegant silhouette to be sure, and even made the color-blocked kids at Marc by Marc Jacobs look refreshingly polished and just plain new.

headline: If Eagles Can Miss Concussion, What Hope Is There for Youth Players?
text: In the wake of the Eagles’ latest misstep involving a player’s concussion — sending linebacker Stewart Bradley back into Sunday’s game minutes after his injury after failing to diagnose him properly — The Times’s Alan Schwarz asked a crucial question in a news analysis on Wednesday:

headline: Geithner to Signal Tougher Stance on China Currency
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is moving to take a harder stance on the Chinese government’s trade and currency policies, with anger toward China rising in both political parties ahead of midterm elections.

headline: Cities With the Most Home Price Cuts
text: Updated | Sept. 15, 2010

headline: Despite Struggles, Entrepreneurs Find Ways to Give Back
text: The economic slowdown that started in 2008 affected just about every aspect of Gumas Advertising’s business  including the company’s long-time support for charities in the San Francisco area. “In good times, we did not have to scrutinize our charitable giving or employee perks,” said John Gumas, the company’s president. “But in these economic times, we’ve really had to think through what we could afford to give and still be able to make a difference.”

headline: From the Roof, to a Battery, to the Grid
text: In the garage of Peter Rive’s San Francisco home is a battery pack. It is not connected to Mr. Rive’s electric Tesla Roadster sports car, but to the power grid.

headline: No. 1 Planet for Alien Tourists
text: “Earth (The Book)” is a mock textbook by writers for “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” — or “the authors of the popular television program ‘The John Daly Show’ ,” as they put it in a fake Wikipedia blurb on the book’s back cover. It is conceived as a handy guide for extraterrestrials who arrive on this planet after humanity has become extinct, in case those extraterrestrials want to know what they’re missing. It explains everyday details about how we live(d), from our use of the fork (“a way to hurt food one last time before eating it”) to our wearing of pants. “We put these on one leg at a time,” it says. “You may require a different approach.”

headline: It’s Demand, Stupid
text: I’ve said this before, but Catherine Rampell has a very nice chart making the point: if you ask businesses — as opposed to their lobbyists — what their problem is, you find no hint of the stories the usual suspects are telling you about government interference, political uncertainty, etc.. Businesses aren’t hiring because of poor sales, period, end of story:

headline: Citi Scoops Up UBS Energy Bankers
text: UBS’s investment banking division has sustained a heavy blow as nearly its entire energy banking team in Houston has defected to Citigroup.

headline: On the Road: Analyzing Citizen Science Reports on Roadkill
text: Overview | What can we learn from animals that have accidentally been killed as a result of human activity? In this lesson, students use a map to navigate local roads from the perspective of a common animal. Then they analyze geographic data collected from animals killed in motor vehicle collisions and propose ways to reduce them. They learn how to analyze the layers of data included in interactive maps, think critically about the data and apply what they have learned to suggesting ways to improve roadway safety for wildlife.

headline: DeMint: ‘We are Going to Win in Delaware’
text: Senator Jim DeMint, who has been a champion of Tea Party candidates throughout the nation, said that Christine O’Donnell‘s victory in the Delaware Republican Senate primary was proof of a nationwide mobilization of voters in favor of smaller government and that the party’s future hinged on embracing candidates like Ms. O’Donnell and rejecting any moderates who might be willing to vote with Democrats.

headline: Quick-Change Artist | Lindsey Wixson
text: The model Lindsey Wixson of Marilyn Model Management gets reinvented eight times.

headline: Sara Bareilles Tops Billboard Chart
text: Sara Bareilles, whose single “Love Song” became a ubiquitous hit two years ago, reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week with her second release, “Kaleidoscope Heart” (Epic). Her new album sold 90,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, beating out Eminem, Katy Perry, Disturbed and several new releases. It was the best week of album sales in Ms. Bareilles’s career so far — her first release, “Little Voice,” peaked at No. 10 and has sold a total of 997,000 copies to date. But her album sales are still dwarfed by the success of “Love Song,” which has had 3.2 million digital downloads.

headline: Reporting Abroad and Cotton Underwear
text: Mort Rosenblum is one of those legendary journalists who has been everywhere and done everything, mostly with gunfire in the background. So it’s fitting that he has just written a guidebook to global reporting — and the big problem is that there aren’t that many young journalists being dispatched to foreign capitals any more. Given the financial constraints, most news organizations (the Times is a major exception) prefer to cut back on overseas coverage.

headline: A Triple Bill at City Ballet
text: The company opened a rare fall season on Tuesday.

headline: Color Anxiety? Don’t Bite Your Nails
text: SEATED near a colleague at Lincoln Center this week, I found myself glancing at her fingertips, which were lacquered in a brooding gray that made my own paler tint seem hopelessly wan. Overcome with the kind of envy only Fashion Week inspires, I ran off in pursuit of that gunmetal shade from Chanel, only to find that it had vanished, supplanted in stores by a range of new pigments  slightly creepy riffs on purple with evocative names like Paradoxal (Chanel), Belle de Nuit (YSL) and Marrow (Butter London).

headline: The Valhalla Machine
text: THE Rhinemaiden descended by a cable to the floor of the Metropolitan Opera stage. She extended her body just in front of a hollow beneath part of the set for Wagner’s “Rheingold.” Slowly, inexorably, the edge of a 45-ton structure tilted down toward her.

headline: Does Fashion Make Good Theater?
text: SHOULD the scramble to get into a fashion show bring to mind the desperate crowds clamoring to board the last choppers out of Saigon?

headline: Have You Found Creative Ways to Give Back?
text: We’ve just published a small-business guide to giving back even when your company is struggling. Written by Jim Witkin, it offers a variety of suggestions. During slow times, for example, Larry O’Toole (above), founder of Gentle Giant movers, has committed his people and vans to doing pro bono work. At the same time, he’s also managed to develop some important business relationships.

headline: In Midtown, Igloos Are Hot
text: THE temperature in Midtown hovered at 101 degrees on an airless day in August. Meanwhile, inside the Jade Igloo, a dome-shaped sauna at Juvenex, a Korean-style spa on West 32nd Street, the thermostat registered 174. The igloo, with its cavelike stone facade, can comfortably accommodate 15, but perhaps because of the mercury reading, on that particular early afternoon, it was hot only for me.

headline: Boeing Plans to Fly Tourists to Space
text: Boeing said Wednesday that it was entering the space tourism business, an announcement that could bolster the Obama administration’s efforts to transform the National Aeronautics and Space Administration into an agency that focuses less on building rockets and more on nurturing a commercial space industry.

headline: Domino’s to Customer: Mea Culpa
text: Domino’s Pizza is known for delivering pizza. Now it’s delivering a pizza executive.

headline: How I Saved My Company: Sea Lake Yacht Sales
text: Two years ago, Vince Morvillo, who owns Sea Lake Yacht Sales, a dealership in Houston, was hit by a  one-two punch. First, Hurricane Ike, a Category 4 storm, struck Texas, doing terrible damage. At a time like that, said Mr. Morvillo, “the thought of buying a yacht is pretty low on the priority list.” And then came the recession.

headline: Remembrances of the Enigmatic Froggy
text: My article about F. Gwynplaine MacIntyre that appeared in last Sunday’s Metropolitan section prompted a flood of e-mail from readers who related their own encounters with Mr. MacIntyre, also known as Froggy.

headline: Shutters Aflutter at New York Fashion Week
text: The move to Lincoln Center seemed as good an occasion as any to discover whether the New York shows were, well, good shows.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Rodarte
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

headline: Finding Missing Music in iTunes
text: Q. I added some songs from a U.S.B. drive to my iTunes library the other day, but when I went to transfer the files to my iPod, iTunes showed an exclamation point next to the song titles and nothing transferred. What’s wrong?

headline: ‘Pattern and Degradation’
text: A large solo exhibition by the artist Rob Pruitt fills 13,000 square feet of space at Gavin Brown’s Enterprise in the West Village and at a neighboring gallery, Maccarone.

headline: XIX, the Hot New Bar in NoLIta
text: CAN’T get in? Well, then, it must be hot. That must explain why XIX, a new subterranean bar in NoLIta, tracked down Disco, the infamous doorman from Bungalow 8, to work its door. It was a bloodbath the other Thursday. Strapping tennis players from the United States Open? Nope. Three guys from Brooklyn? Not a chance. Rejects from the Kenmare up the block? Rejected again.

headline: What We’re Reading: The Economics of Being a Model
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Election Results Bode Well for Change in Albany, Koch Says
text: Edward I. Koch has spent the past several months crisscrossing the state yelling, “Throw the bums out!” and branding state legislators “enemies” and “heroes” of government reform.

headline: Rethinking Investments After a Flight to Security
text: SHAKEN by what seemed to be an earthquake in the world’s financial markets two years ago, millions of retirees fled to safety, shifting their holdings into savings accounts, Treasury bills, money market funds or certificates of deposit. Now they are suffering the aftershocks: with short-term interest rates well below 1 percent, their assets are not producing enough income for daily living expenses.

headline: Thailand's Sin City Reaches for Respectability
text: If Las Vegas is Sin City, Pattaya is a bear hug from Lucifer himself. And yet, amid the back alleys jammed with bars, there are signs of change.

headline: A Giant’s Concussions Begin to Add Up
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants have immediate concerns about how they will compensate for the loss of the versatile tight end Kevin Boss as he recovers from his third concussion since 2008. But the issue could resonate longer than this week.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: In southern Afghanistan, United States Marines took steps to ensure peaceful parliamentary elections on Saturday (Slides 1 and 2), while in Kabul, dozens were injured in anti-American protests widely believed to have been organized by candidates trying to gain political clout.

headline: Shopping With Amy Atlas
text: An event designer shopped for accessories that make the most of desserts.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 15
text: A view of the day in sports, from the waves of Denmark to the outfield walls in Seattle.

headline: Using Orphan Months to Hide Losses
text: From Floyd Norris at Notions on High and Low Finance:

headline: Smoky Cheese Grits with Summer Succotash
text: 1 cup frozen edamame

headline: A Night to Ring Up Some Good Will
text: STYLISH revelers may have flooded the stores and streets of New York on Sept. 10 for the second year of Fashion’s Night Out, but for most shops the evening was more about brand building than racking up sales.

headline: But Can Their Moms Tell Them Apart?
text: THE two young men faced each other aggressively, as if about to fight. They thumped their chests, and grunted. Then their stares turned tender. They drew near, as if to kiss.

headline: On the Colombian Coast, Natural Beauty, Gritty Charm
text: IT’S not called the Parque de Los Novios — Park of the Newlyweds — for nothing. Young couples lock arms as they stroll past rows of freshly planted flowers. A Sinatra love ballad sung in Spanish echoes from a corner dive bar. Aside from a few mustachioed, sombrero-clad men playing a board game, it seemed as if everyone on this breezy August evening was on a romantic sabbatical.

headline: Santa Marta is Ready for Tourists
text: The Colombian city is leaving its gritty past behind.

headline: A Weekend in Rio de Janeiro
text: There will always be sunshine and Carnaval, but these days, Rio has a lot more to strut about.

headline: A New Leader Brings Along Some Old Favorites
text: NEWARK  Music directors typically use their first official concert in the position to make a statement about their interests and programming ideas. When Jacques Lacombe opened the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra’s fall season at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here on Tuesday, this charismatic new conductor revealed his tastes with an affable smorgasbord of popular works and a new piece.

headline: A Hesitancy to Restore Those 401(k) Matches
text: TWICE in the last decade  in 2002-3 and 2008-9  thousands of companies suspended or shrank their 401(k) matching contributions to save money during economic downturns.

headline: The View From the Second Row
text: Some observations from a first-time attendee at New York Fashion Week.

headline: Susan Lehman Is Named Twelve’s New Publisher
text: Susan Lehman, a communications executive, editor and lawyer, has been chosen to replace Jonathan Karp as publisher and editor in chief of Twelve, a tiny, well-regarded imprint of Grand Central Publishing. Her appointment was announced Wednesday.

headline: The Scene: Day Seven
text: Photos from the seventh day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Marc by Marc Jacobs
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Skye Parrott.

headline: Sticking to One Tune, but Not Stuck
text: Winding down his first set at Cornelia Street Café on Tuesday night, Jon Irabagon blew his tenor saxophone in blasts and gales, decelerating the tempo but hardly losing steam. Just under an hour earlier, he had lurched into a lesser-known standard, backed in spartan form by bass and drums. His set consisted solely of that single tune, which he subjected to the jazz equivalent of a brutal interrogation. The performance was trancelike, glowing with intellect, but the main impression it left was of pure physical expenditure.

headline: Boot Camps for the Retired or Soon to Be
text: BY Saturday afternoon, Dorothy Butcher was calling herself Dorothy the Brave.

headline: Is Walking Away from Your Mortgage ‘Acceptable’?
text: While there has been much debate about the ethics of walking away from a burdensome mortgage, the majority of Americans still believe such behavior is unacceptable, according to a  report from Pew Research Center.

headline: For the Fierce of Foot
text: DESIGNED by Raphael Young, the Jaws over-the-thigh-high boots ($1,975)are not for the shy or the diminutive. And it helps to have a partner to take them off. In Paris, where Mr. Young just opened a boutique, women wear these boots with a tunic or denim mini-shorts. Available at Seven New York boutique, 110 Mercer Street (Spring Street); (646) 654-0156. A Web site, raphaelyoung.com, is scheduled to go live on Oct. 1.

headline: iPad Couture, At a Price
text: With New York’s fall Fashion Week in full swing, it’s only natural that the well-dressed, iPad-toting clotheshorses seek out something special to protect their tablets from the touchy-feely hands and fingers of admirers.

headline: Boutique Publisher Names New Chief
text: Susan Lehman, a communications executive, editor and lawyer, has been chosen to replace Jonathan Karp as publisher and editor in chief of Twelve, a tiny, well-regarded imprint of Grand Central Publishing. Her appointment was announced Wednesday.

headline: Jewelry Born of Child’s Play
text: DANNIJO jewelry is run by two sisters, Danielle and Jodie Snyder, who learned how to do wirework by playing with their father’s medical tools in Jacksonville, Fla. The line started in 2008 and is available online at Dannijo.com.

headline: Fences Make Good Neighbors? This One Has Its Doubters
text: In her new documentary for HBO, “The Fence,” Rory Kennedy takes just over a half-hour to demonstrate that the border fence between the United States and Mexico is a political boondoggle that kills migrants but doesn’t keep them out of the country.

headline: Looking Hot When It’s Cold
text: SNOW’S up! Moncler, the Italian brand that makes puffy jackets chic, has a new flagship store in SoHo at 90 Prince Street (at Mercer Street); (646) 350-3620; moncler.com. Thom Browne, who collaborated on the Moncler Gamme Bleu line, translates the Alpine look to the city with a plaid hoodie jacket and a down-filled blazer (from $1,100, up to $9,000 for a beaver jacket).

headline: Baubles and Bags to Customize
text: WENDY NICHOL, whose satchel bags and spiky jewelry are sold at chic stores like Colette, now has a store of her own in SoHo, at 147 Sullivan Street (Houston Street); (212) 431-4171; wendynicholnyc.com. The store has an on-site studio, where clients can customize designs and select pieces of leather.

headline: An Operatic Persona, Cut Down to Size
text: Paulo Szot smolders. With his sultry bedroom eyes, pencil-line mustache and enigmatic half-smile, this Polish-Brazilian baritone is every inch the traditional Latin lover projecting the compressed heat of a boudoir bandit.

headline: ‘Proofiness’
text: “In my opinion the State Department, which is one of the most important government departments, is thoroughly infested with communists.”

headline: A Social Mash-Up During New York Fashion Week
text: The fashion show season seems to have brought back the social scene that was once a standard feature of Manhattan night life.

headline: A Penitent Reflects on the Wilderness
text: Rob Pruitt  who last week opened a gargantuan solo exhibition inspired by the Amish tradition of Rumspringa, the period during which some teenagers sow wild oats before they reach the age to join the church  is not the first artist you might think of when you think Anabaptist. You might go way down the list before getting to Mr. Pruitt, 46, a gleefully tricky purveyor of trash culture who is known for making paintings of pandas and of Paris Hilton, who has fashioned an eternal-flame monument from a bar table and a Bic lighter, and who once held an extremely brief gallery show composed solely of a long floor mirror bisected by a line of real cocaine, which was ingested by visitors.

headline: Leaps and Bounds of At-Home Season
text: A season seldom passes at New York City Ballet without Peter Martins, its ballet master in chief, seizing the chance to drink onstage to the health of someone or other. This has become one of the company’s latter-day gimmicks.

headline: In Reader Comments, a Lens Onto 9/11’s Altered Meaning
text: As City Room live-blogged the 9/11 ceremony held near ground zero for victims’ relatives, the reader comments that poured in were, for the most part, moving and mournful, and tinged with hope. They were long on memories and condolences, and short on politics. Many were shiver-inducing in their poetry and gentle empathy.

headline: High-Tech Wizardry at the Met
text: Images of rehearsals for the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle.

headline: A City Gets Its Groove Back
text: “I’M a rock ’n’ roller,” Nur Khan said recently, nervously spinning a Lazaro Diaz bracelet of black diamonds around his tattooed wrist. “We all know what happened to New York,” the promoter added, citing a well-rehearsed litany: AIDS, night-life crackdowns, bottles-and-models bars, the Crash and, then, the Slump. “Rents went up and pushed out the artists, hedge-fund types came in and creativity died,” Mr. Khan said. “I swear to God,” he added with Scarlett O’Hara fervor, “It’s my mission to bring it back.”

headline: Marchesa: The Red Carpet That Never Ends
text: At 3:30 p.m., the steps of the Chelsea Art Museum were cluttered with black-clad-clipboard-bearing publicists looking down on an obscene crowd of people who wanted to see the spring Marchesa collection.

headline: Sara Bareilles Tops Billboard Chart
text: Sara Bareilles, whose single “Love Song” became a ubiquitous hit two years ago, reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week with her second release, “Kaleidoscope Heart” (Epic). Her new album sold 90,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It was the best week of album sales for Ms. Bareilles, right, to date in her career; her first release, “Little Voice,” peaked at No. 10 and has sold a total of 997,000 copies. But her album sales are still dwarfed by the success of “Love Song,” which has had 3.2 million digital downloads. Eminem’s “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope) is No. 2 with 81,000 sales. With a 12-week total of 2.5 million sales, “Recovery” is gaining fast on Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville) as the best selling album of the year. Also this week, “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 35 fell one spot to No. 3 with 63,000, Katy Perry’s “Teenage Dream” (Capitol) is No. 4 with 59,000, and last week’s chart-topper, Disturbed’s “Asylum” (Reprise), fell to No. 5 with 57,000. Among the contenders for the top spots next week: Linkin Park, Brandon Flowers of the Killers, Robert Plant and Weezer.

headline: 'The Vanilla Ice Project'
text: The opening sequence of a new series on the DIY Network starring Robert Van Winkle, the rapper known as Vanilla Ice.

headline: Gordon-Levitt Announces Plans for New Show
text: After “Inception,” we’ve come to expect a certain degree of inscrutability from all of Joseph Gordon-Levitt’s projects. But his latest venture may take the totemic cake. On Oct. 28 Mr. Gordon-Levitt, the “(500) Days of Summer” star who has been lately turning up at downtown Manhattan clubs to sing Lady Gaga covers, will bring the festivities to Town Hall in Midtown, where he and other artists will perform at “Joseph Gordon-Levitt and the hitRECord.org Fall Formal.” The event grew out of hitRECord.org, the Web site and production company where Mr. Gordon-Levitt invites Internet users to work with him on video and art ventures. Money raised by the show will finance more projects. The show will present some of his collective’s short films accompanied by live narration and music, as well as traditional stage acts. Mr. Gordon-Levitt, above, said the show would “absolutely” feature performers from other film projects with which he is closely associated. “We’re not telling any secrets yet,” he said. “We’ll be dropping those little news cupcakes between now and Oct. 28.”

headline: Unfinished Wallace Novel Gets Cover and Release Date
text: Little, Brown & Company revealed the jacket art for “The Pale King,” an unfinished novel by David Foster Wallace that it will publish next year. In a news release the publisher said that the novel, with a cover designed by Mr. Wallace’s widow, Karen Green, is set in “an I.R.S. tax-return-processing center in Illinois in the mid-1980s,” and tells the story of “a crew of entry-level processors and their attempts to do their job in the face of soul-crushing tedium.” Michael Pietsch, the publisher of Little, Brown and the novel’s editor, said in a statement that the book “takes agonizing daily events like standing in lines, traffic jams, and horrific bus rides  things we all hate  and turns them into moments of laughter and understanding.” The statement went on to say, “Although David did not finish the novel, it is a surprisingly whole and satisfying reading experience that showcases his extraordinary imaginative talents and his mixing of comedy and deep sadness in scenes from daily life.” Little, Brown plans to release “The Pale King” on  when else?  April 15.

headline: Record Set On ‘Jeopardy!’
text: By correctly naming “The Bridge on the River Kwai” as the title of the David Lean film based on the similarly titled Pierre Boulle novel, Roger Craig, a 33-year-old graduate student, set a new one-day earnings record on “Jeopardy!,” winning $77,000 at the end of Tuesday’s broadcast. Mr. Craig went into the Final Jeopardy round with $47,000 and wagered $30,000 in the category of Literary and Movie Title Objects. (The clue for which Mr. Craig provided the correct question was, “The inspiration for this title object in a novel and a 1957 movie actually spanned the Mae Khlung River.”) Mr. Craig and toppled the previous one-day winnings record of $75,000 set by Ken Jennings, who won the game show 74 times in 2004.

headline: Steve Martin Creates Bluegrass Prize
text: Hey, kids: Steve Martin wants to give you $50,000! There’s just one catch: You’re going to have to be really good at bluegrass music. Mr. Martin, the actor, comedian and polymath, has established the Steve Martin Prize for Excellence in Banjo and Bluegrass. The award, which he described on Wednesday as “a mini-MacArthur” grant, will give $50,000 annually to “an individual or group for outstanding accomplishment in the field of five-string banjo or bluegrass music.” The award is intended to help performers pay for their instruments and raise awareness about the music. “Sometimes when you mention money,” Mr. Martin said, “you automatically catch people’s ear.” The award, which is determined by a board that includes Mr. Martin and musicians including Earl Scruggs, Pete Wernick, Tony Trischka and Béla Fleck, will be given in its inaugural year to Noam Pikelny, the banjo player for the band Punch Brothers.

headline: ‘West Side Story’ to Close Jan. 2
text: The producers of the Broadway revival of “West Side Story” said on Wednesday that the production would close at the Palace Theater on Sunday, Jan. 2, 2011, after 27 previews and 748 regular performances.

headline: Redford’s Film Is Picked Up
text: “The Conspirator,” Robert Redford’s independently produced picture about the hanging of Mary Surratt after Abraham Lincoln’s assassination, has a home. Lionsgate and Roadside Attractions said they acquired rights to distribute the film in the United States. They plan to release it next spring. Mr. Redford, right, was among dozens of filmmakers who showed their films at the Toronto International Film Festival, which continues through Sunday. “The Conspirator,” which was financed by the American Film Company and had its debut with a gala presentation in Toronto, was among the higher-profile films to be acquired at the festival, as the deal-making picked up steam. Separately, the Weinstein Company said that it had acquired “Submarine,” a coming-of-age comedy from the first-time director Richard Ayoade.

headline: Pakistanis Ask What a Lynching Means
text: The family of two teenage brothers who were beaten to death last month in Pakistan, after they were mistaken for criminals by an enraged mob, asked that a court-ordered post-mortem be delayed until a new medical expert can be appointed to the case, the Pakistani newspaper Dawn reported.

headline: ‘Talent’ Stays Strong as Season Starts
text: “America’s Got Talent” and the second season debut of “Parenthood” lifted NBC to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 14.3 million viewers tuned in to that talent competition at 9 p.m., more than any other program during the night. At 10, NBC’s “Parenthood” remained in the lead, earning a solid 7.7 million viewers and outperforming CBS’s “Fashion’s Night Out” (3 million) and the ABC News special “Final Witness” (4.8 million). CBS placed second overall with repeats of “NCIS” (10.5 million) and “NCIS: Los Angeles” (8.2 million), while ABC broadcast back-to-back episodes of “Wipeout” (6.8 million). Fox was fourth with repeats of “Glee” (4.6 million), while CW, in fifth place, drew the network’s most Tuesday-night viewers in a year, garnering 2.2 million for the eighth-season premiere of “One Tree Hill” and 1.7 million for “Life Unexpected.”

headline: Detoured by 9/11 Attack, 4,000-Year-Old Tablets Make It Back to Iraq
text: WASHINGTON  The unlikely journey of 362 cuneiform clay tablets and plaques began in ancient Iraq as far back as 2030 B.C. But they would pass through modern Dubai and Newark, survive a government seizure and the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, before finally winding up back at their birthplace, fittingly, almost nine years to the day after 9/11.

headline: Job Tenures Lengthen as Newcomers Get Laid Off
text: While stories about loyal, long-term employees getting laid off may be omnipresent and heart-wrenching, the people disproportionately getting the axe appear to be workers with less seniority.

headline: Scorecard | Rodarte Wins!
text: Tailoring at Rodarte? Has hell frozen over, Scorecard wonders? As New York Fashion Week nears its end, even Cathy Horyn applauded the Mulleavy sisters’ trading in their ripped and shredded collagist essays on slasher flicks, condors and sleepwalking migrant laborers for a bit of California dreamin’. Meanwhile, Vera Wang descended into the darkness from whence they came.

headline: Leaving the Land of a Thousand Hills
text: Our two-week baseline assessment in Rwanda came to an end, and it was time for me to leave “the land of a thousand hills” and head back to New York. I have much data to sift through — my team interviewed 48 households, and collectively we surveyed 378 households in the three sectors. I leave the field with many research-type questions — more than when I entered. For example, how do we actually measure this complex activity known as water access in subsistence communities? I am also left wondering about the relationship between social inequality and environmental disparity, and the social impact that technological changes might bring about in these subsistence communities.

headline: At Columbia, Midday Barber in Strings and Song
text: The fourth season of Columbia University’s Lunchtime Concerts opened on Monday with the gifted Voxare String Quartet playing Barber’s String Quartet. Just that. The idea behind this series could not be more simple or more inspired.

headline: One Man’s Wrathful Vengeance
text: “When we were deep into the orchard, I threw McClennan on his back, ripped his trousers and shorts off, slit them with the knife,” the man before us says without a flicker of emotion.

headline: My Favorite Flight Companion
text: I travel way too much. I give speeches, shoot TV segments that involve multiple interviews around the country and attend trade shows.

headline: Nicole Kidman, Aaron Eckhart and ‘Rabbit Hole’
text: TORONTO — Nicole Kidman returns to Toronto, this time in the role of both actor and producer for her latest project, “Rabbit Hole.” The film, in which she co-stars with Aaron Eckhart, looks at a suburban married couple who experience a tremendous loss.

headline: F.A.A. Offers Guidelines to Fight Pilot Fatigue
text: The Federal Aviation Administration has recently proposed rules to help combat fatigue among commercial pilots of passenger aircraft.

headline: Survey Finds Broad Interest in Koran Story
text: The media coverage of the fringe pastor who planned (and later canceled) a Koran burning on the ninth anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks was followed by roughly half the country last week.

headline: Reed Krakoff Wraps It Up
text: So far, the spring collections have mostly fallen into three camps. There are designers who are pushing a 1970s look (Diane Von Furstenberg, Marc Jacobs), a California summer vibe (Derek Lam, Rodarte, Michael Kors) and an East-meets-West theme (Vera Wang, Carolina Herrera).

headline: A Little Bit Dylan, a Little Bit Lots of Other Stuff
text: Imagine the inside of Bob Dylan’s brain. Crowded in there, isn’t?

headline: Europe and the United States Battle on Six Fronts in Wales
text: The third Buffett Cup was scheduled to end on Thursday at the Miskin Manor Hotel in Cardiff, Wales. In an event fashioned after golf’s Ryder Cup, Europe and the United States each fielded 12 players, who competed in their regular partnerships during the pair and team segments, then played 11 six-board matches, one with each teammate.

headline: Poll Suggests Opportunities for Both Parties
text: Republicans are heading into the general election phase of the midterm campaign backed by two powerful currents: the highest proportion of voters in two decades say it is time for their own member of Congress to be replaced, and Americans are expressing widespread dissatisfaction with President Obama’s leadership.

headline: Looking Ahead to the Spend-Down Years
text: IMAGINE you’re 30 and trying to figure out how much to save for retirement. You consult a Web site that can show you what you will most likely look like at 65  and that shows the more you save now, the happier you will look then.

headline: Vanilla Ice on His New Reality TV Series
text: Robert Van Winkle, the rapper most people know as Vanilla Ice, rose to fame in the early 1990s with the hit single “Ice Ice Baby.” In recent years, however, Mr. Van Winkle has been developing a different area of expertise — renovating and selling homes. On Oct. 14 at 9 p.m. E.S.T., the DIY Network will show the first episode of “The Vanilla Ice Project,” Mr. Van Winkle’s new reality series. The show, which documents his skills as a handyman, follows him and a team of workers as they renovate a 7,000-square-foot, six-bedroom house in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Conservative Group Hits 2 Senate Contenders
text: A conservative group that has vowed to play a big role in this year’s midterm elections went on the attack Wednesday with television advertisements that knock two Democratic Senate candidates for supporting the economic stimulus package and the health care overhaul.

headline: Witnesses Tell of Finding Victims in Conn. Killing
text: NEW HAVEN  At the end of a second-floor hallway still hot from the flames that had engulfed the house, a lieutenant from the Police Department in Cheshire, Conn., could see that there was someone on a bed.

headline: Staying on Balance, With the Help of Exercises
text: STONE-FACED with determination, Margot Luftig was trying hard not to fall.

headline: A New Location That’s All in How You Use It
text: FASHION editors are not as spoiled as their perilously high shoes might indicate. On the contrary: When it comes to seeing exciting new fashion, they will trek anywhere and savor, along with the bragging rights, the experience of seeing a great talent. I have sat on floors and on a washing machine in a Salvation Army branch, and waited in abandoned buildings. Was it worth it? You bet.

headline: A Device Sold Before Its Time
text: What if you were offered magical powers  but at a price?

headline: Obama Attacks G.O.P. on Tax Rates
text: From the White House to Capitol Hill, the war of words continued on Wednesday between President Obama and Congressional Republicans over whether to extend the Bush-era tax rates for the wealthy.

headline: Revis Says Randy Moss Is Still a ‘Slouch’
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. – Jets cornerback Darrelle Revis no longer wants to talk about his holdout.

headline: A Professor’s Review of Online Cheat Sheets
text: At this time of year, students are buying textbooks and looking for ways to avoid reading them.

headline: Furniture Takes a Manly Turn
text: JOOST VAN BLEISWIJK, a 34-year-old Dutch designer, makes domestic objects like clocks and candlesticks, chessboards and china cabinets out of Cor-Ten (otherwise known as “weathering”) steel that he sets outside his Eindhoven studio for a month or so, until it accrues a nice coat of rust.

headline: A Lamp Fashioned From Pennsylvania Slate
text: Richard Miller, a sculptor in eastern Pennsylvania, has been making home furnishings for two decades, ever since he fashioned a vase out of a glacial boulder as a present for a friend, and got hooked. Since then he has made tables, frames, mirrors, lamps — anything that allows him the pleasure of “working with physical materials,” he said.

headline: Hot-Water Dispensers for the Well-Appointed Kitchen
text: In the well-appointed kitchen, the hot-water dispenser has traditionally played the role of the quiet, capable student who sits at the back of the class — reliable but unassuming. Dornbracht, the kitchen and bath fixtures company, is changing that, with two new models for its Tara Ultra and LOT lines.

headline: A Show House Pairs Fashion and Interior Designers
text: On the heels of Fashion Week, American Fashion: Designers at the Aldyn, a show house that pairs fashion and interior designers, opens on Tuesday.

headline: Letters: Stand and Deliver
text: As a New York City public-school teacher, I found David Leonhardt’s discussion of the role of value-added analysis in teacher accountability to be evenhanded and refreshing. A system that measures students’ educational gains based solely on numbers ignores certain uncomfortable realities: faster learners, who already get high scores on tests, may also be capable of greater incremental gains than their slower peers — and in classes groupedby ability level, teachers working with struggling students are unfairly penalized.

headline: Serving Pieces for Dessert
text: MOST people give plenty of thought to presentation when they host a dinner party, but the final course — dessert — is often overlooked, at least according to Amy Atlas.

headline: A Modern Patchwork in San Francisco
text: San Francisco

headline: Keeping Mr. Emerson’s House
text: Concord, Mass.

headline: Design Within Reach Introduces an Accessories Collection
text: Design Within Reach, the modern furnishings retailer, is introducing a collection of accessories to complement its wide range of tables, chairs and sofas — “beautiful objects that can help round out the complete experience,” said Kari Woldum, the company’s vice president for merchandising.

headline: Letters: There Are So Many Iterations of William Shatner
text: As someone who has followed William Shatner’s career, on and off the stage, since the days when “Star Trek” first aired, I am delighted that Pat Jordan captured the essence of Mr. Shatner’s life, namely, that he is the epitome of a “working” actor and a brave soul who is not afraid to be seen as a failure in order to pay the bills. In an often nefarious business such as acting, someone who, as Jordan writes, “showed up on time, knew his lines, worked cheap and always answered his phone” should be revered, especially when he consciously took demeaning jobs (ridiculous game shows or poorly written serial dramas) because he knew he had to put food on the table for his family. What’s admirable is that despite this, he says he has no regrets. On the contrary, he has embraced everything that has made him the icon that he is.

headline: Letter: ‘Man Up’
text: I was happy to see the Man Up Campaign included in Ben Zimmer’s On Language column, exploring what it means to “man up.” Feminist deconstruction aside, manning up, other than describing traditional masculine traits and behaviors, also means taking responsibility for one’s actions. In a world in which 95 percent of physical and sexual violence against women is done by men, it is men’s responsibility to acknowledge that gender violence is their problem and seek ways to challenge themselves and fellow men to eradicate it.

headline: Letter: The Peanut Solution
text: Despite the challenges discussed in Andrew Rice’s article, ready-to-use therapeutic foods remain an important tool for those working to address undernutrition. It is unacceptable that an estimated 35 percent of child mortality is driven by undernutrition. The nutrition community, including the United Nations and Helen Keller International, has created a comprehensive framework to overcome hunger and malnutrition with an emphasis on prevention and treatment. Preventing malnutrition is the vastly preferred solution and is possible through strategies that include improving household feeding practices, increasing access to healthy affordable foods and strengthening health and sanitation services.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: From the Ottoman Empire to wartime Poland, rural Georgia to rural Indiana, the contemporary novel thinks big this month. And the literary world is big enough to make room for new work from the head of a prestigious writing program and one of its recent graduates.

headline: Sales at Lee’s Studio and B & B Italia
text: Floor samples and overstocked items will be marked down as much as 70 percent at the Lee’s Studio fall warehouse sale, on Sept. 18, 19, 25 and 26, and Oct. 2 and 3 (the Elite Leather Crystal Cove sectional sofa, originally $5,000, will be $2,500; the Holtkotter No. 6505 floor lamp, originally about $350, will be $150); 3200 Liberty Avenue, unit 1A, North Bergen, N.J., (212) 581-4400 or leesstudio.com.

headline: Some 401(k) Plans Are Adding an Annuity Option
text: BURDENED with a reputation for being inflexible and expensive, annuities have never been popular in retirement plans. But insurance companies and Wall Street investment firms have produced a new crop of products that fiddle with the standard structure.

headline: Pump Up a 401(k) by Lowering the Fees
text: LOWER your 401(k) costs and you can increase your return. For retirement investors, there is no simpler mantra.

headline: Life in the Ralph Waldo Emerson House
text: Inside the historic house in Concord, Mass., which the property’s new caretakers, a young couple, call home.

headline: Forest, Maker of Celexa, to Pay More Than $313 Million to Settle Marketing Case
text: A unit of Forest Laboratories, the maker of the antidepressant Celexa, agreed on Wednesday to pay more than $313 million to settle criminal and civil complaints, including a claim that it had illegally promoted the drug for use in children.

headline: Concerns Rise About Continuing-Care Enclaves
text: FOR middle- and upper-income retirees who had the money, it was almost a no-brainer in recent years to choose living in a continuing-care retirement community. They could move, as the need arose, from independent living to assisted care to skilled nursing care — all without leaving the community.

headline: An Experiment in Design in San Francisco
text: A house in the Mission district contains both living and work space for a couple’s eco-focused design practice and their young children.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: S.E.C. Defends Exemptions in New Law
text: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission is fighting attempts by some lawmakers to repeal a provision in a new law that gives the commission greater ability to block public disclosure of material it gathers from financial and investment firms.

headline: Devising Strategies While the Estate Tax Is in Limbo
text: THE federal estate tax is scheduled to rise from the ashes on Jan. 1, and a lot more families may feel its bite unless Congress changes current law.

headline: The Tough Guys
text: Rough-looking furniture that carries a whiff of shop class, handmade by guys who have their own power saws, is design’s new tack.

headline: U.S. Debates Response to Targeted Killing Lawsuit
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, fresh off a victory in persuading federal judges to dismiss a torture case for fear of revealing state secrets, is divided over using similar tactics to try to block a lawsuit over government efforts to kill an American citizen accused of ties to Al Qaeda.

headline: Microsoft’s New Browser Is Pretty Cool. No, Seriously.
text: On Wednesday, Microsoft officially released a beta version of Internet Explorer 9, the latest remake of the company’s nearly-ubiquitous Web browser. A few months from now, it will become the built-in browser on all new PCs.

headline: Paladino on a Rival, City Traffic and More
text: BUFFALO  Carl P. Paladino, the Republican nominee for governor, spoke on Wednesday about a range of issues as he points toward the election against Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic nominee. Following are excerpts from the interview.

headline: Surreal in the Moment, a Highlight Throw Will Be Hard to Forget
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Of course Greg Golson saw the replays. How could he not? His television was tuned to ESPN on Wednesday morning as he responded to text messages and answered phone calls, telling everyone about the most surreal moment of his career.

headline: A New Power Broker Rises in Italy
text: VENICE  The Northern League gathered here this past weekend under a blazing sun to celebrate a peculiar late summer ritual. Stalwarts, dressed in emerald green and some wearing T-shirts with anti-immigrant slogans (“+Rum, -Rom,” or Gypsies), poured a vial of water drawn from northern Italy’s Po River into the Venetian lagoon.

headline: 9,000 Paths to the Perfect Sound
text: A long, tuneful trip led Joe Castellon to the Kaufman Astoria Studios, in Queens, where he is executive creative director for the music and sound division. Born to immigrants from Spain and brought up in Gravesend, Brooklyn, he was taught by a family friend to play drums when he was 4, learned to read music at 5 in a summer school program, and quit college at 20 to go on the road with the “ghost version” of the Jimmy Dorsey Orchestra after Mr. Dorsey’s death. Mr. Castellon, 61, lives in Bronxville, N.Y.

headline: N.H.L. Alters Rule on Tie Breakers
text: The N.H.L. took a small step away from the importance of shootouts by changing a rule governing tie breakers in the standings. The board of governors approved a rule revision that would use a team’s total number of victories in regulation and overtime  but exclude shootout wins  to break ties among teams with the same number of points at the conclusion of a season. Teams will continue to get 2 points in the standings for shootout victories.

headline: Crime Blotter Has a Regular: Yankees Caps
text: Two men and a woman broke into a locker at a Manhattan gym in February and stole credit cards, the first in a series of similar thefts.

headline: Somali Town Embodies Enduring Sense of Loss
text: WISIL, Somalia  The wind howls here, lifting off the desert, roaring into town, gathering force as it squeezes between the metal shacks along Wisil’s main drag and blasts into people’s faces.

headline: Long as a California Summer
text: Hot pants are not likely to be chased into the woodwork, fans and onlookers will be happy to hear, but they will have to yield next summer to the long, plain skirt.

headline: Aid to Fight Qaeda in Yemen Divides U.S. Officials
text: WASHINGTON  Senior State Department and American military officials are deeply divided over the pace and scale of military aid to Yemen, which is emerging as a crucial testing ground for the Obama administration’s approach to countering the threat from Al Qaeda.

text: WASHINGTON  Elizabeth Warren, who conceived of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, will oversee its establishment as an assistant to President Obama, an official briefed on the decision said Wednesday evening.

text: Because of the nature of Johan Santana’s shoulder injury and the operation to repair it, the Mets cannot expect him to return to his normal pitching capabilities until late next season at best, and more likely not until 2012, according to an expert on shoulder injuries.

text: Daniel M. Donovan Jr. was born and raised on Staten Island, worked his way through law school at Fordham University and has spent most of his professional life as a local prosecutor.

headline: As Europe Kicks Coal, Hungarian Town Suffers
text: OROSZLANY, Hungary — When the directors of Hungary’s last remaining coal-fired power plant announced that they would close the coal mine and begin dismantling the plant at the end of this year, the news sent shock waves through this weathered industrial city, where a statue of three miners stands in the square.

headline: Election Assured, Victor Over Espada Will Face a Tough Job in Albany
text: A wiry man wearing a Yankees cap and a gold chain did a double-take as he walked up Fordham Road on Wednesday. “Gustavo Rivera!” he shouted. “Congratulations, man!”

headline: Women Sue Goldman, Claiming Pay and Jobs Bias
text: Three women formerly employed by Goldman Sachs sued the investment bank on Wednesday, contending that the firm systematically discriminates against its women employees.

headline: Primary Day 2010: A Little Less Sleaze
text: We found some good news in the primary results in our home state of New York, despite being appalled by the Republicans’ nomination of Carl Paladino for governor and sorely disappointed that Democrats renominated far too many incumbents to the state’s corrupt and incompetent Legislature.

headline: Heisman Trophy Left Vacant for 2005 After Bush’s Forfeit
text: In the wake of Reggie Bush’s decision to relinquish his 2005 Heisman Trophy, the trustees of the Heisman Trophy Trust announced Wednesday that there would be no 2005 recipient of the award. There had been a Heisman Trophy winner every year since 1935.

headline: Boxing Lessons
text: I offer training in both philosophy and boxing. Over the years, some of my colleagues have groused that my work is a contradiction, building minds and cultivating rational discourse while teaching violence and helping to remove brain cells. Truth be told, I think philosophers with this gripe should give some thought to what really counts as violence.  I would rather take a punch in the nose any day than be subjected to some of the attacks that I have witnessed in philosophy colloquia.  However, I have a more positive case for including boxing in my curriculum for sentimental education.

headline: Primary Day 2010: The Machine and the Machines
text: Voting in New York City was an ordeal, pure and simple, but don’t blame the new optical scanner machines. Put the blame where it belongs: on the city’s patronage-encrusted Board of Elections.

headline: City Wants a Smoking Ban on Beaches
text: Beware all you New Yorkers and tourists who have yet to kick the habit.

headline: Floodwaters Give New Life to Pakistani Class Dispute
text: THATTA, Pakistan  Despite being flooded out of their homes and forced to camp on embankments, there is one community that is happy about Pakistan’s worst floods in living memory. They are the fishermen of the Indus River delta, whose livelihoods have diminished over the years from a lack of water, and who welcome the sudden abundance.

headline: Online Woes Plague Chase for 2nd Day
text: Computer problems prevented millions of Chase customers from gaining access to their accounts over the bank’s Web site for a second day on Wednesday. Even after access was restored, complaints persisted as the rush of customers logging on to the site bogged down the company’s computers, making service spotty.

headline: How Pensions Can Get Out of the Red
text: THIS summer’s revelation that New Jersey had misled the public about the health of its state pension funds is only the latest incident in a looming nationwide crisis.

headline: The Vatican: Cardinal Cancels Trip
text: A cardinal long involved in the Vatican’s relations with the Anglican Church will not travel with Pope Benedict XVI on his trip to Britain on Thursday, the Vatican said Wednesday. Cardinal Walter Kasper, who retired last summer as the head of the Pontifical Council for Promoting Christian Unity, caused a stir this week when he told the German magazine Focus that landing at Heathrow Airport was like landing “in a third world country.” He also criticized the “aggressive atheism” of Britain. The Vatican spokesman, the Rev. Federico Lombardi, said that Cardinal Kasper had withdrawn from the trip for health reasons. “The interview had nothing to do with it,” he said.

headline: Nigeria: President to Run for Office
text: President Goodluck Jonathan used Facebook on Wednesday to announce his intention to run in the January election for the job he now holds. Mr. Jonathan, who had been vice president, took over after President Umaru Yar’Adua died in May. For months, Mr. Jonathan, a southerner, had been undecided in the face of strong northern pressure not to run in the regionally divided nation. His announcement on Wednesday stole attention from a rally by a leading competitor in his own party, the former military dictator Ibrahim Babangida. “I make no pretense that I have a magic wand that will solve all Nigeria’s problems,” Mr. Jonathan said in his message, but promised to tell Nigerians the truth “at all times.”

headline: Settled in the City, but Still in a Hurry
text: Jeff Gordon is going to the playoffs. Of course, in Nascar, nearly everybody goes to the playoffs, even if they are not eligible for the championship.
