headline: Competitor Sues Google Over Location Software for Smartphones
text: Skyhook Wireless, which makes software that shows smartphone users where they are on their phone’s maps, filed a lawsuit Wednesday claiming Google had persuaded Motorola and another phone manufacturer to break contracts with Skyhook and use Google’s competing service.

headline: Rethinking the Process for BP Spill Claims
text: HOUMA, La.  Two months ago, Kenneth R. Feinberg barnstormed the gulf states and visited towns like this one to pledge that once he took over a $20 billion BP fund to compensate people affected by the oil spill, things would change. Individuals would see their claims for damages turned around in 48 hours, he said. Businesses? Seven days.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Bicycle for Abel
text: The Op-Ed Columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on how the gift of bicycles from a Chicago-based non-profit has helped change the lives of Zimbabwean students.

headline: A Boy and a Bicycle(s)
text: Early this year I wrote a column from Zimbabwe that focused on five orphans who moved in together and survive alone in a hut.

headline: Before Vote, City Officials Fretted About New System
text: Six days before the primary on Tuesday, state election officials received a request from the city’s Board of Elections: Could it cut short tests on some of its voting machines because of worries that the testing would not be finished before voters went to the polls?

headline: Shareholder Vote Pressures Airgas
text: Airgas shareholders have decided where the hot air was coming from. At the company’s annual meeting on Wednesday, they voted for three directors nominated by Air Products and Chemicals, the company’s rejected suitor, and ousted the Airgas chief executive from the board. In doing so, they rebuffed the incumbents’ claims that Airgas is worth more as an independent company. Air Products may now be able to remain firmer on its $5.5 billion hostile bid.

headline: Paladino, Cuomo Rival, Set to Spend at Will
text: He is explosive, he does not play by the usual rules, and his throw-the-bums-out message has clearly connected with voters. He is also rich, and threatens to drive his populist crusade with millions of dollars in advertisements.

headline: Rebel Republican Marching On, With Baggage
text: DOVER, Del. — In the bright light of Wednesday morning, Christine O’Donnell, whose Republican primary victory upended the calculus for future control of the United State Senate, became quickly known to Americans as the woman who once made dire warnings about the negative impact of masturbation.

headline: Charges of Getting Cash to Failed Times Sq. Bomber
text: A Long Island man has been charged with providing thousands of dollars in cash that was used to support the failed plot to bomb Times Square in May, according to an indictment unsealed on Wednesday.

headline: Thursday: 20th-Century Master
text: BROWN CROSSWORD WEEK continues.

headline: Top Pitching Prospect for Mets Is Injured
text: Mets pitcher Jenrry Mejia will have a magnetic resonance imaging test Thursday to determine the severity of his latest shoulder injury, but no one could mistake the discomfort he showed Wednesday night when he left the mound in the third inning of the Mets’ 8-7 victory over Pittsburgh at Citi Field.

headline: Limbaugh Taken In: The Judge Was Not Loaded for Bear
text: PENSACOLA, Fla.  Anyone listening to Rush Limbaugh’s radio show Tuesday could be forgiven for thinking that Judge Roger Vinson has the federal government dead in his sights.

headline: Show Us Your City
text: As travelers, we know that the best suggestions often come from locals. So we’re asking you to give us the local point of view. What’s amazing about your city, town or neighborhood? When friends visit, where do you take them? What three spots should be on the “must see” list for every traveler?

headline: Harlem Monsignor Accused of Abusing Students Resigns
text: A prominent Harlem priest who helped arrange the New York visit of Pope Benedict XVI in 2008 has resigned, two years after he was suspended on charges of sexually abusing high school students he taught in the 1980s.

headline: Japan’s Move on Yen Lacks Global Support
text: TOKYO  Japan’s decision to intervene in currency markets to weaken the yen and shore up its export-driven economy could be only the first step in a long battle  one made more difficult because Japan, unable to find support among its trading partners, must go it alone.

headline: As His Second Season Unfolds, Jets’ Sanchez Has Far to Go
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  One game into his second season, Mark Sanchez has not inspired confidence. His coach, Rex Ryan, said Sanchez played stiffly and conservatively in the Jets’ 10-9 lossto the Baltimore Ravens on Monday night. The greatest quarterback in Jets history, Joe Namath, criticized Sanchez and the offense on his Twitter feed.

headline: For Teams, Memo Offers Reminder on Conduct
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The N.F.L. on Tuesday sent a memo to the public-relations directors of each of its teams reiterating its equal access and conduct policies toward the news media after a female television reporter was reportedly the object of catcalls at a Jets practice last weekend.

headline: Lawyer Tries to Discredit Informer in Synagogue Bomb-Plot Case
text: Before he became a government informer, Shahed Hussain seemed to have achieved a measure of the American dream. After fleeing Pakistan in 1994 for political reasons, he worked 16-hour days as a gas station attendant until he could buy his own gas stations, expensive cars and a house for his family, according to court testimony.

headline: A Golden Gate Fantasy on the Kansas Prairie
text: MULVANE, Kan.  There is no obvious reason Larry Richardson would want to cross Cowskin Creek, a muddy rivulet that winds through the croplands here, much less why he would want to cross it with a self-designed replica of San Francisco’s Golden Gate Bridge.

headline: Proenza Schouler: A New Twist on Tie Dye
text: “Aren’t you tired of short?” Jack McCollough said, cocking his head in surprise.

headline: New Hampshire Narrowly Bucks an Anti-Establishment Trend
text: CONCORD, N.H.  Kelly Ayotte, the Republican who had her party’s backing in New Hampshire’s crowded Senate primary, was declared the winner on Wednesday after a protracted vote count made for an anxious morning.

headline: An -Ose Is an -Ose
text: The Corn Refiners Association has petitioned the Food and Drug Administration to change the name of high-fructose corn syrup to “corn sugar.” The association says that the phrase “high fructose” is misleading. It became part of the name to distinguish the ubiquitous corn syrup from another kind that contains less of the natural sugar called fructose.

headline: Ex-Dean Accused of Stealing $1 Million From St. John’s
text: Among the many jobs performed by college administrators, Cecilia Chang’s was at once challenging and glamorous. As dean of the Institute of Asian Studies at St. John’s University in Queens, she traveled the world soliciting donations, luring potential contributors with sumptuous meals, entertainment and gifts, all of it paid for by the college. Her expenses sometimes reached $50,000 a month.

headline: A Bit Player Is a Scene Stealer After an Acting Job by Jeter
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  It would have been too nice and neat, not to mention controversial, had the central figure in Wednesday night’s game remained Derek Jeter.

headline: Primary Day 2010: The Tea Party’s Snarl
text: Democratic operatives are ablaze with excitement over the victory of two particularly dubious Tea Party candidates in Tuesday’s Republican primaries, envisioning smoother paths to victory in the races for governor in New York and United States senator in Delaware. But for voters of all stripes, Tuesday’s primaries should illuminate the growling face of a new fringe in American politics  and provide the incentive for level-headed voters to become enthusiastic about the midterm election.

headline: Bloggingheads: Hooray for Lobbyists!
text: Reihan Salam, left, of National Review and Timothy Carney of The Washington Examiner debate the benefits of lobbyists.

headline: Republicans Get a Partner, but Who Will Lead?
text: If ever there was proof that the Tea Party and the Republican Party do not necessarily go hand in hand, it is Christine O’Donnell’s victory over the establishment in the Republican Senate primary in Delaware.

headline: Bank Surveillance Tape
text: Jennifer Hawke-Petit, a victim in the triple-murder case in 2007 in Cheshire, Conn., is seen at a Bank of America, where she withdrew $15,000 and said that men were holding her family hostage.

headline: A Bit More on Abel and his Bike
text: The saga of getting a bike to Abel was actually more complicated than I had space to describe in my Thursday column about him, and there are rather more players.

headline: A Japanese Form of Fly Fishing Gains Fans in the U.S.
text: CROOKED CREEK, Ark. — Misako Ishimura waded knee deep into the current, the water temperature perfect for both swimming and soothing relief from the afternoon sun. But Ishimura, 58, had other things in mind as she swept back her rod and flicked the line upstream in a controlled, gentle cast. The soft-hackle fly dropped into the surface film and drifted near a rock undercut.

headline: Season-Ending Tie Breakers Will Skip Shootout Results
text: The N.H.L. has taken a step away from the importance of shootouts by changing a rule that governs tie breakers in the standings.

headline: BP Well May Be Sealed Soon
text: With BP close to intercepting its stricken Gulf of Mexico well with a relief well, the government said Wednesday that the final sealing of the once-gushing well might occur this weekend.

headline: Strategies Take Shape for Trials in Bully Case
text: NORTHAMPTON, Mass. — The criminal charges filed in the spring against six high school students for bullying 15-year-old Phoebe Prince in the months and hours before her suicide are edging toward a test in court.

headline: J. J. Hill Dead In St. Paul Home At The Age of 77
text: ST. PAUL, May 29--James J. Hill, builder of the "Northwest Empire," died at 9:30 A.M. today at his house, 240 Summit Avenue.

headline:
Ford Offers Amnesty Program Requiring 2 Years Public Work; Defends His Pardon Of
Nixon
text: Washington, Sept. 16--President Ford offered conditional amnesty today to thousands of Vietnam era draft evaders and military deserters who agree to work for up to two years in public service jobs.

headline: 3 Teams Win Automotive X Prize
text: Teams from Virginia, North Carolina and Winterthur, Switzerland, with roots in the world of auto racing have won the first Progressive Insurance Automotive X Prize, the $10 million competition aimed at advancing the technology for more fuel-efficient vehicles.

headline: In One Class, a Close Competition
text: While competitors in the Mainstream class and the Tandem division of the Alternative class of the X Prize were eventually reduced to just one team each, the fight in the Side-by-Side division of the Alternative class was fierce. The winner eventually had to be determined in a tie-breaker held at the Michigan International Speedway on July 27. The Li-Ion Motors Wave II won the $2.5 million prize with a 0.179-second victory. Here were the division’s finalists:

headline: X Prize Winners Announced
text: Three companies are the winners for the first Progressive Insurance Automotive X Prize, a competition to create 100-mile-a-gallon vehicles.

text: dismember •\(ˌ)dis-ˈmem-bər\• verb

headline: Swimming Upstream, the White Sox are Sinking
text: CHICAGO – You can always count on Ozzie Guillen to say exactly what he thinks. A reporter started Guillen’s postgame news conference Wednesday by asking, “Are things looking as bleak as they seem?” Guillen did not hold back.

headline: Some X Prize Entrants and Why They Lost
text: The winners of the Progressive Insurance Automotive X Prize, the three-year competition to produce 100-mile-per-gallon vehicles, will be announced later this morning in Washington. Although there are only three winners, 24 vehicles were fielded from countries that included Canada, Italy and Switzerland. Their cars resembled lobsters, Lyle Lovett’s hair and ordinary Fords. For many reasons, they lost. Here’s how the teams explained it:

headline: Grizzlies’ Contract Standoffs Near End
text: The Memphis Grizzlies moved to end a months-long standoff with their two first-round picks late Wednesday night, heading off a possible holdout by the No. 12 overall selection Xavier Henry.

headline: Khmer Rouge Leaders Indicted
text: BANGKOK  A United Nations-backed court in Cambodia formally indicted four surviving leaders of the Khmer Rouge on Thursday on charges of genocide, war crimes, crimes against humanity and murder as the tribunal moved forward with its second case, after the conviction in July of the director of the main Khmer Rouge prison.

headline: Varnette Honeywood, Whose Art Appeared on ‘Cosby Show,’ Dies at 59
text: Varnette P. Honeywood, an artist whose brilliantly colored collages, paintings and prints presented a warm, upbeat picture of black American life and whose paintings were prominently displayed in the living room of the Huxtable home on “The Cosby Show,” died on Sunday in Los Angeles. She was 59.

headline: Jim Winner, Developer of the Club Antitheft Device, Dies at 81
text: Jim Winner, a businessman who developed and marketed the Club, the popular antiauto theft device, died Tuesday afternoon in an automobile accident in Clarion County in western Pennsylvania. He was 81 and lived in Hollywood, Fla., and Clark, Pa.

headline: Charges Dropped in Enron Case
text: The Justice Department dropped fraud charges against a former Merrill Lynch & Company banker five days before a scheduled retrial over his alleged role in an Enron Corporation scheme.

headline: First Impressions of the Champions League Openers
text: Tuesday offered a couple of shootouts and Wednesday brought a couple of blowouts in the UEFA Champions League. So while you ponder what’s gotten into Cesc Fabregas and how the best player in the world can take one of the worst-looking penalty kicks you’ll ever see, let’s take a look back at which teams look to be the ones to beat after their opening games in the group stage.

headline: Support for Higher Tax on Wealthiest
text: Amid heated debate in Washington over the fate of the Bush-era tax cuts, there is strong support for the Obama administration’s proposal to allow the tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans to expire at the end of the year. However, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll finds the public does not expect that to happen if the Republicans win control of Congress in November.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 10 through Sept. 14 with 990 adults throughout the United States, including 881 who said they were registered to vote.

headline: News Quiz | September 16, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Ally, Once GMAC, Could Turn Profit for U.S. Taxpayers
text: Ally Financial, the recipient of more than $17 billion in American aid, may be able to repay its bailout in full with a profit for taxpayers if General Motors is right about the value of its stake in the auto lender, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Wall St. Critic to Run Consumer Agency
text: Elizabeth Warren, who conceived of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, will oversee its establishment as an assistant to President Obama, an official briefed on the decision said Wednesday evening, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: Japan’s Move on Yen Lacks Global Support
text: Japan’s decision to intervene in currency markets to weaken the yen and shore up its export-driven economy could be only the first step in a long battle — one made more difficult because Japan, unable to find support among its trading partners, must go it alone, Hiroko Tabuchi writes in The New York Times.

headline: Online Woes Plague Chase for 2nd Day
text: Computer problems prevented millions of Chase customers from gaining access to their accounts over the bank’s Web site for a second day on Wednesday. Even after access was restored, complaints persisted as the rush of customers logging on to the site bogged down the company’s computers, making service spotty.

headline: S.E.C. Defends Exemptions in New Law
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is fighting attempts by some lawmakers to repeal a provision in a new law that gives the commission greater ability to block public disclosure of material it gathers from financial and investment firms, Edward Wyatt writes in The New York Times.

headline: Columbia’s Endowment Posts 17% Return
text: Columbia University said on Wednesday that its endowment performed far better than some other large schools’ and better than the major stock market indexes in the latest year, posting a 17.3 percent return on its investments.

headline: California: Higher Penalties proposed for Pipeline Violations
text: Federal penalties for safety violations along the nation’s pipelines would more than double under legislation proposed to Congress on Wednesday by Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood. He cited last week’s natural gas pipeline explosion that killed four people and destroyed dozens of homes south of San Francisco as well as recent pipeline failures in Michigan and Illinois in making his announcement. Under the proposed legislation, maximum fines for safety violations resulting in deaths, injuries or major environmental damages would increase to $2.5 million, from $1 million. The legislation would also finance an additional 40 federal safety inspection and enforcement personnel.

headline: U.S. Adopts Tougher Stance on China
text: The Obama administration is moving to take a harder stance on the Chinese government’s trade and currency policies, with anger toward China rising in both political parties ahead of midterm elections, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Traitorology
text: Today’s word, in association with the expansive Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Morning T | Christian Siriano
text: The designer and Project Runway winner takes tea with Horacio Silva. Among the topics discussed: Siriano’s “Fierce Mamas” maternity collection, “trannygate,” and his willingness to go very high and very low (as in shoes for Payless) with his designs. “I love that I have a $10,000 dress and a $40 shoe,” says the 24-year-old.

headline: Wall Street Finishes the Day Higher
text: Stocks overcame an early slide Wednesday and closed higher as investors kept a September rally alive.

headline: Charges Dropped in Enron Case
text: The Justice Department dropped fraud charges against a former Merrill Lynch banker five days before a scheduled retrial over his alleged role in an Enron Corporation scheme.

headline: Soros to Get a Day in Court Over Insider Trading
text: Europe’s highest human rights court said Wednesday that it would accept a complaint by the international financier George Soros that his rights were impinged on by French courts in convicting him in an insider-trading case dating back more than two decades.

headline: 3 Teams Win Fuel-Efficient Car Prize
text: Teams from Virginia, North Carolina and Winterthur, Switzerland, with roots in the world of auto racing have won the first Progressive Insurance Automotive X Prize, the $10 million competition aimed at advancing the technology for more fuel-efficient vehicles, The New York Times’s Ronald Ahrens reported.

headline: Game On!
text: WHAT is Quest to Learn?

headline: Creativity Comes in Twos
text: Today’s idea: Never mind the lone genius: new research suggests that because the “self” is a social animal, achievement flowers in collaborations — from Emily Dickinson and her sister-in-law, to John Lennon and Paul McCartney.

headline: Charges in Manila Hostage Crisis
text: MANILA  At least 10 people, including police officers, government officials and journalists, should face charges in the deaths of eight Hong Kong residents who were held hostage on a bus in downtown Manila last month, the Philippine justice secretary said Thursday.

headline: Post-Lehman, a ‘Massive Arbitrage’ in U.S. Treasuries
text: Arbitrage: it’s what makes markets efficient and proves they aren’t.

headline: S.E.C. Wants More Disclosure on Muni Markets
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking to expand its powers to demand more financial disclosure from cities, states and municipal-debt issuers, a commissioner with the S.E.C., Elisse Walter told The Wall Street Journal in an interview.

headline: How Concerned Are You About Where Your Food Comes From?
text: There have been many articles in The Times recently about so-called factory farming and the controversial animal confinement and safety monitoring methods the farms employ. Major livestock producers argue that a direct link between these farms and human illnesses, like salmonella and E. coli, has not been proved, but many medical and health experts disagree. How much are you aware of news about food safety, like this summer’s egg recall? How important is this issue to you in general? Do you care about where your food comes from and the conditions under which it was produced? Why or why not?

headline: In Britain, Pope Criticizes Response to Abuse Crisis
text: GLASGOW  Pope Benedict XVI arrived Thursday in Scotland, offering his strongest criticism yet of the Roman Catholic Church’s handling of the sexual abuse crisis. He said that church leaders had not been “sufficiently vigilant” or “sufficiently swift and decisive” in cracking down on abusers.

headline: Grupo ACS Makes $2.3 Billion Bid for Hochtief
text: Actividades de Construccion y Servicios, the Spanish building company, is set to make an all-share takeover bid for its German counterpart Hochtief, in which it already owns a 30 percent stake, according to a statement on the Web site of the Madrid stock exchange, which suspended ACS’s shares on Thursday.

headline: Potash Working on China-Led Buyout, Report Says
text: Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan is trying to stitch together a consortium led by China to back a management buyout to trump BHP Billiton‘s $38.6 billion hostile offer, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: Test Yourself | English, September 16, 2010
text: Test your reading comprehension with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times article “Looking This Way and That, and Learning to Adapt to the World.”

headline: Chinese-U.S. Steel Deal Moves Forward
text: Anshan Iron and Steel is moving ahead with its plans to take a stake in Steel Development, despite concerns by some United States lawmakers about the Chinese investment in the American steel industry, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Sanofi Chief: ‘Reasonable’ Chance of Genzyme Deal
text: Sanofi-Aventis sees a reasonable chance of buying American biotech Genzyme at a fair price, but expects it will take some time to agree a deal that would further diversify the French drug maker and strengthen its United States foothold, Reuters reported.

headline: Seeing the London Olympics, Still in Progress
text: The upcoming 2012 London Olympic and Paralympic Games are less than two years away, but right now is a great time to see the the actual park area in all of its dusty, transitional, dug-up glory.

headline: U.S. Bancorp Foresees Slow Recovery
text: Loan demand will remain sluggish and the economic recovery will proceed slowly, executives at U.S. Bancorp told investors on Wednesday, dampening hopes for a dividend increase in the near future, Reuters reported.

headline: Picking Up the Slack on Global Banking Rules
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is an author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Wilbur Ross Joins Cardinal in Bid for Irish EBS
text: Wilbur Ross, the billionaire investor, had boarded a consortium led by Dublin-based Cardinal Asset Management to bid for EBS, the Irish building society, Mr. Ross told CNBC on Wednesday.

headline: North Korea Proposes Discussing Border Issues
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea has proposed military talks with South Korea to discuss border disputes, the South Korean Defense Ministry said on Thursday, in another sign that the North is reaching out to its rival after months of acrimony.

headline: Alliance Medical Said to Extend Restructuring Talks
text: Alliance Medical, a British medical services business owned by a top Dubai private equity firm, has secured a two-month extension to restructuring talks as it continues to seek a buyer, Reuters reported, citing people close to the discussions.

headline: Gubernatorial Forecast Update
text: There is little aggregate change in the FiveThirtyEight gubernatorial forecast since the previous model run on Sept. 3. On average, over the course of 100,000 simulations, Republicans were projected to control 30.2 governorships after the Nov. 2 elections, up incrementally from 30.1 two weeks ago. Democrats were projected to control the governorships in an average of 19.5 states.

headline: Wright Express Completes Australian Buyout
text: Wright Express, a payment processor for commercial and government trucking fleets, said Wednesday that it has completed its $318 million deal to buy the Australian fleet and prepaid card businesses of Retail Decisions, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Rex Ryan Enlists Fans; Tom Brady Criticizes Them
text: The transcript from Jets Coach Rex Ryan’s talk with reporters on Wednesday. As he did last year, he urged fans to make a “great effort” against the Patriots, the kind of effort that quarterback Tom Brady found lacking in Patriots fans in New England’s opener. Brady said, “I don’t think the Jets fans leave early.”

headline: EMusic Nears Major Label Deals for Fall Relaunch
text: EMusic, the subscription digital music service, is close to wrapping up deals with the last two major labels in time for a planned relaunch in November, its chief executive told Reuters.

headline: Yet Another Extension for MGM on Debt
text: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer‘s lenders have agreed to give the troubled studio its seventh extension to repay its nearly $4 billion of debt.

headline: Polian Sees No Problem With Calvin Johnson Ruling
text: The “Going to Ground” rule for catches in the N.F.L. can get a little complex.

headline: Goldman Fund Run by Prop Traders Beats Average
text: Goldman Sachs proprietary traders who created a hedge fund within the firm in 2007 have generated a return of about 3 percent this year, beating the industry average, Bloomberg News reported, citing people briefed on the gain.

headline: Namath Keeps the Comments Coming on the Jets
text: Joe Namath is offering analysis about the Jets at his Web site, on YouTube, on radio, on Twitter — seemingly anywhere he can.

headline: Food Photography: How to Shoot Soup
text: Andrew Scrivani (@Andrew Scrivani) is a freelance photographer who contributes to The New York Times. He writes the blog Making Sunday Sauce.

headline: Ramius Goes Hostile With Cypress Bid
text: Ramius has begun a hostile bid to buy Cypress Bioscience for $4.25 per share, an increase from the hedge fund’s recent offer for the biotechnology company.

headline: Ex-Carlyle Man to Run Jersey Investing Panel?
text: Robert E. Grady, a former partner in the Carlyle Group, the private equity giant, is set to become chairman of the panel that guides investment policy for New Jersey’s $68 billion pension fund, Bloomberg New reported, citing two people with knowledge of the plan.

headline: More Thoughts on the 3,000-Mile Oil Change
text: My most recent ShortCuts column discussing how often you need to change the oil in your car –- and stating that the need to change your oil every 3,000 miles is largely a myth — elicited a great deal of reader response. I was surprised that so many people felt so strongly about the issue. Some readers were grateful for the information; others told me that I was full of baloney and that they were going to stick to the 3,000-mile changes no matter what.

headline: Mapletree to Said to Weigh  $598 Million I.P.O.
text: Mapletree Industrial Trust‘s coming initial public offering is expected to raise about 800 million Singapore dollars ($598 million), Reuters said, citing sources briefed on the deal.

headline: The Nikon D7000: Moving Up to the Midrange
text: After the wave of entry-level D.S.L.R. cameras of the past two years, many of us are itching to move up to something a bit more capable — and the coming Nikon D7000 looks like a very solid midrange choice.

headline: Accor to Sell Lucien Barriere Stake in I.P.O.
text: Accor, Europe’s largest hotelier, aims to raise as much as 343 million euros ($449 million) by selling its stake in Groupe Lucien Barriere, in an initial public offering that may be France’s biggest this year.

headline: Q&A: Controlling Amazon E-Mail
text: Q.

headline: How the Packers Missed on Randy Moss and Upset Brett Favre
text: A great inside look at the battle between the Patriots and the Packers to land Randy Moss in 2007. Andrew Brandt of The National Football Post worked for the Packers at the time. Here are a few snippets, then read the whole thing.

headline: Morning T | Christian Siriano
text: The designer and Project Runway winner takes tea with Horacio Silva.

headline: Yahoo Shows No Interest in Selling Alibaba Stake
text: Alibaba may want to buy back Yahoo‘s stake in the Chinese Web company, but it seems the American tech giant has no intention of granting that wish.

headline: Financial Crisis Dominates Business Book Short List
text: The financial crisis dominated the short list of six books nominated for the 2010 Business Book of the Year Award, sponsored by The Financial Times and Goldman Sachs, announced on Thursday, Reuters said.

headline: When Food Is Exciting and You Are Bored to Death
text: Are food obsessives and gastronuts taking the fun out of restaurants? That was the question raised and answered by an interesting letter Diner’s Journal received from a fellow named Brian, responding to our recent article about changes in the service and menu at Eleven Madison Park. I figured I’d pitch the conversation over to you, the reader.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –Howard Marks in his latest Oaktree memo: “No one should view the great popularity of bonds relative to stocks without reservation.” (Hat tip to @Morgan_03)

headline: Morgan Stanley Executive Said to Be in Talks to Join State Dept.
text: Thomas R. Nides, Morgan Stanley‘s chief operating officer and one of the firm’s top executives, is in talks to join the State Department in a senior role, according to news reports.

headline: A Look at Palm’s Latest OS
text: Recently Palm announced the release of its new Palm WebOS 2.0 software development kit — I know, be still my beating heart — but it matters, because it gives developers new tools that let their apps do some very cool things.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Vanessa Bley
text: Vanessa Bley took to the stage at the Mercury Lounge on Aug. 28, in support of Josh Fox and his film “Gasland,” which brings to the public eye the debate on natural-gas fracking in the United States. Bley, who is the daughter of the renowned jazz pianist Paul Bley, delivered a raucous set of danceable tracks, bringing an energy, technical prowess and a wildness rarely seen from young female artists today.

headline: Making G.O.P. Dollars Count in Senate Races
text: The strategists at the National Republican Senatorial Committee, which doles out money to candidates every election year, face difficult choices in the next seven weeks as they push to gain 10 seats and take over the Senate.

headline: Pipelines and Anxiety: What Next?
text: As anyone living in the Midwest can tell you, gasoline prices have been mighty high in recent days. Since a pipeline operated by the Canadian company Enbridge ruptured last week outside of Chicago, the second such incident concerning an Enbridge pipeline in the Midwest this summer, prices at the pump have spurted up as much as 30 cents a gallon around much of the region.

headline: Sondheim and Company Christen the Stephen Sondheim Theater
text: “I’m deeply embarrassed,” Stephen Sondheim said Wednesday evening at a ceremony to officially light the marquee of the Broadway theater renamed in his honor. “Thrilled, but deeply embarrassed.”

headline: S.E.C. Said to Examine Banks’ ‘Window Dressing’ Practice
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is preparing to take on banks’ practice of temporarily lowering their debt levels at quarter end to look financially healthier than they may really be, a trick known as “window dressing,” The Wall Street Journal reported Thursday.

headline: Energy Costs Push Up U.S. Producer Prices
text: Higher energy costs pushed the overall measure of producer prices higher in August, the government said Thursday, a modest increase that many analysts said reduced concerns about the possibility of deflation even as the economy continued to recover.

headline: Timeless | Band on the Run
text: When a brand ‘‘goes global,’’ that usually means the forces behind it will be racking up frequent-flier miles. Carolina Herrera Báez, the daughter of the designer Carolina Herrera, is doing exactly that as the creative adviser for CH Carolina Herrera, a casual lifestyle brand that is rolling out 18 boutiques this year. The first New York City boutique, which sells everything from silk dresses to cashmere travel blankets, opened earlier this month.

headline: When Possessions Lead to Paralysis
text: David J. Ekerdt, who directs the gerontology center at the University of Kansas, has a knack for digging into aspects of aging that most of us register only in passing. I’ve been a fan since I read his work on the “busy ethic,” a phrase he coined to describe our attitudes towards retirement.

headline: The Early Word: Geithner and Schapiro on the Hill
text: Economy on the Hill: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner will tell House and Senate lawmakers today that China has kept the value of its currency, the renminbi, artificially low to help its exports and has largely failed to improve the situation, as it promised to do in June. The Times’s Sewell Chan has the details.

headline: The Beast Eyes Broadway: ‘King Kong’ to Take New York Again
text: We don’t remember things working out so well when they tried to fit King Kong onto a New York stage in that classic 1933 film – something about bad opening-night reviews, a scramble up the Empire State Building and one massive cleanup job in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Push to Hire Bankers Accelerates
text: From Julia Werdigier, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Nocturnalist | Partying, Not Just Posing
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: Jason Wu: Knitting at Tse
text: In addition to his signature line, Jason Wu has created a capsule collection for Tse, the knitwear company. He introduced the collaboration last fall with terrific sweaters, but for spring, he wanted to go in a different direction since it’s basically the off-season for a sweater company and no one wants to look at heavy knits.

headline: Your Favorite Mets Malady
text: Despite several witty suggestions from readers about potential promotions to attract fans to this week’s Mets-Pirates series, no one offered the one that came to pass on Wednesday: Come See Jenrry Mejia Hurt His Shoulder Night.

headline: Painting Is Found, but That Solves Nothing
text: Dashiell Hammett could have written this tale: a missing painting turns up on the street — or did it? — and a complicated case gets even weirder. The painting, Corot’s “Portrait of a Girl,” was reported lost, prompting all manner of accusations. But the doorman who found it in Manhattan said he had no idea what it was. William K. Rashbaum of The Times tries to unravel the mystery, but the story ends up prompting even more head-scratching questions. Did you ever watch “The Maltese Falcon” and at the end say, huh? Well, it’s kind of like that.

headline: Poetry Pairing | September 16, 2010
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: For the Coda, a Preface in Washington
text: After you build an electric car, the next step is to sell it. So Kevin Czinger, the president and chief executive of Coda Automotive, trucked his from California to Washington this week to try it out on the General Services Administration, the purchasing arm of the federal government.

headline: Baby Hatch
text: A hatch at an orphanage in Kuala Lumpur where people can anonymously abandon babies.

headline: A Beef With Gaga
text: I’m not one to follow the fashion follies of Lady Gaga, but the meaty getup the singer wore to the MTV Video Music Awards the other night made me think of another artist who has been working in carnivorous creations for quite some time.

headline: A Beef With Gaga
text: I’m not one to follow the fashion follies of Lady Gaga, but the meaty getup the singer wore to the MTV Video Music Awards the other night made me think of another artist who has been working in carnivorous creations for quite some time.

headline: Sympathy For O’Donnell Voters
text: From Dave Weigel’s requiem for Mike Castle:

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: The Digital Life
text: On this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein chats with Nick Bilton, the lead writer for the Bits blog, about his just-published book, “I Live in the Future and Here’s How It Works.” Mr. Bilton, formerly a researcher in the research and development labs of The New York Times, sees digital streams of information becoming increasingly personalized. People want not only content, he says, but also an online experience — and they’re willing to pay if the price is right.

headline: U.S. to Sell G.M. Stake Over Time
text: DETROIT  He is the fourth chief executive at General Motors in less than 18 months, but Daniel F. Akerson set out Thursday to show there is now stability at the top of the nation’s biggest automaker  and that his ascension signals a clear break with the past.

headline: MTV — Yes, MTV — Wants Your Financial Aid Ideas
text: As the stern proctor of the hardly hip SAT exam, the College Board would seem an odd recipient of prominent attention on MTV. It is difficult to imagine a scantily clad, lip-synching Katy Perry – to say nothing of Snooki or the Situation – rolling on a beach with a No. 2 pencil and a bubble sheet.

headline: Thursday Reading: A Downside to Having Lots of Stuff
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: 36 Hours in Rio de Janeiro
text: WITH the World Cup coming in 2014, followed by the Olympic Games two years later, Rio de Janeiro is thinking outside the beach. The historic port area is undergoing an extreme makeover, and museums by such vanguard architects as Santiago Calatrava and Diller Scofidio + Renfro are in the works. A long-anticipated bullet train to São Paulo seems to be finally happening, while the city is making strides (albeit fitful ones) tackling the problems of its notorious favelas. Indeed, there will always be sunshine, thongs and Carnaval, but these days, Rio has a whole lot more to strut about.

headline: Derek Jeter’s Emmy-Worthy Performance
text: As Ben Shpigel reported in Thursday’s Times, Derek Jeter admitted he was acting Wednesday night when he pretended to be hit by a pitch in the Tampa Bay Rays’ 4-3 victory over the Yankees.

headline: Twain’s Nicaragua, 144 Years Later
text: IT was June, the height of the Nicaraguan rainy season, and the sky was thick with clouds. Our small boat cut south through the wind-churned Pacific, rounding one bend, then another. The looming hills were green with shrubby trees and coastal grasses; where they met the water, layers of rock folded like cake frosting into the ocean. Soon a wide bay opened up and the surf-and-sand boomtown of San Juan del Sur came into view. Structures lined the beach in Jolly Rancher shades: apple green, lemon yellow, watermelon pink. At the bay’s northern edge, large houses climbed a steep hillside toward a towering statue of Jesus.

headline: Lima’s Hidden Ateliers
text: WALK along Jr. Julio Victor Aguirre, a peaceful street in Lima, Peru, and you’ll pass a sky-blue home with white-trimmed windows that open out to catch fresh sea breezes. What you won’t know until you step inside this 19th-century house is that it also is the atelier of a top Peruvian fashion designer — one of a number of old buildings in the city that have been turned into boutiques, with plenty of style inside but little splashy signage outside. And many are putting the spotlight on the designs of indigenous people.

headline: Hotel Review: the NOW Hotel in Cali, Colombia
text: BASICS

headline: Buenos Aires: National Treasure in a Cone
text: IN Palermo, a residential neighborhood of Buenos Aires, an elegant specialty store called Persicco doles out a confection called chocuquinna. Inspired by a popular Argentine birthday cake, it has a sweet dulce de leche base balanced with hints of cream cheese and laced with chocolate chunks of what could be described as a cross between a crunchy cookie and a spongy cake. This version comes in a particular sort of serving dish  an ice cream cone.

headline: Restaurant Review: Sorveteria Cairu in Belém, Brazil
text: Belém sits at the mouth of the Amazon River both literally (on the delta where millions of gallons pour into the Atlantic every second) and figuratively — it is the prime destination for travelers seeking out the region’s bafflingly unfamiliar cuisine.

headline: Big-City Cool, Small-Town Charm in Mexico
text: Frida Kahlo’s hometown, Coyoacán, is now an artsy, history-laden neighborhood in Mexico City, with a distinctive mix of preserved past and chic present.

headline: Jon Stewart to Return to ‘The O’Reilly Factor’
text: Set your digital video recorders: Bill O’Reilly and Jon Stewart are returning to each other’s television shows.

headline: Doctored Photo Flatters Egyptian President
text: Updated | 5:18 p.m. An Egyptian blogger has shown that an influential state-run newspaper published an apparently altered photograph of Egypt’s president, Hosni Mubarak, this week, showing him at the front, rather than the back, of a group of leaders who met last week at the White House to talk about peace in the Middle East.

headline: Doctored Photo Flatters Egyptian President
text: Updated | 5:18 p.m. An Egyptian blogger has shown that an influential state-run newspaper published an apparently altered photograph of Egypt’s president, Hosni Mubarak, this week, showing him at the front, rather than the back, of a group of leaders who met last week at the White House to talk about peace in the Middle East.

headline: Selling the ‘Stop’ in ‘Stop and Frisk’
text: There’s no doubt that the New York City Police Department’s tactic of stopping and frisking people on the street can create tensions with those stopped, and within the neighborhoods where many of the encounters occur. Yet the department is loath to give up the tactic, calling it a core law enforcement tool.

headline: U.S. Steps Up Criticism of China’s Practices
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration increased its criticism of China’s economic policies on Thursday, as Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner told Congress that China had substantially undervalued its currency to gain an unfair trade advantage, tolerated theft of foreign technology and created unreasonable barriers to American imports.

headline: Rewards and Punishments for Kids
text: “Let the punishment fit the crime,” Gilbert and Sullivan wrote.

headline: Toyota to Offer Six New Hybrid Models in 2012
text: Toyota plans to offer six new gas-electric hybrid vehicles worldwide by the end of 2012, plus a plug-in Prius in the United States.

headline: ‘Priscilla’ Musical to Take Over ‘West Side Story’ Theater
text: Following “West Side Story” at the Palace Theater will be the new musical “Priscilla Queen of the Desert,” based on the 1994 movie about three Australian drag queens traveling by bus across the outback.

headline: European League Soccer Matchups
text: The outstanding matchups in European league soccer this weekend:

headline: European League Soccer Matchups
text: The outstanding matchups in European league soccer this weekend:

headline: Paterson Says He Will Lay Off Workers
text: Reversing an earlier pledge to not lay off state workers before Jan. 1, Gov. David A. Paterson said on Thursday that he would dismiss government employees before the end of this year to close a persistent budget gap.

headline: For the Coda, a Preface in Washington
text: From our colleagues at Green:

headline: Released Too Soon
text: In my New York Times column Thursday, I reviewed a box called Vulkano, which purports to be both a TiVo (records TV shows effortlessly) and a Slingbox (lets you watch your shows over the Internet—on an iPhone, iPad, iPod Touch, BlackBerry, Android phone, Mac or PC).

headline: My Dinner With Edwin
text: Out here in television land, a lot of us have memories of Edwin Newman, the longtime NBC News correspondent whose death was announced this week. We remember the big stories he had a hand in covering. The presidential debates he moderated. The grammar lessons he probably thought we all needed. The cameo appearance in the film “The Pelican Brief.”

headline: Popcast: The VMAs, Marc Ribot and More
text: On MTV’s 27th annual Video Music Awards this week, Lady Gaga wore a meat dress, Chelsea Handler didn’t make everyone laugh, and Taylor Swift and Kanye West finally confronted each other, sort of, about the unpleasant events at last year’s show. The drama drew plenty of eyeballs: the show had its best ratings in eight years.

headline: Suspect Wanted in 3 Subway Robberies
text: The knife-wielding man struck first on Aug. 7, robbing a woman as she walked off an A train at the 125th Street station in Harlem, the police said. He robbed a second woman on Aug. 27 after waving a knife at her on another A train in Inwood, they said.

headline: Recession Raises Poverty Rate to a 15-Year High
text: The percentage of Americans struggling below the poverty line in 2009 was the highest it has been in 15 years, the Census Bureau reported Thursday, and interviews with poverty experts and aid groups said the increase appeared to be continuing this year.

headline: Runway Beauty | Proenza Schouler
text: Backstage at Proenza Schouler, the makeup artist Diane Kendal and the hairstylist Paul Hanlon repeated the same directive from designers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez: The Proenza girl has grown up — but not entirely. “The boys wanted to move on from the last season, where the hair was kind of bed head,” said Hanlon, who used Frederic Fekkai Coiff Oceanique Touseled Wave Spray to create an unfinished French twist with what can only be described as a rattail hanging out the back. “I thought about when I was a kid on the school bus and a girl would fall asleep against a condensated window, and she’d get off with her hair all mish-moshed up.” The look paired perfectly with the minimal makeup by Kendal, which was simply cheek contour (M.A.C. Pro Sculpt Powders) and a strong, square brow. “We’re not even using any concealer, because we like natural discoloration around the eye,” she said. “The clothes this season are much more ladylike, so they wanted to keep their signature girl — very model-looking and tough.” With a cast including heavyweights Abby Lee, Karolina Kurkova, Liu Wen and Isabeli Fontani, that wasn’t very difficult.

headline: Michael Jackson’s Mother Sues Promoter Over His Death
text: Michael Jackson’s mother has filed a lawsuit against the promoter of his planned concerts last year, saying that the company, AEG Live, failed to supply medical equipment and properly monitor Jackson’s personal doctor, Reuters reported.

headline: Oprah Picks Franzen for Final Book Club
text: It appears that Oprah Winfrey and Jonathan Franzen have kissed and made up.

headline: T Minus 10 Days
text: Here’s the plan, in one longish, timorous breath: the plan is to open the restaurant, and while nothing is written in stone or on stone crabs or any place else other than in our collective consciousness and on the blackboard above the bar, the plan is to open the restaurant called Southfork Kitchen on Sunday, Sept. 26, 2010 — please do not read any religious meaning into opening on a Sabbath — fully realizing that brand new restaurants are functioning, zoetic organisms, like stone crabs, forced to respond to a sea of shifting imperatives, which is why the plan is subject to change, and change, in this instance, means the date may be moved, this way or that, slightly.

headline: Pogue’s Posts: Released Too Soon
text: David Pogue follows up on his review of Vulkano, which purports to be both a TiVo (records TV shows effortlessly) and a Slingbox (lets you watch your shows over the Internet, on an iPhone, iPad, iPod Touch, BlackBerry, Android phone, Mac or PC), on Pogue’s Posts.

headline: Census Numbers Show 50.7 Million Uninsured
text: The Census Bureau released on Thursday the latest figures on how many Americans were without health insurance in 2009: 50.7 million people, an increase of almost 10 percent from the 46.3 million people without coverage in 2008.

headline: The Black-White Pay Gap
text: This morning’s Census report showed that median income last year was on the high side of the expected range — down 0.7 percent in 2009, to $49,777, from $50,112 in 2008. After adjusting for inflation, the 2009 level is the lowest since 1997.

headline: U.S. Envoy Vows to Help Pakistan Rebuild After Flooding
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  A top United States envoy to Pakistan reiterated American vows on Thursday to help the country rebuild after the summer’s devastating floods, even as he acknowledged that the international community could only provide a fraction of the money Pakistan needs.

headline: For Auto I.P.O.’s, a Long Road Ahead
text: General Motors expects the United States government to be a major shareholder for “the next couple of years” even after it sells some of its shares in an initial public offering, the company’s new chief executive told reporters on Thursday.

headline: Abbas Says Israel Talks Will Continue
text: AMMAN, Jordan  After two days of difficult peace negotiations with Israel over the issue of Jewish settlements, the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, sounded a modestly positive note on Thursday, declaring that he saw no alternative but to keep talking.

headline: Coal Challenge Looms in China and India
text: My article in Thursday’s Times looks at Europe’s attempt to reduce its dependence on coal by ending state subsidies for coal plants and mines. Using coal for power generation results in high levels of local pollution as well as the greenhouse gases that contribute to climate change.

headline: IFC Acquires Rights to Film About Harvey Weinstein
text: TORONTO — Harvey Weinstein, the independent film mogul, has a movie here, but it is not one of his namesake company’s entries in the still-underway Toronto International Film Festival. On Wednesday, IFC Entertainment said it had acquired rights to “Unauthorized: The Harvey Weinstein Project,” a documentary biography of Mr. Weinstein from the Toronto filmmaker Barry Avrich.

headline: Sept. 19 — 25
text: Art

headline: One Project, One Faith, and Two Men Who Differ
text: The two men behind the proposed Islamic community center and mosque near ground zero are from different generations and distinct backgrounds  the imam, 61, grew up in England and Malaysia and immigrated to New York as a teenager; the real estate developer, 37, spent his early childhood in Brooklyn, then attended American schools overseas.

headline: Post Your Retirement Spend-Down Strategies
text: My story in today’s special section on retirement, “Looking Ahead to the Spend-Down Years,” details some creative new thinking from behavioral finance experts trying to help people turn their retirement savings into retirement income.

headline: You’re a Step Closer to Being Able to Print From Your iPad
text: Apple announced on Wednesday that it would give developers who create applications for the iOS platform access to a beta version of a new app, AirPrint, which will enable wireless printing on the iPad, iPhone and iPod touch.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Anna Sui
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Bryan Bedder for Getty Images.

headline: Ralph Lauren, at Home on the Range
text: Howdy, pardners! Why, it’s the eighth and final day of New York Fashion Week and Ralph Lauren got things off to a rip roarin’ start with his Wild West-themed collection. It was all about the fringe — miles and miles of fringe as far as the eye could see — fringe on suede jackets, fringe on patterned cloth bags, fringe on deerskin vests, fringe on a frilly scarf and platinum-beaded fringe for evening.

headline: Arctic Shipping Gets Boring
text: Welcome to the transforming Arctic.

headline: Mejia Done for the Season
text: The Mets announced Thursday that Jenrry Mejia would not pitch the rest of the season because of a rhomboid strain of the right shoulder blade. In a statement, the Mets said that Mejia, 20, had a magnetic resonance imaging test, which revealed the injury, and that he would not throw again until he made a full recovery. They gave no time frame.

headline: Doctors’ Group Attacks McDonald’s in TV Ad
text: A new television advertisement that singles out McDonald’s for obesity-related deaths is causing quite the stir.

headline: Home of Overconfidence?
text: Just when you need a good rivalry to liven up a sports season, New York is always the perfect place to turn. It’s a place where foolish overconfidence is a badge of honor  search the city seal, it’s probably in there somewhere  and its teams always seem to make the perfect trash-talking, umpire-duping, controversy-a-day foils.

headline: Giving Away Art Is Easier in Brooklyn

headline: 14 Convicted Abusers Remain Priests in U.K.
text: As my colleague Rachel Donadio reports, at the start of a four-day visit to Britain on Thursday, Pope Benedict XVI told reporters that the Roman Catholic Church’s response to the sexual abuse of children by priests had not been “sufficiently vigilant” or “sufficiently swift and decisive.” In remarks captured on video, he added, “It is difficult to understand how this perversion of the priestly ministry is possible.”

headline: Warner Brothers Gives $5 Million for Movie Theater at Smithsonian Museum
text: Warner Brothers Entertainment has donated $5 million to the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of American History to convert the museum’s auditorium into a film theater, The Washington Post reported. In the new theater, which is expected to be completed next year and will be named the Warner Brothers Theater, the museum will offer programming related to American film history. As part of the gift, the museum will have access to the film archives of Warner Brothers and the MGM film library, but it will not be restricted from showing material from other studios. The museum prominently displays many props and other materials from film and television history, including the ruby slippers from “The Wizard of Oz,” a Warner Brothers property.

headline: Theater Talkback: A New Marquee
text: A new Broadway theater took its first bow on Wednesday night: the Stephen Sondheim, on 43rd Street.

headline: Tipsy Diaries: Drinks in Harlem

headline: China’s Rise Complicates Goal of Using Less Energy

headline: Going Upscale Uptown
text: So long as there’s not a soundtrack of screeching to go with it, I kind of like seeing a stroller in a drinking establishment — and not, I should add, because I’m cavalier about child welfare. Diligent parenting can surely accommodate a glass of wine or stein of beer at happy hour, and procreation shouldn’t prevent the new moms and dads of the world from hanging with the rest of us, who appreciate reinforcements and some diversity around the bar.

headline: Dispute Grows Over France’s Removal of Roma Camps

headline: Q&A: A Long Weekend Jaunt From São Paulo
text: I am traveling to São Paulo, Brazil, to work for a week (Nov. 22 to 26). My boyfriend and 15-year-old daughter are considering joining me for a long weekend. We would like to see a few of the sights outside São Paulo and have thought about Rio de Janeiro. We are open to air travel within the country, but prefer closer jaunts if possible. Any ideas would be much appreciated.

headline: Out of the Oven | The New Museum’s New Cookie
text: Fashion writers dream of the day when they get an exclusive sneak peek at a visionary designer’s next collection. I’d rather be the first girl on the block to sample an iconic baker’s latest creation. That is exactly what happened to me when I dropped by the New Museum for a preview of its latest attraction: a spruced-up cafe. As befits its offbeat location and forward-looking spirit, the New Museum teamed up with Maury Rubin of the City Bakery and its counterpart, Birdbath, Green Neighborhood Bakery — both of which are, he says, “a product of the creative mind-set of downtown New York.” As a result, he adds, “New Museum feels like perfect, symbiotic territory.”

headline: A More Nuanced Look at Poverty Numbers
text: Despite a steady rise in unemployment throughout 2009, America’s poverty rate didn’t rise as much as some analysts had feared. Still, at 14.3 percent, up from 13.2 percent in 2008, it represented 43.6 million people, the highest number of people in poverty since the Census Bureau began publishing estimates in 1959.

headline: Precursor to H.I.V. Was in Monkeys for Millenniums

headline: Lennon’s Killer Wavered Over Decision

His sixth and latest hearing, on Sept. 7, was no exception, going step by step through his muddled planning as if being interrogated for the first time, according to a transcript released Thursday.

headline: Chunking

He’ll gleefully sing along to “Seven,” a catchy tune from their 2008 album “Here Come the 123s” that tells of a house overrun by anthropomorphic number sevens. The first one is greeted at the door: “Oh, there’s the doorbell. Let’s see who’s out there. Oh, it’s a seven. Hello, Seven. Won’t you come in, Seven? Make yourself at home.”

headline: For Head Injuries, a Problem in Practice
text: As discussion about the effects of brain trauma in football turns to avoiding it in the first place, ideas for reducing hits to the head include eliminating the three-point stance for linemen and strengthening rules regarding headfirst tackles. But the adjustment that many see as the easiest and most practical to make, given that football’s appeal derives in part from its violence, is limiting the number of hits to the head in practice, which data show can be as punishing as the games themselves.

headline: After Losing Vote, What’s Next for Airgas?

In addition, Air Products’ proposal to amend the Airgas bylaws to move the company’s next annual meeting date to Jan. 18 was supported by most of the shareholder votes.

headline: Sympathy For Martha Coakley
text: Speaking of extending sympathy, isn’t it time to rethink the whole “Martha Coakley was the worst candidate in all of human history” narrative that took hold — particularly among Democrats looking for a scapegoat, and a reason to push ahead with the health care bill — in the wake of Scott Brown’s astonishing Massachusetts victory last winter? Obviously Coakley ran a lousy race, and deserved much of the opprobrium that was heaped upon her head. But with seemingly-unassailable incumbents dropping right and left in Republican primaries, and with once-safe Democratic seats in play from Washington and Wisconsin to Illinois and Connecticut, it seems pretty clear that she deserves to be remembered less for her own missteps and follies, and more as the first casualty of forces beyond any establishment candidate’s control.

headline: Q. and A.: Hastening the Energy Revolution
text: The International Energy Agency’s primary focus is ensuring energy security for industrialized countries, particularly members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. Founded in the 1970’s during a period of oil shortages, the agency was meant to be a counterweight to the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and serve as a kind of consumers’ union of oil-consuming nations.

headline: Seeing Things | Studio Visit: Pae White
text: I recently visited the artist Pae White in her Los Angeles studio, where she was busy working on a new exhibition for the Power Plant in Toronto. The exhibition, which opens on Oct. 9, will feature a number of her recent tapestry works as well as a new commissioned tapestry called “Sea Beast.” White has called the show “Material Mutters” because, she explained, “it’s about the exploration of process and the material is doing the talking.” Smoke has been a recurring motif in her work lately, and she has been exploring ways to capture its elusive qualities in various media, including a series of carved paper works that she was finishing for the Toronto show. Because smoke moves so rapidly and changes form so quickly, White likes the way the image of something so immaterial contrasts with the physicality of fabric. “It’s one material trying to understand another and it turns the fabric into something other than itself,” she said. At the Whitney Museum’s Biennial this spring, her monumental digitally woven tapestry “Still, Untitled” was a showstopper.

headline: Donk Donk! British Version of ‘Law & Order’ Coming Stateside

headline: Remaking a Dark Tale, With Real-Life Notes
text: DISNEY’S singing candelabra and dancing teapot notwithstanding, the story of “Beauty and the Beast” is no merry lark, but concerns thoughtless trespass, personal violation and the urge to retaliate. In the original European folk tale the title characters become entangled after a ruined merchant presents a rose stolen from the Beast’s garden as a gift to his beautiful, virtuous daughter, who dutifully surrenders herself to the Beast in exchange for her father’s freedom. Endings vary, but the pair always grapple with anger, pain and mistrust.

headline: Not Everyone Looks Forward to Colts-Giants

headline: Sexual Politics
text: On the morning of Aug. 29, 2008, Denver was swarming with journalists covering the Democratic National Convention. Awaking giddy from the euphoria of Barack Obama’s acceptance of his party’s nomination the night before, I turned on CNN to find John McCain announcing he had chosen a woman — an unknown Alaska governor and mother of five — as his running mate: ­Sarah Palin. “Obama’s just won the election,” I called to my still-slumbering companion. Five minutes later, having taken in Palin’s cocky moxie and Wonder Woman veneer, I shouted: “Get up! You’ve got to see this woman. Maybe McCain will win!”

headline: Brooklyn Brainery: Collaborative Learning Courses
text: “Abandon all hierarchical learning ye who enter here,” warns the Web site of Brooklyn Brainery (brooklynbrainery.com), a group that hosts collaborative learning courses in subjects like astronomy, Southern cooking or the more abstract Pseudoscientific Pursuits. For the classes  “Think book clubs on steroids,” Brooklyn Brainery says  group leaders shape discussions among participants, who share their knowledge or what they’ve learned through homework assignments. Online registration is required for the courses, which run two to three weeks and usually cost around $25. (Gowanus Studio Space, 166 Seventh Street, at Third Avenue, Gowanus, Brooklyn; 347-948-5753.)
