headline: Obama’s Plan for Elizabeth Warren Is Questioned
text: President Obama’s plan to have the legal scholar Elizabeth Warren oversee the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau without a confirmation vote in the Senate drew mixed reviews Thursday, even from groups who are inclined to support her, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

headline: House Tour: Skytop, Pa.
text: WHAT Two-story, four-bedroom, four-bath cottage.

headline: How the Other Half Dressed
text: Fashion Week may be over, but the runway at the Museum of the City of New York isn’t going anywhere for a few months. The museum’s fall show “Notorious and Notable: 20th Century Women of Style,” offers a front-row look at the trends of bygone eras.

headline: Shooting Prompts Warning With `Grey’s Anatomy’
text: A repeat two-part episode of ABC’s “Grey’s Anatomy” will be broadcast with a viewer warning Thursday because parts of the script closely parallel a shooting that happened at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore on Thursday.

headline: Odd Faces, Strange in Their Day, but Familiar in Our Time
text: “Anything great in this world has come from neurotics,” Marcel Proust wrote. He could easily have been referring to a string of manic, morose and sometimes quite mad artists who came and went over the centuries, creating a popular impression that creativity and craziness were inextricably linked.

headline: Company Fends Off Challenge on Stuyvesant Town
text: CW Capital, the company overseeing the troubled Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village complexes in Manhattan, fended off a challenge Thursday when a State Supreme Court judge ruled that a rival group could not take control of the property unless it paid off the existing $3.7 billion mortgage.

headline: City Opera Chairwoman To Resign
text: Susan L. Baker, a former Goldman Sachs executive who oversaw the ill-fated and short-lived hiring of Gerard Mortier as general manager of the New York City Opera, is stepping down as the company’s chairwoman, City Opera said Thursday. Her place will be taken on Dec. 16 by Charles R. Wall, a former tobacco company lawyer who served on the board from 2001 to 2008. In a brief statement that came with the announcement Ms. Baker gave no reason. A City Opera spokesman said Ms. Baker was not immediately available to comment. Ms. Baker, who has held the job for seven years, will remain on the board. She championed the hiring of Mr. Mortier, an iconoclastic Belgian opera impresario who also served as artistic director, after meeting him at a dinner. He joined the company in February 2007 but worked out an agreement under which he would continue to serve in his previous job of running the Paris National Opera. Mr. Mortier pushed for the renovation of City Opera’s Lincoln Center home, now the David H. Koch Theater, which was closed for the 2008-9 season. The closing contributed to a financial nightmare for the company, which only last season began a modest comeback. In November 2008 Mr. Mortier quit even before formally taking over, saying the budget he was handed fell far short of what he was promised.

headline: ‘West Side Story’ Revival To Close
text: The producers of the Broadway revival of “West Side Story” said Wednesday that the production would close at the Palace Theater on Sunday, Jan. 2, after 27 previews and 748 regular performances. The show, directed by Arthur Laurents, who wrote the book for the original 1957 production, opened in March 2009 to mostly positive reviews. Though it recouped its $14 million investment, the production has struggled in recent months at the box office. Following “West Side Story” at the Palace Theater will be the new musical “Priscilla Queen of the Desert,” based on the 1994 movie about three Australian drag queens.

headline: Week 2 in Fantasy Football Matchups
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 2. They will answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

headline: Sondheim And Company Christen Sondheim Theater
text: “I’m deeply embarrassed,” Stephen Sondheim said Wednesday evening at a ceremony to officially light the marquee of the Broadway theater renamed in his honor (above). “Thrilled, but deeply embarrassed.” Mr. Sondheim, 80, the composer and lyricist of musicals including “A Little Night Music,” “Into the Woods,” “Company” and “Sweeney Todd,” was joined outside the soon-to-be-former Henry Miller’s Theater on West 43rd Street by his fellow Broadway luminaries Patti LuPone, Nathan Lane and John Weidman, as well as the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, and executives from the Roundabout Theater Company, which operates the theater. Addressing a crowd of Broadway industry veterans and fans of his work, Mr. Sondheim explained the source of his embarrassment. “Partly because I’ve always hated my last name,” he said. “It just doesn’t sing.” After his speech Mr. Sondheim pulled a switch at the front of the stage, and an illuminated version of his signature flickered and came to life (without a still-missing dot in the letter i that has apparently gone into one of Mrs. Lovett’s pies).

headline: Sun Belt Sprawl
text: Christoph Gielen has spent a decade capturing the eerily beautiful shapes that Sun Belt growth — from subdivisions to prisons — create in the southwestern landscape.

headline: The Beast Eyes Broadway
text: We don’t remember things working out so well when they tried to fit King Kong onto a New York stage in that classic 1933 film. But circumstances might turn out better for Global Creatures, the Australian production company behind animatronic touring shows like “Walking With Dinosaurs.” It is aiming to bring a “King Kong” musical to Broadway as soon as 2013. Carmen Pavlovic, the chief executive of Global Creatures, said the project, which has been authorized by the estate of the “King Kong” co-director Merian C. Cooper, and whose creative team will include the director Daniel Kramer, the book writer Craig Lucas (“Prelude to a Kiss”) and the composer Marius de Vries (Baz Luhrmann’s “William Shakespeare’s Romeo + Juliet”), will feature a robotic Kong (above) that can fit in the notoriously narrow wings of a Broadway theater. At heart the show will be a musical. “King Kong doesn’t suddenly grab a microphone and sing a song to Ann Darrow, I promise you,” Ms. Pavlovic said. “But if you think about the story and the character of Ann, and her background as a performer, and sailors on a ship, and Ann’s relationship with Kong, there’s plenty of opportunities within the story itself, where music naturally fits.”

headline: Michael Jackson’s Mother Sues Promoter Over His Death
text: Michael Jackson’s mother has filed a lawsuit against the promoter of his planned concerts last year, saying that the company, AEG Live, failed to supply medical equipment or to monitor his personal doctor properly, Reuters reported. In her suit, filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court on Wednesday, Katherine Jackson seeks unspecified damages and says that the promoter is responsible for the “actions and inactions” of the doctor, Conrad Murray, and that it put “its desire for massive profits” over Jackson’s health. “AEG’s representations to Jackson were false,” the suit says, “because in reality AEG was merely doing whatever it took to make sure that Michael Jackson could make it to rehearsals and shows, and AEG did not provide a doctor who was truly looking out for Jackson’s well-being.” A lawyer for AEG, Marvin S. Putnam, said in a statement that the lawsuit “is inaccurate, unsubstantiated and meritless.” On June 25, 2009, three weeks before he was to begin a series of 50 comeback shows in London, Jackson died from an overdose of powerful sedatives, and the Los Angeles medical examiner has ruled his death a homicide. Dr. Murray, who was not named in Katherine Jackson’s suit, has pleaded not guilty to charges of involuntary manslaughter in the death.

headline: Winfrey And Franzen Reconcile
text: It appears that Oprah Winfrey and Jonathan Franzen have kissed and made up. Nearly a decade after their public literary feud, Ms. Winfrey has selected “Freedom,” Mr. Franzen’s new best-selling novel, as her next book-club pick, according to booksellers who have seen early copies of the book. The selection is expected to be announced on Friday’s “Oprah” broadcast. In 2001 Mr. Franzen offended Ms. Winfrey when he suggested in interviews that some of her book club picks were middlebrow, and that being chosen by a book club  as his novel “The Corrections” was  could turn off male readers. He apologized, but was promptly uninvited to appear on her television show. In an interview with The Star Tribune of Minneapolis-St. Paul last month, Mr. Franzen was asked about the prospect of Ms. Winfrey’s choosing “Freedom” for her next book club selection. “I would be happy if she did,” he said.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: With the nation’s parliamentary poll set for Saturday, Afghanistan leads the news for the third day in a row on Thursday. The Taliban renewed their vow to launch attacks on the polls and have publicly urged a boycott of the election, Reuters reported. Election workers and security forces are said to be the main target. The Karzai government, with the support of 150,000 foreign troops, says it will provide security for all voters.

headline: Connecting the Dots Between 2 Composers
text: The accomplished young Israeli pianist Shai Wosner, who performs regularly with chamber music ensembles in the United States and Europe, has a new recording that fascinatingly juxtaposes works by Brahms and Schoenberg. On Wednesday at Symphony Space, as part of the weeklong New York Chamber Music Festival, Mr. Wosner again showed a knack for drawing connections between composers.

headline: High Balinese Ritual, Low Holga Technology
text: John Stanmeyer is one of the founding members of the photo cooperative VII and his work appears regularly in the National Geographic and Time. He has won the Robert Capa Gold Medal Award and honors from World Press Photo and Pictures of the Year International. James Estrin spoke with him about his new book, “Island of the Spirits,” while Mr. Stanmeyer was at home in the Berkshires making five-foot-long prints for an exhibit opening on Thursday at 6 p.m. at the VII Gallery, 28 Jay Street, Brooklyn. Their conversation has been edited and condensed.

headline: Craigslist Sex Ads Go Offline
text: David Carr and Brian Stelter on the media's role in shutting down sex ads on Craigslist.

headline: Wide Estimates for Fannie-Freddie Bailout Costs
text: It depends on how you count the money.

headline: The Scene: Day Eight
text: Photos from the final day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Season of Change
text: Eric Wilson discusses trends of the Spring 2011 season: minimalism, the 70s and snakeskin.

headline: Palin Steers O’Donnell to Fox News
text: Network television producers are notorious for offering all kinds of enticements to get guests to commit to interviews. At Fox News Channel, on Wednesday at least, an employee took directly to the airwaves.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘The Town’
text: Ben Affleck, the director of “The Town,” discusses a scene from the film.

headline: For Whom the Glass Is Always Half-Empty
text: PHILADELPHIA — Time is measured in martinis in “The Sun Also Rises,” Ernest Hemingway’s 1926 novel of expatriate life in Europe as one long bender. Well, martinis and Pernod and beer and Champagne and bottle after bottle of rough Spanish wine. The religiously efficient Hemingway didn’t bother wasting his terse lyricism on descriptions of drinks, usually just listing the kinds and quantities instead. Alcohol, you see, is the very element through which his characters move, and you might as well try describing oxygen.

headline: Bunker Hill to Fenway: A Crook’s Freedom Trail
text: Somewhat less generic than its title, “The Town,” directed by Ben Affleck from a script he wrote with Peter Craig and Aaron Stockard, is a solid, minor entry in the annals of Boston crime drama. Not as florid as “The Departed” or as sadly soulful as “The Friends of Eddie Coyle” — or even as sticky and gamy as “Gone Baby Gone,” Mr. Affleck’s previous film — it is essential viewing for connoisseurs of dropped r’s, close-cropped hair and aerial views of the city that used to call itself the hub of the universe.

headline: Video: Why Did Craigslist Kill Its Sex Ads?
text: Related: Craigslist Says It Has Shut Its Section for Sex Ads (Sept. 16, 2010)

headline: Getting Back to the Phantom Skill
text: This is the first in a series.

headline: New York City Battered by Fierce Storm
text: A brief but fierce storm roared through New York City on Thursday evening, throwing down trees like sticks, crippling debris-strewn neighborhoods in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, disrupting commuter rail service and killing at least one person.

headline: Separation Anxiety
text: Emma Donoghue’s remarkable new novel, “Room,” is built on two intense constraints: the limited point of view of the narrator, a 5-year-old boy named Jack; and the confines of Jack’s physical world, an 11-by-11-foot room where he lives with his mother. We enter the book strongly planted within these restrictions. We know only what Jack knows, and the drama is immediate, as is our sense of disorientation over why these characters are in this place. Jack seems happily ensconced in a routine that is deeply secure, in a setting where he can see his mother all day, at any moment. She has created a structured, lively regimen for him, including exercise, singing and reading. The main objects in the room are given capital letters — Rug, Bed, Wall — a ­wonderful choice, because to Jack, they are named beings. In a world where the only other companion is his mother, Bed is his friend as much as anything else. Jack, in this way, is a heightened version of a regular kid, bringing boundless wonder and meaning to his every pursuit.

headline: Boehner Pooh-Poohs Shutdown Talk
text: Who said anything about a government shutdown?

headline: The World Where You Aren’t What You Post
text: Nowadays, when you hear people talking about “the Facebook movie,” chances are they mean “The Social Network,” David Fincher and Aaron Sorkin’s soon-to-open inquiry into the rise of Mark Zuckerberg, one of the founders of Facebook. But the description might be even better suited to “Catfish,” a documentary by Henry Joost and Ariel Shulman that caused some hyperventilation at the Sundance Film Festival last winter.

headline: Familiarity Breeds Comfort
text: If irony is the thread that runs through modern fashion, then the Chanel cardigan jacket is the eye of the needle. Just about everyone has interpreted it. But what happens when you use a Japanese method of tie-dyeing and combine the results with soft tweed? And is there a double irony in the fact that young Japanese women are crazy about Chanel?

headline: A Meme Is Born: ‘Dude, You Have No Koran’
text: As with so many things in America these days, a planned Koran burning in Texas last week that seemed as if it might end in tears ended instead in Auto-Tuning.

headline: A Meme Is Born: ‘Dude, You Have No Koran’
text: As with so many things in America these days, a planned Koran burning in Texas last week that seemed as if it might end in tears ended instead in Auto-Tuning.

headline: Fifties Prom at Oscar de la Renta
text: This has been a season for some over-the-top ideas in evening-wear, like Carolina Herrera’s dresses that look like seed packs, and the usual assortment of jaw-dropping dresses at Marchesa. But Oscar de la Renta’s took the cake.

headline: In a Toy Shop, a Sanctuary for Nostalgia
text: The tiny soldiers that are the stars of Burlington Toys, a subterranean store at 1082 Madison Avenue, survived intact, but the Pee-wee Herman doll was put in harm’s way recently when a boiler burst and hot water cascaded inside.

headline: A Chess Center Instead of an Islamic Center?
text: The president of the World Chess Federation has offered to buy the site of the controversial Muslim community center in Lower Manhattan and build a chess center on it.

headline: Film Series and Movie Listings
text: Movies

headline: A Primitive Artist and His Patron
text: “The Man Who Ate Michael Rockefeller,” which opened at the West End Theater in September, has moved to Off Broadway. It is at the Arclight Theater, 152 West 71st Street, Manhattan; (212) 868-4444 or dogrunrep.com. Following is Rachel Saltz’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 20.

headline: New York Fashion Week | Jonathan Simkhai
text: Another season, another batch of new designers. We at T couldn’t help but notice Jonathan Simkhai. The 25-year-old Simkhai, a graduate of F.I.T. and Parsons, showed his second presentation at the Griffin club in the meatpacking district, and appears to have found “his girl.” When he popped in for a visit to the T offices, the native New Yorker identified his idealized customer as an avid boyfriend-jeans kind of girl who is discovering her ladylike sex appeal. Or as Simkhai put it, “She’s come to realize that they key to her boy’s heart is in his mother’s closet.” Which explains the mix of tomboyish cuts (long-john trousers) and girlie glamour (pleated leather skirts) — adorable and completely wearable wardrobe additions. We like.

headline: New York Fashion Week | Jonathan Simkhai
text: Another season, another batch of new designers. We at T couldn’t help but notice Jonathan Simkhai. The 25-year-old Simkhai, a graduate of F.I.T. and Parsons, showed his second presentation at the Griffin club in the meatpacking district, and appears to have found “his girl.” When he popped in for a visit to the T offices, the native New Yorker identified his idealized customer as an avid boyfriend-jeans kind of girl who is discovering her ladylike sex appeal. Or as Simkhai put it, “She’s come to realize that they key to her boy’s heart is in his mother’s closet.” Which explains the mix of tomboyish cuts (long-john trousers) and girlie glamour (pleated leather skirts) — adorable and completely wearable wardrobe additions. We like.

headline: After Delaware, G.O.P. Senate Takeover Appears Much Less Likely
text: Republicans, who are modest favorites to take over the House from Democrats, still have a chance to do the same in the United States Senate. But their odds have dropped significantly: from a 26 percent chance last week to 15 percent today, according to the FiveThirtyEight forecasting model.

headline: Nathan Myhrvold Delays Book, Apologizes to Santa
text: Well-heeled adherents of science-based gastronomy, brace yourselves for disappointment: Grub Street notices that Nathan Myhrvold has had to push back the publication date of “Modernist Cuisine.” The six-volume, 40-pound, 2,400-page, $625 book is the result of years of intensive research. As Kenneth Chang reported in 2009, Dr. Myhrvold, formerly the chief technology officer at Microsoft, “hired 15 people, including 5 professional chefs, a photographer, an art director and writers and editors.”

headline: An Olive Branch in Delaware, More or Less
text: After two days of staying mum, the state Republican Party chairman in Delaware said Thursday afternoon that the state party apparatus would work for the election in November of the party’s candidates — including, apparently, Christine O’Donnell, the party’s nominee for the Senate seat formerly held by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Shared Homeland, Different Worldview
text: The Northern Ireland-born poets Seamus Heaney and Paul Muldoon published their first books in 1966 and 1971, and ever since, their verse has been compared and contrasted, often in facile ways, as if they were Tweedledum and Tweedledee.

headline: Sukkah City
text: Glass walls with a tree-trunk roof and other takes on shelters for Sukkot which will be on display in Union Square in New York.

headline: A Harvest of Temporary Shelters
text: SUKKAHS  temporary shelters in which Jews gather to celebrate Sukkot, the harvest festival  have traditionally been made with sticks and leaves and twine. But since Buckminster Fuller created his geodesic domes, the smartest kids in architecture school have been working on their own ideas for lightweight, transportable buildings. New technologies have multiplied the possibilities.

headline: Goldman Fund Gives $20 Million for Charter School
text: From Sharon Otterman at City Room:

text: Updated, 7:31 a.m. | We’re seeing great eyewitness photo dispatches on TwitPic and Flickr, and video on YouTube and local blogs, including Gothamist, of Thursday afternoon’s fierce storm. We invite readers to share links to photographs, video and text accounts of the storm in the comment thread below.Here is some during and after footage from Brooklyn:

headline: More From Casey Affleck on ‘I’m Still Here’
text: Once Casey Affleck started explaining his real intent in filming “I’m Still Here,” the fake documentary  that seems to follow Joaquin Phoenix on a descent into celebrity hell, he just kept going — and things got more interesting.

headline: Scorecard | Proenza Schouler Wins!
text: Grey, beige, greige, taupe, moss, bone, putty… acid brights! Scorecard has been an attentive student of muted color palette naming for the sea of sportswear separates this New York fashion week, but leave it to the coolest kids in school, Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez, to do bouclé tweeds, bikinis on top — and go straight to the head of the PS11 class.

headline: Setback for Ackman in Stuyvesant Town Bid
text: From Charles V. Bagli at City Room:

headline: Being Naughty to Be Nice, as the Rumor Mill Awaits
text: Whatever else it accomplishes, the sassy high school comedy “Easy A” commands attention for the irresistible presence of Emma Stone, playing a good girl who pretends to be bad. Her performance is the best of its type since Alicia Silverstone’s star turn several high school generations ago in Amy Heckerling’s 1995 hit, “Clueless.” You can only hope that Ms. Stone has better luck with her follow-up films than Ms. Silverstone, who has never again quite hit the bull’s-eye.

headline: Nets’ New Coach Likes His ‘Blank Sheet’
text: The answer to Madison Square Garden is under construction, according to Avery Johnson, rapidly approaching his debut season as the coach of the Nets. After years of delays, the Barclays Center is being built in Brooklyn.

headline: A Coaching Tree That May Not Have Deep Roots
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Ever since Bill Belichick began winning Super Bowls in New England, he has spawned a generation of coaches cut from the same secretive cloth. That is how it goes with coaching trees. They evolve from Bill Parcells to Belichick to Eric Mangini, Romeo Crennel, Josh McDaniels.

headline: Governor? Paladino Gazes Higher
text: Carl P. Paladino, the Republicans’ choice for New York governor, may be getting a bit ahead of himself. The blustering businessman from Buffalo already seems to have visions of the White House dancing somewhere in the back of his head.

headline: Loving Couple Wonder Where the Ardor Went
text: The pangs of monogamy, the nagging worry that no matter how comfortably partnered you are, you may never again be swept away by raw animal passion: that is the uncomfortable, commonplace subject of Katie Aselton’s facetiously named film, “The Freebie.” This minimalist indie with a title appropriate for a Judd Apatow comedy, is a smart seriocomic playlet with some emotionally harsh moments, although it refrains from plumbing its subject in agonizing depth.

headline: Coming Out of Wall Street’s Closet
text: Wall Street has never been particularly hospitable to outsiders.

headline: Recession Creates an Opening for Democrat in Texas
text: HOUSTON — A few months ago, Texas political consultants thought that a Democrat had about as much chance of winning statewide office as a donkey would have of winning the Kentucky Derby. Those odds seemed to grow longer as the anti-tax, anti-government movement known as the Tea Party gathered more followers.

headline: Jets’ Revis Is Slowed by Injury
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The name alone on the injury report surely gave Jets fan shivers on Thursday. There he was  under “limited participation in practice”  Darrelle Revis, the All-Pro cornerback, with a hamstring injury.

headline: Learning to Swim in the Deep End of Life’s Pool
text: With his round, bulky middle and stubby limbs, his pink face and soft features, Jack (Philip Seymour Hoffman) resembles nothing so much as a giant baby. This impression is reinforced by his apparent inability to tackle some simple tasks of urban adult life.

headline: Hedge Fund Managers Set Up for Next Acts
text: James J. Pallotta, a legend of the hedge fund industry, is calling a do-over.

headline: Cartoonist in Hiding After Death Threats
text: A cartoonist in Seattle who promoted an “Everybody Draw Mohammed Day” last spring is now in hiding after her life was threatened by Islamic extremists.

headline: Jewish Prayers Are Modernized in New Book
text: During the Jewish “Days of Awe,” culminating with Yom Kippur, many Conservative Jews will be turning the pages of a prayer book that no longer regards God as “awesome.”

headline: Leaving an Agency Giant to Start a Boutique
text: FASHIONISTAS and fans of late-night television have Coco, and now Madison Avenue has Co  or, to be precise, Co:.

headline: German Lawmaker Insults Polish Diplomat
text: BERLIN  A leading conservative German legislator insulted a distinguished Polish diplomat on Thursday, exposing tensions between two countries still trying to overcome centuries of mistrust and enmity.

headline: Silence Follows Initial Concern for a Dazed Player
text: Immediately after the Philadelphia Eagles’ Stewart Bradley staggered to the Lincoln Financial Field turf while attempting to stand on Sunday, Fox provided the right replays and its announcers said all the right things. But Fox could have added more to the story.

headline: Roma, on Move, Test Europe’s ‘Open Borders’
text: BUCHAREST, Romania  This city is full of stark, Soviet-era housing blocks, and the grimmest among them  gray towers of one-room apartments with communal bathrooms and no hot water  are given over to the Roma population.

headline: Contemplating Life With Less Outdoor Smoking
text: Six people enjoying an afternoon in New York’s Bryant Park discuss Mayor Bloomberg’s proposed ban on smoking at city beaches, parks and plazas.

headline: Temporary Halt to Triple-Murder Trial Over Concerns on Defendant’s Health
text: NEW HAVEN  The judge at a triple-murder trial temporarily halted testimony on Thursday and sent the jury home for the weekend after defense lawyers reported that the defendant had had what appeared to be a seizure.

headline: Republican Group Sees Big  Legislature Gains
text: Republicans, who seem to be pretty confident about the midterm elections on a congressional level, also are feeling pretty good about their prospects back in the states.

headline: Security Concerns Loom Ahead of Afghan Vote
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan’s parliamentary elections on Saturday could determine whether a viable opposition remains in the legislature, but turnout  and the legitimacy of the second election in a year  hangs in the balance as voters fear waning security and brace for fraud.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Urges Denial of Diet Drug
text: A federal advisory panel on Thursday recommended against approval of a new diet pill, the latest setback in efforts to develop treatments for the nation’s obesity epidemic.

headline: Cuomo Takes Queries on Rival, but Doesn’t Answer Them
text: Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic candidate for New York governor, on Thursday made his first public appearance since Carl P. Paladino won the primary this week to become Mr. Cuomo’s Republican challenger.

headline: How to Reduce the Trade Deficit
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Citizens (Gasp) Are the Smoking Police
text: Would you mind putting your cigarette out?

headline: Tutors Made to Measure
text: On a summer afternoon, Isabel, a math tutor with long chestnut-colored hair and hoop earrings, sat in the lower-right corner of my computer screen as I wrestled with geometry problems. When I answered correctly, Isabel gave me a quick congratulatory smile. When I rushed, randomly guessing at perimeters of triangles and rectangles (geometry was never my favorite), Isabel, inferring from the speed of my keystrokes, wanted to know if I was bored. Was it because of the last problem? Did I want to choose the level of the next problem? “I think that more important than getting the answer right,” she said in words reminiscent of many a high-school teacher, “is putting in the effort and that we can all be good in math if we try.”

headline: Dial-a-Class
text: For the past few years, Andreas Haralambou has performed the same ritual. “Can I have a cellphone?” he asks his dad. “When you’re older,” his dad says.

headline: Anytime, Anywhere
text: Karen Cator, director of the office of education technology at the U.S. Department of Education, says she thinks of online learning this way: “If students have their own computer, it can travel with them from home to school. There can be software programs that help the student, or there can be an online teacher, but the technology can also augment a teacher in a face-to-face classroom.”

headline: Online Curiosity Killer
text: My older son , at 9, has spent 3.2 percent of his life on the Internet. I made that statistic up, though it sounds plausible. What’s certain is that he has spent at least three hours on the Internet, because I saw it with my own eyes, last spring, when third grade culminated with an assignment to research rain-forest animals. His animal was the anaconda, and the Internet assisted him in writing a highly factual report that touched on the snake’s habitat (semiaquatic), prey (occasional goats and ponies) and size (freaking huge).

headline: A Textbook Solution
text: The most complicated form in print media is the textbook,” Josh Koppel of ScrollMotion explained to me. “You have a 1,000-page math text with 10,000 more pages of homework assignments. You’ve got the graphic side, the text side, notation, assessment, remediation. And we need to make this all live well digitally without being subtractive.”

headline: Hacks Into Hackers
text: Last spring, Nick Bilton, an adjunct professor at New York University (and a New York Times blogger), and his technology class stashed sensors all over their floor at the Tisch School of the Arts: on elevators, in hallways, outside bathrooms, in the lounge and in classrooms. They let the sensors collect data for about 36 hours and then rounded them back up.

headline: Studying in Disguise
text: For a class in a doctoral program in psychology, we have been studying underserved and marginalized groups. For one project, our instructor required us to spend an afternoon walking in the shoes of a member of such a group — examples include a homeless person requesting money, an overweight person shopping for clothes, a same-sex couple visiting a wedding store. Is it ethical to falsely assume such an identity even for academic purposes? NAME WITHHELD, LOUISVILLE

headline: Achieving Techno-Literacy
text: This past year my wife and I home-schooled our eighth-grade son. One school day, he and I decided we would make fire the old way — out of nothing but plant materials and our own hustle. Our son watched a seemingly endless series of instructional survival videos on YouTube as part of his research. He chose the bow method based on our physics class about friction. He then constructed a bow from a branch in the woods, carved a stick for the spindle and added a fiber string. It was mighty tough going. We spent hours refining the apparatus. He was surprised by the enormous amount of bodily energy required to focus onto a very small spot, and how a minuscule, nearly invisible bit of fuel, once sparked, can quickly amplify into a flame and then a fire. Chemistry, physics, history and gym all in one lesson. And, man, when you are 13 years old and Prometheus, it’s exhilarating!

headline: The Pen That Never Forgets
text: In the spring, Cincia Dervishaj was struggling with a take-home math quiz. It was testing her knowledge of exponential notation — translating numbers like “3.87 x 10²” into a regular form. Dervishaj is a 13-year-old student at St. John’s Lutheran School in Staten Island, and like many students grappling with exponents, she got confused about where to place the decimal point. “I didn’t get them at all,” Dervishaj told me in June when I visited her math class, which was crowded with four-year-old Dell computers, plastic posters of geometry formulas and a big bowl of Lego bricks.

headline: Does the Digital Classroom Enfeeble the Mind?
text: Adding to an already rich life, my father decided in middle age to become an elementary-school teacher in a working-class neighborhood in New Mexico. To this day, people who run grocery stores and work on construction sites, and who are now in late middle age themselves, come out when I’m visiting to tell me how Mr. Lanier changed their lives. Go up to any adult with a good life, no matter what his or her station, and ask if a teacher made a difference, and you’ll always see a face light up. The human element, a magical connection, is at the heart of successful education, and you can’t bottle it.

headline: Drill, Baby, Drill
text: The word “drill” has come to define bad teaching. The piercing violence that “drilling” evokes just seems not to belong in sensitive pedagogy. Good teachers don’t fire off quiz questions and catechize kids about facts. They don’t plop students at computers to drill themselves on spelling or arithmetic. Drilling seems unimaginative and antisocial. It might even be harmful.

headline: The 8-Year-Old Programmer
text: “Our society thinks of computer programming as lucrative, therefore it must be hard and dull,” says the leader of the Kodu project, Matt MacLaurin. He says software development should be like a fourth-grade art class: explore, create, discover.

headline: The School of Hard Drives
text: This interview is for a special issue on education and technology, so let me start by asking you about computers in classrooms. As the secretary of education, do you think every kid in America needs a computer?  I think every student needs access to technology, and I think technology can be a hugely important vehicle to help level the playing field. Whether it’s in an inner-city school or a rural community, I want those students to have a chance to take A.P. biology and A.P. physics and marine biology.

headline: Jobs Recovery in City Outpaces State and U.S.
text: The job market in New York City continued to recover more strongly than in the rest of the state and the nation through the end of the summer, according to figures released Thursday by the State Labor Department.

headline: Outdoor Recreation Chain Will Open Store in SoHo
text: Yosemite. Denali. SoHo?

headline: Twins’ Gardenhire and Anderson Say: Just Throw Strikes
text: CHICAGO  The news clipping came to Ron Gardenhire this season, yellowed and creased, sent by a fan to his home in Minnesota, where he manages the Twins. It was a feature on Gardenhire from a local paper in Virginia, written in the 1980s while he played for the Tidewater Tides, then the Mets’ Class AAA affiliate.

headline: At 103, a Judge Has One Caveat: No Lengthy Trials
text: WICHITA, Kan.  Judge Wesley E. Brown’s mere presence in his courtroom is seen as something of a daily miracle. His diminished frame is nearly lost behind the bench. A tube under his nose feeds him oxygen during hearings. And he warns lawyers preparing for lengthy court battles that he may not live to see the cases to completion, adding the old saying, “At this age, I’m not even buying green bananas.”

headline: A Take on Faith and Capitalism
text: Bizarre and beautiful, disturbing and droll, “The Temptation of St. Tony” wonders what it means to be a good man. Kicking off with a quotation from Dante’s “Inferno,” this delirious sophomore feature from the Estonian filmmaker Veiko Ounpuu observes Tony (Taavi Eelmaa), a triumphantly depressed middle manager. Dissatisfied with his adulterous wife and a boss who orders him to sack all his factory workers, Tony descends into a midlife crisis that manifests itself as a series of increasingly hilarious, horrific visions.

headline: Untaxed Cigarettes Are Sold on Reservation, Mayor Says
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Thursday that an undercover investigation showed vendors on a Long Island Indian reservation sold large quantities of cigarettes on which the required taxes had not been paid.

headline: Once Wary, Obama Now Relies on Petraeus
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama descended into the White House Situation Room on Monday for his monthly update on Afghanistan and Pakistan, the new top American military commander, Gen. David H. Petraeus, ticked off signs of progress.

headline: Dismissal of Torture Case
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fiat Shareholders Approve Plan to Split the Company
text: The Fiat Group gained approval from shareholders on Thursday to spin off its industrial business from its automotive unit, a move the company hoped would lead the stock market to view the two halves more positively than the whole.

headline: Reviews Are In on Jeter’s Role as a Hit Batsman
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  About 1,200 miles Off Off Off Broadway on Wednesday night, Derek Jeter polished his acting chops, convincing an umpiring crew that a pitched ball struck his left arm when, as he later acknowledged with a smile, it did no such thing.

headline: Obama Again Attacks Funding Ruling
text: President Obama on Thursday night revived his attack on a Supreme Court decision allowing corporations to spend unlimited sums to influence elections: Free-spending businesses, he said, are making an “insidious power grab” even as most of the attention in this election year is on grassroots populism.

headline: Chief of Unit With Recalls to Exit J.&J.
text: A longtime senior executive at Johnson & Johnson in charge of the consumer products division is leaving the company early next year, signaling a shake-up after a troubling series of recalls, including of children’s Tylenol, tarnished the company’s reputation in the last year.

headline: Preventing Prison Rape
text: To the Editor:

headline: 30 Years Later, Freedom in a Case With Tragedy for All Involved
text: HATTIESBURG, Miss.  A little after 10 o’clock on Thursday morning, it was all up to Phillip Bivens. Just like that. The judge adjourned the hearing and Mr. Bivens, standing in a red jumpsuit in the corner of the courtroom, could all of a sudden do anything he wanted. After 30 years in prison, he was not sure what that was.

headline: Fashion Week Winds Down
text: Well, this is it, the last show of New York Fashion Week: Gwen Stefani’s L.A.M.B collection shown at Lincoln Center. It was probably scheduled that way just so that newspapers and bloggers could publish the headline, “Fashion Week Goes Out With a L.A.M.B.”

headline: E.U. to Ratify First Free-Trade Deal With Asian Partner
text: BRUSSELS  The European Union said Thursday that it would sign a sweeping free-trade agreement with South Korea, its first with an Asian trade partner.

headline: At Harvard, Protest Over Honoree’s Remarks About Muslims
text: BOSTON  Some Harvard University faculty members and students are objecting to a plan to honor an alumnus and editor of The New Republic because of a blog post he published this month that said Muslim life is “cheap.”

headline: Feeding the World
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Character Actor
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Feud Between Airbus and Boeing Has Given Neither Side a Clear Advantage
text: After years of hearings, millions in legal bills and political posturing on both sides of the Atlantic, the dispute over aircraft subsidies is, in many ways, back where it started five years ago.

headline: Report Says Drilling Ban Had Little Effect
text: WASHINGTON  The moratorium on deepwater oil and gas drilling imposed after the BP accident has had only modest impacts on jobs and on the Gulf Coast economy, the Obama administration said in a report issued Thursday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Sharpe Complaint Dropped
text: The woman who accused Shannon Sharpe, the CBS Sports football analyst, of forcing her to have sex with him and threatening her has dropped her complaint in Fulton County Superior Court in Georgia. She had been granted a temporary restraining order against Sharpe that is no longer in effect. This week, Sharpe took a leave from CBS’s “The NFL Today” to deal with the case and a coming hearing. He will rejoin the program Sunday.

headline: How the United Arab Emirates Sees Iran
text: To the Editor:

headline: Selecting Judges
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reader Photos of the New York Storm
text: Readers sent in their best shots of the storm in the New York City area.

headline: Don’t Enforce ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: For almost a generation, the argument against allowing gay men and lesbians to serve openly in the military rested heavily on the claim that they would damage the morale and readiness of America’s armed forces.

headline: For Yahoo, Finding Value in Asian Parts
text: Yahoo’s resistance to selling its Asian businesses is futile. The Internet company lacks direction. Its stock now trades at about half the $31-a-share offer from Microsoft that it spurned two years ago. Revenue has stagnated. And there’s friction with its partner in China. Yahoo would be worth more carved up and refocused.

headline: Brazil: President’s Chief of Staff Resigns
text: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva’s chief of staff resigned Thursday amid an ethics scandal that threatened to damage the president’s chosen candidate to succeed him in the country’s election next month. Erenice Guerra, left, who took over as chief of staff this year so that Dilma Rousseff could run for president, had come under growing pressure to step down over allegations that she participated in a scheme to receive kickbacks for public works contracts. Ms. Rousseff has not been linked directly to any wrongdoing. Despite allegations that she condoned Ms. Guerra’s conduct, Ms. Rousseff is leading by a wide margin in polls ahead of the Oct. 3 election.

headline: The Recession’s Awful Impact
text: The Census Bureau’s latest report on poverty and health insurance coverage is bleak. With millions of Americans out of work, it could hardly be otherwise.

headline: Iraq: American Airman Killed at Base
text: An American airman was killed on Thursday and a soldier wounded while detonating seized explosives at Balad, a sprawling military base north of Baghdad, the American military said in a statement. The death was the third so far this month, which began with President Obama’s formal declaration of the end of the American combat mission, and the 49th this year. Nearly 50,000 American troops remain in Iraq in advisory and support roles that nonetheless remain risky.

headline: A Summer-of-Awakening Fable
text: In “The Girl,” a languid summer-of-my-awakening movie from the Swedish director Fredrik Edfeldt, an abandoned child discovers alcohol, anatomy books and chronic constipation. Only the last requires an intervention, but not even an enema subdues the film’s resourceful heroine (the admirable Blanca Engstrom), a deceptively meek 10-year-old whose parents have jetted to Africa to tend to the welfare of other people’s children.

headline: A More Democratic Turkey
text: Turkey, already the Muslim Middle East’s sturdiest democracy, fortified its freedoms in a referendum on Sunday, with 58 percent of voters approving a package of constitutional amendments meant to end army meddling in civilian politics. That overwhelming “yes” vote showed that Turks are fed up with ultimatums and coups and want elected politicians fully in charge.

headline: St. John’s Lands Second Top Recruit
text: St. John’s Coach Steve Lavin got another significant lift with the commitment of Jakarr Sampson, a 6-foot-8 wing player considered to be one of the top-25 high school players in the nation. Sampson played at LeBron James’s former high school, St. Vincent-St. Mary in Akron, Ohio, before transferring for his senior season. He picked St. John’s over Louisville, Baylor and Tennessee and will enroll at St. John’s after this school year.

headline: Ballerinas Take a New Approach: Talking
text: Hark! They speak!

headline: Protecting the Capital’s School Reform
text: After virtually guaranteeing his election as mayor of Washington by winning a bitter Democratic primary fight, Vincent Gray tried to reassure wary middle-class voters by promising not to “turn back the clock” to when the city government was known primarily for corruption, cronyism and inefficiency.

headline: Japan: Foreign Minister Resigns
text: Japan’s foreign minister, Katsuya Okada, said Thursday that he would resign as part of what was expected to be a broad reshuffling of cabinet and party posts by the newly re-elected prime minister, Naoto Kan. Mr. Okada will take over the governing Democratic Party’s No. 2 job of secretary general, in one of the first major changes made by Mr. Kan since he fended off a challenge by the party’s power broker, Ichiro Ozawa, this week.

headline: How Not to Build It
text: The Vulkano box, which lets you record TV shows and watch them on devices other than your own television,  is nowhere near ready for prime time, David Pogue concludes.

headline: Democrats Reach Out to Hispanics on Immigration Bill
text: Democrats’ decision to put forward legislation that would grant legal status to some students who are illegal immigrants is meant to bolster support among an important voter group going into the midterms and beyond: Hispanics, the largest minority in the country.

headline: Friday: Self-Evident Truth
text: BROWN CROSSWORD WEEK continues.

headline: Using DDT to Fight Malaria
text: Dr. D. Rutledge Taylor is serious about rehabilitating the reputation of the pesticide DDT so that it can be used more widely in the developing world to battle malaria.

headline: Limiting Lundqvist, or at Least Trying To
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Rangers may not know what to expect this season, but they do know one thing: their workhorse goalie, Henrik Lundqvist, will be playing less.

headline: Long Ignored by the Mets, Perez Is Now an Option
text: Oliver Perez has pitched only three times in the last 54 days and has not started a game since May 14, which demonstrates more than anything the Mets could say about where he fits in their plans.

headline: Informer in Bomb Plot Describes His Two Lives
text: In federal court on Thursday, it was hard to tell which was more mysterious and intriguing  a government informer’s cover story, or his actual life. And sometimes, it was hard to tell where one ended and the other began.

headline: California: Plaintiffs Propose Ban in Suit Over Policy on Gays
text: The group challenging the “don’t ask, don’t tell” law regarding gays in the military has proposed a court order barring the Pentagon from enforcing the law and requiring it to halt all investigations or discharge proceedings related to the law and its regulations, which “infringe the fundamental rights” of military personnel. Judge Virginia A. Phillips of Federal District Court declared on Sept. 9 that the 1993 law is unconstitutional, and called for the Log Cabin Republicans, the plaintiffs, to file a proposed judgment and permanent injunction by Sept. 16. The Department of Justice, which defended the law, has a week to submit objections.

headline: A Look Inside Prisoners’ Lives
text: This film is designated as a Critics' Pick.

headline: Palin Stumps for Others as Her Support Dips
text: With the Republican primary season in the books, and her field of endorsed candidates either heading off to the general election or going back to the drawing board, Sarah Palin is stepping up her presence on the campaign trail to help Republicans raise money. She appeared with Rand Paul on Thursday in Louisville, Ky., where he is locked in a competitive race for the United States Senate. She is scheduled to be the headliner at the Republican Party of Iowa’s annual Reagan Dinner on Friday evening.

headline: The Backlash Myth
text: Many of my liberal friends are convinced that the Republican Party has a death wish. It is sprinting to the right-most fever swamps of American life. It will end up alienating the moderate voters it needs to win elections.

headline: New Review in Anthrax Inquiry
text: The investigative arm of Congress will conduct its own review of the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s scientific work in concluding that Bruce E. Ivins, an Army scientist, mailed the anthrax letters that killed five people in 2001. Colleagues of Dr. Ivins, who killed himself in 2008, have questioned the bureau’s finding. The review, to be conducted by the Government Accountability Office, will begin after an anthrax study by the National Academy of Sciences is completed this year. At the F.B.I.’s request, an academy panel has been looking at the genetic and chemical analysis of the powder and other work on the case by the F.B.I. and its consultants. Representative Rush Holt, Democrat of New Jersey, who has long sought an independent review of the work, praised the G.A.O.’s decision.

headline: Whitman Gives Generously to Herself
text: Attention big-spending politicians: Meg Whitman, the Republican gubernatorial candidate in California, has you all beat.

headline: The Tax-Cut Racket
text: “Nice middle class you got here,” said Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader. “It would be a shame if something happened to it.”

headline: A Model’s Diary
text: “Picture Me” seems surprised to learn that models are painfully thin, permanently tired (which tends to happen when you don’t eat), relentlessly objectified and finally disposable. They fear the effortlessly skinny 12-year-olds jostling for their jobs and the predatory photographers who place them in what one model delicately terms “compromising situations.” And then there’s all that walking.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The H.I.V. Epidemic in Washington
text: Washington has long seemed like the federal government’s illegitimate child, denied statehood and degrees of autonomy. Congress’s neglect extends to the city’s H.I.V. epidemic, a situation made agonizingly clear in Susan Koch’s quietly unblinking documentary, “The Other City.” The title derives from Washington’s split personality: as the illustrious home of politicians and monuments, and as a metropolis with the highest H.I.V. infection rate in the country.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,411 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: They Had Great Character
text: Los Angeles

headline: It Takes a Village to Raise a School
text: WHILE Americans are right to be alarmed by the rising numbers of roadside bombs and suicide attacks in Afghanistan, we can’t overlook a more subtle campaign that has been a key element of the Taliban’s strategy for years: disrupting access to schools.

headline: Record Heat Means Refunds From Con Ed
text: Try this equation: The hottest spring and summer in New York City’s history plus the highest consumption of electricity on record equals refunds for Consolidated Edison’s customers.

headline: Sox’s Wilting Season Takes Death Blow from Twins
text: Dan McGrath is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Elections Show Hurdles for Charter School Backers
text: They were the candidates of riches, flush with hundreds of thousands of dollars from Wall Street investors who believed in the promise of charter schools.

headline: New Libraries Offer New Way of Learning
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: De Blasio Seeks Answers on Voting Snarls
text: Intensifying the pressure on the city’s Board of Elections, Bill de Blasio, the public advocate, is demanding a detailed accounting of the problems that plagued the primary voting on Tuesday, as well as information about how poll workers were recruited and the training materials used to prepare them.

headline: Daley, Even as Lame Duck, Retains His Populist Appeal
text: Mayor Richard M. Daley walked with a bodyguard from Daley Plaza to City Hall on Tuesday afternoon, almost a week after announcing he will not run for a seventh term, and the political regulars noticed a change in his behavior.

headline: Nearby Oil Spill Highlights Hazards in Area’s Pipelines
text: The oil that leaked from a pipeline beneath a warehouse complex in suburban Romeoville for four days was equivalent to only several hours worth of what leaked from the BP gusher in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Cuomo on Debates, E-Mails and Whether He’s an Insider
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic nominee for governor of New York, on Thursday morning held his first news conference since Carl P. Paladino was elected to be his Republican opponent. He took close to three dozen questions on his views of Mr. Paladino, voter anger, the rest of the Democratic ticket and his own platform  but still managed to avoid offering many clear or detailed answers.

headline: A California State of Fashion
text: The number of times one heard the statement “the 90s are back” during New York shows is a reminder of how potent minimalism is in American fashion. It did seem to make a return, in a variety of forms — from the abundance of white fabrics, some of them sheer, to loose and often floor-sweeping dresses and skirts that had little detail. Some of the minimalist designers, like Francisco Costa of Calvin Klein and Narciso Rodriguez just seemed to express themselves with greater precision. Mr. Costa’s paneled dresses and coats seemed to hover between firm structure and airy volume.

headline: Transparency Emerges as Theme in Museums’ Shows and Design
text: René de Guzman’s office is a little more exposed than it was a couple of weeks ago.

headline: Predictor’s Predictions Miss Close to Home
text: Bruce Bueno de Mesquita has been dubbed “the next Nostradamus,” after the 16th-century French apothecary whom some have credited with the ability to predict coming world events.

headline: U.C. Proxy Voting Skirts Review Guidelines, Documents Show
text: The University of California, which prides itself as a leader on social and environmental issues, voted against hundreds of shareholder resolutions designed to promote human rights, environmental sustainability and efforts to fight discrimination, a review of U.C.’s voting record shows.

headline: Bloggingheads: Inequality in America
text: Timothy Noah, left, of Slate and Mickey Kaus of kausfiles debate social and income inequality.

headline: Jon Stewart Plans to Rally Against Extremism
text: Jon Stewart plans a rally in  Washington to  confront what he calls extremism on both sides.

headline: Jon Stewart Plans to Rally Against Extremism
text: Jon Stewart announced his much-awaited “big announcement” on Thursday’s edition of his late-night program, “The Daily Show.” He plans to stage a rally in Washington to counter what he identified as extremists on either side of the political spectrum.

headline: Jon Stewart Plans Washington Rally
text: Bill Carter reports on Media Decoder how Jon Stewart is planning a march in Washington against extremism on both sides of the political spectrum.

headline: Jon Stewart Plans Washington Rally
text: Bill Carter reports on Media Decoder how Jon Stewart is planning a march in Washington against extremism on both sides of the political spectrum.

headline: Expo in Shanghai Raises Questions About Fair in Bay Area
text: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

headline: John Freeborn, British Fighter Pilot, Dies at 90
text: Seventy years ago, John Freeborn was one of the Royal Air Force’s leading fighter pilots, acclaimed for his exploits off Dunkirk and in the air above English villages during the Battle of Britain.

headline: Documenting the Storm
text: Images by Times readers of a violent storm on Thursday and its aftermath.

headline: Word of the Day | ethnic
text: ethnic •\ˈeth-nik\• adjective/noun

headline: All About Deflowering
text: “The Virginity Hit” takes a device — or a style, if you’re feeling generous — that’s become familiar in horror movies and applies it to the teenage sex comedy. The story, about the last of a quartet of high school buddies to lose his virginity (and thereby win the privilege of a ceremonial bong hit), is presented in the guise of amateur videos that are being posted on YouTube. When the on-screen high jinks are sufficiently embarrassing, the videos go viral.

headline: Edward Norton as Good-Bad Twins
text: Who doesn’t love a good-twin/bad-twin story? Or, in the case of “Leaves of Grass,” a dandy new film written and directed by Tim Blake Nelson, a straight-twin/stoned-twin story?

headline: Countrywide Suit Cleared for Trial
text: Angelo Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial, lost a bid to have a government lawsuit on claims he misled investors about risks tied to subprime lending thrown out of court.

headline: Wolves in Love
text: From far down the animation pecking order, where Pixar, DreamWorks and Studio Ghibli are only rumors, comes “Alpha and Omega,” the first in a series of films produced by Lionsgate and the Mumbai-based Crest Animation. This talking-animal tale — the title refers to the strata of wolf society, which are broken down in the name of true love between an alpha female and an omega male — has old-fashioned backgrounds that occasionally achieve a touch of grandeur, but that’s about the best that can be said for it.

headline: News Quiz | September 17, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: City Workers Clear Debris in Aftermath of Fierce Storm
text: From the air, some neighborhoods in Brooklyn and Queens looked like Lego masterpieces that angry children had done their best to sweep aside.

headline: The Story of a Comical Misfit
text: “Last Day of Summer” had a chance to be a decent movie, but Vlad Yudin, who directed and wrote it, couldn’t resist a potty joke. A long, grating potty joke.

headline: a Woman Alone on an Island
text: “The Anchorage,” which stars the director Anders Edstrom’s mother, Ulla, as a woman living alone on a Swedish island, has been cited as an example of the blurring of the lines between documentary and fiction. What it really demonstrates, however, is that when not much interesting is happening on-screen, those lines truly don’t matter.

headline: I.B.M.: Africa Is the Next Growth Frontier
text: Samuel J. Palmisano, I.B.M.’s chief executive, doesn’t jet around the world to make an appearance every time the technology giant wins a services contract. But the announcement Friday morning in Nairobi is different, says I.B.M.

headline: Hedge Fund Managers Set Up for Next Acts
text: James J. Pallotta, a legend of the hedge fund industry, is calling a do-over, Julie Creswell writes in The New York Times.

headline: Louisville, Ky., as a Contemporary Music Hub
text: A singular harmonic convergence is recounted in “Music Makes a City,” Owsley Brown III and Jerome Hiler’s enlightening documentary about how Louisville, Ky., became a locus for contemporary music in the mid-20th century. In striking synchronicity, a mayor, a con- ductor and a robust postwar generation of composers inter- sected to make the city a hub for visionary composition.

headline: Oracle Profit Rises 20%, Higher Than Forecast
text: Fresh off a radical overhaul of its executive suite, Oracle told investors on Thursday that its house remained in order, Ashlee Vance writes in The New York Times.

headline: Test Yourself | History, September 17, 2010
text: Test your knowledge of history with today’s question about the Civil War, from On This Day in History.

headline: Countrywide Suit Cleared for Trial
text: Angelo Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial, lost a bid to have a government lawsuit on claims he misled investors about risks tied to subprime lending thrown out of court, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Fiat Shareholders Approve Company Split
text: The Fiat Group gained approval from shareholders on Thursday to spin off its industrial business from its automotive unit, a move the company hoped would lead the stock market to view the two halves more positively than the whole, David Jolly writes in The New York Times.

headline: For Yahoo, Finding Value in Asian Parts
text: From Reuters Breakingviews:

headline: A Baby Step Toward Rules On Bank Risk
text: From Floyd Norris’s latest column in The New York Times:

headline: Japan to Seek Global Understanding on Yen
text: Japan will try to dispel international criticism of its yen-selling intervention by highlighting the damaging impact of the currency’s climb on an economy mired in deflation, the finance minister said on Friday, Reuters reports.

headline: A Poet Who Wants a Change
text: The sustaining joke of “The Happy Poet,” an indie comedy written and directed by Paul Gordon, is that the poet wants to be happy but doesn’t really know how to go about it. It’s a pretty good joke, and Mr. Gordon tells it with enough discipline and invention to make a significant portion of the film funny in interesting, subversive ways.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Exeleutherostomize
text: Today’s word, in association with the mighty Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: TDC to Sell Swiss Telecom Unit to CVC Funds
text: TDC Group, the Danish telecom, said Friday that it would sell its Swiss subsidiary Sunrise to investment funds advised by CVC Capital Partners, the private equity group, for 3.3 billion Swiss francs ($3.25 billion) — the largest takeover in the European telecommunications sector this year.

headline: What’s Special About Your Hometown?
text: The New York Times In Transit blog has announced an open call for reader-submitted videos about the places to see in their hometowns. If you could be a “video tour guide” of your city or town, what would you include? What offbeat places not on the typical tourist list would you suggest? Why?

headline: Democrats Use Power of Majority to Pursue Agenda
text: The Senate on Thursday approved a multi-billion dollar package of tax breaks and government-backed loans for small businesses, as Democrats sought to use the muscle of their majorities to pursue a Congressional agenda that would make their case for retaining control in the House and Senate this fall, The New York Times’s David M. Herszenhorn reported.

headline: Tourists in Space
text: HOW could Boeing help transform NASA, according to this article?

headline: Spain’s A.C.S. Confirms $3.53 Billion Bid for Hochtief
text: The Spanish construction firm Actividades de Construcción y Servicios confirmed Thursday that it had offered 2.7 billion euros ($3.53 billion) to gain full control of its German rival Hochtief, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Picking Up the Slack on Global Banking Rules
text: From Simon Johnson at Economix:

headline: Cheyne Said to Get $100 million for M.&A. fund
text: Cheyne Capital, the hedge fund manager, has raised more than $100 million for a fund to ride an expected surge in corporate activity such as mergers among medium-sized European firms, a source close to the group told Reuters.

headline: Leaving Ad Giant to Start a Boutique
text: Fashionistas and fans of late-night television have Coco, and now Madison Avenue has Co — or, to be precise, Co:.

headline: Mexico: Newspaper Intern Killed
text: A 21-year-old photography intern for a newspaper in Ciudad Juárez was shot and killed, and another intern was wounded in an attack Thursday at a shopping mall parking lot, their employer said. The shooting comes a week after the Committee to Protect Journalists released a report documenting the deaths or disappearance of more than 30 journalists since Mexico began a crackdown on traffickers that have left more than 28,000 people dead. Eight journalists have been killed this year, the group said. The pair of interns, from El Diario de Juárez, were attacked in their car by gunmen firing several rounds, leaving Luís Carlos Santiago dead. His unidentified companion was being treated at a hospital.

headline: Diaspora, a Facebook Alternative, Releases Its Code
text: From Nick Bilton at Bits:

headline: Mitchells & Butlers Gobbles Up Ha Ha’s
text: Mitchells & Butlers, the British pubs and restaurants group, has agreed to buy Ha Ha Bar & Grill, a restaurant chain, for £19.5 million ($30.6 million), bulking out its food business in a drive to lift margins, Reuters reported.

headline: London Fund Industry Under Threat, Bosses Warn
text: Britain’s strong position in the global fund management industry could be hit by government plans to curb immigration as well as higher tax and competition from rival financial centres, top industry executives warned.

headline: Diamondback Partner Quits Fund to Join Tudor
text: Larry Petrella, a partner with Diamondback Capital Partners, is leaving the $4 billion hedge fund for a top job with Tudor Investment, Reuters reported, citing people familiar with the two funds.

headline: Convoy Carries South Korean Rice Donations to the North
text: SEOUL, South Korea  A convoy of trucks crossed the border with North Korea on Friday, carrying the first South Korean rice donations for North Korea in nearly three years, as officials from both Koreas huddled to discuss the reunion of families separated by the Korean War six decades ago.

headline: Price May Drop at 2nd Auction of Philly Newspapers

headline: France and Germany Spar Over Policies on Roma
text: BERLIN  European tempers over the treatment of Roma immigrants flared again on Friday, as President Nicolas Sarkozy of France said the Germans were preparing to follow France’s lead and expel migrant Roma, while German officials denied they had said any such thing.

headline: Shell Sells Norwegian Field for $225 Million
text: Royal Dutch Shell says it has agreed to sell its stake in the Statfjord oil field in the Norwegian North Sea and several related assets to Centrica Resources for $225 million, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Mulling $2.3 Billion Crucell Bid
text: Johnson & Johnson, the American health products company, said Friday that it was in advanced talks to bid for the 82 percent of Crucell, a Dutch biopharmaceutical firm, that it does not already own, in what would be a 1.75 billion euro ($2.3 billion) deal.

headline: British Police Hold 6 on Terror Charges as Pope Visits
text: LONDON — As Pope Benedict XVI embarked on some of the most symbolic passages of his trip here, the British police arrested six street cleaners on Friday on terrorism charges related to his state visit but gave no details of any threat against him.

headline: Paris Celebrates the American Writer
text: Paris has a hallowed place in American literary lore. Its beauty, art and atmospheric cafes have inspired writers like Wharton, Hemingway and Fitzgerald. A new chapter of this tradition opens later this month, with the kickoff of Festival America, a gathering that will assemble 60 North American authors for discussions, readings and more, from Sept. 23 to 26.

headline: China’s BYD in Strategic Move for Tibet Miner
text: BYD Company, the Chinese battery and car maker that counts Warren E. Buffett as an investor, said Friday it has agreed to buy an 18 percent stake in a Tibetan-based lithium and boron miner, moving to secure a strategically vital asset for its future growth, The Associated Press reported.

headline: 3i Dealmaker to Leave in Shake-Up
text: 3i Group, the British private equity firm, said that Jonathan Russell, one of its top dealmakers, would leave as part of a shake up announced on Friday that will combine two of its key divisions, Reuters reported.

headline: Week 1 Accuracy: Which Fantasy Experts Gave Winning Advice?
text: David Kim is the co-founder of FantasyPros, a site that rates the accuracy of fantasy experts and provides simple tools that reduce the time and stress involved in making good fantasy decisions.

headline: Can Dylan Help Us All Get Along?
text: Today’s idea: Does Bob Dylan bridge the bitter political divide between America’s credentialed “ruling class” and its “country class” of government-averse individualists? Maybe, a writer says.

text: Statoil, Norway’s largest oil and gas company, has tapped Bank of America, Citigroup and ABG Sundal Collier to manage the initial public offering of its fuel and retail unit, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people with knowledge of the transaction.

headline: An iPod Speaker Dock Goes Vertical

headline: Do I Push Aside Existing Customers to Take a Big Order?
text: Thanks for all of the comments on my recent post about my three problems. I reviewed the first problem on Monday, the second Wednesday. Now, let’s turn to the third. I’d like to add some further thoughts — and tell you what I have decided to do.

headline: Vodafone Chief Says He Won’t Be a ‘Forced Seller’
text: Vodafone shareholders hoping for a quick sell-off of the British telecom’s minority stakes may not want to get their hopes up, despite the company’s recent move to unload its 3.2 percent share of China Mobile.

headline: Elizabeth Warren: ‘I Accept’
text: President Obama is expected to announce in a Rose Garden ceremony Friday afternoon that he is appointing Elizabeth Warren to head the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau as his assistant. But hours before the formal announcement, Ms. Warren issued a folksy message on the White House Blog about why she is taking on the job.

headline: Was It a Tornado?
text: Today it’s all about the storm. We warned of thunderstorms on Thursday but, boy, we didn’t see that coming. We expect to hear sometime on Friday whether officials think it was a tornado that cut a deadly swath from Staten Island, through Park Slope and Bushwick in Brooklyn and into Queens. Service on the Long Island Rail Road, stopped on Thursday, was more or less back to normal Friday morning, although the Port Washington branch was still out of service, and all city schools were open, with the exception of John Bowne High School in Flushing, Queens, which was pummeled by the storm.

headline: Citi to Sell Its Student Loan Unit
text: 8:45 a.m. | Updated Citigroup said Friday that it will sell its big student loan business to Sallie Mae and Discover Financial Services for $600 million.

headline: Ford’s Global Focus to Premier in Paris
text: Ford will strut its stuff internationally at the Paris Auto Show later this month. The automaker announced this week that it would introduce the global range of Focus automobiles at the show.

headline: Fast Food, and a Couple of Supersized Jets

headline: JPMorgan Said to Eye Lehman’s London Offices

headline: You’re ‘So Coal': Angling to Shame Facebook

headline: More Fake Things Casey Affleck Would Like You to Know Are Fake
text: Casey Affleck shook up a nation trying to quietly go about its business on Thursday when he revealed that his documentary, “I’m Still Here,” in which an apparently drug-addled Joaquin Phoenix purports to give up acting to pursue a rap career, and whose veracity had been questioned from the moment Mr. Phoenix gave an incoherent interview to David Letterman in 2009, was in fact an elaborate performance stunt. The news jolted many Internet denizens who quickly took to their Web platform of choice to remind us they had suspected Mr. Affleck and Mr. Phoenix’s charade for more than a year.

headline: Horizon Wireless
text: Imagine getting a bit lost in, say, Manchester, England, pointing your cellphone at a nondescript building and learning instantly that you’ve chanced across a legendary pub that opens 30 minutes from now — and, by the way, a nearby rare-vinyl shop is offering a 20 percent discount, today only. Oh, and just down the block is a bistro that is never mentioned in guidebooks but is beloved by locals.

A compendium of “The Walking Dead” comics, which reprints the first 48 of that series (and runs more than 1,000 pages), is at No. 7 on the softcover list this week. For more meaty details on the television program, which has its debut on Oct. 31, AMC has set up a Web site with a zombie gallery, a trailer and production photos.

headline: Extraordinary Elite Delusions and the Madness of Committees
text: Future historians will marvel at the austerity madness that gripped policy elites in the spring of 2010. In a combination of blind panic and irrational exuberance, organizations from the ECB to the OECD suddenly abandoned everything we’ve learned, at bitter cost, about the economics of recessions, and raced to the conclusion that fiscal austerity was the way to go in the depths of a slump — indeed, that it would actually be expansionary.

headline: She Won’t Forget About Him: Molly Ringwald Remembers John Hughes

headline: Is This the Real Life? ‘Borat’ Star to Play Freddie Mercury in Queen Movie

headline: Runway Beauty | Oscar de la Renta
text: “Oscar and I were talking about debutantes, girls dressing up for the first time,” said the hairstylist Orlando Pita at the Oscar de la Renta show. “I remembered Grace Kelly had this hairstyle at her wedding,” he continued, referring to the doughnut-shaped bun atop the head of the model Caroline Trentini, sitting behind him. “We’re exaggerating the volume a bit because we have to think about proportion — some of Oscar’s dresses are quite big, and we didn’t want it to look like a ballerina bun.” Hair was put in a ponytail, around which was fastened a foam ring that back-combed pieces were pinned under, then coated with Frederic Fekkai Sheer Hold Hairspray.

headline: Inside the List
text: BREATHE: “Getting to Happy,” Terry McMillan’s sequel to “Waiting to Exhale,” hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 4. “Waiting to Exhale” had a 38-week run on the hardcover list back in 1992-93, long before the title made everyone think of yoga. McMillan’s four Phoenix women have been a bit banged up by life — only one is happily married — but their you-go-girl spirit seems intact, as is the author’s, despite a bruising and very public divorce. “I can’t tell you how many women I see who are 55 and you’d swear they were 88,” McMillan recently told The News & Observer of Raleigh, N.C. “They say, ‘I don’t care if I never have sex again,’ and I think, ‘What is wrong with this picture?’ ”

headline: Ireland/Spain Update
text: Regular readers may remember that I’ve written a few posts — here and here — about bond yields in Ireland and Spain. Both had big housing bubbles and busts; but their post-bust politics have been very different, with Ireland quickly adopting austerity, Spain being much more grudging. And for a while you saw many news stories asserting that Ireland’s virtue had been rewarded by the markets.

headline: Why High Turnout May Not Help Paladino in November

headline: ‘Promises, Promises’ Will Close, but Questions Remain
text: One of Broadway’s biggest commercial hits of the year, the Sean Hayes-led revival of the musical “Promises, Promises,” will close on Jan. 2, the producers announced on Thursday night. The decision to close the show only nine months after opening is another reminder of the premium that producers put on star casting on Broadway — and the high costs and unpredictability of re-casting.

headline: Up Front: Julie Myerson
The Violence of Bereavement
text: Few writers are as energetic and prolific as Joyce Carol Oates, but reading her also requires a particular kind of energy. I’ve always been unsettled and exhilarated by her work. Hers is an intensely truthful, explicitly emotional yet sometimes nightmarishly heightened world. For just the same reason, I’m often left exhausted by it as well. “Sourland,” her latest collection of short fiction, begins and ends with stories featuring graphic and violent sexual encounters, and the tangle of tales that lie in between explore emotional, physical and sexual hazard in all its forms. Bedtime reading this isn’t.

headline: Fibbing With Numbers
text: Charles Seife is steaming mad about all the ways that numbers are being twisted to erode our democracy. We’re used to being lied to with words (“I am not a crook”; “I did not have sexual relations with that woman”). But numbers? They’re supposed to be cold, hard and objective. Numbers don’t lie, and they brook no argument. They’re the best kind of facts we have.

headline: The Plot Escapes Me
text: Those were glorious days, the ones I spent reading “Perjury: The Hiss-Chambers Case,” by Allen Weinstein. It is a book that I, having long had an interest in domestic Communist intrigues, had been meaning to read for years — decades — and I vividly remember that moment a couple of summers ago when, on my way to visit friends in New Hampshire, I found a hardcover copy in good condition at a restaurant-cum-used-book-store.

headline: Cold Cases
text: The subtitle of BETWEEN SUMMER’S LONGING AND WINTER’S END (Pantheon, $27.95) gives fair notice that Leif GW Persson’s political thriller, the first book in an ambitious trilogy by this Swedish author, is “The Story of a Crime.” But that won’t stop anyone from diving into it in hopes of discovering the next best thing to Stieg Larsson’s addictive Millennium trilogy.

headline: The Age of Citation
text: Imagine that this essay began not with the sentence you’re reading, but with the following observation, attributed to Wittgenstein: “A picture held us captive. And we could not get outside it, for it lay in our language and language seemed to repeat it to us inexorably.” A little oblique for an opening gambit, you might think, but presumably it will pay off shortly. Imagine further, however, that the Wittgenstein quotation was immediately followed by quotes from Simone Weil, the Upanishads and the Hungarian poet Gyorgy Petri. At this point, you might find yourself wondering, “O.K., when is the actual author going to actually give me something he actually wrote?”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: C,  by Tom McCarthy (Knopf, $25.95.) McCarthy’s tour de force follows its hero from a rural English estate, to a German spa, to the killing fields of France, to interwar London and beyond; at its deepest level, the novel is a rigorous inquiry into our need for meaning.

headline: Paperback Row
text: A GATE AT THE STAIRS,  by Lorrie Moore (Vintage Contemporaries, $15.) The heroine of Moore’s powerful novel is a Wisconsin college student coming of age in 2001. She yearns for experience and finds it when she takes a job as a nanny for a yuppie couple who are in the process of adopting a mixed-race child, but neither they nor her exotic boyfriend are who they seem to be. Moore may be “the most irresistible contemporary American writer: brainy, humane, unpretentious and warm,” our reviewer, Jonathan Lethem, said. The novel was one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2009.
