headline: Kidman Coming Back to Broadway in ‘Sweet Bird of Youth’
text: The Academy Award-winning actress Nicole Kidman plans to return to Broadway in the fall of 2011 to star in a revival of the Tennessee Williams play “Sweet Bird of Youth,” to be directed by David Cromer (“Our Town”), a spokesman for the production said on Friday. Ms. Kidman was last on Broadway, in her debut, in the 1998-99 season production of David Hare’s play “The Blue Room.” That show drew mixed reviews but was a hugely tough ticket to come by, given Ms. Kidman’s star appeal.

headline: Tampering Leads to Rare Penalty Against Agent
text: By standard measures, Quincy Douby’s N.B.A. career has been fleeting and forgettable. He entered the league in 2006, played sparingly for three seasons and never averaged more than 5 points before playing last season in Turkey.

headline: Straw Into Gold
text: In the summer of 2009, the atrium of the Museum of Modern Art in New York was the site of a remarkable installation by the conceptual artist Song Dong. Its title, “Waste Not,” referred to a Communist government slogan exhorting the Chinese people to cope with their near-constant shortages and privations by practicing a vigilant form of salvage: nothing durable, however worn or dubious its utility, should be discarded. Song Dong’s mother appears to have followed the directive with unusual zeal, and after his father died in 2002, Song Dong decided her grief might be assuaged if she collaborated with him on a project that would alchemize into art the vast heaps of detritus she had accumulated over decades of state-encouraged hoarding. The result — an ingeniously arranged labyrinth of pens, cookware, buttons, magazines, clothing, shoes, plastic bottles, toys — was powerfully affecting. Walking through the grid of ribbons, buttons, toothpaste tubes, combs and gramophones was a challenge to consider how much our possessions say about us, how eloquently the humblest domestic artifacts communicate the joys and sorrows of family life, and how we can never save enough to protect ourselves from the inevitability of loss.

headline: Firms’ Rankings Are Released, Without Calamity
text: At long last, U.S. News & World Report this week released its highly scrutinized and anticipated law firm rankings, and, wouldn’t you know, Steven Naifeh’s world has not come crashing down.

headline: Mystery Diva
text: In 1874, Sarah Bernhardt wrote a letter to Jean Mounet-Sully, her lover and leading man, in which this great French actress and self-dramatist seemed, for once, to stop performing. He would never be enough for her, she wrote, because she was “not made for happiness.” She was made for sensation: “My heart demands more excitement than anyone can give it. . . . I’m an incomplete person.”

headline: Greta Garbo, 84, Screen Icon Who Fled Her Stardom, Dies
text: Greta Garbo, the enigmatic and elusive star of some of Hollywood's most memorable romantic movies of the 1930's and a 50-year focus of curiosity and myth, died yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. She was 84 years old.

headline: Defense Command Filled As 2 More Take Service Oath
text: Washington, Sept. 18--The top ranks in the new national military establishment were filled today when oaths were taken by John L. Sullivan as Secretary of the Navy and by W. Stuart Symington as the Secretary of the now independent Air Force.

headline: William Golding Is Dead at 81; The Author of 'Lord of the Flies'
text: William Golding, the Nobel Prize-winning author of the classic "Lord of the Flies" and other disturbing novels exploring the dark side of human nature, died yesterday in his home in Perranarworthal, England. He was 81.

headline: The President Dead
text: The sad announcement came at 11 o'clock last night that President Garfield had breathed his last at 10:35, thus putting an end to the long weeks of suffering he has endured. His condition yesterday, aside from a slight rigor in the early morning, was apparently more favorable than it had been on Sunday, and his surgeons and attendants, though realizing the fact that he was in an extremely critical state, were inclined to hope that he might grow better after all. At a few minutes after 10 o'clock last night, however, the sufferer complained of a severe pain in the region of the heart and almost immediately became unconscious. Dr. Bliss, who was hastily called, at once announced that he was dying, and Mrs. Garfield and the consulting surgeons were summoned. Within 15 minutes President Garfield had drawn his last breath and the sorrowful intelligence was being sent with lightning speed throughout the country. Everywhere, notwithstanding the lateness of the hour, the bells were tolled as a mark of respect and sorrow for the long-suffering, patient, and heroic President.

headline: Mrs. King Defeats Riggs, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3, Amid a Circus Atmosphere
text: Houston, Sept. 20--Mrs. Billie Jean King struck a proud blow for herself and women around the world with a crushing 6-4, 6-3, 6-3 rout of Bobby Riggs tonight in their $100,000 winner- take-all tennis match at the Astrodome.

headline: Upton Sinclair, Author, Dead; Crusader for Social Justice, 90
text: BOUND BROOK, N.J., Nov. 25--Upton Sinclair, who crusaded against the nation's social and economic ills in 90 books, died in his sleep tonight at the Somerset Valley Nursing Home. He was 90 years old.

headline: Henry L. Stimson Dies at 83 In His Home on Long Island
text: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 20--Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of War, died here at 4 P. M. today in his home, Highhold, West Hills. He had celebrated his eighty-third birthday on Sept. 21.

headline: John Houseman, Actor and Producer, 86, Dies
text: John Houseman, who spent more than half a century in the theater as an influential producer and director but who did not achieve fame until, at the age of 71, he portrayed a crusty law school professor in the film ''The Paper Chase'' and its subsequent television series, died of spinal cancer yesterday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 86 years old and despite his failing health had been working on various projects until three days ago.

headline: Nixon Leaves Fate To G.O.P. Chiefs; Eisenhower Calls Him To A Talk; Stevenson Maps Inflation Curbs
text: Los Angeles, Sept. 23--Senator Richard M. Nixon, in a nation-wide television and radio broadcast tonight, defended his $18,235 "supplementary expenditures" fund as legally and morally beyond reproach.

headline: Scott Fitzgerald, Author, Dies at 44
text: HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22 (AP)--F. Scott Fitzgerald, novelist, short story writer and scenarist, died at his Hollywood home yesterday. His age was 44. He suffered a heart attack three weeks ago.

headline: Clinton, at U.N., Signs Treaty Banning All Nuclear Testing
text: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 24 -- President Clinton signed a treaty today that would ban all nuclear weapons testing and called on world leaders to take further steps to limit weapons of mass destruction. He also urged them to show 'zero tolerance' for international drug smuggling and for terrorism.

headline: President Sends Troops to Little Rock, Federalizes Arkansas National Guard; Tells Nation He Acted to Avoid An Anarchy
text: Washington, Sept. 24--President Eisenhower sent Federal troops to Little Rock, Ark., today to open the way for the admission of nine Negro pupils to Central High School.

headline: Faulkner's Home, Family and Heritage Were Genesis of Yoknapatawpha County
text: The storm of literary controversy that beat about William Faulkner is not likely to diminish with his death. Many of the most firmly established critics of literature were deeply impressed by the stark and somber power of his writing. Yet many commentators were repelled by his themes and his prose style.

headline: Chechen Is Detained, Then Freed, in Poland
text: MOSCOW  A self-described leader of Chechnya’s separatist movement, wanted in Russia on charges of murder, kidnapping and terrorism, was detained by the police on Friday in Poland, where he planned to attend a gathering of Chechen exiles.

headline: Evolving Circumstances, Enduring Values
text: “If my fellow citizens want to go to hell,” Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes once wrote, “I will help them. It’s my job.” This, for much of the last century, has stood as the purest (or at least the most pungent) distillation of “judicial restraint” — the idea that judges should, for better or worse, leave the business of governing to the people’s duly elected representatives. As practiced by the jaundiced Holmes, restraint was often a shrug of the shoulders: lawmakers, in his view, were predisposed to foolishness, and the Constitution entitled them, in most cases, to be fools.

headline: Unions Find Members Slow to Rally Behind Democrats
text: The Democrats will depend on labor unions — the shock troops of their political campaigns — to offset two new developments this election cycle: Tea Party enthusiasm and corporations’ ability to spend unlimited amounts thanks to a Supreme Court ruling.

headline: California Licenses World’s Biggest Solar Thermal Plant
text: California regulators have licensed what is for the moment the world’s largest solar thermal power plant, a 1,000-megawatt complex called the Blythe Solar Power Project to be built in the Mojave Desert.

headline: Last of 5 Parts, Answers to Your Back-to-School Questions
text: Mr. Dingledine, an independent college counselor in Greenville, S.C., has been responding this week to selected questions from readers of The Choice. His answers conclude today, but you may post a comment using the comment box below, or on the original post. Some questions, and answers, have been edited for space and style. –Jacques Steinberg

text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to submit fool’s errands.

headline: Contemplating Controversy: The Proposed Islamic Center Near Ground Zero
text: Note: The article we are using for this lesson comes from the Sept. 20 issue of The New York Times Upfront. Upfront is a newsmagazine for teenagers published by Scholastic in partnership with The New York Times.

headline: High-End Car Show Thrives, Despite Economy
text: High-end car shows, or concours d’élégance, popped up all over the country during the last economic boom. In these tougher times, many events — for lack of sponsorship or participation — have been forced to either scale back, move to less appealing locations or in some cases go away altogether.

headline: The Metafictional Club
text: Before taking up a novel like Scarlett Thomas’s “Our Tragic Universe,” with its playful and portentous fixations on riddles, paradoxes and Zen koans, it may be helpful to engage in a few preliminary thought experiments. Is a seed placed in a pot and covered with dirt and water a flower? Is an assortment of bread, meat, cheese and condiments piled on a plate a sandwich? And is a sequence of fictional events, populated by characters and imbued with subtexts and recurring themes, a novel? In the abstract we cannot know, but in specific cases we should be able to answer conclusively. So how is it that this lively and thoughtful book possesses all the requisite elements of the thing it wants to be, and is so self-aware of what its components should be, yet lacks the essential spark that would make it a satisfying work of literature?

headline: Runway Beauty | L’Wren Scott
text: The Serengeti-inspired color palette L’Wren Scott used for her spring collection was also the basis for the show’s hair and makeup. “L’Wren gave me fabric samples about three months ago,” said Lancôme’s artistic director for makeup, Aaron de Mey, who seemed preternaturally calm an hour before showtime (possibly thanks to all that notice, and perhaps also because he was departing for Capri immediately after the presentation). “I was inspired by Kiki de Montparnasse — she matched her eye makeup to her outfits,” he said. “It’s an old-fashioned idea, but a quirky one too.” To wit, he custom blended 10 shadows to match each models’ look and applied them over matte black so the effect wasn’t “too junior,” as de Mey put it.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘The Town’
text: TORONTO — Returning to the streets of Boston for his second feature as a director, Ben Affleck looks at how crime both holds a community together and tears it apart in “The Town.” Mr. Affleck discussed a scene from his film, in which he stars with Jeremy Renner and Rebecca Hall.

headline: Lightening the Health Care Load for Small Businesses
text: BETSY BURTON feels as if she dodged a bullet. At 64 and a co-owner of the King’s English Bookshop in Salt Lake City, she has been in business for 33 years and employs 25. Her shop provides health insurance to seven full-time employees.

headline: Health Care Relief for Small Businesses
text: Small businesses struggling to provide health benefits to workers may win some much needed relief under the new health reform law, reports Walecia Konrad in today’s Patient Money column.

headline: Hall of Mirrors
text: The Chilean writer Roberto Bolaño has to be one of the most improbable international literary celebrities since William Burroughs and Henry Miller, two writers whose work Bolaño’s occasionally resembles. His subjects are sex, poetry, death, solitude, violent crime and the desperate glimmers of transcendence that sometimes attend them. The prose is dark, intimate and sneakily touching. His lens is largely (though not literally) autobiographical, and seems narrowly focused at first. There are no sweeping historical gestures in Bolaño. Yet he has given us a subtle portrait of Latin America during the last quarter of the 20th century — a period of death squads, exile, “disappeared” citizens and state-sponsored terror. The nightmarish sense of human life being as discardable as clay permeates his writing.

headline: 30 Arrests and a Cloud of Dust
text: Being a college football fan these days requires almost superhuman abilities. It takes an iron stomach to swallow the Bowl Championship Series system and industrial strength blinders to ignore the endless parade of N.C.A.A. rules shenanigans, including monstrously overpaid coaches blaming everything short of a meteor shower for their programs’ latest ethical crises. It takes a hermetic seal between your hands and your eyes to miss the fantastic moral tap dancing that Reggie Bush keeps doing even after he became the first player to give up his Heisman Trophy.

headline: The Greater Terror
text: Fiction can do whatever it pleases; it’s just got to bring it off, that’s all.

headline: In Mezuzas, a Custom Inherited by Gentiles
text: The doorways inside 30 Ocean Parkway, an Art Deco building in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, are studded with mezuzas of all sizes and styles: plastic, pewter, simple, gaudy, elegant.

headline: Multistrada 1200: A Do-It-All Ducati for Adventurers and Commuters
text: IT used to be so easy for riders to choose among the major European motorcycle makers.

headline: Tailoring the Ride, Electronically
text: IN the race for performance and safety supremacy, features like traction control, antilock brakes and ride-by-wire throttle with multiple engine-control modes have almost become a new standard. These are indeed standard on the $19,995 Ducati Multistrada 1200 S, along with an electronically adjustable suspension — but not on the Multistrada 1200, with its $5,000 lower list price.

headline: In Great Recession, Other Nations Have Suffered More
text: THE Great Recession in America more than earned that title. But by international standards, it was not that bad.

headline: A Town, a Team, a Dream Deferred
text: A vexing problem in applying social weight to contemporary athletics is that so many of the Prome­thean sport-and-society battles have already been fought. Jack Johnson was a boxing champion during perhaps the nation’s most virulently racist post-bellum period. Jesse Owens, at the 1936 Olympics in Berlin, discredited the Aryan-­supremacy subtext that would underlie World War II. Jackie Robinson integrated baseball and, more important, modern American society. Muhammad Ali transformed the attitude of black athletes and made them a political force. Marvin Miller razed the century-old system of indentured servitude, leading to the zillionaire fiesta that is modern free agency.

headline: Solomon’s Travels
text: The Portuguese writer José Saramago died in June at the age of 87. He won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1998, having peaked as a writer later in life. His prose is impish and subtle enough to bear comparison with Italo Calvino and Georges Perec, even if he lacked their scope. Saramago was a Communist. He believed there was a new totalitarianism of multinational companies. “To be a Portuguese Stalinist” well into the 21st century “means you’re simply not living in the real world,” the critic Harold Bloom has said. True enough. Yet when Saramago picked up his pen, a richer world was made.

headline: Developer Starts Paying Back Taxes on Islamic Center Site
text: Sharif el-Gamal, the real estate developer in the national spotlight over his plans to build an Islamic community center and mosque two blocks from ground zero, took care of a much more mundane task on Wednesday: paying his back taxes.

headline: TimesCast | September 17, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, an Afghan journalist looks at parliamentary election candidates, dirt track figure eight auto racing and highlights from the Toronto film festival.

headline: City Rejects Judge’s Offer on Hiring Firefighters
text: The City of New York said on Friday that it would not hire 300 firefighters using any of the options outlined by a federal judge because officials said the choices amounted to race-based quotas and were illegal.

headline: BP Withdraws Radio Spot
text: Sometimes listeners take issue with a radio commercial because they dislike how it sounds. But a spot for the Arco gasoline stations owned by BP is being withdrawn because the sounds heard during the commercial misfired in at least one instance.

headline: Melting Pot
text: “They met, the Chinese boy and the Chinese girl, in San Francisco in the spring of 1875. They met not in Chinatown, but in the 12th Ward, out near Van Ness Avenue, which was then at the fringes of the city’s settlement. This was San Francisco’s newest and most sparsely populated ward; hardly any Chinese lived there.” So begins “The Lucky Ones,” Mae Ngai’s fresh portrait of Chinese immigrants, America and the past century, a deceptively novelistic and evocative ­opening to a book she warns is “neither fiction nor memoir, but a work of history.”

headline: App Smart Extra: For College Football Fans
text: This week’s App Smart column previews the front-runners and upstarts of this season’s N.F.L.-related apps. For some football fans, though, the better action comes on Saturday, when college teams battle.

headline: At War With the Shakers
text: Modern Americans, bombarded with stories of celebrity divorces, probably assume that the tabloid breakup is a recent phenomenon. This lively, well-written and engrossing tale proves them wrong. Even before tabloids existed, a juicy 1810s scandal caused by an erring husband — or was it rather his wife? — attracted widespread public ­attention.

headline: I.M.F. Host Sees Good Chance for Agreement at G-20 Meeting
text: PARIS — Leaders from the Group of 20 nations should be able to sign off soon on agreements to bolster the weight of developing economies at the International Monetary Fund, while also increasing the fund’s resources, a senior South Korean official said Friday.

headline: Shareholders Back United-Continental Merger
text: Shareholders of United Airlines and Continental Airlines voted Friday to approve a combination of their companies that would create the world’s biggest airline and could have far-reaching effects on where they fly and how much they charge passengers, The Associated Press reports.

text: Grace Young, author of the recently published “Stir-Frying to the Sky’s Edge,” from Simon and Schuster, recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers’ questions about healthful stir-fry cooking. Here she responds to readers seeking advice on the best knives for preparing ingredients, getting flavor without the sodium, velvet stir-fries, marinades and meats, the eggplant challenge, the need to fluff rice and more.

headline: Penn Player’s Mother to Testify About Concussions in Congressional Hearing
text: The mother of Owen Thomas, the University of Pennsylvania football player who killed himself in April and was recently found to have died with early stages of the same brain disease found in more than 20 professional players, will testify at a Congressional hearing on youth sports concussions on Thursday.

headline: The Geometry of Sprawl
text: In his novel “The Crying of Lot 49,” Thomas Pynchon describes a suburb that is “less an identifiable city than a grouping of concepts — census tracts, special purpose bond-issue districts, shopping nuclei, all overlaid with access roads to its own freeway.” The novel’s protagonist, Oedipa Maas, “looks down a slope, needing to squint for the sunlight, onto a vast sprawl of houses which had grown up all together, like a well-tended crop, from the dull brown earth,” Pynchon writes, “and she thought of the time she’d opened a transistor radio to replace a battery and seen her first printed circuit. The ordered swirl of houses and streets, from this high angle, sprang at her now with the same unexpected, astonishing clarity as the circuit card had.” The architectural system unfolding in front of her held, according to Pynchon, a “hieroglyphic sense of concealed meaning.”

headline: Afghan Elections: Kidnapping, Fraud, Warlords and Donkeys
text: Our colleagues Rod Nordland and Sharifullah Sahak report on more election-related kidnappings ahead of Saturday’s parliamentary elections. The Taliban claimed to have kidnapped 30 campaign workers, election officials and a candidate for Parliament. Not all of the kidnappings have been confirmed by the government.

headline: Vote Set on Campaign Spending Measure
text: Ask critics of the campaign finance system how it can be fixed, and many answer quickly that it can’t. Not without an infusion of public money, they say, as a way to neutralize the impact of deep-pocketed donors, who have pushed the cost of running for federal office into the tens of millions of dollars in recent election cycles.

headline: Complex Formulas Governing the Afghan Elections
text: On Saturday, Afghan voters will again head to the voting booth, this time to elect members to the Afghan National Assembly, known as the Wolesi Jirga. This election, the second in the history of the legislative body, was initially scheduled for late May. It was postponed, however, because of a lack of money, logistical challenges and the continuing violence in the country.

headline: Writing the Jobs Bill — and Opposing It, Too
text: Among the winners in the Senate’s vote to pass the Small Business Jobs Act of 2010 were two Republican senators — but not the two who voted for the bill, Senators George Voinovich of Ohio and George LeMieux of Florida. Instead, look to the two leading Republicans who helped write large parts of the bill and then voted against it — in effect getting something for nothing.

headline: When Hope Is a Thing With Diapers

headline: Choosing Insurance for the College Life (Grades Not Included)
text: LIKE any concerned parent, Ronald Laconi, president of the Chartis Private Client Group, sat with his son through a security presentation for college freshmen a few weeks ago. “We spent a good hour and a half hour going through the safety procedures,” he said.

headline: Turn on, Tune in to a Trippy Afterlife
text: FEW filmmakers are as invested in the physical experience of film viewing as Gaspar Noé. Hailed by some as a visionary provocateur, dismissed by others as a gimmicky sensationalist, this 46-year-old Argentine-born Frenchman calibrates his films for a physiological response. He doesn’t stop at getting inside the heads of his viewers; he wants to affect their bodies and toy with their nervous systems.

headline: For the Auto X Prize, a Race to the Finish
text: THE $10 million Progressive Insurance Automotive X Prize, the competition to create fuel-efficient vehicles that ended last week with three winners, would have appeared to favor all the technology and finesse that goes with electric vehicles.

headline: Producer Discusses the End of ‘Promises, Promises’
text: Beth Williams, one of the lead producers of “Promises, Promises,” which is closing in January, said in a phone interview on Friday that the producers “considered re-casting, started putting lists together, but we didn’t think there was a way to replace Sean and Kristin” and ensure extending the show’s financial track record as well. Discussions about re-casting developed to the point where producers had some names in mind, but, Ms. Williams said, it never reached the stage of talking with actors or their agents about joining “Promises” to follow Sean Hayes and Kristin Chenoweth.

text: Greg Sargent notes the growing number of Republicans suggesting a “compromise” in the form of temporary extension of high-end tax breaks, and urges Democrats not to take the bait. The report states that “although the TARP provided critical government support to the financial system when the financial system was in a severe crisis, its effectiveness at pursuing its broader statutory goals has been far more limited.”

headline: Ribolla Gialla and a Breg From Josko Gravner
text: It’s been a busy week for the wine trade here in New York, where myriad tastings and winemaker visits have set the city a-buzzing more than usual. One of the highlights for me was the opportunity to taste two new whites from Josko Gravner, easily one of the most idiosyncratic and fascinating winemakers in the world.

headline: Together for 10 Years and Still Totally Committed
text: Ten years ago the Bad Plus came together in a warm rush of camaraderie and with a clear grasp of novelty. Here was a jazz piano trio with the heart and gall of a stadium rock band, grappling wryly but directly with anthemic covers and its own scarcely less anthemic originals. The group was brash and clever, its crooked sincerity often mistaken for smug acidity. A debate arose in jazz circles over the entitlements of such a group, what it meant and whether it deserved what it got.

headline: Bank Leaves Child’s Play Behind
text: One of the most-talked-about advertising campaigns — for a financial institution, anyway — is ending.

headline: A Home Filled With Mementos From the Civil Rights Movement
text: Marcia Young Cantarella lives in a Classic 6 on the Upper West Side in which the presence of her father, the late civil rights leader Whitney M. Young Jr., is felt in almost every room.

headline: Meet the In-Law
text: My brand-new sister-in-law left her e-mail account open, so I read her messages to see what she had to say about me. Well, it wasn’t pretty. She used an expletive to describe me to one friend, and called me a “high-maintenance pain” to another. I’m not sure where her animosity comes from. I know I violated her privacy, but I’d still like to discuss her anger. I want a loving relationship, but my feelings are so hurt I don’t know if I can pretend ignorance. What do you think?

headline: New York Fashion Week | Emily Jerome
text: Resort collections may be a passing thought as spring quickly engulfs the fashion-conscious, but that doesn’t mean designers have all tired of wild cruise prints. Take the nascent Los Angeles designer Emily Jerome, whose Jerome label sells at Ron Herman, L.A., and is worn by Mamie Gummer, Jessica Collins and Catherine and Allison Pierce of the Pierces, among others. Not that you have to be a celebutante to wear it, but wallflowers need not apply. “The Jerome girl is a little bit of everything — the rocker, bohemian and a tad flamboyant at times,” Jerome said via phone while working on her first look book (shot by Eric Ray Davidson) at the Chinati Foundation in Marfa, Tex., with Jessica Joffe. If the backdrop and the artful multiculti prints look familiar, it’s because the estate belongs to Donald Judd, Jerome’s godfather and a collector of ethnic textiles and African masks. “My prints this season derive from Christmas tree worms and ancient, ritual shoulder clothes from Bhutan,” Jerome said. You can take the girl out of Marfa. …

headline: Diving Deep to Reach the Surface
text: AFTER three fruitless years of online dating, I went to an acupuncturist and lay down before needles. I’d left the love of my life because he did not want children and had hoped to meet someone else quickly enough to have my own. Now, at 41, I was still single and paying a stranger to burn mugwort on my back.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 17
text: A view of the day in sports, which included Davis Cup tennis in France.

headline: Tracking a Tag
text: The graffiti artist Momo surreptitiously painted his name across Lower Manhattan.

headline: Fun With Rental Bikes in Paris and London
text: Writing on the London Review of Books blog, Jon Day points out that London’s new fleet of rental bikes have provided a fresh canvas to “Situationist guerrilla teams” intent on undercutting the ads they carry for Barclays Bank.

headline: Fun With Rental Bikes in Paris and London
text: Writing on the London Review of Books blog, Jon Day points out that London’s new fleet of rental bikes have provided a fresh canvas to “Situationist guerrilla teams” intent on undercutting the ads they carry for Barclays Bank.

headline: Fete Accompli | Uma’s Boating Party
text: On a drizzly Sunday night, while most of the city’s boldface names were sucked into the teeming nexus of Fashion Week, Uma Thurman took her first slippery steps down a metal ramp at Chelsea Piers and climbed aboard the Manhattan. The city seemed encased in a wet, almost scary gloom, and inside the cabin, all the windows were fogged up. Everyone worried about visibility. It wasn’t just because the boat — one of those wooden 1920s-style commuter yachts from the upmarket Circle Line alternative Classic Harbor Line — was to sail past famous sights: the Statue of Liberty and the Brooklyn Bridge. It was because this private cruise for 34 was being guided by Ken Burns, the documentarian who has made important films about both landmarks.

headline: Getting Ready for the Afghan Vote
text: The Times's Adam B. Ellick and Afghan Times Reporter Sangar Rahimi discuss Afghan parliamentary candidates.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: It’s said that the eye is bigger than the stomach. “Appetite,” curated by the Herb Lubalin Study Center at The Cooper Union, explores the influence of design in the food industry in a free exhibition at 41 Cooper Gallery, 41 Cooper Square (East Seventh Street). The exhibition opens at noon on Saturday and runs through Oct. 9. The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, has also opened a food-themed exhibition: “Counter Space: Design and the Modern Kitchen.” It explores the transformation of kitchen design in the past century and how it played a role in women’s lives and consumerism. It runs until March 14.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: It’s said that the eye is bigger than the stomach. “Appetite,” curated by the Herb Lubalin Study Center at The Cooper Union, explores the influence of design in the food industry in a free exhibition at 41 Cooper Gallery, 41 Cooper Square (East Seventh Street). The exhibition opens at noon on Saturday and runs through Oct. 9. The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, has also opened a food-themed exhibition: “Counter Space: Design and the Modern Kitchen.” It explores the transformation of kitchen design in the past century and how it played a role in women’s lives and consumerism. It runs until March 14.

headline: When Fantômas Held All of Paris in His Criminal Thrall
text: A GIGANTIC figure, wearing the elegant evening clothes of the Belle Époque, steps out of the horizon line and straddles the city of Paris, one foot ready to crush the Louvre. With an air of ennui, he stares out from behind a black mask, cupping his chin distractedly in his left hand, while his right arm extends behind him, clutching a knife tipped with blood.

headline: A Fond Farewell to ‘As the World Turns’
text: “As the World Turns,” the CBS soap opera with more divorces in its history than, surely, the entire city of Reno, ended for good on Friday after 54 years on television and a prior life on radio. At this commemorative moment it is worth pointing out that a number of now-famous actors appeared on the series including Meg Ryan, Julianne Moore, Steven Weber and Marisa Tomei. Amazingly enough, the last three appear together in this scene of love gone brutally, badly and tediously wrong: Not only does this clip egregiously fail to suggest the talent of Julianne Moore in “Vanya on 42nd Street;” it fails to telegraph the talent of Steven Weber in “Wings.”

headline: Insuring the Risks of College Life
text: In this week’s Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan discusses the many risks that college students face and how proper insurance can help reduce any potential damages.

headline: Insuring the Risks of College Life
text: In this week’s Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan discusses the many risks that college students face and how proper insurance can help reduce any potential damages.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: Lacking in Marquee Value, Not Intrigue
text: At first glance, this Saturday’s schedule seems like a comedown from last week’s. No Oklahoma-Florida State, no Ohio State-Miami, no Notre Dame-Michigan. In fact, there is only matchup between ranked teams this Saturday (No. 9 Iowa at No. 24 Arizona). But it would be remiss to think that the lack of marquee games means Saturday holds little intrigue. Several ranked teams will face serious early-season tests, some of them in hostile environments (just ask Texas Coach Mack Brown how much he’s looking forward to going into Lubbock to play Texas Tech and its new coach, Tommy Tuberville). Eighth-ranked Nebraska will not only be up against Jake Locker, but it will have to contend with the always intimidating atmosphere in Washington. Florida State returns home after getting blown out at Oklahoma last week, but the Seminoles don’t get much of a break when they host Brigham Young. Two A.C.C. teams, Georgia Tech and North Carolina, that have already seen their seasons go in a different direction than they wanted them to, play a game that is already critical for each. And Al Golden, the coach who has turned Temple around and is sure to be mentioned for some high-profile jobs at the end of the season, will see how his Owls fare against Connecticut of the Big East. What this weekend lacks in marquee value, it makes up for in intrigue. And that means that there is plenty of room for error when picking the games. As always, if you agree with the picks, disagree with them or simply find them laughable, feel free to chime in.

headline: The Video Q | Gaspar Noé on “Enter the Void”
text: “Lots of people ask me, ‘Why do you need to show explicit sex in your movies?’ ” said the French-Argentinian film director, Gaspar Noé. And as he explains in this week’s video interview, it’s because “when I have sex, it’s explicit. Life is graphic.”

headline: William S. Macklowe
text: Mr. Macklowe, 42, is the chief executive of the William Macklowe Company, a new venture that will focus on real estate acquisitions, strategic lending and investment.

headline: The Six-Room Scrapbook
text: THE Upper West Side apartment that is home to Marcia Young Cantarella, a longtime educator and a onetime dean at Princeton University, is rich with the presence of the two men who have loomed largest in her life.

headline: A Rift Over Transit-Housing Plan
text: FOR the last few years, developers, planners and politicians have been emphasizing the need for transit-oriented developments  multifamily housing clustered near train stations  as a solution to suburbia’s woes, a way to keep young people on the Island and to provide affordable housing.

headline: A Cool Summer for Housing
text: THE fall real estate season is under way, and the school of hard realities is in session.

headline: Looks Like a Condo, Acts Like a Hotel
text: ROOM service on demand from a celebrity chef. A maid to make the bed with fresh linens every day and leave a chocolate on your pillow at night. An 11,000-square-foot spa an elevator ride away. All yours with the purchase of a luxury condo.

headline: Morris Heights, the Bronx
text: MORRIS HEIGHTS was not first, second or even third on the list of neighborhoods where David Klaw and his fiancée, Jill Sunderland, considered buying a house.

headline: The Pitfalls of Buying Brand-New
text: AS buyers like Sandip K. Agarwala have discovered, opting for new construction these days can be hazardous to your nerves.

headline: Real Estate Q & A
text: Responsibility for Fireplaces

headline: In the Hamptons, Adjusting to the Short-Term Rental
text: RENTING a house in the Hamptons used to mean committing to the whole summer. And once Labor Day arrived, the market shut down until the snow melted and beach lovers started thinking about the ocean again.

headline: Because Dirt-Cheap Has Its Downsides
text: HOW could he possibly relinquish the lease on a $714 rent-stabilized one-bedroom? Everyone told Gary Parker he was crazy.

headline: Reasons Not to Refinance a Mortgage
text: LEW ALTFEST knows how clients will react when he tells them they shouldn’t refinance their mortgages.

headline: In Queens, One Block Bands Together to Clean Up
text: The firefighter had his power saw ready on Friday to cut up a massive London Plane that had crashed the night before across 84th Place in Middle Village, Queens, its crown landing over Frank Soda’s 1989 Grand Marquis.

headline: House Forecast Update: Embracing the Uncertainty
text: In contrast to our prognosis for the United States Senate, where the chances of a Republican takeover dropped sharply this week because of the outcome of the Delaware primary, our forecast for the House of Representatives shows relatively little change from last week.

headline: Above Forest Hills, 12:22 P.M.
text: A tree felled by Thursday’s powerful if brief storm is seen from a helicopter.

headline: Audi Film Crew Injured in Pikes Peak Helicopter Crash
text: Four people were injured, one seriously, when a helicopter crashed while filming an Audi test on Pikes Peak, west of Colorado Springs, Colo.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Mozambique and Elsewhere
text: The pictures are off the immediate news but add graphically to our knowledge of Mozambique. Goran Tomasevic of Reuters has transmitted pictures of gold prospectors panning on rented land. In “The Gold Slaves of Mozambique” (March 24, 2008), Spiegel Online described the prospectors’ lot:

headline: Election Eve in Marja
text: MARJA, Afghanistan—Marines here in this Helmand Province battleground say they expect the Taliban to try to attack polling sites for Saturday’s Parliamentary elections with gunfire and rocket-propelled grenades and so have spent much of the week devising security plans.

headline: O’Donnell Takes to the National Stage
text: Christine O’Donnell took the stage at the annual Values Voters Summit to the tune of Journey’s “Don’t Stop Believing,” and for a little over 18 minutes, she spoke to the true believers.

headline: Afghan Votes Come Cheap, and Often in Bulk
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  How much does it cost to buy an Afghan vote?

headline: Farm Fresh Outside the Lobby
text: ANNE MURPHY says she likes living at the Solaire, a rental building in Battery Park City, because it allows her to feel environmentally “virtuous.”

headline: Tracking Sea Ice in the Arctic
text: This week the National Snow and Ice Data Center in Colorado issued a preliminary estimate of Arctic sea-ice volume for the year. The numbers will not become final until October, but the early calculation is that the summer minimum extent for Arctic sea ice hit its third-lowest level in the modern era, a bit above 2008 and somewhat above the record low of 2007.

headline: Prabal Gurung Video | First Look Challenge Winners and Finalists
text: After 1,786 people played fashion stylist with looks from Prabal’s spring/summer 2011 collection, 25 finalists were chosen from the lot. Here’s a look at the entries that made the cut, in Polyvore’s video, above, and the two winners, below:

headline: Mattingly to Replace Torre at Dodgers’ Helm
text: LOS ANGELES — As the Dodgers wilted this summer — as Matt Kemp continued to make mental mistakes, as Andre Ethier could not shake out of his funk, as Manny Ramirez was not going to ride to the rescue — Joe Torre called more meetings than at any time in his long career as a manager.

headline: Toyota Bolsters Scion Lineup
text: Toyota announced recently that it would be adding two models to the Scion portfolio. The new entries include a restyled tC coupe and a diminutive four-passenger urban car called iQ.

headline: Texas Democrat: I Stood Up to Obama, Pelosi
text: Representative Chet Edwards isn’t the first Democrat running in a moderate or conservative district to air an advertisement distancing himself from party leaders like President Obama and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

headline: Ford to Sell Canadian-Built Edge in China
text: Ford will try to help satisfy China’s thirst for S.U.V.’s by exporting the Canadian-built Edge to that rapidly expanding market. The Edge was first shown in Asia at the Beijing Auto Show in April, and it is appearing this week at the Chengdu Auto Show.

headline: Murkowski Can Win as Write-In
text: The Hotline reports that Alaska Senator Lisa Murkowski, who was defeated in the Republican primary last month by Joe Miller, will run for the Senate as a write-in candidate against Mr. Miller and the Democratic candidate, Scott McAdams.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 17
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the primary election, the ninth anniversary of 9/11 and a ferocious storm.

headline: Notes From a Young American in Congo: Caffeine!
text: “Do you drink that every day? For two dollars?”

headline: Fête Accompli | T Magazine Toasts Sally Singer
text: The flash storm last night cleared just in time for the party at the Spotted Pig to welcome T’s new editor, Sally Singer. Hosted by the New York Times’s publisher, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., and Janet Robinson, the company’s president and chief executive officer, the event drew a veritable who’s who of the fashion, media and entertainment industries, including Maggie Gyllenhaal and Peter Sarsgaard, Brad Goreski, Anna Wintour, Grace Coddington and the designers Olivier Theyskens, Donna Karan, Prabal Gurung, Joseph Altuzarra and Jason Wu, among others. Our favorite sighting of the evening, however, was Courtney Love, who sat in a corner for a while, reading a book. No word on what she was reading.

headline: A Way With Balanchine (and With a Talking Dancer, Too)
text: New York City Ballet is presenting no fewer than 27 works during its inaugural fall season, 10 of them during this opening week. By world ballet standards, this is astonishing. Here, nobody even remarks on it. On Wednesday night four of George Balanchine’s ballets re-entered the repertory, and suddenly the eye, the ear, the mind and the imagination were again all full.

headline: Almond-Apricot Granola Bars
text: Mark Bittman makes a flavorful granola bar, no baking required.

headline: Opposites on Every Count, Kindred Souls in Many Ways
text: In cinematic terms  and this is only one way to absorb the fullness of Raimund Hoghe’s spare choreographic vision  “Sans-Titre” would be a black-and-white movie. In the work, a collaboration with the Congolese choreographer Faustin Linyekula, the German-born Mr. Hoghe explores the idea of being, as the title’s translation reveals, “without papers.” White lights illuminate a black stage. Mr. Linyekula wears white; Mr. Hoghe appears in black.

headline: The World of Robbins: Sinuous Dreams and Complex Geometry
text: Articulate and charming, the ballerina Jenifer Ringer is a perfect representative for New York City Ballet’s opening-week policy of having principal dancers introduce the evening’s ballets. On Thursday night at the David H. Koch Theater, she spoke about her experience dancing in the Jerome Robbins works on the program: “Interplay,” “Opus 19/The Dreamer,” “The Four Seasons.” She particularly loves her entrance in the “Spring” section of “The Four Seasons,” she told us, because of the way the icy blue light of the winter section changes to the warm pink glow of “Spring.”

headline: Scientists React to a Nobelist’s Climate Thoughts
text: 7:14 p.m. | Updated Earlier today, I wrote about the way internal filters can influence how scientists perceive and convey risks (in this instance, risks of human-driven climate change) and how the public weighs scientists’ views. As I stressed, what social scientists call “cultural cognition” is only one factor shaping perceptions of phenomena revealed by science.

headline: A Hands-On Approach to Entertaining His Fans
text: Trey Songz looked out into the Beacon Theater audience on Thursday night and saw a meal half eaten. In between audience screams, he shared his philosophy. “The first thing I do when I see a lovely face,” he said, stopping for effect. “I imagine the faces we would make if we ever made love.”

headline: Sunday Preview
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: The Illusion of Pension Savings
text: Earlier this year, Illinois said it had found a way to save billions of dollars. It would slash the pensions of workers it had not yet hired. The real-world savings would not materialize for decades, of course, but thanks to an actuarial trick, the state could start counting the savings this year and use it to help balance its budget.

headline: Scorecard (Men’s Edition) | N. Hoolywood Wins!
text: Don’t worry, guys: Scorecard hasn’t forgotten about you. We may just have been a little distracted this week — what with the women’s wear whiteout and all — that we forgot to mention: New York suits have done a 180 and the consensus (in the critical community anyway) is that not-so-streamlined conceptualism reigns.

headline: F.D.A. Postpones Rule on Breast Cancer Drug
text: The Food and Drug Administration appears to have postponed an expected decision on whether to revoke the approval of the drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer.

headline: Forget What You Know of Twain, Then Delight in Your Rediscovery
text: Mark Twain’s heroes tend to land in unexpected places: caves, locked cabins, long-gone eras, the Czar’s palace, a Tasmanian jungle, Southern drawing rooms. Whether it’s Huck Finn floating on a raft with an escaped slave or Hank Morgan thrust into the court of King Arthur, they are generally good-humored about their quandary and come out in pretty decent condition, tossing off a few wisecracks, learning a few things, maybe even making a fortune.

headline: Spotlight Glows Brightly in Toronto
text: TORONTO — Years ago, back when branding was a word many of us still associated with cattle, the Toronto International Film Festival was known as “the festival of festivals,” a reference to its identity as an event that gathered hits and misses from more prestigious festivals.

headline: G.O.P. in Florida: Unauthorized Expenses Cited
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. – Gov. Charlie Crist on Friday was drawn into the ongoing financial scandal with the Republican Party of Florida after the party released an audit that says that the party spent thousands on the cost of trips to New York City and Walt Disney World that included Crist, his wife and her family.

headline: Medical Talk, With Antipasti and Pasta on the Side
text: At this Italian restaurant on Madison Avenue between 97th and 98th Streets, the appeal of eating local has nothing to do with the provenance of the food. Opened in February and with Salvatore Fraterrigo as the executive chef, Tre Otto was carved out of an old dress shop by Lauren and Louis Cangiano, who live around the corner. He comes from a family that ran Italian specialty supermarkets for decades on Staten Island and in Brooklyn; she is a real estate agent. With exposed-brick walls, dark-wood furnishings and a menu including casual starters and composed entrees, the place has quickly found a following among residents — of both the neighborhood and medical variety — at the crossroads of Carnegie Hill and East Harlem, near Mount Sinai Medical Center. On Wednesday, that following included a group of medical professionals talking shop.

headline: A Bit Lazy, a Bit Productive
text: Thom Filicia, the interior designer of “Queer Eye” fame, continues to stage home décor interventions as the host of “Tacky House” and “Dress My Nest” on the Style Network. Mr. Filicia, 41, who also has a home furnishings line, lives in SoHo with his companion, Greg Calejo, a publicist, and two dogs, Paco and Foxy. Every other weekend, they head upstate to Skaneateles, where Mr. Filicia is renovating a 1907 lake house.

headline: A New Look at Koch Elevates His Legacy
text: AN unscientific survey of scholars a decade ago ranked Edward I. Koch 15th among America’s worst mayors. Having received 14 negative reviews and 6 positive ones, he fared better than two of his 19th-century New York predecessors (Fernando Wood and A. Oakey Hall), but nonetheless found himself sandwiched between two of his nemeses, Abraham D. Beame (14th) and John V. Lindsay (16th).

headline: Granola Bars, Unwrapped
text: GRANOLA is one of those foods that is assumed to be inherently good for you, so logic suggests that granola bars are, too. Sadly, that is not necessarily the case: if you’ve ever looked at the label on a granola bar, you know it can contain anything from corn syrup and corn flour to chocolate chips and added coloring. Nothing that will make you sick (at least not immediately), but not exactly health food.

headline: Thousands of Trees Killed by New York Tornadoes
text: As National Weather Service officials declared Friday that two tornadoes had indeed swept into New York City on Thursday, some tree-lined streets in Brooklyn and Queens looked -- at least from the air -- like Lego masterpieces that angry children had done their best to sweep aside.

headline: Stalled, Shafted, Mystified
text: A serviceable burst of high-end hokum, “Devil” classes up a flimsy, religion-themed plot (by M. Night Shyamalan) with the kind of limber cinematography only someone like Tak Fujimoto can deliver. Circling wildly within the film’s main set — a stalled elevator car — or hurtling up and down an empty shaft, Mr. Fujimoto’s camera is as giddy as a tween at a Justin Bieber concert.

headline: Making Your Own Granola Bars
text: Mass-produced granola bars are more like candy bars than the health food they’re advertised to be. But you can make your own, with real ingredients, and they’re super. See this week’s Minimalist column.

headline: In Court, Echoes and Ghosts
text: NEW HAVEN

headline: A Writer’s Struggles, on and Off the Page
text: Her feminist war cry of a play, “For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/ When the Rainbow Is Enuf,” is Ntozake Shange’s signature work, produced on Broadway in 1976 when she was in her 20s. Now 61, her speech and movements slowed by a series of minor strokes but her intensity undimmed, Ms. Shange is having another moment, or two, this fall.

headline: Now Serving | Austin Eats
text: With its deep roots of Tex-Mex, breakfast tacos and barbecue, Austin, Tex., has always been considered a foodie town. Some recent additions have elevated the state capitol’s profile in the world of the flavorful and the fabulous. Here are some of the latest offerings worth checking out.Uchiko, 4200 North Lamar, Suite 140; (512) 916-4808. Tyson Cole’s newest venture features one of his trusted chefs, Paul Qui, at the helm. The similar Japanese influences that inspired Cole at Uchi (not surprisingly, “Uchiko” means “offspring of Uchi”) can be found on the menu, as well as new inventions. During a recent dinner, the highlights included a tasty koviche, a ceviche of fresh diver scallops prepared with tomatillo, kalamata olives and black lime; and the ao saba, a grilled Norwegian mackerel with a delightful convergence of flavors that included bluefoot mushroom, onion and juniper huckleberry. For dessert, try the stunning sweet-corn sorbet.

headline: The Best Two Women Could Do
text: Jenna Glazer and Elise Bacolas weren’t looking for the loves of their lives when they met 11 years ago. Both 27, they had each recently ended a big relationship, and felt no rush to start another. But, introduced by a mutual friend outside a bar, they hit it off. Ms. Bacolas gave Ms. Glazer a lift home, and they talked until nearly dawn.

headline: 2011 Cadillac CTS Coupe
text: The CTS Coupe is the first four-seat Caddy coupe since the senior-centric Eldorado.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,412 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Thursday:

headline: Murkowski Will Run as Write-in Candidate
text: A top Republican official in Washington said Friday that Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska has informed the party’s leadership that she intends to run as a write-in candidate for re-election despite losing the Republican nomination in the primary earlier this month.

headline: An Artist’s Alfresco John Hancock
text: The thin orange line of paint traces a winding path though downtown Manhattan neighborhoods like SoHo, Greenwich Village and the Lower East Side. Uneven and wandering, the stripe runs up major avenues and across narrow streets, sometimes prominent, at other times so faint and worn that it is barely visible.

headline: James Levine Says He’s Ready to Work Again
text: In his first detailed comments about his latest health problem, James Levine said he underwent a 10-hour “monster operation” in April to correct curvature of the spine and spinal stenosis, an exceedingly painful condition that compresses the spinal cord.

headline: Two Rockies Share Link to Manning Brothers
text: When the Colorado Rockies held their fantasy football league draft last month, it was no surprise who Seth Smith, the outfielder who was once the backup to Eli Manning at the University of Mississippi, wanted as his quarterback.

headline: At Wagner, Player Has College Football Career After Pro Baseball
text: Nick Doscher has returned to Staten Island, his home, and he has settled in as the 23-year-old starting sophomore quarterback at Wagner College, whose leafy campus sits like a tiara atop Grymes Hill. On Saturday, the Seahawks will play Cornell at home, a good test for both teams.

headline: ‘Borat’ Star To Play Freddie Mercury
text: Now that vérité-style comedies that try to present themselves as documentaries have been made totally passé, Sacha Baron Cohen has decided it’s time for a transition to the less controversial turf of the biopic. Mr. Baron Cohen, above left, the British comedian and star of “Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan” and “Bruno,” is planning to portray Freddie Mercury, above right, the frontman of the rock band Queen, who died in 1991, in a feature, the film’s producers said Thursday night. In a news release, the production company GK Films said it had signed Mr. Baron Cohen for an untitled drama focusing on the era surrounding Queen’s performance at the 1985 Live Aid benefit concert. The screenplay is by Peter Morgan, the “Frost/Nixon” playwright and writer of historical films like “The Queen” and “The Last King of Scotland.” The film’s producers, who also include TriBeCa Productions and Queen Films, did not indicate whether Mr. Baron Cohen would actually sing such demanding Queen songs as “We Are the Champions” or “Bohemian Rhapsody.” But he did get a chance to show off his throat  in more ways than one  in Tim Burton’s film version of “Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street.” GK Films said production would start next year.

headline: City Opera Chairwoman Explains Her Departure
text: Susan L. Baker, who is ceding the job of chairwoman of the New York City Opera, said the move was just part of “good governance” and had nothing to do with the company’s difficult chapter involving the 2008 resignation of its general manager Gerard Mortier. “Heavens, no!” she said late Thursday in a telephone interview. Ms. Baker was chairwoman during Mr. Mortier’s hiring and quick resignation, which was widely viewed as a debacle in the opera world. “I’m a great believer in chairs not overstaying,” Ms. Baker said. “So I put in place a committee sometime over the course of the past year to really commence a process for finding a new leader.” That new leader, as reported, will be Charles R. Wall, a former board member who recently retired as vice chairman of Philip Morris International. Ms. Baker said that she would stay active on the board, but that she and Mr. Wall still had to talk about her specific role. Ms. Baker declined to talk about the Mortier chapter. “I’m not interested in getting into that discussion,” Ms. Baker said.

headline: Nicole Kidman To Return To Broadway Next Year
text: The Academy Award-winning actress Nicole Kidman plans to return to Broadway in the fall of 2011 to star in a revival of the Tennessee Williams play “Sweet Bird of Youth,” to be directed by David Cromer (“Our Town”), a spokesman for the production said on Friday. Ms. Kidman, left, was last on Broadway, in her debut, in the 1998-99 season production of David Hare’s play “The Blue Room.” That show drew mixed reviews but was a very tough ticket to come by, given Ms. Kidman’s star appeal. In “Sweet Bird,” Ms. Kidman will play Alexandra Del Lago, the faded, often-drunk movie star going around with the gigolo Chance Wayne; no word on who will play Chance. The original 1959 production on Broadway starred Geraldine Page as Alexandra and Paul Newman as Chance, who also starred in a film version; a 1975-76 revival, the last on Broadway, starred Irene Worth and Christopher Walken. Scott Rudin (last season’s Tony Award-winning “Fences,” the coming musical “Book of Mormon”) will be producing. The production and Ms. Kidman’s casting were reported in The New York Post.

headline: ‘Promises, Promises’ Will Close In January
text: One of Broadway’s biggest commercial hits of the year, the Sean Hayes-led revival of the musical “Promises, Promises,” will close on Jan. 2, the producers announced on Thursday night. The decision to close the show only nine months after opening is another reminder of the premium that producers put on star casting on Broadway  and the high costs and unpredictability of recasting. Beth Williams, one of the lead producers, said in a phone interview on Friday that the producers “considered recasting, started putting lists together, but we didn’t think there was a way to replace Sean and Kristin” Chenoweth and ensure extending the show’s financial track record as well. In a statement, the producers said they expected to recoup their original capitalization cost  they would not say how much it was, but it was at least in the high seven figures  and turn a profit for their investors, especially as the show heads into the lucrative holiday season. The show has grossed more than $25 million since opening in April. Its leading man and woman  Mr. Hayes (an Emmy Award winner for “Will & Grace”), above, and Ms. Chenoweth (“Wicked,” a Tony winner for “You’re a Good Man, Charlie Brown”)  are under contract only through the end of the year, and they were not re-upping. Katie Finneran, who won a Tony as Marge MacDougall, will pass on the role to Molly Shannon next month. A touring version of this production of “Promises, Promises” is now being discussed, Ms. Williams said.

headline: Egyptian Newspaper Admits Doctoring Photo
text: On Friday, the editor of a newspaper owned by the Egyptian government admitted that a photograph published this week in its pages had been altered to make it seem as if Egypt’s president, Hosni Mubarak, had led, rather than followed, a group of world leaders walking in to a media event at the White House last week.

headline: ‘Law & Order: UK’ Coming to BBC America
text: NBC and its partners started remaking “Law & Order” for British audiences more than a year ago, and now those episodes are heading back to the United States, where they started. BBC America said Thursday that it would import “Law & Order: UK” beginning next month, with the premiere set for a Sunday, Oct. 3, at 10:30 p.m. Other episodes will be shown on Friday nights at 9. “Law & Order: UK” is the first foreign English-language iteration of the long-running crime series. It is produced by NBC Universal, Wolf Films and a British production company called Kudos Film and Television. The producers recycled scripts from the original “Law & Order,” set in New York, “to retain the grittiness” of that series, the BBC said. But the episodes were adapted to reflect the legal system in Britain. Dick Wolf, the executive producer of the “Law & Order” empire, told BBC News last year that legally, “the biggest difference here was the wigs.” He added, “The law is not really that dissimilar.”

headline: Viewers to ‘Apprentice’: You’re Tired
text: After three seasons with celebrity contestants, a recession-themed 10th edition of “The Apprentice,” with Donald Trump, below, made its debut on Thursday with nonfamous contestants whose lives have been hit hard by the economic downturn. Also suffering: the show’s ratings. According to Nielsen’s estimates, NBC drew just 4.7 million viewers for the premiere, the lowest ratings ever for an episode of the franchise and a decline of almost 4 million from the series’ most recent premiere in March (8.3 million). NBC ranked third for the night over all. CBS earned a first-place finish, and ABC was second with lineups of repeats. CW edged past Fox to place fourth with “The Vampire Diaries” (3 million) and “Nikita” (3.4 million).

headline: Scorecard | Calvin Klein Collection Wins!
text: And… curtain! As New York fashion week’s marquee actors take their bows in the city’s newest Theatre and Stage, Scorecard notes in the final reductive tally that there’s no way American fashion’s perennial practitioner of architectural minimalism, Calvin Klein’s Francisco Costa, wouldn’t beat them all in the square the circle game.

headline: Hot Tea, Cool G.O.P.
text: When is a party not a party, but instead a marine echinoderm? The answer is, according to National Journal’s invaluable Jonathan Rauch, when it’s a Tea Party. “The tea party began as a network, not an organization, and that is what it mostly remains,” he explains. “This is a coordinated network, not a hierarchy. There is no chain of command. No group or person is subordinate to any other. The tea parties are jealously independent and suspicious of any efforts at central control, which they see as a sure path to domination by outside interests … Lava is a pretty good analogy. Ask the activists to characterize their organizational structure, however, and usually they will say it is a starfish.”

headline: A Vision of a Place for All Faiths
text: Imagine Yom Kippur 2016: a steady stream of Jews file into a gleaming 13-story building two blocks from ground zero. Maybe one peeks inside the mosque on the building’s ground floor to see whether a friend from her Turkish cooking class is there, then heads up to the third floor, where glass cases display artwork from Western and Middle Eastern artists on the theme of, oh say, fractured identity.

headline: For Amy Ryan, Inspiration Found Around the Corner
text: “WHEN I’m in L.A., I am terribly alone and bored,” the actress Amy Ryan said as she bounded down the stairs to catch the Q train to Brooklyn. “I need the pulse of New York City. I like to steal.”

headline: An Underbid Works Badly, or So It Would Seem
text: In Cardiff, Wales, on Thursday, the United States regained the Buffett Cup, taking an insurmountable lead over Europe, with 18 boards to be played. The final result was 109 to 89.

headline: Spoiler Alert: Whodunit? Wikipedia Will Tell You
text: At the end of each performance of the Agatha Christie play “The Mousetrap,” the person revealed to be the murderer steps forward and tells the audience to “keep the secret of whodunit locked in your heart.”

headline: 10 Questions for Nancy Pelosi
text: With her Democratic majority imperiled, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi spoke with John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC about promoting the party’s agenda, the Bush tax cuts and more. A condensed and edited transcript is below.

headline: A Center Bursting With Life and Raring to Open
text: HACKETTSTOWN, N.J.

headline: Vow Renewals: When One ‘I Do’ Is Not Enough
text: UP until recently, the wedding industry would have you believe that you had only one chance at the perfect day. So spare no expense, be a princess for a day, invite 200 friends, and let it all pass by in a blur.

headline: Couple Accused of Passing Nuclear Arms Secrets
text: A physicist and his wife, who both once worked at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, were arrested Friday and charged with a criminal conspiracy to help Venezuela build an atom bomb.

headline: Social Innovation Fund Posts Data on Judges for Grants
text: The Social Innovation Fund, a federal program to encourage the expansion of promising nonprofit projects, on Friday released the names of independent reviewers involved in helping it award $50 million in grants, taking a further step to address criticism of its transparency.

headline: In Diversity Case, City Rejects a Plan for Hiring Firefighters
text: The City of New York said Friday that it would not hire a new class of firefighters using proposals laid out by a federal judge, who had ruled that the test used to screen Fire Department applicants discriminated against African-Americans and Hispanics.

headline: A Peconic Bay Story, in Quick Brush Strokes
text: IT’S not often that the Suffolk County Historical Society in Riverhead hosts an art exhibit, said Wallace W. Broege, the historical society’s director. But “Helen M. Kroeger & Otto J. Kurth: The Anchorage Studio and Peconic Bay Impressionism” fits in, he said.

headline: For Filipino Boxer, Money Opens Door to Politics
text: ALABEL, the Philippines

headline: Q&A Tip of the Week: Using the ‘Send To’ Feature
text: Right-clicking on a file and choosing the Send To menu in Windows 7 gives you several options, like sending the file to a mail recipient or compressing it into a ZIP archive. If you want even more choices about where you can send the selected file, hold down the Shift key while right-clicking. An extended version of the Send To menu appears, with options for putting the file in the Documents, Music and other folders.

headline: Chinese Investors Flock to London to Buy Real Estate
text: LONDON  Naomi Minegishi, 21, a Japanese woman who lived in China for 10 years, recently took a job with the London property broker Felicity J Lord.

headline: Between Stewart and Colbert, Dueling Rallies
text: A day after the “Daily Show” star Jon Stewart announced plans to stage an ambitious public rally to counter what he identified as extremists on either side of the political spectrum, specifics were in short supply on Friday, with most of the details still to be worked out.

headline: Citigroup to Sell Unit That Lends to Students
text: Nearly two years after Citigroup received a second government bailout and was ordered by regulators to shrink, the bank agreed on Friday to sell its student lending business in two parts, to Discover Financial Services and the lender Sallie Mae.

headline: Immigration Agency’s Tactic Spurs Alarm
text: In his short life, Ousmane Coulibaly, a 19-year-old high school senior in Manhattan, has seen plenty of adversity. He grew up poor in Mali, was estranged from his family at 13 and has lived on the street there and in New York. An illegal immigrant, he is staying in a homeless shelter while he tries to graduate and obtain a special immigration status reserved for young people who have been abandoned or abused.

headline: Mr. Showmanship’s Show Is Closing
text: LAS VEGAS  Bill Holt was gawking. At the room filled with ornate antique pianos, among them a Baldwin grand glistening with a coat of rhinestones that was Liberace’s favorite. At a 1962 Phantom V Landau Rolls-Royce, covered in mirrors, that looked like a disco ball on wheels. At Liberace’s collection of candelabras, rings, capes and boots.

headline: Big Donation Will Allow Penn State to Field Hockey Teams in Division I
text: Joe Paterno and the Penn State football program have long dominated the sports landscape in Happy Valley, but Nittany Lions fans have long clamored for a top-level hockey team, which seemed like a fantasy until Friday.

headline: Cathy Horyn's Fashion Week Wrap-Up
text: Cathy Horyn makes distinctions among the spring 2011 collections including, Rodarte, Calvin Klein, Tom Ford, Reed Krakoff, Proenza Schouler, Ralph Lauren and Oscar de la Renta.

headline: N.F.L. Calls Jets’ Conduct ‘Unprofessional’
text: The N.F.L. will start a training program to remind each team of proper conduct in the wake of its investigation into the treatment of a female reporter in the Jets’ locker room last week.

headline: Musings About the Political Season
text: To the Editor:

headline: Porsche to End 3-Year Snub of Detroit Auto Show
text: Indian Summer is just arriving in Detroit, the harbinger of another long, cold winter, but spirits are warming among planners for January 2011’s North American International Auto Show.

headline: Dodge Morgan, Who Sailed Around World, Dies at 78
text: Dodge Morgan, the first American to sail solo nonstop around the world, a feat in which he cut the previous record time nearly in half, died Tuesday in Boston. He was 78 and lived on Snow Island in Harpswell, Me., a 30-acre sanctuary that he owned and where he moored six sailboats.

headline: Take One Last Look
text: Fashion writers and professionals have been complaining about the motley nature of the shows since the mid-1970s, when designers moved their presentations to hotel ballrooms and, through the use of theatrical lighting and choreographed models, introduced performance to their shows.

headline: Supervising Banks’ Liquidity Is a Pain for Regulators
text: FRANKFURT  When the financial crisis was at its bleakest in September 2008 in the wake of the collapse of Lehman Brothers, only central bank and government intervention ensured that banks like Hypo Real Estate in Germany and Northern Rock in Britain had enough cash to keep operating after financing dried up and customers demanded their money.

headline: Help Pakistanis Here
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Terror Translators
text: INSPIRE magazine, an English-language journal published by Al Qaeda, included in its summer edition what amounted to a “Friends and Foes” list. There, on Page 4, following the letter from the editor (“We survive through jihad and perish without it”), were pictures of, and quotations from, kindred spirits like Faisal Shahzad, who pleaded guilty in a plot to detonate a car bomb in Times Square, and, perhaps surprisingly, David Letterman, who was praised for recent criticism of former President George W. Bush.

headline: Secrets in Plain Sight in Censored Book’s Reprint
text: WASHINGTON  The National Security Agency, headquarters for the government’s eavesdroppers and code breakers, has been located at Fort Meade, Md., for half a century. Its nickname, the Fort, has been familiar for decades to neighbors and government workers alike.

headline: Criminals in Yankee Caps
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:
