text: FIRST, a note on language.

headline: In Skyscraper at Ground Zero, Sentiment Trumped Numbers
text: Timing is everything.

headline: North Korea’s Intentions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Harvesting Homegrown Art
text: In keeping with a trend from the restaurant world, the Aldrich Museum has been having a locavore season. The artist Fritz Haeg has transformed the museum’s formal front lawn into a more rustic-looking fruit and vegetable garden. And inside the building is a cornucopia of small exhibitions, many devoted to artists who live or work in the area.

headline: Pakistani’s Death in London Sets Off Unrest
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The killing of an exiled Pakistani politician in London shut down most of Pakistan’s largest city, Karachi, on Friday as the police contained unrest and moved to prevent wider violence.

headline: A Commune Grows in Brooklyn
text: ON a recent drizzly afternoon in Bushwick, Brooklyn, members of the Bushwick Food Cooperative gathered beneath a tent in a ramshackle backyard to claim their share of the weekly harvest. They picked through crates of cilantro and rosemary from a rooftop farm in Long Island City, Queens, and examined pastured eggs from an Amish farm cooperative in Pennsylvania.

headline: Tributes Top Schedule of Jazz Orchestra
text: AFTER seven years of operation, the Westchester Jazz Orchestra has built a reputation for deeply researched, strikingly executed performances that is reaching well beyond the orchestra’s home county to the country at large.

headline: Tax Increase Would Hit Few Small Businesses
text: As Congress and President Obama wrestle over whether to let the Bush tax cuts expire for the wealthiest Americans, one of the most heated aspects of the debate, in Washington and in neighborhoods across the country, is how a tax increase would affect small businesses.

headline: The Twitter Age Embraces Communal Living
text: Concepts like sharing and bartering are being revived and updated for the Twitter age.

headline: Portrait of a Textile Mill and Its Workers
text: THE 63 photographs that Michael Anthony lent to the American Labor Museum in Haledon for its exhibition “Allied Textile Printers” have not only personal meaning but also historical value.

headline: Charges Dropped for 3 Accused of Planning to Riot
text: Prosecutors have dropped charges against three of seven people accused of organizing a dangerous criminal gang and planning to disrupt the 2008 Republican National Convention in St. Paul with a host of unorthodox tactics. The case, which focused on an anarchist group called the R.N.C. Welcoming Committee, was widely regarded as the marquee criminal prosecution to emerge from the convention.

headline: Tech Firms Said to Be in Talks to Settle Inquiry Over Recruiting
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A number of Silicon Valley companies including Apple, Google and Intel are in advanced negotiations with the Justice Department to avoid facing charges that they violated antitrust laws by agreeing not to poach employees from each other, according to two people briefed on the negotiations.

headline: A Serious Food Store
text: First impressions can be misleading. That’s true of New Morning Natural Foods, where incense, an array of designer cookware and vegetarian cookbooks are the first things you will see.

headline: Ballpark Farewell, Played Adagio
text: CHICAGO  On a gray, damp morning this week, the home of Nancy Faust, White Sox organist, was alive with the sound of ring tones.

headline: An Aura of Romance, Wine Not Included
text: YOU might wonder, as I did, how a tiny place like Amerigo Restaurant in Norwalk could survive without a liquor license. But Amerigo has been going strong since 1999. The keys to its success are its excellent Italian cuisine and the fact that its owners encourage patrons to bring their own wine. In many ways, dining at Amerigo is less like visiting a restaurant and more like being a dinner guest in the home of a very good cook.

headline: The Corner Stall Office
text: MY friend Michael was facing a dilemma earlier this summer. He was running late at work; he was overdue to meet a friend; he needed to return the phone call of an important client, “a Broadway legend,” as he described her. So he did what many people do these days. He multitasked. He slipped into the lavatory; he dialed his client.

headline: Bloggingheads: 'Mad Men' Anachronisms
text: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Benjamin Zimmer of The New York Times discuss the language of "Mad Men."

headline: N.B.A. Chic for the Slim Fit
text: SAM HAAVISTO lays his Mahmoud Abdul-Rauf jersey on an ottoman, carefully smoothing the mesh fabric like it’s an ancient relic. The jersey was purchased on eBay for $7, but for Mr. Haavisto, who began collecting N.B.A. replica jerseys when he was 8, the rarity and historical significance of Mr. Abdul-Rauf’s make it an invaluable collector’s item.

headline: Never Too Many Chefs in These Kitchens
text: SUMMIT, N.J.

headline: No Room for Hesitation
text: In Indianapolis, drivers try to outpace one another, and survive, during three hours of Figure 8 racing.

headline: Wide G.O.P. Field Tests the Waters for 2012 Contest
text: DES MOINES  The Republican presidential field for 2012 is beginning to take shape in a period of intensive upheaval set off by the rise of the Tea Party movement, expanding the roster of potential candidates but presenting a more complicated road to the nomination.

headline: First the Respect, Now the Toast
text: ROMAN ROTH recalled that when he joined Wölffer Estate Vineyard in Sagaponack as its first winemaker in 1992, “you would call up a three-star restaurant in Manhattan and say, ‘Long Island wine’ and they would throw the phone down. Literally, clunk.

headline: Markets Seek to Eliminate Stub Quotes
text: NYSE Euronext, Nasdaq OMX Group and Bats Global Markets asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to eliminate stub quotes, or bids and offers as low as pennies or as high as thousands of dollars provided by market makers. Stub quotes are placeholders provided by market makers to satisfy a regulatory obligation to submit both bids and offers. On May 6, during the so-called flash crash, companies like Accenture tumbled to a penny as traders pulled out of the market, leaving fewer bids in order books.

headline: Two Different Worlds
text: I didn’t notice much when a terrific storm slammed into parts of New York City on Thursday evening. I was working at my computer in a quiet apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. The skies darkened and it began to rain, and I could hear thunder. But that’s all. I made a cup of coffee and kept working.

headline: A Day About the Farm
text: In early October, when pumpkins turn from green to orange and cornstalks rustle in the wind, Stone Barns Center for Food and Agriculture, in Pocantico Hills, will mount its seventh annual Harvest Fest to raise money for farm camp scholarships, school programs and training for young farmers.

headline: Defeated Alaska Senator to Run Write-In Campaign
text: Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, who lost her state’s Republican primary last month to a Tea-Party-backed conservative, announced late Friday that she will run as a write-in candidate in the general election.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Homey Tastes, but Complex, Too
text: ONE of my favorite dishes at River City Grille in Irvington is the petit filet mignon, cooked just as ordered and served with fresh peas and crunchy fries (substituted for mashed potatoes without any problem). Another is the Thai beef, marinated in ginger, soy, garlic and hoisin sauce, pan sautéed and served with nicely dressed noodles in peanut sauce.

headline: Obama Is Said to Be Preparing to Seek Approval on Saudi Arms Sale
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama is preparing to seek Congressional approval for a huge arms sale to Saudi Arabia, chiefly intended as a building block for Middle East regional defenses to box in Iran, according to administration and Pentagon officials.

headline: Palin in Iowa: Renegades, Unite!
text: DES MOINES – Sarah Palin delivered what she called a “quick woodshed moment,” criticizing Karl Rove and other leading Republicans here Friday evening for failing to rally behind some of the party’s newest crop of nominees by suggesting that some of the candidates cannot be elected in November.

headline: Drywall Flaws: Owners Gain Limited Relief
text: Linda and Randall Hunter own their dream house in Plant City, Fla., with an oversize master bedroom, granite countertops in the kitchen and a screened-in pool.

headline: A State of Two Minds
text: PETERSBURG, Alaska

headline: The Grand Illusion
text: Let me be clear: the idea of an inevitable Republican landslide in November is not a foregone conclusion. It’s a self-perpetuating bit of wishful thinking that’s gaining currency through the force of being recycled ad nauseam by overzealous pundits.

headline: Saturday: Makings of a Hero
text: BROWN CROSSWORD WEEK concludes.

headline: Pulse
text: What Anna Dello Russo of Vogue Japan is wearing now; vinyl records make a comeback; and other items.

headline: Yom Kippur at Sea
text: Deer Isle, Me.

headline: Mr. Geithner and China
text: It is clear that China is going to keep manipulating its currency  and crowding out every other exporter  until the world pushes back. So it was good to hear Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner speaking out this week on Capitol Hill, warning that an undervalued Chinese currency “makes it more difficult for goods and services produced by American workers to compete.”

headline: Ducking for Cover Before the N.R.A.
text: The Obama administration still has not nominated a director for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. That can only be seen as a dangerous homage to the National Rifle Association, whose legions of Congressional sycophants undoubtedly are just waiting for the cue to trash whomever the White House chooses. That’s still no excuse.

headline: The Administration’s Press Censorship
text: The Obama administration has made many pledges of transparency and openness, but neither of those fundamental principles were anywhere to be seen when the Pentagon opened its first military trial at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, under President Obama. What we did see were intolerable limitations on journalists covering the trial  or at least trying to cover it.

headline: Dark Comes
text: I don’t go looking for the places of deep comfort on this farm. They call out to me. Why does the mounded hay in the horses’ run-in shed look so inviting? Why does the chicken house  warm and tight and brightly lit  feel like a place where I could just settle in? I climb the ladder to the hayloft and the barn cat watches me warily from his redoubt in the hay bales. I feel like getting my sleeping bag and joining him.

headline: Brooklyn Malls Try to Limit Youth Loitering
text: It is afternoon in Brooklyn, and school has just let out. Swarms of teenagers crowd the sidewalks, looking for a place to socialize. But near Downtown Brooklyn, at the entrances to the Atlantic Terminal mall, there is no hanging out at one popular meeting spot. Students are met by security guards, who block their path, ask questions and check IDs.

headline: How to Deal With Tainted Drywall
text: As my article on Saturday in The Times reports, the first widespread complaints about defective Chinese drywall surfaced in Florida a few years ago, and since then roughly 3,500 homeowners in the United States have filed complaints with the federal government.

headline: In House Full of Cuomos, a Dog Not as Burly as Paladino’s Duke
text: Is there more than one dog in the race for New York governor?

headline: Starbucks Bomber to Get 3½ Years
text: A teenager from Chelsea who said he had been inspired by the movie “Fight Club” pleaded guilty on Friday to setting off a homemade bomb outside a Starbucks on the Upper East Side more than a year ago.

headline: Minaya’s Fate Could Affect Mets’ Ties to Latin Culture
text: Almost immediately after being named general manager of the Mets in late 2004, Omar Minaya initiated and came to symbolize a team movement that celebrated baseball’s Caribbean and Hispanic cultures and tied them to the identity of the club.

headline: Monica Hare, Stacie Cassarino
text: Monica Marie Hare and Stacie Cassarino were married Saturday in Weybridge, Vt. The Rev. Johanna L. Nichols, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the home of Barbara Ganley and William Roper, friends of the couple.

headline: Facing Questions, Jeter Asks One: What’s the Big Deal?
text: BALTIMORE  An aspiring actor could only dream of the attention that Derek Jeter received this week for his performance at Tampa Bay on Wednesday, when he pretended that a pitched ball struck his left arm instead of the knob of his bat.

headline: Danger and Excitement Intersect at Figure Eight Racing
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Figure-eight car racing is like driving full speed through an endless loop of red lights. Luck often expires in a cloudburst of steam and scattered auto parts.

headline: For Yankees, a Swing Changes the Subject
text: BALTIMORE  The Yankees came to Camden Yards on Friday having lost 8 of 10 games, with five of those losses coming by a single run. In that stretch, a funk so severe that it drew General Manager Brian Cashman here, the Yankees seemed unable to get hits when they most needed them.

headline: With Kovalchuk in Camp, Devils Will Face Difficult Cuts
text: NEWARK  Ilya Kovalchuk wheeled into an employee parking lot at Prudential Center in a white Mercedes-Benz for the first day of the Devils’ training camp Friday morning. He tried to fit right in.

headline: Circling Manhattan (Bring Extra Socks)
text: WALKING the High Line? That’s cute. The length of Central Park? Bucolic. The marathon? Try adding six miles. Circumnavigating Manhattan is the ultimate and extreme city walking tour and promises the seemingly impossible: a path less traveled on an overly trodden island. Half sightseeing tour, half endurance test, the journey at Manhattan’s edge takes you into the shadows of 19 bridges, through as many parks and past art installations, city landmarks and 360 degrees of ever-changing views.

headline: Donald W. Davis, Who Headed Stanley Works, Dies at 89
text: Donald W. Davis, who transformed Stanley Works from a tradition-bound New England tool manufacturer into an international pioneer in the do-it-yourself hardware business, died on Sept. 11. He was 89.

headline: Texas: Voting Machine Fire Remains a Mystery
text: A warehouse fire that destroyed most of Harris County’s voting machines last month broke out in a back room used for classes and storage, but trained dogs found no traces of a flammable liquid in the spot where it started, investigators said Friday. Fire marshals have not ruled out arson, but it may take months to reach a conclusion, said Patrick Trahan, a spokesman for the Houston Fire Department. Since the blaze, election officials in the nation’s third-largest county, which contains Houston, have been scrambling to buy or to borrow enough machines to hold the election in November, prompting many in political circles to speculate a saboteur might have been behind the fire.

headline: Ariana Rockefeller and Matthew Bucklin
text: IT was supposed to be only a summer romance.

headline: The Wedding of Ariana Rockefeller and Matthew Bucklin
text: On Sept. 4, the couple were married in Seal Harbor, Me., on Mount Desert Island.

headline: How Much Will You Owe? Tax Plans Compared
text: In the debate over the effect of the expiring Bush tax cuts on small business, it’s already possible to do the math. And the Obama administration is pointing to the tax savings that all small-business owners would reap from its own plan to extend the cuts to all but the highest income levels — if, that is, the alternative is letting the cuts expire altogether.

headline: On the Street | Views
text: Bill Cunningham documents the people who may be the real stars of New York Fashion Week: the guests.

headline: Chart: Who’s Paying for All Those Ads?
text: Federal campaign spending by groups other than candidates and parties this election cycle has far outpaced similar spending from the last midterm election and could rival the 2008 presidential campaign. But with recent decisions by the Supreme Court and the Federal Elections Commission, it has become harder to know whose dollars they are.

Hughes of Washington. The Rev. Dr. Luis León performed the ceremony at St. John’s Episcopal Church Lafayette Square in Washington.

headline: Lisa Levy, Phillip Buehler

headline: Jennifer Zaldivar, Gregory Clark
text: Jennifer Anne Zaldivar, the daughter of Cecilia B. Zaldivar and Bert M. Zaldivar of New York, is to be married Sunday to Gregory Edward Clark, the son of Gloria A. Clark and Richard H. Clark of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Msgr. Lawrence M. Connaughton is to officiate at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. A Russian Orthodox ceremony follows at Our Lady of the Sign in New York, with the Rev. George Larin officiating.

headline: Lacy Garcia, Jack Roosevelt

Garcia of Prides Crossing, Mass., was married Saturday to John Alexander Roosevelt, the son of Patricia Oakes Leigh-Wood of Nassau, the Bahamas, and the late Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., who lived in Millbrook, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Timothy B. Cogan, a retired Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. John’s Episcopal Church in Beverly Farms, Mass.

text: Leonor Denise Ayala and Harold Ferguson Polley were married Thursday by the Rev. Stephen F. Spahn, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. George Roman Catholic Church in Guilford, Conn.

headline: Tracie Strahan and Zelkadis Elvi
text: Tracie Jorge Strahan and Zelkadis Rozz Elvi were married Saturday. The Rev. Violet L. Dease officiated at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in New York, where she is the assistant pastor.

text: Diana Wilson White and Benjamin Clarke Smeal were married Saturday at St. Mark’s Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn.

headline: Laina Vlasnik and Nelson Yip

Bettina Yiannakourou, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated at Bayard’s, a restaurant in Manhattan.

headline: Amanda Lenhart, Scott Smallwood
text: Amanda Brooks Lenhart and Scott Brian Smallwood were married Saturday at the summer home of the bride’s family in Gloucester, Mass. The Rev. Gordon M. Forbes, a retired minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

headline: Sara Benson, Anthony Streich
text: Sara Lanning Benson and Anthony John Streich were married Saturday evening at the Potomac United Methodist Church in Potomac, Md. The Rev. Dr. Ann R. Laprade, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Clayton Dunn, Zachary Patton
text: Clayton Thomas Dunn and Zachary Lee Patton were married Saturday in their apartment in Washington. The Rev. Kent E. Lewis, a Lutheran minister who is Mr. Patton’s stepfather, officiated.

headline: Allison McClain, Brian Joyce
text: Allison Jane McClain and Brian Thomas Joyce were married Saturday at Trinity Church in Boston. The Rev. Paige F. Fisher, an Episcopal priest and an associate rector at the church, led the ceremony.

headline: Maria Thomas, Joseph Kurian

headline: In Marja, Violence and Intimidation Depress Vote

headline: Free Admission to Museums Nationwide
text: Calling all museum fanatics! On Sept. 25, more than 1,000 museums and cultural institutions nationwide will offer free admission as part of Smithsonian magazine’s sixth annual Museum Day. You can search for participating museums and download the ticket at Smithsonian.com/museumday. Each ticket grants free entry to two people, but the pass is limited to one ticket per household.

headline: Urban Forager | Wild Apples
text: I have been fond of apples and apple trees for as long as I can remember. I grew up with a crab apple tree in front of our apartment in Flushing, Queens, which my Manhattan-born mother misidentified as a cherry blossom tree. At the start of every spring and autumn, I was beguiled by the dense cluster of flowers and fruit I saw through our living room window.

headline: From Cashman, Kind Words for Torre
text: BALTIMORE — Don Mattingly will remain absent from the Yankees’ Old-Timers’ Day for the foreseeable future, given his impending job as manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers. But what about Joe Torre, whom Mattingly is succeeding?

headline: Palin the Front-Runner?
text: According to a bipartisan chorus — right, center-right, and liberal — the victory of Christine O’Donnell in Delaware’s primary proves that the race for the Republican nomination in 2012 is no longer wide open, because Sarah Palin is officially the front-runner. This strikes me as bunkum for many of the reasons that Ramesh Ponnuru and Daniel Larison discuss, and especially for this one: It is extremely unlikely that the political landscape in the winter and spring of 2012 will resemble the political landscape in the autumn of 2010. Even setting aside the unpredictability of economic developments, foreign-policy crises, and everything else that could shift the ground beneath our feet, the reality of having a more empowered Republican Party in Washington and a weaker President Obama in the White House will almost certainly work profound changes on the country’s mood — and yes, in the mood of the Republican base as well. (It’s hard to be quite so fired up and furious about socialism when Washington is mired in gridlock, and it’s hard to be quite so outraged at RINO perfidy when you’ve kicked a lot of the RINOs out of office.) The temper of conservative politics in the fall of 1994, the off-year election cycle that most resembles this one (it was a year, as Rich Lowry notes, when a former homeless man defeated the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee), bore little resemblance to the temper of conservative politics in 1996, when Bob Dole cruised to the Republican nomination over more base-pleasing candidates like Pat Buchanan and Phil Gramm. And while it’s likely that the Tea Parties will lend a greater resilience to the present anti-establishment spirit, 12-t0-18 months of divided government will almost certainly have a dampening effect on the impulses that carried Christine O’Donnell to victory.

headline: Reservoir in Gulf May Still Be Used

headline: U.N. Poverty Goals Face Accountability Questions
text: UNITED NATIONS — For all the bitter debates pitting nations against one another, there is conspicuously little disagreement over the United Nations goal of eliminating dire poverty. Virtually none of the countries that signed onto the endeavor in 2000 faults the idea of eradicating hunger, educating children, improving maternal health or combating disease. It would be like opposing mother’s milk.

headline: Prime Number
text: 8.4: The percentage increase in the last two years of people aged 25 to 34 who are living with their parents, according to Census Bureau estimates. More than 40 percent of those 5.5 million people earned less than $11,161 a year, the poverty threshold for a single person under 65. But most were not counted as poor because the government measures poverty by overall household income. “A lot of people would have been worse off if they didn’t have someone to move in with,” said Timothy M. Smeeding, director of the Institute for Research on Poverty at the University of Wisconsin. Still, 14.3 percent of Americans lived in poverty last year, the highest percentage since 1994. The rise was steepest for children, with one in five affected.

text: There are no books in the new Applied Engineering and Technology Library at the University of Texas at San Antonio. None.

The larger houses, barely inhabited, many of them empty, belong to overseas workers who plan to return here one day.

In Manhattan, a summit has nothing to do with crampons and ice picks, but refers instead to a large gathering of important persons, head-of-state types and their rock-star retinues in the vicinity of the United Nations building and creates, therefore, a near total immobilization of the East Side. headline: How Underwater Mortgages Can Float the Economy
text: RECENT calls for another federal stimulus package raise an important question: Before considering costly short-term measures to raise overall consumer demand, have we done enough to ensure that financial markets will work properly and lead us to recovery? For housing  the sector at the center of the crisis  the answer is no. But the good news is that it might be possible to improve the housing market and invigorate the economy in a way that won’t require a costly stimulus package.

headline: Your Comments on My Apology to Muslims
text: My Sunday column is a bit unusual: it’s in the form of an apology to Muslims for all the hysteria and invective directed in their direction lately. As I write, I find the caricature on the airwaves to be deeply offensive, given the number of heroic Muslim peacemakers and aid workers I’ve seen around the world, risking their lives to make the globe a better place. Like all groups, Muslims run the gamut from saintly to evil, and crude stereotypes are unhelpful and wrong.

headline: In the Chase, Harvick Is Pursuing a Car That Will Never Be Caught

He feels as if an eternity has passed since Feb. 23, 2001, when he was introduced as Dale Earnhardt’s replacement  as if anyone could really replace stock-car racing’s Intimidator.

headline: The Patch

text: Like a petulant 2-year-old, the hyperbolic analyses of the Tea Party’s primary victories need a timeout. Political America should quietly listen to a mostly forgotten, gravelly voiced United States senator from Illinois.

headline: Officers See More Sick and Elderly Selling Prescription Drugs
text: In Gregory Watts’s 13 years as a San Francisco police officer, he has arrested countless drug dealers. But only recently did he begin to notice that many of them resembled his grandparents.

headline: The Pulse

headline: 3 Protesters Are Killed in Kashmir
text: NEW DELHI  The death toll in the restive region of Kashmir continued to rise on Saturday, with at least three more protesters being killed, including reports of security officers firing on a crowd that had defied the curfew to march in the funeral procession of a young boy.

headline: For Thome, Nothing Adds Up to a Ring
text: CHICAGO  For a man who swings so ferociously, like a lumberjack with a hammer ringing the bell at a county fair, Jim Thome is all soft edges. He keeps his hair short, and his ears stick out, and he looks you in the eye when he talks. He nods and smiles a lot, often repeating things, earnestly, for emphasis. He is 40 and built like a mountain, yet somehow he seems like a boy.

headline: Comparing China’s Schools and Ours
text: To the Editor:

headline: Behind Venice’s Ads, the Restoration of Its Heritage
text: VENICE  Legend has it that the Bridge of Sighs, which connects the Palazzo Ducale here to an ancient prison, got its name because it gave convicts on the way to serve their sentences a last glimpse of the limpid lagoon.

headline: A Painful Footnote
text: Second baseman Luis Hernandez, up from the minor leagues and trying to establish a name for himself, earned at least a footnote in Mets history with a singular moment of pain and gain Saturday afternoon when the Mets lost, 4-2, to the Atlanta Braves at Citi Field.

headline: The Steelers at the Intersection of Iron City Beer and Art Basel
text: PITTSBURGH — An art gallery sent crews into the cramped basement of a die-hard Steelers fan to box up his vast and eccentric collection of black-and-gold paraphernalia.

headline: With Torre on Market, Who Should Mets Pursue as Manager?
text: Don Mattingly, who will take over the Dodgers next season, would have been an intriguing choice as manager of the Mets if for no other reason than the consternation it would have caused Yankees fans if Mattingly had then gone on to win a World Series ring in Queens.

headline: Stitching a Life From the Scraps of Others
text: About 300 Warao people live by Venezuela’s sprawling trash dump Cambalache, combing it for food, clothing and scrap metal.

headline: Left Behind in Venezuela to Piece Lives Together
text: CIUDAD GUAYANA, Venezuela  The first scavengers one sees in Cambalache, a sprawling trash dump on this city’s edge, are the vultures. Hundreds drift through the veil of smoke that rises from the refuse each day at dawn.

headline: Missouri Tells Judges Cost of Sentences
text: ST. LOUIS  When judges here sentence convicted criminals, a new and unusual variable is available for them to consider: what a given punishment will cost the State of Missouri.

headline: Manfred Gans Is Dead at 88; Combed Wartime Europe for His Parents
text: He was 16 when his parents sent him to England, fearing for his life as a Jew in Nazi Germany, and when war broke out he clamored to join the British armed forces. Finally he was accepted, his fluency in German earning him a spot with a secret commando unit. And with that, Manfred Gans set off on a mission: to find his parents.

headline: America’s Cup Reunion Revels in 12-Meter Era
text: NEWPORT, R.I. — With their multihulls and carbon-fiber bodies, the new America’s Cup boats are light and lightning fast. But it is their predecessors, the sleek 12-meter yachts used from 1958 to 1987, that warm the hearts of veteran sailors. More than 700 people, including 250 sailors, gathered last week at the waterfront home of the New York Yacht Club for their first reunion, three days of racing and a backward glance at what many call the golden age of sailing.

headline: Bias Against Italian-Americans
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Appointment With the Cable Guy?
text: Anyone who has ever wasted half the day waiting for a cable TV technician who showed up late or not at all will find satisfaction in the contract that New York City is close to finalizing with the cable companies. The consumer protection provisions are long overdue and timely, given that Time Warner Cable and Cablevision are now providing not just television but Internet access and telephone service as well.

headline: Pitcher’s Path to Major League Debut at 30 Was No Pipeline
text: The Kansas City Royals used two pitchers against the Oakland Athletics on Monday. The starter was Luke Hochevar, and the reliever was Bryan Bullington. They each began their professional careers as the No. 1 overall pick in the draft.

headline: Longtime Official, Hobbled by Bad Knee, Plans a Comeback
text: An envelope containing the N.B.A.’s referee schedule arrived in Steve Javie’s mailbox the other day, as it has every September for the last 25 years. This one felt different.

headline: Blacks Debate What Is Next in the Wide-Open Mayoral Race
text: The last time anyone not named Daley had a legitimate shot at being elected mayor of Chicago, the city was an emotional tinderbox. Residents and politicians were still reeling from the sudden death two years earlier of Harold Washington, Chicago’s first black mayor, and the racially charged “council wars” that raged during his administration.

headline: Huskers’ Young Quarterback Upstages Locker
text: SEATTLE  Nebraska Coach Bo Pelini said he could not predict how the redshirt freshman quarterback Taylor Martinez would perform in his first start in a hostile environment.

headline: A Spruced Up, More Profitable 18 Holes, but Still ...
text: The Park District hired new management last year, hoping to improve the shabby condition of its six golf courses.

headline: Florida Beats Tennessee but Still Has Long Way to Go
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — Moments into his postgame news conference Saturday, Florida Coach Urban Meyer seemed to pause and consider the uneven play of the 10th-ranked Gators. He said he understood that his team, which is dotted with freshmen, redshirt freshmen and first-time starters, had not come together yet.

headline: With Torre Available on Job Market, the Mets’ Manuel Knows the Score
text: In a light moment Saturday before the Atlanta Braves beat the Mets, 4-2, at Citi Field, Manager Jerry Manuel discussed Joe Torre, the Dodgers’ manager, who is choosing to leave his job.

headline: Healthy on Road Trumps Being Hobbled at Home
text: BALTIMORE  The Yankees awoke here Saturday atop the American League East, the place they have spent virtually all the second half of the season  with a few days this past week, when the Tampa Bay Rays overtook them, standing as the most glaring interruption.

headline: Wayne Hunter Turning Into Jets’ ‘Versatile Guy’
text: It wasn’t an error in the game notes or a mistake on the part of the television or radio announcers. Jets lineman Wayne Hunter was really checking into the game on defense.

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. to Play in South Africa — Again
text: U.S. Soccer announced on Friday that the men’s national team would play South Africa in an exhibition game on Nov. 17 in Cape Town. The friendly will take place three years to the day after the Americans’ first trip to South Africa, and it will be their fourth trip to the country in the last 36 months.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Last Wednesday night, Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter pretended to be hit by a pitch and was awarded first base in a 4-3 loss to the Tampa Bay Rays. Although many people in baseball considered his act a shrewd maneuver, many readers viewed it less positively. Here are some of their responses:

headline: Haunted Man of the Cloth and Pioneer of Gay Rights
text: The death this month of Seymour Pine, the vice officer who in June 1969 led a police raid on the Stonewall Inn in Greenwich Village, unwittingly galvanizing the gay rights movement, is a reminder that history has its forgotten actors, too. For every star in the history of gay rights — think the politician Harvey Milk, or the comedian Ellen DeGeneres — there are many more bit players, people whose names do not even make the credits.

headline: The Mechanisms of a Controlled Trial
text: In the United States, the Food and Drug Administration must approve an experimental drug like PLX4032 before it can be marketed. The process involves several stages, including laboratory and animal studies; controlled clinical trials for safety and effectiveness; and F.D.A. review. The trials are in four phases:

headline: New Drugs Stir Debate on Rules of Clinical Trials
text: Growing up in California’s rural Central Valley, the two cousins spent summers racing dirt bikes and Christmases at their grandmother’s on the coast. Endowed with a similar brash charm, they bought each other matching hardhats and sought iron-working jobs together. They shared a love for the rush that comes with hanging steel at dizzying heights, and a knack for collecting speeding tickets.

headline: G.O.P. Insider Fuels Tea Party and Suspicion
text: WASHINGTON  In the days leading up to the Delaware primary, Sal Russo hosted a radio fund-raiser, organized a political rally and pressed the case with reporters that Christine O’Donnell was the Tea Party’s choice for the United States Senate. He also set off what he calls a “money bomb,” pouring at least $250,000 into television and other advertisements promoting the little-known candidate.

headline: College Football Photo Replay: Sept. 18
text: The day in college football.

headline: Sabathia Reaches 20 Wins for the First Time
text: BALTIMORE  No one has been better the past year at pitching at home than C. C. Sabathia. And he might as well have been pitching at Yankee Stadium on Saturday considering how many Yankees fans packed into Camden Yards.

text: The house Christos Raftopoulos built on his father’s native Ithaca, a small island in the Ionian Sea about two hours from Athens, captured his heart and soul.

headline: A Historic Renovation in Charleston
text: In South Carolina, a luxurious 21st-century home built within an 18th-century structure.

text: This traditional Western town has Rocky Mountain views.

text: Toni Hilton has a fascination with real estate Monferrato region of northern Italy.

text: Cornwall, England, is a mecca for retirees and second-home owners.

headline: A French-Style Town House in Brussels
text: A three-bedroom, four-story town house in the Ixelles Neighborhood of Brussels is on the market for 850,000 euros ($1 million).

headline: Properties for $230,000
text: A condo in downtown Nashville, a house in Boise, Idaho, and a house in Pittsburgh.

headline: Q. and A. With Rick Cerone
text: After being drafted by Cleveland out of Seton Hall University in 1975, Rick Cerone played catcher for eight teams, including the Yankees and the Mets, in 18 major league seasons. He brought minor league baseball back to his birthplace in 1998 as the owner of the Newark Bears. Last month, Cerone, 56, participated in a golf tournament to benefit the Sean Kimerling Testicular Cancer Foundation, which works to raise awareness of the importance of early diagnosis and treatment. Kimerling, who died of the disease in 2003 at age 37, was an anchor for WPIX and a pregame announcer for the Mets.

headline: Obama Rallies Congressional Black Caucus
text: WASHINGTON — For seemingly every occasion where two or more Democrats gather these days, President Obama plays the role of commander in chief for his party’s get-out-the-vote operations, and Saturday night’s gala benefit for a Congressional Black Caucus foundation was no different.

headline: A Little Nudge, and a Soul Singer Is Back to Her Roots
text: NORTH ADAMS, Mass.

headline: Girardi Comments After Another Guthrie Pitch Hits a Yankee
text: Joe Girardi is none too pleased with the Orioles right-hander Jeremy Guthrie, and it is not the first time.

headline: Dissonance on Green Detergents
text: As I note in a Sunday article about the new, low-phosphate dishwasher detergents, consumers are not always thrilled about the performance of environmentally friendly cleaning products. But such products have been gaining acceptance, mainly because of health concerns. Many states and local governments have passed laws requiring the use of these products in schools and other government institutions. Labor unions representing janitors and housekeeping staff have meanwhile begun to push for language in their contracts to also require less toxic products.

headline: Vows: Laina & Nelson
text: Laina Vlasnik agreed to date Nelson Yip if he'd draft a list of the top 10 things to do in New York.  He obliged, and on their first date she concluded she'd found someone delightfully different.

headline: Philippine Troops Kill Wanted Militant
text: MANILA  Military officials said Sunday that Philippine troops had killed a top Islamic militant who had helped plan and carry out the kidnapping of three Americans and 17 Filipinos from a popular resort in 2001.

headline: Joining the Two-Wheelers in Prague
text: Not so long ago, riding a bike through the streets of Prague was what many locals deemed a death wish. There were few bike lanes and the idea of cyclists’ rights, as in most post-Communist capitals, was an alien concept. This is all exactly what makes the Critical Mass ride through Prague, to be held on Sept. 25, unique in comparison to some other mass bike rides in cities that have long embraced a pedal-to-work culture.

headline: All the Group Buying Deals in One Place
text: With so many group buying sites out there now, it can be hard to keep tabs on all the deals available. Luckily, aggregation sites will now put together, and even sometimes sort through, these collective buying coupons for you from the likes of Groupon and others.

headline: Ines Sainz Is Critical of Female Sportswriters Who Defended Her
text: Fast reads from around the Web:

headline: The Sorrow And The Self-Pity
text: Everywhere you look these days, there are terrible stories. I live in a very sheltered world, yet I know young people just out of college who can’t find jobs, men in their late 50s who have lost their jobs and can’t see how they’ll ever find another, families barely scraping by and terrified by what might happen if anyone gets sick.

headline: Home (Market) Truths
text: Wow — a blast from my past (very wonkish). I worked out the math of the home market effect on my kitchen table back in 1978; this was the picture that made sense of it all:

headline: Dozens Dead After Baghdad Car Bombs
text: BAGHDAD  Two powerful bombs ripped through the capital, and one hit the western city of Falluja on Sunday, killing at least 35 people and wounding more than 100. It was one of the worst days of deadly mayhem since the American military declared an official end to its combat operations in Iraq nearly three weeks ago.

headline: Taiwanese Tourists Shot in New Delhi
text: NEW DELHI  Two armed assailants riding a motorcycle opened fire on a tourist bus parked outside of New Delhi’s most famous mosque on Sunday, in an attack that comes as the city prepares to host the Commonwealth Games in two weeks.

headline: A Seneca Indian Connects With His New York Roots
text: Into a hotel suite of white wine, gray hair and Oxford shirts, the ponytailed Seneca entered in his bright red duck cloth frock, knitted strips tied around his beaded leggings and a broad medal across his chest inspired by the one George Washington gave his great-great-uncle’s uncle, Red Jacket.

headline: After Afghan Vote, Complaints of Fraud Surface
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The farmers in Nagahan, a village in Kandahar Province, lined up early to cast their votes on Saturday, but there were no ballots and no ballot boxes, making the election seem a cruel joke.

headline: Cloud Computing Hits Snag in Europe
text: BERLIN — In the world of ideas, cloud computing has the potential to revolutionize the way people work.

headline: Wallace Turner, Pulitzer Prize-Winning Reporter, Is Dead at 89
text: Wallace Turner, who shared a Pulitzer Prize for exposing corruption in Portland, Ore., as a reporter there, and who later illuminated the inner workings of the Mormon Church while covering the American West for The New York Times, died Saturday in Springfield, Ore. He was 89 and lived in Eugene.

headline: U.S. Says BP Well Is Finally ‘Dead’
text: The federal government declared BP’s Macondo oil well dead on Sunday, nearly five months after it blew out of control, unleashing an environmental calamity in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Two Lives, Two Loves, One Con Man
text: “Big Love,” an HBO series about a Mormon ménage à quatre, opened minds to the notion that a man can manage three wives. But it was a reality show, “The Bachelor,” that trained viewers to believe that a young man can be passionately in love with two women at the same time.

headline: Missing Religious Group Found Alive in California
text: PALMDALE, Calif.  The frantic search began after police issued an alert: Members of a cult on the edge of the Mojave Desert had disappeared, leaving behind handwritten notes that raised fears they had planned a mass suicide.

headline: The Sunday Word: Third Party?
text: As the primary season comes to an end, Washington is trying to make sense of how the Tea Party fits into a two-party town.

headline: Ahmadinejad Wants Release of Iranians Held in U.S.
text: One of the three American hikers held in Iran for 13 months on spying charges arrived in the United States on Sunday as the Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, said that the United States, as “a humanitarian gesture,” should now release eight Iranians whom he said were illegally arrested.

headline: Consumer Spending and the Economy
text: The U.S. economy is predominantly driven by consumer spending, which accounts for approximately 70 percent of all economic growth. But if consumers are to continue to drive the economy, they must be in a sound financial position; if they become overburdened with debt, they are not able to maintain their position as the primary driver of economic growth. To that end, consider the following table which shows the total amount of household debt (all consumer loans and mortgages), total nominal gross domestic product, total nominal disposable personal income, the ratio of household debt to G.D.P. and the ratio of household debt to total disposable personal income. All numbers are in billions:

headline: Facebook Denies It Is Secretly Building a Phone
text: The tech blogs were abuzz Sunday with a report in TechCrunch that Facebook is secretly building a phone.

headline: Michigan State Coach Has Heart Attack
text: Michigan State Coach Mark Dantonio had a heart attack late Saturday, shortly after the Spartans’ thrilling overtime victory against Notre Dame.

headline: E.U. Laws Shielding Journalists’ Sources Limited
text: PARIS — In January 2008, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France declared his intention of protecting reporters from having to disclose the names of their sources — a safeguard that many journalists say is necessary for free media to thrive.

headline: Rat Race America
text: Brad DeLong’s post on Todd Henderson, the already-infamous whining Chicago professor who appears to be near the 99th percentile but feels poor, is worth reading for more than the takedown. Brad isn’t the first to make this point, but his discussion of how rising inequality at the top — a fatter right tail in the income distribution — makes the objectively rich feel poor is exceptionally fine:

headline: Bailing Out the Big Guys, Posthaste
text: In the epilogue to his new book, “Overhaul,” Steven Rattner tallies up the bill for the government assistance that spared General Motors, Chrysler and their financial subsidiaries and automotive suppliers from ruin.

headline: Torre and Mattingly to Attend Steinbrenner Ceremony
text: BALTIMORE — Joe Torre is scheduled to attend the monument dedication to George Steinbrenner at Yankee Stadium before Monday night’s game against Tampa Bay, his first visit since a bitter split after the 2007 season ended his successful 12-year run as manager. General Manager Brian Cashman said last week that Torre was “welcome anytime.”

headline: Newsweek’s Howard Fineman to Join The Huffington Post
text: Howard Fineman, one of the more recognizable pundits on cable television and a correspondent for Newsweek for 30 years, is leaving the magazine to become a senior editor at The Huffington Post.

headline: Pope Ends British Trip With Beatification
text: BIRMINGHAM, England  A day after drawing both adoring crowds and the largest protests of his papacy, Pope Benedict XVI wrapped up a historic and contentious four-day visit to Britain on Sunday, moving a Catholic convert one step closer to sainthood and recalling the valor of Britons during the Second World War.

headline: Protesters Return to Bangkok Streets
text: BANGKOK  Antigovernment protesters returned to the streets here on Sunday in a large but short-lived demonstration that underlined the persistent divisions in Thailand four months after a military crackdown.

headline: Swedish Anti-Immigration Party Claims Seats
text: STOCKHOLM  Sweden became the latest European nation to see a breakthrough for populist right-wingers Sunday, when the anti-immigration Sweden Democrats won their first parliamentary seats in elections that failed to produce a clear outcome.

headline: Live Analysis: Jets Beat Patriots, 28-14
text: They looked deflated. The faith in their quarterback seemed to be wavering. Their coach was on the verge of becoming the butt of jokes around the N.F.L. But the Jets were never defeated, and they displayed their resolve against the rival New England Patriots.

headline: After Six Decades, Paterno Is Year to Year
text: With a 24-0 victory over Kent State on Saturday, No. 23 Penn State won its 500th game since Joe Paterno joined the staff as an assistant coach in 1950. That is a long time and a lot of games, but Penn State does not have a succession plan in place for the 83-year-old Paterno.

text: Nymph

headline: Five Dead in German Hospital Shooting
text: BERLIN  A woman opened fire Sunday in a hospital in Germany’s Black Forest in the south of the country, killing four people and seriously wounding several others before fatally shooting herself, German officials said.

headline: Mets Showing Signs of Pluck, if Not Improvement
text: Luis Hernandez hobbled into work Sunday on crutches with a medical boot on his right foot to protect his broken big toe. His season is over but the reason for it may linger in Mets’ lore.

headline: Ask an Expert About Melanoma
text: In her ongoing series in The New York Times, Amy Harmon describes the promise and challenges of new drug testing for melanoma, the most deadly form of skin cancer. Today’s story, “New Drugs Stir Debate on Rules of Clinical Trial,” describes two cousins who developed the lethal cancer; only one could take part in an experimental drug trial.

headline: At the Buffett Cup in Wales, a Defensive-Signaling Show
text: The third Buffett Cup, contested between Europe and the United States last week in Cardiff, Wales, featured several excellently played and defended deals. The one in the diagram exhibited signaling that makes defense more accurate.

headline: The Meat Eaters
text: Viewed from a distance, the natural world often presents a vista of sublime, majestic placidity. Yet beneath the foliage and hidden from the distant eye, a vast, unceasing slaughter rages. Wherever there is animal life, predators are stalking, chasing, capturing, killing, and devouring their prey. Agonized suffering and violent death are ubiquitous and continuous. This hidden carnage provided one ground for the philosophical pessimism of Schopenhauer, who contended that “one simple test of the claim that the pleasure in the world outweighs the pain…is to compare the feelings of an animal that is devouring another with those of the animal being devoured.”

headline: For O’Donnell, Rewinding to the ’90s
text: Christine O’Donnell’s opponents are going to the videotape, and there is plenty of it.

headline: Estate Of Confusion
text: Digby finds another hard-working, wealth-creating salt of the earth type complaining about the possibility of higher taxes: Ben Stein. I think I need a drink.

headline: City Critic: A Ceremony, Not Marriage
text: At the Manhattan Marriage Bureau, a lesbian couple experiences the new individual commitment ceremony offered to those registering for domestic partnership.

headline: The Kisses, the Bites, the Humor of Rodgers and Hart
text: An insomniac’s fantasy of a dream lover hovering over your bed night after night; a prayer for true love that is answered by the sudden appearance of the perfect mate; a mystical moment of romantic déjà vu: those are experiences described in “Dancing on the Ceiling,” “Blue Moon” and “Where or When,” three of the most famous songs by Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart. To hear Karen Akers sing them in her revelatory Rodgers and Hart show, “Dancing on the Ceiling” at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, is almost like listening to them for the first time.

headline: Monday: Longevity
text: We have a special behind-the-scenes feature below, but first, today’s record-setting puzzle.

headline: A Pair of Travelers, Saving London Puzzle by Puzzle
text: Remember edutainment?

headline: The Sailor Who Fell Into Grace With the Wig-Wearing Nymphs
text: A questing hero, a cigarette-smoking ballerina, a grove of white-wigged nymphs and a corps de ballet of Louise Brooks look-alikes populate the deliriously strange, funny world of Alexei Ratmansky’s “Namouna, a Grand Divertissement”  perhaps the oddest and most delightful ballet to pop up in recent memory.

headline: Pettitte Provides the Good News in Losing Effort
text: BALTIMORE  Around the Yankees, the word playoffs is not taboo, even with a berth yet to be clinched this year. They fully expect to be playing beyond September  through October, to be precise  which is why Manager Joe Girardi did not flinch Sunday morning when asked whether three starts were sufficient for Andy Pettitte to round into postseason form.

headline: Snapshots of One Dancer’s Life Give a Glimpse Into an Art Form
text: Jérôme Bel is a French choreographer who doesn’t create steps. Instead he lets others do that for him, whether it’s the dancers whose stories he shapes in documentary-like accounts of their lives or the singers whose words he converts into a literal physicality.

headline: Snippets of Sensation, Clanging Violence and Raging Solos
text: Carrie Ahern’s dance installation “SeNSATE,” originally shown at the Brooklyn Lyceum, began as a collaboration with Nietzsche scholars. Now in residence at the Vault at 14 Wall Street, the underground bank vault where it was first created, the only obvious point it shares with Nietzsche is a sense of nothingness. In the case of this performance, presented by Ms. Ahern and the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, that is hardly a good thing.

headline: 'SeNSATE'
text: Images from Carrie Ahern’s dance installation at an underground bank vault in New York.

headline: Anxiety Wrapped in Gleaming Pop and Lamé
text: Kevin Barnes, the Lady Gaga of indie rock, didn’t stint on polymorphous spectacle when his band, Of Montreal, began its two-night stand at Terminal 5 on Friday night. His seven backup musicians were all dressed in white, while dancers appeared as fish-headed robots, skulls, angels in silver bikinis, faceless checkerboard-skinned aliens and, at one point, a blond dragon for Mr. Barnes to ride.

headline: A Sitcom With More Than Empty Calories
text: Statistics from The Journal of the American Medical Association tell us that two-thirds of men and women in this country are overweight or obese, and this figure doesn’t even account for the legions of perpetual dieters who merely consider themselves too big. Much of television, by design or effect, strips away at the confidence of the very heavy — what is left of it after the world has had its way. Series like “Desperate Housewives” or “Cougar Town” flaunt the radical thinness of middle-age women; competitive reality spectacles like “The Biggest Loser” perceive obesity as laziness, suggesting that it can be combated and self-esteem improved by the simple application of free-market principles.

headline: The Heart That Beats, Heats, Chills and Whips
text: Sometimes a kitchen is just a kitchen, but not often. If a house is a machine for living, as Le Corbusier said, then the kitchen is its engine. If that machine is seen as a living organism  a house that is a home  then the kitchen is its heart and brain.

headline: 'Counter Space'
text: Images from a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

headline: New CDs
text: SANTANA

headline: The Song Remains the Same, but the Breed of Cop Has Changed
text: One of the longest-running crime shows on television, “Hawaii Five-O,” the remake of which begins on Monday, had its debut in 1968 and did not make its exit from American living rooms until the end of the Carter administration. The rich cinematography offered provocative incentives for leaving the mainland, which, in the show’s imagination, thieves, swindlers, hit men, loonies and dropouts were doing in droves, turning Hawaii into a modern Wild West that required especially rigorous law enforcement.

headline: Wedding Bells Thwarted by Bothersome Conspiracy
text: “The Event,” which begins Monday on NBC, is in some part a series about a young couple just starting out, but to describe it that way would be like calling “24” a drama about an unusual number of traffic hassles occurring during a single day. As the series unfolds, Sean (Jason Ritter), a rumpled but well-meaning romantic, and Leila (Sarah Roemer), an earthy blonde, are about to become engaged, except that — and here I quote from NBC press materials with verbiage I could not surpass — “their futures are on a collision course in a global conspiracy that could ultimately change the fate of mankind.” Couples counseling is unlikely to provide solace.

headline: As Killings Mount in Houston, Marshal Dons Cowboy Boots and Starts Running
text: “Chase” may be the ideal title for a series from the Jerry Bruckheimer Television factory, with its suggestion of relentless propulsion and no time to stop and think. The pilot episode on Monday night on NBC opens with a shot of the pounding feet of the show’s star, Kelli Giddish, and spends its first three and a half minutes tracking her as she runs down a bad guy, disrupting a ceremonial cattle drive along the way.

headline: ‘The Town’ Enjoys a Strong Opening
text: “The Town,” Ben Affleck’s robbery thriller, walked away with a stronger-than-expected $23.8 million in ticket sales over the weekend, enough to make it an easy No. 1 at the North American box office. Mr. Affleck (above, in the film with Rebecca Hall) directed, acted in and was a writer of “The Town,” which Warner Brothers backed with an aggressive marketing campaign. (An Oscar push is next.) “Easy A,” a teenage comedy from Sony Pictures Entertainment, was second, with about $18 million in sales, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. “Devil,” a horror entry produced by M. Night Shyamalan and distributed by Universal Pictures, finished third, with $12.6 million. Sony’s “Resident Evil: Afterlife 3D” plummeted to fourth place in its second weekend, selling about $10 million in tickets for a new domestic total of about $44 million. Rounding out the Top 5 was “Alpha and Omega,” an animated movie that Lionsgate has marketed to very young children, with about $9 million in sales.

headline: Organizers Dissolve the New York Collegium
text: The New York Collegium, a period-instrument band that sometimes performed with a chorus, acknowledged in a news release signed by two of its directors on Saturday what had become apparent over several seasons: that it would no longer function as an independent entity. The Collegium, whose Web site still lists the English early-music specialist Andrew Parrott as its music director, gave its first concert in early 1999 and performed series through the 2006-7 season. The name has since surfaced almost solely in connection with an annual workshop, the Clarion-Collegium Week, instituted in 2008 and shared with the Clarion Music Society. That society, founded in 1957 by the period-instrument pioneer Newell Jenkins, who died in 1996, has been revivified under Steven Fox, its artistic director since 2005. The Collegium “will dissolve and continue its legacy under the umbrella” of the Clarion society, the release said. The directors, evidently speaking for the full board, pointed to the Collegium’s successes, but added, “We nevertheless believe that the current economic environment will not support the sustainability of an independent Collegium.” Clarion, they said, has made clear its intention to add several Collegium directors to its board, to continue the Clarion-Collegium Week and to “maintain a relationship” with Mr. Parrott.

headline: ‘Spartacus’ Star Withdraws From Series
text: A recurrence of cancer has forced Andy Whitfield, the lead actor on the Starz series “Spartacus: Blood and Sand,” to withdraw from the show. The channel said in a statement late Friday that it had not decided whether to continue the series without him. Earlier this year Starz adjusted the shooting schedule for the second season of “Spartacus”  the signature production of that premium cable channel  while Mr. Whitfield, right, was being treated for non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma; the adjustments included ordering a prequel to the series, which is moving forward. In June Mr. Whitfield was said to be cancer-free, and the second season was tentatively scheduled to make its debut in September 2011. The new diagnosis has upended that plan. “Our hearts and prayers are with Andy and his family during this difficult time,” Chris Albrecht, the chief executive of Starz, said in a statement. “Andy is not only an incredible actor whose portrayal of Spartacus made an indelible impression on Starz audiences, he is also an amazing human being whose courage, strength and grace in the face of adversity have inspired all of us.”

headline: Footnotes
text: The actress Robin Wright (“The Private Lives of Pippa Lee”) has canceled her Broadway debut in the revival of Lanford Wilson’s play “Talley’s Folly,” Playbill reported. Scheduling conflicts have prevented Ms. Wright, who was to play Sally Talley, a wealthy Missouri woman being courted by an unlikely suitor, a tax collector to be played by Richard Schiff (“The West Wing”), from participating in the production in the spring, Playbill said. A replacement for Ms. Wright, above, performance dates and a theater for the show have not been announced. ...The author and playwright Hanif Kureishi (“My Ear at His Heart,” “My Beautiful Laundrette”) will be awarded the PEN/Pinter Prize, BBC News reported. At a ceremony on Oct. 20 at the British Library, Mr. Kureishi will receive the award, which is for British writers, along with about $1,500.

headline: Roulette Lands New Home in Brooklyn
text: Roulette, a performance space in SoHo that has been a longtime fixture of the downtown avant-garde music scene, is moving to Brooklyn. Roulette, which is operated by a nonprofit organization, announced on Friday that it had signed a 20-year lease on a 7,000-square-foot Art Deco concert hall at Atlantic and Third Avenues in downtown Brooklyn, a few blocks from the Brooklyn Academy of Music. With 25-foot ceilings and room for 600 people, the space offers a major expansion for Roulette, which was founded in 1978. It has been headquartered in lofts in SoHo and TriBeCa, and its current location is in SoHo. Backers hope to open the new hall in the spring. But like Issue Project Room, another stage for experimental performances that recently acquired a big upgrade in downtown Brooklyn, Roulette must make extensive renovations, including new electrical and ventilation systems. Roulette said that it would receive some public financing, but it appealed to patrons and supporters for contributions.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,266 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

text: Inside the great investment houses on Wall Street, business has taken a surprising turn — downward.

text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Mark Sanchez emerged from a swarm of photographers, stopped and thrust his right index finger skyward.

headline: Checking Brett Favre’s Expiration Date
text: Smart football men have written off Brett Favre before, but after his first two outings this year one has to wonder if even Favre is thinking that his latest comeback was a bridge too far.

headline: TV Guide Cuts Path to Relevance
text: There was a time years ago when TV Guide’s fall television preview issues were hundreds of pages thick. Studios would clamor to get their ads placed next to the prime-time listings, knowing that the magazine sat on as many as 20 million coffee tables each week.

headline: Ole Miss Shelves Mascot Fraught With Baggage
text: OXFORD, Miss. — When Levi West walks across campus on game day, admirers sprint to take his photograph. Women coo. Men slap him high-fives. The jovial, 25-year-old senior at the University of Mississippi is not a celebrity in his own right, though.

headline: Trying to Get Unstuck at a Program Ready to Move On
text: BOULDER, Colo.  Before Saturday’s home opener against Hawaii, Colorado Coach Dan Hawkins was so fired up that he head-butted a player who was wearing a helmet. Hawkins took the field with his nose swollen and bloodied, if not broken.

text: BAGHDAD  Two dozen members of Iraq’s newly elected Parliament, including leaders of most of the main coalitions, actually met in Parliament here on Sunday.

headline: Live Analysis: Colts 38, Giants 14
text: Game coverage and live analysis of the Manning Bowl, pitting Eli and the Giants against Peyton and the Colts. Archie will again play the role of Switzerland and wonder what might have been if he had even half the talent his sons are surrounded with when he played. While they are playing in Indianapolis, he will break into their homes and try on their Super Bowl rings.

headline: Fed Expected to Weigh More Stimulus
text: WASHINGTON  With tax rates at the center of the debate over how to revive the stalled recovery, the Federal Reserve is likely to spend its policy meeting on Tuesday weighing the merits of additional steps to stimulate the economy, while deferring some major decisions until later this year.

headline: For Bloomberg, a Round to Remember
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, an avid, even obsessive golfer, has wanted for little as he tries to master the game.

headline: Torre to Attend Steinbrenner Ceremony, Easing a Rift
text: BALTIMORE  The Los Angeles Dodgers have a day off Monday, which will allow their manager, Joe Torre, to end his three-year estrangement from the Yankees to attend the monument dedication to his former boss, George Steinbrenner, at Yankee Stadium. It will be his first visit to the Yankees’ home since a bitter split after the 2007 season ended a 12-year run as manager that included four World Series titles.

headline: Japanese Playing a New Video Game: Catch-Up
text: CHIBA, Japan  A supersonic hedgehog and a plumber named Mario may have been unlikely heroes, but they once dominated video games. Only the Japanese could make innovative games like those, developers here used to boast. The West just didn’t get it.

headline: American Asks Iran to Free Others
text: Sarah Shourd, a teacher released last week after 410 days in an Iranian prison, said Sunday after her arrival back in the United States that she felt only “one-third free” because the two other American hikers arrested with her remain incarcerated in Tehran.

headline: Hudson Tunnel Review Raises Fear for Project
text: Few elected officials have ever inherited a public works project that promised as many benefits as the proposed Hudson River commuter train tunnel is supposed to deliver to the constituents of Gov. Chris Christie.

headline: In Martha Stewart’s Work With Hallmark, Questions for Future
text: LOS ANGELES — A cheerful Martha Stewart was on the line, ready to talk about her new partnership with the Hallmark Channel. Last week, the channel started to run no less than eight hours a day of programming, five days a week, from the décor doyenne’s orbit.

headline: Arrest in Disputed Seas Riles China and Japan
text: TOKYO  What started nearly two weeks ago with the Japanese Coast Guard’s arrest of a Chinese trawler captain in disputed waters has snowballed into a heated diplomatic standoff between China and Japan, highlighting anxieties in Asia about China’s rising power and assertiveness.

headline: Paterson’s No. 2 Calls for Medicaid Overhaul
text: Describing Medicaid as a “massive program” whose growth threatens the state’s finances, Lt. Gov. Richard Ravitch is calling for significant changes in New York’s health care benefits for the poor and disabled, lobbing a volatile issue in the midst of the campaign for a new governor.

headline: Obama Aides Weigh Bid to Tie the G.O.P. to the Tea Party
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s political advisers, looking for ways to help Democrats and alter the course of the midterm elections in the final weeks, are considering a range of ideas, including national advertisements, to cast the Republican Party as all but taken over by Tea Party extremists, people involved in the discussion said.

headline: Jets Cause a Spectacle, This Time on the Field
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Science and the Gulf
text: After months of confusion and contradictory reports, the Obama administration has at last embarked on a systematic effort involving some of the nation’s top scientists to measure the amount of oil remaining in the Gulf of Mexico and its potential impact on marine life. An interim report could be ready in several months.

headline: Dream Time
text: Congress may soon have a chance to repair, in a powerful way, the shambles it has made of immigration. It can pass an amendment to the defense authorization bill due to come before the Senate on Tuesday. The amendment is the Dream Act, an inspired bit of carving from the hugely ambitious, chronically unsuccessful comprehensive immigration reform.

headline: Mormon-Owned Paper Stands With Immigrants
text: SALT LAKE CITY  Joseph A. Cannon is nobody’s liberal. His résumé reads as if it belongs to a delegate to the Republican National Convention, which, incidentally, he was in 2004.

headline: Shortchanging America’s Women
text: Annual earnings data released last Thursday by the Census Bureau confirm a troubling discrepancy facing women workers and their families. Full-time women employees still make, on average, only 77 cents for every dollar earned by men  a lingering gender gap that depresses women’s pay by thousands of dollars.

headline: Patriots’ Offense Stalls in All-Too-Familiar Spot
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Tom Brady could barely spit out the words, so great was his frustration. Another fast start petering out in the second half, a troubling trend that has carried over from last season. A chance to scorch the Jets without their best player on the field wasted.

headline: Miners Die, Congress Dawdles
text: Despite the Senate Republicans’ campaign agenda of nay-saying and filibuster, you would think taxpayers have a right to expect passage of a life-and-death measure to protect the nation’s coal miners. And yet decisive action on even this issue may be shunted aside until after the November elections.

headline: British Chip Designer Prepares for Wider Demand
text: CAMBRIDGE, England  Near the southeastern edge of Cambridge, where this idyllic university town gives way to fields of green, sits the headquarters of ARM Holdings. Neither the modest three-building campus nor its surroundings evoke notions of a thriving hotbed of computing.

headline: Tea Party Victory Opens Rift Between Moderate and Conservative Republicans
text: WASHINGTON  The few remaining Republican centrists in the Senate were eagerly awaiting the arrival of Michael N. Castle of Delaware, a longtime and reliable moderate voice who could provide some counterbalance to the wave of conservatives poised to enter Congress and the steadily rightward shift of party leaders.

headline: The Pope and the Crowds
text: All in all, the visit of Pope Benedict XVI to Britain over the weekend must have been a disappointment to his legions of detractors. Their bold promises notwithstanding, Richard Dawkins and Christopher Hitchens didn’t manage to clap the pope in irons and haul him off to jail. The protests against Benedict’s presence proved a sideshow to the visit, rather than the main event. And the threat (happily empty, it turned out) of an assassination plot provided a reminder of what real religious extremism looks like  as opposed to the gentle scholar, swathed in white, urging secular Britons to look with fresh eyes at their island’s ancient faith.

headline: He Mastered Chess, and Now for the Runway
text: In the chess world, Magnus Carlsen, a 19-year-old Norwegian, is a phenomenon. A grandmaster by the time he was 13, he is ranked No. 1 in the world  the youngest ever.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Dodgers Fan Makes Most of McCourt Divorce Case
text: LOS ANGELES  The scorched-earth divorce case of Frank and Jamie McCourt has pulled back the curtain on the let-them-eat-cake manner in which they have owned and operated the Dodgers.

headline: Political Cauldron Stirred by Old Video of Candidate
text: Critics of Christine O’Donnell, the Tea Party-backed Republican Senate candidate in Delaware, are going to the videotape, and there is plenty of it.

headline: The Angry Rich
text: Anger is sweeping America. True, this white-hot rage is a minority phenomenon, not something that characterizes most of our fellow citizens. But the angry minority is angry indeed, consisting of people who feel that things to which they are entitled are being taken away. And they’re out for revenge.

headline: Witness in 1998 Bombings Is Identified at a Hearing
text: For years, the Tanzanian man had been a mystery, his identity undisclosed. And when he finally testified last week in a heavily guarded courtroom in Manhattan, security was so tight that prosecutors asked the judge to instruct sketch artists to obscure his face in their drawings.

headline: Blurring Satire and Politics
Lidge Is Far From Perfect, but His Slider Looks It
text: PHILADELPHIA  Brad Lidge never promised he could be that pitcher again. The idea of repeating the greatest season a closer could want  perfect in save opportunities, straight through the clincher of the World Series  was never realistic anyway.

headline: Belgian Catholics Remain Anguished by Abuse
text: BRUSSELS  There were 32 worshipers at noontime Mass in a side chapel of the soaring Cathedral of SS. Michael and Gudula, which dates from the 11th century. A third of the faithful were African; there were two nuns and a police officer.

headline: Studies May Not Matter, if Consumers Want to Believe
text: IN a commercial for Truebalance, a new line of women’s toning shoes from New Balance, a woman walking briskly in a park smiles at a man, but instead of meeting her gaze he looks, brow furrowed, at her shoes, which are white and have the clunky, rounded soles that are typical of toning shoes. Then he sees another woman, this one in Truebalance sneakers. He smiles at her, and looking over her shoulder, she smiles back.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: New Journalism Degree to Emphasize Start-Ups
text: The Graduate School of Journalism at the City University of New York wants to capitalize on some of the shifts that have rocked traditional journalism — and traditional journalists — with the creation of the Tow-Knight Center for Entrepreneurial Journalism and a new master of arts degree in entrepreneurial journalism, which the school will announce on Monday.

headline: Moynihan in His Own Words
text: He sniffed at Hillary Rodham Clinton’s smugness, denounced Spiro T. Agnew as a demagogue, opposed Pamela Harriman’s application to a prestigious Manhattan club and called the Peace Corps elitist. He presciently raised the specter of global warming, advocated for safer cars and championed equal rights and recognition for women, especially his wife.

headline: Lottery Numbers
From Afar, a New Kind of Rough-and-Tumble
text: The shirtless men circled and lunged at each other under the bright sun as the crowds watched, rapt, from the sidelines. One combatant, his head lowered like a bull ready to gore, chose an opponent to tag, only to suddenly find himself trapped in an upside-down bear hug and being shaken like a stubborn ketchup bottle as a referee’s whistle blasted.

headline: More Rent Relief for AIDS Patients Is Vetoed
text: Gov. David A. Paterson has vetoed a bill that would have offered more rent relief to roughly 11,000 New Yorkers with H.I.V. or AIDS, his office announced on Sunday, saying the proposed law would strain the state’s already imperiled finances because it was not clear where the money to pay for it would come from.

headline: Nine Seats to Fill on Bench, but None in Stands
text: CHICAGO  At 6 feet 8 inches, Blackhawks defenseman John Scott is a skyscraper on skates. He looks as if he should be paired with the former Sears Tower.

headline: Haitians Cry in Letters: ‘Please — Do Something!’
text: CORAIL-CESSELESSE, Haiti  It was after midnight in a remote annex of this isolated tent camp on a windswept gravel plain. Marjorie Saint Hilaire’s three boys were fast asleep, but her mind was racing.

headline: Evenings of Poetry Provide a Space for New Voices
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — Lukman Derky, the host of a weekly poetry salon here, was in classic form, a beer perched below a microphone he used to joke, to soothe, to provoke. He read a short poem by Mahmoud Darwish, the Palestinian national bard, and gave a shout-out to a regular, a young American named Mitch, who sat in the crowd, among dozens of other foreigners.

headline: Paladino Is Taunting in a Letter to Cuomo
text: Showing no sign of tempering the combative style that helped earn him the Republican nomination for governor, Carl P. Paladino plans to release a taunting and belligerent letter on Monday that questions the manhood of his Democratic opponent, Andrew M. Cuomo, and derides him as a “king-designate” dependent on “daddy’s coattails.”

headline: At Networks, Gloves Are Already Off
text: The new TV season kicks off on Monday night  and it’s sure not starting with a whimper.

text: Worshipers crowded the aisles and spilled out the doorway of a small storefront church in the Bronx, where a small congregation of about 50 swelled on Sunday with those from nearby churches who stopped to offer condolences.

headline: Thieves Cart Off St. Louis Bricks
text: ST. LOUIS — By the time Raymond Feemster awoke to the pounding of firefighters at his door, flames were already licking his shotgun-style home. The vacant house next door, which neighbors said was frequented by squatters, had burst into flames and was now threatening to engulf houses on each side.

headline: A Game Called Kabbadi
text: Cunningham Park became an arena for kabbadi, a Punjabi game, that can be thought of as a combination of rugby and wrestling.

headline: For the Unemployed Over 50, Fears of Never Working Again
text: VASHON ISLAND, Wash.  Patricia Reid is not in her 70s, an age when many Americans continue to work. She is not even in her 60s. She is just 57.

headline: Iraqi Artifacts Are Found in Storeroom
text: BAGHDAD  More than 600 ancient artifacts looted and smuggled out of Iraq, found and returned by the United States, and then lost again for nearly two years were rediscovered in a storeroom of the office of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki on Sunday, an Iraqi official said.

headline: With Revelations of Debt, Georgia Governor’s Race Evens Up
text: LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga.  At a paper-plate luncheon for lawyers and judges on Friday, Nathan Deal, the Republican nominee for governor of Georgia, searched for a metaphor that would resonate. He wanted to describe how it feels to run a major campaign, especially amid revelations last week that he is facing more than $5 million of debt and may need to sell his house to avoid bankruptcy or foreclosure.

headline: A Journalist Whose Sport Is Controversy
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Since Jason Whitlock’s arrival here in 1994 to write a sports column at The Kansas City Star, he has grappled publicly with team owners and coaches, local news media personalities and even the Rev. Al Sharpton. In doing so, he likes to say, he has been speaking “truth to power.”

headline: 5 U.S. Soldiers Accused of Killing Afghan Civilians
text: SEATTLE — The brutal, premeditated killings of three Afghan civilians — allegedly at the hands of American soldiers — are expected to be detailed in military court near here this fall, potentially undermining efforts by the United States as it tries to win support among Afghans in fighting the Taliban.

headline: Reduce, Reuse, Recycle… Oil Rigs
text: Nearly five months after BP’s Macondo well was wrecked in a fiery series of explosions that killed 11 rig workers and unleashed America’s largest oil spill, the well head on the sea floor was officially “killed” over the weekend.
