headline: Bank ‘Bail-Ins’ May Be the Answer
text: The time for “bail-ins” may have come. This idea, in which banks would be rescued with rapid, creditor-enabled restructurings, has been overshadowed by many other plans and some resistance. But regulators are now giving the concept more attention.

headline: Refusing to Take Slogans at Face Value
text: When a new consumer product comes to market, both its brand name and its marketing tag line are the fruit of intense research. Consumers generally realize slogans are a marketer’s attempt to hawk a product, and they unconsciously respond by doing the opposite of what the slogan urges, according to a study to be published next year in The Journal of Consumer Research. But they do not take the same skeptical view of brand names, and are likely to act in accordance with the brand’s “persona.”

headline: William Coblentz, California Power Broker, Dies at 88
text: William Coblentz, who helped shape California’s postwar history  battling Gov. Ronald Reagan as a liberal university regent, representing Patricia Hearst and the Jefferson Airplane as a lawyer, shepherding major building projects as a power broker  died on Sept. 13 in San Francisco. He was 88.

headline: One Manning Stands Out, Leading Colts to a Win
text: INDIANAPOLIS  A game between 2 teams, 90 players and a couple of dozen coaches had been whittled to a singular matchup involving two players who never line up against each another.

headline: Fathi Osman, Scholar of Islam, Dies at 82
text: Fathi Osman, an influential scholar who articulated a liberal version of Islam and published an authoritative guide to the Koran for non-Arabic readers, died on Sept. 11 at his home in Montrose, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Afghanistan’s Parliamentary Elections – Candidates Everywhere
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A singer from “Afghan Star” — our equivalent of “American Idol” — along with dozens of conservative scholars, members of Afghan civil society, hundreds of ex-warlords, former Taliban commanders, old K.G.B.-trained Afghan spies, an amateur comedian, medical doctors, athletes, a couple of young Western-educated Afghans and hundreds of other unknown faces are among those running in the Afghan parliamentary elections.

headline: Giants Photo Replay, Sept. 19
text: A look at the Colts’ 38-14 destruction of the Giants in Indianapolis.

headline: Guggenheim Narrows YouTube Video Entries
text: The Guggenheim Museum announced that it had narrowed down the more than 23,000 submissions for its “YouTube Play, A Biennial of Creative Video” project. In June the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation and YouTube, in collaboration with Hewlett-Packard and Intel, invited people to post videos on a special site, youtube.com/play, as part of an effort to uncover innovative work from outside the traditional art world system. The shortlist of 125 films  by students, video artists, photographers, filmmakers, composers, video-game programmers, a chess champion, an improv comedy troupe, an electronic music producer, a rock band and a hip-hop group  will be on display in kiosks at the Guggenheim’s museums, as well as on the YouTube channel. The Top 20 films will be decided by a jury made up of professional artists, including Takashi Murakami; Stefan Sagmeister, a graphic designer; Laurie Anderson, a performance artist; the music group Animal Collective; and the filmmakers Darren Aronofsky and Apichatpong Weerasethakul. “We artists can no longer call ourselves artists merely by discovering something special and presenting it to the public alone,” Mr. Murakami said in a statement from the museum. “In that way, YouTube has incited a revolution.” The finalists will be announced on Oct. 21 at the museum in New York.

headline: Word of the Day | illusion
text: illusion •\i-ˈlü-zhən\• noun

headline: After Yahoo Talks, Alibaba Says Its Buyback Bid Is Over
text: Alibaba Group Holding, China’s biggest electronic commerce company, said it had “moved on” from talks to buy back shares held by Yahoo after the two sides failed to reach agreement this year.

headline: One on One: Keiji Inafune, Game Designer
text: The Japanese game industry is in crisis, as recounted in a New York Times article Monday by Hiroko Tabuchi. She sat down with Keiji Inafune, head of global research and development and global head of production at Capcom, at the Tokyo Games Show 2010 for a very frank and direct look at the problems facing the industry.

headline: News Quiz | September 20, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Oracle And H.P. Put Feud On Hold for a Night
text: Heading to Oracle’s OpenWorld customer event in San Francisco on Sunday evening, I hoped for one thing – a visceral, verbal brawl between Oracle’s chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison, and Hewlett-Packard’s executive vice president, Ann Livermore. Both were featured speakers at the annual event that takes over a large swath of downtown San Francisco.

headline: Cub’s Bizarre Injury Adds to Scrutiny of Maple Bats
text: Maple bats have been a subject of study and controversy over the past few seasons because they are lighter and far more likely to shatter. On Sunday, a broken maple bat caused perhaps the strangest injury of the season.

headline: In Martha Stewart’s Programs, Questions for Future
text: A cheerful Martha Stewart was on the line, ready to talk about her new partnership with the Hallmark Channel. Last week, the channel started to run no less than eight hours a day of programming, five days a week, from the décor doyenne’s orbit, Brooks Barnes reports in The New York Times.

headline: After Yahoo Talks, Alibaba Says Buyback Bid Over
text: Alibaba Group Holding, China’s biggest electronic commerce company, said it had “moved on” from talks to buy back shares held by Yahoo after the two sides failed to reach agreement this year, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Wall Street’s Engines of Profit Are Slowing Down
text: Inside the great investment houses on Wall Street, business has taken a surprising turn — downward, Nelson D. Schwartz writes in The New York Times.

headline: Wanted: Manic Entrepreneurs
text: Imagine you are a venture capitalist, David Segal writes in The New York Times. One day a man comes to you and says, “I want to build the game layer on top of the world.”

headline: When Mortgage Mediation Is a Gamble
text: From Gretchen Morgenson’s latest column:

headline: The Illusion of Pension Savings
text: Earlier this year, Illinois said it had found a way to save billions of dollars. It would slash the pensions of workers it had not yet hired. The real-world savings would not materialize for decades, of course, but thanks to an actuarial trick, the state could start counting the savings this year and use it to help balance its budget, Mary Williams Walsh reports in The New York Times.

headline: Big Banking, Southern Style
text: Among the more unlikely developments in American finance over the last decade was that Charlotte, N.C., became the headquarters city of two of the nation’s biggest banks. But these banks’ aggressive growth also produced some dire results, both for their shareholders and for the city, during the 2008 economic crisis, Harry Hurt III writes in The New York Times.

headline: Bailing Out the Big Guys, Posthaste
text: In the epilogue to his new book, “Overhaul,” Steven Rattner tallies up the bill for the government assistance that spared General Motors, Chrysler and their financial subsidiaries and automotive suppliers from ruin.

headline: Still a Little Sloppy, but That’s the Point
text: Pavement, on Sunday night at Williamsburg Waterfront in Brooklyn, started out sluggish and indistinct. That could have been fatigue or boredom from months of reunion touring, or sound issues, or a bad approximation of what Pavement used to be through the 1990s: mercurial, discrepant, occasionally a mess. But about 30 minutes in, the band started trying harder, or stopped. If it were clearly one or the other, Pavement would be a lesser band. In any case, the band tightened up and got louder and found its stride. It became a good approximation of what it used to be.

headline: Can the Fed Offer a Reason to Cheer?
text: From Tyler Cowen on the Op/Ed page of The New York Times:

headline: Train the Body, Train the Brain
text: WHO have recently completed two studies, both with children ages 9 and 10, that investigate how fitness affects the immature human brain?

headline: Greece’s Lenders Reassure; Its Banks Get Reprieve
text: Greece’s international lenders assured investors this week that they would not abandon Athens at the end of a 3-year bailout plan if it fulfilled tough reforms but failed to regain market trust, a source told Reuters on Sunday.

headline: Can Digg Find Its Way in the Crowd?
text: Digg, the social news site, is struggling against the same force that has made MySpace an also-ran: Consumers don’t have an endless appetite for social networks, and only the most appealing and useful survive.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Sept. 20, 2010
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the Times article “Cellphone Carriers Are Turning to Wi-Fi, Too.”

headline: Supervising Banks’ Liquidity Is a Pain for Regulators
text: When the financial crisis was at its bleakest in September 2008 following the collapse of Lehman Brothers, only central bank and government intervention ensured that banks like Hypo Real Estate in Germany and Northern Rock in Britain had enough cash to keep operating after financing dried up and customers demanded their money.

headline: Fed Expected to Weigh More Stimulus
text: With tax rates at the center of the debate over how to revive the stalled recovery, the Federal Reserve is likely to spend its policy meeting on Tuesday weighing the merits of additional steps to stimulate the economy, while deferring some major decisions until later this year, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan writes.

headline: Can Cellphones Be Educational Tools?
text: In this weekend’s special education issue of the Sunday Magazine, an article about cellphones quotes a father describing why he doesn’t want his 11-year-old son, Andreas, to have one: “It’s distracting; it’s a diversion…He needs to be concentrating on his schoolwork.” The article then goes on to describe ways in which schools and students might use cellphones for teaching and learning. Do you have a cellphone? Does it distract you from your schoolwork? What might you say to convince your parents and/or teachers that cellphones can be educational tools?

headline: General Mills Mum on Yoplait Report
text: General Mills declined to comment on Sunday on a British newspaper report that it was mulling a bid for tje French yogurt maker Yoplait following a contract dispute, Reuters reported.

headline: Hicks May Team With Blackstone to Keep Liverpool
text: Tom Hicks, the co-owner of Liverpool Football Club, is making another bid to keep hold of the English Premier League soccer team by securing financing from a unit of the Blackstone Group, which would share control with him, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Chess Players as Pitchmen for Products
text: Monday’s New York Times has an article about the hiring of Magnus Carlsen, the world’s No. 1 player, as a spokemodel by G-Star, a Dutch clothing company, and the reasons the company made its decision.

headline: Greenland, Beautiful and Buffeted
text: Magic and melancholy. This is what Andrea Gjestvang found on her first trip last year to Greenland, a startlingly beautiful country with a struggling population; a place where round-the-clock daylight alternates with almost unbroken darkness.

headline: TV Guide Cuts Path to Relevance
text: There was a time years ago when TV Guide’s fall television preview issues were hundreds of pages thick. Studios would clamor to get their ads placed next to the prime-time listings, knowing that the magazine sat on as many as 20 million coffee tables each week, The New York Times’s Jeremy W. Peters reports.

headline: China’s SAIC Noncommittal on Stake in G.M. I.P.O.
text: SAIC, the Chinese automaker and General Motors partner, said Monday it is paying close attention to G.M.’s upcoming stock sale, but gave no hint over whether it would take a stake itself, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Amazon Said to Be in Bid for All of Lovefilm
text: Amazon, the world’s largest online retailer, has made a takeover offer for the movie-rental company Lovefilm, which values it at close to £200 million ($312 million), The Sunday Times reported, without citing sources.

headline: HSBC May Tap Robertson as Temporary Chairman
text: HSBC, Europe’s biggest bank, is considering appointing Simon Robertson as its new chairman for two to three years, Reuters said, citing an article in The Sunday Times.

headline: Sinochem Seeking China’s Support for Potash Bid?
text: Chinese chemical conglomerate Sinochem Group has formally asked the government to back a bid for Canada’s Potash Corp., a local newspaper reported on Sunday, Reuters said.

headline: Tajikistan Says Militants Were Behind Attack on Troops
text: MOSCOW  Tajikistan on Monday blamed Islamic militants, some with ties to Afghanistan and Pakistan, for an assault on a military convoy that killed at least 23 soldiers in the nation over the weekend.

headline: Are We Having ‘Fun’ at Work Yet?
text: Today’s idea: The cult of fun has spread throughout the corporate world “like some disgusting hemorrhagic disease,” a columnist says.

headline: General Growth Said to Settle With Hughes Heirs
text: General Growth Properties, the U.S. mall owner, will take full ownership of a Las Vegas residential property by paying $230 million to the heirs of Howard Hughes in a bid to settle a potential dispute, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Peloton Founder Said to Launch New Fund
text: Ron Beller, the hedge fund manager whose firm, Peloton Partners, collapsed after a huge bet on subprime securities went catastrophically sour, has launched a new shingle with former Peloton colleague Manal Mehta, Financial News reported.

headline: Alinta Lenders Try to Hammer Out Recuse Package
text: Alinta Energy, the Australian electricity group, appeared to make some head-way in talks with lenders as TPG Capital offered compromises on some key terms of its proposed rescue package, The Australian reported.

headline: Avista to Drive Off With Clorox Auto-Care Units?
text: Clorox, the maker of household cleaning products, is close to selling its auto-care business to Avista Capital Partners for between $750 million and $800 million, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.

text: So many teams swapped quarterbacks in Week 2 that it might be a good idea to take a minute and survey the landscape.

headline: A Bumper Year for Seedcamp Start-Ups?
text: Last week in London was Seedcamp week, in which European start-up incubator Seedcamp announced 12 new investments.

headline: Coal Firms Seek to Mine $1.3 Billion in H.K. I.P.O.’s
text: Mongolian Mining Corp. and Winsway Coking Coal Holdings are seeking to raise as much as 9.74 billion Hong Kong dollars ($1.3 billion) in Hong Kong initial public offerings to fund expansion to meet Chinese coal demand, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: What Do Your Holiday Gifts Say About You?
text: Yes, it’s September and around many companies, turning that calendar page means a last, full-court press for profits during the year’s final quarter. It can also signal a scramble to figure out what to send clients and customers for the holidays. While this annual assignment often falls to an office manager or administrative assistant, it can also be a great opportunity to enhance your company’s brand.

headline: Tossing and Then Turning for Giants and Their Fans

headline: Denmark’s Pandora Prices I.P.O.
text: Pandora, the Danish jewelry maker, on Monday priced its initial public offering of stock at a preliminary 175-225 crowns per share, which it said valued the company at up to 29.2 billion crowns ($5.13 billion), Reuters reported.

headline: Safran to Buy Biometric Firm L-1, With BAE’s Help
text: 11:14 a.m. | Updated Safran, the French aerospace and defense systems company, said Monday that it would buy most of L-1 Identity Solutions, a United States company that specializes in biometrics, for $1.1 billion in the latest sign of consolidation in the sector.

headline: Into Africa: Banks Expand South of Sahara
text: “Now everyone’s looking at Africa,” Jacko Maree, the boss of Standard Bank, South Africa’s biggest lender, told The Economist in an article detailing the steady rise in investment on the continent.

headline: Pod Cars Start to Gain Traction in Some Cities
text: Is the pod car finally ready for prime time? After almost 50 years of trial and error, these futuristic personal rapid transit systems, or P.R.T.’s, may be coming to airports and city centers because of technological advances and a growing interest in sustainable transportation.

headline: K.K.R.’s BMG Buys 4th Music Publisher
text: BMG Rights Management, the music publisher backed by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, continued its shopping spree, announcing Monday that it has bought Evergreen Copyright Acquisitions from investors including the private equity firm Trilantic Capital Partners.

headline: India’s Sahara Said to Make $2 Billion Bid for MGM
text: Sahara India Pariwar, an Indian conglomerate with real estate and media holdings, has made a $2 billion bid to buy the debt of the struggling Hollywood studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, according to press reports.

headline: Number of Women on Wall Street Drops
text: Women on Wall Street are becoming a rarer commodity, with about 141,000 having left the financial industry over the past decade, The Wall Street Journal reported Monday, citing data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Vegan Indian Stir-Fried Cauliflower
text: “This is my favorite northern Indian street food,” said Hemant Mathur, the executive chef and an owner of Tulsi, a restaurant expected to open in November in Manhattan. He was speaking of the dish called gobi taka tin, or stir-fried cauliflower with peppers and tomatoes.

headline: The Week Ahead in Congress
text: Senate Democrats will try to take up the annual military authorization bill on Tuesday, having promised to turn it into a legislative goodie bag of election-year priorities for their party’s base, including a measure that would provide a path to citizenship for some illegal immigrants who arrived in the United States as children.

headline: A Look at the New Twitter
text: Last week, Twitter began rolling out a big redesign of its Web interface. The company’s goal is to keep users from having to click through to other sites to see photos and videos tweeted by members, as well as to encourage more searching of its content. It’s also intended to make it easier to follow back-and-forth conversations between others. But even for heavy Twitter users, it can be hard to figure out some of the new design’s basic functions.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –Wall Street wonders what it can expect from Obama in his speech Monday.

headline: Spirit Files for an I.P.O.
text: Spirit Airlines, the low-cost airline that caused an uproar when it started charging for carry-on bags, has filed to go public later this year.

headline: I.S.S. Backs Burkle Slate for Barnes & Noble’s Board
text: 3:57 p.m. | Updated Barnes & Noble suffered a setback on Monday when a powerful advisory firm backed a slate of directors proposed by the billionaire investor Ron Burkle (left) over its own candidates, including its chairman, Leonard S. Riggio.

headline: A Call for a Medicaid Overhaul
text: New York may need a better health care system, but the infinite expansion of Medicaid is not the answer, Lt. Gov. Richard Ravitch says. In a report to be released today, Mr. Ravitch calls for reining in the program, which now serves one in four state residents and consumes about a third of all the money the state spends — roughly $20 billion a year. Mr. Ravitch, writes Anemona Hartocolis, who covers health issues for The Times, wants to take control of the rate-setting process away from the Legislature and make it harder for middle-class families to qualify, among many other things.

headline: The Voters: Men Are Fuming, Women Despairing
text: It is not exactly the year of the angry man, but it may be something close to that. A recent New York Times/CBS News poll found a sharp difference in the way men and women say they are going to vote in November.

headline: I.B.M. to Buy Analytics Firm for $1.7 Billion
text: I.B.M. on Monday agreed to buy Netezza, a Massachusetts data warehouse company, for $1.7 billion in cash.

headline: Great Players Remembered for Big Wins, and Big Losses
text: When great players die, as the Danish grandmaster Bent Larsen did on Sept. 9 at age 75, retrospectives of their careers always focus on their most significant victories. But, like everyone else, great players have suffered ignominious defeats.

headline: Women and Immigrants Gain in Graduate Enrollment
text: Women now make up the vast majority of graduate students, according to a new report from the Council of Graduate Schools.

headline: Defensive Wizard: Rex Ryan and Not Belichick?
text: Something to behold: Randy Moss’s one-handed catch in the second quarter against the Jets. It happened to be the last score for the Patriots, and the last play of the game for Darrelle Revis.

text: In this installment, Horacio Silva takes tea with the Victoria’s Secret model. Among the topics discussed: being blessed by Tyra Banks, learning from her mentor Serena Williams, working with Kanye West and the eternal question: Popeye’s or Hooters?

text: Internet Brands, an Internet media company, said Monday that its board had agreed for the company to be acquired by Hellman & Friedman Capital Partners in a $640 million deal.

headline: Highly Subjective Highlights From the Guggenheim YouTube Contest
text: In an epic display of ruthless but necessary judgment, the Guggenheim Museum  has announced that it had winnowed the entries for its “YouTube Play, A Biennial of Creative Video” contest to a mere 125 from more than 23,000 online submissions. We’re not art critics and we’re not even going to pretend that we’ve watched the 125 selections (which will be reduced to a maximum of 20 top choices on Oct. 21). But there are some very cool films to be found through random wanderings of the competition’s official Web site, at youtube.com/play, including, above, Tiffany Shlain’s “Yelp,” a 21st-century update of Allen Ginsberg’s “Howl.” (“I saw the best minds of my generation distracted by texting, e-mailing, tweeting…”)

text: A BBC television crew discovers tigers living at high altitude in Bhutan; a breeding pair is captured on video above 12,000 feet. “These tigers are living right in the shadows of the high Himalayas,” a wildlife cameraman says. “These are the highest living tigers in the world.” [BBC]

headline: Is the Web Dead?
text: The garish red cover of September’s Wired magazine bears the huge headline “The Web is dead.” The article’s argument is that we do a lot of stuff on the Internet nowadays that does not, in fact, take place on a Web page. We use all kinds of tools — phone apps, Internet radio, Twitter, Skype and so on — that don’t necessarily involve going to a Web site.

text: 1:18 p.m. | Updated See below for several comments that take issue with the position argued here, including from Sally Rubenstone of College Confidential and Stacey Cunitz of the Crefeld School in Philadelphia.

headline: ‘The King’s Speech’ Takes Top Prize at Toronto Film Festival
text: The Toronto International Film Festival‘s People’s Choice Award, a prize that has sometimes served as a bellwether for future success at the Academy Awards, was given on Sunday to “The King’s Speech,” a feature directed by Tom Hooper, Reuters reported. The film stars Colin Firth as King George VI of Britain, who overcame a nervous stammer to deliver a crucial address on the eve of that country’s entrance into World War II, and will be released in the United States by the Weinstein Company later this year. Previous winners of the award, which comes with a prize of about $30,000, have included “Slumdog Millionaire,” “Crash” and “American Beauty,” all winners of the Oscar for best picture; last year’s winner, “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ By Sapphire,” was a best picture nominee.

headline: Have You Left No Sense Of Decency?
text: Let me recommend, once again, Brad DeLong’s superb discussion of how it is that people at the 99th percentile, despite making twice what their counterparts made in 1980, feel poorer now than they did then. On reflection, however (and discussion with Robin), it seems to me that there’s something Brad didn’t say that’s worth mentioning — the change in social norms.

headline: Five-Star Apps Are Awesome, Simple and Done
text: There are more than 250,000 apps in the Apple App Store, and with that many, it’s difficult to separate the good from the bad or mediocre, and, of course, the ugly. To help its customers, Apple developed the Customer Ratings system, where customers can apply a star rating to applications and add comments discussing why they loved or hated their most recent download.

headline: A 10-Year Checkup on Global Goals
text: Ten years after the world’s nations pledged to cut deeply into the problems afflicting the world’s poor by 2015, a Millennium Development Goals Summit is being held at the United Nations today through Wednesday to assess progress. The event overlaps with a batch of related meetings in New York City, including Climate Week and the Clinton Global Initiative.

headline: Monday Reading: Why Not to Refinance
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Bowyer’s ‘Nothing to Lose’ Strategy Pays Off
text: Clint Bowyer, who squeaked into Nascar’s 10-race chase for the championship on the final day in the 12th and final qualifying spot, said he has nothing to lose -– so he’s going for broke. That strategy paid off Sunday with a victory at New Hampshire Motor Speedway.

headline: Bike Sharing Expands in Washington
text: As Lauren Statman made her way along Calvert Street in Washington on Sunday, she stopped to investigate a new phenomenon on the sidewalk near her home: a large, empty bike share station.

headline: The Recession Has (Officially) Ended

headline: Weighing the Risks for Kids
text: In an article in the Week in Review section this weekend, I look at the sobering story of Owen Thomas, a junior lineman on the University of Pennsylvania football team. After a sharp and sudden emotional collapse, he committed suicide last spring, and last week researchers at Boston University revealed that a brain autopsy found evidence of chronic traumatic encephalopathy. It’s a syndrome seen most often in professional boxers and N.F.L. players — athletes whose brains have been slammed around inside their skulls for decades, leading to a pattern of damage that is linked to depression, loss of impulse control and often suicide.

headline: The Week Ahead in Health Industry News
text: The race to replace the decades-old anti-coagulant warfarin, a drug to treat an irregular heartbeat disorder called atrial fibrillation, heats up in earnest on Monday as a cardiology advisory panel at the Food and Drug Administration meets to consider a new drug, dabigatran, from Boehringer Ingelheim.

headline: Numberplay: Answers Hang in the Balance
text: There is a popular class of puzzle that uses a balance scale, like the one shown above, to find one or more items from a group that are different in weight from the others but are otherwise identical. In a year and a half of puzzling, we’ve never used these puzzles. Today we bring them out of the closet.

headline: Lloyds Chief Sets Departure
text: Eric Daniels on Monday announced that he would step down as chief executive of Lloyds Banking Group of Britain in a year’s time.

headline: Madison Avenue Serves Up More Branded Breakfasts
text: During the last couple of years of economic distress, most marketers of packaged-food products have increased their advertising budgets to capitalize on the trend of consumers eating at home more often to save money.

headline: Cutbacks Part of Plan to Save Parochial Schools
text: For more than a quarter-century, while Roman Catholic leaders around the country have closed parochial schools by the dozens in the face of rising costs and falling enrollments, the Archdiocese of New York has conducted a more stately retreat. It has shuttered schools a few at a time, in a reluctant if relentless downsizing that has come to be known among some church leaders as “the melancholy rite.”

headline: Purell for iPads
text: Even if you are not a purist lover of physical keyboards, touch screens do have a big drawback. It does not take much use before the screen is covered with smudgy fingerprints and face grease.

headline: Frank Zappa Bust Unveiled in Baltimore
text: “There will come a time,” Frank Zappa sang, “when everybody who is lonely will be free to sing and dance and love.” And there will come a time, he vowed, “when you can even take your clothes off when you dance.” Until then, the city of Baltimore has found a more traditional way to honor Zappa, the genre-bending avant-garde rock musician who was born in Baltimore and died in 1993, with a bust in his likeness that was dedicated there on Sunday, The Associated Press reported. In a ceremony timed to the 25th anniversary of Zappa’s Senate testimony, at which he compared the labeling of explicit records to censorship, and attended by Zappa’s widow, Gail, his sons, Dweezil and Ahmet, and daughter Diva, as well as Baltimore’s mayor, Stephanie Rawlings-Blake, a bust of the mustachioed, pony-tailed Zappa was unveiled atop a 12-foot pole outside the Southeast Anchor Branch of the Enoch Pratt Free Library. It isn’t very large, but the bust is a replica of a similar sculpture in Vilnius, Lithuania. The duplicate was donated to Baltimore by the Lithuanian nonprofit organization ZAPPART. “He’d be wildly amused by this,” Gail Zappa told The A.P., “because of the absurdity of these guys in Lithuania coming up with this phenomenal sculptor who normally does busts of Stalin.”

headline: King Among Grains
text: What’s not to like about quinoa? This grain has a delicate texture, nutty flavor and high protein content  an average of 16.2 percent protein per serving, compared to 7.5 percent for rice and 14 percent for wheat. (Some varieties provide more than 20 percent protein.) Quinoa also is easy to cook and free of gluten. And best of all, it’s versatile.

headline: Scorecard | Hannah Marshall Wins!
text: If it’s Monday, Scorecard must be in Britain. A helpful reminder, because while John Galliano might have given the Fashion Fringe award to a newbie in his OG maximalist magpie image, when it comes to the big kids’ shows during London Fashion Week’s opening days, for once, critics were finding the eccentric sparkle princess look less than Unique. It is thus that Hannah Marshall takes the win for her minimalist vision — albeit one that gives new definition to “stripped-down” chic.

headline: Rattner Speaks: Chrysler, Congress and Khakis
text: “Overhaul,” a book by Steven Rattner, the New York Times reporter cum investment banker cum private equity magnate cum car czar, hits bookstores on Monday.

headline: Video: Obama’s Town-Hall-Style Meeting
text: 7:15 p.m. | Updated President Obama spoke for a full hour on Monday about the economy and jobs during a CNBC town-hall-style meeting hosted by John Harwood, the network’s chief Washington correspondent.

headline: Assessing the G.O.P. and the Tea Party
text: Whatever the outcome of the Nov. 2 elections, you can be certain that commentators around the country will be fixated on the impact of the Tea Party movement. If Republican candidates do well on Election Day –- and particularly if Tea Party-backed candidates like Rand Paul of Kentucky and Sharron Angle of Nevada win their races -– the Tea Party will be credited with having revived a moribund Republican Party. But if the Republicans fail to live up to expectations — and expectations are exceedingly high –- the Tea Party will be blamed for curbing the Republicans’ ability to capitalize on historic levels of voter dissatisfaction.

headline: Christie’s Names New Chief Executive
text: Christie’s, the auction house based in London, announced to its staff on Monday morning that Edward Dolman, its chief executive for nearly 11 years, had been replaced by an outsider, Steven Pleshette Murphy. Mr. Dolman was promoted to the post of chairman of the company worldwide.

headline: Expert Answers About Melanoma
text: This week, Dr. David E. Fisher of Harvard Medical School joined the Consults blog to answer readers’ questions about melanoma. Here, Dr. Fisher addresses readers concerns about aging skin and the risk of melanoma, recurrences of the deadly skin cancer and melanoma that has spread to the nasal cavity.

headline: A Crop Sprouts Without Soil or Sunshine
text: On the rooftop garden at St. Philip’s Academy, a private school in Newark, students tend plots of everything from broccoli and beets to sweet corn and spaghetti squash.

text: I have an article today that looks at the plight of older workers — specifically those 55 or older — who have lost their jobs and fear they may never work again.

headline: Cecilia Bartoli Named Artistic Director for Salzburg Whitsun Festival
text: Cecilia Bartoli, the Italian mezzo-soprano, will take over in 2012 as artistic director of the Salzburg Whitsun Festival, a three-day annual event that falls between the Salzburg Easter Festival and the Salzburg Festival in the summer. The conductor Riccardo Muti has been running the Whitsun Festival, with a focus on lesser-known Neapolitan operas. The Salzburg Festival made the announcement on Monday.

text: Will Wilkinson has a request, alas:

headline: Two German Landesbanks in Merger Talks
text: FRANKFURT — Two German landesbanks said Monday that they were discussing a merger that would create the country’s third-largest bank, a move that could set off a scramble by other public-sector banks to find partners and lead to the long-awaited consolidation of the crisis-prone institutions.

headline: 2 Weeks, and Injuries Have Already Taken Toll
text: The cart came out Sunday and Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Dennis Dixon was gone, joining a pretty competitive team of players  if only they were not all injured  in the training room.

headline: Lahno Wins Women’s World Blitz Championship
text: Kateryna Lahno finished ahead of a field that included many of the best female players in the world, including Alexandra Kosteniuk, the reigning women’s world champion.

headline: From Cleaning Pools to Changing Diapers
text: Martha Plimpton isn’t the only reason “Raising Hope”could be the best new sitcom of the season, but she is the main reason. Because it isn’t until the actress trudges into view as Virginia Chance, a cleaning woman in a sherbet-pink uniform, a cigarette dangling from her lip and a hostile glint in her eyes, that the premiere on Tuesday on Fox hits full comic stride.

headline: Bandwagons Get a Workout
text: The transition from Week 1 to Week 2 in the N.F.L. season is always one of the most entertaining stretches of the year, with people jumping on and off bandwagons with such ferocity it ought to be its own reality show. Remember, oh, two days ago, when the Colts were done as Super Bowl contenders. Peyton Manning was old, the defense couldn’t have stopped a Pee Wee team’s rushing game, the offensive line was considering a career switch to professional poker.

headline: ‘Catch Me If You Can’ Sets Broadway Opening Date
text: The new musical “Catch Me If You Can,” created by several of the forces behind the Broadway hit “Hairspray,” will arrive in New York in the spring, with preview performances starting on March 7, 2011, and an opening night of April 10, the producers announced on Monday.

headline: I.B.M.’s Hybrid Strategy in Business Intelligence
text: I.B.M.‘s announcement Monday that it is buying Netezza for $1.7 billion highlights how much the fast-growing field of business intelligence is increasingly both a hardware and a software technology.

headline: Former Goldman Quant Plans Comeback
text: Ray Iwanowski, who co-managed Goldman Sachs‘ flagship Global Alpha hedge fund until March 2009, is considering a new fund, according to Absolute Return + Alpha magazine.

headline: Gay Service Members Discuss ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: Sept. 21, 4:23 p.m. | Updated The Senate voted against taking up the annual Pentagon authorization bill, which included a provision allowing the repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell policy” regarding gay soldiers. The vote was 56 to 43, with Democrats falling short of the 60 votes needed to overcome a filibuster and take up the bill.

headline: The Legality of Copying Your Favorite Clothes
text: When I next go to China, my suitcase will be filled with some of my favorite dresses and blazers. I’m not just bringing them to wear, however. I’m also bringing fabric with me and the names of tailors who can copy the dress and blazer designs in different colors.

headline: Bridge Fire Halts Metro-North Trains
text: All train traffic in and out of Grand Central Terminal has been suspended, after a fire broke out underneath the 138th Street Bridge, which is owned by Metro-North and which carries all four Metro-North tracks. Officials said they believed that a wooden pier beneath the bridge that serves as a bumper for ships caught fire about 11:38 a.m. A fireboat was on the scene. There were no injuries, a spokeswoman said. Update: service has resumed.

headline: Christopher Kane Puts a Princess in Acid Tones
text: Trying to work out Christopher Kane’s backstage comments about his collection today — Did he say “a royal on crack?” — was a wee difficult. Mr. Kane is a Scot, as well as a chatty personality, and a good ear must be attuned. In fact, he was referring to Princess Margaret’s fashion in her youth, and to the discreet elegance of the royal dressmaker Norman Hartnell. As for those fluorescent shades of green, orange and pink in the collection, “those colors just make your heart race,” Mr. Kane said.

headline: Disappointed Supporters Question Obama
text: It took only a few minutes into CNBC’s town-hall-style meeting for President Obama to get questions that cut to the heart of his political problem.

headline: Fewer Deaths From Distracted Driving Reported in ’09
text: The number of deaths attributed to distracted drivers fell 6 percent in 2009 from the previous year, the Transportation Department said in a report released Monday.

headline: ‘Even Silence Has an End’
text: Painfully, I tore myself away from the light, turned on my heels, and plunged into the thick matted darkness. It had begun to rain again. It was difficult to walk; every other step I tripped. I had my hands out in front of me to avoid obstacles. I couldn’t see a thing. I hadn’t managed to get hold of a machete, but I did have a flashlight. The risk involved in using it was as great as the fear that prevented me from using it. I went slowly into this threatening space and told myself I would switch it on only when I couldn’t take it anymore. My hands collided with wet, rough, sticky surfaces, and I expected at any moment to feel the burn of some violent poison. The storm was raging. I could hear the thundering of the rain pounding on the canopy of vegetation that for a few more minutes would protect me. I expected the fragile roof of leaves to yield and open under the weight of water at any moment. The prospect of the flood that would soon submerge me made my situation all the more distressing. I no longer knew whether it was raindrops or my own tears that were flowing down my cheeks, and I hated to have to drag along this relic of a sniveling, shivering child, when I knew that I couldn’t allow myself any weakness.

headline: Artifacts | Sarah Sze’s Fine Mess

Walk into the central exhibition space and you start listing to the left, as if the whole place were sailing into a stiff wind. Yet the only breeze is coming from a plastic Ikea fan rotating slowly on the floor, the atmosphere is placid and serene, and the hundreds of small objects arrayed across the floor and on the leaning towers of shelves that display them are in perfect order. Make that super-perfect.

headline: Soros, Obama, And Me
text: What do we have in common? We’re all small business owners, according to Mitch McConnell. Obama and I make our business income off books — he sells the audacity of hope, Robin and I sell the misery of Econ 101; Soros makes his money off financial destruction directing funds to their most productive use; but we’re all in the same category as the owner of a small factory.

headline: H.P. Settles Lawsuit Against Hurd
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A fierce and public feud between Oracle and Hewlett-Packard, two of the world’s largest technology companies, has ended after all of two weeks.

headline: A Moment of Zen Before Taking Flight
text: WHEN I was a young, I dreamed about becoming dancer, a singer or a flight attendant. I still dance, and I still sing. But the flight attendant dream went nowhere, which is good. I don’t like flying.

headline: Torre and Cashman Have a Cordial Reunion
text: As camera flashes flickered above them, Joe Torre and Brian Cashman shook hands and embraced in an interview room at Yankee Stadium late Monday afternoon, their first encounter since Torre’s acrimonious departure from the organization after the 2007 season.

headline: When Mascots Fight: Rufus vs. Brutus
text: The most competitive part of No. 2 Ohio State’s 43-7 victory over Ohio on Saturday may have come before the game. That’s when Ohio’s mascot, Rufus the Bobcat, decided to tussle with his Ohio State counterpart, Brutus the Buckeye.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Jerusalem and Elsewhere
text: Far be it from Lens to judge the ritualistic suitability of an etrog, but has there ever been a more luscious looking one than that depicted by Sebastian Scheiner of The Associated Press? Mr. Scheiner’s photo also plays a trick on the eye: the center and right background make it appear as if the etrog buyer is standing on the shore of some cobalt-colored body of water, with a mountain range in the distance. A closer look at the left edge, however, reveals that these are folds and flaps in a blue tent.

headline: Poll Showing Gains by Paladino Excluded Key Candidate From Ballot
text: A new poll this morning from Rasmussen Reports suggests significant tightening in the New York governor’s race. The poll has the Democrat, Andrew Cuomo, ahead 54 percent to 38 percent against Carl P. Paladino, the boisterous Buffalo businessman who soundly won the Republican primary last week against Rick Lazio. In the previous Rasmussen Reports poll, taken before the primary, Mr. Cuomo led Mr. Paladino by a much larger margin: 58 to 29.

headline: For Trop50, PepsiCo Seeks to Improve Odds for Success
text: PepsiCo is taking additional steps to put behind it the mistakes made last year in marketing its Tropicana family of juices with a major campaign for the Trop50 juice beverage variety.

headline: Red Bulls’ Henry Fined but Not Suspended

headline: No Fastballs, Just Nibbling at the Corners of the Boss’s Legend

headline: The Power of Bach, the Comfort of Morricone
text: The indomitable Brazilian conductor João Carlos Martins has faced tremendous hurdles, his career as a pianist derailed by a soccer injury, repetitive stress syndrome, a tumor in his left hand and a mugging that left him unable to use his right arm.

headline: Lady Gaga Goes Political in Maine

headline: Obama Campaigns for Sestak

headline: Indian Bid for MGM Is a Safe Move for Hollywood

That may sound groundbreaking, but a purchase of MGM by the Indian conglomerate would probably provoke only relief in Tinseltown because it would not upset the industry’s status quo. A more radical buyout could be something Google’s YouTube unit might be capable of, if it dares.

headline: Windfall in New York
text: A few years back, a column I wrote recounting a successful effort by an alliance of citizens to beat back wind-turbine interests in Andes, N.Y., provoked a massively negative response. I was accused (a) of elevating the views I enjoyed from the windows of my second home above the interests of the society in encouraging green energy, (b) of displaying the usual latecomer’s indifference to the needs of the locals who had been living in Andes forever and (c) of not knowing what I was talking about when I described the construction (massively disruptive), effects (awful on land, animals and people), contribution to the grid (minimal) and financing (tax credits and accelerated depreciation rates) of the 400-foot-high towers with a 52-foot circumference base and blades 130 feet wide whooshing through the air at 178 m.p.h.

headline: Yankees, Past and Present, Pay Tribute to Steinbrenner

Together they represented the span of George Steinbrenner’s 37-year reign as the club’s principal owner, a bombastic, colorful and often successful era that was honored Monday night with the unveiling of a monument to him.

headline: Selig Talks Steinbrenner, and Other Topics

headline: Excerpt From 'Dan Rather Reports'
text: An excerpt from "Dan Rather Reports" on HDNet about the phenomenon of Afghan families who disguise their daughters as sons. The show airs Tuesdays at 8 p.m. and 11 p.m. ET. For more information, go to "Dan Rather Reports" on Facebook and iTunes.

headline: Channeling a Family’s Silence Into Songs About the Holocaust
text: The music on “Silver and Ash,” a new album from the songwriter Clare Burson, started with silence. There was the silence that descended in 1941, when letters from her maternal great-grandparents, German Jews who had fled to Latvia, abruptly stopped arriving in Memphis, where Ms. Burson’s grandmother settled in 1938. Then there was the second silence: the silence in Ms. Burson’s family about the first silence.

headline: Donor Names Remain Secret as Rules Shift
text: Crossroads Grassroots Policy Strategies would certainly seem to the casual observer to be a political organization: Karl Rove, a political adviser to President George W. Bush, helped raise money for it; the group is run by a cadre of experienced political hands; it has spent millions of dollars on television commercials attacking Democrats in key Senate races across the country.

headline: Muslim Leaders Unite Behind Center

Most were immigrants in this country illegally, and their bodies, fully clothed, formed giant letters that spelled out a message for Floridians and one of their senators, complete with a human exclamation point: Call LeMieux!

headline: The ‘Freedom’ Agenda
text: Very few novels make clear and provocative arguments about American life anymore, but Jonathan Franzen’s important new book, “Freedom,” makes at least two. First, he argues that American culture is overobsessed with personal freedom. Second, he portrays an America where people are unhappy and spiritually stunted.

headline: Afghan Boys Are Prized, So Girls Live the Part
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Six-year-old Mehran Rafaat is like many girls her age. She likes to be the center of attention. She is often frustrated when things do not go her way. Like her three older sisters, she is eager to discover the world outside the family’s apartment in their middle-class neighborhood of Kabul.

headline: Jacobs Has His Helmet Back, but May Not Want It for Long
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  While the Giants headed for their cars to drive home Monday afternoon, Brandon Jacobs retreated to the weight room. Perhaps to clear his head, perhaps to simply be by himself. Either way, Jacobs decided to work out.

headline: Hug Won’t Unite Torre and Cashman
text: “Let’s get this over with,” Brian Cashman said, and then he waited for Joe Torre again. Cashman, the Yankees’ general manager, slipped into an alcove behind a conference room as Torre finished a radio interview late Monday afternoon. It was their first encounter in almost two years.

text: In Prohibition-era Harlem, bootleggers sold cheap and sometimes toxic liquor and moonshine at rent parties and speakeasies for as little as 25 cents a pop.

headline: The Wars’ Continuing Toll
text: The United States military has never been better at helping soldiers survive the battlefield with sophisticated advances in treatment and transportation. Service members who come home with psychic wounds and hidden traumas are still not getting enough support.

headline: Questions About Fracturing
text: The Environmental Protection Agency is about to begin a much-needed study of the health and environmental effects of extracting natural gas through hydraulic fracturing. The issue isn’t whether the country should keep drilling for natural gas, which is vital to our energy future. It is whether it can be done this way safely.

headline: In an Ugly Human-Trafficking Case, Hawaii Forgets Itself
text: This is a story of two farmers, Laotian immigrant brothers who grow vegetables in Hawaii. People love their onions, melons, Asian cabbage, herbs and sweet corn, and their Halloween pumpkin patch is a popular field trip for schoolchildren all over Oahu. They count local politicians and community leaders among their many friends, and run a charitable foundation.

headline: SAIC of China Weighs Buying Stake in G.M.
text: DETROIT  A Chinese automaker has expressed interest in buying a stake in General Motors when it holds a public stock offering later this year, a move that could raise concerns about foreign influence over the largest American automaker.

headline: Gaza: Israel Permits Car Imports
text: For the first time in more than three years, Israel on Monday allowed cars to be imported into Gaza. About 20 cars, most of them recent secondhand models, were driven from the border by Palestinian drivers to where local car dealers and Hamas Transportation Ministry officials waited. Car imports are now expected to occur regularly as part of the recently eased Israeli restrictions on Gaza. Spare parts and engine oil are also being allowed in.

headline: Developing Nations to Get Clean-Burning Stoves
text: WASHINGTON  Nearly three billion people in the developing world cook their meals on primitive indoor stoves fueled by crop waste, wood, coal and dung. Every year, according to the United Nations, smoke from these stoves kills 1.9 million people, mostly women and children, from lung and heart diseases and low birth weight.

headline: High Flier in Real Estate Is Sentenced for $17 Million Theft

headline: Jill Johnston, Critic Who Wrote ‘Lesbian Nation,’ Dies at 81
text: Jill Johnston, a longtime cultural critic for The Village Voice whose daring, experimental prose style mirrored the avant-garde art she covered and whose book “Lesbian Nation: The Feminist Solution” spearheaded the lesbian separatist movement of the early 1970s, died on Saturday in Hartford. She was 81 and lived in Sharon, Conn.

headline: Lohan Drops Lawsuit but Other Legal Troubles Persist
text: Lindsay Lohan continues to keep the nation’s legal system busy on two coasts. According to a filing made Monday in a Manhattan court reported by The Associated Press, Ms. Lohan, the 24-year-old “Mean Girls” star, withdrew her lawsuit against E-Trade over a Super Bowl commercial for that online brokerage that she believed was taking aim at her. In the advertisement, a baby with an adult’s voice asks another infant whether he’s been visited by “that milkaholic Lindsay.” A lawyer for Ms. Lohan wrote in an earlier filing that the babies “were actually portraying” Ms. Lohan “and her grown-up friends,” but a lawyer for E-Trade responded, “No reasonable person would connect” the actress with the commercial.

headline: The McQueen Memorial: More Impressions
text: Some British newspapers this morning picked up on the extreme shoes worn by guests to the memorial to Alexander McQueen. The Daily Express featured a photo on its cover, next to the headline: “A shoebiz tribute to McQueen.” Against the backdrop of the London shows, one impression that stuck was seeing Plum Sykes in her perfectly fitted black McQueen day dress. I saw Ms. Sykes from a distance in the cathedral, but you would know from the line of her outfit that it was a McQueen. That sort of authority and fashion imprint hasn’t been seen here — and I didn’t expect to see it. That’s one reason Mr. McQueen was so rare.

headline: The Peace Dividend
text: On a crisp morning in Sarajevo, the filmmaker Danis Tanovic breezed through the front door of Delikatesna Radnja wearing designer sunglasses and a newsboy cap. There are something like 1,300 cafes in Sarajevo, each embodying a unique ambience and clientele — Zlatna Ribica (“the Goldfish”) has a speakeasy aesthetic and serves a famed Mexican coffee; Kino Bosna is a converted movie theater known for its live music, rakija (a local fruit brandy) and unabashed seediness. The Delikatesna Radnja, with floor-to-ceiling windows that face the Miljacka River and the mountains beyond, caters to the theater and film crowd. Tanovic, who directed “No Man’s Land,” winner of the 2002 Oscar for best foreign language film, is something of a celebrity here. While the waiter prepared macchiatos for us, Tanovic chatted up customers at nearby tables. With his heavy eyelids and tendency to speak out of the side of his mouth, he resembled a younger, stockier Robert DeNiro. He seemed to know everyone in the room.

headline: Why Generic Ballots May Underestimate Democrats
text: In the last couple of posts on our House forecasts, I’ve noted that the generic Congressional ballot tends to show worse results for Democrats than other indicators like polls of individual House races. The generic ballot, as of last week, pointed toward a Republican lead of 7 or 8 percentage points among likely voters, according to our estimates. Local polls are a little bit less straightforward to read because you have to make a lot of adjustments for polls that are (i) partisan, (ii) bad, or (iii) both. But in general — while there is a lot of variance from district to district — the local polls seem to point toward a House vote that would be about evenly divided.

headline: The Filter, a Times iPhone Guide to New York Coffee
text: There’s a new feature for coffee drinkers on The Scoop, the free New York Times iPhone guide to great places to enjoy yourself in New York. Called The Filter, it is a list of favorite New York coffee spots compiled by Oliver Strand, who writes frequently about food for the Times. The Filter includes the locations listed in the interactive coffee map Mr. Strand published in March and adds new ones he has found since then, including Caffetteria in SoHo, Kickstand in Brooklyn (and wherever else their wheels will take them), Little Skips in Bushwick, Brooklyn, and Third Rail Coffee, a popup in Rapha Cycle Club on the Bowery. Over the coming months, he’ll keep the list current to reflect the city’s growing coffee scene.

headline: Looking for Something When Life Signifies Nothing
text: “You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger” begins with an unseen narrator — Zak Orth, sounding a lot like Woody Allen — paraphrasing Shakespeare. You may remember the quotation from high school English, about how life is a tale told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing. The observation is attributed to the playwright himself (“Shakespeare once said”), rather than to Macbeth, whose grim experience led him to such nihilism, but never mind. In context, it amounts to a perfectly superfluous statement of the obvious. This movie, after all, is a tale told by Mr. Allen, who is very far from an idiot and who has become the American cinema’s great champion of cosmic insignificance.

text: The BMW Group announced on Tuesday that Dan Creed would succeed the late Jack Pitney as the brand’s vice president of marketing for BMW of North America. The assignment, which is effective Oct. 1, gives Mr. Creed responsibility for the brand’s product planning, strategy and marketing in the United States.

headline: Medicare Advantage Premiums to Fall in 2011
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration announced Tuesday that average premiums paid by individuals for private Medicare Advantage plans, which insure about one-fourth of all beneficiaries, would decline slightly next year, even as insurers provide additional benefits required by the new health care law.

headline: On Your Cellphone, Six Sidney Crosbys
text: When the Penguins play this fall, those seated in the new 18,000-seat Consol Energy Center will be able to connect, via cellphone, with a video system that allows them to simultaneously watch the game from six angles, see game statistics, roster and other information, and view instant replay.

headline: Immigrantification
text: The gentrifying effects immigrants can have on run-down areas.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 21
text: A view of the day in sports.

headline: What We’re Reading: Women Desert Wall Street
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: The Democrats' Strategy
text: Jim Roberts, the associate managing editor, talks Tea Party and Democratic politics with Nate Silver, the lead writer of the FiveThirtyEight Blog.

headline: Hopes Fade for Success of Commonwealth Games in India
text: NEW DELHI  Skepticism about India’s preparedness for the Commonwealth Games deepened Tuesday after a partly constructed footbridge collapsed outside the main arena for competition, injuring dozens.

headline: H.P. Proves Printers Don’t Have to Be Boring
text: A couple of weeks ago, H.P. invited me to a preview of 11 new printers, enough to populate a very large boardroom table. I don’t normally find printers totally mesmerizing—and I hope you don’t either—but two were definitely worthy of a little rubbernecking.

headline: Fed Stands Pat and Says It Is Still Ready to Buy Debt
text: WASHINGTON  Officials at the Federal Reserve signaled on Tuesday for the first time that they were worried that the slow-moving economic recovery could be undermined by very low rates of inflation, and hinted strongly that it might resume buying vast amounts of government debt to spur the recovery. While the central bank’s Federal Open Market Committee did not take any new steps on interest rates, it communicated in unmistakable terms its concerns about the fragility of the economic recovery and a threat to stable prices.

headline: FEMA to Assess Storm Damage
text: Was the damage wrought by last Thursday’s brief but destructive storm severe enough to earn the city federal disaster dollars?

headline: The Long View of China’s Currency
text: Beijing

headline: Morning T | Brad Goreski
text: In this installment of our video interview series, Horacio Silva sits down with Brad Goreski, the style director for Rachel Zoe and the breakout star of the reality show “The Rachel Zoe Project.” Goreski opens up on everything from growing up in Sleepytown, Canada, to jury-rigging a gel-filled breast enhancer on Cameron Diaz’s heel.

headline: Ford Ranger Goes Global, Minus North America
text: 11:30 p.m. | Updated Ford offered a glimpse of its new Ranger pickup on Monday when it released a teaser photo and some preliminary product information. The compact truck will be introduced at the Australian International Auto Show on Oct. 15. While it will be offered to 180 markets worldwide, it will not be available in the United States, where production of the current Ranger will end in 2011.

headline: Releasing a Green Sea Turtle
text: A team of scientists studied the behavior of two sea turtle species found at Palmyra Atoll in the Pacific Ocean. (Video by Felicity Arengo)

headline: Prospects Rise for Clean Cooking in Poor Places
text: 10:35 p.m. | Updated At the Clinton Global Initiative on Tuesday, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and various partners described details of a plan to curb the clouds of toxic cooking smoke killing nearly 2 million people a year in the world’s poorest places. More than 2 billion people rely on firewood or dried dung for cooking and often burn these fuels in unvented stoves or fireplaces. (The photo above was shot for The Times in Kohlua, India, by Adam Ferguson.)

headline: Video: The Democrats’ Strategy
text: Nate Silver chats with Jim Roberts about President Obama’s campaign schedule and the key states for Democrats.

headline: Money-Laundering Inquiry Touches Vatican Bank
text: ROME  Italian monetary authorities said Tuesday that they had impounded $30 million from the Vatican bank and placed its top two officers under investigation in connection with a money-laundering inquiry. The announcement amounted to another potential storm confronting the papacy of Benedict XVI, who is struggling with the effects of a priestly abuse scandal.

headline: Discovery Channel Sues ‘Deadliest Catch’ Captains
text: The Discovery Channel is suing two captains on its popular program “Deadliest Catch” for $3 million in damages for what it called a refusal to finish work on a television episode.

headline: You Heart N.Y.
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: Injuries Gain Attention as Football Feels Pain
text: Could we be witnessing the demise of American football as we know it?

headline: Strategy Session: Developing Campaign Plans for the 2010 Midterm Elections
text: Overview | What can Republican and Democratic candidates learn from public opinion going into November’s midterm elections? What campaign strategies will resonate most with American voters? In this lesson, students act as “political strategists.” They study the political landscape and create 10-point plans detailing campaign strategies for candidates.

headline: After Two Games, Rolle Criticizes Giants Leadership
text: Safety Antrel Rolle, in his first season with the Giants, said in a radio interview Tuesday that there is a lack of leadership in the locker room and that the organization is too restrictive with its players.

headline: The Fed Speaks
text: We’re failing in our mandate to deliver full employment; meanwhile, inflation is below target; therefore, we’ve decided to do nothing.

headline: Who You Gonna Believe?
text: I went through my mail today, and got the usual batch of letters declaring that I’m wrong about everything, and that we should do the opposite of anything I say. Hey, it’s a free country.

headline: Move to End ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Stalls in Senate
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Tuesday voted against taking up a major military bill that would allow the repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy, disappointing advocates of allowing gay Americans to serve openly in the armed forces but leaving open the likelihood of another vote later this year.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Giles Deacon
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Haifa Wøhlers Olsen.

headline: DC Entertainment (Not the Comics) Moving to California
text: Time Warner shook up its DC Entertainment business on Tuesday, announcing that operations focused on developing feature films, television, digital media, video games and consumer products would move to California from New York.

headline: Mysteries Of Moderation
text: Oh, Kay. The moderation software flags potential obscenities in red — which is actually quite helpful. And I understand that there will necessarily be a lot of false positives; it’s kind of funny that “MBS” gets painted red, but sort-of understandable.

headline: Economists’ Reactions to Fed Statement
text: 6:24 p.m. | Updated to include more reactions.

headline: Retirements May Mean Less Help for Home-Schoolers
text: When Karen Holmes decided to home school her daughter, Zoe, in the middle of 10th grade, she sent the required letter to her local school district. But there were problems, and Zoe ended up with “F”s in all of her classes, marked persistently absent instead of legally transferred from the school.

headline: Fishing Expands in the Gulf
text: Citing tests, the federal government is reopening 8,000 more square miles of the Gulf of Mexico to commercial and recreational fishing, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said on Tuesday. That leaves just 13 percent of the gulf’s waters closed as a result of contamination from the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in April.

headline: A Plug For Lenovo
text: Ask a few owners of laptop computers—as I did recently—which computer accessory they value most, and a second (or third) power adapter is right at the top of their lists.

headline: Vimeo Announces Finalists for Video Awards
text: Vimeo, the video-sharing site for grown-up YouTubers, has announced the 45 finalists for its first online video award contest. A grand-prize winner, who will receive a $25,000 grant to create a new work, will be announced in New York on Oct. 9.

headline: Bloomberg Company Commits $1 Million to Hirshhorn Museum Project
text: Business people generally don’t want to have anything to do with bubbles, but Bloomberg, the financial-services company, has committed to provide more than $1 million over two years as a naming gift for an unusual architectural project in Washington, a 145-foot-tall inflatable meeting hall that will puff out of the top of the internal courtyard of the Hirshhorn Museum, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Coming Soon: Michelle Obama, Campaigner
text: Michelle Obama will begin appearing on behalf of Democratic candidates starting in mid-October, bringing a softer appeal to voters for a continuation of the policies of her husband’s party.

headline: Divining Intent Will Do Little to Ease Another Star’s Pain
text: London

headline: BHP to Walk Away if Potash Bids Go Too High
text: The chief executive of BHP Billiton said Tuesday that the British-Australian mining company was prepared to walk away from its $38.6 billion bid for the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan if a rival suitor were to make an offer so high that a deal did not make sense for BHP’s shareholders, Reuters reports.

headline: Part 2: Answers to Questions About Video Games and Learning
text: Last week we asked readers to submit questions and comments to James Paul Gee, an expert on how video games fit within an overall theory of learning and literacy, in response to article “Learning by Playing” in The New York Times Magazine. It featured a public middle school where the curriculum is gamelike.

headline: Is It Harder to Have a Child with Down Syndrome?
text: The conversation sparked by Amy Julia Becker’s guest post last week about her decision not to have prenatal testing is still going strong. One of the many themes in the comments is the “burden” — and the differing perceptions of that word — of raising a child with Down syndrome in particular and with disabilities in general.

headline: Father, Son and Secret Converge Amid Glue Guns
text: Evangelical fervor thrives on depression, so it’s no surprise that America’s economic free fall and plummeting national morale have coincided with a sharp rise in religious crusading. (Koran burning, anyone?) With no solution to his own or the world’s problems, the end-times believer at the center of “A Bright New Boise” simply chants, “Now, now, now,” in a prayer for deliverance.

headline: Answering Readers’ Sea Turtle Questions
text: Eleanor Sterling of the American Museum of Natural History studied sea turtles at Palmyra Atoll this summer.

headline: 'The Divine Sister'
text: Charles Busch and Amy Rutberg in a scene from the show, which was written by Mr. Busch. (Courtesy of Applause Video)

headline: Waiter, There’s Soup in My Bug
text: SOMETHING happened when Kisha Moorehead looked into the bowl of live worms.

headline: Morning T | Brad Goreski
text: In this installment of our video interview series, Horacio Silva sits down with Brad Goreski, the style director for Rachel Zoe.

headline: The Place | A Guide to Marrakesh, Part Two
text: CARPET BAGGINGIt’s easy to be taken on a magic carpet ride when you’re buying rugs — hawkers will wave you into their stalls, ply you with mint tea and take you through stacks of fake antique rugs. However, La Porte d’Or, in the thick of the souks, is the real deal. Marc Jacobs, Tom Cruise and Edgar Kauffman, who picked up carpets for his Fallingwater house, have all shopped here. The staff will guide you through a vast selection — kilims from the Glowa tribe, carpets made from 400-year-old silk — and pass on valuable tips. (Lamb’s-wool rugs won’t shrink; a double-knotted weave lets you restore holes.) The shop also ships. 115 Souk Semmarine; 011-212-524-44-54-54.

headline: 25 Years at Union Square
text: The area around Union Square has thrived even in the recession.

headline: A Trade-In Market for the Volt Battery?
text: When the Chevy Volt hits dealerships next month, it will have a 16-kilowatt-hour battery that will power the car for 40 miles, General Motors says. Like most rechargeable batteries, the one in the Volt will slowly lose its abiltiy to store energy, though; G.M. will give the battery a warranty for eight years and 100,000 miles, although it says it should last 10 years.

headline: Q. & A. With Andrew Zimmern
text: Andrew Zimmern, (@andrewzimmern) the host of the Travel Channel show “Bizarre Foods,” has eaten tarantulas in Cambodia and stir-fried bees in Taiwan. “Because the psychological handicap is so intense in our culture when it comes to food,” Mr. Zimmern said in an interview in Jeff Gordinier’s article about entomophagy, “for people who flip the light switch and head on down the hallway with alternative foods, the bliss factor is quadrupled.”

headline: The Bugs You Can Eat
text: “In most cultures outside of North America and Western Europe, tiny many-legged creatures are a delicacy, and an important source of protein,” Jeff Gordinier writes in a report on a five-course Mexican feast featuring insect cuisine last Saturday in Brooklyn. “Here in the United States they represent the growing realm of gastronomic spelunking.” For omnivores who want to take it to the next level, Tom Turpin, a professor of entomology at Purdue University, offers information on three common bugs you can easily buy, prepare and cook.

headline: Avista Buys Auto-Care Business From Clorox
text: From our colleagues at DealBook:

headline: Photos of the Moment | Christopher Kane
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Haifa Wøhlers Olsen.

headline: Brown Gains Ground in California; Few Other Changes in Gubernatorial Forecast
text: The Senate forecast that we release tomorrow ought to be pretty fascinating. Between the ongoing developments in Alaska, some good polling numbers for Democrats in California, and some very good polling numbers of Republicans in West Virginia and Wisconsin, the model is going to have a lot to chew on.

headline: Murkowski Ad Offers Write-In Tips
text: “Today, we’re going to learn how to vote for Lisa Murkowski,” says the teacher in Senator Lisa Murkowski’s voter education ad that went up online Monday night. “It’s as easy as two steps.”

headline: A Trade-In Market for the Volt Battery?
