headline: Pictures of the Day: The U.N. and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from South Africa, the European Parliament, the village of Bello Patan in Pakistan and the Buriganga River in Bangladesh.

headline: FanVision Gadget Makes Debut in Some N.F.L. Stadiums
text: For football spectators, a device called FanVision might be nirvana  or it might turn them into stadium versions of zombies who stumble down streets staring mesmerized at their BlackBerrys.

headline: G.O.P. Reception Stirs Up Criticism From Democrats
text: In the rhetorical war over which political party has deeper ties to much-maligned Washington lobbyists, White House officials on Tuesday seized on a perhaps ill-timed party invitation.

headline: A Bipartisan Bill on Renewable Energy
text: In a rare show of bipartisanship, a group of Democratic and Republican senators introduced legislation on Tuesday that would require utilities nationwide to generate at least 15 percent of their electricity from renewable sources like wind, solar and biomass by 2021.

headline: When It’s Illegal to Photograph Artwork
text: Who hasn’t walked into a local gallery, been shocked by how expensive all the pieces are and then walked out empty-handed?

headline: Rehearsing 'Boris Godunov'
text: Stephen Wadsworth directing a rehearsal at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Met’s Replacement Gets in Tune
text: Opera singers drop out of productions left and right. Conductors even cancel once in a while. Directors? Rarely.

headline: Union Square Booming Despite Soft Economy
text: Twenty-five years ago, fresh from a stint cooking in France and Italy, Danny Meyer searched the streets around Union Square for a site to open his first restaurant. He was drawn to the area’s cheap rents and proximity to one of the city’s best farmers’ markets, but the neighborhood left something to be desired.

headline: House Hunting in ... Ukraine
text: A TWO-BEDROOM TWO-BATH APARTMENT IN THE HEART OF KIEV

headline: An Apartment in Kiev
text: A two-bedroom apartment in an early 20th-century apartment building is on the market for $500,000.

headline: What’s a Submarine Officer Doing in the Desert?
text: Christopher Brownfield’s memoir, “My Nuclear Family,” is not the best book written by an insider about America’s post-9/11 military, but it’s certainly the most entertaining. It’s got a cocky, star-spangled, wide-angle feel, as if a subversive young novelist had decided to rewrite a Tom Clancy thriller after first piloting some nuclear submarines as a gonzo practice drill.

headline: Top White House Economic Adviser to Depart
text: 6:29 p.m. | Updated Lawrence H. Summers, who for nearly two years has been the architect of President Obama’s economic policies, is leaving the White House to return to Harvard University at the end of the year, the White House announced on Tuesday.

headline: New Season Brings Strong Ratings – for Most
text: One night into the new television season, three networks had something to celebrate — and one had to decide how to moderate the panic.

headline: Vandaag
text: THIS is a city of beautiful restaurants. No one who has lunched at Le Bernardin, or wandered at twilight into the Harrison, or spent a Don Draper evening under the towering ceilings of Eleven Madison Park can deny it. These dining rooms are stages, for both chef and customer. They captivate.

headline: Green Light for Experimentalism: Tweaking Conventions and Bending Rules
text: When contemporary artists tamper with time-honored masterpieces, those who object usually cite what they consider a reliably horrifying image: drawing a mustache on the Mona Lisa. But as Marcel Duchamp discovered in 1919, sometimes drawing a mustache on the Mona Lisa (or a copy of it) is exactly the right thing to do, and it may be that having the right artist paint the right mustache can yield some insight about the lady with the faint smile.

headline: Reviewing Vandaag
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: Travel Groups Start Online Petition on Airline Fees
text: Does having to pay an airline $8 for a pillow and blanket tick you off? If so, a coalition of travel groups wants to hear from you, and they’ve set up a special Web site just for that purpose: MadAsHellAboutHiddenFees.com.

headline: Murkowski to Lose Senate Committee Spot
text: Senate Republicans are not happy with their colleague, Senator Lisa Murkowski, for running as a write-in candidate in Alaska’s Senate race, and they intend to show it.

headline: Supporting a Modest Contest for Artists, but Hoping for a Big Influence
text: When it comes to art competitions, there are high-profile contests with big prizes and then, well, there are other ones.

headline: Summers to Leave Obama’s Economic Team
text: 7:10 p.m. | Updated The chief architect of President Obama’s economic policies, Lawrence H. Summers, will leave the White House and return to his position as a professor at Harvard, the administration announced Tuesday.

headline: Obama’s Economics Chief Is Set to Leave
text: WASHINGTON  The White House said Tuesday that Lawrence H. Summers, the chief architect of President Obama’s economic policy, would leave at the end of the year, continuing an exodus of top-level advisers at a time when voters are expressing deep dissatisfaction with the president’s stewardship of the economy.

headline: Theater Renovation Welcomed as a Gain for Arts in Brooklyn
text: An experimental music organization has plans to renovate a dilapidated 600-seat theater space near the Brooklyn Academy of Music, a move that some hope will re-energize an effort to build a cultural district around the academy in downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Bulletproof Clothing: Take Your Best Shot
text: THE opening of a palatial new boutique on the priciest stretch of Madison Avenue during a downturn, when so many storefronts have papered their windows, raises questions. Who are these people? Are they from an alternate dimension where there is a parallel, but separate, economy? Can they fly?

headline: Two New York Groups Win ‘Promise Neighborhood’ Grants
text: Twenty-one local community organizations around the country won $500,000 federal grants on Tuesday to begin replicating the Harlem Children’s Zone’s cradle-to-college approach to improving education block by block.

headline: Blogging Pioneer Is Bought by Video Ad Firm
text: Six Apart, the pioneering company behind the Movable Type and TypePad blogging services, is being acquired by the online advertising firm VideoEgg.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Nutritious Chips: Not an Oxymoron
text: The Rorschach allure of the dark, leafy shapes have you admiring the crisp kale chips before you nibble. Thin and glazed with various seasonings, they not only are snack worthy and packed with nutrients, but they also can be used for dipping or as a salad topping or a garnish for all sorts of dishes, like baked fish or even soups. Amy Hamberry and Joe Orr make them by dehydrating kale in their Brooklyn plant, where some magic makes than taste fried. They come in three flavors: spicy miso, vegan cheese and, my favorite, Bombay curry, which I would certainly serve with an Indian dinner.

headline: At the Latest Food Complex, Dim Sum Gets Into the Mix
text: Ed Schoenfeld and Jeffrey Chodorow’s FoodParc, the city’s latest food complex, cuts straight through the new Eventi Hotel and will lead to a spacious park, which will open to the public in October. For now, only the indoor section, with a futuristic design by Syd Mead, is open. At RedFarm Stand, the dumpling master Joe Ng (above) is fashioning inventive shumai, some served on skewers; potstickers; assorted egg rolls, including one filled with Katz’s Deli pastrami; salads; and seared short rib on a bun. Opposite is a bar, and nearby Fornetti features flatbreads with various toppings, including salad. The 3 Bs refers to bacon, burgers and beer and is where the food also includes grilled cheese, bacon optional. The Press is a coffee and juice bar that also sells newspapers.

headline: Gastronomes Await ‘Modernist Cuisine’
text: THE wait for the 30-hour cheeseburger just got a little longer. The dish, which takes more than a day to prepare, calls for a short-rib patty to be slow-cooked in a vacuum pack, then dunked in liquid nitrogen before it is deep fried. It is among more than a thousand recipes in “Modernist Cuisine,” a cookbook whose publishing delay, announced on Sept. 15, set off a collective sigh among gastronomes.

headline: Doctor’s Orders: Eat Well to Be Well
text: OAKLAND, Calif.

headline: New Wonjo Restaurant
text: IF you judge by appearances, New Wonjo Restaurant is the same Koreatown standby it was when it was just plain Wonjo. It’s still open 24 hours a day, and the menu is still the size of a ledger. As always, runners thread through the busy upstairs dining room carrying braziers of glowing coals for the in-table grills in what must be one of the most unsafe, if exhilarating, opening acts to a meal you’ll find in Midtown.

headline: El Bulli and a Meal for the Ages
text: MORE than a year ago, before anybody had the slightest inkling that a potential closing was in the offing, I achieved the unexpected coup of a reservation at El Bulli, Ferran Adrià’s temple of avant-garde dining in Spain.

headline: Oil With Flavor You Can See
text: The bottle of Esperanto Oil holds a jumble of spices, whole and crushed, that give it a ruddy color and a bright, complex flavor, heightened by cumin and fennel. Drizzle it on fish, pork chops, roasted vegetables, plain ricotta or even toasted country bread. Most of the seasonings stay in the bottle, keeping the flavor of the remaining oil going. It’s concocted by Esperanto, a pan-Latin restaurant in the East Village.

headline: At Bonny Doon’s Restaurant, Dinner With, Oh, Yes, Wine
text: SANTA CRUZ, Calif.

headline: Spiking Summer Fruit in Order to Preserve It
text: AT the end of every summer, as the heaps of fresh fruit start to dwindle at the farmers’ markets, the urge to preserve it all pulls strong.

headline: Preserving the Dewiness of Youth
text: IN the last decade, the dermatologist Dr. Nicholas Perricone has become an outspoken platoon leader in the battle against aging. Mostly, his troops of true believers were the wrinkled middle-aged. They bought into his theory that inflammation causes aging, and that eating wild salmon and blueberries would make their skin glow anew.

headline: Cantors Try to Heal Rift Through Song
text: In the old days, the best cantors — Jewish clergy who specialize in the musical interpretation of prayer — were stars. Many dressed to the nines and had entourages that followed them in the street and crowded into temple to hear them sing. That’s because “Good synagogue is good show,” as one current practitioner says, quoting his boyhood cantor, in “100 Voices: A Journey Home.”

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Market Designs on View

headline: As Chess Olympiad Begins, No Surprises, but More Controversy
text: Competition began at the biennial event on Tuesday and there were no major upsets, but some countries are angry about the number of teams from Russia, the host of the Olympiad.

headline: Scorecard | Christopher Kane Wins!
text: Psst … want a little tip on improving your Scorecard odds? Don’t show on the same day as Christopher Kane. For though Peter Pilotto picked a peck of polymorphous prints on the fourth day of shows, London’s prince of perversity already had the prim-and-prudish-princess-on-acid thing pinned down.

headline: More Legal Drama for Wednesdays, From New York to Las Vegas
text: If you are an assistant district attorney meeting the tormented parents of a murdered and apparently angelic teenage girl for the first time, what do you do? Well, if you are confronting this circumstance in a Jerry Bruckheimer television production, you offer up extraneous self-explanation. “I love the law,” says the prosecutor with the pixie haircut early on in “The Whole Truth.” “It is the only thing I am good at. Just ask anybody unfortunate enough to be involved in my personal life.”

headline: Picking a Wine for a 38-Course Meal
text: If you want to set a daunting task for yourself, try picking a bottle of wine that will pair with a 38-course dinner. How many courses, 38? Alright, make it two bottles.

headline: Three Couples, Three Different Stages of Romance
text: The first question regarding “Better With You,” the new ABC comedy that begins on Wednesday night, is how to say the title. Better with you, as opposed to without you, implying squabbling partners? Or better with you, as opposed to with someone else, implying the act of choosing a partner?

headline: New Worlds to Conquer, Even for Casual Rulers
text: When you think of the most evocative characters in video games, various commandos and knights and even a plumber come to mind. But I’ve always been taken by the image of a tiny band of settlers in the vast wilderness of an unknown world at the very dawn of recorded history, 4000 B.C. On a riverbank they build their first huts and begin to discover what separates men from beasts: pottery, writing, mining, the wheel.

headline: Filming ‘The Black Tulip’
text: Production photographs from a feature film shot on location in Afghanistan, directed by, and starring, Sonia Nassery Cole.

headline: A Director’s Many Battles to Make Her Movie
text: LOS ANGELES — Sonia Nassery Cole knew that shooting a movie on location in Afghanistan could get her killed. The most vivid reminder came a few weeks before filming, she said, when militants located her leading actress and cut off both of her feet.

headline: EBay Executive Leaves for Personal Reasons
text: Lorrie Norrington, the leader of eBay’s vast online auction business, will be resigning, the company said Tuesday.

headline: Will Summers Reunite With Wall Street?
text: With Lawrence H. Summers set to depart the Obama administration, forgive us for wondering whether he will reestablish his ties to high finance.

headline: Excerpt: 'Better With You'
text: The ABC sitcom follows three couples.

headline: Stores Scramble to Accommodate Budget Shoppers
text: The country’s continued economic doldrums have stores scrambling for the once-ignored low-end customer, as people make fewer costly shopping trips to stock their pantries, and increasingly, can only afford inexpensive items in small quantities like those sold at dollar stores.

headline: Range Rover Evoque to Be Unwrapped in Paris
text: The LRX concept car, unveiled by Land Rover at the 2008 Detroit auto show, is coming to production in 2011 as the Evoque, which will break cover Sept. 30 at the Paris motor show.

headline: Sort of a Salon, Sort of a Church
text: IN a narrow, high-ceilinged theater space on 14th Street in Chelsea this summer, congregants sat raptly on white folding chairs as a man in a black suit and skinny tie made his way down the aisle to the front of the room. With his mop-haired colleague wolf-whistling through an effects-filtered microphone, he proceeded in slow motion, as though he were underwater, until he got to the front of the assembly.

headline: Tower Plan Clears Hurdle
text: One obstacle to construction of a tower designed by Jean Nouvel next to the Museum of Modern Art has been removed. Justice O. Peter Sherwood of State Supreme Court in Manhattan last week rejected a petition by nearby residents to have the project’s approvals by the City Council and the New York City Planning Commission overturned. The petitioners  two local residents’ associations (the West 54-55 Street Block Association and the Coalition for Responsible Midtown Development) and three individual residents  oppose the planned tower, which is to include a hotel, residential apartments and space for the museum, on the ground that it would be too tall for the neighborhood. In his decision Justice Sherwood said the Council and the Planning Commission had not acted irrationally or arbitrarily, as the petitioners had charged. Before approving it, the Planning Commission required that the tower’s height be reduced to 1,050 feet from 1,250 feet.

headline: Manuel Questions Torre’s Integrity
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Jerry Manuel expressed his displeasure at Joe Torre on Tuesday regarding Torre’s comments on what is, at least for the next 12 games, still Manuel’s job.

headline: Giving Voice to Sylvia Plath’s Pregnant Women
text: ROBERT SHAW, the British producer and director, has rather unusual taste in vacation reading. While most of us fill our overnight bags with Stieg Larsson novels, fashionable memoirs or local guide books, Mr. Shaw found himself some years ago lazing about in his Dubrovnik hotel reading the poetry of Sylvia Plath. A Web site he’d chanced on mentioned that Plath had written a radio play in verse, “Three Women,” which the BBC had broadcast in August 1962, less than six months before her suicide. Mr. Shaw soon located the piece, a forceful meditation on pregnancy and childbearing. He read it, he said, and decided: “This is powerful. This is incendiary. I have to go with this. I have to pursue it.”

headline: The Rich, Their Taxes and Obama
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Dancing’ Leads Night of Strong Debuts
text: The 11th-season premiere of ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars,” featuring Bristol Palin and the “Jersey Shore” star Mike Sorrentino, known as the Situation, topped the ratings on a Monday night packed with series debuts. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 21 million viewers tuned in to “Dancing,” down from the 24.2 million who watched the spring premiere in March, but up considerably from last September’s debut (18.8 million). Also posting strong ratings were CBS’s re-imagined version of “Hawaii Five-0” (13.8 million viewers), which at 10 p.m. led premieres of ABC’s “Castle” (11.2 million) and NBC’s “Chase” (7.9 million). At 9, NBC’s new conspiracy thriller “The Event” (11.2 million viewers) also made a solid debut, but the premieres of CBS’s sitcoms “Two and a Half Men” (14.5 million) and “Mike & Molly” (12.2 million) fared better. Fox’s new drama “Lone Star” drew just 4.1 million in its premiere at 9.

headline: For Cubs’ Japanese Star, Cheers Become Whispers
text: CHICAGO  Katsushi Nagao is lonely. A reporter for the Kyodo News, Japan’s foremost news service, Nagao was once at one of the centers of Japanese baseball in the United States, surrounded by a legion of colleagues with cameras, digital recorders and notepads aimed squarely at Kosuke Fukudome, the multitalented right fielder for the Chicago Cubs.

headline: Homes for $335,000
text: A three-bedroom in Texas, a condo in a converted church in Denver and a five-bedroom in upstate New York.

headline: Step Right Up for Pest Control at Bedbug Meeting
text: ROSEMONT, Ill.  This may be the only place in the country where, for two days at least, the prospect of a bedbug infestation carries not the slightest, slimmest of stigmas.

text: The unlimited MetroCard may live on, if vocal New Yorkers around the region have anything to do it.

headline: Disobeying Israel’s Law of Entry, for Fun

text: 5:30 a.m. | Updated A.I.G. announced the sale Thursday morning.

headline: City Officials Arrested in Los Angeles Suburb
text: BELL, Calif.  The investigators from the district attorney’s office showed up at the mayor’s house early Tuesday morning, arrest warrant and battering ram in hand, banging on the door. When the mayor, Oscar Hernandez, ignored their shouts  “Come out!” and “Put your hands up!”  they rammed down the door and arrested Mr. Hernandez on charges of looting the treasury of his own city to enrich himself.

headline: Online Marketer Settles With New York for $5.2 Million
text: The online marketing company Webloyalty has agreed to pay $5.2 million in penalties and refunds to customers who were charged unauthorized fees after they signed up for discount club programs online, the New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, announced on Tuesday.

headline: Going to the 3-4 for a Reason: It’s Working
text: Almost half the teams in the N.F.L. are fielding a 3-4 defense of one degree or another.

headline: U.S. Joins Pfizer Suit Over Drug’s Marketing
text: The Justice Department on Tuesday joined a whistle-blower lawsuit against Pfizer and its subsidiary Wyeth Pharmaceuticals that accuses Wyeth of illegal off-label marketing of Rapamune, a drug used to prevent rejection of kidney transplants.

headline: A Grounded Kuchar Is on Top of the World (and the PGA Money List)
text: ATLANTA  When he moves on the golf course, with the languid, almost liquid ease of an athlete, Matt Kuchar looks as if he is in no hurry to get anywhere. This tranquillity with which he approaches his game, and most everything in his career, is a fitting place to start with him.

headline: Airline Trade Group Lifts Profit Forecast
text: An industry trade association more than tripled its profit forecast for the world’s airlines, to $8.9 billion, this year, citing steady gains in passenger demand and a strong rebound in the air freight market.

headline: Scott Brown to Raise Money for Toomey
text: Senator Scott P. Brown is slated to head to Philadelphia later this week to help raise campaign cash for Pat Toomey, the Republican Senate candidate in Pennsylvania.

headline: Tight Budgets for Campaigns May Hinder Republicans
text: WASHINGTON  Republicans enter the final six weeks of the election with a political wind at their back and opportunities for victory across the country, yet several state parties are at a severe financial disadvantage with Democrats, raising questions about whether Republicans can fully capitalize on a favorable climate.

headline: Tensions Linger Between Pope and Anglicans
text: LONDON  The pope and the archbishop prayed together last weekend, a rare event at Westminster Abbey meant to show the fundamental closeness of Catholics and Anglicans, their churches separated in doctrine by few degrees and each battered by secularism and division. The signal sent was that, someday, a more formal union would strengthen both.

headline: Woman on Death Row Runs Out of Appeals
text: “She is clearly the head of this serpent,” the judge said of Teresa Lewis in 2003 when he sentenced her to death by lethal injection, describing her as the mastermind of the cold-blooded murders of her husband and his son as they slept in rural Virginia.

headline: Oracle Growth Plans Worry Rivals and Customers
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Each year, Oracle’s presence looms over this city for a week, during the company’s Open World customer conference. About 41,000 people arrived this week to discuss business software in fine detail and talk over beers. Stretches of downtown streets closed and gave way to makeshift tents housing coffee stands, bars, Lego play areas and candy buffets.

headline: Eagles Change Direction and Name Vick as Starter
text: On Monday, Philadelphia Eagles Coach Andy Reid talked about the “beautiful situation” he had at quarterback, Kevin Kolb returning from a concussion to reclaim his starting job on Sunday against Jacksonville and Michael Vick coming off the bench with a hot hand for a change of pace.

headline: Woodward Book Says Afghanistan Divided White House
text: WASHINGTON — Some of the critical players in President Obama’s national security team doubt his strategy in Afghanistan will succeed and have spent much of the last 20 months quarreling with one another over policy, personalities and turf, according to a new book.

headline: Prosecutor Is Investigating the Handling of a Reclusive Heiress’s Vast Fortune
text: Huguette M. Clark always had a place in the society pages, but rarely, if ever, was she the headliner. She was listed as a guest of this engagement dinner and that party. Her charitable contributions were noted, not celebrated.

headline: Jets Assail Edwards for ‘Poor Judgment’
text: While the Jets’ reality television show of a football season started with HBO documenting training camp, the events of Tuesday morning were more suited to an episode of “Cops.”

headline: Lawsuits Accuse Megachurch Leader of Sexual Misconduct
text: ATLANTA  Two young men in Georgia said Tuesday that the pastor of a 33,000-person Baptist megachurch, Bishop Eddie L. Long, had repeatedly coerced them into having sex with him.

headline: At Empire State Building, a 40th Floor Squatter
text: Daniel K. Perlman had the quietest, cheapest and strangest office in New York City. It was quiet because he had a deserted six-room suite to himself; cheap because he paid zero in rent; and strange because he had all of this on the 40th floor of one of the most famous skyscrapers in the world.

headline: Everyone Agrees: Steinbrenner’s Plaque Is Big
text: After George Steinbrenner’s death in July, the Yankees and his family discussed how they would remember him in Monument Park at Yankee Stadium. They chose the wide space on the rear granite wall that separates two groups of modest plaques.

headline: Pantless Stand Against Authority Is a Mere Blip in Boulder’s Long Culture War
text: BOULDER, Colo.  Seth Brigham’s boxer shorts might not be the spark for a new culture war. But that is probably because in this college city near Denver, where Ph.D.’s, million-dollar homes and high-end shopping districts bump up against a golden-glow hippie sensibility anchored somewhere around 1972, the culture war never ended.

headline: Cox Earns Respect (and Wins) to the End

headline: An Iowa Egg Farmer and a History of Salmonella
text: On a July night in 1987, scores of elderly and chronically ill patients at Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital in New York City began to fall violently sick with food poisoning from eggs tainted with salmonella.

headline: We Are What We Eat
text: Most of the antibiotics sold in the United States  70 percent  go to the animals we eat, especially pigs and chickens. To speed up growth and to prevent the spread of disease in crowded conditions, growers put small amounts of antibiotics into animals’ daily feed. The result is nearly the same as if we were eating the antibiotics ourselves: an increase in antibiotic resistance in humans and the emergence of drug-resistant microbes.

headline: Ensuring Petty Crimes Don’t Lead to Big Ones
text: The 16-year-old defendant seemed annoyed and a bit confused. Seated in the witness box in a courthouse in Staten Island, her answers were curt and short on detail. The inquiry into her crime  stealing a shirt in April at the Staten Island Mall  had just begun. Could she describe what happened?

headline: Near Cuba, Wary Kin Wait for Proof of a New Path
text: MIAMI  Fashion boutiques, restaurants, a bank  Jorge Gomez plans to help his relatives in Havana open whatever business they want. But when?

headline: New Knicks Hope to Avoid Old Results
text: Amar’e Stoudemire did not need the ball to make Knicks fans swoon. His first thunderous dunk was entirely verbal  a product not of extreme athleticism, but supreme self-confidence.

headline: In Bullpen, Vazquez Could Be Out of Playoff Picture
text: The wallpaper on Javier Vazquez’s computer shows him in happier times. He is standing along the New Jersey waterfront, the Manhattan skyline behind him, with his wife and three children. A wide smile creases his face.

headline: Fair Pay Isn’t Always Equal Pay
text: Washington

headline: Despite Setback, Gay Rights Move Forward
text: Efforts that could lead to a reversal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy that prohibits openly gay soldiers from serving in the military may have stalled in the United States Senate, but the legal fight is advancing in the federal courts along with other important gay rights litigation.

headline: France: 3 Men Sentenced in Case of Stolen Picassos
text: Three men accused of trying to peddle stolen Picasso paintings were sentenced to up to seven years in prison on Tuesday after they portrayed themselves in court as witless sellers who did not know they possessed anything valuable. The paintings  “Maya à la poupée et au cheval de bois” and “Portrait de Jacqueline”  were recovered in a sting operation by the French national art brigade in 2007. Months earlier, meticulous thieves had entered the Left Bank apartment of Picasso’s granddaughter and cut away the works, leaving without a trace. One of the men, Jean Sala, 61, whose heart condition delayed the trial, was sentenced to four years, as was Paula Sabbah, 57. Abdelatif Redjil, 56, who said rope, gloves and fake keys found in his car were tools of his construction trade, was sentenced to seven years.

headline: M.T.A. Brings TVs to the Subway
text: Get ready for a new kind of subway series. Just don’t expect to see the Yankees going glove-to-glove with the Mets.

headline: For a Few, Papers Seem a Timely Bet
text: Randall D. Smith, a pioneer in the hard knocks business of vulture investing, is circling a new target: the beleaguered newspaper industry.

headline: Truly Madly Purely Jimmy
text: Christine O’Donnell has accomplished the impossible: She’s made Jimmy Carter look like a libertine.

headline: Right-Wing Sentiment, Ready to Burst Its Dam
text: BERLIN  As anti-immigrant sentiment continues to sweep across Europe, generating a right-wing populist wave from the shores of the Mediterranean to the chilly reaches of Scandinavia, there is growing concern that such politics could take root here, too, in the fertile ground of financial uncertainty, rising anti-Muslim sentiment and a widening political vacuum left by the misfortunes of the once mighty Christian Democratic Union.

headline: Passion and Politics on Immigration Act
text: WASHINGTON  Cesar Vargas graduated from James Madison High School in Brooklyn, just like Senators Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Bernard Sanders, independent of Vermont.

text: ROCKVILLE, Md. — So what do you call a salmon that is genetically engineered to grow fast?

headline: Military Equality Goes Astray
text: The best chance this year to repeal the irrational ban on openly gay members of the military slipped away Tuesday, thanks to the buildup of acrimony and mistrust in the United States Senate.

headline: Benefits and Burdens of Medicaid
text: The vital importance and the staggering cost of Medicaid have become painfully clear over the last two years. Millions of out-of-work Americans have turned to Medicaid to help pay their medical bills. State governments, which share the cost with Washington, have had to struggle to find the money; many have cut back on other vital programs to try to balance their budgets.

headline: Informer in Synagogue Plot Is Accused of Bullying Defendant
text: April 2009 was an uneasy month for federal investigators who had set up a sting operation for a group of would-be terrorists in Newburgh, N.Y. The group’s purported leader was having doubts about his role in the plan, and as a result, a government informer made increasingly lavish offers  including $250,000  to draw him back in, a defense lawyer argued in court on Tuesday.

headline: Former World Cup Referee Arrested in Heroin Transport
text: A former referee involved in Italy’s controversial elimination from the 2002 World Cup was caught at Kennedy Airport with 10 bags of heroin attached to his body, federal prosecutors said Tuesday. United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents arrested Byron Moreno late Monday after he arrived in New York on a commercial flight from his native Ecuador.

headline: Wednesday: It Multiplies by Dividing
text: This is a pretty cool theme, with an E-I-E-I-O appearing in four answers, in that order and with no other vowels being used.

China’s Expanding Reach
text: Responding to the growing numbers of Chinese working in Hungary and thie rising number of Chinese companies investing in the region, a Hungarian-Chinese bilingual primary school was opened in 2004.

headline: Group Fights for Homes on City Beach
text: As summer officially draws to a close this week, beachgoers are coming to terms with the many months ahead without sand and surf.

headline: A Dysfunctional Family, Greedy With ‘the Gimmes’

headline: 'The Little Foxes'
text: Images from Ivo van Hove's production at New York Theater Workshop.

headline: Paris Offers Water With Bubbles, but No Bottles
text: PARIS  In the latest in a series of unusual efforts to make Paris green, the city is now offering residents free sparkling water to try to wean Parisians not from red wine, but from overconsumption of plastic bottles.

headline: Google Campaign to Build Up Its Display Ads
text: Google, the online search ad giant that rarely advertises, has decided it needs to advertise the fact that it is in the online display advertising business.

headline: U.N. to Announce Aid for Women and Children
text: UNITED NATIONS  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon plans to end a development summit meeting of world leaders on Wednesday by announcing a huge increase in aid to improve the health of women and children, but independent specialists said they were skeptical about the amount of actual new money committed, given the global economic crisis.

headline: Brushing Back Torre, Manuel Gets an Apology
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  With the Mets mathematically eliminated from making the playoffs by Tuesday’s 5-2 loss to the Florida Marlins, Manager Jerry Manuel knows no amount of battling on his part will stave off the seemingly inevitable result of that failure, which will be the loss of his job. But Manuel continues to fight for the respect he feels he is due.

headline: Zimbabwe: Public Meetings on Constitution Are Suspended
text: Public meetings on a new constitution meant to guarantee democratic rights were suspended in the capital, Harare, the state-owned newspaper reported Tuesday. A new independent newspaper, Newsday, said the suspension was prompted by allegations that President Robert Mugabe’s ZANU-PF party bused in participants from rural areas who were involved in acts of violence, intimidation and racism against supporters of the Movement for Democratic Change, ZANU-PF’s rival and partner in a power-sharing government. It quoted the leader of the Movement for Democratic Change, Morgan Tsvangirai, as warning that his party would not participate in elections until a new constitution was adopted and the violence stopped.

headline: Illinois: Congressman Denies Dealing for Senate Seat
text: Representative Jesse Jackson Jr. on Tuesday denied a report that he told a fund-raiser to offer former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich campaign contributions in exchange for appointing Mr. Jackson to Barack Obama’s Senate seat. The account appeared in The Chicago Sun-Times, which said the fund-raiser, Raghuveer Nayak, told the authorities that Mr. Jackson wanted Mr. Blagojevich to know that he would help him raise $6 million. The report also said that Mr. Nayak paid for two airline trips for a “social acquaintance” of Mr. Jackson’s. Mr. Jackson did not appear to report the trips as a gift on financial disclosure forms, according to The Sun-Times. In a statement, Mr. Jackson said: “The allegations about fund-raising and the Senate seat are not new. I’ve already talked with the authorities about these claims, told them they were false, and no charges have been brought against me. The very idea of raising millions of dollars for a campaign other than my own is preposterous.” He said the reference to a social acquaintance “is a private and personal matter between me and my wife that was handled some time ago.”

headline: Politically Charged Clerks
text: As Adam Liptak recently reported in The Times, Supreme Court justices are increasingly choosing clerks who reflect and reinforce their political leanings, the more conservative justices especially but also the more liberal. Just as striking, perhaps, is that this practice isn’t sparking many objections in Washington.

headline: Texas: Shooting Prompts Review of Weapons Policy
text: The commander of Fort Bliss said he would order a review of the post’s policy on personal weapons after a retired sergeant was accused of shooting two women in a convenience store on the base Monday afternoon, killing one of them. The man, Steven Kropf, 63, of El Paso, was killed by members of the base’s civilian police force after he fatally shot Bettina Maria Goins, 44, in the head and seriously wounded a second clerk at the store, the F.B.I. said. Mr. Kropf, who recently lost his job at another store on the base, died Tuesday morning. A motive for the shooting has not been determined, the F.B.I. said.

headline: Energy Access Seen as Vital to Abolishing Worst Poverty
text: More than $36 billion a year is needed to ensure that the world’s population benefits from access to electricity and clean-burning cooking facilities by 2030, the International Energy Agency said Tuesday.

headline: Under Attack in Afghanistan
text: American soldiers west of Kandahar, Afghanistan, came under attack by insurgents during an operation.

headline: Eileen Nearne, Wartime Spy, Dies at 89
text: LONDON — After she died earlier this month, a frail 89-year-old alone in a flat in the British seaside town of Torquay, Eileen Nearne, her body undiscovered for several days, was listed by local officials as a candidate for what is known in Britain as a council burial, or what in the past was called a pauper’s grave.

headline: Hurricane Season, Bargain-Hunting in Bermuda
text: Parched from the sun and speckled with powdery white sand after spending last Tuesday afternoon on Bermuda’s idyllic Horseshoe Bay Beach, two middle-aged American women waited for snow cones from the Cool Run-Ins cart nearby.

headline: Brandon Jacobs Fined $10,000; Wants to Stay
text: Brandon Jacobs was fined $10,000 by the N.F.L. on Tuesday for throwing his helmet into the stands during the Giants’ loss to the Colts on Sunday night. (He blamed it on sticky fingers, but when it landed 10 rows deep in some of the Colts’ most expensive seats, he almost didn’t get it back.)

headline: Chinese Business Gains Foothold in Eastern Europe
text: BUDAPEST  The classroom walls at the Hungarian-Chinese bilingual primary school here are decorated with Chinese calendars and banners. Chinese lanterns hang from the ceilings of the main entrance hall. There are stacks of new Chinese language books in the staff room, provided by the Chinese authorities, who also send two teachers a year, depending on the school’s needs.

headline: Film Director Comes to the Defense of a Convicted Internet Pirate
text: PARIS  A Frenchman convicted of copyright theft for illegally downloading thousands of songs on the Internet has found an unlikely patron: a famous film director.

headline: Hughes Gives Solid Audition for Postseason
text: It would be presumptuous, General Manager Brian Cashman was saying, for the Yankees to begin conferring about their playoff roster. Until they qualify, every sentence ends with a question mark. “Everything you see as we move forward obviously is going to the discussion bin,” Cashman said.

headline: Chief of UniCredit Resigns at Request of Board
text: ROME  Alessandro Profumo, the chief executive of the big European lender UniCredit, resigned on Tuesday.

headline: A Good Payday for Banks in Petrobras Sale
text: Brazil’s sale of about $79 billion of stock in Petróleo Brasileiro looks set for a string of financial superlatives. One of them, however, won’t be loudly crowed about by investment bankers. The underwriting fee on the deal, which is expected to close this week, appears to be among the lowest in a global stock offering of this kind.

headline: Joyce Beber, Creator of Ads for Leona Helmsley, Dies at 80
text: Being fired by a client is hardly an adman’s dream, but being fired by Leona Helmsley can make you a legend  especially if it happens four times. So it was with Joyce Beber.

headline: The Money Sweepstakes, August Edition
text: In spite of predictions of a Republican rout at the polls in November, Democratic Party committees outraised their Republican counterparts in August. The Democrats also have more money on hand over all.

headline: Phys Ed: Looking at How Concussions When Young Influence Later Life
text: For a study published last fall, researchers at the University of Illinois asked 90 college-age athletes, male and female, to complete a series of tests of cognitive dexterity while the researchers measured the electrical activity within their brains. The athletes played a range of sports, including ice hockey, rugby and soccer, or ran track. About half had been given a diagnosis at some point in their young athletic careers of a concussion. Some had had three or more.

headline: Sony Hopes for a Blockbuster as ‘Dr. Oz’ Format Goes to China
text: How is this for expanding an audience? The program known in America as “The Dr. Oz Show” is about to welcome an additional 876 million potential viewers.

headline: Halladay Wins 20, Recalling Carlton in ’82
text: PHILADELPHIA – Steve Carlton in 1982 is the reason I fell in love with baseball. There were many other reasons, but mostly, I was lucky enough to be 7 years old and living nearby when he had his last big season. It hooked me for life.

headline: Fed Stands Pat and Says It Is Still Ready to Buy Debt
text: Officials at the Federal Reserve signaled on Tuesday for the first time that they were worried that the slow-moving economic recovery could be undermined by very low rates of inflation, and hinted strongly that it might resume buying vast amounts of government debt to spur the recovery.

text: From David Leonhardt’s latest column in The New York Times:

headline: Money-Laundering Inquiry Touches Vatican Bank
text: Italian monetary authorities said Tuesday that they had impounded $30 million from the Vatican bank and placed its top two officers under investigation in connection with a money-laundering inquiry. The announcement amounted to another potential storm confronting the papacy of Pope Benedict XVI, who is struggling with the effects of a priestly abuse scandal.

headline: Chief of UniCredit Resigns at Request of Board
text: Alessandro Profumo, the chief executive of the big European lender UniCredit, resigned on Tuesday, Elisabetta Povoledo and Matthew Saltmarsh write in The New York Times.

headline: Abbott Laboratories Plans to Cut 3,000 Jobs
text: Abbott Laboratories said Tuesday that it planned to cut 3,000 jobs, or about 3 percent of its work force, after its purchase of Solvay‘s pharmaceuticals business, Reuters reported.

headline: 2 Get Prison for Complex Mortgage Scam in N.Y.
text: Two men convicted of leading a $100 million mortgage fraud were sentenced Tuesday to prison in a scheme that amassed a cast of corrupt mortgage brokers and lawyers to dupe sellers and buyers and pocket money that banks lent people to buy real estate, The Associated Press reported.

headline: AMP Said to Postpone Decision on AXA Bid
text: AMP, the Australian insurer, will take at least a month to decide whether to revive its bid for wealth manager AXA Asia Pacific, two sources told Reuters on Wednesday, signaling more delays for the $10 billion-plus deal.

headline: UBS Said to Hire Analyst Naomi Takagi
text: UBS, Switzerland’s biggest bank, said it hired analyst Naomi Takagi from JPMorgan Chase in a bid to expand its equity research business in Japan, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Weakness on Wall Street After Fed Decision
text: Shares on Wall Street got a brief bump on Tuesday after word that the Federal Reserve was ready to do more to help the economy, but indexes ended mostly lower after the central bank disappointed some investors by not taking any bold new actions, The Associated Press said.

text: HSBC‘s chief executive, Michael Geoghegan, is considering leaving his position at the bank after a meeting last week that signaled that he might be passed over for the role of chairman, The Financial Times reported, citing two people familiar with the matter.

headline: Indian Firms Scramble to Tap I.P.O. Market
text: Large numbers of Indian companies are planning initial public offerings in the next few weeks, tapping a market trading at 32-month highs, and rushing to get out of the way of many jumbo state-run offerings expected during the next couple of months, Reuters writes.

headline: Lady Gaga’s Political Foray
text: WHO was in the crowd when Lady Gaga gave a political speech?

headline: UBS Americas Backs U.S. Infrastructure Bank
text: The chief executive of UBS‘s Americas unit threw his support behind the Obama administration’s proposal for an infrastructure bank on Tuesday, but warned against creating a quasi-government agency like the housing finance enterprises Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, Reuters reported.

headline: China Takes a Sharper Tone in Dispute With Japan
text: BEIJING  Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao “strongly urged” Japan to immediately and unconditionally release from custody the captain of a Chinese trawler, threatening further action if Japan refuses.

headline: Relativity to Exceed $2 Billion in Revenue, Chief Says
text: Relativity Media, the privately held film financing company, will bring in more than $2 billion in revenue for the first time this year, its chief executive, Ryan Kavanaugh, said Tuesday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Britain’s Fraud Police Said to Widen Fund Inquiry
text: Britain’s Serious Fraud Office has widened its long-running investigation into Weavering Capital, drawing in Swedish investigators and overseas creditors, Reuters reported, citing a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Avista’s Thompson Publishing Files for Bankruptcy
text: Thompson Publishing Group, backed by private equity firm Avista Capital Partners, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, The Associated Press reported.

headline: How (Over)Protective Are Your Parents?
text: An article in the Week in Review discusses the risks that parents worry about most — and contrasts them with the dangers that are actually more likely to affect kids. What do your parents worry about when it comes to your safety and welfare? What rules do they have that are designed to keep you safe?

headline: Goldman Said to Plan Sale of Primo Japan Stake
text: Goldman Sachs wants to sell its stake in Primo Japan, a Japanese retailer of diamond rings, and is seeking bids of as much as 10 billion yen ($118 million), Reuters reported, citing four people with direct knowledge of the transaction.

headline: Term Paper Mills Are in a Flunk
text: Today’s idea: Essay mills produce work of such low quality that students have no other option but to actually write their own papers, a professor says — “or maybe get help in the old-fashioned way and copy from friends.”

headline: Severstal Said to Plan $4 Billion I.P.O. of Gold Unit
text: Severstal, Russia’s largest steel producer, is preparing an initial public offering of its gold unit this year in London, in a deal that would value the business at $4 billion, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Liking to Like on Facebook
text: Face it: People like to Like.

headline: The Lawless Jets? The Numbers Don’t Back It Up
text: The Jets made headlines with the signing of Braylon Edwards, Antonio Cromartie and Santonio Holmes — players with troubled pasts. The news that Edwards was arrested early on Tuesday morning in Manhattan on suspicion of drunken driving seemed to confirm for many that the Jets were and are the bad boys of the league.

headline: Life After the Home Buyer Tax Credit
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Dinner for Sale, Deep Pockets and No Fear of Heights Required
text: Taking the idea of the pop-up restaurant to breathtaking new heights, Gordon Ramsay, Daniel Boulud and nine other top chefs will be serving stellar meals in capsules high on the London Eye, the world’s tallest observation wheel, in October. Two of the evenings are still up for grabs — but you’ll need deep pockets to score a table.

headline: A Fancy Place for a Squatter
text: New York City has long been home to many squatters, people who want to stay even when the fickle but often expensive real estate market makes it all but impossible. Most of them, whether holed up in a converted Brooklyn factory, decrepit Lower East Side tenement or the man-made cavern of an abandoned subway station, cannot imagine the luxury Daniel K. Perlman enjoyed. Manny Fernandez reports in today’s About New York column that Mr. Perlman, a family law and criminal defense lawyer, was the sole occupant of a six-room suite on the 40th floor of the Empire State Building for seven months after a mortgage broker who rented him space in the suite for little or no rent went under.

headline: Once More Into the Groove: ‘Desperately Seeking Susan’ Turns 25
text: Empty out your vintage shopping bags from Love Saves the Day, unroll your fishnet stockings and dust off that pyramid jacket you claim belonged to Jimi Hendrix, because “Desperately Seeking Susan” is a quarter-century old. This 1985 comedy-drama, which starred Rosanna Arquette as a New Jersey housewife masquerading as a bohemian Manhattanite – and, by the way, provided Madonna with her first lead role in a movie – was for a generation of viewers an introduction to New York’s downtown counterculture and its motley fashion sensibility. Now the film plays like a cinematic time capsule, filled with endearingly grimy places, authentic and imagined, and distinctive personalities that have vanished from the city.

headline: Chief of Staff Pick Would Offer a View on Obama’s Strategy
text: By all knowledgeable accounts, Rahm Emanuel hasn’t yet decided whether he will leave his job as White House chief of staff to run for mayor of Chicago. But that hasn’t dampened the intense speculation in Washington on the question of who might replace him.

A crowd of people was held behind a police barricade on the opposite sidewalk, and guests waved their plastic entrance cards and then entered the darkened show space mobbed with people. More than once I found myself turning to apologize to someone’s giant handbag.

Itchy artist fingers are always looking for a different place to play, and leather motorcycle jackets are a good one. Turning them into graffiti art doesn’t just make them unique. You can wear them. Which can make you look unique. That’s the point.

headline: Kafka’s Last Trial
text: During his lifetime, Franz Kafka burned an estimated 90 percent of his work. After his death at age 41, in 1924, a letter was discovered in his desk in Prague, addressed to his friend Max Brod. “Dearest Max,” it began. “My last request: Everything I leave behind me . . . in the way of diaries, manuscripts, letters (my own and others’), sketches and so on, to be burned unread.” Less than two months later, Brod, disregarding Kafka’s request, signed an agreement to prepare a posthumous edition of Kafka’s unpublished novels. “The Trial” came out in 1925, followed by “The Castle” (1926) and “Amerika” (1927). In 1939, carrying a suitcase stuffed with Kafka’s papers, Brod set out for Palestine on the last train to leave Prague, five minutes before the Nazis closed the Czech border. Thanks largely to Brod’s efforts, Kafka’s slim, enigmatic corpus was gradually recognized as one of the great monuments of 20th-century literature.

We have since exchanged a few questions and answers by e-mail, and I thought our discussion — which you’ll find below — might spark some conversation on The Choice, particularly among young women and their families. So please use the comment box below to weigh in on the state of women’s colleges — not just Bryn Mawr — and their future. Questions and answers have been edited. — Jacques Steinberg

headline: Runway Beauty | Burberry Prorsum
text: “Sultry, sexy and fresh” was how Burberry’s head makeup consultant Wendy Rowe described the look she put together for the label’s show yesterday afternoon. Brightly colored makeup has popped up on more than a few runways this season, but Rowe kept her palette cool, leaving the spotlight to the accessories (think canary-yellow belts and turquoise clutches). “This season’s Burberry girl climbs off the back of her boyfriend’s bike and shakes her hair out, still looking beautiful,” Rowe says. “She has a vaguely feline face, and we did a slightly disappearing lip, with a touch of lip gloss, to make it more modern. The look isn’t too considered.” Naturally, this look was achieved using Burberry’s recently introduced makeup collection, which she helped develop with Christopher Bailey, Burberry’s creative director.

headline: End of Summer, and Summers
text: It is presumably accidental that the papers on the last day of summer report that Larry Summers is leaving the administration. There is an exodus of economic officials from the Obama team, and they are mostly going out with hostile commentary. The economy is not booming, and the president’s poll numbers are poor. That must be the economic team’s fault. One commentary I read this morning says President Obama will be the Democratic Herbert Hoover.

headline: Jack McBrayer Joins Anniversary Reading of ‘The Normal Heart’
text: Days after “30 Rock” broadcasts its live episode on Oct. 14 Jack McBrayer will once again be flying without a net. Mr. McBrayer, who on “30 Rock” plays the NBC page and lovable rube Kenneth, will make his Broadway debut in a staged reading of Larry Kramer’s “The Normal Heart” at the Walter Kerr Theater on Oct. 18, the production’s publicists said on Wednesday. The reading, to celebrate the 25th anniversary of Mr. Kramer’s play about the early years of the AIDS crisis, will be directed by Joel Grey; its previously announced cast will include Patrick Wilson, Victor Garber, Joe Mantello, Michael Stuhlbarg, Jason Butler Harner and John Benjamin Hickey. The reading, which is produced by Daryl Roth, is a benefit for the Actors Fund and the organization Friends in Deed, which provides services for people with life-threatening illnesses.

headline: Mexican New Yorkers Are Steady Force in Workplace

Men and women pass one another at the entrance of a four-story building on 21st Avenue in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, on their way out to work, or back in for a few hours of sleep between shifts. They are line cooks, construction laborers, deliverymen, deli workers, housecleaners and gardeners.

headline: In Macedonia, the Lure of the Grape
text: LAND-LOCKED Macedonia often feels like a forgotten place, tucked among Greece, Albania, Kosovo, Serbia and Bulgaria. For centuries, it seemed to be part of someplace else, including, until two decades ago, Yugoslavia. Unlike Croatia, with its stunning coastline, or Sarajevo, with its airy hills, Macedonia has struggled for the world’s attention since gaining independence in 1991 and lacks the allure of a must-see destination. Other than a smattering of castles and a few colorful bazaars, the country’s cities are unexceptional.

headline: On Being Chopped Liver
text: Atrios makes a good point. There have, broadly speaking, been two schools of criticism of the Obama administration’s economic policy — those who said it was doing too much, and those who said it was doing too little. Yet reporting on the departure of Larry Summers simply fails to acknowledge the existence of the second group. The range of opinion worth even mentioning runs from Boehner on the right to Summers on the left, and stops there.

headline: Letter: Lost In Tangier
text: To the Editor: In “Lost in Tangier,” Matt Gross romanticizes “getting lost” in Tangier’s medina. He makes the journey seem eminently doable for a solo traveler. He fails to mention that this may be much more difficult for a woman traveling alone. I lived in Morocco for eight months on a Fulbright grant, and traveled quite a bit around the country. In Tangier, like many cities I visited in Morocco, it was not advisable to be out alone at night if you were not a male or accompanied by one. Come-ons aloud and whispered, being followed in cars, the occasional grab: none of these are much fun. Matt Gross, as a man traveling alone, perhaps did not think about any of this as none of it happened to him, or perhaps he did not think to ask any of the women he met.

headline: Caregiving Thrives at an Intersection of Faiths

headline: Illusions Found In Our Narratives
text: Laurie Anderson’s art has always been more theatrical than musical, driven mainly by an amalgam of text, wordplay and imagery  verbal and visual  and only secondarily by notes and rhythms. In her latest work, “Delusion,” which opened the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave Festival on Tuesday evening at the BAM Harvey Theater, stretches of the score are little more than a shimmering drone, against which Ms. Anderson spins curious tales and observations in the impish, matter-of-fact speaking voice that has become one of her trademarks (and in the folksy, electronically manipulated baritone that has become another).

headline: Gucci: Somewhere in North Africa
text: Merely as an exercise, I was trying to think this evening of a tweet-size summary of the Alberta Ferretti show, because I was pretty sure that if I wrote down peasant blouses, faded floral tiered skirts, long-sleeved linen dresses with white crochet trim, and floppy hats and rope sandals, you might get the wrong idea — that it was corny or something. But I guess I kept coming back to Nantucket in the summer of 1974 or ’75 (I had my driver’s license). I was driving into town early one morning and I stopped to pick up a young couple hitchhiking on the Milestone Road. They had just been married on the beach, and the bride was wearing a dress with white crochet.

headline: Irish Actors Get a Taste of Yiddish Theater

headline: Artists in Residence
text: Rome has nothing on Detroit. The industrial ruins in this American city are at least as spectacular, and largely unmatched in scale anywhere in the United States. They are also fertile ground for a growing number of artists like Scott Hocking, who find inspiration in the tatters. To make his large-format photographs, Hocking has built anomalous sculptures in two ghostly auto plants, Fisher Body and Packard, both designed by Detroit’s leading industrial architect, Albert Kahn.

headline: On Our Radar: Copenhagen’s Cargo Bikes

headline: Generation Mex
text: There’s a great line in Carlos Fuentes’s 1958 novel, “Where the Air Is Clear,” describing Mexico City as a “city new upon sculptured dust.” And if you sit in the library of Labor, a contemporary art gallery that opened in the noble old Roma district last fall, you’ll understand what Fuentes means. The building used to house a run-down pool hall and an outlaw band space where Pamela Echeverría, the gallery’s owner, remembers spending many a late night of her youth at the tocadas, or gigs, the decrepit floors a chronicle of “years and years condensed in a thousand thin layers of dry beer and cigarette ash.”

headline: Beauty Spots
text: IMPERIAL POLISH Jin Soon Choi, a celebrity manicurist and owner of the Jin Soon Hand and Foot Spa in New York, has collaborated with MAC Cosmetics for the second consecutive year to introduce a nail polish line for fall. Inspired by the colors of the Forbidden City in Beijing, she has created six shades, including Concubine (dark red), Jade Dragon (green with teal shimmer) and Earthly Harmony (taupe with copper shimmer); $13 at MAC locations.

headline: Sauvage Grace
text: Night falls, as it does in the mountains, all at once. Preceding it are ominous claps of thunder, but the rain doesn’t begin to fall until I drive through the stone gate and pull up in front of Château de Riell. Once a fortified mountain redoubt in Molitg-les-Bains, a spa town in the Roussillon area of France, the main building is a four-story hotel with views to the Castellane River. Michel Costa stands in the regal entryway, regards the angry sky briefly and then hurries out to greet me. Costa, dressed in white shirt sleeves, a yellow bow tie and a full-length black apron, is the bellman. He is also the valet and the barman. He inspects my luggage thoughtfully before declaring himself able to transport it to my room.

headline: After Quiet Dinner, Angels Get Indigestion

headline: How Clean Is Clean? Testing Detergents and Analyzing Product Claims

In this lesson, students analyze the information included on labels of popular dish detergents. They then test the efficacy of a variety of laundry detergents and determine which are most effective at removing various types of stains. In so doing, they learn how to design an experiment using common consumer goods and evaluate the marketing claims made on product labels.

headline: 36 Hours in Chicago
text: ALL cities have their ups and downs, but Chicago has been on the rise by playing to its strengths, adding parks, architectural crowd pleasers and public art. Much of this has happened on the watch of Mayor Richard M. Daley, who, after 21 years in office, announced this month that he would be stepping down. How will the city fare without him? Just fine, probably, thanks to the raft of improvements that has left Chicago fortified both by 19th- and 20th-century public spaces brimming with 21st-century attractions.

headline: In Sicily, a Step Back in Time
text: WE were standing in the piazza of the Italian town of Castelbuono waiting for the remains of Jesus’ grandmother. It was hot. It was dark. It was crowded. For the past 45 minutes, my boyfriend, Chris, and I had stood watching as processions of hooded monks carrying candles and banners painted with the images of saints come down the steps of the town’s 15th-century castle. Finally after a deafening burst of fireworks, the soup-tureen-shaped reliquary began to descend the stairs, carried by a group of local men in dark suits and priests dressed in gold.

headline: Recipe Redux: Saratoga Potatoes, 1904
text: In “America Cooks,” by the 1940s food writers Cora, Rose and Bob Brown, the trio declared: “A century ago, when Saratoga Springs was in its heyday as a fashionable resort, specialties from there swept the country, and one of them, Saratoga Chips, will endure as long as there are spuds left to slice.” They were partly right. The recipe has endured, all right, but Saratoga vanished from the name. We now call them potato chips, and they’ve reached that late-mannerist “seasoning” stage, which has produced such atrocities as sour-cream-and-onion-flavored chips and even “cool ranch.”

Mr. Ou has been based in Nairobi as a photographer for Reportage by Getty Images and is soon to begin working as a photo intern at The Times. His remarks have been edited and condensed.

headline: Did Firehouse Subs Pick the Right Plan?
text: In a case study we’ve just published, Kermit Pattison writes about Firehouse Subs, a fast-food sandwich chain based in Florida. When the recession hit, the chain’s sales took a dive. At first, Firehouse responded by rescinding the 2 percent marketing fee it had been collecting from its franchisees and encouraging them to spend that money on local marketing. When that failed, the chain took a very different approach: it asked its franchisees to increase the amount of money they were spending on marketing and it unleashed an $8 million advertising campaign — right into the teeth of the recession. It also chose Zimmerman Advertising to handle its corporate account.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Cookies and Orb
text: Are you being followed online? If you’ve ever used the Flash program from Adobe to watch videos — and odds are you have — you may have code on your computer that tracks your Web browsing, sending that information to companies that may sell it or use it for tailored advertising. On this week’s Tech Talk podcast from The New York Times, Bettina Edelstein talks to Tanzina Vega, a Times media reporter, about so-called Flash cookies, which have raised privacy concerns and prompted lawsuits from consumers against companies involved in this form of tracking.

headline: Google’s Chief Defends His Privacy Comment — or Joke
text: Eric E. Schmidt, Google‘s chief executive, has faced some pretty tough critics in the past, defending the companies stance on privacy issues and new features on the Web site, but on Tuesday, he went right into the lion’s den when he was a guest on “The Colbert Report” on Comedy Central.

headline: Festival Spotlights Emerging Playwrights
text: With readings of new plays, performances and panel discussions, the inaugural New Black Fest for emerging black playwrights is set for Oct. 9-17 in New York, the organizers announced. In addition to readings of six new plays at Bric Arts/Media/Bklyn (in Fort Greene, Brooklyn) on Oct. 16 and 17, festival highlights include a panel discussion on arts and activism featuring Suzan-Lori Parks (“Topdog/Underdog”) and Kia Corthron (“Breath, Boom”) at the Juilliard School on Oct. 10 and a cabaret-style evening of performances at Bric Arts on Oct. 14, which will present new work from Eisa Davis (“Passing Strange”) and Colman Domingo (“The Scottsboro Boys”). The seven playwrights whose works will be featured are Kwame Kewi-Armah (“Seize the Day”), Keli Garrett (“Space”), J. Nicole Brooks (“Black Diamond”), Radha Blank (“Nannyland”), Cori Thomas (“When January Feels Like Summer”), and Godfrey L. Simmons and Brandt Adams, authors of “Dispatches From (A)mended America.”

headline: Letter: War Games
text: I was fascinated by Chris Suellentrop’s article on war games. It touched on the business of entertainment, the horrors of war and the moral ambiguity of the very idea of virtual war through computer games. But for the record, while I take no offense at the generality that my cable-TV miniseries are “always about World War II,” only half of the series my company has produced for HBO are about that war.

headline: Migrant Workers Hear From Guggenheim
text: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation and its government-owned partner in Abu Dhabi, the Tourism Development and Investment Company, issued a joint statement on Wednesday committing to protect the rights of migrant workers building the Guggenheim’s vast new museum in Abu Dhabi. According to the statement, all companies involved in the construction must provide workers with electronic wage payment, overtime provisions, 30 days’ paid annual leave, a weekly day off and health insurance. They will also pay all recruitment fees for their employees. In a news release, Human Rights Watch, which previously raised concerns about how workers building the museum would be treated, called the museum’s action a positive step but said it fell short, noting that the Guggenheim had not explicitly required companies to reimburse workers for recruitment fees that they are found to have paid. Human Rights Watch said that the Guggenheim’s announcement also lacked provisions for independent monitoring of working conditions.

headline: More Shows Return as Hasselhoff Departs
text: The return of “NCIS” gave CBS a ratings victory on Tuesday night, drawing 18.9 million viewers for its eighth-season opener, according to Nielsen’s estimates. That was the night’s largest audience, outperforming ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” results episode (18.3 million) in which David Hasselhoff was sent packing. CBS finished strong with a two-hour season premiere for “NCIS: Los Angeles” (14.6 million) while ABC got a so-so start from its new crime drama “Detroit 1-8-7” (9.8 million). On Fox, the second season of “Glee” (12.3 million) got off to an impressive start, but ratings dropped off considerably for the network’s new comedies “Raising Hope” (7.5 million) and “Running Wilde” (5.9 million). NBC finished a distant fourth with the 10th edition of “The Biggest Loser” (7.2 million) followed by “Parenthood” (5.9 million).

headline: Letters: Living to Be a Parent
text: I feel compelled to correct a common misperception about evolution that appears in Lisa Belkin’s essay. We do not “as a species” act in particular ways to benefit the species. A primary premise of evolutionary theory is that individuals behave in ways that maximize individual reproductive success, relative to other individuals within a population. Hereditary behavioral traits of individuals that help them to increase the proportion of their offspring in future generations will thus be “selected for,” i.e., become more common; this process results in evolution.

headline: Ways to Remove a Broken Plug
text: Q. The headphone plug broke off in my laptop’s sound jack. Is there anyway to fix this so I can listen to my music?

headline: Letters: Engineering Terror
text: I am not going to comment on the statistics and methodology of Gambetta and Hertog’s analysis, but their description of the engineer’s mind-set is off base, behind the times and deserves clarification. Most leading universities in the U.S. are cultivating thinking skills completely opposite to what they state as a preference for “clear answers to ambiguous questions.” The goal of my own school — and I know that we are not alone in this — is to produce whole-brain thinkers. We want to produce engineers who are firmly grounded in analysis, logic and rational thinking but who also have intuitive and metaphorical thinking skills — the kind that open up new avenues of thought.

headline: Democrats Offer a Change in Campaign Finance Bill
