headline: Afghanistan as Obama and Others Game It
text: It’s no secret that there have been ferocious arguments within the Obama administration over the war in Afghanistan: both substantive policy debates, encouraged by the president during meetings as a means of fully exploring various military and diplomatic options; and nasty public exchanges and orchestrated leaks from the Pentagon and White House, exposing rifts over America’s mission and strategy there as well as heated disagreements over troop levels, timetables and tactical priorities.

headline: 10 Years After the Prom: Friends as Landmarks
text: “Mine is the generation of unfulfilled expectations,” is how Joyce Maynard described herself in a 1972 article in The New York Times Magazine that served as a manifesto of baby-boomer apathy and self-absorption. “My generation is special because of what we missed rather than what we got.”

headline: Vein Study Gets a Rare Challenge
text: Point. Counterpoint.

headline: Waaaaah Street
text: A great piece about Wall Street rage by Max Abelson. Basically, they feel underappreciated. How dare Obama talk about fat cats, or suggest that runaway finance had something to do with the mess we’re in?

headline: Paths Converging on a Rhythmic Base
text: Closing out his first set at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night, the drummer Antonio Sanchez finally opened the floodgates and let loose. He was playing “Challenge Within,” a tune based on a streamlined Afro-Latin groove, in 10/8 meter. His left foot tapped a cowbell in a modified clave pattern, steadily syncopated; the rest of his body seemed intent on framing rhythm as a blur. This was virtuoso stuff, almost drumming as sport, and while it served the purpose of the tune, it also justified its climactic placement in the show.

headline: Promising Results in Trial of Heart Valve Procedure
text: A new way of replacing a failing heart valve in patients too sick to undergo open-heart surgery proved successful in a large-scale clinical trial, according to a report in the New England Journal of Medicine.

headline: The Sony Alpha A55
text: A new camera from Sony adopts a new spin on a decades-old photographic idea.

headline: ‘Idol’ Announces Two New Judges
text: Two singers, Jennifer Lopez and Steven Tyler, will join Randy Jackson on the judges’ panel of “American Idol” next winter, effectively remaking the show, Fox confirmed on Wednesday.

headline: Sony Raises Camera Feats to New Level
text: When it made up the term “S.L.R.,” the technology terminology industry was not operating at its peak creative powers.

headline: Beginning the Season With a Show of Restraint
text: The programs of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center this season are meant to illustrate “the phenomenon of musical inheritance,” in the words of a subscription brochure, with Brahms pretty much at the center. Few composers inherited more or bequeathed more, and the juxtaposition of Brahms with Erno Dohnanyi in the first concert, on Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall, was especially suggestive.

headline: Chilling Account in Connecticut Triple-Murder Case
text: NEW HAVEN  A riveted courtroom heard a chilling account on Wednesday of a home invasion in Cheshire, Conn., that left a woman and her two daughters dead three years ago.

headline: New York Times Company Expects Quarterly Loss on Decrease in Revenue
text: The New York Times Company said Wednesday that it was anticipating a slight loss in the third quarter, in part because of a decrease in revenue from print advertising and rising costs.

headline: Blogging the Conflict on Jerusalem’s Streets
text: Bloggers are well-known for trying to understand the world from behind their keyboards, in the comfort of their own homes, but a few took to the streets on Wednesday to document a struggle between Jewish settlers and Palestinian residents in one East Jerusalem neighborhood.

headline: The Austerity Zone: Isabel Hahn
text: Austerity measures are the new reality for Europeans in the post-recession economy. Across the continent the pain of higher taxes, inflation and wage cuts are hitting workers now.

headline: When a God Loves a Nymph, and Other French Court Intrigues
text: For the Baroque obsessed, the pairing of Concert Royal and the New York Baroque Dance Company makes a felicitous match. The groups have joined forces to create (or recreate) selections of French Baroque opera-ballet, including their most recent effort, Jean Philippe Rameau’s one-act “Zéphyre.” The rarely performed jewel  its exact year of creation is not known  served as the main attraction on Tuesday night at Symphony Space.

headline: A Sun Spot in Midtown to Celebrate the Autumnal Equinox
text: You don’t need to tell us what you’re going to be doing on Wednesday night at 11:09. Party time, right? After that brutal summer, who wouldn’t be rejoicing at the arrival of the autumnal equinox?

headline: The Austerity Zone:  Margit Köpppen
text: Austerity measures are the new reality for Europeans in the post-recession economy. Across the continent the pain of higher taxes, inflation and wage cuts are hitting workers now.

headline: Judge Shouts at Witness in Synagogue Bomb Case
text: A federal judge overseeing a high-profile terrorism trial put decorum aside on Wednesday, shouting at the government informer who is the key witness in the case: “I’m tired of your playing games with the questions.”

headline: A Pianist’s ‘Character Pieces’ in 12 Minor Keys
text: The Classical composer-pianist, a common breed in the 18th and 19th centuries, seems perilously close to extinction in the 21st. But the exemplary Canadian pianist Marc-André Hamelin is doing his part to resuscitate this endangered species.

headline: Instruments and Voice, Improvising on Melodies
text: Sara Serpa, a young Portuguese jazz singer who’s been living in New York for the last few years, is cool all over, from concept to execution. She has a halting, careful, nearly affectless soprano that prowls a narrow pitch range in mostly wordless lines, perching naturally around the E above a piano’s middle C, then surprises you when it gradually swells in volume or suddenly jumps up an octave, without breaking stride.

headline: After the Volcanic Cloud, a Bright Spot in Iceland
text: The 10 million people stranded by ash from the Eyjafjallajokull this spring may still be cursing the volcano’s name, if they can pronounce it. But in Iceland, Eyjafjallajokull is being hailed as the volcano that is raising tourism to new heights.

headline: The Case Against Structural Unemployment
text: 11:34 a.m. | Updated Menzie Chinn has a thoughtful discussion about the interactions between cyclical and structural unemployment on the Econbrowser blog.

headline: Insurers Scramble to Comply With New Rules
text: The first big wave of new rules under the federal health care law goes into effect on Thursday, leaving many insurers scrambling to get ahead of the changes.

headline: Mammograms’ Value in Cancer Fight at Issue
text: A new study suggests that increased awareness and improved treatments rather than mammograms are the main force in reducing the breast cancer death rate.

headline: Scorecard | Jonathan Saunders Wins!
text: Got your clicker fingers ready? The champion in London fashion week’s final battle of the bands is A) a glammed-to-the-max rocker or B) a lo-fi rockabilly. We could say that Christopher Bailey’s 31 (click-to-buy during the iPad live stream!) iterations of the studded, metallic python “biker trench” for the 154-year-old British heritage house was an if-Burberryed-out-is-a-WAG-ideal, I’ll-show-them-mindless-acquisition-has-a-style moment — but that’s too meta, even for Scorecard.

headline: Senate Forecast: Republican Takeover Chances Improved, but Democrats Are Building Pacific Firewall
text: Polls show that the Republican nominee has gained ground in a key Senate race, Wisconsin — and Republicans have put another Senate race, in West Virginia, squarely into play. But strong polling for Democrats in two Pacific Coast states, California and Washington, have somewhat offset these gains, and Republicans are only modestly more likely to take control of the Senate than they were a week ago.

headline: Making a Big Contribution at the Buffett Cup
text: The Buffett Cup, which was held this month in Cardiff, Wales, was fashioned after golf’s Ryder Cup. This made it easy to tally how many points each player contributed toward her or his team’s total. The most successful was Bob Hamman, who scored 11.75 points for the victorious American team. He was 1.25 ahead of his partner in the pair and team segments, Zia Mahmood.

headline: Man Charged in Cabby Attack Ranted to Police, Documents Show
text: A 21-year-old film student accused of trying to kill a Muslim cabdriver called himself a “patriot” while in police custody, and accused an officer of allowing “them to blow up buildings in this country.”

headline: Arranging the Art in Salon Style
text: A designer transformed the wall of a stairwell in a Jersey City apartment into a display space for a photography collection.

headline: The Austerity Zone: Fernando Acuña
text: Austerity measures are the new reality for Europeans in the post-recession economy. Across the continent the pain of higher taxes, inflation and wage cuts are hitting workers now.

headline: Fox Wants ‘Idol’ to Return to Its Roots
text: During an announcement about two new judges for “American Idol” Wednesday, Fox’s message was clear: this is return-to-your-roots time.

headline: The Beauty Cultist
text: In December of 1874, when Serge ­Diaghilev was 2 years old, he stood in the drawing room of his home in St. Petersburg, belly thrust out, and took in the spectacle of the family Christmas tree. He “gravely inspected the tree with its glittering lights,” his stepmother recalled in her memoirs, “glanced at the toys placed around it and said quietly, ‘Not bad. . . .’ ”

headline: Scoring Is by Points, but Top 5 Can Win by Knockout
text: The PGA Tour’s FedEx Cup points system has often been criticized  it has been changed twice and may be changed again after this season  for being quirky and too complicated.

headline: Feingold Ad: 18 Years Later, the Same Guy
text: How do you show voters that Washington hasn’t changed you? Senator Russ Feingold hopes it’s by casting himself as the same guy Wisconsin sent to the Capitol 18 years ago.

headline: The Designer Alexa Hampton
text: Alexa Hampton has one of the most recognizable surnames in interior design. And she embraced it at a young age, working with her father, Mark Hampton, then assuming the role of president of his company when he died in 1998. Since then, she has quietly built her own business and design portfolio, creating furniture, fabric, lighting and carpet collections.

headline: East-West Décor
text: JOSIE NATORI, the designer, loves to combine Eastern and Western styles, and one reason for that tendency is her childhood in the Philippines. “The Philippines is a mongrel culture because there are so many influences: Chinese, Spanish, Malaysian,” she said. “It is very unique.”

headline: Glassware Etched With City Scenes
text: By the Glass, a Chicago company, grew out of a dinner conversation between John Ehrlich, the deputy corporation counsel for the City of Chicago, and Ulf Henricsson, who practices naprapathy, a type of alternative medicine. “We were talking about all the things that we like — design, architecture and drinking,” Mr. Ehrlich said. “It all coalesced into doing something with glass.”

headline: The Flyer Chair Mimics the Feeling of Takeoff
text: The Flyer chair, designed by Dominique Houriet, a San Diego architect, has square lines, but the backward-canted seat offers the sensation of flight — specifically, takeoff.

headline: A Nonprofit Group Remakes Teachers’ Lounges
text: Remaking five teachers’ lounges in five public schools in five states — and in less than three months, with a total budget of only $12,500 — was a big challenge. But Diana Burroughs, executive director of TeachersCount, a nonprofit group, agreed to take it on when her organization was given a grant by the Staples Foundation last spring. She persuaded Brian Patrick Flynn, an Atlanta designer with a blog called Décor Demon, to volunteer his services. His rationale: “It was a good cause, and I like a challenge.”

headline: Testing a $50,000 Mattress
text: Savoir Beds, a 105-year-old luxury British company, opened its first store in New York last weekend. A cynic might wonder if the No. 1, the $50,000 mattress they were touting, was a marketing ploy, a question we put to Roger Ericson, the company’s London-based creative director.

headline: Lots of Pictures, Little Space
text: WHEN Rachel Hudgins decided to turn a longtime hobby of photographing friends’ children into a career, she left Los Angeles and her job in the film industry and moved East, to be closer to the photography world in New York City.

headline: Choosing the Right Seed
text: STEVE RACKLIFFE, who teaches turf-grass science at the University of Connecticut, said the first step to a lush lawn is proper seed selection. Evaluate how much sun the lawn gets, whether the area seems prone to particular diseases or insects, and the amount of wear the lawn will get, and generally be realistic about your expectations for the lawn, given those conditions.

headline: For a Nice Lawn in Spring, Start Now
text: EARLY fall is the time to assess the health of your lawn and take steps to help it grow well next spring. This year that is especially true, because all but the most pampered lawns took a beating during the long summer heat.

headline: A Thing for Beauty
text: At home in Northern California with Leonard Koren, a maker of deceptively modest books about deceptively modest subjects.

headline: An Idiosyncratic Designer, a Serene New Home
text: POINT REYES, Calif.

headline: The Austerity Zone: Mathilde Donovan
text: Austerity measures are the new reality for Europeans in the post-recession economy. Across the continent the pain of higher taxes, inflation and wage cuts are hitting workers now.

headline: The Austerity Zone: Santi Ortiz
text: Austerity measures are the new reality for Europeans in the post-recession economy. Across the continent the pain of higher taxes, inflation and wage cuts are hitting workers now.

headline: Steps for Reseeding
text: Start now for next spring’s garden.

headline: Facebook Founder to Donate $100 Million to Help Remake Newark’s Schools
text: Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive and a founder of Facebook, has agreed to donate $100 million to improve the long-troubled public schools in Newark, and Gov. Chris Christie will cede some control of the state-run system to Mayor Cory A. Booker in conjunction with the huge gift, officials said Wednesday.

headline: In Singapore, Embracing the Humidity
text: Sentosa Island, Singapore

headline: The Knicks’ Brain Trust Shows Calm Confidence
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Mike D’Antoni and Donnie Walsh spoke for 43 minutes on Wednesday, and spent 41 of them talking about players who are actually on the Knicks’ roster. This was clearly a welcome departure.

headline: G.O.P. Cites Tax Cuts and Health Care as Main Focus
text: WASHINGTON  House Republicans on Thursday will issue a legislative blueprint called “A Pledge to America” that they hope will catapult them to a majority in the November elections. Its goals include a permanent extension of all the Bush-era tax cuts, repeal of the newly enacted health care law, a cap on discretionary federal spending and an end to government control of the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

headline: Show’s Title, in Symbols, Defies DVRs
text: CBS knew that when it ordered a sitcom with a vulgar word in the title, it would get attention. The network also knew there would be some hand-wringing about the coarseness of popular culture.

headline: China’s Disputes in Asia Buttress Influence of U.S.
text: BEIJING  For the last several years, one big theme has dominated talk of the future of Asia: As China rises, its neighbors are being inevitably drawn into its orbit, currying favor with the region’s new hegemonic power.

headline: Joaquin Phoenix, Clean-Shaven, Returns to Letterman
text: Joaquin Phoenix returned to the scene of his most famous television appearance — and acting performance — Wednesday night when he sat down for an interview with David Letterman.

headline: States Ask for Phase-In on Insurance Change
text: WASHINGTON  State insurance regulators told the White House on Wednesday that health insurance markets in some states would be disrupted unless President Obama gave insurers a temporary dispensation from one major provision of the new health care law.

headline: The Give and Take of a Fall Campaign
text: To the Editor:

headline: Debate on Tax Cuts May Be Delayed
text: Floor debate over the highly contentious issue of what to do about the expiring Bush-era tax cuts may be delayed until after the November elections, senior Democratic aides said on Wednesday.

headline: Public TV Project Aims to Make Baby Boomers Its Own
text: THE commercial television networks, eager to portray their shows as demographically desirable to youth-craving advertisers, have always had a love-hate relationship with aging baby boomers.

headline: Els Cruises Into Hall of Fame
text: Was there ever any doubt that the golfer known as the Big Easy would glide into the World Golf Hall of Fame? Hardly. But even Ernie Els was a bit surprised when he received 66 percent of the vote and admission to the Hall on the first ballot.

headline: Is Jonathan Franzen’s View of America Too Bleak?
text: To the Editor:

headline: His Bedside Manner, Your Home
text: Hung Hsin, known as Joe, 29, who jokes that he was probably desensitized to the sight of blood by watching horror movies as a teenager, has been a nurse since 2006 with the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. It was his mother, Cindy Hsin, also a visiting nurse, who convinced him that he had inherited healing genes. Mr. Hsin lives in Flushing, Queens, is working on a bachelor’s degree in nursing at Hunter College and is engaged to be married on Oct. 24 to — what else? — a nursing student, Michelle Hwang.

headline: Russia Ends Talk of Missile Sale to Iran
text: MOSCOW  Russia interprets the latest round of United Nations sanctions against Iran as prohibiting all exports of major weapons systems to that country, President Dmitri A. Medvedev announced Wednesday, ending some Russian equivocation on whether an advanced air defense system would fall under the ban.

headline: False Confessions: The View From the Bar Association
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Field, $10 Million at Stake. For a Few, Player of the Year. For One, No. 1.
text: ATLANTA  In years past, this week was all about the money.

text: To the Editor:

text: Austerity measures are the new reality for Europeans in the post-recession economy. Across the continent the pain of higher taxes, inflation and wage cuts are hitting workers now.

headline: After Crash Course, Jeter Improves at the Plate
text: Ask Derek Jeter why his production has improved over the last 10 days, and he plays coy.

headline: The Austerity Zone
text: Austerity measures are the new reality for Europeans in the post-recession economy. Across the continent the pain of higher taxes, inflation and wage cuts are hitting workers now.

text: Austerity measures are the new reality for Europeans in the post-recession economy. Across the continent the pain of higher taxes, inflation and wage cuts are hitting workers now.

text: Austerity measures are the new reality for Europeans in the post-recession economy. Across the continent the pain of higher taxes, inflation and wage cuts are hitting workers now.

headline: At Warner, Shuffle at Top Is Postponed
text: LOS ANGELES  Barry M. Meyer will remain chairman of Warner Brothers after all.

headline: Dozens of Cabbies Charged in Fraud Scheme
text: Dozens of taxi drivers were arrested and charged in Manhattan on Wednesday with overcharging riders in what is believed to be the largest takedown of cabbies in New York, the authorities said.

headline: Heavy Nascar Penalties Damage Bowyer’s Chances for the Title
text: Nascar severely punished Clint Bowyer and his team Wednesday for what it said were rules violations at the Sprint Cup race he won Sunday in Loudon, N.H., levying heavy fines and taking away so many points that it all but wrecked Bowyer’s pursuit of a championship.

headline: Seeking Bank Secrecy in Asia
text: For centuries, Switzerland has been the sanctuary of choice for wealthy people seeking to hide their fortunes and evade taxes. Now, amid a growing crackdown on Swiss private banking, the rich are flocking to Singapore and Hong Kong, which still offer some of the world’s most secret accounts.

headline: Bigger Problem for Giants: Tentative Steps by Jacobs
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Playing Ball in October Instead of Playing Golf
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: Don’t Ask, Don’t Debate
text: The legislative process is almost never uplifting. But if you watch the United States Senate in action these days, you come away convinced that the nation has jumped the shark.

headline: A Coach’s Rebuke, and a Player’s Shrug
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Coach Rex Ryan looked tired, sounded beaten, appeared uncharacteristically worn thin. Stubble covered his face. His voice, filled with frustration, tinged with anger, carried an edge.

headline: Nestlé Plans a Research Center to Focus on Indian Foods
text: NEW DELHI  Nestlé, the maker of Kit Kat bars and Maggi noodles, is focusing on masala.

headline: Curse of the Scorned Class
text: MILAN, Italy — Beware, they told us in the train stations of northern Italy, of the Gypsy baby trick — an old ruse by Europe’s most reviled underclass. A woman will suddenly ask you to hold her child, and then just as you fumble to respond another Gypsy will grab your wallet.

headline: Phinney Leaving RadioShack for BMC
text: Taylor Phinney, the newly minted United States time trial champion, announced on Wednesday that he would not renew his contract with Lance Armstrong’s RadioShack team, opting to join the BMC Racing team instead.

headline: Tibetan Ex-Prisoner Evokes His Homeland’s Struggle in a Movie
text: This has been a busy week for some Tibetans in New York, who have seized on the Chinese prime minister’s visit to the United Nations to hold angry street demonstrations against that nation’s rule in their homeland.

headline: 24, and Back in the Fold
text: Once Lacey E. McLear turned 23 and aged out of her parents’ health insurance, she changed her route home from work to circumvent dangerous intersections. When she came down with the flu, she continued to wait tables (“I know, it’s gross,” she conceded) because she could not afford a doctor and could not skip work without a note. At Christmas, she strung lights only halfway up the tree, to avoid climbing a ladder.

headline: Chronically Ill, and Covered
text: Joe and Mary Thompson had agreed to adopt Emily before her birth in 1999, and it never occurred to them to back out when she was born with spina bifida. But that same year, their residential remodeling business in Overland Park, Kan., went under, prompting job changes that left the family searching for health coverage with a child who was uninsurable.

headline: Cap Lifts, and So Do Spirits
text: As a healthy couple in their mid-20s, Bill and Victoria Strong’s last concern when shopping for health insurance was a cap on lifetime benefits. Then Gwendolyn was born, and six months later was found to have spinal muscular atrophy Type I, a degenerative condition that typically kills its victims before age 2.

headline: For Many, Health Care Relief Begins Today
text: Sometimes lost in the partisan clamor about the new health care law is the profound relief it is expected to bring to hundreds of thousands of Americans who have been stricken first by disease and then by a Darwinian insurance system.

headline: New Charges for Rodriguez Over Flurry of Text Messages
text: Francisco Rodriguez, the Mets’ embattled closer, was back in Queens Criminal Court on Wednesday, this time to face charges that he sent dozens of text messages to his estranged girlfriend in violation of an order of protection.

headline: Gates and Buffett Remain Atop the Forbes 400
text: Once again, Bill Gates is ranked the richest person in the United States, with $9 billion more than Warren E. Buffett. Mr. Gates, the co-founder of Microsoft, topped the annual Forbes 400 list of the richest Americans with $54 billion, an increase of $4 billion from last year.

headline: Chinese Leader Fields Executives’ Questions
text: When Bill Gates confronts the prime minister of China on the need to honor software copyrights, it helps to have a referee  say, a Henry Kissinger  to moderate the debate.

headline: Confrontation in Jerusalem
text: Palestinians clashed with Israeli security forces in and around the Old City of Jerusalem after an Israeli guard fatally shot a Palestinian resident.

headline: The Mets Have Decided Not to Decide Just Yet
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  The Mets are moving closer to making a decision about the structure of their front office and coaching staff for next season, but one potential candidate came off the market Wednesday when Kevin Towers was named general manager of the Arizona Diamondbacks.

headline: Buyers Send iPhones on a Long Relay to China
text: They show up in the early-morning hours: Chinese men and women, waiting silently and somewhat nervously outside of Apple stores in New York. On some days the lines they form can be a block long.

headline: On the Atlantic City Boardwalk, Other Stories Remain to Be Told
text: ATLANTIC CITY

headline: At Labor Meeting, N.B.A. and Union Agree — to Meet Again
text: With N.B.A. teams opening training camp in the next few days, the league and the players’ union met Wednesday to discuss the labor agreement and its ticking expiration date.

headline: As Spain Struggles, Energy Plan Proves Difficult to Agree On
text: MADRID  On one side, angry coal miners are striking to force the government to save their jobs from a torrent of inexpensive imports. On another, the solar power industry, which was once booming, complains that it is being crippled by the mere prospect of an end to generous state subsidies.

headline: Brooklyn Democrat Is Said to Be Investigated
text: Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, a long-serving Brooklyn Democratic leader who is widely viewed as the borough’s patronage king, is at the center of two separate federal investigations, according to several people briefed on the matter. A third inquiry, by the city’s Department of Investigation, those people said, is focused on a network of nonprofit groups Mr. Lopez controls.

headline: Many States in Mexico Crack Down on Abortion
text: GUANAJUATO, Mexico — The woman came into the hospital, bleeding, scared and barely out of her teens. But before anyone would treat her, the authorities had to be called.

headline: Thursday: Have We Met?
text: David J. Kahn gives us a touch of culture today with another of his patented, tribute puzzles. As usual, it has a lot of interlocking material.

headline: A Salt-of-the-Earth Romance Amid Shadows of the Apocalypse
text: Don’t ask me why two of the three characters in Gregory S. Moss’s play “Orange, Hat & Grace” are called Orange and Hat. I haven’t a clue, and I suspect they don’t either. More to the point, I cannot fathom why this dreary hillbilly romance is onstage at Soho Rep, one of the city’s more prestigious incubators of avant-garde theater.

headline: No Doubt, Not a Typical Singing Nun
text: We all have our own ideas of heaven. For some, it’s white clouds and harps; for others, an eternal shore of silence. But perhaps you’re one of those souls (and I know you’re out there) who imagine an endless swirl of beautifully bad old movies — a place where the acting is always overripe, the plots as thick as oatmeal and the taste level close to the gutter. If this describes you, paradise awaits you, friend, just south of Houston Street.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 22
text: A view of the day in sports, from handball to baseball, with plenty of soccer in between.

headline: For Economic Team, a Chance to Retool
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama and his top aides have already begun to discuss how a successor for Lawrence H. Summers, the chief economic gatekeeper inside the White House, can help reshape the administration’s economic team without signaling major changes in policy, either to markets or voters.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Fellow Republicans Keep Christie in Demand
text: LOS ANGELES  Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey sat center stage in a Hollywood hotel ballroom on Wednesday afternoon, next to Meg Whitman, who is running for governor of California, and told a parable of a schoolyard bully as he talked about “standing up to teachers’ unions” in New Jersey.

headline: Playoffs Come Into Focus for Sweeney
text: PHILADELPHIA – Ask Raul Ibanez about Mike Sweeney, and this is the first thing he says: “He’s one of the best human beings I’ve ever had the privilege of knowing.”

headline: An Audit Finds a City Spent Uncontrollably
text: LOS ANGELES — The state controller, John Chiang, released the first of three audits of the City of Bell on Wednesday after several state and local investigations and the indictment of eight current or former city officials on dozens of felony counts.

headline: Feeling Slighted by France, and Respected by U.S.
text: BONDY, France — The residents of this poor, multiracial Paris suburb say they have been abandoned. For 30 years, they say, the French authorities have written off Bondy and neighborhoods like it, treating their inhabitants as terminal delinquents and ignoring their potential.

headline: Condo Ruling May Let Many Cancel Deals
text: A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that the Related Companies, the sponsor of a luxury condominium building on the Upper East Side, must return a $510,000 buyer’s deposit, a decision that lawyers said could chill development in New York and across the country.

headline: With Summers, Harvard Lets Bygones Be Bygones
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  He will not be moving back to Elmwood, the yellow mansion where he lived as president of Harvard, but Lawrence H. Summers will still be a big shot  presumably a less contentious one  when he returns to campus next year.

headline: Amid Tension, China Blocks Vital Exports to Japan
text: HONG KONG — Sharply raising the stakes in a dispute over Japan’s detention of a Chinese fishing trawler captain, the Chinese government has blocked exports to Japan of a crucial category of minerals used in products like hybrid cars, wind turbines and guided missiles.

headline: To Connect, Obama Heads Into Backyard
text: FALLS CHURCH, Va.  President Obama is trying to reconnect with the American people, and he is using that most American of settings, the backyard, to do it.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday and Friday, because of Sukkot. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Yale Hockey Player Has Stem-Cell Transplant
text: Mandi Schwartz, the Yale hockey player whose battle with leukemia has drawn widespread attention, underwent a stem-cell transplant on Wednesday that her doctors hope will save her life.

headline: Cuomo’s Image as Unstoppable Suffers a Blow
text: Andrew M. Cuomo’s painstakingly constructed veneer of political invincibility began to crack on Wednesday, as he and his advisers struggled with how to handle his combative opponent in the race for New York governor, Carl P. Paladino, whom a new poll showed with unexpected strength.

headline: The Austerity Zone: Life in the New Europe
text: Europe’s debt crisis and an unresponsive economy have changed future prospects for people across Europe.

headline: A Claim of Pro-Islam Bias in Textbooks
Missed Goals
text: Ten years ago, leaders of rich and poor countries pledged to build a better world by 2015. Among their vital goals: halving extreme poverty and hunger from 1990 levels, reducing by two-thirds the child-mortality rate and slashing maternal mortality by three-quarters and achieving universal primary education.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,276 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: An Extreme Judicial Blockade
text: The Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to meet on Thursday with an agenda that includes consideration of nominees for federal district and circuit court judgeships who have already been approved by the committee once, or even twice.

headline: U.S. Lauds Russia on Barring Arms for Iran
text: UNITED NATIONS  The White House praised Russia’s president, Dmitri A. Medvedev, on Wednesday for publicly barring the shipment of an advanced antimissile system to Iran, even as American diplomats here discussed a plan to reopen negotiations with Tehran over its nuclear program.

headline: The Hague: Plea in Bribery Case
text: A former member of a Serbian defense team pleaded not guilty on Wednesday to charges that she bribed three potential witnesses to give false information to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague. Jelena Rasic was the defense case manager during the trial of Milan Lukic, a Bosnian Serb convicted of mass murder in Visegrad. One of the three men told the court that Ms. Rasic had paid him and two others 1,000 euros, or $1,300 each, for signing a false declaration intended to clear Mr. Lukic. Ms. Rasic was recently arrested by the Serbian police and sent to the tribunal. No date was set for her trial.

headline: Freeing Up More Airwaves
text: It took two years to overcome the opposition of television broadcasters, Broadway impresarios and Dolly Parton, but the Federal Communications Commission is finally releasing long-awaited telecommunications spectrum for public use. This should vastly increase the reach of wireless broadband around the country, extending Americans’ access to the Internet.

headline: Tomorrow’s School Lunches
text: Effective lawmakers know when it makes sense to stand and fight for principle and when the time comes to accept a decent compromise. The House now faces that choice on legislation to improve school nutrition.

headline: Florida Court Calls Ban on Gay Adoptions Unlawful
text: A 30-year-old Florida law that prohibits adoption by gay men and lesbians is unconstitutional, a state appeals court ruled on Wednesday, and the state’s governor said the law would not be enforced pending a decision on whether to appeal.

headline: Antonina Pirozhkova, Engineer and Widow of Isaac Babel, Dies at 101
text: Antonina Pirozhkova, who as the widow of the renowned short-story writer Isaac Babel campaigned for more than half a century to keep his literary legacy alive after his execution by Stalin’s N.K.V.D., and who wrote a memoir about the last seven years of his life, died on Sept. 12 at her home in Sarasota, Fla. She was 101.

headline: Jobs and Bonuses Worry Wall Street
text: Wall Street’s bankers and traders are getting nervous again. This time, it is not fear of regulatory backlash that has them concerned, but the more traditional worries about bonuses and layoffs.

headline: Boast, Build and Sell
text: United Nations

headline: U.S., Caught Off Guard by New Tensions With China, Cultivates Back-Channel Ties
text: WASHINGTON  Few foreign policy problems took the Obama administration more by surprise this year than the rapid escalation of tensions with China: The countries’ common approach to North Korea disintegrated, Beijing has balked at energy sanctions against Iran, the always-wary conversation between the American and Chinese militaries was cut off.

headline: New Jersey: Copper Penny From ’43 Fetches a Mint
text: A penny minted from the wrong metal in World War II has been sold for $1.7 million, said Laura Sperber of Legend Numismatics in Lincroft, who arranged the sale. Virtually all United States cents minted in 1943 were struck in steel rather than copper alloy, and are worth only a few cents each today, but a few coins were mistakenly made from bronze blanks left over in mint machinery. The coin was unknown to the collectors until 1979. Proceeds will go to charity.

headline: Armstrong Associate Goes Before Grand Jury
text: One of Lance Armstrong’s close associates testified Wednesday before a federal grand jury looking into possible crimes relating to doping in cycling, according to people briefed on the investigation.

headline: Georgia: Another Allegation Against Church Leader
text: A third man said Wednesday that he had been molested by Bishop Eddie L. Long, the prominent pastor of a Baptist megachurch in suburban Atlanta. A lawsuit filed by Jamal Parris, 23, a former member of the church’s congregation, alleges that Bishop Long gave him gifts in exchange for sexual acts while Mr. Parris was a teenager. Bishop Long is a nationally known author, the pastor at New Birth Missionary Baptist Church in Lithonia, Ga., and an outspoken critic of homosexuality. On Tuesday, two men who also claim that Bishop Long sexually abused them when they were teenage members of his 25,000-person congregation filed suits against him.

headline: Detroit vs. Newport Beach
text: Coldwell Banker, the real estate brokerage firm, is out with an unscientific survey of prices in the nation’s real estate markets.

headline: Detroit vs. Newport Beach
text: Coldwell Banker, the real estate brokerage firm, is out with an unscientific survey of prices in the nation’s real estate markets.

headline: Gourmet Is Reincarnated, This Time as an iPad App
text: Tonight, with the introduction of an iPad app, Condé Nast continues its attempt to prove that there is life after print for Gourmet.

headline: Won't You Be My Neighbor?
text: For Op-Ed's 40th anniversary, the author and professor Peter Lovenheim recounted the story of his Op-Ed about reaching out to his neighbors.

headline: Next Installment of the ’39 Clues’ Children’s Series Due in April
text: The second installment of the popular multimedia children’s book series “The 39 Clues” is scheduled for release in April, the publisher said. Scholastic, the American publisher of the Harry Potter series, introduced “The 39 Clues” in 2008 as a 10-book mystery series for 8-to-12-year-olds. The second part of the series will be called “The 39 Clues: Cahills vs. Vespers” and, like the first part, will include an online game and collector’s cards. According to Scholastic, there are more than 8.5 million copies of the books in print. David Baldacci, the best-selling author, will write the final book in the “39 Clues” series, set to be published in March 2013.

headline: Help Rename High-Fructose Corn Syrup
text: The companies that make high-fructose corn syrup want to pick a new name for the sweetener, so we’re asking Well readers to help.

text: The second installment of the popular multimedia children’s book series “The 39 Clues” is scheduled for release in April, the publisher said. Scholastic, the American publisher of the Harry Potter series, introduced “The 39 Clues” in 2008 as a 10-book mystery series for 8-to-12-year-olds. The second part of the series will be “The 39 Clues: Cahills vs. Vespers,” and like the first part will include an online game and collectors’ cards. According to Scholastic, more than 8.5 million copies of the books are in print. David Baldacci, the best-selling author, will write the final book in the “39 Clues” series, set to be published in March 2013.

text: 12:44 p.m. | Updated  They are obviously expecting to have something to celebrate.

headline: After Delay, Long Night for Yankee Bullpen
text: The fans who hung around Yankee Stadium through a 131-minute rain delay Wednesday night were treated to less than scintillating baseball when play resumed. They witnessed the much-anticipated debut of Royce Ring, who gave way to Dustin Moseley, who was replaced by Chad Gaudin, who gave up back-to-back homers in the seventh that buried the Yankees in their 7-2 loss to the Tampa Bay Rays. Jonathan Albaladejo followed Gaudin.

headline: Bloggingheads: Was Summers a Mistake?
text: Glenn Loury, left, of Brown University and James Pinkerton of Fox News discuss President Obama's economic policies.

headline: News Quiz | September 23, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: At Philharmonic, Jazz Blended Unevenly
text: What better way to open an orchestra’s new season than with a new piece? That was Alan Gilbert’s reasoning last September, when he inaugurated his tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic with the premiere of “EXPO,” an exciting work by Magnus Lindberg, the Philharmonic’s composer in residence.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 23, 2010
text: Test your vocabulary skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times article “A Hotel Where Some Guests Have Been Dead for Years.”

headline: Seeking Bank Secrecy in Asia
text: For centuries, Switzerland has been the sanctuary of choice for wealthy people seeking to hide their fortunes and evade taxes. Now, amid a growing crackdown on Swiss private banking, the rich are flocking to Singapore and Hong Kong, which still offer some of the world’s most secret accounts, Lynnley Browning writes in The New York Times.

headline: Rumors Swirl of a Daimler-Fiat Truck Deal
text: Daimler, the German car and truck maker, said Wednesday that it was not in talks to acquire the non-car business of Fiat of Italy, responding to a report in an Italian newspaper. But analysts speculated that Daimler, based in Stuttgart, might be interested in a partnership with the Italian conglomerate’s Iveco truck division.

headline: Amid Tension, China Blocks Crucial Exports to Japan
text: Sharply raising the stakes in a dispute over Japan’s detention of a Chinese fishing trawler captain, the Chinese government has blocked exports to Japan of a crucial category of minerals used in products like hybrid cars, wind turbines and guided missiles.

headline: Watchdog to Review G.M.’s AmeriCredit Deal
text: A government bailout watchdog will review the General Motors $3.5 billion all-cash purchase of the auto finance company AmeriCredit, a deal financed with federal bailout money, Reuters reports.

headline: Timing of Goldman Case ‘Suspicious,’ Watchdog Says
text: The timing of the Securities and Exchange Commission’s case against Goldman Sachs is “suspicious,” a federal watchdog said, suggesting that the S.E.C. used it to divert attention from a report that sharply criticized its probe into R. Allen Stanford.

headline: Australian Buyout Sector on Brink of Closures
text: Up to a quarter of private equity funds in Australia’s $21 billion buyout industry could close, as investors lose patience with weak returns at underperforming firms, buyout executives say.

headline: Goolsbee Says ‘Go-Go Days’ Over for Wall St.
text: President Barack Obama’s chief economist said Wall Street has largely recovered from the 2008 crisis and will be strengthened by the White House-backed regulatory overhaul that Congress passed this year.

headline: What Do You Want Your Obituary to Say?
text: Do you ever read Times obituaries or look through the annual “Lives They Lived” issue of The Times Magazine? Recently, there have been obituaries about a female spy in World War II, the man whose name inspired the rock band Lynyrd Skynyrd and the inventor of the Club antitheft device. If The Times were to write your obituary someday, what would you want it to say?

headline: Questions on Concussions
text: For WHOM is Washington State’s law on concussions named?

headline: Demand Is Strong at Auction for Portuguese Debt
text: Portugal raised 750 million euros in a debt auction on Wednesday that drew strong investor interest, but its borrowing cost was the highest since it adopted the euro, underlining market worries about the country’s financial health, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Is Facebook Positioning Itself to Take on PayPal?
text: For all its success, Google is often criticized for being a one-trick pony. After 12 years, the Internet search company is still struggling to find a significant new revenue source to supplement its lucrative text advertising business.

headline: Zuckerberg Gives $100 Million for Newark Schools
text: Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive and a founder of Facebook, has agreed to donate $100 million to improve the long-troubled public schools in Newark, and Gov. Chris Christie will cede some control of the state-run system to Mayor Cory A. Booker in conjunction with the huge gift, The New York Times’s Richard Perez-Pena reports.

headline: Investors Unnerved by Slides in Tech and Financials
text: A weaker earnings outlook for technology and financial companies dragged down stock indexes on Wednesday, overshadowing speculation that the Federal Reserve would take steps to bolster the economy, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Spending Too Carefully on Renewable Energy?
text: From Matthew L. Wald at Green:

headline: Swaps Need to Be Like Stock Market, Schapiro Says
text: The top securities regulator says the new market for swaps trading would benefit from the “competition, access, liquidity and transparency” already established in the cash equities market, Reuters reports.

headline: Yunnan Province in Three Dimensions
text: These aren’t your childhood pop-up books.

headline: Structured Notes Boom, but Some Investors Are Perplexed
text: Leona Miller, an 84-year-old retired beautician, says she was seeking safe and steady income from bonds two years ago when her Wachovia broker recommended she buy securities paying 9 percent interest, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: A Second, Smaller Strike Over Pensions in France
text: PARIS  French workers sought Thursday to test President Nicolas Sarkozy’s resolve on overhauling the pension system, staging a major strike that snarled transportation and closed schools and public offices for the second time this month.

headline: A Powerful Panasonic, With Optional 3-D
text: Panasonic has put some impressive horsepower under the hood of its new Lumix DMC-GH2 Micro Four Thirds camera. And it will need that processing lift to handle an interchangeable 3-D lens—the world’s first—designed for Panasonic’s MFT cameras.

headline: Angels Fire Back on Collusion Accusations
text: Michael Arrington, the TechCrunch founder and blogger, threw a bombshell into Silicon Valley with a blog post on Tuesday night, accusing the Valley’s top angel investors of colluding to reduce the price of investing in tech start-ups and keep competitors from investing.

headline: Raymond Perelman in Solo Bid for Philly Newspapers
text: Raymond Perelman, the Philadelphia businessman and philanthropist, has mounted a solo bid of at least $50 million as he fights creditors for control of Philadelphia’s two largest newspapers, The Associated Press reported.

headline: E.U. Approves Super-Watchdogs for Finance
text: European Union lawmakers have approved the creation of pan-E.U. watchdogs to police banking, insurance and trading, in one of the most far-reaching financial reforms of the decade, Reuters reported.

headline: Jefferies’ Fallen Revenue Sounds Alarm for Banks
text: Jefferies Group, the brokerage firm and investment bank, said on Wednesday that revenue for the third quarter had fallen to $520 million, from $700 million for the same period the year before, a 26 percent drop, despite a doubling of its investment banking business, to $246 million.

headline: Shapeways and Its 3-D Printing Comes To New York
text: Seattle may have Amazon.com and its books, vacuums, electronics and pet supplies. But Manhattan can now lay claim to an online shopping service that deals in far more bizarre objects.

headline: Hedge Fund Boss Wins Role in Wall St. Sequel
text: Hedge fund managers are well known for extracting huge fees from their wealthy investors. Relatively few have landed a role in a client’s Hollywood blockbuster.

headline: The Fed, Innovation and the Next Recession
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is an author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Istanbul’s Islands Get a Museum of Their Own
text: In addition to spanning two continents, Istanbul also counts nine islands within its city limits, celebrated in all their glory in the newly opened Museum of the Princes’ Islands, which offers a geographical, social, cultural and historical panorama of the offshore havens.

headline: Last Night and this Morning
text: The voices outside my window grew and filled the narrow street like a clot. Givenchy, I soon learned, had opened a store (perhaps a pop-up) and was having a party to celebrate this event. Earlier, I had gone to the Palazzo Morando for an exhibition of new designers by Franca Sozzani, the editor of Italian Vogue, and Anna Wintour of American Vogue. Ms. Sozzani and a company called Altaroma hold an annual design competition in Rome called “Who Is On Next,” and the finalists were present, as well as some other newcomers recognized for their concepts.

headline: Canary Wharf Owner Posts Rise in Net Asset Value
text: Songbird Estates, majority owner of Canary Wharf in London, booked a 6 percent rise in net asset value on Thursday, as demand for offices across the estate held firm against the government’s feeble economic outlook, Reuters said.

headline: Changing the Guard, at Last
text: To lose one chief executive may be regarded as a misfortune; to lose more looks like carelessness, John Gapper suggests in his Financial Times blog, when he asks how Lady Bracknell of “The Importance of Being Earnest” might react to the current exodus of prominent British banking chiefs.

headline: Perella Weinberg to Open Office in Abu Dhabi
text: Perella Weinberg Partners, the financial adviser, said on Wednesday that it would open its first office in the Middle East, with two former Nomura bankers to head up its operations in Abu Dhabi.

headline: Blockbuster Files for Bankruptcy
text: 8:08 a.m. | Updated Blockbuster, the video rental chain, on Thursday filed for Chapter 11, hoping to slash its hefty debt load and retrench in the face of competition from rivals providing online and mail-based services.

headline: Diamond: Banks Value Social Responsibility More
text: The president of Barclays, Robert E. Diamond, said that while the global financial crisis led to tighter regulation of the banking industry’s excesses, it also had a more important result: greater emphasis on social responsibility, Reuters reported.

headline: Should Jets Take a Stand and Suspend Braylon Edwards?
text: The Jets could use Braylon Edwards at Miami on Sunday night. In fact, they will. He won’t start, the Jets have said, but he may play most of the game.

headline: Another Wireless PC-to-TV Idea
text: Watching Internet video on your living room TV shouldn’t be hard. The stuff already plays on your laptop, so why not just connect your laptop to your TV? A new $99 gadget called Veebeam, introduced a few days ago, promises to make that easy to do.

headline: Nasdaq Raises Cost Forecast and Sees Revenue Growth
text: The Nasdaq OMX Group increased its short-term cost expectations on Wednesday but outlined the longer-term growth it expects in the clearing and technology businesses — areas on which the exchange operator will lean in coming years, Reuters reported.

headline: Lehman Says Differences With Creditors ‘Narrowing’
text: Lehman Brothers Holdings is “optimistic” that its reorganization plan will be confirmed by the end of the first quarter, according to a securities filing on Wednesday, Reuters reported. A representative for the firm said it had recovered $60 billion to be distributed to its debt holders.

headline: Iberia Board Backs British Airways’ Pension Plan
text: The board of Iberia, the Spanish airline, has backed the plan of British Airways for closing a huge pension deficit, clearing the way for a merger of the two airlines, the British carrier said Thursday.

headline: Trustmark Buys Cadence for $23.8 Million in Stock
text: Trustmark, a regional bank based in Mississippi, announced a deal to buy a smaller rival, Cadence Financial, in an all-stock deal worth about $23.8 million, The Associated Press reported.

headline: The Ballets Russes: Notes on a Scandale
text: Updated | It may sound inconceivable now, but there was a day when ballet could incite an audience to riot. And in the early 20th century, the mastermind behind such riots was, more often than not, Serge Diaghilev, director of the Ballets Russes.

headline: Taking Different Routes to Opening the Books
text: Have you ever experienced one of those moments when you think, Holy Cow, has anyone actually understood a word I was saying? I had one a few weeks ago after giving a talk at a training session at SRC headquarters. It has since led me on an eye-opening journey about what open-book management means.

headline: Liberals vs. Populists: It’s a Long Story
text: Today’s idea: American political life has long been marked by mutual incomprehension and outright hostility between liberalism and populism, an essay says. Today is no different.

text: Quick links on Andy Reid’s decision to start Michael Vick on Sunday instead of Kevin Kolb. What do you make of the move?

headline: British Minister Faces City’s Wrath After Speech
text: “Capitalism takes no prisoners and kills competition where it can,” Britain’s business secretary, Vince Cable, said Wednesday as part of a venomous attack on the British banking establishment.

headline: Making GPS Easier to Understand
text: If you have struggled trying to figure out exactly where to turn when the navigation device says “left in 2,000 feet,” you are not alone. According to research from the navigation and map data provider Navteq, half of all drivers can’t judge distances visually. And instructing people to turn by street name was no real solution.

headline: Amid Tension, China Blocks Crucial Exports to Japan

headline: Buffett Sells Another Chunk of Moody’s Shares
text: For the second time this month, Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway has sold off stock in Moody’s, the credit ratings agency, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Houston’s Problem: Porous Pass Defense
text: The Houston Texans  achieved the dubious distinction of becoming the first team to give up 400 yards passing in each of its first two games.

text: –Warren Buffett, usually Mr. Positive, says his gut tells him we’re still in a recession, no matter what the statistics indicate. “We’re not gonna be out of it for a while.”

headline: The ‘Hockey Stick’ Lives
text: Few images in the climate change debate have stirred as much controversy as the storied “hockey stick” graph, which shows average temperatures in the northern hemisphere holding roughly steady for 900 years or so, until the 20th century, when they rise sharply.

headline: A $100 Million Gift to Newark’s Schools
text: Could Facebook save the long-troubled Newark schools? Richard Pérez-Peña of The Times reports that Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive and a founder of Facebook, will donate $100 million to improve the Newark schools. In conjunction with the gift, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey will cede some control of the state-run school system to Mayor Cory A. Booker. The three plan to announce the arrangement on Friday on the “Oprah Winfrey Show.”

headline: The Connecticut-Country-Club Crackup
text: You could spend your life around political campaigns and never see a celebration quite like the one Linda McMahon held last month after Connecticut Republicans made her their Senate candidate in a three-way primary. McMahon is the fabulously wealthy founder (along with her high-school sweetheart and husband, Vince) of World Wrestling Entertainment, a company the McMahons transformed into a sort of Disney for the age of postindustrial American anger. Unknown to Connecticut voters before she began her run, she spent more than $20 million of her own fortune to beat out two Republican candidates — one of them recruited by the national party — for the right to square off this November against Richard Blumenthal, the state’s longtime Democratic attorney general, in a contest to succeed Christopher Dodd, who is retiring.

headline: U.S. Home Sales in August Matched Modest Forecasts
text: Home sales stabilized in August after a deep tumble in July, a development that, in the context of a severely troubled housing market, counts as good news.

headline: The Early Word: The Case for Peace
text: President Obama will devote his day to foreign policy, even as the White House struggles to demonstrate that jobs and the economy are Democrats’ top priorities.

headline: Will the Real Designer Please Stand Up

headline: Gay Marriage Gets Boost From Wall Street
text: The American Foundation for Equal Rights held a fund-raiser in New York City Wednesday night at the Mandarin Oriental hotel on Columbus Circle. The AFER is the organization that led the legal battle, led by lawyers Theodore Olson and David Boies, to challenge California’s ban on gay marriage. A trial court judge struck down the statute last month, but the case is on appeal

headline: French Officials Warn of Heightened Terrorism Risk
text: PARIS  France’s highest police official warned on Wednesday of a significant and “specific” risk of a terrorist attack on French soil from Al Qaeda’s North African affiliate.

headline: In Europe, a Mood of Austerity and Anxiety
text: Anastassios Haros never used to be angry or afraid. These days, that’s almost all he feels after Greece became the epicenter of a European debt crisis that continues to unnerve financial markets and is now manifesting itself in government cutbacks, personal hardships and labor unrest.

headline: U.S. Investors Expected to Dominate G.M. I.P.O.
text: General Motors plans to make most of the shares in its initial public offering available to investors in the United States, and a stock split should make shares accessible to individual investors, Reuters reported.

headline: Deficits Are Evil! Let’s Make Them Bigger!
text: What is there to say about the Republican Pledge To America (pdf)? No ideas; no respect for the public’s intelligence.

headline: (Some) Shades of Maradona Mexico ’86
text: A few years ago, Kazbek Tambi, the coach of the United States under-17 women’s national team, offered a forecast: Watch out for Japan.

headline: La Pétillante
text: The name of a drinking fountain in Paris which dispenses sparkling (and still) water.

headline: Athletic Association
text: Richard Phibbs’s black and white photography focuses on the graceful athleticism of man and beast, from sweaty rugby players in postgame repose to a snow-covered pack of horses to Phibbs’s beloved dog, Huck, leaping over a sand dune. This refined ideal of beauty has made him the perfect photographer for Giorgio Armani, Polo Ralph Lauren and Calvin Klein advertising campaigns. While working for Ralph Lauren, Phibbs formed an inspired partnership with the label’s chief creative officer, Alfredo Paredes, whose encouragement and art direction led to “Chasing Beauty” (Powerhouse; $50), the photographer’s first monograph, out next week. In his elegant foreword, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author Michael Cunningham succinctly describes the images as a “vastly interconnected series of marvels, different in their particulars, but alike in their ravishing, unorthodox perfections.”

headline: Obama’s Remarks at the United Nations
text: Following is a text of President Obama's speech to the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday, as released by the White House:

headline: For the First Time, No Sellout in Minnesota
text: ¶The Minnesota Wild plays a home game before a nonsellout crowd for the first time in their history. The crowd of “just” 16,129 for the Wednesday night exhibition game does not count against Minnesota’s streak of 382 straight regular-season and playoff sellouts, which also happens to be every such home date since the club joined the N.H.L. in 2000. Minnesota, however, also sold out an additional 27 home exhibition games during that time, so now the streak ends at 409, prompting this wistful blog post from the Wild’s owner, Craig Leipold.

headline: How to Be a Geek God
text: I’m not a gamer, so I had never heard of “God Mode” until yesterday, when I stumbled upon a reference to it on the TuneUp Blog. In gaming, God Mode is a cheat code that gives the player super-human skills and ample ammunition needed to prevail.

headline: Poetry Pairing | Sept. 23, 2010
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Indian Court Delays Ruling on Mosque Site
text: NEW DELHI  India’s Supreme Court on Thursday postponed a ruling on whether Hindus or Muslims would control the country’s most disputed religious site.

headline: Pay for Massages With a Flexible Spending Account
text: The article currently topping The New York Times hit parade (otherwise known as the most e-mailed list) is about new research suggesting that even a single session of massage can cause positive biological changes.

headline: Thursday Reading: Health Care Relief Begins
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: With Warning, Obama Presses China on Currency
text: UNITED NATIONS — President Obama increased pressure on China to immediately revalue its currency on Thursday, devoting most of a two-hour meeting with China’s prime minister to the issue and sending the message, according to one of his top aides, that if “the Chinese don’t take actions, we have other means of protecting U.S. interests.”

headline: Let Us Now Praise Famous Mice
text: Let it be known that I am a dedicated mouse person.

headline: ‘Affirmative Action for the Rich’
text: 12:18 p.m. | Updated See below for a comment from the author, Mr. Kahlenberg.

headline: Susan Boyle Will Have Her ‘Perfect Day’ After All
text: Susan Boyle‘s idea of a perfect day may or may not include feeding animals at the zoo or taking in a movie, but she will at last be able to check off recording the Lou Reed song “Perfect Day” from her agenda. A cover of that blissed-out track from Mr. Reed’s album “Transformer” (and which we still unfortunately associate with Ewan McGregor‘s heroin overdose in “Trainspotting”) will appear on Ms. Boyle’s coming album, “The Gift,” The Guardian reported, after she was denied the opportunity to sing the song on television earlier this month.

headline: We Made It Ourselves | Cheshire Canning
text: Last year, Jennifer Lazzaro found herself in a pickle. Literally. Technically, she found herself in a secret sauce, but the pickle followed soon after. Cutbacks forced her to leave a glamorous life as the director of human resources at Narciso Rodriguez and start over. “With this economy,” she asked herself, “why not take a chance and turn a hobby into more than that?”

headline: When Parents Differ on Prenatal Tests
text: I am torn. On the one hand, there is clearly interest among Motherlode readers for a conversation about prenatal testing in general, and Down syndrome in particular. I see that in the energetic, mostly thoughtful, sometimes harsh, discussion that has gone on in the comments threads (and in my in-box) in response to two posts by Amy Julia Becker this past week. (You can read them here and here.)

headline: Emanuel Not Packing Boxes – Yet
text: It was 20 months ago this week that Rahm Emanuel unpacked his boxes in the West Wing, placed several framed pictures of his family on his bookshelves and began welcoming visitors. He made a point of telling them that the chief of staff’s office was eight-square-feet larger than the vice president’s.

headline: Somali Forces Fight Islamists in the Capital
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia  At least 22 people were killed and more than 60 were wounded on Thursday in intense clashes between Islamist insurgent groups and Somali government forces supported by African Union soldiers, witnesses and health officials said.

headline: Channing, Keach, Marvel Join Cast of Baitz Play at Lincoln Center

headline: PayPal Makes It Easy to Give

The beauty of it is that you avoid the rigmarole of most Web-based giving: Typing in name, address, phone number, credit card number and expiration date.

headline: Medals vs. Points for the F1 Title
text: SINGAPORE – Bernie Ecclestone has again brought up his idea of awarding medals to decide the world championship. He says the new points system has not done its job making the drivers fight more for a victory, and the same drivers at the top now would have been there even with last year’s points system. He would rather have the title winner be the man who has won the most races, with each race victory earning a medal — rather than points.

headline: PEN American Center Names Award Winners
text: Break out the Champagne and the deposit slips. The PEN American Center has announced the 14 winners of its annual literary awards. Don DeLillo won the $25,000 Saul Bellow Award for Achievement in American Fiction, while Paul Harding, who earlier this year received the Pulitzer for his novel “Tinkers,” won the $35,000 Robert Bingham Fellowship for Writers. Susan Choi was awarded the W. G. Sebald Award for a Fiction Writer in Mid-Career, worth $10,000, while Michael Scammell received a $5,000 award for his biography “Koestler: The Literary and Political Odyssey of a Twentieth-Century Skeptic.” David Mamet took home the top prize for an American dramatist, Theresa Rebeck won the midcareer playwriting honor and Marilyn Hacker was cited for her poetry. They and the other winners will receive their awards at an Oct. 13 ceremony.

headline: Rex’s Cafe
text: If you could stomach  no pun intended  Rex Ryan’s performance Wednesday as he professed indignation at how his nice little Jets franchise has transformed into a frat house run amok, it was eventually possible to see the dark humor in it all. Dig through the bluster and false indignation and hypocrisy, and it was a scene straight out of “Casablanca.”

headline: Film Society of Lincoln Center Hires Editor of Indie Film Site
text: Eugene Hernandez, a founder and the editor in chief of the film news Web site IndieWire, will leave that site to become the director of digital strategy for the Film Society of Lincoln Center, the society said on Thursday. Started in 1996 as an e-mail newsletter, IndieWire grew into a Web site and blog network covering the independent film industry, and in 2008 was acquired by the online aggregator SnagFilms.

headline: Jenkins Considering Another Comeback
text: MORRISTOWN, N.J. – Sitting at his kitchen table on Wednesday night, Jets defensive tackle Kris Jenkins spent nearly an hour talking about his future. And his answer -– that he is still considering returning to the N.F.L. next season –- was unexpected.

headline: Millions of Friends, but Not Very Popular
text: What makes Mark Zuckerberg run? In “The Social Network,” David Fincher’s fleet, weirdly funny, exhilarating, alarming and fictionalized look at the man behind the social-media phenomenon Facebook — 500 million active users, oops, friends, and counting — Mark runs and he runs, sometimes in flip-flops and a hoodie, across Harvard Yard and straight at his first billion. Quick as a rabbit, sly as a fox, he is the geek who would be king or just Bill Gates. He’s also the smartest guy in the room, and don’t you forget it.

headline: Now Seating | Franz West at Gagosian
text: The Austrian artist Franz West has long made art that can picked up or sat down upon without reservation as well as actual furniture that has the presence of sculpture. “If I would give the truthful answer,” he says, “I would have to say that I really do not think in such categories between furniture and sculptures.” His latest installation, “Roman Room,” at Gagosian Gallery in Rome, makes a practical distinction if not a conceptual one. A cluster of sculptures made largely from papier-mâché, foam, gauze and cardboard, perched on low pedestals, intermingle with a pair of linen sheathed sofas and a chair that West created specially for the occasion. “I had the idea while watching my 3-year-old son looking up at the sculptures,” the artist says of the arrangement. “The seatings make for alternative positions and viewing platforms throughout the show.” The sculptures, which, depending on how you look at them and also maybe how old you are, might bring to mind enormous, melting ice cream treats, are as lumpy and charming as the seating is lean and angular. Both exude comfort in their own way. “When I was younger, I thought it was all right to make the visitor uncomfortable,” West says. “But now that I am older it would not be correct because my problems have gone.”

headline: Virgin to Debut Hotel Chain

The organization recently announced that it will soon make a logical addition to this roster: hotels.

headline: After Years of Failure, an Awakening at Temple

headline: Contractor Deaths in Iraq and Afghanistan Outnumber Service Member Deaths
text: More private military contractors than uniformed service members were killed while serving in Iraq and Afghanistan between January and June of this year, marking the first time that corporations have lost more personnel on America’s battlefields than the United States military, according to ProPublica, the nonprofit investigative reporting group. More than 250 civilians working under American contractors were killed in Iraq and Afghanistan during the first six months of 2010, while 235 soldiers died in that same period, according to the latest report in ProPublica’s Disposable Army series.

headline: Vanessa Bruno | L.A. Femme
text: “I’m not a typical French girl who’s only been in Europe and doesn’t know America,” said the Parisian designer Vanessa Bruno, who spent her childhood summers road tripping with her supermodel mom in the Rocky Mountains and the Pacific Northwest. Now, Bruno has made her way back to the West Coast, opening her first United States boutique on Melrose Avenue in West Hollywood. (A London store is scheduled to open later this month.) “I of course have the Parisian way of seeing things,” she continued, “but I definitely have this laid-back, young American spirit in what I do.”

headline: Brooklyn Sounds, Brews and Chow: A Mile-Long Street Fair With Moxie
text: STROLLING a street fair should be a wholesome, cheerful endeavor, a chance to ogle artisanal wares, help a giggling toddler onto a pony or watch your buttoned-down neighbor slam power chords with his garage band. But New York’s traffic-thwarting, tube-sock-peddling version  the kind that plagues Midtown Manhattan avenues in the summer  inspires something more like mass grumbling. The music is canned, the goods are suspect, and the entire enterprise seems aimed at tourists.

headline: Vatican Defends Bank After Seizure of $30 Million

headline: At the Barre, but Not to Dance
text: IN a light-filled studio in Midtown Manhattan, the class wasn’t even half over, but the students were already grimacing in pain. The dozen women stood in front of a ballet barre, feet in a V position, heels lifted and a soft ball between their thighs. They bent their knees and pulsed and pulsed, as if performing nonstop pliés. After almost 60 repetitions, the cheerful instructor declared the set over, and the group sighed with relief.

headline: Buried Alive at Fantastic Fest
text: For all that has been written about the shrinking world of independent film, there seems to be be no shortage of independent film festivals. But when hundreds of festivals around the country are vying for audiences, how do organizers make theirs stand out? Fantastic Fest, a festival in Austin, Tx., that devotes itself to genre cinema, likes attention-getting stunts.

headline: A Week of Cooking and Eating Solo: Tuesday to Saturday
text: Last month Mark Bittman spent a week alone up at his place on Cape Cod. He kept track of what he cooked and ate for the seven days. Part 1 was the first three days; here is the rest of the week.

headline: Instapaper Goes From Hobby to Start-Up
text: On Tuesday Marco Arment, the chief technology officer at the social networking site Tumblr, announced that he would be leaving it to tend to a personal project: Instapaper.

headline: London Design Festival | Understatements
text: One of the more poetic sights at the London Design festival is “Thin Black Lines,” an exhibition of new works by the Japanese design office Nendo at the Saatchi Gallery. Organized by Brent Dzekciorius of the auction house Phillips de Pury, the show (on view until the end of November) consists of pieces in steel that look like delicate, geometric line drawings, but which, when seen from certain angles, suddenly snap into three dimensions. Oki Sato, Nendo’s founder, who likens the designs to Japanese calligraphy, says that they “move alternately between the becoming and collapse of form.” In an adjoining gallery, the Projectory is a pop-up store (in place until April) that Dzekciorius has stocked with edgy pieces by young designers like Peter Marigold, Oscar Diaz and Leon Ransmeier.

headline: In New York, Cuomo Fires First Salvo Against Paladino
text: Andrew Cuomo released a television advertisement on Thursday in his first direct assault on Carl P. Paladino, his Republican opponent in the New York governor’s race.  The advertisements came a day after signs that Mr. Paladino, a novice candidate who won an upset victory in the Republican primary last week, showed unexpected strength, including a poll that showed him surprisingly close to Mr. Cuomo, New York State’s attorney general. While a new poll issued Thursday showed a much wider gap, Mr. Cuomo, who had initially held Mr. Paladino at arm’s length, appears to have concluded that it was time to confront his opponent more directly. Read more about the race on the City Room blog.
