text: So says one of my commenters. And for my sins, I actually get the reference.

headline: Savory Bread Pudding, in Lieu of Potatoes
text: A dear friend of ours, Richard Miller, died recently, and a few of us got together to spend an evening doing pretty much what we used to do when we visited him in Paris: have a glass of vodka or Champagne (or both, sequentially) with some nibbles, then enjoy a simple dinner and pleasant conversation. Richard liked fancy restaurants well enough — or at least he indulged us and pretended that he did — but his favorite dishes were things like roasted and braised meats. If hard-boiled eggs napped with mayo — oeufs mayonnaise — were on the menu, he could rarely resist ordering them as a first course.

headline: Keeping Score: When Good Prospects Go Bad
text: Plenty of baseball players have made a splash after being called up in midseason. But for Chris Carter, the A’s 23-year-old outfield prospect, this September is one he would just as well forget. Carter (not to be confused with the Mets’ Chris Carter or the former N.F.L. receiver Cris Carter) worked his way into the record books by going hitless in his first 10 starts. By the time he collected his first major league hit, on Sept. 20 — a line-drive single off the White Sox’ Scott Linebrink — he had been waiting 11 games, 42 days and 34 at-bats.

headline: Pregame Huddle: Early Tests
text: Alabama faces its first real road test against Arkansas, Notre Dame takes on Stanford and Boise State hopes to make a lasting impression against Oregon State.

headline: The Battle of the Bulbs
text: Three House Republicans, Joe Barton and Michael Burgess of Texas and Marsha Blackburn of Tennessee, have introduced the Better Use of Light Bulbs Act, which would repeal the section of the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 that sets minimum energy efficiency standards for light bulbs and would effectively phase out most ordinary incandescents.

headline: Small-Business Bill Advances; Campaign Finance Bill Stalls
text: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats failed Thursday to advance campaign finance legislation that would force businesses, unions and others to disclose how they were spending money in political campaigns and where they were getting it.

headline: Outtakes From Documentary Shown in Court in Chevron Case
text: The footage showed an American lawyer, Steven Donziger, at meetings and during mealtimes, discussing his class-action suit against Chevron and ruminating about trial strategy and the workings of the Ecuadorian justice system.

headline: Monkey Business at Prada
text: The world can always use a little more glamour, and that was essentially the underlying message at the Prada spring 2011 show here in Milan tonight, set as it was on a raised runway covered in steel mesh. But this is Prada, and no one is more questioning of glamour — and the banality of luxury — than Miuccia Prada.

headline: Giants May Give Koets His First Start at Center
text: With center Shaun O’Hara missing practices this week, the Giants could turn to Adam Koets to start against the Tennessee Titans on Sunday at New Meadowlands Stadium.

headline: Creditors Win 2nd Auction for Philadelphia Papers
text: Senior creditors won Round 2 of the bankruptcy court auction of The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Philadelphia Daily News on Thursday.

headline: At Steinbeck’s Getaway as Heirs’ Feud Revives
text: SAG HARBOR, N.Y.  Many things about the little house at the end of a point jutting into a cove of Noyac Bay have not changed in the 50 years since John Steinbeck set out from here with his poodle on the 10,000-mile, 11-week road trip that would become “Travels With Charley.”

headline: It Takes Eight for Eclypse
text: Chalk it up to oversaturation, but the days of young bands blowing up overnight on MySpace are long gone. So it’s all the more surprising to hear stories like the one of the Band Eclypse. The New York area octet put together an EP, “Ten Past,” on their own, and self-published it on iTunes two weeks ago. Within 24 hours it had climbed to No. 9 on the music seller’s influential hip-hop charts. The band’s style is something of a 2010 update on the 1990s rap-rock formula, which sounds cringe worthy, but these teenagers (ages 14-19) put a spin on it that works. They rap over rock riffs reminiscent of MGMT and Phoenix, and set their rhymes into soft relief with an amazing shoegazer-y female vocalist. On the eve of their record release show on Friday at 7 p.m. at Santos Party House in TriBeCa, The Moment caught up with the band.

headline: Facebook Says It Is Working on Technical Troubles
text: 7:30 p.m. | Updated  Noting that Facebook says the problems have been resolved.

headline: Picky Eaters
text: François Brouillard is waving something green under my nose, asking me if I think it smells like pineapple. (It does.)He has me sniff the clump of leaves in his other fist and, smiling impishly, asks if I think it smells like marijuana. Whatever it is, its bouquet is highly skunky. So far we’ve plucked and nibbled at cats’ tongue, garlic mustard flower, live-forever, linden, several violet species, spring beauty, stinging nettle, bellwort . . . and I’ve lost track of whatever else.

headline: Big Apple Meat Market
text: Those in the know steer their shopping carts here in search of bargains on meat and groceries.

headline: A Ram for the Well-Heeled Rancher
text: Could driving an abundantly luxurious pickup truck be as significant a social error for real cowboys as tucking designer jeans inside one’s boots might be? Chrysler intends to find out.

headline: Landlords Are Back in Control
text: TO the chagrin of many renters in New York City, the balance of power in the rental market has tipped back toward landlords — if not far enough for landlords to start celebrating quite yet.

headline: Trimming the Fat Off Prices
text: THE Big Apple Meat Market, on the Port Authority bus terminal’s western flank, lures chefs and those who watch their pennies with London broil and filet mignon for a fraction of the prices charged elsewhere  $2.88 and $5.98 a pound, respectively. It is a giant walk-in fridge of a store, where meat hooks and rails hang from the ceiling.

headline: Share Your Stories With ‘A Year at War’
text: The New York Times has been capitalizing on the popularity of broadband Internet and digital cameras to solicit readers’ photos and video, for special online features. “A Year at War” is one of the projects at NYTimes.com that has benefited from photo and video submissions from its readers — particularly soldiers.

headline: War, Revolution and a King Who Says ‘By Jove’
text: A lot happens on the first page of Ken Follett’s “Fall of Giants.” King George V is crowned at Westminster Abbey. A Welsh boy named Billy Williams turns 13 and begins his wretched life as a coal miner. And Mr. Follett, who was once a Welsh boy himself but grew up to become his generation’s most vaunted writer of colorless historical epics, kicks off a whopping new trilogy. His apparent ambition: to span the whole 20th century in blandly adequate novels so fat that they’re hard to hoist.

headline: Seoul Ascending
text: I’m standing with Cho Min-suk, one of Seoul’s foremost architects, atop one of his own skyscrapers, a luxury apartment complex called Boutique Monaco. And it’s only perhaps from here, on high, that one can grasp what is meant by “the Miracle on the Han,” as Seoul, South Korea, is sometimes known. A hundred years ago, the city had fewer than a million people. Today Seoul boasts 23 million, making it by some counts the second-largest metropolitan area in the world.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Enter the Void’
text: Gaspar Noé, the director of “Enter the Void,” discusses a scene from his film featuring Paz de la Huerta and Nathaniel Brown.

headline: HSBC Chief Said to Be Planning to Step Down
text: 8:23 a.m. | Updated Landon Thomas Jr. and Julia Werdigier have more.

headline: The Bowery’s New, Narrow Showcase for Art
text: Back in the fall of 2008, when Sperone Westwater Gallery announced plans to construct an eight-story building of its own on the Bowery, it seemed a bold but possibly foolhardy idea. Almost a year into the great recession, it did not appear to be the most propitious moment for such a daring and expensive move.

headline: Netflix Fans at Media Event Were Actors
text: Netflix, the video rental company, admitted on Thursday that some of the enthusiastic onlookers who told reporters in Toronto a day earlier how excited they were to learn that service would now be available in Canada were, in fact, paid actors.

headline: Tunneling to the Core of Family
text: THE local children’s hospital has a massage therapist for parents whose children are admitted. I wish I never had to know this, but I was grateful for the service. Our son’s stay was 19 days. He was 2 1/2 years old. And I was eight and a half months pregnant with our second child.

headline: Landrieu to Block O.M.B. Nominee
text: Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, said Thursday that she would block confirmation of President Obama’s new budget director until the administration lifts the moratorium on deep-water oil drilling in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: A Ballet’s Costumes Take Center Stage

text: Alabama faces its first real road test against Arkansas, Notre Dame takes on Stanford and Boise State hopes to make a lasting impression against Oregon State.

headline: Now Celebrating | Lane Crawford’s 160th
text: The Hong Kong-based Lane Crawford, Asia’s leading purveyor of all things luxury, is celebrating its 160 years of pioneering design by enlisting a small army of the store’s style-setting friends from around the globe to create special pieces in honor of the celebration. Customized one-of-a-kind Burberry trenches were created by 23 top fashion folks like Anna Della Russo, Simon Doonan, Milan Vukmirovic and Lane Crawford’s own gravity-defying fashion director Sarah Rutson, while eight antique Chinese Ming chairs were redesigned by the likes of Tom Dixon and Fornasetti. For the next 30 days, the Heritage 160 collection, as it is being called, is being sold off in an online auction to benefit Unicef. A store visit is also highly recommended in order to try on limited-edition reissues of iconic shoes from 13 top brands, including Jimmy Choo, Nicholas Kirkwood, Pierre Hardy and Christian Louboutin. It’s sure to be a birthday party not to be missed.

headline: The Price Tag May Be Big, but So Are the Views
text: A PENTHOUSE on the top floor of the 56-story Park Millennium building near Lincoln Center is being listed this weekend by Prudential Douglas Elliman for $34.5 million.

headline: Spare Times
text: Around Town

headline: Tangled in a Dreamscape With Friends in Tow
text: “I can’t be left to my imagination,” Theo Bleckmann sang at Le Poisson Rouge on Wednesday night, ethereal but in the moment, neatly underscoring the line’s iambic pentameter, as well as its slow undercurrent of dread. He was about halfway through his version of “And Dream of Sheep,” a Kate Bush song from her 1985 album, “Hounds of Love.”

headline: Not Just a Perch for King Kong
text: THE new exhibition at the Keith de Lellis Gallery, “New York: A Bird’s-Eye View,” has a striking assortment of aerial views of the city. No image is more arresting than that of the Navy dirigible Los Angeles docking at the mooring post of the Empire State Building, a giant cigarlike cylinder coming nose-to-nose with the tallest building in the world.

headline: Streetscapes | The Empire State Building
text: The mooring mast atop the Empire State Building was said to be for dirigibles. But no airship ever docked there.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: ‘THE MAGIC ORANGE TREE’ CELEBRATION

headline: Honda Goes 3-D in Times Square for the CR-Z
text: Times Square is not a place where people are known to come and zone out. But there was 12-year-old Safwan Kahan, sitting Thursday afternoon beneath a blue canopy at 43rd Street and Broadway, at the wheel of a racing video game. His eyes were shielded by tinted shades rimmed in black, to enhance the 3-D sensation that the black sports car on the screen was real and that he was in command.

headline: Following the Dots Around the City
text: Autumn in New York is the perfect time for an accidental festival of the work of the Pop artist Roy Lichtenstein. This one is made possible by three separate exhibitions spread around Manhattan, which seems only fitting. After all (and perhaps surprisingly), Lichtenstein was one of the few great American painters of the postwar era born on the island of Manhattan: in 1923, into the cushier precincts of the Upper West Side. He attended public school and then the private Franklin School for Boys before heading off to Ohio State University to study painting. He died in Manhattan in 1997.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: Pop

headline: In Bing Crosby’s Wine Cellar, Vintage Baseball
text: How a near pristine black-and-white reel of the entire television broadcast of the deciding game of the 1960 World Series  long believed to be lost forever  came to rest in the dry and cool wine cellar of Bing Crosby’s home near San Francisco is not a mystery to those who knew him.

headline: F.C.C. Opens Unused TV Airwaves to Broadband
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission approved a proposal on Thursday that would open vast amounts of unused broadcast television airwaves for high-speed wireless broadband networks and other unlicensed applications.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: Classical

headline: Walgreens Gets Fresh
text: Drugstores are where New Yorkers go round the clock for necessities — toilet paper, a pint of ice cream, sometimes even medicine. Fresh fruit would seem as out of place at one of them as fine wine.

headline: Giuseppe Arcimboldo

headline: Several Obsessions, United on the Canvas
text: Of all the Mannerists’ winks, smirks and capers, the composite heads imagined by the 16th-century Milanese painter Giuseppe Arcimboldo must be the weirdest. Substituting fruits, vegetables and other bits of the natural world for human features, they tease the eye and sometimes turn the stomach. A ripe pear, for instance, looks suddenly unappetizing once it’s made to serve as a chin.

headline: Scorecard | Gucci Wins!
text: Oh, Frida Giannini, you listened to Scorecard! Kicking off Milan fashion week, the Gucci designer struck a strong chord with critics by tempering her trashy-chic rocker chick look with (subtle) notes of Saint Laurent. Meanwhile, the sometimes couturier to Her Gaganess, Francesco Scognamiglio, seemed not to realize that all little monsters might not want to do a dance in the dark.

text: Jazz

headline: The Fallout From Blockbuster’s Bankruptcy
text: Stephen J. Lubben writes about bankruptcy and debt issues for DealBook.

headline: Gates Defends Policy on Afghanistan and the Debate That Shaped It
text: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Thursday rejected assertions that a fractious internal debate had hobbled policy for Afghanistan, expressing full confidence in the strategy and saying that he expected no major shift in direction when the Obama administration completed a review of the war effort in December.

headline: Small Gifts Sent to Ease U.S. Debt

headline: Moving Preciously to the Music, Sometimes Stealing Away With It
text: It’s good to see musicians onstage in a ballet. Currently this is happening at the Miller Theater; the occasion is the American premiere of Kaija Saariaho’s “Maa,” a seven-movement score she composed in 1991 for the Finnish National Opera.

headline: 'Orlando'
text: More photos from the Classic Stage Company's production of Sarah Ruhl's play.

headline: We Have a Situation
text: I’m an attractive guy in my mid-30s. Because I’m single, most of my Facebook photos are of me with beautiful women. The pictures document good times, not conquests. Still, I receive lots of catty comments from female friends. To them, these photos prove that I’m a boastful player and a jerk. Why do they feel free to flame my social life?

headline: Images of War, Finally Unpacked
text: Somehow, in the summer of 1970, I ended up in an anarchist campground deep in the mountains of Southern France. Most of the campers were young French and Italian live wires, tense, raucous, full of theater. But there was also a contingent of older people, Spanish Civil War veterans, still fugitives after 30 years, living out of the backs of vans.

headline: Chinese Attitudes on Generosity Are Tested
text: BEIJING  Like most everything else in China’s economy, philanthropy here is in a boom period, fueled by phalanxes of newly minted billionaires and foundations, encouraged by an army of professional advisers on charity and, increasingly, sanctioned by the government.

headline: Images of History, Recovered
Robert Capa's Lost Negatives
text: Images from the show at the International Center of Photography.

headline: A Moroccan Tradition in Full Cry
text: When the lights rose on the large, voluptuous women arranged on low cushioned benches in Bouchra Ouizguen’s “Madame Plaza,” it was easy for the mind to go to art historical references: the Venus figurines, Manet’s “Olympia,” or even the recent sculptural dances of Maria Hassabi, who embodies centuries of suggestively positioned women.

headline: Auction World’s Blast of Brash
text: IN 2006 when the market for contemporary art was red hot and dealers and collectors spent hours jockeying to be first in the door at Art Basel, the world’s most important contemporary art fair, Philippe Ségalot could be seen hanging back, his manner calm and self-assured. That’s because Mr. Ségalot, a private New York dealer, had pulled the stunt of all art-world stunts. He hired a Hollywood makeup artist to fly to Basel, Switzerland, and transform him into a balding nerd with Coke-bottle glasses. Then, using a fake exhibitor’s pass with his new face on it, he sneaked past the phalanx of security guards and into the fair days before it opened, reserving the best artworks for his clients well ahead of anyone else.

headline: An ‘I ♥’ Reprise for Milton Glaser
text: This morning we told you that Milton Glaser, the 81-year-old graphic designer emeritus of New York, sneakily submitted to The Times two of his own take-offs on his original “I ♥ NY” logo for our growing collection of them. More than 50 of you tried to guess which pair of designs they could be.

headline: Losing Battles
text: In the introduction to his 2003 collection of journalism, “Death as a Way of Life,” the Israeli novelist David Grossman wrote: “The daily reality in which I live surpasses anything I could imagine, and it seeps into my deepest parts.” In a note at the conclusion of his somber, haunting new novel, “To the End of the Land,” he explains that he began writing it in May 2003 — around the same time he wrote that introduction, six months before the end of his older son’s military service and a year and a half before his younger son, Uri, enlisted. “At the time,” he writes, “I had the feeling — or rather, a wish — that the book I was writing would protect him.”

headline: Thais Bristle at Australian’s Take on Thai Cuisine
text: BANGKOK  It’s been a rough year for Thailand. First there were the images of deadly street battles between soldiers and protesters beamed around the world. Then people living in neighboring dictatorships snickered that Thailand was a democracy in decline. Foreign tourists wondered whether it was safe to travel here.

headline: A Film Festival With a Penchant for Making Tastes, Not Deals
text: The New York Film Festival  which begins its 48th iteration Friday night at Lincoln Center with a gala screening of “The Social Network”  is at once buoyed and burdened by its past. This is true of other festivals, too. Spend a few hours at Sundance or Cannes and you are bound to hear someone conjuring up the old days, when indie film really, you know, mattered or when Marcello Mastroianniwas standing right over there.

headline: Aid Sought for Nuclear Plants
text: The federal loan guarantee program and other aid for new nuclear plants may not be enough to induce Constellation Energy to build a third reactor at its Calvert Cliffs site, 40 miles south of Washington, the company’s president and chief executive said on Thursday.

headline: The Thin Family Line: A Dynasty of City Cops
text: Six years ago, Edward Conlon, a New York City police officer who had been writing about his beat under a pseudonym for The New Yorker, published an acclaimed memoir about his experiences in law enforcement called “Blue Blood.” Mr. Conlon comes from a long line of cops and joined the family profession even though he had gone to Harvard.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Whole Truth'
text: The ABC legal drama presents both sides of its cases.

headline: ‘Busted’
text: Randy Britton e-mails: “I’ve noticed in much of the coverage of the BP oil spill that the press has taken to calling the oil well ‘busted.’ Since when is ‘busted’ the proper way to describe a broken oil well?  It seems very colloquial and not a form I would expect to see in proper journalistic forums.” Even now that BP’s troubled oil well in the Gulf of Mexico is being permanently sealed, news reports continue to refer to the “busted well,” particularly wire services like the Associated Press and AFP. Reuters was an early adopter, reporting on efforts to contain the “busted well” on May 3. Alternatively, busted has modified oil rig, or just plain rig. A database search of coverage of the BP spill finds the first recorded use of busted came nine days into the crisis on April 29, when the MSNBC host Ed Schultz said, “The busted rig is leaking — get this — 200,000 gallons of oil a day.” Is busted overly informal for journalists? The verb bust certainly has colloquial roots, beginning its life on the American scene as a folksy variant of burst. (The same dropping of the “r” turned curse into cuss, horse into hoss and parcel into passel.) Building on earlier use as a noun, bust busted out as a verb as early as 1806, when Meriwether Lewis, while on his famous expedition with William Clark, wrote in his journal, “Windsor busted his rifle near the muzzle.” Since then, bust has worked its way into a wide variety of American expressions.  “Bust runs the gamut from slang to standard,” explain David K. Barnhart and Allan A. Metcalf in their book “America in So Many Words.” “When it is used to mean ‘to explode or fall apart or be arrested,’ bust is generally slang. In the sense of failing (especially financially) it is informal, as busting the bank in gambling lingo, while in the specialized sense of taming a horse it is standard, the only way to say busting a bronco.” Despite its potential slanginess, busted is “not actually forbidden” in the news media, as the Boston Globe language columnist Jan Freeman wrote in August. Indeed, reporters often latch onto the occasional colloquialism that seems particularly expressive, and in this case, Freeman surmises they were drawn to the term’s “criminal-cowboy-macho connotations.” Regardless of the reasons for its current vogue, it’s notable that busted was rarely relied on by the press to describe stricken oil wells before the BP disaster — even in incidents that were highly similar, such as the 1979 blowout of the Ixtoc I well in the Gulf of Mexico. Most of the precursors I found come from more literary sources. It was appropriate, for instance, in some light verse by J.W. Foley published in The New York Times in 1904: Dear friend, there’s a question I’d like to ask you, (Your pardon I crave if it vexes) Have you ever invested a hundred or two In an oil well somewhere down in Texas? Have you ridden in autos (I mean in your mind), With the profits you honestly trusted Would flow from your venture in oil stocks — to find That the oil well was hopelessly busted?  I can’t find fault in reporters drawing on the rich history of bust and busted in American English to add a little extra oomph to their dispatches from the gulf. Calling the well busted does evoke a looser, wilder state of disrepair than broken, or the more technically accurate blown-out. But after many months of news coverage, the phrase “busted well” has now turned into little more than a cliché. That’s a far worse journalistic offense than a bit of well-placed slang.

headline: Player Strike Averted in Italy, for Now
text: MILAN — Footballers in Italy came very, very close to going on strike in recent weeks.

headline: Roy Lichtenstein
text: Works by the Pop artist are on view in three separate exhibitions in Manhattan.

headline: Altering Perceptions on an Astral Plane Trip
text: In “Enter the Void” the camera soars above the world like a bird, like a kite, like a ghost. It moves with smooth, gentle motions and seemingly indecisive purpose, passing through walls, drifting over alleys and climbing high above the roofs of a nighttime city agleam in jeweled color. At times it hovers next to one of the city’s inhabitants like an angel or a threat. Occasionally it even appears to take up temporary residence in someone’s head — dive-bombing toward the back of a skull like a blow — so that it (and we) can see the world directly from another point of view: This is your brain. This is your brain on a Gaspar Noé movie.

headline: S.E.C. v. Hedge Funds: This Week It’s a Tie
text: Let’s take a look at one win and one loss for the Securities and Exchange Commission on the hedge-fund front this week.

headline: Spain’s Civil War, Inside a Suitcase
text: In “Images of War, Finally Unpacked,” Holland Cotter reviews an exhibition called “The Mexican Suitcase” at the International Center of Photography in New York, which documents wartime life in Spain between 1936 and 1939 through the eyes of three photographers — Robert Capa, Gerda Taro and David Seymour (Chim) — in images no one seems to have seen for more than a half century.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 23
text: A view of the day in sports, from fencing to rhythmic gymnastics.

headline: Senate Won’t Vote on Bush-Era Tax Cuts Until After Elections
text: Democrats have decided not to seek a pre-election showdown on the soon-to-expire Bush tax cuts, saying lawmakers will instead wage the legislative battle with Republicans in a lame-duck session in November.

headline: Avis Raises Bid for Dollar Thrifty, Topping the Accepted Offer From Hertz
text: Just a week before shareholders of the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group vote on a proposed takeover by Hertz Global Holdings, the Avis Budget Group is keeping up the fight.

headline: Leaping Off the Page, a Beatnik’s Poetic Rant
text: I saw the best poems of previous generations destroyed by sanity, well-fed, calm, neatly dressed, tiptoeing through lecture halls at 10 a.m. looking for a passing grade on a term paper.

headline: Will Mow Lawns for ‘Lone Star’ Eyeballs
text: The Texas soap opera “Lone Star” is, to date, the dud of the fall season, having attracted a disastrously low average number of viewers, 4.1 million, for its first episode on Monday. The show is lucky that it hasn’t already been canceled.

headline: Cutting Schools’ Energy Waste and Bills
text: The Clinton Global Initiative, which just completed its fifth conference, has become a bustling bazaar for ideas and investments aimed at making the world a better place. This week it indeed had the feel of a crowded marketplace. Hallways at the event in midtown Manhattan were flooded with well-heeled, well-intended people matching up with social, financial and technological innovators.

headline: Fighting Words, Indeed
text: A political fund-raising opportunity lurks around every corner.

headline: From Boehner’s Lips, Fodder for Democrats
text: The idea behind Thursday morning’s news conference by House Republican leaders was not to provide ammunition for Democrats.

headline: When Season Ends, Casey Is Ready to Ride
text: ATLANTA — At the conclusion of the Tour Championship, when every other top-10 player in the world travels to Wales for the Ryder Cup, Paul Casey will fly to Canada to ride mountain bikes in Whistler and Blackcomb Mountains.

headline: Hoyer Jabs G.O.P. on ‘Pledge’ Rollout
text: On Thursday, House Republicans formally issued their “Pledge to America” at a Virginia small business. Later in the day, the chamber passed legislation that aims to help small businesses over almost unanimous G.O.P. opposition.

headline: Baz Luhrmann to Bring ‘Strictly Ballroom’ to the Stage
text: Baz Luhrmann, the film auteur behind “William Shakespeare’s Romeo + Juliet” and “Moulin Rouge,” is moving forward on a long-intended stage musical adaptation of his first movie, “Strictly Ballroom,” with hopes of bringing it to Broadway someday, Mr. Luhrmann said in a phone interview this week.

headline: Captive in Iraq, Stymied by Voice Mail
text: “Buried” is a horror movie with delusions of moral grandeur. One minute, the nightmare endured by Paul Conroy (Ryan Reynolds), a nonmilitary truck driver in Iraq who is buried alive and held for ransom, is a pulse-elevating thriller that wants to prick your deepest terrors of claustrophobic confinement.

headline: 9/11 Conspiracy Theory Not as Popular as Ahmadinejad Says
text: As my colleagues Neil MacFarquhar and Liz Robbins report, at the United Nations on Thursday, Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, claimed that “the majority of the American people, as well as most nations and politicians around the world agree” that “some segments within the U.S. government orchestrated” the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks.

headline: Lawyers Look to Exploit a Scientific Error
text: The spying indictment filed late last week against a former Los Alamos scientist contains evidence of tape-recorded conversations, clandestine meetings, confidential places for the transfer of documents and a pattern of false statements.

headline: Political Points Podcast: A New Agenda for the G.O.P.
text: Click to Listen

headline: When Fast Risers Start Slowly
text: Plenty of baseball players have made a splash after being called up midseason. But for Chris Carter, the Athletics’ 23-year-old outfield prospect, this September is one he would just as well forget. Carter (not to be confused with the Mets’ Chris Carter or the former N.F.L. receiver Cris Carter) worked his way into the record books by going hitless in the first 10 games he started. By the time he collected his first major league hit, on Sept. 20  a line-drive single against the White Sox’ Scott Linebrink  he had been waiting 11 games, 42 days and 34 at-bats.

headline: Students Caught in the School Squeeze
text: “One of the saddest days of my life was when my mother told me ‘Superman’ did not exist,” the educational reformer Geoffrey Canada recalls in the opening moments of “Waiting for ‘Superman,’ ” a powerful and alarming documentary about America’s failing public school system. “She thought I was crying because it’s like Santa Claus is not real. I was crying because no one was coming with enough power to save us.”

headline: Outspoken, Irascible and Out of a Job, Chris Daly Improvises
text: It is something of a feat to be branded the most impossible, irascible, ultra-liberal politician in San Francisco. It is less of an achievement to be impossible, irascible and perhaps unemployable.

headline: The Frisbee of Art
text: This is the second in a series.

headline: Vietnamese Community Faces Tumultuous Race
text: The Vietnamese community has aligned itself with the Republican Party since the first refugees arrived in the United States from Communist Vietnam four decades ago. They brought with them a deep suspicion of left-leaning politicians; not wearing a South Vietnamese freedom pin was enough to doom a candidate.

headline: Murder Defendant’s Text Messages Detailed
text: NEW HAVEN  Hours before the home invasion and killings for which they are both facing capital charges, two longtime criminals exchanged jaunty cellphone text messages about their plans. Their exchange included the signoff “LOL,” the abbreviation known to 12-year-olds and e-mailing grandmothers alike as shorthand for “laughing out loud.”

headline: It’s a Mean-Girl World: Are You Bully or Victim?
text: Pity poor Marni (Kristen Bell), a high school student with acne, bad hair, braces on her teeth and glasses. In the opening scenes of the stupefying comedy “You Again,” she is persecuted and branded a loser by Joanna (Odette Yustman), a bullying alpha girl, and her fellow cheerleaders.

headline: Woman in Priestly Garb Sounds ‘a Great Echo’
text: MILAN  While other little girls in her hometown of Nissoria, Sicily, were dressing up and playing house, Maria Vittoria Longhitano would pretend to say Mass, dispensing cookies and chips to her toys for communion. Sometimes, she would even baptize her dolls.

headline: In This Race, No Shortage of Rage
text: They may be running for governor, but the nominees of both major parties sound as if their true ambition is to become New York’s anger manager in chief.

headline: A Nonprofit’s Republican Ties
text: Though Americans for Job Security says it is not aligned with a political party, a close look shows that its connections and choice of campaigns resemble those of a Republican political operation.

headline: Beltran Starts Hitting Again, Giving the Mets Some Options
text: After seeing Carlos Beltran do an uncanny impersonation of Carlos Beltran over the past couple of weeks, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel made a forecast that, if true, means very good things for Beltran and the Mets.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,285 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: A Wave of Addiction and Crime, with the Medicine Cabinet to Blame
text: BOSTON  Police departments have collected thousands of handguns through buy-back programs in communities throughout the country. Now they want the contents of your medicine cabinet.

headline: Seeking to Protect Investors
text: “We are the investor’s advocate.”

headline: Would Mets Hire Stan Kasten?
text: An intriguing announcement was made in Washington when the Nationals said that Stan Kasten, their team president, would be stepping down at the end of the season, with little mention of his future plans. Would the Mets consider making a bold move by asking Kasten to join the club as an overseer of the baseball department, a president of baseball operations who would pick a general manager and a field manager?

headline: New York Parking Rules for Sukkot
text: On Friday, because of Sukkot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Top Executives Say It Pays to Spend Time in Asia
text: HONG KONG  Many Western companies have operated blue-collar manufacturing sites in Asia for a long time. Now, as the region grows in importance, the most senior white collars of some of those companies are spending more time here than ever before.

headline: Ways to Measure Student Learning
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pendleton Round-Up
text: Photos from the Pendelton Round-Up, an eastern Oregon rodeo celebrating its centennial this year.

headline: Congress Considers Concussion Protections
text: WASHINGTON  Congressional interest in legislation to protect young athletes from the effects of concussions has become so spirited that on Thursday morning one House committee held a hearing on one bill at the same moment another committee passed a different bill just 400 feet down the hall.

headline: How a School Chief Tried to Turn a District Around
text: To the Editor:

headline: Blockbuster, Hoping to Reinvent Itself, Files for Bankruptcy
text: Blockbuster, the struggling video rental giant, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday, seeking to shed its onerous debt and remake itself to compete against nimbler rivals.

headline: S.E.C. Nears a Setback on Disclosure
text: WASHINGTON  The House on Thursday repealed a section of the recently passed Dodd-Frank Act that let the S.E.C. keep secret nearly all information it gathers during investigations.

headline: Mickelson Has Up and Down Opening Round
text: ATLANTA — Phil Mickelson, the defending champion, made two eagles on the back nine at East Lake Golf Club on Thursday en route to a one-under-par 69. That was the good news. The bad news is he made a bogey on the next hole both times.

headline: Spitzer Says Cuomo Fights Dirty
text: Some may wonder if it is the political equivalent of the pot calling the kettle black.

headline: Old West Traditions, and Tensions, at Rodeo
text: PENDLETON, Ore.  The sign at the entrance to the rodeo’s bleachers said “Wrist Bands Required.” So Reggie Queampts dutifully wore his: “2010 Round-Up NDN Seating.”

headline: The Privacy of Donors: A Group States Its Case
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Nicaraguan Official Is Found Slain in the Bronx
text: A Nicaraguan official was found dead on Thursday, his throat slashed, in his Bronx apartment, the police said.

headline: Goya Aims to Expand the Neighborhood
text: ASK Latinos who grew up in the Northeast about Goya Foods and chances are they have used many of the company’s products — canned beans, jars of olives and adobo seasoning among them — to prepare traditional dishes like ropa vieja or arroz con gandules.

headline: Moscow Mayor Pokes Kremlin. (Cue Hornets.)
text: MOSCOW  Of all the high priests of Russian officialdom, few have become more deeply entrenched in power than Moscow’s mayor, Yuri M. Luzhkov.

headline: Batting Average Is Low, but Production Is High
text: The official Major League Baseball statistics packet, available in every press box and clubhouse in the game, lists the teams according to batting average. The essential statistic should be runs scored, because runs win games.

headline: City Reports Nearly Fivefold Increase in Students Repeating a Grade
text: The number of New York City elementary and middle school students who failed to move on to the next grade skyrocketed this school year, as weak students faced a higher bar on state tests and the broadening of the city’s tough promotion policy.

headline: Gators Look to Re-establish the Run
text: Florida might have looked like a finesse team in 2008 and 2009 with all those wide receivers and that empty backfield, but the Gators could play rock ’em, sock ’em football. They were a physical bunch, and it was no more evident than when Tim Tebow put his head down.

headline: Italian Villa
text: Joe BastianichAge: 42 Occupation: Food entrepreneur

headline: Mighty Strange Birds
text: Zack Snyder, director of “300,” “Watchmen” and the coming “Sucker Punch,” aims for younger males with the animated “Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga’Hoole,” and a mighty strange bird the movie is.

headline: Payday Nears, and Casey Has a Chance at Payback
text: ATLANTA  For all of the pretournament talk about the complex points permutations in the FedEx Cup playoffs, the first round of the Tour Championship on Thursday provided simple symmetry sprinkled with some real spice atop the leader board.

headline: Hidden Under Tax-Exempt Cloak, Political Dollars Flow
text: Alaskans grew suspicious two years ago when a national organization called Americans for Job Security showed up and spent $1.6 million pushing a referendum to restrict development of a gold and copper mine at the headwaters of Bristol Bay.

headline: China Is Blocking Minerals, Executives Say
text: HONG KONG — China’s Commerce Ministry denied on Thursday that it had halted exports to Japan of a crucial category of minerals, but industry executives said that factories in China were still not shipping to Japan after Chinese customs agents blocked shipments earlier this week.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Steinbeck’s Summer Home
text: The writer’s shack where John Steinbeck wrote “Travels with Charley” in Sag Harbor, N.Y., is the subject of a long-running and bitter real estate battle.

headline: In TV Ad, Cuomo Levels First Attack on Paladino
text: Andrew M. Cuomo, leaving little doubt that he is concerned about his Republican opponent, Carl P. Paladino, unleashed his first direct attack on Mr. Paladino on Thursday with a television advertisement that criticized him for his donations to Albany politicians and for his failure to create jobs after winning tax breaks intended to promote economic development.

headline: Confronting Autism
text: Amid growing awareness of Asperger’s syndrome and the spectrum of autism in general, Fridrik Thor Fridriksson’s riveting documentary “A Mother’s Courage: Talking Back to Autism” leaps into the mysteries surrounding the disorder, tracing the efforts of Margret Dagmar Ericsdottir, a mother in Iceland, to seek treatment for her severely autistic son, Keli. While the title is accurate, the film is less a portrait of her than an inquiry into the origins and nature of autism and therapies for it.

headline: The ‘Dream Act’ Proposal on Immigration
text: To the Editor:

headline: Balance and the Elderly
text: To the Editor:

headline: Different Paths for Two California Republicans
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Both are former corporate chief executives, with personal fortunes, impressive résumés and famous friends. Both are conservatives who say that they have lived the American dream and fear for its future. And both are Bay Area women, with their eyes and ambitions firmly fixed on a change of address.

headline: Giants’ Storied History, in 5,000 Square Feet
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  John Mara this week walked into the Giants’ new Legacy Club and went straight to his father Wellington’s old desk. He had remembered the pieces since he was a child  the gold “F” for Fordham paperweight; the small black binoculars Wellington Mara, the former owner, used to watch games; the framed photo of Ann Mara, John’s mother, taken at Yankee Stadium; the gray manual typewriter on which Wellington typed the speech he would give to usher Vince Lombardi into the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

headline: Revisiting Katrina
text: By the time Hurricane Katrina passed to the east of New Orleans, it wasn’t a once-in-a-lifetime storm; the city probably experienced no more than Category 2 conditions. And many of the levees that failed weren’t breached, but simply gave way because they had been improperly built on ground vulnerable to seepage.

headline: U.S. Is Said to Rein in G.M. Stock Offering
text: DETROIT  The initial public stock offering by General Motors will be smaller than previously suggested, and the federal government will most likely sell a relatively small portion of its 61 percent stake in the company, according to people with knowledge of the preparations.

headline: Jenkins Considering a Return
text: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  Sitting at his kitchen table on Wednesday night, Jets defensive tackle Kris Jenkins gave an unexpected answer about his football future: he is considering returning next season.

headline: Who Stands for Standing?
text: The legal doctrine of “standing,” as in standing to sue, doesn’t usually get people’s juices flowing — even people like newspaper editors who (take my word for this) tend to regard the topic as dry and technical, more suitable for courthouse geeks than general readers.

headline: Some Obama Allies Fear School Lunch Bill Could Rob Food Stamp Program
text: WASHINGTON  In her campaign to reduce childhood obesity and improve school nutrition, Michelle Obama has become entangled in a fight with White House allies, including liberal Democrats and advocates for the poor.

headline: After Tasting Lakers’ Success, Turiaf Has Chance With Knicks
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The man looking over Ronny Turiaf’s shoulder at the Knicks’ practice facility earlier this week was none other than Phil Jackson, forever frozen and framed with his teammates in a photograph from 1973, the last time the Knicks captured an N.B.A. title.

headline: Nobel Laureate Retracts Two Papers Unrelated to Her Prize
text: Linda B. Buck, who shared the 2004 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for deciphering the workings of the sense of smell, has retracted two scientific papers after she and her colleagues were unable to repeat the findings.

headline: The Sunday Deadline
text: President Obama made a compelling case at the United Nations for why a peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians is not only essential but may even be possible this time. Since the current talks began three weeks ago, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, are reportedly grappling with some of the toughest issues.

headline: Tea Party’s Big Money
text: Tea Party supporters and their candidates like to imagine themselves as insurgents, crashing the barricades of Washington to establish a new order of clean and frugal government. In earthbound reality, many of the people pulling the Tea Party’s strings are establishment Republican operatives and lobbyists. Some have made money off the party for years.

headline: Facebook and Newark
text: It is good news that Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive of Facebook, is donating $100 million to remake the failing public schools in Newark. But it will take a lot more than money to improve student performance in that city’s troubled system, which has continued to perform dismally since being taken over by the state 15 years ago. Mayor Cory Booker, who will get substantial control of the system as a condition of the donation, must now rally his city and its unions behind an ambitious reform plan that raises standards and holds teachers and principals accountable for student performance.

headline: Europe’s Financial Footing Is Rocky, Central Bank Says
text: Money markets in the euro zone continue to function unevenly while the overall volume of transactions has declined from last year, data released by the European Central Bank indicated on Thursday. It was a reminder that the banking system remains fragile.

headline: Friday: Some Choice Words
text: An interesting-looking grid is always worth a few style points, so today’s was ahead of the game before I even started.

headline: The Weather Was Perfect for Outrage
text: The police were looking for suspicious characters, but the 10-foot-tall Ahmadinejad pretender dancing to rap music with a fake missile strapped to his back did not qualify. No, he was comfortably within the realm of normal at demonstration central.

headline: Who’s Afraid of Fluid Gender and Time?
text: We’ve all had a strange night’s sleep now and then. But it would be hard to top the transformation that overtakes the slumbering title character of Virginia Woolf’s novel “Orlando” after an evening of heady debauchery in 17th-century Constantinople. As admirers of the book will recall, the young English nobleman goes to bed one night a duke and wakes up a duchess.

headline: Senate Democrats Delay a Vote on Bush Tax Cuts
text: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats said Thursday that they would postpone a highly contentious floor fight over what to do about the expiring Bush-era tax cuts until after the November elections, a decision that spares some politically vulnerable incumbents from casting a potentially difficult vote to let taxes rise for the rich.

headline: Schools Run by Newark May Yet Reflect Christie’s Vision
text: Handed new power to reinvigorate the Newark school system, Mayor Cory A. Booker is likely to push for politically charged ideas like more charter schools, aid for private-school tuition and linking teacher pay to student performance, according to people who have worked with the mayor and followed his career and comments on education.

headline: Cleaner, Healthier Cookstoves
text: Here is a shocking statistic: nearly two million people  mostly women and children  in the developing world die annually from illnesses brought on by breathing toxic smoke from indoor cooking stoves. The Obama administration is rightly doing something about it.

headline: Battered Economy in Ireland Contracts 1.2%
text: LONDON  Already reeling from a banking crisis that is threatening its financial credibility, Ireland suffered another setback on Thursday when fresh data showed that its ailing economy shrank 1.2 percent in the second quarter.

headline: Adoption Struggles
text: There’s no denying that the acting in “Like Dandelion Dust,” an adoption drama directed by Jon Gunn from a novel by Karen Kingsbury, is superb.

headline: Pakistani Sentenced to 86 Years for Attack
text: A Pakistani neuroscientist who was convicted of trying to kill American soldiers and F.B.I. agents in Afghanistan was sentenced to 86 years in prison on Thursday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Huge Wind Turbine Farm Opens Off Coast of Southeast England
text: LONDON  The world’s largest offshore wind turbine farm, with a capacity to power more than 200,000 homes for a year, opened on Thursday off the coast of southeast England.

headline: YouTube Can’t Be Liable on Copyright, Spain Rules
text: A Spanish court on Thursday sided with Google in a dispute with the broadcaster Telecinco, saying Google’s online video-sharing service, YouTube, did not have to screen television clips for potential copyright violations before posting them on the site.

headline: Long Recovery for a Yankees Pitching Prospect
text: Tommy John surgery has been mostly a boon to pitchers. Sometimes, it is said, they return even better than they were before the surgery.

headline: The Responsibility Deficit
text: One of the oddities of the current moment is that the country wants a radical change in government but not a radical change in policy.

headline: Snickers Greet Premiere of Afghan Film
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghans proved a tough audience for the world premiere of “The Black Tulip” at the Ariana Cinema on Thursday afternoon (an evening showing was deemed too dangerous). It was meant to be a serious film about Afghanistan, by an Afghan-born director, set in present-day Kabul and even filmed on location here, but many of the Afghans who saw it said they did not recognize the society they knew.

headline: Downhill With the G.O.P.
text: Once upon a time, a Latin American political party promised to help motorists save money on gasoline. How? By building highways that ran only downhill.

headline: Brothers Compete to Lead Labour Party in Britain
text: LONDON  Ever since the Labour Party’s defeat in May’s general election, a group of five candidates to succeed the former party leader, Gordon Brown, have been crisscrossing Britain, debating at more than 60 party gatherings and seeking to persuade the party’s huge electoral college that they can inspire a regeneration of the party after 13 exhausting years in power.

headline: A Dreamlike Tale of a Gay Hustler
text: “I like adventure,” says the boyish gay hustler (Ben Bonenfant) at the heart of “Strapped,” Joseph Graham’s dreamlike debut feature. The statement may or may not be true, but it helps fabricate the persona of the moment: what makes this particular young man desirable — aside from a guileless face, a knowing body and a sweet disposition — is the facility to morph into whomever his customer most desires.

headline: A Day of Protests
text: On another rackety day of dissent at Dag Hammarskjold Plaza in New York, various groups decried world leaders appearing at the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: British Cuts to Military Concern U.S. Officials
text: WASHINGTON  Plans by the British government to make significant cuts in defense spending have spurred concerns among American military experts about Britain’s ability to carry out its role as the United States’ most dependable ally.

headline: A Fight to Preserve Tibetan Music
text: Ngawang Choephel, a Tibetan musicologist who was imprisoned by the Chinese for more than six years, would have had a compelling film had he simply stuck to his own remarkable story. But his documentary, “Tibet in Song,” is doubly powerful because he also weaves in the overall history of Tibet’s struggle, a primer on the Chinese government’s campaign to muzzle Tibetan culture and vignettes from other Tibetans who resisted.

headline: Transit Court Should Have Translators, Group Says
text: New Yorkers who speak little or no English are being illegally denied interpreters in transit court, often leaving them at a disadvantage as they try to fight summonses for littering, fare beating and other violations, the New York Civil Liberties Union charged on Thursday.

headline: Brief Films About Staying Off the Wagon
text: Three short films that probably need “don’t try this at home” warnings constitute a nutty, nicely conceived bill at the ReRun Gastropub Theater in Brooklyn. “Liquor and Drugs” is the program’s subtitle, and liquor and drugs are used and abused rather a lot in the films, which don’t exactly issue ringing endorsements of moderation.

headline: A.L. Cy Young Race Tightens
text: The Tampa Bay Rays did more than batter C.C. Sabathia and the Yankees on Thursday night. They might have also decided the American League Cy Young Award.

headline: The Founding Fathers Versus the Tea Party
text: LIKE many popular insurgencies in American history, the Tea Party movement has attempted to enlist the founding fathers as fervent adherents to its cause. The very name invokes those disguised patriots who clambered aboard ships in Boston Harbor in December 1773 and dumped chests of tea into the water rather than submit to the hated tea tax. At Tea Party rallies, marchers brandish flags emblazoned with the Revolutionary slogan “Don’t Tread on Me” while George Washington impersonators and other folks in colonial garb mingle with the crowds.

headline: A Musical by the Bay
text: If nothing else, “Fruit Fly” desperately wants to please. A musical on a threadbare budget, the film gamely reaches for the stars, but is hamstrung by its constraints, not all of which derive from a lack of funds.

headline: Rebels’ Second in Command Has Been Killed, Colombia Says
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombia’s security forces killed the second in command of Latin America’s largest rebel group in an elaborate bombing raid in the country’s remote Macarena mountain range, the government said Thursday, dealing a major blow to a four-decade insurgency that had re-emerged with new vigor in recent months.

headline: Sabathia Struggles as Yankees Limp to Finish
text: Even before reliever Javier Vazquez hit three consecutive Tampa Bay batters in the seventh inning Thursday night, the game had unraveled into something like a spring-training exhibition for the Yankees.

headline: China Arrests Four Japanese Amid Tensions
text: BEIJING  In what could be another sign of rising tensions between Japan and China, the authorities here said Thursday that four Japanese had been arrested for videotaping military installations.

headline: India Rushes to Finish Work to Host Games
text: NEW DELHI  India on Thursday began a last-minute blitz to rescue the Commonwealth Games, as Prime Minister Manmohan Singh convened an emergency meeting with sports officials, and cleanup and construction crews rushed to finish preparations with only nine days remaining before the opening ceremony.

headline: Film Series and Movie Listings
text: Movies

headline: Woman, 41, Is Executed in Virginia
text: A woman convicted of orchestrating a plot that led to the murders of her husband and stepson was executed in Virginia Thursday night, becoming the first woman executed in the state in almost a century.

headline: Folk Music, as Close to Nature as It Gets
text: When Britt Govea, a marketing manager at a TV station in Monterey and a record buff, started taking hikes around the California coast, he never imagined that he could get his musical heroes to play in tiny venues nestled in tall redwoods. But on an epic outing in Big Sur in 2004 while walking around the forest with his headphones on, he had a revelation.

headline: Timetable for Education Guidelines
text: The United States Department of Education said it would announce a new timetable Friday for releasing the final version of regulations aimed at the for-profit higher-education industry  and education groups are expecting a postponement of the “gainful employment” rule, a controversial rule cutting off federal student aid to programs whose students have the highest debt burdens and lowest loan-repayment rates. The department received about 90,000 public comments on the rule this summer, double the previous record. To give it time to review those comments and refine the rule  now the object of intense lobbying  the department is likely to put off releasing the final rule until after Nov. 1, the deadline for rules’ going into effect, delaying its effective date until 2012. However, because full enforcement of the gainful employment rule was not scheduled to start until 2012, the delay would have little practical effect.

headline: Making History, Twice, at Grace Cathedral
text: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

headline: North Carolina: Group Protests Planned Religious Rally at Fort Bragg
text: Americans United for Separation of Church and State has sent a letter to the Secretary of the Army saying it is unconstitutional for the military to hold an evangelistic rally scheduled for Fort Bragg this Saturday. The event is sponsored by the base’s chaplains, local churches and the Billy Graham Evangelistic Association, now led by the famous evangelist’s son, the Rev. Franklin Graham. The Rev. Barry W. Lynn, executive director of Americans United, said, “It is not the Army’s job to convert Americans to Christianity.”

headline: Bloggingheads: Those Crazy G.O.P. Women!
text: Katherine Mangu-Ward of Reason and Stephen Spruiell of National Review discuss the public perception of prominent conservative women.

headline: Judiciary Panel Reapproves 4 Nominees to Federal Courts
text: The Senate Judiciary Committee approved four of President Obama’s nominees to federal courts for a second time Thursday after Republicans used a delaying tactic last month to send their names back to the White House. The panel voted 12 to 7 along party lines to reapprove Prof. Goodwin Liu of the University of California at Berkeley for the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The committee also voted in favor of three district court nominees: Edward Chen in California, Louis Butler in Wisconsin and John McConnell Jr. in Rhode Island. The votes split along party lines, with the exception of Mr. McConnell, who was supported by one Republican, Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina.

headline: Use of Midwives Rises, Challenging the State to Respond
text: After three “really traumatic” hospital births, Alyssa Ruben was determined to have her fourth child at home. She hired a midwife, and eight months later, Ms. Ruben delivered a healthy baby girl at her home in Geneva.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: The Jackson Star Has Dimmed, but It’s Still Shining
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Agencies Vie to Make City a Power Hub
text: Todd Dore never worries whether there will be room at the two-space electric-car-charging station in the downtown garage where he juices up his converted VW Beetle after commuting from the western suburbs.

headline: Two Jazz Greats, Tightly Bound by Chicago
text: Rudresh Mahanthappa grew up in Boulder, Colo., attended the Berklee College of Music in Boston and lives in New York. But talking about his trip to Chicago, where he plays the Jazz Showcase this weekend, he sounded like a man heading home.

headline: Word of the Day | correlation
text: correlation •\ˌkȯr-ə-ˈla-shən, ˌkär-\• noun

headline: Disney’s Internet Chief Resigns
text: The Walt Disney Company’s top Internet executive, Steve Wadsworth, resigned late Thursday following a difficult tenure in which Disney’s Web strategy underwent repeated retrenchments.

headline: Gus Bevona, Ex-Union Chief, Dies at 69
text: Gus Bevona, whose persona as a hefty, blunt-talking, boss-denouncing throwback to old-time labor leaders helped him make janitors, handymen and elevator operators in New York City apartment and office buildings the highest paid in the nation, died Tuesday. He was 69.

headline: Wayne Winterrowd, Gardening Expert, Dies at 68
text: Wayne Winterrowd, a gardening expert who wrote widely about the subject, designed gardens for others across the United States and spent more than 30 years building a seven-acre garden in southern Vermont that draws visitors from all over the world, died on Sept. 17 at his home in Readsboro, Vt. He was 68.

headline: Jack Kershaw Is Dead at 96; Challenged Conviction in King’s Death
text: Jack Kershaw, who represented James Earl Ray as he fought to overturn his conviction in the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., arguing that Ray was an innocent participant in a conspiracy led by a mysterious figure named Raul, died Sept. 7. in Nashville. He was 96.

headline: Calling Paladino a ‘Welfare King’
text: This 30-second television advertisement — titled “One Job?” — is the third for Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democrat, in his campaign for governor of New York. His Republican challenger is Carl P. Paladino, a Buffalo businessman and developer. The Cuomo campaign declined to specify where the advertisement would run, on what channels or at what cost.

headline: Stuart E. Hample, Humorist and Cartoonist, Dies at 84
text: Stuart E. Hample, a humorist who entertained children (and adults) as an author, playwright, adman, performer and cartoonist (and probably a few other things besides), died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Howard Brodie, 94, Combat and Courtroom Artist, Dies
text: Howard Brodie, a noted combat artist during World War II who went on to sketch some of the most famous courtroom dramas of the postwar era, including the trials of the Chicago Seven, Charles Manson and Patty Hearst, died on Sunday at his home near Parkfield, Calif. He was 94.

headline: News Quiz | September 24, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: S.E.C. Nears a Setback on Disclosure
text: The House on Thursday repealed a section of the recently passed Dodd-Frank Act that let the Securities and Exchange Commission keep secret nearly all information it gathers during investigations, Edward Wyatt reports in The New York Times.

headline: Battered Irish Economy Contracts 1.2 Percent
text: Already reeling from a banking crisis that is threatening its financial credibility, Ireland suffered another setback on Thursday when fresh data showed that its ailing economy shrank 1.2 percent in the second quarter, Landon Thomas Jr. reports in The New York Times.

headline: Frederick Jelinek, Who Gave Machines the Key to Human Speech, Dies at 77
text: Frederick Jelinek, who survived the Nazi occupation of Czechoslovakia to become a pioneer in computer research in America, helping to make it possible for computers to decipher and translate human speech, died on Sept. 14 in Baltimore. He was 77.

text: From Floyd Norris’s latest column in The New York Times:

headline: Europe’s Financial Footing Is Rocky, E.C.B. Says
text: Money markets in the euro zone continue to function unevenly while the overall volume of transactions has declined from last year, data released by the European Central Bank indicated on Thursday. It was a reminder that the banking system remains fragile, Jack Ewing writes in The New York Times.

headline: BHP Bid for Potash Clears Antitrust Hurdle
text: BHP Billiton has cleared the first regulatory hurdle in its bid for Canada’s Potash Corporation., but any potential deal still faces major regulatory obstacles, especially within Canada.

headline: Fragmented Stock Markets Seen Due for Pruning
text: The 50 some locations where U.S. stocks can now trade are due for a pruning, industry executives said on Thursday, citing both free market forces and new rules expected in the wake of the May “flash crash,” Reuters reported.

headline: Japan Retreats With Release of Chinese Boat Captain
text: TOKYO — A diplomatic showdown between Japan and China that began two weeks ago with the arrest of the captain of a Chinese trawler near disputed islands ended Friday when Tokyo accepted Beijing’s demands for his immediate release, a concession that appeared to mark a humiliating retreat in a Pacific test of wills.

text: Today’s word, in association with the dependable Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Test Yourself | History, Sept. 24, 2010
text: Test your knowledge of history with today’s question about the the Brooklyn Dodgers.
