headline: Eastern Promises
text: When David Lynch and Frank Gehry made headlines last year for their involvement in two multimillion-dollar cultural centers in the economically downtrodden city of Lodz, Poland, confusion ran high. What could they possibly see in the so-called Manchester of Poland? In fact, Lodz is undergoing something of a creative rebirth. The city has begun turning its 19th-century textile buildings into new-economy hubs — a case in point is the Manufaktura complex (Ogrodowa Street), home to a museum and the city’s first upscale design hotel, Andel’s. Lodz is also financing cultural festivals and programs aimed at retaining local art school grads, and once a planned high-speed rail slashes the Warsaw commute to 35 minutes, they’ll have one more reason to stay put.

headline: Instapaper Goes From Hobby to Start-Up
text: From Nick Bilton at Bits:

headline: Small-Business Bill Advances
text: A Democratic plan to aid small businesses was approved by the House on Thursday and sent to President Obama for his signature.

headline: Vultures to Benefit From Stricter Capital Rules?
text: Stricter capital rules for banks could benefit distressed debt investors hoping to buy loans at a discount as lenders try to lighten their books, Reuters said, citing industry insiders.

headline: Banks Sitting Out Bond Surge as Lending Dries Up
text: Banks are sitting out the busiest September for corporate bond sales in a sign they may refrain from lending while the Federal Reserve considers how to jolt the economic recovery, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: CoreSite Realty Flat in Debut
text: Shares of CoreSite Realty, backed by founders of The Carlyle Group, remained relatively flat in their market debut, after the data center owner and manager raised about $270.4 million in its initial public offering.

headline: Stepping Back From Towering Heels
text: (View more accessories from Milan.)

headline: E.U. Hedge Fund Law Looms for Commercial Real Estate
text: Europe’s commercial real estate owners, saddled with 1.9 trillion euros ($2.5 trillion) of debt, may be forced to make billions of euros in cash payments under planned laws that would treat them like hedge funds, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Credit Suisse Team to Start Blackstone-Backed Fund
text: A senior Credit Suisse commodity executive and a team of traders have left the bank to set up a hedge fund backed by the Blackstone Group, the latest shake-up resulting from tough financial reform.

headline: Madoff Trustee Mistreating Victims, Lawmakers Say
text: Investors who fell victim to Bernard L. Madoff’s $65 billion Ponzi scheme should not be forced to return profits they believed they had legitimately made, U.S. lawmakers said on Thursday.

headline: Singapore’s Olam in Deal Talks With Louis Dreyfus
text: Is Olam International, the Singapore-based commodity trader, heading for a merger with French rival Louis Dreyfus Commodities?

headline: Oracle Isn’t Interested in Services Deals, Chief Says
text: Oracle‘s chief executive, Larry Ellison, says his company won’t follow one of the technology world’s hottest trends: buying services companies.

headline: Petrobras Raises $70 Billion in Share Issue
text: Petroleo Brasileiro, the Brazilian oil and gas giant, on Thursday raised 120.36 billion reais in the largest share issue ever, arming it with the cash needed to realize an ambitious offshore development plan.

headline: The Vatican Museums Come Alive at Night
text: Visiting the Vatican Museums after hours used to be a rare privilege enjoyed at great expense — think 275 euros (about $350) a person for a two-hour group tour. Strolling the galleries at twilight and basking in the glory of the Sistine Chapel without all the tour groups and daytime hordes is an extraordinary experience, even for the veteran traveler. Last fall, such experiences became a  lot more accessible when the Vatican Museums began organizing Friday night visits from 7 to 11  at the affordable price of 19 euros (about $24.30) per person.

headline: The Perennial Quest to Lower Health Care Spending
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Chanos Plans to Spend Film Fee on ‘Acting Lessons’
text: Is James Chanos planning a second act in Hollywood?

headline: McClure Creates Fund for Twilio Start-Ups
text: From VentureBeat:

headline: Woody Paige Writes About Being Saved From Suicide
text: Most sports fans know Woody Paige as the goofy, impassioned, mischievous panelist on ESPN’s “Around the Horn.”

headline: Buffett to Talk Tough to China’s BYD?
text: Is Warren E. Buffett mulling a move to sell down some of his holdings in BYD Company?

headline: With 64% of Dana, KNOC Makes Bid ‘Unconditional’
text: Korea National Oil Corporation said it had taken control of Dana Petroleum, paving the way for the biggest hostile acquisition by a South Korean firm, and increasing the country’s oil reserves, Reuters reported.

headline: They Want Their MTV, and to Read, Too
text: Today’s idea: Music videos with subtitles in the viewers’ spoken language can help the illiterate learn to read, an experiment in India suggests.

headline: India Rushes to Finish Work to Host Games
text: NEW DELHI  India was beginning a last-minute blitz to rescue the Commonwealth Games, after Prime Minister Manmohan Singh convened an emergency meeting with sports officials, and cleanup and construction crews rushed to finish preparations with only nine days remaining before the opening ceremony.

headline: Vale Announces Buyback and Hong Kong Listing
text: Vale, the Brazilian mining company, said on Thursday its cash generating ability would allow it to buy back up to $2 billion in shares and return to investors $2.75 billion over the next five months, Reuters reported.

headline: Week 3 N.F.L. Matchups
text: Cowboys (0-2) at Texans (2-0)Sunday, 1 p.m.Line: Texans by 3

headline: CSG Systems to Buy Britain’s Intec for $317 Million
text: CSG Systems International, a United States provider of billing services to cable-television operators, has agreed to buy Britain’s Intec Telecom Systems for £236.7 million ($371 million), Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Clinton: Where Have All the Hedge Funds Gone?
text: Former President Bill Clinton said he has noticed that few hedge-fund managers attended his four-day conference aimed at linking philanthropists with groups working to spur economic development around the world.

headline: Gennadi I. Yanayev, 73, Soviet Coup Plotter, Dies
text: MOSCOW Gennadi I. Yanayev, a former Soviet apparatchik who was part of a short-lived  coup in 1991 that hastened the fall of the Soviet Union, died Friday in Moscow, according to Russian news reports. He was 73.

headline: McLaren Calls New Model a Building Block for a New Look
text: Executives for McLaren brought their new model MP4-12C to show off in Manhattan last week.

headline: F.S.A. to Defend Funds Against ‘Misguided’ Pay Rules
text: British hedge funds may have been heartened by comments made Thursday by a regulator at the Financial Services Authority, who said that the F.S.A. was ready to defend them against “misguided European regulations” on compensation.

headline: At Film Festival, Social Media and Goats
text: A. O. Scott narrates a look at the first week of the New York Film Festival.

headline: Koreas Fail to Reach Deal on Reunions
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Red Cross officials from North and South Korea met Friday in the North Korean border town of Kaesong but failed to reach an agreement about restarting reunions between families separated by the Korean War.

headline: Q&A Tip of the Week: Easy Listening
text: Most online music stores offer a free 30-second sample of each song for sale, which is a great way to make sure you’re buying the right song. If you’re album shopping and want to get a taste of each track without having to click constantly, look for a button than lets you listen to a sample from every song.

headline: In Delaware, Castle Calculates the Write-In Odds
text: Representative Mike Castle, Republican of Delaware, has a few more days to decide whether to follow the lead of Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, and begin a write-in bid for the United States Senate.

headline: Signs of Stability Help Extend September’s Rally
text: Wall Street continued its September rally and closed higher for a fourth week on Friday, with industrial and financial stocks climbing more than 2 percent after new statistics were interpreted as a sign the economy could be stabilizing.

headline: European League Soccer Matchups
text: The outstanding matchups in European league soccer this weekend:

headline: Blackstone Says $10 Billion Buyout Possible
text: The Blackstone Group said on Thursday that the debt markets have recovered to such an extent that it should be possible for a $10 billion leveraged buyout deal to happen soon, Reuters reported.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: — Yves Smith reviews “Inside Job,” the financial crisis documentary by Charles Ferguson.

headline: When a Drug Battle Spells Extinction
text: The drug trade and other domestic strife are wreaking havoc on Colombia’s dwindling population of indigenous peoples while also threatening the integrity of the country’s biologically diverse forests, the United Nations High Council on Refugees reported this week.

headline: Sunny and Warm, With a Strong Possibility of Vitriol
text: Thursday was a rackety day of dissent at Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, a leafy oasis opposite the United Nations, as this group or that group had its permissible moment to decry one of the world leaders appearing at the annual General Assembly session. The weather was spectacular, N. R. Kleinfield reports, making for a very good day for vitriol.

headline: Rajaratnam: From Boastful Beginnings to Bail
text: Raj Rajaratnam is “a man of Falstaffian appetites and a craving for power,” Forbes writes, in a profile of the former billionaire Galleon hedge fund manager arrested last October and charged with running the largest insider-trading ring busted since the 1980s.

headline: In France, Monet Is Rediscovered
text: PARIS — In the city where his art was once ridiculed as unworthy of wallpaper, Claude Monet is making a showy comeback. He is being lionized in two expansive exhibitions in Paris this season, and two French museums — the Musée d’Orsay and the Musée Marmottan Monet — have been feuding over his mythic painting of a misty orange and gray sunrise.

headline: Toward a Grand Unified Theory of the NBC Sitcom
text: At the end of the 2009-2010 television season we said farewell to NBC’s Thursday-night comedy lineup by noting how eerily similar the season finales of the network’s sitcoms were. But what looked like mere coincidence in May is now starting to look like the guiding hand of some larger instrument, as “Community,” “30 Rock” and “The Office” returned on Thursday night with similar jokes that can only point toward their convergence into one identical show.

headline: Volcker Says the ‘Financial System Is Broken’
text: The financial system is still at risk even after an overhaul of financial regulation in the United States and new capital requirements for international banks, says Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve and an adviser to President Obama.

headline: The Place | A Guide to Marrakesh, Part Four
text: Steamy AffairThere’s no better way to end a day of dodging mopeds and vendors in the souks than a long steam at a hammam. The smell of roses emanating from the spa at Amanjena resort is so intoxicating that you’ll quickly find yourself supine in the steam room. Choose from services that include a four-handed massage and a scrub-down with local products like black Moroccan soap and sesame seeds. Route de Ouarzazate; 011-212-524-39-90-00.

headline: The Early Word: Chinese Currency
text: After a busy Thursday at the United Nations, President Obama’s last day on his trip to New York is to include a working lunch with Southeast Asian leaders and a meeting dealing with Sudan.

headline: Family Donates Probert’s Brain for Head Trauma Research
text: ¶ The family of Bob Probert, the Red Wings and Blackhawks enforcer who died last June at 45, have agreed to donate Probert’s brain to Boston University researchers studying the health effects of repeated head trauma in athletes. “I know Dani and Bob had spoken about it prior to his passing,” Daniel Parkinson, whose daughter Dani was married to Probert, tells AOL FanHouse. “I know he wanted to advance the research.” Last year B.U.’s Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy released results of its study of the brain of Reggie Fleming, which showed the same kind of damage as that experienced by boxers and football players. Probert died of an apparent heart attack while boating on Lake St. Clair.

headline: Complaint Box | Misnomers Run Amok
text: “Can I help the next guest?”

headline: Europe’s Investment Banker Hegemony
text: 2:56 p.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Landon Thomas Jr. and Julia Werdigier provide more details of the management shakeup at HSBC.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Carlos’
text: A.O. Scott analyzes an excerpt from Olivier Assayas’s new film.

headline: A New Kind of Cineaste
text: 'You are now in French territory.'

headline: Deception at the Farmers’ Market
text: Is the produce you buy at your local farmers’ market really grown locally?

headline: Friday Reading: Diabetes Drug Gets New Restrictions
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Getting the Most From Your Wok
text: Grace Young, whose most recent cookbook is “Stir-Frying to the Sky’s Edge,” from Simon and Schuster, recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers’ questions about healthful stir-fry cooking.

headline: Donegality
text: A term to describe a story’s unique essence or atmosphere.

headline: The Insider | Laura Holmes
text: Whether it’s connecting a photographer with a stylist or finding the right location or editor, Laura Holmes puts all the fashion pieces together. Since leaving the London creative production company Gainsbury and Whiting, where she worked with Alexander McQueen, to set up her namesake company, Holmes has made a niche for herself in the worlds of photography and film production and has become the go-to girl for creatives like Sharif Hamza, who shot the most recent cover of Dazed & Confused. Holmes’s recent projects include two films with Katie Grand for Love magazine’s new iPad app and one with Alasdair McLellan and Dree Hemingway.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: Head Screws On, Head Screws Off
text: A creator who can conjure up a hero who exists as a disembodied head that is employed by Abraham Lincoln to battle an archvillain named Emperor Zombie would seem to have enough material to fill a dozen comic books.

headline: Father Exposure
text: I work for a charity selling donated goods. An acquaintance brought in items of his late father’s. Slipped inside a book of poetry was a letter from a lover ending what was clearly an extramarital affair. My instinct is to destroy it, but the father did save it for years and left it where he must have known his children would find it. The mother is dead, so it can’t hurt her. And perhaps the son is aware of the affair. Should I give the children the letter? NAME WITHHELD, NEW JERSEY

headline: The Empowerment Mystique
text: True confession: at age 16, I performed in a high-school production of the musical “Free to Be . . . You and Me,” dressed in Mork-from-Ork rainbow suspenders and matching toe socks. Our troupe defended William’s right to a doll and explained why Mommies were People, too, at every elementary school in St. Louis Park, Minn.; I can still recite “Don’t Dress Your Cat in an Apron.” So early last month, when I heard the familiar lilt of the New Seekers’ voices (“Come with me, take my hand, and we’ll liiiii-IIIIVE . . .”) emanating from the TV in my den, I dashed in, already singing along.

headline: The Mistaken Mushroom
text: I started hunting wild mushrooms after an operation to save my left eye, a consequence of 27-inning August softball madness. My retina detached in protest of my being dehydrated and 52 and running around crashing into people. A week after the operation, I was allowed to walk around but was only supposed to look down.

headline: Time Is Money
text: What a relief it has been to relinquish the modernist obsession with clockwork — the 9-to-5 workday, the TV grid, the wristwatches with second hands, the regimented lives measured out with coffee spoons.

headline: Take a Look at Him Now
text: Although you are known best as an English drummer and the frontman of the defunct rock band Genesis, your new album, “Going Back,” consists mostly of Motown hits from the ’60s. Do you see the album as an exercise in pure nostalgia?  I suppose you can’t argue that it isn’t. It’s not melancholy, though. These are the songs that I grew up with and heard my favorite bands do, and I always wanted to sing them.

headline: Carrot Talk
text: We know junk food when we see it, and maybe we know something else, too: It’s delicious! Feel free to reject that point of view if you like, but farmers who grow carrots have decided to embrace it. As a group, they hired an advertising agency that has landed on a strategy of promoting the root vegetable as if it were junk food. Most notably, they sell baby carrots in plastic bags that explicitly reference processed snacks, like Doritos. Related tongue-in-cheek TV spots end by pointing out that baby carrots now come in “junk-food packaging.”

headline: Limited Blogging Today
text: Dealing with parental health issues.

headline: The Bias of the Generic Ballot: It’s Complicated
text: Henry Olsen at National Review Online has a smart critique up on my observation that the generic Congressional ballot may underestimate Democrats’ standing in House races this year. Let me warn you up front: this post is going to get into some fairly technical issues.

headline: Britain’s F.S.A. to Bankers: Stop Leaking
text: It may make folks in our business unhappy, but the Financial Services Authority is telling British bankers to clam up about pending deals.

headline: Jonathan Klein to Leave CNN
text: Jonathan Klein, the president of the beleaguered CNN/U.S. cable channel, is being replaced by Ken Jautz, the head of the tabloid-oriented sister channel HLN, the company said Friday.

headline: Kimberly Nichols, Peter Donaghy III
text: Kimberly Ellen Ann Nichols, a daughter of Nancy Rabstejnek Nichols of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Ronald E. Nichols, was married Saturday evening to Peter James Donaghy III, the son of Angela S. Donaghy and Mr. Donaghy Jr. of Yonkers. The Rev. Dr. Fred R. Anderson officiated at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, where he is the pastor. The Rev. John J. Mattimore, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

headline: Gibbs: Our Defense of Don’t-Ask Is Pro Forma
text: How sensitive is the White House to charges that President Obama has not done enough to push for an end to the military’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” ban on gays serving openly in the armed forces?

headline: Hertz Declares Its Dollar Thrifty Bid ‘Best and Final’
text: Hertz Global Holdings is standing by its deal to acquire the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, even after the Avis Budget Group unveiled on Thursday what it described as a significantly higher offer.

headline: The Power of the Pocketbook
text: In an essay in the New York Times Magazine this weekend, my colleague Peggy Orenstein notes a change in the message that some marketers are aiming at girls. Or, more likely, at the mothers of girls. From the Target spot that paints back-to-school clothes as empowering with music from “Free to Be, You and Me” to the Verizon ad that shows bright-eyed, young women announcing, “I can lead the army that will follow,” advertisers are selling girls as strong and powerful.

headline: Nocturnalist | Justice Is Served. For Some, as a Diversion.
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: Who Gets to Set Earth’s Thermostat?
text: There’s a useful package of pieces in Slate (related to a meeting on Monday) exploring aspects of the intensifying debate over “geo-engineering,” the batch of methods proposed as ways to counter global warming with artificial cooling.

headline: A Few Minutes With the Margaret Mead of ‘Mad Men’
text: Elisabeth Moss has certainly been a topic of conversation lately, possibly because of her acting work, which earned her a second consecutive Emmy Award-nomination for her performance on “Mad Men,” or possibly because of articles like this one. This particular interview is going to address only one of those two topics; before a recent conversation with ArtsBeat, Ms. Moss let us know she would not discuss her personal life. But hey, why let 15 minutes of telephone time go to waste? Ms. Moss was still game to talk about her recent role in the comedy “Get Him to the Greek,” in which she played the long-suffering girlfriend of a hapless record-label flunky played by Jonah Hill (and which will receive a DVD release on Tuesday). And of course she was open to discussing Peggy Olson, her “Mad Men” alter ego, who in just four seasons has gone from a timid new hire to an ambitious, pot-smoking, clothes-shedding, lesbian-befriending, dead-executive-secretary-poking young copywriter.

headline: Citigroup Sued by Norway’s Central Bank
text: Norway’s central bank has sued Citigroup over $835 million in losses on Citi shares and bonds.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Prada
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of ioulex.

headline: Walt Frazier Buys Three Harlem Penthouses
text: WALT FRAZIER had settled into semiretirement on St. Croix, V.I., living in a vacation home he found decades ago. He spent much of his time there creating elaborate gardens with the indigenous plants, and he bought five acres and built and renovated 10 houses that he rents out.

headline: Protests in Pakistan at Long Jail Term for Scientist in U.S.
text: Protesters took to the streets of cities across Pakistan on Friday, calling on their government to intervene in the case of Aafia Siddiqui, an American-educated Pakistani scientist who was sentenced to 86 years in jail on Thursday in New York.

headline: In Search of a Good Wine List
text: The Internet has been a great boon for wine lovers, not least for offering the opportunity to scan wine lists online in advance, relieving us of the awkward social withdrawal at the table for the task of wine selection. But Internet wine lists can also come back to bite you.

headline: Week in Pictures, Sept. 24
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

headline: Qatar Signals Intention to Invest in Greece
text: Greece has signed a preliminary deal with Qatar’s sovereign wealth fund that could clear the way for investments of up to $5 billion in the indebted European country, officials said Friday.

headline: Tea Party Convention Is Canceled
text: The Tea Party is off.

headline: Zucker Announces Departure From NBC
text: Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, told the company’s employees in an e-mail Friday morning that he would step down from his position upon the completion of the takeover of NBC by Comcast.

headline: There’s Something About Quinoa
text: During my recent interview with Martha Rose Shulman about her new Recipes for Health cookbook, she mentioned that she had just finished cooking up some new quinoa dishes. Although she has written about the grain before, she realized there was more to say — and eat.

headline: ‘Aftershock’
text: Chapter One: Eccles's Insight

headline: Fairer Deal
text: Way way back, which means before the financial sector imploded, it wasn’t Wall Street bonuses and vampire squids that excited the most fury. People agonized, instead, about the stagnation of middle-class incomes and exploding inequality. In “Aftershock” — impressively, his 12th book — Robert B. Reich steers our attention back to those earlier worries, which have arguably become more urgent in the wake of the financial crisis. But right on the first page, he comes close to blowing it.

headline: Ply the Pen
text: For a poet, life after the Nobel can be pottering, or bookkeeping, or simply keeping busy — it’s rarely full of radical departures or stunning new poems. (Eliot called the prize a “ticket to one’s own funeral,” and indeed it proved the funeral of his poetry.) Even pottering can be difficult when you are constantly in demand to judge this prize or sign that public letter, to give a blurb to old X or a recommendation to young Y. For a poet, all life can be a distraction from the siren call of the page. When you read that Seamus ­Heaney has a secretary to help him answer correspondence, you wish he had half a dozen, and perhaps a few armed guards. Yet apart from Pasternak, who was bullied by his government, no poet has ever turned down the poisoned chalice.

headline: Calculating the Castle Write-In Bid
text: Lisa Murkowski, who has decided to run a write-in campaign for the Senate, may soon have some company. Representative Mike Castle, the moderate Delaware Republican who was upended by Christine O’Donnell in the primary, is also said to be considering a write-in bid. Although both Mr. Castle and his advisers have characterized a bid as unlikely, his interest is serious enough that he’s commissioned a poll, according to reporting by Politico.

headline: Obsession
text: To enter the world of the crime writer James Ellroy, one must accept a certain degree of time warp. His prose clings to the underbelly of mid-20th-century modern, a place that the era’s celebrated advertising doesn’t even reach — where men are men and women are cocktail waitresses; where shady characters of both sexes screech in hot rods from dive bars to no-tell motels and back again. The genre is noir, and it has its own argot (noir-got?). People don’t divorce; they “split the sheets.” They “pitch boohoo” rather than merely cry, and become “stiff” in all senses of the word: awkward, engorged with desire and then dead.

headline: They Did What?
text: Scandal has never had it so good: typically ogled, mocked, knocked down and dismissed, it’s at last being graciously invited to lie down on the couch. In “How to Become a Scandal,” Laura Kipnis delivers consumers of high and low culture that rare twofer, taking material that self-respecting people are supposed to resist and treating it with such smarts that the reader feels nothing short of enlightened. Her book is filled with sensational subjects (Eliot Spitzer, Linda Tripp, James Frey and that notorious astronaut with the diaper), but Kipnis delivers all the thrills.

headline: Great Muppet Caper Continues as Elmo Defends Katy Perry
text: In circumstances George Stephanopoulos probably never imagined when he gave up a hands-on role in politics to become a broadcaster, two fuzzy, nonhuman members of the “Sesame Street” cast joined him Friday morning on “Good Morning America,” along with that PBS children’s show’s executive producer, Carol-Lynn Parente, to discuss the recent decision at “Sesame Street” to pull a music video featuring the pop singer Katy Perry.

headline: Blood Ties
text: For roughly the last half-century, nearly every black female writer of any consequence in America seems to have had one very particular story to tell — or, rather, one particular question she’s tried to answer: Just how in heaven (or hell) have black women managed to survive? How, that is, were great-­grandmothers not completely destroyed by enslavement, grandmothers not irreparably broken by bigotry, mothers not wholly defeated by loneliness? How have black women in this country kept on doing battle with everything, for what seems like forever, without falling apart? And what toll has this taken on their daughters? From Margaret Walker to Octavia Butler, Sherley Anne Williams, Toni Morrison and Gayl Jones, to name only a few, America’s black female authors have tried to make sense of a difficult present by writing bridges to the traumas of the past.

headline: Film Has Two Big Names and a Dog, but No Big Screens
text: In the animal kingdom of Hollywood, there is still an audience for movies whose casts feature Richard Gere, and for films directed by Lasse Hallstrom. And since time immemorial  or at least since the 1943 release of “Lassie Come Home”  there has been a loyal viewership for pictures about dogs and their unflagging fidelity to their human companions.

headline: Poetic Justice
text: Imagine Stephen Dedalus in a fiction workshop surrounded by 20-something neophytes. Better yet, picture Huck Finn, having lit out for the territory, handing sections of his new memoir to Tom and Aunt Sally. Though this may seem amusing, today thousands of hopeful authors distribute their self-portraits to other hopeful authors who sit around seminar tables in one of the hundreds of writing programs thriving nationwide.

headline: Pilgrim’s Progress
text: Reading “Scott Pilgrim” is like watching your (funny, immature) slacker friend play a video game in which the objective is to attain emotional maturity. Specifically, if “Scott Pilgrim” were a video game, it would be an open-world “sandbox” game, in which messing around in the fictional world is not only more fun than properly playing the game — it’s kind of the whole point. The Canadian cartoonist Bryan Lee O’Malley, creator of the “Scott Pilgrim” juggernaut, has been romping around in this sandbox, testing the limits of his comics environment, for six years, and with Volume 6, “Scott Pilgrim’s Finest Hour,” he brings the series to a close.

headline: Paterson Takes His Chances on ‘Saturday Night Live’
text: In a series of skits and “Weekend Update” segments over the last two years, the cast of “Saturday Night Live” has mercilessly mocked Gov. David A. Paterson’s impaired vision and presented him as an improbably clumsy figure who walks into cameras, holds charts upside down, and hates New Jersey. The genial Mr. Paterson, in turn, has made it clear that he finds the parodies to be in poor taste, even for a comedy show.

headline: Gucci Goes Virtual
text: Suzy Menkes discusses the ways Gucci is using technology with Frida Giannini, the label's creative director.

headline: ‘Half Empty’
text: Chapter One: The Bleak Shall Inherit

headline: Nabob of Negativism
text: The book jacket of “Half Empty,” David Rakoff’s third essay collection, contains not only the warning “No Inspirational Life Lessons Will Be Found in These Pages,” but the guarantee that the author will have you “positively reveling in the power of negativity.” It’s never clear whether the pessimism alluded to is Rakoff’s philosophy, Rakoff’s device or Rakoff’s publicist clearing his throat. Luckily, we don’t have to judge this book by its cover.

headline: Photos of the Moment | D&G
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Insuring Young Adults
text: For young Americans with no health insurance, Thursday was an important day: those younger than 26 were able to join their parents’ plans under the recently enacted health care overhaul. (Previously, children were dropped from their parents’ policies at 19, or 23 if they were full-time students.) Young people make up the largest group of uninsured Americans, although they are healthier and cheaper to insure. And they are much less likely to vote. Still, in many states with high rates of uninsured young adults, providing health coverage is not at the forefront of political campaigns. Below, the areas of the country with high rates of uninsured, and how health care is playing out as an issue in those areas:

headline:
Nixon And Kennedy Clash in TV Debate on
Spending, Farms and Social Issues
text: Chicago, Sept. 26--Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy argued genteelly tonight in history's first nationally televised debate between Presidential candidates.

headline: Pope Paul VI Is Dead of a Heart Attack at 80; Guided the Church Through Era of Change
text: In contrast to Pope John XXIII, his predecessor, Paul VI was not naturally gregarious and innovative. He was the consummate bureaucrat in his Vatican career and not given to striking out in new directions.

headline: Richard Serra Sculpture Rusts in Bronx Yard
text: To see gargantuan steel sculptures fashioned by Richard Serra, you could visit the Guggenheim in Bilbao, Spain, or the Dia: Beacon, 60 miles north of New York City. Or you could go to a crane yard near a heating-oil terminal in Port Morris, an industrial corner of the South Bronx.

headline: New Birth of Freedom
text: Human rights have come to dominate international discourse, but while this fact is often portrayed as the culmination of a centuries-old tradition, Samuel Moyn, a professor of history at Columbia University, takes a different view. The modern concept of human rights, he says in “The Last Utopia,” differs radically from older claims of rights, like those that arose out of the American and French Revolutions. According to Moyn, human rights in their current form — applicable to all and internationally protected — can be traced not to the Enlightenment, nor to the humanitarian impulses of the 19th century nor to the impact of the Holocaust after World War II. Instead, he sees them as dating from the 1970s, exemplified by President Jimmy Carter’s effort to make human rights a pillar of United States foreign policy.

headline: Warren Commission Finds Oswald Guilty and Says Assassin and Ruby Acted Alone; Rebukes Secret Service, Asks Revamping
text: Washington, Sept. 27--The assassination of President Kennedy was the work of one man, Lee Harvey Oswald. There was no conspiracy, foreign or domestic.

headline: Admiral Mahan, Naval Critic, Dies
text: WASHINGTON, D. C., Dec. 1--Rear Admiral Alfred Thayer Mahan, U. S. N., retired, America's foremost naval strategist and the world's greatest authority on sea power, died suddenly at the United States Naval Hospital here at 7:15 o'clock this morning of heart disease.

headline: Fliers At Seattle End World Flight of 27,000 Miles
text: Seattle, Wash., Sept. 28 (Associated Press).--The American army round-the-world fliers completed the circuit of the globe this afternoon, landing at Sand Point Field at 1:36 P. M., Pacific Time, after hopping off from Eugene, Ore., at 10:02 A. M.

headline: Ed Sullivan Is Dead at 73; Charmed Millions on TV
text: Ed Sullivan, who entertained hundreds of millions of Americans over his long career as Broadway columnist and host of the long-running televised Sunday evening variety show, died last night of cancer. He was 73 years old.

headline: Enrico Fermi Dead at 53; Architect of Atomic Bomb
text: CHICAGO, Nov. 28--Dr. Enrico Fermi, an architect of the atomic age and Nobel Prize winner, died at his home here this morning of cancer. His age was 53.

headline: The New York Giants: 1883-1957
text: The New York Giants played--and lost--their last game at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

headline: Britain and Germany Make Anti-War Pact; Hitler Gets Less Than His Sudeten Demands; Polish Ultimatum Threatens Action Today
text: Prime Minister Chamberlain and Chancellor Hitler, at a final conference at Munich yesterday, agreed that: "We regard the agreement signed last night and the Anglo- German naval agreement as symbolic of the desire of our two peoples never to go to war with one another again." Terms imposed on Czechoslovakia were found to be milder than Hitler's Godesberg plan. They provided immediate occupation of about half of the Sudeten area, the rest to be allotted by the International Commission or to be subject to plebiscite.

headline: Truman Capote is Dead at 59; Novelist of Style and Clarity
text: Truman Capote, one of the postwar era's leading American writers, whose prose shimmered with clarity and quality, died yesterday in Los Angeles at the age of 59.

headline: 3 Afghan Journalists, 2 of Whom Were Held by NATO Forces, Are Released
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Three Afghan journalists detained by the authorities were released from custody on Friday, officials said.

headline: Character Building
text: When I used to ask my mother about her family village in China, she always said it was three hours from Canton by bus. A hundred years ago, when my great-grandfather left China for good, that couldn’t have been far, but it was certainly no help in locating it. So I was pleased — though still mystified — to read in Deborah Fallows’s charming and witty little book that in China, “if you ask someone where their hometown is, they’ll say it is seven hours by bus. Or four hours by train. They won’t tell you where it is.”

headline: Falling to Earth
text: Scanning online news releases from the Department of Defense, one discovers, interspersed among policy announcements, statistical reports and accounts of recent casualties in Afghanistan and Iraq, the occasional release concerning the identification of soldiers missing in earlier wars. In contrast to the brutal, minimalist bulletins about today’s combat deaths, narratives of the repatriation of older remains, tempered by historical distance, present robustly detailed forensic reconstructions of events once thought untraceable. Unlike the stinting report of young lives violently ended just days before by “rifle, rocket-propelled grenade and small-arms fire” in Kandahar City, accounts of Vietnam-, Korea- or World War II-era soldiers located, identified and laid to rest offer resolution to stories long unfinished.

headline: Michael Schumacher’s Future Discussed in Singapore
text: SINGAPORE – During a press meeting at the Mercedes motor home Thursday in Singapore, someone asked Michael Schumacher if we going to see him again next year. There had been rumors that he would not finish his contract at Mercedes and retire again in the off-season.

headline: Michael Schumacher’s Future Discussed in Singapore
text: SINGAPORE – During a press meeting at the Mercedes motor home Thursday in Singapore, someone asked Michael Schumacher if we going to see him again next year. There had been rumors that he would not finish his contract at Mercedes and retire again in the off-season.

headline: Feisty Barbadian, Reluctant Centenarian, Dies at 102
text: Mae Bishop, a proud Barbadian immigrant who raised two daughters and worked in the New York hotel industry, retiring in 1976 as an assistant housekeeper in the linen room at the Delmonico Hotel on Park Avenue, died on Wednesday. She was 102 — or, as she put it, just past the 72nd anniversary of her 30th birthday.

headline: ‘Waterfront’ Jungle
text: Say you’re a New York City newspaper reporter and the year is 1948. Your editor tells you to go down to the docks and check out the latest in a string of murders.

headline: Le Fooding Fights | David Chang on Daniel Patterson
text: To get ready for this weekend’s Le Grand Fooding 2010: New York vs. San Francisco at P.S.1, we asked David Chang to respond to Daniel Patterson’s post about what West Coast cuisine really means. Gentlemen. …

headline: Saved by Rock ’n’ Roll
text: Rob Sheffield is a geek. Most rock critics are, but Sheffield, a columnist for Rolling Stone, takes it to a whole new level. In “Talking to Girls About Duran Duran: One Young Man’s Quest for True Love and a Cooler Haircut,” he lays bare the tortured soul of a music geek coming of age in New England in the 1980s. And make no mistake about it, his soul is tortured. Blame liberal doses of Catholicism, Morrissey and John Hughes. Sheffield is Duckie without the fashion sense, or the girl.

headline: Sept. 26 — Oct. 2
text: Dance

headline: Unilever’s ‘Mad Men’ Spots Worked, Study Says
text: A series of commercials for six big Unilever brands, which appeared during — and were inspired by — the AMC series “Mad Men” were successful, according to the results of a study.

headline: Voting With Their Wallets, College Profs Overwhelmingly Support Democrats
text: Somebody call David Horowitz: College educators — or at least those involved enough in political campaigns to donate — are indeed generally liberal.

headline: The End of Tenure?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Young Love
text: Tao Lin’s short new novel, “Richard Yates,” has little to do with the man it was named for, the author of “Revolutionary Road” and “The Easter Parade.” Instead, Yates’s name appears both as a provocation — to showcase Lin’s quirky nature — and as an attempt at appropriation. Lin aspires to the emotionally devastating work that is Yates’s legacy. If he falls short, though, he’s maintained enough ironic distance to have an out: Just kidding, see?

headline: Eddie Fisher, Pop Singer, Dies at 82
text: Eddie Fisher, whose matinee-idol looks and smooth, romantic voice made him one of the most popular singers of the 1950s, and whose busy love life stole headlines in 1959 when he divorced Debbie Reynolds to marry Elizabeth Taylor, died on Wednesday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 82.

headline: A Shared Language
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Right Star Rising’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fight ‘The Power’
text: Maybe it’s happened to you too. You’re reminiscing about a friend who moved away years ago, and then she arrives unexpectedly at your door. You can’t stop thinking about getting the phone call with the job offer, and it comes the next week. Or you have a vision of a family member becoming sick, and then you hear that he has been taken to the hospital.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: BARNACLE LOVE  By Anthony De Sa.  Algonquin, paper, $13.95.

headline: Up Front: Kaiama L. Glover
text: “The first thing you notice walking into my childhood home,” Kaiama L. Glover recalled in a recent e-mail, “is the collection of family photographs that chronicle about four generations of maternal history. And not a visit goes by that I don’t stop there with my mother, listening to a story I’ve heard for the umpteenth time but can never get enough of.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: ROOM,  by Emma Donoghue (Little, Brown, $24.99.) In this remarkable novel, the entire world of a 5-year-old boy is the 11-by-11-foot room in which his mother is being held against her will. Donoghue’s child narrator is one of the most engaging in years.

headline: Paperback Row
text: HALF BROKE HORSES: A True-Life Novel,  by Jeannette Walls (Scribner, $15.) In an author’s note, Walls says that this book is “a retelling of stories handed down by my family through the years.” Narrated in the first person in the voice of Walls’s grandmother, Lily Casey Smith, it describes her hardscrabble upbringing in West Texas, where she was born in 1901, and her subsequent frontier life as a mustang breaker, schoolteacher, ranch wife, bootlegger, poker player, bush pilot and mother of two. A sort of prequel to Walls’s luminous memoir, “The Glass Castle” (2005), “Half Broke Horses” was one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2009.

headline: Andrea Harris and David Smith
text: Andrea Kate Harris and David Richard Smith were married Saturday in New York. Andra M. Miller, the president of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, officiated at the Boathouse in Central Park.

headline: Calling Chuck Woolery; N.B.A. Needs You
text: The N.B.A. would like your love back. Look, it’s really sorry about that whole LeBron James “The Decision” thing. It has done everything it can to keep Gilbert Arenas from bringing his guns anywhere near you. It has been trying super, super hard to get Mark Cuban to be quiet. It is even promising to cut back on players’ whining. Training camps open in a few days, and even if you’re transfixed by the Yankees-Rays race for the American League East or wondering if the Kansas City Chiefs are for real, it’s wondering if you won’t hang out with its news for a few minutes.

headline: In Pursuing Progress, Should Borders Matter?
text: Toward the end of a week focused on how the world’s rich can foster progress at the other end of the Slinky of social and economic progress, a reader here posted a provocative comment.

headline: Red Hook Is Out, So Mexico Will Have to Do
text: When LeNell Smothers’s landlord would not renew her lease and she reluctantly closed her beloved liquor store in Red Hook, taking her Alabama chandelier and little-boy-urinating fountain with her, her predictions for the future, however cryptic, proved prescient.

headline: Endzhe Akhmatshina; Rafay Farooqui
text: Endzhe Akhmatshina and Rafay Farooqui were married Friday. Imam Ghazi Y. Khankan officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in Manhattan.

text: In Ristretto, Oliver Strand, the author of The Filter, a guide to New York coffee from The New York Times, explores the world of coffee gadgets, coffee beans and why it’s never been easier to get a cortado.

headline: College Professors and Their Support for Democrats
text: College educators — or at least those involved enough in political campaigns to donate — are indeed generally liberal. That is the implication of a new analysis of federal political contributions conducted by the Center for Responsive Politics, which tracks public data on campaign donations. Read more about the analysis, and view a chart at the Economix blog.

headline: Big Deal | Walt Frazier’s Harlem Penthouse(s)
text: Walt Frazier, the N.B.A Hall of Fame player who was known as “Clyde” in his heyday as a point guard for the Knicks, closed on three Harlem penthouses Thursday, for $2.4 million, according to the developer of the new condominium building, known as the Lenox Grand. Mr. Frazier bought the entire seventh and eighth floors of the building, with a total of 4,600 square feet and another 2,500 square feet of terraces. Our colleagues in the Real Estate section have the full story.

headline: What We’re Reading: R.I.P., Toxic Asset
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Amgen and Johnson & Johnson Recall Anemia Drugs
text: Amgen’s anemia drugs have been embroiled in controversy about their safety for several years as evidence has mounted that their overuse can cause heart attacks or strokes or make cancer worse. Now comes yet another problem, though presumably a temporary one.

headline: The Best Savings Account Rate Just Got Worse
text: SmartyPig, the online savings bank known for its competitive interest rates, recently became a little less generous.

headline: Vegetables Bring In $100,000 at Sotheby’s
text: Last night the old masters up for auction at Sotheby’s on York Avenue were heirloom vegetables. And they brought in more than $100,000 to support local farming programs.

headline: Grassley Backs Renewable Electricity Standard
text: A bipartisan bill introduced in the Senate this week that would require utilities nationwide to generate at least 15 percent of their electricity from renewable sources like wind, solar and biomass by 2021 continues to garner Republican support, with Charles E. Grassley of Iowa signing on as a co-sponsor. His support brings the number of Republican co-sponsors to four; 25 senators in all have signed on to the bill.

headline: For Glenn Gould, Form Followed Fingers
text: EVEN to his most passionate admirers, the phenomenally gifted if wildly unconventional pianist Glenn Gould was a tangle of personal tics and complexes. Sometimes he seemed a provocateur bent on riling the public with extreme interpretations and odd behavior. Other times he came across as a fragile, fearful man, at ease only when making music.

headline: Lindsay Lohan Sent to Jail Again
text: Lindsay Lohan was sent back to jail on Friday morning by a California judge after the actress failed a recent drug test, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lohan, the “Mean Girls” star, was ordered by Judge Elden S. Fox of Los Angeles County Superior Court to be held without bail until Oct. 22, when a formal probation hearing will be held.

headline: Madonna — Finally, a Real Feminist
text: For Op-Ed's 40th anniversary, author and professor Camille Paglia recounts the story behind her 1990 Op-Ed about feminism, Madonna, and the music video “Justify My Love.”

headline: Thinking of Buying a Nissan Leaf? Get in Line
text: The Nissan Leaf is a go. In fact, until next year, it’s gone.

headline: Princess Shakes Up Equestrian World
text: BAYAMON, P.R.  As a daughter of King Hussein and the wife of the ruler of Dubai, Princess Haya bint al-Hussein of Jordan has the pedigree that is practically a prerequisite for presiding over the International Equestrian Federation, which governs the sport. Members of noble or royal families have led the organization, with few exceptions, since its founding in 1921.

headline: Just 28 Days to Make a Choice
text: If choosing the law firm that you could spend much of your professional life at was not already a frenetic and stressful enough process, the system became even a little bit more fast paced this year.

headline: Runway Beauty | Prada
text: The hairstylist Guido Palau seems to have been hitting the history books since February — the look he created for the Marc Jacobs show was all ’70s scene queens, and now for Prada he said he channeled the ’30s icon Josephine Baker and her signature hairstyle, a helmet of Marcel waves. The hair was slicked down with Redken Hardwear 16 Super-Strong Sculpting Gel, and in the back it was coiled into two buns, which Palau intended to look “playful.” Perhaps to shake up the historical reference, the makeup artist Pat McGrath created a futuristic look she said she meant to look a bit androgynous: a strong brow, clean skin and a shiny slick of silver across the eyelids. The metallic shadow offset the bright colors and Carmen Miranda prints in the “minimal baroque” collection, and the graphic shape of the hair on the forehead meshed perfectly with Prada’s wacky eyewear.

headline: Chicago and Muti: Chemistry in Action
text: CHICAGO  Riccardo Muti officially began his tenure as music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra on Thursday night with an imaginative, elegantly performed and enthusiastically received Berlioz program. Yet the Muti lovefest here started well before this milestone concert.

headline: Cerberus’s Freedom Names Nardelli as Chief
text: Robert L. Nardelli has taken the helm of yet another portfolio company of Cerberus Capital Management, assuming on Friday the role of head of the gun maker Freedom Group‘s newly created office of the chief executive.

headline: Book Review Podcast: James Ellroy’s Memoir
text: This week: Alexandra Jacobs on the novelist James Ellroy’s new memoir, “The Hilliker Curse: My Pursuit of Women”; Kaiama Glover discusses “Some Sing, Some Cry,” a novel by the sisters Ntozake Shange and Ifa Bayeza; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Mixing Urgency and Relaxation
text: THE first time I heard the English pianist Paul Lewis perform live was at the Risor Chamber Music Festival in Norway in the summer of 2002. He impressed me as an accomplished and insightful artist. Still, with the pianists Leif Ove Andsnes and Till Fellner among the participants in the festival that season, it was hard for Mr. Lewis to stand out.

headline: Friday Night Lights: L.A. Edition
text: Major League Soccer’s media machine has been operating at full power all week ahead of Friday night’s match between the Red Bulls and Los Angeles Galaxy at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif. The match will be televised live nationally by ESPN2 at 11 p.m. Eastern.

text: A photographer's view of the allied offensive in Southern Afghanistan and a house so well insulated it doesn't need a furnace.

headline: Weekend Competition: Wire Taps, Stock Tickers and Other Frozen Phrases
text: This weekend, Schott’s Vocab is soliciting frozen words and phrases – those terms that are still in use, despite their archaic references.

headline: Reneging by Georgia Blindsides Orchestra
text: The Republic of Georgia canceled an invitation to the New York Philharmonic just weeks before it was to visit, the Philharmonic said on Friday. The called-off performances will cost the orchestra hundreds of thousands of dollars, and they add another setback to its efforts to be a world-traveling band.

headline: Trunk Show | European Fashion in L.A.
text: Most museum fashion shows are relegated to a dark basement, reflecting not just the status of fashion vis-à-vis fine art but also the vulnerability of, say, a 150-year-old silk gown, to the effects of sunlight. When the Los Angeles County Museum of Art shows off its newly acquired, and reportedly groundbreaking, trove of European clothing on Saturday, it will do so in a new light-filled pavilion designed by Renzo Piano. “Fashioning Fashion: European Dress in Detail, 1700-1915,” which runs through April 3, ends well before the invention of ready-to-wear. In this stunning context, even a man’s vest from the 18th century (it is embroidered with symbolism relevant to the French Revolution and it predates the message T-shirt by at least 200 years) somehow seems modern and alive.

headline: N.B.A. Aims to Rein in Players’ Whining
text: When the whistle blows in the N.B.A., the gesticulations begin. Players howl, shrug, punch the air, raise their palms and sometimes chase referees 90 feet to plead their case. League officials have seen  and heard  enough.

headline: Trisha Brown in Space and Time
text: Mikhail Baryshnikov, Laurie Anderson and other artists describe working with Trisha Brown from the 1960s on.

headline: Twitter Walks, Urban Sharecropping and Other Matters
text: Everyone has projects.

headline: In Rare Find, Prado Says Painting Is by Bruegel the Elder
text: Calling it “one of the most important discoveries for many years,’’ curators at the Prado Museum in Madrid have uncovered what they say is the largest surviving canvas painted by the 16th-century Flemish master Pieter Bruegel the Elder.

headline: Kelly McGillis and Melanie Leis
text: Collingswood, N.J.

headline: The Whole Truthiness and Nothing But
text: Stephen Colbert testified in Congress on Friday about an immigration bill that he said — in all truthiness — he had not read, “like most members of Congress.”

headline: Inside the List
text: CAT AND MOUSE: Bill O’Reilly, the excitable Fox News host, is no fan of this newspaper — his latest book, “Pinheads and Patriots,” includes an index entry for “The New York Times, blind partisanship at” — but he’s compiled an impressive track record on our best-seller lists. With “Pinheads and Patriots” making its debut this week at No. 2 on the hardcover nonfiction list, O’Reilly has now seen eight of his nine books become New York Times best sellers. The one exception? “Those Who Trespass: A Novel of Murder and Television,” his 1998 mystery about serial killings and other misdeeds within the TV news industry.

headline: The Endless Film Reel
text: IT was a bad day for surfing. The wind was low, the waves small, and a reporter brand new to the sport was nearly inept. Plus, it was Long Beach on Long Island  not exactly a hotbed of surfing. Still, that didn’t stop the surfing filmmaker Dana Brown from trying his best to help the reporter catch a wave and actually ride it.

headline: Obama Calls Ahmadinejad’s 9/11 Comments ‘Inexcusable’
text: Updated | 3:13 p.m. In a television interview with the BBC’s Persian-language satellite channel on Friday, President Barack Obama called remarks made by Iran’s president, suggesting that the American government was responsible for the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, “inexcusable.”

headline: Yale Endowment Gained 8.9% Last Year
text: Yale University said on Friday that its endowment, which has sizable assets in real estate, had an investment gain of 8.9 percent last year, an underwhelming performance in a year when many big endowments are reporting gains of 9 percent to 14 percent.

headline: Achebe Wins $300,000 Prize
text: The Nigerian novelist Chinua Achebe has won the $300,000 Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, which recognizes artists who have had an extraordinary impact in their field. The award, named after the silent film stars, will be delivered at a ceremony on Oct. 27 in New York. Past winners include Robert Redford, Ornette Coleman, Merce Cunningham and Frank Gehry. Mr. Achebe’s books are among the most widely read in African literature. His 1958 novel, “Things Fall Apart,” has sold more than 10 million copies, and he has also won the Man Booker International Prize for Fiction and the Nigerian National Merit Award.

headline: ‘Dark Harbor’
text: Chapter One: "DOV'È PANTO?"

headline: Old Mon and the Sea
text: Jamaica has been on the defensive lately. jamaica . . . no problem T-shirts sold in sticky tourist flytraps seemed like so much wishful thinking in June, when a popular mafioso went on the lam and riots shocked the slums of Kingston. It would be a while before the memory of daily body counts receded into a haze of happy ganja smoke.

headline: House May Move on Tax Cuts Despite Delay
text: WASHINGTON  The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, said Friday that Democrats in her chamber may still force a vote next week on the expiring Bush-era tax cuts, even though their counterparts in the Senate have decided not to bring the issue to the floor until after the November elections.

headline: Photographing Ntozake Shange and Ifa Bayeza
text: One of the moody pleasures of this week’s Book Review is Chester Higgins Jr.’s tender-tough black-and-white portrait of the sisters Ntozake Shange and Ifa Bayeza, who are noted playwrights and the co-authors of the generational family novel “Some Sing, Some Cry.” Our reviewer, Kaiama L. Glover, writes that the novel is “a rich mix of storytelling and African-American history” following “seven generations of black women who, largely through music, are able to survive the violence of their national and personal histories.”

headline: Photographing Ntozake Shange and Ifa Bayeza
text: One of the moody pleasures of this week’s Book Review is Chester Higgins Jr.’s tender-tough black-and-white portrait of the sisters Ntozake Shange and Ifa Bayeza, who are noted playwrights and the co-authors of the generational family novel “Some Sing, Some Cry.” Our reviewer, Kaiama L. Glover, writes that the novel is “a rich mix of storytelling and African-American history” following “seven generations of black women who, largely through music, are able to survive the violence of their national and personal histories.”

headline: Now Online | T’s Fall Travel Issue
text: In T’s new fall travel issue, the spotlight is on Mexico City’s movers and shakers — an illustrious bunch that includes architects, artists and actors photographed for a cover story in some of the capital’s iconic spots. For a look at other cities on the rise, we survey the design scene in Valencia, Spain; check in on politically minded filmmakers in Sarajevo; and take the pulse in Seoul, where tradition gets cozy with 21st-century ambition. Then we head for the hills — that is, the mysterious peaks and untrammeled valleys of Roussillon, one of France’s last frontiers. The pioneer spirit continues with a profile of the trailblazing hotelier and hitmaker Chris Blackwell, as well as a romp through the Canadian wilderness with one of the world’s foremost food foragers. And for some unabashed sybaritism, we offer a top-to-toe guide to Marrakesh, a playground so swanky it will knock your caftan off.

headline: Week 4 Matchups: Plenty to Choose From
text: It’s another huge weekend in college football. The Southeastern Conference schedule gets started for real and gives us a couple of potential great games. Boise State needs a big win over Oregon State in its last non-conference test of the season. Notre Dame needs to avoid losing its third in a row. West Virginia hopes to boost the Big East’s Q rating a little bit. Stay with me. There’s a lot going on here.

headline: Judge Accepts Citigroup’s Settlement With S.E.C.
text: WASHINGTON  A federal judge said Friday that she would accept the $75 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Citigroup over the bank’s failure to adequately disclose its exposure to subprime mortgage debt in 2007.

headline: Taiwan Museum to Lend Painting to China
text: A Taiwan museum plans for the first time to lend a major painting for exhibition in China, Agence France-Presse reported. The National Taiwan Museum plans to lend a 17th-century portrait of a Chinese general, along with other artworks, to the Hubei Provincial Museum in central China and another museum in Fujian Province for exhibitions next year. In exchange, the museum in Hubei will lend more than 100 objects to the National Taiwan Museum for an exhibition in November.

headline: Crist Spots Take a Darker Tone
text: 6:01 p.m. | Updated At first, the general election ads for Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida were smooth, clean and positive, with gentle Florida waves washing away the line in the sand between Democrats and Republicans to symbolize his independent bid for the United States Senate.

headline: Obama: Ahmadinejad’s 9/11 Comments ‘Inexcusable’
text: In a television interview to be broadcast to Iran by the BBC’s Persian-language satellite channel, President Obama said remarks made by Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, suggesting that the American government was responsible for the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, were “inexcusable.” Watch the video, or read an excerpt of his comments, at The Lede blog.

headline: By Her Support, Does She Earn His Infidelity?
text: THE GIST Economically dependent men are more likely to cheat on their female partners.

headline: G.M. Is Recalling 20,000 Cadillac CTS Models
text: General Motors is recalling about 20,000 of its 2009-10 Cadillac CTS all-wheel-drive and CTS-V models. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said that in a frontal crash the CTS would not adequately protect an unbelted passenger under 5 feet tall sitting in the front seat.

headline: Notes From a Young American in Congo: A Soldier Speaks (Sort of)
text: I wanted so badly to hate this man. He’s extremely handsome, with soft eyes, thick, curling lashes, and a nervous glance. It doesn’t fit with the dirty green uniform and rickety gun hanging from his shoulder.

headline: Director Selects Winner of Philips Consumer Contest
text: Ridley Scott, known for directing movies like “Blade Runner” and “Gladiator,” has chosen the winner of a contest to create short films that was sponsored by Philips.
