headline: The Caucus: Speaking Truthiness to Power
text: The comedian Stephen Colbert appeared in character before Congress on Friday to testify about an immigration bill that he acknowledged he had not read, “like most members of Congress.” His credentials: a day spent picking beans in a segment for his satirical news show on Comedy Central. “I believe that one day of me studying anything makes me an expert,” Mr. Colbert said. Read more on The Caucus…

headline: Cost and Lack of Awareness Hamper Adult Vaccination Efforts
text: VACCINES are not just for children.

headline: For Pandit, $1 This Year, a Big Bump in 2011
text: Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague, reports:

headline: The Morning Skate: New Head Check Rules a Step Forward
text: When it comes to checks to the head, the N.H.L. is trying something new this season. Earlier this week, the league released a video outlining its new rules on checks to the head delivered from the blindside or laterally, which mandates an automatic game misconduct and either a major or match penalty. The player also faces the possibility of supplementary discipline.

headline: Apple Goes After The Camera Market Too
text: Any iPhone owner knows that there are a lot of gadgets and objects the iPhone has replaced. Among its Web and communications abilities phone owners do not need maps, notepads, music players and a litany of other single-serving devices.

headline: Ejecting BP and Anointing Halliburton
text: In June, as thousands of barrels of oil gushed hourly into the Gulf of Mexico from its blown-out deepwater well, BP was stripped from the Dow Jones Sustainability Index. The index, which tracks “sustainability leaders” in industry worldwide, determined that the oil spill was an “extraordinary event” that merited BP’s removal.

headline: Iran’s President Expresses Hope for More Nuclear Talks
text: Iran’s president dismissed a fusillade of criticism on Friday over his inflammatory speech at the United Nations a day earlier, in which he asserted that most people believed the United States orchestrated the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: Onward and Upward? Documenting Local Economic Conditions
text: Overview | If the economic recession officially ended 15 months ago, why is the poverty rate still rising? In this lesson, students learn about the correlation between job growth and poverty. They investigate how national trends in economics, labor and commerce are playing out in their area and then go into the community to photograph and compile evidence. They present their findings in a class-wide project.

headline: A Charmer
text: Style-setters like Margherita Missoni, Queen Rania of Jordan and Giovanna Battaglia of L’Uomo Vogue are wearing elegant but playful pieces by Ca & Lou, a new Milan-based label designed by the fashion insiders Carolina Neri and Bérengère Lux. Inspired by Art Deco geometric shapes with a touch of 1980s glamour, this Snake bracelet, of gold-dipped bronze and Swarovski crystals, is $565 at saksfifthavenue.com.

headline: Hand-Holding Across the Aisle
text: THERE comes a moment in the dating and mating crescendo of any couple when a new significant other must be presented to the Friends. But H. P. Goldfield had a particularly tough audition: He was courting Kristin Mannion, who’d been involved in Democratic politics all her life, numbering Cuomos and Clintons among her nearest and dearest. “A lot of well-known Democrats were my friends, and I had to get their permission,” said Ms. Mannion, an executive recruiter in New York City. “Could I really date a Republican?”

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Enter the Void’
text: In her review of “Enter the Void,” Manohla Dargis writes that “the camera soars above the world like a bird, like a kite, like a ghost.” With an exploration of the afterlife at its center, “Enter the Void” takes viewers on an extended, sometimes frantic, visual journey. Above, its director Gaspar Noé discusses a scene shot from overhead with a roving crane and featuring the film’s two leads, Paz de la Huerta and Nathaniel Brown.

headline: Baseball Continued: Between Rebirth and Calamity
text: IT seemed improbable in 1994 that Ken Burns would ever feel compelled to update his nine-part documentary on baseball. At 18 ½ hours, “Baseball” was his longest film yet, and if his critics agreed on anything, it was that it lasted a few too many innings.

headline: From Jon Stewart, Echoes of G.O.P. Past
text: Sometimes, the past catches up to you.

headline: Marco Service Helps People Find Each Other
text: This summer Tarikh Korula and a friend set out into New York City’s Lower East Side to a find a beer garden they had visited once before. There was one problem: neither of them remembered the name of the bar, let alone the street address. So they split up and began wandering down blocks, planning to call each other when they finally found their destination.

headline: For Automakers, the Lights Seem Brighter in Paris
text: THE Paris Motor Show, the world’s first auto salon, is shaping up to be perhaps the most notable show this year.

headline: An Uzbek Survivor of Torture Seeks to Fight It Tacitly
text: GERMANTOWN, Tenn.

headline: Judge Accepts S.E.C.-Citigroup Settlement
text: A federal judge said Friday that she would accept the $75 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Citigroup over the bank’s failure to adequately disclose its exposure to subprime mortgage debt in 2007, The New York Times’s Edward Wyatt reports from Washington.

headline: Leaving a Childhood Room Behind, and Much More
text: I WAS sitting around the table with some friends at an end of summer barbecue and the talk turned to college because one couple had just dropped off their daughter to start her freshman year.

headline: A Father-to-Be in the Middle of a Rebirth
text: ATLANTA  At the San Diego Chargers’ home game last Sunday against the Jacksonville Jaguars, Charley Hoffman and his wife sat near the end zone at Qualcomm Stadium, using tickets they bought on Craigslist. Hoffman wore an autographed Eric Weddle jersey and his lucky football sneakers, the ones with the lightning bolts stitched on them, and it was a great day: the Chargers won by two touchdowns and Weddle, a free safety, was in on a sack.

headline: If Customers Have to Pay for Checking, They Should Be Consoled With Perks
text: Banks want many of us to start paying monthly fees again for our checking accounts. So why won’t they give us something worth paying for?

headline: Whether Jazz, Rock Or War Anthems, A Vintage Harvest
text: Henry Threadgill

headline: Malcolm Forbes’s Toys Are Up for Sale
text: The Forbes Galleries on lower Fifth Avenue will be emptying out their darkened maze of toys in dioramas, The Associated Press reported. Sotheby’s will organize about 7,500 pieces, including metal marching bands, submarines, motorcycles and a box of Titanic brand soap (“Guaranteed to Sink”), into about 250 lots for an auction on Dec. 17.

headline: Where Engineering Prowess Meets Burning Man
text: At World Maker Faire, you might see a robot solving a Rubik’s Cube. Or you might watch visitors making full 360-degree circles in a swing while, in another pavilion, people dressed as mice tap dance around a life-size version of the game “Mouse Trap.”

headline: From Bargain Bin to the Battle Lines
text: MOST versions of the 2011 Volkswagen Jetta are capable of inducing a sort of reverse sticker shock, since they now cost some $1,700 to $2,300 less than the cars they replaced. No one is going to organize a protest against lower prices, but it is unclear how consumers will react to how Volkswagen achieved the savings.

headline: Checking Accounts Worth the Fees
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I take a deep dive into the world of what bankers like to call “mobile remote deposit capture.” In English, that is a system that allows you to take a photograph of a check using a smartphone and then push a button to deposit it instantly into your checking account.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Jamey Johnson, ‘Wall Street,’ Ken Burns and More
text: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

headline: Avoid Legal Pitfalls When Buying Art
text: Even in a sluggish economy, art auctions can be frothy places. But as the fall auction season kicks into high gear, the same emotion that gets buyers to bid up works of art may well lead to a different variation of buyer’s remorse.

headline: 2011 Volkswagen Jetta
text: Volkswagen did not cut the Jetta’s core value: how entertaining it can be to drive.

headline: James Madison’s Win Over Virginia Tech Shows Rewards for F.C.S.
text: The day after James Madison stunned Virginia Tech in a game it was not expected to have a prayer of winning, Dukes Coach Mickey Matthews went to church. When Matthews sat down, his pastor pulled a James Madison hat from behind the pulpit, and the congregation stood and applauded.

headline: Accessories From Milan Fashion Week
text: Shoes, handbags and glasses form the Gucci, Prada, Fendi and Verace spring 2011 shows.

headline: N.B.A. Refereeing, There Will Be a Quiz
text: The N.B.A. announced a crackdown on players complaining about calls at its annual referee camp on Thursday and a marginal increase in instant replay to include its use in clear-path fouls and all of overtime.

headline: Recessions and Recoveries Are Not All the Same
text: In the old days  before 1990  American recessions tended to be fairly sharp. But the recoveries, when they came, were also rapid. Laid-off workers were recalled and consumers who had deferred purchases out of fear they might lose their jobs were willing again to buy cars and homes.

headline: Upstairs Downstairs
text: Good food and good mattresses are a classic combination, but this season three inns are breathing new life into the restaurant-with-rooms trend. In London, the St. John chef Fergus Henderson (above left), known for his nose-to-tail fare, is teaming with Trevor Gulliver (above right) to bring his humble yet decadent principles to the St. John Hotel (1 Leicester Street; 011-44-207-251-0848; doubles from about $310). It will offer 15 whitewashed and wainscoted rooms (‘‘mini grand urban hut’’ is the theme) above the restaurant and bar. At Chicago’s Longman & Eagle gastropub (2657 North Kedzie Avenue; 773-276-7110; doubles from $75), you’ll soon be able to retire upstairs to one of six retro-modern rooms should that flight of small-batch bourbons prove too much. And why stay in a chateau when you can stay in a revolving dome? The Dôme de Montmiral (011-33-5-63-57-26-78; double room and board from about $193), near Castelnau de Montmiral, France, combines organic vegetarian food and cooking classes with a U.F.O.-worthy design.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: It’s a good weekend to be a beer drinker in New York. Today is the kick off of Craft Beer Week (It’s actually a 10-day event that ends Oct. 3), when nearly 100 bars and 30 restaurants across all five boroughs will offer specials on beers (and some food pairings). A $10 pass gets you 3 beers.

headline: Subaru Reworks Its 21-Year-Old Boxer Engine
text: Now that Subaru’s engine is old enough to drink, the automaker has taken steps to make it less thirsty. Subaru announced on Thursday that it has redesigned the horizontally opposed 4-cylinder boxer engine that has been a key component of its vehicles for many years. This reworking marks the first substantial change to the engine since the current version was introduced in 1989.

headline: Expensive Cars, Built by Hand
text: Bristol builds expensive cars by hand in England and despite the global downturn, its sales are up.

headline: A Quirky Car Company, Serving Quirky Customers
text: LONDON  For a certain kind of company, recessions may be beside the point.

headline: Michael Crawford to Star in New ‘Wizard of Oz’
text: 3:18 p.m. | Updated Michael Crawford is set to play the Wizard in Andrew Lloyd Webber’s new production of “The Wizard of Oz,” which will begin previews at the London Palladium on Feb. 7, 2011, according to Mr. Lloyd Webber’s Web site. “We will be going a lot further than simply presenting the movie on stage,” Mr. Lloyd Webber said in a comment posted on the site. “We have revisited the original novel and re-conceived our ‘Oz’ as a piece of new musical theater using the wonderful Arlen/Harburg songs and adding a few new ones where there are gaps.” Mr. Crawford starred in Mr. Lloyd Webber’s production of “The Phantom of the Opera” in the West End in 1986 and on Broadway in 1988, where he won a Tony Award for best actor in a musical. Danielle Hope, the winner of the BBC television reality show “Over the Rainbow,” will play Dorothy. The production of L. Frank Baum’s classic tale will be directed by Jeremy Sams, choreographed by Arlene Phillips, with music and lyrics by Harold Arlen and E.Y. Harburg, with additional music and lyrics by Mr. Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice.

headline: Borough Park, 9:25 A.M.
text: Rabbi Moshe Steinberg recites a blessing in the sukkah outside his home on 41st Street in Borough Park, Brooklyn. Sukkahs, which symbolize the transient homes the Israelites built during their 40 years in the desert, are built yearly to celebrate the holiday Sukkot. Today is the second day of the weeklong Jewish holiday.

headline: A Conference Makes Learning Free (and Sexy)
text: ONCE a year, there is a mass migration of the intelligentsia to Long Beach, Calif.

headline: Games Official Angers India With Hygiene Comment
text: NEW DELHI  Had the statement come from a non-Indian, especially a Westerner, it probably would have been angrily repudiated as an affront to Indian dignity. But the offending words came from a top Indian official trying to deflect criticism for the bureaucratic failings and lax preparations threatening the coming Commonwealth Games.

headline: Chic in Review | Lady Gaga: 0, Daphne Guinness: -1
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: G.E. and Better Place to Partner on E.V. Charging
text: When General Electric announced the WattStation electric car charger last July, it seemed likely that it would need a charging company partner to make sure its E.V. station, styled with a designer touch by Yves Behar, would reach a wider world. It’s one thing to produce a nice piece of hardware, but quite another to actively engage with automakers, governments, businesses and interest groups to make sure they get installed, both in public and in home garages.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: Starting at the Top
text: The list of intriguing games this Saturday starts right at the top, with No. 1 Alabama traveling to Arkansas to take on the Razorbacks and their Heisman hopeful, quarterback Ryan Mallett. The Tide has been dominant so far, and the return of Mark Ingram last week gives them even more firepower. This is the kind of game that makes coming out of the Southeastern Conference unscathed such a feat, as is South Carolina’s matchup with Auburn. Notre Dame has hit some bumps already in Brian Kelly’s first season as coach and it doesn’t get any easier this weekend, with No. 16 Stanford coming to South Bend. Andrew Luck has been spectacular for the Cardinal so far, and a big game against the Irish could give him a lot of confidence heading into the rest of the Pac-10 schedule. West Virginia and Louisiana State are both undefeated, but have still managed to seem somewhat suspect. Will the Mountaineers be able to overcome the hostile environment they are sure to be greeted with in Baton Rouge? But perhaps the weekend’s most intriguing game is Oregon State traveling to Boise State, where it will face the Broncos on the Smurf Turf. Boise State needs a convincing win to answer some of the critics now downplaying its victory over Virginia Tech. Of course, the Beavers have knocked off top teams before (just ask U.S.C.). Will the Broncos see their national championship hopes dashed or will they get through their final non-conference test without a blemish? We have our thoughts. Feel free to share yours.

headline: Congregations Reeling From Decline in Donations
text: Late this summer, as the country’s economic slump entered its third year, Bishop Robert E. Girtman met with the board of his church to discuss finances. The weekly collection of tithes and offerings, routinely $4,000 before the recession, had sunk to barely $3,000. Some members, newly jobless and ashamed, turned in tithing envelopes that were empty. Others skipped church a few Sundays a month to avoid the awkwardness of having nothing to give.

headline: Delaware G.O.P. Spokesman Leaves Job
text: Thomas Doheny, spokesman for the Delaware Republican Party, was pretty tough on the opposition in the state’s recent Senate primary. As it turned out, the opposition, Christine O’Donnell, won an upset victory, putting her on the campaign trail as the Republican Senate nominee while Mr. Doheny is hitting the road.

headline: Halak’s Start a Shaky One
text: Slap Shot’s blogger Stu Hackel is now also blogging for The Montreal Gazette’s Habs Inside/Out blog and the sports departments of The Times and Gazette have agreed to cross-link Stu’s posts. These Habs Inside/Out posts will, like The Morning Skate, generally focus on league-wide issues and news. Today’s post concerns some familiar names, like Stanley Cup playoff hero Jaroslav Halak, Alex Kovalev, Nikolai Khabibulin, as well as items on the Rangers hopeful Ryan McDonagh and the Anaheim Ducks owners.

headline: Matt Damon in '30 Rock'
text: The actor guest stars as Tina Fey's boyfriend.

headline: Visiting Pakistan’s Cut-Off Villages
text: Two months after the worst flooding in decades displaced millions of Pakistanis, Britain’s Channel 4 News reports that tens of thousands of people remain stranded in villages and farmsteads across the southern province of Sindh.

headline: Clip: 'It's Kind of a Funny Story'
text: A John Hughes-inspired scene from "It's Kind of a Funny Story," with Keir Gilchrist and Emma Roberts.

headline: Nets Discuss 4-Team Deal to Acquire Anthony
text: A complex four-team trade that would send Carmelo Anthony to New Jersey  and renew the dormant rivalry between the Nets and the Knicks  was under discussion Friday as N.B.A. teams prepared to open training camps.

headline: And in the Left Corner, Weighing In ...
text: “I’M one of those actors who finds the part in the wardrobe,” Lawrence O’Donnell said. “So this dressing like an anchorman thing is beginning to work.”

headline: Festivals Grow Up, Even as Screens Grow Small
text: FOR much of the world, film festivals remain impossibly glamorous affairs filled with rapturous beauties, flashing lights and the adoring cries of the public, an image that hews closer to a Federico Fellini film than the truth. These days, festivals tend to look very different, partly because their mission extends beyond the 10 or so days of the event itself. This might have interested the film theorist André Bazin, who in the early 1950s asked of the Cannes Film Festival, “Why can’t we have a serious geology as well as a flashy geography of our art?” At the time, Cannes didn’t present retrospective screenings that allowed festivalgoers to explore the history (geology) of cinema and not just its gaudy surface (geography). These days, the major festivals attend to both, and more.

headline: Betty White in 'Community'
text: The actress guest stars as a professor.

headline: Clip: 'The Breakfast Club'
text: A scene from John Hughes's "Breakfast Club."

headline: Justin Bieber on 'C.S.I.'
text: The pop singer guest stars as a troubled youth.

headline: YouTube Introduces a Travel Channel
text: YouTube introduced an online travel channel this month called the YouTube Vacationer. Sponsored by Norwegian Cruise Line, it features short videos on various destinations and activities organized geographically by tabs: Caribbean/Bahamas; Europe; United States and Canada; and Exotic (Latin America, Middle East, Africa).

headline: ‘Wall Street’ Sequel: Buy, Sell or Hold?
text: Gordon Gekko is back. Whether that is entirely a good thing is open for debate – and there is no shortage of debate on the subject.

headline: London Design Festival | Cool and Cooler
text: This morning, Jasper Morrison held a press preview at his London studio and shop. He was showing the final prototypes of three designs: the country Trainer, a redesign of Camper’s 1975 Camaleon shoe; the r5.5 platinum chronograph for the Swiss watchmaker Rado; and the DP01 phone for Punkt, a new Swiss company. I liked them all, but I loved the phone. It sits keyboard side up on a hammock-like base, so you can read the screen and dial the number without picking it up, and the handset is magnetized, so the phone can sit horizontally or vertically (and be mounted on a wall). That it’s simple and beautiful goes without saying. The only bad thing about this phone is that it will not be available in the United States.

headline: SoHo Holdouts
text: Murray Reich and Elizabeth Weatherford moved to SoHo when it was in transition from an industrial neighborhood to a residential frontier colonized by artists. They still live in their original loft, now quite domesticated.

headline: A Teenager Flying Over a Cuckoo’s Nest
text: WHEN thinking of the directors Ryan Fleck and Anna Boden, light comedy may not be the first thing to come to mind. The team’s first movie, “Half Nelson,” examined the life of a drug-addicted schoolteacher, while the follow-up, “Sugar,” tracked the trials of a Dominican baseball player who joins a minor-league team in Iowa. But the filmmakers have a message for audiences: They do have a sense of humor. And they love John Hughes.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Pakistan, Afghanistan, India, Cuba and China. (And, nearly all seriousness aside, don’t stop till the very end of today’s show, where there is some end-of-the-week comedy, centrally from Stephen Colbert, who testified before Congress in Washington on Friday.)

headline: A Recession’s Effect on Poverty
text: The recession pushed nearly 100,000 additional New York City residents into poverty last year, according to an analysis by the Fiscal Policy Institute to be published on Monday.

headline: Fast and Finely Crafted, Spindizzies Still Dazzle
text: Fresno, Calif.

headline: Living in Prince’s Bay, Staten Island
text: A lush seaside community in Staten Island, Prince’s Bay has a relatively modern housing stock, along with a few older homes.

headline: Credit Unions Expand Their Clientele
text: OVER the years, a number of home buyers have turned to credit unions as a less expensive alternative, often finding fixed- and adjustable-rate mortgages with interest rates equal to or lower than those offered by mainstream banks.

headline: The 3,200-Square-Foot Adventure
text: IN a fourth-floor loft on Spring Street near Greene Street, where a century ago workers cut fabric for hospital scrubs, a fragment of the old SoHo is preserved as if in amber, removed from the tourists and shoppers who now crowd the streets.

headline: Annemarie G. DiCola
text: Ms. DiCola is the chief executive of Trepp, a private analytics company based in New York that tracks the market for commercial real estate financing, from commercial mortgage-backed securities, or C.M.B.S., to bank lending.

headline: Leaving Room to Renovate
text: SOME buyers who scooped up homes at lower prices thanks to the economy are now plowing what they saved into renovations and decorating.

headline: A Planned Community Stays the Course
text: NORWALK

headline: Real Estate Q & A
text: A Repair Needed by Next Summer

headline: Silvercup Studios Founders Enter the Condo Fray
text: The Industry, a new apartment building in Long Island City, Queens, is coming a little late to the local condominium party, but its developers have already played a role in the area’s recent transformation from industrial to residential.

headline: Horses, Beaches, Boats and New Houses
text: IN real estate, as in romance, leaving your first love can be hard to do. For John Rosas Jr., who lived most of his first 38 years in Bensonhurst, choosing to buy a home outside of Brooklyn was not accomplished without emotion. But in 2008, after a brief rental in the Oakwood section of Staten Island, Mr. Rosas and his wife, Nikki, packed up their three children and moved to Prince’s Bay, on the south shore.

headline: A Tall Order for a Large Family
text: THREE years ago, when Lisa Rosenberg and Thomas Kitts met at a neighborhood bar, they lived half a mile apart in Brooklyn, each renting a three-bedroom apartment, each divorced and the parent of two teenagers, each paying around $2,000 a month.

headline: Seat-of-the-Pants Driving Lessons, Courtesy of Lexus
text: Certain carmakers are pretty eager to do anything to get the word safety into the same sentence as their company name, and Lexus — there, it did it — is one of them. On Friday morning in a parking lot at the Meadowlands in New Jersey, though, the company took what might seem to be an incongruous route to that goal, inviting journalists to stop by and purposely drive some Lexus vehicles recklessly.

headline: Spindizzies in a Tizzy
text: From the beginning, tether cars were much more than simple toys.

headline: Efforts to Promote Electric Cars Charge Ahead
text: Consumers are getting used to seeing pitches for electric cars, thanks to the big ad campaign from Nissan Motor for its coming Leaf as well as efforts by Chevrolet to familiarize the public with the coming Volt.

headline: Yankees Getting Rotation in Order
text: With the Yankees close to securing a playoff berth, Joe Girardi announced on Friday the first of a few changes intended to align the rotation heading in the division series opener on Oct. 6.

headline: Photographer to Lead Reuters Pictures
text: Reinhard Krause has spent much of his photojournalism career in some of the most tumultuous and critical places on the planet — including North Korea, Kosovo, Tibet and, most recently, the flooded regions of Pakistan. Beginning in November, all the hot spots in the world will constitute his beat, as the global pictures editor of Reuters, leading 400 staff and freelance photographers.

headline: For Tether Car Collectors, Originality Counts Most
text: SPINDIZZIES, or tether cars, come in three categories of descending value: original as raced, restored and reproduced.

headline: Just Tune In. Please. He’ll Do Anything.
text: Kyle Killen will mow your lawn if you’ll just watch his television show.

headline: Resources for Novices
text: TETHER car races are regularly held at three tracks: in Anderson, Ind.; Seaford, N.Y.; and the Whittier Narrows Recreation Area in South El Monte, Calif. Details are at amrca.com.

headline: California Dreaming
text: Jay Carroll, the man behind the style site onetrippass.com, and who was recently featured in our men’s fall fashion issue, has spent the last week driving from Portland, Oregon to Los Angeles with Jou-Yie Chou, the curator of the Ace Hotel and photographer Nate Bressler. Travelling in a vintage Airstream, they’ve picked up a couple of stylish friends —Cassie McGettigan, co-owner of San Francisco’s Gravel & Gold,  Andrea Westerlind, the brand manager for outerwear company Fjallraven— along the way. The mission was simple: to collect all things California—from interesting artwork to vintage crafts. “Who doesn’t want to cruise around the West Coast cultivating a cross section of California culture in an Airstream with good friends,” says Carroll. “Stopping to camp every night, drink PBR and blast a daily dose of vitamin Neil?”

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Sept. 24
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Report: Max Weinberg Won’t Follow Conan to TBS
text: On a day of rapid transitions and abrupt departures in the television industry, could the late-night landscape at least be spared? Apparently not: Max Weinberg, the drummer and longtime band leader for Conan O’Brien, will not be following the host to his new show at TBS, according to a report in The Riverfront Times of St. Louis.

headline: Choreographic Institute Alumni to Present Works
text: Larry Keigwin, Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon are among the alumni of the New York Choreographic Institute who will create original works for the 10th-anniversary celebration of the organization, an affiliate of New York City Ballet. Their work, along with new pieces by their fellow alumni Darius Barnes, Marco Goecke, Jessica Lang and Justin Peck, will be performed during three shows at the Miller Theater at Columbia University on Nov. 5 and 6. Members of New York City Ballet, including Joaquin De Luz, Megan Fairchild, Sara Mearns, Tiler Peck, Teresa Reichlen, Wendy Whelan and Andrew Veyette, as well as students from the School of American Ballet, will perform and live music will be provided by the American Contemporary Music Ensemble. Mr. Keigwin, Mr. Ratmansky and Mr. Wheeldon will each create a short dance set to the same original music by Daniel Ott. The New York Choreographic Institute was founded in 2000 by the philanthropist Irene Diamond and City Ballet’s ballet master in chief, Peter Martins, as a laboratory for classical choreography.

headline: Thursday Is Father’s Day
text: Viewers gave two new sitcoms solid debuts on Thursday night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “$#*! My Dad Says,” a CBS series starring William Shatner that is based on a Twitter feed, earned an impressive start, attracting 12.5 million viewers. That was down from the 14 million who watched the premiere of CBS’s “Big Bang Theory,” but enough to outperform all other programming for the night, with the exception of season premieres of ABC’s “Grey’s Anatomy” (14 million), CBS’s “CSI” (14.6 million) and “The Mentalist” (15.3 million). NBC’s “Outsourced” (7.4 million) also made a promising start, about a million less than its lead-in, “The Office” (8.4 million), but considerably better than NBC’s returning comedies “Community” (five million) and “30 Rock” (5.8 million). Meanwhile, the new series “My Generation” kicked off the night for ABC with a disappointing 5.2 million viewers.

headline: Armfuls of Wiener Rolls, Mouthfuls of Coffee Milk and Outstretched Palms
text: NORTH PROVIDENCE, R.I.

headline: Improvising, in Truest Sense of the Word
text: The most important member of Rhonda Vincent’s touring troupe on Thursday night turned out not to be her fiddle player or her bassist but her bus driver. Sometime during the afternoon, while the band was already in Manhattan, he got into an accident in the Lincoln Tunnel. The instruments, the stage outfits, the merchandise: none of it made it to Joe’s Pub by showtime.

headline: A Thai Region Where Husbands Are Imported
text: UDON, THAILAND — The most dazzling creatures Nui Davis saw when she was a child were the village girls who had found foreign husbands, visiting in their Western finery and handing out candies to the children.

headline: Dell Settles a Client’s Claim That It Hid Computer Defects
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Dell settled a lawsuit Thursday that accused it of selling faulty computers and then trying to conceal the defects from its customers.

headline: With Flesh Like This, Who Needs Food?
text: Dance doesn’t usually occupy that part of contemporary life that lets us update our Facebook status while simultaneously blogging, sending an e-mail, listening to voice mail and consulting an app. Dance typically needs flesh-and-blood bodies, with an old-fashioned concentration on complex physical activity, in one place at one time.

headline: Yale’s Endowment Returns 8.9% for the Year
text: Yale University said on Friday that its endowment, which has sizable assets in real estate, had an investment gain of 8.9 percent last year, an underwhelming performance in a year when many big endowments are reporting gains of 9 percent to 14 percent.

headline: Seduced by a Savior Who Likes to Dance
text: The theme of Danspace Project’s latest Platform series, “certain difficulties, certain joy,” fits Larissa Velez-Jackson perfectly. A choreographer who is not afraid of being (or showing) ugly onstage, she also disarms her audiences with  humor. When the approach works  as it did to varying degrees on Thursday night  there is a dark charm to the way difficulty and joy bump up against each other and, in fleeting moments, interlace.

headline: Sounds Both Skin Deep and Soul-Piercing
text: The New York early-music world has ways of squelching ambition and keeping its practitioners humble.

headline: Savory Cheddar Biscotti
text: Mark Bittman adds cheese, herbs and spices to biscotti, which need not be sweet.

headline: It’s Kind of a John Hughes Homage
text: The spirit of John Hughes seems to be making a resurgence this fall. Last week, the Film Society of Lincoln Center paid its respects to the director, who died last year, with a 25th-Anniversary screening of his teen comedy “The Breakfast Club.” Now, Ryan Fleck and Anna Boden, the filmmakers behind the dramas “Half Nelson” and “Sugar,” make their third directorial outing with a comedy inspired in part by Mr. Hughes’s work. “It’s Kind of a Funny Story,” which opens October 8, is based on the young adult novel by Ned Vizzini and, much in the Hughesian tradition, features a teenage protagonist (Keir Gilchrist). Mr. Fleck and Ms. Boden discussed Mr. Hughes’s impact in an interview for Arts & Leisure. While they didn’t aim to copy the director’s style, they did make a direct homage to “The Breakfast Club” in one scene. Below is a look at the scene from “Funny Story.”

headline: Sunday Preview
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: Vaccinations for Grown-Ups
text: So when is the last time you went to the doctor to get shots?

headline: Structural Failure
text: An important new report from EPI on why you shouldn’t believe the hype about structural unemployment.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 24
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the aftermath of the Brooklyn tornadoes, Carl P. Paladino’s surging campaign for governor and a demonstration during the president of Iran’s visit to the United Nations.

headline: Putting Ballads Aside for Soul That’s More Soothing Than Sweaty
text: A digitized American flag was fluttering on the large scrim behind John Legend & the Roots on Thursday night at Terminal 5 as they began a cover version of Bill Withers’s 1972 Vietnam protest, “I Can’t Write Left Handed.” The United States, Mr. Legend noted unctuously, is still at war.

headline: Spice Gives Biscotti a Whole New Personality
text: EVERYONE knows biscotti, the crunchy twice-cooked, cookie-like bars that you dip into your cappuccino or sweet wine. But biscotti need not be flavored with chocolate or hazelnuts. They do not even need to be sweet. You can add cheese, herbs, spices, even chopped sun-dried tomatoes or olives, making these biscuits a nifty alternative to crackers.

headline: As Sales Slump, Rental Stock Rises
text: IN New Jersey, those big suburban homes that used to be called exemplars of the American dream of homeownership are increasingly available for a monthly fee.

headline: Bank Losses Lead to Drop in Credit Card Debt
text: The substantial drop in credit card debt in the United States since early 2009 has been widely attributed to newly frugal consumers. But analysts say that a significant portion of the decline is actually the result of financial institutions writing off billions of dollars in credit card debt as losses.

headline: Matali Crasset Takes Manhattan (and Tunisia)
text: The jazz trumpeter Dizzie Gillespie never actually spent a night in Tunisia, but New Yorkers will now have an occasion to do so. The future-fabulous Parisian designer Matali Crasset just landed in New York to promote a new eco lodge she designed in Nefta, in southern Tunisia, as well as check on the lounge she designed for this weekend’s Le Grand Fooding at P.S.1 in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Making Savory Biscotti
text: Biscotti are sweet, right? Not necessarily. Check these out.

headline: Class Alliances and Ambition in Thatcher Time
text: The Long Good Friday

headline: Inside a Grand Church, His Days Are Numbered
text: Comparing the buttoned-up experience of seeing a play to going to church is an old insult, but maybe it shouldn’t be. Or at least that’s what you might think while watching the dynamic modern-dress revival of T. S. Eliot’s “Murder in the Cathedral,” which takes place in the pews, inside illuminated confessional booths and under the cross of a grand church in Brooklyn that has seen better days.

headline: A Small Runner With the Capacity for Big Things
text: The most dangerous runner in the elite men’s field of the Fifth Avenue Mile on Sunday may well be the smallest. Leonel Manzano, 5 feet 5 inches and 122 pounds, spent the summer slaying giants on the European track circuit with his devastating finishing kick.

headline: Ideas That Go Beyond Heritage
text: Milan

headline: Tall Towers and Sharp Razors
text: Q. For exactly how long was 40 Wall Street the tallest building in the world? Six days? Six hours? Please tell.

headline: Staying Out of Trouble When Buying Art
text: In this weekend’s Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan offers some words of warning to people getting ready to buy art at the autumn auctions.

headline: Starbucks, With Pooch in Purse
text: Kristin Chenoweth, a Tony- and Emmy-winning actress (and “Glee” guest star), recently extended her run starring with Sean Hayes in “Promises, Promises,” the musical revival playing at the Broadway Theater, through Jan. 2. For Ms. Chenoweth, 42, this means more time in New York, where she lives on the Upper West Side with her Maltese, Madeline. Despite a 3 o’clock Sunday matinee, she makes time for God and Starbucks. —ELISSA GOOTMAN

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Sept. 24
text: More Photographs

headline: Playing a Superhero, Yes; Typecasting, No
text: BURBANK, Calif.  The actor Michael Chiklis, wearing a suit jacket riddled with bullet holes, seemed fretful, though not about the bullets.

headline: Widespread Fraud Seen in Latest Afghan Elections
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Evidence is mounting that fraud in last weekend’s parliamentary election was so widespread that it could affect the results in a third of provinces, calling into question the credibility of a vote that was an important test of the American and Afghan effort to build a stable and legitimate government.

headline: Scorecard | Prada Wins!
text: We must be over the rainbow! With a splash of Technicolor in evidence even at the austere house of Fendi, and New York’s black and white minimalism now seeming a (relatively) distant memory, on our second day on the Continent, Scorecard crowns Miuccia “Go for Baroque” Prada the Good Witch of Milan.

headline: Making a Name Writing to Editors
text: JUST before 9 a.m. on a Monday, Bobby Crawford arrived at the Hearst Tower, the slick Midtown temple of glossies like Esquire and Cosmopolitan. In the sprawling lobby, editors, writers and arbiters of style glided skyward to their respective aeries, on escalators flanked by rainwater waterfalls. Mr. Crawford, 38, skateboard under his arm, headed to his work space through a side door, taking the stairs beneath the escalators to the basement. He’s the mail guy.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: THE WHISKEY BROOKLYN, the latest bar to push the nightlife scene deeper into north Williamsburg, is more than just a place to drink. It is the culmination of a dream for two brothers, Justin and George Ruotolo, who diligently saved tips while working as bartenders to start their own chain of bars. “It’s the first we’ve built from the ground up,” said Justin, 31, who owns two bars in downtown Manhattan with George, 38. (The brothers have another business partner, Rob Magill.)

headline: TV Guests Overstaying Their Welcome
text: Stunt casting — and that includes Justin Bieber on the season premiere of “CSI”  on Thursday and Jennifer Aniston on “Cougar Town” the day before — is the new plague of television. And a little like that other maddening affliction, bedbugs, it too is rooted in good intentions.

headline: Fight Gets Louder Between Bars and Neighbors as Heat Subsides
text: As the numbingly hot and airless days of summer have given way to the cool snap of fall, New Yorkers have been spilling back outdoors for a drink at a backyard patio or rooftop lounge.

headline: Ira Judelson, Bail Bondsman
text: He gets the call when the famous, the infamous and the everyman have trouble with the law.

headline: Marcie Weibgen, Peter Scranton
text: Marcie Fried Weibgen and Peter Scranton were married Saturday at the Inn of the Seventh Ray, a restaurant in Topanga, Calif. Barton Phelps, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: After a Losing Spade Lead, His Trumps Come to the Rescue
text: At the Buffett Cup in Wales this month, the most successful player for the losing European team was Claudio Nunes from Italy. He won 10.5 points, 1.75 more than Daniela von Arnim from Germany.

headline: Mad Men, and Women, to Gather in New York
text: Organizers are putting the final touches on the seventh annual Advertising Week, a kind of Madison Avenue version of Fashion Week.

headline: No Tethering, and It’s All Good
text: MANY of Judy Collins’s love songs are filled with images of wildflowers, wild men, broken hearts and stormy weather. It is often snowing, hard, when people fall in or out of love. Ms. Collins, 71, grew up in Colorado and like many people in the Rocky Mountains, she associates snow with love.

headline: Anne Green, Leonard Braman
text: Anne Elizabeth Green and Leonard Matthew Braman were married Saturday evening by Rabbi James Prosnit at the Greentree Country Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

headline: Erin Pond, Peter Friedland
text: Erin Adele Pond, the daughter of Kirk P. Pond of Cape Elizabeth, Me., and the late Loretta T. Pond, was married Saturday to Peter Hess Friedland, the son of Marlene Hess of New York and Dennis A. Friedland of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. John B. McCall, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at the Inn by the Sea in Cape Elizabeth; Rabbi Richard S. Chapin took part.

headline: Bailing Out the Stars
text: A SELLOUT crowd and a $300,000 payday awaited the comedian Katt Williams one November evening two years ago. It was to be his first performance at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Injecting a Sense of Play in Religious Tradition
text: Over by the subway entrance, a Trotskyite with a megaphone was mounting his soap box. On the steps, some artfully unbathed skatepunks were laughing and smoking. And from across the street, the unholy trinity of ShoeMania, Whole Foods and Forever 21 were bathing the scene in a multicolor neon glow. It was another Sunday night in Union Square Park.

headline: Sanchez Under Fire for Ethnic Remarks
text: LOS ANGELES – Loretta Sanchez, a Democrat, is attracting criticism for a remark to a television reporter that, “the Vietnamese and the Republicans” were “trying to take away” her seat representing California’s 47th Congressional District.

headline: Republican Ad Ties Manchin to Obama
text: Do Republicans in Washington think they can capture the Senate seat in West Virginia? A new $1.2 million advertising buy in the state certainly seems to suggest they do.

headline: Success With Pinot Noir
text: Conventional wisdom, which questions whether Long Island is pinot noir country, hasn’t daunted Russell McCall.

headline: Counting on Luck, and Asian Favorites
text: THE name of the Farmingville restaurant J & C 68 may require an explanation. The J stands for Japanese, the C for Chinese; the 68 was added because the numbers 6 and 8 are considered lucky in China.

headline: On Our Radar: Hardball on Drilling Ban
text: Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, plays hardball on the deepwater drilling moratorium: she threatens to block President Obama’s pick to run the Office of Management and Budget unless the ban, set to expire at the end of November, is immediately lifted. Earlier this week, Ms. Landrieu declared she would vote against a bipartisan renewable energy bill unless the drilling ban was lifted. [New Orleans Times-Picayune]

headline: A Community-Minded Market
text: It’s B.Y.O.B. (bring your own bag), reusable please, to Chappaqua’s Table Farm Market, which opened this month at the Chappaqua train station.

headline: Firing Up the Barbecue the Korean Way
text: SEVEN years ago, Kalbi House moved into a space in White Plains that was previously occupied by a Japanese restaurant, which may explain why a sushi counter is still in play here, even though Korean dishes dominate the menu.

headline: One-Stop Cheesemaking
text: Eran Wajswol and his wife, Debra Van Sickle, who own the Valley Shepherd Creamery in Long Valley, saw something like a stampede when they inaugurated the Autumn Leaves Artisan Cheese and Foods Festival three years ago.

headline: A Steakhouse Roams Far From the Range
text: IT seems logical somehow that Zylo, a sleek Italian restaurant on the southern stretch of Hoboken’s riverfront promenade, has a direct view across the Hudson of the meatpacking district of Manhattan. It’s essentially cut from the same cloth as many of that neighborhood’s dining spots, with its casually chic vibe, coolly modern interior and carefully calibrated menu, all played for maximum dramatic effect.

headline: The Honey Makers and Their Keepers
text: TAKE a bite of a Connecticut-grown apple and you may be struck by its crisp texture, the juiciness of its pulp, perhaps even the skill of the farmer who grew it. What probably will not cross your mind are all of the honeybees that helped produce that apple and most of the others grown in the state.

headline: G.M., Ford and Kia Lead Nominees for Car of the Year
text: General Motors, Ford Motor and Kia each have three contenders for the North American Car and Truck of the Year Awards, to be announced in January at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.

headline: To Repair Aging B.Q.E., Tunnels Are on Table
text: Like many New Yorkers, the people of Brooklyn Heights have something of a love-hate relationship with the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.

headline: Regulators Step in to Aid Credit Unions
text: Nearly two years after Wall Street’s giants were rescued by the federal government, regulators on Friday took over three financial institutions that provide the underpinning for hundreds of the nation’s credit unions.

headline: Citigroup’s Pandit Takes $1 in Compensation for 2010
text: Vikram S. Pandit, Citigroup’s chief executive, turned down a potentially lucrative compensation package for the second consecutive year in a move that could help him avoid the uproar over pay in the postbailout era.

headline: A Spotlight on Shaken Baby Syndrome

headline: Obesity in Children
text: To the Editor:

headline: Eliza and Henry, and an Undercurrent
text: It’s hard to imagine today the sensation that “My Fair Lady” caused when it made its debut on Broadway in 1956. After reading the glowing reviews, theater lovers across the nation longed to see it. My mother became an instant celebrity among her friends in Atlanta after she went while visiting New York.

headline: A Billionaire Army of One vs. a Bank
text: A few weeks ago, I was pitched a seemingly irresistible story about an investor who had been wronged by JPMorgan Chase during the financial crisis. The investor, Len Blavatnik, was now fighting in court to get back some of the money he had lost because of the bank’s alleged negligence.

headline: A Shake-Up at HSBC, Known for a Steady Hand
text: LONDON  The British banking giant HSBC Holdings said Friday that Michael Geoghegan had stepped down as chief executive after not being promoted to chairman, a surprise departure that has rattled a bank not generally known for boardroom intrigue.

headline: Seeking the Natural Tie of Art and Science
text: Artists and scientists have plenty in common: Both work in competitive fields that value creativity, ingenuity and results. But an artist is not a scientist, and vice versa  unless you are Natalie Jeremijenko. Ms. Jeremijenko has degrees in fields that link biochemistry, physics, neuroscience and engineering. She directs the Environmental Health Clinic at New York University, crossing over into the art and computer science departments. But all that really matters when visiting “Natalie Jeremijenko: Connected Environments” at the Neuberger Museum of Art is how what is on view functions as art.

headline: Stepping Down, NBC Chief Relishes His Long Tenure
text: Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal and the longest-serving senior manager at NBC Universal, announced Friday that he would step down upon the completion of the takeover of NBC by Comcast.

headline: A Bicycle Trip for a New Art Space
text: LAST year, the small stucco building that had long been called the Tee Ridder Miniatures Museum got a new mission as an art museum for children. Now called the Art Space for Children and part of the 145-acre Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor, it is on the verge of a greater transformation that would increase its size and programming, and change its look entirely.

headline: Where East Weds West
text: In Udon Thani, a poor farming area in northeastern Thailand, marriages between Western men and Thai women are so common that they have become a local business.

headline: Escher’s Journeys to and From Reality
text: Art usually presents us with incontrovertible facts. Abstract canvas or marble bust, representational drawing or fanciful relief  all fix a specific image in a specific way for all time.

headline: The Killing of Afghan Civilians
text: To the Editor:

headline: Circus Magic, With Legendary Undertones
text: If you look carefully at the program for “Aurélia’s Oratorio,” you will see the name Chaplin. (It’s part of the director’s name.) If you see “Aurélia’s Oratorio,” now at the McCarter Theater Center, without having read the program that carefully, you may be too busy smiling and laughing appreciatively to think about anybody’s family background.

headline: Fair and Equal Paychecks for Women

headline: Chicanery Abounds in a New ‘All’s Well’
text: Watching “All’s Well That Ends Well,” Shakespeare’s fairy tale of a comedy, now in a captivating new production at the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey, we want to believe in the possibility of a truly happy ending. With all the indignities suffered by Helena, the lovely “poor physician’s daughter” who is rejected by her husband, we’re rooting for her to come out a winner.

headline: Combating Poverty in Tough Economic Times
text: To the Editor:

headline: CNN Fires Executive Who Led Makeover
text: There has been a corporate bull’s-eye on the back of Jonathan Klein, the president of CNN/U.S., for years, because of the stubbornly low ratings of his channel’s prime time lineup. But it still came as a shock to many CNN employees when Mr. Klein was fired Friday, ending a six-year run at the head of the beleaguered cable news channel.

headline: Accelerant Was on Girls’ Beds, Witness Tells a Connecticut Jury
text: NEW HAVEN  Accelerant was poured across the beds where the two daughters of a family in Cheshire, Conn., had been tied before a fire during a home invasion in 2007, a fire investigator told jurors on Friday.

headline: Donatella Versace Has Friends for Dinner and Dances
text: MILAN — The models at the Versace show tonight looked wetted down; their shoulders and chests glistened, their red lips were heavily glossed and their hair was pulled into tight buns and covered with a snood of black vinyl or patent leather. Donatella Versace used all the top girls, naturally, and I can’t remember when they looked that good. They could certainly walk, and that hasn’t been true for a lot of the models this week in Milan. They seem to waver rather than walk.

headline: In Diverging New York Polls, Methods Mattered
text: The campaign for governor of New York was shaken up this week by the release of polls that offered vastly different impressions of the race more than six weeks before Election Day.

headline: Six Technology Firms Agree to More Hiring Competition
text: The American job market is tough for many workers, but things are looking even better than usual for highly paid engineers and scientists in Silicon Valley.

Chesterton, the perhaps over-beloved Catholic controversialist whom I’ve been occasionally (just occasionally!) known to quote, and defend, and generally applaud. Bramwell’s complaint, roughly speaking, is that Chesterton wasn’t intellectually rigorous enough, and that his grand style is too easily mistaken for substance:

text: The technology industry is being rattled by a quiet and sophisticated malicious software program that has infiltrated factory computers.

headline: The Provocateur Loading Paladino’s Slingshot
text: He has hired strippers to embarrass a political opponent. He cycles through eight pairs of eyeglasses to make himself more difficult to recognize. And he readily shows reporters the scar from a bullet wound he says was the result of a drunken encounter with a rival in Russia.

text: Many football coaches are convinced they could pass right out of this world while the last-second field-goal attempt swerves wide right  or sails directly through the posts. Either way.

headline: Gazing Up at First, Francona Can Hold His Head High

headline: Further Improbables
text: What good, smart reading your comments are on my column about how unlikely our existence is.

headline: With Sharp Putting Stroke, Furyk Takes Share of Lead
text: ATLANTA  With much of the field battling the tight fairways and gnarly rough at East Lake Golf Club on Friday, three of the best putters in the game cracked the code on the greens and rose to the top of the leader board after two rounds of the Tour Championship.

headline: Agency Admits Fault in Death of Child
text: A supervisor and a caseworker for New York City’s child welfare agency have been suspended without pay for failing to adequately oversee the case of a bruised and emaciated 4-year-old girl who was found dead in her mother’s apartment in Brooklyn this month, the agency said Friday.

headline: Feb. 10, 1990: My Time as a Sniper
text: All that is keeping women out of combat is the same discrimination we’ve faced breaking into every other male-dominated position.

headline: From Young Mogul, a Gift on the Scale of Philanthropy’s Elders
text: PALO ALTO  Mark Zuckerberg, America’s youngest billionaire at 26, has not spent much money on himself. Forbes estimates his fortune at $6.9 billion, but Mr. Zuckerberg, chief executive of Facebook, has yet to sell any sizable portion of his holdings in the company.

headline: GMAC’s Errors Leave Foreclosures in Question
text: The recent admission by a major mortgage lender that it had filed dubious foreclosure documents is likely to fuel a furor against hasty foreclosures, which have prompted complaints nationwide since housing prices collapsed.

headline: What Really Scares Microsoft

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 24
text: A view of the day in sports, from rhythm gymnastics to basketball.

headline: List Shows Surprising Police Expenses for Summit Security
text: OTTAWA  Canadians were amazed to learn that hosting the world’s leaders at back-to-back summit meetings on a weekend in June cost more than $1 billion, most of it for security. Their surprise was renewed this week when newly released documents provided a glimpse into how the police had managed to spend so much money in so little time.

headline: Nets’ Future May Take Some Time to Arrive
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In the lobby of the Nets’ practice facility, a calendar on a wall counts down the days until the start of the season. The reality is that the Nets appear to be waiting much longer for their future to arrive.
