headline: Megan Hollaway, James Ponsoldt
text: The Rev. Megan Lane Hollaway and James Adam Ponsoldt were married Saturday at St. Paul’s Episcopal Church in Richmond, Va. The Rev. David H. May, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Dominique Lee, Joshua Abbott
text: Dominique Younga Lee and Joshua Stone Abbott are to be married Sunday evening. The Rev. Marie April Gismondi, a minister of the Church of Ancient Ways, is scheduled to officiate at Bubby’s restaurant in Brooklyn.

headline: Jennifer Smythe, Jackson Rice
text: Jennifer Anne Smythe, the daughter of John B. Smythe and Patricia Smythe of Glen Rock, N.J., was married Saturday to Jackson Elliott Rice, the son of Cynthia Elliott and R. Douglass Rice of New York. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the summer home of the bridegroom’s family in Stonington, Conn.

headline: Elizabeth Van Heuvelen, Adam Shoemaker
text: Elizabeth Sherburne Van Heuvelen, the daughter of Jane C. Sherburne and Robert Van Heuvelen of Bethesda, Md., was married Saturday to Adam Matthew Shoemaker, the son of Rebecca S. Shoemaker and Raymond L. Shoemaker of Indianapolis. The Rev. Art Vermillion, a Disciples of Christ minister, officiated at the National City Christian Church in Washington. The Rev. Steven Moore, the associate minister of the church and also a Disciples of Christ minister, took part.

headline: Bridgit DePietto, Peter Hardin
text: Bridgit Marie DePietto, a daughter of Kathleen Anne DePietto and Anthony Joseph DePietto Jr. of DeBary, Fla., was married Saturday evening in New Orleans to Capt. Peter Parrish Hardin, a son of Jo Parrish Hardin and Judge Adlai Stevenson Hardin Jr. of New York. The bridegroom’s father, a retired federal bankruptcy judge for the Southern District of New York, officiated at the Audubon Zoo.

headline: Amy Vittorio, Edward Travaglianti
text: Amy Catherine Vittorio, a daughter of Linda C. and Michael N. Vittorio of Merrick, N.Y., was married to Edward Joseph Travaglianti, the son of Patricia and Edward Travaglianti of Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., on Saturday at the Curé of Ars Roman Catholic Church in Merrick. The Rev. Edward J. Brown, a Roman Catholic priest and a chaplain at Long Island University’s C. W. Post campus in Brookville, N.Y., officiated.

headline: Megan Hafner, John Bacigalupi
text: Megan Rachel Hafner and John Mellott Bacigalupi were married Saturday at the Padua Hill Theater, an event space in Claremont, Calif. Tom Sverchek, a friend who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Bianna Golodryga, Peter R. Orszag
text: Bianna Golodryga and Peter R. Orszag were married Saturday evening at Capitale, an event space in New York. Rabbi Sarah H. Reines officiated.

headline: Amy Strekas, Nathaniel Katin-Borland
text: Amy Marie Strekas, the daughter of Fara L. Strekas and Thomas Strekas of Baldwin, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Nathaniel Katin-Borland, a son of Marj Katin-Borland and Bruce Katin-Borland of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. Sam R. Watkins, a village justice in Croton-on-Hudson, officiated at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Erin Pond, Peter Friedland
text: Erin Adele Pond, the daughter of Kirk P. Pond of Cape Elizabeth, Me., and the late Loretta T. Pond, was married Saturday to Peter Hess Friedland, the son of Marlene Hess of New York and Dennis A. Friedland of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. John B. McCall, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Inn by the Sea in Cape Elizabeth; Rabbi Richard S. Chapin took part.

headline: Melissa Rothberg and Ben Goldberger
text: Melissa Blair Rothberg, the daughter of Katherina B. Rothberg and James A. Rothberg of Nashville, was married Saturday evening to Ben Goldberger, a son of Susan L. Solomon and Paul Goldberger of New York. Rabbi Kenneth A. Kanter officiated at a 200-acre farm in Kingston Springs, Tenn., that is owned by friends of the bride’s family.

headline: Megan Hafner, John Bacigalupi
text: Megan Rachel Hafner and John Mellott Bacigalupi were married Saturday at the Padua Hill Theater, an event space in Claremont, Calif. Tom Sverchek, a friend who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Christina Lewis, Daniel Halpern
text: Christina S. N. Lewis, a daughter of Loida Nicolas Lewis of New York and the late Reginald F. Lewis, was married Saturday to Daniel Halpern, the son of Joan Halpern and Joseph Halpern of Brookline, Mass. David N. Dinkins, the former mayor of New York, officiated in East Hampton, N.Y., at the home of the bride’s mother.

headline: Jesseca Salky, Christopher Cunneen
text: Jesseca Salky and Christopher Cunneen were married Saturday evening at the Center for Southern Folklore in Memphis. Diane K. Vescovo, a federal magistrate judge for the United States District Court for the Western District of Tennessee, officiated.

headline: Emily Curry, Christopher Schlosser
text: Emily Stanton Curry, a daughter of Helen P. Curry and Robert V. K. Curry of New Canaan, Conn., was married Saturday to Christopher Joseph Schlosser, the son of Susan M. Schlosser and R. Joseph Schlosser of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Judith M. Joyce, a minister affiliated with the Sanctuary of the Beloved, an interfaith religious organization, performed the ceremony at the Talmadge Hill Community Church in Darien, Conn.

headline: Laura Kimberly, Brigham Keehner
text: Laura Lenox Kimberly and Brigham Michael Keehner were married Tuesday at City Hall in Philadelphia. Judge Paul P. Panepinto, of the Court of Common Pleas in the First Judicial District of Pennsylvania, officiated.

headline: Peggy Bonapace, Richard Gelfond
text: Peggy Bonapace and Richard Lewis Gelfond were married on Friday by Judge Nicholas G. Garaufis at his chambers at Federal District Court in Brooklyn

headline: Peggy Bonapace, Richard Gelfond
text: Peggy Bonapace and Richard Lewis Gelfond were married on Friday by Judge Nicholas G. Garaufis at his chambers at Federal District Court in Brooklyn

headline: We Haven’t Hit Bottom Yet
text: Wallingford, Conn.

headline: On the Street | Prowling
text: The cat patterns that arrived with the first blast of fall dressing are often the stuff of accessories.

headline: Unhold Us, Senators
text: Congress is staggering toward recess. I’m going to go way out on a limb and guess that they’re not going to accomplish anything major before they leave. But as long as they’re still in town, taking up space, the least they could do is approve the National Women’s History Museum bill.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Gauging Jurors’ Fears Before a Terrorism Trial Even Starts
text: The 11-page questionnaire touches on some of the most volatile issues today. What are your views on the detention of terrorism suspects at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba? Do you have feelings about Islam or Muslims that you believe would make it hard for you to render a fair verdict? Are you afraid of dying in a terrorist attack?

headline: Bedbugs Finding a Way Into New York’s Schools
text: Having invaded New York City’s bedrooms, retail stores, movie theaters and offices, bedbugs are now showing up with growing frequency in another place: public schools.

headline: Judge Will Not Dismiss Charges on Misconduct Grounds in Mafia Case
text: A federal judge in Manhattan rejected on Friday a request that he dismiss charges in a prominent Mafia case on the grounds that the government had engaged in misconduct by allowing a cooperating witness to run a sex-trafficking ring that involved a 15-year-old girl.

headline: Cuba Details New Policies on Budding Entrepreneurs
text: MEXICO CITY  Cubans learned on Friday the details of what they would soon be able to do as budding entrepreneurs, including renting spaces for their businesses, hanging out a shingle, and if things go well, hiring a few employees.

headline: App Smart Extra: Organizing Business Cards
text: This week’s App Smart column features apps that quickly scan business cards and import that information to your smartphone.

headline: Bledsoe Grade Change Questioned but Upheld
text: An independent investigation into the improbable academic makeover of Eric Bledsoe, which allowed him to qualify for a scholarship at Kentucky, has concluded that the reasons for a grade change that assured him eligibility are “not credible.”

headline: Pakistani Journalist Speaks Out After an Attack
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — An investigative reporter for a major Pakistani newspaper was on his way home from dinner here on a recent night when men in black commando garb stopped his car, blindfolded him and drove him to a house on the outskirts of town.

headline: Saturday: Jack Benny Statue
text: RANCHO CUCAMONGA. Now there’s an answer. The city was originally a land grant when California was under Mexican control, became home to the state’s first winery and gained fame on The Jack Benny Program from Mel Blanc’s train depot character’s announcing, “Train now leaving on track five for Anaheim, Azusa and Cuc … amonga.” The name comes from the American Indian word “kukamonga,” meaning “sandy place.”

headline: Voters Moving to Oust Judges Over Decisions
text: DES MOINES  After the State Supreme Court here stunned the nation by making this the first state in the heartland to allow same-sex marriage, Iowa braced for its sleepy judicial elections to turn into referendums on gay marriage.

headline: Giants Prepare Replacement for O’Hara at Center
text: Eli Manning might have a new center this weekend.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: No Easy Explanation, but Statistic Is Signal of Mets’ Disappointment
text: PHILADELPHIA  Of all the statistics that capture the futility and disappointment of this season’s Mets, the record disparity between the number of grand slams they have allowed and the number they have hit is perhaps the most galling. Through 153 games, the Mets have not hit a grand slam, but they have given up 12, to become the only team to have such a glaring disproportion of grand slams in a season.

headline: Told to Eat Its Vegetables, America Orders Fries
text: It’s been a busy week for vegetables.

headline: Of Punching Hippies and Jumping Ship
text: Larry Summers? Outta here. David Axelrod? Him, too. Rahm Emanuel? Give it a minute.

headline: With September’s Goal in View, Yanks Put Rotation on an October Alignment
text: Slowly but surely, the Yankees’ plans for their postseason rotation are sharpening into focus. With a playoff berth in their grasp, Manager Joe Girardi revealed on Friday the first of a few changes intended to align the starting pitchers heading into the division series opener Oct. 6.

headline: Points Leader Kuchar Not Willing to Give Up
text: ATLANTA — No matter how it ends up for Matt Kuchar this week, he will have established himself in the minds of fans as the golfer least likely to blow a fuse, throw a club or throw in the towel.

headline: Gas Blasts Spur Questions on Oversight
text: At a Christmas Eve gathering in 2008, a natural gas explosion in a suburban Sacramento neighborhood killed a 72-year-old man and injured his daughter and granddaughter. Investigators determined that Pacific Gas and Electric was to blame for a leak, but federal and state regulators never cited the utility for safety violations.

headline: About Your Premiums
text: With health insurers jacking up their premiums by double-digit amounts for people who buy their own policies, Republicans have been predictably eager to blame health care reform. Consumers, and voters, beware.

headline: In Search of Mr. Cuomo
text: Andrew Cuomo, the Democratic nominee for governor of New York, may have imagined that he could coast into office without the messy inconvenience of actually campaigning. It is time to set that illusion aside. The Republican candidate, Carl Paladino, may be a blowhard without a serious plan to govern New York. But he is clearly ready to give Mr. Cuomo a fight.

headline: China, Japan and the Sea
text: China and Japan have wisely stepped back from a confrontation in the East China Sea. The incident showed the alarming potential for territorial disputes to quickly escalate and why the players need to work a lot harder to resolve competing claims.

headline: ‘What Do You Want From Us?’
text: An extraordinary front-page newspaper editorial on Sunday in Ciudad Juárez cast a chilling light on the mortal dangers faced by journalists in Mexico’s escalating drug wars. The editorial, in El Diario, was an open letter to the drug cartels who have slaughtered tens of thousands, including dozens of journalists  two from El Diario in the last two years.

headline: Afghan Equality and Law, but With Strings Attached
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  It was an engaging idea.

headline: Yanks Come Back, Just Not All the Way
text: The optimists out there will view Andy Pettitte’s outing Friday night and say that he will absolutely, positively be sharp for the postseason. The pessimists will say that Pettitte’s miserable start, coming the night after the 20-game winner C. C. Sabathia came unhinged, leaves the Yankees vulnerable for a first-round exit  that is, if they make the playoffs at all. Somewhere in the middle, reality exists. And on a day teeming with potential, the reality is that nothing was accomplished Friday when the Yankees hit six home runs but lost, 10-8, to the Boston Red Sox.

headline: New F.D.A.: Transparence and Flexibility
text: WASHINGTON  During the Bush administration, the Food and Drug Administration was mostly a place of black-and-white decisions. Drugs were approved for sale or they were not, and the agency’s staff was expected to publicly support those decisions.

headline: Vans on the Run
text: IN the face of drastic cuts in the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s bus service, the Bloomberg administration recently decided to allow private vans to carry passengers along several routes in Brooklyn and Queens where city buses once ran. One company began service earlier this month, and four more will be operating by October.

headline: With Conditions, Judge Clears Way for a California Execution
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A murderer and rapist has been cleared by a federal judge for execution in California next week in what would be the state’s first execution in more than four years. But the judge set specific conditions, including giving the condemned man the option of a single drug to be used in a lethal injection, an issue that has bogged down executions in the state before.

headline: Florida Bank Robbery Starts With a Kidnapping
text: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  Three men kidnapped a bank teller at his apartment early Friday, strapped a suspected bomb to his back and then forced him to enter the bank where he worked and turn over an undisclosed sum of cash.

headline: F.B.I. Searches Antiwar Activists’ Homes
text: F.B.I. agents executed search warrants Friday in Minneapolis and Chicago in connection to an investigation of support of terror organizations.

headline: The Soldiers We Need at Home
text: FIVE years ago I was a soldier with the 82nd Airborne Division, based at Fort Bragg, N.C. But rather than heading to Iraq or Afghanistan, I was getting ready to go to New Orleans, where I would assist in the relief efforts after Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Army Limits Use of Images of Casualties in G.I.’s Case
text: A top Army official has ordered that images of dead or wounded “casualties or detainees” may not be made public during hearings involving an American soldier accused of murdering three Afghan civilians during a deployment to Afghanistan this year.

headline: Bloggingheads: Abolish the Estate Tax?
text: Annie Lowrey, left, of The Washington Independent and Reihan Salam of National Review debate the estate tax.

headline: Promoting Healthy Eating, With 31 Other First Ladies
text: POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y.  “I can’t believe I’m hugging you,” a third-grade girl said as she clung to Michelle Obama in the kitchen of Blue Hill at Stone Barns, where Mrs. Obama was watching a group of children from nearby schools make lunch with ingredients they had gathered from the restaurant’s garden and henhouse.

headline: Forbes Article Spurs Media Soul Searching
text: When Forbes published a cover story this month by Dinesh D’Souza, the conservative author, asserting that President Obama is opposed to free markets and traditional American values because he inherited his father’s anticolonial beliefs, all the media tripwires were set off: enthusiastic support by conservative commentators like Glenn Beck, Newt Gingrich and Rush Limbaugh, and an uproar among liberal bloggers and columnists.

headline: Joyce Beber, Creator of Hotel Ads for Leona Helmsley, Dies at 80
text: Being fired by a client is hardly an adman’s dream, but being fired by Leona Helmsley can make you a legend  especially if it happens four times. So it was with Joyce Beber.

headline: Paterson, Target of Cast’s Jokes, Will Be on ‘Saturday Night Live’
text: In a series of skits and “Weekend Update” segments over the past two years, the cast of “Saturday Night Live” has mercilessly mocked Gov. David A. Paterson’s impaired vision and presented him as an improbably clumsy figure who walks into cameras, holds charts upside down and hates New Jersey. The genial Mr. Paterson, in turn, has made it clear that he finds the parodies to be in poor taste, even for a comedy show.

headline: Hard Slide by Utley Upsets Mets
text: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets took offense to a hard slide by Phillies second baseman Chase Utley, who barreled into second baseman Ruben Tejada in the fifth inning of the Phillies’ 3-2 victory at Citizens Bank Park on Friday.

headline: Obama Presses for Peace in Likely Sudan Partition
text: UNITED NATIONS  After months of leaving Sudan policy on a back burner, President Obama put the weight of his administration and his own personal esteem in Africa on the line Friday, demanding that north and south Sudan ensure that their likely split into two nations early next year proceed peacefully.

headline: Mexico: President Condemns Killing of Another Mayor
text: President Felipe Calderón “energetically condemned” the murder late Thursday of Mayor Prisciliano Rodríguez of the northern town of Doctor González, the fourth killing of a local mayor in less than two months. Gunmen killed Mr. Rodríguez and a local government aide, Eliseo López, on a highway in Nuevo León State, according to the state attorney general’s office.

headline: China: Weekend Traffic Expected to Be Especially Heavy in Beijing
text: Chinese officials are warning that this weekend will likely be an especially bad traffic period in Beijing, as people return to work after the three-day Moon Festival holiday. Chinese workers are expected to be at their jobs Saturday and Sunday to make up for days off during two holiday periods. The traffic warning is a further indication that the number of cars clogging Beijing roads is reaching a critical mass. On the evening of Sept. 17, a record 140 traffic jams were recorded in Beijing, according to Chinese news organizations. Chinese officials had designated Sept. 22, the day of the Moon Festival, as a “car-free day,” but roads throughout central Beijing were clogged at dinnertime. In late August, a 10,000-car, 60-mile-long traffic jam outside Beijing that lasted 10 days threw a spotlight onto China’s epic congestion problems.

headline: Israel: Palestinians Blame Israel in Death of a Gaza Fisherman
text: Israeli naval forces fatally shot a Gaza fisherman early Friday, Palestinian officials said. The Israeli military said naval forces fired warning shots at a Palestinian fishing boat that had sailed closer to Israeli waters than the three nautical miles the country has designated as a fishing zone boundary. When the boat did not stop or change course, the navy fired on it directly. The Palestinians identified the dead fisherman as Muhammad Mansour Bakr, 20.

headline: Afghanistan: Copies of a War Memoir Are Destroyed
text: The Defense Department confirmed on Friday that it had destroyed 9,500 copies of an Afghan war memoir by a former intelligence officer to prevent the disclosure of what it considered to be classified information, a Pentagon spokeswoman said. Department officials on Monday observed the destruction of the books, the uncensored first printing of Anthony Shaffer’s “Operation Dark Heart,” the spokeswoman said. A second printing, with about 250 passages blacked out, went on sale Friday. A person familiar with the negotiations said the Pentagon had paid St. Martin’s Press about $5 a book, for a cost to taxpayers of nearly $50,000. Publishing executives say they believe it was the first time the government had destroyed a print run of a book to protect secrets. About 100 uncensored advance copies of “Operation Dark Heart” were distributed before the Pentagon intervened, and some have sold online for as much as $2,000.

headline: Secrets Cited in White House Effort to Block Suit
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday asked a federal judge to throw out a lawsuit seeking to stop the government from killing an American citizen accused of ties to Al Qaeda.

headline: Britain’s Fourth Afghan War, Through the Lens of Three Others
text: LONDON — Among the promotional posters displayed besides the escalators in London’s Underground in recent weeks, there has been one, starker than others in black and white, that has caught the eye.

headline: Two Bad Starts, or One Bad Sign, for the Yankees?
text: The next two games, the Yankees will start pitchers – Ivan Nova and Dustin Moseley – who, if all goes according to plan, will not start in the postseason. How they pitch, especially Nova, will still be of interest, of course, but the results of this weekend’s games will trump their individual performances. The same could not have been said about Andy Pettitte’s start on Friday night, when he allowed seven runs and had as many hits allowed (10) as outs recorded (10), which is never a good thing for a starting pitcher, no matter what the number is.

headline: Stuart E. Hample, Student of Comedy, Dies at 84
text: Stuart E. Hample, a humorist who entertained children (and adults) as an author, playwright, adman, performer and cartoonist (and probably a few other things besides), died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Mapping Third-Party Spending
text: Since January, third-party groups have spent $26 million on the most competitive House and Senate races across the country, a majority of them supporting Republican candidates. Maps below show where third-party groups have spent the most money in the general election so far.

headline: California: Lawmaker’s Comments Anger Vietnamese
text: Loretta Sanchez, a Democrat, is drawing criticism for a remark to a television reporter that “the Vietnamese and the Republicans” were “trying to take away” her seat representing California’s 47th Congressional District. Though the interview was first broadcast on Univisión on Sept. 12, her remarks drew widespread attention this week after a report appeared in Orange County Weekly and were mentioned by Roger Hedgecock, a nationally syndicated conservative radio commenter. The comments sparked anger among residents of Santa Ana, home to one of the country’s oldest and largest Vietnamese communities, and threatened to further tighten her race against State Assemblyman Van Tran. She released a statement saying her words referred only to “those in the Vietnamese community who are supporting her opponent.”

headline: Better to Be Fast Than Rich as Red Bulls Win
text: CARSON, Calif.  For all the million-dollar players on the field Friday night when the Red Bulls played the Los Angeles Galaxy, it was not the one with the thickest wallet who made the difference.

headline: Vows: Lindsay & Matthew
text: Lindsay Auer and Matthew Collins met at an art gallery in SoHo in 2006. After quickly realizing they had a shared interest in surfing, they began four years of adventures around the world.

headline: After Four Rounds of the Chess Olympiad, Several Favorites Have Fallen
text: Croatia, Vietnam and Bosnia and Herzegovina are among the teams that have played the role of David early in the competition.

headline: A 1950s Teen Idol
text: Eddie Fisher’s matinee-idol looks and smooth, romantic voice made him one of the most popular singers of the 1950s.

headline: Boris Spassky Reportedly Gravely Ill
text: Boris Spassky, the world champion from 1969-72, who lost the “Match of the Century” to Bobby Fischer, reportedly had a stroke while in Moscow and is in intensive care. Several Web sites have carried news of his hospitalization, but Chessdom seems to have the most complete information.

headline: Eat Like a Jet, Healthily
text: Writing my food column for The New York Times has been a blast. The off-season offered me a great opportunity to eat at some of my favorite New York City restaurants, and it was a chance to try some new places. And trust me, it was a great off-season of eating some amazing food.

headline: Classic Ad: Volkswagen Jetta
text: Some car ads are straightforward, some are nostalgic and others are silly. And then there are some that are just plain cool.

headline: Q&A With Graeme McDowell
text: One lasting sports image from this year was Graeme McDowell’s embrace of his father, Ken, after winning the United States Open on Father’s Day. McDowell, 31, was the first player from Northern Ireland to win the tournament and its first European winner since Tony Jacklin in 1970. McDowell will be a member of Europe’s team for the Ryder Cup next week. He spoke about his game at a recent appearance in Manhattan for Callaway Golf.

headline: Jets’ Mangold Will Play Against Dolphins
text: Jets center Nick Mangold, who injured his right shoulder Sunday in a 28-14 victory over New England, was limited in practice Friday but will play in Sunday’s game against the Miami Dolphins, Coach Rex Ryan said.

headline: Finding Surprises in the Small-Business Jobs Bill
text: Most of the controversy surrounding the small-business jobs bill that cleared the House of Representatives on Thursday — after nearly a year of discussion — concerned a $30 billion small-business lending fund to be established by the Treasury Department.

headline: Default Is In Our Stars
text: Not in ourselves.

headline: Arsenal of Recovery
text: A very nice new paper by Gordon and Krenn on the end of the Great Depression.

headline: July 24, 1972: Fantasy, Celebrity, Bigotry
text: Over the years I have acquired a certain fame and celebrity, and that is one reason so much gossip and speculation goes on about me. It happens to a lot of stars. But it is complicated in my case because my name ends in a vowel. There is a form of bigotry abroad in this land that allows otherwise decent people, including many liberals, to believe the most scurrilous tales if they are connected to an Italian-American name. They seem to need the lurid fantasy; they want to believe that if an entertainer is introduced to someone in a nightclub, they become intimate friends forever.

headline: Jan. 30, 1978: Lighter With Age
text: Love, we still think, many of us, is for the young. But what do they really know about it? It is hard for them to differentiate between sexual passion and love itself, for instance.

headline: Saturday Word: Who’s Listening?
text: Republicans and Democrats agree on one thing this Saturday morning – Americans are speaking out. But what they are saying and who’s listening isn’t exactly clear.

headline: Singletary Has Met the Enemy: The News Media
text: The Raiders had the market cornered in the Bay Area for poor news media relations. But Coach Mike Singletary and the 49ers are giving them a battle.

headline: Another Rugby World Cup Prompts Deals
text: Not going to make it to the Rugby World Cup in New Zealand?There’s another World Cup event — and itinerant travel deals — taking place closer to our shores, in Bermuda.

headline: Fighting Words
text: In a speech before the United Nations General Assembly last week, Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, offered a theory of 9/11. At least 33 delegations walked out.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: Prime Number
text: 14,000: The estimated number of gay and lesbian active service members discharged from 1994 through 2008 under the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy, according to the Servicemembers Legal Defense Network. (The Pentagon says 10,935 were discharged from 1997 through 2009.)

headline: Fried, Scrambled, Infected
text: Last week, Austin J. DeCoster, one of the country’s biggest egg farmers, was asked by a Congressional committee how eggs from his Iowa farms had sickened thousands of people nationally with a bacterium called Salmonella enteritidis. His answer: “This is a complicated subject.”

headline: ‘Pledge to America’ Gaining Conservative Support
text: Even before the “Pledge to America” was unveiled Thursday by the House Republican leadership, some conservatives were grumbling that it didn’t go far enough, calling it a watered-down manifesto.

headline: How to Tilt an Election Through Redistricting
text: It was a gerrymander too ambitious for its own good.

headline: How Do Alaskans Spell S-E-N-A-T-O-R?
text: As my colleague Michael Shear explained on Friday, history shows that running a write-in campaign for office is not easy, particularly for candidates whose names voters might find hard to spell.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Moschino
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: U.S. Tries to Breathe Life Back Into Mideast Talks
text: WASHINGTON  With the deadline for a potentially deal-breaking decision on Jewish settlements looming on Sunday, American diplomats shuttled furiously between Israeli and Palestinian officials at the United Nations to prevent the peace talks from collapsing.

headline: Alonso on Pole in Singapore
text: The top contenders for the Formula One titles this year had been saying it all weekend: Ferrari is back. At 11 p.m. Saturday in Singapore, Fernando Alonso proved it by scoring pole position for the Singapore Grand Prix on Sunday.

headline: Alonso on Pole in Singapore
text: The top contenders for the Formula One titles this year had been saying it all weekend: Ferrari is back. At 11 p.m. Saturday in Singapore, Fernando Alonso proved it by scoring pole position for the Singapore Grand Prix on Sunday.

headline: Red Bulls Are for Real
text: Hans Backe is a forthright kind of guy. He is normally careful with his words, like most coaches in professional sports, but Backe, who is from Sweden, also has a loquacious streak that has helped him earn points in his first season with the Red Bulls of Major League Soccer.

headline: Learning to Share, Thanks to the Web
text: WASHINGTON — Can Americans share? Or, at least, not steal?

headline: Scores of Taliban Killed in 2 Airstrikes
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two separate airstrikes killed more than 70 Taliban insurgents on Saturday, NATO officials said, although some local residents said that civilians were among the victims.

headline: Egypt and Thirsty Neighbors Are at Odds Over Nile
text: BATAMDA, Egypt — One place to begin to understand why this parched country has nearly ruptured relations with its upstream neighbors on the Nile is ankle-deep in mud in the cotton and maize fields of Mohammed Abdallah Sharkawi. The price he pays for the precious resource flooding his farm? Nothing.

headline: Political Flavor Infuses Venezuela’s New Cafes
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  On the eve of parliamentary elections on Sunday, a litmus test of President Hugo Chávez’s 12-year rule, one way to gauge the sentiment within his political movement is to wander through the streets of this city’s old center before slipping into a new state-owned cafe.

headline: Three Faces of the New China
text: UNITED NATIONS — In a blur of headlines over the past few days, Americans have been surprised with brief, seemingly contradictory glimpses of how China is wielding its newfound power.

headline: Runway Beauty | Versace
text: As with the fall 2010 shows, eyebrows have emerged as a focal point for spring — but instead of being colored Easter-egg pastels or dashed with obvious pencil strokes, they’re now being augmented to ’80s Brooke Shields proportions or bleached to oblivion. At Versace, it was the former, with the makeup artist Pat McGrath punctuating models’ dewy-skinned faces with soft pink blush, a hint of brown eye shadow,and just a bit of mascara. The hairstylist Guido Palau slicked back hair to a knot, which he then coated with shiny black fabric.

headline: At Jil Sander, Raf Simons Raises the Volume
text: MILAN — Mention the word “couture,” and people usually think of serious clothes with draping and embellishment. They don’t necessarily think of couture’s extreme forms — and that’s what Raf Simons gave Jil Sander this afternoon in a collection that will probably change some thinking about spring.

headline: Acrostic: Littoral Ogdoad
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Two clue words in this puzzle particularly struck my fancy, so I put them together in the title. What would qualify as a littoral ogdoad? I suppose a maximum-size rowing crew might, although they use a different body of water. Plus, there’s that pesky coxswain that throws the count off. A washed-up octopus?

headline: Karl Returns to Nuggets With His Resolve Intact
text: DENVER  Nuggets Coach George Karl was talking last week about all the things that have turned his life upside down  the cancers, the changes through the organization, and the possibility of losing the All-Star forward Carmelo Anthony.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Gianfranco Ferrè
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Britt from Women Model Management before (top) and after (bottom) makeup by Lucia Peroni and hair by Luigi Murenu. (Drag the orange bar up to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: U.S. Gift for Iraqis Offers a Primer on Corruption
text: BAGHDAD  The shipment of laptop computers that arrived in Iraq’s main seaport in February was a small but important part of the American military’s mission here to win hearts and minds. What happened afterward is a tale of good intentions mugged by Iraq’s reality.

headline: Tribute to a Hero in Twilight
text: Tuesday is the 50th anniversary of Ted Williams’s last game, in which, with an impeccable sense of occasion, he hit a home run, a miraculous line drive to deep right center, in his final at-bat.

headline: Sex Scandal Threatens a Georgia Pastor’s Empire
text: LITHONIA, Ga.  Over the last two decades, Bishop Eddie L. Long has built a religious and financial empire from scratch, transforming a small, faltering church into a modern cathedral with one of the largest and most influential congregations in the country.

headline: Obama, Empathy and the Midterms
text: MY homework for an hourlong interview with President Obama last week began with reviews of his earlier speeches and interviews, and conversations with economists and political operatives. It ended around a dinner table.

headline: More Often Than Not, Yankees Keep Their Lead
text: Pitch for pitch and at-bat for at-bat, this duel between the Yankees and the Tampa Bay Rays in the American League East is a reminder that a pennant race is supposed to be baseball at its best. But with 13 losses in their last 19 games, the Yankees are at their worst.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Versace
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Samantha Casolari.

headline: The Public Apology Is Nothing but a Sorry Act
text: If Braylon Edwards accomplished nothing else last week, he demonstrated how the public apology has become a charade. We’ve seen these  the auction-block news conferences where a player or sometimes a coach (rarely an owner) reads a prepared statement expressing deep regret, then spends 15 minutes with reporters explaining how he’s really not that sorry after all.

headline: FanVision Gadget Makes Debut in Some N.F.L. Stadiums
text: For football spectators, a device called FanVision might be nirvana  or it might turn them into stadium versions of zombies who stumble down streets staring mesmerized at their BlackBerrys.

headline: Favre Plays On, but Vikings Are Out of Tune in an 0-2 Start
text: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  Hank Baskett missed all the fun.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Gianfranco Ferrè
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Ioulex.

headline: When Life Gets in the Way of Art
text: The photographs of Ernest C. Withers — of the Little Rock integration battle, of the Emmett Till murder trial, of the aftermath of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. — are among the most powerful records of the civil rights movement. They have lived on in dozens of books and museum collections.

headline: Still Ahead of the Curve, Goff Leads the Defense
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  He sang with his high school choir on a trip to Europe. He studied mechanical engineering in college. He is so reserved, his nickname likens him to a robot. No, Giants linebacker Jonathan Goff does not always fit in in an N.F.L. locker room.

headline: For Jenkins, Scary Moment Leaves Career at Crossroads
text: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  On the sixth play of his 10th N.F.L. season, Jets defensive tackle Kris Jenkins toppled like a giant oak tree toward the ground. He knew instantly what happened, knew right then his life had changed.

headline: Absent a Fight for the Title, a Rivalry Finds New Fire
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Phillies ran the basepaths hard Friday night in their victory over the Mets. The Mets, according to their manager, responded by running their mouths. Perhaps nothing better demonstrates why the Phillies were on the verge of clinching their fourth consecutive division title Saturday night, while the Mets are facing an off-season of changes.

headline: Understudies Shine in Red Bulls’ Victory Over Galaxy
text: CARSON, Calif.  After spending Friday night on the field with David Beckham, Landon Donovan, Rafael Marquez and Juan Pablo Angel, the Red Bulls rookie defender Tim Ream declared it was, in fact, no big deal.

headline: Job Loss Looms as Part of Stimulus Act Expires
text: Tens of thousands of people will lose their jobs within weeks unless Congress extends one of the more effective job-creating programs in the $787 billion stimulus act: a $1 billion New Deal-style program that directly paid the salaries of unemployed people so they could get jobs in government, at nonprofit organizations and at many small businesses.

headline: Japan Rejects Apologizing to China
text: TOKYO  Tensions between China and Japan over the arrest of a Chinese trawler captain flared anew Saturday, a day after his release, with Beijing demanding an apology for the detention, and Tokyo refusing.

headline: Winning Can Be as Fun as Losing; Just Ask 1962 Mets
text: Charles Salzberg is a co-author of “On a Clear Day They Could See Seventh Place: Baseball’s Worst Teams” with George Robinson.

headline: Webb’s Road to Recovery Will Run Down the Middle of Fifth Avenue
text: Alan Webb accepted the physical challenge with typical determination. The American record-holder in the mile, Webb faced a two-mile hike up a steep, zigzag trail to a rail-protected deck he had envisioned as the setting for the most romantic moment of his life.

headline: India Calls for Easing of Security in Kashmir
text: NEW DELHI  The Indian government announced a major policy shift in Kashmir on Saturday, calling for the release of jailed student protesters, easing security strictures in major cities, reopening schools and universities, and offering financial compensation to the families of the more than 100 civilians killed since the restive region erupted in protests in June.

headline: Milan Fashion Week | Halftime Report
text: Midway through Milan, and the mood among retailers and the press is optimistic. Bananas and stripes at Prada! Leather fringe at Gucci! Long day at D and G! Perky, preppy bags at Fendi! And everywhere flag colors are set against chic white, skirts to midcalf, and wearable, non-conceptual clothes. Fashion appears to have come to its senses again or at least to have regained a sense of proportion, an impression fortified by London’s refined, unselfconsciously pretty offerings at Christopher Kane, Erdem, Marios Schwab, Peter Pilotto and Meadham Kirchhoff.

headline: Petition Urges Nobel for Jailed Chinese Writer
text: BEIJING — In a move sure to irk the Chinese government, a group of 300 scholars, lawyers, factory workers and retired government officials have signed a petition calling on the Nobel Peace Prize committee to award this year’s prize to Liu Xiaobo, an imprisoned writer who has spent much of his life calling for democratic reform in China.

headline: Holding Pattern in House Forecast
text: There is little change in the House forecast from last week. Republicans are assigned a 65 percent chance of taking over the House by our forecasting model, up slightly from 62 percent last week. They are projected to control 224 House seats in the new Congress, up a single seat from 223 last week; this would imply a gain of 45 seats from the 179 they have now (counting one vacant seat most recently held by a Republican member). Substantially larger — or smaller — gains are possible, however.

headline: Zeile’s Last Swing One to Remember
text: Todd Zeile was born in Van Nuys, Calif., in 1965, on the day that Sandy Koufax pitched his perfect game in Los Angeles. So perhaps Zeile was destined to earn his share of trivial distinctions over 16 seasons in the major leagues.

headline: Golfer Who Has Been a Model of Fitness Is Now Becoming a Nude Model
text: ATLANTA  On their way to a half-Ironman triathlon in Augusta, a few of Camilo Villegas’s friends stopped by East Lake Golf Club to catch the end of his second round at the Tour Championship.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Stoudemire Won’t Worry if Anthony Goes to Nets
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  There is nothing bashful or modest about Amar’e Stoudemire, not his nickname (STAT), nor his jersey number (1), nor the way he practices jump shots with his shirt off, every sculptured muscle on display.

headline: How Do Alaskans Spell S-E-N-A-T-O-R?
text: As my colleague Michael Shear explained on Friday, history shows that running a write-in campaign for office is not easy, particularly for candidates whose names voters might find hard to spell.

headline: Parry Leads by 2 Strokes
text: John Parry of England shot a two-under 70 to take a one-stroke lead after the third round of the Vivendi Cup in Chambourcy, France. Parry, a 23-year-old chasing his first European Tour win, was at 15-under 201, one stroke ahead of Mark Haastrup of Denmark (66) and Johan Edfors of Sweden (67).

headline: Would It Help If I Wore Suspenders?
text: From one review of the new Wall Street movie:

headline: Brother Beats Brother in Labour Vote
text: LONDON — In a battle of brothers for the leadership of Britain’s Labour Party, the younger of the two, Ed Miliband, 40, was elected on Saturday, beating his brother David, the 45-year-old former foreign minister, by a margin of a little more than 1 percent of the votes in a runoff.

headline: The G.O.P.’s ‘Pledge’
text: Extravagant promises and bluster are the stuff of campaign rhetoric, but the House Republicans’ “Pledge to America” goes far beyond the norm.

headline: Man Is Arrested in Death of Brooklyn Boy, 2
text: A 2-year-old Brooklyn boy died on Friday night after his bruised, listless body was discovered in his mother’s apartment, and the death was later ruled a homicide, the authorities said.

headline: Drop-Offs Aid Effort to Clear Medicine Cabinets
text: WORCESTER, Mass.  It was not as big a draw as the playground or the hot dog truck, but the drug collection program at a busy downtown park here on Saturday still netted a few hundred bottles of prescription pills as part of a broader one-day effort to clean out the nation’s medicine cabinets.

headline: At Iraqi Port, Chaos and Corruption Reign
text: Umm Qasr, a crucial lifeline for oil going out and imports coming in, is hobbled by a lack of accounting systems, sporadic electricity and aging equipment.

headline: Alabama Presents Formidable Challenge for Mallett
text: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. — This is the tape that N.F.L. scouts will want to see before the 2011 draft: Arkansas quarterback Ryan Mallett against a first-rate defense like Alabama’s that will try to knock him around and make him get out of the pocket.

headline: Birth Control Over Baldness
text: Over the next decade, some astonishing new technologies will spread to fight global poverty. They’re called contraceptives.

headline: Australian Football Tie Is Win for Ogilvy
text: ATLANTA — Geoff Ogilvy was 3 over par after two holes in his third round of the Tour Championship, but he said his sluggish start had nothing to do with the fact he stayed up until 3 a.m. watching his favorite Australian Football League team, St. Kilda, play St. Collingwood to a 68-68 draw in the Grand Final, the A.F.L. equivalent of the Super Bowl.

headline: My Missing Barber
text: One day, a barber said, “Do you want me to do something about your eyebrows?” I’d never thought of my eyebrows as needing something done. They didn’t beetle outward or obscure my sight like a thicket of gorse. I said yes, wondering George Clooney or Joan Crawford? Snick, snick, snick. The answer was Clooney, and I knew I’d found my regular barber.

headline: Iran Fights Malware Attacking Computers
text: WASHINGTON  The Iranian government agency that runs the country’s nuclear facilities, including those the West suspects are part of a weapons program, has reported that its engineers are trying to protect their facilities from a sophisticated computer worm that has infected industrial plants across Iran.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:
