text: To the Editor:

headline: Planning a Sustainable City in the Desert
text: Promoters of Masdar, a city under construction near Abu Dhabi, say that it will be the world’s first carbon-neutral city.

headline: A Tour of Masdar
text: Photographs of renderings of the sustainable city under construction near Abu Dhabi.

headline: Support for Moderates, and a Memo to Democrats
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Arabian Desert, a Sustainable City Rises
text: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  Back in 2007, when the government here announced its plan for “the world’s first zero-carbon city” on the outskirts of Abu Dhabi, many Westerners dismissed it as a gimmick  a faddish follow-up to neighboring Dubai’s half-mile-high tower in the desert and archipelago of man-made islands in the shape of palm trees.

headline: The Beauty of a Mezuza
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Aside on Contraception
text: My Sunday column is about contraception — saying that research on new technologies is woefully underfunded, but that nonetheless some new contraceptives are expected on the market that could have a far-reaching effect. The backdrop is that so often when I travel, I come across women who have far more babies than they want, because existing methods don’t meet their needs.

headline: Slouching Toward Washington
text: WASHINGTON

headline: When Artists Lie
text: What we learn about an artist’s life can profoundly change how we receive their work. Take as an example “I’m Still Here,” Casey Affleck’s film about Joaquin Phoenix, which the two recently disclosed was a not a documentary but a performance.

headline: Their Moon Shot and Ours
text: China is doing moon shots. Yes, that’s plural. When I say “moon shots” I mean big, multibillion-dollar, 25-year-horizon, game-changing investments. China has at least four going now: one is building a network of ultramodern airports; another is building a web of high-speed trains connecting major cities; a third is in bioscience, where the Beijing Genomics Institute this year ordered 128 DNA sequencers  from America  giving China the largest number in the world in one institute to launch its own stem cell/genetic engineering industry; and, finally, Beijing just announced that it was providing $15 billion in seed money for the country’s leading auto and battery companies to create an electric car industry, starting in 20 pilot cities. In essence, China Inc. just named its dream team of 16-state-owned enterprises to move China off oil and into the next industrial growth engine: electric cars.

headline: With a Subtle Shift, Watney Gets Back on Track
text: ATLANTA — Nick Watney shifted his weight on the eighth fairway at East Lake Golf Club on Saturday and tipped the course in his favor.

headline: The Readers’ Front Page
text: Views from readers, responses from the staff, and thoughts from the public editor.

headline: Energy Efficiency, a Step Further
text: A so-called passive home like the one the Landaus are building is purposefully designed such that it often uses 90 percent less heating and cooling energy than similar homes built to local code.

headline: Can We Build in a Brighter Shade of Green?
text: NORWICH, Vt.

headline: Passive House
text: A European-style home that requires no heating is built in Vermont.

headline: Scorecard | Versace Wins!
text: Now Scorecard knows we’re not in Kansas any more. On day three of Milan fashion week, the design duo behind the beyond-the-point-of-leveraged-to-the-max house of Ferré put enough lacy, racy microminis and eye-searing hot pink on the catwalk to nearly squash memories of minimalism. But then the erstwhile queen of short and supersexy, Donatella Versace, went and pared things down — to a woman’s clavicle curves.

headline: Sunday: Location, Location, Location
text: Each set of circled letters forms a word that’s described, literally, by an answer elsewhere in the grid. The reference is to either the location of the circled letters or how that grouping is arranged. Four of the descriptive answers repeat the circled word, while the other four merely describe it. The specifics can be found here.

headline: Wagner for a Song
text: ON Monday night, “Das Rheingold,” the first part of a mammoth new production of Richard Wagner’s opera cycle “Der Ring des Nibelungen,” will thunder down on the Metropolitan Opera. A 45-ton set will test the theater’s foundations; a reported $16 million budget will test the company’s finances. In the midst of economic troubles, is it seemly to spend such a vast amount on a spectacle that will be seen by a relatively small, elite audience?

headline: When Kennedy Met Nixon: The Real Story
text: FIFTY years ago today, the “Great Debate” between Vice President Richard M. Nixon, the Republican nominee for president, and Senator John F. Kennedy, the Democratic nominee, attracted 70 million viewers — the largest audience in American history for any political event.

headline: Want to Lead? Steer Clear of Rarefied Air
text: This interview with Abbe Raven,  president and C.E.O. of A&E Television Networks,  was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: My Tortured Decision
text: For Op-Ed's 40th anniversary, Ali Soufan, a F.B.I. supervisory special agent from 1997 to 2005, recounted the events that triggered his Op-Ed in April 2009.

headline: Sept. 25: College Football Replay
text: Highlights from Saturday’s big games, including Alabama’s close victory over Arkansas.

headline: Questions, and Directors, Lost in the Ether
text: ANNUAL shareholder meetings may not be the most efficient occasion for managers to meet with the owners of the companies they run  they can be hard for shareholders to get to and are sometimes hijacked by gadflies with personal agendas and long-winded, irrelevant questions. Because most, if not all, shareholders cast their votes before the meetings even take place, they can feel ritualistic and not terribly meaningful.

headline: Seton Hall Student Is Fatally Shot at a Party
text: A Seton Hall University honors student was fatally wounded and four other people, including two fellow students, were injured early Saturday when a gunman walked into a house party about a mile from the campus and opened fire, the authorities said.

headline: In This War, Movie Studios Are Siding With Your Couch
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: The Defenders of Free Software
text: ARMIJN HEMEL, 32, lives with his parents in Tiel, a town smack-dab in the middle of the Netherlands. He works as a technology consultant, but spends several hours a week on his avocation: pestering some of the world’s most powerful consumer electronics and technology companies.

headline: Ditch Your Laptop, Dump Your Boyfriend
text: Advice for freshmen from the people who actually grade their papers and lead their class discussions.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 26
text: The policy agenda Republicans outlined in their “Pledge to America” is the hot topic on the Sunday talk shows, as lawmakers involved with the project appear on the networks.

headline: Staying Professional in Virtual Meetings
text: Q. Virtual meetings have become a staple of business life, whether conducted by phone or video. What are the biggest differences between a virtual meeting and one that is face-to-face?

headline: Spindizzy: Out of the Basement and Ready for a Makeover
text: For years it sat in our basement, cloaked in the anonymity of an unmarked banker’s box. Now, fired by an impulse to winnow one’s “stuff,” I was hauling it out, up the stairs and into the sun.

headline: Working to Keep a Heritage Relevant
text: HAMBURG, Pa. — To millions of Americans, autumn means not just N.F.L. games and the World Series but also the start of hunting season — a few months packed with chances to stalk deer, bear, ducks and doves with rifles, shotguns, bows and even black-powder muskets.

headline: A Winged Symbol, but With More Than One Meaning
text: LEE’S SUMMIT, Mo.  Elsewhere, the mourning dove is a symbol of peace.

headline: Poll Shows Boxer Out Front in California; Governor’s Race Is Tight
text: LOS ANGELES — Senator Barbara Boxer, a Democrat, has built a comfortable lead over her Republican opponent, Carly Fiorina, in a Senate race that could prove central to Republican hopes of capturing the Senate this November, according to a poll published by the Los Angeles Times on Saturday. The poll showed that Ms. Boxer was supported by 51 percent of likely voters, compared with 43 percent support for Ms. Fiorina.

headline: For Many Youths, Hunting Loses the Battle for Attention
text: GRAND JUNCTION, Colo.  It was the second day of the hunt last year when Tyler Seacrest, then 16, took his first deer.

headline: These Digital Trainers Know How to Motivate
text: STICKING to exercise and weight-loss goals can be tough. But new computer-based products can help you along the road to fitness, offering steady electronic encouragement and suggestions.

headline: Like Great-Great-Great-(Etc.)-Grandpa Did It
text: APPLE CREEK CONSERVATION AREA, Mo.  Mist clung to the oaks here as Arron Hendershott, a spear in one hand and a Stone Age weapon known as an atlatl in the other, stalked his prey.

headline: From Electrical to Medical
text: WHEN I was a teenager, I started a business cutting grass and made more money than any of my friends. I had a big appetite for technology, and I liked music. I used my earnings to buy Heathkits for building home audio equipment and made my own amplifiers, tuners and radios.

headline: Power Shifts to the Northwest
text: BOISE, Idaho — A commercial came on a local radio station Saturday advertising a free gun with the purchase of a truck. Outside of a convenience store, a vending machine sold live bait.

headline: Democrats Unleash Ads Focusing on Rivals’ Pasts
text: WASHINGTON  Democratic candidates across the country are opening a fierce offensive of negative advertisements against Republicans, using lawsuits, tax filings, reports from the Better Business Bureau and even divorce proceedings to try to discredit their opponents and save their Congressional majority.

headline: Rove Returns, With Team, Planning G.O.P. Push
text: WASHINGTON  In 2004, the Republican master strategist Karl Rove led weekly sessions at his Washington residence where, over big plates of his butter-smothered “eggies” and bacon slabs, he planned the re-election of President George W. Bush  and what he hoped would be lasting Republican dominion over Democrats.

headline: The Secrets of a Passive House
text: When completed, the Landau residence now under construction in Norwich, Vt., will be one of about a dozen buildings certified as “passive houses” in the United States.

headline: Boehner’s Top Aide Is Little Known
text: WASHINGTON  Representative John A. Boehner and Barry Jackson cut an odd figure.

headline: Sloppy but Strong, Alabama Rallies
text: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark.  In the era of the spread offense and the quarterback who can sling the ball down the field, it is still imperative to have the running back who can hold the football high and tight and gash a defense without fumbling. The reliable rushing game trumps the slick plays of the spread passing game  if not all the time, then most of the time.

headline: Aug. 12, 1974: Closed Government, Broken Republic
text: During a recent country-radio discussion of a new so-called sunshine law  one that requires open governmental meetings  a caller said to me: “There are two things a person should never watch being made. One is potted meat, and the other is laws.”

headline: An Introduction to Op-Ed at 40
text: On Sept. 21, 1970, readers who turned to the last inside page of The Times’s main section found something new. The obituaries that normally appeared in that space had been moved, replaced by something called Op-Ed. The vision of John Oakes, the editorial page editor, and Harrison Salisbury, the eminent foreign correspondent, Op-Ed was meant to open the paper to outside voices. It was to be a venue for writers with no institutional affiliation with the paper, people from all walks of life whose views and perspectives would often be at odds with the opinions expressed on the editorial page across the way. (Hence, Op-Ed  Opposite Editorial.)

headline: Jan. 14, 1976: Israel’s Reality
text: We dispossessed no Arabs. Whatever subsequent ills befell the Arabs were the inevitable result of the Arab design to drive us into the sea. Had Israel not repelled her would-be destroyers there would have been no Jewish refugees alive in the Middle East to concern the world.

headline: March 29, 2000: Elián González, Stranded
text: On Friday, when Juan Miguel González went to school to pick up his son Elián for the weekend, he was told that Elizabet Brotons, his ex-wife and the boy’s mother, had taken Elián at midday and had not brought him back in the afternoon. In his routine as a divorced father, this seemed normal to Juan Miguel. From the time when he and Elizabet had separated two years earlier, on the most amicable terms, the boy had lived with his father and spent every other day at his mother’s house.

headline: Dec. 18, 1981: Poland Takes On an Empire
text: Takeovers by military juntas, like the one in Poland, are nothing new in the sad chronicles of our century. Again and again, guns and tanks have been used to silence voices calling for freedom and dignity. Yet, there is something radically new in the current Polish situation, just as the Solidarity movement is without precedent in modern history.

headline: June 8, 1974: My Con Ed Bill
text: On quitting New York City in 1957 where I had been living under the name Jean Stafford, I asked Consolidated Edison to send my final bill. Instead of a bill, I received a check for six cents, which represented, I supposed, what was left of my deposit. I kept it, partly as a curio, partly in the hope that in a wee way I could bollix up the company books, and partly because I thought it might come in handy some day. Eleven years later, thanks to my mean-spirited foresight, I was able to use it as a tactical diversion in a battle I fought with and won from Con Ed.

headline: July 18, 1983: Aid for Apartheid
text: We shall continue to intensify the struggle in South Africa. If Washington genuinely wants to contribute to stability in the region, it should use its influence with Pretoria to restrain it from exporting the conflict it has imposed on the people of South Africa.

headline: June 1, 2008: My Big Bang
text: Like a life without music, art or literature, a life without science is bereft of something that gives experience a rich and otherwise inaccessible dimension.

headline: Feb. 18, 1996: Machine 1, Man 0
text: Among the array of graver and more material contests now facing civilization, struggles from Sarajevo to New Hampshire, the one decided yesterday in Philadelphia stands out in its symbolic weight. In the chess match between Garry Kasparov, the world’s best living player, and I.B.M.’s Deep Blue, an otherwise undistinguished supercomputer, humanity’s collective self-esteem was once more on the line.

headline: May 5, 1991: Lawn Care
text: THREE years after George Bush told us he wanted to be remembered as the “environmental president,” he has done little to earn that distinction  unless one regards his catch-and-release policy on bonefishing as a major environmental initiative.

headline: Nov. 20, 1991: Date Rape Mythology
text: Now the cry across campuses is “date rape.” Those involved frame it as a liberal concern, cut and dry, beyond debate. But they don’t stop to consider the sexist images lurking beneath their rhetoric. The term “date rape” itself hints at its conservative bent. More than just a polemic against rape, it reveals a desire for dates.

headline: Jan. 17, 1993: Auguries, Pieties and Memory
text: MY Washington town house was built in 1905  just in time, perhaps, to observe the inauguration of Theodore Roosevelt, who was sworn in on March 4. As a writer living in what amounts to an ivory tower  or at least an off-white walk-up  I like to imagine myself seated here then, catching a few of Roosevelt’s screechy remarks. It was a windy day, and he had to keep a tight hold of his typescript. Who knows, the phrase “Power invariably means both responsibility and danger” may have blown across the park and buffeted against these curving panes.

headline: Jan. 31, 1978: The Paralyzing Bullet
text: It is the morning of Jan. 20, 1978. I couldn’t sleep last night because today is my anniversary. It was 10 years ago on this day that I was shot and paralyzed in Vietnam.

headline: Aug. 19, 2003: Lights Out, Everybody Home
text: Mine is a youngish, slightly tatty ’hood: video clerks, personal trainers, life coaches, voice-over actors and lots of chain-smoking older women with small dogs.

headline: July 29, 1979: If Black English Isn’t a Language, What Is?
text: I DO not know what white Americans would sound like if there had never been any black people in the United States, but they would not sound the way they sound. Jazz, for example, is a very specific sexual term, as in jazz me, baby, but white people purified it into the Jazz Age. Sock it to me, which means, roughly, the same thing, has been adopted by Nathaniel Hawthorne’s descendants with no qualms or hesitations at all, along with let it all hang out and right on! Beat to his socks, which was once the black’s most total and despairing image of poverty, was transformed into a thing called the Beat Generation, which phenomenon was, largely, composed of uptight, middle-class white people, imitating poverty, trying to get down, to get with it, doing their thing, doing their despairing best to be funky, which we, the blacks, never dreamed of doing — we were funky, baby, like funk was going out of style.

headline: Aug. 15, 1973: Goings On in the Barnyard
text: WHEN The Times asked me to report on what’s being said in my barnyard about Watergate, I immediately sought an audience with the goose. She is sore at me at the moment but is always willing to talk.

headline: May 18, 2003: All the President’s Girls
text: I too was an intern in the J.F.K. White House. I was. This is not one of those humor pieces where the writer pretends to some experience related to the news in order to make an “amusing” point. It was 1961, and I was hired by Pierre Salinger to work in the press office, the very same place where Mimi Beardsley, later Fahnestock, was to work the next year. And now that she has been forced to come forward to admit that she had an affair with Kennedy, I might as well tell my story.

headline: Sept. 22, 1988: The Biggest Insult in Politics
Sept. 16, 1975: Asleep at the Fiscal Crisis
text: We are in a fiscal mess. The effects were not merely regional but nationwide. We induced cheap labor to come here to glut a full-up market. We created a huge relief program, only part of which should on any reasonable theory fall on New York. We have had little sympathy and aid from Washington.

headline: June 17, 1987: Our Central American Misadventure
text: Central America is another example of the superpower fallacy. Our policy of military intervention seeks to save the other countries from the wicked Sandinistas. But most Latin American governments think that policy increases desperation and chaos and is far more likely to promote than to check the spread of Marxist revolution.

headline: June 7, 2004: Making Peace With Reagan
text: Ronald Reagan’s first term had been dedicated to restoring America’s self-confidence. He regarded as his main task strengthening the economy and the military might of the United States. This was accompanied by confrontational rhetoric toward the Soviet Union, and by actions that caused concern both in our country and throughout the world. It seemed that the most important thing for Reagan was his reputation as a hawk who saw the Soviet Union as an “evil empire.”

headline: Aug. 28, 2008: Johnson’s Dream, Obama’s Speech
text: As I watch Barack Obama’s speech at the Democratic convention tonight, I will be remembering another speech: the one that made Martin Luther King cry. And I will be thinking: Mr. Obama’s speech  and in a way his whole candidacy  might not have been possible had that other speech not been given.

headline: May 16, 2010: Fatal Attraction
text: Philosophy should come with the kind of health warning one finds on packs of European cigarettes: “Philosophy kills.” Socrates was charged with impiety toward the gods of the city and with corrupting the youth of Athens. He was obliged to speak in court in defense of these charges, to speak against the water clock, that thief of time. He ran out of time and suffered the consequences: he was condemned to death and forced to take his own life.

headline: Sept. 28, 1972: Winning Vietnam
text: The United States forces have fulfilled their role in supporting the South Vietnamese in a superb manner. Particularly noteworthy and effective have been the United States air operations against the invading enemy forces.

headline: March 19, 1989: The Planetary Crisis on the Horizon
text: Humankind has suddenly entered into a brand-new relationship with our planet.

headline: Feb. 25, 1971: A Quagmire Widens
text: So this time it is Laos.

headline: Jan. 31, 2010: Where Do Numbers Come From?
text: The best introduction to numbers I’ve ever seen appears in a “Sesame Street” video. Humphrey is working the lunch shift at the Furry Arms hotel, when he takes a call from a room full of penguins. Humphrey listens carefully and then calls out their order to the kitchen: “Fish, fish, fish, fish, fish, fish.” This prompts Ernie to enlighten him about the virtues of the number six.

headline: Feb. 3, 2002: The Palestinian Vision of Peace
text: For the past 16 months, Israelis and Palestinians have been locked in a catastrophic cycle of violence, a cycle that promises only more bloodshed and fear. The cycle has led many to conclude that peace is impossible, a myth borne out of ignorance of the Palestinian position.

headline: March 18, 1972: Mr. Auden’s Neighborhood
text: New York is a city of neighborhoods, and I consider myself extremely fortunate in the one where I have lived for the past 20 years. (To me, it will always be the “the Lower East Side,” never “the East Village.”)

headline: May 20, 2009: What You Don’t Know Makes You Nervous
text: People feel worse when something bad might occur than when something bad will occur. Most of us aren’t losing sleep and sucking down Marlboros because the Dow is going to fall another thousand points, but because we don’t know whether it will fall or not  and human beings find uncertainty more painful than the things they’re uncertain about.

headline: Oct. 8, 1992: How to Use Military Force
text: There has been a spate of commentary over the use of American military force to deal with the vexing problems of an untidy post-cold-war world. Let me respond by reviewing recent history.

headline: July 27, 1972: Supersonic Slowdown
text: A supersonic transport is fast, but it is costly, noisy and a polluter, and its range is relatively short.

headline: Aug. 11, 1974: Nixon vs. Laws
text: We have had constitutional crises before but, except for the Civil War and Reconstruction, none that had the dimensions of those precipitated by Richard M. Nixon. Never before have we had a crisis that challenged the basic assumptions of our constitutional system itself, and the basic processes and mechanisms through which it worked.

headline: March 4, 1993: A First Assault on the Twin Towers
text: PUT yourself in the mind’s eye of the bomber. It’s likely he first viewed the city from the air, looked out and saw the twin towers mirroring each other’s dizzying rise. Or maybe he stood at the window of a safe house in Queens or New Jersey and looked at them thrusting so immodestly over a thousand feet in the air; no doubt he thought they mocked his passionate intensity.

headline: Dec. 17, 1983: Criminal Neglect
text: The Lower East Side as we know it, and as our parents and grandparents knew it, may disappear. There is a war being fought there, a territorial war. On one side are hard-working, law-abiding people. On the other are the invaders who use the streets and abandoned buildings to carry on an open market in drugs.

headline: Oct. 28, 1992: No Party Toppled the Soviets
text: The claim heard in campaign rhetoric that the United States under Republican Party leadership “won the cold war” is intrinsically silly.

headline: Talk From Dungy Doesn’t Lead to Much Pep for the Struggling Yankees
text: Should Manager Joe Girardi want his Yankees to hear another football pep talk, he might consider that old film of Knute Rockne addressing his Notre Dame players.

headline: Sept. 10, 2002: War on Whom?
text: Since the Sept. 11 attacks, the Bush administration has told the American people that America is at war. But this war is of a peculiar nature. It seems to be, given the nature of the enemy, a war with no foreseeable end. What kind of war is that?

headline: July 6, 2003: What I Didn’t Find in Africa
text: Did the Bush administration manipulate intelligence about Saddam Hussein’s weapons programs to justify an invasion of Iraq?

headline: What the Rich Don’t Need
text: WANT to give affluent households a present worth $700 billion over the next decade? In a period of high unemployment and fiscal austerity, this idea may seem laughable. Amazingly, though, it is getting traction in Washington.

headline: April 1, 1971: Victims of Welfare
text: Welfare is a national moral and administrative disaster  a cancer that is destroying those it should succor and threatening society itself.

headline: July 8, 2005: London’s Shock
text: In Auden’s poem “Musée des Beaux Arts,” the tragedy of Icarus falling from the sky is accompanied by life refusing to be disrupted. A plowman goes about his work, a ship “sailed calmly on,” dogs keep on with “their doggy life.”

headline: Nov. 27, 2000: Why Gore Should Concede
text: FOUR years ago, I conceded the presidential election as soon as the winner was determined. There was a lot less suspense that year than this time around. But when the outcome was clear, so was my duty.

headline: Oct. 4, 1998: A Case Against Impeachment
text: When I succeeded to the presidency, in August 1974, my overriding priority was to draw off the poison that had seeped into the nation’s bloodstream during two years of scandal and partisanship. Some Americans have yet to forgive me for pardoning my predecessor. In the days leading up to that hugely controversial action, I didn’t take a poll for guidance, but I did say more than a few prayers. In the end I listened to only one voice, that of my conscience. I didn’t issue the pardon for Richard Nixon’s sake, but for the country’s.

headline: Dec. 25, 1990: A Brooklyn Story
text: I heard this story from Auggie Wren. Since Auggie doesn’t come off too well in it, at least not as well as he’d like to, he’s asked me not to use his real name. Other than that, the whole business about the lost wallet and the blind woman and the Christmas dinner is just as he told it to me.

headline: Jan. 4, 2009: Wall Street’s Fatal Blind Spot
May 4, 1989: China in Revolt
text: The possibility exists that the democratic movement will be suppressed by force. Indeed, a government spokesman has hinted at reprisals against “a handful of people behind the scenes engaged in political struggle against the Communist Party.”

headline: April 23, 2009: My Tortured Decision
text: For seven years I have remained silent about the false claims magnifying the effectiveness of so-called enhanced interrogation techniques like waterboarding. I have spoken only in closed government hearings, as these matters were classified. But the release last week of four Justice Department memos on interrogations allows me to shed light on the story.

headline: Dec. 2, 1994: Give ’em Hell
text: The similarities between the 1994 Republican triumph and the Congressional elections of 1946 are the subject of great interest. Not only did the Republicans win the House and Senate by substantial majorities, recovering power after years of Democratic control, but the Democrat in the White House was humiliated, both at the polls and by the withering invective of the campaign.

headline: Nov. 5, 1992: Generation’s End
text: HAVING rebuffed a fine man whose presidency failed, about half the country, I suspect, will have the rueful blues this weekend.

headline: Sept. 28, 2008: Greenwich Time
text: Be aware that your correspondent is merely bringing you the news when he reports how many people have besieged the author of “The Bonfire of the Vanities” with the question, “Where does this leave the Masters of the Universe now?”

headline: Jan. 29, 1979: Misreading Islam
text: In times of trouble, certain characteristics of predominantly Muslim countries are emphasized in the media, while others disappear. Consider Iran.

headline: Oct. 27, 1996: Superstores That Were Truly Super
text: Any kid who grew up in the city before the arrival of McDonald’s and the “big box” stores selling books, beds and bath towels can tell you how strange a first trip to a shopping mall was. For us, shopping was synonymous with striding through the city. One day we could cruise a Fifth Avenue department store, just like Lauren Bacall in a career-gal movie, and later spend hours in an Eighth Street bookshop, displaying a genuine interest in the poetry of Allen Ginsberg.

headline: June 22, 1975: Is the Third World War Over?
text: When the Second World War followed on the heels of the First, the question that obsessed everyone was whether World War III would follow in turn. How many concessions and sacrifices were made to delay it, in the hope of perhaps avoiding it altogether?

headline: March 19, 2003: Growing Up at Normandy
text: Until I set foot on the Normandy sands, I was a chap of calm and sanguine disposition whose worst anxieties were on the order of seeing a traffic cop in the rearview mirror; now, in a single tick of a clock, I became a marionette on a string, ducking and weaving in an effort to get away from the invisible bits of metal I could hear buzzing like bees above my head and past my ears. (Useless acrobatics on my part, of course; the bullet you hear has already missed you.)

headline: Dec. 31, 2007: Across the World in 36 Hours
text: I left California for Jerusalem a few hours after Christmas Day, and in short order I witnessed the excitement of Friday prayers at the Temple Mount, clusters of pilgrims chanting their way along the Via Dolorosa, dancing Jews greeting the Sabbath at the Western Wall. On the same British Airways flight down from Heathrow that I took, more than 30 years ago, Saul Bellow encountered three-hour “security exercises,” a desperate dearth of kosher food and aisles blocked by the praying faithful. This week all I faced was a day in a transit lounge, a plane with just four Hasidim but 10 times as many American college students, and chewable toothpaste on sale at Heathrow.

headline: March 12, 2004: Madrid’s Silent Noon
text: The terrorist attacks almost always happen in the early morning. Whether it turns out that yesterday’s train-station bombings in Madrid were the work of the usual suspects  the Basque terrorist group ETA  or of Al Qaeda or another group altogether, the murderers stuck to the usual timetable.

headline: Aug. 18, 1982: How to Think About Détente
text: To many Americans, détente has become a dirty word, virtually synonymous with appeasement. To most Europeans, it is a good word. To them it describes a period in the early and middle 1970s when tensions between East and West were lessened and when there was more trade, more contact, some liberalization in Eastern Europe and, above all, a reduced danger of nuclear war.

headline: Aug. 19, 2007: The Iraq We Saw
text: Viewed from Iraq at the tail end of a 15-month deployment, the political debate in Washington is indeed surreal. To believe that Americans, with an occupying force that long ago outlived its reluctant welcome, can win over a recalcitrant local population and defeat this counterinsurgency is far-fetched.

headline: Sept. 14, 1974: Raising Boys
text: For the last 27 years I have been stewing and brewing about an incident that took place one misty autumn afternoon in a farmyard on the outskirts of the village of Great Missenden, and I have many times wondered where and when I should make the facts known to the world. So here we go. The story is a true one.

headline: Sept. 22, 1992: The Draft Card
text: I was at Oxford just before Bill Clinton, but while he was lobbying to get a deferment I was undergoing Marine Corps training, utterly convinced I was preparing to be killed. When he received his high lottery number and went off to Yale Law School, I was leading a platoon of high school dropouts west of Danang.

headline: Jan. 19, 1987: The Roots of Howard Beach
text: By now, the Howard Beach story is well known: three black men walking in a white neighborhood were set upon by a gang of white teenagers. Shouting racial epithets, the gang chased and assaulted the black men, one of whom was killed when he ran onto a highway. The assaults appear to have been provoked only by the fact that the men were black.

headline: Jan. 23, 2003: Why We Know Iraq Is Lying
text: Eleven weeks after the United

headline: If Congress Stalls, Do Stocks Rise?
text: IS political gridlock really good for the stock market?

headline: Feb. 20, 1983: Second City Police Blotter
text: Chicago, which likes to think of itself as the city primeval, has burst into sensational flower this winter. Tuesday’s Democratic mayoral primary has produced some strange growths, and simultaneously the underworld, volcanically disturbed by pressure from the federal government, has erupted spectacularly. Not long ago, Allen Dorfman of the Teamsters pension fund was gunned down in a parking lot. Now plea-bargaining witnesses are talking freely about Joey Lombardo, known as Joey the Clown, convicted with Dorfman and Roy Williams, the Teamsters union president, of conspiring to bribe Senator Howard W. Cannon of Nevada. Politics are politics, crime is crime, but in Chicago they occasionally overlap. The line between virtue and vice meanders madly  effective government on one side, connections on the other.

headline: Aug. 4, 1993: Balkan Excuses
text: As America lies in its state-induced moral stupor, lots of people die violent deaths all over the place, particularly in the Balkans. When it comes to externalizing evil, few things can rival geography or, for that matter, history.

headline: Dec. 4, 1970: A Righteous America?
text: Our record as a righteous nation has proved so filled with error that, obviously, we must stop thanking God we are not like other nations. This humility will not solve the multiple problems that confront our nation, once infant and comparatively innocent, but now a nuclear super-nation.

headline: March 6, 2006: Desert Fog
text: The other morning I walked out of my hooch and saw antennae standing watch like silent sentinels, sticking their heads up out of the fog. The sun looked like a silver coin through the haze. You could stare right at it. The horizon was shrouded. I heard a large explosion, but the sound was compressed as if in a vacuum; it was hard to tell if it was an I.E.D. on a road just outside the base or a mortar attack inside the wire. By midmorning, the clouds served as a prism and there was a golden glare all over the world. It wasn’t the kind of gold you might imagine while reading a poem by Robert Frost. It was the fallow brown of a vast desert come to steal away the mirage of safety.

headline: Dec. 3, 1976: Tax Cuts and False Hopes
text: In the weeks  after the presidential election, quite a number of my economist friends of distinguished reputation expressed themselves promptly and decisively on behalf of a tax reduction to stimulate the economy. No partisanship was involved; the same action was also proposed and taken early in the Ford administration.

headline: April 19, 1992: My AIDS Death
text: When I discovered I was infected with H.I.V., I wasn’t worried at first. Maybe I was in denial. My T4 cells, a key measure of immune system health, were high.

headline: July 14, 1991: A Cost to Freedom
text: The experience of the postwar period has shown us that no amount of economic assistance will make a totalitarian country more prosperous unless it is also made more democratic. In the beginning of 1990, the Soviet Union was still largely undecided about where it was going, and any economic assistance would most likely have gone down the bottomless drain of bureaucracy, incompetence and corruption. This situation has changed. The democratic forces are trying to organize themselves and to make a radical break with the past.

headline: Oct. 2, 1970: God and the Future
text: Millions of Americans are caught up in a desperate attempt to know the future. The phenomenal rise in the sale of crystal balls, Ouija boards and Viennese fortunetelling tarot cards is only a part of the new “groping” into the future.

headline: July 1, 1972: Union Blues
text: I am a pensioned railroader. I put in 42 years in overalls on one of America’s great railroad systems. Before that I worked in the coal mines, in the timber country and in the building trades. I earned my first wages working underground helping to gut this old earth. I bought my first overcoat and overshoes from my mine earnings in August. I had been cold all my life.

headline: Oct. 4, 1995: Reasonable Doubt
text: The prosecution of O. J. Simpson was doomed from the start. Not in the sense that the state lacked proof  the case against Mr. Simpson remains compelling. But the prosecution was a low-road enterprise that began with the kinds of ugly tactics that have aroused suspicions about the criminal justice system among members of racial minorities in Los Angeles and elsewhere.

headline: April 23, 1993: God and Waco
text: No three cultures could be more mutually incomprehensible than the trinity at Waco: Branch Davidians, G-men and the news media. This is not because they came from different places; on the contrary, it is easy to imagine members of all three groups growing up in the same town in the Midwest, starting out as schoolmates and winding up on opposite sides of barricades shouting gibberish at one another.

headline: Jan. 4, 1975: Captive to Human Nature
text: For reasons with which I sympathize, one makes oneself unpopular with progressive people if one blames human nature for public evils. True, the argument that human nature is bad is often used as an excuse by interested parties who oppose social change. All the same, we seem to have got to a stage in the world’s history where at every point we are brought up against “human nature” as an impassable wall that prevents us taking obvious measures to save ourselves from destruction.

headline: Stanford’s Defense, and Confidence, Grows
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — Moments after his defense carried No. 16 Stanford to its first victory at Notre Dame Stadium since 1992, Coach Jim Harbaugh smiled, looked around a packed media room, and remarked that it might have been the biggest press conference he had ever been to.

headline: May 5, 2006: Mad Women
text: Standing in the kitchen, my fingers gripping the baking sheet, my wrist preparing to fling it like a Frisbee, it began to dawn on me that perhaps I was having some issues. I had not been quite this crazy since the spring of 2003, when my new French au pair had up and quit on the eve of the Iraq war (“It’s too dangerous here”), which happened to be the very week when my book (of which I had not written a word) was officially due to its publisher. Back then, I’d become mentally paralyzed, unable to decide for days whether to order a basic or deluxe Hello Kitty package from Birthday Express. Now, it was chocolate: double boiler or not?

headline: March 22, 1998: Why Feminists Support Clinton
text: If all the sexual allegations now swirling around the White House turn out to be true, President Clinton may be a candidate for sex addiction therapy. But feminists will still have been right to resist pressure by the right wing and the news media to call for his resignation or impeachment. The pressure came from another case of the double standard.

headline: June 1, 1997: The Terrorist Next Door
text: “Lady, you would be so easy to kill.” More than three years later, these words still haunt me. My assailant growled this threat as I lay in the darkness on the floor of my garage, stunned and dazed from being beaten, kicked and knifed. Then he put a gun to my head and dry-fired it several times.

headline: June 21, 2006: Dead of the Night
text: Four of my friends were killed by a double roadside bomb in Karada. That’s right, four, count them  that is, if you can identify their bodies. Forever gone  can you imagine that?

headline: March 30, 2009: Drinking Games
text: My years of heavy drinking were roughly coterminous with my youth, and looking back now, it’s hard to figure out which one of them I really miss.

headline: Feb. 11, 1991: Valentine’s Day Deconstructed
text: Roses are red/Violets are blue/

headline: Aug. 17, 1992: A Bible for All
text: Those who speak for the religious right do not speak for all American Christians, and the Bible is not theirs alone to interpret. The same Bible that the advocates of slavery used to protect their wicked self-interests is the Bible that inspired slaves to revolt and their liberators to action.

headline: April 24, 2008: Visible Man
text: I try to keep a low profile. Maybe you see me in the hallway but don’t know my name. Say hi to me in the coffee room but don’t really know me. I break my silence now because of this election mess. Before the primary in Pennsylvania this week, Bill Clinton was doing magic tricks  now you see the race card, now you don’t. Geraldine Ferraro and Bob Johnson, the founder of Black Entertainment Television, have been complaining that Barack Obama is leading in the Democratic presidential campaign only because of his skin color. Multimillionaire TV pundits are lecturing “the common man” on how outraged they should be about Mr. Obama’s elitism.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: April 13, 2004: Fortress of Youth
text: The imagination of teenagers is often  I’m tempted to say always  the only sure capital they possess apart from the love of their parents, which is a force far beyond their capacity to comprehend or control. During my own adolescence, my imagination, the kingdom inside my own skull, was my sole source of refuge, my fortress of solitude, at times my prison. But a fortress requires a constant line of supply; those who take refuge in attics and cellars require the unceasing aid of confederates; prisoners need advocates, escape plans or simply a window that gives onto the sky.

headline: Dec. 19, 1988: The Mind’s Prison
text: To those of us who have suffered severe depression, the general unawareness of how relentlessly the disease can generate an urge to self-destruction seems widespread; the problem badly needs illumination.

headline: Nov. 28, 1973: Life With Cars
text: The trouble with cars, to adapt the old saying, is that you can’t live with them or without them. We in Detroit are told that we produce an extravagant luxury that can no longer be tolerated. We are admonished, on the other hand, not to push up the price of one of life’s necessities.

headline: Sept. 12, 2010: My War Story
text: I had an easy deployment. I didn’t kill anybody. I never even fired my weapon in combat. I mostly drove around Baghdad. I saw nasty things and met some nasty people. I got shot at. I twisted my ankle. Some of my fellow soldiers didn’t come back in one piece and some didn’t come back at all. I remember the United Nations building’s wreckage after it got car-bombed, Humvees burning on Route Irish, the sound of incoming mortar rounds, blood, smoke and fear.

headline: Oct. 8, 1990: The Civil War in Us
text: I believe our deep feeling for the Civil War is a nostalgia for leadership. Lee and Lincoln, Whitman and Douglass belong not just to another time and race but to another species. True, that early war, like our own age, proves that the most fearful rivalries are family ones. Our Civil War’s greatest allure is precisely what our own age lacks and so yearns for: the cult of leadership. That saved us the first time, right?

headline: Feb. 13, 2008: A Head Full of Patterns
text: As a child, I was fascinated by patterns, starting with the patterns in our house  the square colored floor tiles we had on the porch, the tessellation of small pentagonal and hexagonal ones in the kitchen; the herringbone pattern on the curtains in my room, and the pattern on my father’s checked suit. When I was taken to the synagogue for services, I was more interested in the mosaics of tiny tiles on the floor than in the religious liturgy. And I was fascinated by a pair of antique Chinese cabinets we had in our drawing room, for embossed on their lacquered surfaces were patterns of wonderful intricacy, patterns on different scales, patterns nested within patterns, all surrounded by clusters of tendrils and leaves.

headline: April 3, 1984: Inflation Nation
text: During the 1980 presidential campaign, both Democrats and Republicans proclaimed inflation the nation’s No. 1 problem. “Double-digit inflation” became a household term. During the current campaign, the inflation issue is notable by its absence  except for Republican boasting about conquering it. And, indeed, the reduction in inflation has been remarkable. In the summer of 1980, consumer prices were rising at more than 12 percent per year; in early 1984, at 5.5 percent.

headline: July 20, 1992: Bias Is Poison
text: During the past decade, the historic relationship between African-Americans and Jewish Americans  a relationship that sponsored so many of the concrete advances of the civil rights era  showed another and less attractive face.

headline: Jan. 10, 1976: Wild Man
text: Euell Gibbons had begun learning about wild and edible vegetation when he was a small boy in the Red River Valley. Later, in the dust-bowl era, his family moved to central New Mexico. They lived in a semi-dugout, and almost starved there. His father left in a desperate search for work. The food supply diminished until all that was left were a few pinto beans and a single egg, which no one would eat.

headline: Oct. 21, 1987: Black Monday: A Warning, an Opportunity
text: The market meltdown does not presage another depression. With suitable policy responses, it need not even signal a significant decline in the economy.

headline: Dec. 24, 2003: My Christmas Picture
text: And this is me and my dad one Christmas past. I’m 5 and he’s too old to have a 5-year-old. At the time the Smiths lived in London in a half-English, half-Irish housing project called Athelston Gardens, one black family squished between two tribes at war.

headline: Jan. 15, 2006: Thanks for the Memoirs
text: And now, writing my own memoirs, I know God is in the truth. Only by studying actual events and questioning your own motives will the complex inner truths ever emerge from the darkness. I tell aspiring memoirists, if you’re the kind of person who can’t apologize, who digs in, trusts only the first impulse, then this won’t be your form. The convenient sound bites into which I store my sense of self are rarely accurate  whose are? They have to be unpacked and pecked at warily, with unalloyed suspicion. You must testify and recant, type and delete.

headline: Nov. 26, 1995: Running in Place
text: Americans have always moved. We move for a better job, a better house, better neighbors, better weather.

headline: April 5, 2008: The Seeds of a Song
text: People always ask me, “What comes first, the music or the lyrics?” I don’t know why people are so fascinated with the answer to that question, and the question always makes me slightly nervous, as if I should have an expert opinion or a backlog of statistics on my own songwriting to give a definitive answer. I can’t.

headline: Nov. 1, 1971: Seeds of Wrath
text: I guess God meant for me to write. We can’t get any help from the newspapers here in Florida for they depend on the big-money people and if they tried to help the poor old hungry migrant farm worker it wouldn’t be good for business.

headline: Manuel Now Considers Utley’s Slide a Good Play
text: PHILADELPHIA  After a night to sleep on it, Jerry Manuel reversed course Saturday regarding Chase Utley’s aggressive slide into second base the night before  deciding that not only was the play clean, but he wished his own players approached the game in the same aggressive manner.

headline: Stalled at the Rental Car Counter
text: AND now, rental car hassles.

headline: Dr. William Harrison, Defender of Abortion Rights, Dies at 75
text: “Oh, God, doctor, I was hoping it was cancer.”

headline: Tournament Is in Reach, but Furyk Will Need Help to Win the Big Bonus
text: ATLANTA, Ga.  Even when things were not going according to plan for Jim Furyk on Saturday at East Lake Golf Club, he did what he has done since he started playing golf: he focused on advice he received from his father, which that day came as they walked through the crowds toward the first tee.

headline: A Struggle Over the Nile
text: Egypt, Sudan and the nations upstream along the Nile have been struggling over how to control the use of the river’s precious water.

headline: Courts and Foreclosures
text: To the Editor:

headline: Working to Preserve a Way of Life in the Wild
text: As the nation becomes more urban and teenagers seek other recreation, the popularity of hunting is declining. The latest federal survey, in 2006, found that 12.5 million people hunt each year, down from 17 million in 1975.

headline: Union May Back a Suspension for First-Time Drunken Driving
text: The N.F.L. players association may consider supporting a suspension for first-time drunken-driving offenses when the union and the N.F.L. make changes to the substance-abuse and personal-conduct policies in the future, according to a union executive who was granted anonymity because he was not authorized to speak publicly about negotiations with the league.

headline: Op-Ed at 40: Four Decades of Art
text: A short history of Op-Ed illustration, featuring interviews with art directors and illustrators and a detailed look at some of the work that has appeared in the paper and the Web site.

headline: Op-Ed at 40: Four Decades of Art
text: A short history of Op-Ed illustration, featuring interviews with art directors and illustrators and a detailed look at some of the work that has appeared in the paper and the Web site.

headline: Marecic Does It All for Stanford
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — In 12 seconds Saturday, Owen Marecic may have gone from college football rarity to college football phenomenon in No. 17 Stanford’s 37-14 victory at Notre Dame.

headline: The Concrete Ceiling, Bending and Breaking
text: To the Editor:

headline: Beyond Innovation
text: To the Editor:

headline: March 27, 2007: C-Flat Blues
text: One gray November Sunday morning in 1953 I was marching down Dorrance Street in Providence, R.I., playing the “Colonel Bogey March” (a tune later heard in “Bridge on the River Kwai”) in a local National Guard band of about 15 musicians led by my high school music teacher Eddie McCabe. I was a mere kid  they needed an extra trombonist. As the band was about to pass the viewing stand  mind you, this was my first and last appearance in military clothing, including an ill-fitting helmet that sat mostly over my eyes  I went for a low C-flat, a note playable only in seventh position, the one where you push the slide to the near end of its fixed tubing, but the slide kept going, flying magically from my hands and to wit from the trombone  dropping, like-oh-my-God, klunk, to the indifferent asphalt.

headline: Skeptics Challenge Conventional Wisdom of Emanuel as No. 1 in Mayoral Race
text: Chicago is abuzz with talk about Rahm Emanuel’s expected entrance into the wide-open mayor’s race, with rumors swirling about when he might head back to town to formally open a campaign.

headline: Running for Mayor Without the Machine’s Muscle
text: As Rahm Emanuel and a host of others consider campaigns to replace Mayor Richard M. Daley, they must reckon with a key issue: how to mount a successful citywide effort without the political machine that propelled Mr. Daley successfully through six mayoral elections.

headline: Tea Party Pure, With Idiosyncrasies
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative

headline: Bears Are a Surprise, Not That Coach Shows It
text: If I knew what makes Lovie Smith tick, I’d say it took all the self-control he could muster not to stick out his tongue or waggle a finger or have Mike Martz improvise a cool way to show his disdain for the Chicago news media in the wake of the Bears’ stirring victory over the Dallas Cowboys last Sunday.

headline: Entrenched Republican Faces Test
text: Out of San Francisco’s 41 elected leaders  from Mayor Gavin Newsom to the 11-member Board of Supervisors, from the school board to the city attorney to the assessor  there is but one Republican.

headline: When the Call of the Wild Comes Too Close to Home
text: In the early morning of Aug. 31, a young mountain lion took an ill-fated walk through North Berkeley. The police shot it dead after it was first spotted in the parking lot of a shuttered pharmacy, just down the street from the legendary dining spot Chez Panisse.

headline: The Future of California, Ready for Discussion
text: Jonathan Weber writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Urban Ore Ecopark
text: Sprawling across three acres in West Berkeley, Urban Ore is a huge thrift store that sells about 7,000 tons of reused and recycled goods per year. Dan Knapp and Mary Lou Van Deventer, who are married, opened the store in 1980, and pride themselves on only sending 120 tons  2 percent of their inventory  to the landfill annually. HANK PELLISSIER

headline: Beltran on Utley’s Slide: Two Can Play That Game
text: PHILADELPHIA  Carlos Beltran is not known as someone who makes fiery statements aimed at opposing players or who slides aggressively on the basepaths. But Beltran, steamed at the aggressive behavior of Phillies second baseman Chase Utley the night before, did both on Saturday as the Mets fought back to beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-2, at Citizens Bank Park.

headline: Robert W. McCollum, Who Studied Viral Diseases, Dies at 85
text: Robert W. McCollum, a former dean of the Dartmouth Medical School who made significant contributions to the understanding of viral diseases, including polio, hepatitis and mononucleosis, died Sept. 13 at his home in Etna, N.H. He was 85.

headline: Ralph T. Coe, 81, Advocate for Native American Art, Is Dead
text: Ralph T. Coe, a former art museum director and a private collector who played a central role in the revival of interest in Native American art, from the ancient to the modern, died Sept. 14 at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 81.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Boise State’s Path Is Cleared, if Voters Say So
text: BOISE, Idaho  The opening days of autumn have just arrived in the high desert here, but the competition for Boise State  at least from the big-boy leagues  has already packed up for winter.

headline: Paterson Makes Up With ‘Weekend Update’
text: Back before he ascended to the state’s top office, Gov. David A. Paterson was known for his sense of humor. As his term winds down, he’s free to resurrect that reputation.

headline: Boston’s Not-So-Secret Plan to Catch the Yankees
text: In September 2008, the Yankees were on the verge of being eliminated from playoff contention for the first time in 15 years. But with 11 games to go, they went on a five-game winning streak that brought them to the final week of the season with a faint, but distinct, hope: if they could sweep three games from the Blue Jays in Toronto while the Red Sox were swept at home by the Indians, then they would still be technically alive, with Boston’s magic number to clinch the wild card stuck at one.

headline: Paterson Makes Up With ‘Weekend Update’
text: Long after Gov. David A. Paterson’s advisers criticized “Saturday Night Live” for mocking his impaired vision in its send-up of him, Mr. Paterson confronted his impersonator, Fred Armisen, with a batch of his own one-liners. Read more on City Room …

headline: At Lincoln Center, Using Both Sound and Silence
text: One of the most accurate ways to understand jazz these days is through Roy Haynes’s cymbal beat. On Saturday night at the Rose Theater, for about three-quarters of his stage time, he tilted his head toward his ride cymbal and drove a changing stream of swing through it, using every other sound — from the snare drum, kick drum and the rest of his kit — as circulating accents around that primary force. It was mesmerizing, affirmative, flexible and incredibly artful. It made internal sense.

headline: In Mumbai, Finding the Flavors of Goa
text: Since its “discovery” by Western travelers in the late 1960s, Goa, a region 12 hours south of Mumbai by train, has developed a reputation for carefree living, shading into hedonism. The region’s unique cuisine, though, has added to its charms. With a large Christian population unrestrained by dietary taboos, Goan cooking features plenty of meat (pork and beef included) and fish, combined with a generous use of spice.

headline: Jason Taylor Hopes to Hear a Few Cheers Against Dolphins
text: You can almost tell from the look on his face: The Jets’ Jason Taylor is conflicted about returning as a visiting player to his old stomping grounds.

text: Who said this? More important, when did he say it?

headline: Milan Puts Wind in Its Sails

headline: Wildcat as a Wild Card as Jets Face Dolphins
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. – On Thursday after practice, having had a few days to absorb the Dolphins’ offense and see the wrinkles, the Jets walked away scratching their heads a bit. Linebacker Jaamal Westerman called the Wildcat formation “not just something they do, it is part of their base of offensive plays.”

headline: Isabella Blow, Revisited
text: During the flight over to Milan to catch the tail end of the Italian collections and over a couple of jet-lagged evenings, I finished reading an advance copy of Detmar Blow’s new book about the tragic life of his late wife, Isabella, who committed suicide in 2007. “Blow by Blow,” as it is called, is a page turner, but not entirely in the way one would hope.

headline: Alonso Cruises to Victory in Singapore Race
text: Fernando Alonso led the Singapore Grand Prix in his Ferrari from start to finish on Sunday to take his second Formula One victory in a row, his fourth of the season and his second at Singapore.

text: Fernando Alonso led the Singapore Grand Prix in his Ferrari from start to finish on Sunday to take his second Formula One victory in a row, his fourth of the season and his second at Singapore.

headline: A Move to Unify Europe’s Media Market
text: PARIS — Serving as a member of the European Parliament can be a thankless task. Lobbyists accost you from all corners. Tabloid newspapers complain about your expenses. And after a day of plenary sessions in Strasbourg, you might not be able to watch television shows from your home country without breaking the law.

headline: American and Afghan Troops Begin Combat for Kandahar
text: ARGHANDAB, Afghanistan  American and Afghan troops began active combat last week in an offensive to drive the Taliban out of their strongholds surrounding the city of Kandahar, military officials said Sunday.

headline: My Problem With Narayana Kocherlakota
text: He has too many characters in his name! I mean, folks, the regular column has to fit into a limited physical space — and every time I mention the president of the Minneapolis Fed, there goes a large chunk of scarce journalistic real estate.

text: One way to describe the progress on a project to repair a 75-foot wall that collapsed onto Riverside Drive and the Henry Hudson Parkway in Washington Heights is: Finally, really, finished. Almost.

text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Four aid workers for the United States Agency for International Development were kidnapped by gunmen on one of the country’s major highways on Sunday, according to embassy and police officials.

text: Chess players are not movie stars  no one has ever stalked a chess player, at least not for playing chess  but some fans go to great lengths to meet and even play against the game’s best.

headline: Green Day Star Will Join ‘American Idiot’
text: This should boost ticket sales for the musical “American Idiot” during Broadway’s traditional September doldrums: Billie Joe Armstrong, the frontman and lead guitarist of the rock band Green Day, will step into the role of St. Jimmy in the musical for eight performances from this Tuesday through Sunday evening, the producers have announced.

text: Bishop Eddie L. Long said in a press conference earlier today that he would fight charges of sex abuse.

headline: Katy Perry Finds a Home in Springfield
text: Katy Perry’s costumes may be too revealing for the audience of “Sesame Street,” but the pop star’s outfits should fit right in on “The Simpsons.” Ms. Perry will appear as herself, and as the girlfriend of the bartender Moe, in a live-action segment that will feature puppet versions of the show’s characters, Entertainment Weekly reported on its Web site.

headline: Has Beltran Become a Fiery Leader? At Least for a Day
text: Carlos Beltran is known by many Mets fans as a good player with a placid demeanor, whose talents are overshadowed by what they see as his passive approach to the game and his lack of leadership skills.

headline: What Structural Unemployment Looks Like
text: One thing I should probably make clear in this discussion of structural unemployment is that I have no problem in principle with the idea that shifts in the economy can temporarily lead to a large rise in the “natural” rate of unemployment. Let me offer a case in point: it was quite clear, circa 1990, that Britain was no longer capable of running unemployment rates as low as those of the 1960s and early 1970s.

headline: Yankees Change Course; Will Start Hughes on Sunday
text: The Yankees, mired in a four-game losing streak and struggling to clinch a playoff spot, decided to start Phil Hughes against the Red Sox on Sunday for his regular turn in the rotation. The Yankees had planned to start Dustin Moseley to give Hughes extra rest for the postseason. Starting pitching has been a particular concern over the course of the losing streak after poor appearances by C.C. Sabathia, A.J. Burnett, Andy Pettitte and Ivan Nova.

headline: Nokia’s New Chief Faces Culture of Complacency
text: A few years before Apple introduced the iPhone, research engineers at Nokia prepared a prototype of an Internet-ready, touch-screen handset with a large display, which they thought could give the company a powerful advantage in the fast-growing smartphone market.

headline: A Kid With a Camera and a Documenter
text: Those annoyed by the trendy term meta are going to be disinclined to tune in “Teenage Paparazzo,” a film about a 14-year-old who takes pictures of famous actors, made by one of those actors, who became famous for playing a famous actor, being shown on the cable outlet that carries the famous actor’s show. Let’s pause briefly while you go take some antidizziness pills.

headline: Putting On the Squeeze at the Honors Club
text: Regular pair-event duplicate players know that overtricks are important. If you score, say, plus 600 and everyone else with your cards is plus 630, you receive zero match points. But if they are all plus 600 and you are plus 630, you get a top  all of the match points available on the board. However, there is a time and a place for the overtrick hunt.

headline: Mets Make Sure Phillies’ Champagne Stays on Ice
text: PHILADELPHIA  Carlos Beltran and most of the Mets, but not all of them, seemed to play down the significance of preventing the Philadelphia Phillies from celebrating another divisional title in front of them. Beltran’s bat, glove and legs, however, told a markedly different story.

headline: Students Interpret Kafkaesque Score
text: The New Juilliard Ensemble, conducted by Joel Sachs, is one of several contemporary-music groups at the Juilliard School, and though Mr. Sachs pursues no particular stylistic agenda, he is committed to giving his student players music that pushes their technical and interpretive abilities. He is also intent on focusing their attention quickly: as in past years, he led the group’s season opener only a few weeks into the semester. But the performance, on Saturday evening at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, had the polish, energy and nuance you would expect from an ensemble that had worked and grown together over a much longer time.

headline: A Stage as Big as All Outdoors but Without Rain
text: Many artists come to New York to play the big room, and these days the biggest of the big rooms is the 55,000-square-foot Drill Hall at the Park Avenue Armory, a faded relic of the Gilded Age that has been gradually undergoing a $200 million conversion into an arts space meant to fit things that can’t fit anywhere else in the city.

headline: From Seat of Power, Battling Many Crises
text: Jimmy Carter’s first book, “Why Not the Best?”  published in 1976 when he was a long shot running for president  introduced him charmingly as a born-again Christian, former Georgia governor, former naval officer, Sunday school teacher and peanut farmer. But its frontispiece cast a shadow by quoting the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr: “The sad duty of politics is to establish justice in a sinful world.”

headline: Creating a Musical Is the Best Revenge (or Catharsis)
text: During rehearsals last week for his autobiographical entry in this year’s New York Musical Theater Festival, the composer and lyricist Jay Alan Zimmerman sat with his wife, Lisa Ingram, watching a scene inspired by his anxieties about their marriage. In the song “Fall,” an actress playing Lisa reveals feeling torn between the happy memories of falling in love with Jay years earlier and the heartache she feels as her husband begins to lose his hearing.

headline: Making Beautiful ‘Le Noise’ Together
text: Neil Young’s fans have long known he’s a stickler about sound. There’s nothing unpremeditated when he summons thick lava surges of electric-guitar distortion or when he plucks acoustic-guitar chords to ring in pristine solitude. So perhaps it was inevitable that he would end up collaborating with another careful shaper of reverberation and depth, Daniel Lanois, the producer who has opened up somber spaces on albums by U2, Peter Gabriel, the Neville Brothers and Bob Dylan.

headline: Gestures From an Explosive Movement Palette
text: The big hook for the Batsheva Dance Company’s Joyce Theater engagement is that two casts perform Ohad Naharin’s “Project 5” sampler program, one all-female and the other all-male. Audiences can compare and contrast, seeing just what a difference gender makes in this Israeli choreographer’s intensely physical work.

headline: An Evening Revisits Mark Morris Hits (Along With a Few of Chopin’s)
text: ALBANY — In the last 10 years the dancer Bradon McDonald has been the foremost exponent of the great roles that Mark Morris once made for himself. In New Haven last year he gave a brilliant account of the Dido-Sorceress alter ego of Mr. Morris’s “Dido and Aeneas.” On Friday night, at the Egg in Albany, he gave his last featured solo performance with the Mark Morris Dance Group and also danced in ensemble works.

headline: New CDs
text: KENNY CHESNEY

headline: Monday: Gets Lucky
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Patrick Merrell was talking recently about how tough Monday puzzles are to create. We haven’t heard from the constructor Janice M. Putney for a while, but she’s an early week specialist. Monday puzzles have to be easy enough for beginners, but interesting enough to be engaging. You need three or four, or more commonly, now, five theme answers (like today) that are amusing and fresh. This crossword is a fine example.

headline: Return to ‘Wall Street’ Delivers for Stone
text: Gordon Gekko reigns again. Oliver Stone’s “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps,” with Michael Douglas, below, reprising his Oscar-winning role as the financial miscreant Gekko, sold about $19 million in tickets for first place at North American theaters over the weekend. Twentieth Century Fox, which spent an estimated $60 million to make the picture, said that 65 percent of the audience was over 30. “I think that bodes well because what we know about adult audiences is that they don’t rush out, but they do keep coming,” said Chris Aronson, Fox’s senior vice president for domestic distribution. The other major release of the weekend, “Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga’Hoole,” finished second, selling about $16.3 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. That total was weak considering that “Guardians,” which Warner Brothers spent about $80 million to make, had premium-priced 3-D tickets to help prop it up. Ben Affleck’s “Town” (Warner Brothers) was a close third with $16 million  demonstrating impressive hold in its second weekend  for a new total of more than $49 million. The comedy “Easy A” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fourth with $10.7 million ($32.8 million total). “You Again,” a modestly budgeted comedy from Walt Disney Studios, landed in fifth place in its first weekend with about $8.3 million.

headline: Detroit Musicians Announce Strike Date
text: The musicians of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra say they will go on strike next Monday, when the season’s first rehearsal is scheduled. The players and the administration are locked in a dispute over how much of a salary cut the musicians should take and how their jobs should be redefined. The announcement came after a mediation session on Friday failed to produce any progress. The orchestra has been sustaining huge financial losses, mainly because of declines in ticket sales and donations; the players also blame bad decision-making. The administration, saying that major cuts are necessary for survival, is seeking to reduce the players’ base salary by 33 percent, and by 42 percent for incoming players. The musicians are offering a 22 percent reduction in the first year for both categories. (The base salary is $104,650.) The orchestra’s executives also want to loosen work rules so the musicians can be given other assignments, like coaching, teaching and playing chamber concerts. The Detroit Symphony faces perhaps the worst challenges of any major American orchestra at the moment, largely because of the city’s financial decline.

headline: Black Men in America Trying to Move on Up
text: “Through the Night” was initially produced at the Riverside Theater in May and has reopened for an Off Broadway run at the Union Square Theater. This review by Anita Gates appeared in The New York Times on May 12.

headline: Venezuelans Vote for Legislators
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Millions of voters cast ballots at polls across Venezuela on Sunday in tightly contested legislative elections seen as a test of whether the country’s opposition could appeal to large blocs of the electorate ahead of the next presidential election in two years.

headline: Boise State’s Moore Ignores, and Justifies, Heisman Hype
text: BOISE, Idaho — The night before Boise State played Oregon State, Kellen Moore hung out with his family in the lobby of a nearby Courtyard Marriott. He wore flip flops and cargo shorts and blended in seamlessly with a lobby full of fans, loitering members of the news media and travelers waiting to check in.

headline: Anger as a Private Company Takes Over Libraries
text: SANTA CLARITA, Calif.  A private company in Maryland has taken over public libraries in ailing cities in California, Oregon, Tennessee and Texas, growing into the country’s fifth-largest library system.

headline: Cowboys Win, and Pitchforks Are Set Aside
text: The Cowboys finally got their first win on Sunday,  27-13  over the Texans, in the 6A state championship game. Tony Romo threw two touchdown passes, Roy Williams caught them, and the coaching staff didn’t mess things up.

headline: After a Long Wait, a Critic of Citigroup Wins a Meeting With Top Executives
text: Citigroup has decided to embrace the old adage that one should keep friends close  and enemies even closer.

headline: Hyundai Recalls 139,500 of Its 2011 Sonatas for Steering Defect
text: Hyundai is recalling about 139,500 of its 2011 Sonatas because of a steering defect that could cause the driver to lose control of the vehicle, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Dalai Lama Donates to Center in Wisconsin
text: MADISON, Wis.  They say money can’t buy happiness  but it can finance the research.

headline: Losing Oregon State Coach Has Unusual Influence on Title Race
text: BOISE, Idaho  Oregon State Coach Mike Riley, one of college football’s consummate gentlemen, was able to crack a smile despite his team’s loss to Boise State.

headline: Number of Tenants Owing Back Rent Rises Sharply at City Housing Authority
text: In a sign of the toll the dismal economy has taken on working families in New York, more than 1 in 10 households living in public housing owe at least one month in back rent, a rise of nearly 50 percent over the past year.

headline: A Former Division II Doormat Has Taken Some Big Steps Up
text: Fordham scheduled Assumption College, an N.C.A.A. Division II team from Worcester, Mass., as its homecoming opponent Saturday. Big white tents were set up outside Jack Coffey Field, but the game was not such a celebration for Fordham, which lost, 30-24.

headline: New Labour Leader Looks to ‘Middle England’
text: LONDON — After beating his older brother David Miliband to the Labour Party leadership by a hair’s-breadth margin he owed to a left-leaning campaign that won the support of the country’s most powerful labor unions, Ed Miliband set out on Sunday to reposition himself as a centrist politician who could lead Labour back to power by winning the backing of middle-class voters who decide elections in Britain.

headline: Omanis Arrive in Iran to Aid 2 U.S. Hikers, Paper Reports
text: TEHRAN  An Omani delegation arrived in Iran on Sunday to help secure the release of two American hikers still held on espionage charges after their arrest last year, an Iranian newspaper reported Sunday.

headline: Liberal Groups Planning to Rally on National Mall
text: Hoping to overshadow last month’s large rally led by Glenn Beck that drew many Tea Party advocates and other conservatives, a coalition of liberal groups plan to descend on Washington on Saturday to make the case that they, and not the ascendant right, speak for America’s embattled middle class.

headline: Move Over, Bedbugs: Stink Bugs Have Landed
text: SABILLASVILLE, Md.  When they retreated from the Battle of Gettysburg, Confederate troops passed by the area that is now Richard Masser’s orchards. If only the latest enemy  the brown marmorated stink bug  would follow suit.

headline: Helicopter Attacks Militant Meeting in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia  An unidentified military helicopter blasted rockets at a house where Somali militants were meeting on Sunday, according to residents and insurgent leaders, in an apparent strike against the Shabab insurgent group.

headline: An Effort to Recapture Democratic Enthusiasm
text: President Obama plans to recapture energy by moving away from small town-hall-style meetings and going big, with his first large-scale campaign rally since 2008 scheduled to be held Wednesday.

headline: Lax State Gun Laws Tied to Crimes in Other States
text: WASHINGTON — Nearly 600 mayors nationwide, led by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and other city leaders, are mounting a new campaign to identify states with lax gun laws and push for tighter restrictions to prevent the trafficking of guns used in crimes.

headline: Iraq Waits for a Government on a Long Vacation
text: BAGHDAD  More than six months ago, millions of Iraqis cast aside fears about bombs and bullets to vote. In households without a reliable supply of water, the indelible purple ink on the voters’ index fingers did not wear off for more than a week.

headline: The Sexes and the Media They Focus On
text: Advertisers have long kept an uneasy eye on the incidence of multitasking among consumers of media. After all, a person who watches television while browsing the Web or cooking a meal is less likely to heed the ads than someone who gives the TV her exclusive attention. And rates of multitasking continue to rise, according to GfK MRI, a media and marketing research firm.

headline: Cocktail? Choices Vary on Rail Lines From the City
text: On the Metro-North Railroad, they toss back Foster’s beer and corn chips, but rarely rum or rosé. On the Long Island Rail Road, they prefer Bud Lights and Heinekens, and plain club soda is all but out of the question.

headline: A New Political Face at a Queens Parade
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo did not make it to the Columbus Day Parade in Howard Beach in Queens on Sunday, but his Republican opponent in the race for governor, Carl P. Paladino, appeared, passing out lollipops, carrying Italian and American flags and marching briskly in front of Cub Scout packs and bagpipe players.

headline: Water Drops for Migrants: Kindness, or Offense?
text: BUENOS AIRES NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, Ariz.  In this remote, semidesert landscape along the United States-Mexico border, water is a precious commodity  and a contentious one, too.

headline: New Team Alters Disney Studios’ Path

headline: Giants’ Bid to Rebound Blunders Out of Control
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In the moments after his team’s 29-10 loss to the Tennessee Titans, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin was asked about his team’s 3 turnovers and 11 penalties, with six whistles for personal fouls. Without a word, Coughlin shook his head, filling the room with his simmering disgust.

headline: New-Look Knicks, but Same Old Curry
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  In a gymnasium bursting with optimism and energy, Eddy Curry is a distant, gloomy soul on the baseline. In a training camp defined by everything that is new and promising, Curry is the last reminder of the Knicks’ troubled past  an anachronism in orange and blue.

text: Seton Hall University has a leafy, quiet campus surrounded by an iron fence, but its students say they sometimes attend fraternity parties in a nearby neighborhood so dangerous that guests are patted down for weapons at the door.

headline: Tough Weather Made 17th Hole Even Tougher
text: ATLANTA — As the weather got nastier on Sunday, so did the penultimate hole at East Lake Golf Club. The 17th hole is a 455-yard par 4 with water lining the left. When the water started coming from above, the scores on the hole soared.
