text: In Jeff Zucker’s announcement on Friday that he was stepping aside as the head of NBC Universal, Comcast’s purchase of the company was taken almost as a fait accompli.

headline: Out of Work, and Running Out of Hope
text: To the Editor:

headline: Victory for Families
text: A state appeals court in Florida toppled a monument to bigotry last week, declaring unconstitutional a 33-year-old state law that prohibited gay people from adopting children. The animus behind the ban is unmistakable. Its sponsor in the Florida State Senate, Curtis Peterson, declared in 1977 that its purpose was to send a message to the gay community that “we’re really tired of you” and “we wish you’d go back into the closet.”

headline: China Imposes a Steep Tariff on U.S. Poultry
text: HONG KONG  Days after it flexed its economic muscle in a diplomatic dispute with Japan, China continued to display a more assertive international economic policy on Sunday as it imposed steep tariffs on poultry imports from the United States.

headline: A Reminder for the F.B.I.
text: The day after Thanksgiving, 2002, was a slow day in the Pittsburgh office of the F.B.I., so a supervisor sent a special agent to a rally against the threatened war in Iraq to look for any terrorism suspects who might be there, just to “see what they are doing.” The peace rally was sponsored by the Thomas Merton Center, which has opposed violence and armed conflict since the days of Vietnam, and consisted largely of people distributing leaflets. There was not the slightest indication that there were any terrorists there or even the hint of a connection to terrorism. Nonetheless, the agent kept the leafleteers under surveillance and even took pictures.

headline: Forget the $10 Million. Think About Staying Dry.
text: ATLANTA — There was a bright spot to the gray veil of rain that covered East Lake Golf Club on Sunday during the final round of the Tour Championship. When the players contending for the FedEx Cup title reached the final holes, their focus was firmly on trying to stay dry and not on the $10 million bonus that loomed like a rainbow on the horizon for the winner.

headline: Cuomo Facing Criticism From Blacks
text: Andrew M. Cuomo faces discontent among black elected officials and community leaders who say Mr. Cuomo has ignored them during his campaign for governor and is offering black New Yorkers little reason to rally to his cause, endangering his prospects for November.

headline: The Senate and the Spill
text: The Coast Guard’s announcement a week ago that BP’s runaway Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico was “effectively dead” brought a collective sigh of relief from the company, the citizens of the Gulf Coast and President Obama  indeed from anyone who for nearly five harrowing months had been transfixed by one of the worst environmental disasters in American history.

headline: Early Lessons Forged Paladino’s Combative Style
text: When his troubled son spent a night in the Erie County lockup on drunken-driving charges, Carl P. Paladino parked outside the jail and slept in his car, just to be close to him.

headline: Shifting Online, Netflix Faces New Competition
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Even though Netflix’s arch rival Blockbuster has filed for bankruptcy protection, the victory lap will have to wait. The company that filled American mailboxes with red envelopes containing DVDs is already fighting the next war.

headline: Big Money Bolsters Equestrian Endurance Race
text: LEXINGTON, Ky.  The 100-mile endurance race is easily the most romantic of the eight horse disciplines on display here at the World Equestrian Games, evoking Bedouin desert races or the nostalgia of the Pony Express.

headline: Without Star, Often Broadway Shows Can’t Go On
text: To understand why the hit Broadway musical “Promises, Promises” will close after just nine months, gaze up at the show’s giant billboard over Times Square. There are the smiling faces of Sean Hayes and Kristin Chenoweth, stars who are the chief reasons the show usually grosses $1 million a week.

headline: Moroccan Leaves Lagat Behind in Fifth Avenue Mile
text: Shortly after Amine Laalou of Morocco walked out of Pennsylvania Station on Saturday and had his first glimpse of New York City, he quickly appreciated its visual allure.

headline: Donald Set to Take on Country He Embraces
text: ATLANTA  Luke Donald is a Ryder Cup hybrid: an Englishman who will represent Europe this week at Celtic Manor in Wales but who feels more at home in the United States, where he has lived for more than a decade.

headline: For Muslims, Day of Celebration Amid Controversy
text: The scene seemed surreal, yet oddly poignant: at a silent, deserted intersection in the center of Midtown Manhattan, beneath bland corporate logos and brick office buildings, hundreds of Muslims knelt on a sprawling tarpaulin, faced due east and commenced the midday call to prayer.

headline: Furyk’s Day: One Putt, Two Titles, $11 Million
text: ATLANTA  On a wet, dark and difficult Sunday, it all came down to making a par at the last hole. Just a par, from the deep greenside bunker at East Lake Golf Club, and Jim Furyk would win it all  the Tour Championship, the FedEx Cup, all the money, his career-best third title of the year and, probably, the player of the year award.

headline: A Judge’s Warning About the Legitimacy of the Supreme Court
text: During interviews about his new book, Justice Stephen Breyer has spoken mainly about one of its two themes, how the Supreme Court should decide cases. A week before the court’s new term, it’s the second theme  about the court’s legitimacy, or the respect it relies on  that deserves attention.

headline: In Week 3, the Cowboys Finally Get It Together
text: The Dallas Cowboys had all the classic signs of an implosion in progress. The players-only meetings. The votes of confidence for the coach. The head-scratching play-calling.

headline: Structure of Excuses
text: What can be done about mass unemployment? All the wise heads agree: there are no quick or easy answers. There is work to be done, but workers aren’t ready to do it  they’re in the wrong places, or they have the wrong skills. Our problems are “structural,” and will take many years to solve.

headline: Player Who Took H.G.H. Is Found Dead
text: Terry Newton, the British rugby player who was the first athlete to be suspended for testing positive for human growth hormone, was found dead Sunday at his home in England, according to the British Broadcasting Corporation.

headline: Obama to Speak With College Journalists
text: President Obama, who is trying to get young people to the polls to vote for Democrats in November, will host an on-the-record conference call with college student journalists on Monday to “discuss the steps his administration has taken to address the concerns and issues important to young Americans,” the White House said.

headline: The Seduction of the Tea Partiers
text: On the surface, the Pledge to America that House Republicans unveiled last week, in obvious imitation of Newt Gingrich’s famous  Contract With America, feels like a triumph for the Tea Party.

headline: To Fix Bad Breath, a Gadget Seen on YouTube

headline: A Good Moment to Open a Mongolian Bourse
text: The Mongol conqueror Genghis Khan may have been globalization’s most ardent early supporter. But Mongolia has taken its time embracing international capital markets. Now this “mortar economy” (the country is wedged between Russia and China, two of the BRIC countries) may be set for rapid growth.

headline: Murray Sayle, Reporter and Adventurer, Is Dead at 84
text: Early in his tenure at The Sunday Times of London, Murray Sayle reported on the escape of an eagle from the London Zoo by following the bird around Regent’s Park on a bicycle. It was a minor story in a major journalistic career, but it suggested Mr. Sayle’s inventive and audacious approach to his job: he would go anywhere and get there by any means necessary.

text: So much for the defensive battle many expected. The Jets prevailed in a close one, 31-23, thanks to a key scoring drive with less than seven minutes remaining in the fourth quarter.

text: With the Islamic finance industry worth an estimated $1 trillion and growing rapidly, it is perhaps no surprise that a number of Asia-Pacific nations are among a growing band of countries worldwide to signal their intention to carve out a larger share of the market, Liz Gooch writes in The New York Times.

headline: Not With the Greatest of Ease, but the Jets Win Amid a Circus

headline: U.S. Tries to Make It Easier to Wiretap the Internet
text: WASHINGTON  Federal law enforcement and national security officials are preparing to seek sweeping new regulations for the Internet, arguing that their ability to wiretap criminal and terrorism suspects is “going dark” as people increasingly communicate online instead of by telephone.

headline: Versace Schoolyard
text: People arrived at the Versace Theatre expecting a walk-through presentation of Versus, the line designed by Christopher Kane, and instead found a sod-covered playground and a 45-minute wait for the models to get their hair blown straight. Versus has been making a slow comeback, and this time Mr. Kane had a lot more to say about day clothes. Skinny dresses in tartan or tiny flower prints were the main story, with matching shoes. There were tube skirts in stripes, clingy cardigans and cute minidresses that featured color blocking, a pleated skirt and an asymmetrical top layer in a contrasting color or print.

headline: Raters Ignored Proof of Unsafe Loans
text: As the mortgage market grew frothy in 2006 — leading to a housing bubble that nearly brought down the banking system two years later — ratings agencies charged with assessing risk in mortgage pools dismissed conclusive evidence that many of the loans were dubious, according to testimony given last week to the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, Gretchen Morgenson writes in The New York Times.

That man will be the photographer Chris Hondros, who will be accompanying the musicians on his computer, projecting 900 of his images of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Shift in Venezuelan Politics as Chávez’s Opposition Reclaims Seats in Legislature
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  The results of the legislative elections here on Sunday suggest that, after years of conducting politics as a contact sport in venues like vitriolic television talk shows, President Hugo Chávez and his opposition might be ready to square off in an unlikely place: one of Venezuela’s beleaguered institutions, its legislature.

headline: At London Museum, Fashions That Evoke ‘Mad Men’ Era
text: Fans of the retro styles showcased on the hit TV show “Mad Men” should get themselves to the Fashion and Textile Museum (83 Bermondsey Street; 44-207-407-8664; www.ftmlondon.org). The museum’s current exhibition, “Horrockses Fashions: Off The Peg Style in the ’40s and ’50s,” features fashions that look to be straight out of Betty and Joan’s on-screen closets. Horrockses, a British design company that formed in 1946, existed successfully for only 21 years but covered a diverse customer base, from Queen Elizabeth II to the average girl on the street, and left a significant legacy.

headline: Global Underwriting Down 9% So Far This Year
text: JPMorgan Chase nabbed the top spot among banks for global equity capital markets underwriting in the first three quarters of 2010, but it hauled in less than half of what it did a year earlier.

headline: K.K.R. Buys Norway’s Visma From HgCapital
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has agreed to buy Visma, a Norwegian software company, from HgCapital for an enterprise value of £1.2 billion ($1.88 billion), the companies said on Sunday.

headline: Petroplus to Exit PBF Energy Venture
text: Petroplus Holdings, the Swiss-based oil refiner, said on Sunday that it will sell its 32.62 percent stake in the refining venture PBF Energy back to its private equity partners for $91 million to preserve liquidity and refocus on buying European assets, Reuters reported.

headline: 3i Buys Debt Specialist Firm From Mizuho
text: 3i Group, the British private equity firm, is buying Mizuho Investment Management from one of Japan’s largest banks to boost its presence in the European loan market, Reuters reported.

headline: Diplomats Try to Save Mideast Talks
text: JERUSALEM  Israel’s decision this weekend to end its freeze on West Bank Jewish settlement construction sent diplomats on three continents scurrying on Monday to keep the Middle East peace talks alive. And while the discussions covered many topics, in the end they came down to one stubborn goal: how to curb settlement construction.

headline: Nestle Seeks to Expand in Health Foods
text: The Swiss food giant Nestlé said Monday that it would seek to expand in the profitable health and wellness sectors by setting up a new unit and investing hundreds of millions of dollars in medical research, Matthew Saltmarsh reports in The New York Times.

text: A last-ditch treatment for Hodgkin’s lymphoma has succeeded in a clinical trial, the drug’s developer, Seattle Genetics, announced Monday.

headline: Ask About World War II in New York
text: This week, Richard Goldstein, an author and historian of the Second World War, will be answering questions from readers about all aspects of New York and the war. Please submit your questions using the comments box below. His first set of answers will appear on Wednesday.

headline: Leon Washington Still Has Plenty Left
text: Leon Washington’s Jets career effectively ended last October, when he sustained a gruesome compound fracture in a win at Oakland. Surgeons inserted a rod to stabilize his broken right leg, but the Jets gave him to Seattle in April in a largely meaningless swap of late-round draft picks.

text: M&T Bank‘s talks to buy Sovereign Bank from Banco Santander have stalled over disagreements as to who would control the combined entity, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: With NBC, Comcast’s Burke Gets the Spotlight
text: After last week’s announcement that Jeff Zucker would leave NBC Universal after its sale to Comcast is complete, it took no one by surprise when Comcast‘s chief operating officer, Steve Burke, was named to replace him.

headline: David Tepper, Feeling Groovy

headline: Gianfranco Ferré Nears Sale to Prodos Consortium

headline: Congress: The Week Ahead
text: Congress aims to wrap up its brief fall session this week by passing a temporary spending resolution to finance the federal government until after the November elections. headline: The Power of Conventional Wisdom
text: Duncan Black, aka Atrios, was startled by my Clinton quote in today’s column, sufficiently so that he went to check whether Bill Clinton really said anything like that – only to discover that he did, and that the full text is even more damning. What Atrios missed, I think – rarely for him – is just how powerful the force of conventional wisdom is.

headline: On Our Radar: The China-Russia Pipeline
text: The completion of a 620-mile oil pipeline linking China and Russia is celebrated in Beijing. “The smooth completion of the pipeline project is a model for the two countries’ mutually beneficial win-win cooperation and a milestone for China-Russia energy cooperation,” China’s president, Hu Jintao, says. headline: Paladino: Polarizing for Decades
text: Carl P. Paladino, a rumpled, weary-eyed developer from western New York, seemed to emerge from nowhere to capture the Republican nomination for governor this month. But for decades he has been an outsize, impulsive and often outrageous figure: polarizing in his politics, relentless in amassing his real estate empire and irrepressible in seeking to impose his will on civic life. The Times’s Metro desk has just published a profile, written by David M. Halbfinger and Michael Barbaro,  of Mr. Paladino, exploring how events in his childhood and early career shaped him to be the outsize and impulsive figure he is today.

headline: Recalling a Simple Life in Brooklyn

headline: Waived by Rangers, Redden Faces Uncertainty
text: ¶ The much-maligned Rangers defenseman Wade Redden, waived Saturday after two disappointing years with the Blueshirts, clears waivers on Monday without being claimed by another N.H.L. club. He and the $6.5 million cap hit he represents are now clear to go to the Rangers’ American League affiliate in Hartford. The long-anticipated move puts the Rangers beneath the salary cap and even leaves them with a couple of million dollars to make a new signing. But some believe that sending Redden to the minors (or to Europe, where he could sign with a club as former Blackhawks goalie Cristobal Huet did last month) could prove problematic under the collective bargaining agreement. Redden, a former N.H.L. all-star with Ottawa who once shared the league’s plus-minus award and played for Team Canada at the World Cup, I.I.H.F. World Championship and Winter Olympics, scored 5 goals and 40 points while going plus-3 in 156 games with the Rangers. Those stats are pretty good, but far short of the performance expected from a player who still has four years and $23 million left on his current Rangers deal. Redden does have a third option if he clears waivers: refuse to report to Hartford, which would void his contract and leave him free to seek a deal with another N.H.L. team, which will undoubtedly pay him much less.

headline: Fun House?
text: When designers make gallery pieces, you get sculptural chairs and charred chandeliers. But when artists create furniture, even the pretense of functionality disappears, leading to weird works like homoerotic bunk beds and chandeliers, like the one by Lee Bul (below), that don’t light up. These are the kinds of conceptually charged objects cataloged in ‘‘The New Décor,’’ the book based on a recent exhibition at the Hayward Gallery in London and traveling to the Garage in Moscow this month. Their purpose is not to elevate the trappings of domestic life but to question our very faith in them. ‘‘Contemporary artists are associating the home with a sense of movement, insecurity and precariousness,’’ says the Hayward’s director, Ralph Rugoff. ‘‘Rather than being a castle, home is a vulnerable place now.’’ While the more absurd pieces — like a giant hot-pink papier-mâché phallus bench by Franz West — explore our private space as a kind of public theater, others are more obviously unsettling. The Swiss artist Fabrice Gygi’s tented writing desk is somewhere between a child’s fort and a bomb shelter, and Jin Shi’s Chinese migrant worker’s dwelling is a chilling reminder of how the other half lives.

headline: For U.S. Wildlife, a Climate Change Blueprint
text: New efforts to measure what warming temperatures are doing to forests, streams and animals at a regional level are at the core of a strategic plan by the Fish and Wildlife Service to respond to the effects of climate change.

headline: Arrington Avoids Allegations of Collusion
text: Silicon Valley’s latest intrigue involving secret meetings and accusations of collusion and greediness sputtered when it finally reached a public stage on Monday.

headline: Now Screening | Giorgio Armani
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Giorgio Armani at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: For Better Pastas, Try Rice Noodles
text: Recently I decided to use up a package of rice noodles, also known as rice sticks, that had been sitting on a pantry shelf for some time. I wanted to see whether these quick-cooking noodles work in Italian pastas and in a few other dishes. I was pleasantly surprised  not only do they work, but because rice noodles don’t get soggy, I was able to enjoy leftovers for a few days.

headline: How Many Choices for Dinner?
text: Spuds is back with more lists. When Victor Crawford first became a full-time parent to his six children, he had some learning to do. He had spent much of his adult life in the military, and his cooking skills were subpar at best. He certainly didn’t know how to cook for a family of seven (which would become nine when his parents moved in).

headline: Where Are All the Prosecutions From the Crisis?
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Dancing Flies Dress Up to Lure Female Partners
text: In the animal kingdom, it is common for males to have ornamentation, like bright feathers, to impress females of their species, but a newly identified species of dancing flies found in Japan adds something new to the game of sexual display.

headline: The Odd Relationship Between Money and Happiness
text: Carl Richards, a certified financial planner, regularly publishes new sketches at BehaviorGap.com that try to simplify complex money decisions

headline: Raising the Barriers
text: Q. Why do barrier islands form along certain areas of coastline? A. Barrier islands form and shift along many, but not all, of the coastlines of the United States and about 15 percent of the coastlines worldwide. They are punctuated by inlets that let water flow in and out. What barrier islands have in common is a large supply of sand subject to the action of tides and waves and a gentle slope of ocean depth.

headline: 'Das Rheingold' at the Met
text: The director Robert Lepage narrates a look at his high-tech production at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Segway Owner Dies in Segway Crash
text: Call it irony, fate or simply an accident: in Britain, the owner of Segway died over the weekend when he apparently drove one of the devices off a cliff near his home, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Winners and Losers in Reapportionment
text: No one will know for sure until the end of the year, but a new analysis of state population figures suggests that the state of New York will lose two United States House seats – not just one, as earlier predicted — in the coming decennial reapportionment.

headline: Neanderthals’ Tools Were Their Own Work
text: Neanderthals living in southern Italy 42,000 years ago developed bone and stone tools, decorative ornaments and pigments on their own, not through interactions with Homo sapiens, according to Julien Riel-Salvatore, an anthropologist at the University of Colorado, Denver.

headline: Legal Challenge Fails, so Chess Federation Elections Will Proceed
text: There is an update to this blog entry at the bottom.A lawsuit challenging the qualifications of one slate of candidates for the top posts in the World Chess Federation has been unsuccessful. So the election will be held as originally planned on Wednesday at the Chess Olympiad that is currently going on in Khanty-Mansiysk, Russia.

headline: Longer Roots Are Discovered in Large Plant Family
text: The Asteraceae family is one of the largest plant families in the world. Its 20,000-plus members are found on every continent but Antarctica and include daisies, sunflowers, dandelions, lettuce and artichokes.

headline: Childbirth: Breast-Feeding Ends by 6 Months for Many
text: Most mothers start breast-feeding after they give birth, but many quit by the time their babies are 6 months old, according to new data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: ‘Snippets’ of Patient Data Are Accidentally Posted
text: NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center said Monday that bits and pieces of information, including 10 Social Security numbers, from about 6,800 patients had been inadvertently disclosed on the Internet.

headline: Coyote Comeback
text: James Gorman and Henry Fountain on the resurgence of the coyote population, especially in the eastern United States.

headline: Converging Flight Paths
text: The deregulation of the airline industry in 1978 led to a wave of mergers that continues to this day. But even as the legacy carriers have been consolidating and growing, they have been losing market share to low-cost carriers. Two of them, SouthWest and AirTran, have just agreed to merge and carried the most passengers in 2009 combined.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Dolce & Gabbana
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Karmen Pedaru from Ford Model Management before (right) and after (left) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Eugene Soulemain. (Drag the orange bar right to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: A Guided Tour of Modern Medicine’s Underbelly
text: “Adventures on the dark side of medicine” — now that sounds like a lot of fun. A few juicy stories about black-market organs, fingerprint erasure, murder and mayhem in the I.C.U. would make a welcome change from the usual humdrum stuff of hospital and clinic, where the big events are a drug that doesn’t work properly, or a visit from a pharmaceutical salesman that screws up the entire afternoon schedule.

headline: Report From the Taliban Heartland
text: “I’ve been working here for nine years and it’s become worse and worse…..”

headline: Mysteries That Howl and Hunt
text: With a chorus of howls and yips wild enough to fill a vast night sky, the coyote has ignited the imagination of one culture after another. In many American Indian mythologies, it is celebrated as the Trickster, a figure by turns godlike, idiotic and astoundingly sexually perverse. In the Navajo tradition the coyote is revered as God’s dog. When European colonists encountered the species, they were of two minds, heralding it as an icon of the expansive West and vilifying it as the ultimate varmint, the bloodthirsty bane of sheep and cattle ranchers.

headline: Weighing the Lives of Babies in Haiti
text: We were 18 doctors, nurses and other health professionals from Children’s Hospital Boston, on a nine-day mission to the General Hospital in Port-au-Prince to work with a Haitian pediatric team.

headline: A Finding on Malaria Comes From Humble Origins
text: It has taken 10 years for Dr. Beatrice H. Hahn to build the world’s most comprehensive treasury of great ape dung samples.

headline: Polar Sidekicks Earn a Place on the Map
text: Late by almost a century, cartographic immortality is being accorded the dogs and ponies who bore much of the burden, and in most cases gave their all, in the 1911-12 race between the Norwegian Roald Amundsen and the Englishman Robert Falcon Scott to be the first to reach the South Pole.

headline: A Badge That Tells Consumers, ‘Trust This App’
text: The Internet-connected cellphones in our pockets know a lot of personal things about us, like our location, e-mail contact list and credit card numbers. How do we know we can trust them to keep it all private?

headline: BlackBerry Tablet Revealed: The PlayBook
text: At Research in Motion‘s Web-developer conference on Monday in San Francisco, the company has revealed its tablet, called the PlayBook. The 9.7  mm-thick tablet has a seven-inch display, front and rear HD cameras and full 1080p support along with H.D.M.I. output. The PlayBook has no cellular connection of its own: it has Wi-Fi or works in concert with a BlackBerry handheld, using an encrypted Bluetooth connection to tether to the phone.

headline: An Economy Tour of Rhone Syrahs
text: AS with Yankees caps and “Law & Order” reruns, syrah is nowadays the property of the world. In pretty much any country that makes wine today, humans grow syrah.

headline: Versatile Voice From Mexico, in Rock Mode
text: Passion is never less than tempestuous in the music of Ely Guerra, the Mexican songwriter who performed at Le Poisson Rouge on Friday night as part of the Celebrate Mexico Now festival, which this year marks Mexico’s bicentennial. For Ms. Guerra, passion is profound and all-consuming, a matter of ecstasy or desperate need, and it’s the eternal subject of songs that climb toward catharsis or plummet into lonely desolation.

headline: Reports From the Hive, Where the Swarm Concurs
text: [Like the Science Times page on Facebook. | Sign up for the Science Times newsletter.]

headline: Photos of the Moment | Roberto Cavalli
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: At Ferragamo, Peasant Skirts With Polish
text: Massimiliano Giornetti, the designer of Salvatore Ferragamo, had an interesting take on the long trend occurring throughout Milan, looking back to the tiered peasant skirts that were ubiquitous on the streets of fashion capitals about six years ago. Mr. Giornetti’s long skirts were arguably more polished, shown in fine cotton the color of army fatigues or in neutral crochet versions that looked luxe, and still a bit more accessible than some of the extreme variations we’ve seen.

headline: Soldier Describes Murder of Afghan for Sport in Leaked Tape
text: Updated | 6:41 p.m. On Monday, at Joint Base Lewis-McChord in western Washington, Specialist Jeremy N. Morlock, one of five American soldiers accused by Army investigators of taking part in the murders of three Afghan civilians this year, appeared at a hearing to determine the formal charges against him.

headline: What a Top Energy Banker Brings to Citigroup
text: Citigroup’s hiring of Stephen Trauber and his team of energy bankers from UBS was seen as a victory for the bank when it was announced earlier this month.

headline: DVRs Bring Some Shows a Boost in Ratings
text: Were there any new hits in the first week of the new television season? More than it first seemed, according to some preliminary results.

headline: Simplifying the Decision for a Prostate Screening
text: One of the most difficult decisions a man makes about prostate cancer happens long before the diagnosis. Should he get a regular blood test to screen for the disease?

headline: A Fusillade of Sound Made for One Noisy Night in Greenwich Village
text: Masami Akita, who goes by the stage name Merzbow, spent about 75 minutes onstage at Le Poisson Rouge on Sunday night, generating a constant fusillade of sound: from two laptops, four digital-effects stompboxes and a homemade metallic contraption slung around his neck by a guitar strap.

headline: Gadgetwise: BlackBerry Tablet Revealed – The PlayBook
text: At Research In Motion‘s Web-developer conference on Monday in San Francisco, the company revealed its tablet, called the PlayBook. The 9.7mm-thick tablet has a seven-inch display, front and rear HD cameras, and full 1080p support along with H.D.M.I. output. The PlayBook has no cellular connection of its own: it works in concert with a BlackBerry hand-held, using an encrypted Bluetooth connection to tether to the phone.

headline: South Carolina to Start an Investment Firm for Its Private Equity Bets
text: For decades, public pension funds have bankrolled the private equity industry, investing billions of dollars with large firms like Apollo Global Management and the Blackstone Group.

headline: Gauging High-Speed Spin Inside a Lilliputian World
text: SAN FRANCISCO  I.B.M. scientists have modified a scanning-tunneling microscope, making it possible to observe dynamic processes inside individual atoms on a time scale one million times faster than has previously been possible.

headline: Dollar Thrifty Backs Hertz, Avis Seeks Delay
text: Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group on Monday reaffirmed its support for a takeover bid from Hertz Global Holdings, passing on what it described as a more lucrative but riskier offer from the Avis Budget Group.

headline: Dinner, Readers Agree, Should Not Be ‘Worked On’
text: Since when is someone waiting in line for 10 minutes to buy a sweater a “guest,” not a customer? And why, when one is dining at a restaurant and actually wants to feel like a pampered guest, must waiters persist in asking, “Are you still working on that?” These are some of the questions that Laurie Graff raised in last weekend’s Complaint Box.

headline: Stevens to Speak Up for Murkowski?
text: Ted Stevens may still have a voice in Alaska politics.

headline: A Designer’s Oeuvre | From Soup to Nuts
text: One has to wonder how the designer Patrick Jouin manages to stay so svelte, given his fondness for gastronomy. For the past decade, Jouin, 43, has been collaborating with the Michelin-starred chef Alain Ducasse on numerous projects, including the PastaPot for Alessi and the chic interiors for Ducasse’s restaurants at the Plaza Athénée in Paris and the Dorchester in London. ‘‘Patrick Jouin: Design and Gesture,’’ which opens Nov. 9 at the Museum of Arts and Design, will showcase his culinary product designs, complete with video sequences that illustrate their functions. Other items include Jouin’s sleek stainless steel Zermatt flatware for Puiforcat, plastic Champagne bucket for G. H. Mumm and carbon fiber chairs for Le Jules Verne, the restaurant in the Eiffel Tower. ‘‘My products are not related,’’ Jouin said before acknowledging that ‘‘they all come from the same pencil.’’ Pieces like his Optic storage cubes for Kartell and C2 Solid chair for MGX will also be on view, along with the light he designed for the museum lobby (above). Designing, it seems, burns a lot of calories.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Scotland and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Venezuela, Somalia and New York.

headline: Amorous Confusion in Pasatieri’s Adaptation of Chekhov’s Play
text: In all but title, Thomas Pasatieri would seem to be the composer in residence this season at Dicapo Opera Theater. In December this small, enterprising company on the Upper East Side of Manhattan will present the premiere of Mr. Pasatieri’s “God Bless Us Everyone,” with a libretto by Michael Capasso, Dicapo’s general director. The opera imagines what might have happened to Dickens’s Tiny Tim 20 years after the events of “A Christmas Carol.”

headline: Preparing a Dainty Dish to Set Before a King
text: Gotham Early Music Scene was founded in 2007 to promote early music in New York, both by presenting its own concerts and getting the word out about others. Its own productions include an annual series of season-opening showcases, now called the GEMS Project, in which several ensembles share a bill, each offering a taste of its repertory and interpretive style.

headline: An Airport Designer Is Sometimes Brought to Earth
text: IF karma works out right, I may come back in my next life as a little dog, something cuddly that everybody loves. In this life, I’m an airport architect, and people either like what you did on a job or hate what you did and, of course, could do it better.

headline: Rocker Follows His Work Onto a Broadway Stage
text: Minutes before the musical “American Idiot” had its first performance on Broadway last March 24, the packed crowd at the St. James Theater gave a roaring ovation to Billie Joe Armstrong, the lead singer of Green Day, as he took his center orchestra seat for the show, which is based on the band’s music. And for the 90 minutes of singing that followed, his head bobbed along to his own harmonies, and his lips could be seen moving to his own lyrics.

headline: American Gothic Tale With a Ray of Sunshine
text: NEW HAVEN — There’s nothing wrong in the new musical “We Have Always Lived in the Castle” at the Yale Repertory Theater, and that’s exactly the problem.

headline: Plácido Domingo to Step Down as Director of the Washington National Opera
text: Plácido Domingo, the busy opera singer, conductor and impresario, took a step off the treadmill with an announcement on Monday that he would end his term as general director of the Washington National Opera.

headline: Obama Puts Campaigning Back on His Agenda
text: WASHINGTON  On a Monday night in July, President Obama’s political advisers gathered for their weekly strategy session in a small, windowless, wood-paneled room in the West Wing. After 18 months marked by legislative victories and political setbacks, the question before them was how to re-energize the Democratic base  particularly young people who turned out in droves in 2008.

headline: Dusting Off an Elusive President’s Dull Image
text: When George Washington was sworn in as the first president of the United States, he had only one original tooth left. It was “a lonely lower left bicuspid,” according to Ron Chernow’s vast and tenaciously researched new biography. But Mr. Chernow was not content merely to write about the tooth and its larger implications, which range from questions about Washington’s apparent reticence in later life (did his dental troubles keep him from speaking?) to his harshly pragmatic attitude toward slavery (he purchased slaves’ teeth, perhaps for use in dentures). Mr. Chernow also paid a personal visit to the tooth at the medical library where it is stored.

headline: Milan Shopper, Minus Vegetables
text: Jil Sander had totes in its collection based on the common plastic grocery bag. The idea can’t be new (I believe Miguel Adrover once did a version), but it turned up in both leather and vinyl, and was shown with handbags.

headline: Unilever Makes a $3.7 Billion Deal to Buy Alberto Culver
text: Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer goods company, said Monday that it had agreed to buy the beauty care company Alberto Culver for $3.7 billion.

headline: South Carolina Starting Firm for Its Pension Fund
text: For decades, public pension funds have bankrolled the private equity industry, investing billions of dollars with large firms like Apollo Global Management and the Blackstone Group.

headline: George Blanda Dies at 83
text: George Blanda, whose 26-year career was the longest of any player in N.F.L. history, has died at age 83. The Oakland Raiders, the team with which he came synonymous and from which he finally ended his career, confirmed his death.Blanda played so long that he had what amounted to three pro careers. He spent 10 years with the Chicago Bears, but retired when they tried to make him solely a kicker, and then seven more with the Houston Oilers of the upstart A.F.L. When the Oilers decided he was finished in 1967, he joined the Raiders and played nine more seasons. He wound up in the Hall of Fame with a reputation as one of the greatest clutch performers in football history.

headline: What’s In R.I.M.’s PlayBook?
text: So now that R.I.M. has introduced its new tablet, the PlayBook, it’s worth putting this into context. For starters, it was not a terribly big surprise that R.I.M. had this up its sleeve — the rumor mill was in overdrive last week regarding the details of a coming BlackBerry tablet. Back then, it was being referred to as the BlackPad.

headline: Ken Burns & Co. Return to the Old Ballgame
text: “The Tenth Inning,” Ken Burns and Lynn Novick’s four-hour follow-up to Mr. Burns’s 18.5-hour documentary series, “Baseball,” does without some of the things that characterized the original. There are hardly any vintage photos or archival films, no roll calls of minor league teams, no forced detours into women’s baseball.

text: Milan

text: Updated | 6:41 p.m. On Monday, at Joint Base Lewis-McChord in western Washington, Specialist Jeremy N. Morlock, one of five American soldiers accused by Army investigators of taking part in the murders of three Afghan civilians this year, appeared at a hearing to determine the formal charges against him.

headline: Old Trees May Soon Meet Their Match
text: GREAT BASIN NATIONAL PARK, Nev.  For millenniums, the twisted, wind-scoured bristlecone pines that grow at the roof of western North America have survived everything nature could throw at them, from bitter cold to lightning to increased solar radiation.

headline: DC Comics Names New Editor in Chief
text: It’s not uncommon to see super-powered champions switch allegiances from one side to the other in the pages of their comic-book adventures, and so it goes for the people who create and publish their stories. On Monday, DC Comics, the longtime home of heroes like Batman, Superman and Wonder Woman, said that it had named as its new editor in chief Robert Harras, a veteran editor there who had also spent five years as the editor in chief of rival Marvel Comics, the publisher of Spider-Man, the Hulk and Iron Man.

headline: George Blanda in Quotations
text: George Blanda, who died Monday at 83, was a part of football for so long that he intersected with seemingly everybody who was anybody in the game. Here are a few quotations that tell part of his amazing journey:

headline: JPMorgan Shifting Its Proprietary Trading Desk
text: JPMorgan Chase is moving its proprietary trading unit out of its investment bank and into its asset management unit in a bid to comply with new federal regulations that seek to restrict commercial banks from trading for their own account.

headline: Football and ‘Family Guy’ Make Strong Showings
text: “60 Minutes,” “Desperate Housewives” and “Family Guy” were among the highest-rated shows on Sunday, a night otherwise dominated by NBC’s “Sunday Night Football.” According to Nielsen’s preliminary overnight estimates, NBC’s football coverage led the night, up compared with last year’s corresponding Sunday-night game, which drew 17.5 million viewers. CBS ranked second, its prime-time lineup helped by an overrun of football coverage, followed by “60 Minutes” (15 million) and the 90-minute premiere of “The Amazing Race” (11.9 million). On ABC the season premiere of “Desperate Housewives” (12.8 million) was down from last year’s debut (13.6 million), but strong for the night. “Family Guy” (9.1 million) made a solid return on Fox with an hourlong murder mystery.

headline: Governor Postpones Execution in California
text: SAN FRANCISCO  With the clock ticking and uncertainties  both legal and pharmaceutical  hovering, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger ordered a temporary last-minute reprieve on Monday in what would be California’s first execution in more than four years.

headline: Romanticism and Modernism, Joined by the Violin
text: Three ballets choreographed to violin concertos could have been a nice idea on paper but a bad one in practice. Amazingly, however, New York City Ballet’s triple violin bill on Saturday night at the David H. Koch Theater offered not just a magnificent range of 20th-century scores by Barber, Prokofiev and Stravinsky, but also a dance program that seemed perfectly composed too.

headline: Stevens Case Prosecutor Kills Himself
text: WASHINGTON  A Justice Department lawyer involved with the botched corruption trial of former Senator Ted Stevens committed suicide over the weekend, the law firm representing him said on Monday.

headline: Rosy Sunsets, Silver Caves and Three Divergent Works
text: Last season New York City Ballet poured all of its creative and marketing might into Architecture of Dance, a festival of new choreography and music featuring designs by the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava. Commercials in taxicabs and sleek billboards promised to brush the dust off ballet, but it was more like watching the pile grow higher. The works featuring Mr. Calatrava’s designs were mainly forgettable  ballets destined for the City Ballet graveyard, which, frankly, is getting kind of crowded. (What is a set without a great dance?)

headline: Socialists’ Economic Policy in Portugal Wins Support
text: Portugal must stick to plans to cut public spending and possibly raise taxes further, according to a report released on Monday by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development amid a political standoff over the country’s budget plans.

headline: Mendes Making a Difference for Red Bulls
text: Red Bulls defender Carlos Mendes has been through so many new beginnings, new eras and new coaches that the meaning of the word “new” has scant significance.

headline: Proposals Would Stiffen Debt Penalties in Europe
text: BRUSSELS  Draft proposals to tighten the rules for countries using the euro will demand earlier action and near-automatic sanctions against countries that breach debt and deficit limits.

headline: Giants Say Answer Is Simple: Teamwork
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Coach Tom Coughlin stood behind a lectern Sunday at New Meadowlands Stadium and tried to explain the Giants’ 29-10 loss to the Tennessee Titans.

headline: Political Masks Are So 2009
text: MIAMI   Lady Gaga is likely to become this Halloween’s hottest celebrity  Madonna with meat, as one costume salesman described it  but when it comes to message-minded get-ups, political ghouls like Barackula are out and corporate horror is in.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Spokesman for WikiLeaks Steps Down
text: LONDON  A prominent spokesman for WikiLeaks announced his resignation on Monday in an interview with a German news magazine, marking the latest in a series of public rifts within the organization.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Critics' Picks: 'A Shot in the Dark'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Blake Edwards's 1964 comedy, with Peter Sellers as Inspector Clouseau.

headline: A Wider Wi-Fi Stream on Domestic Flights
text: EVEN as the number of airlines is dwindling — look at Southwest’s plan to buy AirTran, announced on Monday, and the imminent merger of United and Continental — the business of providing in-flight Wi-Fi service on domestic airlines is expanding.

headline: A Federal Gun Bill
text: To the Editor:

headline: Still Few Women in Management, Report Says
text: Women made little progress in climbing into management positions in this country even in the boom years before the financial crisis, according to a report to be released on Tuesday by the Government Accountability Office.

headline: Water Use in Southwest Heads for a Day of Reckoning
text: LAKE MEAD NATIONAL RECREATION AREA, Nev.  A once-unthinkable day is looming on the Colorado River.

headline: In Change, September Isn’t Breeze For Rivera
text: TORONTO  Silence reigned at Rogers Centre around 3:30 p.m. Monday, the only sounds coming from the footfalls of Mariano Rivera, the most dominant closer in baseball history. The afternoon after blowing his third save in two weeks  after giving up a run for his third straight outing, after allowing four stolen bases, after revealing his vulnerability  Rivera walked toward the Yankees’ bullpen to find out why.

headline: Nestlé to Expand Business in Health Care Nutrition
text: Nestlé said on Monday that it planned to invest more than $500 million over the next decade to develop health and wellness products to help prevent and treat major ailments like diabetes and obesity.

headline: Amfar Benefit Ends Milan Fashion Week
text: Milan Fashion Week closed Wednesday night with a black-tie gala at La Permanente to benefit Amfar, the Foundation for AIDS Research, where it was pretty clear that the designers were ready to blow off some steam after a week of lively shows.

headline: A Homeowner’s Lament
text: To the Editor:

headline: In the Bronx, Looking in the Mirror for Blame, and Solutions, on Gun Violence
text: The older woman sitting in church was fed up with pretty much everyone  the politicians, the clergy, the police, the district attorneys  but most of all with the gun-slinging young men who act as if the streets of the Bronx were the streets of Laredo.

headline: Urban Turn for Workers Accustomed to the Forest
text: An unusual scene unfolded in the rain in Prospect Park on Monday morning, as a crew from Tennessee confronted the aftermath of a particularly turbulent storm.

headline: 4,100 Students Prove ‘Small Is Better’ Rule Wrong
text: BROCKTON, Mass. — A decade ago, Brockton High School was a case study in failure. Teachers and administrators often voiced the unofficial school motto in hallway chitchat: students have a right to fail if they want. And many of them did — only a quarter of the students passed statewide exams. One in three dropped out.

headline: Pressure Begins in Miami for Stars, and the Coach
text: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  The opening act of the spectacle known as Miami Heat media day featured Coach Erik Spoelstra. He climbed onto a platform illuminated by stage lights and surveyed a veritable armada of 275 reporters, bloggers, photographers and more cameras than a reality show.

headline: Domingo to Quit Washington Opera
text: Plácido Domingo, the busy tenor, conductor and opera impresario, took a step off the treadmill with an announcement on Monday that he would end his term as general director of the Washington National Opera.

headline: Wal-Mart Opens Up Its Wallet in Africa
text: Wal-Mart has finally sounded the vuvuzela on African expansion. After months of speculation about how it would try to capitalize on the continent’s growth, the retailer is offering $4.2 billion to acquire South Africa’s Massmart Holdings. The price could grate on shareholders’ ears. But the deal gives Wal-Mart a local vehicle — and local knowledge — to help it gain access to a market with a profile that should suit it well.

headline: Insurgent Group in Iraq, Declared Tamed, Roars
text: BAQUBA, Iraq  This spring, United States military commanders said that Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia was a group in disarray, all but finished as a formidable enemy after American and Iraqi troops had killed or captured more than three-quarters of its leaders.

headline: Panel Wants BP Fines to Pay for Gulf Restoration
text: WASHINGTON  A large share of the penalties collected from BP for its Gulf of Mexico oil spill should be dedicated to repairing the ecological, economic, public health and psychological damage from the spill, according to a group named by President Obama to chart a course for the future of the wounded gulf.

headline: George Blanda, Hall of Fame Football Player, Dies at 83
text: George Blanda, a quarterback and place-kicker who played professional football longer than anyone else and who retired having scored more points than anyone else, died Monday. He was 83.

headline: Cleveland Stews Over Its Breakup With James
text: CLEVELAND  There is hair to be cut and money to be made, so Tony Houston opens his barbershop before the sun rises on weekends. To enter, you walk over a life-size decal of LeBron James, although just a few months ago the same image hung proudly on the barbershop’s wall.

headline: Corporate Loans in Europe Fell Less Steeply in August
text: Borrowing by European companies showed signs of stabilizing in August, according to data released Monday that the European Central Bank president said signaled “a little more dynamism” in a crucial component of the economy.

headline: Germany Takes a Step Toward Ending Its Draft
text: BERLIN  Germany moved a step closer to ending military conscription on Monday when conservative party leaders agreed to halt a draft embedded in the Constitution half a century ago to help keep the armed forces from ever again developing into a self-directed state within a state.

headline: Saab Talks With BMW About Forming Alliance
text: Saab Automobile, the Swedish brand that was rescued from near death early this year by a Dutch manufacturer of high-end sports cars, may soon be getting some German help as well.

headline: Antaeus and the Tea Party
text: Liberal pundits and the politicians whose agendas they favor continue to misunderstand the Tea Party movement and, what is worse, fail to realize how much the disdainful tone of their criticism fuels it. This may be changing now as the ominous signs proliferate — the primary victories of Christine O’Donnell, Joe Miller, Rand Paul and Sharron Angle, the likely election victory of Marco Rubio and, in recent days, the startling news that Carl Paladino and Joe DioGuardi may be closing in on supposed shoo-ins Andrew Cuomo and Kirsten Gillibrand (I say “may be” because there are conflicting polls). And of course there is Sarah Palin, who, despite endless analyses of her personal and political shortcomings, looms larger on the national stage every day.

headline: Cuomo Assails Paladino for ‘Extremist Views’
text: Andrew M. Cuomo sharply criticized his Republican opponent for governor, Carl P. Paladino, on Monday for his positions on abortion, welfare, and education, after days of public and private pleas from fellow Democrats to take his rival more seriously.

headline: Court Hears of U.S. Unit Killing Afghan Civilians at Random
text: JOINT BASE LEWIS-MCCHORD, Wash. — Members of an American Army unit consumed with drug use randomly chose Afghan civilians to kill and then failed to report the abuses out of fear they would suffer retaliation from their commander, according to testimony in military court here on Monday.

headline: Defense’s Struggles Leave Jets Unsettled
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets held on at the last minute to defeat the Miami Dolphins on Sunday night, and Rex Ryan said Monday afternoon that he was still happy  or, as he quipped, as happy as a coach can be for not recognizing some of the coverages the Jets used.

headline: A Trial on Identity Theft, With Scholarly Discourse
text: Loyal son. Academic crusader. Dead Sea Scrolls expert.

headline: Maker of BlackBerry Introduces Tablet
text: OTTAWA  Research In Motion, the Canadian maker of the BlackBerry smartphone, introduced its first tablet computer on Monday at a developers’ conference in San Francisco. But in a return to its roots, the company said that the new device, the BlackBerry PlayBook, would be aimed mainly at business users.

headline: Zeal for Dream Drove Scientist in Secrets Case
text: Many people who know P. Leonardo Mascheroni describe him as a maverick and a technology zealot. Now, the Justice Department will try to prove that he is dangerous, too  a man willing to sell atomic secrets in exchange for a chance to realize his dream.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Nagging Questions for Yankees’ Rotation
text: Toronto

headline: Stanley Chais, Investor With Madoff Tie, Dies at 84
text: Stanley Chais, who built a reputation as a prominent investment manager and philanthropist only to see it fall apart after he was caught up in the financial scandal masterminded by Bernard L. Madoff, died on Sunday in New York. He was 84 and had suffered from a blood disorder.

headline: C.I.A. Steps Up Drone Attacks on Taliban in Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON  The C.I.A. has drastically increased its bombing campaign in the mountains of Pakistan in recent weeks, American officials said. The strikes are part of an effort by military and intelligence operatives to try to cripple the Taliban in a stronghold being used to plan attacks against American troops in Afghanistan.

headline: A Dark Horse Emerges in Alaska: The Incumbent
text: JUNEAU, Alaska — The night Lisa Murkowski announced she would mount a write-in campaign to retain her Senate seat, she acknowledged to a crowd of supporters that her odds were slim. Then she prompted a defiant roar: invoking Native Alaskan culture, she told the crowd that the ancient Aleut language contained no word for “impossible.”

headline: The Value of a Piece of Facebook
text: Yep, it was another deal hatched in Sun Valley.

headline: Brother of Afghan Leader Is Subject of Wiretapping
text: WASHINGTON  The National Security Agency has been conducting electronic surveillance of a brother of the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, as part of a corruption investigation into his business dealings in Afghanistan, according to United States officials.

headline: Florida Voters Enter Battle on Growth
text: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla.  Lesley Blackner drove through a maze of condominium towers, rarely seeing any curtains in the windows, or residents, and tried to contain her anger.

headline: Suspect Who Fled to Serbia Pleads Guilty in 2008 Beating
text: A former college basketball player pleaded guilty in Belgrade, Serbia, on Monday as part of a deal that would send him to prison for his role in a barroom brawl in Binghamton, N.Y., that left a classmate badly injured, the classmate’s lawyers said.

headline: As Laws Shift, Voters Cast Ballots Weeks Before the Polls Close
text: CINCINNATI  At least one-third of all ballots across the country this year will be cast before Election Day, party officials said, reflecting a steady rise in early voting that is profoundly influencing how political campaigns are conducted in many parts of the country.

headline: France: Agreement in Chirac Embezzlement Case
text: The Paris City Council on Monday approved a settlement in an embezzlement case involving former President Jacques Chirac, who was accused of diverting millions of dollars in public funds to political allies during his tenure as mayor, from 1977 to 1995. Under the agreement, Mr. Chirac, left, and his former political party, the governing Union for a Popular Movement, are to pay $3 million, a sum representing the embezzled funds, plus interest and legal fees. In exchange, the city is to withdraw its complaint against Mr. Chirac, who is still to face trial on state charges. He has denied any wrongdoing.

headline: Buddy Collette, Jazz Musician and Bandleader, Dies at 89
text: Buddy Collette, a jazz saxophonist, flutist, clarinetist and bandleader who blended his usually soothing, often pungent sounds with those of many jazz greats and who was a leader in the struggle to break racial barriers in the music industry, died on Sept. 19 in Los Angeles. He was 89.

headline: China: Building Starts on Rail Line to Tibet
text: Workers began construction Sunday on a railway extension to connect the Tibetan capital, Lhasa, with the region’s second-largest city, Xigaze, state media reported. It is the first new leg on the Qinghai-Tibetan railway, an engineering feat opened in 2006 that has been hailed as an engine for Tibetan development  and criticized by some as a conduit for the migration of Han Chinese from the rest of the country. The 150-mile-long line will cost nearly $2 billion and take four years to complete, according to China Daily. Officials plan two more extensions, including a proposed route to the Nepal border.

headline: Trade Rumors Continue, but Anthony Remains With Nuggets
text: DENVER  The increasing possibility that the All-Star forward Carmelo Anthony could be traded at any moment gave Denver Nuggets media day a surreal feel to it Monday, one that left more questions than answers about his future in Colorado.

headline: Mexico: Mayor of Western Town Is Murdered
text: The acting mayor of a western town was found murdered Monday along another man. It was the fifth killing of a mayor in Mexico in six weeks and the 11th this year. Gustavo Sánchez Cervantes, a teacher, took over as the mayor of Tancítaro, in the state of Michoacán, last December after the elected mayor and the City Council resigned, arguing that pressure from organized crime made it impossible to do their jobs. The state police said that Mr. Sánchez, who was blindfolded and whose hands had been tied, had been struck in the head by a rock. No motive had been determined, the authorities said.

headline: Massachusetts High School Turns Performance Around
text: Brockton High School outperformed 90 percent of Massachusetts high schools, in part because of efforts incorporate reading and writing lessons into every class.

headline: Israel Kills Three Militants in Gaza
text: GAZA  Three Palestinian militants were killed late Monday in an Israeli bombing in Gaza, witnesses, medical and security personnel said, a continuation of sporadic violence in the territory that is controlled by the Islamist group Hamas.

headline: Paying Fee, Firm Is Set to Bring Slots to Aqueduct
text: The check is in; the gambling may soon begin.

headline: Proposal Would Expand Reporting of Money Transfers
text: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department on Monday proposed a requirement for banks to make weekly reports of all electronic money transfers into and out of the United States.

headline: Tuesday: A Bushel of Boscs
text: In Xanadu did Kubla KhanA stately pleasure-dome decree,Where Alph, the sacred river, ranThrough caverns measureless to manDown to a sunless sea.

headline: Sarah Palin Drops In on ‘Dancing With the Stars’
text: Sarah Palin is rarely shy about expressing her preferences in many matters, but she was more diplomat than politician in an appearance Monday night on the ABC reality competition “Dancing With the Stars,” taking care not to put her thumb on the scales even though her daughter Bristol is a contestant on the show this season.

headline: Retrospect Puts Randolph in a New Light
text: Consider it a twist of scheduling fate, or a message from a baseball authority much higher than the commissioner’s office, that Willie Randolph appeared at Citi Field for what is likely to be Jerry Manuel’s last homestand as the Mets’ manager. And possibly Omar Minaya’s final days at the helm of the team’s front office.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Trojan Makes Concessions to Place a Suggestive Ad
text: TROJAN, the condom brand, has had its share of run-ins with censors, most notably in 2007, when both Fox and CBS rejected a commercial with a safe-sex message that featured anthropomorphized pigs. Now Trojan is introducing a vibrator called Tri-Phoria, and it says a new commercial is actually drawing less resistance than it had expected.

headline: Political Fund-Raising As if It’s Going Out of Style
text: Consider it the last-minute rush, Congressional campaign-style.

headline: Yanks Miss Chance to Seal Playoff Spot
text: TORONTO  One start remains for A. J. Burnett, and it will be his most important of the season. One more chance to convince the Yankees to trust him in a first-round playoff game. One more disaster resembling Monday night, when he imploded in the third inning of the Yankees’ 7-5 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays, could banish him to oblivion  unless he is already there.

headline: Opponent Called ‘Taliban Dan’
text: Representative Alan Grayson, an outspoken freshman Democrat from Florida, has a new advertisement that looks to equate his Republican opponent with the Taliban.

headline: Davis Shares His Family’s Holocaust History
text: Mets first baseman Ike Davis is half Jewish and not religious. But he is acutely aware of the two distinct branches of his family history, which have a common thread in World War II and the horrors of the Holocaust. Davis, whose father is Baptist and whose mother is Jewish, had many relatives on his mother’s side who died in the Holocaust, and one great aunt who survived it.

headline: Emanuel ‘Nearing a Decision’ on Mayoral Run
text: Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, is “nearing a decision” on whether to leave the Obama administration to explore a run for mayor of Chicago and could make an announcement as early as Friday, a person close to Mr. Emanuel said Monday night.

headline: Lazio Leaves Race, Giving Reluctant Aid to a Rival
text: Former Representative Rick A. Lazio withdrew from the New York governor’s race on Monday, clearing the way for the Republican nominee, Carl P. Paladino, to bolster his surprisingly aggressive candidacy with the added ballot line of the state Conservative Party.

headline: Utley and Wright Discuss Hard Slide
text: While David Wright stood at second base during a timeout on Sunday, Philadelphia Phillies second baseman Chase Utley approached him to give his side of the story in the sliding controversy from Friday night.

headline: Terror Witness Returns, Facing Gentler Questioning
text: A prosecutor spent several hours on Monday trying to rehabilitate the reputation of an important government witness, an informer in a terrorism trial whose credibility had been attacked by defense lawyers again and again over days of vigorous cross-examination.

headline: How to Spot a Terrorist
text: Newark A YOUNG man walks into a Home Depot and buys a large quantity of acetone. Later, a young man walks into a beauty supply store and buys hydrogen peroxide. Still later, a young man is observed parked outside a nondescript federal building in a rented van, taking photographs.

headline: Tom Joad Gave Up
text: Atherton, Calif.

headline: What Is Paladino About?
text: Is the Republican candidate for governor of New York a racist, sexist, pornography-loving creep? Or are there other, more benign, explanations for the stomach-turning e-mails distributed by Carl Paladino?

headline: Sports Replay: Sept. 27
text: A view of the day in sports, from high-stepping horses to hard-sliding baseball players.

headline: Profiles in Timidity
text: We are starting to wonder whether Congressional Democrats lack the courage of their convictions, or simply lack convictions.

headline: Yankees’ Starters Wheezing to the Finish
text: TORONTO – It was so simple last year, wasn’t it? Line up C.C. Sabathia, A.J. Burnett and Andy Pettitte for the postseason, and let them pitch. Oh, sure, the Yankees flirted with the idea of giving Chad Gaudin a start. But, really, even with two-game leads in all three series, that was never a serious temptation.

headline: A Cynical Farewell
text: Bronx voters will see an unexpected name on the November ballot for State Supreme Court judge: Rick Lazio, placed there by the New York Republican Party. Mr. Lazio won’t be elected a judge in the Democratic county. He won’t even campaign for the job. His faux candidacy is all part of a cynical effort by the Republicans to get him out of the way of the Republican nominee for governor, Carl Paladino.

headline: Man Is Arrested in Killing Near Seton Hall
text: The authorities arrested and charged a suspect on Monday night in the weekend shooting near Seton Hall University that left one student dead and four other people injured.

headline: Even Sweden
text: Sweden’s reputation for fairness and tolerance took a nasty hit this month after a xenophobic anti-immigrant party that misleadingly calls itself the Sweden Democrats won 20 seats in the 349-seat Parliament. Neither of the two main coalitions secured a clear majority, so this former fringe group is hoping to leverage its power.

headline: MacArthur Foundation Honors 23
text: The creator of the television series “The Wire,” about drugs, poverty and corruption in Baltimore; a historian who traced the lives of a slave family connected to Thomas Jefferson; and an economist who helped calculate the worth of a standout kindergarten teacher were among the 23 recipients of the $500,000 “genius awards” to be announced on Tuesday by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation.

headline: Basic Religion Test Stumps Many Americans
text: Americans are by all measures a deeply religious people, but they are also deeply ignorant about religion.

headline: Word of the Day | isotope
text: isotope •\ˈi-sə-ˌtop\• noun

headline: Googling the Censors
text: In most repressive countries, government censors like to toil in the shadows, maintaining a cover of deniability as they block citizens’ access to information. It is gratifying to see that the Internet and Google are making their job tougher.

headline: Wal-Mart Bids for Massmart to Expand Into Africa
text: Wal-Mart Stores announced plans on Monday to enter the African market, with a preliminary offer to buy the Johannesburg-based retailer Massmart Holdings for about $4.2 billion, Stephanie Clifford writes in The New York Times.

headline: Mayor’s Fall Doesn’t Settle Who Rules in Russia
text: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev has long endured questions about whether he truly rules Russia or is merely a figurehead manipulated by Vladimir V. Putin, the former  and possibly future  president. On Tuesday, Mr. Medvedev moved to quiet those doubts by ousting a heavyweight political rival, Moscow’s longtime mayor, who had tried in recent weeks to cast Mr. Medvedev as a weakling unfit to run the Kremlin.

headline: News Quiz | September 28, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: At Chess Olympiad, No Team Is Perfect
text: After Monday, there are no teams in the top section with no losses or ties at the Chess Olympiad.

headline: James Levine Is Back for Met’s Opening Night
text: The Metropolitan Opera’s opening-night gala traditionally begins with an appearance in the pit by the conductor of the evening, who for the last 40 years has usually been James Levine, to take a bow before leading a performance of the national anthem.

headline: Still Few Women in Management, Report Says
text: Women made little progress in climbing into management positions in this country even in the boom years before the financial crisis, according to a report to be released on Tuesday by the Government Accountability Office, Catherine Rampell writes in The New York Times.

headline: Bloggingheads: The Career-Ending Tweet
text: Daniel Drezner, left, of Tufts University and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic discuss politics and the Internet's memory.

headline: The Value of a Piece of Facebook
text: Mark Zuckerberg’s donation of $100 million to the troubled schools of Newark made waves last week, but now it’s time to look a gift horse in the mouth, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: Divided Parliament Opens in Australia
text: SYDNEY, Australia  Australia’s most bitterly divided Parliament in recent history convened for the first time on Tuesday as Prime Minister Julia Gillard urged legislators to engage in “consensus, not confrontation.”

headline: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 28, 2010
text: Test your vocabulary skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times blog post “The Ontology of Plagiarism: Part Two.”

headline: Proposal Would Expand Reporting of Money Transfers
text: The Treasury Department on Monday proposed a requirement for banks to make weekly reports of all electronic money transfers into and out of the United States, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: North Koreans Bolster Power of Ruler’s Kin
text: TOKYO  Kim Jong-il, North Korea’s supreme leader, took new steps on Tuesday to ensure that his family remains in charge after his death, but the biggest leadership shuffling in a generation has so far produced more political intrigue than signs of real change in North Korea, one of the world’s most isolated nations.

headline: His True Colors
text: Imagine one of those glacially chic early-20th-century Modernist interiors. What do you see? White walls and wide windows? Gleaming glass and tubular steel furniture? Constructivist paintings? A natty young woman with fashionably bobbed hair reclining langorously on a leather chaise longue?

headline: Saab Talks With BMW About Forming Alliance
text: Saab Automobile, the Swedish brand that was rescued from near death early this year by a Dutch manufacturer of high-end sports cars, may soon be getting some German help as well, Jack Ewing writes in The New York Times.

headline: With Tablet, R.I.M. Returns to Corporate User Base
text: Research In Motion, the Canadian maker of the BlackBerry smartphone, introduced its first tablet computer on Monday at a developers’ conference in San Francisco. But in a return to its roots, the company said that the new device, the BlackBerry PlayBook, would be aimed mainly at business users.

text: Today’s word, in association with the invaluable Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Wall Street Ends Lower Amid a Rush of Deals
text: Shares on Wall Street finished lower on Monday, stopping the September rally for at least one day.

headline: Corporate Loans in Europe Fell Less Steeply in August
text: Borrowing by European companies showed signs of stabilizing in August, according to data released Monday that the European Central Bank president said signaled “a little more dynamism” in a crucial component of the economy.

headline: Money for Meditation
text: WHO is Richard Davidson, and WHAT does he study?

headline: Stanley Chais, Who Funneled Money to Madoff, Dies
text: Stanley Chais, a Beverly Hills money manager for Hollywood’s elite who was accused of recklessly plowing nearly $1 billion in client funds to Bernard L. Madoff, has died, Reuters reports. He was 84.
