text: From Verne G. Kopytoff at Bits:

headline: Kno, Backed by Andreessen, Offers Tablet
text: From Miguel Helft at Bits:

headline: A $47 Billion Bailout for Anglo-Irish?
text: Standard & Poor’s estimate that Ireland will have to pour 35 billion euros ($47 billion) into Anglo Irish Bank looks increasingly realistic and any amount beyond that could trigger rating downgrades, an S.&P. analyst was quoted on Tuesday as saying, Reuters reported.

headline: New York City by Alfred Stieglitz
text: Alfred Stieglitz does not need the Lens blog to enhance his reputation.

headline: A New Face on the Rise at Goldman Sachs?
text: As far as achievements go, being an Olympic Gold medal winner has to be near the top, and being regional head for Goldman Sachs’s Asian operations is nothing to sneeze at, either.

headline: What Superpower Do You Wish You Had?
text: In a new television show, members of a family find that they have miraculously developed superhuman abilities — and that the shared experience brings them closer together. What superpower would you like to have?

headline: Owner of Segway Company Dies in a Segway Accident
text: James W. Heselden, a British businessman who invented and sold fortification containers for flood control and military protection and who owned the company that makes Segway electric scooters, died Sunday after plunging from a cliff in West Yorkshire, the police said, apparently while touring his property on a Segway. He was 62.

headline: A Cliff-Hanger End for Barnes & Noble Fight?
text: As proxy fights go, the one between Barnes & Noble and Ron Burkle, the billionaire investor, has been a page turner, and it could come with a cliff-hanger ending Tuesday, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Carlyle Ponies Up for Student Housing
text: The Carlyle Group is stepping up its drive into Europe’s fast-growing student housing sector after forming its first British development joint venture, with a special focus on London’s under-supplied market, Reuters reports.

headline: Aberdeen Assets Rise on Inflows in Equities
text: Aberdeen Asset Management said inflows accelerated over the summer, with clients favouring equity funds despite volatile markets.

headline: Man Group Battles Outflows
text: The Man Group said clients pulled out assets for an eighth straight quarter, confounding hopes that a recovery in its flagship fund would help it follow the wider hedge fund industry and attract investors once again, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Michelin to Offer $1.6 Billion in New Shares
text: Michelin said Tuesday that it would issue 1.2 billion euros ($1.6 billion) worth of new shares to finance growth in emerging economies and strengthen its credit rating, an announcement that caused its share price to fall more than 8 percent.

headline: In Hong Kong, Thai Art Gets Political
text: As protesters in Bangkok hit the streetsagain recently, a new exhibition at Hong Kong’s Para/Site gallery makes an ambitious attempt to share the impact of Thailand’s current political crisis through its contemporary art.

headline: Right-Turn Signal: Privatizing Our Way Out of Traffic
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

headline: Blanda Made Middle Age Cool
text: Andy Barall  writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down. George Blanda died on Monday at age 83.

headline: MGM China to Seek I.P.O.
text: MGM Resorts International is planning an initial public offering of its joint venture in China on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, The Associated Press reported.

headline: JPMorgan May Pursue F.D.I.C. Funds for WaMu Claims
text: JPMorgan Chase has told federal regulators it may seek to recoup the money it used to buy the banking assets of Washington Mutual Inc, The Wall Street Journal reported on Monday, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline: Ningbo Port Shares Sink in Shanghai Debut
text: Ningbo Port, China’s third-largest port operator, fell as much as 2.7 percent in its Shanghai debut on fears of limited growth potential, after it raised $1.1 billion in China’s sixth-biggest initial public offering this year.

headline: China Wireless Firm Sells $1.84 Billion in Convertibles
text: A unit of China Unicom Hong Kong, the nation’s second-largest wireless operator, sold $1.84 billion worth of convertible bonds maturing in 2015 as the company invests to expand its third-generation network, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: U.S. Approves Coca-Cola’s Buy of Big Bottler
text: Coca-Cola won approval from the United States and Canada to buy the North American operations of its largest bottler on the condition that it safeguards rival Dr Pepper Snapple Group‘s confidential business information, Reuters said.

headline: Cerberus Said to Eye $500 Million Lockheed Unit
text: Cerberus Capital Management is among the suitors for a Lockheed Martin division that provides military training services and is being marketed for around $500 million, Reuters reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Doubting Online Activism
text: Today’s idea: Online activism is typically weak activism because the participants don’t have strong ties to one another and aren’t highly motivated, an article argues.

headline: Potash Corp.’s Suit Against BHP Allowed to Proceed
text: A U.S. federal judge said on Monday he would allow the discovery process to proceed in a lawsuit filed by Potash Corp. to fend off BHP Billiton‘s $39 billion hostile takeover bid.

headline: NBC Launches $5.1 Billion Debt Sale
text: NBC Universal on Monday launched a $5.1 billion, four-part debt sale, said IFR, a Thomson Reuters service.

headline: Japan’s Takefuji Said to File for Bankruptcy
text: Takefuji Corp. filed for bankruptcy protection, becoming Japan’s biggest casualty of a four-year crackdown on coercive lending to consumers, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Obama Signs Small Business Bill Into Law
text: President Barack Obama signed a $30 billion small business lending bill into law on Monday, claiming a victory on economic policy for his fellow Democrats ahead of November congressional elections, Reuters reported.

headline: Judge Refuses to Dismiss A.I.G. Lawsuit
text: A judge refused to dismiss a securities fraud lawsuit accusing American International Group of misleading investors about its exposure to subprime mortgages, which led to a liquidity crisis and $182.3 billion of federal bailouts.

headline: Feel the Noise: Bears Are Still Unbeaten
text: In honor of our colleague Stu Hackel, who is blogging away on Slapshot now that hockey season is near, we’ve added two songs to accompany a few links on the Bears’ victory against the Packers on Monday night:

headline: Before ‘Scott Pilgrim,’ a Girl Adrift
text: Bryan Lee O’Malley is best known for his comics series “Scott Pilgrim,” which Charles Yu described in the Book Review this past weekend as “an appealing, lighthearted account of a transitional period of life” whose protagonist “seems stuck in that ever expanding territory between the formerly contiguous states of adolescence and adulthood.”

headline: Before ‘Scott Pilgrim,’ a Girl Adrift
text: Bryan Lee O’Malley is best known for his comics series “Scott Pilgrim,” which Charles Yu described in the Book Review this past weekend as “an appealing, lighthearted account of a transitional period of life” whose protagonist “seems stuck in that ever expanding territory between the formerly contiguous states of adolescence and adulthood.”

headline: Analyzing the Small-Business Tax Hysteria
text: Last week, Senate Democrats decided, at least for the moment, not to pursue the Obama administration’s plan to let the Bush tax cuts expire for those in the top tax brackets. Most Democrats supported the plan. Most, if not all, Republicans opposed it, arguing primarily that increasing taxes on the wealthiest Americans would be devastating to small businesses.

headline: Bank Regulators Delay ‘Too Big to Fail’ Reform
text: Banking regulators on Monday put off proposing how the government would use its new authority to dismantle large, collapsing financial companies, saying they need more time for industry and other regulators to weigh in, Reuters said.

headline: Avenue Capital in Talks With Goldman’s Prop Traders?
text: Avenue Capital Group, the hedge fund run by Marc Lasry, is in talks to hire members of Goldman Sach’s proprietary-trading business in the United States, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people briefed on the discussions.

headline: Endo to Buy Apax’s Qualitest for $1.2 Billion
text: Endo Pharmaceuticals said Tuesday that it would buy Qualitest, a rival American generic drug maker, for $1.2 billion in cash from Apax Partners, adding to its offer of treatments for pain and in the field of urology.

headline: Are the 3-0 Chiefs for Real?
text: Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com.

headline: Air Force A-10 Monster Truck: Fires T-Shirts, Not Bombs
text: In matters of early 20th century diplomacy, Theodore Roosevelt recommended a speak-softly, big-stick doctrine. In matters of early 21st century United States Air Force recruitment, that logic appears as salient as ever.

headline: China Softens Tone in Japan Dispute
text: BEIJING  After weeks of escalating diplomatic tension over Japan’s detention of a Chinese fishing captain, China on Tuesday called on Tokyo to cooperate in resolving the messy dispute involving territorial sovereignty, compensation for damaged boats and such intangibles as wounded national pride.

headline: Q&A: When Ping Is Not Your Thing
text: Q.

headline: Never Mind Oil, Group Says: Think Atlantic Wind
text: The Atlantic coast has more energy to give via wind than it does from oil or gas, according to a study sponsored by Oceana, an environmental group.

headline: Norway Says Three Planned Attack Over Cartoons
text: PARIS  The Norwegian police said Tuesday that three suspected militants arrested in July had been planning an attack on a Danish newspaper whose publication of cartoons lampooning the Prophet Muhammad in 2005 ignited fury in much of the Muslim world the following year.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: —Remembering the Flash Crash in graphs and CNBC footage.

headline: AOL in Talks to Buy TechCrunch, Reports Say
text: AOL has held talks with TechCrunch about buying the Silicon Valley blog, the GigaOm blog and The Wall Street Journal reported. What terms were being discussed were not known.

headline: Headlines We Love Too Much
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Headlines We Love Too Much
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Bill Patterson, Investor and Philanthropist, Dies
text: William J. Patterson, a prominent San Francisco investor and philanthropist who led the effort to revitalize the California Academy of Sciences, died on Friday. He was 48 and had suffered from a brain tumor.

headline: ‘Jewish Boat to Gaza’ Intercepted by Israel
text: Updated | 9:06 a.m. The Israeli navy intercepted a catamaran carrying humanitarian aid and nine Jewish activists off the coast of Gaza on Tuesday morning, according to the Israel Defense Forces and the mission’s organizers.

headline: Health Industry and Fed Action Help Wall Street Rebound Quickly
text: Markets in the United States on Tuesday erased most of their losses from Monday, as Walgreen led a rally in consumer staples and health companies. Investors also speculated that the Federal Reserve would buy more debt to safeguard the economy.

headline: A Young Star at Risk of Burning Out
text: LONDON

headline: Israel Stops Jewish Activists From Entering Gaza
text: TEL AVIV — Israeli Navy commandos on Tuesday peacefully commandeered a catamaran sailed by an international group of Jewish activists trying to break Israel’s blockade on Gaza.

headline: The Insider | Gillian Frisk Schwartz
text: Gillian Frisk Schwartz, an art director, graphic designer, storyteller and the founder of Schwartz & Sons, is known for her unorthodox approach to branding. Before starting her firm, she was an independent consultant for clients like Steven Alan and Vena Cava. The Schwartz & Sons team just wrapped up a quirky graphic identity for the Jane Hotel and recently celebrated their official launch at the Lafayette House.

headline: Looking Back Is a Bad Habit: ‘True Grit’ Then and Now
text: It’s far too soon to review “True Grit,” the coming adaptation of the Charles Portis novel and remake of Henry Hathaway’s 1969 feature, directed by Joel and Ethan Coen (“No Country for Old Men”) and starring Jeff Bridges (“The Big Lebowski,” “Crazy Heart”) as Rooster Cogburn: So far, all that’s been released of the new film is the teaser trailer above, and besides, as anyone within earshot will happily remind us, we’re not movie critics.

headline: As BHP Waits, the Next Steps for Potash

headline: Ford Says Fiesta Buyers Are Choosing Hatchbacks
text: The hatchback is back, at least according to Ford. The automaker announced on Tuesday that 60 percent of early 2011 Fiesta sales had been four-door hatchbacks. That compares with a 2009 national hatchback market penetration of just 8.3 percent, as measured by Ward’s Auto.

headline: It Takes a Neighborhood
text: Five years ago the media was full of articles about the death of New Orleans. Hurricane Katrina, the pundits declared, had proved that the city was unnatural and unsustainable. The mass exodus after the flooding would leave it hobbled at a fraction of its former size, and some even advocated government policies to keep it that way.

headline: Playing the Alliterative Ponies With a Funny Fellow

headline: Milan Fashion Week Wrap-Up
text: When the fashion horde flooded into Milan’s Linate Airport Monday night to catch flights bound for Paris, they were not an unhappy bunch. For the first time in recent memory, Milan — the fashions, the city, the weather when not storming — had looked and felt pretty cool.

headline: Buffalo and Hamilton Renew Their Love-Hate Thing
text: ¶ The Buffalo Sabres and the Ottawa Senators face off Tuesday night in the first real on-ice event of the N.H.L. season, the Kraft Hockeyville game, played this year at Dundas, Ontario, the picturesque little valley town adjacent to Hamilton. For the Sabres it’s the first of several keynote events in this, their 40th anniversary season. On Nov. 6 they will go to Toronto to play the Leafs, their neighbors and historic rivals, in the Hall of Fame game, and from Dec. 26 to Jan. 5 their downtown rink will play host to the world junior tournament. Back to the Hamilton area, where there are a fair number of Sabres season-ticket holders. Still, it’s slightly odd that the Sabres’ annus mirabilis should start near Hamilton, as their presence just 50 miles down the Queen E. Way is one of two reasons Hamilton cannot get an N.H.L. team (the other reason, of course, is the presence of the Leafs less than 50 miles the other way).

headline: Moscow’s Ousted Mayor Leaves a Mixed Legacy
text: MOSCOW — This capital city was on the brink of collapse when Yuri M. Luzhkov became mayor in 1992, with food shortages, trash-strewn streets and rampant crime. Cigarettes, one of the few luxuries available to the masses in the Soviet era, were in such short supply that Muscovites blockaded the city’s main thoroughfares in protest.

headline: Plan B: Connecticut and W. Virginia Create New Outline for G.O.P. Senate Takeover
text: When Christine O’Donnell won Delaware’s Republican Senate  primary two weeks ago, some headlines screamed that it was a nightmare for the G.O.P. Indeed,  unless polling is unusually inaccurate in Delaware, Ms. O’Donnell is unlikely to win in November, and her nomination significantly reduced the likelihood of a Republican takeover of the Senate. Two other races that once looked like tossups — in California and Washington — have also broken in the Democrats’ direction.

headline: Amid Deluge, Mudslide Strikes Mexican Town

headline: A Key Democrat Keeps Her Silence on the Small-Business Jobs Bill
text: At the East Room of the White House Monday, a handful of handpicked small-business owners, administration officials and members of Congress watched as President Obama signed the small-business jobs bill. But there was one member of Congress who was conspicuous for her absence. Representative Nydia Velázquez, Democrat from New York, heads the House Small Business Committee, so normally one would expect to find her at a small-business bill signing, where she might take a bow and collect a souvenir pen. Ms. Velázquez, though, was one of 13 Democrats to vote against the bill.

headline: Structural Problems, Not Structural Unemployment
text: Maxine Udall responds to my writing about structural unemployment and the absence thereof by arguing that the US economy probably does have some major structural problems. She’s right, of course — but there’s no contradiction between arguing that structural unemployment has very little to do with the sharp rise over the past three years, and arguing that the economy was badly distorted even in 2007. To be fair, Udall seems to get that; but others might not.

headline: The Return of the Bears

(This is only partly because of the brain-scrambling analysis of Jon Gruden, who is living proof that ESPN hates us and who does things like spend an entire Packers touchdown drive lauding the Bears defense.) The Packers did everything better, apparently leading the officials to believe they were cheating, and they were penalized for everything including, we believe, being from Wisconsin.

headline: Fete Accompli | T Party in Milan
text: Wondering what the chicest party during Milan Fashion Week was? The dinner to celebrate the appointment of Sally Singer as editor in chief of T, naturalmente. Held at the Palazzo Marino across from La Scala, and hosted by Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The New York Times; Janet Robinson, chief executive officer of The New York Times Company; and Letizia Moratti, mayor of Milan, the bash attracted local luminaries like the artist Francesco Vezzoli and Diego Della Valle of Tod’s, and enough designers to line Via Montenapoleone. Marni’s Consuelo Castiglioni came for drinks but left early because her show was on the next morning. Among the sleep-deprived designers who stayed for dinner of risotto and fish were Miuccia Prada, Raf Simons, Tomas Meier, Roberto Cavalli, Peter Dundas, Ennio Capasa and Remo Ruffini of Moncler.

headline: Packers Erred by Not Allowing Late Touchdown to Bears
text: Green Bay Coach Mike McCarthy missed an opportunity Monday night. With the score tied at 17-17 and with 1 minute 44 seconds on the clock, the Bears had a first-and-goal from the 9. The Packers had one timeout, so Chicago had the option of nearly running out the clock and kicking a field goal. Field goals from that range are successful about 94 percent of the time, and with the good conditions, probably even higher.

headline: White House to Supporters: Buck Up
text: Update: President Obama has again added his voice to those critical of dispirited Democrats, telling reporters for Rolling Stone magazine that it is “just irresponsible” and “inexcusable” for his supporters to sit on their hands this election.

headline: More to the Story: A History of Gay America
text: In 1980, convinced that Ronald Reagan’s references to “the American people” were not intended to include gay citizens like him, Larry Kramer began writing a book called “The American People,” envisioned as a national history of homosexuality. The author of such plays as “The Normal Heart” and “The Destiny of Me,” Mr. Kramer focused at first on the 20th century but concluded that he had plenty to say about 19th century, the 18th century, and, ultimately, precolonial gay life. It became a magnum opus, with Mr. Kramer writing on and off for 30 years while he was a co-founder of the Gay Men’s Health Crisis and the protest group ACT UP and nearly dying from end-stage liver disease until receiving a transplant in 2001.

headline: Now on TiVo: Hulu Plus

Hulu Plus is the service that streams video on demand to PCs and devices like the iPhone and iPad. It costs $9.99 a month. TiVo Premiere can be purchased in different bundles, but its monthly rate is $12.95.

headline: Eurofile | Pret-à-Bouffer in Paris
text: Indian summer in Paris, and with vacation bragging rights fading as quickly as summer tans — major points this year go to anyone who stayed at the new Hotel Sezz in Saint Tropez, Philippe Starck’s revamp of La Corniche in Pyla-sur-Mer or packed their bags for the Greek island of Paros, the Parisian’s Martha’s Vineyard — the talk has turned to the rentrée’s hot new tables. After a summer of salads and cold soups, Parisians are hungry again, which means you get a couple of “textos” every day about the latest de rigueur opening, or all of those places the fashion pack won’t want to miss during the coming shows.

headline: Mini and Smart to Unveil Electric Scooters at Paris Show
text: With little in the way of new four-wheel models to show off, both Smart and Mini have announced that they will unveil electric scooters at the Paris auto show, which opens to the press on Friday. Both are concepts, not production models.

headline: Morgan Hiring Slowdown More Than a Pause
text: Like a lot of investment banks, Morgan Stanley won’t be doing much hiring in the fourth quarter. As the end of the year approaches, jumping to a new job becomes less and less likely in finance because new employers have to buy people of their bonus — that is, compensate for the money they would make if they had waited for the check.

headline: Drones as Occupational Hazard

It’s on Atlantic Avenue in Richmond Hill, Queens, down the street, fittingly, from the Queens Auto Mall — You Are Already Approved! — and a couple of blocks from Phil Rizzuto Park, where the Scooter’s ghost still pitches for the Money Store.

headline: At East Village Food Pantry, the Price Is a Sermon
text: The shopping carts are lined up hours early in Tompkins Square Park, not far from the dog run, where the East Village’s more genteel residents are unleashing retrievers and beagles and chatting animatedly. The poor or elderly waiting on benches to get the free food that comes with a dose of the Gospel seem more lost in their own thoughts, even though many meet every Tuesday.

headline: Predators: A Response

headline: The Morning Skate: Hockeyville Game Brings N.H.L. Back to its Roots
text: As Jeff Z. Klein mentioned in his daily News of Hockey post, the N.H.L.’s annual Hockeyville game goes tonight, in which a small Canadian town hosts a big league preseason game and gets rewarded by the sponsor Kraft with $100,000 to improve its tiny barn and hockey programs. The N.H.L. supplies the teams, the N.H.L. Players’ Association donates equipment to the town’s youth hockey program and both contribute to local charities.

headline: Opinion Through the Ages: Exploring 40 Years of New York Times Op-Eds
text: Overview | What role does an Op-Ed page play in a newspaper? How can reading Op-Eds expand our understanding of important issues? In this lesson, students consider the purpose and history of Op-Eds by exploring the Times feature celebrating the 40th anniversary of the Op-Ed page. They then do one of several multidisciplinary activities designed to make Op-Eds relevant to their experience, perspective and learning.

headline: Amazon Introduces Kindle for the Web
text: Amazon is continuing its cover-all-the-bases approach to digital books online with the test launch of a new product called Kindle for the Web. It lets digital book buyers read books on the Web and also offers the ability to embed book samples on blogs or other Web sites, similar to the function offered with video clips on YouTube.

headline: ‘Barbra Streisand’ Video Goes Viral

Here’s the best new candidate: “Barbra Streisand” by the D.J. duo Duck Sauce. Appropriately for the YouTube age it is a roll call of musicians famous enough to shock a nation and underground enough for you to show off to all your friends, if you can recognize them. See how many artists you can identify, and, as a bonus, count the number of M. C. Hammer moves too.

headline: Warnings About Discounted Pet Drugs
text: The United States Food and Drug Administration has issued a consumer alert to pet owners, warning them about the dangers of buying discounted pet drugs online.

headline: It’s a Down Goes Brown Preview: the Eastern Conference
text: The start of the 2010-11 season is almost here, and that means it’s time to take one last look around the league. All 30 NHL teams have their strengths and weaknesses, as well as specific players or situations to watch carefully. And while nobody can say exactly what the new year will bring, a bit of in-depth analysis can be revealing.

text: At SUNY Maritime College in the Bronx, Coach Clayton Kendrick-Holmes has tried to build a football program around the military ideals of accountability, responsibility and character.

headline: New Life and Uses for a Movie Palace in Brooklyn
text: After decades of neglect, a long-dormant movie palace in Brooklyn  is being transformed into a charter school and space for national and local retailers.

headline: By the Numbers: Apple, Microsoft, Dell, H.P.
text: Back in May, Apple edged past Microsoft as the most valuable technology company. And, my oh my, has Apple stretched its lead since then.

headline: Obama Says Fox News Promotes ‘Destructive’ Viewpoint
text: In his sharpest critique yet of the nation’s highest-rated cable news channel, President Obama said in an interview with Rolling Stone magazine that Fox News promoted a point of view that was “destructive” to the growth of the United States.

headline: A Modern Italian Master
text: GREAT restaurants may start out that way. But an extraordinary restaurant generally develops only over time, the product of prolonged artistic risk and managerial attention. An extraordinary restaurant uses the threat of failure first as a spur to improvement, then as a vision of unimaginable calamity. An extraordinary restaurant can transcend the identity of its owners or chef or concept.

headline: U.S.O.C. to Take Steps to Protect Against Sexual Abuse
text: The United States Olympic Committee agreed to take a central role in helping the governing bodies of Olympic sports tackle the issue of sexual and physical abuse of young athletes by coaches, and has said it will implement the recommendations of a task force it convened to formulate its approach.

headline: Generals in Pakistan Push for Shake-Up of Government
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani military, angered by the inept handling of the country’s devastating floods and alarmed by a collapse of the economy, is pushing for a shake-up of the elected government, and in the longer term, even the removal of President Asif Ali Zardari and his top lieutenants.

headline: Israeli Foreign Minister Distances Himself From Talks
text: UNITED NATIONS  Sharp differences within the Israeli government over peace negotiations played out in the unusual setting of the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday, with Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman using the podium to say that peace with the Palestinians required an intermediate agreement lasting “decades” and that the issue of Iranian belligerence should be addressed first.

headline: Latest Design Is Unveiled for Atlantic Yards Plaza

headline: No Death Sentence for Tycoon in Egypt

headline: Going Up | Guerrilla Architecture in Israel
text: Bat Yam, just south of Tel Aviv, is Israel’s most densely populated city. Few would call it beautiful. But it is precisely the absence of architectural splendor in this seaside burg, population 160,000, that makes it an ideal incubator for the 72 Hour Urban Action, a guerrilla architecture and design festival that wraps up today.

headline: Karzai Names Peace Panel for Taliban Negotiations
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Repeating his determination to find a peaceful solution to the war, President Hamid Karzai named a 70-member peace council on Tuesday, a long-awaited announcement that was the government’s first concrete step to open formal contacts with the Taliban.

headline: New-Music Benefit Becomes the Art Itself
text: If you need to raise money, as arts organizations perpetually do, you might as well make the exercise fun for your supporters, who are constantly being hit up for donations these days. The directors of MATA, the new-music festival that has become a year-round concert series, has come up with a lively approach. Its benefit concert at the Chelsea Art Museum on Monday evening included short sets by composers and players who exemplify the border-free approach to new music that MATA has long espoused.

headline: House Republicans Urge Action on Ethics Trials
text: Representative Zoe Lofgren, the California Democrat and chairwoman of the House ethics committee, is “stalling” the start of trials for two fellow Democrats, five Republican members of the committee charged in an unusual statement released on Tuesday.

headline: Woods Addresses the News Media in Wet Wales
text: NEWPORT, Wales — It was gray, cold and wet late on Tuesday afternoon when Tiger Woods’s image popped up on the giant screen that towers above the 18th green at Celtic Manor like a jeans ad above Times Square. The panorama below was lighted by the picture on the screen and by a bright orange line in the sky that was flattened like a layer in a rain cloud cake.

headline: Stuyvesant Town Foreclosure Sale Is Approved
text: The senior lenders at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the sprawling apartment complex overlooking the East River, can proceed with a foreclosure sale on Monday, the appellate division of the State Supreme Court said Tuesday.

headline: Scorecard | Giorgio Armani Wins!
text: Bonus question: Was it for the study in contrasts between the monochromatic and the not so that the fashion calendar placed the two perma-tanned patresfamilias of Italian fashion head to head on the sixth and final day of shows? Though Roberto Cavalli’s catwalkers looked like they could take to the streets, Scorecard thinks critics were more feeling Giorgio Armani’s Blue Period. Comments are for limericks — discuss.

headline: Chief Justice Sells Pfizer Stock

headline: The Gods Are Stranded as Set Misfires
text: It is a moment of glorious climax, and one of the most memorable in Wagner’s “Ring” cycle. Borne along by surging brass chords and shimmering strings, the gods cross a bridge into Valhalla and bring “Das Rheingold” to a close.

headline: Worldwide Viewpoints With an Animated Edge
text: “Nine Nation Animation” is the third installment in the  series The World According to Shorts, anthologies of award-winning short films made outside the United States. It’s the first to consist entirely of animation, and it’s a winner, with only one or two duds among the nine movies.

headline: Filly Rachel Alexandra Is Retired
text: Rachel Alexandra, the reigning Horse of the Year, was retired Tuesday after a disappointing 2010 campaign. She will be bred next year to another former Horse of the Year, Curlin.

headline: So, Picture Briscoe With a Tan
text: “Law & Order: Los Angeles” doesn’t begin with the original introduction: “In the criminal justice system, the people are represented by two separate yet equally important groups. ...”

headline: Long Jail Term for Iran’s ‘Blogfather’
text: Updated | 6:29 p.m. An Iranian news Web site reported on Tuesday that Hossein Derakhshan, an influential Iranian-Canadian blogger who was arrested two years ago when he returned from self-imposed exile to live in Iran, was sentenced to nearly two decades in prison by a court in Tehran.

headline: Strahan Says Giants Need a Field Leader
text: The former Giants defensive end Michael Strahan was the vocal leader of the locker room in his years in New York, but now he sees a team that has been missing a similar presence.

headline: Chrysler Fires Employees in Drinking Video
text: DETROIT — Chrysler has fired 13 employees of its Jefferson North assembly plant here, after reviewing broadcast video showing some of them drinking beer and smoking what appeared to be marijuana during their lunch break. Two additional workers are suspended for a month without pay.

headline: Google Predicts More Social, and Profitable, Display Ads

At the Interactive Advertising Bureau’s Mixx conference in New York on Tuesday, Google made seven predictions for display advertising that the company thinks will happen by 2015.

headline: D. E. Shaw Layoffs Show Wall Street’s Pain Spreading
text: The big hedge fund D.E. Shaw & Company laid off 150 employees on Tuesday, or about 10 percent of its work force, Institutional Investor reports, citing unidentified people familiar with the situation.

headline: Plan de Paris | What to See, Off the Runways
text: The high-heeled set is about to land in Paris for the spring 2011 ready-to-wear shows, and the local art scene, not to be eclipsed, is stepping up its game accordingly.

headline: UBS Names Co-Chief for Asian Operations
text: Alex Wilmot-Sitwell, the co-head of UBS’s investment bank, has been named co-chairman and co-chief executive of the bank’s operations in Asia. Mr. Wilmot-Sitwell will relocate from London to Hong Kong in November and will lead the region together with Chi-Won Yoon, the bank’s current chief executive in Asia.

headline: A Poll of Ohio Voters

headline: Alabama Puts Up a Wall Against the Run

headline: After Recalls of Drugs, a Congressional Spotlight on J.& J.’s Chief
text: In recent weeks, the chief executive of Johnson & Johnson has gone on the offensive in a very public way, trying to assure customers and company employees that the recalls of popular over-the-counter drugs like children’s liquid Tylenol did not reflect systemic problems across the corporation.

headline: Rare Scenes Re-Emerge From Nuremberg Trials
text: The Nuremberg war crimes trials began in November 1945, six months after Germany’s defeat, on a continent still strewn with rubble and awash in displaced persons. The American military had commissioned Stuart Schulberg (brother of Budd) to make a documentary of the proceedings, believing that a visual record of Nazi crimes and of the legal process that would bring the perpetrators to justice was a crucial element to the reassertion of law and decency where barbarism had recently governed. The truth of what had been done by the defeated German regime and the fairness with which it was being addressed by the victorious powers needed to be shared with the world.

headline: Media Decoder: Google Predicts More Social Display Ads
text: Google might be late to the display advertising game, but it wants Madison Avenue to know that it will be ahead of the game in the future. In Media Decoder, Tanzina Vega and Claire Cain Miller write about seven things the company thinks will happen with display advertising by 2015.

headline: Networks Sort Good, Bad and Ugly Ratings
text: Despite all the waving red flags about initial ratings’ not meaning what they used to — because of increasing time-shifting of shows by more and more viewers — the television business is making many of the usual snap judgments about the early prime-time results.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 23 through Sept. 27 with 1,114 adults throughout Ohio, including 973 who said they were registered to vote.

headline: The Supersnooper Pursuing the Paranoid Politician
text: Heaping scorn on Jack Anderson (1922-2005), the muckraking syndicated newspaper columnist, became an art form among the politicians of the 1960s and ’70s.

headline: Sally Menke, Film Editor for Tarantino, Dies at 56
text: Sally Menke, an Oscar-nominated film editor known for her long professional association with the director Quentin Tarantino, was found dead in Los Angeles early Tuesday morning. She was 56 and a Los Angeles resident.

headline: Ohio Tests Arguments of Midterms
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Beverly Milum lost her job as a real estate agent and her house fell into foreclosure, and she has seen few signs that Democrats are delivering on their pledge to create jobs. She was ready to vote Republican at the top of her ballot, but now is uncertain.

text: Anyone who has seen a significant number of short plays will know that for every pithy one-act that makes smart, exacting use of the form to provide a concentrated theatrical experience, dozens more are diet drama  insubstantial narrative morsels that leave little aftertaste.

headline: Cal-Berkeley Cuts 5 Athletic Programs
text: The University of California, Berkeley, eliminated five of its intercollegiate sports programs Tuesday, two of which, baseball and men’s rugby, had become particular points of pride over the years.

headline: A Classic Puff Pastry Dough, Now in Chocolate

Turn it into palmier cookies (above), or fashion layers for feuilletée desserts filled with chocolate mousse or other creams and raspberries. It bakes up beautifully, especially with a dusting of sugar on top.

headline: Dressage Riders Embrace Helmets, to a Point
text: LEXINGTON, Ky.  The Olympic dressage rider Courtney King Dye has no memory of the day last March when she jumped on a horse she was training, to demonstrate its progress to its owner. With inexperienced horses, she liked to wear a helmet as a safety precaution, but it was the busy winter show season in Palm Beach, Fla., and she was in a hurry.

headline: With Vegetables Aplenty, Put Some Soup on the Stove

headline: Out of the O.R., Back Onto the Stage

headline: Tax Debate Also Involves Dividends, Capital Gains
text: The debate over what to do about the expiring Bush-era tax cuts has focused mainly on income tax rates and the fight between Democrats and Republicans over maintaining the tax breaks for the wealthiest Americans.

headline: New York Film Festival Revives Its Offerings
text: The quickest way to measure the breadth of this year’s revitalized New York Film Festival is to compare its two “social” movies. David Fincher’s sensational, hyperkinetic “Social Network,” which opened the festival, feels like a once-in-a-generation movie that could affect Hollywood, much as the Facebook phenomenon whose creation it chronicles has rocked modern communications. “Film Socialisme” is the latest cryptic essay on language, semiotics and film technology by Jean-Luc Godard, the French New Wave prophet who turns 80 in December. Avaricious young hotshots and a grumpy old master: that the festival accords them equal respect is a sign of its renewed vigor.

headline: Awkwardness as the Avenue to Success
text: JOSEPH, a high school principal, is on the phone trying to cancel his wife’s yoga magazine subscription, his measured calm giving way to mounting irritation and then to anguished rage as he lays out the reasons she no longer wishes to receive the publication. What he doesn’t say is that his wife is dead.

headline: BP Sells First Debt Since Gulf Oil Spill
text: BP successfully returned to the bond market on Tuesday, five months after its disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico left investors worrying whether the giant energy company could survive the tens of billions of dollars in cleanup costs and liabilities.

headline: Wisconsin Senate Candidate: Lots of Lawyers in Senate
text: Cue the lawyer jokes.

headline: Twitter Introduces New Types of Ads
text: Twitter, the company that early on never wanted to talk about money, now has a money-making strategy that it says is working well.

headline: Hevesi Is Expected to Plead Guilty in Pension Case
text: ALBANY — Alan G. Hevesi, the former state comptroller, is poised to plead guilty to a felony corruption charge after a lengthy investigation into his office’s rewarding of pension investment business to firms that provided financial benefits to Mr. Hevesi and his aides, people with knowledge of the case said on Tuesday.

headline: Obama Says Fox News Promotes ‘Destructive’ Viewpoint
text: Updated, 11:01 a.m. Wednesday | On the Media Decoder blog, President Obama has strong words about Fox News in an interview with Rolling Stone magazine. After the cable network said, at first, that it would not respond to the president’s comments, some of Fox’s well-known hosts did respond, as reported here on The Caucus.

headline: Many Shows Drop in Second Week
text: Not even an open letter from the creator of “Lone Star,” Kyle Killen, volunteering to “mow your lawn or offer you some sort of sensual massage” was enough to reverse the fortunes of that sinking series on Tuesday night. In its second episode that Fox drama about a Texas con man drew just 3.8 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Its debut last week attracted 4.1 million, prompting Mr. Killen to write his headline-grabbing blog post. Most new shows were down slightly from their premieres, including CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” (12.3 million) and “Mike & Molly” (11.2 million), and NBC’s “The Event” (9 million) and “Chase” (6.4 million viewers), as well as returning series like Fox’s “House” (10.1 million) and CBS’s “Two and a Half Men” (13.9 million). The evening’s brightest spot continued to be “Dancing With the Stars,” which drew 21.6 million viewers.

headline: Heard Any Good Books Lately, Zelda?
text: A MAN sits down at a gray metal desk one morning and tries to boot up a computer from the Flintstone age, one with a screen that looks like an old cathode-ray TV set. Nothing happens, so he pulls out a paperback and begins to read aloud. The book is “The Great Gatsby,” but this guy apparently skipped 10th-grade English when it was assigned. He reads slowly, haltingly, stumbling over pronunciations, getting the emphasis all wrong. The last time we heard “Gatsby” read this badly was in the old Andy Kaufman sketch.

headline: Would the City Shut Down Your Kitchen?
text: THE night before a health inspector came to my apartment, I had a brief nightmare about a grim-faced woman in a lab coat who crawled across my kitchen floor with a pair of tweezers. So when it came time to greet the actual inspector, Beth Torin, one of the first things I uttered to her had a slightly unaccommodating air about it: “Your presence in my home terrifies me.”

headline: Obama Whips Up Large Campus Crowd
text: Facing the potential for historic losses in midterm elections, President Obama sought tonight to light a fire under his party’s supporters at a rally in front of thousands of college students in Madison, Wis.

headline: New Ads in Kentucky Senate Race
text: The Kentucky Senate race is intensifying, with a new commercial suggesting that Rand Paul, the Tea Party candidate, is “off the wall.”

headline: New Arab Museum to Open in Doha
text: Qatar will open a new museum on Dec. 30 devoted to modern Arab art in its capital, Doha. Called Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art, it will house a collection of more than 6,000 works, spanning the 1840s to the present and representing major artistic trends. Its opening exhibition, “Sajjil: A Century of Modern Art,” will feature work by more than 100 artists. For now, Mathaf (which means “museum” in Arabic) will be located in a former school building, redesigned for the museum by the French architect Jean-François Bodin. Plans for a permanent home will be announced later. The museum is being established by the Qatar Museums Authority, a government department, and the Qatar Foundation , a government-sponsored entity. In 2008, the authority, run by the daughter of Qatar’s emir, opened the Museum of Islamic Art in a building designed by I.M. Pei.

headline: Jail Confession Is Retold in a Triple Murder Trial
text: NEW HAVEN  Prosecutors rested their case on Tuesday in the home invasion and triple murder in Cheshire, Conn., three years ago, after a corrections officer testified about a confusing jailhouse confession by the defendant.

headline: In Multilingual Switzerland, One Tongue Struggles
text: CHUR, Switzerland — The people of this corner of Switzerland are arguing whether language is a matter of the heart or the pocketbook.

headline: Paladino Has Aides With Tainted Pasts
text: As he mounts an outrage-filled campaign for governor of New York, Carl P. Paladino has vowed to forcibly rid Albany of the wayward officials and misbehaving bureaucrats who he says have demeaned state government, promising to “take out the trash.”

headline: France: Eiffel Tower Evacuated After Another Bomb Scare
text: The Eiffel Tower was evacuated and closed for two hours on Tuesday after an anonymous call that a bomb was about to go off, the second such evacuation in a month at the world’s most visited monument. Despite the call, which the police said came from a nearby phone booth, no suspicious object was found. The tower and surrounding area were evacuated two weeks ago after a bomb threat. Similar threats have recently disrupted public transportation in Paris, including at the central St.-Lazare train station on Monday, several weeks after French officials warned of a significant risk of a terrorist attack on French soil.

headline: At Council Hearing on Stop-and-Frisk Policy, the Police Stay Silent
text: A City Council hearing on the New York Police Department’s use of its controversial “stop, question and frisk” policy in public housing became a one-sided affair on Tuesday, after police and housing officials declined to testify.

headline: Financial Advice Made for the Internet Age
text: A campaign from a big brokerage firm that borrows formats from reality television is getting under way on Wednesday, but do not look for it on TV.

headline: In Miami Re-enactment, Capone Has New Day in Court
text: MIAMI  Arrest the bum and run him out of town: that was the approach of the Miami police when Alphonse Gabriel Capone moved to South Florida in 1928. But when he sued the city for harassment two years later and was then tried for perjury, the authorities ended up looking like chumps.

headline: Census Shows How Recession Hit N.Y.
text: The nation’s economic collapse jolted many New Yorkers into financial distress, driving some into poverty and dependence on food stamps and unemployment benefits and even altering their living arrangements between 2007 and 2009, according to census data released Tuesday that offered the first extensive measure of how the city weathered the recession.

headline: After Proxy Fight, Barnes & Noble Faces New Challenges
text: The chain operates in an industry on the edge of an abyss; it needs quickly to find a buyer or a way to turn things around.

headline: Rivals Reach Consensus on New Earmark Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Corporate lobbyists and government watchdog groups are rarely on the same side of any money-and-ethics issue in this town, generally being more accustomed to sending out dueling press releases than joint proclamations.

headline: A One-to-Two-State Solution
text: This week’s bad news from the West Bank — the resumption of settlement construction after a 10-month moratorium, just as a new round of peace talks had gotten underway — didn’t much dampen optimism among seasoned Middle East watchers.

headline: Cathy Horyn's Milan Fashion Week Report
text: Highlights of the brightest collections from Milan including, Fendi, Giorgio Armani, Prada, Jil Sander, Max Mara, Missoni and other standouts.

headline: Niese and Rookies Provide Bright Spots for the Mets

text: The Obama administration is pressing aggressively for a deal to end its support of the American International Group and hopes to have a completed plan to announce by next week, ahead of the midterm elections.

headline: The Tea Kettle Movement
text: There are actually two Tea Party movements in America today: one you’ve read about that is not that important and one you’ve not read about that could become really important if the right politician understood how to tap into it.

headline: Bill to End Tax Provision on U.S. Jobs Is Blocked
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Tuesday rejected efforts by Democratic leaders to advance a bill to end a tax provision that supporters of the measure said encourages American companies to ship jobs overseas. The bill also would have given a tax break to companies that move jobs back to the United States.

headline: Ex-Union President Issues Denial of Inquiries
text: Andy Stern, the former president of the Service Employees International Union, said on Tuesday that news reports that the F.B.I. and Labor Department were investigating him were “simply false.”

headline: A Job Title That Adds Confusion
text: Who’s in control here? Or should that be comptrol?

headline: Fair Courts in the Cross-Fire
text: Holding elections to fill important state judgeships is one of those ideas that may sound good in theory but works terribly in practice. As spending in state judicial races by special interests has vastly escalated in recent years, so has the threat to public confidence in judicial neutrality that is fundamental to the justice system.

headline: Nothing Is Easy for the Braves
text: ATLANTA — The threadbare Braves, who have lost third baseman Chipper Jones and starting pitcher Kris Medlen to injury, and battled through all manner of slumps, bumps and bruises this season, took another hit Tuesday night. Infielder Martin Prado, who had been the team’s most consistent hitter this season (.307), was ruled out for the rest of the season with a hip pointer and oblique muscle injury.

headline: Lottery Numbers
In Hearings, a Campaign for Legal Aid in Civil Cases
text: She had come to America, lured from her home in Mangalore, India, by the prospect of child care work that would pay prevailing wages and offer weekends off.

headline: Likely Losses of House Seats in Midwest Stir Partisan Feuds
text: CHICAGO  Whatever the outcome of the fall elections, one political loser this year seems certain: the Midwest.

headline: A Mayor in Arizona Is Charged With Bribery
text: PHOENIX  The mayor of the border city of Nogales, Ariz., was arrested by F.B.I. agents at City Hall on Tuesday morning and charged with bribery, theft, fraud and money laundering, the authorities said.

headline: Dockworkers From Camden Close New York Harbor Ports
text: The main cargo ports in New York Harbor were shut down by picketing dockworkers on Tuesday and could be idle again on Wednesday if local longshoremen decide to defy a federal judge.

headline: Gallinari Is a Knick for Now, or Longer

headline: Justice Department Seeks a Broader Fraud Law to Cover Self-Dealing
text: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department asked Congress on Tuesday for a law that would restore powers prosecutors have used against public and private sector officials who intentionally hide conflicts of interest for personal gain.

headline: A Plan for the Gulf
text: Three months ago, President Obama asked Ray Mabus, the Navy secretary, to figure out what comes next in the Gulf of Mexico  to design a strategy that moves beyond the immediate job of cleaning up the oil to the larger task of restoring an ecosystem that was in deep trouble even before the BP spill and is worse off now.

headline: Ancient Italian Town Has Wind at Its Back
text: TOCCO DA CASAURIA, Italy  The towering white wind turbines that rise ramrod straight from gnarled ancient olive groves here speak to something extraordinary happening across Italy.

headline: Lifeline for Refugees
text: Thousands of elderly and disabled refugees who receive cash assistance from the Social Security Administration are in danger of losing that lifeline. Their eligibility for benefits expires on Friday. Congress has granted temporary extensions before. It needs to do so again.

headline: Who Attacked Umar Cheema?
text: Umar Cheema, an investigative reporter for a major Pakistani newspaper, The News, has long tackled difficult and risky topics. His articles have questioned the conduct and performance of the Army and the intelligence services and detailed accusations of corruption against President Asif Ali Zardari.

headline: Wednesday: Candlelit Romance Setting

headline: Arm’s-Length Soul Mates, Swooning but Stoically Chaste
text: The acrobatics of love are performed in high style in “Brief Encounter,” which is surely the most enchanting work of stagecraft ever inspired by a movie. It’s not erotic, Kama Sutra-style contortions that I’m talking about. The physical activities that occur in this exquisite British-born production, which opened on Tuesday night at Studio 54, are both more everyday and exotic than that, routinely described but seldom enacted.

headline: The Withering Heights and Depths of a Dying British Paper

The play, which opened on Tuesday night at the Harold Clurman Theater on Theater Row, depicts the frantic antics at a withering daily newspaper in the British provinces.

Dating from 1950, the legal battle between Hindus and Muslims over a religious site in the city of Ayodhya began as a little-noticed title dispute. With a ruling finally expected on Thursday, the case has become something altogether different: a test of India’s secular soul.

text: SAN FRANCISCO — With polls showing a tight race and a large block of undecided voters still in play, the two major party candidates for California governor met on Tuesday in the first of three debates, with the state’s economy and its deep financial problems dominating the discussion.

headline: Arthur Holch, Emmy-Winning Documentarian, Dies at 86
text: Arthur E. Holch Jr., an Emmy Award-winning television documentarian whose work at midcentury and afterward tackled charged subjects like race relations, Nazism and Communism, died on Thursday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 86 and a longtime Greenwich resident.

headline: California: Death Toll Rises to 8 in Pipeline Explosion
text: A 58-year-old man who was injured during the natural gas pipeline explosion in San Bruno earlier this month died Monday, bringing the blast’s death toll to eight. James Emil Franco lived near the section of pipeline that exploded on Sept. 9, resulting in a fire that injured dozens of people and destroyed nearly 40 homes. Mr. Franco was hospitalized with serious injuries the night of the blast and remained hospitalized until his death. Though the cause of the explosion is still under investigation, safety experts have raised concerns in the blast’s aftermath about the potential risks and problems with regulatory oversight of pipelines nationwide.

headline: Illinois: Stimulus Program, Facing Expiration, Is Extended
text: Facing the loss of 26,000 Illinois jobs when a stimulus program expires later this week, Gov. Pat Quinn of Illinois said Tuesday that he would spend $75 million of the cash-strapped state’s money to keep the program going for two more months. “I don’t want to see 26,000 people lose their jobs,” said Mr. Quinn, a Democrat locked in a tight election campaign. He said he hoped that Congress would eventually extend the subsidized jobs program.

headline: France: Parliament Debates Tougher Immigration Legislation
text: Members of Parliament on Tuesday began debating an immigration bill under which people who have acquired French citizenship within the last 10 years could be stripped of that citizenship if they committed certain violent crimes, especially against public officials. The bill would also subject foreigners, including citizens of European Union countries, to orders to leave the country if they overstay their welcome, abuse the French social welfare system or resort to “aggressive begging.” Human rights groups and opposition politicians say the proposed law singles out Roma, or Gypsies.

headline: Koreas Plan to Hold Talks on Military, South Says
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Just a day after a new leadership structure had taken shape in North Korea, with the youngest son of the nation’s leader being awarded major military and political posts, the South Korean Defense Ministry said that the two Koreas held military talks on Thursday at the border village of Panmunjom.

headline: Canada: ‘Bondage Bungalow’ Madam Wins Prostitution Law Challenge
text: An Ontario court struck down key provisions of Canada’s prostitution laws on Tuesday after finding that they endanger women by forcing them to work on the streets rather than from their homes. While prostitution is legal in Canada, federal criminal law bans almost every activity that makes it possible. The decision, by the Ontario Superior Court of Justice, overturns laws prohibiting “the keeping of a bawdy house, communicating for the purposes of prostitution and living on the avails of the trade.” The constitutional challenge was brought by two prostitutes and a dominatrix who was convicted under the bawdy-house law for running what she called the “Bondage Bungalow.” The ruling will not take effect for at least 30 days to allow Parliament to write new laws. An appeal by the government is likely to extend that period.

headline: Clinton Manges, Volatile Texas Oilman and Rancher, Dies at 87
text: Clinton Manges, who dropped out of grade school to pick cotton before rising to become a Texas legend by amassing a $1 billion fortune through land and oil deals, funneling millions to politicians, declaring bankruptcy and going to prison, died Thursday in a San Antonio nursing home. He was 87.

headline: Phys Ed: Are Bad Knees in Our Genes?
text: Are fragile knees inherited? That intriguing question motivated a new study published earlier this month in The British Journal of Sports Medicine, during which researchers looked at one family’s propensity for shredding anterior cruciate ligaments during sports. The report was part of a much larger, ongoing study of risk factors for A.C.L. injury, led by researchers affiliated with the Cincinnati Children’s Hospital and Ohio State University, which involves thousands of young athletes. For this pocket version of the larger experiment, the scientists singled out a set of fraternal twin girls who already had been videotaped in the laboratory while wearing reflective markers. The angles of their knees during landing and cutting maneuvers had been analyzed, and the knees themselves measured. At the time of the taping, both girls’ knees were healthy. But within a year, each had suffered a catastrophic A.C.L. tear during separate volleyball and basketball games, as had an older sister, who wasn’t part of the original study.

headline: In Study, Children Cite Appeal of Digital Reading
text: Many children want to read books on digital devices and would read for fun more frequently if they could obtain e-books. But even if they had that access, two-thirds of them would not want to give up their traditional print books.

headline: Timeless
text: It is a rare and exhilarating experience for a photographer to capture a moment in history that then becomes imprinted on the national consciousness. The euphoric V-J Day kiss between sailor and nurse in Times Square. An astronaut’s ticker-tape parade. Babe Ruth making a final appearance at Yankee Stadium. These are images that have inspired me and guided me through a 48-year career in photography.

headline: Senate Democrats Press I.R.S. to Review Political Spending by Nonprofits

headline: One-Stop Living
text: In 1953, the architect Benjamin Thompson (1918-2002) opened a store called Design Research on Brattle Street in Cambridge, Mass. Thompson, a former partner of the Modernist master Walter Gropius, wanted a place where people could buy everything they needed for contemporary living. He made Marimekko dresses and Iittala glasses must-haves, eventually opening stores in New York and San Francisco and designing a striking new glass-and-concrete home for the Cambridge store that opened in 1969. ‘‘The architect’s place on this planet,’’ he said, ‘‘is to create that special environment where life can be lived to its fullest.’’ D/R, as it was known, closed in 1978, but many people, including me, never got over it.

headline: Being Glenn Beck
text: Glenn Beck was sprawled out on his office couch a couple of weeks ago, taking — as self-helpers like to say ­— an inventory. “I think what the country is going through right now is, in a way, what I went through with my alcoholism,” he told me. “You can either live or die. You have a choice.” Beck, who is 46, was in the Midtown Manhattan offices of his production company, Mercury Radio Arts, which is named for Mercury Theater, the company created by Orson Welles. He had just finished his three-hour syndicated radio show and was a few hours away from his television show. It was a Wednesday afternoon in the middle of September, and Beck had just returned from a week’s vacation in the Grand Tetons followed by a quick hop to Anchorage, where he and Sarah Palin appeared at an event on Sept. 11.

headline: 18-Game Season Is a Bad Bet by the N.F.L.
text: Bill Polian, the Colts’ team president, said this week that an 18-game regular season was a “fait accompli.”Commissioner Roger Goodell has been pushing for this. Goodell and the owners he serves are smart people. On paper, extending the N.F.L. regular season to 18 games is a rational idea. Replacing meaningless preseason games with meaningful regular-season games translates to more revenue. But if it were as simple as “more games equals more revenue,” we’d see 52 games a year, wouldn’t we?

headline: Filling in the Gaps After the Skilling Decision
text: “Good morning. We’re going consider another in a series of recent cases in which the Supreme Court appears to have undermined Congressional efforts to protect hard-working Americans from powerful interests. In Skilling v. United States the court sided with an Enron executive who had been convicted of fraud and gutted a statute vital to combatting public corruption, corporate fraud and self-dealing. Now we have to explore the kinds of problematic conduct that may go unchecked in the wake of the Skilling decision and consider what Congress should do or could do to fill those gaps and bring strong enforcement against corrupt and fraudulent conduct.”

headline: It’s a Total Gas When Brittany Meets Britney on ‘Glee’
text: Last night’s long-awaited, long-promoted, Britney Spears-themed episode of “Glee” lived up to its billing as a tour de force – if not for Ms. Spears herself (who appeared in cameo) then for her namesake, the blissfully unaware cheerleader and glee-choir member Brittany S. Pierce, played in a perfect, unblinking deadpan by Heather Morris. Traditionally relegated to a background role and one or two solid punchlines an episode, Ms. Morris, a former backup dancer for Beyoncé, got to take center stage in Tuesday’s episode, in which Ms. Spears and a dentist’s nitrous oxide help the other Brittany find her confidence as a performer, ever so slightly. (And then sometimes too much.)

headline: Well Rounded

The Ovale collection plays with multiple variations on a slightly asymmetrical, rectangular silhouette with rounded corners. This sounds simple enough, but the Bouroullecs’ delicate balance between whimsy and refinement will make even the biggest design snob smile. The reasonably priced collection (from $14 for the smallest mocha cup to $275 for the elegant stainless steel ice bucket) will be in stores just in time for the holidays — hint, hint.
