headline: Cup Champion Kozlov Signs With CSKA
text: ¶ Slava Kozlov, who won the Stanley Cup with the Detroit Red Wings in 1997 and ’98, signs with CSKA Moscow of the K.H.L. Kozlov, 38, was not re-signed by Atlanta, where he spent the last seven seasons and compiled 145 of the 356 N.H.L. goals he scored in 1,182 regular-season games dating to 1991-92. Kozlov last played with CSKA, his youth club, during the 1994-95 lockout.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Would Your Kitchen Pass Inspection?
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Quantifying the Impact of Turnovers in the N.F.L.
text: When we talk about the top defenses in the N.F.L., we usually refer to yards conceded.  This measure ignores the potentially game-changing phenomenon that is a turnover.

headline: Galapagos
text: Term used in Japan to describe the country’s increasing global isolation.“‘Galapagos,’ the name of the South American chain of islands where Charles Darwin observed the wondrous creatures which helped formulate his theory of evolution, has taken on new meaning in Japan,” Daisuke Wakabayashi wrote on The WSJ’s Japan Real Time blog:

headline: The Samurai Shopper | Ancestor Worship
text: The Samurai Shopper hails from a celebrated line of ancient nobility who live on an isolated island, wielding swords and dressing in a manner best described as ornate but casual-Friday. They are samurai, and until the overthrow of the shogunate, they were the Man. When Japan entered into trade agreements with America some 150 years ago, their future and ours became inextricably mixed.

headline: Delaware Race Is Bellwether: All Politics Is National
text: WILMINGTON, Del.  One of the great truisms of 20th-century politics, attributed to the legendary House speaker Tip O’Neill, is that all politics is local. If this year tells us anything, though, it’s that O’Neill’s adage may now be as much a part of history as he is.

headline: Beach Avenue, the Bronx, 8:41 A.M.
text: Morning glory and fence: a Bronx still life.

headline: Fill-In | ‘The Social Network’
text: Fill in the blanks in the first several paragraphs of the article “‘A Zillion Friends, and a Few Enemies,” about the movie “The Social Network.” Use your own words and phrases, or click “read more” to choose from a scrambled list of the words or phrases that were removed.

headline: With Barnes & Noble Win, I.S.S. Takes a Ding
text: 10:40 a.m. | Updated The election of Barnes & Noble‘s slate of directors on Tuesday was an unusual defeat for Institutional Shareholder Services, the influential proxy advisory firm.

headline: As a Senate Race Tightens, Wrestling Becomes a Campaign Issue
text: Wrestling will become more than an overworked metaphor in the final rounds of the suddenly too-close-to-call race for Connecticut’s open United States Senate seat. It will be part of Richard Blumenthal’s closing argument in an election that many had thought he would win while barely breaking a sweat.

headline: Jail and Jobs
text: Incarceration reduces former inmates’ earnings by 40 percent when compared to demographically similar counterparts who have not been imprisoned, according to a new report from Pew’s Economic Policy Group and the Pew Center on the States.

headline: Courthouse Gallery Honors Judge’s Passion for Art
text: Judge Raymond J. Dearie remembers when he realized that another federal judge in Brooklyn, Charles P. Sifton, had a serious appreciation of art.

headline: Carter’s Hospital Stay Is Extended
text: Former President Jimmy Carter remained hospitalized in Cleveland on Wednesday and planned to spend Wednesday night in the hospital as well.

headline: After Crisis, Dubai Keeps Building, but Soberly
text: DUBAI — The planned replica of the Las Vegas Strip and a glow-in-the-dark copy of a Giza pyramid are now delayed. But only a few miles away, workers are busy on a series of government-backed projects of a far more practical nature.

headline: The Notes of Northern Rhone Syrahs
text: In my column on Crozes-Hermitages, I offer a moment of adjectival pileup in trying to describe the typical flavors of northern Rhone syrahs. “Olive, thyme, violet and sizzling bacon-scented glory,’’ I wrote, with full awareness that the words I choose to describe the aromas and flavors I sense in the wine are not only a possibly misguided effort to break a complete unit down to myriad components, but perhaps very different from what you experience in the wine.

headline: House Passes Bill to Help With 9/11 Health Care
text: The House approved legislation on Wednesday that would provide billions of dollars for medical treatment to rescue workers and residents of New York City who suffered illnesses from breathing in toxic fumes, dust and smoke from ground zero.

headline: Even After Judge Picks Owner, Dodgers’ Troubles May Persist
text: LOS ANGELES  Lawyers gave their closing arguments Wednesday in the divorce trial of the Dodgers’ owner, Frank McCourt, and his estranged wife, Jamie, leaving the decision of whether the team belongs solely to him or is community property in the hands of a judge.

headline: Cosmo Campaign Puts Viewers in the Photo Shoot
text: COSMOPOLITAN magazine, Hearst Magazines’ popular publication for young women, is harnessing the power of social media for its first global, digital advertising campaign.

headline: Call to Taliban After Bomb Attempt in Times Sq.
text: After Faisal Shahzad planted a car bomb in Times Square, he returned to his home in Connecticut and contacted the Pakistani Taliban via computer, telling one of his handlers what he had done, federal prosecutors in Manhattan said Wednesday.

headline: Pressure Raised as Armstrong Allies Are Called to Testify
text: People inside Lance Armstrong’s inner circle of friends and colleagues are being called to testify in front of a grand jury investigating suspected doping and fraud in professional cycling, raising the intensity of the inquiry into the possibility of Armstrong’s involvement in crimes while he rode for the United States Postal Service team.

headline: Some House Challengers Outdo Incumbents in Fund-Raising
text: Challengers in 11 House races have raised more money than incumbents, according to an analysis by the Center for Responsive Politics. Incumbents generally have a financial edge over their rivals. During the 2010 election cycle, for example, incumbents for all House races have raised an average of $897,100 more than their opponents. Shown below are the 11 races to watch in which challengers have outraised the incumbents by an average of $613,200. All but one of those races are in districts that are competitive, and all but two have Democratic incumbents.

headline: New Planet May Be Able to Nurture Organisms
text: It might be a place that only a lichen or pond scum could love, but astronomers said Wednesday that they had found a very distant planet capable of harboring water on its surface, thus potentially making it a home for plant or animal life.

headline: Surging Twins Miss Morneau, Their Phantom at First
text: MINNEAPOLIS  Nearly three months after sustaining a concussion in a game in Toronto, Justin Morneau often seems like a phantom. Minnesota Twins General Manager Bill Smith says he occasionally sees Morneau, the Twins’ four-time All-Star first baseman, running along the warning track at Target Field, foul pole to foul pole. And just about every day, Manager Ron Gardenhire says, Morneau takes batting practice in the indoor cages.

headline: Jure Robic, Endurance Bicyclist, Dies at 45
text: Jure Robic, a long-distance bicyclist who won the grueling Race Across America five times and whose seemingly endless, sleep-eschewing stamina tested the limits of human endurance, died during a training ride on Friday when he collided with a car on a mountain road in Plavski Rovt, Slovenia, near his home in Jesenice. He was 45.

headline: Shortage of Widely Used Anesthetics Is Delaying Executions in Some States
text: A nationwide shortage of several widely used anesthetics, which has been exasperating doctors and veterinarians for months, has now spread to the country’s death rows.

headline: Gates Fears Wider Gap Between Country and Military
text: DURHAM, N.C.  The United States is at risk of developing a cadre of military leaders who are cut off politically, culturally and geographically from the population they are sworn to protect, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates told an audience at Duke University on Wednesday night.

headline: Manningham Sustained Concussion Against Titans
text: Giants wide receiver Mario Manningham sustained a concussion in a 29-10 loss to the Tennessee Titans but did not alert the medical staff until Sunday night. Manningham did not practice Wednesday, and his status for Sunday night’s game against the Bears is uncertain. He was unavailable for comment on Wednesday.

headline: Reefer Gladness
text: It was early still, and daylight, so when I called up The Dude to get his take on new polls showing California on the verge of becoming the first state to legalize, tax and regulate recreational use of marijuana, I knew he wouldn’t be, um, distracted. Not just yet.

headline: Promised a State Lifeline, Family Farms Are Still Waiting
text: CORTLANDT MANOR, N.Y.

headline: Positive Test for Contador May Cost Him Tour Title
text: Alberto Contador, a three-time winner of the Tour de France, tested positive for a banned substance on the final rest day of the Tour in July, according to a statement sent Wednesday by his spokesman, Jacinto Vidarte.

headline: Many Big Donors to Democrats Cut Support
text: Many wealthy Democratic patrons, who in the past have played major roles financing outside groups to help elect the party’s candidates, are largely sitting out these crucial midterm elections.

headline: Pace University Student Fatally Shot in Robbery Attempt
text: A 21-year-old Pace University student who investigators believe had been selling marijuana from his apartment in a Lower Manhattan high-rise was shot to death early Wednesday by an unknown assailant who came to rob him, officials said.

headline: Muslim Center’s Developer to Use Islamic Loan Plan
text: The developer of the planned Muslim community center and mosque near ground zero hopes to finance the bulk of the $140 million project using instruments developed to allow many Muslim investors to comply with religious prohibitions on interest.

headline: Knee Is No Worse, but Beltran’s Year Ends
text: Carlos Beltran, the Mets’ highly paid and oft-injured center fielder, missed a season’s worth of games last year and this year, and his return from the disabled list in July was less than impressive.

headline: Police Heed Black Clergy and Set Up Panel on Crime
text: Prompted by the concerns of black clergy members in crime-plagued sections of central Brooklyn, the New York Police Department has set up a task force aimed at reducing violent crime there, particularly among black people.

headline: After 2 Days, Dockworkers Agree to End Strike
text: Dockworkers who shut down all of the big cargo ports in New York Harbor on Tuesday agreed to return to work Wednesday evening, just as their employers were preparing to ask a federal judge to make the longshoremen’s union pay $1 million a day in penalties.

headline: Bloomberg Ribbed (Lightly) on ‘Letterman’
text: There were no short-people jokes, but Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg did not escape some playful ribbing about his programs and perennial New York problems when he stopped by the “Late Show With David Letterman” on Wednesday.

headline: Paladino Spars With Cuomo and Reporter
text: In a sharply personal attack, Carl P. Paladino, the Republican nominee for governor, said in an interview published Wednesday night that the private life of his Democratic opponent, Andrew M. Cuomo, deserved more scrutiny from the news media than it had received.

headline: Witness’s Last Turn in Synagogue Bomb Trial
text: The witness looked exhausted. As the jurors filed in for the afternoon session on Wednesday, he stood, but his head bowed over his hunched shoulders, making it seem as if he was trying to disappear into his black suit.

headline: Video Hints at Executions by Pakistanis
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An Internet video showing men in Pakistani military uniforms executing six young men in civilian clothes has heightened concerns about unlawful killings by Pakistani soldiers supported by the United States, American officials said.

headline: Send Us Your Photos: Tailgating Merriment
text: Oct. 6 | Updated

headline: Thursday: Uh-uh!
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Victor Fleming works as a judge in Arkansas. He’s used to hearing various pleas, objections and explanations, and seems to have collected a slew of phrases denying them. He uses five in his grid today, all clued as “Uh-uh.” I like to imagine a gavel crashing down on each one.

headline: Knicks’ Gallinari Revisiting Basketball Roots
text: GRAFFIGNANA, Italy  The road has faded from four lanes to two, from two to one and finally, from pavement to gravel and dust. It winds past chipped brick edifices, weathered barns and cornfields until it ends, finally, at an iron gate. Beyond the gate is a basketball court, the first ever seen in this tiny pastoral village.

headline: In a Computer Worm, a Possible Biblical Clue
text: Deep inside the computer worm that some specialists suspect is aimed at slowing Iran’s race for a nuclear weapon lies what could be a fleeting reference to the Book of Esther, the Old Testament tale in which the Jews pre-empt a Persian plot to destroy them.

headline: Avis Raises Dollar Thrifty Offer
text: On the eve of a vote by shareholders of the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group on a takeover by Hertz Global Holdings, the Avis Budget Group said on Wednesday that it would offer the one thing Dollar Thrifty had said was lacking in its rival bid: a breakup fee.

headline: Elections Chief Attacks Reports of Primary Day Chaos
text: City election officials on Wednesday gave their first public accounting of the problems that occurred during the primary this month and, while acknowledging missteps, they vigorously and sometimes heatedly defended their handling of the transition to electronic machines from lever-operated voting booths.

headline: Vance Deputy Nominated to Be Federal Appellate Judge
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Wednesday nominated Caitlin J. Halligan, a prominent New York lawyer, to be a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. It is considered the nation’s second most powerful court because it hears many lawsuits involving the federal government.

headline: Where Gallinari Calls Home
text: The rising N.B.A. star will display his skills to Italian fans when the Knicks play an exhibition Sunday against Milano at the Mediolanum Forum.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Web Tastes Freedom Inside Syria, and It’s Bitter
text: DAMASCUS, Syria  Earlier this month, a graphic video of teachers beating their young students appeared on Facebook. Although Facebook is officially banned here, the video quickly went viral, with Syrian bloggers stoking public anger until the story was picked up by the pan-Arab media.

headline: Why America Isn’t Eating Its Veggies
text: To the Editor:

headline: California’s Environment
text: To the Editor:

headline: Performing Wagner
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Paladino E-Mails
text: To the Editor:

headline: Postseason Is Secured, but Infield Won’t Rest
text: TORONTO — The swim goggles and beer-sodden carpet in their clubhouse notwithstanding, life went on as normal Wednesday for the Yankees, who expected nothing different. The day after clinching at least the American League’s wild-card berth, the Yankees’ regular infielders told Manager Joe Girardi that they did not need a day off.

headline: Proposal Pending on Mileage for Heavy-Duty Vehicles
text: WASHINGTON  For three decades, the federal government has calculated the fuel economy of cars and other “light-duty vehicles” and periodically tightened mileage standards. For the first time, it is preparing to do the same with heavy-duty vehicles, which could greatly reduce their consumption of diesel fuel.

headline: Selling Treasures of the Stars
text: When Catherine D. Elkies conducted her first auction for Christie’s in 1990, she was overcome by stage fright. But then the adrenaline kicked in. Sold! Ms. Elkies, 45, who majored in art history at Kenyon College, is a senior vice president and director of private and corporate collections for Christie’s Americas, specializing in the acquisition and marketing of celebrity memorabilia. She has a 2-year-old son, Oliver, and lives on the Upper East Side.

headline: S.E.C. Is Sued Over Board Nomination Rule
text: The United States Chamber of Commerce and the Business Roundtable on Wednesday sued the Securities and Exchange Commission to overturn a rule that makes it easier for investors to oust corporate directors.

headline: Green Products Aren’t So Undesirable
text: To the Editor:

headline: Government's Controlled Detonation Test
text: Prosecutors released a video of a controlled detonation by the Joint Terrorism Task Force of a bomb built to be what Faisal Shahzad intended.

headline: With Fewer Nasty Battles, One Firm Profits Less
text: By LYNNLEY BROWNINGBrutal proxy fights that pit shareholders against executives are the lifeblood of IVS Associates, a private firm with a headlock on the high-stakes business of tallying shareholder votes in corporate battles.

headline: A Megamerger: Pop Culture and the Financial Crisis
text: By ERIC DASH

headline: Using Drug War Methods to Look for Insider Trading
text: By PETER J. HENNING

headline: A New Kind of Defense Against Hostile Bids
text: By STEVEN M. DAVIDOFF

headline: When Private Equity Meets Packer Fandom
text: By PETER LATTMAN

headline: Obama, in Iowa, Hears Barbed Questions in a Subdued Backyard
text: DES MOINES  President Obama returned Wednesday to Iowa, the state that put him on the presidential map, this time fighting to keep his Democratic Party in power and confronting skeptical voters who challenged him on policies from tax cuts to health care.

headline: Congress Wraps Up Session Early as Midterm Races Loom
text: WASHINGTON — Congress on Thursday adopted a stopgap spending measure to finance the government through Dec. 3 as lawmakers dashed for an earlier-than-expected exodus from Washington and headed home to focus on the midterm elections.

headline: Goldman Tops Takeover Tables
text: A surprisingly busy August, led by BHP Billiton’s $39 billion hostile offer for Potash, drove global merger activity in the third quarter to its highest level in two years.

headline: In Austere Era, Goldman Workers Adopt Lower Profile
text: By KEVIN ROOSE

headline: Four Suicides in a Week Take a Toll on Fort Hood
text: HOUSTON  Four veterans of the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan died this week from what appeared to be self-inflicted gunshot wounds at Fort Hood in central Texas, raising the toll of soldiers who died here at their own hands to a record level and alarming Army commanders.

headline: Next Steps
text: DealBook’s latest special section graphic explores where some of the top figures of the 2008 financial crisis have landed two years later.

headline: Elite Colleges, or Colleges for the Elite?
text: Washington

headline: The Regulatory Pregame: Laying Bets on the Winners
text: By SUSANNE CRAIG and ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Private Equity Thrives Again, but Dark Shadows Loom
text: By JULIE CRESWELL and PETER LATTMAN

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Talk of Reform to Enliven Leaders’ Meeting in China
text: BEIJING  Against a backdrop of a rare discussion about political reform, China’s top leaders are preparing to set the country’s economic policies and political leadership for the next decade.

headline: A Warning Sign in Canceled I.P.O.’s
text: Wall Street just lost some insurance in more ways than one. At the 11th hour, the Liberty Mutual Group yanked the initial public offering of its property and casualty arm. The $1.2 billion deal would have been the biggest flotation in the United States this year. It was also being closely watched as a barometer of investor appetite for the backlog of new share sales meant to keep bankers busy. Weaker trading volumes already had many of them nervous about their fates. If I.P.O.’s flag too, more jobs could be on the line.

headline: Trying to Lace Together a Consensus on Biodiversity Across a Global Landscape
text: UNITED NATIONS  Amid the howling motorcades, the scrums of burly security guards and the buzz of countless meetings around the United Nations in recent days, the Venerable Bun Saluth, a Cambodian Buddhist monk with a shaved head, stood out with his vivid saffron robes, his unassuming manner  and for taking what some might call tree hugging to an entirely different level.

headline: Consumer Advocate Seeks to Reassure Bankers About Protection Agency
text: WASHINGTON  Elizabeth Warren, who is overseeing the creation of a federal agency charged with protecting consumers from abusive financial products, told Wall Street executives on Wednesday evening that her relationship with them need not be antagonistic, or even adversarial.

headline: Get New York to the Polls
text: ON Primary Day this month, New York voters faced numerous delays and equipment malfunctions at the polls. In some cases residents stood in line for hours, leading state politicians to make accusations of disenfranchisement and resulting in three government investigations.

headline: Taliban Video of Faisal Shahzad
text: The government made public a video produced by the Taliban in which Faisal Shahzad appears.

headline: Waiting for Somebody
text: Let’s talk for a minute about education.

headline: Robert Truax, a Top Rocket Scientist, Is Dead at 93
text: When Evel Knievel failed to leap the Snake River Canyon in 1974, he rode a vehicle powered by Robert C. Truax’s rockets. Drag racers could not beat speed records in his rocket-powered cars. NASA never bought his idea of using battleship-size missiles to launch satellites.

headline: Chronicle of a Genocide Foretold
text: The global refrain about genocide is “Never Again,” but we may be watching how that slips into “One More Time.”

headline: Shady Secrets
text: A midnight filing by the Obama administration on Friday, asking a federal judge to throw out a lawsuit because of the so-called state secrets doctrine, again raises a troubling question. Why do the White House and Justice Department continue to invoke this severe legal tool essentially as prior administrations have used it, in the face of a considerable body of opinion that it has been abused and should be significantly reformed?

headline: China Reportedly Releases 3 Japanese
text: BEIJING  Chinese authorities have released three of four Japanese citizens who were accused last week of videotaping at a military installation in northern China, state media reported on Thursday.

headline: A Reprieve for Stem Cell Research
text: A federal appeals court made the right choice on Tuesday when it allowed the Obama administration to keep financing embryonic stem cell research while legal arguments continue over whether to uphold or reject a temporary ban imposed by a lower court judge. Even a brief ban on financing would have disrupted research that scientists hope will lead to cures for devastating ailments like Parkinson’s disease and spinal cord injuries.

headline: Gov. Christie’s Tunnel Vision
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has made a national name for himself by slashing spending on education and other vital services. New Jersey’s children and other vulnerable residents are paying the price. Now he wants to stall  and perhaps cancel  one of the most important transportation projects in the country: a new railway tunnel under the Hudson River linking New Jersey and Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Lincoln Meets ‘Mad Men’ in New Campaign
text: John Slattery, who portrays Roger Sterling in “Mad Men,” the AMC series about advertising, is getting some real-life experience with Madison Avenue as he becomes an endorser for Lincoln.

headline: Nolan Ryan’s New Pitch
text: To get to the owner’s seats at the Texas Rangers’ stadium, a retro redbrick bandbox that looks utterly out of place on the suburban plains of Dallas, you have to pass through a small room beneath the stands that George W. Bush, who participated in the design and construction of the stadium in the early 1990s, envisioned as a bunker for his father, then president of the United States. But the younger Bush divested himself of his interest in the Rangers before the Ballpark at Arlington was completed, and the concrete bunker now serves as a V.I.P. lounge.

headline: Polar Ponies and Ice Dogs
text: The ancient convention for naming newly discovered geographical features is fairly simple: royalty, sponsors, loved ones and crewmates come first, possibly followed by the explorer. That is how most of the landmarks around Antarctica got their names. But now a new set of names is being added  not to geographical spots, which are mostly taken, but to navigation waypoints along the main air routes between New Zealand and McMurdo Station in Antarctica.

headline: Reports Say Deadline Hinders Asylum Seekers
text: A nurse in Zimbabwe who joined an opposition political party was assaulted after she tried to bring foreign medical supplies to a struggling hospital. A student from China who follows Falun Gong, a banned spiritual movement, left his country when most of the followers he knew were detained.

headline: Word of the Day | automaton
text: automaton •\ȯ-ˈtä-mə-tən, -mə-ˌtän\• noun

headline: Italy: Premier Survives Confidence Vote
text: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi survived a confidence vote in Parliament on Wednesday, saving his government from collapse, but not removing the prospect of early elections before his mandate ends in 2013. Mr. Berlusconi, who had called for the vote in an effort to shore up his embattled government, received 342 votes in favor of his government, 275 votes against, with 3 abstentions, thanks to the support of some legislators loyal to his former deputy, Gianfranco Fini, the speaker of the lower house of Parliament, who left the center-right coalition in July over increasingly vocal differences with Mr. Berlusconi. Addressing Parliament, Mr. Berlusconi cited the strength of the Italian economy, and vehemently denied allegations that he had offered money or positions to several undecided deputies.

headline: Britain: After Loss, Brother Steps Back
text: Seeking to end what he had described as part of the Labour Party’s “soap opera,” David Miliband, 45, a narrow loser to his younger brother, Ed Miliband, 40, in the race to become the party’s new leader, said Wednesday that he was stepping down from the party’s top ranks and would serve as a backbench member of Parliament. The announcement came as a blow to many in Labour who saw the older Miliband, the former foreign minister, as the leader of the party’s moderate New Labour wing and a counterbalance to his more left-wing, pro-union brother. David Miliband said he wanted to spend more time with his family, and not to be the focus of “perpetual, distracting and destructive attempts to find division” within Labour. Ed Miliband, who has called the media frenzy over the brothers’ rivalry a “psychodrama” that needed to end, called his brother’s decision “thoughtful and gracious.”

headline: China: Effort to Attract Foreign Students
text: A senior Chinese education official says that China plans to have 150,000 foreign students studying for degrees by 2020, according to a report on Wednesday in China Daily, an official English-language newspaper. The central government intends to offer more scholarships and to encourage local governments and schools to do the same, the report said. The plan to attract more foreigners to degree programs is part of the country’s push to increase its soft power, or influence through culture and diplomacy. The official, Hao Ping, vice minister of education, said that the 240,000 foreign students in China last year were a record. About 60 percent of foreign students are studying Chinese, and 13.5 percent are studying medicine.

headline: Greg Giraldo, Insult-Humor Comic, Dies at 44
text: Greg Giraldo, a comedian famous for his stinging insult humor, disgruntled rants and frequent appearances on Comedy Central’s highly watched roast series, died on Wednesday at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 44.

headline: Britain: Defense Chief Denounces Cuts
text: In the first sign of major strains within Prime Minister David Cameron’s governing coalition over plans for a four-year, $135 billion cut in Britain’s annual deficit, the secretary of state for defense, Liam Fox, has warned Mr. Cameron that he could not support the “draconian cuts” being discussed for the military budget. In a private letter to Mr. Cameron, a leaked version of which was published in The Daily Telegraph, Mr. Fox said that the proposed cuts of 10 percent to 20 percent of the $60 billion defense budget, with cuts of tens of thousands in the country’s force of 180,000 uniformed service members, would damage troop morale, involve unacceptable dangers “at a time when we are at war” in Afghanistan and imperil Britain’s submarine-born nuclear missile force. Senior Pentagon officials have also voiced concern about the proposed cuts, and Mr. Fox has said that Britain needs to weigh American concerns carefully.

headline: Bloggingheads: Bloody Business
text: Spencer Ackerman, left, of Wired.com and Eli Lake of The Washington Times discuss the myth and reality of counterinsurgency.

headline: Russia: Chess Official Is Re-elected
text: A provincial leader who claims to have been abducted by space aliens and was backed by top Russian officials for another term as president of the World Chess Federation was re-elected Wednesday, according to Chessdom, a chess news Web site, and Russian news agencies. Kirsan N. Ilyumzhinov, left, the Kremlin-appointed leader of Kalmykia in southern Russia, defeated Anatoly Karpov, the former world champion, 95 to 55, at the federation’s meeting in Khanty-Mansiysk. Mr. Karpov and his longtime rival, Garry Kasparov, had accused Mr. Ilyumzhinov of presiding over the game’s decline during the 15 years he has led the federation. They also accused him of mental instability. Mr. Ilyumzhinov has said he met with extraterrestrials in yellow suits at his Moscow apartment and that chess comes from outer space. He has also been accused of corruption and human rights abuses, and has been linked to the killing of a journalist. Mr. Karpov’s prospects may have been hurt by the backing of Mr. Kasparov, who is not well liked in some corners of the chess world. Each country in the federation has one vote.

headline: Two Are Confirmed for Fed’s Board
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday night confirmed Janet L. Yellen as vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve and Sarah Bloom Raskin as a Fed governor, adding two officials to the Fed’s board as it faces a decision on whether to take new steps to stimulate the economy.

headline: Russia: U.S. Congressmen Propose Sanctions in Lawyer’s Death
text: Members of the United States Congress introduced legislation on Wednesday that would impose financial sanctions and visa bans on Russian officials implicated in the case of Sergei L. Magnitsky, a Russian lawyer who died in prison in Moscow in November after being ensnared in tax inquiry. The measure’s sponsors  including Senator Benjamin L. Cardin, a Maryland Democrat, and Representative Jim McGovern, a Massachusetts Democrat  said it was intended to spur the Russian government to properly investigate Mr. Magnitsky’s death. His defenders contend that he was jailed in an effort to force him to falsify testimony against Hermitage Capital Management, a major foreign investment fund that once had large holdings in Russia. His death caused widespread outrage and focused renewed attention on police tactics and corruption in Russia.

headline: Boy, 8, Dies in Brooklyn Fire
text: An 8-year-old boy was killed and five other children were seriously injured when a fast-moving fire broke out in a residential building in the Midwood section of Brooklyn on Wednesday, Fire Department officials said.

headline: North Korea Releases First Photo of Kim’s Heir
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korean state media released a photograph and video of Kim Jong-un, the son and presumed heir of the ailing dictator, Kim Jong-il, the first verified images of the young man as an adult.

headline: Danny Elfman and Tim Burton on 'Batman'
text: The composer and director teamed on the 1989 film.

headline: News Quiz | September 30, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Gates, Buffett Say China Charity Meeting a Success
text: BEIJING — After a night of wining and dining 50 of China’s richest people in the name of promoting philanthropy, Warren Buffett and Bill Gates told a horde of journalists on Thursday that the biggest difference between eating with Chinese tycoons and Western ones was the food.

headline: Parking Rules
text: In New York City, because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzeret and Simhat Torah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Thursday and Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: JPMorgan Suspending Foreclosures
text: In a sign that the entire foreclosure process is coming under pressure, a second major mortgage lender said that it was suspending court cases against defaulting homeowners so it could review its legal procedures, David Streitfeld writes in The New York Times.

headline: In Tax Cut Plan, Debate Over the Definition of Rich
text: Much of the debate about whether to extend the Bush tax cuts has focused on big economic issues: how the decision might affect the fragile economy, the widening federal deficit and hiring by small businesses, David Kocieniewski writes in The New York Times.

headline: A Meeting of Unconventional Minds With Vienna Philharmonic
text: Carnegie Hall opened its season on Wednesday night with the Vienna Philharmonic in the first of four programs. A concert by this great orchestra is always a privilege. This gala event offered Nikolaus Harnoncourt in a Beethoven program. What could be better?

headline: Eye on China, House Votes for Greater Tariff Powers
text: The House of Representatives sent an unusually confrontational signal to the Chinese leadership on Wednesday, voting overwhelmingly to give the Obama administration expanded authority to impose tariffs on virtually all Chinese imports to the United States.

headline: Test Yourself |English, Sept. 30, 2010
text: Test your grammar and punctuation skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times article “Empire vs. Rebel Alliance in High-Def.”

headline: Warren Seeks to Reassure Bankers on Protection Agency
text: Elizabeth Warren, who is overseeing the creation of a federal agency charged with protecting consumers from abusive financial products, told Wall Street executives on Wednesday evening that her relationship with them need not be antagonistic, or even adversarial.

headline: After Crisis, Dubai Keeps Building, but Soberly
text: The planned replica of the Las Vegas Strip and a glow-in-the-dark copy of a Giza pyramid are now delayed. But only a few miles away, workers are busy on a series of government-backed projects of a far more practical nature.

headline: With Bank Inquiry, Vatican Confronts Modern Life
text: When Rome magistrates opened an investigation last week into the Vatican bank over transparency issues, it was not only a bold assertion of state over church, it also pointed to one of the Vatican’s greatest continuing challenges: facing modernity.

headline: In Diller Resignation, the Upshot of a Merger
text: The merger of Live Nation and Ticketmaster last year created an unusual executive power-sharing arrangement and united some of the media and music industry’s biggest egos in a single boardroom — a recipe, some predicted, for turmoil, Tim Arango writes in The New York Times.

headline: Signaling Tensions, Pakistan Shuts NATO Route
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  American officials pressed their Pakistani counterparts on Thursday to reopen a vital supply route for American and NATO forces in Afghanistan, as relations deteriorated after the fourth strike by coalition helicopters in a week killed three members of Pakistan’s border force.

headline: Can You Pass a Basic Religion Test?
text: The Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life asked more than 3,400 Americans 32 questions about the Bible, Christianity and other world religions, religious history and geography. On average, people answered half the questions incorrectly, and many flubbed even questions about their own faith. Atheists, agnostics, Jews and Mormons seemed to know the most. Could you pass this test? Answer some of the same questions here, then tell us how you did. How much do you think you know about religion in general, and your own faith in particular?

headline: Charming Billy
text: Adam Lewis’s new book, ‘‘Billy Baldwin: The Great American Decorator’’ (Rizzoli), surveys the life and career of the man whose pared-down versions of the slipper chair and brass bookshelves became famous, and whose work continues to influence designers long after his death in 1983. Baldwin, a charming, well-born native of Baltimore who was the protégé of Ruby Ross Wood (see Lewis’s previous book, ‘‘The Great Lady Decorators’’), developed a bold, modern style that confidently mixed patterns and periods; he became the go-to decorator for people like Babe Paley, Cole Porter and Diana Vreeland, whose legendary ‘‘garden in hell’’ red living room he designed. Baldwin was never afraid of color and is said to have pioneered the use of aubergine walls, in a Maryland house (above) in the 1940s. The book, which has an affectionate foreword by Albert Hadley, Baldwin’s former student, is a welcome addition to the two (out-of-print and increasingly expensive) volumes on the decorator’s work, ‘‘Billy Baldwin Decorates’’  and ‘‘Billy Baldwin Remembers.’’

headline: S.E.C. Sued Over Board Nomination Rule for Investors
text: The United States Chamber of Commerce and the Business Roundtable on Wednesday sued the Securities and Exchange Commission to overturn a rule that makes it easier for investors to oust corporate directors, arguing the provision gave activist investors too much leverage, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Two Are Confirmed for Fed’s Board

headline: Protests in Europe Lead to a Down Day
text: Shares on Wall Street moved lower Wednesday as protests against austerity measures in Europe brought new worries about the region’s financial system, The Associated Press reported.

text: Almost two years and $700 billion after it began, the government’s financial bailout program officially draws to a close Monday, with the financial sector happily still standing, The Wall Street Journal reports.

headline: Prudential Buys A.I.G. Japan Units for $4.8 Billion

headline: U.N. Reports Mixed Results on Afghan Poppy Crops
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  With extraordinary effort, the Afghan government and Western aid programs have modestly reduced poppy cultivation in the country’s largest opium-producing province in the past year, but cultivation nationwide remained at last year’s levels and in two provinces increased sharply, according to the annual report released Thursday by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime.

headline: Giants Surprised by Manningham’s Concussion
text: Giants wide receiver Mario Manningham sustained a concussion in a 29-10 loss to the Tennessee Titans but did not alert the medical staff until Sunday night. Manningham did not practice Wednesday, and his status for Sunday night’s game against the Bears is uncertain. He was unavailable for comment on Wednesday.

headline: Dancing to Shakespeare at London’s Barbican
text: Now in its 25th year, the Stephen Petronio Companycontinues to enthrall audiences worldwide with its repertory of electrifying, high-energy dances set to music by artists like Fischerspooner, Rufus Wainwright and Lou Reed. Always on the cutting edge, Mr. Petronio enjoys bringing fashion and art together in his works, enlisting designers like Benjamin Cho, Leigh Bowery and Manolo Blahnik, and visual artists like Cindy Sherman and Anish Kapoor.

text: Tony Curtis, a classically handsome movie star who came out of the Hollywood studio system in the 1950s to find both wide popularity and critical acclaim in dramatic and comic roles alike, from “The Defiant Ones” to “Some Like It Hot,” died on Wednesday at his home in Henderson, Nev., near Las Vegas. He was 85.

headline: Indian Court Divides Disputed Ayodhya Holy Site

headline: Ristretto | Not Just in Kansas Anymore

PT’s had just been named Roaster of the Year by Roast Magazine, the respected trade journal, and it earned a following among the coffee-crazed for buying some of the best beans available, but it was nearly impossible to find here in New York. It was like wandering into the corner liquor store and coming across a rare Burgundy.

headline: ‘Modern Family’ Fans Get Their ‘Kiss’
text: To the extent that it is possible for a genial and widely lauded comedy like “Modern Family” to get itself into trouble (at least in a way that doesn’t involve hyping the Apple iPad), that ABC series caused a minor stir in the spring: after an episode in which Claire and Phil Dunphy, a married couple played by Julie Bowen and Ty Burrell, were shown kissing, while Mitchell Pritchett and Cam Tucker, a gay couple played by Jesse Tyler Ferguson and Eric Stonestreet, were hugging, some fans of “Modern Family” complained that the show would not allow its gay characters to kiss, going so far as to start a Facebook campaign demanding such a scene. The “Modern Family” producers countered that an episode involving a kiss between Cam and Mitchell was already in the works.

headline: Popcast: Teenage Fanclub Performs and More

It’s been a long time since that Scottish band has been in the spotlight — Spin magazine somewhat notoriously chose its “Bandwagonesque” as the best album of 1991, over Nirvana’s “Nevermind” — but since then it has been consistently, if slowly, making music that is highly acclaimed by critics, other musicians and a small but devoted cult of fans, as Ben Sisario reports.

headline: Tables of Content
text: For Dieter Roth, life and art were part of the same messy process. His creative output included a multimedia diary of six months of his life, which he produced for the 1982 Venice Biennale, and cumulative works like ‘‘Gartenskulptur,’’ which started out as a self-portrait in chocolate and birdseed and acquired enough collateral material over the course of several years — various household objects, ladders, television monitors, even a live rabbit in a hutch — to fill an entire room. Other pieces Roth made used the clothes off his back.

headline: U.S. Issues New Rules on Offshore Drilling
text: WASHINGTON  The Interior Department tightened its rules on offshore oil and gas operations on Thursday but left in place the moratorium on deepwater drilling that has left oil executives frustrated and Gulf Coast officials fuming.

headline: Poetry Pairing | Sept. 30, 2010
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: After Long Injury Layoff, Westwood Says He Is Ready to Play
text: NEWPORT, Wales — Lee Westwood of England was introduced as “Europe’s No. 1 player” for his Thursday morning interview in the Ryder Cup media center, and nothing in his body language or spoken words to indicate he will be anything less this week.

headline: Searching for the Dear (Younger) Leader
text: Updated | 4:41 p.m. As our colleague Mark McDonald reports, on Thursday the North Korean government released a photograph and video of Kim Jong-un, the son and presumed heir of the country’s ailing “dear leader,” Kim Jong-il.

headline: Chevrolet Aveo Aims to Inspire the Young

headline: Feel-Good Scarves | Anthropologie
text: There is a chill in the air, and while it might not be boots and fur-trapper hat weather just yet, that doesn’t mean we’re not taking a pencil to our fall shopping list. What’s missing between all those glossy packages? Brownie points for shopping for a good cause. When I learned that Anthropologie and Indego Africa had teamed up to sell loop scarves made by the 40 female artisans of the Ingenzi Knit Union in Rwanda, and that 100 percent of the proceeds are being used for further training in long-term skills, I knew that bundling up had just got sweeter.

headline: One From the Vaults: A Boxed Set to Celebrate Danny Elfman’s Music for Tim Burton
text: When you’ve built a career working with Tim Burton, as Danny Elfman has, it’s inevitable that you end up with entire crypts full of buried material. But now an (un)healthy portion of the catalog created by Mr. Elfman, the musician and composer who has written the scores for nearly all of Mr. Burton’s films, including “Beetlejuice,” “Batman” and “Edward Scissorhands” — and provided the singing voice for Jack Skellington of “The Nightmare Before Christmas” — is about to be unearthed. On Thursday, Warner Brothers Records said it would release a boxed set commemorating the 25 years that these two artists have worked together, dating back to 1985, when Mr. Burton recruited Mr. Elfman from the band Oingo Boingo to create the score for “Pee-wee’s Big Adventure.” The “Danny Elfman & Tim Burton 25th Anniversary Music Box,” which is planned for a December release, will contain 18 hours of music on 16 CDs, including seven hours of previously unreleased material, a hardcover book with a foreword by Johnny Depp and a DVD conversation between Mr. Elfman and Mr. Burton.

headline: CNN’s Anderson Cooper in Daytime Talk Show Deal
text: The CNN anchor Anderson Cooper will add a second show to his daily duties next year, a lighthearted daytime talk show on local television stations.

headline: Thanking the Canadiens for a Trade to New York
text: ¶ “I’m so happy to be here — I want to say thanks to Montreal Canadiens that they traded me to New York Rangers,” says the 22-year-old rookie Pavel Valentenko in the Rangers dressing room after Wednesday night’s 5-1 exhibition-game victory over Detroit at Madison Square Garden. Valentenko, whose previous pro stints were with Neftekhimik Nizhnekamsk; Montreal’s A.H.L. farm club in Hamilton; and, most recently, Dinamo Moscow, is one of four defensemen competing for two roster spots on the Rangers’ blue line and has impressed Coach John Tortorella with his poise and hard work. On Thursday he went off doubled over after his first shift (“broke my nose; it’s nothing”), returned to play solid, plus-2 defense — and helped set up this goal by his fellow rookie Derek Stepan on a play that featured wonderful footwork by another Rangers hopeful, the veteran forward Ruslan Fedotenko:

text: I went for Gershwin, and I got Tina Turner.

headline: G.M. Building Electric Opels for Vehicle-to-Grid Test in Germany
text: With financing from the German Ministry of Economics and Technology, General Motors and a partner, MeRegioMobil, will produce a trio of battery electric vehicles based on the subcompact Opel Meriva. They are intended to demonstrate the E.V.’s ability to not only take in energy from the grid, but also to give it back.

headline: Your Guidance Counselor May Be in St. Louis
text: As regular readers of this blog know — but new ones may not — about 5,000 high school counselors and college admissions officers leave their respective campuses every fall to convene in one setting.

headline: He Still Wants to Rock: Dee Snider Joins ‘Rock of Ages’
text: Did we miss the meeting of the Broadway League where it was ruled that the cast of every musical must feature at least one rock or pop star? “American Idiot” has Billie Joe Armstrong, “Fela!” has Patti LaBelle and now “Rock of Ages” has Dee Snider. On Thursday, press representatives for “Rock of Ages” said Mr. Snider, the Twisted Sister frontman, will join the musical for an 11-week run beginning Oct. 11. Mr. Snider, who is also a star of the A&E reality show “Growing Up Twisted,” will play the role of the nightclub owner Dennis, and will host a weekly talkback series called “Rock Senate Hearings” that will begin on Oct. 19. “Rock of Ages,” a jukebox musical built around headbanging hits of the 1980s (including the Twisted Sister songs “I Wanna Rock” and “We’re Not Gonna Take It”), recently lost its Tony Award-nominated star, Constantine Maroulis, to the show’s national tour. In recent weeks, the musical, which is performed at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, has played to about 75 percent capacity and has grossed under $500,000 a week.

headline: Flood Watch in Effect for City and Suburbs
text: It may not be raining right now — and in Central Park it’s not — but don’t let that fool you into thinking the worst of the downpour is over.

headline: Gray, Gay…and Worried
text: David and his partner, Paschal, together for more than 20 years, married during the brief period that same-sex marriages were legal in California. They’re in their 60s, in decent health and financial shape. Yet thinking about their future makes David uneasy.

headline: Recession Drove Many to Medicaid Last Year

headline: Restaurant Workers Don’t Stay Home When Sick, Study Finds

headline: Paris Drops a Needle in a Worn Groove
text: After an exciting Milan ready-to-wear season, the Paris shows seem to be running at the speed of a 45-r.p.m. record. Balmain today reached for Sid Vicious and “My Way” — a short reach even by high-fashion standards — as the designer Christophe Decarnin sent out safety-pinned leather jackets, slashed T-shirts and frayed denim cutoffs worn with snagged fishnets. A punk never had it so good. (See the full Balmain collection.)

It was a facelifted version of the Mazda 2, not the Shinari concept car. While the Shinari had been expected to be displayed in Paris, Mazda did not take that car to the show.

He determined that “politics in the online age is increasingly borderless, and can often be shaped more by national causes than by anything having to do with local constituents.” The columnist is answering selected reader questions this week about the midterms and more.

headline: Paladino Campaign Blames Reporter for Taped Confrontation

Paladino was caught on tape angrily threatening to “take out” a reporter who questioned his tactics, the candidate’s aides on Thursday unleashed a blistering and an unusually personal attack on the journalist and the newspaper that he works for, saying that they had put Mr. Paladino’s family in “harm’s way.”

headline: Boston Globe to Start a Paid Web Site
text: The Boston Globe, part of The New York Times Company, announced on Thursday that it would start a new paid Web site in the second half of 2011. The site will be called BostonGlobe.com and will be in addition to the company’s current Web site, Boston.com, in what the company calls a “two-brand” strategy.

headline: Blaming the Beef
text: It is not easy for a cyclist not named Lance Armstrong to crack the mainstream sports conversation, so you have to give an appreciative nod to Alberto Contador. He did not accomplish this by testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs while winning the Tour de France in July. That news has all the shock value of finding out a politician is dishonest (no!). What vaulted Contador into newsworthiness was his instant classic of an excuse: bad meat.

headline: Eyeing the Unreal Estate of Gatsby Esq.
text: IF the measure of the great American novel is whether thousands of people will pay to watch a staged reading of its every word in a single seating, interrupted only by a meal and maybe a sipped Manhattan or six, then Jonathan Whatshisname’s latest doorstopper is not your book. “The Great Gatsby” is.

headline: Monkeys With Personality
text: To the untrained eye, all geladas look alike. Complicating matters, they form some of the largest aggregations of any nonhuman primate. We have seen groups in excess of 1,000 individuals.

headline: Kin of Detainees Seek Prosecution of Iran Officials
text: TEHRAN  In an unusually bold public request, families of three antigovernment protesters who died after beatings at Iran’s notorious Kahrizak prison have demanded the prosecution of high-ranking officials responsible for running the extralegal detention center.

headline: Cocktails and Fist-Pumping: California’s Ballot Battle
text: The fight over Proposition 23, the California ballot initiative that would suspend the state’s landmark global warming law, has spawned some unusual political alliances. Mainstream environmentalists, venture capitalists, labor unions, tech chieftains and even some Republicans have all made common cause to oppose the measure, which is backed by two Texas oil companies.

headline: Can Photography Bookstores Survive?
text: Timothy Whelan will be closing his photography bookstore in Rockport, Me., on Oct. 2. The bookstore, Timothy Whelan Photography Fine Photographic Prints and Books, is known as one of the finest of its kind in the United States. Mr. Whelan discussed photographers, books and the economic difficulties that small bookstores face with Ashley Gilbertson earlier this month. The interview has been edited for brevity and clarity.

headline: Joel Grey Joins ‘Anything Goes’ Revival
text: Is this the face of a hardened criminal? Joel Grey, the original Wizard of “Wicked,” the impish M.C. of “Cabaret” and Amos Hart of the “Chicago” revival, is headed back to Broadway in Roundabout Theater Company’s coming revival of “Anything Goes” as one of musical theater’s best-known, least-intimidating gangsters. On Thursday, publicists for Roundabout said Mr. Grey will play the role of Moonface Martin — a k a Public Enemy No. 13 — who helps provide several changes of identity for Billy Crocker, a lovesick stowaway on the S.S. American. Sutton Foster was previously announced to play the role of the singer Reno Sweeney in Roundabout’s production, which will be directed by Kathleen Marshall; it is to begin previews at the Stephen Sondheim Theater on March 10 with an opening night set for April 7.

headline: The Paris That Awoke to Atget’s Lens
text: EUGÈNE ATGET was a stooped-over 69-year-old carrying a heavy load of camera equipment across Paris by the time he shot some of his greatest photographs: misty visions of Paris and its great parks in the dawn light, muted by clouds and filled with trees.

headline: A Chicken Topped  With Tomato
text: The other night I roasted a chicken stuffed with essentially the same mixture from which I’d made a savory bread pudding  the week before (at our new e-friend Christina von Koehler’s suggestion: it reminded her of her Hungarian grandmother’s stuffing). I could have made a “proper” sauce using chicken stock and so forth, but since the Union Square Greenmarket tomatoes were so spectacular I decided to use them for the sauce.

Photographer Ed Alcock discusses how he went about taking contemporary

headline: U.S. Presses Israelis on Renewal of Freeze
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is trying to cajole the Israeli government into a 60-day renewal of the freeze on Jewish settlement building by offering it security guarantees, ranging from military hardware to support for a long-term Israeli presence in the strategically sensitive Jordan Valley, according to lawmakers and other officials briefed on the proposals.

headline: Bryant Remains Europe’s Favorite
text: The European fashion crowd apparently likes Kobe Bryant jerseys. Bryant’s Lakers jersey remains the No. 1 seller in European stores, for the third consecutive year, according to the league’s latest sales numbers. Bryant’s jersey is also the top seller in China.

headline: Opel Ampera vs. Chevrolet Volt
text: PARIS — The Paris Motor Show has seen sister rivalries before, and will again. This week in Hall 5.2 here at the Exposition Center, it was the Opel Ampera plug-in hybrid on one side of the aisle, and the Chevrolet Volt on the other.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: Birds fly above the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco.

headline: Recession Is Still Pinching City’s Business Owners
text: Nearly a year after the Federal Reserve Bank of New York deemed the recession over, many small-business owners are still waiting for real signs of recovery. In this video, part of a series of articles and videos that have followed several small businesses in New York City since 2008, one gets a glimpse of how unevenly the economic rebound is playing out across the city and various industries. A bicycle manufacturer in Queens has adapted to changing markets and come out a leaner, more diversified company. Meanwhile, a butcher in the Bronx recently closed shop because of outstanding debt.

headline: The Zootopian
text: ‘Every time an animal gets sent back, I feel like a child has come back to me,” said the German designer Renate Müller, referring to the jute-and-leather creatures she has been making, on and off, since the mid-1960s. Her menagerie ranges from rhinos to songbirds, from ottoman-size to hand-held. Müller’s animals were always intended to be much more than cute. She designed the first ones while still a student, as teaching tools for children with special needs, to be used at clinics, kindergartens and at home to teach balance, grip and other motor skills as well as colors, shapes and textures. They had to be appealing enough to generate spontaneous play while still incorporating the work of the German therapists that Müller had observed.

headline: Very Serious Reactions to the Levin Bill
text: As regular readers know, I’m getting increasingly disgruntled with Very Serious People, who offer wise reasons not to do anything about devastating unemployment. Inevitably, the VSPs are weighing in on the Levin bill authorizing countervailing duties on Chinese goods, offering very wise-sounding reasons why we should do nothing about outrageous, destructive currency manipulation.

headline: ‘Free Night of Theater’ Returns
text: Thousands of free tickets to Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway shows are available for the taking through the month of October as part of New York City’s third annual “Free Night of Theater,” run by Theater Communications Group, a national organization of not-for-profit theaters.

headline: Internal Logic
text: You can think of the architect Michael Maltzan’s design for a house in the San Gabriel, Calif., foothills as a form of therapy  an architectural journey that takes you from the edge of anxiety back to some sort of mental equilibrium.

headline: Hey Gio
text: It’s been a good year or so for Gio Ponti. Last fall, Rizzoli reprinted a lavish monograph devoted to the staggeringly prolific Italian designer, critic and bon vivant who, before his death at 87 in 1979, founded Domus magazine, created sets for La Scala, brought a touch of playful luxury to the interiors of the Andrea Doria and planted works in every medium in just about every corner of the world. Meanwhile, auction prices for vintage Ponti pieces have been on a winning streak, not unlike the thoroughbred racehorse named after him. Now ‘‘The Expression of Gio Ponti,’’ curated by Germano Celant, gives the designer his biggest local showcase since the days of the old Alitalia ticket offices he created at 666 Fifth Avenue. The whopping retrospective, which opens in early 2011 and is the first exhibition at the brand-new Triennale di Milano design museum in Midtown, includes 250 items, from drawings to majolica to furniture, including the iconic Superleggera chair, which Ponti called, with characteristic flair, ‘‘the chair for all times.’’ Classical yet modern, rigorous yet whimsical, Ponti’s work conforms to no dogma except his own exhortation to ‘‘make something beautiful!’’

headline: 'The Pitmen Painters'
text: A scene from the new Broadway play at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater. (Video courtesy of the Manhattan Theater Club)

headline: Novartis Pays $422.5 Million in Settlement
text: The Swiss drug giant Novartis has agreed to pay $422.5 million to settle criminal and civil investigations into the marketing of the antiseizure medicine Trileptal and five other drugs, officials said on Thursday.

headline: Open House
text: Patrizia Moroso is the creative director of Moroso, the 58-year-old company in Udine, Italy, that is one of the last remaining family-owned furniture manufacturers in a country that was once famous for them. A petite, intense figure  a kind of den mother in Issey Miyake  who loves to nurture new talent, she helped propel designers from Ron Arad and Massimo Iosa Ghini to Tord Boontje and Tokujin Yoshioka onto the global stage by commissioning envelope-pushing chairs, sofas and tables from them.

text: Automakers are displaying new concepts and world-market cars at the auto show in Paris.

headline: Paying Doctors for Patient Performance
text: Not long ago, a fellow doctor told me that his local health care insurers, in an effort to improve care and rein in costs, had been evaluating physicians and paying them according to their “quality ranking.” With “pay for performance” reimbursement, doctors who had, for example, managed more timely follow-up and achieved better test results with their diabetic or hypertensive patients would rank more highly and earn more in financial bonuses than physicians whose patients failed to meet the insurers’ guidelines.

headline: How Do You Measure Physician Quality?
text: Many health insurance providers now link a doctor’s reimbursement fees and bonuses to the quality of care provided to patients. But as Dr. Pauline Chen explains in today’s Doctor and Patient column, the measures typically used to measure a doctor’s performance can be misleading.

headline: Reining Puts Some Giddyup Into Equestrian Games
text: LEXINGTON, Ky.  The Dutch rider Anky van Grunsven has won eight Olympic medals in the sport of dressage, but she left her top hat and tailcoat at home this week to compete at the World Equestrian Games. As Rihanna’s “Only Girl” blared over the loudspeakers, van Grunsven rollicked around the indoor arena at the Kentucky Horse Park in a cowboy hat and spangled orange shirt, guiding her horse into dizzying spins and skidding stops.

headline: Paladino Blames Reporter for Taped Confrontation
text: Over in the City Room, Michael Barbaro reports on the fallout after Carl P. Paladino was caught on tape angrily threatening to “take out” a reporter who questioned his tactics. headline: Procrustean Economics (Wonkish)
text: Brad DeLong manfully takes on the efforts of various commentators to define away the paradox of thrift and redefine our current problems as somehow wholly monetary. As I see it, this is all a desperate attempt to cut and stretch things into a quasi-monetarist framework, for no good reason.

headline: In Chicago, Excitement and Skepticism at Emanuel’s Decision
text: CHICAGO – The news that Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, will return to Chicago to run for mayor was met  Thursday with excitement and skepticism among downtown workers.

headline: An American Wit: Approaching Mark Twain’s Life and Works
text: Overview | Who was Mark Twain? How do Twain’s characters and works reflect his sometimes contradictory view of the world? In this lesson, students mark the Twain centennial by reading about the man and then investigating and choosing a Twain project to further learn about the author, his times and his relevance to our world.

headline: Boehner Outlines Changes if G.O.P. Takes House
text: WASHINGTON  Representative John A. Boehner said Thursday that if Republicans take control in the midterm election, he will try to fundamentally change the way the House is run to give both parties a fair hearing while making their doings more transparent.

headline: Previews for ‘Women on the Verge’ Delayed
text: The new Broadway musical “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown” has delayed the start of preview performances for a second time, switching from Tuesday Oct. 5 to Friday Oct. 8. In a brief interview, the show’s director, Bartlett Sher, said the production was “an enormous, complex undertaking” and required a few more days for technical rehearsal, when all facets of a production — lighting cues, sound, special effects and costume changes, as well as the acting, choreography and music — come together on an actual stage.

headline: The Best Director of His Era?
text: Reading the near-universal (and richly-merited) praise for David Fincher’s “The Social Network,” it occurred to me that Fincher is gradually building a plausible claim to being the best filmmaker of his generation. Obviously defining “his generation” is a somewhat tricky thing — but suppose we do it roughly by decade, and compare his body of work to other filmmakers who came into their own between 1990 and 2005. (This ends up excluding the Coen brothers and Steven Soderbergh, who would otherwise provide some of his stiffest competition, as well as some recent bloomers like Jason Reitman.) Using that time frame, Fincher is up against Quentin Tarantino, Paul Thomas Anderson, Peter Jackson, Christopher Nolan, Wes Anderson, Sofia Coppola, Alexander Payne, Spike Jonze, Danny Boyle, Ang Lee, and no doubt some others I’m forgetting. Many of the directors on that list have made individual movies that might be better than a given Fincher film. But I’m not sure any of them can match the sustained excellence of his entire body of work.

headline: Parcells Mulls Life After the Dolphins
text: When the Miami Dolphins announced just before the season that Bill Parcells was ceding full control of the football operations to General Manager Jeff Ireland, it started speculation about whether Parcells’ peripatetic career would soon take him out of South Florida.

headline: Now Showing | ‘Jerry Thompson & Walker Evans’
text: The relationship between mentor and pupil is at the core of “Jerry Thompson & Walker Evans: Pictures of People,” a new exhibition at the Gallery at Hermès opening on Friday. Thompson met and befriended the legendary Evans in 1971 while he was a student at Yale. Evans’s Depression-era street portraits profoundly influenced Thompson’s photographs of New York denizens from the 1970s and ’80s. The latter are not merely an homage to his teacher but a continuation of the mystery and forwardness of the direct gaze in portraiture. Thoughtfully curated by Cory Jacobs, the exhibition explores both artists’ frank visual styles, the ongoing connection between subject and viewer, and the inspiration of one artist on another.

headline: Murkowski and Tea Party Express Battle on Airwaves
text: Lisa Murkowski is determined to have the last word in the Alaska Senate race.

headline: Dear FloFab: My Favorite Restaurant Plays Awful Music

headline: Revising Our Ideas of Colonial Sewing
text: Three exhibitions opening in the next few days are meant to dispel common myths about Colonial women’s sewing habits. Young embroiderers, it turns out, did not learn much at their mothers’ knees by the fireside, nor did they diligently copy designs that were fed to them.

headline: Lawmakers Grill J&J and F.D.A. Officials

Lawmakers faulted executives at Johnson & Johnson and regulators at the Food and Drug Administration for their handling of the recall, as well as a separate controversial recall of adult Motrin pills.

headline: The Latest Attack Ad in Nevada Senate Race
text: Nevada’s Senate race received another attack ad Thursday, when the incumbent, Harry Reid, released a spot criticizing his opponent, Sharron Angle, for opposing mandatory coverage for mammograms.

headline: Russian Parties Making Gains in Latvia
text: RIGA, Latvia  When Latvians wrested their country from the Soviet Union two decades ago, their first thought, it seemed, was escape. Unable to physically uproot the country from its tiny plot next to Russia, they sought to integrate as deeply as possible with the West, eventually joining the European Union and NATO while spurning their former colonial masters and marginalizing the Russians who remained here.

text: Roger Maris yesterday became the first major league player in history to hit more than sixty home runs in a season.

headline: Vladimir Horowitz, Titan of the Piano, Dies
text: Vladimir Horowitz, the eccentric virtuoso of the piano whose extraordinary personality and skill overwhelmed six decades of concert audiences, died suddenly early yesterday afternoon at his home in Manhattan, apparently of a heart attack. Though standard biographies list his birth date as Oct. 1, 1904, Mr. Horowitz recently celebrated what he called his 86th birthday.

headline: Mohandas K. Gandhi: The Indian Leader at Home and Abroad
text: The assassin was a Hindu who disagreed with Gandhi's ideology. Gandhi was shot at point-blank range as he was going to delive his daily prayer meeting message. The assassin was immediately seized by the crowd and later told a foreign correspondent, "I am not at all sorry."

headline: President Sees Marshall Take Supreme Court Seat
text: Washington, Oct. 2--President Johnson paid an unannounced visit to the Supreme Court this morning to witness the swearing in of Thurgood Marshall, who became the first Negro to sit on the high court. Mr. Johnson took his seat in the "family section" near the bench, shortly before the Justices took their seats for the opening of the new term. The President left immediately after the five-minute ceremony. He did not attempt to congratulate Justice Marshall, who remained on the bench with the other Justices for almost an hour, as 223 lawyers were admitted to practice before the Court. Justice Marshall, the great-grandson of a slave, gained national fame as a counsel for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. He swore today to "administer justice without respect to persons, and do equal right to the poor and to the rich."

headline: Two Germanys Unite After 45 Years With Jubilation and a Vow of Peace
text: Berlin, Wednesday, Oct. 3 -- Forty-five years after it was carved up in defeat and disgrace, Germany was reunited today in a midnight celebration of pealing bells, national hymns and the jubilant blare of good old German oom-pah-pah.

headline: Emily Post Is Dead Here at 86; Writer was Arbiter of Etiquette
text: Mrs. Emily Post, for many years a leading authority on all matters of social good form, died Sunday in her apartment at 39 East Seventy-ninth Street after a brief illness. Her age was 86.

headline: Buster Keaton, 70, Dies on Coast; Poker-Faced Comedian of Films
text: Hollywood, Feb. 1--Buster Keaton, the poker-faced comic whose studies in exquisite frustration amused two generations of movie audiences, died of lung cancer today at his home in suburban Woodland Hills. His age was 70.

headline: SOVIET FIRES SATELLITE INTO SPACE: IT IS CIRCLING THE GLOBE AT 18,000 M.P.H.; SPHERE TRACKED IN 4 CROSSINGS OVER U.S.
text: Moscow, Saturday, Oct. 5--The Soviet Union announced this morning that it successfully launched a man-made earth satellite into space yesterday.

headline:
SADAT ASSASSINATED AT ARMY PARADE AS MEN AMID RANKS FIRE
INTO STANDS; VICE PRESIDENT AFFIRMS 'ALL TREATIES'
text: CAIRO, Oct. 6 -- President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was shot and killed today by a group of men in military uniforms who hurled hand grenades and fired rifles at him as he watched a military parade commemorating the 1973 war against Israel.

text: BRYANT, Ark.  That Democrats are in trouble is hardly news these days, at least in most places.

SHIP CARRYING 400 SEIZED; HIJACKERS DEMAND RELEASE OF 50
PALESTINIANS IN ISRAEL

headline: Elijah Muhammad Dead; Black Muslim Leader, 77
text: Chicago, Feb. 25--Elijah Muhammad, spiritual leader of the nation's Black Muslims, died here today of congestive heart failure.

headline: BP to Pay Record Fine for Refinery Violations
text: BP has agreed to pay a $15 million penalty to resolve Clean Air Act violations at its scandal-plagued refinery in Texas City, Tex., federal regulators announced Thursday.

headline: Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker Is Dead at 82
text: Eddie Rickenbacker, a leading fighter ace in World War I and retired chairman of Eastern Air Lines, died early yesterday in a Zurich hospital.

headline: WARSAW OUTLAWS SOLIDARITY UNION
text: WARSAW, Oct. 8 -- The Polish Parliament overwhelmingly approved a law today that bans Solidarity, the independent trade union that once captured the imagination and allegiance of nearly 10 million Poles.

headline: Craving a Baby at 50
text: Bonnie Bernstein has a 23-year-old son. She is nearly 50. And she wants to have a baby. She wrote about this yesterday on babble.com, in an essay titled “I’m Almost 50 and I Want to Get Pregnant, Am I The Only One?” and I read it with my mouth open. Unlike Bernstein, I spend a lot of time quite happy that I am not pregnant. It was lovely (well, parts of it). Twice. And now I’m done.

headline: Tabla Is Closing

headline: Bolivia Confirms Guevara's Death; Body Displayed
text: Valle Grande, Bolivia, Oct. 10--The army high command officially confirmed today that Ernesto Che Guevara, the Latin revolutionary leader, was killed in a clash between guerrillas and Bolivian troops in southeastern Bolivia last Sunday.

headline: Bruce Catton, Civil War Historian, Dies at 78
text: Bruce Catton, a Yankee-born prolific writer on the Civil War whose anthology "A Stillness At Appomattox" won him a Pulitzer Prize, died Monday at 78, hospital officials said.

headline: Emanuel’s Departure Set; Replacement Is Longtime Aide
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama plans to continue reshaping his inner circle on Friday, replacing his brusque and aggressive chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, with a soft-spoken insider who has worked quietly in Mr. Obama’s shadow for years.

headline: Tony Curtis’s New York, on Film and in Reality
text: Bruce Goldstein remembers when he realized that Tony Curtis had “a spiel.”

headline: Ochocinco Cereal Isn’t Entirely Whole-Grain Goodness
text: Bengals receiver Chad Ochocinco has a skill for finding controversy, but on Thursday he stumbled into one in a most unusual fashion: by way of a misprinted phone number on boxes of cereal that bear his name. A phone number on OchocincO’s Cereal that was supposed to connect callers to a charity instead sent them to a sex line.

headline: Cabaret Love Is Busting Out All Over (but Not on TV)
text: When the Mabel Mercer Foundation holds its annual Cabaret Convention, from Thursday through Saturday in Rose Hall at Jazz at Lincoln Center, before a mostly older audience that can’t get enough of the old songs, the decades will slip away, and the Gershwins, Irving Berlin, Cole Porter and Noël Coward will rule the day.

headline: Where Recent Graduates, and History, Roam
text: “No more pencils, no more books” could be the unofficial motto of Murray Hill, where fresh-faced college graduates often settle after the last airborne cap has plummeted back to earth. But the neighborhood, east of Madison Avenue from 34th to 42nd Street, is rich in brainier pursuits than beer pong.

headline: Week 4 Fantasy Football Matchups
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 4. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.
