headline: Chasing Beauty
text: Federico de Vera is a man of parts  body parts, specifically: carved feet, hands and heads of wood, ivory, stone or brass, ornamented or unadorned. But that’s hardly all. De Vera, a shy aesthetic savant with an Enlightenment point of view, is catholic in his interests, Catholic in his upbringing, a believer in a democracy of beauty. For almost two decades, de Vera  merchant, collector, jewelry and exhibition designer and now, with the pending release of his books “De Vera Objects” and “De Vera Jewelry,” publisher  has trafficked in lovely and sometimes macabre articles of man’s and nature’s making.

headline: Birth Pangs
text: After the birth of each of our three children, my wife and I breathed a deep sigh of relief. We had been meticulous in following our obstetrician’s advice: we had been screened for the Tay-Sachs trait, and had an amniocentesis to check for chromosomal changes associated with Down syndrome, and ultrasound to assess the fetus’s growth. Everything looked normal. But with the acute awareness of two physicians, we knew that these tests did not reveal all the problems that can occur during gestation. So when we heard the piercing cry of our newborn and were told the baby had a high Apgar score, we believed we had successfully skirted the perils of pregnancy.

headline: New BP Chief Seeks a ‘Fast Evolution’
text: HOUSTON  One day away from becoming BP’s third chief executive in four years, Robert Dudley described the oil company as one that needed a “fast evolution, not revolution” to rebuild its reputation after the explosion in the Gulf of Mexico that killed 11 workers and caused tens of billions of dollars in damages.

headline: Former SAP Chief to Lead Hewlett-Packard
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Hewlett-Packard’s board chose equal parts pragmatism, aggressiveness and surprise with its hiring of Léo Apotheker as the company’s new chief executive.

headline: Training, Experience and Luck Lead to Helicopter’s Safe Landing
text: When the trouble came, the police helicopter was soaring about 100 feet over the surface of Jamaica Bay.

headline: A Warhol Soup Can Comes to Market
text: Even when the economy is struggling and buyers are reluctant to spend money, there are always a handful of collectors willing to splurge for a good, early Warhol painting. So when Barney Ebsworth, a Seattle collector, was assessing his holdings, trying to decide what to sell to finance a church designed by the Japanese architect Tadao Ando that he is building, it was Warhol rather than de Kooning or Calder or Pollock that he chose to auction.

headline: New York’s Coffee Menu Gets Longer
text: On the Moment blog, Oliver Strand writes about the latest well-respected coffee roaster whose product is available in New York  — PT’s Coffee Roasting Company from Topeka, Kan.

headline: Bernie Schwartz Has Gone To The Valley Of The Sun
text: Tony Curtis is dead. He never actually said “Yonda lies dah castle of my faddah”; but he did say “Dis is duh palace ah my fadda, an’ yonda lies duh Valley ah duh Sun“.

headline: Lonely Boy Finds Friend in Blood-Craving Pixie
text: The title of “Let Me In” might be understood as a plea to the audience. Even if you think you’ve had enough of the vampirization of popular culture — “Twilight,” “True Blood,” “The Vampire Diaries” and so on — find room in your heart for this one. And though it teases out the usual horror movie sensations of dread and anxiety and eyes-averted disgust, this movie also makes a direct and disarming play for affection, eliciting in viewers something akin to the awkward, resilient tenderness that is its subject.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 30

headline: Swimming Through Bausch’s World
text: When it was all over, the dancers stood in a line onstage, soaking wet and clearly exhausted. And the audience stood in the Howard Gilman Opera House, applauding and cheering through multiple curtain calls, until some of the performers’ drawn faces softened into small smiles.

headline: Whitman Says She Didn’t Know Housekeeper Was an Illegal Immigrant
text: 5:31 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES –  Meg Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor, said today she would take a lie detector test to back up her claim that she did not know that her Mexican housekeeper of nine years was an illegal immigrant. She first learned of it, Ms. Whitman said, when her housekeeper came and informed her of it last year, six months after Ms. Whitman had entered the race, at which point Ms. Whitman fired her on the spot.

headline: A Big Band Theory: The More Energy the Better
text: You’ve heard of the leadership crisis in America? Orrin Evans is not part of that problem. Running a jazz big band in 2010 involves skill in composing, arranging, conducting and scheduling; it also involves nerve, because a big band these days is naturally a kind of statement, a platform for adventuresome writing or maintaining a tradition. And it takes strength: musical and physical.

headline: Seeing Things | Julius Shulman’s Legacy
text: The legendary architectural photographer Julius Shulman (1910-2009) once said, “Whether we recognize it or not, we all live in a world of architecture.” Shulman would have celebrated his 100th birthday on Oct. 10, and to mark the occasion, the Julius Shulman Institute — which was founded in 2005 at Woodbury University in Burbank, Calif. — will present “Image.Architecture.Now,” an exhibition and symposium that explore the intersections between architecture and photography.

headline: Judge Approves Sale of Philadelphia Papers
text: A federal bankruptcy judge approved the sale of The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Philadelphia Daily News to the newspapers’ senior creditors on Thursday for about $139 million, including $105 million in cash.

headline: It’s Me, Not Caring
text: A friend of mine is obsessed with Twitter; her number of daily tweets is out of control: she posts every item she eats (down to the ingredients) and every place she visits (Foursquare!). The worst part is that she acts as if she’s something of a celebrity in the Twitter-sphere. I’ve stopped following her feed to eliminate the annoyance, but I want to be honest. Is there a gracious way to tell her that no one cares about her hemp and spirulina smoothies?

headline: Director’s Fancy Leads to a Tale-Spinning Cat
text: Moisés Kaufman has wrestled with the trials of Oscar Wilde and the murder of Matthew Shepard. He’s grappled with Beethoven and Jane Fonda, both in the same play (“33 Variations”).

headline: Sword Swallowers and Beer Swiggers
text: Tap-dancing bears, kung fu juggling, clown bands, aerialists, sword swallowers, cowboys and a cougar contortionist  these are just a few of the acts that the Bindlestiff Family Cirkus has brought to the stage at Galapagos Art Space in Brooklyn over the last few years. Once a month Keith Nelson, a founder of the Cirkus and host of Bindlestiff Family Cirkus’s Open Variety Night there, presents emerging artists performing vaudeville, circus acts, Wild West shows, sideshows and burlesque, beginning at 8 p.m. And if that’s not enough to pique your interest, perhaps the $5 admission will. (Monday, 16 Main Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn; 718-222-8500, galapagosartspace.com.)

headline: Models Versus Slogans
text: One thought tying together this post and this post. When it comes to commenting on economics, there are two kinds of people: people who divide people into two kinds and people who don’t people who think in terms of models, and people who think in terms of slogans.

headline: Tom Hanks Unveils His Sci-Fi Internet Series, ‘Electric City’
text: When Tom Hanks imagines the future, you might think he sees a desk strewn with Oscars, Emmys and the scripts for a dozen more World War II projects. But the far-flung earth that Mr. Hanks will present in a new Internet-based animated series called “Electric City” will be a more complicated one and yet – not surprisingly, given its creator – an optimistic one.

headline: Would Hemingway Cry?
text: TEN years ago, my high school sweetheart and I liked to pretend we were disaffected expatriates living in some crumbly postwar foreign capital. In reality, we lived in an affluent New York City suburb.

headline: American Office Idiot, the Exported Edition
text: In “The Increasingly Poor Decisions of Todd Margaret,” which begins on Friday on IFC, the comedian David Cross plays a yucky American in Britain, a cultural interloper so tone deaf and socially maladroit that he alone could threaten to further erode our national reputation abroad. The character of the title is one to whom Mr. Cross, an expert in evoking self-idiocy, is especially well suited, as anyone familiar with his work on “Arrested Development” and his old sketch-comedy series, “Mr. Show,” can vouch. Here his comic persona is redoubled, having the effect of making Larry David’s or Ricky Gervais’s seem enviably diplomatic.

headline: Lotus Unveils Its New Sedan Concept
text: If Porsche can make S.U.V.’s, what’s next, a Lotus sedan?

headline: Desperate Housewife
text: Poor Emma Bovary. She will never escape the tyranny of her desires, never avoid the anguish into which her romantic conceits deliver her, never claim the oblivion she sought from what is perhaps the most excruciating slow suicide ever written. Her place in the literary canon is assured; she cannot be eclipsed by another tragic heroine. Instead, each day she will be resurrected by countless readers who will agonize over the misery she brings herself and everyone around her and wonder at Flaubert’s ability to, godlike, summon life from words on a page.

headline: Now Showing, the Edge: A Festival’s Calling Card
text: In 1966, Amos Vogel, one of the founders of the New York Film Festival, wrote a letter to Schuyler Chapin, a higher-up at Lincoln Center, asking for a 16-millimeter projector. As Raymond J. Haberski Jr. writes in his book “Freedom to Offend: How New York Remade Movie Culture,” the festival, even then, favored foreign-language cinema, for which it was criticized. It also took flak for not showing work by American independents, many of whom shot on the less expensive 16-millimeter film (ah, film!).

headline: Oscar de la Renta Buys SoHo Apartment
text: THE fashion designer Oscar de la Renta, who has an apartment on Park Avenue and whose main residence is a sweeping estate in Kent, Conn., bought a $2.4 million condominium in the SoHo Mews for his son Moises de la Renta, also a fashion designer, and for visiting friends and guests, according to East Egg Realty, which closed the deal with Mr. de la Renta on Thursday.

headline: An iPod Dock That Shuffles a Duo of Devices
text: The living room equivalent of fighting over the car radio dial is fighting over which playlist to listen to. While one spouse may prefer the mellow stylings of Feist and Rufus Wainwright, the other may lean toward the dulcet tones of Eric B. & Rakim or Gangstarr.

headline: Learning to Be Lincoln
text: Do we need yet another book on Lincoln, especially in the wake of all the Lincoln volumes that appeared last year in commemoration of the 200th anniversary of his birth? Well, yes, we do — if the book is by so richly informed a commentator as Eric Foner, the DeWitt Clinton professor of history at Columbia. Foner tackles what would seem to be an obvious topic, Lincoln and slavery, and manages to cast new light on it.

headline: Who’s the Teacher? (Mr. Danza)
text: It’s a bad time for public schools, but a good time to examine how far they have declined — rage over the state of American education is suddenly all the rage.

headline: With a Jury of Their Peers
text: The Museum of Modern Art doesn’t mess around with its vaunted permanent collection and core narrative. It may sometimes festoon the atrium or exterior with video projections or set live performers loose in the temporary-exhibition galleries.

headline: The Spirit of Xanadu, Morphing Across Borders
text: Art history is not a jigsaw puzzle waiting to be assembled. It’s more like a smashed sheet of reflective glass, continually reshattering, with splinters scattered here and there, many lost forever. With luck and work, scholars retrieve a few splinters, put them in a guessed-at order and turn on some lights. The result is an exhibition.

headline: Using Her Head
text: Chase Cohl, the singer-songwriter turned accessories maven behind the Littledoe label, went into design on a whim. The craft fanatic sourced vintage materials to make herself a floral headband; it caught the attention of her friends, who urged her to go into business. Any fears she may have had were quelled during the shoot for her first look book, when a chance meeting with the singer Fergie led to two of her pieces being purchased on the spot.

headline: A Best Seller as 4 Films Tied Together With Talk
text: The jocular screen adaptation of the 2005 best seller “Freakonomics: a Rogue Economist Explores the Hidden Side of Everything” is a shallow but diverting alternative to the book, whose authors, Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner, supply small talk between its four chapters. Their banter, as they sit side by side, has the same tone of cheerful certainty as a pair of movie critics batting opinions back and forth on TV between clips of the week’s new releases. The awkward transitions between its parts were written and directed by Seth Gordon (“The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters.”), whose introduction describes deceptive sales pitches of real estate agents.

headline: Mardig Kachian Selling TriBeCa Building
text: HE was a pioneer nonpareil in that virtual wasteland once known as the Lower West Side, long before real estate brokers had the opportunity to market it as the “Gold Coast of TriBeCa.”

headline: Learning to Be Washington
text: George Washington’s corpse was scarcely a month in its grave when an enterprising minister from Maryland named Mason Locke Weems made a pitch to a Philadelphia publisher. “I’ve got something to whisper in your lug,” Weems wrote in January 1800. “Washington, you know is gone! Millions are gaping to read something about him. . . . My plan! I give his history, sufficiently minute” and “go on to show that his unparalleled rise & elevation were due to his Great Virtues.” Weems was on to something. His sentimental and often fictional biography became a best seller, the first in a seemingly endless stream of studies of the man who led the Continental Army to victory in the American War for Independence and who as the first president of the United States did more than anyone else to establish the legitimacy of a national government merely outlined in the Constitution of 1787. Today, books about Washington continue to appear at such an astonishing rate that the publication of Ron Chernow’s prompts the inevitable question: Why another one?

headline: A Question for BP’s New Chief
text: Robert Dudley will undoubtedly have his hands full when he takes over on Friday as chief executive of BP, seeking to rebuild the company after the gulf spill. He gave a series of interviews on Thursday, and I thought I would forgo the usual queries about faulty blowout preventers and the vast damages that BP will have to pay for an explosion that killed 11 workers and poured millions of barrels of crude oil into the gulf.

headline: Donmar Warehouse Director to Step Down in 2011
text: Michael Grandage, who won the 2010 Tony Award for best director of a play for “Red,” announced on Thursday evening that he would step down as artistic director of Donmar Warehouse in London in late 2011 to concentrate on mounting plays and musicals, like a Broadway revival of “Evita” planned for the spring of 2012. The recent Broadway productions of “Red,” “Hamlet” (with Jude Law), “Mary Stuart” and “Frost/Nixon” all transferred from the Donmar, which has developed into a leading theatrical producer under Mr. Grandage and his predecessor, Sam Mendes. Mr. Grandage, 48, above, has led the Donmar since November 2002. “I am now keen to have a career that moves away from being in charge of a building in order to develop my work as a director in other ways,” he said in a statement. His next productions for the Donmar are “King Lear,” which starts performances in December, and “Schiller’s Luise Miller,” which is scheduled to run next summer. He is also set to make his debut at the Met next year with a new production of “Don Giovanni.”

headline: New Parents in Need of Sleep
text: Chronic insomnia has been linked to a range of medical problems, from loss of concentration to high blood pressure, explained Dr. Michael Thorpy and Dr. Shelby Freedman Harris of the Sleep-Wake Disorders Center at Montefiore Medical Center in an earlier Consults post, “Can You Die of Insomnia?” But can getting up throughout the night to tend to new baby cause long-term health problems as well? Dr. Harris and Dr. Thorpy respond.

headline: A Camera on Your Ear
text: Rik Fairlie Demonstrates the Looxcie Camcorder

headline: Last Monarch Standing
text: The British novelist Ken Follett’s two-part medieval epic, “The Pillars of the Earth” (now a TV mini­series) and “World Without End,” teemed with oppressed peasants, bloodthirsty warlords and lusty wassailers. His new novel, “Fall of Giants,” is the first volume of a projected trilogy in which the 20th century has replaced the Middle Ages as a stage for life’s grandeurs and miseries, but the book’s narrative structure is the same: multiple plot strands woven through a vast tapestry of times past. In this huge panorama, empires rise and fall, wars break out and characters of varying social backgrounds live mostly happy or mostly unhappy lives — mostly happy, more often than not, because Follett is an optimist, and firmly on the side of the good guys. He prefers to save history’s horrors for the villains, who are frequently humiliated in satisfying ways.

headline: New ‘Law & Order’ Wins Face-Off
text: NBC’s latest “Law & Order” spinoff, “Law & Order: Los Angeles,” made a solid debut on Wednesday, helping to lift NBC to second place in the night’s ratings. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the procedural drew 10.5 million viewers, leading the 10 p.m. hour, slightly ahead of the CBS legal drama “The Defenders” (10.4 million). CBS ranked No. 1 for the night. Its “Criminal Minds” delivered the largest audience over all with 14.4 million viewers, while “Survivor: Nicaragua” finished close behind with 12.2 million. NBC garnered somewhat more modest numbers with “Undercovers” (7.1 million) and “Law & Order: SVU” (9.2 million). ABC was third with its comedies “The Middle” (8.3 million), “Better With You” (7.1 million), “Modern Family” (11.9 million) and “Cougar Town” (7.1 million). ABC’s drama “The Whole Truth” struggled with 4.7 million viewers. Fox finished fourth with “Hell’s Kitchen” (6.3 million).

headline: In Printing Posters, East Germans Escaped the Censors
text: If you could be magically transported to a time and a place that were a Valhalla for art and artists, East Germany before the Wall fell probably would not be your first choice. Thought police discouraged non-Socialist Realist painting as too bourgeois and elitist. Modernist abstraction was considered decadent, to say nothing of the sorts of avant-garde styles prevailing in the capitalist West. Artists who veered from the party line put themselves at great risk.

headline: The Natural
text: Remarkable writing reaches through the mind and touches the body, sometimes in the form of rainy eyes or a tremulous chin. There are pages in “The Silent Season of a Hero,” a collection of sportswriting by Gay Talese, that will do just that. Consider, for instance, a passage from the title essay, which first appeared in Esquire in 1966 and which some insist is the best piece of sportswriting in history.

headline: Scorecard | Dries Van Noten Wins!
text: When phrases like “elegant androgyny” and “his-and-hers space age jumpsuits” start cropping up in the reviews, you know Scorecard must be in the City of Light, where deconstructing the heteronormative always garners praise. On the opening day of Paris Fashion Week, consensus was that the Sputnik-era couturier Pierre Cardin’s attempt at contemporary design failed to (re)launch. But critics were left pondering the ontological question of whether Gareth Pugh’s made-for-ShowStudio film presentation of Kristen McMenamy’s performative body constituted a fashion show or not.

text: The first thing you’ll want to do with a copy of “The Lampshade,” Mark Jacobson’s new book, is to remove its dust jacket, fold it neatly, and shove it as far down into your trash can as it will go. You’ll feel better almost instantly.

headline: Official Says J.&J. Plants Had Widespread Failings
text: A top official at the Food and Drug Administration told lawmakers on Thursday that quality control failures at the Johnson & Johnson unit involved in the recalls of popular medications like children’s liquid Tylenol were not isolated to one plant, but were far more widespread.

headline: Greenberg Is Not a Fan of A.I.G.’s Repayment Plan
text: Many parties were singing the praises of the American International Group‘s plan to eventually repay its government-financed bailout. Maurice R. Greenberg, its blunt former chief executive, isn’t one of them.

headline: Chekhov Meets Vaudeville in an Adaptation of His Early Works
text: “The Sneeze,” the sketch from which a collection of eight stories and playlets by Chekhov takes its title, evokes classic silent comedy from the schools of Buster Keaton through to Mr. Bean. It involves Mr. and Mrs. Senior Government Official (Bradford Cover and Rachel Botchan) watching a performance of Tchaikovsky’s “Swan Lake,” with a low-level counterpart and his wife (Chris Mixon and Lee Stark) seated directly behind them. The offending outburst causes a ticklish pantomime of flying nasal debris, mortification, apology, insult, umbrage and political death, before it crescendos to cardiac arrest. The vignette earns laughs as physical comedy and as a swipe at a rigidly hierarchical society.

headline: The Uncanny Accuracy of Polling Averages*, Part II: What the Numbers Say

text: The countdown to the new year at midnight on Dec. 31 has been a fixture of Times Square for decades. Soon, the other 364 days of the year will also get their own midnights in the spotlight.

headline: Two Brothers on the Road, and One’s Bad Company
text: It may be true — or at least closer to true now than in the past — that anyone can make a movie. But whether everyone should is another question. “Douchebag” is the second feature directed by Drake Doremus, and the best that can be said about it is that it shows reasonable technical competence. Mr. Doremus, a 27-year-old graduate of the American Film Institute, deftly mimics the restless camera movements and loose cutting associated with the do-it-yourself mumblecore aesthetic, giving a lived-in look to a pat, sentimental and not very believable story.

text: NEWPORT, Wales — Continuing the unpredictable pattern he established with his final captain’s pick last month, the United States Ryder Cup captain, Corey Pavin, cracked open some surprises at the Ryder Cup opening ceremonies on Thursday.

text: A closer look at “River Intersection,” a new painting by Wayne Thiebaud.

headline: Looking for ‘Gatsby’ on Long Island
text: A journey to real-life models for, and reminders, of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s fictional East and West Eggs.

headline: Dates on Maps
text: Q. My son is a student at Columbia and lives at Broadway and 104th Street. Perhaps you can help me understand the old maps of the area that I have happened upon. Is the “1875” on the map the date for the first building on the block? That seems earlier than his building would suggest. Barry Smith, Los Altos Hills, Calif.

headline: From Popgun Hitter to Powerhouse
text: Going into the 2010 season, Jose Bautista was not much more than a borderline major league starter, more valuable for his defensive versatility than for his hitting skills. After all, he had played every position except shortstop, pitcher and catcher, and his best single-season home run total was 16, with the Pittsburgh Pirates in 2005. His career on-base plus slugging percentage, or O.P.S., was a pedestrian .729  more Skip Schumacher than Albert Pujols.

headline: Liberté in a Lover’s Embrace
text: Much happens, if not nearly enough, from the moment a shot rings out in the opening of the visually restrained, emotionally turbulent French drama “Leaving” and the film’s blunt ending, when you learn who shot whom and why. In between, a married woman, Suzanne (Kristin Scott Thomas), and a single man, Ivan (Sergi López), fall in love, leading to bedroom panting, glazed post-coital smiles, domestic stress and storm, and a world that should be shattered but often comes across as canned.

headline: Midnight’s Other Children
text: In the spring of 1997, the literary quarterly Granta published an issue devoted to India’s Golden Jubilee. The tone was cautious but celebratory: on the cover, the country’s name was printed in bright red letters, followed by an exclamation point. Fifty years after partition, an independent India was rapidly establishing itself as an international power. The issue, which consisted largely of contributions from native Indians writing in English, was a testament both to the country’s extraordinary intellectual and artistic richness, and to one of the few legacies of British colonialism that could be unequivocally celebrated by readers in South Asia and the West: a common language. Seventeen years after Salman Rushdie’s shot across the bow with “Midnight’s Children,” a new generation of Indian writers was, in Granta’s words, “matching India’s new vibrancy with their own.”

headline: Uncontrollable Urges
text: It’s love that brings the blush of life to Ruth Rendell’s singular portraits of English eccentrics. No matter how quirky their personal foibles or how penetrating her analysis of their bizarre behavior, Rendell never loses affection for her beloved crackpots. And in PORTOBELLO (Scribner, $26), that warm feeling extends to the colorful market street in London’s Notting Hill where some of the city’s most peculiar characters tend to gravitate. As Rendell notes approvingly in her salute to the area’s rich history, vibrant personality and raffish street life, “eccentricity is the norm in the Portobello Road.”

headline: Nonfiction Chronicle
text: THE BODY SHOP  Parties, Pills, and Pumping Iron; Or, My Life in the Age of Muscle.  By Paul Solotaroff.  Little, Brown, $24.99.

headline: Hatching the Pot
text: This is the third in a series.

headline: Deliverance
text: Captive for more than a year in the jungles of Colombia, ­Ingrid ­Betancourt took to her insect-­infested cot, drained by despair. Fat Martha, her aptly nicknamed guard, had brought fresh news: the hell in which ­Betancourt was living wasn’t harsh enough. A veritable concentration camp, complete with chain-link fences and barbed wire, was being thrown up in haste under the canopies of the country’s impenetrable interior.

headline: Keeping Score: From Popgun Hitter to Powerhouse
text: Going into the 2010 season, Jose Bautista was not much more than a borderline major league starter, more valuable for his defensive versatility than for his hitting skills. After all, he had played every position except shortstop, pitcher and catcher, and his best single-season home run total was 16, with the Pittsburgh Pirates in 2005. His career on-base plus slugging percentage, or O.P.S., was a pedestrian .729 — more Skip Schumacher than Albert Pujols.

headline: Up Front: Jerome Groopman
text: Jerome Groopman’s children were born when the American family was transitioning from Scotch-drinking, baseball-tossing Old Dad to diaper-changing, Baby Bjorn-slinging New Dad.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: TO THE END OF THE LAND,  by David Grossman. Translated by Jessica Cohen (Knopf, $26.95.) Two friends are deeply involved with the same woman in Grossman’s somber, haunting novel of love and loyalty in time of conflict, set in Israel between 1967 and 2000.

headline: Paperback Row
text: HOMER & LANGLEY,  by E. L. Doctorow (Random House, $15.) Doctorow’s affecting novel uses the imagined experience of the Collyer brothers, who died within a labyrinth of trash in their Fifth Avenue brownstone in 1947, to evoke decades of American life. This “compassionate double portrait,” as Liesl Schillinger described it in the Book Review, succeeds in “elevating the Collyers beyond caricature” and turns them into “creatures of their times.”

headline: A Tough Hill to Climb, but Not Impossible
text: Welcome back to cycling, where the dog often eats the homework.

headline: The Hezbollah Project
text: There is a striking episode early on in “A Privilege to Die,” Thanassis Cambanis’s well-reported account of the rise of Lebanon’s Hezbollah movement. The 2006 war between Hezbollah and Israel has just begun, a war Hezbollah provoked by crossing the border and kidnapping two Israeli soldiers. Israel has responded with a massive bombing campaign; thousands of Lebanese Shiites are fleeing their villages in the south, traveling north to the relative safety of Beirut. Hezbollah, remarkably, has replaced bombed out roads and bridges to ease the evacuation. It has organized reception ­areas for the refugees.

headline: The Uses of Enchantment
text: At 6 feet 5 inches tall, Roald Dahl was larger than life. His imposing and complicated personality makes all the more sense when you picture him as a near giant: Donald Sturrock notes that at their first meeting, “his body seemed larger than the doorway and far, far too big for the proportions of the cottage.” How to capture him in words? Dahl told Sturrock, “while munching on a lobster claw,” that “biographies were boring,” and Sturrock has set out to prove him wrong. He is significantly aided in this by the flamboyance of the subject himself.

headline: Living to Tell
text: In Moscow back in the 1980s, frustrated by a conversation with a pedantically orthodox Soviet woman, I blurted out that I never really saw the moral distinction between Stalin and Hitler. I just wanted to be ornery, and I never expected the reaction I drew. She stared at me, then began to cry. It had been inculcated in her from birth that the Soviet Union, through great heroism and sacrifice, had rescued the nation and the civilized world from the scourge of fascism. Victory in the Great Patriotic War was the one unquestioned achievement of the Soviet state, endlessly glorified in art, song, film and monuments. Stalin’s crimes, by contrast, had been pushed into the deep background after Nikita Khrushchev fell from power in 1964, and there they remained, off limits to the public and concealed behind euphemisms like “mistakes” or “cult of personality,” for the duration of Leonid Brezhnev’s bland rule. People don’t like to have their myths punctured, and I knew it was a cheap shot on my part.

headline: Treasury Reaps Billions as It Sells Its Citi Shares
text: The Treasury Department is well on its way to bidding a fond farewell to Citigroup.

headline: Inside the List
text: CAPTIVE CROWD: When Ann Patchett’s winsome novel “Bel Canto” was published in 2001, she freely acknowledged that its plot — about an eclectic group of people held hostage by South American terrorists — had been inspired by an actual kidnapping in Peru several years earlier. By the time “Bel Canto” started its 16-week run on the paperback list in 2002, however, readers might have had a different true-life incident in mind: in February of that year, the Colombian presidential candidate Ingrid Betancourt was seized by leftist guerrillas and held, along with a group of other people, in a series of spartan jungle camps. Their captivity lasted six and a half years. Betancourt, inset, who hails from a prominent French family (she holds dual French-Colombian citizenship), became one of the world’s most famous prisoners and a symbol of courage in the face of adversity.

headline: Eastern Religion in an Ensemble Drama
text: You almost hate to say it, but the thought is unavoidable: If Christopher Moltisanti had ever managed to write and direct his own film, it might have been very much like “The Hungry Ghosts,” written and directed by Michael Imperioli.
